en: Mighty soon we’ll have the cave so cluttered up with women, and fellows waiting to be ransomed, that there won’t be no place for the robbers.
vi: Because soon enough, this cave of ours will be bustling with women, with those waiting to be ransomed, and then there won't be any space left to accommodate our gang of thieves.
tr: In a short time, the cave would be filled with women and men waiting for their ransom to be paid, leaving no room for the robbers.
es: Soon we will have the cave so full of women and guys waiting to be rescued that there won't be any room left for the thieves.

en: But go ahead, I ain’t got nothing to say.”
vi: But anyway, just go on, I won't ask anything else.
tr: But go ahead, continue, I have nothing more to say.”
es: But go ahead, I have nothing to say.

en: Little Tommy Barnes was asleep now, and when they waked him up he was scared, and cried, and said he wanted to go home to his ma, and didn’t want to be a robber any more.
vi: Little Tommy Barnes, being young, had fallen fast asleep earlier, and when the group woke him up, he burst into tears out of fear, wanting to go home to his mother, and said he didn't want to be a robber anymore.
tr: Little Tommy Barnes had fallen asleep, and when they woke him up, he got scared, started crying, said he missed his home and his mother, and that he no longer wanted to be a robber.
es: Little Tommy Barnes had already fallen asleep, and when they woke him up, he was scared, started crying, and said he wanted to go back home to his mom and that he didn't want to be a bandit anymore.

en: So they all made fun of him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him mad, and he said he would go straight and tell all the secrets.
vi: The whole group saw this and teased him even more, calling him a crybaby, which made him furious and he said he would quit immediately and reveal all the secrets.
tr: Everyone made fun of him, calling him a crybaby. Upon this, he got very angry and immediately said he would go and reveal all the secrets.
es: So everyone laughed at him a lot, and when they called him a crybaby, he got angry and said he was going to tell all the secrets.

en: But Tom give him five cents to keep quiet, and said we would all go home and meet next week, and rob somebody and kill some people.
vi: But Tom gave him five cents to keep quiet, then told everyone to go home and meet again next week, when they would rob or kill someone.
tr: But Tom gave him five cents to keep quiet and said that we would all go home now, and next week we would meet again to rob someone and kill a few people.
es: But Tom went and gave him five cents to keep quiet and said that we were all going home and would meet next week to rob someone and kill some people.

en: Ben Rogers said he couldn’t get out much, only Sundays, and so he wanted to begin next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be wicked to do it on Sunday, and that settled the thing.
vi: Ben Rogers said that he wasn't allowed to leave the house except on Sundays, so he wanted to start the next Sunday. But the group said that if they did it on Sunday, they would be punished by the spirits. So that was a no-go.
tr: Ben Rogers said that he couldn't go out very often, but he was available on Sundays. Therefore, he wanted us to start next Sunday; but when the other children reminded him that doing such things on Sunday was a sin, that idea was also abandoned.
es: Ben Rogers said he couldn't go out much, only on Sundays, so he wanted to start next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be very bad to do it on Sunday, and the discussion ended.

en: They agreed to get together and fix a day as soon as they could, and then we elected Tom Sawyer first captain and Jo Harper second captain of the Gang, and so started home.
vi: Then the group agreed to decide on a date as soon as they could meet again. Then, they elected Tom Sawyer as the first commander of the group, and Joe Harper as the second commander. After that, the group went home.
tr: They decided to get together at the first opportunity to set a date, then we set off home after electing Tom Sawyer as the captain of the gang and Jo Harper as the second captain.
es: They decided to meet to determine the date as soon as they could and then we chose Tom Sawyer as first captain and Joe Harper as second captain of the band and went home.

en: I clumb up the shed and crept into my window just before day was breaking.
vi: I climbed over the roof of the stable and slipped through the window just as dawn was breaking.
tr: Just before dawn, I climbed up the veranda and slipped inside through the window.
es: I crawled up the shed to my window just before dawn.

en: My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was dog-tired.
vi: My new clothes were covered in filthy dirt, and I was out of breath.
tr: My brand-new clothes were covered in oil and mud, and I was utterly exhausted.
es: My new clothes were all covered in mud stains, and I was as tired as a dog.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: Chapter III
tr: Chapter Three
es: Chapter 3

en: Well, I got a good going-over in the morning from old Miss Watson on account of my clothes; but the widow she didn’t scold, but only cleaned off the grease and clay, and looked so sorry that I thought I would behave a while if I could.
vi: In the morning, Miss Watson lectured me about my dirty clothes; as for the widow, she didn't scold me at all but just quietly cleaned the stains. Seeing that, I felt remorseful and thought that if possible, I should behave well for a while.
tr: In the morning, I got a good scolding from our Miss Watson because of the state of my clothes; but the widow didn't get mad at all, though she looked so sad while cleaning the grease and dirt that I decided to try to behave for a while if I could.
es: WELL, in the morning old Miss Watson gave me a good scolding about the clothes, but the widow didn't scold me, she just cleaned the stains and mud, and she seemed so sad that I thought if I could, I would behave well for a while.

en: Then Miss Watson she took me in the closet and prayed, but nothing come of it.
vi: Then Miss Watson pulled me into the small room to pray. But it was useless.
tr: Then Miss Watson took me into the closet and prayed, but it still didn't do any good.
es: Then Miss Watson took me to the parlor to pray, but nothing happened.

en: She told me to pray every day, and whatever I asked for I would get it.
vi: She told me I had to pray every day, and if I did, I would get whatever I wanted.
tr: She told me that if I prayed every day, I would get everything I wanted.
es: She told me to pray every day and that everything I asked for would be given to me.

en: But it warn’t so.
vi: But that wasn't true at all, I had tried many times.
tr: But I didn't get anything.
es: But it wasn't true.

en: I tried it.
vi: But that wasn't true at all, I had tried many times.
tr: I tried.
es: I tried.

en: Once I got a fish-line, but no hooks.
vi: Once, I got a fishing rod but no hook.
tr: Once, I had a fishing line, but no hook.
es: Once I got a fishing line, but without hooks.

en: It warn’t any good to me without hooks.
vi: Without a hook, I couldn't do anything.
tr: Without a hook, the line was useless.
es: Without hooks it was useless to me.

en: I tried for the hooks three or four times, but somehow I couldn’t make it work.
vi: I diligently prayed four times but it was useless.
tr: I tried praying for a fishing hook three or four times, but it never worked.
es: I tried to get the hooks three or four times, but I don't know why it didn't work.

en: By-and-by, one day, I asked Miss Watson to try for me, but she said I was a fool.
vi: I then asked Miss Watson to pray for me, but she called me crazy.
tr: Then one day, I asked Miss Watson to try it for me, but she said I was a fool.
es: So one day I asked Miss Watson to try for me, but she said I was silly.

en: She never told me why, and I couldn’t make it out no way.
vi: She didn't explain why, and I couldn't understand it at all.
tr: She never explained why, and I couldn't make any sense of it.
es: She never explained why and I could never understand it.

en: I set down one time back in the woods, and had a long think about it.
vi: Once, I sat deep in the forest and pondered for a long time about that matter.
tr: Once, when I went to the forest, I sat down and thought about this for a long time.
es: Once I went to sit in the forest to think it over calmly.

en: I says to myself, if a body can get anything they pray for, why don’t Deacon Winn get back the money he lost on pork?
vi: I wondered if a person could pray for anything and get it, then why couldn't old Deacon Winn get back the money he lost over the pigs?
tr: If a person can obtain something by praying, why can't the assistant pastor Winn get back the money he lost in the pork trade?
es: I said to myself: "If one can get everything they ask for when they pray, why don't they return to Deacon Winn the money he lost with the pigs?

en: Why can’t the widow get back her silver snuffbox that was stole?
vi: Why couldn't the widow get back her stolen silver snuffbox?
tr: Why can't the widow find her stolen silver snuffbox?
es: Why don't they return to the widow the silver snuffbox that was stolen from her?

en: Why can’t Miss Watson fat up?
vi: Why couldn't Miss Watson get fatter?
tr: Why can't Mrs. Watson gain weight?
es: Why can't Miss Watson get fat?

en: No, says I to myself, there ain’t nothing in it.
vi: No, there's no such thing; I told myself that.
tr: No, I said to myself, there's no way that thing called prayer works.
es: No, I said to myself, all that doesn't make sense."

en: I went and told the widow about it, and she said the thing a body could get by praying for it was “spiritual gifts.”
vi: So I went and told the widow my thoughts, and she said that the things people pray for are only spiritual blessings.
tr: I went and told the widow about this, and she said that a person can only gain "spiritual gifts" by praying.
es: I went and told the widow, and she said that what could be obtained through prayer were "spiritual goods."

en: This was too many for me, but she told me what she meant—I must help other people, and do everything I could for other people, and look out for them all the time, and never think about myself.
vi: That was really hard for me to understand. But then she said what she meant was this: that one must help others, do everything one can for others, always take care of others, and never think of oneself.
tr: I couldn't grasp this much, but then she explained it clearly – I should help other people, do everything I can for others, constantly look out for them, and never think of myself.
es: That was too much for me, but she explained what it meant: I had to help other people and do everything I could for them and always take care of others and never think of myself.

en: This was including Miss Watson, as I took it.
vi: If I understood correctly, this should include Miss Watson too.
tr: As far as I understood, this included Mrs. Watson as well.
es: It seemed to me that included Miss Watson.

en: I went out in the woods and turned it over in my mind a long time, but I couldn’t see no advantage about it—except for the other people; so at last I reckoned I wouldn’t worry about it any more, but just let it go.
vi: I went back out into the woods and kept wandering around, thinking about it for a long time, but I couldn't see how it would benefit me, only others. Finally, I decided not to worry about it anymore and just let it be.
tr: I went back to the forest and pondered this for a long time, but I couldn't see any good in it – that is, it only benefited others. Finally, I decided not to bother myself with this anymore and to let everything take its course.
es: I went to the forest and thought about it for a long time, but I didn't see the advantage, except for other people; so finally I figured I wasn't going to worry about it anymore, but would forget it.

en: Sometimes the widow would take me one side and talk about Providence in a way to make a body’s mouth water; but maybe next day Miss Watson would take hold and knock it all down again.
vi: Sometimes the widow would pull me aside and talk about God's blessings; it sounded so tempting. But then the next day, Miss Watson might take up the same topic and say something completely different.
tr: From time to time, the widow would pull me aside and speak about God in a way that made my mouth water; but maybe the very next day, Mrs. Watson would catch me and tell me the opposite of everything I had learned.
es: Sometimes the widow would take me with her and talk to me about Providence in a way that made one's mouth water, but maybe the next day Miss Watson would undo it all again.

en: I judged I could see that there was two Providences, and a poor chap would stand considerable show with the widow’s Providence, but if Miss Watson’s got him there warn’t no help for him any more.
vi: I thought I had figured out that there were two kinds of God; those who were miserable followed the God the widow talked about, but if someone unfortunately encountered Miss Watson's God, then there was no hope for them.
tr: In the end, I concluded that there were two Gods. A poor boy couldn't get enough of listening to the widow's God, but if he fell into the hands of Mrs. Watson's God, he had no chance.
es: It seemed to me that there might be two Providences and that one, poor fellow, would do very well with the widow's Providence, but if it was Miss Watson's, there was nothing to be done.

en: I thought it all out, and reckoned I would belong to the widow’s if he wanted me, though I couldn’t make out how he was a-going to be any better off then than what he was before, seeing I was so ignorant, and so kind of low-down and ornery.
vi: I kept thinking about this and decided that I would follow the widow's God, if He would have me; although I wasn't sure if He would still be as good once He knew that I was ignorant and liked odd, trivial things.
tr: After thinking about all this over and over, I decided to belong to the widow's God, if He would accept me. Though I didn't know if this God would treat me any better than before; because I was very ignorant, ordinary, and from the lower class.
es: I thought it all over and figured that if she wanted, I would go with the widow's, although I didn't see what she would gain by having me on her side that she didn't have before, given how ignorant and insignificant and ordinary I was.

en: Pap he hadn’t been seen for more than a year, and that was comfortable for me; I didn’t want to see him no more.
vi: My father has been gone for more than a year now. That also makes me feel relieved, because I don't want to see my father anymore.
tr: It had been over a year since my father disappeared, and this suited me just fine; I no longer wanted to see him.
es: It had been over a year since anyone had seen my father, and I was so happy; I didn't want to see him again.

en: He used to always whale me when he was sober and could get his hands on me; though I used to take to the woods most of the time when he was around.
vi: Whenever he wasn't drunk and caught me, it was only beatings; so I always ran into the forest, especially when my father was wandering around the house.
tr: If he caught me while sober, he would trample me underfoot, but when he was around, I would always run away and hide in the forest.
es: He always hit me when he was sober and could get his hands on me, although when he was around, I usually ran off to the woods.

en: Well, about this time he was found in the river drownded, about twelve mile above town, so people said.
vi: Back then, people found my father drowned in the river downstream, about twenty miles from the town.
tr: At one point, they said he was found drowned in the river about twenty kilometers upstream from the town.
es: Well, around that time they found him drowned in the river, about twelve miles upstream from the town, people said.

en: They judged it was him, anyway; said this drownded man was just his size, and was ragged, and had uncommon long hair, which was all like pap; but they couldn’t make nothing out of the face, because it had been in the water so long it warn’t much like a face at all.
vi: They said that the drowned person had the same build as my father, with tattered clothes and a long, unkempt hair. And those things were exactly like my father. But no one could clearly see the face, because the body had been in the water for too long, so the face was no longer recognizable.
tr: More precisely, they guessed that the person they found was my father, because the drowned man was exactly his height, looked very disheveled, and had unusually long hair – they were describing my father exactly – but they couldn't identify him by his face; because he had been in the water so long that his face had become unrecognizable.
es: At least, they believed it was him; they said that the drowned man was the same height as him and was dressed in rags and had very long hair, just like my father, but they couldn't tell by the face, because he had been in the water so long that it didn't look like a face at all.

en: They said he was floating on his back in the water.
vi: They said my father was floating face up on the water.
tr: They said he was found floating on his back.
es: They said he was floating on his back in the water.

en: They took him and buried him on the bank.
vi: They retrieved the body and buried it on the riverbank.
tr: They immediately took him out of the water and buried him on the shore.
es: They took him out and buried him on the riverbank.

en: But I warn’t comfortable long, because I happened to think of something.
vi: But I wasn't at ease for long before I suddenly thought of something.
tr: But the relief I felt didn't last long, because something important came to my mind.
es: But I didn't stay calm for long, because something occurred to me.

en: I knowed mighty well that a drownded man don’t float on his back, but on his face.
vi: I knew clearly that a drowned man never floats face up, but face down.
tr: I knew very well that a drowned man would turn face down, not face up.
es: I knew very well that a drowned person doesn't float on their back, but on their face.

en: So I knowed, then, that this warn’t pap, but a woman dressed up in a man’s clothes.
vi: If that's true, then that body wasn't my father, but perhaps a woman dressed in men's clothing.
tr: So, the drowned person was not my father, but a woman dressed like a man.
es: So then I realized that it wasn't my father, but a woman dressed as a man.

en: So I was uncomfortable again.
vi: Thinking that made me worried again.
tr: My peace was disturbed again.
es: And I got nervous again.

en: I judged the old man would turn up again by-and-by, though I wished he wouldn’t.
vi: I guessed that he would soon come back. And I kept hoping he wouldn't come back anymore.
tr: I was no longer in doubt that he would eventually show up, but deep down, I wished he would never come back.
es: I thought the old man would show up someday, although I hoped he wouldn't.

en: We played robber now and then about a month, and then I resigned.
vi: Occasionally, we pretended to be robbers, played for almost a month, then I withdrew and stopped playing.
tr: We played at being robbers whenever we found time for a month, then I left the gang.
es: We played bandits for a month, off and on, and then I quit.

en: All the boys did.
vi: The whole group stopped as well.
tr: All the children left.
es: All the boys did the same.

en: We hadn’t robbed nobody, hadn’t killed any people, but only just pretended.
vi: We never robbed anyone, never killed anyone, we just pretended like that.
tr: We hadn't robbed anyone, we hadn't killed anyone, we had just pretended to rob and kill.
es: We hadn't robbed anyone, we hadn't killed anyone, we had only pretended.

en: We used to hop out of the woods and go charging down on hog-drivers and women in carts taking garden stuff to market, but we never hived any of them.
vi: We often ran out into the forest, pretending to attack shepherds and women carrying vegetables to the market. But we never gathered to take anything from them.
tr: We would suddenly emerge from the forest and attack pig herders or the carts of women taking vegetables and fruits to the market, but we never captured any of them.
es: We would jump out of the woods and charge at the pig herders and the women who were taking their garden produce to market in carts, but we never did anything to them.

en: Tom Sawyer called the hogs “ingots,” and he called the turnips and stuff “julery,” and we would go to the cave and powwow over what we had done, and how many people we had killed and marked.
vi: Tom Sawyer called the sheep gold bars and the turnips and cabbages clothes and furniture. Afterwards, our whole group would gather in the cave to discuss our recent actions, counting how many people we had killed and how many marks we had made on the dead.
tr: Tom Sawyer called pigs "gold bars" and turnips or similar things "jewels. " Then we would return to the cave and tell each other what we had done; we would talk about the many people we had killed and marked.
es: Tom Sawyer called the pigs "ingots" and the turnips and such "jewels," and we would go to the cave and talk about what we had done and how many people we had killed and marked with our sign.

en: But I couldn’t see no profit in it.
vi: But then I found it useless.
tr: But I couldn't understand what good it would do us.
es: But I didn't see any advantage in it.

en: One time Tom sent a boy to run about town with a blazing stick, which he called a slogan (which was the sign for the Gang to get together), and then he said he had got secret news by his spies that next day a whole parcel of Spanish merchants and rich A-rabs was going to camp in Cave Hollow with two hundred elephants, and six hundred camels, and over a thousand “sumter” mules, all loaded down with di’monds, and they didn’t have only a guard of four hundred soldiers, and so we would lay in ambuscade, as he called it, and kill the lot and scoop the things.
vi: Once, Tom sent someone to town, holding a bright torch which he called the signal (our group's sign whenever we gathered). Then he said he had just received secret news from his scouts; reporting that the next day a caravan of very wealthy Spanish and Arab merchants would pass by, camping at Hole Cave; this caravan had two hundred elephants, six hundred camels, and more than a thousand mules, all carrying diamonds and jewels; and they only had four hundred guards. So we would set up an ambush, Tom said, ambush and quickly rob them of those items.
tr: Once, Tom made one of the boys run through the town with a burning torch in his hand. He said it was a password (a signal for the gang to gather). Then he claimed he had received secret information from his spies. The next day, a lot of Spanish merchants and rich Arabs were supposed to camp at Rocky Cave with two hundred elephants, six hundred camels, and over a thousand mules. All the animals were loaded with diamonds and they had no guards other than four hundred soldiers. So, as he put it, we would ambush them and kill everyone and plunder the goods.
es: Once Tom sent a boy running through the town with a burning stick that he said was a "signal" (a sign that the gang had to meet) and then said that his spies had sent him secret news that the next day a bunch of rich Spanish and Arab merchants were going to camp at the Mouth of the Cave with two hundred elephants and six hundred camels and more than a thousand pack mules, all carrying diamonds, and that they only had a guard of four hundred soldiers, so we had to ambush them and kill them all.

en: He said we must slick up our swords and guns, and get ready.
vi: He instructed us to thoroughly clean our knives, swords, and guns and be ready.
tr: He said we needed to take care of our swords and weapons and get ready.
es: He said we should prepare the swords and shotguns and be ready.

en: He never could go after even a turnip-cart but he must have the swords and guns all scoured up for it, though they was only lath and broomsticks, and you might scour at them till you rotted, and then they warn’t worth a mouthful of ashes more than what they was before.
vi: His kind couldn't even handle a vegetable cart, but he insisted on having swords and guns cleaned until they shone to do those things; although the swords and guns were just wooden sticks, broom handles, no matter how much they were cleaned or polished, they were still worth no more than a pile of firewood.
tr: He couldn't even keep up with a turnip cart, but he made sure we cleaned our swords and weapons; and these were just sticks and broom handles, no matter how much you scrubbed them, they didn't look any different than before.
es: He could never even get a cart of turnips, but he insisted that the swords and shotguns be all clean, although, since they were just wooden slats and broomsticks, you could clean them until you died of boredom and they wouldn't be worth a cent more than before.

en: I didn’t believe we could lick such a crowd of Spaniards and A-rabs, but I wanted to see the camels and elephants, so I was on hand next day, Saturday, in the ambuscade; and when we got the word we rushed out of the woods and down the hill.
vi: I didn't believe we could defeat such a caravan of Spanish and Arabs, but I wanted to see the elephants and camels, so the next day I also joined the ambush. That Saturday, after receiving the order, we left the forest and ran down the hill.
tr: I didn't believe we could defeat that crowd of Spaniards and Arabs, but I wanted to see the camels and elephants, so the next day, which was Saturday, I was among those who ambushed; when the order was given, we jumped out from the trees and started running down the hill.
es: I didn't believe we could defeat so many Spaniards and Arabs, but I wanted to see the camels and elephants, so the next day, which was Saturday, I showed up for the ambush, and when he gave the order we ran out of the woods and down the hill.

en: But there warn’t no Spaniards and A-rabs, and there warn’t no camels nor no elephants.
vi: But we didn't see any Spaniards or Arabs, nor any camels or elephants.
tr: But there were no Spaniards or Arabs down there, no camels or elephants either.
es: But there were no Spaniards or Arabs or camels or elephants.

en: It warn’t anything but a Sunday-school picnic, and only a primer-class at that.
vi: It was just a group of small schoolchildren from the convent school on a Saturday afternoon picnic.
tr: All we found down there was a picnic of the Sunday school, and it was just a picnic for the first graders.
es: There was only a Sunday school picnic, and on top of that, it was the first graders.

en: We busted it up, and chased the children up the hollow; but we never got anything but some doughnuts and jam, though Ben Rogers got a rag doll, and Jo Harper got a hymn-book and a tract; and then the teacher charged in, and made us drop everything and cut.
vi: We rushed into that group and herded the children into the cave. But we didn't get anything except a sweet bread and some bacon, Ben Rogers grabbed a ragged doll, Joe Harper grabbed a church hymn book and a small Bible. Then suddenly the teacher appeared, making us drop everything and run away.
tr: Still, we surprised them and chased the children to the rocks; but we didn't get anything except some buns and jam, although Ben Rogers got a rag doll, Jo Harper got a hymn book and a pamphlet; then their teacher attacked and we had to run away, leaving all the loot behind.
es: We scattered them and chased the kids down the hill, but we only got some jam and a few donuts, although Ben Rogers took a rag doll and Joe Harper a hymn book and a propaganda pamphlet, and then the teacher came running and made us leave everything and run away.

en: I didn’t see no di’monds, and I told Tom Sawyer so.
vi: I didn't see any diamonds or jewels at all. I told Tom Sawyer that.
tr: I didn't see any diamonds around and I told Tom Sawyer that.
es: I didn't see any diamonds, and I told Tom Sawyer.

en: He said there was loads of them there, anyway; and he said there was A-rabs there, too, and elephants and things.
vi: He said there were plenty. He also said there were Arabs, elephants, and all sorts of things there.
tr: But he said there were sacks of diamonds down there, and there were Arabs too, even elephants and such.
es: He replied that there were plenty of them anyway and that there were also Arabs and elephants and things.

en: I said, why couldn’t we see them, then?
vi: I asked why I didn't see them?
tr: Then why didn't we see them, I asked.
es: Then I asked him why we couldn't see them.

en: He said if I warn’t so ignorant, but had read a book called Don Quixote, I would know without asking.
vi: He said how stupid I was, if I had read a book called Don Quixote, I would know without having to ask him like that.
tr: If I wasn't so ignorant and had read this book called Don Quixote, I wouldn't even need to ask.
es: He told me that if I weren't so ignorant and had read a book called Don Quixote, I would know without asking.

en: He said it was all done by enchantment.
vi: He said it was because of magic.
tr: He said it was all done with magic.
es: He said they did everything by magic.

en: He said there was hundreds of soldiers there, and elephants and treasure, and so on, but we had enemies which he called magicians; and they had turned the whole thing into an infant Sunday-school, just out of spite.
vi: There were hundreds of soldiers, elephants, treasures, etc... but because we had many enemies, what he called magicians had turned all those things into a group of schoolchildren on a picnic, so they tricked us like that.
tr: There were hundreds of soldiers, elephants, and treasure there, but we had enemies whom Tom called magicians, and just to annoy us, they had turned all of it into a Sunday school picnic for little kids in the blink of an eye.
es: He said there were hundreds of soldiers and elephants and treasures and all that, but that we had enemies he called magicians who had turned everything into a Sunday school picnic for kids, just out of spite.

en: I said, all right; then the thing for us to do was to go for the magicians.
vi: I said then let's go find those magicians and fight them.
tr: Alright then, I said, what we need to do is defeat those magicians.
es: Then I said that well, what we had to do was attack the magicians.

en: Tom Sawyer said I was a numskull.
vi: Tom Sawyer called me an idiot. He said:
tr: Tom Sawyer said I was a complete blockhead.
es: Tom Sawyer called me a clodhopper.

en: “Why,” said he, “a magician could call up a lot of genies, and they would hash you up like nothing before you could say Jack Robinson.
vi: - How can that be? The magician can summon a bunch of gods, they will chop you into pieces immediately.
tr: “Wizards can summon a bunch of jinns at once, and before you can say Jack Robinson, the jinns will chop you into pieces.
es: —Man —he said—, a wizard can summon a bunch of genies, who could mince you in half a minute.

en: They are as tall as a tree and as big around as a church.”
vi: Those gods are as big as trees, as large as a church.
tr: These jinns are said to be as tall as trees and as wide as a church building.”
es: They are as tall as trees and as square as three-door wardrobes.

en: “Well,” I says, “s’pose we got some genies to help us—can’t we lick the other crowd then?”
vi: I said: - If we had a few gods like that helping us, could we defeat the other group?
tr: “Then let's find some jinn to help us,” I said. “Then can't we defeat the other jinn?”
es: —Well —I say—, so what happens if we get some of those geniuses to help us? Couldn't we then defeat the others?

en: “How you going to get them?”
vi: - How did I end up with those gods?
tr: “So where will we find them?”
es: —How are you going to achieve it?

en: “I don’t know.
vi: - I don't know either.
tr: "I don't know, where did they find it?"
es: —I don't know.

en: How do they get them?”
vi: But then how did they get it?
tr: "I don't know, where did they find it?"
es: How do they manage it?

en: “Why, they rub an old tin lamp or an iron ring, and then the genies come tearing in, with the thunder and lightning a-ripping around and the smoke a-rolling, and everything they’re told to do they up and do it.
vi: - They rub their hands against the tin lamp or the iron ring, and then that genie comes roaring, with thunder and lightning flashing around him, smoke billowing up, and whatever task they are commanded to do, they can do it immediately.
tr: “They rub an old tin lamp or an iron ring; then the genies suddenly appear. Meanwhile, lightning flashes around, thunder strikes, and smoke rises. The genies have to do everything they are told.
es: —Well, they rub an old tin lamp or an iron ring, and then the genies arrive, accompanied by thunder and lightning and all the smoke in the world, and they go and do everything they are told to do.

en: They don’t think nothing of pulling a shot-tower up by the roots, and belting a Sunday-school superintendent over the head with it—or any other man.”
vi: They might not need to use any strength to uproot a fortress or tie up the school supervisor or anyone else on it and carry them away.
tr: Uprooting a shot tower from its roots and then hitting the head of the Sunday school teacher or someone else with it is no big deal for them.”
es: It's extremely easy for them to tear a tower out by the roots and hit a Sunday school superintendent, or anyone else, on the head with it.

en: “Who makes them tear around so?”
vi: - Then who could call them to gather noisily around like that?
tr: “Who is causing them to run around like this?”
es: —Who forces you to do all that?

en: “Why, whoever rubs the lamp or the ring.
vi: - Who else would rub the lamp or the ring?
tr: “The one who rubs the lamp or the ring is him.
es: —Man, the one who rubs the lamp or the ring.

en: They belong to whoever rubs the lamp or the ring, and they’ve got to do whatever he says.
vi: These genies are under the command of anyone who rubs the lamp or the ring, and they must do everything according to that person's orders.
tr: They belong to the person who rubs the lamp or the ring and are obliged to do everything he says.
es: They belong to the one who rubs the lamp or the ring and have to do whatever they are told.

en: If he tells them to build a palace forty miles long out of di’monds, and fill it full of chewing-gum, or whatever you want, and fetch an emperor’s daughter from China for you to marry, they’ve got to do it—and they’ve got to do it before sun-up next morning, too.
vi: If told to build a forty-mile-long castle entirely out of diamonds, and fill that castle with chewing gum, or anything else one desires, and then bring back a princess, the daughter of the Emperor of China, to marry, they must do it all, and they must complete these tasks before the sun rises the next morning.
tr: If he tells them to build a sixty-five-kilometer-long palace made of diamond, and then fill it with gum or whatever he desires, and also wants to bring the daughter of the Chinese emperor to marry her, they have to do it all – and they have to do it before the sun rises the next day.
es: If they are told to build a palace forty miles long out of diamonds and fill it with chewing gum, or whatever you want, and to bring the daughter of an emperor of China to marry you, they have to do it, and moreover before the next day dawns.

en: And more: they’ve got to waltz that palace around over the country wherever you want it, you understand.”
vi: Moreover, these genies must also move the castle to any place one wishes. Do you understand? I said:
tr: Moreover, they should take that palace to wherever in the country you want, that is, wherever you want, do you understand?”
es: And on top of that, they have to transport that palace across the country whenever they are told, do you understand?

en: “Well,” says I, “I think they are a pack of flat-heads for not keeping the palace themselves ’stead of fooling them away like that.
vi: - If then I think that they are just a bunch of fools who don't know how to keep that castle for themselves but instead waste it like that.
tr: “Alright,” I said, “if you ask me, these jinn are quite foolish; instead of moving the palace from place to place, they should have kept it for themselves, my brother.
es: —Well —I said—, I think they are idiots for not keeping the palace, instead of doing all that nonsense.

en: And what’s more—if I was one of them I would see a man in Jericho before I would drop my business and come to him for the rubbing of an old tin lamp.”
vi: Moreover, if I were one of those gods, I would just ask for enough, there's no reason to leave my work to serve people every time they rub the tin lamp like that.
tr: Moreover... if I were in their place, instead of dropping everything and running to him, I would have sent the man who rubbed the lamp to Jericho.”
es: And besides, if it were me, I would go to the ends of the earth before leaving what I was doing to do what some guy rubbing an old tin lamp told me to do.

en: “How you talk, Huck Finn.
vi: - Huck Finn, you're very foolish.
tr: "You have no brains, Huck Finn.
es: —What things you say, Huck Finn.

en: Why, you’d have to come when he rubbed it, whether you wanted to or not.”
vi: When someone rubs the lamp, whether they want to or not, those genies have to appear.
tr: You have to come when he rubs it, whether you want to or not."
es: But you would have to go when she rubbed it, whether you wanted to or not.

en: “What! and I as high as a tree and as big as a church?
vi: - So, will I be as big as this, as big as the church?
tr: “No way, despite being as tall as a tree and as big as a church building?
es: —What! If I were as tall as a tree and square like a three-door wardrobe?

en: All right, then; I would come; but I lay I’d make that man climb the highest tree there was in the country.”
vi: That would be great: I will go to that place; but I intend to make that person climb the tallest tree in this land.
tr: If that's the case, I would have come, but I swear I would have made that man climb to the top of the tallest tree in the country.”
es: Well, okay; I would go, but I bet you that man would have to climb the tallest tree in the whole country.

en: “Shucks, it ain’t no use to talk to you, Huck Finn.
vi: - Stop it, Huck Finn, talking to you is utterly boring.
tr: “Man, trying to explain things to you is harder than getting a camel through the eye of a needle, Huck Finn.
es: —Darn, it's just impossible to talk to you, Huck Finn.

en: You don’t seem to know anything, somehow—perfect saphead.”
vi: You're not completely clueless, yet you're entirely foolish.
tr: Doesn't a person know anything at all… you're just a complete fool.”
es: It's like you don't know anything at all, like a complete idiot.

en: I thought all this over for two or three days, and then I reckoned I would see if there was anything in it.
vi: I had to think about this for a few days. I planned to see if there was anything real in it.
tr: I thought about this issue for two or three days, then I decided to see for myself whether it was real or not.
es: I kept thinking about all that for two or three days and then decided to try, to see if it was true or not.

en: I got an old tin lamp and an iron ring, and went out in the woods and rubbed and rubbed till I sweat like an Injun, calculating to build a palace and sell it; but it warn’t no use, none of the genies come.
vi: I went to find an old tin lamp and an iron ring, took them out to the forest, and rubbed and rubbed until I was sweating, having already planned to build a castle to sell. But it was useless, no genie appeared.
tr: I took an old tin lamp and an iron ring and went to the forest to start rubbing them. I kept rubbing until I was drenched in sweat with the hope of having a palace built and then selling it, but it was all in vain; none of the genies appeared.
es: I took an old tin lamp and an iron ring to the forest and started rubbing until I was sweating like an Indian, figuring I would build a palace to sell it; but nothing, no genie came.

en: So then I judged that all that stuff was only just one of Tom Sawyer’s lies.
vi: After that, I concluded that all those absurd stories were just one of Tom Sawyer's many lies.
tr: At that point, I concluded that all of this was just Tom Sawyer's inventions.
es: Then I thought that all that was just one of Tow Sawyer's lies.

en: I reckoned he believed in the A-rabs and the elephants, but as for me I think different.
vi: I was sure he believed there were real Arabs and elephants; but as for me, I thought differently.
tr: He probably believed in Arabs and elephants, but I thought differently.
es: I supposed he believed in the Arabs and the elephants, but I don't think the same as him.

en: It had all the marks of a Sunday-school.
vi: Because clearly, they were just a bunch of students from the local school.
tr: In my opinion, the spirit of Sunday school was infused into everything he told.
es: That seemed like a Sunday school thing.

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: Chapter IV
tr: Fourth Chapter
es: Chapter 4

en: Well, three or four months run along, and it was well into the winter now.
vi: Four months have passed, and now it is the middle of winter.
tr: Three or four more months passed like this, and we had now fully entered winter.
es: WELL, three or four months passed and it was already deep into winter.

en: I had been to school most all the time and could spell and read and write just a little, and could say the multiplication table up to six times seven is thirty-five, and I don’t reckon I could ever get any further than that if I was to live forever.
vi: All this time, I have been going to school and have learned to spell, read, write a little, and have memorized the multiplication table up to six times seven is thirty-five. I am not sure if I could get any better than that if I were to live longer.
tr: Most of the time, I was at school and had learned to count the letters of words, to read, and to write a little bit. The multiplication table was memorized up to six times seven equals thirty-five, but I didn't think I could go any further even if I lived forever.
es: I had gone to school almost all the time, I knew the letters and could read and write a little and I knew the multiplication table up to six times seven is thirty-five, and I thought I would never get beyond that even if I lived forever.

en: I don’t take no stock in mathematics, anyway.
vi: Anyway, I do not like math very much.
tr: Anyway, I didn't care much about mathematics.
es: Anyway, I don't like math very much.

en: At first I hated the school, but by-and-by I got so I could stand it.
vi: At first, I really hated going to school, but gradually, as I attended classes, I found it bearable.
tr: At first, I hated school, but over time it became more bearable.
es: At first, school annoyed me, but little by little I learned to endure it.

en: Whenever I got uncommon tired I played hookey, and the hiding I got next day done me good and cheered me up.
vi: Whenever I felt tired or unwell, I would skip school. And the next day, after getting a beating, I would study diligently and more enthusiastically.
tr: Whenever I got fed up, I would skip school, and the beating I received the next day would actually do me good; it would lift my spirits a bit.
es: When I got too tired, I would skip school, and the beating I got the next day felt good and cheered me up.

en: So the longer I went to school the easier it got to be.
vi: Thus, studying became easier for me over time.
tr: As I continued attending school, it started to seem not so difficult anymore.
es: So the more time I spent at school, the easier it became for me.

en: I was getting sort of used to the widow’s ways, too, and they warn’t so raspy on me.
vi: I also got used to the widow's temperament and didn't find it too annoying.
tr: I was also getting used to the widow's way of life, and I wasn't feeling as restless anymore.
es: I was also starting to get used to the widow's ways, which didn't bother me as much anymore.

en: Living in a house and sleeping in a bed pulled on me pretty tight mostly, but before the cold weather I used to slide out and sleep in the woods sometimes, and so that was a rest to me.
vi: Living in a house, sleeping on my own bed, sometimes I felt it was somewhat confining. Therefore, before the weather got too cold, I would occasionally sneak out to sleep in the forest.
tr: Living in a house and sleeping in a bed usually suffocated me, but before the weather turned cold, I had occasionally snuck out at night to sleep in the forest, taking a bit of a break.
es: Living in a house and sleeping in a bed was almost always bothersome to me, but before it got cold, I would usually sneak away to sleep in the forest, which served as a break for me.

en: I liked the old ways best, but I was getting so I liked the new ones, too, a little bit.
vi: To me, that felt like a break. I preferred the old ways of living the most. But when I had to live like this, I kind of liked it a bit.
tr: I loved my old life more, but I had also started to like my new life a little.
es: I liked the old ways better, but I was also starting to like the new ones a little.

en: The widow said I was coming along slow but sure, and doing very satisfactory.
vi: The widow told me that adapting to these things, though slow, was reliable and left no room for criticism.
tr: The widow said that I was progressing slowly but surely, and that my development was very satisfying.
es: The widow said I was progressing slowly but surely and that I was doing very well.

en: She said she warn’t ashamed of me.
vi: She said she wasn't ashamed of me.
tr: She wasn't ashamed of me at all.
es: She said she wasn't ashamed of me.

en: One morning I happened to turn over the salt-cellar at breakfast.
vi: One morning while I was having breakfast, I accidentally knocked over the salt dish.
tr: One morning while having breakfast, I accidentally knocked over the salt shaker.
es: One morning by chance I knocked over the salt shaker at breakfast time.

en: I reached for some of it as quick as I could to throw over my left shoulder and keep off the bad luck, but Miss Watson was in ahead of me, and crossed me off.
vi: I hurriedly scooped it up with my hand and threw it over my left shoulder to avoid bad luck, but suddenly Miss Watson appeared right in front of me and stopped me.
tr: I immediately reached out to take a pinch of the spilled salt and throw it over my left shoulder to ward off bad luck, but Miss Watson was quicker and blocked my way.
es: I grabbed some salt as soon as I could to throw it over my left shoulder and ward off bad luck, but Miss Watson got ahead of me to stop me.

en: She says, “Take your hands away, Huckleberry; what a mess you are always making!”
vi: She said: - Huck, let go of that, why are you always playing with dirty things?
tr: “Get your hands off, Huckleberry,” she said. “You’re always making a mess everywhere.”
es: She goes and says to me: "Get those hands away, Huckleberry; you spend your life making everything dirty!"

en: The widow put in a good word for me, but that warn’t going to keep off the bad luck, I knowed that well enough.
vi: The widow added a light sentence; but that couldn't prevent me from the misfortune, I knew that very well.
tr: The widow said a few kind words on my behalf, but I knew very well that those words wouldn’t keep the bad luck away.
es: The widow tried to excuse me, but that wasn't going to ward off the bad luck, and I knew it.

en: I started out, after breakfast, feeling worried and shaky, and wondering where it was going to fall on me, and what it was going to be.
vi: After the meal, I stepped outside, feeling anxious and fearful, not knowing where that misfortune would befall me and not knowing what it would be like.
tr: After breakfast, I was anxious and uneasy. It was uncertain where and how the bad luck would catch up with me.
es: After breakfast, I left, worried and trembling, wondering where it was going to hit me and what I was going to do.

en: There is ways to keep off some kinds of bad luck, but this wasn’t one of them kind; so I never tried to do anything, but just poked along low-spirited and on the watch-out.
vi: There are ways to avoid some bad luck, but this case was not among them; so I didn't know what to do, just wandering around with sad and fearful thoughts.
tr: There are ways to avoid some bad luck, but this time it was a different kind of bad luck. So I didn’t bother myself, just wandered around moodily and stayed alert.
es: There are ways to escape some types of bad luck, but this wasn't one of them, so I didn't try to do anything, but just kept going, very discouraged and alert to what was happening.

en: I went down to the front garden and clumb over the stile where you go through the high board fence.
vi: I went down to the garden, climbed over the fence gap, at the place where people usually come and go.
tr: I went out to the front yard, climbed the gate, and crossed to the other side of the fence.
es: I went down the front garden and jumped over the small gate where the tall fence is crossed.

en: There was an inch of new snow on the ground, and I seen somebody’s tracks.
vi: On the ground, the newly fallen snow covered a few inches, and I suddenly saw human footprints.
tr: The thickness of the snow on the ground had reached a few centimeters, and someone's footprints were clearly visible.
es: There was an inch of freshly fallen snow on the ground and I saw someone's footprints.

en: They had come up from the quarry and stood around the stile a while, and then went on around the garden fence.
vi: These footprints came from the direction of the mountain, stopped at this gap for a while, and then went around the fence.
tr: The tracks were coming from the quarry, had lingered a bit by the gate, and then circled around the fence.
es: They came from the quarry, stopped at the gate, and then went around the garden fence.

en: It was funny they hadn’t come in, after standing around so.
vi: How strange, who would linger there like that but not come in?
tr: It was strange that after waiting so long, they didn't enter.
es: It was curious that they hadn't passed through after stopping there.

en: I couldn’t make it out.
vi: I couldn't figure it out.
tr: I couldn't make sense of it.
es: I didn't understand it.

en: It was very curious, somehow.
vi: Anyway, it was very peculiar.
tr: For some reason, I was very curious.
es: In any case, it was strange.

en: I was going to follow around, but I stooped down to look at the tracks first.
vi: I was about to follow the footprints, but I bent down to look at them closely first.
tr: I was going to follow them, but first, I bent down and looked at the tracks carefully; at first, nothing caught my eye, but then I saw something familiar.
es: I was going to follow them, but first I stopped to examine them.

en: I didn’t notice anything at first, but next I did.
vi: At first, I didn't notice anything, but then I realized.
tr: I was going to follow them, but first, I bent down and looked at the tracks carefully; at first, nothing caught my eye, but then I saw something familiar.
es: At first, I saw nothing; then I did.

en: There was a cross in the left boot-heel made with big nails, to keep off the devil.
vi: There was a cross mark on the heel of the left shoe made with large nails, meant to ward off evil spirits.
tr: A cross made of large nails to keep the devil away was on the heel of the left boot.
es: On the heel of the left boot, there was a cross made with nails to keep the devil away.

en: I was up in a second and shinning down the hill.
vi: I immediately jumped up and ran down the hill.
tr: I immediately broke the bowstring and ran down the slope without stopping.
es: In a second I got up and ran down the hill.

en: I looked over my shoulder every now and then, but I didn’t see nobody.
vi: Every now and then, I looked back, but saw no one.
tr: I frequently turned my head to look back, but I didn't see anyone.
es: From time to time I looked over my shoulder, but I didn't see anyone.

en: I was at Judge Thatcher’s as quick as I could get there.
vi: I ran as fast as I could to Judge Thatcher's house.
tr: Without slowing down at all, I went straight to Judge Thatcher's house.
es: I reached Judge Thatcher's house as soon as I could.

en: He said:
vi: He saw me and asked:
tr: “What's the matter, son, you're out of breath,” he said.
es: He said to me:

en: “Why, my boy, you are all out of breath.
vi: - What's wrong, why are you in such a hurry?
tr: “What's the matter, son, you're out of breath,” he said.
es: —But, boy, you're out of breath.

en: Did you come for your interest?”
vi: Are you here to collect the interest?
tr: “Did you come for the interest?”
es: Have you come to collect the interest?

en: “No, sir,” I says; “is there some for me?”
vi: I replied: - No, sir, that's not it. So, there is interest for me?
tr: “No, sir,” I said, “was there any interest?””
es: —No, sir —I replied—; do you have them for me?

en: “Oh, yes, a half-yearly is in, last night—over a hundred and fifty dollars.
vi: - Yes, of course. As of yesterday, it has been half a year. That means it's more than one hundred and fifty dollars.
tr: “Of course, the six-month interest came in last night. More than one hundred and fifty dollars.
es: —Ah, yes, last night the semester's money arrived: more than one hundred and fifty dollars.

en: Quite a fortune for you.
vi: A substantial amount for you.
tr: It counts as a fortune for you.
es: For you, quite a fortune.

en: You had better let me invest it along with your six thousand, because if you take it you’ll spend it.”
vi: But it's best if you let me keep it and add it to the six thousand dong from before, otherwise, if you take it back, you'll end up spending it all.
tr: It's best to invest it along with your six thousand, because if you take it, you'll squander it away.”
es: You better let me invest it with your six thousand, because if I give it to you, you'll spend it.

en: “No, sir,” I says, “I don’t want to spend it.
vi: - No, sir, I don't want to spend all six thousand, just like before.
tr: “No; sir,” I said, “I don't want to spend it.
es: —No, sir —I said—. I don't want to spend them.

en: I don’t want it at all—nor the six thousand, nuther.
vi: - No, sir, I don't want to spend all six thousand, just like before.
tr: In fact, I don't want it at all… I don't want the six thousand either.
es: I don't want them for anything; and neither the six thousand.

en: I want you to take it; I want to give it to you—the six thousand and all.”
vi: I want you to take it, it's a gift for you, all six thousand, everything.
tr: I want you to take all of it; I want to give it to you… the six thousand and all the rest of it.”
es: I want you to keep them; I want to give them to you: the six thousand and everything.

en: He looked surprised.
vi: The old man was very surprised.
tr: He looked surprised.
es: He seemed surprised.

en: He couldn’t seem to make it out.
vi: It seemed that he couldn't understand why.
tr: He seemed like he didn't understand what I wanted to do.
es: It was as if he couldn't understand it.

en: He says:
vi: The old man asked:
tr: “Hey, what do you mean, my dear?” she said.
es: He goes and says:

en: “Why, what can you mean, my boy?”
vi: - What do you mean by saying that?
tr: “Hey, what do you mean, my dear?” she said.
es: —But, what do you mean, boy?

en: I says, “Don’t you ask me no questions about it, please.
vi: - Please don't ask me any more questions about that.
tr: “Please don't ask me questions about this, please.
es: And I go and tell him: —Please, don't ask me anything.

en: You’ll take it—won’t you?”
vi: Keep that money, do you want to?
tr: You will take it… won't you?”
es: You will keep it; right?

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: “Honestly, I was quite surprised by this,” he said.
es: And he goes and says:

en: “Well, I’m puzzled.
vi: - I'm really having a hard time.
tr: “Honestly, I was quite surprised by this,” he said.
es: —Well, I don't know what to do.

en: Is something the matter?”
vi: What's the matter with you?
tr: “Is there a problem?”
es: Is something wrong?

en: “Please take it,” says I, “and don’t ask me nothing—then I won’t have to tell no lies.”
vi: I replied: - Please take all the gold and don't ask me what I'm doing anymore. I don't want to lie.
tr: “Please take it and don't ask me anything,” I said. “If you don't ask, I won't have to make up a lie.”
es: —Please, keep it and don't ask me anything... that way I won't have to tell lies.

en: He studied a while, and then he says:
vi: The old man thought for a moment and then said:
tr: After thinking for a while, he said:
es: He thought about it for a while and then said:

en: “Oho-o!
vi: - Okay, I understand now.
tr: “Haa.
es: —Ah, ah!

en: I think I see.
vi: - Okay, I understand now.
tr: Now I think I understand.
es: I think I understand now.

en: You want to sell all your property to me—not give it.
vi: So, you want to sell all of your assets to me, not give them as a gift.
tr: You want to sell me all your goods… not give them.
es: You want to sell me all your goods; not give them to me.

en: That’s the correct idea.”
vi: Is that correct?
tr: This would be more accurate.”
es: That is correct.

en: Then he wrote something on a paper and read it over, and says:
vi: Then he wrote something on a piece of paper, read it aloud, and said:
tr: After writing something on a piece of paper and reading it from start to finish, he continued:
es: Then he wrote something on a piece of paper, which he read to me and which said:

en: “There; you see it says ‘for a consideration.’
vi: - Do you see? It says here it's a contract.
tr: “Let's see... as you can see, it says 'for a price.'
es: —Look; you'll see it says "for the agreed sum."

en: That means I have bought it of you and paid you for it.
vi: That means I bought it from you and paid you.
tr: So I bought it from you and paid you the price.
es: That means I bought it from you and I paid for it.

en: Here’s a dollar for you.
vi: Here, take one dollar.
tr: Here's a dollar.
es: Here's a dollar.

en: Now you sign it.”
vi: Now sign here.
tr: Come on, sign here.”
es: Now sign it.

en: So I signed it, and left.
vi: I signed my name and then left
tr: I signed and left there.
es: So I signed it and left.

en: Miss Watson’s nigger, Jim, had a hair-ball as big as your fist, which had been took out of the fourth stomach of an ox, and he used to do magic with it.
vi: Jim, the black man who worked for Miss Watson, had a tuft of hair as big as a fist that he got from the fourth stomach compartment of a cow, and he used it for magic tricks.
tr: Jim, Watson's black man, had a ball of hair the size of a fist. He had taken the ball from the fourth stomach of an ox and used it for magic.
es: Jim, Miss Watson's black man, had a hairball the size of a fist that had been taken from the fourth stomach of an ox, and he did magic things with it.

en: He said there was a spirit inside of it, and it knowed everything.
vi: He claimed that inside the tuft of hair was a creature that knew everything.
tr: He claimed that it had a spirit inside and knew everything.
es: He said that inside there was a spirit that knew everything.

en: So I went to him that night and told him pap was here again, for I found his tracks in the snow.
vi: That night, I went to Jim out of curiosity and told him that my father was in the snow.
tr: That night, I went to him and told him that my father had returned because I had seen his footprints in the snow.
es: So that night I went to see him and told him that my father had returned, because I had seen his footprints in the snow.

en: What I wanted to know was, what he was going to do, and was he going to stay?
vi: What I wanted to know was what my father would do and if he intended to stay there.
tr: I wanted to know what he was going to do, would he stay?
es: What I wanted to know was what he was going to do and where he planned to sleep.

en: Jim got out his hair-ball and said something over it, and then he held it up and dropped it on the floor.
vi: Jim took out the tuft of hair, mumbled something to it for a while, then held it up high, and let it fall to the floor.
tr: Jim took out the ball of hair and said something to it, then lifted it up and dropped it to the ground.
es: Jim took out his hairball and said something over it, then he lifted it and let it fall to the ground.

en: It fell pretty solid, and only rolled about an inch.
vi: The tuft of hair fell with a thud and rolled a few inches.
tr: The ball looked very solid and only rolled a few centimeters.
es: It fell with a single thud and didn't roll more than an inch.

en: Jim tried it again, and then another time, and it acted just the same.
vi: Jim picked it up again, let it fall once more, and the tuft of hair listened.
tr: Jim tried again and again, and each time the ball did the same thing.
es: Jim tried again and again, always the same result.

en: Jim got down on his knees, and put his ear against it and listened.
vi: Jim picked it up again, let it fall once more, and the tuft of hair listened.
tr: Jim knelt down, put his ear to the ball, and listened.
es: He knelt down and put his ear close to listen.

en: But it warn’t no use; he said it wouldn’t talk.
vi: But it was useless.
tr: But it was no use; he said the ball wouldn't talk.
es: But nothing; it didn't want to talk.

en: He said sometimes it wouldn’t talk without money.
vi: Jim said that the tuft of hair didn't want to speak. Jim said that sometimes it wouldn't speak without money.
tr: Sometimes it wouldn't talk unless money was given.
es: Jim said it wouldn't talk unless we gave it money.

en: I told him I had an old slick counterfeit quarter that warn’t no good because the brass showed through the silver a little, and it wouldn’t pass nohow, even if the brass didn’t show, because it was so slick it felt greasy, and so that would tell on it every time.
vi: I told him I had a fake twenty-five cent coin, old and unusable.
tr: I said I had an old, smooth counterfeit quarter, but it was useless because its silver had worn off, revealing a yellowish color underneath; moreover, even if the yellow wasn't visible, it wouldn't pass because it was too slippery and looked oily, it was obviously fake.
es: I told him I had an old, smooth, fake quarter dollar that was worthless because you could see a bit of the copper underneath the silver, and no one would accept it, even if you couldn't see the copper, because it was so smooth it would slip and everyone would notice (I thought not to tell him about the dollar the judge had given me).

en: (I reckoned I wouldn’t say nothing about the dollar I got from the judge.)
vi: I kept repeating this (I had already planned not to mention the dollar Judge Thatcher had just given me).
tr: (I definitely wasn't going to mention the dollar I got from the judge. )
es: I told him I had an old, smooth, fake quarter dollar that was worthless because you could see a bit of the copper underneath the silver, and no one would accept it, even if you couldn't see the copper, because it was so smooth it would slip and everyone would notice (I thought not to tell him about the dollar the judge had given me).

en: I said it was pretty bad money, but maybe the hair-ball would take it, because maybe it wouldn’t know the difference.
vi: I said the coin was very bad, but maybe the tuft of hair would accept it. Because perhaps it couldn't tell the difference between good and bad.
tr: I said it was quite a bad coin, but maybe the ball of hair would take it, because it might not know the difference.
es: I told him it was very bad money, but maybe the hairball would accept it because it might not understand the difference.

en: Jim smelt it and bit it and rubbed it, and said he would manage so the hair-ball would think it was good.
vi: Jim took the coin, sniffed it, bit it, then rubbed it clean. Then he said he would trick the tuft of hair into thinking it was a good coin.
tr: Jim sniffed the coin, bit it, rubbed it, and said it would work because he knew a way to trick the ball of hair into thinking the coin was real.
es: Jim smelled it, bit it, rubbed it, and said he would make the hairball believe it was good by cutting a raw Irish potato in half and putting the coin in the middle and leaving it there all night, so that by the next morning you wouldn't be able to see the copper and it wouldn't be so slippery, so anyone in town would accept it, let alone a hairball.

en: He said he would split open a raw Irish potato and stick the quarter in between and keep it there all night, and next morning you couldn’t see no brass, and it wouldn’t feel greasy no more, and so anybody in town would take it in a minute, let alone a hair-ball.
vi: He said he would split a raw potato and place the coin in the middle, leave it overnight, and by the next morning, it wouldn't look like a coin anymore and wouldn't be dirty; anyone in town could mistake it for a real coin, let alone the tuft of hair.
tr: He would cut a raw potato in half, put the quarter in between, and keep it there all night. By morning, the yellow would no longer be visible, the coin wouldn't be slippery, and not only the ball of hair but everyone in town would take the coin without a second thought.
es: Jim smelled it, bit it, rubbed it, and said he would make the hairball believe it was good by cutting a raw Irish potato in half and putting the coin in the middle and leaving it there all night, so that by the next morning you wouldn't be able to see the copper and it wouldn't be so slippery, so anyone in town would accept it, let alone a hairball.

en: Well, I knowed a potato would do that before, but I had forgot it.
vi: Previously, I had known how to do this with a potato, but I had forgotten over time.
tr: I knew that potatoes worked for this before, but I had forgotten.
es: Well, I already knew that potatoes were good for that, but I had forgotten.

en: Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened again.
vi: Jim placed the coin under the tuft of hair and then knelt down to listen.
tr: Jim placed the quarter under the ball of hair and knelt down to listen again.
es: Jim placed the coin under the hairball, bent down, and listened again.

en: This time he said the hair-ball was all right.
vi: This time he said the tuft of hair had given a sign.
tr: This time, he said the ball of hair was working.
es: This time he said the hairball was fine.

en: He said it would tell my whole fortune if I wanted it to.
vi: He said the tuft of hair would tell me I could become as rich as I wanted.
tr: He said it could tell me my entire future if I wanted.
es: He said he would tell my fortune if I wanted.

en: I says, go on.
vi: I said, okay, go ahead and do it.
tr: I said I wanted it to tell me.
es: I go and tell him to go ahead.

en: So the hair-ball talked to Jim, and Jim told it to me.
vi: So the tuft of hair spoke to Jim, and Jim relayed to me that:
tr: So the ball of hair talked to Jim, and Jim told me the fortune.
es: Then the hairball spoke to Jim, and Jim told me about it.

en: He says:
vi: So the tuft of hair spoke to Jim, and Jim relayed to me that:
tr: He said:
es: He goes and says:

en: “Yo’ ole father doan’ know yit what he’s a-gwyne to do.
vi: - We don't know yet what your father will do.
tr: “Your father doesn't know what to do now.
es: —Your father still doesn't know what he's going to do.

en: Sometimes he spec he’ll go ’way, en den agin he spec he’ll stay.
vi: He might go far away, or he might decide to stay.
tr: Sometimes he thinks of leaving, sometimes he says he'll stay.
es: Sometimes he thinks he's going to leave and then he thinks he's going to stay.

en: De bes’ way is to res’ easy en let de ole man take his own way.
vi: But it's best to stay calm and let him do whatever he wants.
tr: If it's best to leave it empty, let the man run his own course.
es: The best thing is to leave things be and let the old man do what he wants.

en: Dey’s two angels hoverin’ roun’ ’bout him.
vi: There are two angels flying around him.
tr: Two angels are hovering above his head.
es: There are two angels circling around him.

en: One uv ’em is white en shiny, en t’other one is black.
vi: A white angel, bright and sparkling. And one angel is black.
tr: One is white, it ties, the other is black.
es: One of them is white and radiant and the other is black.

en: De white one gits him to go right a little while, den de black one sail in en bust it all up.
vi: The white angel guides him along the good path for a while, then the black angel jumps in and ruins everything.
tr: The white one calls him to the right path for a while, then the black one comes out and ruins everything.
es: The white one makes him go down the right path for a while and then the black one comes and messes everything up.

en: A body can’t tell yit which one gwyne to fetch him at de las’.
vi: It's impossible to say which angel will ultimately take him.
tr: One day, one of them will take him in their palm, but which one is unknown.
es: It's impossible to know which one will be the last to catch him.

en: But you is all right.
vi: But as for you, there's nothing to worry about.
tr: But your fortune is open.
es: But you will be fine.

en: You gwyne to have considable trouble in yo’ life, en considable joy.
vi: Your life will encounter many troubles, but also many joys.
tr: Throughout your life, you will see a lot of suffering, but there will also be much joy.
es: You will have many problems in life and many joys.

en: Sometimes you gwyne to git hurt, en sometimes you gwyne to git sick; but every time you’s gwyne to git well agin.
vi: Sometimes you will be in pain, sometimes you will be weak, but each time you will recover as usual.
tr: Sometimes you will get wet, sometimes you will get sick, but you will always be well in the end.
es: Sometimes you will have a hard time and sometimes you will get sick, but each time you will get better.

en: Dey’s two gals flyin’ ’bout you in yo’ life.
vi: There are two young women who will hover around you throughout your life.
tr: There are two girls in your life.
es: There are two women who matter in your life.

en: One uv ’em’s light en t’other one is dark.
vi: One is fair-skinned, the other is dark-skinned.
tr: One is white, one is dark.
es: One is fair and the other is dark.

en: One is rich en t’other is po’.
vi: One is rich, the other is poor.
tr: One is rich, one is poor.
es: One is rich and the other is poor.

en: You’s gwyne to marry de po’ one fust en de rich one by en by.
vi: You will marry the poor one first, then the rich one.
tr: First, you will marry the poor one, then the rich one.
es: You will marry the poor one first and then the rich one.

en: You wants to keep ’way fum de water as much as you kin, en don’t run no resk, ’kase it’s down in de bills dat you’s gwyne to git hung.”
vi: You must stay away from rivers and waters as much as possible. And above all, don't do anything risky, because if they record your name, you will be hanged.
tr: You avoid water, you feel distant from it, and if there's a risk of hanging, you don't take the risk.”
es: You have to be very careful with water and not have adventures, because it is written that you will be hanged.

en: When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap his own self!
vi: That night, just as I lit the candle and went up to the room, I saw my father sitting there from who knows when. Yes, it was definitely my father!
tr: That night, when I lit the candle and went up to my room, I found my father in front of me, it was him!
es: That night, when I lit the candle and went up to my room, there was father, in person!

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: Chapter V
tr: Chapter Five
es: Chapter 5

en: I had shut the door to.
vi: I had just closed the door and turned around to see him sitting there.
tr: I had closed the door behind me.
es: I HAD closed the door.

en: Then I turned around and there he was.
vi: I had just closed the door and turned around to see him sitting there.
tr: Then I turned the other way and there it was.
es: Then I turned around and there it was.

en: I used to be scared of him all the time, he tanned me so much.
vi: Whenever I saw him, I was always terrified because he had beaten me so many times.
tr: I was always afraid of it, it used to beat me a lot.
es: Before, I was afraid of it because it used to hit me all the time.

en: I reckoned I was scared now, too; but in a minute I see I was mistaken—that is, after the first jolt, as you may say, when my breath sort of hitched, he being so unexpected; but right away after I see I warn’t scared of him worth bothring about.
vi: At that moment, I was very frightened, but just a minute later, I realized I was mistaken - that is, after the initial shock, so to speak, when my breath suddenly caught due to the unexpected sight of him there, I no longer felt scared, and thus there was nothing to worry about.
tr: I thought I was still afraid, but I realized I was wrong a little later… that is, after overcoming the initial shock, when I started breathing again, I immediately understood that I wasn't really that afraid of it.
es: I thought I would still be afraid of it now, but after a minute I realized I was wrong, that is, after the initial shock, so to speak, when I was left breathless because I wasn't expecting it at all; but immediately I realized that I wasn't as afraid of it.

en: He was most fifty, and he looked it.
vi: My father is about fifty years old.
tr: He was almost fifty years old, and he looked his age.
es: He was almost fifty years old and he looked it.

en: His hair was long and tangled and greasy, and hung down, and you could see his eyes shining through like he was behind vines.
vi: His hair is long, messy, hanging down, and dirty. Through that hair, you can see his bright eyes shining out, as if he were hiding behind a grapevine and looking at you.
tr: His long, greasy, and disheveled hair fell over his face, making his eyes shine as if they were behind ivy.
es: He had long, tangled, greasy hair that hung down to his neck, and through it, his eyes shone as if he were hiding behind a vine.

en: It was all black, no gray; so was his long, mixed-up whiskers.
vi: His hair is completely black without a single gray strand, and the long sideburns intertwine with each other as well.
tr: There was no gray in his hair, nor in his long and tangled sideburns.
es: It was all black, without any gray; just like his long, disheveled beard.

en: There warn’t no color in his face, where his face showed; it was white; not like another man’s white, but a white to make a body sick, a white to make a body’s flesh crawl—a tree-toad white, a fish-belly white.
vi: Looking at his face, except for the places without hair, there is no other color, just white, not the kind of white everyone has, but a white that makes the flesh of people cringe. A white like that of a climbing plant, a white like the belly of a fish.
tr: As far as could be seen from his hair, its color had faded; his face was ghostly white; but not white like others, a stomach-turning white, a hair-raising white – the white of a tree frog, the white of a fish belly.
es: There was no color in his face, where it was visible; it was all white, not like other men, but a white that was disgusting, a white that made you itch, a white like a tree frog, like a fish's belly.

en: As for his clothes—just rags, that was all.
vi: As for his clothes, apart from a few tattered pieces, there is nothing else.
tr: His clothes were– truly rags.
es: And his clothes: rags and nothing more.

en: He had one ankle resting on t’other knee; the boot on that foot was busted, and two of his toes stuck through, and he worked them now and then.
vi: He sits cross-legged, the shoe on the leg that is crossed over has its mouth open, a toe sticking out, occasionally wiggling.
tr: He had one ankle resting on the opposite knee; on that foot, he kept wiggling the two toes visible through the hole in the tip of his boot.
es: He had one ankle resting on the other knee; the boot on that foot was torn and two of his toes were visible, which he moved from time to time.

en: His hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, like a lid.
vi: His hat thrown on the floor is a wide-brimmed, black hat, old, with a huge hole on the crown that looks like a door frame leading down to a ship's hold.
tr: He had placed his hat on the ground; the wide-brimmed, shabby black hat had its crown caved in, looking like a pot lid.
es: He had left his hat on the floor: an old slouch hat with the crown all caved in, like a lid.

en: I stood a-looking at him; he set there a-looking at me, with his chair tilted back a little.
vi: I stood looking at him. He also sat looking at me, the back of the chair slightly tilted backward.
tr: I stood there motionless, staring; he was sitting in the chair, slouching a bit, scrutinizing me.
es: I stayed looking at him; he remained seated looking at me, with the chair tilted back a little.

en: I set the candle down.
vi: I placed the candle down.
tr: I placed the candle somewhere.
es: I placed the candle on the floor.

en: I noticed the window was up; so he had clumb in by the shed.
vi: I noticed that the window had been raised, so he must have climbed through the warehouse roof to get in here.
tr: I noticed that the window was open, so he must have climbed up from the veranda.
es: I saw that the window was open, so he had climbed up through the shed.

en: He kept a-looking me all over.
vi: He kept looking all over me like that.
tr: He continued to scrutinize me from head to toe.
es: He did nothing but look at me.

en: By-and-by he says:
vi: After a while, he spoke:
tr: Then he spoke:
es: After a while, he goes and says:

en: “Starchy clothes—very.
vi: - Your clothes look really cool.
tr: "Starched clothes, huh... wow."
es: —You wear good clothes, very good.

en: You think you’re a good deal of a big-bug, don’t you?”
vi: Do you think you look like someone important?
tr: "Are you going to act all high and mighty now, is that it?""
es: You must think you're a big shot, don't you?

en: “Maybe I am, maybe I ain’t,” I says.
vi: I replied: - It could be like that, or it might not be.
tr: “Whether I become one or not,” I said.
es: —Maybe yes and maybe no —I replied.

en: “Don’t you give me none o’ your lip,” says he.
vi: He asked again: - Have you been badmouthing me?
tr: “Don't you dare talk back to me,” he said.
es: —Don't get cocky —he goes and says—.

en: “You’ve put on considerable many frills since I been away.
vi: Since I've been away, you've been acting all high and mighty, huh?
tr: “You've gotten quite full of yourself in my absence.
es: Since I left, you've been putting on airs.

en: I’ll take you down a peg before I get done with you.
vi: I'll bring you down a notch before I give up on you.
tr: But I know how to deflate your ego.
es: I'll bring you down a peg before I'm done with you.

en: You’re educated, too, they say—can read and write.
vi: I've heard people say that you're educated, that you can read and write.
tr: They say you're going to school, that you can read and write.
es: And I've been told you're educated: that you know how to read and write.
