en: You think you’re better’n your father, now, don’t you, because he can’t?
vi: Now you think you're better than your father, don't you; because your father can't read or write.
tr: Just because your father is illiterate, you think you're better than him now, huh?
es: You think you're worth more than your father now, don't you? Just because he doesn't know how.

en: I’ll take it out of you.
vi: Fine, I'll show you.
tr: But I'll set you straight, don't you worry.
es: I'll show you.

en: Who told you you might meddle with such hifalut’n foolishness, hey?—who told you you could?”
vi: Who told you that you could get involved in such crazy things, huh? Who gave you the right to do that?
tr: Who told you to waste your time with such trivial nonsense, huh?.. Who told you, I said?”
es: Who told you to go around acting all high and mighty? Who gave you permission?

en: “The widow.
vi: - The widow, did she tell you that? - A widow?
tr: “Stop, woman.
es: —The widow.

en: She told me.”
vi: Then who told her to meddle in something that isn't her business?
tr: He said.”
es: She told me.

en: “The widow, hey?—and who told the widow she could put in her shovel about a thing that ain’t none of her business?”
vi: Then who told her to meddle in something that isn't her business?
tr: “Calling her a widow, huh?.. Who told the widow to stick her nose into matters that don't concern her?”
es: —The widow, huh? And, who has come to give the widow a candle at this funeral?

en: “Nobody never told her.”
vi: - No one told her anything.
tr: “Nobody said anything to him.”
es: —Nobody has given it to her.

en: “Well, I’ll learn her how to meddle.
vi: Alright, I'll teach her not to get involved.
tr: “I'll show him what it means to meddle in everything.
es: —Well, I'm going to teach him to mind his own business.

en: And looky here—you drop that school, you hear?
vi: And you listen here: you better stop, no more studying, got it?
tr: Now listen to me… No ifs, ands, or buts, you're leaving that school.
es: And listen to what I'm telling you: stop going to school, got it?

en: I’ll learn people to bring up a boy to put on airs over his own father and let on to be better’n what he is.
vi: I'll let them know not to raise a child who thinks they can look down on their father and believe they're better than they actually are.
tr: I'll show them what it means to raise sons who don't respect their fathers and to allow them to act as if they're superior to their fathers.
es: I'm going to teach them to educate a boy so that he doesn't put on airs in front of his own father and act like he's better than him.

en: You lemme catch you fooling around that school again, you hear?
vi: If I catch you studying again, you'll be in trouble, got it?
tr: If I catch you near that school again, did you hear me?
es: Don't let me catch you near that school again, got it?

en: Your mother couldn’t read, and she couldn’t write, nuther, before she died.
vi: Your mother couldn't read or write until the day she died.
tr: Your mother couldn't read or write either.
es: Your mother didn't know how to read or write, and she died peacefully.

en: None of the family couldn’t before they died.
vi: No one in this family knew how to read or write before they died. I don't know how either.
tr: No one in the family could read a single line until they died.
es: Nobody in the family learned to read before they died.

en: I can’t; and here you’re a-swelling yourself up like this.
vi: So why do you think you have the right to do so now?
tr: I can't read either, but now you're standing in front of me acting all high and mighty.
es: I don't know how, and there you are putting on airs.

en: I ain’t the man to stand it—you hear?
vi: I'm not the kind of person who can tolerate that, got it?
tr: I have no patience for such things, just so you know.
es: And I'm not the kind of man to put up with that, got it?

en: Say, lemme hear you read.”
vi: Now, try reading something out loud for me?
tr: Well, go ahead and read, let's see.”
es: Hey, let's see how you read.

en: I took up a book and begun something about General Washington and the wars.
vi: I picked up a book, started reading a bit about Washington and the war, I read.
tr: I picked up a book and started reading something about General Washington and the wars.
es: I took out a book and started reading something that talked about General Washington and the wars.

en: When I’d read about a half a minute, he fetched the book a whack with his hand and knocked it across the house.
vi: About half a minute later, he flicked the book to the corner of the room with his hand and said:
tr: I had barely read for half a minute when he struck the book with the back of his hand, sending it flying to the other side of the room.
es: When I had been reading for about half a minute, he suddenly snatched the book from me and threw it to the other side of the room.

en: He says:
vi: About half a minute later, he flicked the book to the corner of the room with his hand and said:
tr: “So that's how it is.
es: And then he says:

en: “It’s so.
vi: - Ah, you can read it again?
tr: “So that's how it is.
es: —It's true.

en: You can do it.
vi: - Ah, you can read it again?
tr: You are studying.
es: You really do know.

en: I had my doubts when you told me.
vi: I've heard people say that, but I still doubt it, not fully believing it yet.
tr: At first, I didn't believe it.
es: I had my doubts when you told me.

en: Now looky here; you stop that putting on frills.
vi: Listen here, stop acting all high and mighty, I don't like it.
tr: Listen here, kid, you will stop this arrogance.
es: Well, look, stop with the airs.

en: I won’t have it.
vi: I'm telling you, my child.
tr: Don't test my patience.
es: I'm not going to put up with it.

en: I’ll lay for you, my smarty; and if I catch you about that school I’ll tan you good.
vi: If I catch you lingering around that school again, I'll give you a good beating.
tr: I'll knock you out cold, you smarty-pants; if I see you around that school again, I'll beat you to a pulp.
es: I'll be very watchful, smart aleck, and if I catch you at that school, I'll give you a beating.

en: First you know you’ll get religion, too.
vi: First of all, you need to know that you must listen to me.
tr: Once you start studying, you'll probably turn religious too.
es: If you keep this up, the nun will also give you one.

en: I never see such a son.”
vi: I've never seen a child like this before.
tr: Such a child is better off not existing.”
es: I've never seen a boy like you.

en: He took up a little blue and yaller picture of some cows and a boy, and says:
vi: He picked up a colorful photograph with some cows and a child in it, and asked me:
tr: He saw a small blue and yellow picture showing cows and a child.
es: He grabbed a blue and yellow trading card with some cows and a boy, and then he says:

en: “What’s this?”
vi: - What is this?
tr: “What is this?””
es: —What is this?

en: “It’s something they give me for learning my lessons good.”
vi: - That is their reward for you because you memorized the lesson
tr: "It's something they gave me because I learned my lesson well."
es: —They gave it to me because I knew the lesson well.

en: He tore it up, and says:
vi: He immediately tore up the photo and said:
tr: He tore it up as soon as he received it.
es: He broke it and then says:

en: “I’ll give you something better—I’ll give you a cowhide.”
vi: - I will give you something better. I will give you the whip.
tr: “I will give you something better… a good beating.”
es: —I'm going to give you something better: I'm going to give you a good thrashing.

en: He set there a-mumbling and a-growling a minute, and then he says:
vi: Then he sat muttering, grumbling for a long time and then said:
tr: After sitting for a while, mumbling and grumbling to himself, he spoke again:
es: He remained seated, murmuring and grumbling for a while, and then he goes and says:

en: “Ain’t you a sweet-scented dandy, though?
vi: - The type of pampered young master, drenched in perfume, right?
tr: “So, you became like those well-scented ladies?
es: —But you're quite the dandy, aren't you?

en: A bed; and bedclothes; and a look’n’-glass; and a piece of carpet on the floor—and your own father got to sleep with the hogs in the tanyard.
vi: There’s a bed, bed sheets. There's even a mirror. Ah, and there's also a carpet on the floor. While your father has to sleep with the pigs in the tannery.
tr: Beds, pajamas; mirrors; carpets on the floor and all... but your own father sleeps with pigs in the tannery.
es: Bed and sheets, mirror and your carpet on the floor, while your own father has to sleep with the pigs in the tanneries.

en: I never see such a son.
vi: Never have I seen a child like this.
tr: Such a child is not worth having.
es: I've never seen a boy like this.

en: I bet I’ll take some o’ these frills out o’ you before I’m done with you.
vi: I must make you get rid of all those pretentious airs first, then we’ll talk. Well, you still haven’t dropped those manners, have you?
tr: I swear I will shatter your arrogance so thoroughly.
es: I'm sure you'll have fewer airs when I'm done with you.

en: Why, there ain’t no end to your airs—they say you’re rich.
vi: They say you’re very rich, is that true?
tr: What's with this attitude... they say you're rich.
es: But you just keep putting on airs... I've been told you're rich.

en: Hey?—how’s that?”
vi: How did you become rich?
tr: Huh?.. How is that possible?”
es: Eh?... How did that happen?

en: “They lie—that’s how.”
vi: - They are lying, there's no such thing.
tr: “Liars… they are lying.”
es: —It's a lie... that's how it happened.

en: “Looky here—mind how you talk to me; I’m a-standing about all I can stand now—so don’t gimme no sass.
vi: - Hey, watch your mouth when you talk to me. Everything I could have done, I always dared to do, so don't try to deceive me.
tr: “Look at me… speak to me properly. I'm already at the end of my patience, I don't want any nonsense.
es: —Look, be careful how you talk to me. I've been tolerating you too much already, so don't get insolent.

en: I’ve been in town two days, and I hain’t heard nothing but about you bein’ rich.
vi: I've been out of town for the past two days.
tr: I've been in town for two days and everyone is talking about your wealth.
es: I've been in the village for two days and the only thing everyone has told me is that you're rich.

en: I heard about it away down the river, too.
vi: Even down by the river, people were saying the same thing.
tr: I heard the story all the way down by the river.
es: And I've also heard it said by the river.

en: That’s why I come.
vi: That's why I came here.
tr: That's why I came.
es: That's why I came.

en: You git me that money to-morrow—I want it.”
vi: Tomorrow, you have to give me that money; I need it.
tr: Tomorrow, you will give me that money…
es: Tomorrow you bring me that money: I want it.

en: “I hain’t got no money.”
vi: - I don't have any money
tr: All of it.” "I have no money."
es: —I don't have any money.

en: “It’s a lie.
vi: - Speak, old man.
tr: “Liar.
es: —Liar. Judge Thatcher has it.

en: Judge
vi: Judge Thatcher took that money.
tr: It's with Judge Thatcher.
es: —Liar. Judge Thatcher has it.

en: Thatcher’s got it.
vi: Judge Thatcher took that money.
tr: It's with Judge Thatcher.
es: —Liar. Judge Thatcher has it.

en: You git it.
vi: You have it.
tr: You will go and get it.
es: Yes, you have it.

en: I want it.”
vi: I need that money.
tr: You will give it all to me.”
es: And I want it.

en: “I hain’t got no money, I tell you.
vi: - I'm telling the truth, I don't have any money.
tr: “I told you, I have no money at all.
es: —I don't have any money. I'm telling you.

en: You ask Judge Thatcher; he’ll tell you the same.”
vi: Just go ask Judge Thatcher, he will tell you the same thing.
tr: Go ask Judge Thatcher; he’ll tell you the same.”
es: Ask Judge Thatcher and he'll tell you the same.

en: “All right.
vi: - Okay, then I'll ask him, I'll talk to him to see what's going on.
tr: “Alright then, I'll go and ask.
es: —Very well.

en: I’ll ask him; and I’ll make him pungle, too, or I’ll know the reason why.
vi: - Okay, then I'll ask him, I'll talk to him to see what's going on.
tr: Then I'll tell them to take it all apart, and if they can't, I'll understand why.
es: I'm going to ask him and make him cough up, and if not, I'll find out why.

en: Say, how much you got in your pocket?
vi: Hey, how much do you have in your pocket right now?
tr: How much money do you have in your pocket now?
es: Hey, how much do you have in your pocket?

en: I want it.”
vi: Give it to me, I need it.
tr: Give it all to me.”
es: Give it to me.

en: “I hain’t got only a dollar, and I want that to—”
vi: - I only have one dollar. I was planning to...
tr: “But I only have one dollar; I was going to do something with it…””
es: —I only have a dollar and I want it for...

en: “It don’t make no difference what you want it for—you just shell it out.”
vi: - Whatever you intend to do, I don't care, I don't need to know, just hand it over.
tr: “What you will do is none of my business... go ahead, spill it.”
es: —It doesn't matter what you want it for... Just give it to me and that's it.

en: He took it and bit it to see if it was good, and then he said he was going down town to get some whisky; said he hadn’t had a drink all day.
vi: He immediately grabbed the coin and bit it to see if it was good; then he said he was going downtown to get some whiskey, claiming he hadn't had a drop all day.
tr: He took the dollar and bit the edge to see if it was real. Then he said he would go to town to buy some whiskey, as he hadn't had a drop all day.
es: I gave it to him and he bit it to see if it was good, and then he said he was going to the town center to have a whiskey; that he hadn't drunk all day.

en: When he had got out on the shed he put his head in again, and cussed me for putting on frills and trying to be better than him; and when I reckoned he was gone he come back and put his head in again, and told me to mind about that school, because he was going to lay for me and lick me if I didn’t drop that.
vi: As he stepped out into the darkness, he turned back and warned me not to act like I was better than him. When I thought he was gone, he came back, stuck his head in, and warned me to be careful with that school, or he would come and give me a beating if I didn't quit.
tr: After stepping out onto the veranda from the window, he poked his head back inside and blamed me for my airs and graces and for trying to be superior to him. Just when I thought he had left, his head appeared in the window again, and he warned me to drop out of school, or else he would corner me and beat me until the cows came home.
es: When he went out to the shed, he stuck his head back through the window and cursed me for having airs and trying to be better than him, and when I thought he had already left, he stuck his head back through the window and told me to be careful with that school, because he would be very watchful and would thrash me if I didn't stop going.

en: Next day he was drunk, and he went to Judge Thatcher’s and bullyragged him, and tried to make him give up the money; but he couldn’t, and then he swore he’d make the law force him.
vi: The next day, he was completely drunk, stumbled to old chief Thatcher's house, intending to force him to hand over all the money. But it was useless; then he swore he would bring the old chief to justice.
tr: The next day, with a drunken mind, he went to Judge Thatcher's door and tried to scare him into giving the money, and when that didn't work, he swore he would sue him.
es: The next day he was drunk and went to see Judge Thatcher, to bother him trying to get him to give him the money, but he didn't succeed, and then he swore he was going to make the law force him.

en: The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge that had just come, and he didn’t know the old man; so he said courts mustn’t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said he’d druther not take a child away from its father.
vi: The village chief and the widow went to court to get me out of my father's hands and to have the court assign one of them as my guardian. But there was a new judge who had just arrived, who didn't know what kind of person my father was, and said that the court had no right to interfere in separating families, but rather should reunite them, and certainly couldn't force a child to be away from their father.
tr: The judge and the widow lady applied to the court to rescue me from him and to appoint one of them as my legal guardian; but at that time a new judge had been appointed and he did not know my father: Therefore, he said that it was not right for the courts to intervene and separate families unless absolutely necessary. He did not want to deprive a child of his father.
es: The judge and the widow went to court to have the custody taken away and for one of them to become my guardian, but a new judge had arrived and he didn't know my old one, so he said that the courts should not intervene to separate families if they could avoid it; he said he preferred not to separate a child from his father.

en: So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to quit on the business.
vi: So, the village chief Thatcher and the widow had to give up.
tr: Judge Thatcher and the widow lady had to reluctantly give up on this matter.
es: So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to give up the matter.

en: That pleased the old man till he couldn’t rest.
vi: That made my father so delighted that he couldn't sit still.
tr: Our old man couldn't stay still from excitement.
es: The old man was happier than a clam.

en: He said he’d cowhide me till I was black and blue if I didn’t raise some money for him.
vi: He said he would beat me black and blue if I didn't give him the money.
tr: He said that if I didn't give him money, he would beat me until I was bruised all over.
es: He said he was going to keep beating me until I was covered in bruises if I didn't get him some money.

en: I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and pap took it and got drunk, and went a-blowing around and cussing and whooping and carrying on; and he kept it up all over town, with a tin pan, till most midnight; then they jailed him, and next day they had him before court, and jailed him again for a week.
vi: I borrowed three dollars from old Judge Thatcher and gave it to him, and he went off to get drunk; then he wandered around town, talking nonsense and causing trouble everywhere; carrying an iron pot and roaming until midnight. Then they arrested him and put him in jail for a week.
tr: I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher. My father took the money and immediately started drinking heavily, then began wandering around town, shouting and cursing. He grabbed a pan and clanged it around almost until midnight. They locked him up; the next day he went to court and got a week's sentence.
es: I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and father took them, got drunk, and caused a ruckus everywhere with his swearing, shouting, and scandals, and he kept at it throughout the town, banging on a pan until almost midnight; then they jailed him and the next day took him to court and put him back in jail for a week.

en: But he said he was satisfied; said he was boss of his son, and he’d make it warm for him.
vi: But he said that it was all worth it; he was very pleased because he had asserted his authority over me.
tr: But he was very pleased with himself; he was saying that he could now control his son and that he would make his life miserable from now on.
es: But he said he was happy, that he was the one in charge of his son, and that he would settle the score with me.

en: When he got out the new judge said he was a-going to make a man of him.
vi: When he got out of prison, the new judge who had just been transferred said he would teach my father to become a proper person.
tr: After getting out of prison, the new judge said he would straighten him out.
es: When he left, the new judge said he was going to turn him into another man.

en: So he took him to his own house, and dressed him up clean and nice, and had him to breakfast and dinner and supper with the family, and was just old pie to him, so to speak.
vi: The judge took my father to his private home, dressed him in clean, beautiful clothes. Morning, noon, and evening, he let my father eat with his family, treating him very kindly. Something like that.
tr: He took my father into his own home, dressed him up in fine clothes, and, as the saying goes, treated him like an old friend, giving him breakfast, lunch, and dinner at his family's table.
es: So he took him to his house, gave him good and clean clothes, and invited him to have breakfast, lunch, and dinner with the family, and he behaved like a brother to him, so to speak.

en: And after supper he talked to him about temperance and such things till the old man cried, and said he’d been a fool, and fooled away his life; but now he was a-going to turn over a new leaf and be a man nobody wouldn’t be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him.
vi: After dinner, the judge sat and talked to my father about how to live properly in various ways, to the point that my father cried, saying he had been foolish and had ruined his life. My father promised that from now on he would change his behavior and become a person that no one would be ashamed of anymore. He also hoped that the judge would help him and not despise him.
tr: After dinner, he gave such a speech to make him quit drinking that our old man burst into tears, saying he had been foolish until then and had wasted his life; now he would turn over a new leaf and become a man no one would be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him.
es: And after dinner, he talked to him about temperance and things like that until the old man started to cry and said he had been an idiot and had wasted his life on foolishness, but now he was going to change completely and be a man that no one would be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not despise him.

en: The judge said he could hug him for them words; so he cried, and his wife she cried again; pap said he’d been a man that had always been misunderstood before, and the judge said he believed it.
vi: The judge said that hearing such words from my father was truly heartening. So both the judge and his wife cried too. My father said that he had always been misunderstood. The judge said he also believed that was the case.
tr: When the judge heard these words, he almost wanted to embrace him. He too started crying, and his wife also burst into tears. My father said he had always been misunderstood until that day, and the judge said he believed him.
es: The judge said that made him want to hug him, and even he and his wife started to cry; father said he had been a man whom no one had understood until then, and the judge said he believed it.

en: The old man said that what a man wanted that was down was sympathy, and the judge said it was so; so they cried again.
vi: My father then said that what a person needs deep in their heart is affection. The judge said: exactly. So both sides cried again.
tr: Our old man said all he wanted was to be shown empathy; the judge agreed with him, and they started crying again.
es: The old man said that what a fallen man needed was solidarity, and the judge said that was true; so they started crying again.

en: And when it was bedtime the old man rose up and held out his hand, and says:
vi: When it was time to go to bed, my father stood up, spread his arms, and said:
tr: When it was time to go to bed, our old man stood up, extended his hand to them, and said:
es: And when it was time to go to bed, the old man got up, extended his hand, and said:

en: “Look at it, gentlemen and ladies all; take a-hold of it; shake it.
vi: - Here, ladies and gentlemen, look at me. Please take my hand and let me shake hands with you.
tr: “Take a good look at this hand, gentlemen and ladies.
es: —Look at it, ladies and gentlemen; take it in yours, give them yours.

en: There’s a hand that was the hand of a hog; but it ain’t so no more; it’s the hand of a man that’s started in on a new life, and’ll die before he’ll go back.
vi: This is a hand that used to be like a pig's hoof; but now it is not anymore; this is the hand of a person who has started to step into a new life. If I ever go back to the old ways, I would rather die.
tr: Hold this hand. Squeeze this hand. The owner of this hand used to be a swine, but not anymore; now it's the hand of a man starting a new life, the hand of someone who would rather die than go back.
es: This hand used to be a pig's, but it is no longer; it is the hand of a man who has started a new life and who will die before returning to the old one.

en: You mark them words—don’t forget I said them.
vi: Ladies and gentlemen, please remember these words well, and do not forget that it was I who said them.
tr: Listen carefully to my words… always remember that I said these things.
es: Remember these words: do not forget that I have said them.

en: It’s a clean hand now; shake it—don’t be afeard.”
vi: Now this is a clean hand, so please shake hands without fear.
tr: This is now a clean hand; squeeze this hand… don't be afraid.”
es: Now it is a clean hand; give me yours, do not be afraid.

en: So they shook it, one after the other, all around, and cried.
vi: One by one, people came to shake hands, and then everyone cried.
tr: Thus, crying, he shook hands with each one of them.
es: So everyone shook his hand, one after another, and cried.

en: The judge’s wife she kissed it.
vi: The judge's wife even bent down to kiss that hand.
tr: The judge's wife even took his hand and kissed it.
es: The judge's wife kissed it.

en: Then the old man he signed a pledge—made his mark.
vi: Then my father made a solemn vow.
tr: Then our old man had a contract written up and signed it.
es: Then the old man signed a promise: he made his mark.

en: The judge said it was the holiest time on record, or something like that.
vi: The judge said that it was truly the most sacred moment, or almost so.
tr: The judge said something about it being the most sacred moment up to that day.
es: The judge said it was the most sacred moment he could remember, or something like that.

en: Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him after sun-up.
vi: Then they took my father to a splendid room, which was a private room. At night, when my father was extremely thirsty, he climbed over the gate roof, clung to a column, slid down to the ground, took the coat they had just given him to exchange for a bottle of liquor, then climbed back to the room and drank to his heart's content until dawn, when he crawled out, drunk, crashing into the gate so hard that his left hand got injured in several places. In the morning, when someone found him, he was nearly frozen to death.
tr: They placed our father in a very nice room where no one else stayed. After everyone went to bed, he couldn't stand the thirst, climbed out the window onto the veranda roof, slid down a support beam, and sold his jacket for a bottle of the hardest liquor. Then he climbed back into the room and had a grand old time. In the early morning, unable to see an inch in front of him, he climbed out the window again, rolled off the veranda roof, fell, and broke his left arm in two places. When someone found him after the sun had risen, he was on the verge of freezing to death.
es: Then they made the old man lie down in a very nice room, which was the guest room, and that same night, a while later, he got very thirsty and climbed down the porch roof, down one of the columns, and traded his new jacket for a jug of rat poison whiskey and went back to the room and had a great time, and towards dawn he went out again, drunk as a skunk, and rolled down the porch roof and broke his left arm in two places, and had almost frozen to death when someone found him after the sun came up.

en: And when they come to look at that spare room they had to take soundings before they could navigate it.
vi: When everyone entered that private room, they saw that the furniture was all in disarray.
tr: When they went up to the room where he had been sleeping, they struggled to make sense of the damage he had caused.
es: And when they went in to see what was in that guest room, they had to find a pilot to show them the way.

en: The judge he felt kind of sore.
vi: The chief judge was very sad.
tr: The judge was furious.
es: The judge felt a bit bitter.

en: He said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn’t know no other way.
vi: He said that perhaps only a gunshot could help my father change his ways, as there was no other way.
tr: He said that our old man could only be reformed at gunpoint, that no other way was possible.
es: He said that he figured someone might be able to reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but that he didn't know any other way.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Chapter VI
tr: Chapter Six
es: Chapter 6

en: Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he went for me, too, for not stopping school.
vi: Then, right after that, my father got up again, walked around, went to Mr. Thatcher's house to make him return the money, and then came to me asking why I hadn't quit school yet.
tr: Before long, our father recovered and started wandering around. He filed a lawsuit against Judge Thatcher to get the money, and because I didn't stop going to school, he started chasing after me.
es: WELL, the old man soon recovered and then he got involved with Judge Thatcher in the courts to force him to give him that money, and then with me for not stopping going to school.

en: He catched me a couple of times and thrashed me, but I went to school just the same, and dodged him or outrun him most of the time.
vi: He held onto me for a long time and beat me. But I still kept going to school as usual. All day long, I had to avoid him and run away.
tr: He caught me a few times and beat me terribly, but I continued going to school and mostly either stayed out of his sight or lost him by running faster.
es: He grabbed me a couple of times and thrashed me, but anyway I kept going to school and most of the time I either hid from him or outran him.

en: I didn’t want to go to school much before, but I reckoned I’d go now to spite pap.
vi: Before, I didn't really want to go to school, but now I thought I had to go to school to show my father.
tr: Actually, I didn't really want to go to school before, but I guess I started going just to spite my father.
es: Before, I didn't have much desire to go to school. But now I thought I would go just to spite my father.

en: That law trial was a slow business—appeared like they warn’t ever going to get started on it; so every now and then I’d borrow two or three dollars off of the judge for him, to keep from getting a cowhiding.
vi: The legal proceedings were so slow. It seemed like they hadn't even started yet. Occasionally, I had to borrow a few dollars from Mr. Thatcher to give to my father to avoid being beaten.
tr: The court was progressing quite slowly, and as far as I could tell, it hadn't even started yet. So, to avoid getting beaten by my father, I occasionally borrowed two or three dollars from the judge for him.
es: The lawsuit was going very slowly: it seemed like it was never going to start; so from time to time I borrowed two or three dollars from the judge to give to him and avoid a beating.

en: Every time he got money he got drunk; and every time he got drunk he raised Cain around town; and every time he raised Cain he got jailed.
vi: Every time he had money, he would get drunk, and every time he got drunk, he would cause trouble in town, and every time he caused trouble, he would end up in jail.
tr: As soon as he got his hands on some money, he would drink like a fish, and every time he drank, he would cause a commotion in the town. Naturally, they would throw him in jail every time.
es: Every time he had money he got drunk, and every time he got drunk he caused a commotion in town, and every time he caused a commotion they put him in jail.

en: He was just suited—this kind of thing was right in his line.
vi: It became a habit, a routine.
tr: He was living a life that suited him perfectly; this behavior was just his style.
es: And he was so happy: that kind of life was what he liked.

en: He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble for him.
vi: My father kept hanging around the widow, and the widow said if he didn't go find food somewhere else, she would make trouble for him.
tr: He started hanging around the widow a lot. Finally, the widow told him that if he showed up again, he would be in big trouble.
es: He started spending too much time hanging around the widow's house, so she finally told him that if he didn't stop hanging around there, he was going to get into some trouble.

en: Well, wasn’t he mad?
vi: Well, I don't know if he's crazy or not; he even said he would show everyone who has the right to know who has authority over Huck Finn.
tr: Upon hearing this, he went completely mad.
es: Man, did he get mad.

en: He said he would show who was Huck Finn’s boss.
vi: Well, I don't know if he's crazy or not; he even said he would show everyone who has the right to know who has authority over Huck Finn.
tr: He said he would show him who Huck Finn's boss was.
es: He said he was going to show who was in charge of Huck Finn.

en: So he watched out for me one day in the spring, and catched me, and took me up the river about three mile in a skiff, and crossed over to the Illinois shore where it was woody and there warn’t no houses but an old log hut in a place where the timber was so thick you couldn’t find it if you didn’t know where it was.
vi: Then one spring day, he somehow caught me, took me down to a boat, and went upriver about three miles; then rowed up to the Illinois shore, in a place with dense trees, where there wasn't a single house except an old cabin hidden by thick foliage, and anyone who didn't know the place wouldn't be able to find it.
tr: One day in spring, he set a trap by the creek and caught me, put me in a boat, and took me about three miles up the river. From there, he took me across to the Illinois side of the river. This side was forested and had nothing but an old wooden cabin. The trees were so dense that it was impossible to find the cabin without knowing its exact location.
es: So one day he waited for me at the spring, grabbed me, and took me three miles upriver in a boat and crossed over to the Illinois side, where there were forests and no houses except for an old log cabin in a place with so many trees that you couldn't find it unless you already knew the way.

en: He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off.
vi: Day and night, he kept me close by his side, I had no way to escape to go to school.
tr: Since he never let me out of his sight, I never had a chance to escape even once.
es: He always took me with him and I never had the chance to escape.

en: We lived in that old cabin, and he always locked the door and put the key under his head nights.
vi: So the two of them lived in that hut. My father locked the door all day; at night he kept the key at the head of his bed.
tr: We were living in that old cabin, and at night he always locked the door and put the key under his pillow.
es: We lived in that cabin and he always locked the door; at night, he would go to bed with the key under his pillow.

en: He had a gun which he had stole, I reckon, and we fished and hunted, and that was what we lived on.
vi: He had a gun that I guessed he had stolen from somewhere. The two of them went fishing and hunting, living like that day after day.
tr: Somehow, he had managed to steal a rifle. We were getting by through hunting and fishing there.
es: He had a shotgun that I think he had stolen and he would take me fishing and hunting, which is what we lived on.

en: Every little while he locked me in and went down to the store, three miles, to the ferry, and traded fish and game for whisky, and fetched it home and got drunk and had a good time, and licked me.
vi: Occasionally, he would lock the door, trapping me inside, then go down to a store three miles away, at the ferry to trade birds and fish for whiskey, come back drunk at night, and beat me.
tr: From time to time, he would lock me inside, jump into the boat, and go to a store three miles down to trade the fish he caught or the animals he hunted for whiskey. When he came back home, he would drink and get drunk, then beat me.
es: From time to time he would leave me locked up and go to the store, which was three miles away, where the ferry passed, and he would trade fish and game for whiskey, and he would bring it home and get drunk, have a great time, and give me a beating.

en: The widow she found out where I was by-and-by, and she sent a man over to try to get hold of me; but pap drove him off with the gun, and it warn’t long after that till I was used to being where I was, and liked it—all but the cowhide part.
vi: Later, the widow found out where I was, and sent someone to spy and take me back. But my father chased them away with his gun. Living like that for a while, I got used to the place and even came to like it. I liked everything except for the beatings.
tr: The widow eventually found out where I was and sent a man to bring me back, but my father chased him away with a gun. Before long, I got used to the place and even started to like life there, except for the frequent beatings.
es: The widow found out where I was and after a while sent a man to try to take me away, but father chased him off with the shotgun and it didn't take long for me to get used to being where I was, and I liked it... except for the beatings part.

en: It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking and fishing, and no books nor study.
vi: It was a kind of laziness that was quite pleasant. All day long, just relaxing, smoking, fishing, no books and no studying at all.
tr: Spending the whole day smoking tobacco and fishing, lying around without studying at all, both made a person lazy and brought them joy.
es: Everything was very peaceful and it was enjoyable, lying around all day, smoking and fishing, without books or studies.

en: Two months or more run along, and my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didn’t see how I’d ever got to like it so well at the widow’s, where you had to wash, and eat on a plate, and comb up, and go to bed and get up regular, and be forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you all the time.
vi: About two months later, my clothes were dirty and tattered. I didn't think that when I was living with the widow, I ever liked it as much as this. Because there, I had to wash clothes. I had to eat with bowls and plates, comb my hair, go to bed and get up on time, always worry about books and notebooks, and listen to Miss Watson's nagging all day long.
tr: After about two months, all the clothes I had on turned into filthy rags. I no longer knew why I loved the widow's house so much, where I constantly washed, ate from a plate, combed my hair, went to bed and got up on time, constantly dealt with books, and was always scolded by our Miss Watson.
es: Two months or more passed and all my clothes became tattered and dirty, and I didn't understand how I had liked being at the widow's house, where you had to wash yourself and eat from a plate and comb your hair and go to bed and get up at fixed times and spend your life with a boring book while old Miss Watson was always nagging at you.

en: I didn’t want to go back no more.
vi: I didn't feel like going back to that place anymore.
tr: I didn't want to go back.
es: I no longer wanted to go back.

en: I had stopped cussing, because the widow didn’t like it; but now I took to it again because pap hadn’t no objections.
vi: Before, I had stopped using bad language because the widow didn't like it. But now, I started again because my father didn't forbid it at all.
tr: I had stopped swearing because the widow didn't like it, but I had started again since my father didn't object.
es: I had stopped cursing because the widow didn't like it, but now I started cursing again because father didn't see anything wrong with it.

en: It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.
vi: Living in the forest was truly enjoyable, everywhere was just as delightful.
tr: To be honest, I was having quite a good time in the forest.
es: All things considered, I had a pretty good time there in the forest.

en: But by-and-by pap got too handy with his hick’ry, and I couldn’t stand it.
vi: But gradually, when my father became too familiar with this forest, I began to feel that I couldn't stand it anymore.
tr: But after a while, my father increased the beatings so much that I couldn't bear it anymore.
es: But little by little, father started to get too fond of beating me, and I couldn't take it anymore.

en: I was all over welts.
vi: I kept getting beaten all the time.
tr: Every part of my body was covered in bruises and wounds.
es: I was covered in bruises.

en: He got to going away so much, too, and locking me in.
vi: He often went far away and locked me in the house.
tr: Moreover, he frequently left, locking me inside.
es: He also started spending a lot of time away, and he would leave me locked up.

en: Once he locked me in and was gone three days.
vi: Once, he locked the door and kept me inside for three whole days.
tr: Once, he locked the door and didn't come back for three days.
es: Once he locked me up and disappeared for three whole days.

en: It was dreadful lonesome.
vi: I felt terribly lonely.
tr: I felt terribly lonely.
es: I felt horribly alone.

en: I judged he had got drownded, and I wasn’t ever going to get out any more.
vi: I thought that if he drowned somewhere, I would be stuck here, unable to get out.
tr: I thought he had drowned somewhere and that I would never be able to get out.
es: I thought he had drowned and that I would never get out of there again.

en: I was scared.
vi: I was so scared and thought to myself that I definitely had to find a way to escape.
tr: I was very scared.
es: I was scared.

en: I made up my mind I would fix up some way to leave there.
vi: I was so scared and thought to myself that I definitely had to find a way to escape.
tr: I decided to find a way to escape from there.
es: I decided to find a way to leave.

en: I had tried to get out of that cabin many a time, but I couldn’t find no way.
vi: I had tried several times but failed.
tr: Previously, I had tried very hard to get out of the cabin but couldn't find a way.
es: I had tried to leave that cabin many times, but I couldn't find a way.

en: There warn’t a window to it big enough for a dog to get through.
vi: There wasn't a single window big enough for a dog to squeeze through.
tr: The windows were so small that even a dog couldn't fit through.
es: There wasn't a window big enough for even a dog to get through.

en: I couldn’t get up the chimbly; it was too narrow.
vi: The chimney was also too narrow to crawl through.
tr: I tried the chimney, but it was too narrow as well.
es: I couldn't go out through the chimney because it was too narrow.

en: The door was thick, solid oak slabs.
vi: The door was thick, made entirely of very sturdy ebony planks.
tr: The door was made of thick oak planks.
es: The door was thick, made of solid oak planks.

en: Pap was pretty careful not to leave a knife or anything in the cabin when he was away; I reckon I had hunted the place over as much as a hundred times; well, I was most all the time at it, because it was about the only way to put in the time.
vi: My father was careful not to leave a knife or any other object in the house whenever he went away. I figured I had searched the house hundreds of times, always thinking of ways to escape, and spent all my time on that, but it was still to no avail.
tr: My father was careful not to leave any knives or such in the house when he was outside. I searched every corner of the cabin maybe a hundred times. In fact, I had no other job than to explore the surroundings, because it was the only way to pass the time.
es: Father was very careful and never left a knife or anything in the cabin when he left; I suppose I had searched around there at least a hundred times; well, the truth was that I spent all my time looking, because it was the only way to keep myself entertained.

en: But this time I found something at last; I found an old rusty wood-saw without any handle; it was laid in between a rafter and the clapboards of the roof.
vi: But this time, I found something. I found an old, rusty saw blade without a handle, wedged under the roof crevice.
tr: But this time, I finally managed to find something. It was a rusty, handleless saw wedged between the roof beam and the ceiling planks.
es: But once, I finally found something; I found an old rusty saw without a handle; it was stuck between a beam and the tiles above.

en: I greased it up and went to work.
vi: I cleaned it and started working.
tr: I oiled the saw and started working.
es: I cleaned it and got to work.

en: There was an old horse-blanket nailed against the logs at the far end of the cabin behind the table, to keep the wind from blowing through the chinks and putting the candle out.
vi: There was a piece of felt used to pad the saddle, nailed to the crumbling part of the wall in the corner of the house, right behind the table, to block the wind from blowing through the gaps and extinguishing the lamp.
tr: There was an old horse blanket nailed to the wood behind the table at the back of the cabin to prevent the wind from blowing out the candle through the cracks in the wall.
es: There was a horse blanket nailed to the logs at one end of the cabin, behind the table, so the wind wouldn't come through the cracks and blow out the candle.

en: I got under the table and raised the blanket, and went to work to saw a section of the big bottom log out—big enough to let me through.
vi: I crawled under the table, lifted the piece of felt, and sawed a hole just big enough for me to squeeze through.
tr: I crawled under the table, lifted the edge of the blanket, and started working to cut the lowest log to create a hole big enough for me to pass through.
es: I got under the table, lifted the blanket, and started sawing a section of the big log below, big enough for me to fit through.

en: Well, it was a good long job, but I was getting towards the end of it when I heard pap’s gun in the woods.
vi: It was quite a time-consuming task, but I tried my best to see it through. In the midst of it, I heard my father's gunshot in the forest.
tr: This took quite a long time, but I was about to finish when I heard my father's gunshot in the forest.
es: Well, it took me a long time but I was almost finished when I heard father's shotgun in the forest.

en: I got rid of the signs of my work, and dropped the blanket and hid my saw, and pretty soon pap come in.
vi: I erased all traces, let the felt fall back down, and hid the saw. Just as I finished, my father stepped in.
tr: I immediately cleaned up the sawdust around, hung the blanket back in place, and hid my saw. Soon after, my father appeared at the door.
es: I hid the traces of my work, let the blanket and the saw fall, and father arrived immediately.

en: Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self.
vi: He didn't seem very happy at that moment.
tr: His mood wasn't very good – in other words, it was as usual.
es: Father was not in a good mood, which is to say, he was as usual.

en: He said he was down town, and everything was going wrong.
vi: Besides, it had always been like that. He said he had just returned from the province, and the work was a complete mess.
tr: He said he went down to the town and everything was going badly.
es: He said he had gone to the town center and that everything was going badly for him.

en: His lawyer said he reckoned he would win his lawsuit and get the money if they ever got started on the trial; but then there was ways to put it off a long time, and Judge Thatcher knowed how to do it.
vi: The lawyer told my father that he would win the lawsuit and get money if they brought the matter to trial. But then they found ways to prolong the matter, and old Judge Thatcher was very skilled at this sort of thing.
tr: His lawyer told him that if the trials could start, he would win the case and get the money, but there were ways to delay it and Judge Thatcher knew all of them very well.
es: His lawyer had told him that he estimated he would win the lawsuit and get the money if the trial ever started, but that there were always ways to keep postponing it, and Judge Thatcher knew all of them.

en: And he said people allowed there’d be another trial to get me away from him and give me to the widow for my guardian, and they guessed it would win this time.
vi: Then he said that people outside the province were hoping for another trial to get me away from my father and bring me back to the widow so she could take care of me, and they believed that this time they would definitely succeed.
tr: Also, another case had been filed to take me from my father and appoint the widow as my legal guardian to place me in her care, and it seemed like they were going to win this time.
es: He said that according to people, there was going to be another trial to separate me from him and make the widow my guardian, and they estimated that this time she would win.

en: This shook me up considerable, because I didn’t want to go back to the widow’s any more and be so cramped up and sivilized, as they called it.
vi: That made me very confused, because I didn't want to go back to the widow to be bound and civilized as I used to say.
tr: I felt uneasy when I heard this because I no longer wanted to go to the widow's house, be restricted, and "become a man."
es: That made me very nervous, because I no longer wanted to go back to the widow’s house and to so much discipline and civilization, as they called it.

en: Then the old man got to cussing, and cussed everything and everybody he could think of, and then cussed them all over again to make sure he hadn’t skipped any, and after that he polished off with a kind of a general cuss all round, including a considerable parcel of people which he didn’t know the names of, and so called them what’s-his-name when he got to them, and went right along with his cussing.
vi: After that, my father started cursing, cursing everything and everyone. He cursed anyone he thought of. He cursed and cursed to show that he wouldn't spare anyone, and after he had cursed everyone, he made a summary curse, including a lot of people whose names he didn't even know. That meant those people whom he had to refer to as "that guy... what's his name" whenever he cursed them. After getting tired of cursing, he started cursing from the beginning again.
tr: Our old man started cursing, he cursed everything and everyone that came to his mind, then to make sure he didn't miss anyone, he cursed them all again, and finally, he gave a thorough cursing to everything in general as a final touch. When it came to some of the last things he cursed, he didn't even know their names, so he would say "whatever its name is" and then continue.
es: Then the old man started cursing everything and everyone he could think of, and then cursed them again to make sure he hadn't forgotten anyone, and ended with a sort of general curse against everyone, even a bunch of people whose names he didn’t know, so when he got to them he would say whatever their name is, and kept on cursing.

en: He said he would like to see the widow get me.
vi: He said he would see how the widow planned to take me back.
tr: If that man tries to take me, he said he would make him regret it.
es: He said he would like to see how the widow would take me away.

en: He said he would watch out, and if they tried to come any such game on him he knowed of a place six or seven mile off to stow me in, where they might hunt till they dropped and they couldn’t find me.
vi: He would guard me carefully, and if they tried to trick him, there was a place six or seven miles from here where he would hide me, and they could search all they wanted, but they would never find me.
tr: He would constantly watch them, and if they tried to play tricks on him, he knew another place six or seven miles away to hide me. Even if they searched there until they died of exhaustion, they wouldn't be able to find me.
es: He said he was going to be watchful and that if they tried to pull that trick on him, he knew a place six or seven miles away where he could hide me, and where they could search until they dropped dead without finding me.

en: That made me pretty uneasy again, but only for a minute; I reckoned I wouldn’t stay on hand till he got that chance.
vi: That made me uneasy. But only for a moment. Because I had already decided that I wouldn't be here by the time he did that.
tr: When I heard this, I got worried again, but only for a minute; right after, I made my decision, I certainly wasn't going to sit and wait for him to do it.
es: That made me nervous again, but only for a minute; I figured that by then I wouldn't be around there anymore.

en: The old man made me go to the skiff and fetch the things he had got.
vi: He ordered me to go out to the boat to fetch the letters he had just brought back.
tr: My father sent me to the boat to carry the materials he brought.
es: The old man made me go to the boat to fetch what he had brought.

en: There was a fifty-pound sack of corn meal, and a side of bacon, ammunition, and a four-gallon jug of whisky, and an old book and two newspapers for wadding, besides some tow.
vi: There was a bag of flour weighing about more than twenty pounds, a piece of lard, bullets, and four large bottles of whiskey, along with an old book and two newspapers for cleaning, and a few other miscellaneous items.
tr: On the boat, there was a twenty-five-kilogram sack of corn, pork bacon, ammunition, a sixteen-liter barrel of whiskey, an old book to make tinder, two newspapers, and some rope.
es: There was a fifty-pound sack of corn oats and a quarter of streaky bacon, ammunition, a four-gallon jug of whiskey, an old book and two newspapers to fill gaps, as well as some tow.

en: I toted up a load, and went back and set down on the bow of the skiff to rest.
vi: I carried everything, stepped out to the bow of the boat, and then sat down to rest.
tr: I carried some of it and took it away, then went back and lay down at the front of the boat to rest.
es: I carried a load and then went back to sit at the bow of the boat to rest.

en: I thought it all over, and I reckoned I would walk off with the gun and some lines, and take to the woods when I run away.
vi: I kept thinking to myself, planning that when I escaped, I would take the gun and some fishing rods and run into the forest.
tr: Before leaving the cabin, I would take the rifle and the fishing gear and escape through the forest.
es: I thought it all over again and decided to escape with the shotgun and some fishing lines, and when I escaped I would go to the woods.

en: I guessed I wouldn’t stay in one place, but just tramp right across the country, mostly night times, and hunt and fish to keep alive, and so get so far away that the old man nor the widow couldn’t ever find me any more.
vi: I planned not to stay in one place but to travel all over the country, moving at night, hunting and fishing to survive. In this way, I would go so far that my father and the widow would never be able to find me again.
tr: I wouldn't stay in one place, but would wander from place to place. I would generally travel at night, hunt and fish to survive, and get so far away that neither my father nor the widow would ever find me.
es: I thought I wouldn't stay in one fixed place, but rather go from one side of the country to the other, mostly at night, hunting and fishing for food, until I got so far that neither the old man nor the widow could ever find me.

en: I judged I would saw out and leave that night if pap got drunk enough, and I reckoned he would.
vi: I thought I would saw through the piece of wood and escape that very night if my father was already drunk, and I guessed he would be.
tr: If my father drank enough and passed out, which he most likely would, I thought I could cut the rest of the plank and get out at night.
es: I figured I could finish sawing and leave that night if father got drunk enough, as I supposed he would.

en: I got so full of it I didn’t notice how long I was staying till the old man hollered and asked me whether I was asleep or drownded.
vi: I thought so much about it that I didn't know how long I had been sitting there. Until my father yelled, asking if I was asleep or had drowned there.
tr: I was so lost in these thoughts that I forgot how time passed. Finally, I heard him calling and asking if I had fallen asleep or drowned.
es: I got so excited that I didn't realize how much time had passed until the old man started shouting and asked if I had fallen asleep or drowned.

en: I got the things all up to the cabin, and then it was about dark.
vi: I carried everything into the tent. By then, it was almost dark.
tr: By the time I had carried everything inside, it was almost dark.
es: I took all the things to the cabin and then it got dark.

en: While I was cooking supper the old man took a swig or two and got sort of warmed up, and went to ripping again.
vi: While I was preparing dinner, he downed another glass of wine, warmed up, and then went to cause trouble again.
tr: While I was cooking dinner, our old man had a few drinks and then started cursing again.
es: While I was cooking dinner, the old man had a couple of drinks to warm up and started making a fuss again.

en: He had been drunk over in town, and laid in the gutter all night, and he was a sight to look at.
vi: Previously, in the province, he was already dead drunk, sleeping on the roadside every night, looking very miserable, people might have thought he was Adam.
tr: He had gotten drunk in town and ended up lying in a ditch, quite a sight to see indeed.
es: He had already gotten drunk in town and spent the night in the ditch, and he was truly a sight to see.

en: A body would a thought he was Adam—he was just all mud.
vi: Covered in mud, when the alcohol kicked in, he often sought out the authorities.
tr: He was so covered in mud that one could have mistaken him for Adam himself.
es: Anyone would think he was Adam: you couldn't see anything of him but mud.

en: Whenever his liquor begun to work he most always went for the govment, this time he says:
vi: This time he spoke.
tr: Whenever he got drunk, he would always curse the government. He started again:
es: When he was quite drunk, he almost always picked on the government. That time he goes and says:

en: “Call this a govment!
vi: - Huh! And you call that a government?
tr: “Such a government should not exist!
es: —And they call this a government!

en: why, just look at it and see what it’s like.
vi: Let's see what it has done.
tr: Just standing still and looking is enough to see what it is.
es: Just look around to see what it really is.

en: Here’s the law a-standing ready to take a man’s son away from him—a man’s own son, which he has had all the trouble and all the anxiety and all the expense of raising.
vi: This is the law.
tr: This so-called law is ready to take a man's son away from him – his own son, whom he has endured countless troubles and hardships to raise.
es: They make a law to take a man's son away from him: his own son, with all the work, worries, and expenses it took to raise him.

en: Yes, just as that man has got that son raised at last, and ready to go to work and begin to do suthin’ for him and give him a rest, the law up and goes for him.
vi: The law is ready to take people away, huh? People have to work hard and worry so much to raise their stepchildren. Yes, that's right, people raise their children to grow up, and when they are about to start working to earn something to support their parents, this is what happens. The law is made to help people.
tr: When the poor man finally thinks he has raised his child, and expects to find a job and take care of him, and perhaps find some peace for himself, the laws suddenly stand against him.
es: Yes, and just when that man has finally raised his son to the age where he can start working and doing something for him so he can rest, the law comes and takes him away.

en: And they call that govment!
vi: And you call that a government!
tr: Is this what a government should be like!
es: And they call that a government!

en: That ain’t all, nuther.
vi: It's not a government at all.
tr: No, it shouldn't be like this.
es: And that's not all.

en: The law backs that old Judge Thatcher up and helps him to keep me out o’ my property.
vi: The law supports that old Thatcher and helps him take all my property?
tr: The law supports our Judge Thatcher and helps him take my property away from me.
es: The law sides with that old Judge Thatcher and helps him take away my property.

en: Here’s what the law does:
vi: Here, this is what the law does; the law takes six thousand dollars from people and forces them into an old trap in a house like this, making them wander around in clothes not even fit for pigs.
tr: This is what the laws are good for.
es: Look at what the law does: the law grabs a man who has six thousand dollars or more and locks him up in an old cabin like this and lets him wear clothes that aren't even fit for a pig.

en: The law takes a man worth six thousand dollars and up’ards, and jams him into an old trap of a cabin like this, and lets him go round in clothes that ain’t fitten for a hog.
vi: Here, this is what the law does; the law takes six thousand dollars from people and forces them into an old trap in a house like this, making them wander around in clothes not even fit for pigs.
tr: Their so-called law strips a man worth six thousand dollars to the bone and stuffs him into such old shacks, making him wear clothes that even pigs wouldn't wear.
es: Look at what the law does: the law grabs a man who has six thousand dollars or more and locks him up in an old cabin like this and lets him wear clothes that aren't even fit for a pig.

en: They call that govment!
vi: And you call that a government.
tr: Is this a government!
es: And they call that a government!

en: A man can’t get his rights in a govment like this.
vi: With a government like this, people have no rights at all.
tr: Who can seek their rights in this government?
es: With a government like that, there's no way a man can have rights.

en: Sometimes I’ve a mighty notion to just leave the country for good and all.
vi: Sometimes I think it's better to just leave this place for good.
tr: Sometimes I think of leaving this country and never coming back.
es: Sometimes I'm tempted to leave the country for good.

en: Yes, and I told ’em so; I told old Thatcher so to his face.
vi: Yes, I told everyone that, I said it straight to Thatcher's face.
tr: I told them this too. I even told it to our Thatcher's face.
es: Yes, and I've said it; I've said it to old Thatcher's face.

en: Lots of ’em heard me, and can tell what I said.
vi: Many people heard me say that and can confirm that I said it.
tr: Several men heard me, they all witnessed it.
es: Lots of people heard me, and they can say I said it.

en: Says I, for two cents I’d leave the blamed country and never come a-near it agin.
vi: I said just give me two cents and I would leave this cursed place immediately and never come back.
tr: I said I would even pay money to leave this country and never come back.
es: I go and say: "For two cents I'd leave this damned country and never come back even if they paid me."

en: Them’s the very words.
vi: And everyone says the same thing.
tr: That's exactly what I said.
es: That's exactly what I said; "Look at this hat—if you can even call it a hat—it lifts up at the top and falls down until it slips under my chin and it's not even a hat anymore, but more like they stuck my head in a chimney pipe.

en: I says look at my hat—if you call it a hat—but the lid raises up and the rest of it goes down till it’s below my chin, and then it ain’t rightly a hat at all, but more like my head was shoved up through a jint o’ stove-pipe.
vi: Here, look at my hat - if you can even call it a hat, the top pops off, and the rest falls down to my chin. How can you call that a hat anymore? Putting my head in the hat is like sticking it into a chimney. Here, look, this is how my hat fits.
tr: Look at this hat of mine, I said… can this even be called a hat… its top opens up and it comes down to my chin. It's no longer a hat, it's as if my head is stuck in a stove pipe.
es: That's exactly what I said; "Look at this hat—if you can even call it a hat—it lifts up at the top and falls down until it slips under my chin and it's not even a hat anymore, but more like they stuck my head in a chimney pipe.

en: Look at it, says I—such a hat for me to wear—one of the wealthiest men in this town if I could git my rights.
vi: If I had all my rights, I would be one of the richest people in the province...
tr: Look here, I said, this is the kind of hat you make me wear, one of the richest men in town. Oh, if only I could get my rights.
es: Look at it," I go and say: "What a hat for a guy like me, one of the richest men in this town if my rights were recognized."

en: “Oh, yes, this is a wonderful govment, wonderful.
vi: Ah, yes, yes, this government is really very good.
tr: Yeah, what a fine government, what a fine one.
es: »Ah, yes, this government is wonderful, wonderful and you just have to see it.

en: Why, looky here.
vi: There, try to see.
tr: Listen to me carefully.
es: »Ah, yes, this government is wonderful, wonderful and you just have to see it.

en: There was a free nigger there from Ohio—a mulatter, most as white as a white man.
vi: There was a free black man from Ohio who came, he was almost white, nearly like a white person.
tr: There is a free black man from Ohio there, but he is a mulatto, almost as white as the whites.
es: I saw a free black man from Ohio: a mulatto, almost as white as a white man.

en: He had the whitest shirt on you ever see, too, and the shiniest hat; and there ain’t a man in that town that’s got as fine clothes as what he had; and he had a gold watch and chain, and a silver-headed cane—the awfulest old gray-headed nabob in the State.
vi: He wore the whitest shirt anyone had ever seen, and the most stylish hat. No one in this province had clothes better than his; then he had a gold watch, with a gold chain, and a silver-tipped cane, truly a millionaire, with gray hair, the most formidable in this land.
tr: He walks around in the whitest shirt you can see; he wears the finest hat. There is no one in town who dresses as well as he does. He has a gold pocket watch and a cane with a silver knob. The most pompous, the oldest, the richest dandy in the state.
es: He wore the whitest shirt you've ever seen in your life and the shiniest hat, and in the whole town, there's no one who has clothes as good as his, and he carried a gold watch with its chain and a cane with a silver handle: he was the most impressive white-haired nabob in the state.

en: And what do you think?
vi: What do you think?
tr: And do you know what they say?
es: And, what do you think?»

en: They said he was a p’fessor in a college, and could talk all kinds of languages, and knowed everything.
vi: People say he is a university professor, able to speak various languages, knowledgeable about everything.
tr: They say he is a professor at a university, speaks every language, and knows everything.
es: They said he was a university professor, and that he spoke lots of languages and knew everything.

en: And that ain’t the wust.
vi: And that’s not even the worst of it.
tr: As if all this were not enough...
es: And that's not the worst part.

en: They said he could vote when he was at home.
vi: They also say that he can vote just by sitting at home.
tr: He can even vote in the state he lives in.
es: They said that in his state he could vote.

en: Well, that let me out.
vi: Ah, who can tolerate that?
tr: What insolence!
es: That was already too much.

en: Thinks I, what is the country a-coming to?
vi: I wonder what will become of this country?
tr: I said, what will become of this country...
es: I say: «What's happening with this country?

en: It was ’lection day, and I was just about to go and vote myself if I warn’t too drunk to get there; but when they told me there was a State in this country where they’d let that nigger vote, I drawed out.
vi: On election day, I was about to go vote - if I wasn’t drunk and could go - then I suddenly heard that in this country there’s a state where they don’t let black people vote, so I immediately withdrew my vote.
tr: On election day, I was just about to go to the ballot box, I mean, I would have gone if I hadn't been too drunk to walk, when they told me there is a state in this country where blacks can vote.
es: If it were election day and I thought about going to vote if I wasn't too drunk to get there, when they told me that there was a state in this country where they let that black man vote, I wouldn't go».

en: I says I’ll never vote agin.
vi: I said that I would never bother to vote, let the country say what it wants about me.
tr: I turned back right there. I said I would never vote again.
es: And I go and say: «I'm not going to vote again».

en: Them’s the very words I said; they all heard me; and the country may rot for all me—I’ll never vote agin as long as I live.
vi: As long as I live, I will definitely not vote.
tr: I said exactly that, and they all heard it anyway. Let the country burn for all I care... I will never vote again in my life.
es: That's what I said, word for word; everyone heard me, and as far as I'm concerned, the country can rot: I'm not going to vote again in my life.

en: And to see the cool way of that nigger—why, he wouldn’t a give me the road if I hadn’t shoved him out o’ the way.
vi: Just look at the indifferent attitude of that black man, he wouldn’t be ready to give up his seat for me unless I pushed him aside.
tr: You should have seen the airs of that black guy… if I hadn't pushed him aside and passed, he wouldn't have even given way.
es: And the airs that black man gave himself: but if he didn't get out of the way, I would have given him a shove.

en: I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know.
vi: I told everyone why not auction off that black man? That’s all I needed to know.
tr: Why don't they put this black guy up for auction and sell him… tell me why, I said.
es: And I go and tell people: «Why don't they auction off this black man and sell him? I'd like to know».

en: And what do you reckon they said?
vi: Do you know what they answered me?
tr: Do you know what they answered?
es: And, do you know what they said?

en: Why, they said he couldn’t be sold till he’d been in the State six months, and he hadn’t been there that long yet.
vi: What else, they said that he hasn’t been in this land for six months yet so he can’t be auctioned off.
tr: Apparently, he can't be sold until he has been in the state for six months, and it hasn't been six months yet, sir.
es: Well, they said he couldn't be sold until he had been in the state for six months and he hadn't been there that long yet.

en: There, now—that’s a specimen.
vi: What else, they said that he hasn’t been in this land for six months yet so he can’t be auctioned off.
tr: Here's another example for you.
es: But anyway, just so you see.

en: They call that a govment that can’t sell a free nigger till he’s been in the State six months.
vi: What else, they said that he hasn’t been in this land for six months yet so he can’t be auctioned off.
tr: They call a government that can't sell a free black guy before he's been in the state for six months a government.
es: And they call that a government when you can't sell a free black man until he's been in the state for six months.

en: Here’s a govment that calls itself a govment, and lets on to be a govment, and thinks it is a govment, and yet’s got to set stock-still for six whole months before it can take a hold of a prowling, thieving, infernal, white-shirted free nigger, and—”
vi: Ah, so this is a government that considers itself a government, and insists that it is a government, thinking that’s what makes a government; yet it stays silent for six months before daring to touch a black man who robs, horrendous; wearing a white shirt and being free, and then...
tr: He himself calls it my government, continues his work, and thinks he is the government; the vagabond, thief, disgusting, waits for six months without lifting a finger to catch and sell a free black man in a white shirt...”
es: Well, what a government that says it's a government and acts like it's a government and believes it's a government and then has to stay calm for a whole six months before laying hands on a free black man who's lurking around, stealing, infernal, with his white shirts, and... »

en: Pap was agoing on so he never noticed where his old limber legs was taking him to, so he went head over heels over the tub of salt pork and barked both shins, and the rest of his speech was all the hottest kind of language—mostly hove at the nigger and the govment, though he give the tub some, too, all along, here and there.
vi: My father was talking while walking around like that, not even noticing that his old but still flexible legs were taking him somewhere. Suddenly, he fell headfirst into a barrel of salted meat, scraping both his shins. So, the end of his speech turned into a very lively language - mostly still talking about the black man and the government - while he angrily kicked the barrel around the house.
tr: My father kept talking non-stop, not paying attention to where his trembling legs were taking him. He tripped over the hog-salting tub and fell headfirst, hitting both of his shins somewhere, and his subsequent speech turned into a dreadful curse – mostly hurling insults at that black man and the government, but the tub also got its share of the swearing.
es: Father was so angry that he didn't realize where his legs were taking him, so he tripped over the barrel of salted pork and skinned his ankles, and the rest of his speech was a series of the most terrible insults, mostly against the black man and the government, although he also directed some at the barrel, interspersed from time to time.

en: He hopped around the cabin considerable, first on one leg and then on the other, holding first one shin and then the other one, and at last he let out with his left foot all of a sudden and fetched the tub a rattling kick.
vi: He hopped on one leg around the room, holding one shin, then let it down and held the other leg, then suddenly kicked the barrel very hard. But unfortunately, one of his shoes had a hole with some toes sticking out.
tr: Inside the cabin, he hopped first on one foot, then on the other, and then he kicked the tub.
es: He was jumping around the cabin like a madman, first on one leg and then on the other, grabbing first one ankle and then the other, and finally he suddenly kicked the barrel with his left foot.

en: But it warn’t good judgment, because that was the boot that had a couple of his toes leaking out of the front end of it; so now he raised a howl that fairly made a body’s hair raise, and down he went in the dirt, and rolled there, and held his toes; and the cussing he done then laid over anything he had ever done previous.
vi: He hit the barrel; he let out a blood-curdling scream; then he rolled on the ground, holding his toes. Now, I don't know when he started cursing me.
tr: But he made a mistake, because the toe of the boot on that foot was torn, and two of his toes were sticking out. He started howling so much that it made my hair stand on end. Then he began rolling around in the dust, clutching his aching toes in pain. Meanwhile, he was cursing even more vehemently than before.
es: But he didn't do it right, because he hit it with the boot through which two of his toes were sticking out, so he started screaming in a way that made one's hair stand on end, and he fell to the ground, rolling around grabbing his toes and uttering worse curses than all the previous ones.

en: He said so his own self afterwards.
vi: Later, he himself said the same thing.
tr: When he finished, he didn't forget to mention that he had outdone himself this time.
es: He himself said later: he had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his good times and claimed that he had surpassed him, but it seems to me that he might have been exaggerating a bit.

en: He had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his best days, and he said it laid over him, too; but I reckon that was sort of piling it on, maybe.
vi: He had heard of Mr. Sowberry Hagan in his glorious days and said that he had influenced him. But I think that was probably just something my father made up.
tr: He had listened to Sowberry Hagan in his golden age, but now he was leaving even him in the dust, though it seemed to me he was exaggerating a bit.
es: He himself said later: he had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his good times and claimed that he had surpassed him, but it seems to me that he might have been exaggerating a bit.

en: After supper pap took the jug, and said he had enough whisky there for two drunks and one delirium tremens.
vi: After finishing dinner, my father grabbed the bottle of liquor again, saying there was enough for two regular drinks and one really drunk session.
tr: After dinner, my father looked at the barrel and said he had enough whiskey to get drunk twice and to completely pass out once.
es: After dinner, father handed him the jug, saying that there was enough whiskey for two drunks and a delirium tremens.

en: That was always his word.
vi: He always said that.
tr: He always said that.
es: It was what he always said.

en: I judged he would be blind drunk in about an hour, and then I would steal the key, or saw myself out, one or t’other.
vi: I had planned that within about an hour he would be so drunk he wouldn't know anything, and then I would either steal the key or saw through the piece of wood to get out; one of the two ways.
tr: I had calculated that he would be dead drunk within about an hour, and after that, I would either steal the key or cut the planks.
es: I thought he would be completely drunk within an hour, and then I would either steal the key or escape, one of the two things.
