en: He drank and drank, and tumbled down on his blankets by-and-by; but luck didn’t run my way.
vi: My father kept drinking steadily and then lay down on the bed a while later. But I really wasn't lucky at all.
tr: He drank and drank, and finally collapsed on the blankets, but my luck had not favored me.
es: He kept drinking and drinking, and after a while, he lay down on top of the blankets; but I had no luck.

en: He didn’t go sound asleep, but was uneasy.
vi: It wasn't that my father was sound asleep, he was just tired.
tr: Instead of falling into a deep sleep, he kept tossing and turning.
es: He didn't fall completely asleep, but woke up from time to time.

en: He groaned and moaned and thrashed around this way and that for a long time.
vi: He mumbled, muttered, turned this way and that for a long time.
tr: For a long time, he continued to make snoring and groaning sounds, turning from side to side.
es: He spent a long time moaning and complaining and tossing and turning.

en: At last I got so sleepy I couldn’t keep my eyes open all I could do, and so before I knowed what I was about I was sound asleep, and the candle burning.
vi: Finally, I waited so long that I got too sleepy to keep my eyes open. So, before I knew what was happening, I had fallen fast asleep while the candle was still burning.
tr: Eventually, I got so sleepy that I couldn't keep my eyelids open. At some point, I must have completely fallen asleep, and it didn't even occur to me to extinguish the candle.
es: Finally, I got so sleepy that I couldn't keep my eyes open, and without realizing it, I fell completely asleep, with the candle still lit.

en: I don’t know how long I was asleep, but all of a sudden there was an awful scream and I was up.
vi: I don't know how long I had been asleep; but suddenly a scream startled me awake.
tr: I don't know how long I slept, but suddenly a terrifying scream woke me up.
es: I don't know how long I had been asleep, but suddenly a horrible scream sounded and I woke up.

en: There was pap looking wild, and skipping around every which way and yelling about snakes.
vi: I saw my father, his face very angry, running around from corner to corner, shouting that there was a snake.
tr: My father was running around like crazy, shouting, "There's a snake! Snake!"
es: It was father, who seemed crazy and was jumping from one place to another, shouting that there were snakes there.

en: He said they was crawling up his legs; and then he would give a jump and scream, and say one had bit him on the cheek—but I couldn’t see no snakes.
vi: He said the snake had crawled up his leg and then suddenly jumped up screaming, saying that one had bitten his cheek.
tr: He said one was climbing up his leg, then he let out another scream and jumped into the air, saying one had bitten his cheek – but I couldn't see any snake around.
es: He said they were crawling up his legs, and then he would jump and scream and say that one had bitten him on the cheek, but I didn't see any snakes.

en: He started and run round and round the cabin, hollering “Take him off!
vi: I didn't see any snake at all, but he kept running around the house, shouting: Catch it!
tr: He was running around the cabin shouting, "Get it off me, get it off me, now it bit my neck!"
es: He started running around the cabin, shouting: "Get it off me!

en: take him off!
vi: Catch it!
tr: He was running around the cabin shouting, "Get it off me, get it off me, now it bit my neck!"
es: Get it off me!

en: he’s biting me on the neck!”
vi: It bit my neck right here!
tr: He was running around the cabin shouting, "Get it off me, get it off me, now it bit my neck!"
es: It's biting my neck!"

en: I never see a man look so wild in the eyes.
vi: Never had I seen anyone with such fierce eyes.
tr: I'd never seen a man's eyes open so wide.
es: I've never seen anyone with such a crazy look.

en: Pretty soon he was all fagged out, and fell down panting; then he rolled over and over wonderful fast, kicking things every which way, and striking and grabbing at the air with his hands, and screaming and saying there was devils a-hold of him.
vi: After a while, he was so exhausted that he collapsed, gasping for breath; then he moved very quickly, his legs hitting all the furniture in the house, his hands flailing in the air, his mouth still screaming, saying that some ghosts had come to take him away.
tr: Soon he became exhausted and collapsed to the ground, gasping for breath. Then he started rolling on the ground, kicking in all directions, slapping and punching at something in the air. He was shouting that demons had taken over him.
es: He quickly got exhausted and fell to the ground panting; then he started spinning around at full speed, kicking everywhere and hitting the air and grabbing it with his hands, shouting and saying that the devils were taking him away.

en: He wore out by-and-by, and laid still a while, moaning.
vi: Gradually, too tired, he lay still for a while, but his mouth still groaned.
tr: But then he got really tired and lay still, moaning for a while.
es: Little by little he began to tire and stayed quiet for a while, moaning.

en: Then he laid stiller, and didn’t make a sound.
vi: Then he lay completely still, with no more sound.
tr: Finally, he became completely motionless, his voice fell silent.
es: Then he stayed still and didn't make a sound.

en: I could hear the owls and the wolves away off in the woods, and it seemed terrible still.
vi: I faintly heard the sound of owls hooting and wolves howling in the distant forest; and at that moment the silence was terrifying.
tr: I could hear owls hooting and wolves howling in the distant parts of the forest, and a terrifying silence filled the cabin.
es: In the distance, in the forest, you could hear the owls and the wolves and everything seemed to be in a terrible silence.

en: He was laying over by the corner.
vi: My father still lay motionless in the corner of the house.
tr: My father had collapsed in a corner.
es: He was lying in a corner.

en: By-and-by he raised up part way and listened, with his head to one side.
vi: A moment later, he sat up, tilted his head to one side to listen, then whispered:
tr: After a while, he got up and started listening intently.
es: After a while, he partially got up to listen, with his head tilted to one side.

en: He says, very low:
vi: A moment later, he sat up, tilted his head to one side to listen, then whispered:
tr: He began to speak in a low voice:
es: And then he says, in a very low voice:

en: “Tramp—tramp—tramp; that’s the dead; tramp—tramp—tramp; they’re coming after me; but I won’t go.
vi: - Clop - clop, clop - clop; the dead are passing through here; clop - clop, clop - clop; they are chasing me, but I am not going anywhere.
tr: “Rap… rap… rap; the dead are rising; rap… rap… rap; it's coming from behind me; but I won't go…
es: —Boom... Boom... Boom...; it's the dead, boom... boom...; they come to get me, but I'm not going.

en: Oh, they’re here!
vi: Oh, oh, they have arrived here already!
tr: Aah, here they come!
es: Ah, there they are!

en: don’t touch me—don’t!
vi: Don't touch me! Don't! Don't!
tr: Don't touch…
es: Don't touch me... no!

en: hands off—they’re cold; let go.
vi: Go away, their hands are so cold!
tr: Move away! Take your hands off… Your hands are so cold; leave me…
es: Get those hands off... they are cold; let go of me.

en: Oh, let a poor devil alone!”
vi: Let me go! Oh! oh! Please spare this wretched man!
tr: Aah, don't bother this poor soul!”
es: Leave this poor devil alone!

en: Then he went down on all fours and crawled off, begging them to let him alone, and he rolled himself up in his blanket and wallowed in under the old pine table, still a-begging; and then he went to crying.
vi: Then he knelt on all fours, crawling and bowing to be forgiven, then curled himself up in a blanket, then when he got close to the old table made from a pine stump; his mouth kept begging, begging until he was tired, then he cried.
tr: He crawled forward, begging them on his knees to leave. Wrapping himself in his blanket, he continued to beg as he crawled under the old pine table and started to cry there.
es: Then he got on all fours and crawled away, asking them to leave him alone, and wrapped himself in the blanket and got under the pine table as best as he could, while he kept begging them, and then he started to cry.

en: I could hear him through the blanket.
vi: Through the blanket, I could hear every single word clearly.
tr: I could hear him sobbing under the blanket.
es: You could hear him from under the blanket.

en: By-and-by he rolled out and jumped up on his feet looking wild, and he see me and went for me.
vi: Then a little later, he threw off the blanket and stood up straight. His face looked even more ferocious, staring intently at me and stepping closer.
tr: After a while, he came out from under the table, sprang to his feet in a frenzy, saw me, and immediately walked towards me.
es: Then he rolled out and jumped to his feet with a crazed look, saw me, and lunged at me.

en: He chased me round and round the place with a clasp-knife, calling me the Angel of Death, and saying he would kill me, and then I couldn’t come for him no more.
vi: He chased me around the house, holding a pocket knife, calling me the Grim Reaper, and saying he would kill me. So I couldn't get close to him.
tr: He was chasing me with a switchblade in his hand; while I was running around the cabin, he was shouting that I was the Angel of Death, that he would kill me, and thus I would never come to take him again.
es: He chased me all over the cabin with a switchblade, calling himself the Angel of Death and saying he was going to kill me, and I wouldn't be able to come back for him anymore.

en: I begged, and told him I was only Huck; but he laughed such a screechy laugh, and roared and cussed, and kept on chasing me up.
vi: I begged, telling him that I was just Huck. But he let out a terrifying laugh, roared curses back, and kept chasing me.
tr: I begged him, told him that I was just poor Huck; but he let out a terrible, shrill laugh, continued to chase me, roaring and cursing.
es: I begged him; I told him I was just Huck, but he laughed with a screeching laugh and didn't stop roaring, cursing, and chasing me.

en: Once when I turned short and dodged under his arm he made a grab and got me by the jacket between my shoulders, and I thought I was gone; but I slid out of the jacket quick as lightning, and saved myself.
vi: I ran, then suddenly turned around and slipped under his arm, somehow he managed to grab the back of my shirt. I thought to myself that I was done for. But as quick as lightning, I slipped out of my shirt and escaped.
tr: Once, when I suddenly turned and tried to slip under his arm, he grabbed me by the collar of my jacket. I thought I was done for, but then I slipped out of the jacket like lightning and saved myself.
es: Once, when I stopped suddenly and was about to dodge under his arm, he grabbed me by the jacket between the shoulders, and I thought that was the end of me, but I quickly slipped out of the jacket like lightning and saved myself.

en: Pretty soon he was all tired out, and dropped down with his back against the door, and said he would rest a minute and then kill me.
vi: After a while, he got so tired that he collapsed, leaning against the door, and said he would rest for a minute before killing me.
tr: Soon after, he became exhausted again, leaned against the door to catch his breath, and said that after resting there for a while, he would kill me.
es: He soon got exhausted again and collapsed backward against the door, saying he was going to rest for a moment before killing me.

en: He put his knife under him, and said he would sleep and get strong, and then he would see who was who.
vi: He tucked the knife into his waistband, saying he would take a nap to regain strength and then show me what he could do.
tr: Then he leaned back completely, hid the knife underneath him, and said he would take a nap to regain his strength, and then show me who was who.
es: He hid the knife where he was sitting and said he was going to sleep to regain his strength, and then we would see who was who.

en: So he dozed off pretty soon.
vi: Then he nodded off to sleep.
tr: He soon fell completely asleep.
es: So he fell asleep very quickly.

en: By-and-by I got the old split-bottom chair and clumb up as easy as I could, not to make any noise, and got down the gun.
vi: A moment later, I slipped under the seat, quietly crawled up, without making a sound, and took down the gun.
tr: I quietly and slowly pulled the old chair with the broken seat as best as I could, climbed on it, and took the rifle down from the wall.
es: Then I took out the old chair that had the broken seat and climbed onto it very calmly, so as not to make any noise, and took down the shotgun.

en: I slipped the ramrod down it to make sure it was loaded, then I laid it across the turnip barrel, pointing towards pap, and set down behind it to wait for him to stir.
vi: I pulled out the magazine to check if it was loaded, then placed the gun on the crate of radishes, aiming it directly at my father. Then I sat there quietly, waiting to see if he would move.
tr: I checked if it was loaded with the ramrod, and upon realizing it was, I pointed the barrel at my father, placed it on the turnip barrel, and sat behind the barrel, waiting for him to move.
es: I inserted the ramrod to make sure it was loaded and then placed it on top of the barrel of turnips, pointing at father, and sat behind it until he moved.

en: And how slow and still the time did drag along.
vi: At that moment, time seemed to pass so slowly and silently.
tr: Time was passing so slowly, and it was so quiet around.
es: And time passed very slowly, always in silence.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: Chapter VII
tr: Chapter Seven
es: Chapter 7

en: “Git up!
vi: - Wake up!
tr: "Get up!
es: —GET UP!

en: What you ’bout?”
vi: What do you think you're doing?
tr: What are you doing here?"
es: What are you doing?

en: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to make out where I was.
vi: I opened my eyes wide and looked around, trying to think where I was.
tr: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to understand where I was.
es: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to see where I was.

en: It was after sun-up, and I had been sound asleep.
vi: At that moment, the sun had risen, and I had just had a deep sleep.
tr: The sun had risen high, and I had fallen asleep.
es: The sun had already risen and I had slept like a log.

en: Pap was standing over me looking sour and sick, too.
vi: My father was standing in front of me, looking sad and tired.
tr: My father was standing over me, looking irritable and quite pale.
es: Father was standing next to me, with a sour face and looking like he felt unwell.

en: He says:
vi: My father asked:
tr: He continued:
es: He goes and says:

en: “What you doin’ with this gun?”
vi: - Why did you bring the gun here?
tr: “What is this rifle doing here?”
es: —What are you doing with that shotgun?

en: I judged he didn’t know nothing about what he had been doing, so I says:
vi: I guess my father didn't know anything about what he had done the night before, so I said:
tr: I realized that he didn't remember what he did at night, so I said:
es: I thought he didn't know anything about what had happened, so I went and told him:

en: “Somebody tried to get in, so I was laying for him.”
vi: - It seems like someone intends to enter the house, so I have to sit here and keep watch.
tr: “Someone tried to get in, so I took it down.”
es: —Someone tried to get in, so I was keeping watch.

en: “Why didn’t you roust me out?”
vi: - Why didn't you call me to wake me up?
tr: “Why didn't you wake me up?”
es: —Why didn't you wake me up?

en: “Well, I tried to, but I couldn’t; I couldn’t budge you.”
vi: - Yes, I called Dad to wake him up but it didn't work. I shook him for a long time but he wouldn't wake up.
tr: “I tried to lift you, but it didn't work, you didn't even budge.”
es: —Well, I tried, but I couldn't; you didn't notice.

en: “Well, all right.
vi: - Fine, stop sitting here and rambling.
tr: “Alright, fine.
es: —Alright.

en: Don’t stand there palavering all day, but out with you and see if there’s a fish on the lines for breakfast.
vi: Go outside and check if there's any fish on the line to bring back for breakfast.
tr: You’re not going to chatter here all day, I suppose. Go outside and check if there are any breakfast fish on the lines.
es: Don't stay there chatting all day, go outside and see if there's any fish on the line for breakfast.

en: I’ll be along in a minute.”
vi: I'll come out in a bit.
tr: I’ll come in a bit.”
es: I'll go in a moment.

en: He unlocked the door, and I cleared out up the river-bank.
vi: My father unlocked the door, and I dashed out to the riverbank.
tr: He opened the door and immediately dashed outside, walking upstream along the river.
es: He opened the door and I went out to the riverbank.

en: I noticed some pieces of limbs and such things floating down, and a sprinkling of bark; so I knowed the river had begun to rise.
vi: Seeing a few floating branches and scattered pieces of bark, I knew the water had started to rise.
tr: Tree branches were floating in the water, and there were also pieces of tree bark. I realized that the river was starting to rise.
es: I saw pieces of branches and other things floating downstream and some tree bark, so I understood that the river had started to rise.

en: I reckoned I would have great times now if I was over at the town.
vi: I thought to myself that if I were in the city right now, I would be playing and having fun.
tr: If I were in town, this would be very beneficial for me.
es: I thought that if I had been in town, I would have had a great time.

en: The June rise used to be always luck for me; because as soon as that rise begins here comes cordwood floating down, and pieces of log rafts—sometimes a dozen logs together; so all you have to do is to catch them and sell them to the wood-yards and the sawmill.
vi: June is the season of rising water, which always brings me a lot of luck. Because whenever the water rises, driftwood and logs float down, along with pieces of rafts, sometimes dozens at a time. All I have to do is collect them and sell them to the lumber yard or sawmill.
tr: The June floods always brought me good fortune, because as soon as the river started to rise, bundles of firewood and pieces of raft timber would float downstream – sometimes I would come across a dozen pieces of wood at once. I would catch them and sell them to the woodcutter or directly to the lumber mill.
es: The June flood always brought me luck, because as soon as that flood arrives, cut logs and pieces of log rafts come down: sometimes a dozen logs together; so you just have to collect them and sell them to the sawmill and the carpenters.

en: I went along up the bank with one eye out for pap and t’other one out for what the rise might fetch along.
vi: I followed along the riverbank, heading upstream, keeping an eye on my father while also looking to see if the rising water might bring anything useful.
tr: While looking to see if my father was coming and also investigating what the flood was bringing, I walked up the shore.
es: I climbed up the shore with one eye on father and the other on what the rising water might bring.

en: Well, all at once here comes a canoe; just a beauty, too, about thirteen or fourteen foot long, riding high like a duck.
vi: Suddenly, a boat drifted by, a very beautiful boat, about three or four meters long, with its bow raised like a duck's beak.
tr: Before long, I saw a canoe. It was very beautiful, about four meters long, and gliding like a duck.
es: Then suddenly a canoe arrives; and moreover, a splendid one, about thirteen or fourteen feet long, sailing very stiffly like a duck.

en: I shot head-first off of the bank like a frog, clothes and all on, and struck out for the canoe.
vi: From the riverbank, I dove in headfirst like a frog, fully clothed, towards the boat.
tr: Without even taking off my clothes, I immediately dived headfirst into the water like a frog and swam towards the canoe.
es: I jumped headfirst into the water like a frog, clothes and all, and swam towards the canoe.

en: I just expected there’d be somebody laying down in it, because people often done that to fool folks, and when a chap had pulled a skiff out most to it they’d raise up and laugh at him.
vi: I guessed that there must be someone lying inside the boat, because it was common for people to lie inside and then pop their heads out to laugh at you.
tr: I thought someone was lying in it waiting, because people often do this as a joke. When someone gets close enough with a boat, they suddenly sit up and laugh at their reaction.
es: I imagined there might be someone inside, because that's what some people do to trick others, and when someone is about to pull a boat to shore, they stand up and start laughing.

en: But it warn’t so this time.
vi: But this time, there was no one.
tr: But this time, it wasn't like that.
es: But not this time.

en: It was a drift-canoe sure enough, and I clumb in and paddled her ashore.
vi: It was surely an abandoned drifting boat. I climbed in and used my feet to paddle the boat towards the shore.
tr: It was clear that it was an abandoned canoe. I got into the canoe and brought it to the shore.
es: It was a canoe truly drifting, and I got into it and took it to the shore.

en: Thinks I, the old man will be glad when he sees this—she’s worth ten dollars.
vi: I thought to myself that my father would be very pleased to see it - the boat was worth ten dollars - but when I reached the shore, he was still nowhere to be seen.
tr: I thought our old man would be happy to see the canoe – it was worth almost ten dollars.
es: I thought the old man would be happy when he saw it: it would be worth ten dollars.

en: But when I got to shore pap wasn’t in sight yet, and as I was running her into a little creek like a gully, all hung over with vines and willows, I struck another idea: I judged I’d hide her good, and then, ’stead of taking to the woods when I run off, I’d go down the river about fifty mile and camp in one place for good, and not have such a rough time tramping on foot.
vi: I pushed the boat into a small inlet, overgrown with small leaves and willows, and suddenly had another idea. I planned to hide the boat well, so instead of running into the forest, I could drift down the river about fifty miles and anchor somewhere, saving time and avoiding the effort of running on foot.
tr: But when I reached the shore, my father was still nowhere to be seen. As I was pulling the canoe into a small creek mouth covered with ivy and willows, another idea came to my mind. I would hide the canoe well, and instead of escaping through the forest, I would go down the river about fifty miles and set up camp somewhere. That way, my feet wouldn't get sore from walking.
es: But when I reached the shore, father was still not in sight, and as I was taking it into a half-hidden stream, all covered with willows and vines, another idea occurred to me: I thought of hiding it well and then, instead of going into the woods when I escaped, I would go down the river about fifty miles and camp in a place forever, without the trouble of wandering around on foot.

en: It was pretty close to the shanty, and I thought I heard the old man coming all the time; but I got her hid; and then I out and looked around a bunch of willows, and there was the old man down the path a piece just drawing a bead on a bird with his gun.
vi: This place is quite close to the hut. I thought I heard my father's footsteps approaching. But I had already hidden it, and after hiding it, I looked through the willow bushes and saw my father walking down the small path, raising his gun to aim at birds.
tr: Since I was quite close to our cabin, I was constantly scared that our old man would come any moment. But still, I hid the canoe, and then looked towards the cabin through the willows. My father was aiming at a bird at the end of the road.
es: That was very close to the hut and all the time it seemed to me that I heard the old man arriving, but I managed to hide it and then went out and looked through a group of willows and saw the old man down the path, aiming at a bird with the shotgun.

en: So he hadn’t seen anything.
vi: So that means he doesn't know anything yet.
tr: So, he hadn't noticed the canoe.
es: So he hadn't seen anything.

en: When he got along I was hard at it taking up a “trot” line.
vi: When my father came back, I awkwardly grabbed a fishing rod.
tr: When my father came to me, I was diligently working to reel in a fishing line.
es: When he arrived, I was pulling with all my strength on a line set to drag.

en: He abused me a little for being so slow; but I told him I fell in the river, and that was what made me so long.
vi: He asked me why I took so long, and I told him I had just fallen into the river, which is why it took so long.
tr: He complained that I was too slow, but I told him it took so long because I had fallen into the river.
es: He insulted me a bit for being so slow, but I told him that I had fallen into the river and that's why I had taken so long.

en: I knowed he would see I was wet, and then he would be asking questions.
vi: I knew he would ask when he saw my clothes were soaking wet.
tr: Because I knew he would notice that I was wet and start asking questions.
es: I knew he would notice that I was wet and then he would start asking questions.

en: We got five catfish off the lines and went home.
vi: The two of us caught five big fish on the line and then returned to the hut.
tr: We gathered five catfish from the lines and returned home.
es: We pulled five catfish from the drag and went home.

en: While we laid off after breakfast to sleep up, both of us being about wore out, I got to thinking that if I could fix up some way to keep pap and the widow from trying to follow me, it would be a certainer thing than trusting to luck to get far enough off before they missed me; you see, all kinds of things might happen.
vi: After finishing breakfast, we went back to sleep. Both of us were exhausted. I thought about how to ensure that neither my father nor the widow could pursue me anymore. Perhaps trusting in luck and going far away so they couldn't find me was the safest bet. Because who knows, maybe nothing would happen. After thinking for a long time, I couldn't come up with any solution.
tr: After breakfast, a heaviness settled over both of us, and we began to doze off somewhere. Meanwhile, I was looking for a solution so that my father or the widow wouldn't come after me once I escaped. I needed to find a more certain way than just hoping to get far enough away before they noticed my absence. You never know what might happen to you.
es: When we took a nap after breakfast, because we were both exhausted, I started thinking that if I could manage to prevent either my father or the widow from trying to follow me, I would be safer than if I relied on luck to get very far before they missed me; you know, thousands of things could happen.

en: Well, I didn’t see no way for a while, but by-and-by pap raised up a minute to drink another barrel of water, and he says:
vi: My father sat up for a moment, drank some water, and then said:
tr: For a while, no solution came to mind, but then when my father got up to fetch some water from the barrel, he said:
es: Well, for a while nothing came to mind, but then father got up for a moment to drink another barrel of water, and he goes and says:

en: “Another time a man comes a-prowling round here you roust me out, you hear?
vi: - Next time someone comes snooping around here, you have to call me out immediately, understand?
tr: “If someone comes near the house again, you will wake me up, do you understand?
es: —If another man comes to spy on us here, wake me up, do you understand?

en: That man warn’t here for no good.
vi: That person coming here doesn't have good intentions.
tr: I don't think that man came with good intentions.
es: That man hasn't come for anything good.

en: I’d a shot him.
vi: I'll shoot them dead.
tr: I'll shoot him.
es: I would have shot him.

en: Next time you roust me out, you hear?”
vi: Remember to call me out next time, understand?
tr: Next time, you will wake me up, did you hear?”
es: Next time, wake me up, do you understand?

en: Then he dropped down and went to sleep again; but what he had been saying give me the very idea I wanted.
vi: Then he lay down again and slept. What he just said made perfect sense to me.
tr: Then he lay down again and started to sleep – but his words had just helped me find the idea I was looking for.
es: Then he lay down and went back to sleep; what he had said gave me the exact idea I wanted, so I said to myself: "I can arrange it so that no one thinks of following me."

en: I says to myself, I can fix it now so nobody won’t think of following me.
vi: I told myself that I could use that excuse, and from now on, no one would think about chasing me anymore.
tr: Now I think I've found a way to ensure no one follows me, I said to myself.
es: Then he lay down and went back to sleep; what he had said gave me the exact idea I wanted, so I said to myself: "I can arrange it so that no one thinks of following me."

en: About twelve o’clock we turned out and went along up the bank.
vi: By around twelve noon, the two of us stepped out of the house and walked along the riverbank.
tr: We got up around noon and went back to the shore.
es: By midday we got up and went up the riverbank.

en: The river was coming up pretty fast, and lots of driftwood going by on the rise.
vi: The river water was rising quite quickly. Rotten branches were also floating along with the rising water.
tr: The river had started to flow faster, and because of the flood, a lot of tree branches and wood were being carried along.
es: The river was rising quickly and lots of things were floating down with the water.

en: By-and-by along comes part of a log raft—nine logs fast together.
vi: A little later, a nine-piece raft floated down.
tr: A little later, a piece of a raft came – there were nine logs tied together.
es: After a while, a piece of a raft appeared: nine logs tied together.

en: We went out with the skiff and towed it ashore.
vi: We rowed the boat out to pull it to shore.
tr: We immediately took the boat and pulled the raft to the shore.
es: We went out with the boat and brought it to shore.

en: Then we had dinner.
vi: Then we went to have lunch.
tr: Then we ate.
es: Then we ate.

en: Anybody but pap would a waited and seen the day through, so as to catch more stuff; but that warn’t pap’s style.
vi: If it had been anyone else but my father, they would have waited there all day to see if they could pick up anything else, but my father was not like that.
tr: Anyone else would have waited all day and tried to catch more things, but that wasn't my father's style.
es: Anyone who wasn't father would have waited to see what happened that day to bring us more things, but that wasn't his style.

en: Nine logs was enough for one time; he must shove right over to town and sell.
vi: Those nine pieces of the raft were enough for one meal, as he could take them to town and sell them.
tr: Nine logs were enough for one trip. All he had to do was take the logs to town and sell them.
es: With nine logs he had enough for one time; he had to go to town immediately to sell them.

en: So he locked me in and took the skiff, and started off towing the raft about half-past three.
vi: So he locked the door, locked me in, and went out to take the small boat to tow the raft pieces. It was around three-thirty in the afternoon then.
tr: He locked me inside, got on the boat, and set off around three-thirty, towing the raft along.
es: So around three-thirty he locked me up and left with the boat and started towing the raft.

en: I judged he wouldn’t come back that night.
vi: I guessed he wouldn't be back tonight.
tr: I knew he wouldn't come back that night.
es: I figured he wouldn't come back that night.

en: I waited till I reckoned he had got a good start; then I out with my saw, and went to work on that log again.
vi: I waited until I figured he had gone before taking out the saw and continuing to saw through that wooden wall.
tr: I waited until I was sure he was far enough away, then took out the saw and continued cutting the plank.
es: I waited until I thought he was far enough away and then took out the saw and went back to working on that log.

en: Before he was t’other side of the river I was out of the hole; him and his raft was just a speck on the water away off yonder.
vi: Before my father crossed to the other side of the river, I had already crawled through the hole. Looking at my father with the raft, he was just a tiny dot on the very distant water surface.
tr: Before my father even reached the other side of the river, I had climbed out through the hole. The boat and the raft were just two small dots far away.
es: Before he finished crossing the river, I was already out through the hole; he and his raft were just a speck in the water, far away.

en: I took the sack of corn meal and took it to where the canoe was hid, and shoved the vines and branches apart and put it in; then I done the same with the side of bacon; then the whisky-jug.
vi: I took the bag of noodles and brought it to the hiding place, pushing aside the thick branches and placing the boat there.
tr: I took the sack of corn and brought it to the place where I had hidden the canoe, parted the vines and branches, and placed the sack in the canoe, then I brought the bacon.
es: I grabbed the sack of cornmeal, took it to where the canoe was hidden, moved the vine leaves and branches aside, and put it in; then I did the same with the quarter of smoked bacon, and then with the jug of whiskey.

en: I took all the coffee and sugar there was, and all the ammunition; I took the wadding; I took the bucket and gourd; I took a dipper and a tin cup, and my old saw and two blankets, and the skillet and the coffee-pot.
vi: Then I took the fat, the bottle of whiskey, all the coffee and sugar from the house, all the bullets, the cotton stuffed with medicine, the water scoop, the wooden basin, a spoon and a metal cup, my saw, two blankets, a pot, and a coffee pot.
tr: After that, I carried the whiskey barrel, took all the coffee and sugar from the house, and also brought the ammunition. I took the tinder. I took the bucket and the water container. I also took the ladle, the tin cup, the old saw, two blankets, the pan, and the coffee pot.
es: I took all the coffee and sugar there was, and all the ammunition. I took the stuffing paper, the bucket, and the canteen; I took out a pot, a metal cup, my old saw, and two blankets, the frying pan, and the coffee pot.

en: I took fish-lines and matches and other things—everything that was worth a cent.
vi: I took the fishing rod, matches, and other things, anything worth even a penny.
tr: I took the fishing line, the matches, and other things; everything that was worth money.
es: I grabbed the fishing lines, the matches, and other things: everything that was worth something.

en: I cleaned out the place.
vi: After that, I cleaned everything up thoroughly.
tr: I had swept everything clean.
es: I emptied the cabin.

en: I wanted an axe, but there wasn’t any, only the one out at the woodpile, and I knowed why I was going to leave that.
vi: I needed an axe, but there wasn't one in the house. There was only one at the woodpile, but I had already planned to leave it there.
tr: I also needed an axe, but there wasn't one inside, only by the woodpile, and I knew why I had to leave it there.
es: I needed an axe but there was only the one in the woodpile and I knew why I was going to leave it there.

en: I fetched out the gun, and now I was done.
vi: I also took the gun. That was everything.
tr: Finally, I took the rifle; I had completed the task.
es: I took out the shotgun and finished.

en: I had wore the ground a good deal crawling out of the hole and dragging out so many things.
vi: Because I had to crawl through the hole to get out and move a lot of furniture through it, the ground in that spot was dug up quite a bit.
tr: By going in and out of the shed and carrying a lot of things, I had made quite a few tracks on the ground.
es: I had left all the ground packed down with the exit of the hole and with the transport of so many things.

en: So I fixed that as good as I could from the outside by scattering dust on the place, which covered up the smoothness and the sawdust.
vi: So I figured that from the outside, I would cover it to hide the rough spot with sawdust.
tr: So, I carefully erased my tracks from the outside and cleaned up the sawdust.
es: So I fixed it as best as I could, throwing dirt on top, which disguised the packed part and the sawdust that had fallen.

en: Then I fixed the piece of log back into its place, and put two rocks under it and one against it to hold it there, for it was bent up at that place and didn’t quite touch ground.
vi: Then I put the wooden plank back in its original place. I wedged two pebbles underneath and one on top to hold the plank firmly in place, and that spot sloped down without touching the ground.
tr: Then I placed the piece of plank firmly in its place, putting two stones underneath and one in front to keep it steady – because it didn't fit perfectly and didn't touch the ground.
es: Then I put the piece of log back in its place and put two stones underneath it and another one on the side so it wouldn't fall, because that part was irregular and didn't quite touch the ground.

en: If you stood four or five foot away and didn’t know it was sawed, you wouldn’t never notice it; and besides, this was the back of the cabin, and it warn’t likely anybody would go fooling around there.
vi: If someone stood four or five steps away, they wouldn't be able to see the sawed spot and wouldn't know about it; besides, this was the back of the house, and probably no one would bother to go around there anyway.
tr: But I had placed it so well that someone standing a meter or two away, who didn't know it had been cut, wouldn't even notice it, plus this was at the back of the cabin where hardly anyone would come.
es: If one stayed four or five feet away, without knowing it was sawed, it couldn't be seen, and besides, that was the back of the cabin and it wasn't likely that anyone would look around there.

en: It was all grass clear to the canoe, so I hadn’t left a track.
vi: From here to the hiding place, it's all grass, so there are no traces left behind.
tr: The road up to Kanoya was covered with grass, so I hadn't left any tracks there.
es: Until reaching the canoe, there was nothing but grass, so no tracks were left.

en: I followed around to see.
vi: I walked around once to check again.
tr: To be sure, I went back and forth once to check.
es: I took a walk around to be sure.

en: I stood on the bank and looked out over the river.
vi: I stood on the riverbank looking out into the distance.
tr: Then I went to the shore and watched the river.
es: I stayed on the riverbank and looked upstream and downstream.

en: All safe.
vi: Everything was safe.
tr: Everything was fine.
es: There was no danger.

en: So I took the gun and went up a piece into the woods, and was hunting around for some birds when I see a wild pig; hogs soon went wild in them bottoms after they had got away from the prairie farms.
vi: Then I took the gun and walked a distance into the forest. Usually, when domestic pigs escape from the pen, they easily turn into wild boars.
tr: I took the rifle and went into the forest, looking for a bird to hunt. Instead, I encountered a wild boar. Pigs that escaped from large farms would become feral after staying in the forest for a while.
es: So I grabbed the shotgun and went a little into the forest. I was looking for birds to hunt when I saw a wild pig; the pigs would quickly go wild around that area when they escaped from the prairie farms.

en: I shot this fellow and took him into camp.
vi: I immediately shot this pig and dragged it back home.
tr: I shot the boar and took it to the hut.
es: I shot this one and took it to the camp.

en: I took the axe and smashed in the door.
vi: I took the axe and struck the door with a strong blow.
tr: I took the axe and broke the door – I had hit it with all my strength and shattered the planks.
es: I grabbed the axe and jumped over the door.

en: I beat it and hacked it considerable a-doing it.
vi: It took a lot of hitting, quite a long time to break the door.
tr: I took the axe and broke the door – I had hit it with all my strength and shattered the planks.
es: I smashed it as much as I could.

en: I fetched the pig in, and took him back nearly to the table and hacked into his throat with the axe, and laid him down on the ground to bleed; I say ground because it was ground—hard packed, and no boards.
vi: I dragged the pig inside, pulled it near the table, then struck the pig's neck with an axe, leaving it on the ground for a while to let the blood flow out.
tr: I took the pig inside and brought it to a spot near the table, then cut its throat with the axe. I left it on the ground so the blood could drain – I say ground because there was no flooring, no planks laid, just the compacted earth beneath.
es: I brought the pig inside and dragged it almost to the table, then I cut its throat with the axe and left it on the ground to bleed; I say on the ground because it was dirt: compacted and without floorboards.

en: Well, next I took an old sack and put a lot of big rocks in it—all I could drag—and I started it from the pig, and dragged it to the door and through the woods down to the river and dumped it in, and down it sunk, out of sight.
vi: I say ground because it was real ground, just compacted earth, not wood flooring, then I grabbed an old bag, filled it with large pebbles, heavy enough for me to drag, then from the pig's location, I dragged the bag of pebbles to the door, through the woods to the riverbank, and threw it down there. The bag of pebbles sank, disappearing completely.
tr: Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones – just enough that I could still drag it. I dragged the sack from where the pig was, through the door, down to the riverbank among the trees, and left it in the water there. It immediately sank and disappeared from sight.
es: Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones —all that I could drag—, starting where the pig was, and dragged it to the door and through the woods to the river, where I threw it; it sank and disappeared.

en: You could easy see that something had been dragged over the ground.
vi: Anyone could see that something had been dragged along the ground.
tr: It was clear that something had been dragged on the ground.
es: It was easy to see that something had been dragged across the ground.

en: I did wish Tom Sawyer was there; I knowed he would take an interest in this kind of business, and throw in the fancy touches.
vi: I wished Tom Sawyer were here at this moment because I knew he would love this kind of thing and would add more details to make it even more thrilling.
tr: I wish Tom Sawyer had been with me... I knew very well how keen you were on such schemes, if he saw it now, who knows what cunning ideas would come to his mind.
es: I thought that I wished Tom Sawyer had been there; I knew he was interested in these things and that he would add the precise details.

en: Nobody could spread himself like Tom Sawyer in such a thing as that.
vi: For such stories, no one could boast more than Tom Sawyer.
tr: I've never seen anyone in my life whose mind worked as sharply as Tom Sawyer's in such matters.
es: Nobody knew how to embellish things like Tom Sawyer in a matter like this.

en: Well, last I pulled out some of my hair, and blooded the axe good, and stuck it on the back side, and slung the axe in the corner.
vi: Then I pulled out some hairs, smeared blood all over the axe blade, stuck some hairs onto the axe, and threw it in the corner of the house.
tr: Then I pulled out a few strands of my hair, covered the axe thoroughly with blood, stuck the hair onto it, and threw the axe into a corner.
es: Well, the last thing I did was pull out some of my hair, stain the axe with blood, and leave it in the back, thrown in a corner.

en: Then I took up the pig and held him to my breast with my jacket (so he couldn’t drip) till I got a good piece below the house and then dumped him into the river.
vi: I picked up the pig, held it against my chest, covered it with my shirt (so that the blood wouldn't drip), and carried it to a spot behind the house to throw it into the river.
tr: Then I took the pig, wrapped it in my jacket (so the blood wouldn't drip on the ground), and pressed it against my chest. Finally, after walking downstream and getting quite far from the house, I threw the blood-stained jacket and the pig into the river.
es: Then I grabbed the pig and covered it against my chest with the jacket (so it wouldn't drip) until I got far away from the house, and I threw it into the river.

en: Now I thought of something else.
vi: At that moment, I thought of something else.
tr: Then another idea came to mind.
es: Then I thought of something else.

en: So I went and got the bag of meal and my old saw out of the canoe, and fetched them to the house.
vi: I went to the boat to get a bag of flour and a saw and brought them into the house.
tr: I took the sack of flour and the old saw from the canoe and brought them back to the house.
es: So I went to take the sack of flour and the old saw from the canoe and brought them to the house.

en: I took the bag to where it used to stand, and ripped a hole in the bottom of it with the saw, for there warn’t no knives and forks on the place—pap done everything with his clasp-knife about the cooking.
vi: I put the bag of flour back in its original place, used the saw to poke a hole at the bottom of the bag, because there wasn't a pocket knife around to do everything.
tr: After placing the sack in its usual spot, I made a hole in the bottom with the saw – since my father handled everything with his switchblade, there were no knives or forks in the house for cooking.
es: I left the sack where it usually was and made a hole in the bottom with the saw, because there were no knives or forks there: father cooked everything with the pocket knife.

en: Then I carried the sack about a hundred yards across the grass and through the willows east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five mile wide and full of rushes—and ducks too, you might say, in the season.
vi: Then I carried the bag of flour about a hundred yards past the grass field, through the willow bushes to the east of the cabin, to a shallow but wide hole about five miles long, filled with reeds that in season would also be full of ducks.
tr: I carried the sack about a hundred meters through the willows east of the house to a shallow lake that was five miles wide and covered with reeds – there were also many ducks in season.
es: Then I carried the sack about a hundred yards through the grass, among the willows, to the east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five miles wide and full of reeds and also ducks when it was the season.

en: There was a slough or a creek leading out of it on the other side that went miles away, I don’t know where, but it didn’t go to the river.
vi: There was a small stream leading to the far side of the lake, several miles away. I didn't know exactly where it went, but I was sure it didn't run into the river.
tr: On the other side of the lake, there was a pond or stream that went on for miles. I didn't know exactly where it went, but it definitely didn't flow into the river.
es: There was a stream or a brook that came out from there on the other side and ran for miles and miles, I don't know where, but it didn't go to the river.

en: The meal sifted out and made a little track all the way to the lake.
vi: The flour fell through the hole in the bag, leaving a long trail from the house to the lake.
tr: The flour spilling from the sack left a thin trail all the way to the lake.
es: The flour kept moving and leaving a small trail all the way to the lake.

en: I dropped pap’s whetstone there too, so as to look like it had been done by accident.
vi: I also threw my father's whetstone there, to make it look accidental.
tr: On the shore, I also threw down my father's whetstone; it would look like it had fallen accidentally.
es: There I also threw father's sharpening stone, to make it look like something accidental.

en: Then I tied up the rip in the meal sack with a string, so it wouldn’t leak no more, and took it and my saw to the canoe again.
vi: Then I tied a string around the hole in the flour bag to stop it from spilling out. Then I took the bag of flour and the saw back to the boat.
tr: Then I tied the bottom of the flour sack tightly with a rope, and once I was sure it wasn't spilling anymore, I took it back to the canoe along with the saw.
es: Then I closed the hole in the sack of flour with a string so that no more would fall out and took it back with the saw to the canoe.

en: It was about dark now; so I dropped the canoe down the river under some willows that hung over the bank, and waited for the moon to rise.
vi: At this time, the sky was nearly dark. I pushed the boat downwards, to the spot where the willow trees on the shore drooped down, and I sat there waiting for the moon to rise.
tr: It was about to get dark. I lowered the canoe a bit further down and went under the willows hanging over the water, and began to wait for the moon to rise. I tied the canoe to a willow trunk.
es: It was almost dark, so I left the canoe downstream covered by some willows that hung over the bank and waited for the moon to come out.

en: I made fast to a willow; then I took a bite to eat, and by-and-by laid down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and lay out a plan.
vi: I tied the boat to the base of the willow, took out a piece of bread to eat, and after eating, I lay back in the boat, smoked a cigarette to think of a new plan.
tr: Then I ate something and soon lay inside the canoe, smoking my pipe and starting to think about my plan.
es: I tied the canoe to a willow; then I ate something and after a while, I lay down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and make a plan.

en: I says to myself, they’ll follow the track of that sackful of rocks to the shore and then drag the river for me.
vi: I told myself that they would surely follow the trail of the gravel bag to the riverbank and then along the shore to find me.
tr: They would follow the stone sack to the shore and then search the river for my body.
es: And I go and tell myself: "They are going to follow the trail of that sack of stones to the shore and then they will drag the river to look for me.

en: And they’ll follow that meal track to the lake and go browsing down the creek that leads out of it to find the robbers that killed me and took the things.
vi: Then they would follow the flour trail to the hole, and follow the stream to somewhere to find the robbers who had killed me and taken my belongings.
tr: Additionally, they would follow the flour trail to the lake, and from there, they would search along the creek to find the robbers who killed me and took my belongings.
es: They will follow the flour trail to the lake, search the stream that comes out of it to find the thieves who killed me and took my things.

en: They won’t ever hunt the river for anything but my dead carcass.
vi: They would scour the river with the sole task of finding my body.
tr: They would find a lot of things in the river besides my dead body.
es: They are only going to search the river for my corpse.

en: They’ll soon get tired of that, and won’t bother no more about me.
vi: They will get tired of searching and won't bother thinking about me anymore.
tr: Eventually, they would get tired and give up searching.
es: Then they will soon get tired and won't worry about me anymore.

en: All right; I can stop anywhere I want to.
vi: Great, I can stop wherever I want.
tr: It was all set, I could go wherever I wanted.
es: Very well, I can stay wherever I please.

en: Jackson’s Island is good enough for me; I know that island pretty well, and nobody ever comes there.
vi: Jackson Island is a place where I can take refuge. I know that island very well, no one ever goes there.
tr: Jackson Island was just right for me. I knew the island well and no one ever went there.
es: Jackson's Island is enough for me; I know it very well and no one ever comes here.

en: And then I can paddle over to town nights, and slink around and pick up things I want.
vi: Then at night, I can paddle up to the top, wander around, and steal whatever I need.
tr: At night, I could row down to the town and sneak around to take whatever I needed.
es: And then I can go to town at night, look around and take what I need.

en: Jackson’s Island’s the place.
vi: Then at night, I can paddle up to the top, wander around, and steal whatever I need.
tr: Jackson Island was perfectly fine.
es: Jackson's Island is fine."

en: I was pretty tired, and the first thing I knowed I was asleep.
vi: At that time, I was quite tired. The first thing to do was to sleep.
tr: As I was quite tired, I fell asleep while thinking about these things.
es: I was quite tired and without realizing it, I fell asleep.

en: When I woke up I didn’t know where I was for a minute.
vi: When I woke up, it took me a minute to realize where I was.
tr: When I woke up, I couldn't remember where I was for a moment.
es: When I woke up, I didn't know for a moment where I was.

en: I set up and looked around, a little scared.
vi: I sat up, looked around, a bit scared.
tr: I sat up and looked around with some anxiety.
es: I sat up and looked around, a little scared.

en: Then I remembered.
vi: Then I remembered.
tr: Then I remembered everything.
es: Then I remembered.

en: The river looked miles and miles across.
vi: The river stretched vast and wide for miles.
tr: The river seemed to be miles wide.
es: The river seemed to be miles and miles wide.

en: The moon was so bright I could a counted the drift logs that went a-slipping along, black and still, hundreds of yards out from shore.
vi: The moon was so bright. I couldn't count all the pieces of wood drifting, black and silent, a few hundred meters from the shore.
tr: The moon was so bright that I could distinguish the dark logs passing by from hundreds of meters away.
es: The moon shone so brightly that you could count the logs drifting down, black and silent, hundreds of yards from the shore.

en: Everything was dead quiet, and it looked late, and smelt late.
vi: Everything was as silent as death. It seemed very late at night, I could sense it was very late.
tr: A deathly silence had settled over everything, and it was evidently late; it even smelled late.
es: Everything was in total silence and it seemed to be late, it smelled like it was late.

en: You know what I mean—I don’t know the words to put it in.
vi: I'm sure you understand what I mean - I can't find the right words to say it properly.
tr: You know what I mean – I just can't choose the right words every time.
es: You know what I mean... I don't know with what words to say it.

en: I took a good gap and a stretch, and was just going to unhitch and start when I heard a sound away over the water.
vi: I let out a long yawn and stretched.
tr: I stretched and yawned widely, and just as I was about to untie the rope and set off, I heard a sound coming from afar over the water.
es: I yawned and stretched comfortably, and I was about to untie to set off when I heard a noise in the water.

en: I listened.
vi: I let out a long yawn and stretched.
tr: I immediately perked up my ears.
es: I listened.

en: Pretty soon I made it out.
vi: Just as I was about to take off my shirt and start on my way, I suddenly heard a distant sound on the water.
tr: Soon, I understood what it was.
es: Immediately I understood what it was.

en: It was that dull kind of a regular sound that comes from oars working in rowlocks when it’s a still night.
vi: I listened carefully and immediately recognized the creaking sound of oars grinding against the rowlocks in the stillness of the night.
tr: It was the regular sound of oars rubbing against the rowlocks on silent nights.
es: It was that rhythmic and muffled noise that oars make in the oarlocks in the silence of the night.

en: I peeped out through the willow branches, and there it was—a skiff, away across the water.
vi: I poked my head out from the willow bushes and saw a boat gliding on the river.
tr: When I looked through the willow branches, I saw it – there was a boat in the distance.
es: I looked through the branches of the willows and there it was: a boat on the river.

en: I couldn’t tell how many was in it.
vi: It was impossible to tell how many people were on the boat.
tr: I couldn't see how many people were inside.
es: I couldn't see how many people it carried.

en: It kept a-coming, and when it was abreast of me I see there warn’t but one man in it.
vi: Only when it came closer did I see that there was only one person on the boat.
tr: It was coming towards me, and when it got closer, I saw that there was only one person inside.
es: It kept getting closer, and when it reached in front of me it only had one man.

en: Think’s I, maybe it’s pap, though I warn’t expecting him.
vi: I guessed it might be my father, although deep down I thought he couldn't be back yet.
tr: I wasn't expecting anyone that night, but maybe it was my father.
es: And I go and think: "Maybe it's father," even though I wasn't expecting him.

en: He dropped below me with the current, and by-and-by he came a-swinging up shore in the easy water, and he went by so close I could a reached out the gun and touched him.
vi: The boat continued to drift with the current, past my hiding spot, and then after a while, it docked at the shore where the water was still. It came so close that I almost reached for my gun and aimed at him.
tr: As the boat passed by me, it rippled the water, and soon after the water calmed, it continued rowing towards the shore. It had passed so close to me that I could have touched it with my rifle if I had extended it.
es: It went downstream with the current and after a while it reached the shore, where the water was calm, and passed so close that I could have touched it by extending the shotgun.

en: Well, it was pap, sure enough—and sober, too, by the way he laid his oars.
vi: Oh, it was indeed my father - and he wasn't drunk either, judging by the way he handled the oars.
tr: This was definitely my father – and judging by his rowing, he was completely sober.
es: Well, it was indeed father, and moreover calm, by the way he left the oars.

en: I didn’t lose no time.
vi: I did not waste a single moment.
tr: I didn't waste any time.
es: I didn't waste any time.

en: The next minute I was a-spinning down stream soft but quick in the shade of the bank.
vi: Just a minute later, I was already gliding the boat downstream, light and fast, in the darkness close to the shore.
tr: A little later, I was moving silently but swiftly in the direction of the current from within the shadows on the shore.
es: The next moment, I was going downstream, silently but quickly, in the shadow of the riverbank.

en: I made two mile and a half, and then struck out a quarter of a mile or more towards the middle of the river, because pretty soon I would be passing the ferry landing, and people might see me and hail me.
vi: I rowed for more than two miles, then rowed a few hundred more yards to the middle of the river. Because in just a moment, I would be passing the ferry dock, and if someone saw me, they might call out.
tr: After going about two and a half miles, I moved to the middle of the river for about a quarter mile, because I would soon be passing the steamboat dock and people might see and call out to me.
es: I covered two and a half miles and then moved a quarter of a mile more towards the center of the river, because I was about to pass by the ferry landing and people could see me and call out to me.

en: I got out amongst the driftwood, and then laid down in the bottom of the canoe and let her float.
vi: I steered the boat through the floating logs on the river, stuffing a few pieces at the bottom of the boat to let it drift along.
tr: I dove among the drifting logs, then lay down inside the canoe, letting go of the oars.
es: I got among the drifting logs and then lay down at the bottom of the canoe and let it float on its own.

en: I laid there, and had a good rest and a smoke out of my pipe, looking away into the sky; not a cloud in it.
vi: I lay down to rest again, smoked a cigarette, and looked up at the clear sky without a single cloud.
tr: I rested there nicely, watching the cloudless sky and puffing on my pipe.
es: There I stayed, rested well, and smoked a pipe, gazing at the sky; there wasn't a single cloud.

en: The sky looks ever so deep when you lay down on your back in the moonshine; I never knowed it before.
vi: On a moonlit night, lying on my back and looking up at the sky, it seemed incredibly high; I had never seen the sky so high before.
tr: When lying on my back in the moonlight, the sky seemed so deep; I had never noticed this before.
es: The sky always seems so deep when you lie on your back in the moonlight; I had never noticed it until then.

en: And how far a body can hear on the water such nights!
vi: On such nights, one can hear the sounds on the water from very far away.
tr: Also, how far sounds traveled over water on such nights!
es: And how many things you can hear from afar on nights like that!

en: I heard people talking at the ferry landing.
vi: I heard people talking near the ferry dock.
tr: Men were talking at the steamboat dock.
es: I heard people talking at the landing.

en: I heard what they said, too—every word of it.
vi: I clearly heard every word of the folk songs.
tr: I could hear every word they said.
es: And I heard what they were saying: every single word.

en: One man said it was getting towards the long days and the short nights now.
vi: Someone said that now the days are long and the nights are short.
tr: One of the men said that the days were getting longer and the nights shorter.
es: One man remarked that the long days and short nights were coming.

en: T’other one said this warn’t one of the short ones, he reckoned—and then they laughed, and he said it over again, and they laughed again; then they waked up another fellow and told him, and laughed, but he didn’t laugh; he ripped out something brisk, and said let him alone.
vi: Another person said this was not yet one of the short nights; and both laughed. Then they woke up another person to laugh again, but the other person didn't laugh and uttered a vulgar phrase to let him sleep in peace.
tr: The other said that this night was not one of the short ones – then they laughed heartily. He said the same thing again and they laughed once more. Then they woke up another man, told him, and laughed; but the man did not laugh.
es: The other said that this wasn't one of the short ones, he guessed, and then they laughed and said it again and again and laughed again; then they woke up another person and told him, laughing, but he didn't laugh; he said something very grumpily and they left him alone.

en: The first fellow said he ’lowed to tell it to his old woman—she would think it was pretty good; but he said that warn’t nothing to some things he had said in his time.
vi: The first person said to stop and take that to tell his old wife - she would listen. Then he said that it was nothing compared to what he had said before.
tr: After scolding them, he told them to give him a little peace. The first man mentioned that he would tell this to his wife – she would find it very funny too. But compared to the jokes he used to make, this one was nothing.
es: The first one said he would surely tell his old lady because she would find it very funny, but he said that was nothing compared to the things he had said in his time.

en: I heard one man say it was nearly three o’clock, and he hoped daylight wouldn’t wait more than about a week longer.
vi: I heard someone else say that it was already almost three in the morning; wishing not to have to wait more than a week for it to be morning.
tr: Another man said it was three o'clock and hoped that the day wouldn't take more than a week to dawn.
es: I heard a man say it was almost three o'clock and he hoped daylight wouldn't take more than a week to arrive.

en: After that the talk got further and further away, and I couldn’t make out the words any more; but I could hear the mumble, and now and then a laugh, too, but it seemed a long ways off.
vi: Then after that, the conversation gradually faded; gradually faded, I could no longer hear each word clearly. But I could still hear murmurs, occasionally a few laughs, but it seemed very distant.
tr: Then the conversations gradually faded away, I could no longer make out the words, but I could still hear their murmurs. From time to time, they laughed, but their voices came from very far away.
es: Then the conversation gradually faded away, and I could no longer distinguish the words, but I could still hear the noise and occasionally a laugh, only now everything seemed very far away.

en: I was away below the ferry now.
vi: Now, I was far away from the ferry dock.
tr: I had already passed the ferry dock.
es: The ferry had already passed.

en: I rose up, and there was Jackson’s Island, about two mile and a half down stream, heavy timbered and standing up out of the middle of the river, big and dark and solid, like a steamboat without any lights.
vi: I sat up, seeing Jackson Island, about more than two miles down the river. The island had many dense trees, lying in the middle of the river, large and dark, as steady as a big ship without lights.
tr: When I looked up, I saw Jackson Island two and a half miles down. It looked huge, dark, and solid with its dense trees rising from the middle of the river. It resembled a steamboat with its lights turned off.
es: I got up and there was Jackson Island, about two and a half miles downstream, full of trees and rising in the middle of the river, big, dark, and solid, like a steamboat without any lights.

en: There warn’t any signs of the bar at the head—it was all under water now.
vi: The way to the port was unobstructed, the mounds had sunk below the water surface.
tr: The sandy beach at the front had disappeared from sight – it was now completely underwater.
es: There wasn't a single sign on the tip bar: now all that was submerged.

en: It didn’t take me long to get there.
vi: I rowed to the place without spending much time.
tr: It didn't take long for me to get there.
es: It didn't take me long to get there.

en: I shot past the head at a ripping rate, the current was so swift, and then I got into the dead water and landed on the side towards the Illinois shore.
vi: I turned the canoe through the whirlpool and into the calm stream, then glided it into the still water, docking on the Illinois side.
tr: I passed the front of the island like lightning; the current was very strong. Then I entered calm water and landed on the Illinois side.
es: I passed by the point at great speed, given the swiftness of the current, and then I reached the calm waters and disembarked on the side facing the Illinois shore.

en: I run the canoe into a deep dent in the bank that I knowed about; I had to part the willow branches to get in; and when I made fast nobody could a seen the canoe from the outside.
vi: I pushed the canoe into a deep pool inside the shore that I had known before. I had to part the willow bushes to push the canoe in, and I did it quickly so no one outside could see.
tr: I pulled the canoe into a nook I knew on the shore. I had to part the willow branches to get inside. After tying it tightly, no one would be able to see it from the outside.
es: I put the canoe into a deep crevice in the bank that I had seen before. I had to part the willow branches to get in, and when I tied it up, no one could see it from outside.

en: I went up and set down on a log at the head of the island, and looked out on the big river and the black driftwood and away over to the town, three mile away, where there was three or four lights twinkling.
vi: I climbed up and sat on a fallen tree at the edge of the island and looked out at the wide river. Looking at the black floating logs, then looking towards the town three miles away, I saw three or four twinkling lights.
tr: I went and sat on a log at the head of the island and started watching the big river, the drifting black logs, and the town three miles away where three or four lights were flickering.
es: I climbed up and sat on a log at the tip of the island to contemplate the great river and the lumber that was passing by, and the town, three miles away, where three or four lights could be seen blinking.

en: A monstrous big lumber-raft was about a mile up stream, coming along down, with a lantern in the middle of it.
vi: A huge raft was coming down from upstream, about a mile from where I was sitting; a light was lit in the middle of summer.
tr: A massive lumber raft was coming from about a mile upstream. There was a lantern right in the middle of it.
es: There was a huge raft of logs floating a mile upstream, coming down with a lit lantern in the middle.

en: I watched it come creeping down, and when it was most abreast of where I stood I heard a man say, “Stern oars, there!
vi: I watched as a raft slowly drifted right to where I was, and someone said: Row harder!
tr: I watched as the raft slowly approached. When it reached right opposite me, I heard a man shout, “Oars at the stern!
es: I watched as it slowly approached, and when it was almost in front of me, I heard a man say, "Ahoy, stern oars!

en: heave her head to stabboard!”
vi: That's it! Push the edge of the paddle down!
tr: Turn the bow to starboard!”
es: Turn the bow to starboard!"

en: I heard that just as plain as if the man was by my side.
vi: I heard the voice booming as if the person was standing right next to me.
tr: I heard his voice as clearly as if he were right next to me.
es: I heard him just as clearly as if that man had been right next to me.

en: There was a little gray in the sky now; so I stepped into the woods, and laid down for a nap before breakfast.
vi: The sky had started to turn gray. I walked into the forest and lay down to sleep for a while before having breakfast.
tr: The color of the sky had started to lighten slightly. I went into the trees to take a nap before breakfast.
es: Now there was already some gray in the sky and I went into the forest and took a nap before breakfast.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: Chapter VIII
tr: Chapter Eight
es: Chapter 8

en: The sun was up so high when I waked that I judged it was after eight o’clock.
vi: When I woke up, the sun was already high in the sky, I guessed it was past eight o'clock.
tr: When I woke up, the sun had risen so high that I thought it was past eight o'clock.
es: THE SUN WAS already so high when I woke up that I thought it would be after eight.

en: I laid there in the grass and the cool shade thinking about things, and feeling rested and ruther comfortable and satisfied.
vi: I lay on the grass, in the cool shade, not thinking about much, feeling rested, both reassured and content.
tr: I lay down again on the grass in the cool shade and started to think. I felt rested and quite relaxed, I was content with my life.
es: I lay in the grass in the cool shade, thinking about things and feeling rested and very comfortable and satisfied.

en: I could see the sun out at one or two holes, but mostly it was big trees all about, and gloomy in there amongst them.
vi: After a few empty months, I could see the sun. All around were large trees, so the place was quite dark.
tr: I could see the sun through a few small holes, but the top was mostly covered by large tree branches, and the part underneath was a bit dim.
es: The sun could be seen through one or two holes, but mostly there were large trees everywhere and among them many shadows.

en: There was freckled places on the ground where the light sifted down through the leaves, and the freckled places swapped about a little, showing there was a little breeze up there.
vi: There were also spots where sunlight pierced through the leaves and shone on the ground, and the sunlight there shimmered like a gentle breeze blowing through.
tr: In a few places where the light seeped through the branches, bright spots had formed, and from the slow movement of these spots, it was clear that there was a light breeze above.
es: There were dappled spots on the ground where the light filtered through the leaves, and the dappled spots changed a bit, which showed that there was a slight breeze blowing.

en: A couple of squirrels set on a limb and jabbered at me very friendly.
vi: A pair of squirrels sat on a branch, looking at me and chattering in a friendly manner.
tr: Two squirrels sat on a branch and chirped something to me in a very friendly manner.
es: A couple of squirrels sat on a branch and chattered at me in a very friendly manner.

en: I was powerful lazy and comfortable—didn’t want to get up and cook breakfast.
vi: I feel so comfortable and steady here that I become lazy and don't want to get up to cook a meal.
tr: A great sense of ease and laziness had settled over me; I didn't even feel like getting up to prepare breakfast.
es: I felt very lazy and comfortable: I didn't want to get up to make breakfast.

en: Well, I was dozing off again when I thinks I hears a deep sound of “boom!” away up the river.
vi: But then, as I close my eyes to sleep again, I suddenly hear a boom outside by the river.
tr: Just as I was about to fall back asleep, I heard a deep "boom" sound far off, upstream of the river.
es: Well, I was about to go back to sleep when it seemed to me that I heard a "boom!" in the distance, upriver.

en: I rouses up, and rests on my elbow and listens; pretty soon I hears it again.
vi: I prop myself up on my elbows, listening intently. After a while, I hear another sound.
tr: I immediately propped myself up on my elbow and listened intently. Soon, there was another boom.
es: I wake up and prop myself on my elbow and listen; immediately I hear it again.

en: I hopped up, and went and looked out at a hole in the leaves, and I see a bunch of smoke laying on the water a long ways up—about abreast the ferry.
vi: I stand up and step out, looking outside through a gap in the bushes. A cloud of smoke spreads over the water, drifting farther away—perhaps all the way to the ferry dock.
tr: I quickly jumped to my feet and went to look around through a gap in the branches and leaves. High above, a small puff of smoke was rising over the water – it was level with the dock.
es: I jumped up and went to look through a gap between the leaves, and I see a lot of smoke above the water, very far upriver: approximately in front of the ferry.

en: And there was the ferry-boat full of people floating along down.
vi: Then a boat full of people is coming down this way.
tr: There was the steamboat, coming down filled with people.
es: And there was the ferry, full of people, floating down.

en: I knowed what was the matter now.
vi: Now I know what is happening.
tr: Now I understood what was going on.
es: Then I understood what was happening.

en: “Boom!” I see the white smoke squirt out of the ferry-boat’s side.
vi: Boom! A puff of white smoke comes out from the boat.
tr: "Boom!" I saw another white cloud of smoke emerge from the side of the steamboat.
es: "Boom!" I saw the white smoke coming out of the side of the ferry.

en: You see, they was firing cannon over the water, trying to make my carcass come to the top.
vi: They are firing cannons into the river to make my body float to the surface.
tr: They were firing the cannon to make my body rise to the surface of the water.
es: So, they were firing the cannon over the water, trying to make my corpse surface.

en: I was pretty hungry, but it warn’t going to do for me to start a fire, because they might see the smoke.
vi: I was hungry, but I couldn't start a fire at that moment because they might see the smoke.
tr: I was very hungry, but I was hesitant to light a fire because they could see the smoke.
es: I was quite hungry, but it was better not to make a fire, because they might see the smoke.

en: So I set there and watched the cannon-smoke and listened to the boom.
vi: So I had to sit there watching the cannon smoke and listening to the explosions.
tr: So I settled down right there and watched the cannon smoke and listened to the "boom" sounds.
es: So I sat there watching the smoke from the cannon and listening to the "boom."

en: The river was a mile wide there, and it always looks pretty on a summer morning—so I was having a good enough time seeing them hunt for my remainders if I only had a bite to eat.
vi: The river was wide and even more beautiful here. If there was anything to be curious about, I would sit there for a long time to see how they would search for my dead body.
tr: The river was a mile wide there and always looked very beautiful on summer mornings – so their attempt to find my remains had turned into quite a spectacle, oh if only there was something to eat.
es: The river was a mile wide there and it always looks very beautiful on a summer morning, so I had a pretty good time watching them search for my remains, and all I was missing was something to eat.

en: Well, then I happened to think how they always put quicksilver in loaves of bread and float them off, because they always go right to the drownded carcass and stop there.
vi: I wondered why people would put mercury into loaves of bread and let them float down the river, and then those loaves would stop exactly where there was a drowned body.
tr: Then I remembered that they floated loaves of bread with mercury in them on the river. The loaf would always stop over the drowned body.
es: Well, then it occurred to me that they always put mercury in loaves of bread and let them float, because they usually go straight to where the drowned body is and stay there.

en: So, says I, I’ll keep a lookout, and if any of them’s floating around after me I’ll give them a show.
vi: I told myself to stay calm and see what happens; if I didn't see those loaves floating by to find me, I would reveal myself.
tr: I thought, I’ll watch to see if they’ll float a loaf after me, and if they do, I’ll find a way to get it.
es: So I said to myself, "I'll keep an eye out, and if one of them floats by close to me, I'll give it a try."

en: I changed to the Illinois edge of the island to see what luck I could have, and I warn’t disappointed.
vi: I walked around the island to the Illinois shore to see if there was anything there. And I wasn't too disappointed.
tr: I went to the side of the island facing Illinois and tried my luck and wasn’t disappointed.
es: I moved to the side of the island facing Illinois to see how lucky I would be, and it didn't go badly.

en: A big double loaf come along, and I most got it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and she floated out further.
