vi: A large loaf of bread floated by. I used a long stick to pull it in, but I slipped, and the loaf floated away again.
tr: A huge double loaf came, and with the help of a long stick, I almost caught it, but I slipped and the loaf drifted away.
es: A big loaf floated by and I almost grabbed it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and it kept floating.

en: Of course I was where the current set in the closest to the shore—I knowed enough for that.
vi: The spot where I was standing was where the current was closest to the shore, I knew that already.
tr: Of course, I was where the current was closest to the shore; I knew this very well.
es: Of course, I was where the current came closest to the shore, because I knew that was the best spot.

en: But by-and-by along comes another one, and this time I won.
vi: A while later, another loaf floated by, and this time I managed to catch it.
tr: But a little later, another loaf came, and this time I won.
es: But after a while, another one came by, and this time I hooked it.

en: I took out the plug and shook out the little dab of quicksilver, and set my teeth in.
vi: I pried off the stopper, shook out the mercury, and then took a bite.
tr: I opened the top of the loaf, removed the drop of mercury inside, and then started eating.
es: I took out the plug to remove the little piece of mercury and took a bite.

en: It was “baker’s bread”—what the quality eat; none of your low-down corn-pone.
vi: Wow, it was a genuine piece of bread, very valuable, not like the miserable cornbread I had been eating before.
tr: It wasn’t one of our terrible corn breads but a "baked" bread – the kind respectable people eat.
es: It was "baker's bread": the kind that fine people eat; not cheap corn bread.

en: I got a good place amongst the leaves, and set there on a log, munching the bread and watching the ferry-boat, and very well satisfied.
vi: I went looking for a good spot in the thick woods, sat on a log, chewing on some bread while watching the boat, feeling incredibly relaxed. Suddenly, I was startled; because at that moment I thought, what if the widow, or the schoolteacher, or someone had prayed for these pieces of bread to find me?
tr: I chose a good spot among the branches, sat on a log there, and enjoyed myself eating the bread and watching the steamboat.
es: I found myself a good spot among the leaves and sat on a log, chewing the bread and watching the ferry, very happy.

en: And then something struck me.
vi: If so, then there must be something in the bread.
tr: Then suddenly something came to my mind.
es: And then something occurred to me.

en: I says, now I reckon the widow or the parson or somebody prayed that this bread would find me, and here it has gone and done it.
vi: Meaning that when the widow's family or the schoolteacher prayed, it went into the bread? But I thought it probably wouldn't matter to me.
tr: The widow, the preacher, or someone else had prayed for this loaf to find me, and indeed it had come and found me.
es: I go and say: "Now I suppose the widow or the parson or someone has prayed for this bread to find me, and that's what happened.

en: So there ain’t no doubt but there is something in that thing—that is, there’s something in it when a body like the widow or the parson prays, but it don’t work for me, and I reckon it don’t work for only just the right kind.
vi: And whatever it was, it would likely be something good for me anyway.
tr: So there must have been something to this loaf business. That is, when the widow or the preacher prayed, it worked, but when people like me prayed, nothing happened; apparently, only the right people were heard when they prayed.
es: So there's no doubt that there's some truth to that story: that there's some truth when someone like the widow or the parson prays, but it doesn't work with me, and I suppose it only works with certain people."

en: I lit a pipe and had a good long smoke, and went on watching.
vi: I lit a cigarette, took a long drag, and then sat back looking outside.
tr: I continued to watch, enjoying myself for a long time while smoking my pipe.
es: I lit a pipe and spent a good while smoking while I continued watching.

en: The ferry-boat was floating with the current, and I allowed I’d have a chance to see who was aboard when she come along, because she would come in close, where the bread did.
vi: The boat continued to follow the current, and I would have a chance to see clearly who was on it when it got closer to my spot. Because it would definitely come closer, just like the piece of bread that had floated to that point.
tr: The steamboat was moving downstream with the current, and as it got closer, I would be able to see who was on the deck, because it was certain to come very close to where the bread was going.
es: The ferry floated downstream and I thought I would have a chance to see who was on board when it got closer, because it would stay almost beside me, just like the bread had done.

en: When she’d got pretty well along down towards me, I put out my pipe and went to where I fished out the bread, and laid down behind a log on the bank in a little open place.
vi: When it got really close to me, I put out the cigarette and went back to the spot where I had fished out the piece of bread earlier.
tr: When the steamboat turned towards me, I put out my pipe and approached the spot where I had caught the bread, hiding behind a log in a small opening on the shore.
es: When they got close enough to me, I put out the pipe and went to where I had hooked the bread and hid behind a log on the riverbank in a small clearing.

en: Where the log forked I could peep through.
vi: I lay down flat, hiding behind a log; this spot was a bit open, so I could peek out from a crack in the log.
tr: I could watch without showing myself through a knot on the log.
es: I could look through the part where the log forked.

en: By-and-by she come along, and she drifted in so close that they could a run out a plank and walked ashore.
vi: Then the boat came closer, so close that just throwing a plank could allow one to step ashore.
tr: The steamboat came very close and passed so near that it wouldn't have been difficult for them to throw a plank and come ashore.
es: After a while they arrived, and the boat came so close that they could have laid down a plank to get ashore.

en: Most everybody was on the boat.
vi: Then the boat came closer, so close that just throwing a plank could allow one to step ashore.
tr: Almost everyone had gathered on the deck.
es: After a while they arrived, and the boat came so close that they could have laid down a plank to get ashore.

en: Pap, and Judge Thatcher, and Bessie Thatcher, and Jo Harper, and Tom Sawyer, and his old Aunt Polly, and Sid and Mary, and plenty more.
vi: Everyone was on the boat; my father, old man Thatcher, then Becky Thatcher's daughter, then Joe Harper, then Tom Sawyer, then Tom's Aunt Polly, then Sid, then Mary, and a few others.
tr: My father, Judge Thatcher; Bessie Thatcher, Jo Harper; Tom Sawyer; his old aunt Polly, Sid and Mary, and many other familiar faces.
es: Almost everyone was on the boat: father and Judge Thatcher and Becky Thatcher, and Joe Harper, and Tom Sawyer and his old Aunt Polly and Sid and Mary and many more.

en: Everybody was talking about the murder, but the captain broke in and says:
vi: Everyone was discussing the murder case. But suddenly the boat owner said:
tr: Everyone was talking about the murder, but the captain silenced them with his loud voice, saying:
es: Everyone was talking about the murder, but the captain goes and interrupts them and says:

en: “Look sharp, now; the current sets in the closest here, and maybe he’s washed ashore and got tangled amongst the brush at the water’s edge.
vi: - Look closely, the water flows closest to the shore here, perhaps it drifted onto the land and got caught in some bush near the water's edge.
tr: “Now look carefully. This is the place where the current is closest to the shore. Maybe it has washed ashore and got caught in the branches of the trees by the water.
es: —Pay attention now; this is where the current comes closest and maybe it has floated to the shore and is tangled in the weeds at the water's edge.

en: I hope so, anyway.”
vi: I hope so.
tr: I hope we find it.”
es: At least, that's what I hope.

en: I didn’t hope so.
vi: But as for me, I didn't hope for that.
tr: I never expected it that way.
es: I did not expect it.

en: They all crowded up and leaned over the rails, nearly in my face, and kept still, watching with all their might.
vi: The whole group leaned forward, sticking out from the side of the boat, right in front of me, and everyone silently watched attentively.
tr: They all suddenly crowded near the railing, almost close enough to look directly into my eyes, and without moving, they began to scan the shore with all their attention.
es: They all crowded together to look over the railing, and they almost hit me in the face, and they did nothing but look, look with all their might.

en: I could see them first-rate, but they couldn’t see me.
vi: I could see them very clearly, but they couldn't see me.
tr: I could see them all very clearly, but they couldn't see me.
es: I could see them perfectly, but they couldn't see me.

en: Then the captain sung out:
vi: Suddenly, the boat owner shouted: - Back off.
tr: Then I heard the captain's voice:
es: Then the captain shouted: "Move aside!", and the cannon fired such a blast right next to me that it left me deaf from the noise and almost blind from the smoke, and I thought I was going to die.

en: “Stand away!” and the cannon let off such a blast right before me that it made me deef with the noise and pretty near blind with the smoke, and I judged I was gone.
vi: Then the sound of the cannon exploded right in front of me, making my ears deaf and my eyes almost blind from the gun smoke; I almost thought I was done for.
tr: “Move aside a bit!” and the cannonball exploded right in front of me with such force that I was deafened by the noise and blinded by the smoke.
es: Then the captain shouted: "Move aside!", and the cannon fired such a blast right next to me that it left me deaf from the noise and almost blind from the smoke, and I thought I was going to die.

en: If they’d a had some bullets in, I reckon they’d a got the corpse they was after.
vi: If there had been real bullets in there, they would have found the body they were looking for.
tr: For a moment, I thought I was dying. If there had been a cannonball inside the cannon, they would have finally found the corpse they were looking for.
es: If they had put some charge in it, I reckon they would have gotten the corpse they were looking for.

en: Well, I see I warn’t hurt, thanks to goodness.
vi: Thank God, I saw that I wasn't hurt at all.
tr: But thankfully, I wasn't injured.
es: Well, I saw that I wasn't injured, thank God.

en: The boat floated on and went out of sight around the shoulder of the island.
vi: The boat continued on and disappeared around the bend of the island.
tr: The steamboat continued on its way and disappeared from sight after passing the tip of the island.
es: The ship kept floating and disappeared around the tip of the island.

en: I could hear the booming now and then, further and further off, and by-and-by, after an hour, I didn’t hear it no more.
vi: Occasionally, I could still hear the booming sounds getting fainter, and then about an hour later, I couldn't hear anything anymore.
tr: The occasional booms that were still heard gradually faded away, and after about an hour, I could no longer hear them at all.
es: From time to time I heard the cannon shots, getting farther and farther away, and after a while, about an hour or so, I couldn't hear them anymore.

en: The island was three mile long.
vi: The island was three miles long, and I guessed they had reached the other end and given up the search.
tr: The island was three miles long.
es: The island was three miles long.

en: I judged they had got to the foot, and was giving it up.
vi: The island was three miles long, and I guessed they had reached the other end and given up the search.
tr: I thought they had gone to the end of the island and finally given up.
es: I thought they had reached the end and were giving up; but not yet.

en: But they didn’t yet a while.
vi: But they continued.
tr: But they still hadn't given up.
es: I thought they had reached the end and were giving up; but not yet.

en: They turned around the foot of the island and started up the channel on the Missouri side, under steam, and booming once in a while as they went.
vi: They went around the other end of the island and then followed the narrow stretch of the river up to the Missouri shore and then turned back.
tr: After reaching the end of the island, they turned and entered the strait on the Missouri side; as the steamboat moved forward, it occasionally continued to boom, sending out puffs of smoke from its chimney.
es: They circled the island and steamed up the river on the Missouri side, firing cannon shots now and then as they went.

en: I crossed over to that side and watched them.
vi: They went around the other end of the island and then followed the narrow stretch of the river up to the Missouri shore and then turned back.
tr: I also moved to that side and watched them.
es: I went to that side and watched them.

en: When they got abreast the head of the island they quit shooting and dropped over to the Missouri shore and went home to the town.
vi: They went around the other end of the island and then followed the narrow stretch of the river up to the Missouri shore and then turned back.
tr: When they reached the level of the head of the island, they stopped firing the cannon, scanned the Missouri shore briefly, and then headed back towards the village.
es: When they reached the other end of the island, they stopped firing and headed towards the Missouri shore and returned to the town.

en: I knowed I was all right now.
vi: Well, now it was all quiet.
tr: I knew I had finally gotten away.
es: Now I understood that I was already safe.

en: Nobody else would come a-hunting after me.
vi: No one was searching for me anymore.
tr: No one else would come looking for me.
es: Nobody was going to come looking for me.

en: I got my traps out of the canoe and made me a nice camp in the thick woods.
vi: I took my belongings from the boat, set up a nice little resting spot in the thick trees.
tr: I took my belongings out of the canoe and set up a nice camp spot in the dense forest.
es: I took the traps out of the canoe and set up a good camp in the middle of the forest.

en: I made a kind of a tent out of my blankets to put my things under so the rain couldn’t get at them.
vi: I used a blanket to make a small tent and put my belongings inside to keep them from getting wet in the rain.
tr: I made something like a tent out of my blankets so the rain wouldn't reach my things.
es: I made a sort of tent with the blankets to put my things under it so they wouldn't get wet from the rain.

en: I catched a catfish and haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp fire and had supper.
vi: I caught a fish, used a saw blade to gut it, and waited until sunset to start my campfire to cook dinner.
tr: I caught a catfish, cut its belly open with a saw; then lit my campfire at sunset and had my dinner.
es: I caught a catfish, opened it with the saw, and towards dusk, I lit my fire and had dinner.

en: Then I set out a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
vi: After that, I set a fishing line in the river so that I would have fish for breakfast the next morning.
tr: Afterwards, I cast a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
es: Then I cast a line to catch something for breakfast.

en: When it was dark I set by my camp fire smoking, and feeling pretty well satisfied; but by-and-by it got sort of lonesome, and so I went and set on the bank and listened to the current swashing along, and counted the stars and drift logs and rafts that come down, and then went to bed; there ain’t no better way to put in time when you are lonesome; you can’t stay so, you soon get over it.
vi: It was completely dark, I sat by the fire smoking and felt very interested. But gradually, I also felt how lonely it was, if I went to sit by the river listening to the murmuring water, looking up at the sky counting stars, then counting the branches and rafts drifting down from above; getting bored and then going to sleep. When to kill time. Can't sit still like that forever, it has to end soon somehow.
tr: When night fell, I started puffing on my stick by my campfire, I was very content with my situation; but then I gradually began to feel lonely, so I went and sat by the shore, listened to the bubbling flow of the water; I counted the stars, the drifting logs, and the rafts going downstream, then I lay down and slept; there is no better way to pass the time when you are alone; but you won't feel lonely for too long anyway, it passes with time.
es: When it got completely dark, I sat by the campfire, smoking, and felt very satisfied; but after a while, I started to feel lonely, so I went to sit by the riverbank to listen to the splashing of the water. I counted the stars and the logs drifting by and the rafts, and then I lay down; there is no better way to pass the time when one feels lonely; you can't continue like that, and after a while, it passes.

en: And so for three days and nights.
vi: I kept living like that for three days and nights.
tr: So, three days and three nights passed like this.
es: And so three days and nights passed.

en: No difference—just the same thing.
vi: Nothing changed. Everything remained the same.
tr: There was nothing different; I was doing the same thing all the time.
es: No change: always the same.

en: But the next day I went exploring around down through the island.
vi: The next day, I searched around where I lived and went down to the lower part of the island. I was the master of the island.
tr: But the next day, I started to explore the island.
es: But the next day I went to explore the whole island.

en: I was boss of it; it all belonged to me, so to say, and I wanted to know all about it; but mainly I wanted to put in the time.
vi: The whole island was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know everything about this island in detail. Actually, it was just to pass the time.
tr: One could say I was the master of the island; it all belonged to me; that's why I wanted to learn every inch of it; although what I really wanted was to find something to keep myself busy.
es: I was the master; everything was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know it entirely, but above all, I wanted to pass the time.

en: I found plenty strawberries, ripe and prime; and green summer grapes, and green razberries; and the green blackberries was just beginning to show.
vi: I found a lot of ripe and delicious berries, and even green summer grapes; the rice fruits were also starting to sprout, and eventually, it would be time to harvest them all.
tr: I found plenty of strawberries, both ripe and delicious, then I found unripe grapes and raspberries, and also the blackberries had started to grow green and fleshy.
es: I found heaps of strawberries, ripe and wonderful, and green summer grapes and green blackberries, and the blackberries were just starting to come out.

en: They would all come handy by-and-by, I judged.
vi: I found a lot of ripe and delicious berries, and even green summer grapes; the rice fruits were also starting to sprout, and eventually, it would be time to harvest them all.
tr: In time, they would all become edible.
es: I thought everything would come in very handy in time.

en: Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far from the foot of the island.
vi: Just like that, I wandered deeper into the forest until I guessed that this place wasn't far from the other end of the island anymore.
tr: I wandered through the dense forest until I reached a place not too far from the edge of the island.
es: Well, I was entertaining myself inside the forest until it seemed to me that I was not far from the tip of the island.

en: I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh home.
vi: I had a gun in my hand but hadn't fired a single shot. The gun was just for self-defense, and I also thought I would shoot an animal near its den.
tr: My rifle was always by my side, but I hadn't shot anything; the rifle was for my protection; although if I were near the house, I would hunt something.
es: I had taken my shotgun, but I hadn't shot at anything; it was for protection; I thought I would find something to hunt near home.

en: About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it, trying to get a shot at it.
vi: At that moment, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered into the grass and flowers to escape. I chased after it, determined to shoot the snake.
tr: Meanwhile, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered away through the grass and flowers, and I chased after it, thinking I might be able to shoot it.
es: Then I almost stepped on a good-sized snake, which went slithering through the grass and flowers, and I went after it, trying to shoot it.

en: I clipped along, and all of a sudden I bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
vi: While I was in hot pursuit, I suddenly stumbled upon a pile of ashes from a campfire that was still smoldering.
tr: As I moved quickly, I suddenly found myself standing over the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.
es: I was making good progress when suddenly I came across the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.

en: My heart jumped up amongst my lungs.
vi: My heart seemed to leap in my chest.
tr: I was bewildered.
es: My heart jumped between my lungs.

en: I never waited for to look further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as fast as ever I could.
vi: I didn't wait to see anything else, I slowly lowered my gun and quietly tiptoed backward, retreating very quickly.
tr: I didn't linger to scout the surroundings, I cocked the rifle and tiptoed back as quickly as possible.
es: I didn't wait to keep looking further; instead, I assembled the shotgun and tiptoed as fast as I could in silence.

en: Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear nothing else.
vi: Occasionally stopping for a second in the thick foliage and listening; but my breath was so loud that my ears couldn't hear anything.
tr: From time to time, I would stop among the dense branches and listen around, but I was breathing so loudly from excitement that I couldn't hear anything else.
es: From time to time, I would stop for a moment among the leaves and listen, but I was breathing so hard that I couldn't hear anything else.

en: I slunk along another piece further, then listened again; and so on, and so on.
vi: I took a deep breath, then listened again; then took another breath.
tr: After walking a bit, I stopped again to listen to the surroundings, then again, and again.
es: I kept moving forward a bit and listened again, and so on, over and over.

en: If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
vi: Seeing a fallen tree trunk, I thought there was someone. Stepping on a dry branch that snapped with a crack, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in half, and I could only hold onto a very short half-breath.
tr: If I saw a tree stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a branch and it broke, it felt as if someone had cut my breath in half and left me with the shorter half.
es: If I saw a stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a twig and broke it, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in two and I was left with only half, and the shorter half at that.

en: When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around.
vi: Returning to the tent, I felt uneasy. I felt that I was no longer as bold as before. But I told myself: there is no time to wander around.
tr: When I arrived at the camp, I had neither my vitality nor my boldness left; I had somewhat lost my former determination, but now is not the time to dawdle or get lost in thoughts, I told myself.
es: When I arrived at the camp, I didn't feel very calm or very brave, but I went and said: "This is no time to fool around."

en: So I got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight, and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
vi: Then I moved all the belongings down to the boat so that no one would see them. I extinguished the fire, scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old fire from last year, then I climbed up a tree and sat.
tr: Therefore, after packing all my belongings back into my canoe and hiding it from sight, extinguishing the fire and scattering the ashes to create the appearance of an old campsite, I climbed up a tree.
es: So I put all my traps back in the canoe so no one could see them, put out the campfire and scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old camp from last year, and then I climbed up a tree.

en: I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I didn’t hear nothing—I only thought I heard and seen as much as a thousand things.
vi: I guess I've been sitting on the tree for several hours, seeing nothing and hearing nothing else. But in my mind, it felt like I had seen and heard thousands of things.
tr: I probably stayed at the top of the tree for about two hours; but I saw nothing, I heard nothing – I only thought I saw or heard thousands of things.
es: I think I spent two hours in the tree, but I didn't see anything. I didn't hear anything; it just seemed to me that I had heard and seen at least a thousand things.

en: Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the time.
vi: Well, I couldn't stay on the tree like that forever. After that, I slid down and remained among the dense trees, always keeping an eye out.
tr: I couldn't stay at the top of the tree forever; so finally, I came down, but I was stuck among the dense trees and constantly watched my surroundings.
es: Well, I couldn't stay there forever either, so I finally got down, but I remained in the center of the forest and alert the whole time.

en: All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from breakfast.
vi: I had only eaten a few fruits from the tree and some leftover food from breakfast.
tr: There was only a bit of fruit and leftovers from breakfast as food.
es: I couldn't eat anything but blackberries and what was left of breakfast.

en: By the time it was night I was pretty hungry.
vi: It was already night by then. My stomach was growling with hunger.
tr: In the evening, I was very hungry.
es: When it got really dark, I was quite hungry, so when it was completely dark, I silently slipped into the water before the moon came out and paddled to the Illinois shore: about a quarter of a mile.

en: So when it was good and dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile.
vi: Waiting until it was completely dark, I slipped out from the shore, before the moon rose, and pushed the boat towards the Illinois shore, about half a mile away.
tr: So, I waited for the darkest moment and rowed away from the shore towards the Illinois coast, a quarter mile away, before the moon rose.
es: When it got really dark, I was quite hungry, so when it was completely dark, I silently slipped into the water before the moon came out and paddled to the Illinois shore: about a quarter of a mile.

en: I went out in the woods and cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all night when I hear a plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk, and says to myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices.
vi: I went into the forest to cook dinner and planned to stay there all night. Suddenly, I heard a clattering sound. I told myself: there are horses coming. Then, there were voices.
tr: I went into the forest, cooked some food, and had decided to stay there all night when I heard the clattering sounds of horses approaching; soon after, I also heard human voices.
es: I went into the woods, cooked myself something for dinner, and had practically decided to spend the whole night there when I heard a clip-clop and thought that horses were coming; and then I heard people's voices.

en: I got everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping through the woods to see what I could find out.
vi: I quickly loaded everything back onto the boat, then went back into the forest to see if I could spot anything.
tr: After hurriedly loading everything onto the canoe, I crawled through the forest to see what was happening.
es: I put everything in the canoe as quickly as I could and crawled through the woods to see if I could find out anything.

en: I hadn’t got far when I hear a man say:
vi: After crawling a few steps, I heard someone speak:
tr: Before I could go any further, I heard a man's voice:
es: I hadn't gone far when I heard someone say:

en: “We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about beat out.
vi: - If we can find a good spot, we should stop here; the horses are very tired.
tr: “If we find a good spot, let's camp here; the horses are very tired.
es: —We better camp here if we find a good spot; the horses are very tired.

en: Let’s look around.”
vi: Let's look around here.
tr: Let's explore the surroundings.”
es: Let's take a look.

en: I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy.
vi: I no longer waited for anything, the sky receded and I immediately pushed the boat away.
tr: I didn't wait at all, I immediately set off and rowed away comfortably.
es: I didn't wait, but moved away and began to leave silently.

en: I tied up in the old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.
vi: I tied the boat back to its old spot and intended to sleep under the boat.
tr: I returned to my old spot, tied up the canoe, and decided that the best thing to do was to sleep inside it.
es: I went back to tie up at the previous spot and figured I would sleep in the canoe.

en: I didn’t sleep much.
vi: I couldn't sleep much.
tr: I couldn't sleep much.
es: I didn't sleep much.

en: I couldn’t, somehow, for thinking.
vi: Moreover, I couldn't sleep because I had to think.
tr: My thoughts were not giving me peace.
es: I don't know why, but I couldn't, because I was thinking.

en: And every time I waked up I thought somebody had me by the neck.
vi: Every time I suddenly woke up, I felt as if someone was coming to grab my neck.
tr: Moreover, every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing my neck.
es: And every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing me by the neck.

en: So the sleep didn’t do me no good.
vi: So sleeping was of no use.
tr: Therefore, it can't really be said that I got enough sleep.
es: So the sleep was of no use to me.

en: By-and-by I says to myself, I can’t live this way; I’m a-going to find out who it is that’s here on the island with me; I’ll find it out or bust.
vi: Gradually, I told myself that I couldn't live like this, I had to find out who the person coming to live on this island with me was. I would find out, otherwise, I had to escape.
tr: I had slowly started to understand that I couldn't live like this anymore; I had to find out who else was on the island besides me; either I would find out or I would burst from curiosity.
es: After a while, I go and tell myself: "I can't keep living like this; I'm going to find out who is on the island with me; either I find out or I die."

en: Well, I felt better right off.
vi: I thought it would be better to do it right away.
tr: This firm decision brought me some relief.
es: Well, I immediately felt better.

en: So I took my paddle and slid out from shore just a step or two, and then let the canoe drop along down amongst the shadows.
vi: Then I pushed the boat away from the shore a bit, and just let it drift downstream.
tr: So I took the paddle and moved a few steps away from the shore, then the canoe already got caught in the current and started moving through the shadows.
es: So I grabbed the paddle and went down just one or two steps from the shore, and then let the canoe drift into the shadows on its own.

en: The moon was shining, and outside of the shadows it made it most as light as day.
vi: The moon was shining brightly. Except for the places with shadows, the moonlight illuminated everything as if it were daytime.
tr: The moon was shining and everywhere outside the shadows was lit up like daytime.
es: The moon was shining, and where there was no shadow it was almost like daylight.

en: I poked along well on to an hour, everything still as rocks and sound asleep.
vi: I paddled the boat for about an hour; everything was silent and asleep like stones.
tr: I drifted for an hour, but everything was as still as a rock and in a state of complete sleep.
es: I was searching for almost an hour, in a silence like a tomb, while everything slept.

en: Well, by this time I was most down to the foot of the island.
vi: This time, I had reached the other end of the island.
tr: Meanwhile, I had reached the far end of the island.
es: Well, by then I had almost reached the tip of the island.

en: A little ripply, cool breeze begun to blow, and that was as good as saying the night was about done.
vi: A gentle, cool breeze began to blow. This meant that the night was almost over.
tr: A calm and cool breeze started to blow, indicating that the night was about to end.
es: A gentle, rippling, and fresh breeze started to blow, which meant that the night was about to end.

en: I give her a turn with the paddle and brung her nose to shore; then I got my gun and slipped out and into the edge of the woods.
vi: I kicked the water with my foot, turned the boat around, and headed towards the edge of the forest.
tr: I used the paddle to turn the canoe and pressed its nose against the shore; then I got out of the canoe, took my rifle, and plunged into the forest.
es: I gave a stroke of the paddle and brought the canoe to the shore; then I took out the shotgun and slipped to the edge of the forest.

en: I sat down there on a log, and looked out through the leaves.
vi: I sat down on a fallen tree trunk, looking through the leaves.
tr: I sat on a log and looked at the sky through the leaves.
es: There I sat on a log, looking through the leaves.

en: I see the moon go off watch, and the darkness begin to blanket the river.
vi: The moon had disappeared, and darkness once again covered the river.
tr: I saw that the moon had finished its watch and the darkness was starting to cover the river like a blanket.
es: I saw that the moon was finishing its shift and that the river was starting to get dark.

en: But in a little while I see a pale streak over the treetops, and knowed the day was coming.
vi: But after a while, looking up through the treetops and seeing a faint light, I knew that dawn was approaching.
tr: But soon a pale line appearing at the tops of the trees indicated that the day was coming.
es: But after a while, I saw a pale strip above the trees and knew that day was coming.

en: So I took my gun and slipped off towards where I had run across that camp fire, stopping every minute or two to listen.
vi: I took my gun and quietly approached the spot where I had seen the campfire earlier. Every minute or two, I stopped to listen.
tr: So I took my rifle and quietly moved towards the place where I saw the campfire, stopping every two minutes to listen around.
es: So I took out the shotgun and advanced to where I had found that campfire, stopping to listen every minute or two.

en: But I hadn’t no luck somehow; I couldn’t seem to find the place.
vi: But unfortunately, I couldn't find any sign of the fire.
tr: But my luck wasn't very good, I couldn't find the place where the fire was.
es: But I don't know why I wasn't lucky; it was as if I couldn't find the place.

en: But by-and-by, sure enough, I catched a glimpse of fire away through the trees.
vi: But unfortunately, I couldn't find any sign of the fire.
tr: Then, after a while, a fire burning among the trees caught my eye.
es: But after a while, finally, I saw a remnant of the fire's glow among the trees.

en: I went for it, cautious and slow.
vi: I slowly and carefully walked to that spot.
tr: I approached there very carefully and slowly.
es: I went towards it, very carefully and calmly.

en: By-and-by I was close enough to have a look, and there laid a man on the ground.
vi: When I arrived, I saw someone lying on the ground.
tr: Finally, I got close enough to take a look and saw a man lying on the ground.
es: Soon after, I was close enough to take a look, and there was a man lying on the ground.

en: It most give me the fan-tods.
vi: I thought it was a ghost.
tr: I started trembling with fear.
es: It almost gave me a fit.

en: He had a blanket around his head, and his head was nearly in the fire.
vi: The person lying there had wrapped a piece of blanket around their head and was resting right next to the fire.
tr: He had pulled the blanket over his head and his head was almost in the fire.
es: He had his head wrapped in a blanket, right next to the fire.

en: I set there behind a clump of bushes, in about six foot of him, and kept my eyes on him steady.
vi: I stood silently behind the bushes, about a meter away from where that person was lying, and stared intently.
tr: I crouched behind the bushes about one and a half to two meters away and started watching him without taking my eyes off.
es: I sat next to some bushes about six feet from him, staring at him.

en: It was getting gray daylight now.
vi: The sky was getting light.
tr: The air had turned a bit gray and was gradually getting lighter.
es: It was already starting to get light with the gray of dawn.

en: Pretty soon he gapped and stretched himself and hove off the blanket, and it was Miss Watson’s Jim!
vi: A moment later, the person yawned, stretched, and threw off the blanket. Oh, it turned out to be Jim, the black man who worked for Miss Watson.
tr: Soon the man yawned, stretched, and pulled off the blanket, it was Miss Watson's black slave Jim in front of me!
es: Soon after, he yawned, stretched, and took off the blanket, and it was Jim, Miss Watson's Jim!

en: I bet I was glad to see him.
vi: I was really glad to see Jim here.
tr: I had never been so happy to see him.
es: Boy, was I glad to see him!

en: I says:
vi: I spoke up:
tr: Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es: I go and say:

en: “Hello, Jim!” and skipped out.
vi: - Hello Jim! Then jumped out suddenly.
tr: Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es: —Hi, Jim! —and I jumped out.

en: He bounced up and stared at me wild.
vi: Jim started and jumped up, looking at me in horror.
tr: Suddenly, he flinched and looked at me in horror.
es: He stood up abruptly and looked at me with wide eyes.

en: Then he drops down on his knees, and puts his hands together and says:
vi: Then he knelt down, clasped his hands, and said:
tr: Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands together, and began to plead:
es: Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands, and said:

en: “Doan’ hurt me—don’t!
vi: - Please don't do anything to me, don't!
tr: “Don't hurt me – please!
es: —Don't hurt me, please!

en: I hain’t ever done no harm to a ghos’.
vi: I never harm ghosts.
tr: I swear I haven't even hurt a fly.
es: I've never harmed a ghost.

en: I alwuz liked dead people, en done all I could for ’em.
vi: I always love the dead, and whatever I can do for them, I will gladly do.
tr: I have always loved the dead, and I did everything I could for them.
es: I've always been a friend to the dead and done what I could for them.

en: You go en git in de river agin, whah you b’longs, en doan’ do nuffn to Ole Jim, ’at ’uz awluz yo’ fren’.”
vi: Please go back to the river. Where did you come from, please don't do anything to poor Jim. I've always been your friend!
tr: Go, return to the riverbank, your home is there. Don't hurt poor Jim, he has been your friend.”
es: Go back to the river again, which is your place, and don't do anything to old Jim, who has always been your friend.

en: Well, I warn’t long making him understand I warn’t dead.
vi: I also didn't have to spend much time explaining to him that I wasn't dead.
tr: It didn't take me long to convince him that I wasn't dead.
es: Well, it didn't take long for me to make him understand that I wasn't dead.

en: I was ever so glad to see Jim.
vi: I was so happy to meet Jim here.
tr: Besides, I was so happy to see Jim that I could hardly contain myself.
es: He was very happy to see Jim.

en: I warn’t lonesome now.
vi: Now I am no longer lonely.
tr: I no longer felt alone.
es: I no longer felt alone.

en: I told him I warn’t afraid of him telling the people where I was.
vi: I told him that if he went and told everyone that I was here, I wouldn't be afraid.
tr: I told him that I wasn't the least bit afraid of him telling people where I was.
es: I told him that I wasn't afraid of him telling people where he had seen me.

en: I talked along, but he only set there and looked at me; never said nothing.
vi: I kept talking, but he just sat there looking at me without saying a word.
tr: I kept talking and talking, but he just sat there watching me; he didn't say a word.
es: I kept talking, but he continued sitting there, looking at me, without saying a single word.

en: Then I says:
vi: Then I told him.
tr: So I changed the subject:
es: Then I go and say:

en: “It’s good daylight.
vi: - It's morning already.
tr: "It's getting quite bright."
es: —It's already daytime.

en: Le’s get breakfast.
vi: Let's have a light meal.
tr: "Let's have breakfast."
es: Let's go look for breakfast.

en: Make up your camp fire good.”
vi: Light the fire. - Why start a fire?
tr: "Stoke the fire a bit.""
es: Stoke the fire well.

en: “What’s de use er makin’ up de camp fire to cook strawbries en sich truck?
vi: To roast some strawberries and wild herbs here?
tr: “What good is it to light a fire when there's nothing but strawberries and grass to cook?
es: —What good is it to stoke the fire to cook strawberries and things like that?

en: But you got a gun, hain’t you?
vi: But you have a gun, don't you?
tr: You have a gun, right?
es: But you have a shotgun, don't you?

en: Den we kin git sumfn better den strawbries.”
vi: We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend!
tr: We can eat something better than strawberries.”
es: That way we can eat something better than strawberries.

en: “Strawberries and such truck,” I says.
vi: We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend!
tr: “Strawberries and grass?” I said.
es: —Strawberries and things like that —I go and say—.

en: “Is that what you live on?”
vi: - Dậu with wild vegetables, oh so you live on those things?
tr: “Were you only eating these?”
es: Are you living off that?

en: “I couldn’ git nuffn else,” he says.
vi: - I couldn't find anything else
tr: "I couldn't find anything else," he said.
es: —It's the only thing I can find —he says.

en: “Why, how long you been on the island, Jim?”
vi: - Oh, so how long have you been on this island?
tr: “Why, how long have you been on the island, Jim?”
es: —But, how long have you been on the island, Jim?

en: “I come heah de night arter you’s killed.”
vi: - I came here right after the night you were killed!
tr: “I came to the bull the night you died.”
es: —The night comes after they killed you.

en: “What, all that time?”
vi: - Really, since that day until now?
tr: “What, since then?”
es: —How, so long?

en: “Yes—indeedy.”
vi: - Yes, that's right
tr: “Yeah… it really is like that.”
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “And ain’t you had nothing but that kind of rubbage to eat?”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: “Since that day, have you only been eating grass and berries?”
es: —And you haven't eaten anything other than those things?

en: “No, sah—nuffn else.”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: “There isn't, master… there's nothing else.”
es: —No, sir; nothing else.

en: “Well, you must be most starved, ain’t you?”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: "So, you must be starving now, am I wrong?""
es: —Well, you must be starving, right?

en: “I reck’n I could eat a hoss.
vi: - If I think about it now, I can eat a lot.
tr: “Honestly, I could even eat a horse.
es: —I reckon I could devour a horse.

en: I think I could.
vi: Alright, buddy.
tr: I'm that hungry.
es: Really, I could.

en: How long you ben on de islan’?”
vi: So, how long have you been on this island?
tr: How long have you been on the island?”
es: How long have you been on the island?

en: “Since the night I got killed.”
vi: - From the night I was killed
tr: "Since the night I was killed.""
es: —Since the night they killed me.

en: “No!
vi: - Oh, why is that?
tr: “Wow!
es: —No!

en: W’y, what has you lived on?
vi: Then what do you live on?
tr: So, what did you eat?
es: And, what have you lived on?

en: But you got a gun.
vi: Ah, but you have a gun.
tr: Burp, you have a gun.
es: But you have a shotgun.

en: Oh, yes, you got a gun.
vi: Yes, you have a gun.
tr: It's different with a gun, yeah.
es: Ah, yes, you have a shotgun.

en: Dat’s good.
vi: That's very good.
tr: How nice.
es: That's very good.

en: Now you kill sumfn en I’ll make up de fire.”
vi: Now you go shoot something, and I'll stay here and start a fire.
tr: Come on, you shoot something, and I'll light the fire.”
es: Now you kill something and I'll make a fire.

en: So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft.
vi: Both of us went to the place where the canoe was hidden. Then, while Jim started a fire on a patch of grass among the surrounding trees, I went to get the bacon and coffee, the coffee pot; the pan, then the sugar, and the tin cups. The black man was very frightened because he thought that all these things were the result of some witchcraft.
tr: So we went to where the cannon was, and while we were lighting a fire in a grassy area among those trees, I quickly took out cornmeal, bacon, coffee, a coffee pot, a pan, sugar, and a tin cup.
es: So we went to where the canoe was, and while he was setting up the bonfire in a clearing in the grass among the trees, I went to get flour and bacon and coffee, and a coffee pot and a pan and sugar and some tin cups, and the black man was very astonished, because he thought I did everything by witchcraft.

en: I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.
vi: I caught a big fish, and Jim used his pocket knife to clean it and then fried it.
tr: Jim was astonished because he thought I had done it all by magic. I also caught a big catfish, and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried the fish.
es: I also caught a good catfish and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried it.

en: When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot.
vi: After finishing, we just lay on the grass and ate a hot breakfast.
tr: When breakfast was ready, we settled on the grass and ate it hot.
es: When breakfast was ready, we lay down on the grass and ate it while it was still warm.

en: Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved.
vi: Jim ate vigorously because he was extremely hungry.
tr: Jim was stuffing everything into his mouth because he was about to die of hunger.
es: Jim started eating with great appetite, as he was half dead from hunger.

en: Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied.
vi: Once full, we sprawled out, not wanting to do anything else.
tr: After filling our stomachs well, we lay down and relaxed.
es: When we were full, we rested and lay down.

en: By-and-by Jim says:
vi: Then Jim said:
tr: A little later, Jim asked:
es: Shortly after, Jim goes and says:

en: “But looky here, Huck, who wuz it dat ’uz killed in dat shanty ef it warn’t you?”
vi: - But hey, Huck, if it wasn't you, then who was killed in that house?
tr: "If you weren't the one who died in that cabin, then who was it, Huck?"
es: —But, hey, Huck, who did they kill in the cabin if it wasn't you?

en: Then I told him the whole thing, and he said it was smart.
vi: At that moment, I recounted the whole story to him; he said it was truly ingenious.
tr: I told her everything, she said it was clever.
es: Then I told him the whole story and he said that I had been very clever.

en: He said Tom Sawyer couldn’t get up no better plan than what I had.
vi: He said that even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a trick better than mine.
tr: Even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine.
es: He said that Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine.

en: Then I says:
vi: I asked:
tr: Then I asked:
es: Then I go and say:

en: “How do you come to be here, Jim, and how’d you get here?”
vi: - Jim, how did you end up here, and how did you get here?
tr: “So why did you come here, Jim, and how did you get here?”
es: —And how is it that you're here, Jim, how did you get here?

en: He looked pretty uneasy, and didn’t say nothing for a minute.
vi: He seemed puzzled for a minute, saying nothing, then he replied:
tr: First, he lost his composure and didn't know what to say.
es: He seemed to get nervous and didn't say anything for a minute.

en: Then he says:
vi: He seemed puzzled for a minute, saying nothing, then he replied:
tr: Then he spoke:
es: Then he goes and says:

en: “Maybe I better not tell.”
vi: - Perhaps I shouldn't say anything, my friend
tr: "Maybe it's better if I don't say it.""
es: —Maybe it's better if I don't tell you.

en: “Why, Jim?”
vi: - What's wrong, Jim?
tr: "Why, Jim?"
es: —Why, Jim?

en: “Well, dey’s reasons.
vi: - For many reasons.
tr: "Well, it's because of the reason."
es: —Well, there are reasons.

en: But you wouldn’ tell on me ef I uz to tell you, would you, Huck?”
vi: But if I tell you, you mustn't tell anyone else, Huck!
tr: "But if you don't tell anyone, I'll tell you, okay?""
es: But you wouldn't snitch if I told you, would you, Huck?

en: “Blamed if I would, Jim.”
vi: - Jim, I swear I won't tell anyone
tr: “If I'm lying, may I lose my eyesight.””
es: —Not by these, Jim.

en: “Well, I b’lieve you, Huck.
vi: - Alright, I trust you.
tr: “Alright, I believe you, Huck.
es: —Well, I believe you, Huck.

en: I—I run off.”
vi: I... I'm going to run away.
tr: I… ran away.”
es: I... I have escaped.

en: “Jim!”
vi: - Jim!
tr: “Jim!””
es: —Jim!

en: “But mind, you said you wouldn’ tell—you know you said you wouldn’ tell, Huck.”
vi: - See, you said you wouldn't tell. You remember you promised not to tell anyone, Huck.
tr: “Remember, you said you wouldn't tell anyone... you know, you weren't supposed to tell anyone, Huck.”
es: —But remember you said you wouldn't tell... you know you said you wouldn't tell, Huck.

en: “Well, I did.
vi: - Yes, I already said that.
tr: “Alright, I said.
es: —Well, it's true.

en: I said I wouldn’t, and I’ll stick to it.
vi: I said I wouldn't talk, and I won't talk.
tr: I won't tell anyone, I said, and I won't.
es: I said no and I stand by it.

en: Honest injun, I will.
vi: I will keep my promise.
tr: Really, I will never go back.
es: Really, truly.

en: People would call me a low-down Abolitionist and despise me for keeping mum—but that don’t make no difference.
vi: Even if people call me a coward, an anti-Black oppression sympathizer, and despise me for keeping my mouth shut, it's fine, it doesn't matter.
tr: Everyone will say that I am a lowly anti-slavery person, they will hate me for staying silent… but it doesn't matter at all.
es: People will call me a damn abolitionist and despise me for not saying anything, but I don't care.

en: I ain’t a-going to tell, and I ain’t a-going back there, anyways.
vi: I will not speak. And I won't go back there either.
tr: I won't tell anyone anything, and I won't go back there anyway.
es: I'm not going to accuse you and anyway, I'm never going back there.

en: So, now, le’s know all about it.”
vi: Now, you tell me everything.
tr: Yes, now tell me everything from the beginning.”
es: So now tell me everything.

en: “Well, you see, it ’uz dis way.
vi: Here, like this, buddy.
tr: “Alright, here’s how it happened.
es: —Well, look, it happened like this.

en: Ole missus—dat’s Miss Watson—she pecks on me all de time, en treats me pooty rough, but she awluz said she wouldn’ sell me down to Orleans.
vi: My aunt, that is Mrs. Watson, keeps tormenting me all day and treating me terribly. But she still says she won't take me down to Orleans to sell me.
tr: My owner, that is, Miss Watson, was constantly scolding me and treating me badly, but she always said, ‘I won’t sell you to those folks in Orleans.’
es: The old maid, that is, Miss Watson, spends her time picking on me and treats me very badly, but she always said she wouldn't sell me in Orleans.

en: But I noticed dey wuz a nigger trader roun’ de place considable lately, en I begin to git oneasy.
vi: But I noticed that there was a new black slave trader around here last night, and I started to get scared.
tr: But in recent days, I noticed a slave trader wandering around our place, and I started to get suspicious.
es: But I noticed that there was a slave trader who spent a lot of time around the house, and I started to get nervous.

en: Well, one night I creeps to de do’ pooty late, en de do’ warn’t quite shet, en I hear old missus tell de widder she gwyne to sell me down to Orleans, but she didn’ want to, but she could git eight hund’d dollars for me, en it ’uz sich a big stack o’ money she couldn’ resis’.
vi: Then one late night, I crawled to the door, which wasn't fully closed, and I heard her telling the widow that she would take me to Orleans to sell, but she didn't want to sell me right away because she could still get eight hundred dollars more for me. With such a large amount of money, she probably couldn't resist.
tr: Anyway, one night, late at night, as I was passing by a door left ajar, I heard our old master telling the widow that he was going to sell me to those folks in Orleans; he didn’t actually want to sell me, but he could get eight hundred dollars for me, which was too much money to resist.
es: Well, one night I go up to the door very late, and the door wasn't completely closed, and I hear the old maid telling the widow that she's going to sell me in Orleans, even though she didn't want to, but that she could get eight hundred dollars for me, and it was so much money that she couldn't resist.

en: De widder she try to git her to say she wouldn’ do it, but I never waited to hear de res’.
vi: The widow wanted to tell her not to do that. But at that moment, I didn't wait to hear what happened next.
tr: The widow tried to talk him out of it, but I didn’t stay to hear more.
es: The widow tried to make her promise not to, but I didn't wait to hear the rest.

en: I lit out mighty quick, I tell you.
vi: I ran away quickly. I'm telling you the truth.
tr: I ran away immediately, just like that.
es: I assure you, I left as fast as I could.

en: “I tuck out en shin down de hill, en ’spec to steal a skift ’long de sho’ som’ers ’bove de town, but dey wuz people a-stirring yit, so I hid in de ole tumble-down cooper-shop on de bank to wait for everybody to go ’way.
vi: I ate a hearty meal and then hurried down the hill, hoping to steal a boat somewhere along the riverbank in town, but there were too many people around, so I had to hide in the old ruined tavern by the river to wait for everyone to leave.
tr: I went down the slope, intending to steal a boat and then go upstream along the shore, but the surroundings were very crowded, so I hid in the old fisherman's shop by the shore and waited for everyone to leave.
es: »I dashed downhill, hoping to steal a boat on the shore somewhere upstream from the town, but there were still people awake, so I hid in the old cooper's workshop, which is half-collapsed on the shore, to wait for everyone to leave.

en: Well, I wuz dah all night.
vi: I had to wait until the end of the year.
tr: I stayed there all night.
es: Well, I spent the night there.

en: Dey wuz somebody roun’ all de time.
vi: There were always people around.
tr: People were constantly running around the area.
es: There was always someone around.

en: ’Long ’bout six in de mawnin’ skifts begin to go by, en ’bout eight er nine every skift dat went ’long wuz talkin’ ’bout how yo’ pap come over to de town en say you’s killed.
vi: Around six o'clock, boats started passing by, and all I could hear was talk about your father going to town to report that you had been killed.
tr: Around six in the morning, boats started crossing the river, and by eight or nine, everyone in the boats was talking about your father coming to town and saying you were dead.
es: Around six in the morning, boats started passing by, and by eight or nine, all the boats that passed were saying that your father had come to town to say you had been killed.

en: Dese las’ skifts wuz full o’ ladies en genlmen a-goin’ over for to see de place.
vi: The boats that followed were all carrying distinguished gentlemen and ladies going to the scene to investigate.
tr: The last boat that passed was full of gentlemen and ladies going to see the crime scene.
es: The last boats were full of ladies and gentlemen who were going to see the place.

en: Sometimes dey’d pull up at de sho’ en take a res’ b’fo’ dey started acrost, so by de talk I got to know all ’bout de killin’.
vi: Occasionally, they would dock their boats to rest for a while before continuing on. So, by listening to their conversations, I learned the whole story about the murder.
tr: Some were pulling their boats ashore, resting a bit, and then setting off again; that’s how I learned everything about the ‘murder’.
es: Sometimes they would tie up at the shore to rest before starting the crossing, and I found out about your death from what they were saying.

en: I ’uz powerful sorry you’s killed, Huck, but I ain’t no mo’ now.
vi: When I heard you were really killed, I was heartbroken, Huck. But now, I am no longer heartbroken.
tr: I was very sad because you died, Huck, but now there's no reason to be sad anymore.
es: I felt very sorry that you had been killed, Huck, but not anymore.

en: “I laid dah under de shavin’s all day.
vi: All day long I have to hide here like this. I'm hungry but I'm not afraid.
tr: I hid and stayed in the rubble all day.
es: "I stayed hidden there all day, under the shavings and sawdust.

en: I ’uz hungry, but I warn’t afeard; bekase I knowed ole missus en de widder wuz goin’ to start to de camp-meet’n’ right arter breakfas’ en be gone all day, en dey knows I goes off wid de cattle ’bout daylight, so dey wouldn’ ’spec to see me roun’ de place, en so dey wouldn’ miss me tell arter dark in de evenin’.
vi: Because I know that Mrs. Watson and the widow will go check on that right after breakfast. That will take the whole day. And they also know that during the day I am out herding cattle, so they won't see me around here, and if they ask about me, they'll have to wait until nightfall.
tr: My ox-cart was hungry, but I wasn't afraid, because I knew that my old master and the widow would go to the church meeting right after breakfast and wouldn't return all day, and they thought I had gone to herd the cattle early in the morning, so they didn't expect to see me around, and therefore wouldn't notice my absence until it got dark.
es: I was hungry, but not scared, because I knew the old maid and the widow were going to the camp sermon shortly after breakfast and would be gone all day, and they knew I went out with the cattle at dawn, so they wouldn't expect to see me around the house and wouldn't miss me until after dark.

en: De yuther servants wouldn’ miss me, kase dey’d shin out en take holiday soon as de ole folks ’uz out’n de way.
vi: As for the other workers, no one needs me for anything, and as soon as the owners leave the house, they also sneak off to rest.
tr: The other servants wouldn't notice my absence either, because as soon as the old ladies left, they would all scatter and become invisible in the courtyard.
es: The other servants wouldn't either, because they were going to go partying as soon as the old women were out of the house.

en: “Well, when it come dark I tuck out up de river road, en went ’bout two mile er more to whah dey warn’t no houses.
vi: It was dusk when I finally ventured out; I walked along the riverbank and after a few miles reached a place with no houses at all.
tr: When the weather cleared, I went up the road along the riverbank, and about two miles up, I came to a place with no houses.
es: "Well, when it got dark, I went up the river road, about two miles or more until there were no more houses."

en: I’d made up my mine ’bout what I’s agwyne to do.
vi: I had already carefully planned in my mind what I was going to do.
tr: After that, I made a definite decision about what to do next.
es: "I had decided what I was going to do."

en: You see, ef I kep’ on tryin’ to git away afoot, de dogs ’ud track me; ef I stole a skift to cross over, dey’d miss dat skift, you see, en dey’d know ’bout whah I’d lan’ on de yuther side, en whah to pick up my track.
vi: You see, if I just kept walking, dogs could track me down by scent; if I stole a boat to cross the river, they would notice the missing boat, figure out where I crossed, and then trace my footprints.
tr: I continued to run on foot, then the dogs started chasing me; if I were to steal a boat and cross to the other side, they would notice the absence of the boat and realize that I had crossed to the other side.
es: "I mean, if I tried to escape on foot, the dogs would find me; if I stole a boat to cross, it would be missed, you understand, and they would know I was going to the other side and where to look for my trail."

en: So I says, a raff is what I’s arter; it doan’ make no track.
vi: So I thought using a raft would be the best option, as it wouldn't leave any traces.
tr: Thus, they would find my trail.
es: "So I say: 'What I need is a raft; that leaves no tracks.'"

en: “I see a light a-comin’ roun’ de p’int bymeby, so I wade’ in en shove’ a log ahead o’ me en swum more’n half way acrost de river, en got in ’mongst de drift-wood, en kep’ my head down low, en kinder swum agin de current tell de raff come along.
vi: Then at that moment, a light shone, and I grabbed a floating plank in front of me, swimming out to the middle of the river; I blended in with the driftwood floating on the river, pulled my neck back, and kept swimming downstream for a long distance along with the floating rafts.
tr: Therefore, the only solution was to get on a raft, then there would be no trace left behind. I saw a light approaching from the direction I was hiding, so I immediately dived into the water and pushed a log in front of me to help me swim. In this way, I swam to the middle of the river, then I climbed onto a drifting tree branch; without ever raising my head, I swam against the current until a raft came.
es: "I saw a light passing by the tip, so I got in and pushed a log in front of me and swam more than half of the river and got in among the timber that was floating down, with my head low, and kind of swam upstream until the raft appeared."

en: Den I swum to de stern uv it en tuck a-holt.
vi: Then I kept swimming like that, pulling in a few more logs with the plank for security.
tr: Then I swam to the starboard side and caught the raft.
es: "Then I swam to the stern to grab on."

en: It clouded up en ’uz pooty dark for a little while.
vi: At that time, the clouds gathered and darkened the sky for a while.
tr: Shortly after, the moon went behind the clouds and the surroundings darkened.
es: "Clouds came and it was dark for a while."

en: So I clumb up en laid down on de planks.
vi: I climbed up and lay on the plank in the area where the light was still on and people were passing by.
tr: Taking advantage of this opportunity, I climbed onto the raft and lay down.
es: "So I climbed up to lie down on the planks."

en: De men ’uz all ’way yonder in de middle, whah de lantern wuz.
vi: The river water was rising rapidly and flowing swiftly.
tr: All the men on the raft were far away, in the middle of the raft, sleeping next to the fire.
es: "The men were all in the middle, where the lantern was."

en: De river wuz a-risin’, en dey wuz a good current; so I reck’n’d ’at by fo’ in de mawnin’
vi: I estimated that by around four in the morning, I would have floated twenty-five miles downstream; I would then swim to the shore before dawn.
tr: The river was rising and there was quite a current; I calculated that we would reach about twenty-five miles downstream by around four in the morning.
es: "The river was rising and there was a good current, so I thought that by four in the morning I would be twenty-five miles downstream and then I would get back into the water before swimming again and getting into the woods on the Illinois side."

en: I’d be twenty-five mile down de river, en den I’d slip in jis b’fo’ daylight en swim asho’, en take to de woods on de Illinois side.
vi: Then I went into the forest towards Illinois.
tr: Before sunrise, I dived into the water and swam to the shore to hide in the forest on the Illinois side of the river.
es: "The river was rising and there was a good current, so I thought that by four in the morning I would be twenty-five miles downstream and then I would get back into the water before swimming again and getting into the woods on the Illinois side."

en: “But I didn’ have no luck.
vi: But truly, I was unlucky.
tr: But my luck did not go well.
es: "But I wasn't lucky."

en: When we ’uz mos’ down to de head er de islan’ a man begin to come aft wid de lantern, I see it warn’t no use fer to wait, so I slid overboard en struck out fer de islan’.
vi: Just as I reached the edge of the island, there was a person holding a lantern behind me. Seeing that I couldn't delay, I immediately plunged into the water, leaving the island to swim elsewhere.
tr: When we came to almost the other side of the island, the men took a boat and approached my side; there was no point in waiting, so I quietly slipped into the water and started swimming towards the island.
es: "When we had almost reached the tip of the island, a man started coming aft with the lantern." "I saw that it was useless to wait, so I let myself fall and swam to the island."

en: Well, I had a notion I could lan’ mos’ anywhers, but I couldn’t—bank too bluff.
vi: It was terrifying; I thought I could get ashore anywhere, but no, the riverbank was steep everywhere.
tr: Actually, I thought I could climb the rock from any part of the island, but no, the shore was very steep and rocky.
es: "Well, I thought I could touch the bottom almost anywhere, but no; the shore was too steep."

en: I ’uz mos’ to de foot er de islan’ b’fo’ I found’ a good place.
vi: When I swam close to the other end of the island, I found a good spot.
tr: I came all the way to the tip of the island to find a good place.
es: "I had to go almost to the end of the island before finding a good spot."

en: I went into de woods en jedged I wouldn’ fool wid raffs no mo’, long as dey move de lantern roun’ so.
vi: I went into the forest, thinking that I couldn't continue using the raft, because drifting like that, I would surely encounter the light.
tr: I decided to go straight into the forest and not to get involved with any more boats, especially if there were men with guns in them, I wouldn't even approach them.
es: "I went into the forest and thought I wouldn't get on any more rafts while they kept walking around with the lantern."

en: I had my pipe en a plug er dog-leg, en some matches in my cap, en dey warn’t wet, so I ’uz all right.”
vi: I had a pipe and a torn tobacco pouch with some matches in my shirt that hadn't gotten wet, so I felt reassured.
tr: I had a pipe and some tobacco with me, and there were a few matches left in my hat, my situation wasn't too bad."
es: "I had the pipe and a bit of tobacco in my cap that hadn't gotten wet, so there was no problem."

en: “And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time?
vi: - So, from that day until now, you haven't had any meat or cake to eat?
tr: “So, you haven't had any meat or bread to eat since then?
es: —So you haven't eaten either meat or bread all this time?

en: Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”
vi: Why don't you find some roots in the mud to eat?
tr: Why didn't you catch a turtle?”
es: Why didn't you look for river turtles?

en: “How you gwyne to git ’m?
vi: - How can I get it?
tr: “How do you catch it?
es: —And how was I supposed to catch them?

en: You can’t slip up on um en grab um; en how’s a body gwyne to hit um wid a rock?
vi: How can I retrieve it? What can I do with just a stone in my hand?
tr: If you can't catch up and grab it, how do you manage to hit it with a stone?
es: You can't just pounce on them and grab them; and, how are you supposed to kill them with a stone?

en: How could a body do it in de night?
vi: And at night, how can I get it?
tr: Especially at night, how do you do it?
es: How do you do that at night?

en: En I warn’t gwyne to show mysef on de bank in de daytime.”
vi: During the day, I don't dare go to the riverbank for fear of being seen. - Ah, I see, so you have to stay in the forest all day long.
tr: If it's daytime, I must not show myself by the shore, oh no.”
es: And I wasn't going to let them see me on the shore during the day.

en: “Well, that’s so.
vi: That's right.
tr: “So that's how it is.
es: —Well, it's true.

en: You’ve had to keep in the woods all the time, of course.
vi: Did you hear them firing cannons?
tr: Of course, you had to spend all your time in the forest.
es: Of course, you had to stay in the forest the whole time.

en: Did you hear ’em shooting the cannon?”
vi: Did you hear them firing cannons?
tr: Did you hear the sound of the cannons?”
es: Did you hear how they fired the cannon?

en: “Oh, yes.
vi: - Yes, I do.
tr: “Ah, yes.
es: —Ah, yes.

en: I knowed dey was arter you.
vi: I know they are looking for you.
tr: I understood that you were the lord.
es: I knew they were looking for you.

en: I see um go by heah—watched um thoo de bushes.”
vi: I saw them passing by here. I hid in the bushes and watched.
tr: I saw you going down the river... I followed you from behind the bushes.”
es: I saw them pass by here... I watched them through the bushes.

en: Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting.
vi: A few young birds here flew over, only flying short distances of a few yards before perching again.
tr: Young birds appeared around, flying a meter or two and landing on branches.
es: Some little birds passed by, flying a yard or two each time and then landing again.

en: Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain.
vi: Jim said it was a sign of rain.
tr: Jim said this was a sign that it would rain.
es: Jim said it was a sign that it was going to rain.

en: He said it was a sign when young chickens flew that way, and so he reckoned it was the same way when young birds done it.
vi: He said that when chicks fly erratically, it means rain is coming, so seeing birds fly like that also made him predict rain.
tr: When chicks flew like this, it meant rain, so he guessed it would mean the same for other young birds as well.
es: He said that it meant the same thing when chicks did it, so he thought it was the same when little birds did it.

en: I was going to catch some of them, but Jim wouldn’t let me.
vi: I intended to catch a few birds, but Jim wouldn't let me.
tr: I wanted to catch a few, but Jim didn't allow it.
es: I was going to hunt some, but Jim didn't let me.

en: He said it was death.
vi: He said doing so would bring death.
tr: He said it was akin to death.
es: He said it brought death.

en: He said his father laid mighty sick once, and some of them catched a bird, and his old granny said his father would die, and he did.
vi: He said that his father once fell seriously ill, and when someone else caught birds, his father told him that doing so would cause his father to die. And indeed, he died.
tr: Once, his father had gotten very sick, and when someone caught a bird, his old grandmother said his father would die, and indeed, he did.
es: He said that his father got very sick once and someone in his family caught a bird and his grandmother said that his father would die and that's what happened.

en: And Jim said you mustn’t count the things you are going to cook for dinner, because that would bring bad luck.
vi: Jim also said that one should not plan ahead what to cook for dinner, as it would bring bad luck.
tr: Also, Jim said that you shouldn't count the things you eat in the evening, because it brings bad luck.
es: And Jim said that one shouldn't talk about the things one was going to cook for dinner, because it brought bad luck.

en: The same if you shook the table-cloth after sundown.
vi: And shaking out the tablecloth at sunset is the same.
tr: The same thing happens if you shake the tablecloth after sunset.
es: The same as if one shook the tablecloth after nightfall.

en: And he said if a man owned a beehive and that man died, the bees must be told about it before sun-up next morning, or else the bees would all weaken down and quit work and die.
vi: He also said that when the sun rises the next morning, the bees would already know. If not, the bees would fall ill, refuse to work, and eventually die.
tr: And if a man has a beehive, when that man dies, you need to inform the bees before the sun rises the next morning, otherwise all the bees will weaken, stop working, and die.
es: And he said that if a man had a beehive and that man died, one had to tell the bees before the sun rose again the next morning, because if not, the bees would get sick and stop working and die.

en: Jim said bees wouldn’t sting idiots; but I didn’t believe that, because I had tried them lots of times myself, and they wouldn’t sting me.
vi: Jim said that bees never sting fools. But I don't believe that, because I've tried it several times and still haven't been stung.
tr: Jim also said that bees don't sting fools, but I didn't believe it, because I had dealt with them many times and they hadn't stung me.
es: Jim said that bees didn't sting idiots, but I didn't believe it, because I had messed with them dozens of times and they never stung me.

en: I had heard about some of these things before, but not all of them.
vi: Before that, I had heard about those things but hadn't heard everything.
tr: Some of the things you told me I had heard before, but I hadn't heard all of them.
es: Some of those things I had already heard before, but not all of them.

en: Jim knowed all kinds of signs.
vi: Jim knew the omens.
tr: Jim knew all kinds of signs.
es: Jim knew a bunch of those signs.

en: He said he knowed most everything.
vi: He said he knew most of them.
tr: He said he knew almost everything.
es: He said he knew almost all of them.

en: I said it looked to me like all the signs was about bad luck, and so I asked him if there warn’t any good-luck signs.
vi: I said it seemed to me that all the omens were bad, so I asked Jim if there were any good omens.
tr: Upon this, I said that apparently all signs bring bad luck and asked if there were any signs that bring good luck.
es: I said that it seemed to me that all the signs brought bad luck, so I asked him if there was any sign of good luck.

en: He says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: He said:
es: And he goes and says:

en: “Mighty few—an’ dey ain’t no use to a body.
vi: - Very little.
tr: “Very little… and even that is of no use to anyone.
es: —Very few, and they are of no use to anyone.

en: What you want to know when good luck’s a-comin’ for?
vi: And those things are of no use to anyone.
tr: Why do you care so much about when luck will smile on you?
es: Why do you want to know when good luck is coming?

en: Want to keep it off?”
vi: Why do you want to know, do you want to keep it?
tr: Is it to keep luck away from yourself?”
es: Do you want it not to come? —and he added—:

en: And he said: “Ef you’s got hairy arms en a hairy breas’, it’s a sign dat you’s agwyne to be rich.
vi: Then Jim said again: - If you have a lot of hair on your arms and chest, it's a sign that you're about to get rich.
tr: He also added: “If your arms and chest are hairy, then you will either soon or eventually become rich.
es: If you have hairy arms and a hairy chest, it's a sign that you are going to be rich.

en: Well, dey’s some use in a sign like dat, ’kase it’s so fur ahead.
vi: Such an omen can be useful; the more hair you have, the luckier you are.
tr: This is such a sign that brings luck, but sometimes it can take a very long time to come.
es: Well, that is worth something, because it is always for a long time in the future.

en: You see, maybe you’s got to be po’ a long time fust, en so you might git discourage’ en kill yo’sef ’f you didn’ know by de sign dat you gwyne to be rich bymeby.”
vi: You see, at first, you might be poor. But if you don't know in advance that it's a sign you'll become rich, you might get discouraged and commit suicide.
tr: Do you understand? Maybe at first, you need to wait a long time, so you don't recognize the sign and don't know the signs that will make you rich, God forbid, you might even end up in despair and kill yourself.”
es: You know, maybe you have to be poor for a long time first, and then you might get discouraged and kill yourself, if you didn't know from that sign that in time you are going to be rich.

en: “Have you got hairy arms and a hairy breast, Jim?”
vi: - Do you have a lot of arm hair, Jim?
tr: “Are your arms and chest hairy, Jim?”
es: —Do you have hair on your arms and chest?

en: “What’s de use to ax dat question?
vi: - What's the point of asking that, can't you see I'm here?.
tr: “Is this what you call cold?
es: —And why are you asking me that?

en: Don’t you see I has?”
vi: - What's the point of asking that, can't you see I'm here?.
tr: Can't you see that it is?”
es: Can't you see that I am?

en: “Well, are you rich?”
vi: - Yeah, so are you rich?
tr: “So, are you rich?”
es: —Well, are you rich?

en: “No, but I ben rich wunst, and gwyne to be rich agin.
vi: - No, I was rich once before, and I will be rich again.
tr: “No, but once I was rich, and I will be rich again.
es: —No, but I was rich once and I will be again.

en: Wunst I had foteen dollars, but I tuck to specalat’n’, en got busted out.”
vi: Once I had fourteen dollars, but I went into speculative trading, and unfortunately lost it all.
tr: At one point, I had fourteen shops, I got into trading, and eventually, I went bankrupt.”
es: Once I had fourteen dollars, but I got into speculating and ruined myself.

en: “What did you speculate in, Jim?”
vi: - Speculating on what, Jim?
tr: “What were you buying and selling, Jim?”
es: —What did you speculate on, Jim?

en: “Well, fust I tackled stock.”
