vi: - First of all, it's about stockpiling
tr: “Well, at first I got into the business of buying and selling animals.”
es: —Well, I started with stocks.

en: “What kind of stock?”
vi: - Hoarding what?
tr: “What kind of animal?”
es: —What kind of values?

en: “Why, live stock—cattle, you know.
vi: - And what else - livestock, you know.
tr: “Farm animal.
es: —Well, real assets: you know, livestock.

en: I put ten dollars in a cow.
vi: I spent ten dollars to buy a cow.
tr: Just the usual cattle and such. I invested ten dollars in a cow.
es: I invested ten dollars in a cow.

en: But I ain’ gwyne to resk no mo’ money in stock.
vi: But then I almost had nothing left because as soon as I got the cow, it died.
tr: But I won't risk more money in the animal business.
es: But I won't risk money on assets again.

en: De cow up ’n’ died on my han’s.”
vi: But then I almost had nothing left because as soon as I got the cow, it died.
tr: The cow soon died.”
es: The cow went and died on me.

en: “So you lost the ten dollars.”
vi: - So you lost ten dollars, huh?
tr: “So you lost ten dollars.”
es: —So, you lost the ten dollars.

en: “No, I didn’t lose it all.
vi: - No, I didn't lose all ten đồng, I only lost nearly nine đồng.
tr: “No, I didn't lose all of them.
es: —No, I didn't lose them all.

en: I on’y los’ ’bout nine of it.
vi: Because I sold the cowhide for one đồng.
tr: I only lost about nine of them.
es: Just about nine.

en: I sole de hide en taller for a dollar en ten cents.”
vi: - So you have five and a half dimes left.
tr: I sold the animal's skin and fat for about ten cents.”
es: I sold the skin and the tail for a dollar and ten cents.

en: “You had five dollars and ten cents left.
vi: - So you have five and a half dimes left.
tr: "So, you have five dollars and ten cents left."
es: —You had five dollars and ten cents left.

en: Did you speculate any more?”
vi: Do you have anything else to speculate on?
tr: "Did you trade with this again?""
es: Did you keep speculating?

en: “Yes.
vi: - Yes, of course.
tr: “Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: You know that one-laigged nigger dat b’longs to old Misto Bradish?
vi: Do you know the black cripple who works for Mr. Bradish?
tr: You know Old Mr. Bradish’s one-legged Negro, right?
es: Do you remember that black man of old Mr. Bradish who only has one leg?

en: Well, he sot up a bank, en say anybody dat put in a dollar would git fo’ dollars mo’ at de en’ er de year.
vi: He just started a bank. He says that whoever puts in one dollar can take out four dollars at the end of the year. So all the black folks are putting their money in there.
tr: Well, he started a bank and said that whoever deposits a dollar will earn an extra four dollars by the end of the year.
es: Well, he set up a bank and said that anyone who deposited a dollar would receive four more dollars at the end of the year.

en: Well, all de niggers went in, but dey didn’t have much.
vi: But they don't have much anyway.
tr: All the Negroes deposited their money in this bank, but they didn't have much money.
es: Well, all the black people deposited, but they didn't have much.

en: I wuz de on’y one dat had much.
vi: Only the evening is the most.
tr: I was the only one who had that much money.
es: I was the only one who had it.

en: So I stuck out for mo’ dan fo’ dollars, en I said ’f I didn’ git it I’d start a bank mysef.
vi: I put in more than four dollars, and I said if it doesn't work out, I'll start my own bank.
tr: So I wanted to get more than four dollars in interest, otherwise I said I would start my own bank.
es: So I deposited more than four dollars and said that if he didn't give me what I was owed, I would open my own bank.

en: Well, o’ course dat nigger want’ to keep me out er de business, bekase he says dey warn’t business ’nough for two banks, so he say I could put in my five dollars en he pay me thirty-five at de en’ er de year.
vi: Of course, that black guy doesn't want me to get involved because he says if there are two banks, there won't be enough to run the business. So he told me I could put in a handful of dollars and by the end of the year, he'd pay me back thirty-five dollars.
tr: Of course, that Negro wanted to keep me out of it, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he said if you deposit five dollars in my bank, then at the end of the year you'll get thirty-five dollars.
es: Well, of course that black man didn't want me to compete with him, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he says I could put in my five dollars and he would pay me thirty-five at the end of the year.

en: “So I done it.
vi: So I put the money in.
tr: I also made the payment.
es: »So that's what I did.

en: Den I reck’n’d I’d inves’ de thirty-five dollars right off en keep things a-movin’.
vi: I figured that afterward, I would invest those fifteen dollars again to grow the capital even more.
tr: So, after that, I was going to make thirty-five more payments and run my business.
es: Then I thought I would invest the thirty-five dollars to keep things moving.

en: Dey wuz a nigger name’
vi: There was another black man named Bob who had just acquired a wooden house that his landlord didn't know about, so I bought it from him and told him that by the end of the year, he would come to collect thirty-five dollars.
tr: Bob, a black man, caught a chest of money and his owner didn't know about it; so I bought it from him and promised to transfer thirty-five dollars to him by the end of the year, but that night someone stole the chest of money and the next day a one-legged black man said the bank went bankrupt.
es: There was a black man named Bob who had a flatboat and his master didn't know about it, and I bought it from him and told him I would give him the thirty-five dollars at the end of the year; but someone stole the boat that night and the next day the lame black man said the bank had failed, so we all ended up without the money.

en: Bob, dat had ketched a wood-flat, en his marster didn’ know it; en I bought it off’n him en told him to take de thirty-five dollars when de en’ er de year come; but somebody stole de wood-flat dat night, en nex day de one-laigged nigger say de bank’s busted.
vi: But that night, someone had already stolen that house. The next day, the limping black man came and told me that the bank had also collapsed.
tr: Bob, a black man, caught a chest of money and his owner didn't know about it; so I bought it from him and promised to transfer thirty-five dollars to him by the end of the year, but that night someone stole the chest of money and the next day a one-legged black man said the bank went bankrupt.
es: There was a black man named Bob who had a flatboat and his master didn't know about it, and I bought it from him and told him I would give him the thirty-five dollars at the end of the year; but someone stole the boat that night and the next day the lame black man said the bank had failed, so we all ended up without the money.

en: So dey didn’ none uv us git no money.”
vi: So none of us got our money back.
tr: So none of us got five cents.”
es: There was a black man named Bob who had a flatboat and his master didn't know about it, and I bought it from him and told him I would give him the thirty-five dollars at the end of the year; but someone stole the boat that night and the next day the lame black man said the bank had failed, so we all ended up without the money.

en: “What did you do with the ten cents, Jim?”
vi: - So what did you do with the remaining ten cents, Jim?
tr: “So what did you do with the ten cents, Jim?”
es: —What did you do with the ten cents, Jim?

en: “Well, I ’uz gwyne to spen’ it, but I had a dream, en de dream tole me to give it to a nigger name’
vi: - Well, at that moment I was about to spend those ten cents when I suddenly had a dream, and the dream told me that I should give those ten cents to a black man named Balum Balum, they called him Ass for short.
tr: “Actually, I wanted to spend it, but I supposedly saw in a dream that I had to give the money to a black man named Balum – everyone just calls him Balum’s Donkey, he’s a bit slow in the head.
es: —Well, I was going to spend it, but I had a dream and the dream told me to give it to a black man named Balum, who they call Balum's Donkey; you know, one of those half-wits, but they say he's lucky, and it was already clear that I wasn't.

en: Balum—Balum’s
vi: - Well, at that moment I was about to spend those ten cents when I suddenly had a dream, and the dream told me that I should give those ten cents to a black man named Balum Balum, they called him Ass for short.
tr: “Actually, I wanted to spend it, but I supposedly saw in a dream that I had to give the money to a black man named Balum – everyone just calls him Balum’s Donkey, he’s a bit slow in the head.
es: —Well, I was going to spend it, but I had a dream and the dream told me to give it to a black man named Balum, who they call Balum's Donkey; you know, one of those half-wits, but they say he's lucky, and it was already clear that I wasn't.

en: Ass dey call him for short; he’s one er dem chuckleheads, you know.
vi: He was one of the very foolish people, you know?
tr: “Actually, I wanted to spend it, but I supposedly saw in a dream that I had to give the money to a black man named Balum – everyone just calls him Balum’s Donkey, he’s a bit slow in the head.
es: —Well, I was going to spend it, but I had a dream and the dream told me to give it to a black man named Balum, who they call Balum's Donkey; you know, one of those half-wits, but they say he's lucky, and it was already clear that I wasn't.

en: But he’s lucky, dey say, en I see I warn’t lucky.
vi: But he often got lucky, they said so, I didn't know. As for me, I never got lucky.
tr: But everyone says he’s lucky, and I’m not lucky at all.
es: —Well, I was going to spend it, but I had a dream and the dream told me to give it to a black man named Balum, who they call Balum's Donkey; you know, one of those half-wits, but they say he's lucky, and it was already clear that I wasn't.

en: De dream say let Balum inves’ de ten cents en he’d make a raise for me.
vi: The dream told me that Balum would take my ten cents to invest and would make me rich. So I gave the money to Balum.
tr: In the dream, it was said that if Balum took the ten cents, he would return the money to me.
es: The dream says that Balum should invest the ten cents and make them grow.

en: Well, Balum he tuck de money, en when he wuz in church he hear de preacher say dat whoever give to de po’ len’ to de Lord, en boun’ to git his money back a hund’d times.
vi: When he went to church, he heard the pastor say that whoever put money into this box for God would be rewarded a hundredfold by God.
tr: Balum took the money and went to church, and the preacher there said that whoever gives their money to the poor is actually giving it to God, and in the end, their money will return a hundredfold.
es: Well, Balum took the money, and when he was in church, he heard the preacher say that whoever gives to the poor lends to the Lord and in time would receive the money multiplied by a hundred.

en: So Balum he tuck en give de ten cents to de po’, en laid low to see what wuz gwyne to come of it.”
vi: So Balum took out ten cents from his pocket and put it right into the box. Then he bent down to see if there was anything in the box that would be given back to him.
tr: So Balum gave the ten cents to the poor and started waiting for his money to return.”
es: So Balum goes and gives the ten cents to the poor and waits to see what happens.

en: “Well, what did come of it, Jim?”
vi: - Well, is there anything you can give back?
tr: “So, did the money increase, Jim?”
es: —Well, and, what happened, Jim?

en: “Nuffn never come of it.
vi: - There isn't, I don't see anything at all.
tr: “No, it never happened.
es: —Nothing happened.

en: I couldn’ manage to k’leck dat money no way; en Balum he couldn’.
vi: I also don't know how to get that money back anymore. Balum also gave up.
tr: There was no way for me to get that money, and Balum couldn't do it either.
es: I couldn't get him to return that money to me at all, and neither could Balum.

en: I ain’ gwyne to len’ no mo’ money ’dout I see de security.
vi: Well, I won't lend money anymore if I'm not sure.
tr: If I were in his place, I wouldn't give my money without securing my position.
es: I'm not going to lend any more money until they give me a guarantee.

en: Boun’ to git yo’ money back a hund’d times, de preacher says!
vi: It will be returned a hundredfold the amount spent! The pastor said so!
tr: The preacher said, 'You will definitely get a hundred times more money!'
es: And the preacher said they would return the money to you a hundred times over!

en: Ef I could git de ten cents back, I’d call it squah, en be glad er de chanst.”
vi: If I get those ten cents back, it's considered even, and that would already be very lucky.
tr: Even if I got my ten cents back, that would be enough, I was very happy with my luck.”
es: If he returned the ten cents to me, we would be even and I would be so happy.

en: “Well, it’s all right anyway, Jim, long as you’re going to be rich again some time or other.”
vi: - Well Jim, it's alright, because there will be times when you'll be rich later on.
tr: “Never mind, Jim, just let it go, you are going to be rich one day anyway.”
es: —Well, Jim, it doesn't matter anyway, if you're going to be rich again sooner or later.

en: “Yes; en I’s rich now, come to look at it.
vi: - Yes, now I am rich, come near my house and see.
tr: “Yes… actually, if you look at it, I am rich now too.
es: —Yes, and I'm already rich if you think about it.

en: I owns mysef, en I’s wuth eight hund’d dollars.
vi: I already have my own body. My body is worth eight hundred dollars.
tr: I own myself and I am worth exactly eight hundred dollars.
es: I own myself and I'm worth eight hundred dollars.

en: I wisht I had de money, I wouldn’ want no mo’.”
vi: Before, I only wished for money, but now I don't care anymore.
tr: If only I had that money, I wouldn't want anything else.”
es: I wish I had the money; I wouldn't want anything more.

en: CHAPTER
vi: Chapter IX
tr: Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 9

en: IX.
vi: Chapter IX
tr: When I set out to explore the island, there was a place I found right in the middle; now I wanted to take a look at it.
es: Chapter 9

en: I wanted to go and look at a place right about the middle of the island that I’d found when I was exploring; so we started and soon got to it, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide.
vi: I want to go back and see the place right in the middle of the island that I discovered while exploring. Both of us went together and found it immediately, because the island is only three miles long and a quarter mile wide.
tr: We set out towards this place and soon found where it was, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter mile wide.
es: I FELT LIKE GOING to find a place that was towards the center of the island and that I had seen when I was exploring, so we set off and soon arrived, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide.

en: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high.
vi: This place is a high mound, more than ten meters high, both long and steep.
tr: This was quite a long and steep hill or ridge, and its height was about 12 meters.
es: That place was a rather long and steep hill, about forty feet high.

en: We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick.
vi: We climbed to the top of the mound with quite a bit of difficulty, because the slopes on both sides were steep and the bushes were very dense.
tr: We had quite a hard time climbing the hill; the slope was very steep, and the bushes were very dense.
es: It was hard for us to get to the top, as the sides were steep and the trees were thick.

en: We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top on the side towards Illinois.
vi: We had to take each step around the mound, and after a while, we found a large cave in the rock face, extending all the way to the top towards the Illinois shore.
tr: By holding on and climbing, we explored every part of the ridge and finally found a huge cave near the top on the Illinois side.
es: We searched everywhere and finally found a good cave in the rock, almost at the very top, on the side facing Illinois.

en: The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it.
vi: The cave was as wide as two or three rooms combined, and Jim could stand upright in it.
tr: The cave was the size of two or three rooms, and Jim could stand upright inside it.
es: The cave was as big as two or three rooms together, and Jim could stand up without hitting the ceiling.

en: It was cool in there.
vi: This place is very cold.
tr: It was cooler inside compared to outside.
es: It was cool.

en: Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
vi: Jim wanted to bring our belongings here right away, but I said there was no point in climbing up and down all day.
tr: Jim immediately wanted to move the stuff there, but I said that going up and down the cave every time wouldn't be convenient for us.
es: Jim was in favor of storing our traps there immediately, but I told him it wouldn't be convenient to keep going up and down all the time.

en: Jim said if we had the canoe hid in a good place, and had all the traps in the cavern, we could rush there if anybody was to come to the island, and they would never find us without dogs.
vi: Jim said that we had a boat hidden in a secret place, and the belongings were stored in this cave, so if anyone came to the island, we could escape into here. And if they didn't bring dogs, they wouldn't be able to find us.
tr: Jim said that if we hide the canoe in a good place and move all the belongings to the cave, we can immediately hide in the cave when someone comes to the island, and without the dogs, they would never find us.
es: Jim said that if we had the canoe hidden in a good spot and had all the traps in the cave, we could hide in it quickly if someone came to the island, and that without dogs they would never find us.

en: And, besides, he said them little birds had said it was going to rain, and did I want the things to get wet?
vi: Jim also said that the young birds had predicted it was going to rain, so how could we let our belongings get all wet?
tr: Moreover, the baby birds had said it was going to rain, or did I want everything to get wet?
es: And, besides, he said that the little birds had said it was going to rain and, did I want all our things to get wet?

en: So we went back and got the canoe, and paddled up abreast the cavern, and lugged all the traps up there.
vi: So we returned to the boat, pushed it up to the shore near the cave, and carried all our belongings into the cave.
tr: Upon this, we went back and got the canoe, paddled to the cave's level, and then carried all our belongings into the cave.
es: So we went back, took out the canoe, and arrived in front of where the cave was and brought all the traps there.

en: Then we hunted up a place close by to hide the canoe in, amongst the thick willows.
vi: Then we found a spot nearby to hide the boat, concealing it in a dense willow bush.
tr: Then, we searched for a nearby spot among the dense willows where we could hide the canoe.
es: Then we looked for a place nearby to hide the canoe, among the large willows.

en: We took some fish off of the lines and set them again, and begun to get ready for dinner.
vi: We retrieved a few fish from the end of the line, then cast the hook back into the water and began preparing lunch.
tr: We took out a few fish from the fishing lines and cast the lines back, then started preparing dinner.
es: Some fish had bitten on the lines; we caught them, rebaited the hooks, and started preparing for dinner.

en: The door of the cavern was big enough to roll a hogshead in, and on one side of the door the floor stuck out a little bit, and was flat and a good place to build a fire on.
vi: The store is quite spacious, enough to roll a large barrel of wine into it. On one side of the store, there is a flat protruding piece of land that can be used as a very good kitchen.
tr: The mouth of the cave was wide enough to fit a large barrel inside, and the ledge next to the entrance was flat enough to light a fire.
es: The entrance of the cave was large enough to fit a barrel, and on one side of the entrance, the floor was a bit higher and smooth, meaning it was a good spot to light a fire.

en: So we built it there and cooked dinner.
vi: We set up the kitchen to cook lunch.
tr: So we lit the fire there and cooked our meal.
es: So we lit it there and prepared dinner.

en: We spread the blankets inside for a carpet, and eat our dinner in there.
vi: We spread the blanket inside to use as a mat to sit on and eat.
tr: We threw a blanket inside as a carpet and ate our meal on it.
es: Inside, we spread the blankets to serve as a carpet and to eat there.

en: We put all the other things handy at the back of the cavern.
vi: All the easily accessible items were also kept inside.
tr: We also put everything useful at the back of the cave.
es: We placed everything else within reach at the back of the cave.

en: Pretty soon it darkened up, and begun to thunder and lighten; so the birds was right about it.
vi: A while later, the sky darkened and it began to thunder and lightning; those birds had indeed predicted it accurately.
tr: Before long, it got dark, thunder started rumbling, and lightning began flashing; it seemed the birds were right.
es: Soon after, it got dark and started to thunder and lightning, meaning the birds were right.

en: Directly it begun to rain, and it rained like all fury, too, and I never see the wind blow so.
vi: Immediately, it started to rain heavily, pouring down like a waterfall, and I had never seen the wind blow so fiercely.
tr: Suddenly, a downpour began, it was as if the sky had burst open, I had never seen the wind blow so hard.
es: Immediately after, it began to rain heavily, and I have never seen the wind blow like that.

en: It was one of these regular summer storms.
vi: It was a typical summer storm.
tr: A full-blown summer storm had erupted.
es: It was one of those good summer storms.

en: It would get so dark that it looked all blue-black outside, and lovely; and the rain would thrash along by so thick that the trees off a little ways looked dim and spider-webby; and here would come a blast of wind that would bend the trees down and turn up the pale underside of the leaves; and then a perfect ripper of a gust would follow along and set the branches to tossing their arms as if they was just wild; and next, when it was just about the bluest and blackest—fst!
vi: As the sky grew darker, everything outside took on a beautiful bluish-purple hue. The rain poured down so heavily that even the tops of the tall trees became indistinct; they looked just like spider webs. Then, with each gust of wind, those trees were bent over and the pale gray color beneath the branches changed. Then another, even fiercer gust of wind came, forcing the branches to stretch out like the arms of wild animals.
tr: You know, it gets so dark that the outside turns into a strange navy blue, creating a magnificent scene, the rain pours down so heavily that even the trees a short distance away become blurry, as if hiding behind a spider web. Sometimes, with a strong gust, the trees bend and the light-colored undersides of the leaves are revealed. As the wind intensifies, all the tree branches sway wildly. Then everything is cloaked in the darkest navy blue, but with the sudden splitting of the sky, everything turns white.
es: It was so dark that outside everything seemed a beautiful blue-black, and the rain fell so densely that the trees a short distance away looked like cobweb-like shadows, and gusts of wind came that bent the trees and made the leaves lift from the pale underside, and then came a fierce gust that made the branches wave their arms as if they had gone mad, and then, when it was at its bluest and blackest, whoosh!

en: it was as bright as glory, and you’d have a little glimpse of tree-tops a-plunging about away off yonder in the storm, hundreds of yards further than you could see before; dark as sin again in a second, and now you’d hear the thunder let go with an awful crash, and then go rumbling, grumbling, tumbling, down the sky towards the under side of the world, like rolling empty barrels down stairs—where it’s long stairs and they bounce a good deal, you know.
vi: After that, when everything had turned completely blue and purple, suddenly - oh my; it brightened up, and during that storm, if you looked at the distant treetops, you could see them hundreds of meters farther away than before; then in just a second, it became pitch dark again; at that moment, you could hear the thunder roaring terrifyingly, followed by rumbling sounds gradually descending from above and traveling to the other side of the world, just like the sound of an empty barrel rolling down a long staircase, with the same rumbling noise.
tr: Far away, even hundreds of meters further than before, the tops of the trees can be seen flapping in the wind. Again, everything turns pitch black, then a crackling sound erupts, turning into a rumble and descending to the ground with a growl, echoing downwards as if rolling barrels down a staircase, of course, the stairs here are quite high and the barrels make a lot of noise.
es: There was a glow like glory and the treetops swaying in the distance in the middle of the storm, hundreds of yards farther than what could be seen before; they turned black as sin in a second and then the thunder returned with a terrifying drumroll that continued growling, rolling, and staggering across the sky to the other side of the world, as if barrels were being rolled down stairs, you know, very long stairs where the barrels bounce a lot.

en: “Jim, this is nice,” I says.
vi: I said: - It's so fun, Jim!
tr: “Isn't it beautiful, Jim,” I said.
es: —Jim, this is very good —I said—.

en: “I wouldn’t want to be nowhere else but here.
vi: I just want to stay here and not go anywhere.
tr: “I wouldn't want to be anywhere else right now.
es: I wouldn't want to be anywhere else in the world.

en: Pass me along another hunk of fish and some hot corn-bread.”
vi: Give me a piece of fish and a hot piece of bread.
tr: Pass me another piece of fish and some of that hot cornbread.”
es: Give me another piece of fish and some hot cornbread.

en: “Well, you wouldn’t a ben here ’f it hadn’t a ben for Jim.
vi: - You see, if it weren't for Jim, you wouldn't have come up to this cave, and you would be in that forest with nothing to eat, and you might have drowned too.
tr: "If it weren't for Jim, you would have been in big trouble with this mistake.
es: —Well, you wouldn't be here if it weren't for Jim.

en: You’d a ben down dah in de woods widout any dinner, en gittn’ mos’ drownded, too; dat you would, honey.
vi: - You see, if it weren't for Jim, you wouldn't have come up to this cave, and you would be in that forest with nothing to eat, and you might have drowned too.
tr: If you were down there now, you would have been hungry, almost drowned, you would have perished, my dear.
es: You'd be out there in the forest and almost drowned; I assure you, my boy.

en: Chickens knows when it’s gwyne to rain, en so do de birds, chile.”
vi: Chicks know when it's about to rain, and so do baby birds.
tr: Chickens know when the rain is coming, birds know too, my child."
es: Chickens know when it's going to rain and birds do too, boy.

en: The river went on raising and raising for ten or twelve days, till at last it was over the banks.
vi: The river water kept rising, continuously for ten to twelve days, overflowing onto the banks.
tr: For twelve days, the river rose and finally overflowed its banks.
es: The river kept rising for ten or twelve days until it began to flood the banks.

en: The water was three or four foot deep on the island in the low places and on the Illinois bottom.
vi: The water flooded the island, reaching over a meter in low areas and at the head of the island towards the Illinois shore.
tr: In the low-lying areas of the island and at the Illinois end, the depth reached one meter.
es: The water was three or four feet deep on the island in the low-lying areas and on the Illinois shore.

en: On that side it was a good many miles wide, but on the Missouri side it was the same old distance across—a half a mile—because the Missouri shore was just a wall of high bluffs.
vi: On that side, the island was several miles wide, but on the Missouri side, it was about half a mile because the Missouri shore was like a large vertical wall.
tr: On the Illinois side, the river had reached a width of miles; but on the Missouri side, the distance was still the same – about half a mile – because the Missouri shore consisted of steep cliff walls.
es: In that part, it measured many miles in width, but on the Missouri side, it was the same distance as always —half a mile— because the Missouri shore was like a wall of cliffs.

en: Daytimes we paddled all over the island in the canoe, It was mighty cool and shady in the deep woods, even if the sun was blazing outside.
vi: During the day, we could paddle the boat all around the island. The weather was quite cold. In the deep forest, it was even darker, although it was still sunny outside. We maneuvered the boat between the tree trunks.
tr: During the day, we would explore every part of the island by canoe. Despite the sun being bright and scorching, the depths of the forest were very cold and dark.
es: During the day, we would paddle around the island in the canoe. In the middle of the forest, it was very cool and there was always shade, even if outside the sun was burning us.

en: We went winding in and out amongst the trees, and sometimes the vines hung so thick we had to back away and go some other way.
vi: In many places, grapevines hung down, obstructing the way, so we had to turn back and find another route.
tr: We would weave in and out of the trees; sometimes the branches were so dense that we had to turn back and find another path.
es: We would go winding between the trees, and sometimes the vines were so thick that we had to backtrack and find another path.

en: Well, on every old broken-down tree you could see rabbits and snakes and such things; and when the island had been overflowed a day or two they got so tame, on account of being hungry, that you could paddle right up and put your hand on them if you wanted to; but not the snakes and turtles—they would slide off in the water.
vi: In places where fallen trees lay, there could be rabbits, snakes, and other animals. Whenever the island was flooded for a few days, those animals became very tame because they were too hungry. At that time, you could paddle the boat right up to them and catch them with your hand. But with snakes and turtles, it wasn't possible because they would dive to the bottom of the water.
tr: On every fallen rotten tree, you could see rabbits, snakes, and other animals; after the island had been submerged for a day or two, the animals had become tame from hunger, and if you wanted, you could go right up to them and touch them; of course, except for the snakes and turtles – they would slip into the water immediately.
es: Well, in every old hollow tree, you could see rabbits and snakes and such things, and when the island had been flooded for one or two days, they were so tame from hunger that you could approach them and pet them if you wanted, but not the snakes or the turtles, which would slip away into the water.

en: The ridge our cavern was in was full of them.
vi: In one spot in the cave, we also had many of these creatures, and if we wanted to catch and raise them, we could get plenty.
tr: The ridge where our cave was located was filled with animals.
es: The hill where our cave was located was full of them.

en: We could a had pets enough if we’d wanted them.
vi: In one spot in the cave, we also had many of these creatures, and if we wanted to catch and raise them, we could get plenty.
tr: If we wanted, we could have had a lot of domestic animals.
es: We could have had plenty of pets if we had wanted to.

en: One night we catched a little section of a lumber raft—nice pine planks.
vi: One night we salvaged an entire section of a wooden raft, made entirely of pine planks.
tr: One night we caught a small piece of a raft made from a tree trunk – it was beautiful pine lumber.
es: One night we took a piece of a log raft: good pine logs.

en: It was twelve foot wide and about fifteen or sixteen foot long, and the top stood above water six or seven inches—a solid, level floor.
vi: It was three meters wide, four to five meters long, and up to twenty centimeters thick. This wood is very sturdy for flooring.
tr: It was six meters wide and four and a half to five meters long, with fifteen to twenty centimeters of it above the water, and its surface was flat and solid.
es: It measured twelve feet wide and fifteen or sixteen feet long, and the highest part was six or seven inches above the water: a solid and level surface.

en: We could see saw-logs go by in the daylight sometimes, but we let them go; we didn’t show ourselves in daylight.
vi: During the day, we also saw many pieces of wood that had been sawed off floating by, but we let them drift away; because during the day we didn't dare to go outside.
tr: During the day, we also saw logs coming out of the sawmill, but we let them go; we didn't show ourselves during the daytime.
es: Sometimes we saw sawn logs passing by in the daylight, but we let them pass, because we never went out during the day.

en: Another night when we was up at the head of the island, just before daylight, here comes a frame-house down, on the west side.
vi: One night, when we reached the edge of the island near dawn, we saw an entire wooden house from upstream drifting to the western shore.
tr: One night just before dawn, while we were at the front side of the island, we saw that a wooden house was drifting on the west side.
es: Another night, when we were at the tip of the island, just before dawn, a wooden house appeared on the west side.

en: She was a two-story, and tilted over considerable.
vi: The house had an attic; it was tilted and about to collapse.
tr: The house was two stories high and was leaning quite a bit.
es: It had two floors and was very tilted.

en: We paddled out and got aboard—clumb in at an upstairs window.
vi: We rowed the boat out, jumped on, and climbed through the attic window to get inside.
tr: We quickly rowed towards the house – we climbed up to a window on the upper floor.
es: We rowed over and climbed aboard: we got in through one of the upstairs windows.

en: But it was too dark to see yet, so we made the canoe fast and set in her to wait for daylight.
vi: We then tied the boat to it and sat waiting for daylight.
tr: But it was still very dark inside, so we tied the canoe to a secure spot and waited for daylight.
es: But it was still too dark to see, so we tied up the canoe and sat waiting for dawn.

en: The light begun to come before we got to the foot of the island.
vi: The house drifted to the head of the island as the sky began to lighten.
tr: Before we reached the end of the island, it started to get light.
es: The light began to arrive before we reached the other end of the island.

en: Then we looked in at the window.
vi: From outside the window, we looked in and saw a bed, a table, two old chairs, and on the attic floor, there were many other things; clothes were also hanging on the wall.
tr: Then we looked inside through the window.
es: Then we looked out the window.

en: We could make out a bed, and a table, and two old chairs, and lots of things around about on the floor, and there was clothes hanging against the wall.
vi: From outside the window, we looked in and saw a bed, a table, two old chairs, and on the attic floor, there were many other things; clothes were also hanging on the wall.
tr: Inside, there was a bed, a table, two old chairs, and a lot of stuff scattered on the floor; we also saw clothes hanging on the wall.
es: We saw a bed and a table and two old chairs and piles of things scattered on the floor, and there were clothes hanging next to the wall.

en: There was something laying on the floor in the far corner that looked like a man.
vi: There was something lying on the floor in the corner of the house that looked like a person.
tr: In the other corner of the room, something resembling a man was lying on the floor.
es: In the farthest corner of the floor, there was something that looked like a man.

en: So Jim says:
vi: Jim called out:
tr: Jim called out to him:
es: So Jim says:

en: “Hello, you!”
vi: - Hey! Hey!
tr: "Hey, sen!"
es: —Hey, you!

en: But it didn’t budge.
vi: There was no movement.
tr: But there was no movement.
es: But he did not move.

en: So I hollered again, and then Jim says:
vi: I called again. Then Jim said:
tr: This time I called out, then Jim turned to me:
es: So I shouted again, and then Jim says:

en: “De man ain’t asleep—he’s dead.
vi: - This person is not sleeping, but dead.
tr: “Adam is not sleeping… he is dead.
es: —That one is not asleep: he is dead.

en: You hold still—I’ll go en see.”
vi: You stay here, let me go in and check.
tr: You stay here… I will go and check.”
es: You stay there, I'm going to check.

en: He went, and bent down and looked, and says:
vi: Jim walked in, bent down to look, and then said:
tr: He went over to the man, leaned in, and after looking carefully, he called out:
es: He approached, bent down to look, and said:

en: “It’s a dead man.
vi: - One person is dead.
tr: “The man is dead.
es: —He is dead.

en: Yes, indeedy; naked, too.
vi: That's right, and they are naked too.
tr: Yes, for real, and naked too.
es: Yes, sir; and naked.

en: He’s ben shot in de back.
vi: They were shot in the back.
tr: He was shot in the back.
es: He has been shot in the back.

en: I reck’n he’s ben dead two er three days.
vi: I'm sure they've been dead for two or three days now.
tr: He's probably been lying there for two or three days.
es: I estimate he has been dead for two or three days.

en: Come in, Huck, but doan’ look at his face—it’s too gashly.”
vi: Come in, Huck, but don't look at their face, it's got many cuts, very gruesome.
tr: Go inside Huck, but don't look at the man's face, because it's a horrible sight.”
es: Come, Huck, but don't look at his face. It's too horrible.

en: I didn’t look at him at all.
vi: I didn't dare to look.
tr: I didn't look at the man at all.
es: I didn't look at all.

en: Jim throwed some old rags over him, but he needn’t done it; I didn’t want to see him.
vi: Jim threw the torn clothes over the dead body. But why did he have to do that? I didn't want to see the dead body anyway.
tr: Jim covered the corpse with a few rags, but he didn't need to; I didn't want to see it.
es: Jim threw some old rags over it, but it wasn't necessary; I didn't want to see it.

en: There was heaps of old greasy cards scattered around over the floor, and old whisky bottles, and a couple of masks made out of black cloth; and all over the walls was the ignorantest kind of words and pictures made with charcoal.
vi: There was a pile of old, dirty cards scattered on the floor, some whiskey bottles, a few masks made of black cloth; and on the walls, there were scribbles and poorly written words drawn with charcoal everywhere.
tr: Worn-out, greasy playing cards were scattered on the ground, there were old whiskey bottles around, and I also saw a few masks made of black cloth; there were also crudely drawn words and pictures on the walls made with charcoal.
es: All over the floor were scattered piles of old, greasy playing cards, old whiskey bottles, and a couple of masks made of black cloth, and the walls were full of the clumsiest signs and drawings, made with charcoal.

en: There was two old dirty calico dresses, and a sun-bonnet, and some women’s underclothes hanging against the wall, and some men’s clothing, too.
vi: There were two old thick fabric shirts, a sun hat, some women's underwear hanging on the wall, and some men's pants too.
tr: Two old and dirty calico dresses, a sun hat, and women's underwear were hanging on the wall; there were also men's clothes.
es: There were two old dresses made of dirty calico and a bonnet and some women's underwear hanging next to the wall, and also men's clothing.

en: We put the lot into the canoe—it might come good.
vi: We picked them all up and put them in the boat to use later.
tr: We carried everything to the canoe, it might come in handy.
es: We put everything in the canoe: it might be useful.

en: There was a boy’s old speckled straw hat on the floor; I took that, too.
vi: There was also a child's hat on the floor, which I picked up as well.
tr: There was an old, dirty straw boy's hat on the ground; I took that too.
es: On the floor, I found an old straw hat for a boy; I picked it up too.

en: And there was a bottle that had had milk in it, and it had a rag stopper for a baby to suck.
vi: Then there was a bottle of milk with some milk left in it, and a torn rubber baby bottle nipple.
tr: There was milk in a bottle; also, a cloth stopper was made at the mouth for the baby to suck on.
es: And there was also a bottle with milk and a cloth stopper for a baby to suck on.

en: We would a took the bottle, but it was broke.
vi: We intended to take the bottle of milk but it was already spoiled.
tr: We were going to take the bottle, but we saw it was broken.
es: We would have taken the bottle, but it was broken.

en: There was a seedy old chest, and an old hair trunk with the hinges broke.
vi: There was an old, tattered trunk and a woven hair chest with broken hinges.
tr: There was an old, shabby console and a chest with broken hinges.
es: There was an old, damaged dresser and an old trunk with broken locks.

en: They stood open, but there warn’t nothing left in them that was any account.
vi: Both were wide open, but inside there was nothing of value.
tr: Both were open, but there was nothing of value left inside.
es: They were open, but there was nothing left worth taking.

en: The way things was scattered about we reckoned the people left in a hurry, and warn’t fixed so as to carry off most of their stuff.
vi: From the way the furniture was scattered around, we guessed that someone had fled in a hurry and didn't have the presence of mind to take everything with them.
tr: Judging by how things were scattered around, people had left the house in a hurry and hadn't had time to take most of their belongings.
es: From the way things were scattered, we figured that the people had left in a hurry, without time to take most of their belongings.

en: We got an old tin lantern, and a butcher-knife without any handle, and a bran-new Barlow knife worth two bits in any store, and a lot of tallow candles, and a tin candlestick, and a gourd, and a tin cup, and a ratty old bedquilt off the bed, and a reticule with needles and pins and beeswax and buttons and thread and all such truck in it, and a hatchet and some nails, and a fishline as thick as my little finger with some monstrous hooks on it, and a roll of buckskin, and a leather dog-collar, and a horseshoe, and some vials of medicine that didn’t have no label on them; and just as we was leaving I found a tolerable good curry-comb, and Jim he found a ratty old fiddle-bow, and a wooden leg.
vi: We found an old iron lamp, a meat cleaver without a handle, and a new Barlow-style dagger, which would cost at least two dimes at any store; along with a bunch of tallow candles, an iron candlestick; an iron cup, then a blanket still usable but gnawed by mice, a small bag for sewing supplies complete with waxed needles, a hook as small as my little finger but with large hooks, a roll of buckskin, a dog collar, a horseshoe, and some bottles of medicine without any labels.
tr: An old tin lantern, a butcher knife without a handle, a brand new Barlow knife that you could buy from any store for just two bits, a bunch of tallow candles, a tin candle holder, a gourd, a tin cup, an old quilt we took from the bed, a handbag containing needles, beeswax, buttons, and thread, a small hatchet and some nails, some fishing line almost as thick as my little finger and large fish hooks attached to the line, a rolled-up deer skin, a leather dog collar, a horseshoe, a few medicine bottles without labels; and just as we were leaving, a nice currycomb caught my eye. Jim also found an old violin bow and a wooden prosthetic leg.
es: We took an old tin lantern and a butcher knife without a handle and a brand-new Barlow knife that would be worth twenty-five cents in any store and a bunch of tallow candles; a tin candlestick and a canteen; a tin cup and an old frayed bed quilt; a sewing kit with needles and pins and beeswax and buttons and thread and all those things; an axe and some nails and a fishing line as thick as my little finger with some huge hooks; a roll of buckskin and a leather dog collar and a lock and many medicine bottles that had no labels, and when we were leaving I found a pretty good currycomb and Jim an old worn-out violin bow and a wooden leg.

en: The straps was broke off of it, but, barring that, it was a good enough leg, though it was too long for me and not long enough for Jim, and we couldn’t find the other one, though we hunted all around.
vi: Just as we were about to leave, we found a fairly good horse brush. Jim also picked up an old, broken woman's comb and a wooden leg. The leather straps were all broken, but if tied back together, they were still usable, although they were too long for me and a bit short for Jim. After searching around, we couldn't find the other leg.
tr: The straps of the prosthetic leg were broken, but other than that, it looked like a good leg, though it was too long for me, too short for Jim, and despite searching everywhere, we couldn't find the other leg.
es: The suspenders had fallen off, but other than that it was a pretty good leg, although too long for me and not long enough for Jim, and we couldn't find the other one, even though we searched everywhere.

en: And so, take it all around, we made a good haul.
vi: So we made a big haul and carried everything away.
tr: Thus, overall, we had done a good job.
es: So, overall, we got a good load.

en: When we was ready to shove off we was a quarter of a mile below the island, and it was pretty broad day; so I made Jim lay down in the canoe and cover up with the quilt, because if he set up people could tell he was a nigger a good ways off.
vi: As we were about to leave the house, we realized we had drifted a quarter of a mile downstream from the island, and it was already daylight, so I told Jim to lie down in the boat and cover himself with a blanket. Because if Jim sat up, people would immediately recognize him as a runaway black man.
tr: By the time we were ready to leave the house, we had reached about a quarter mile down the island, and it was midday; so I told Jim to lie down inside the canoe and covered him with a blanket, because if he sat up, people could tell from a long distance that he was a black man.
es: When we were ready to leave, we were already a quarter of a mile below the island and it was broad daylight, so I had Jim lie down in the canoe and cover himself with the quilt, because if he sat up, people could see from afar that he was black.

en: I paddled over to the Illinois shore, and drifted down most a half a mile doing it.
vi: I rowed the boat towards the Illinois shore, drifting another half mile further. When we reached calm waters, I started rowing back upstream.
tr: I rowed towards the Illinois shore, but while doing so, I had drifted nearly half a mile.
es: I paddled to the Illinois side and meanwhile gained half a mile drifting.

en: I crept up the dead water under the bank, and hadn’t no accidents and didn’t see nobody.
vi: Nothing happened and there was no one around.
tr: As I came back up from the still water along the shore, nothing happened to me, nor did I see anyone.
es: I went up the still waters under the bank and had no accidents nor hurt anyone.

en: We got home all safe.
vi: We returned home safely.
tr: We had returned home completely safe.
es: We got home safe and sound.

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: Chapter X
tr: Tenth Chapter
es: Chapter 10

en: After breakfast I wanted to talk about the dead man and guess out how he come to be killed, but Jim didn’t want to.
vi: After finishing breakfast, I wanted to talk about the dead person in that floating house and guess why they were killed. But Jim didn't like talking about it.
tr: After breakfast, I wanted to talk about the dead man and ponder together how he was killed, but Jim objected.
es: AFTER BREAKFAST I wanted to talk about the dead man and speculate on how he might have been killed, but Jim didn't want to.

en: He said it would fetch bad luck; and besides, he said, he might come and ha’nt us; he said a man that warn’t buried was more likely to go a-ha’nting around than one that was planted and comfortable.
vi: Jim said talking about it would bring bad luck, and moreover, the dead person might come back. Jim said that the dead who are not buried tend to come back more often than those who are properly buried.
tr: Such conversations would bring bad luck; moreover, the man could come and haunt us, he said that the likelihood of an unburied man haunting people was much higher compared to a properly buried man resting peacefully in his grave.
es: He said it brought bad luck, and besides, he said, it could come to haunt us, because a man who wasn't buried had more chances of going around as a ghost than one well planted and comfortable.

en: That sounded pretty reasonable, so I didn’t say no more; but I couldn’t keep from studying over it and wishing I knowed who shot the man, and what they done it for.
vi: That made sense, so I didn't say anything more; but I couldn't stop thinking about it, wanting to know who shot that person and why?
tr: There was some truth in what Jim said, so I didn't insist, but this matter continued to bother me, I was curious about who killed the man and why.
es: That seemed quite reasonable, so I didn't say more, but I couldn't stop thinking about it or wanting to know who had shot that man and why.

en: We rummaged the clothes we’d got, and found eight dollars in silver sewed up in the lining of an old blanket overcoat.
vi: We rummaged through the clothes we brought back and found eight silver dollars sewn into the hem of an outer garment.
tr: When we thoroughly examined the clothes we had bought, we found eight silver dollars sewn into an old coat.
es: We searched through the clothes we had taken with us and found eight dollars in coins sewn into the lining of an old overcoat.

en: Jim said he reckoned the people in that house stole the coat, because if they’d a knowed the money was there they wouldn’t a left it.
vi: Jim said that perhaps the person in that house stole the garment, because if they knew there was money, they wouldn't have left it behind.
tr: Jim said that the people in that house had stolen the coat because if they had known the money was there, they would have definitely taken the coat with them when they left.
es: Jim said that he thought the people in the house had stolen the overcoat, because if they had known the money was there, they wouldn't have left it.

en: I said I reckoned they killed him, too; but Jim didn’t want to talk about that.
vi: I said maybe they were hiding that person here, but Jim still didn't want to talk about it.
tr: I said that I thought they had also killed the owner of the coat, but Jim didn't want to talk about it.
es: I said that surely they had also killed him, but Jim didn't want to talk about that.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: Then I said:
es: I go and say:

en: “Now you think it’s bad luck; but what did you say when I fetched in the snake-skin that I found on the top of the ridge day before yesterday?
vi: - You said it was bad luck; so what do you say about me finding a snake skin on top of the hill the day before yesterday?
tr: “You say this will bring bad luck; but what did you say when I brought the snake skin I found on the top of your back not yesterday, but the day before?
es: —Well, you think it brings bad luck, but what did you say when I brought the snake skin I found on the hill yesterday?

en: You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake-skin with my hands.
vi: Didn't you say that touching a snake skin would bring the worst luck in the world?
tr: Holding a snake skin with your hand would bring the greatest misfortune in the world, you said.
es: You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake skin with your hands.

en: Well, here’s your bad luck!
vi: Well, here's the bad luck; we found so many things, and even got eight dollars.
tr: Well, here's your bad luck!
es: Well, look at the bad luck!

en: We’ve raked in all this truck and eight dollars besides.
vi: Well, here's the bad luck; we found so many things, and even got eight dollars.
tr: We found a lot of things, and eight dollars to boot.
es: We have brought all this and on top of that eight dollars.

en: I wish we could have some bad luck like this every day, Jim.”
vi: I wish we could have this kind of bad luck every day, Jim!
tr: I wish we had such bad luck every day.”
es: I wish we had such bad luck every day, Jim.

en: “Never you mind, honey, never you mind.
vi: - Don't think so, my friend, don't think so.
tr: "Don't worry at all, my dear, don't worry at all.
es: —Don't think anymore, my child, don't think anymore.

en: Don’t you git too peart.
vi: Don't celebrate too soon.
tr: This luck won't last long.
es: Don't get too excited.

en: It’s a-comin’.
vi: You will see.
tr: Soon something will happen to us.
es: It will come.

en: Mind I tell you, it’s a-comin’.”
vi: Remember, you will see, I'm telling you the truth.
tr: Don't forget what I said, it's imminent."
es: Remember what I tell you, it will come.

en: It did come, too.
vi: Indeed, the misfortune really came.
tr: He really did come.
es: And yes, it did arrive.

en: It was a Tuesday that we had that talk.
vi: We talked about that story on the third day.
tr: It was Tuesday when we had this conversation.
es: It was a Tuesday when we talked about it.

en: Well, after dinner Friday we was laying around in the grass at the upper end of the ridge, and got out of tobacco.
vi: Then on the sixth day, after dinner, we were lying on the grass on the hilltop, and having run out of cigarettes, I went back to the cave to get some and suddenly saw a snake lying there.
tr: On Friday, while lying on the grass at the upper end of the ridge, I ran out of tobacco.
es: Well, on Friday after lunch we were lying on the grass at the top of the hill and we ran out of tobacco.

en: I went to the cavern to get some, and found a rattlesnake in there.
vi: Then on the sixth day, after dinner, we were lying on the grass on the hilltop, and having run out of cigarettes, I went back to the cave to get some and suddenly saw a snake lying there.
tr: When I went to the cave to get some, I encountered a rattlesnake.
es: I went to the cave to look for something and I came across a rattlesnake.

en: I killed him, and curled him up on the foot of Jim’s blanket, ever so natural, thinking there’d be some fun when Jim found him there.
vi: I killed the snake immediately, but I coiled it up and threw it under the blanket where Jim was lying. It was just a prank, thinking that Jim would be scared when he unexpectedly saw it, and I would get a good laugh.
tr: I killed the snake and coiled it up at the foot of Jim's blanket. I did this quite naturally, thinking we would have a laugh when Jim found it.
es: I killed it and coiled it at the foot of Jim's blanket, very naturally, thinking how much fun it would be when Jim found it.

en: Well, by night I forgot all about the snake, and when Jim flung himself down on the blanket while I struck a light the snake’s mate was there, and bit him.
vi: But at night, I had forgotten about the snake, and just as Jim crawled into the blanket and I lit the lamp, the female snake, which had been there for some time, bit Jim immediately.
tr: By evening, I had forgotten about the snake, and as I was lighting the lamp, Jim threw himself onto the blanket, and the snake's mate bit him.
es: Well, at night I forgot about the snake, and when Jim lay down on the blanket while I was lighting a lantern, there was the snake's mate and it bit him.

en: He jumped up yelling, and the first thing the light showed was the varmint curled up and ready for another spring.
vi: Jim jumped up and screamed, I shone the light and saw the female snake coiling up, ready to strike again.
tr: Jim jumped into the air with a shout, and the first thing I saw in the light was a coiled snake ready to strike again.
es: He jumped and screamed, and the first thing we saw in the light was the creature coiled and ready to strike again.

en: I laid him out in a second with a stick, and Jim grabbed pap’s whisky-jug and begun to pour it down.
vi: I grabbed a stick and struck it dead with one blow, while Jim grabbed my father's whiskey bottle and poured it down his throat.
tr: I killed it in one swift motion with the stick in my hand, and Jim grabbed my father's whiskey bottle and started drinking.
es: I killed it in a second with a stick and Jim grabbed father's jug of whiskey and began to pour it.

en: He was barefooted, and the snake bit him right on the heel.
vi: Jim was barefoot, and the snake had bitten him right on the heel.
tr: Because he walked barefoot, a snake had bitten him on the heel.
es: He was barefoot and the snake had bitten him on the heel.

en: That all comes of my being such a fool as to not remember that wherever you leave a dead snake its mate always comes there and curls around it.
vi: I realized how foolish I was for not remembering that after killing one snake and leaving it there, its mate would come and coil up beside it.
tr: It was all because I acted like a complete fool. Wherever you leave a dead snake, its mate will come and coil up next to it. How could I have forgotten this!
es: And all that because I had been so stupid that I didn't remember that whenever you kill a snake, its mate always appears and coils around it.

en: Jim told me to chop off the snake’s head and throw it away, and then skin the body and roast a piece of it.
vi: Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it far away, then skin it and roast a piece, saying that would neutralize the venom.
tr: Jim asked me to cut off the snake's head and then skin the rest and cook a bit of it.
es: Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it away, then skin the body and roast a piece.

en: I done it, and he eat it and said it would help cure him.
vi: Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it far away, then skin it and roast a piece, saying that would neutralize the venom.
tr: I did as he said, he ate the snake meat and said it would help him heal.
es: That's what I did, and he ate it and said it would help cure him.

en: He made me take off the rattles and tie them around his wrist, too.
vi: He also told me to take the rings from the tails of both snakes and tie them around my wrist.
tr: He also had me remove the snake's rattle and tie it to his wrist.
es: He made me remove the rattles and tie them to his wrist.

en: He said that that would help.
vi: Jim said that would make everything alright.
tr: This would also work.
es: He said that would also relieve him.

en: Then I slid out quiet and throwed the snakes clear away amongst the bushes; for I warn’t going to let Jim find out it was all my fault, not if I could help it.
vi: Then he quietly went outside, threw the bodies of the two snakes far into the bushes; because I wasn't foolish enough to play with them.
tr: After that, I quietly went outside and threw the snake carcasses far away into the bushes; because I was determined to do everything I could so that Jim wouldn't learn it was all my fault.
es: Then I went out quietly and threw the snakes far away into the bushes, because I wasn't going to let Jim find out that it was all my fault if I could help it.

en: Jim sucked and sucked at the jug, and now and then he got out of his head and pitched around and yelled; but every time he come to himself he went to sucking at the jug again.
vi: Jim gulped down the liquor, gulped it down again, occasionally stretching his neck, shaking his head, and howling; but after each time returning to normal, he would gulp down the liquor again.
tr: Jim was constantly drinking, occasionally losing control and attacking and shouting at those around him, but every time he came to his senses, he would drink a little more from the bottle.
es: Jim sucked and sucked from the demijohn and occasionally he would get furious and writhe, screaming, but every time he came to, he would suck from the jug again.

en: His foot swelled up pretty big, and so did his leg; but by-and-by the drunk begun to come, and so I judged he was all right; but I’d druther been bit with a snake than pap’s whisky.
vi: Jim's foot swelled up very quickly, then his calf too. Gradually the liquor took effect and I thought Jim would be fine. But I also thought that being bitten by a snake would be better than gulping down my father's whiskey.
tr: His foot was quite swollen, and his leg was in bad shape, but then gradually the alcohol took effect, so I thought he was fine; but if it were me, I would prefer to draw snake venom rather than drink my father's whiskey.
es: His foot swelled up a lot and the same happened to his leg. But after a while, he started to get drunk, so I thought he was okay, although I would have preferred to be bitten by a snake than to have my father's whiskey.

en: Jim was laid up for four days and nights.
vi: Jim lay bedridden for four days and nights.
tr: Jim couldn't get up for four days and nights.
es: Jim lay down for four days and nights.

en: Then the swelling was all gone and he was around again.
vi: Then the swelling disappeared and Jim was able to walk again.
tr: But then the swelling went down and he started walking around again.
es: Then the swelling disappeared, and he started walking again.

en: I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever take a-holt of a snake-skin again with my hands, now that I see what had come of it.
vi: I thought to myself that from now on, I would definitely not touch the shed snake skin anymore, because I had seen how harmful it could be.
tr: I decided never to hold a snake skin with my hand again, now that I knew what it could lead to.
es: I decided that I would never again touch a snake skin with my hands, now that I had seen what happened.

en: Jim said he reckoned I would believe him next time.
vi: Jim said that he hoped I would believe him from now on.
tr: Jim said he hoped I would believe him next time.
es: Jim said he figured that next time I would believe him because touching snake skins brought so much bad luck that it might not even be over yet.

en: And he said that handling a snake-skin was such awful bad luck that maybe we hadn’t got to the end of it yet.
vi: Then he reiterated that touching the shed snake skin was extremely unlucky, and perhaps we hadn't yet realized how harmful it could be.
tr: Holding a snake skin was such terrible bad luck that he expected other things to happen too.
es: Jim said he figured that next time I would believe him because touching snake skins brought so much bad luck that it might not even be over yet.

en: He said he druther see the new moon over his left shoulder as much as a thousand times than take up a snake-skin in his hand.
vi: Jim said he would rather glance at the crescent moon over his left shoulder a thousand times than hold the shed snake skin in his hand.
tr: He said he would prefer to look at the new moon over his left shoulder a thousand times rather than hold a snake skin with his hand.
es: He said he would rather see the new moon over his left shoulder a thousand times than touch a snake skin with his hand.

en: Well, I was getting to feel that way myself, though I’ve always reckoned that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder is one of the carelessest and foolishest things a body can do.
vi: I felt the same way, because I also understood that looking at the crescent moon over one's left shoulder was one of the most careless and foolish things that no one ever did.
tr: I had started to think like him, although I always thought that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder was one of the most thoughtless and foolish things a person could do.
es: Well, I was also beginning to think the same, although I have always thought that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder is one of the silliest and most absurd things you can do.

en: Old Hank Bunker done it once, and bragged about it; and in less than two years he got drunk and fell off of the shot-tower, and spread himself out so that he was just a kind of a layer, as you may say; and they slid him edgeways between two barn doors for a coffin, and buried him so, so they say, but I didn’t see it.
vi: Old man Huck Bunker once did that and kept boasting about it. Yet, in less than twenty years, he got drunk and fell from a high platform to the ground, lying flat like a log used to wedge a tree stump, so to speak; then they had to carry him through the window to put him in a coffin for burial.
tr: Old Hank Bunker did it once, and even bragged about it; within two years, he got drunk one day, fell from a shot tower, and hit the ground so hard he was almost flat; they say they buried him between two big doors instead of a coffin; I didn't see it.
es: Old Hank Bunker did it once and bragged a lot about it, and less than two years later he got drunk, fell from the water tower, and was so flattened that he looked like a sheet, so to speak, and they had to put him sideways between two barn doors instead of a coffin and buried him that way, they say, but I don't believe it.

en: Pap told me.
vi: That's what they said, I hadn't seen it with my own eyes. My father said so too.
tr: My father told me.
es: My father told me, but anyway, that's what happens when you look at the moon like that, like an idiot.

en: But anyway it all come of looking at the moon that way, like a fool.
vi: Anyway, it was because the old man dared to look at the moon in such a way. Truly foolish.
tr: Anyway, this happened to him because he foolishly looked at the moon that way.
es: My father told me, but anyway, that's what happens when you look at the moon like that, like an idiot.

en: Well, the days went along, and the river went down between its banks again; and about the first thing we done was to bait one of the big hooks with a skinned rabbit and set it and catch a catfish that was as big as a man, being six foot two inches long, and weighed over two hundred pounds.
vi: Day by day, the river water receded and lay between the two banks. The first thing we did was bait a big hook with a skinned rabbit. We cast the bait and caught a giant fish as big as a person, nearly two meters long and weighing almost a hundred pounds.
tr: Days later, the river receded to its old banks, and the first thing we did was bait one of the huge fishing hooks with a skinned rabbit and set a trap to catch a catfish almost as tall as a man. This fish, nearly two meters long, weighed almost ninety kilos.
es: Well, the days went by and the river flowed again between its banks, and one of the first things we did was bait one of the big hooks with a skinned rabbit and cast it, and we caught a catfish as big as a man, because it measured six feet and two inches and weighed more than two hundred pounds.

en: We couldn’t handle him, of course; he would a flung us into Illinois.
vi: We couldn't pull the fish up, and who knows, it might have dragged us all the way to Illinois.
tr: Of course, we couldn't hold it directly; it could have flung us all the way to Illinois.
es: Of course, we couldn't pull it in, because it would have dragged us to Illinois.

en: We just set there and watched him rip and tear around till he drownded.
vi: We had no choice but to leave it there and watch it thrash until it died.
tr: We just stood and watched it thrash and tear around until it drowned.
es: We sat watching it thrash and struggle until it drowned.

en: We found a brass button in his stomach and a round ball, and lots of rubbage.
vi: We found a bronze frame inside the fish's belly, with a ball inside, which contained a spool of wire.
tr: We found a brass mallet, a perfectly round ball, and a bunch of odds and ends in the fish's stomach.
es: In its stomach, we found a copper button, a round ball, and lots of other things.

en: We split the ball open with the hatchet, and there was a spool in it.
vi: Jim said that it had been inside the ball all along, and they wrapped it outside to make the ball.
tr: When we split the ball with an axe, a spool came out of it.
es: We split the ball with the axe and inside there was a spool.

en: Jim said he’d had it there a long time, to coat it over so and make a ball of it.
vi: Jim said that it had been inside the ball all along, and they wrapped it outside to make the ball.
tr: Jim said the spool had been in the fish's stomach for a long time, turning into a ball as it got coated over and over.
es: Jim said it had swallowed it a long time ago and that's why it had formed a ball around it.

en: It was as big a fish as was ever catched in the Mississippi, I reckon.
vi: I'm sure this is the biggest fish I've ever seen; I've never seen a fish bigger than this.
tr: It was probably the biggest fish ever caught in the Mississippi until that day.
es: It was one of the biggest fish ever caught in the Mississippi, I think.

en: Jim said he hadn’t ever seen a bigger one.
vi: I'm sure this is the biggest fish I've ever seen; I've never seen a fish bigger than this.
tr: Jim said he had never seen a bigger fish either.
es: Jim said he had never seen a bigger one.

en: He would a been worth a good deal over at the village.
vi: If it were in the village, it would have sold for a lot of money.
tr: If we were in the village, it would have fetched quite a good price.
es: In town, it would have been worth a lot of money.

en: They peddle out such a fish as that by the pound in the market-house there; everybody buys some of him; his meat’s as white as snow and makes a good fry.
vi: With a fish like this, they would cut it into many small pieces, each half a pound, and sell them at the market; everyone would want to buy a few pieces. Its meat is as white as snow and smells delicious when fried.
tr: They had sold a fish this big by the kilo in the market, and everyone had bought a piece; the fish's flesh was as white as snow and made for good frying.
es: They sell those fish by the pound at the market; everyone buys some; their skin is as white as snow and they taste very good when fried.

en: Next morning I said it was getting slow and dull, and I wanted to get a stirring up some way.
vi: The next morning, I told Jim that I felt sad and tired, so I wanted to find some way to be a bit more active.
tr: The next morning, I said that life was passing slowly and boringly and that I wanted a bit of action.
es: The next morning I said that everything was getting very boring and that I wanted to see some action.

en: I said I reckoned I would slip over the river and find out what was going on.
vi: I planned to go out to the river to see if there was anything there.
tr: I thought it would be good to cross the river and see what was happening.
es: I said that I thought I was going to cross the river to see what was happening.

en: Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp.
vi: Jim agreed, but told me to wait until evening to go and to be careful.
tr: Jim agreed with me, but he said I should go in the dark and be very careful.
es: Jim liked the idea; but he said I had to go at night and be very careful.

en: Then he studied it over and said, couldn’t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl?
vi: He thought for a moment and then suggested that I should take off the old clothes I was wearing and disguise myself as a girl.
tr: Then, after thinking about the matter a bit more, he asked if I could go disguised as a girl using some of those old clothes.
es: Then he kept thinking and added that I could put on some of the clothes we had and dress as a girl.

en: That was a good notion, too.
vi: That idea sounded good.
tr: That was indeed a good idea.
es: That was also a good idea.

en: So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it.
vi: So we took a short-cut dress, rolled up my pants to the knees, and then put the dress on.
tr: So we shortened one of the calico dresses, rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees, and I put on the dress.
es: So we shortened one of the calico dresses and I rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees and put it on.

en: Jim hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit.
vi: Jim used a fishhook to gather the back of the dress, making it look quite nice.
tr: When Jim fastened the clasps at the back of the dress, it fit me perfectly.
es: Jim fastened it at the back with the hooks, and it fit me well.

en: I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe.
vi: I put on a wide-brimmed hat and tied the hat's string under my chin. If anyone wanted to look closely and see my face, they would have to bend down as if looking into a stove chimney.
tr: I put on the sun hat and tied its string under my chin; since the wide brim curved down on both sides, anyone wanting to see my face would have to look in like through a stovepipe.
es: I put on the bonnet and tied it under my chin, and if someone looked at me and saw my face it was like looking through a chimney pipe.

en: Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly.
vi: Jim said that no one would recognize me, even in broad daylight; it would be very hard to recognize me.
tr: Jim said that no one would recognize me even in daylight.
es: Jim said no one would recognize me, not even during the day.

en: I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didn’t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket.
vi: All day long, I practiced walking to get used to it, and gradually I felt quite comfortable in that outfit; but Jim told me that my walk still didn't look like a girl's walk and that I should stop lifting the dress to put my hands in my pants pockets.
tr: I practiced all day long and gradually started to move quite comfortably in the dress; according to Jim, the only thing that didn't resemble girls was my walk; he also told me to stop lifting my skirt and plunging my hand into my pocket.
es: I spent the whole day training to get used to it, and after a while it fit me quite well, only Jim said I didn't walk like girls, and that I had to stop lifting my skirts to put my hands in my pockets.

en: I took notice, and done better.
vi: I followed his advice and imitated more accurately.
tr: It got better when I paid attention to that.
es: I listened to him and it fit better.

en: I started up the Illinois shore in the canoe just after dark.
vi: It was just getting dark when I rowed the boat up to the Illinois shore.
tr: As soon as darkness fell, I set off towards the Illinois shore by canoe.
es: I went to the Illinois side in the canoe just after dark.

en: I started across to the town from a little below the ferry-landing, and the drift of the current fetched me in at the bottom of the town.
vi: I went past the provincial area, down at the ferry dock a distance, the current carried my boat to the end of the province.
tr: I approached the town from a bit below the ferry dock and, with the help of the current, reached the shore from the very bottom of the town.
es: I went towards the town from a little below the ferry landing and the current drifted me to the edge of the town.

en: I tied up and started along the bank.
vi: I got off the boat and walked along the foot of the dyke.
tr: I tied up the canoe somewhere and started walking along the beach.
es: I moored and started walking along the shore.

en: There was a light burning in a little shanty that hadn’t been lived in for a long time, and I wondered who had took up quarters there.
vi: There was a light in a small hut that seemed to have been unoccupied for a long time. I was curious to know who had come to stay here.
tr: I saw a light in a small cabin that had been uninhabited for a long time and wondered who had moved in there.
es: There was a light on in a cabin where no one had lived for a long time and I wondered who might be there.

en: I slipped up and peeped in at the window.
vi: I cautiously approached and peeked through a crack in the window.
tr: I approached quietly and looked inside through the window.
es: I approached to look through the window.

en: There was a woman about forty year old in there knitting by a candle that was on a pine table.
vi: Inside the hut, a woman about forty years old was sitting by a candle placed on a pinewood table.
tr: Inside, a woman in her forties was sitting at a pine table, knitting by candlelight.
es: There was a woman of about forty years old knitting by the light of a candle placed on a pine table.

en: I didn’t know her face; she was a stranger, for you couldn’t start a face in that town that I didn’t know.
vi: I did not recognize her face; she must have been new here because in this province there was no one whose face I did not know.
tr: Her face didn't look familiar to me; she must have been a stranger, because there wasn't a single person in the town that I didn't know.
es: I had never seen her before; she was a stranger, because in that town there wasn't a single face I didn't know.

en: Now this was lucky, because I was weakening; I was getting afraid I had come; people might know my voice and find me out.
vi: This was fortunate; earlier I had been worried that someone might recognize my voice and discover who I was.
tr: This was what you called luck, as I had started to feel a bit regretful, fearing that someone might recognize my voice and I would get caught.
es: That was fortunate, because I was starting to have doubts. I was beginning to get scared that I had come; people might recognize me by my voice.

en: But if this woman had been in such a little town two days she could tell me all I wanted to know; so I knocked at the door, and made up my mind I wouldn’t forget I was a girl.
vi: But if that woman had been in this small province for two days, she might be able to tell me everything I wanted to know. Thinking that, I knocked on the door and reminded myself not to forget that I was pretending to be a daughter.
tr: But if this woman had been living in such a small town for a short time, she could tell me everything I wanted to know; that's why I knocked on the door and decided to absolutely remember that I was a girl.
