es: But if that woman had been in such a small town for only two days, she could tell me everything I wanted to know, so I knocked on the door and decided not to forget that I was a girl.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: Chapter XI
tr: Chapter Eleven
es: Chapter 11

en: “Come in,” says the woman, and I did.
vi: The woman said: - Come in. I walked in.
tr: "Come in," said the woman. I went inside.
es: —COME IN —said the woman, and I obeyed—.

en: She says: “Take a cheer.”
vi: She said: - Sit down here.
tr: “Sit down.”
es: Sit down.

en: I done it.
vi: I sat down.
tr: I sat down.
es: I sat down.

en: She looked me all over with her little shiny eyes, and says:
vi: She looked me over with small but very bright eyes, then asked:
tr: With her sparkling little eyes, she examined me from head to toe.
es: She looked at me very attentively with bright little eyes, and then she says:

en: “What might your name be?”
vi: - What is your name?
tr: “What's your name, let's see?”
es: —And, what's your name?

en: “Sarah Williams.”
vi: - Sara Willim
tr: “Sarah Williams.”
es: —Sarah Williams.

en: “Where ’bouts do you live?
vi: - Where are you?
tr: “Where do you live then?
es: —Where do you live?

en: In this neighborhood?’
vi: Is it nearby?
tr: Around here?”
es: Around here?

en: “No’m.
vi: Is it nearby?
tr: “No. I’m from Hookerville, seven miles down.
es: —No, ma'am.

en: In Hookerville, seven mile below.
vi: - No, I live in Hookerville, seven miles down from here.
tr: “No. I’m from Hookerville, seven miles down.
es: In Hookerville, seven miles down.

en: I’ve walked all the way and I’m all tired out.”
vi: I walked all the way up here, and now I'm tired.
tr: I walked all the way here, I’m exhausted, I swear.”
es: I walked all the way and I am very tired.

en: “Hungry, too, I reckon.
vi: - Surely, you must be hungry, right?
tr: "You must be hungry."
es: —And I bet you're hungry.

en: I’ll find you something.”
vi: Let me find something for you to eat.
tr: "Let me get you something.""
es: I'm going to get something.

en: “No’m, I ain’t hungry.
vi: - No, I'm not hungry.
tr: “No, no, I'm not hungry.
es: —No, ma'am. I'm not hungry.

en: I was so hungry I had to stop two miles below here at a farm; so I ain’t hungry no more.
vi: Earlier, I stopped at a camp two miles from here; I was hungry then, but now I'm not hungry anymore.
tr: When I got really hungry, I stopped by a farm two miles down; that's why I'm full now.
es: I was so hungry that I had to stop two miles down from here at a farm, so I'm not hungry anymore.

en: It’s what makes me so late.
vi: That's why I'm walking slowly.
tr: That's why I was so late anyway.
es: That's why I'm so late.

en: My mother’s down sick, and out of money and everything, and I come to tell my uncle Abner Moore.
vi: My mother is seriously ill, we have no money and nothing left. I'm going to find and inform my uncle, Abner Moore.
tr: My mother is very sick, we ran out of money and food, so I came to talk to my uncle Abner Moore.
es: My mother is sick and has run out of money and everything, and I've come to tell my uncle Abner Moore.

en: He lives at the upper end of the town, she says.
vi: My mother said my uncle is at the lower end of the province over there.
tr: He lives at the upper end of this town, according to my mother.
es: He lives in the upper part of town, my mother told me.

en: I hain’t ever been here before.
vi: I've never been to this place before.
tr: I've never been here before.
es: I've never been here before.

en: Do you know him?”
vi: Do you know my uncle?
tr: Do you know my uncle?”
es: Do you know him?

en: “No; but I don’t know everybody yet.
vi: - No, I don't know anyone yet.
tr: “No; but I don't know everyone yet.
es: —No, but I still don't know everyone yet.

en: I haven’t lived here quite two weeks.
vi: I've only been here for less than two weeks.
tr: It's not even been two weeks since I moved here.
es: I haven't even been here for two weeks.

en: It’s a considerable ways to the upper end of the town.
vi: From here to the end of the province, there are many dirt roads.
tr: The upper end of the town is quite far away.
es: It's a long way from here to the upper part of the village.

en: You better stay here all night.
vi: You should stay here tonight.
tr: If you want, you can stay here overnight.
es: You'd better spend the night here.

en: Take off your bonnet.”
vi: Take off your hat first.
tr: You can also take off your hat.”
es: Take off your hat.

en: “No,” I says; “I’ll rest a while, I reckon, and go on.
vi: - No, I replied.
tr: "No need," I said, "I should continue on my way after resting a bit.
es: —No —I said—; I'm just going to rest for a while and then continue.

en: I ain’t afeared of the dark.”
vi: No, I'm just resting here for a moment and then I'll go right away, I'm not afraid of the dark at all.
tr: I'm not afraid of heading out in the dark."
es: The darkness doesn't scare me.

en: She said she wouldn’t let me go by myself, but her husband would be in by-and-by, maybe in a hour and a half, and she’d send him along with me.
vi: She said she wouldn't let me go alone. Her husband was coming back in about an hour and a half, and she would ask him to go with me.
tr: He said he wouldn't let me go alone, her husband was supposed to come in about an hour and a half and could take me.
es: She said she wouldn't let me leave alone but that her husband would arrive later, maybe in an hour and a half, and he would tell her to accompany me.

en: Then she got to talking about her husband, and about her relations up the river, and her relations down the river, and about how much better off they used to was, and how they didn’t know but they’d made a mistake coming to our town, instead of letting well alone—and so on and so on, till I was afeard I had made a mistake coming to her to find out what was going on in the town; but by-and-by she dropped on to pap and the murder, and then I was pretty willing to let her clatter right along.
vi: Then she went on about her husband, and the familiar people at the river's beginning and end, about how happy things were in the old place, and how coming to this province without knowing was so long and tedious, that it would have been better to stay alone - and so on, and so on... To the point that I became scared because I had foolishly come here to ask her about things in the province. But then a moment later, she started talking about my father and the murder case. I wanted to just let her talk and listen.
tr: Then she started talking about her husband, she talked about their relatives upriver, she talked about their relatives downriver, they used to be very well off, but they were wondering if they made a mistake by coming to this town, they wished they had stayed in the old place – and so on and so forth; I was beginning to fear that I made a mistake by coming to her to find out what was happening in the town; but then she brought up my father and the murder, and that's when I started listening to her chatter wholeheartedly.
es: Then she started talking about her husband and her relatives upstream and her relatives downstream and how they used to live much better and that they didn't know if they had made a mistake by coming to our town, instead of settling for staying as they were, and so on, until I feared I had been wrong in thinking that she was going to give me news about what was happening in the town, but then she started talking about father and the murder and there I was indeed willing to let her keep on talking.

en: She told about me and Tom Sawyer finding the six thousand dollars (only she got it ten) and all about pap and what a hard lot he was, and what a hard lot I was, and at last she got down to where I was murdered.
vi: She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I earned twelve thousand dollars (she said twenty thousand), and everything about my father, saying my father was very stubborn, and I was very stubborn too. Then finally, she talked about the part where I was killed.
tr: She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I found six thousand dollars (though she thought it was ten thousand), everything about my father and what a troublemaker he was, and also what a troublemaker I was; finally, she got to the part where I was killed.
es: She told me how Tom Sawyer and I had found the twelve thousand dollars (only she said it was twenty) and the whole story about father, and how bad he was and how bad I was and finally she got to the part where I was murdered, and I said:

en: I says:
vi: I asked:
tr: “Who did it?” I asked.
es: She told me how Tom Sawyer and I had found the twelve thousand dollars (only she said it was twenty) and the whole story about father, and how bad he was and how bad I was and finally she got to the part where I was murdered, and I said:

en: “Who done it?
vi: - Who killed him?
tr: “Who did it?” I asked.
es: —Who was it?

en: We’ve heard considerable about these goings on down in Hookerville, but we don’t know who ’twas that killed Huck Finn.”
vi: I heard people talking a lot about it in Hookerville, but I don't know who killed Huck Finn.
tr: “We heard a lot of things about what happened in Hookerville, but we couldn't find out who killed Huck Finn.”
es: In Hookerville, there has been much talk about all those things, but we don't know who it was that killed Huck Finn.

en: “Well, I reckon there’s a right smart chance of people here that’d like to know who killed him.
vi: - I think the people here really have many special qualities.
tr: "Actually, almost everyone here wants to know who killed him.
es: —Well, I suppose there are lots of people here who would want to know who killed him.

en: Some think old Finn done it himself.”
vi: Even I want to know who killed Huck Finn.
tr: Some think that the killer is old Finn himself."
es: Some say it was old Finn himself.

en: “No—is that so?”
vi: - No! Really, ma'am?
tr: "No way..." "Really?""
es: —No ... do they say that?

en: “Most everybody thought it at first.
vi: - At first, almost everyone thought so.
tr: “At first, everyone thought that way.
es: —At first, that's what everyone believed.

en: He’ll never know how nigh he come to getting lynched.
vi: But then by the afternoon, people changed their minds and said that it was a runaway black man named Jim who killed Huck Finn.
tr: The man will never know how close he came to being lynched.
es: He will never know how close he came to being lynched.

en: But before night they changed around and judged it was done by a runaway nigger named Jim.”
vi: But then by the afternoon, people changed their minds and said that it was a runaway black man named Jim who killed Huck Finn.
tr: But before nightfall, the situation changed and people concluded that a runaway black man named Jim committed the murder.”
es: But soon they changed their minds and decided it was done by a runaway Black man named Jim.

en: “Why he—”
vi: Oh no - he...
tr: “Well, but he…”
es: —But if he...

en: I stopped.
vi: I immediately fell silent.
tr: I bit my lip.
es: I kept quiet.

en: I reckoned I better keep still.
vi: I thought that it was better to just sit quietly.
tr: It would have been better if I hadn't said anything.
es: I figured it was better not to say anything.

en: She run on, and never noticed I had put in at all:
vi: She continued speaking, ignoring the sentence I had just interjected.
tr: The woman continued talking, she hadn't even noticed that I was about to interrupt.
es: She kept talking and didn't realize that I had interrupted her:

en: “The nigger run off the very night Huck Finn was killed.
vi: - The black man escaped on the very night Huck Finn was killed.
tr: “The black man escaped the very night Huck Finn was killed.
es: —The black man escaped the same night Huck Finn died.

en: So there’s a reward out for him—three hundred dollars.
vi: They offered a reward to catch him: three hundred dollars.
tr: That's why they put a bounty on his head… three hundred dollars.
es: So now they are offering a reward for him: three hundred dollars.

en: And there’s a reward out for old Finn, too—two hundred dollars.
vi: Then they also offered a reward to catch Finn's father: two hundred dollars.
tr: They also put a bounty on old Finn's head… two hundred dollars.
es: There is also a reward for old Finn: two hundred dollars.

en: You see, he come to town the morning after the murder, and told about it, and was out with ’em on the ferry-boat hunt, and right away after he up and left.
vi: You know, he went to town the morning after the murder happened; he told the story and then went with them on the boat to search for the body. Then right after that, he also escaped.
tr: He came to town the morning after the murder and told what happened, he was on the deck while the search was conducted with the steamboat, but then he left.
es: Notice that he came to town the morning after the murder and reported it, and went with the others to search for him on the ferry and immediately left.

en: Before night they wanted to lynch him, but he was gone, you see.
vi: In the evening, they intended to put him on trial, but he had already escaped.
tr: They wanted to lynch him before nightfall, but he was nowhere to be found.
es: Right away they wanted to lynch him, but notice that he had already disappeared.

en: Well, next day they found out the nigger was gone; they found out he hadn’t ben seen sence ten o’clock the night the murder was done.
vi: The next day, the black man escaped again. They said they saw him at ten o'clock on the night of the murder.
tr: The next day it was noticed that the black man was gone, no one had seen him since ten o'clock on the night of the murder.
es: Well, the next day they found out that the black man had fled and that no one had seen him since ten o'clock on the night of the murder.

en: So then they put it on him, you see; and while they was full of it, next day, back comes old Finn, and went boo-hooing to Judge Thatcher to get money to hunt for the nigger all over Illinois with.
vi: So they accused him, you know. After they were sure of it, the next day Finn's father came back, crying loudly, demanding Judge Thatcher to spend money to hunt the black man all over Illinois.
tr: That's why the murder was pinned on him, while people were thinking this, old Finn came back the next day and asked Judge Thatcher for money to search for the black man all over Illinois.
es: So then they offered a reward for him, you understand, and when everyone was convinced the next day, old Finn came back and went crying to Judge Thatcher to ask for money to search for the black man all over Illinois.

en: The judge gave him some, and that evening he got drunk, and was around till after midnight with a couple of mighty hard-looking strangers, and then went off with them.
vi: The judge gave some money, and in the evening, Finn's father got drunk and lingered until midnight with two very ugly strangers, then left with them. Since then, he hasn't returned, and people haven't bothered to look for him.
tr: The judge gave him some money, Finn drank until evening and wandered around with a few rather tough-looking strangers until midnight, then took them and left.
es: The judge gave him some and that night he got drunk and stayed until after midnight with two very shady-looking strangers and then left with them.

en: Well, he hain’t come back sence, and they ain’t looking for him back till this thing blows over a little, for people thinks now that he killed his boy and fixed things so folks would think robbers done it, and then he’d get Huck’s money without having to bother a long time with a lawsuit.
vi: It's considered over now; but some people think that Finn's father killed his son and arranged things to make it look like a robbery, so he could take Huck's money without worrying about being sued.
tr: He hasn't returned since then; for a while no one looked for him, but rumors spread and people now think he killed his own son and made it look like robbers did it. That way he could get hold of Huck's money without wasting time on a long trial.
es: Well, since then he hasn't returned and they don't expect him until this blows over a bit, because now people think he killed his son and arranged things so everyone would believe it was done by some robbers and that way he could take Huck's money without having to bother with a lawsuit for too long.

en: People do say he warn’t any too good to do it.
vi: They said what he did wasn't right.
tr: People think he's despicable enough to do that.
es: People say it wouldn't be surprising of him.

en: Oh, he’s sly, I reckon.
vi: Oh, but I think he was very clever.
tr: I think he's a hypocrite too.
es: Well, I reckon he's very clever.

en: If he don’t come back for a year he’ll be all right.
vi: If he doesn't return within a year, then it's all settled.
tr: If he doesn't come back by the end of the year, he'll get away with it.
es: If he doesn't come back in a year, nothing will happen to him.

en: You can’t prove anything on him, you know; everything will be quieted down then, and he’ll walk in Huck’s money as easy as nothing.”
vi: There's no evidence to accuse him, you understand. So at that point, everything will be fine, and he can easily spend Huck's money without any trouble.
tr: No one can prove anything anyway; by then things will settle down and he'll easily get Huck's money.”
es: Nothing can be proven against him, you know; by then things will have calmed down and he can leave with Huck's money without any problem.

en: “Yes, I reckon so, ’m.
vi: - Yes, I think so too, grandma.
tr: "You are right, ma'am.
es: —Yes, I suppose so, ma'am.

en: I don’t see nothing in the way of it.
vi: I don't see anything difficult about that.
tr: I also don't think there will be any obstacles in front of him.
es: I don't think there will be any problems.

en: Has everybody quit thinking the nigger done it?”
vi: So now no one thinks that the black man did it anymore?
tr: Does no one think anymore that the murder was committed by the black man?"
es: Do people no longer believe that the black man did it?

en: “Oh, no, not everybody.
vi: - Oh no, not everyone.
tr: “Of course it does.
es: —Ah, no, not everyone.

en: A good many thinks he done it.
vi: Many people still think the black man did it.
tr: Many people think he committed the murder.
es: Many believe it was him.

en: But they’ll get the nigger pretty soon now, and maybe they can scare it out of him.”
vi: But soon they will catch the black man, and perhaps they will still suspect him a lot.
tr: But they will soon catch the black man; maybe if they scare him a little, he'll confess to the murder.”
es: But they will catch the black guy very soon and they might scare him into telling the truth.

en: “Why, are they after him yet?”
vi: - So, are they still looking to catch him?
tr: "How will they catch him; did they even start chasing him?""
es: —But, are they still looking for him?

en: “Well, you’re innocent, ain’t you!
vi: - Oh, how naive you are, child.
tr: "Man, how naive you are!
es: —Well, you really are innocent!

en: Does three hundred dollars lay around every day for people to pick up?
vi: It's not every day that people can easily earn three hundred dollars.
tr: Do you think three hundred dollars are picked up from the roadside every day?
es: Do you think three hundred dollars grow on trees every day?

en: Some folks think the nigger ain’t far from here.
vi: Some people think that the black man hasn't fled far from here.
tr: Some people think the black man isn't very far from here.
es: Some believe the black man hasn't gone very far.

en: I’m one of them—but I hain’t talked it around.
vi: I think so too, but I haven't told anyone.
tr: I'm one of them... but I haven't told anyone.
es: And neither do I... But I haven't told anyone.

en: A few days ago I was talking with an old couple that lives next door in the log shanty, and they happened to say hardly anybody ever goes to that island over yonder that they call Jackson’s Island.
vi: A few days ago, I talked to an old couple in the wooden house next door, and they said that few people go to that distant island called Jackson Island.
tr: A few days ago, I was talking to the old couple living in the wooden cabin next door, and they said almost no one goes to the island they call Jackson Island.
es: A few days ago, I was talking with a couple of old folks who live next door in the log cabin, and they said that almost no one goes to that island over there called Jackson Island.

en: Don’t anybody live there?
vi: I asked if there was anyone on that island.
tr: I asked if no one lives there.
es: “And no one lives there?” I asked.

en: says I.
vi: I asked if there was anyone on that island.
tr: I asked if no one lives there.
es: “And no one lives there?” I asked.

en: No, nobody, says they.
vi: They said: no, there's no one there at all.
tr: No; no one lives there, they said.
es: “No, no one,” they said.

en: I didn’t say any more, but I done some thinking.
vi: I didn't say anything more, but I kept thinking about it.
tr: I didn't say anything else, but I started thinking.
es: I didn't say anything more, but I've been thinking about it.

en: I was pretty near certain I’d seen smoke over there, about the head of the island, a day or two before that, so I says to myself, like as not that nigger’s hiding over there; anyway, says I, it’s worth the trouble to give the place a hunt.
vi: Since I live nearby, I'm sure I saw smoke rising from that direction, from the head of that island, a few days ago. I wondered if the black man might be hiding on the island. I said that anyway, it would be worth the effort to go to that island and search it. Since that day, I haven't seen any more smoke, so I think if there was a black man, he must have left by now.
tr: I'm almost sure I saw smoke there, it was rising from the head of the island a day or two ago. So, I said to myself, can't the black man be hiding there; in any case, it's worth going there to investigate.
es: I was almost sure I had seen smoke over there, towards the tip of the island, a day or two ago, so I said to myself: “Maybe the black man is hiding there; in any case,” I said, “it's worth searching that island.”

en: I hain’t seen any smoke sence, so I reckon maybe he’s gone, if it was him; but husband’s going over to see—him and another man.
vi: But my husband will go up there to check, along with another person.
tr: I haven't seen smoke since that day, maybe he's gone now, that is, if it was him: Though my husband will go and check, he'll take a man with him.
es: Since then, I haven't seen any more smoke, so maybe he's gone, if it was him; but my husband is going to check it out, with another person.

en: He was gone up the river; but he got back to-day, and I told him as soon as he got here two hours ago.”
vi: He went upriver and just returned today. Two hours ago, as soon as he stepped into the house, I told him about it.
tr: He had gone up the river, but he returned today and as soon as he arrived two hours ago, I told him everything."
es: He had to go upriver, but he came back today, and I told him as soon as he arrived two hours ago.

en: I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still.
vi: At this moment, I was extremely confused, unable to sit still any longer.
tr: I was so on edge that I couldn't stay still anymore.
es: I had gotten so nervous that I couldn't stay still.

en: I had to do something with my hands; so I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it.
vi: I had to move my hands a bit, so I picked up the sewing needle on the table and threaded it.
tr: I needed to do something with my hands; so I took the sewing needle on the table and tried to thread it.
es: I had to do something with my hands, so I took a needle from the table and started threading it.

en: My hands shook, and I was making a bad job of it.
vi: My hands were trembling, and I couldn't thread it.
tr: My hands were trembling and I couldn't get the thread through the hole.
es: My hands were shaking and I did it very poorly.

en: When the woman stopped talking I looked up, and she was looking at me pretty curious and smiling a little.
vi: The woman stopped talking, looked up, and gazed at me with a somewhat strange expression, then smiled.
tr: The woman stopped talking, and when I looked up, I saw that she was looking at me curiously and smiling slightly.
es: When the woman stopped talking, I looked up and she was looking at me very curiously and smiling a little.

en: I put down the needle and thread, and let on to be interested—and I was, too—and says:
vi: I put the needle and thread down, pretending to be interested in the story as well, and said:
tr: I pretended to be interested in the needle and thread; in fact, I was interested. I said:
es: I put down the needle and thread and put on an interested face —and the truth is, I was interested— and I go and say:

en: “Three hundred dollars is a power of money.
vi: - Three hundred dollars, that's a lot of money.
tr: “Three hundred dollars is not a small amount of money.
es: —Three hundred dollars is a lot of money.

en: I wish my mother could get it.
vi: I also hope my mother can get such an amount.
tr: It would be great if my mother took it.
es: I wish my mother had it.

en: Is your husband going over there to-night?”
vi: Is your husband going to that island tonight?
tr: Will your husband go there tonight?”
es: Is her husband going there tonight?

en: “Oh, yes.
vi: - Oh, yes.
tr: “Yes, of course.
es: —Ah, yes.

en: He went up-town with the man I was telling you of, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun.
vi: He is going to town with the people I just mentioned to get a boat and see if he can borrow a gun.
tr: He went to the town with the man I mentioned to find a boat, and he will also try to borrow an extra rifle.
es: He has gone to the upper part of the town with the man I told you about, to look for a boat and see if they can borrow another shotgun.

en: They’ll go over after midnight.”
vi: Around midnight, they will leave.
tr: They will leave after midnight.”
es: They are going to cross after midnight.

en: “Couldn’t they see better if they was to wait till daytime?”
vi: - Why not wait until daytime when it's clearer to see?
tr: “Wouldn't they see better if they waited for the daylight?”
es: —Wouldn't they see better if they waited until it was daytime?

en: “Yes.
vi: - Yes, but during the day the black man can also see us more easily.
tr: “Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: And couldn’t the nigger see better, too?
vi: - Yes, but during the day the black man can also see us more easily.
tr: But wouldn't the black man see better then?
es: And, wouldn't he also see better in the dark?

en: After midnight he’ll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he’s got one.”
vi: After midnight, the black man might be fast asleep, so you can sneak through the forest, and if he lights a fire in the dark, it will be easier to find him.
tr: After midnight, he would probably be asleep, so they could quietly move through the forest and search the surroundings, and if there's a fire, they would find it more easily.”
es: After midnight, he is most likely asleep, and they can go through the forest and look for his campfire better if it's dark, if he has a campfire.

en: “I didn’t think of that.”
vi: - It's not that certain.
tr: "This had never occurred to me.""
es: —It hadn't occurred to me.

en: The woman kept looking at me pretty curious, and I didn’t feel a bit comfortable.
vi: The woman looked at me with a tattletale expression, making me even more uneasy.
tr: The woman kept looking at me with curiosity, and I didn't feel comfortable at all.
es: The woman kept looking at me very curiously and I didn't feel comfortable at all.

en: Pretty soon she says,
vi: She asked:
tr: A little later, she spoke again:
es: And after a moment she goes and asks:

en: “What did you say your name was, honey?”
vi: - Earlier, what did you say your name was?
tr: “What did you say my name was, sweetheart?”
es: —How did you say your name was, beautiful?

en: “M—Mary Williams.”
vi: - M - Mary William
tr: “M… Mary Williams.”
es: —M ... Mary Williams.

en: Somehow it didn’t seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn’t look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too.
vi: Strange, didn't I just say it was Mary? Thinking that, but I didn't look up. It seems like I said it was Sara earlier. I felt like I was being cornered, so scared that I didn't dare to look up anymore.
tr: When she first asked, I felt like I didn't say Mary, so I couldn't lift my head to look; I think I said Sarah; that's why I felt cornered and was afraid that the woman would read it from my face.
es: I don't know why, but it didn't seem to me that I had said it was Mary before, so I didn't look up... It seemed to me that I had said it was Sarah, so I felt cornered and was afraid that maybe it would show.

en: I wished the woman would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was.
vi: The quieter she was, the more confused I felt.
tr: I wished the woman would say something more; the longer we sat in silence, the more uneasy I became.
es: I wanted the woman to say something else; the longer she stayed silent, the more uncomfortable I felt.

en: But now she says:
vi: But then she asked:
tr: Finally, the woman spoke:
es: But then she goes and says:

en: “Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?”
vi: - I thought you said it was Sara when you first came in?
tr: “When you first came in, I thought you said your name was Sarah, honey, isn't that right?”
es: —Beautiful, I thought you said your name was Sarah when you arrived.

en: “Oh, yes’m, I did.
vi: - Yes, that's right.
tr: “Yes, ma'am, that's what I said.
es: —Oh, yes, ma'am, it's true.

en: Sarah Mary Williams.
vi: Sara Mary William, Sara is my first name.
tr: Sarah Mary Williams.
es: Sarah Mary Williams.

en: Sarah’s my first name.
vi: Sara Mary William, Sara is my first name.
tr: Sarah is my first name.
es: They called me Sarah as a first name.

en: Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary.”
vi: Some people call me Sara, some people call me Mary.
tr: Some call me Sarah; some call me Mary.”
es: Some call me Sarah and others Mary.

en: “Oh, that’s the way of it?”
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Ah, is that what's happening?

en: “Yes’m.”
vi: I feel more at ease now.
tr: "Yes, ma'am.""
es: —Yes, ma'am.

en: I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway.
vi: But I still hope I don't have to sit there anymore.
tr: I was feeling better, but I still wanted to get out of there as soon as possible.
es: I was already feeling better, but I still wanted to leave there anyway.

en: I couldn’t look up yet.
vi: I still can't look up.
tr: I still couldn't lift my head to look at the woman.
es: I still didn't dare to lift my gaze.

en: Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again.
vi: But then she started talking about how hard and poor life was, and how here the mice ran in and out freely as if they owned the house, and so on...
tr: Upon this, the woman began to talk about the difficulty of making a living, how they lived in poverty, mice running around as if the house belonged to them, and so on, and I started to feel more at ease.
es: Well, the woman started talking about how difficult times were and how poor they were and how rats were running everywhere, as if the house belonged to them, and about this and that, and I began to feel calmer.

en: She was right about the rats.
vi: At that moment, I felt more at ease, and she immediately started talking about the mice.
tr: She was right about the mice.
es: She was right about the rats.

en: You’d see one stick his nose out of a hole in the corner every little while.
vi: Every now and then, a mouse would poke its snout out of a hole in the corner of the house.
tr: From time to time, you could see them poking their noses out of the hole in the corner.
es: Every now and then you could see one poking its snout out of a hole in a corner.

en: She said she had to have things handy to throw at them when she was alone, or they wouldn’t give her no peace.
vi: She said that one must always hold something in hand to throw at the mice whenever alone at home. Otherwise, the mice wouldn't let you sit still.
tr: She explained that when she was alone, she kept something to throw at the mice, otherwise they wouldn't leave her in peace.
es: She said she had to have things on hand to throw at them when she was alone, because otherwise, they wouldn't leave her in peace.

en: She showed me a bar of lead twisted up into a knot, and said she was a good shot with it generly, but she’d wrenched her arm a day or two ago, and didn’t know whether she could throw true now.
vi: She showed me a twisted piece of lead, like a knot, and said it was very good for throwing at mice.
tr: She showed me a rod made of twisted lead and said that she usually threw it very accurately, but she was afraid she might miss because she had injured her arm a couple of days ago.
es: She showed me a twisted lead bar shaped like a knot and said that she generally had good aim, but that a day or two ago she had dislocated an arm and didn't know if she could aim well now.

en: But she watched for a chance, and directly banged away at a rat; but she missed him wide, and said “Ouch!” it hurt her arm so.
vi: But just a few days ago, she sprained her hand while keeping an eye out, then suddenly threw it, but it was still far from the mouse. She cried out in pain; and her hand hurt again.
tr: Still, she watched for an opportunity and threw it at a mouse she saw, but the lead missed the mouse, and she held her arm saying "Ouch!"
es: She waited for an opportunity and immediately threw the bar at a rat, but missed by a lot and said, "Oh!", that her arm hurt a lot.

en: Then she told me to try for the next one.
vi: Then she asked me to try throwing at the next mouse.
tr: She asked me to hit the next mouse.
es: Then she asked me to try with the next one.

en: I wanted to be getting away before the old man got back, but of course I didn’t let on.
vi: I wanted to leave before her husband came home, but somehow I couldn't.
tr: I wanted to leave before the old man came, but of course, I couldn't just rush out.
es: I wanted to leave before her old man came back, but of course, I didn't say that.

en: I got the thing, and the first rat that showed his nose I let drive, and if he’d a stayed where he was he’d a been a tolerable sick rat.
vi: I grabbed the piece of lead, waited for another mouse to poke its snout out, and threw it recklessly. The lead hit the mouse, and it fell over, hitting a thin mouse.
tr: I took the lead ball in my hand and threw it at the first mouse I saw; if it had stayed where it was, it would have been in trouble.
es: I grabbed the bar and threw it at the first rat that poked its snout out, and if it had stayed where it was, it wouldn't have felt very good.

en: She said that was first-rate, and she reckoned I would hive the next one.
vi: She said I was really good, and thought I would throw at the next one too.
tr: The woman said my throw was top-notch and she had no doubt I would hit the next one.
es: She said I threw very well and that she figured I would hit the next one.

en: She went and got the lump of lead and fetched it back, and brought along a hank of yarn which she wanted me to help her with.
vi: She picked up the piece of lead, then brought a spool of thread and asked me to help untangle it.
tr: She went and fetched the lead, then took out a skein of yarn and asked for my help.
es: She got up to fetch the bar and brought it back along with a skein of yarn with which she wanted me to help her.

en: I held up my two hands and she put the hank over them, and went on talking about her and her husband’s matters.
vi: I held out my hands, she placed the spool of thread in them, and continued talking about her and her husband.
tr: I extended my hands and she looped the skein over them, then continued talking about her husband's work.
es: I raised both hands and she placed the skein on them and continued talking about her things and her husband.

en: But she broke off to say:
vi: But then she fell silent and said:
tr: But she paused at one point:
es: But she interrupted herself to say:

en: “Keep your eye on the rats.
vi: - Keep an eye on the mouse.
tr: "Be on guard against the mice.
es: —Stay alert for the rats.

en: You better have the lead in your lap, handy.”
vi: Just hold the lead bar in your hand.
tr: It's best if the bullet stays in your lap."
es: You better keep the bar handy, on your lap.

en: So she dropped the lump into my lap just at that moment, and I clapped my legs together on it and she went on talking.
vi: She dropped the lead ingot into the hem of my skirt just as I closed my legs to hold the ingot in place. She started talking again.
tr: He threw the lead ball towards my lap while still talking, and as I clamped my legs together to avoid dropping it, he continued to speak.
es: So she threw the piece of lead into my lap right at that moment and I squeezed my legs to catch it and she kept talking.

en: But only about a minute.
vi: But only for a moment.
tr: But he only spoke for a minute.
es: But only for a minute or so.

en: Then she took off the hank and looked me straight in the face, and very pleasant, and says:
vi: Then she lifted the spool, looked straight at my face with a playful expression, and asked:
tr: Finally, he took the burden from my hands, looked straight into my face, and asked in a sweet voice:
es: Then she took the skein from me and looked me in the eyes and said very kindly:

en: “Come, now, what’s your real name?”
vi: - Hey, tell me the truth, what is your name?
tr: “Tell me… what is your real name?”
es: —Come on, now tell me what your real name is.

en: “Wh—what, mum?”
vi: - What did you say?
tr: "What did you say, ma'am?""
es: —Whaaat? What, ma'am?

en: “What’s your real name?
vi: - What is your real name?
tr: “What is your real name?
es: —What is your real name?

en: Is it Bill, or Tom, or Bob?—or what is it?”
vi: Is it Bin, Tom, or Bob? Or what is it?
tr: Is it Bill, Tom, or Bob?.. What is it?”
es: Is it Bill or Tom, or Bob? What is your name?

en: I reckon I shook like a leaf, and I didn’t know hardly what to do.
vi: I thought I was trembling like a leaf, and truly didn't know what to do.
tr: At that moment, I started trembling like a leaf, I didn't know what to do.
es: I think I started trembling like a leaf, not knowing what to do.

en: But I says:
vi: But I replied:
tr: “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said.
es: But I said:

en: “Please to don’t poke fun at a poor girl like me, mum.
vi: - Please don't tease a miserable girl like me.
tr: “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said.
es: —Please, do not laugh at a poor girl like me, ma'am.

en: If I’m in the way here, I’ll—”
vi: If my sitting here bothers you, then I apologize...
tr: “If I am bothering you, I will immediately…””
es: If I bother you, I...

en: “No, you won’t.
vi: - No, no, don't go anywhere.
tr: “No, you are not going.
es: —No, nothing like that.

en: Set down and stay where you are.
vi: Just sit still here.
tr: Sit down and don't move anywhere.
es: Sit down and stay where you are.

en: I ain’t going to hurt you, and I ain’t going to tell on you, nuther.
vi: I won't harm you, and I won't tell anyone about you, trust me, tell me the truth.
tr: I won't harm you, and you can be sure that I won't betray you.
es: I'm not going to do anything to you nor will I betray you.

en: You just tell me your secret, and trust me.
vi: I won't harm you, and I won't tell anyone about you, trust me, tell me the truth.
tr: Just reveal your secret, you can trust me.
es: You tell me your secret and trust me.

en: I’ll keep it; and, what’s more, I’ll help you.
vi: I will keep it a secret for you, I will help you.
tr: I can keep a secret; moreover, I might be able to help you.
es: I'll keep it, and what's more, I'll help you.

en: So’ll my old man if you want him to.
vi: I will even tell my husband to keep it a secret for you, if you want.
tr: If you want, even my husband can help you.
es: My man, the same, if you want.

en: You see, you’re a runaway ’prentice, that’s all.
vi: Do you understand, you are just a naive young horse that ran away from the herd, nothing more.
tr: It's clear that you are a runaway apprentice.
es: I understand that you are an apprentice and you have run away and nothing more.

en: It ain’t anything.
vi: Do you understand, you are just a naive young horse that ran away from the herd, nothing more.
tr: So what?
es: It's nothing.

en: There ain’t no harm in it.
vi: Do you understand, you are just a naive young horse that ran away from the herd, nothing more.
tr: There's nothing wrong with that.
es: There's nothing wrong with it.

en: You’ve been treated bad, and you made up your mind to cut.
vi: But it's okay, you were treated harshly so you decided to run away, right?
tr: They treated you harshly, and you decided to run away.
es: They have treated you badly and you have decided to run away.

en: Bless you, child, I wouldn’t tell on you.
vi: It's so pitiful, I won't tell anyone about you.
tr: I'm thinking of your well-being, my child, why would I betray you?
es: My son, I wouldn't betray you.

en: Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”
vi: Now tell me everything, come on, good boy.
tr: Come on, tell me… be a good child.”
es: Now tell me everything, be a good boy.

en: So I said it wouldn’t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musn’t go back on her promise.
vi: I thought to myself that continuing to act would be futile, so I decided to confess to her and tell her everything, but she must keep her promise.
tr: Then I said that there was no point in pretending anymore, I would act completely honestly and tell him everything, but he must not go back on his word.
es: So I said that there was no point in continuing to pretend and that I would stop lying and tell him everything, but he had to keep his promise.

en: Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so bad I couldn’t stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughter’s old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles.
vi: Then I told her that both my parents had died, and the law had forced me to live with an old and cruel landlord in a place thirty miles away from the river. They treated me so badly that I couldn't stay there any longer. Taking advantage of the landlord's absence for a few days, I seized the opportunity to escape and stole some clothes from his daughter, traveling for three nights straight until I arrived here.
tr: Then I told him that my father and mother had died, that they had given me to a mean old farmer thirty miles away from the river, and that he had treated me so badly that I could no longer bear it; he had gone on a trip for a few days, so I took the opportunity to steal some of his daughter's old clothes and ran away; I had been on the road for three nights and had come thirty miles; I was traveling at night, hiding and sleeping during the day; I had taken a bag full of meat and bread from the house, and my provisions would last longer.
es: Then I told him that my father and mother had died and that the law had assigned me to an old and mean farmer who lived at least thirty miles from the river and treated me so badly that I couldn't stand it anymore; he had gone away for a couple of days and I took the opportunity to steal an old dress from his daughter and run away, and it had taken me three nights to cover the thirty miles.

en: I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty.
vi: I traveled by night and hid somewhere to sleep during the day. The bundle of bread and meat I brought was just enough to eat along the way.
tr: Then I told him that my father and mother had died, that they had given me to a mean old farmer thirty miles away from the river, and that he had treated me so badly that I could no longer bear it; he had gone on a trip for a few days, so I took the opportunity to steal some of his daughter's old clothes and ran away; I had been on the road for three nights and had come thirty miles; I was traveling at night, hiding and sleeping during the day; I had taken a bag full of meat and bread from the house, and my provisions would last longer.
es: I traveled at night and hid to sleep during the day, and the bag of bread and meat I had taken with me had lasted the whole way, and I still had some left.

en: I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.
vi: I also said that I believed my uncle, Abner Moore, would take care of me, which is why I made my way to this Goshen area.
tr: I thought my Uncle Abner Moore would take me in, so I had come to the town of Goshen.
es: I said that I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me and that was why I had come to this town of Goshen.

en: “Goshen, child?
vi: - Goshen, where are you, boy!
tr: “Is this Goshen, my dear?
es: —Goshen, kid?

en: This ain’t Goshen.
vi: This is not Goshen, this is Petersburg.
tr: This isn't Goshen.
es: This is not Goshen.

en: This is St. Petersburg.
vi: This is not Goshen, this is Petersburg.
tr: This is St. Petersburg.
es: This is Saint Petersburg.

en: Goshen’s ten mile further up the river.
vi: Goshen is still ten miles up the river.
tr: Goshen is ten miles up the river.
es: Goshen is ten miles upriver.

en: Who told you this was Goshen?”
vi: Who told you this was Goshen? - Really?
tr: Who told you this was Goshen?”
es: Who told you this was Goshen?

en: “Why, a man I met at daybreak this morning, just as I was going to turn into the woods for my regular sleep.
vi: But there was a person I met at dawn today, when I was about to turn into the forest to sleep, who told me to turn right at the fork, then go five more miles to reach Goshen.
tr: "This morning at dawn, before going to sleep among the trees, I met a man.
es: —Well, a man I met at dawn this morning, just as I was about to go into the forest to sleep, as always.

en: He told me when the roads forked I must take the right hand, and five mile would fetch me to Goshen.”
vi: But there was a person I met at dawn today, when I was about to turn into the forest to sleep, who told me to turn right at the fork, then go five more miles to reach Goshen.
tr: He told me to turn right when I reached the fork in the road, and after five miles, I would reach Goshen."
es: He told me that the roads split and that I should follow the one on the right and after five miles I would be in Goshen.

en: “He was drunk, I reckon.
vi: - He must be drunk.
tr: “He was probably drunk.
es: —He must have been drunk.

en: He told you just exactly wrong.”
vi: What he said is completely wrong.
tr: He gave you the directions completely wrong.”
es: He told you exactly the opposite of what it is.

en: “Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain’t no matter now.
vi: - Yes, he does look drunk. But well, there's nothing we can do about it now.
tr: “No wonder, it was swaying back and forth, but that’s of no use now.
es: —Well, he did seem drunk, but it doesn't matter anymore.

en: I got to be moving along.
vi: I have to travel a bit further.
tr: I must continue on my way.
es: I have to keep going.

en: I’ll fetch Goshen before daylight.”
vi: I'll reach Goshen before dawn.
tr: I will reach Goshen before dawn breaks.”
es: I'll reach Goshen before dawn.

en: “Hold on a minute.
vi: - Wait a moment, let me get you something to eat quickly.
tr: “Wait a minute.
es: —Wait a moment.

en: I’ll put you up a snack to eat.
vi: - Wait a moment, let me get you something to eat quickly.
tr: Let me pack you something to eat.
es: I'm going to give you something to eat.

en: You might want it.”
vi: You must be hungry.
tr: You can eat it on the way.”
es: Maybe you need it.

en: So she put me up a snack, and says:
vi: She gave me food and then asked:
tr: After stuffing some food into my hand, he continued:
es: So he prepared something for me to eat and said:

en: “Say, when a cow’s laying down, which end of her gets up first?
vi: - Hey, when a cow is lying on the ground, which end does it stand up from first?
tr: “Tell me... when a cow is lying down, which part of it gets up first?
es: —Hey, when a cow lies down, which part does it get up from?

en: Answer up prompt now—don’t stop to study over it.
vi: Answer immediately, no thinking allowed.
tr: Answer quickly, don't think about it.
es: Answer quickly, come on; don't stop to think about it.

en: Which end gets up first?”
vi: Which end stands up first?
tr: Which part gets up first?”
es: Which side does it get up from?

en: “The hind end, mum.”
vi: - The tail end
tr: "The back side, ma'am."
es: —Through the back, ma'am.

en: “Well, then, a horse?”
vi: - The tail end
tr: “What about the horse?”
es: —Well, how about a horse?

en: “The for’rard end, mum.”
vi: - The tail end
tr: "The front will lift, ma'am."
es: —Through the front one, ma'am.

en: “Which side of a tree does the moss grow on?”
vi: - So, which side of the tree does moss grow on?
tr: “On which side of the tree does moss grow?”
es: —On which side of a tree does moss grow?

en: “North side.”
vi: - The north
tr: “On the north side.”
es: —From the north.

en: “If fifteen cows is browsing on a hillside, how many of them eats with their heads pointed the same direction?”
vi: - If fifteen cows graze on the hill, how many face the same direction?
tr: “If fifteen cows are grazing on a hillside, how many of them have their heads turned in the same direction?”
es: —If there are fifteen cows grazing on a slope, how many of them eat with their heads facing the same direction?

en: “The whole fifteen, mum.”
vi: - All fifteen of them
tr: "All of them, ma'am."
es: —Three o'clock, ma'am.

en: “Well, I reckon you have lived in the country.
vi: - Alright, so I know you were in the countryside.
tr: “Alright, it’s clear that you know farm life.
es: —Well, I suppose it's true that you've lived in the countryside.

en: I thought maybe you was trying to hocus me again.
vi: I thought you were going to trick me again.
tr: I was afraid that you might be deceiving me again.
es: I thought maybe you were trying to deceive me again.

en: What’s your real name, now?”
vi: So what's your real name now?
tr: What is your real name, let’s see?”
es: And what's your real name?

en: “George Peters, mum.”
vi: - George Peter is old.
tr: "George Peters, ma'am.""
es: —George Peters, ma'am.

en: “Well, try to remember it, George.
vi: - Alright, remember this, George.
tr: “Alright, try not to forget this, George.
es: —Well, George, try to remember it.

en: Don’t forget and tell me it’s Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it’s George Elexander when I catch you.
vi: Before you go, make sure to tell me that you are Alexander, and then when you are outside, say that I caught you and that you are George Alexander.
tr: Don't forget and don't tell me your name is Elexander before you leave, and especially don't make up the lie that your name is George-Elexander when your cover is blown.
es: Don't forget and tell me it's Elexander before you leave and then try to fix it by saying it's George Elexander when I catch you.

en: And don’t go about women in that old calico.
vi: And don't wear those old clothes when you go to places with women.
tr: Also, don't approach women in that shabby calico dress.
es: And don't go near women with that old dress.

en: You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe.
vi: You can pretend to be a poor girl, but men will still notice.
tr: Your imitation of a girl is quite bad, but maybe you can fool the men.
es: You do a pretty bad job as a girl, but maybe you can fool the men.

en: Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don’t hold the thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and poke the thread at it; that’s the way a woman most always does, but a man always does t’other way.
vi: Poor you, whenever you thread a needle, don't hold the needle still and then thread it; women always do that, but men do it differently.
tr: For heaven's sake, child, the next time you need to thread a needle, don't try to push the needle's eye through the thread; keep the needle steady and pass the thread through the eye... Women always do it this way, but men always do the opposite.
es: And remember, son, when you start threading a needle, you don't have to hold the thread still and bring the needle to it: keep the needle still and pass the thread through it; that's how practically all women do it, but men always do it the other way around.

en: And when you throw at a rat or anything, hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot.
vi: And whenever you throw a mouse or anything else, remember to stand on tiptoe a bit, raise your hand over your head to look very awkward, and throw it a few feet away from the mouse.
tr: Also, if you're going to throw something at a mouse or whatever, rise up on your toes, lift your hand as awkwardly as possible over your head, and then throw it two or three meters away from the mouse.
es: And when you throw something at a rat or something like that, remember that you have to stand on tiptoe and raise your hand above your head as clumsily as you can and miss the rat by six or seven feet.

en: Throw stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out to one side, like a boy.
vi: You have to throw in a way that looks stiff all the way from the shoulder down, as if there's a pin in your shoulder that rotates your arm, so it looks like a girl, not throwing with your wrist or elbow and spreading your arm out to one side like a boy.
tr: Throw directly using your shoulder, as if your arm is moving from the shoulder... Do it like girls do; don't throw like a man by bending your wrist and elbow and opening your arm to the side.
es: Throw with a stiff arm from the shoulder, as if you had an axis, like girls do, and not with the wrist and elbow with the arm to the side, like boys do.

en: And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don’t clap them together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead.
vi: And also remember that when a girl moves, she spreads her knees apart, not keeping them together like you did earlier to hold the lead piece.
tr: And remember, a girl spreads her knees apart to catch something that falls into her lap; she doesn't keep her knees together like you did when catching the lead ball.
es: And remember that when a girl tries to pick something up in her lap, she spreads her knees apart, not together like you did when I threw the lead bar at you.

en: Why, I spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I contrived the other things just to make certain.
vi: It's no wonder, from the moment you threaded the needle, I knew you were a boy, so I tested that to be sure.
tr: I realized you were a boy when you first tried to thread the needle; then I had you do the others to be sure.
es: But man, I knew you were a boy as soon as you started threading the needle, and the other things I did to be sure.

en: Now trot along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble you send word to ms Judith Loftus, which is me, and I’ll do what I can to get you out of it.
vi: Now, go find your uncle, Sara Mary William George Alexander Peter. If you run into any trouble, send word to me, Mrs. Judith Loftus. I'll do whatever I can to help you.
tr: Now go to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble, send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, that is, to me, and I'll do what I can to help.
es: Now, run along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into any trouble, send a message to Mrs. Judith Loftus, who is me, and I'll do what I can to get you out of it.

en: Keep the river road all the way, and next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you.
vi: Follow the river path, and next time you walk such a long distance, wear shoes and socks.
tr: Continue along the river path and don't forget to take shoes and socks with you the next time you go out.
es: Always follow the river road, and next time you set out, wear shoes and socks.

en: The river road’s a rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon.”
vi: The river path is full of pebbles; by the time you get to Goshen, your feet will hurt a lot.
tr: The river path is rocky, and your feet won't be in good shape by the time you reach Goshen.”
es: The river road has a lot of stones, and I figure your feet will be worn out by the time you get to Goshen.

en: I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house.
vi: I walked upstream about fifty meters and then turned back, rushing to the place where the boat was, a distance below that house.
tr: I went fifty meters up along the river, then walked back on my own footprints and moved to the hidden spot below the house where my canoe was.
es: I went along the riverbank for about fifty yards and then retraced my steps to return to where my canoe was, quite far below the house.

en: I jumped in, and was off in a hurry.
vi: I jumped into the boat, hurriedly rowing away.
tr: I immediately jumped into the canoe and hurriedly moved away.
es: I jumped in and started running.

en: I went up-stream far enough to make the head of the island, and then started across.
vi: I went quite far upstream, all the way to the head of the island, then veered across.
tr: After rowing against the current along the shore until I reached the head of the island, I began to cross the river.
es: I went upstream far enough to reach the tip of the island, and then I started to cross.

en: I took off the sun-bonnet, for I didn’t want no blinders on then.
vi: I took off my hat, as there was no need to disguise anymore.
tr: I took off the hat because I didn't want it to obstruct my view.
es: I took off my bonnet, because I didn't want to go as if with earmuffs.

en: When I was about the middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven.
vi: Earlier, when I was halfway there, I heard the bell ringing, faintly over the water but still clear, it was eleven o'clock.
tr: When I reached the middle of the river, I heard the clock chime; I stopped and listened; the sound was faintly coming over the water but I heard it clearly – eleven.
es: When I was about halfway across, I heard the clock start to chime, so I stopped to listen; the sound was faint over the water, but clear: eleven o'clock.

en: When I struck the head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded, but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.
vi: At the head of the island, even though the wind was blowing strong, I didn't need to take cover anymore but headed straight for the spot with the log where I had hidden when I first arrived and had once lit a fire in a dry place.
tr: When I reached the head of the island, even though I was very tired, I didn't wait to catch my breath; I immediately carried some wood to the place where my old camp was and built a huge fire in a high and dry spot.
es: When I reached the tip of the island, I didn't stop to rest, even though I was out of breath; instead, I went straight to where my old camp was and lit a good fire, in a high and dry place.

en: Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go.
vi: I rowed hard to the place where we stayed, more than a mile downstream.
tr: Then I got back into the canoe and rowed about a mile and a half downstream to our main location.
es: Then I jumped into the canoe and went to our spot, a mile and a half downstream, as fast as I could.

en: I landed, and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern.
vi: Then I went ashore, leaped over the log, climbed up the mound, and rushed into the cave.
tr: I landed, quickly passed through the trees, climbed the slope, and entered the cave.
es: I disembarked and moved through the trees to the hill and reached the cave.

en: There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground.
vi: Jim was lying there, fast asleep on the ground.
tr: Jim was sleeping like a log inside.
es: There was Jim, sleeping like a log on the ground.

en: I roused him out and says:
vi: I shook him awake and said:
tr: I immediately woke him up.
es: I woke him up and said to him:

en: “Git up and hump yourself, Jim!
vi: - Wake up, Jim, we're doomed.
tr: “Get up quickly and pack, Jim!
es: —Get up and get ready, Jim!

en: There ain’t a minute to lose.
vi: We can't afford to be late by even a minute.
tr: We don't have a minute to lose.
es: There isn't a minute to lose.

en: They’re after us!”
vi: They're hunting us down!
tr: They're after us!”
es: They're looking for us!

en: Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared.
vi: Jim didn't ask anything nor did he say anything, but just by looking at his hasty manner for about half an hour, one could tell he was very scared.
tr: Jim didn't ask anything, he didn't even say a word; his behavior over the next half hour was enough to show how scared he was.
es: Jim didn't ask any questions or say a word; but from the way he worked the next half hour, it was clear that he was terrified.

en: By that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid.
vi: When the raft was ready to leave the willow thicket, where we had been hiding it.
tr: Now, everything we owned was on our raft, and we were ready to take it out from behind the willow curtain where we had hidden it.
es: By then, we had everything we owned in the raft and were ready to take it out from among the willows where it was hidden.

en: We put out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn’t show a candle outside after that.
vi: The first thing we did was extinguish the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light any candles either.
tr: We had put out the fire in the cave from the very beginning and never lit even a candle outside again.
es: The first thing we did was put out the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light even a candle.

en: I took the canoe out from the shore a little piece, and took a look; but if there was a boat around I couldn’t see it, for stars and shadows ain’t good to see by.
vi: I took the boat out a bit from the shore to scout ahead. But even if there was a boat right there, nothing could be seen because it was pitch dark, with only starlight, nothing visible.
tr: I wanted to sail a bit away from the island to see what was happening, but even if there was a boat there, I couldn't see it; because it was impossible to distinguish anything in the shadows under the starlight.
es: I moved the canoe away from the shore a little and started to look; but if there was a boat around there, I couldn't see it, because the stars and shadows aren't good for seeing much.

en: Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.
vi: Then we pushed the raft out, letting it glide down the river, through the darkness past the other end of the island, silent as death, no one uttering a word.
tr: Then we launched the raft and started descending through the shadows, not moving or uttering a word as we passed the foot of the island.
es: Then we took out the raft and went down among the shadows, to the foot of the island in total silence, without saying a word.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: Chapter XII
tr: Chapter Two
es: Chapter 12

en: It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow.
vi: It was probably close to one in the morning when we finally reached the area below the island. It seemed like our raft was moving incredibly slowly.
tr: It was probably around one o'clock by the time we reached the lower part of the island. Don't even ask how slowly the raft was moving.
es: IT MUST HAVE BEEN almost one o'clock when we finally passed the end of the island and the raft seemed to move very slowly.

en: If a boat was to come along we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois shore; and it was well a boat didn’t come, for we hadn’t ever thought to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat.
vi: If any boat or ship had come by, we would have had to jump into the canoe and make a run for the Illinois shore immediately. But luckily, no boats came by, and we didn't think to put the gun, the fishing rod, or any food into the canoe either.
tr: If we saw a boat, we were going to immediately jump into the canoe and escape to the Illinois shore. Fortunately, no boats were in sight, because we hadn't thought to place the rifle, fishing rods, or food in the canoe.
es: If a boat came near, the plan was to get into the canoe and head towards the Illinois shore, and it's a good thing none did, because it hadn't occurred to us to put the shotgun in the canoe, nor a fishing line, nor anything to eat.

en: We was in ruther too much of a sweat to think of so many things.
vi: At that moment, we were in such a rush, panicking, and didn't think everything through.
tr: We were too drenched in sweat to think of so many things.
es: We were in too much of a hurry to think of so many things.

en: It warn’t good judgment to put everything on the raft.
vi: Besides, putting everything onto the raft wouldn't have been practical.
tr: Loading everything onto the raft was not a wise move at all.
es: It hadn't been very smart to put everything on the raft.

en: If the men went to the island I just expect they found the camp fire I built, and watched it all night for Jim to come.
vi: If those two people come to the island, I'm sure they will see our campfire and wait there all night for Jim to come.
tr: I thought that if the men went to the island, they would find the fire I had lit and lie in ambush, waiting for Jim to return throughout the night.
es: If the men went to the island, I suppose they would find the bonfire I had made and would wait all night for Jim to arrive.

en: Anyways, they stayed away from us, and if my building the fire never fooled them it warn’t no fault of mine.
vi: Anyway, they are still farther from our place, and if our fire deceives them, it's not my fault.
tr: Anyway, they were already far from us, and if the fire I had lit did not deceive them, it was not my fault.
es: In any case, they did not come near us, and if that bonfire did not deceive them, it was not my fault.

en: I played it as low down on them as I could.
vi: But the more we can trick them, the better.
tr: For this, I had made as good a plan as I could.
es: I had done everything possible to mislead them.

en: When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there had been a cave-in in the bank there.
vi: When the first light of day appeared, we tied the raft to a crevice near a large beach on the Illinois side; using an axe, we cut some cottonwood branches to cover it, making it look as if there had long been a recess at this part of the riverbank.
tr: As the first light of dawn began to appear, we pulled the raft to a wooded shore that caught our eye as we came to a large bend on the Illinois side. We covered the raft nicely with branches we cut from the shore, which was lined with densely packed poplar trees like the teeth of a comb.
es: When the first light of day began to appear, we moored to a sandbar that was in a large curve on the Illinois side, cut cottonwood branches with the axe, and covered the raft with them so that it would look like there had been a landslide along that shore.

en: A tow-head is a sandbar that has cottonwoods on it as thick as harrow-teeth.
vi: At the front was a sandbar, with dense cottonwood trees growing thickly like the teeth of a comb.
tr: When we finished our work, it looked as if there was a natural depression among the poplars; the raft was completely invisible.
es: On those sandbars, the cottonwoods are as tightly packed as the teeth of a rake.

en: We had mountains on the Missouri shore and heavy timber on the Illinois side, and the channel was down the Missouri shore at that place, so we warn’t afraid of anybody running across us.
vi: On the Illinois side, there are mountains. On the Illinois side, there are only big trees. This stretch of the river has a creek flowing towards the Illinois side, so we weren't afraid of anyone passing by here.
tr: On the Missouri side, there were mountains, while on the Illinois side, there were dense forests, and since the river flowed from the Missouri side, we had no fear of encountering anyone where we were.
es: We saw mountains on the Missouri side and a lot of forest on the Illinois side, and the channel, on that part, ran on the Missouri side, so we weren't afraid of running into anyone.

en: We laid there all day, and watched the rafts and steamboats spin down the Missouri shore, and up-bound steamboats fight the big river in the middle.
vi: We lay there all day, watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Illinois side, and the boats going upstream roaring in the middle of the river.
tr: We lay there all day watching the rafts and steamers descend towards Missouri and the steamers coming up struggle with the vast river in the middle.
es: We stayed there all day watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Missouri side and the steamboats going upriver fighting against the current in the center.

en: I told Jim all about the time I had jabbering with that woman; and Jim said she was a smart one, and if she was to start after us herself she wouldn’t set down and watch a camp fire—no, sir, she’d fetch a dog.
vi: I told Jim about the time I sat chatting with that woman, and Jim said she was a strange woman; if she had been the one hunting us, she wouldn't have bothered sitting by the campfire, but instead, sir, she would have led the hunt herself.
tr: I told Jim about the conversation I had with that woman; he said she was a cunning woman, and if she were after us, she wouldn't just sit by the campfire – no, sir, she would definitely bring a dog with her.
es: I told Jim everything that had happened when I was talking to the woman and Jim said she was very smart and that if she were the one looking for us, she wouldn't just sit by a fire; no, sir, she would go with a dog.

en: Well, then, I said, why couldn’t she tell her husband to fetch a dog?
vi: I asked why she didn't suggest her husband bring the dogs.
tr: But couldn't she have told her husband to go get a dog?
es: Well, then, I said, why couldn't she tell her husband to get a dog?

en: Jim said he bet she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all that time, or else we wouldn’t be here on a tow-head sixteen or seventeen mile below the village—no, indeedy, we would be in that same old town again.
vi: Jim said he guessed she had thought of that when her husband was about to leave, and probably the man went to town to get the dogs, which took so much time. That's why we could run to this place, sixteen or seventeen miles away from the village; otherwise, we would still be stuck in that old town.
tr: Jim said that the woman had probably already thought of that before the men set out and that they were likely delayed because they went to get a dog from the upper part of the town, otherwise, we wouldn't be at this shallow spot sixteen or seventeen miles down from the village – we would find ourselves back in the old town.
es: Jim said that she would surely think of it when the men set out, and he supposed she must have gone to the upper part of the town to get a dog, so they had lost all that time, or else we wouldn't be there on the sandbar sixteen or seventeen miles below the town; no, sir, we would be back in town.

en: So I said I didn’t care what was the reason they didn’t get us as long as they didn’t.
vi: I think as long as they haven't caught us, it doesn't matter why they haven't caught us yet.
tr: I said that as long as they didn't catch us, I wouldn't care why they didn't catch us.
es: So I said I didn't care why they weren't coming, as long as they didn't come.

en: When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the things dry.
vi: It started to get dark, so we poked our heads out from the pile of cotton, looked around, and saw nothing. Then Jim lifted the planks on the raft and set them up into a tent so we could crawl into it when it rained or shone, and to keep our belongings from getting wet.
tr: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out from between the dense poplars and looked up, down, and across; there was nothing; so Jim took apart a few of the upper planks of the raft to make a narrow shelter to get under in the extreme heat and rain, and also to keep our belongings dry.
es: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out among the poplars and looked up and down and to the sides but saw nothing, so Jim took some of the logs off the top of the raft and built a very comfortable wigwam for us to take shelter in when it got very hot or rained and to keep things dry.

en: Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps was out of reach of steamboat waves.
vi: Jim also built an additional wooden platform about thirty centimeters high on the outside so that when large waves from passing ships hit, they wouldn't splash onto our belongings.
tr: He made space on the raft for the shelter, then raised it about half a meter above the raft's floor; this way, our blankets and traps would no longer be affected by the waves created by the steamers.
es: Jim made a floor for the wigwam and raised it a foot above the level of the raft, so that the blankets and traps were out of reach of the steamboat waves.

en: Right in the middle of the wigwam we made a layer of dirt about five or six inches deep with a frame around it for to hold it to its place; this was to build a fire on in sloppy weather or chilly; the wigwam would keep it from being seen.
vi: In the middle of the tent, we made a small depression, filled it with soil about a decimeter deep, and surrounded it with wood to make a fireplace for when it rained and got cold, and also to keep it inside the tent so people wouldn't see it.
tr: We made a 15-centimeter deep hole in the middle of the shelter out of mud, and supported its perimeter with planks to prevent it from spreading; this was for making a fire in rainy or cool weather, and the shelter would block the fire from being seen from a distance.
es: Right in the middle of the wigwam, we put a layer of dirt five or six inches thick and surrounded it with a frame to keep it from spilling out; it was for making a fire when it rained or got cold; with the wigwam, it wouldn't be visible.

en: We made an extra steering-oar, too, because one of the others might get broke on a snag or something.
vi: We erected a short stick with a notch at the top to hang an old lantern on whenever a ship was passing downstream, to avoid collisions.
tr: We also made an extra steering pole, because the others could get stuck somewhere and break.
es: We also prepared a spare rudder, because one of the ones we had could break or get caught or whatever.

en: We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.
vi: As for the boats going upstream, we didn't need to light the lantern unless we were crossing the river; because the surface water flowed quite strongly, and there were many hidden sandbars below, so upstream boats often didn't travel in the middle of the river but chose spots where the current was less strong.
tr: We set up a short forked stick to hang the old tattered lantern, because when you see a steamer coming down the river, you must light the lantern so it doesn't hit you; but if we weren't at one of those places they call "crossings," there was no need to light the lantern for steamers going upriver. The river was still quite high, and the low-lying banks were still underwater; so the ships going upriver could prefer places with less current instead of using the usual channel.
es: We set up a pole with a fork to hang the old lantern from, because we would always have to light it when we saw a steamboat coming downstream, so it wouldn't miss us, but we didn't have to light it for the ones going upstream unless we found ourselves in what they call "between currents," because the river was still very high and the low banks were still submerged, so the boats going upstream didn't always go through the channel but looked for easier waters.

en: This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour.
vi: On the second night, we traveled for about seven or eight hours, on the fast-flowing water that moved at four miles per hour.
tr: On the second night, we traveled for another seven or eight hours, thanks to the current, we were probably going faster than four miles per hour.
es: The second night we sailed for seven or eight hours, with a current that went more than four miles per hour.

en: We catched fish and talked, and we took a swim now and then to keep off sleepiness.
vi: We caught fish, chatted, and occasionally jumped into the water for a quick swim to stay awake.
tr: We fished, chatted, and when we got sleepy, we tried to wake up by swimming a bit.
es: We fished and chatted and occasionally went for a swim to avoid falling asleep.

en: It was kind of solemn, drifting down the big, still river, laying on our backs looking up at the stars, and we didn’t ever feel like talking loud, and it warn’t often that we laughed—only a little kind of a low chuckle.
