vi: Traveling on this large and quiet river felt solemn somehow. We lay on our backs looking at the stars in the sky, never daring to speak loudly, and rarely laughed. We just kept our mouths shut, making a few puffing sounds.
tr: Drifting on the wide and calm river while lying on our backs and watching the stars felt a bit gloomy, we didn't want to speak loudly at all, nor did we laugh much – occasionally we would let out short, muffled laughs.
es: It was quite solemn to drift down the great silent river, lying on our backs and looking at the stars, and we didn't feel like speaking loudly or laughing much, just an occasional low chuckle.

en: We had mighty good weather as a general thing, and nothing ever happened to us at all—that night, nor the next, nor the next.
vi: Overall, the weather was very nice; that night, the next night, and the night after that, nothing happened.
tr: Generally, the weather was very good and nothing happened to us – neither that night, nor the next, nor the night after that.
es: Overall, we had very good weather and nothing happened to us, neither that night nor the next nor the one after.

en: Every night we passed towns, some of them away up on black hillsides, nothing but just a shiny bed of lights; not a house could you see.
vi: Every night we passed through places with towns, sometimes the town was on a distant hillside, only visible as a long streak of light without clear sight of the houses.
tr: Every night we passed by towns, some of which were on dark slopes in the distance, and all you could see were clusters of bright lights, you couldn't distinguish a single house.
es: Every night we passed by villages, some of them far away on black hills, without seeing anything more than the glow of a few lights, and not a single house.

en: The fifth night we passed St. Louis, and it was like the whole world lit up.
vi: On the fifth night, we passed through St. Louis, which looked like an entire world lit up.
tr: On the fifth night, we passed St. Louis, it was as if the whole world was illuminated.
es: On the fifth night we passed by Saint Louis and it was as if the entire world was illuminated.

en: In St. Petersburg they used to say there was twenty or thirty thousand people in St. Louis, but I never believed it till I see that wonderful spread of lights at two o’clock that still night.
vi: In Petersburg, they always said that St. Louis had up to twenty or thirty thousand people, but I didn't believe it until we passed by at two in the morning and saw such brilliant lights, then I believed it was true.
tr: St. The people in St. Petersburg used to say that twenty to thirty thousand people lived in St. Louis, but I didn't believe it until I saw the beautiful flood of lights covering the entire slope on that still night.
es: In Saint Petersburg, they said that Saint Louis had twenty or thirty thousand inhabitants, but I never believed it until I saw that wonderful amount of lights at two on a silent night.

en: There warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.
vi: Inside the city, there was not a sound, everyone had gone to sleep.
tr: There was no sound, everyone was in a deep sleep.
es: Not a sound was heard: everyone was asleep.

en: Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t roosting comfortable, and took him along.
vi: Every night, I usually go ashore at ten o'clock, go to a small village to buy ten or fifteen cents worth of bread or meat or something to eat, sometimes I catch and bring back a chicken that refuses to stay in its coop.
tr: Every night around ten o'clock, I would secretly go to the shore near a small village; I would buy flour, pastrami, or some other food worth ten or fifteen cents; sometimes I would steal a chicken, but cooking it was difficult and took a long time.
es: Every night I would go to the shore near some village and buy ten or fifteen cents worth of flour or salted bacon or other things to eat, and sometimes I would borrow a chicken that did not seem to feel comfortable.

en: Pap always said, take a chicken when you get a chance, because if you don’t want him yourself you can easy find somebody that does, and a good deed ain’t ever forgot.
vi: My father used to say that whenever there was a chance to catch a chicken, just catch it, because that way you never forget an act of kindness.
tr: My father always used to say, if you come across a chicken, don't miss the opportunity; because even if you didn't eat it yourself, you could always find someone who would, and kindness never went unrewarded.
es: Father always said that you should take a chicken when you have the chance, because if you don't want it, it's easy to find someone who does, and a good deed is never forgotten.

en: I never see pap when he didn’t want the chicken himself, but that is what he used to say, anyway.
vi: I've never actually seen my father not care about chickens, but he always said that.
tr: I never saw my father not eat the chicken himself, but he would still say that.–
es: I never saw a single time that father didn't want it, but in any case, that's what he said.

en: Mornings before daylight I slipped into cornfields and borrowed a watermelon, or a mushmelon, or a punkin, or some new corn, or things of that kind.
vi: There were times when, at the break of dawn, I would sneak into the fields to borrow a melon or a pumpkin, or some corn or sweet potatoes.
tr: In the mornings, before the break of dawn, I would sneak into the cornfields and borrow a watermelon, melon, pumpkin, or fresh corn.
es: In the mornings, before dawn, I would go into the cornfields and borrow a watermelon, or a melon, or a pumpkin, some new corn or things like that.

en: Pap always said it warn’t no harm to borrow things if you was meaning to pay them back some time; but the widow said it warn’t anything but a soft name for stealing, and no decent body would do it.
vi: My father often said that borrowing something from someone with the intention of returning it later is not a bad thing. But the widow said that it was nothing more than a euphemism for stealing, and respectable people don't do such things.
tr: My father used to say that if you intend to pay for something later, there's no harm in borrowing it; but the widow said that this was just dressing up theft and that an honest person would never steal.
es: Father always said that there was nothing wrong with borrowing things if you intended to pay for them someday; but the widow said that it was nothing but stealing, no matter how you dressed it up with words, and that decent people didn't do it.

en: Jim said he reckoned the widow was partly right and pap was partly right; so the best way would be for us to pick out two or three things from the list and say we wouldn’t borrow them any more—then he reckoned it wouldn’t be no harm to borrow the others.
vi: Jim thought that both the widow and my father were somewhat right. So, it was better to take a few things and then tell them that we wouldn't take anything next time. And Jim thought that doing so would make it okay to borrow other things in the future.
tr: According to Jim, the widow was somewhat right, and my father was somewhat right too; so the best thing was to cross off a few items from our list and say we wouldn't borrow those again – then there would be no harm in borrowing the others.
es: Jim said he figured the widow was partly right and dad was partly right, so the best thing would be to pick two or three things from the list and not borrow them again, and then he figured it wouldn't be wrong to borrow the others.

en: So we talked it over all one night, drifting along down the river, trying to make up our minds whether to drop the watermelons, or the cantelopes, or the mushmelons, or what.
vi: So we discussed whether to take melons, pumpkins, or other things.
tr: One night, while drifting down the river, we talked at length about the matter and tried to decide whether to cross off the watermelon, the melon, or something else from the list.
es: So we spent a whole night talking about it, while we went down the river, trying to decide whether to eliminate the watermelons, the cantaloupes, the melons, or what.

en: But towards daylight we got it all settled satisfactory, and concluded to drop crabapples and p’simmons.
vi: But by morning, we resolved the matter and decided to take wild apples and wild pears.
tr: By dawn, we had both thought enough about the matter and decided to cross off wild apples and dates from the list.
es: But by dawn we had everything satisfactorily resolved and concluded that we would eliminate the reinettes and the persimmons.

en: We warn’t feeling just right before that, but it was all comfortable now.
vi: Before that, we were worried that we were doing something wrong, but now we felt at ease.
tr: Before that, we weren't sure if we were doing the right thing, but now we both felt at ease.
es: We hadn't felt quite right before, but now we were at ease.

en: I was glad the way it come out, too, because crabapples ain’t ever good, and the p’simmons wouldn’t be ripe for two or three months yet.
vi: Personally, I was also satisfied with this resolution, partly because wild apples weren't very tasty, and wild pears wouldn't ripen for another few months.
tr: It didn't matter much to me anyway, because wild apples weren't very good and the dates wouldn't be ripe for another two or three months.
es: I was glad we resolved it that way, because reinettes are never good and the persimmons wouldn't be ripe for another two or three months.

en: We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening.
vi: Occasionally, we would shoot a lone animal that was out foraging early in the morning or late at night before it had found a place to sleep.
tr: If we occasionally saw a waterfowl that had either woken up very early in the morning or had not gone to bed early enough at night, we would shoot it.
es: Every now and then we would kill a waterfowl that got up too early in the mornings or didn't go to bed early enough in the evenings.

en: Take it all round, we lived pretty high.
vi: At those times, our life became quite lively.
tr: Considering all of it together, it can be said that we were quite comfortable.
es: Overall, we lived very well.

en: The fifth night below St. Louis we had a big storm after midnight, with a power of thunder and lightning, and the rain poured down in a solid sheet.
vi: By Thursday, down below St Louis, we encountered a big storm around past midnight, with thunder rumbling and rain pouring down heavily.
tr: St. On the fifth night after descending below St. Louis, a great storm broke out after midnight; thunder was rumbling; lightning was flashing, and it was pouring rain.
es: The fifth night, downstream from Saint Louis, there was a great storm after midnight, with lots of thunder and lightning, and the rain fell like a sheet.

en: We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft take care of itself.
vi: We crawled into the tent and let the raft drift.
tr: We went inside the shelter and let the raft drift aimlessly.
es: We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft steer itself.

en: When the lightning glared out we could see a big straight river ahead, and high, rocky bluffs on both sides.
vi: When the lightning flashed, we could see a vast stretch of river and high rocky cliffs on both sides.
tr: When the lightning flashed, we could see the wide river stretching straight ahead of us and rocky cliffs on both sides.
es: When the lightning flashed, we saw the huge and straight river ahead and great cliffs on both sides.

en: By-and-by says I, “Hel-lo, Jim, looky yonder!”
vi: Suddenly I called out: Jim, look over there.
tr: At one point, I called out, “Hey, Jim, look ahead!”
es: And once I go and say: —Wow, Jim, look over there!

en: It was a steamboat that had killed herself on a rock.
vi: It was a steamboat that had crashed into a rocky outcrop.
tr: There was a steamboat wrecked on the rocks ahead of us.
es: It was a steamboat that had wrecked against a rock.

en: We was drifting straight down for her.
vi: We steered the raft directly to the spot.
tr: We were drifting directly towards the boat.
es: We were heading straight towards it.

en: The lightning showed her very distinct.
vi: The lightning lit up everything clearly.
tr: We could see the boat very clearly in the lightning's light.
es: With the lightning, it was very clear.

en: She was leaning over, with part of her upper deck above water, and you could see every little chimbly-guy clean and clear, and a chair by the big bell, with an old slouch hat hanging on the back of it, when the flashes come.
vi: The boat was leaning over, with part of its bow already submerged. Each time the lightning flashed, we could see every small column gleaming, a chair in the pilot's cabin with a hat hanging behind it.
tr: It was lying on its side, part of its upper deck was above water, we could see the ship's smokestacks clearly, there was a chair next to the big bell, and when another lightning flashed, I saw an old wide-brimmed hat hanging on the back of it.
es: It was all listed, with part of the upper deck above the water, and you could see each of the chimney cables very clearly and a chair next to the big bell, with an old hat hanging on the backrest, when the lightning struck.

en: Well, it being away in the night and stormy, and all so mysterious-like, I felt just the way any other boy would a felt when I see that wreck laying there so mournful and lonesome in the middle of the river.
vi: On a stormy night like this, going far from home, everything seems so mysterious; I think any other kid would feel the same as I did when seeing the wrecked ship lying there, as sad as death in the middle of the river.
tr: Breathing in all that mysterious air in the middle of the storm at night and seeing the wreck lying so sorrowful and all alone in the middle of the river made me feel the things that every boy would feel.
es: Well, since it was so late, there was that storm, and everything seemed so mysterious, I thought the same thing any other boy would when I saw that ship stranded so sad and lonely in the middle of the river.

en: I wanted to get aboard of her and slink around a little, and see what there was there.
vi: I wanted to climb up the wrecked ship to look around a bit to see if there was anything.
tr: I wanted to get on the ship and wander inside, to see what was there.
es: I wanted to board it and explore a bit to see what was inside.

en: So I says:
vi: I said.
tr: I wanted to get on the ship and wander inside, to see what was there.
es: So I said:

en: “Le’s land on her, Jim.”
vi: - Climb up, Jim
tr: “Let's get on the ship, Jim,” I said.
es: —Let's tackle it, Jim.

en: But Jim was dead against it at first.
vi: At first, Jim remained silent and said nothing, but then he replied: - I'm not climbing onto that wrecked ship.
tr: Jim didn't want to at first.
es: But at first Jim was totally against it.

en: He says:
vi: We've already committed a sin, so it's better not to commit another, as the book says.
tr: “What are we doing in the wreckage in this weather?
es: He goes and says:

en: “I doan’ want to go fool’n ’long er no wrack.
vi: What if there's a guard on that ship?
tr: It says in the good book, you live and let live, why should we poke around beyond that?
es: —I don't want to go poking my nose into a dead ship.

en: We’s doin’ blame’ well, en we better let blame’ well alone, as de good book says.
vi: I said:
tr: What's your problem?
es: We're doing very well, and it's better to let it stay that way, as the Book says.

en: Like as not dey’s a watchman on dat wrack.”
vi: - What watch? There's no watch, nobody is guarding anything here.
tr: Besides, there might be guards at the wreckage.”
es: I'm sure there's a watchman on that ship.

en: “Watchman your grandmother,” I says; “there ain’t nothing to watch but the texas and the pilot-house; and do you reckon anybody’s going to resk his life for a texas and a pilot-house such a night as this, when it’s likely to break up and wash off down the river any minute?”
vi: Do you think anyone is foolish enough to stay here and guard the engine room and the cockpit on a stormy night like this, especially when we don't know when the ship will break apart and sink to the bottom of the river.
tr: “What guard would be there,” I said. “What else is left to guard besides the upper cabin; moreover, who would risk their life on such a night for a ship that could break apart and drift down the river at any moment?”
es: —Watchman, your grandma —I said—; there's nothing to watch over except the wheelhouse and the upper cabins, and do you think anyone is going to risk their life for a wheelhouse and some cabins on a night like this, when it's most likely to break in two and go down the river at any moment?

en: Jim couldn’t say nothing to that, so he didn’t try.
vi: Jim didn't know what to say, so he gave up.
tr: Jim couldn't find a response to this, so he remained silent.
es: Jim couldn't respond to that, so he didn't try.

en: “And besides,” I says, “we might borrow something worth having out of the captain’s stateroom.
vi: I continued: - Besides, we can temporarily borrow something valuable from the captain's cabin.
tr: “Besides,” I said, “we might find something valuable to borrow from the captain's cabin.
es: —And besides —I said—, we could borrow something worthwhile from the captain's cabin.

en: Seegars, I bet you—and cost five cents apiece, solid cash.
vi: Cigars, you know, each cigar is worth five cents, definitely.
tr: I bet there are cigars... each worth at least five cents.
es: I'm sure there are cigars, the kind that cost five cents each in hard cash.

en: Steamboat captains is always rich, and get sixty dollars a month, and they don’t care a cent what a thing costs, you know, long as they want it.
vi: Captains on riverboats are always rich, earning up to sixty dollars a month, and they never hesitate to buy whatever they want.
tr: Steamboat captains are rich; they earn sixty dollars a month; so if they want something, they don't mind the cost.
es: Steamboat captains are always rich and earn sixty dollars a month, and they don't care what things cost, you know, if they feel like it.

en: Stick a candle in your pocket; I can’t rest, Jim, till we give her a rummaging.
vi: Take a candle out of the bag, Jim, I can't sit still until we've rummaged through there.
tr: Put a candle in your pocket, I won't feel at ease without searching the ship, Jim.
es: Put a candle in your pocket, Jim; I can't wait until we've searched it.

en: Do you reckon Tom Sawyer would ever go by this thing?
vi: Do you think if Tom Sawyer were here he would sit still?
tr: Do you think Tom Sawyer would pass by this wreck?
es: Do you think Tom Sawyer would just leave a place like this?

en: Not for pie, he wouldn’t.
vi: No way, I bet you he wouldn't.
tr: He definitely wouldn't.
es: No way.

en: He’d call it an adventure—that’s what he’d call it; and he’d land on that wreck if it was his last act.
vi: He would call this an adventure, that's right; and eventually, he would have to climb up to that wrecked ship.
tr: He would say this is an adventure... Yes, he would call it an adventure; even if it was the last thing he did, he would climb onto the wreck.
es: He would say it was an adventure, that's what he would say, and he would board that ship even if it was the last thing he did in his life.

en: And wouldn’t he throw style into it?—wouldn’t he spread himself, nor nothing?
vi: And wouldn't he add all sorts of thrilling stories, make up all kinds of things?
tr: And wouldn't he do it in style? He would be so full of swagger.
es: And he would surely do it in style; don't you think he would organize a great one?

en: Why, you’d think it was Christopher C’lumbus discovering Kingdom-Come.
vi: Just go up and see, Jim, and you'll feel like Columbus discovering a new continent. Go up.
tr: You'd think he was Christopher Columbus setting out to discover the Kingdom of God.
es: Man, you would think he was Christopher Columbus discovering the New World.

en: I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”
vi: I just wish Tom Sawyer were here right now.
tr: I wish Tom Sawyer were here!”
es: I wish Tom Sawyer were here.

en: Jim he grumbled a little, but give in.
vi: Jim grumbled a bit, but then he complied.
tr: Jim grumbled a bit more, but finally gave in.
es: Jim grumbled a bit, but he gave in.

en: He said we mustn’t talk any more than we could help, and then talk mighty low.
vi: He said we should stop talking, and if we must speak, to do so very quietly.
tr: He said we absolutely shouldn't talk unless we had to, and if we did, we should whisper.
es: He said we didn't have to talk more than necessary, and that in a very low voice.

en: The lightning showed us the wreck again just in time, and we fetched the stabboard derrick, and made fast there.
vi: Lightning flashed just as we caught sight of the wrecked ship and approached it. We searched for the mast to tie our raft to.
tr: The lightning once again showed the wreck just in time, and we caught the dock on the starboard side and tied the raft.
es: The lightning showed us the wrecked ship just in time again, and we grabbed the starboard davit and tied up there.

en: The deck was high out here.
vi: The side of the ship was high here.
tr: The deck was well above the water level.
es: The deck was very high on that side.

en: We went sneaking down the slope of it to labboard, in the dark, towards the texas, feeling our way slow with our feet, and spreading our hands out to fend off the guys, for it was so dark we couldn’t see no sign of them.
vi: In the darkness, we carefully felt our way along the side of the ship to the cabin door; it felt like our feet were moving too slowly. We reached out in front of us to avoid bumping into posts, as it was pitch black and we couldn't see a thing. Gradually, our eyes adjusted to the dim light of the night, and we managed to climb up.
tr: We boarded the ship from the dock and proceeded towards the captain's cabin. We were feeling the ground with our feet, advancing with our arms outstretched to avoid tripping over the ropes, because it was so dark that we couldn't see anything.
es: We slowly descended the slope towards port, in the darkness, towards the high cabins, feeling our way very slowly with our feet and with our arms wide open to push aside the ropes, because it was so dark that we couldn't see anything.

en: Pretty soon we struck the forward end of the skylight, and clumb on to it; and the next step fetched us in front of the captain’s door, which was open, and by Jimminy, away down through the texas-hall we see a light!
vi: One more step and we would reach the captain's cabin door. The door was already open.
tr: Soon, we reached the skylight and climbed on top of it; a step later, we had reached the open door of the captain's cabin.
es: Soon we reached the front part of the skylight and climbed onto it, and with the next step we found ourselves in front of the captain's door, which was open, and, what the devil, at the other end of the cabins we saw a light!

en: and all in the same second we seem to hear low voices in yonder!
vi: Standing next to Jim, I looked down into the engine room and saw a faint light, and at that moment, it seemed we also heard murmuring voices coming from that direction.
tr: Just then, we saw a light in the cabin and heard someone speaking in a low voice!
es: And at the same moment, it seemed that we heard low voices in the distance!

en: Jim whispered and said he was feeling powerful sick, and told me to come along.
vi: Jim leaned into my ear and whispered that he was very scared, telling me to leave.
tr: Jim whispered that he was feeling bad and wanted to go back.
es: Jim whispered to me that he felt very bad and told me that we should leave.

en: I says, all right, and was going to start for the raft; but just then I heard a voice wail out and say:
vi: I said okay, and was about to head back to the raft when I heard a shout.
tr: I agreed with him and was preparing to return to the raft, but just then I heard someone inside moaning: "Please don't, boys; I swear I won't tell anyone!"
es: I said okay, and we were about to return to the raft when I heard a whining voice saying:

en: “Oh, please don’t, boys; I swear I won’t ever tell!”
vi: - Oh, please, I beg you, don't, I swear I won't tell.
tr: I agreed with him and was preparing to return to the raft, but just then I heard someone inside moaning: "Please don't, boys; I swear I won't tell anyone!"
es: —Oh, please, no, guys! I swear I will never say it!

en: Another voice said, pretty loud:
vi: The voice of another person was louder:
tr: Another person answered loudly:
es: Another voice said, very loudly:

en: “It’s a lie, Jim Turner.
vi: - You are lying, Jim Turner.
tr: “You are lying, Jim Turner.
es: —It's a lie, Jim Turner.

en: You’ve acted this way before.
vi: You have done this before.
tr: You have done this before.
es: You've done the same thing before now.

en: You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell.
vi: You always demand more than your share, and every time you get it because you threaten to expose us if you don't.
tr: You always want more than your share and every time you get it by threatening to snitch on us if we don't give it to you.
es: You always want more than your share of the loot, and you've always taken it, because you swore that if not, you would betray us.

en: But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many.
vi: This time you are saying the same thing.
tr: But this time you have pushed us too far.
es: But now you've said it one time too many.

en: You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”
vi: You are the most despicable, deceitful dog in this place.
tr: You are the vilest, most treacherous dog in this country.”
es: You are the most disgusting and treacherous dog in this country.

en: By this time Jim was gone for the raft.
vi: At this moment, Jim had already gone to the raft.
tr: At that moment, Jim had moved away to go to the raft.
es: By then, Jim had gone to the raft.

en: I was just a-biling with curiosity; and I says to myself, Tom Sawyer wouldn’t back out now, and so I won’t either; I’m a-going to see what’s going on here.
vi: As for me, my curiosity kept me there, and I told myself; if it were Tom Sawyer, he wouldn't leave now. So I thought, I should stay too, to see what was going on here.
tr: But I couldn't go anywhere out of curiosity. I told myself that Tom Sawyer wouldn't turn his back and leave in such a situation, so I wouldn't either; I would find out what was happening there.
es: I was boiling with curiosity. And I told myself that Tom Sawyer wouldn't back down now, so neither would I, and that I was going to see what was happening.

en: So I dropped on my hands and knees in the little passage, and crept aft in the dark till there warn’t but one stateroom betwixt me and the cross-hall of the texas.
vi: I crouched down and crept into the dark, making my way to the captain's cabin.
tr: I started crawling through the narrow passage in the dark; finally, there was only one passenger cabin left between me and the captain's cabin.
es: So I got down on all fours in the hallway and moved forward in the dark until there was only one cabin between the cross-section of the cabins and me.

en: Then in there I see a man stretched on the floor and tied hand and foot, and two men standing over him, and one of them had a dim lantern in his hand, and the other one had a pistol.
vi: I peeked in and saw a man lying on the floor, tightly bound hand and foot, with two other men standing over him, one holding a dim lantern and the other holding a pistol.
tr: When I poked my head out, I saw a man lying on the ground with his hands and feet tied, two men standing over him, one holding a dimmed lantern and the other holding a gun.
es: Then I saw a man lying on the floor, tied hand and foot, and two others over him, one of them holding a dark lantern and the other with a gun.

en: This one kept pointing the pistol at the man’s head on the floor, and saying:
vi: The man with the pistol pointed it at the head of the man on the ground and said:
tr: The one with the gun had the barrel pointed at the man on the ground's head and was saying:
es: The latter kept pointing the gun at the head of the one on the floor and said:

en: “I’d like to!
vi: - Better that way.
tr: “I won't show any mercy!
es: —I would like to, and that's what I should do, you filthy snitch!

en: And I orter, too—a mean skunk!”
vi: I want to shoot you dead, you skunk.
tr: I shouldn't anyway... You despicable man!”
es: —I would like to, and that's what I should do, you filthy snitch!

en: The man on the floor would shrivel up and say, “Oh, please don’t, Bill; I hain’t ever goin’ to tell.”
vi: The person lying on the floor craned their neck and said: - Oh, I beg you, don't, Bill, I swear I will never say:
tr: The man on the ground was trembling violently. "Please, don't do it, Bill. I won't tell anyone."
es: The man on the ground was shrinking, saying: —Oh, please, no, Bill; I will never betray you.

en: And every time he said that the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
vi: Each time it happened, the person holding the lantern would laugh:
tr: Whenever the man on the ground said this, the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
es: And every time he said that, the man with the lantern laughed and said:

en: “’Deed you ain’t!
vi: - Are you really not going to talk?
tr: “No doubt about it!
es: —Of course not!

en: You never said no truer thing ’n that, you bet you.”
vi: You have never been more truthful than this, right?
tr: You've never said anything this true before.”
es: In your life, you have never spoken a greater truth, I assure you —and once he said—: Listen to how he begs!

en: And once he said: “Hear him beg!
vi: Listen to him begging you!
tr: At one point, he said: “Look how he's begging!
es: In your life, you have never spoken a greater truth, I assure you —and once he said—: Listen to how he begs!

en: and yit if we hadn’t got the best of him and tied him he’d a killed us both.
vi: If we don't find a way to tie him up, he'll kill us all.
tr: But if we hadn't acted first and tied him up, he would have killed both of us.
es: But if we didn't have him subdued and tied up, he would have killed us both.

en: And what for?
vi: And what are you planning to kill us for?
tr: And for what?
es: And why?

en: Jist for noth’n.
vi: You won't gain anything.
tr: For a whole lot of nothing.
es: For nothing.

en: Jist because we stood on our rights—that’s what for.
vi: We just want to protect our own interests.
tr: Just because we're defending our own rights… for this.
es: Just because we defended our rights, that's why.

en: But I lay you ain’t a-goin’ to threaten nobody any more, Jim Turner.
vi: But I won't let you scare anyone anymore, you hear me, Jim Turner.
tr: But from now on, you won't be able to threaten anyone, Jim Turner.
es: But I bet you, Jim Turner, that you won't threaten anyone again.

en: Put up that pistol, Bill.”
vi: Put the gun down, Bill.
tr: Put down that gun, Bill.”
es: Put down that gun, Bill.

en: Bill says:
vi: Bill said:
tr: Put down that gun, Bill.”
es: Bill says:

en: “I don’t want to, Jake Packard.
vi: - I don't want that, Jake Packark.
tr: "I can't lower it, Jake Packard.
es: —I don't feel like it, Jake Packard.

en: I’m for killin’ him—and didn’t he kill old Hatfield jist the same way—and don’t he deserve it?”
vi: I want to kill him. Didn't he kill old Hatfield like that before? Isn't it worth killing him now?
tr: I'm determined to kill him... just like he shot poor Hatfield... Doesn't he deserve it?"
es: I'm okay with killing him, didn't he kill old Hatfield like that, and doesn't he deserve it?

en: “But I don’t want him killed, and I’ve got my reasons for it.”
vi: - But I don't want it to die, and I already have my plan. The person lying on the ground is crying and wailing.
tr: “But I don't want him to die, listen to me first.”
es: —But I don't want to kill him, and I have my reasons.

en: “Bless yo’ heart for them words, Jake Packard!
vi: - Please, spare Jack Packard!
tr: "Don't be absent, Jake Packard!
es: —Bless you for those words, Jake Packard!

en: I’ll never forgit you long’s I live!” says the man on the floor, sort of blubbering.
vi: As long as I live, I will never forget you.
tr: As long as I live, I will never forget you!" said the man lying on the ground, amidst sobs.
es: I won't forget them as long as I live! —says the man on the ground, as if stuttering.

en: Packard didn’t take no notice of that, but hung up his lantern on a nail and started towards where I was there in the dark, and motioned Bill to come.
vi: Packard didn't pay attention to those words, hung the lamp on a nail, and walked towards the spot where I was hiding in the dark and called Bill to come out as well.
tr: Packard didn't care at all, he hung his lantern on a nail and started walking towards the place where I was waiting in the dark and signaled Bill to follow him.
es: Packard paid no attention, but hung the lantern on a nail and advanced towards where I was in the darkness and gestured to Bill to come closer.

en: I crawfished as fast as I could about two yards, but the boat slanted so that I couldn’t make very good time; so to keep from getting run over and catched I crawled into a stateroom on the upper side.
vi: I hurriedly crawled quickly for a few yards, but the ship was swaying, so I couldn't get far. To avoid being stepped on and caught, I crawled back up towards the cockpit.
tr: I crawled back about two meters as fast as I could, but since the ship was listing, I hadn't moved quickly enough; so I retreated towards an upper passenger cabin to avoid being caught.
es: I retreated about two yards as quickly as I could, but the ship was so tilted that I couldn't go very fast, so to avoid him stumbling upon me and catching me, I hid in a cabin on the upper part.

en: The man came a-pawing along in the dark, and when Packard got to my stateroom, he says:
vi: The person leading the way groped in the darkness, reaching the cockpit right next to where I was hiding; then said:
tr: The man advanced in the dark by feeling his way and when he reached the level of the cabin where I was, he called out behind him:
es: The man groped in the darkness, and when Packard reached my cabin he said:

en: “Here—come in here.”
vi: - Here, come in.
tr: “Come… Let's go in here.”
es: —Here, come here.

en: And in he come, and Bill after him.
vi: He was let in, and Bill followed.
tr: Packard entered, and Bill followed him.
es: And there he went in, with Bill behind him.

en: But before they got in I was up in the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come.
vi: But before the two of them fully entered, I had already managed to slip up onto the hanging bed above and curl up in a corner. Regretting in my gut that I had foolishly crawled to this spot.
tr: But by the time they arrived, I had climbed to the top bunk, huddled in the corner, and was writhing in regret for coming there.
es: But before they entered, I had climbed up to the top bunk, cornered and regretting having gone.

en: Then they stood there, with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked.
vi: They stood right next to me, holding onto the bed frame and talking.
tr: Then they stood there and started talking, leaning their hands on the edge of the bunk.
es: Then they stayed there with their hands on the edge of the bunk, talking.

en: I couldn’t see them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they’d been having.
vi: I couldn't see the two clearly, but I could tell where they were standing because their breath reeked of whiskey.
tr: I couldn't see them, but I could tell where they were from the smell of whiskey on their breath.
es: I couldn't see them, but I knew where they were by the smell of the whisky they had drunk.

en: I was glad I didn’t drink whisky; but it wouldn’t made much difference anyway, because most of the time they couldn’t a treed me because I didn’t breathe.
vi: Fortunately, I don't drink whiskey; but that didn't make much difference; they still couldn't know I was lying there because I wasn't breathing.
tr: I was glad I didn't drink whiskey, but it didn't really matter, because they couldn't notice me since I wasn't even breathing.
es: I was glad I didn't drink whisky, although it wouldn't have mattered much, because it was almost impossible for them to smell me since I wasn't breathing.

en: I was too scared.
vi: I was too scared.
tr: I was very scared.
es: I was too scared.

en: And, besides, a body couldn’t breathe and hear such talk.
vi: Besides, if I breathed, I wouldn't be able to hear their conversation.
tr: Besides, one can't both breathe and listen to them at the same time.
es: And besides, one couldn't breathe while listening to that.

en: They talked low and earnest.
vi: They spoke very softly and slowly.
tr: They were speaking in hushed and angry tones.
es: They spoke in low voices and very seriously.

en: Bill wanted to kill Turner.
vi: Bill wanted to know about Turner right away.
tr: Bill's intention was to kill Turner.
es: Bill wanted to kill Turner.

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: He said:
es: He says:

en: “He’s said he’ll tell, and he will.
vi: - It said it would tell, so it will definitely tell.
tr: “He said he would betray us, and he will do exactly that, I have no doubt.
es: —He said he would betray us, and he will.

en: If we was to give both our shares to him now it wouldn’t make no difference after the row and the way we’ve served him.
vi: If we have to give it our share, it still wouldn't be any better, especially after all the hard work and the way we've been serving it.
tr: Even if we both give him our shares now, it won't make any difference after what we've done. I know for sure that he will snitch on us.
es: If we gave him our shares now, it wouldn't matter after the fight and what we've done to him.

en: Shore’s you’re born, he’ll turn State’s evidence; now you hear me.
vi: Everything we've done, it will report it all; do you hear me?
tr: He will testify against us. Listen to me.
es: You can be sure he would testify against us; now, listen to me.

en: I’m for putting him out of his troubles.”
vi: I'll get rid of it, and that'll be the end of it.
tr: Let's just end all his troubles once and for all.”
es: I'm in favor of removing his troubles forever.

en: “So’m I,” says Packard, very quiet.
vi: Packard calmly said:
tr: “I think so too,” Packard whispered.
es: —And me too —said Packard, very calmly.

en: “Blame it, I’d sorter begun to think you wasn’t.
vi: - I thought the same. - You monkey. I thought you didn't want that.
tr: “Damn it, I was beginning to think you had something else on your mind.
es: —Damn it, I had started to believe it wasn't going to happen.

en: Well, then, that’s all right.
vi: If so, that's great.
tr: Alright then.
es: Well, then there's no problem.

en: Le’s go and do it.”
vi: Alright, let's get to it.
tr: Let's go finish this job.”
es: Let's go with it.

en: “Hold on a minute; I hain’t had my say yit.
vi: - Wait a minute, I haven't finished talking.
tr: “Wait a minute, I haven't finished what I have to say yet.
es: —Wait a moment; I haven't said my part yet.

en: You listen to me.
vi: Listen here, shooting is fine but there are quieter ways if we need to kill it.
tr: Now you listen to me.
es: Listen to me.

en: Shooting’s good, but there’s quieter ways if the thing’s got to be done.
vi: Listen here, shooting is fine but there are quieter ways if we need to kill it.
tr: If necessary, we will strike, but there are quieter ways to resolve this issue.
es: It's fine to shoot him, but there are more discreet ways if it needs to be done.

en: But what I say is this: it ain’t good sense to go court’n around after a halter if you can git at what you’re up to in some way that’s jist as good and at the same time don’t bring you into no resks.
vi: Listen here, shooting is fine but there are quieter ways if we need to kill it.
tr: This is what I say: There's no point in sticking our necks out when there's another way that has no risk but will have the same effect.
es: But what I'm saying is this: there's no point in looking to get a noose around our necks when we can achieve the same thing without any risk.

en: Ain’t that so?”
vi: I think this: if we hang it, we'll feel guilty wherever we go later.
tr: Am I wrong?”
es: Isn't that right?

en: “You bet it is.
vi: If there's a way like that without any worries and also not dangerous for us, we should do it, don't you think?
tr: “You are absolutely right.
es: —Surely yes.

en: But how you goin’ to manage it this time?”
vi: - Yes, but what else can be done at this moment?
tr: Okay, but how are we going to handle this job this time?”
es: But, how are you going to manage this time?

en: “Well, my idea is this: we’ll rustle around and gather up whatever pickins we’ve overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and hide the truck.
vi: - No, I think we should look around here, pick up the things we find in the cockpit, and hide them on the shore first.
tr: “I have an idea: We'll search the area thoroughly again and check if there's anything we missed in the cabins, then we'll row to the shore and hide everything.
es: —Well, I've thought of the following: we search everywhere and gather what we might have forgotten in the cabins, we go to the shore and hide the loot.

en: Then we’ll wait.
vi: Then we'll see.
tr: After that, we'll wait.
es: Then we wait.

en: Now I say it ain’t a-goin’ to be more’n two hours befo’ this wrack breaks up and washes off down the river.
vi: I'm sure that in just over two hours, this ship will break apart and sink to the bottom.
tr: If you ask me, this wreck will break apart within two hours and drift down the river.
es: I say it won't be more than two hours before this wreck splits in two and floats down the river.

en: See?
vi: Do you hear?
tr: Do you understand?
es: Do you understand?

en: He’ll be drownded, and won’t have nobody to blame for it but his own self.
vi: It will drown, and it won't be able to blame anyone, only itself.
tr: The man will drown and there will be no one else to blame but himself.
es: He will drown and won't be able to report anyone.

en: I reckon that’s a considerble sight better ’n killin’ of him.
vi: I think killing it this way is the best option. I don't want to kill someone and then be haunted by it forever.
tr: I think doing something like this is much better than shooting him.
es: I think it's much better than killing him.

en: I’m unfavorable to killin’ a man as long as you can git aroun’ it; it ain’t good sense, it ain’t good morals.
vi: That's not good, and it's not ethical.
tr: Shooting a man when there's another way doesn't sound good at all. It's neither wise nor does it preserve our morals.
es: I'm not in favor of killing someone if it can be avoided; it doesn't make sense and it's not moral.

en: Ain’t I right?”
vi: Isn't it?
tr: Am I wrong?”
es: Am I right or not?

en: “Yes, I reck’n you are.
vi: - Yeah, I think you might be right.
tr: “Yes, you are right.
es: —I suppose so.

en: But s’pose she don’t break up and wash off?”
vi: But what if the ship doesn't break or sink?
tr: But what if the wreckage doesn't break apart and disappear?”
es: But, what if it doesn't break and floats down?

en: “Well, we can wait the two hours anyway and see, can’t we?”
vi: - Well, anyway, let's wait for two hours and see what happens
tr: “Alright, we can still wait for two hours and see, can't we?”
es: —Well, anyway, we can wait two hours to see what happens, right?

en: “All right, then; come along.”
vi: - Alright, let's go!
tr: “Alright then, let's go.”
es: —Alright; let's go.

en: So they started, and I lit out, all in a cold sweat, and scrambled forward.
vi: Two people stepped out, and I slipped out after them, cold sweat covering my body. I crawled forward.
tr: So they set to work; I, drenched in cold sweat, crawled out of the cabin and made my way to the bow.
es: So they set off and I took off, drenched in cold sweat, staggering to the bow.

en: It was dark as pitch there; but I said, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “Jim!” and he answered up, right at my elbow, with a sort of a moan, and I says:
vi: It was pitch dark. I softly called out: Jim, right next to my arm, Jim's voice responded, sounding like a moan. I said:
tr: It was pitch dark there, but still, I whispered, "Jim!" and a groan came from right beside my elbow.
es: It was pitch dark but I said in a sort of hoarse whisper: "Jim!" He responded right next to me with a sort of groan and I said:

en: “Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the wreck there’s one of ’em going to be in a bad fix.
vi: - Hurry up, Jim. There's no time for nonsense and lamenting anymore. There are some robbers in there.
tr: “Hurry up, Jim, we don't have time to dawdle or moan; there's a gang of murderers inside, and if we don't find their boat and untie it to trap them here, they'll be stranded and one of them will be killed.
es: —Quick, Jim, there's no time to waste with complaints; there's a gang of murderers over there, and if we don't find their boat and push it into the river so they can't leave the ship, one of them is going to be in big trouble.

en: But if we find their boat we can put all of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em.
vi: If we find their boat and let it drift away so they can't escape from this wrecked ship, one of them will be doomed. And if we find their boat, we can ensure that all of them are caught because the sheriff will come and arrest them.
tr: If we find the boat, they'll all be stranded... The sheriff can come and catch them too.
es: But if we find the boat, we can leave them all in big trouble: the sheriff will find them.

en: Quick—hurry!
vi: Now hurry up, I'll go to the side of the pilot's cabin, and you run to the other side.
tr: Hurry up... hurry!
es: Quick... hurry!

en: I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard.
vi: Now hurry up, I'll go to the side of the pilot's cabin, and you run to the other side.
tr: I'll check the starboard side, you check the port side.
es: I'll search the port side and you search the starboard side.

en: You start at the raft, and—”
vi: You go to the raft then...
tr: Go and start from there with the raft...”
es: Start with the raft, and...

en: “Oh, my lordy, lordy!
vi: Oh, my God, the raft?
tr: “Oh, Tanğım, Tanğım!
es: —Oh, my lord, my lord.

en: Raf’? Dey ain’ no raf’ no mo’; she done broke loose en gone I—en here we is!”
vi: Where is the raft? It has broken loose and drifted away - well, we're stuck here now!
tr: Is it gone? There is no raft or anything on the river, the rope has come undone, it's gone... we are stranded on this shore!”
es: Raft? There is no raft left. It has broken or disappeared! And we are here!

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Chapter XIII
tr: Chapter Thirteen
es: Chapter 13

en: Well, I catched my breath and most fainted.
vi: I was breathless, almost about to collapse.
tr: My breath got stuck in my throat, I almost fainted.
es: WELL, I jumped and fainted.

en: Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that!
vi: Being stuck on a wrecked ship with a bunch of pirates like this!
tr: Being trapped in the same wreck with such a gang!
es: Trapped on a shipwreck with a band of murderers!

en: But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering.
vi: But no, there’s no time to sit and lament.
tr: But it was no time to get emotional.
es: But there was no time for whining.

en: We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves.
vi: We had to find a way to get something out of there and escape.
tr: We had to find that boat immediately… we were going to use it ourselves.
es: Now we had to find the boat and take it for ourselves.

en: So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern.
vi: We walked while shaking the ship's sides, but why did it feel so slow, as if it would take a week just to reach the stern.
tr: So, trembling with fear, we started to move towards the dock, progressing very slowly; it felt like it took a week to reach the stern.
es: We went down trembling and shivering on the starboard side and it took a long time: it seemed like a week passed before we reached the stern.

en: No sign of a boat.
vi: There was no sign of any boat.
tr: There was no trace of the boat.
es: There was no sign of the boat.

en: Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said.
vi: Jim said he wasn't sure if he could walk anymore, he was so scared that he had no strength left to walk - that's what he said.
tr: Jim said he couldn't go any further – he was so scared that he had no strength left.
es: Jim said he didn't think he had the strength to go on: he was so scared he couldn't take it anymore, he said.

en: But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure.
vi: But I urged him to keep going, if we got stuck on this wrecked ship, we would surely die.
tr: But I explained to him that if we stayed in this wreck, we would be in big trouble.
es: But I told him: "Come on, if we stay here, we're sure to have a bad time."

en: So on we prowled again.
vi: We continued to grope our way forward.
tr: So we started walking again.
es: So we kept looking.

en: We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water.
vi: We managed to reach the stern, clinging to the window frame, but the window was almost submerged.
tr: We passed behind the captain's cabin, then reached for the skylight, holding onto the covers as part of the window was underwater.
es: We went to the stern of the upper deck and found it; then we climbed up through the skylight as best we could, grabbing onto every iron, because the edge of the skylight was already in the water.

en: When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough!
vi: When we got to the main door to go to the passenger cabin, we saw a small boat there.
tr: As we got closer to the corridor door, we finally located the boat!
es: When we were quite close to the lobby, we found the boat, at last!

en: I could just barely see her.
vi: It's definitely a boat, I can see it clearly.
tr: I could barely see its silhouette.
es: I barely saw it.

en: I felt ever so thankful.
vi: Oh my God! There is no greater joy than this.
tr: I didn't know how to thank God.
es: I felt very happy.

en: In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened.
vi: I was just about to climb up when the door suddenly opened.
tr: A second later, I would have jumped onto the boat, but just then the door opened.
es: One more second and I would have boarded, but just then the door opened.

en: One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:
vi: A person stuck their head out, just about half a meter away from me. I thought I was done for, but then the person pulled their head back in and said:
tr: One of the men poked his head out just a few steps away from me! At that moment, I thought I was done for, but he pulled his head back in and called out:
es: One of the men stuck his head out just a couple of feet from me and I thought my final hour had come, but he pulled it back in and said:

en: “Heave that blame lantern out o’ sight, Bill!”
vi: - Lift the lamp up a bit so we can see, Bill!
tr: "Get that damn lantern out of sight, Bill!"
es: —Bill, hide that damn lantern!

en: He flung a bag of something into the boat, and then got in himself and set down.
vi: He threw some kind of bundle into the ship's hold, then stepped in following the steps down.
tr: He threw a full bag into the boat, then got in and sat down himself.
es: He threw a sack with something into the boat and then got in and sat down.

en: It was Packard.
vi: That was Packard.
tr: This was Packard.
es: It was Packard.

en: Then Bill he come out and got in.
vi: Then Bill followed in as well.
tr: Then Bill appeared and boarded the boat.
es: Then Bill came out and got into the boat.

en: Packard says, in a low voice:
vi: Packard whispered:
tr: Packard whispered:
es: Packard goes and says:

en: “All ready—shove off!”
vi: - It's all done, push it
tr: “Everything is ready... Row the oars!”
es: —Ready... push!

en: I couldn’t hardly hang on to the shutters, I was so weak.
vi: - I couldn't swing up to the door, because I was too weak.
tr: I was so exhausted that I was about to let go of the lid I was holding onto.
es: I could barely hold onto the bars, I felt so weak.

en: But Bill says:
vi: Bill said:
tr: But Bill hesitated:
es: But Bill goes and says:

en: “Hold on—’d you go through him?”
vi: - Hold on to it, have you thoroughly checked it yet?
tr: “Wait a moment... Did you search him?”
es: —Wait... have you searched him?

en: “No. Didn’t you?”
vi: - Not yet, did you check again?
tr: “No. Didn't you call?”
es: —No.

en: “No.
vi: - No, but it hasn't taken its share yet.
tr: “No.
es: And you? —No.

en: So he’s got his share o’ the cash yet.”
vi: - No, but it hasn't taken its share yet.
tr: Then your share of the cash is still on you.”
es: So, he still has his share of the money.

en: “Well, then, come along; no use to take truck and leave money.”
vi: - Alright, that's enough, go, you don't need to take your belongings or leave any money behind.
tr: “What are we waiting for, let's take it immediately; there's no point in taking the goods and leaving the money.”
es: —Alright, let's go then. It doesn't make sense to take the things and leave the money.

en: “Say, won’t he suspicion what we’re up to?”
vi: - But hey, could it be suspected that I went up to do something?
tr: “Shouldn't she understand what we are going to do to her?”
es: —Hey, do you think he suspects what we're preparing?

en: “Maybe he won’t.
vi: - Maybe not.
tr: “He probably won't understand.
es: —Maybe not.

en: But we got to have it anyway.
vi: But anyway, I've already got it in the bag.
tr: Besides, what does it matter, let's take them all.
es: So they disembarked and went back in.

en: Come along.”
vi: Let's go.
tr: Come on, let's go.”
es: So they disembarked and went back in.

en: So they got out and went in.
vi: Then they went out.
tr: They got out of the boat and boarded the ship again.
es: So they disembarked and went back in.

en: The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me.
vi: The door slammed shut because it was on the side that closed in. In just a split second, I had jumped into the small boat.
tr: Since he was on the upper side of the ship, he bumped into the backs of doors; within half a second, I was in the boat, and Jim came tumbling after me.
es: The door slammed shut because it was on the tilted side, and half a second later I found myself in the boat and Jim stumbled in behind me.

en: I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
vi: Jim shakily jumped in after me, and I pulled out my pocket knife to cut the rope. And then we were off.
tr: I took out my knife, cut the rope, and we set off!
es: I took out the knife, cut the rope, and we were off!

en: We didn’t touch an oar, and we didn’t speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe.
vi: We did not touch a single paddle, did not speak nor whisper, not even daring to breathe heavily.
tr: We did not touch the oars, we did not speak at all, we did not even whisper, we did not dare to breathe.
es: We did not touch a single oar nor did we speak or whisper, and we almost didn't even breathe.

en: We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
vi: Letting the boat glide silently, as quiet as death, passing by the ship's wheel, then passing by the stern, and a few seconds later, we were nearly a hundred meters away from the wrecked ship. The darkness had completely obscured everything, and we could no longer see the ship. And we knew that we had escaped.
tr: We were rapidly moving away without making any noise, narrowly missing the wheel, separating from the stern, and a few seconds later we were about a hundred meters away from the wreckage, which had completely sunk into darkness, with not the slightest trace left, we were safe now.
es: We slid down very quickly, in total silence, past the drum of the wheel and the stern, and then, in a second or two more, we were a hundred yards below the ship and the darkness hid it without a trace; we were safe and we knew it.

en: When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.
vi: When we had gone about three or four hundred meters away, I looked back and saw the light flicker for a moment at the engine room door for about a second. We knew that those guys couldn't leave the ship and were just as confused as Jim Turner, who was tied up.
tr: After going down the river for about three to four hundred meters, a lantern flickered like a spark at the door of the captain's cabin; the bandits had noticed that the boat was leaving and realized that they were in at least as much trouble as Jim Turner.
es: When we were three or four hundred yards downstream, we saw the lantern like a little spark at the door of the upper deck for a second and knew from that that the bandits had seen that they were left without the boat and were beginning to understand that they themselves had as much trouble as Jim Turner.

en: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.
vi: Then Jim took the oar, and we quickly rowed the boat to find our raft.
tr: Then Jim took to the oars and we started following our raft.
es: Then Jim took to the oars and we started looking for our raft.

en: Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the men—I reckon I hadn’t had time to before.
vi: At this point, I began to think about those guys, because honestly, earlier I didn't have the heart to worry about them at all.
tr: For the first time, I began to worry about the men – I guess I hadn't had the time before.
es: It was then that I began to worry about the men: I guess I hadn't had time before.

en: I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix.
vi: I started to think that, even for murderers, being trapped to death in such a situation is truly horrifying.
tr: I started to think about how terrifying it must be to be in such a situation, even for killers.
es: I started to think how terrible it was, even for murderers, to be in such a situation.

en: I says to myself, there ain’t no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it?
vi: I told myself that I couldn't talk about becoming a murderer, so how could I possibly want them to be like that.
tr: Who knows, maybe one day I myself would become a killer, would I like it then?
es: I told myself that I didn't know if I would ever become a murderer and then how I would feel about it.

en: So says I to Jim:
vi: I told Jim:
tr: So I turned to Jim:
es: So I go and say to Jim:

en: “The first light we see we’ll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it’s a good hiding-place for you and the skiff, and then I’ll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.”
vi: - Whenever we see a place with lights, we will dock about a hundred meters from there, find a spot where you can hide this small boat, and I will go find someone who came to the shipwreck earlier to rescue those pirates.
tr: "Let's land a hundred meters below or above the first light we see, and after arranging a good hiding place for both you and the boat, I'll go find someone. Let them save that gang of murderers, and when the time comes, let them hang them."
es: —The first light we see, we disembark a hundred yards below or above it, in a place where you and the boat can hide well, and then I'll go and tell them some story and get someone to go fetch that gang and get them out of their situation, so they can be hanged when the time comes.

en: But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever.
vi: But that idea couldn't be carried out, because just as it was mentioned, the storm came again, and this time it was even more terrifying.
tr: But I couldn't realize this idea; because a worse storm than the last one started shortly after.
es: But the idea failed, because the storm started again immediately, and this time worse than before.

en: The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon.
vi: The rain poured down without any lightning. I think at this moment everyone was asleep.
tr: It was pouring rain and not a single light was visible; presumably, everyone was asleep.
es: The rain was pouring down in torrents and not a light was to be seen; I guess everyone was in bed.

en: We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.
vi: We kept rowing the boat along the river, looking for lights, looking for our raft.
tr: We continued down the river, searching for lights and our raft.
es: We went down the river looking for lights and keeping an eye on our raft.

en: After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
vi: After a very long time, the rain stopped but the sky was still heavy with clouds, then there was a rumbling thunder and a flash of lightning, we saw something black floating ahead, and we rushed forward to chase it.
tr: After a while, the rain lightened, but the sky was still cloudy and the thunder continued; at one point, when lightning struck, we saw a black object floating ahead of us and steered towards it.
es: After a long while, the rain stopped but it remained cloudy and lightning continued to flash, and one of them showed us something black floating ahead, so we headed there.

en: It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again.
vi: That is the raft. We were extremely delighted and climbed back on.
tr: We had found it on Tuesday and were very happy when we got back on it.
es: It was the raft, and we were very happy to get back on it.

en: We seen a light now away down to the right, on shore.
vi: On the right bank, a little below us, we suddenly saw a light.
tr: We had seen a light on the right side, on the shore.
es: Then we saw a light down on the shore, to the right.

en: So I said I would go for it.
vi: I decided to go there.
tr: I suggested going there.
es: So I said we should go there.

en: The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck.
vi: The boat was still full of the belongings that the robbers had taken and loaded in. We hauled a pile of them onto the raft.
tr: The boat was half-filled with the odds and ends the gang had stolen from the wreck.
es: The boat was half full of the loot that the gang had stolen from the wrecked ship.

en: We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light.
vi: I told Jim to let the boat drift further downstream. I pointed out to him the light that he thought was nearly two miles away, but the light kept flickering until we got closer. I took up the paddle and pushed the boat towards the light.
tr: We stacked everything on the raft and told Jim to keep going downstream, light a lamp after about two miles, and keep it lit until I got there; then I took the oars and started rowing towards the light.
es: We piled it all onto the raft and I told Jim to drift downstream and light a signal when he thought he had gone two miles and to keep it lit until I arrived; then I took the oars and headed towards the light.

en: As I got down towards it, three or four more showed—up on a hillside.
vi: The closer I got, the more I saw three or four more lights flashing on the hillside.
tr: As I got closer to the light, three or four more lights appeared – they were all on the hillside.
es: When I got closer, I saw three or four more lights on a hill.

en: It was a village.
vi: It turned out to be a village.
tr: So, this was a village.
es: It was a town.

en: I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated.
vi: I moved towards the light closest to the shore, keeping the paddle in place to let the boat drift gently.
tr: I pulled the oars out of the water just above the light on the shore and continued with the current.
es: I went straight to the light on the shore, stopped rowing, and kept floating.

en: As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
vi: When I got there and looked closely, it turned out to be a lantern hanging on the mast of a wrecked ship.
tr: As far as I could see, this light was coming from a lantern hung on the mast of a double-hulled ferry.
es: As I passed, I saw it was a lantern hanging from the mast of a double-hulled ferry.

en: I skimmed around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and by-and-by I found him roosting on the bitts, forward, with his head down between his knees.
vi: I stepped up to find the guard and saw a guy sleeping there, his head leaning forward and his knees tucked in as he slept.
tr: I searched around to find where the watchman was sleeping and finally found him curled up on the deck bollard at the bow, sleeping.
es: I started looking for the watchman, wondering where he might be sleeping, and after a while, I saw him leaning against the bow bitt, with his head resting on his knees.

en: I gave his shoulder two or three little shoves, and begun to cry.
vi: I gently tapped him on the shoulder twice and then spoke in a tearful tone.
tr: I nudged his shoulder two or three times and started crying.
es: I gave him two or three taps on the shoulder and started to cry.

en: He stirred up, in a kind of a startlish way; but when he see it was only me, he took a good gap and stretch, and then he says:
vi: He startled awake, looked out and saw only me, then yawned, stretched, and said:
tr: Adam was startled for a moment, but then, seeing that it was just a boy in front of him, he stretched and yawned.
es: He started to stretch as if alarmed, but when he saw it was only me, he yawned and stretched well, and then said:

en: “Hello, what’s up?
vi: - Huh, what's going on?
tr: “What's the matter, child?
es: —Hey, what's wrong?

en: Don’t cry, bub.
vi: Don't cry, little brother.
tr: Don't cry, come on.
es: Don't cry, boy.

en: What’s the trouble?”
vi: What's wrong, what's wrong?
tr: What's your trouble?”
es: What's happening to you?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and…””
es: And I say:

en: “Pap, and mam, and sis, and—”
vi: - My father, my mother, and my sister, and...
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and…””
es: —Father and mother and my little sister...

en: Then I broke down.
vi: Then I stopped.
tr: Then I started crying again.
es: And I started crying again.

en: He says:
vi: He asked:
tr: Then I started crying again.
es: Then he goes and says:

en: “Oh, dang it now, don’t take on so; we all has to have our troubles, and this’n ’ll come out all right.
vi: - Oh, don't worry. Just relax. Everyone has difficulties, but it all works out in the end.
tr: “Pull yourself together, don't let yourself go like this; we all have problems, yours will be solved too.
es: —Come on, damn it, don't be like that; we all have our problems and this one will get sorted out.

en: What’s the matter with ’em?”
vi: So, what's wrong with them?
tr: Come on, tell me, what happened to them?”
es: What's wrong with them?

en: “They’re—they’re—are you the watchman of the boat?”
vi: - They... uh - they... but are you the train guard?
tr: “They... they... are you the guardian of the ship?”
es: —They... they... are you the ship's watchman?

en: “Yes,” he says, kind of pretty-well-satisfied like.
vi: - Yes - He answered with a delighted voice.
tr: “Yes,” he said, with an air of pride.
es: —Yes —he says, with a very satisfied air—.

en: “I’m the captain and the owner and the mate and the pilot and watchman and head deck-hand; and sometimes I’m the freight and passengers.
vi: I am the captain, the owner of the ship, the assistant, the helmsman, the watchman, the commander on deck, sometimes I am the cargo, and the passenger on the ship too.
tr: “I am the captain, the owner, the first mate, the helmsman, the watchman, and the chief deckhand; sometimes I am also the cargo and the passenger.
es: I am the captain and the owner and the second mate and the pilot and the lookout and the chief sailor, and sometimes I am the cargo and the passengers.

en: I ain’t as rich as old Jim Hornback, and I can’t be so blame’ generous and good to Tom, Dick and Harry as what he is, and slam around money the way he does; but I’ve told him a many a time ’t I wouldn’t trade places with him; for, says I, a sailor’s life’s the life for me, and I’m derned if I’d live two mile out o’ town, where there ain’t nothing ever goin’ on, not for all his spondulicks and as much more on top of it.
vi: I am not as wealthy as old Jim Hornback, and I cannot get along well with Tom, Dick, and Harry like old Jim does, but I have vouched many times that I would not trade places with him, because listen here, my life is the life of a sailor, and if I live two miles away from the city, I would be very bored, because there is nothing interesting in this place; I am not here for his money, I say I don't need it...
tr: I am not as rich as our Jim Hornback, so I cannot hand out generous tips to everyone who comes, nor can I throw money around like him; I have said it many times, I never want to be in his place; because for me, life means the life of a sailor, even if they laid all the riches of the world at my feet, I could not live two miles outside of town, in a place where there is nothing exciting.
es: I am not as rich as Jim Hornback and I can't be as generous with everyone and throw money around like him, but I have told him many times that I wouldn't trade places with him; because, I say, mine is the life of a sailor, and hang me if I would live two miles from town, where nothing ever happens, with all his money and much more he might have.

en: Says I—”
vi: I interjected:
tr: I said...”
es: I say...

en: I broke in and says:
vi: I interjected:
tr: I immediately interrupted:
es: I interrupt him and say:

en: “They’re in an awful peck of trouble, and—”
vi: - They are about to die and...
tr: “They are in big trouble and…”
es: —They are in a horrible situation, and...

en: “Who is?”
vi: - Oh?
tr: “Whose?”
es: —Who?

en: “Why, pap and mam and sis and Miss Hooker; and if you’d take your ferry-boat and go up there—”
vi: - And who else, father, mother, sister, and Miss Hooker, if you can take this boat to that place...
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and Mrs. Hooker; if you can reach them by going up with the ferry…”
es: —Well, father and mother and my little sister and Miss Hooker, and if you were there with your ferry...

en: “Up where?
vi: - Where, where are they?
tr: “Where up?
es: —Where?

en: Where are they?”
vi: - Where, where are they?
tr: Where are they?”
es: Where are they?

en: “On the wreck.”
vi: - on the sinking ship
tr: “They are in the wreckage.”
es: —On the ship that has wrecked.

en: “What wreck?”
vi: - Which ship sank? - Which train?
tr: "Which wreckage?""
es: —What ship?

en: “Why, there ain’t but one.”
vi: There's only one.
tr: “There is only one wreck.”
es: —Well, it's the only one there is.

en: “What, you don’t mean the Walter Scott?”
vi: - Huh! Are you talking about the Walter Scott ship?
tr: “So, are you talking about Walter Scott?”
es: —What? You don't mean Walter Scott, do you?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Good land!
vi: - Oh my God, what on earth are they doing here?
tr: "Oh my God!
es: —Heavens!

en: what are they doin’ there, for gracious sakes?”
vi: - Oh my God, what on earth are they doing here?
tr: For the love of God, what are they doing there?"
es: What are they doing there, for the love of God?

en: “Well, they didn’t go there a-purpose.”
vi: - It's not that they want to go there
tr: “They probably didn't step on it on purpose!”
es: —Well, they weren't on purpose.

en: “I bet they didn’t!
vi: - I know!
tr: “That's right, why would they leave!
es: —Surely not!

en: Why, great goodness, there ain’t no chance for ’em if they don’t git off mighty quick!
vi: It's really bad, if they don't get out quickly, it will be very dangerous.
tr: My God, if they don't leave there soon, they won't stand a chance!
es: But, my God, they don't have a chance if they don't leave at full speed!

en: Why, how in the nation did they ever git into such a scrape?”
vi: But how could they be so unlucky?
tr: Wow, how did they get themselves into such a complicated situation?”
es: But, how on earth did they get into that?

en: “Easy enough.
vi: But how could they be so unlucky?
tr: "Don't even ask.
es: —It's very easy.

en: Miss Hooker was a-visiting up there to the town—”
vi: - It's nothing, probably just Hooker planning to head up to the province
tr: Mrs. Hooker had come to visit the town, you know..."
es: Miss Hooker was visiting there in the town...

en: “Yes, Booth’s Landing—go on.”
vi: - Yes, and then what?
tr: “Hah, that place near Çardaklı Pier… keep going.”
es: —Yes, at Booth's landing... go on.

en: “She was a-visiting there at Booth’s Landing, and just in the edge of the evening she started over with her nigger woman in the horse-ferry to stay all night at her friend’s house, Miss What-you-may-call-her I disremember her name—and they lost their steering-oar, and swung around and went a-floating down, stern first, about two mile, and saddle-baggsed on the wreck, and the ferryman and the nigger woman and the horses was all lost, but Miss Hooker she made a grab and got aboard the wreck.
vi: - She intended to take that route to Booth Landing, and somehow by nightfall, she ended up going with a black servant who planned to take a horse ferry to a friend's house and stay there overnight. I can't quite remember the name of that friend, but then somehow they lost the oar while rowing, and the boat turned sideways and drifted downriver, the stern leading the way for nearly two miles, and then crashed right into a wrecked ship. Both the boatman and the black servant went missing. As for Miss Hooker, she managed to cling to the wrecked ship.
tr: “You see, he had come there to visit an acquaintance, and as evening fell, he and the black woman boarded the horse ferry and went to his friend's place to spend the night… the woman's name slips my mind… but then they lost control of the tiller, drifted about two miles downstream, and ran aground on some wreckage, capsizing. The ferryman, the black woman, and all the horses were swept away, but Mrs. Hooker clung to the wreckage and then climbed on top of it.
es: —She was there visiting Booth's landing and right in the middle of the afternoon she set off with her black woman on the horse ferry to spend the night at her friend's house, Miss whatever her name is—I don't remember—and they lost the rudder and started spinning around and floated down, stern first, and got caught on the wrecked ship, and the ferry guy, the black woman, and the horses were lost, but Miss Hooker grabbed on and climbed onto the ship.

en: Well, about an hour after dark we come along down in our trading-scow, and it was so dark we didn’t notice the wreck till we was right on it; and so we saddle-baggsed; but all of us was saved but Bill Whipple—and oh, he was the best cretur!
vi: About an hour after dusk, we rowed along searching, but it was too dark to see the wrecked ship, so we ended up crashing into it as well, and our boat capsized. All of us made it out, except for Bill Whipple.
tr: About an hour after dark, we arrived there with our sailboat, and it was so dark that we didn't notice the wreck until we hit it; we capsized too, but all of us except Bill Whipple were saved… oh poor thing, he never harmed anyone…
es: Well, about an hour later we arrived in our goods barge and it was so dark that we didn't see the ship until we crashed into it and got stuck, but we all survived except Bill Whipple, as good as he was...

en: —I most wish’t it had been me, I do.”
vi: Oh my God, Bill was such a smart person.
tr: I wish he had been saved instead of me…”
es: I almost would have preferred it to be me, really.

en: “My George!
vi: I keep thinking, why didn't I die instead of Bill!
tr: "Bite your tongue, my child!
es: —By God!

en: It’s the beatenest thing I ever struck.
vi: - Uncle George, I've truly never heard of such a painful thing before!
tr: I've never heard such a crazy story.
es: That's the strangest thing I've ever heard in my life.

en: And then what did you all do?”
vi: So what happened to you all after that?
tr: So, what did you do next?"
es: And then, what did you do?

en: “Well, we hollered and took on, but it’s so wide there we couldn’t make nobody hear.
vi: - We shouted loudly, but the river was too wide, no one could hear us.
tr: “We also clung to the wreckage and climbed on top of it, shouting for help, but the river was so wide that no one could hear us.
es: —Well, we shouted and made a lot of noise, but the river is so wide there that no one could hear us.

en: So pap said somebody got to get ashore and get help somehow.
vi: Then my father said someone should go ashore and call for help.
tr: Then my father said that someone needed to go to the shore and get help.
es: So father said that someone had to go to the shore to get help.

en: I was the only one that could swim, so I made a dash for it, and Miss Hooker she said if I didn’t strike help sooner, come here and hunt up her uncle, and he’d fix the thing.
vi: Only I knew how to swim, so I went immediately. Ms. Hooker told me that if I couldn't quickly find someone to help, I should come back right away and call her uncle so he could figure out a solution.
tr: I was the only one who could swim, so I volunteered, and Mrs. Hooker also asked me to come here and find her uncle if I couldn't find help before, saying he would solve the problem.
es: I was the only one who knew how to swim, so I came, and Miss Hooker said that if I couldn't find help sooner, I should come here to find her uncle, who would sort everything out.

en: I made the land about a mile below, and been fooling along ever since, trying to get people to do something, but they said, ‘What, in such a night and such a current?
