vi: I went nearly a mile searching, hoping to find someone to help, but everyone said: Oh my, it's night, with the river like this, how can we rescue anyone?
tr: I landed about a mile downstream and have been shuttling between houses ever since, trying to get people to do something; but they all said, ‘What, in this darkness and storm?
es: I reached the shore a mile downstream and have been walking since then, trying to get people to do something, but everyone says: "What? On a night like this and with this current?

en: There ain’t no sense in it; go for the steam ferry.’
vi: We need to find a ferry boat.
tr: It's impossible, try the steam ferry,’ they said.
es: It makes no sense; go get the steam ferry."

en: Now if you’ll go and—”
vi: So, now please go and...
tr: If you go and...”
es: If you would like to go and...

en: “By Jackson, I’d like to, and, blame it, I don’t know but I will; but who in the dingnation’s a-going’ to pay for it?
vi: - Well, I want to, but damn it, I don't know if I should. And who is going to pay me?
tr: “My God, of course I'll go, I don't know how I'll go but I will go; but who will pay for it?
es: —By God, I would like to, and darn it, I don't know if I'm going to go, but, who the devil is going to pay for it?

en: Do you reckon your pap—”
vi: Is it your father?
tr: Do you think your father has money…”
es: Do you think your dad...?

en: “Why that’s all right.
vi: - What? Of course.
tr: "Don't worry about that.
es: —Bah, that's settled.

en: Miss Hooker she tole me, particular, that her uncle Hornback—”
vi: Miss Hooker told me that, especially since her uncle is Mr. Hornback...
tr: Miss Hooker specifically told me, her uncle Hornback..."
es: Miss Hooker said that her uncle Hornback...

en: “Great guns!
vi: - Goodness, is he her uncle?
tr: “There are a thousand deck cannons!
es: —Damn!

en: is he her uncle?
vi: - Goodness, is he her uncle?
tr: His uncle?
es: Is that your uncle?

en: Looky here, you break for that light over yonder-way, and turn out west when you git there, and about a quarter of a mile out you’ll come to the tavern; tell ’em to dart you out to Jim Hornback’s, and he’ll foot the bill.
vi: Here, let me tell you, go around that place with the light over there, then turn west, walk about a quarter of a mile and you'll reach an inn, ask them to show you the way and Jim Hornback will sign the paper to pay for it.
tr: Now look, run upstairs, go to that light over there, and when you get there, turn west. After a quarter mile, you'll reach a tavern; ask them to take you to Jim Hornback, he will pay the bill.
es: Look, go to that light you see over there and turn west when you get there, and about a quarter of a mile later you'll reach the tavern; tell them to take you quickly to Jim Hornback's house and that he will pay for everything.

en: And don’t you fool around any, because he’ll want to know the news.
vi: And don't dawdle, because he's waiting for news.
tr: Just don't dawdle, because he will want to be informed as soon as possible.
es: And don't waste time, because he will want to have the news.

en: Tell him I’ll have his niece all safe before he can get to town.
vi: Tell him that I'll ensure his niece's safety before he goes to the city.
tr: Tell him that his nephew will safely reach the shore before he arrives in town.
es: Tell him that I will have his niece safe before he can get to town.

en: Hump yourself, now; I’m a-going up around the corner here to roust out my engineer.”
vi: Now, run as fast as you can. I'll stay around here to find the mechanic.
tr: Now get going; I'll turn this corner and wake up the engineer.”
es: Now go quickly; I'm going around the corner to wake up my engineer.

en: I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some woodboats; for I couldn’t rest easy till I could see the ferry-boat start.
vi: I went around to the place with the light, but waited until he had just gone to the corner, then I turned back and jumped into my small boat to escape straight away. I let the boat go along the shore where the water was still for about six hundred meters, then I hid among the wooden boats docked there to watch, because I wasn't at ease until I saw the patrol boat leave the dock.
tr: I started running towards the light, but as soon as the man turned the corner, I went back, got into my boat, and pushed it into the water. Then, I rowed about five hundred and fifty meters upstream in the calm waters and hid among the wooden boats when I found a suitable spot; because I wouldn't be at ease until I saw the ferry move.
es: I went out into the light, but as soon as he turned around, I stepped back, got into the boat, bailed out the water, and then entered the calm part of the river about six hundred yards away and hid among some wooden boats, because I couldn't relax until I saw the ferry start moving.

en: But take it all around, I was feeling ruther comfortable on accounts of taking all this trouble for that gang, for not many would a done it.
vi: But all in all, I felt relieved because I had struggled with those robbers while many others wouldn't have done the same.
tr: But when I thought about what I had done, the fact that I had gone through so much trouble for that gang made me feel at ease, many people wouldn't go to such lengths.
es: But, overall, I felt pretty good for having cared so much about the gang, even though many people wouldn't have.

en: I wished the widow knowed about it.
vi: I hope the widow knows about this.
tr: I wished the widow would hear about it.
es: I wish the widow had known.

en: I judged she would be proud of me for helping these rapscallions, because rapscallions and dead beats is the kind the widow and good people takes the most interest in.
vi: I'm sure she will be proud of me for helping those unruly men because those unruly, useless people are the ones the widow and respectable people often care about.
tr: She would probably be proud of me for helping these notorious criminals, because the widow and good people are most interested in rascals and pests.
es: I thought she would be proud of me for helping those scoundrels, because scoundrels and cheats are the people the widow and good folks care about the most.

en: Well, before long, here comes the wreck, dim and dusky, sliding along down!
vi: Then after a long while, I saw the wrecked ship approaching, dark and looming, slowly drifting down.
tr: Soon I saw the wreckage, it was rapidly sliding down as a dark mass!
es: Well, soon the shipwrecked boat appeared, all dark and lifeless, drifting along.

en: A kind of cold shiver went through me, and then I struck out for her.
vi: When I saw it, a cold feeling made me startle.
tr: For a moment, a cold shiver ran through my whole body, then I immediately grabbed the oars and approached.
es: A cold sweat ran through my body and I headed towards it.

en: She was very deep, and I see in a minute there warn’t much chance for anybody being alive in her.
vi: It looked truly massive, and for a moment I thought that if anyone were inside, it would be very difficult to survive.
tr: It had sunk very deep, and I realized shortly after that there was no chance of anyone being alive inside.
es: It was very sunken, and after a moment I saw that there weren't many chances that anyone was still alive on board.

en: I pulled all around her and hollered a little, but there wasn’t any answer; all dead still.
vi: I pushed the boat closer and called out softly, but there was no response, everything was deathly silent.
tr: I circled around and called out, but no one answered; everything was engulfed in silence.
es: I circled it completely and shouted a bit, but no one responded; there was a sepulchral silence.

en: I felt a little bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they could stand it, I could.
vi: I felt a bit sad about the pirates, but not too much, because I thought if the world could be indifferent, then so could I.
tr: My heart ached a little for the gang, but not too much, after all, if they could endure it, so could I.
es: I felt a bit sad for the crew, although not much, since I figured that if they could endure it, so could I.

en: Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river.
vi: Then I saw the ferryboat coming. I immediately rowed out to the middle of the river to a spot with an undercurrent, and once I was sure I was out of sight, I rested my oars, turned around, and watched the ferryboat follow, releasing a cloud of smoke that completely obscured the damaged boat ahead, which had Miss Hooker's body that the captain earlier was convinced was inside and thought he could bring back to old Hornback. A little while later, the ferryboat let the other boat go on its way, while it turned into the dock. Then I returned to my work and pushed the boat downstream.
tr: Soon the ferry appeared; I rowed towards the fast-flowing middle of the river, and when I realized I had reached a place where I could no longer be seen, I gathered the oars and turned around to watch the ferry circle around the wreck, looking for Mrs. Hooker's body; Captain Hornback knew that at least Uncle would want to see the body; but soon the ferry gave up and headed to the shore, and I started to move downstream in the roaring waters.
es: Then the ferry appears, so I went to the middle of the river, in a long drift downstream, and when it seemed to me that I could no longer be seen, I lifted the oars to look back and saw that the ferry was circling and searching around the boat for the remains of Miss Hooker, because the captain would know that her uncle Hornback would want to see them, and then immediately the ferry gave up and headed to the shore; I got to my work and sped down the river.

en: It did seem a powerful long time before Jim’s light showed up; and when it did show, it looked like it was a thousand mile off.
vi: It took a long time before I saw Jim's light, and when it flashed, it looked like it was thousands of miles away.
tr: It felt like a very long time had passed before Jim's light appeared; when I first saw it, it seemed to be burning a thousand miles away.
es: It seemed to me that an enormous amount of time passed before I saw Jim's light, and when it finally appeared, it felt like it was a thousand miles away.

en: By the time I got there the sky was beginning to get a little gray in the east; so we struck for an island, and hid the raft, and sunk the skiff, and turned in and slept like dead people.
vi: At this moment, the horizon had already lightened with a grayish-blue color, so we went back to the island, hid the raft, sank the small boat, and then went back to sleep like the dead.
tr: By the time we arrived, the sky in the east had started to turn slightly gray, so we landed on an island, hid the raft, sank the boat, and then lay down and slept like the dead.
es: When I arrived, the sky was starting to turn a bit gray towards the east, so we headed to an island and hid the raft, sank the boat, lay down, and fell asleep like logs.

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: Chapter XIV
tr: Chapter Fourteen
es: Chapter 14

en: By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars.
vi: When we woke up, we opened the bundle of things the robbers had taken from the wrecked ship to see what was inside. There were shoes, blankets, clothes, and all sorts of other things, a set of books, a pair of binoculars, and three boxes of cigars.
tr: When we started investigating what the gang had stolen from the wreck after waking up, we found boots, blankets, clothes, and a lot of other things; there were also many books, a binocular, and three boxes of cigars.
es: AFTERWARDS, when we got up, we looked at what the loot that the gang had stolen from the wrecked ship consisted of and found boots and blankets and clothes and all kinds of different things, a bunch of books and a spyglass and three boxes of cigars.

en: We hadn’t ever been this rich before in neither of our lives.
vi: We had never been so rich in our lives.
tr: Neither of us had ever been this rich before.
es: Neither of us had ever been this rich in our lives.

en: The seegars was prime.
vi: The cigars were of the finest quality.
tr: The cigars were top-notch.
es: The cigars were top-notch.

en: We laid off all the afternoon in the woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good time.
vi: We spent the whole afternoon lying in the forest talking. I read books, which was very enjoyable.
tr: In the afternoon, we lay among the trees, chatted a lot, I read the books, and we generally had a good time.
es: We spent the whole early afternoon in the woods, chatting, and I reading the books and generally having a good time.

en: I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the ferry-boat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said he didn’t want no more adventures.
vi: I recounted to Jim everything that had happened on the wrecked ship and at the ferry, and then I told him that those were adventures. But Jim said he didn't like such adventures anymore.
tr: I told Jim everything that happened in the wreck and on the ferry and said that these kinds of things were adventures; but Jim said he didn't want any more adventures.
es: I told Jim everything that had happened on the ship and on the ferry and he said those things were adventures, but he didn't want any more.

en: He said that when I went in the texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone, he nearly died; because he judged it was all up with him, anyway it could be fixed; for if he didn’t get saved he would get drownded; and if he did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure.
vi: He said that when I was curious and went into the ship's cabin, he crawled back to the raft only to find it had drifted away. He was almost paralyzed with fear and thought it was the end of his life, that he wouldn't escape from there, and if no one came to rescue him, he would drown. And if someone did rescue him, they would take him back for a reward, and Miss Watson would sell him down South.
tr: When I went to the pilot house, he had gone back to get on the raft and was shocked to find it gone, because no matter how things turned out, it would affect him; if no one saved him, he would drown, and if someone did save him, they would take him to town to claim the reward, and Miss Watson would definitely sell him to the South.
es: He said that when I got onto the upper deck and he crawled back to the raft and saw that it had disappeared, he almost died, because he thought that whatever happened, it was all over for him, because if he didn't save himself, he would drown, and if he did save himself, whoever saw him would take him back home to collect the reward and then Miss Watson would surely sell him in the South.

en: Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head, for a nigger.
vi: That was certain. He was right. He usually made sense when he spoke. He had an unusually sharp mind for a black man.
tr: He was really right; he was almost always right anyway; he had an unusual intelligence for a black man.
es: Well, he was right; he was almost always right; he had the most reasonable head for a black man.

en: I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, ’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested.
vi: I read to Jim quite a lot about kings, dukes, counts, etc... how they dressed in luxurious and splendid attire with all sorts of styles, addressing each other with terms like: "Your Majesty," "Your Grace," "Your Highness," etc... instead of calling each other "sir." Jim sat listening, his eyes wide open, very attentive.
tr: I told Jim about the kings, dukes, counts, and the like that I had read a lot about, how fancily they dressed, the airs they put on, how they called each other "your majesty" instead of "sir," referred to each other as "your excellency," "your highness," etc.;
es: I read to Jim many things about kings and dukes and counts and all that, and how well they dressed and how elegant they looked and how they called each other "your majesty," "your lordship," "your excellency," and all that, instead of "mister," and Jim's eyes were wide open and he was very interested.

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: Jim's eyes were wide open because the matter interested him.
es: He goes and says:

en: “I didn’ know dey was so many un um.
vi: - I don't know why they have so many of them.
tr: “I didn't know there were so many kings,” he said.
es: —I didn't know there were so many.

en: I hain’t hearn ’bout none un um, skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat’s in a pack er k’yards.
vi: In the past, I only heard of one king, and even then, it was rarely mentioned, that is, King Solomon, but I had no idea you had to count those kings like counting cows and horses.
tr: “Actually, I hadn't heard of any king other than old King Solomon, and besides him, I only saw a king on a playing card.
es: I had almost never heard of them, except for that old one of King Solomon, not counting the kings in the deck of cards.

en: How much do a king git?”
vi: So how much money does each king get??
tr: How much does a king earn?”
es: How much does a king earn?

en: “Get?” I says; “why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to them.”
vi: - Can they? Those guys can get a thousand dollars a month if they want; whatever they want, they get. Everything belongs to them.
tr: “Earn?” I said. “If he wants, he can earn a thousand dollars a month, he can take as much as he wants; everything already belongs to him.”
es: —Get paid? —I say—; well, at least a thousand dollars a month if they want; they can take whatever they want; everything is theirs.

en: “Ain’ dat gay?
vi: - Oh, that's interesting, isn't it?
tr: "It's good, right?
es: —Great, isn't it?

en: En what dey got to do, Huck?”
vi: So what are those gentlemen doing, Huck?
tr: So, what will we do with it to make money?"
es: And what do they have to do, Huck?

en: “They don’t do nothing!
vi: - They don't do anything at all.
tr: “They do nothing!
es: —They do nothing!

en: Why, how you talk!
vi: Why are you so foolish?
tr: Your words are just talk…
es: What things you say!

en: They just set around.”
vi: They just sit there.
tr: They just sit on the throne.”
es: They are there and nothing more.

en: “No; is dat so?”
vi: -Nonsense! Really?
tr: "Ha! Is there such a thing?""
es: —No; really?

en: “Of course it is.
vi: - Of course, that's how it is.
tr: “Of course, it can happen.
es: —Well, of course.

en: They just set around—except, maybe, when there’s a war; then they go to the war.
vi: They just sit there. Maybe except in cases like going to war, then they go to the battlefield.
tr: They just sit on the throne. If a war breaks out, they might get up, then they go to war. But other than that, they lie around or hunt birds… they just hunt birds and…
es: They do nothing but stay there, except maybe when there's a war; then they go to war, or if not, they go hunting. Yes, with falcons and all that...

en: But other times they just lazy around; or go hawking—just hawking and sp— Sh!—d’ you hear a noise?”
vi: But at other times, they just lounge around, or go hunting, and... shh... Jim, did you hear something?
tr: Shh!.. did you hear a sound?”
es: Shhh! Didn't you hear a noise?

en: We skipped out and looked; but it warn’t nothing but the flutter of a steamboat’s wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.
vi: We quietly stepped out to look, but there was nothing, only the clattering sound of a train heading downstream, passing by. The two of us then returned to our spot.
tr: We went to check immediately, but it was nothing more than the sound of a steamboat paddle coming from the bend below; so we turned back.
es: We came out of the forest to look, but there was nothing except the paddling of a steamboat's wheel in the distance, rounding the point, so we went back.

en: “Yes,” says I, “and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with the parlyment; and if everybody don’t go just so he whacks their heads off.
vi: I continued speaking:
tr: "Yes," I said. "At other times, when things get very boring, they quarrel with the parliament; if everyone doesn't do as they say, they behead them.
es: —Yes —I said—, and other times, when things are boring, they mess with Parliament, and if they don't do things the way they want, they cut off their heads.

en: But mostly they hang round the harem.”
vi: - Yes, at other times, like when they are sad, they look at the parliament, if anyone doesn't comply, they hit them on the head, but mostly those kings just linger around in the harem.
tr: But usually, they hang out in the harem."
es: But where they spend the most time is in the harem.

en: “Roun’ de which?”
vi: - In what?
tr: "What are you stuck on?""
es: —In what?

en: “Harem.”
vi: - Female palace
tr: "In the harem."
es: —In the harem.

en: “What’s de harem?”
vi: - What is the female palace?
tr: "What is this?""
es: —What is the harem?

en: “The place where he keeps his wives.
vi: - It's the place where those men keep their wives.
tr: "The place where he keeps his wives.
es: —Where they keep their women.

en: Don’t you know about the harem?
vi: Don't you understand what a harem is?
tr: Don't you know the harem?
es: Don't you know what a harem is?

en: Solomon had one; he had about a million wives.”
vi: King Solomon also had a harem like that in the past, and he had up to a million wives.
tr: Solomon had one too; he had almost a million wives."
es: Solomon had one with at least a million women.

en: “Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it.
vi: - Ah, that's right, that's right. I forgot about it.
tr: “Yes, right; I… I had completely forgotten about it.
es: —Well, it's true; I... I had forgotten.

en: A harem’s a bo’d’n-house, I reck’n.
vi: The harem is like a house full of people, I'm sure of it.
tr: It was always noisy like his house.
es: A harem is a boarding house, I suppose.

en: Mos’ likely dey has rackety times in de nussery.
vi: It's probably like the chaos in an orphanage, isn't it?
tr: There was quite a bit of noise coming from the children's room, right?
es: I'm sure there's a lot of commotion in the children's room.

en: En I reck’n de wives quarrels considable; en dat ’crease de racket.
vi: I'm sure when those wives fight with each other, it must be something to see! It's bound to be chaotic.
tr: They were always arguing, the noise would rise up at that time.
es: And I'm sure the women fight a lot, so there's even more commotion.

en: Yit dey say Sollermun de wises’ man dat ever live’.
vi: And then they say that King Solomon was the wisest man on earth.
tr: However, everyone says that Solomon is the wisest man who has ever lived until today.
es: But they say that Solomon was the wisest man who ever lived.

en: I doan’ take no stock in dat.
vi: I don't believe that.
tr: But I never believe them.
es: But they say that Solomon was the wisest man who ever lived.

en: Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids’ er sich a blim-blammin’ all de time?
vi: Why? If he was wise, why would he live in such a messy situation like that?
tr: Why? Would a wise man constantly want to live in such noise and commotion?
es: I can't quite believe it, because why would such a wise guy want to live in the middle of all that racket?

en: No—’deed he wouldn’t.
vi: No, he definitely wasn't wise.
tr: No... he wouldn't want that in his life.
es: No... definitely not.

en: A wise man ’ud take en buil’ a biler-factry; en den he could shet down de biler-factry when he want to res’.”
vi: A wise person would set up a food factory, and when he wanted to rest, he would just close the factory.
tr: A wise man would go and open a factory, and then when he wants to rest, he would close the factory.”
es: A wise man would have a boiler factory built and then he could shut everything down whenever he wanted to rest.

en: “Well, but he was the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told me so, her own self.”
vi: - But anyway, he used to be the wisest person, because even the widow told me so.
tr: “But still, Solomon was the wisest man; because the widow lady told me this, and she said it with her own mouth.”
es: —Well, but in any case he was the wisest man in the world, because the widow told me so, no less.

en: “I doan k’yer what de widder say, he warn’t no wise man nuther.
vi: - I don't know what that widow said, but King Solomon was definitely not a wise man.
tr: “So what if he said it!
es: —I don't care what the widow said; he wasn't that wise.

en: He had some er de dad-fetchedes’ ways I ever see.
vi: He had ways of judging people that I had never seen before.
tr: I have never heard of a more incompetent man than him.
es: He came up with some of the strangest ideas I've ever heard in my life.

en: Does you know ’bout dat chile dat he ’uz gwyne to chop in two?”
vi: Do you know the story of the baby that he intended to cut in half?
tr: He almost split a child in two, did you hear that?”
es: Do you know about the child he wanted to split in two?

en: “Yes, the widow told me all about it.”
vi: - Yes, the widow also told me about this matter
tr: “Yes, the widow told me every detail.”
es: —Yes, the widow told me.

en: “Well, den!
vi: - There! See!
tr: “Then listen carefully!
es: —Well then!

en: Warn’ dat de beatenes’ notion in de worl’?
vi: Isn't that the most bitter thing in life?
tr: Isn't this the strangest idea you've ever heard in the world?
es: Don't you think it's the most idiotic idea in the world?

en: You jes’ take en look at it a minute.
vi: Just think about it.
tr: Think about it for a moment. Do you see that tree?
es: You just need to think about it for half a minute.

en: Dah’s de stump, dah—dat’s one er de women; heah’s you—dat’s de yuther one; I’s Sollermun; en dish yer dollar bill’s de chile.
vi: That matter is so complicated, on one side is a woman, you hear me, for example, you are another woman; I am Solomon, and this dollar bill is the child.
tr: One of those women is the tree; and you are the root. I am Solomon; and this torn banknote is the child.
es: That log over there, that's one of the women; that's you, the other log; I am Solomon, and that one-dollar bill is the child.

en: Bofe un you claims it.
vi: Both sides demand to take it.
tr: Both of you want the money.
es: Both of you want it.

en: What does I do?
vi: So what should I do?
tr: What do I do?
es: What do I do?

en: Does I shin aroun’ mongs’ de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill do b’long to, en han’ it over to de right one, all safe en soun’, de way dat anybody dat had any gumption would?
vi: Should I go ask the neighbors whose dollar bill it is, and then give it to the one who has the whole bill intact; all practical-minded people would do that, right?
tr: To find out who the money belongs to, wouldn't I ask all your neighbors and give the money to the right person? Any sensible person would do that.
es: Do I go around the neighbors to see whose bill it is and give it to the rightful owner, as is normal, as anyone with the slightest sense would do?

en: No; I take en whack de bill in two, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman.
vi: But instead, I go and tear the dollar bill in half and give one half to you, and the other half to the other woman.
tr: But no. Instead, I split the money in two, giving half to you and half to the other woman.
es: No; I go and tear the bill in two and give you one half and the other half to the woman.

en: Dat’s de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile.
vi: That's what Mr. Solomon did with a child.
tr: Solomon thinks of doing the same with the child.
es: That's what Solomon was going to do with the child.

en: Now I want to ast you: what’s de use er dat half a bill?—can’t buy noth’n wid it.
vi: Now let me ask you: what can you do with half a dollar bill? You can't buy anything.
tr: Now I ask you: What use is a torn banknote? You can't buy anything with it.
es: And what I'm telling you: What's the use of half a bill to anyone? You can't buy anything with that.

en: En what use is a half a chile?
vi: So what can you do with half a child?
tr: What use is a split child?
es: What's the use of half a child?

en: I wouldn’ give a dern for a million un um.”
vi: I think that even if a million kings did that, it still wouldn't be worth a penny.
tr: Honestly, I wouldn't take such a child even if you gave me a million.”
es: I wouldn't give anything for a million half children.

en: “But hang it, Jim, you’ve clean missed the point—blame it, you’ve missed it a thousand mile.”
vi: - Stop it, Jim, you're completely wrong, nonsense, you're off by thousands of miles.
tr: “But wait a minute, Jim, you haven't understood the essence of the matter... you haven't even come close.”
es: —But, damn it, Jim, you don't understand anything... Damn it, you just don't get it.

en: “Who?
vi: - Oh, me?
tr: “Who?
es: —Who?

en: Me? Go ’long.
vi: - Oh, me? Please.
tr: Me? Come on, son.
es: Me? Come on.

en: Doan’ talk to me ’bout yo’ pints.
vi: Don't talk about your measurements with me.
tr: Tell me the truth and don't lie.
es: Don't come telling me that I don't understand it.

en: I reck’n I knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain’ no sense in sich doin’s as dat.
vi: I know that when I see something clearly, I understand its meaning right away. And the meaning of this cannot be confused with that.
tr: When I see something sensible, I understand it immediately. There's no common sense in this matter.
es: I think I understand what common sense is and what it isn't. And doing something like that doesn't make sense.

en: De ’spute warn’t ’bout a half a chile, de ’spute was ’bout a whole chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a ’spute ’bout a whole chile wid a half a chile doan’ know enough to come in out’n de rain.
vi: Arguing like this is not about winning half of the child, but the whole child, and anyone who thinks they can resolve the argument by giving each side half of the child is like someone walking in the rain without knowing how to avoid getting wet.
tr: It was like a man trying to solve a child's problem by asking a woman, who wouldn't even think to find shelter in the rain.
es: The fight wasn't over half a child; the fight was over a whole child, and the man who thinks he can solve a fight over a whole child with half a child doesn't know what life is.

en: Doan’ talk to me ’bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back.”
vi: So, don't talk to me about Solomon anymore, Huck, I know even the back of his head.
tr: Don't talk to me about Solomon, Huck, I know his kind.”
es: Don't talk to me about that Solomon, Huck. I've seen plenty like him.

en: “But I tell you you don’t get the point.”
vi: - But I told you that you're speaking out of turn!
tr: “But I'm telling you, you haven't understood the real issue.”
es: —But I tell you that you don't understand it.

en: “Blame de point!
vi: - Ignore that measurement of yours.
tr: “What good would it do if I understood?
es: —There you go again with "I don't understand it!"

en: I reck’n I knows what I knows.
vi: What I know is what I know.
tr: I know what I know.
es: I understand what I understand.

en: En mine you, de real pint is down furder—it’s down deeper.
vi: You have to understand that the container for measuring the truth can go even deeper.
tr: Besides, the real issue is much more than this.
es: And, get this, what you really need to understand is more complicated; much more complicated.

en: It lays in de way Sollermun was raised.
vi: Whether it's right or wrong lies in the judgment of Mr. Sollermun, doesn't it?
tr: It's about Süleyman's upbringing.
es: It's how Salamón was raised.

en: You take a man dat’s got on’y one or two chillen; is dat man gwyne to be waseful o’ chillen?
vi: Try taking the example of a person with one or two children, would that person dare to sacrifice their children?
tr: For example, think of a man with one or two children, can he easily neglect his children?
es: Think about it: a man has only one or two children; is that man going to go around splitting them in half?

en: No, he ain’t; he can’t ’ford it.
vi: No, there's no such thing.
tr: No, he cannot neglect them, he can't afford to.
es: No, no way; he can't afford to.

en: He know how to value ’em.
vi: That person would know the value of children.
tr: He knows the value of a child.
es: He knows how to appreciate them.

en: But you take a man dat’s got ’bout five million chillen runnin’ roun’ de house, en it’s diffunt.
vi: But if you take someone who has about five million children at home, then it's different.
tr: But if a man has five million children running around his house, then the situation changes.
es: But a man who has five million children all over the house, that's different.

en: He as soon chop a chile in two as a cat.
vi: He would be ready to cut a child in half like cutting a cat.
tr: He would treat one child like a cat because he has other children.
es: To him, splitting a child in half is the same as splitting a cat in half.

en: Dey’s plenty mo’.
vi: Because he has many.
tr: There are always more anyway.
es: There are plenty more.

en: A chile er two, mo’ er less, warn’t no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!”
vi: One or two children, more or less, what does that mean to Sollermun?
tr: One or two children don't matter to Süleyman. Damn him!”
es: One or two more or less children didn't matter at all to Salamón, damn him!

en: I never see such a nigger.
vi: - I have never seen a black man like that.
tr: I had never seen a black man like this.
es: I've never seen a black man like that.

en: If he got a notion in his head once, there warn’t no getting it out again.
vi: If he has an idea in his head, it's impossible to make him give it up.
tr: Once an idea got into his head, it was never possible to change it.
es: Once he got something into his head, there was no way to get it out.

en: He was the most down on Solomon of any nigger I ever see.
vi: He is the black man who has blasphemed Sollermun the most, and now I know he is one.
tr: He was more furious at Süleyman than any other black man I knew.
es: I've never seen a black man who had such a grudge against Solomon.

en: So I went to talking about other kings, and let Solomon slide.
vi: So I had to talk about other kings, putting the story of Sollermun aside.
tr: So, I left Süleyman aside and talked about other kings.
es: So I started talking about other kings and left that one alone.

en: I told about Louis Sixteenth that got his head cut off in France long time ago; and about his little boy the dolphin, that would a been a king, but they took and shut him up in jail, and some say he died there.
vi: I talked about King Louis XVI of France, who had been beheaded a long time ago, and mentioned his young son, the crown prince, who was supposed to become king but was imprisoned, and some say he died there.
tr: I told him about Louis XVI, who was beheaded in France a long time ago; I added that his heir, his son, would have become king, but they captured him, imprisoned him, and according to some, he died there.
es: I told him about Louis XVI, who was beheaded in France a long time ago, and about his young son, the dauphin, who would have been king, but they took him away and put him in prison, and some say he died there.

en: “Po’ little chap.”
vi: - Poor, unfortunate boy!
tr: "Poor little child," said Jim.
es: —Poor thing.

en: “But some says he got out and got away, and come to America.”
vi: - But there are also people who say that he escaped death and has gone to America.
tr: “But some say that he escaped from prison and fled the country, coming to America.”
es: —But others say that he escaped and came to America.

en: “Dat’s good!
vi: - That's great!
tr: “That's good then!
es: —That's good!

en: But he’ll be pooty lonesome—dey ain’ no kings here, is dey, Huck?”
vi: But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right?
tr: Although he was quite alone in this town.
es: But he will feel very lonely... There are no kings here, right, Huck?

en: “No.”
vi: But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right?
tr: There's no one in this town, right?” "No."""
es: —No.

en: “Den he cain’t git no situation.
vi: But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right?
tr: "Then he cannot find a throne for himself.
es: —Then he can't get a job.

en: What he gwyne to do?”
vi: What does he plan to do?
tr: What can he do in this situation?"
es: What is he going to do?

en: “Well, I don’t know.
vi: - Who knows.
tr: "I don't know."
es: —Well, I don't know.

en: Some of them gets on the police, and some of them learns people how to talk French.”
vi: Among those kings, some became police officers, and some became French teachers.
tr: "Some become police officers; others teach French to people.""
es: Some become police officers and others teach people to speak French.

en: “Why, Huck, doan’ de French people talk de same way we does?”
vi: - Oh, so the French don't speak like us, Huck?
tr: “Why, Huck, don't the French talk like us?”
es: —But, Huck, don't the French speak like us?

en: “No, Jim; you couldn’t understand a word they said—not a single word.”
vi: - No, Jim, if you listen to what people say, you won't understand a single sentence, not even a word.
tr: "No, Jim; you won't understand a single word they say... not a single word.""
es: —No, Jim; you wouldn't understand a single word of what they're saying... not a single word.

en: “Well, now, I be ding-busted!
vi: - Oh, then I am really foolish.
tr: “No way, how did it happen!
es: —Well, hang me!

en: How do dat come?”
vi: So what should I do?
tr: How am I supposed to understand that?”
es: Why?

en: “I don’t know; but it’s so.
vi: - I don't know either. But that's how it is.
tr: “I don't know, but you just wouldn't understand.
es: —I don't know, but it's true.

en: I got some of their jabber out of a book.
vi: I saw a few of their words in the book.
tr: I had learned something about their conversation from a book.
es: I've seen some of the things they say in a book.

en: S’pose a man was to come to you and say Polly-voo-franzy—what would you think?”
vi: For example, if someone comes and asks you: "Parlez-vous français?" what would you think?
tr: Let's say a man comes up to you and says parle-vu-franse... what would you think?”
es: Imagine a man comes up to you and says "parlé vu fransé"; what would you think?

en: “I wouldn’ think nuff’n; I’d take en bust him over de head—dat is, if he warn’t white.
vi: - I don't think anything of it. I would hit him on the head, that is, if he were not a white man.
tr: “I don't think about anything, I just shoot one in the middle of his forehead. That is, if he's not white.
es: —I wouldn't think anything; I would break his face; well, if he wasn't white.

en: I wouldn’t ’low no nigger to call me dat.”
vi: If he were black, I wouldn't allow anyone to call me that.
tr: I would never allow a black man to talk to me like that.”
es: I wouldn't let a black person call me that.

en: “Shucks, it ain’t calling you anything.
vi: - Go away, that's not calling you.
tr: "But he didn't say anything to you.
es: —Damn, I wouldn't be calling you anything.

en: It’s only saying, do you know how to talk French?”
vi: That's just asking if you know how to speak French.
tr: He just asked if you could speak French."
es: I would just be asking if you know how to speak French.

en: “Well, den, why couldn’t he say it?”
vi: - Well, why couldn't he just say it straight out like that?
tr: “Haa, okay, but why isn't it cooling properly?”
es: —Well, then, why don't you say it?

en: “Why, he is a-saying it.
vi: - He himself said it like that.
tr: “But she's asking, you see.
es: —But that's what he's saying.

en: That’s a Frenchman’s way of saying it.”
vi: That is the way the French speak. - Oh, that is really bizarre, strange.
tr: That's how the French ask.”
es: That's how the French say it.

en: “Well, it’s a blame ridicklous way, en I doan’ want to hear no mo’ ’bout it.
vi: But anyway, I don't want to hear about it anymore.
tr: "But this is very absurd, I don't want to hear anything else."
es: —Well, it's a ridiculous way of saying it and I don't want to keep talking about it.

en: Dey ain’ no sense in it.”
vi: It doesn't make any sense at all.
tr: "It doesn't make any sense.""
es: It doesn't make sense.

en: “Looky here, Jim; does a cat talk like we do?”
vi: - Here, Jim, I ask if the cat speaks like us?
tr: “Listen now, Jim; do cats talk like us?”
es: —Look, Jim; do cats speak the same way we do?

en: “No, a cat don’t.”
vi: - No, which cat said that
tr: “No, cats don't talk like that.”
es: —No, not the cats.

en: “Well, does a cow?”
vi: - Ah, what about the cow?
tr: “What about the cow?”
es: —Well, what about the cows?

en: “No, a cow don’t, nuther.”
vi: - Not even crawling
tr: “No, cows don't talk either.”
es: —No, not the cows either.

en: “Does a cat talk like a cow, or a cow talk like a cat?”
vi: - Does the cat speak like the cow? Or does the cow speak like the cat?
tr: “Do cats talk like cows or do cows talk like cats?”
es: —Do cats speak the same as cows or do cows speak the same as cats?

en: “No, dey don’t.”
vi: - No
tr: “No, it can't be.”
es: —No.

en: “It’s natural and right for ’em to talk different from each other, ain’t it?”
vi: - So it's natural and correct for one child to speak differently from another, right?
tr: “It's perfectly natural for the two of them to speak differently from each other, isn't it?”
es: —The natural and normal thing is that they speak differently, right?

en: “’Course.”
vi: - Of course
tr: “Of course.”
es: —Of course.

en: “And ain’t it natural and right for a cat and a cow to talk different from us?”
vi: - And the cat, the cow speaking differently from us, is that also natural and correct?
tr: “Well, isn't it normal and correct for the cat and the cow to speak differently from us?”
es: —And isn't it natural and normal that cats and cows speak differently from us?

en: “Why, mos’ sholy it is.”
vi: - Oh, it definitely is like that
tr: “Of course, sure.”
es: —Man, of course.

en: “Well, then, why ain’t it natural and right for a Frenchman to talk different from us?
vi: - Ah, so why do the French speak differently from us, saying it's incorrect and unnatural.
tr: “Then isn't it normal and right for a French person to speak differently from us?
es: —Well, then, why isn't it natural and normal for a French person to speak differently from us?

en: You answer me that.”
vi: Try answering me.
tr: Answer this, let's see.”
es: Answer me that.

en: “Is a cat a man, Huck?”
vi: - Is the cat someone else, Huck?
tr: “Is a cat a human, Huck?”
es: —Huck, are cats the same as men?

en: “No.”
vi: - No
tr: “No.” “So, do you really think so?
es: —No.

en: “Well, den, dey ain’t no sense in a cat talkin’ like a man.
vi: - Ah, then the cat can't talk like a human.
tr: Why would a cat speak like a human?
es: —Well, then, it doesn't make sense for cats to talk the same way as men.

en: Is a cow a man?—er is a cow a cat?”
vi: So is the cow a human - is the cow a cat?
tr: Well, is a cow a human? Or is a cow a cat?”
es: Are cows the same as men? Or are cows the same as cats?

en: “No, she ain’t either of them.”
vi: - No, none of them are cats.
tr: "No; none of them.""
es: —No, neither of the two things.

en: “Well, den, she ain’t got no business to talk like either one er the yuther of ’em.
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: “Then he won't speak like the others from this place.
es: —Well, then they don't have to talk like men or cats.

en: Is a Frenchman a man?”
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: A French person?”
es: Are the French men?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Well, den!
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: “Alright then!
es: —Well then!

en: Dad blame it, why doan’ he talk like a man?
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: Damn it, why doesn't this Frenchman speak like a normal person?
es: Damn it, why don't they speak the same as men?

en: You answer me dat!”
vi: Can you try to answer me?
tr: You answer him, come on!”
es: You answer me that one.

en: I see it warn’t no use wasting words—you can’t learn a nigger to argue.
vi: I find that sitting and talking like this is just a waste of words. I can't possibly learn the way black people reason.
tr: There was no point in wasting my breath any longer... You can't teach a black person to argue.
es: I saw that it made no sense to keep wasting my breath: you can't teach black people to argue.

en: So I quit.
vi: So I stopped.
tr: So I gave up.
es: So I gave up.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Chapter XV
tr: Fifteenth Chapter
es: Chapter 15

en: We judged that three nights more would fetch us to Cairo, at the bottom of Illinois, where the Ohio River comes in, and that was what we was after.
vi: We calculated that in just three more nights we would reach Cairo, which is at the southern tip of Illinois, where the Ohio River flows in, and that is exactly where we intended to go.
tr: We were calculating that if we went three more nights, we would reach Cairo, at the very bottom of Illinois, at the mouth of the Ohio River, which was exactly where we wanted to go.
es: WE CALCULATED THAT in three nights we would arrive in Cairo, at the end of Illinois, where the waters of the Ohio River meet, and that was what we were looking for.

en: We would sell the raft and get on a steamboat and go way up the Ohio amongst the free States, and then be out of trouble.
vi: We would sell the raft and board a steamboat to travel up the Ohio River through the free states, so there would be nothing to worry about anymore.
tr: We would sell the raft, board a steamboat, and go up the Ohio to the free states, and then our troubles would be over.
es: We would sell the raft and take a steamboat up the Ohio to the free states, and there we would no longer have any problems.

en: Well, the second night a fog begun to come on, and we made for a tow-head to tie to, for it wouldn’t do to try to run in a fog; but when I paddled ahead in the canoe, with the line to make fast, there warn’t anything but little saplings to tie to.
vi: On the second night, the fog suddenly became so thick that we had to find a ravine to tie the raft. Because it was not wise to recklessly continue in the fog. But while I was rowing the boat upstream, carrying a hook pole, I couldn't find a place to hook it as there were only small reeds.
tr: The second night, the fog set in and we pulled up to a shore to tie the raft, because there was no point in trying to escape in the fog; but as I rowed ahead with the canoe tied to the raft to speed up, I found nothing to throw the rope at except for thin saplings.
es: Well, around the second night, the fog started to come down, and we went to look for a sandbar to moor because it was useless to go on with the fog; but when I went ahead with the canoe, rowing with the rope to tie up, there were only some small logs.

en: I passed the line around one of them right on the edge of the cut bank, but there was a stiff current, and the raft come booming down so lively she tore it out by the roots and away she went.
vi: I cast the fishing line to wrap it around a reed on the water's edge, but this spot had such a strong current that it uprooted the reed and it kept drifting away.
tr: I threw the rope and tied it to a sapling on the shore, but the current was so strong that the raft, which was a bit behind, passed me and pulled the rope so fast that it uprooted the sapling and drifted away.
es: I threw the rope to one of them, right next to the edge of the shore, but the current was so strong there that the raft was moving so fast it uprooted it and kept going.

en: I see the fog closing down, and it made me so sick and scared I couldn’t budge for most a half a minute it seemed to me—and then there warn’t no raft in sight; you couldn’t see twenty yards.
vi: The fog grew heavier, making me so scared that I couldn't move for half a minute. Without the raft here, I couldn't see more than twenty meters ahead.
tr: The fog was getting denser and denser. I felt terrible, I was so scared that I couldn't move a finger for almost half a minute… then I lost sight of the raft, it was impossible to see even twenty meters ahead.
es: I saw the fog getting denser and felt so bad and scared that I couldn't move for almost half a minute, or so it seemed to me, and then the raft was no longer visible; you couldn't see beyond twenty yards.

en: I jumped into the canoe and run back to the stern, and grabbed the paddle and set her back a stroke.
vi: I jumped to the back of the boat, grabbed the paddle, and pushed back once.
tr: I jumped back into the canoe and went to the stern, grabbed the oars, but the canoe didn't move.
es: I jumped into the canoe and ran to the stern, grabbed the paddle, and gave a stroke, but it didn't move.

en: But she didn’t come.
vi: But the boat didn't budge.
tr: I jumped back into the canoe and went to the stern, grabbed the oars, but the canoe didn't move.
es: I jumped into the canoe and ran to the stern, grabbed the paddle, and gave a stroke, but it didn't move.

en: I was in such a hurry I hadn’t untied her.
vi: It turned out I was in such a hurry that I hadn't untied the rope.
tr: I had been in such a hurry that I forgot to untie the oar's rope.
es: I was in such a hurry that I hadn't untied it.

en: I got up and tried to untie her, but I was so excited my hands shook so I couldn’t hardly do anything with them.
vi: I stood up to untie the rope, but I was so nervous that my hands were shaking and I couldn't do anything.
tr: I immediately got up and tried to untie the rope, but I was so excited that my hands were trembling and I couldn't do anything.
es: I stood up and tried to untie it, but I was so nervous that my hands were trembling so much I could hardly do anything with them.

en: As soon as I got started I took out after the raft, hot and heavy, right down the tow-head.
vi: As soon as I untied the rope, I immediately rowed to find the raft, the cozy raft carrying our heavy belongings right at the head of that creek.
tr: I followed the raft down the river by keeping close to the shore.
es: As soon as I managed to get going, I started chasing the raft at full speed, directly towards the sandbar.

en: That was all right as far as it went, but the tow-head warn’t sixty yards long, and the minute I flew by the foot of it I shot out into the solid white fog, and hadn’t no more idea which way I was going than a dead man.
vi: I found it right away because it was only sixty yards away. Just as I got close, I ran into an even thicker fog, unable to find my way out; it was as if I were completely dead.
tr: As long as I didn't stray from the shore, there was no problem, but the islet was only sixty meters long, and a few seconds after reaching its end, I found myself in a blinding white mist, with no idea where I was going.
es: That was well thought out, but the bar wouldn't measure even sixty yards long, and as soon as I left it behind, I got into the middle of that white and dense fog without having the slightest idea of where I was going.

en: Thinks I, it won’t do to paddle; first I know I’ll run into the bank or a tow-head or something; I got to set still and float, and yet it’s mighty fidgety business to have to hold your hands still at such a time.
vi: I think perhaps we shouldn't row the boat anymore; first, let's get closer to the shore or land somewhere. I had to sit still and let the boat drift, and having to sit still with my hands tied at that moment was very distressing.
tr: It occurred to me that rowing would be useless; I could crash into the shore or shallow water as soon as I started; I had to stay still and go with the current. In such a situation, it was really hard not to move your hands.
es: I thought it wasn't worth rowing; I knew that at the first sign of trouble I would run aground on the shore or on a sandbar or something like that; I stayed still letting the canoe drift, but one gets very nervous when they have nothing to do with their hands in a moment like that.

en: I whooped and listened.
vi: I cleared my throat and listened.
tr: I called out ahead and waited for a response.
es: I shouted and listened.

en: Away down there somewheres I hears a small whoop, and up comes my spirits.
vi: Far below, I heard a faint sound echoing back, which reassured me.
tr: My spirits lifted when I heard someone faintly calling out from somewhere in the distance.
es: In the distance, I don't know where, I heard another muffled shout and I felt somewhat encouraged.

en: I went tearing after it, listening sharp to hear it again.
vi: I moved closer to hear more clearly.
tr: I immediately started moving towards the sound, while also straining my ears to hear it again.
es: I went there at full speed, listening carefully in case I heard it again.

en: The next time it come, I see I warn’t heading for it, but heading away to the right of it.
vi: Getting even closer, it was on the left side.
tr: When I heard it the second time, I realized I was going to the right of where the sound was coming from, not directly towards it.
es: The next time I heard it, I saw that I wasn't heading towards it, but to its right, and the next time to its left, and I wasn't making much progress either, because I was going around in circles, while that voice was going straight down the whole time.

en: And the next time I was heading away to the left of it—and not gaining on it much either, for I was flying around, this way and that and t’other, but it was going straight ahead all the time.
vi: Then I heard nothing more, and I didn't search further because I had to keep turning the boat in all directions; instead, I just kept heading straight ahead.
tr: The next time, I was heading to the left of where the sound was coming from – and I hadn't gotten much closer, because I was rowing either to the right or the left, but the sound was coming straight from ahead.
es: The next time I heard it, I saw that I wasn't heading towards it, but to its right, and the next time to its left, and I wasn't making much progress either, because I was going around in circles, while that voice was going straight down the whole time.

en: I did wish the fool would think to beat a tin pan, and beat it all the time, but he never did, and it was the still places between the whoops that was making the trouble for me.
vi: At that moment, I wished that someone would just bang on a pot and bang it rhythmically so it would be easier to know where to look. But no one was banging, and the silence, punctuated by a few coughs, only made me more confused.
tr: I hoped that our foolish Jim would think of hitting something like a pan, he should have kept hitting it continuously; but since he didn't do that, the silences between his calls became a problem for me.
es: What I wanted was for the very fool to think of starting to bang repeatedly on a pan, but he didn't think of it, or maybe he did, and what worried me were the silences between the screams.

en: Well, I fought along, and directly I hears the whoop behind me.
vi: I went further up, and suddenly I heard a howl behind me.
tr: I rowed forward with all my strength and soon heard the sound behind me.
es: Well, I kept going and immediately heard the scream behind me.

en: I was tangled good now.
vi: Well, I was really surrounded.
tr: By now, I was completely bewildered.
es: Now I was really confused.

en: That was somebody else’s whoop, or else I was turned around.
vi: It was definitely the howl of someone else. I was definitely surrounded.
tr: Either someone else was calling out or I was going in the wrong direction.
es: Either there was another person screaming or I had turned all the way around.

en: I throwed the paddle down.
vi: I threw the paddle down.
tr: I threw the oar into the boat.
es: I put down the oar.

en: I heard the whoop again; it was behind me yet, but in a different place; it kept coming, and kept changing its place, and I kept answering, till by-and-by it was in front of me again, and I knowed the current had swung the canoe’s head down-stream, and I was all right if that was Jim and not some other raftsman hollering.
vi: Again, I heard the howling sound still behind me, but from a different place. It crept closer, it changed places, it answered itself, occasionally falling silent and then resounding in front of me; I knew that the current had already turned my boat downstream, and if it was Jim and not some other ferryman howling, I would be at ease.
tr: I heard the voice again, it was behind me once more but in a different place; the voice kept coming and kept changing places, and I kept responding; finally, I started hearing the voice in front of me again and realized that the current had turned the canoe's head downstream and things were falling into place, of course, if the person calling out to me was indeed Jim and not someone else.
es: I heard the shout again; it was still behind me, but in a different place; it sounded over and over and always changed location, and I kept responding, until finally it was ahead of me again, and I realized that the current had turned the canoe around as it moved downstream and that I was going the right way if it was Jim and not another raftsman shouting.

en: I couldn’t tell nothing about voices in a fog, for nothing don’t look natural nor sound natural in a fog.
vi: In the fog, nothing seen by the eyes or heard by the ears seems natural anymore.
tr: I absolutely couldn't distinguish the sounds coming through the mist; because nothing looks natural in the mist, and the sounds don't seem natural either.
es: I couldn't understand any of the voices in the fog, because in a fog nothing seems or sounds natural.

en: The whooping went on, and in about a minute I come a-booming down on a cut bank with smoky ghosts of big trees on it, and the current throwed me off to the left and shot by, amongst a lot of snags that fairly roared, the currrent was tearing by them so swift.
vi: The howling continued, and about a minute later, I crashed right into a clearing with several large trees looming like ghosts, then the current pushed me to the left and I crashed into the bank again, amidst a pile of floating rotten wood that creaked when it hit the boat. And the water continued to quietly meander through the pile of wood.
tr: The sound continued and about a minute later, I was gliding along a steep shore where the ghostly forms of large trees loomed within the mists. The current grabbed me and flung me to the left, and as I passed through the water plants, the water roared and the current battered the plants.
es: The screams continued and after a minute or so I found myself rushing down at full speed in front of a steep bank filled with blurry ghosts of large trees, and the current threw me to the left and kept going, dragging a bunch of logs that thundered down, due to the speed at which the current broke them.

en: In another second or two it was solid white and still again.
vi: Later, the fog became even denser. Even quieter.
tr: A few seconds later, everything turned completely white again and the sounds ceased.
es: After one or two seconds, nothing could be seen but a white mass, and everything had fallen silent.

en: I set perfectly still then, listening to my heart thump, and I reckon I didn’t draw a breath while it thumped a hundred.
vi: I sat completely still, listening to the pounding of my heart. I thought if my heart beat reached a hundred, I wouldn't be able to breathe anymore.
tr: I was listening to my heartbeat without moving, it must have beaten a hundred times until I took another breath.
es: Then I sat still, completely motionless, listening to the beats of my heart, and I think I didn't breathe even once in a hundred beats.

en: I just give up then.
vi: I had to give up.
tr: Then I gave up trying.
es: Then I gave up.

en: I knowed what the matter was.
vi: And I know why it turned out this way.
tr: I had understood what the matter was.
es: I knew what was happening.

en: That cut bank was an island, and Jim had gone down t’other side of it.
vi: This stormy mass is an island, and Jim has drifted to the other side.
tr: The shore we had just seen belonged to an island, and Jim was on the other side of the island.
es: That steep shore was an island, and Jim had crossed to the other side of it.

en: It warn’t no tow-head that you could float by in ten minutes.
vi: There is no creek that can be crossed in about ten minutes.
tr: This was not a shore you could pass by in ten minutes.
es: It wasn't like a sandbar that you could cross in ten minutes.

en: It had the big timber of a regular island; it might be five or six miles long and more than half a mile wide.
vi: This island also has large trees like any other island; it is probably about five or six miles long and half a mile wide.
tr: It had big trees like normal islands; it was five or six miles long and at least half a mile wide.
es: It had big trees like a normal island; it could be five or six miles long and more than half a mile wide.

en: I kept quiet, with my ears cocked, about fifteen minutes, I reckon.
vi: I remained still, listening intently for fifteen minutes.
tr: Without making a sound, I listened intently for fifteen minutes.
es: I remained silent, with my ear attentive, for about fifteen minutes, I estimate.

en: I was floating along, of course, four or five miles an hour; but you don’t ever think of that.
vi: Of course, the boat continued to drift, at about five or six miles per hour. But deep inside, I didn't dare to hope for such a thing.
tr: Meanwhile, I was of course moving at four or five miles per hour, but I wasn't even thinking about it.
es: Naturally, I kept floating downstream at four or five miles per hour, but one never thinks about that.

en: No, you feel like you are laying dead still on the water; and if a little glimpse of a snag slips by you don’t think to yourself how fast you’re going, but you catch your breath and think, my!
vi: It felt as if I were lying unconscious on the water. If no piece of wood floated by, it would be impossible to tell how fast or slow I was drifting.
tr: No, it felt like you weren't moving at all on the water; if a passing branch caught your eye, you wouldn't think about how fast you were going; you'd hold your breath and think, wow, how fast that branch is moving.
es: No, one believes they are completely still in the water, and if some sticks pass by, one doesn't think about how fast they are going, but rather takes a breath and says: "Wow!

en: how that snag’s tearing along.
vi: But I just held my breath, thinking and watching the piece of wood float by.
tr: No, it felt like you weren't moving at all on the water; if a passing branch caught your eye, you wouldn't think about how fast you were going; you'd hold your breath and think, wow, how fast that branch is moving.
es: How fast those sticks are going."

en: If you think it ain’t dismal and lonesome out in a fog that way by yourself in the night, you try it once—you’ll see.
vi: If anyone has never experienced the loneliness and desolation of being alone in the fog late at night, they should try it once to understand.
tr: If you think you won't worry or feel lonely when you get lost alone in the fog at night, try it once – then you'll see.
es: If anyone thinks that being alone at night in the middle of such a fog is not one of the saddest and most terrible things, let them try it just once and they will find out.

en: Next, for about a half an hour, I whoops now and then; at last I hears the answer a long ways off, and tries to follow it, but I couldn’t do it, and directly I judged I’d got into a nest of tow-heads, for I had little dim glimpses of them on both sides of me—sometimes just a narrow channel between, and some that I couldn’t see I knowed was there because I’d hear the wash of the current against the old dead brush and trash that hung over the banks.
vi: Then about half an hour later, I occasionally let out a scream. After that, I heard a distant reply, tried to follow it but couldn't, and I guessed that I had wandered into a place full of many intertwined streams. I looked at both banks and saw only darkness. Sometimes I clearly saw each small canal, sometimes I could only guess because I heard the sound of water hitting the banks.
tr: Then, for half an hour, I called out from time to time; finally, I heard someone shouting back from afar and tried to follow the voice, but I couldn't manage it. At that moment, I realized I had entered the sandbanks, because I could vaguely see sandbanks on either side of me, sometimes with only a narrow channel in between, and even when I couldn't see the sandbanks, I knew they were there because I could hear the current hitting dead branches and debris piled up on the shore.
es: Afterward, for about half an hour or so, I kept shouting from time to time, until I finally heard a response far away, and I tried to follow it, but I couldn't, and immediately I thought I had gotten myself into the middle of a labyrinth of sandbars, because I saw them blurry on both sides: sometimes with only a narrow channel in the middle, and other times I couldn't see them but knew they were there because I heard the current crashing against old dry logs and debris on the banks.

en: Well, I warn’t long loosing the whoops down amongst the tow-heads; and I only tried to chase them a little while, anyway, because it was worse than chasing a Jack-o’-lantern.
vi: I didn't even bother to call out in this maze of uneven land anymore, but just walked a bit further, because it was worse than chasing will-o'-the-wisps.
tr: Soon, I lost the voices among the sandbanks, which I had only tried to follow for a short while anyway, because it was worse than trying to follow will-o'-the-wisps in the marsh.
es: Well, it didn't take long before I stopped hearing the shouts among the sandbars and only tried to follow them for a little while, in any case, because it was worse than chasing a will-o'-the-wisp.

en: You never knowed a sound dodge around so, and swap places so quick and so much.
vi: Never before had I heard echoes that lingered and shifted places so quickly.
tr: I had never thought that a voice could come from so many places and change location so frequently.
es: In my life, I had never heard a noise so difficult to follow nor that changed places so many times and so quickly.

en: I had to claw away from the bank pretty lively four or five times, to keep from knocking the islands out of the river; and so I judged the raft must be butting into the bank every now and then, or else it would get further ahead and clear out of hearing—it was floating a little faster than what I was.
vi: Four or five times, I had to take it down to avoid getting stuck on the shore and to prevent it from hitting the rocks in the river. I was sure the raft had also hit the shore many times; otherwise, it would have moved on and we could have heard it somewhere. The raft still drifted faster than the boat.
tr: I had to push off from the sandy shores four or five times with all my strength, because I didn't want to hit the islands here and there in the river; surely the raft must have been getting stuck in some places on the shore from time to time, otherwise it would have already gone down the river and become too far away to hear – it was just moving a little faster than me.
es: Four or five times I had to push myself away from the shore to avoid bumping into it, so I figured that the raft must be hitting the shore from time to time, because otherwise, it would keep moving and you wouldn't be able to hear it anymore; it was floating a bit faster than I was.

en: Well, I seemed to be in the open river again by-and-by, but I couldn’t hear no sign of a whoop nowheres.
vi: Then, it seems like I might have crashed into the river again, but I still haven't heard any howling sounds.
tr: It seemed that I had once again reached a freely flowing part of the river, but I couldn't hear anyone calling from around.
es: Well, after a while it seemed like I was in open river again, but there wasn't a sound anywhere.

en: I reckoned Jim had fetched up on a snag, maybe, and it was all up with him.
vi: I guess Jim must have crashed into some pile of wood, and maybe that's the end of it.
tr: Maybe Jim had gotten caught on a branch or something, which would mean he was done for.
es: I figured that maybe Jim had gotten caught on a log and that it was all over for him.

en: I was good and tired, so I laid down in the canoe and said I wouldn’t bother no more.
vi: I was so tired, I lay down in the boat and told myself not to care about it anymore.
tr: I was now thoroughly exhausted and felt like lying down in the canoe and letting everything take its course.
es: I was extremely tired, so I lay down at the bottom of the canoe and said I wasn't going to bother anymore.

en: I didn’t want to go to sleep, of course; but I was so sleepy I couldn’t help it; so I thought I would take jest one little cat-nap.
vi: I thought maybe I should take a little nap.
tr: Of course, I didn't want to sleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I decided to take a little nap.
es: Of course, I didn't want to fall asleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I thought I would just take a little nap.

en: But I reckon it was more than a cat-nap, for when I waked up the stars was shining bright, the fog was all gone, and I was spinning down a big bend stern first.
vi: But it turned out it wasn't just a blink of an eye, because when I woke up, there were twinkling stars in the sky, the fog had cleared; I had taken a long nap at the stern.
tr: It seems my sleep lasted longer than a nap, because when I woke up, stars were twinkling above me, the fog had completely lifted, and I had entered a wide bend of the river with my canoe in reverse.
es: But I figure it was more than a nap, because when I woke up the stars were shining brightly, the fog had disappeared, and I was drifting backward down a large bend of the river.

en: First I didn’t know where I was; I thought I was dreaming; and when things began to come back to me they seemed to come up dim out of last week.
vi: At first, I didn't know where I was. I thought I was still dreaming, but upon reflection, it gradually felt like the events that had just happened were from a week ago.
tr: At first, I couldn't understand where I was; I thought I was dreaming; then I slowly began to remember what had happened before I fell asleep, but I could only vaguely recall it, as if it had happened not just a moment ago, but last week.
es: At first, I didn't know where I was. I thought I was dreaming, and when I started to remember things, it seemed like everything had happened a week ago.

en: It was a monstrous big river here, with the tallest and the thickest kind of timber on both banks; just a solid wall, as well as I could see by the stars.
vi: This part of the river is terrifyingly wide, with tall star-like trees lining both banks.
tr: The river was incredibly wide here, and on both banks, there were very tall and dense trees; as far as I could see in the starlight, they stood like a straight wall.
es: There the river was monstrously large, with very tall and tightly packed trees on both banks; like a solid wall, as far as one could see by the light of the stars.

en: I looked away down-stream, and seen a black speck on the water.
vi: I looked down at the river and saw something dark on the surface of the water.
tr: When I looked downstream, I saw a black spot on the water.
es: I looked downstream and saw a black spot in the water.

en: I took after it; but when I got to it it warn’t nothing but a couple of sawlogs made fast together.
vi: I approached it and found out it was just two rotten logs tied together.
tr: I immediately moved towards it, but when I got closer, I saw that it was nothing but a few logs tied together.
es: I went towards it, but when I got there it was nothing more than a couple of tied logs.

en: Then I see another speck, and chased that; then another, and this time I was right.
vi: Then I saw another object, chased it, and it wasn't what I thought either.
tr: Then I saw another spot and chased after it, then followed another one, and this time I had come to the right place.
es: Then I saw another spot and chased it; then another, and that time I was right: it was the raft.

en: It was the raft.
vi: Then another time, and this time it was indeed our raft.
tr: The raft was in front of me.
es: Then I saw another spot and chased it; then another, and that time I was right: it was the raft.

en: When I got to it Jim was setting there with his head down between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering-oar.
vi: When we arrived, we saw Jim sitting slumped, his head tucked between his knees, sleeping, with his right hand resting on the steering oar.
tr: When I boarded the raft, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, sleeping, and his right hand was resting on the steering oar.
es: When I arrived, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering oar.

en: The other oar was smashed off, and the raft was littered up with leaves and branches and dirt.
vi: The oar was broken, and the surface was covered with leaves, branches, and debris.
tr: The other oar had broken off and the raft was covered all over with branches, leaves, and mud.
es: The oar had broken and the raft was full of leaves, branches, and dirt.

en: So she’d had a rough time.
vi: The raft had gone through a tough ordeal.
tr: It was clear that he had also gone through very difficult moments.
es: So he had had a hard time.

en: I made fast and laid down under Jim’s nose on the raft, and began to gap, and stretch my fists out against Jim, and says:
vi: I tied the boat to the raft, then lay down right next to Jim, started yawning, stretched out my legs to kick Jim, and said:
tr: Without wasting any time, I lay down on the raft right under Jim's nose and turned towards Jim, starting to yawn and stretch my fists.
es: I moored and lay down on the raft right next to Jim, and I started yawning and stretching my arms beside him, and I go and say:

en: “Hello, Jim, have I been asleep?
vi: - Hey Jim, was I sleeping?
tr: “Hi, Jim, I fell asleep, didn't I?
es: —Hello, Jim, did I fall asleep?

en: Why didn’t you stir me up?”
vi: Why didn't you wake me up!
tr: Why didn't you wake me up?”
es: Why didn't you wake me up?

en: “Goodness gracious, is dat you, Huck?
vi: - Oh my God, is that you, Huck?
tr: “Dear God, is that you, Huck?
es: —My holy God, is it you, Huck?

en: En you ain’ dead—you ain’ drownded—you’s back agin?
vi: Haven't you died yet, haven't drowned yet, and you're back here?
tr: And you're not dead... you haven't drowned... have you come back?
es: And you haven't died, you haven't drowned, have you come back?

en: It’s too good for true, honey, it’s too good for true.
vi: I'm so glad, Huck, so glad. Really unexpected.
tr: No way, it can't be this good to be true.
es: It's too beautiful to be true, my boy, it's too beautiful to be true.

en: Lemme look at you chile, lemme feel o’ you.
vi: Let me look at you, let me touch you.
tr: Let me see you, son, let me touch you.
es: Let me look at you, boy, let me touch you.

en: No, you ain’ dead!
vi: Yes, you're not dead, you're still alive and back here, it's really you, Huck, it's Huck.
tr: No, you're not dead!
es: No, no, you haven't died!

en: you’s back agin, ’live en soun’, jis de same ole Huck—de same ole Huck, thanks to goodness!”
vi: Oh my God, so glad!
tr: You've come back again, your voice is just like our Huck's voice, and you look just like him... our Huck, thank God!”
es: You have come back again, safe and sound, the same Huck as always... the same Huck as always, thank God!

en: “What’s the matter with you, Jim?
vi: - What's wrong with you, Jim?
tr: “What's wrong with you, Jim?
es: —What’s wrong, Jim?

en: You been a-drinking?”
vi: Have you been drinking??
tr: Have you been drinking?”
es: Have you been drinking?

en: “Drinkin’?
vi: - Drinking alcohol?
tr: “Drinking?
es: —Drunk?

en: Has I ben a-drinkin’?
vi: Me, drinking alcohol?
tr: Me, drinking?
es: Have I been drinking?

en: Has I had a chance to be a-drinkin’?”
vi: Have I ever drunk alcohol?
tr: So, was there even an opportunity to drink?”
es: Have I had even a moment to drink?

en: “Well, then, what makes you talk so wild?”
vi: - Uh, so why are you saying such strange things?
tr: “Okay, but then why are you saying such crazy things?”
es: —Well, then, why do you say such strange things?

en: “How does I talk wild?”
vi: - How am I strange?
tr: “How crazy, man?”
es: —What strange things do I say?

en: “How?
vi: - What else could it be.
tr: “How so?
es: —Which ones?

en: Why, hain’t you been talking about my coming back, and all that stuff, as if I’d been gone away?”
vi: Why do you keep talking about things that make me feel like I'm coming back with all those weird things. It's as if I'm dead!
tr: You were talking about me coming back and other things, as if I didn't exist!”
es: But you keep talking about how I've come back and all that, as if I had left...

en: “Huck—Huck Finn, you look me in de eye; look me in de eye.
vi: - Huck, Huck Finn, look straight into my eyes. Look straight into my eyes.
tr: “Huck… Huck Finn, look me in the eye; look me in the eye.
es: —Huck... Huck Finn, look me in the eyes, look me in the eyes.

en: Hain’t you ben gone away?”
vi: Did you go away?
tr: Hadn't you already gone?”
es: Haven't you left?

en: “Gone away?
vi: - Gone?
tr: “Leave?
es: —Me? Gone?

en: Why, what in the nation do you mean?
vi: Strange, I don't understand what you mean by that?
tr: What do you mean, for God's sake?
es: But, what the devil are you talking about?

en: I hain’t been gone anywheres.
vi: I haven't gone anywhere.
tr: I haven't gone anywhere.
es: I haven't gone anywhere, where would I go?

en: Where would I go to?”
vi: And where would I go anyway? - No, listen to me.
tr: Where would I go?”
es: I haven't gone anywhere, where would I go?

en: “Well, looky here, boss, dey’s sumf’n wrong, dey is.
vi: There must be something wrong.
tr: “Hey, look at the bull, boss, something strange is happening.
es: —Well, look, boss, something's going on here.

en: Is I me, or who is I?
vi: Am I really myself? Or who am I?
tr: Am I me, or who am I?
es: Am I me, or who am I?

en: Is I heah, or whah is I?
vi: Am I here or somewhere else?
