tr: Am I in the bull, if not in the bull, where am I?
es: Am I here, or who is the one that is here?

en: Now dat’s what I wants to know.”
vi: I want to know that.
tr: This is what I need to know.”
es: That's what I want to know.

en: “Well, I think you’re here, plain enough, but I think you’re a tangle-headed old fool, Jim.”
vi: - Oh, I thought you were here, completely intact, but I suppose you might be out of your mind or something, Jim
tr: "I think it's quite clear that you are here, but I must add that you are a completely confused fool, Jim."
es: —Well, I think you're here, no doubt, but I think you're an old crackpot.

en: “I is, is I?
vi: - I'm here, right?
tr: “I am, right?
es: —Ah, so you did?

en: Well, you answer me dis: Didn’t you tote out de line in de canoe fer to make fas’ to de tow-head?”
vi: Alright, then answer this for me: did you jump into the boat earlier to tie the raft to the mouth of the creek?
tr: Okay, answer this: You took the rope and paddled away with the canoe, tied the canoe to a shallow spot, right?”
es: Well, answer me this: didn't you take the end of the canoe to tie it to the sandbar?

en: “No, I didn’t.
vi: - No, not at all.
tr: “There is no such thing.
es: —No.

en: What tow-head?
vi: Which raft head?
tr: What shallowness?
es: What sandbar?

en: I hain’t see no tow-head.”
vi: I don't see any gap at all.
tr: I didn't see any shallowness.”
es: I haven't seen any sandbar.

en: “You hain’t seen no tow-head?
vi: - Can't you see any gap?
tr: “So, you didn't hit any shallows?
es: —Haven't you seen any sandbars?

en: Looky here, didn’t de line pull loose en de raf’ go a-hummin’ down de river, en leave you en de canoe behine in de fog?”
vi: Here, is it like the raft's rope broke and drifted down the river, leaving you alone with the boat in the fog?
tr: Look at the ox, when the rope snapped, it went down the river, and didn't you get stuck in the fog with the canoe?”
es: Look, didn't the raft's cable come loose and go buzzing down the river, leaving you in the canoe behind, in the fog?

en: “What fog?”
vi: - Which fog? - There's no more fog.
tr: “Is it us, really?” “Here is the fog.
es: —What fog? —Well, the fog!

en: “Why, de fog!—de fog dat’s been aroun’ all night.
vi: The fog covered the whole night, didn't it?
tr: The fog that didn't lift all night.
es: The fog we've had all night.

en: En didn’t you whoop, en didn’t I whoop, tell we got mix’ up in de islands en one un us got los’ en t’other one was jis’ as good as los’, ’kase he didn’ know whah he wuz?
vi: Didn't you call out and I answered? Then we got lost all over this island and no one knew where anyone was, right?
tr: You called out to me, I called out to you, in the end, we got lost between the sandy shore and the islands, and we lost each other, neither of us knew where the other was, so we were lost.
es: And weren't you shouting and I was too, until we stumbled upon one of the islands and one of us got lost and the other as if he were lost, because he didn't know where he was?

en: En didn’t I bust up agin a lot er dem islands en have a turrible time en mos’ git drownded?
vi: Then I got stuck in a dense storm, struggling and almost drowned!
tr: Then I crossed the islands again, had a very difficult time, and almost drowned.
es: And wasn't I looking through a bunch of those islands and had a terrible time and almost drowned?

en: Now ain’ dat so, boss—ain’t it so?
vi: Isn't that right? Or is it not?
tr: Isn't that right, boss… ha, isn't that right?
es: Tell me it's not true, boss, isn't it?

en: You answer me dat.”
vi: Answer me
tr: Tell me!”
es: Answer me that.

en: “Well, this is too many for me, Jim.
vi: - Oh, then I give up, Jim.
tr: “Alright, but they all came more than once, Jim.
es: —Well, this is too much for me, Jim.

en: I hain’t seen no fog, nor no islands, nor no troubles, nor nothing.
vi: I don't see anything at all. Fog, then the island, then all sorts of things, I don't see anything at all.
tr: I didn't see any fog, I didn't see the islands, and we weren't in any trouble.
es: I haven't seen any fog, nor any island, nor had any problem, nor anything.

en: I been setting here talking with you all night till you went to sleep about ten minutes ago, and I reckon I done the same.
vi: I've been sitting here talking to you all night until you went to bed ten minutes ago, and I think I also fell asleep.
tr: We sat here and chatted all night, and you fell asleep ten minutes ago, I think I did the same.
es: I've been sitting talking with you all night until you fell asleep about ten minutes ago and I think I did too.

en: You couldn’t a got drunk in that time, so of course you’ve been dreaming.”
vi: You probably drank alcohol, so you slept so deeply.
tr: Since you couldn't get drunk in such a short time, I have no doubt you were dreaming.”
es: In that time you couldn't have gotten drunk, so what happened is that you were dreaming.

en: “Dad fetch it, how is I gwyne to dream all dat in ten minutes?”
vi: - Nonsense, how could I have dreamed all those things in just ten minutes?
tr: “That can't be? How did I see that much of a dream in ten minutes?”
es: —Damn it, how am I going to dream all that in ten minutes?

en: “Well, hang it all, you did dream it, because there didn’t any of it happen.”
vi: - Stop talking. It's true that you were dreaming, because nothing happened at all.
tr: “It doesn't matter, you saw it in your dream, because none of these things happened.”
es: —Well, we're in trouble, but you did dream it, because none of that happened.

en: “But, Huck, it’s all jis’ as plain to me as—”
vi: - But clearly I saw all of that, Huck
tr: "But Huck, it's all so muddled in my head...""
es: —But, Huck, I see it as clearly as...

en: “It don’t make no difference how plain it is; there ain’t nothing in it.
vi: - Clear or not clear, I don't know, but there is nothing at all.
tr: “But what difference does it make if it's clear, it has nothing to do with reality.
es: —It doesn't matter that you see it clearly; that's not what happened.

en: I know, because I’ve been here all the time.”
vi: I know it is true, because I have been here the whole time since then.
tr: I'm sure of it, because I've always been here.”
es: I know because I've been here the whole time.

en: Jim didn’t say nothing for about five minutes, but set there studying over it.
vi: Jim was silent for five minutes, saying nothing, just sitting there thinking.
tr: Jim didn't say anything for five minutes, he was trying to put the pieces together in his mind.
es: Jim didn't say anything for about five minutes, but just sat there thinking about it.

en: Then he says:
vi: Then he said:
tr: “So it seems I supposedly died, Huck,” he said finally.
es: Then he goes and says: —Well, then, I reckon I dreamed it, Huck; but hang me if it wasn't the most real dream I've ever seen in my life.

en: “Well, den, I reck’n I did dream it, Huck; but dog my cats ef it ain’t de powerfullest dream I ever see.
vi: - Alright, let's just assume I was sleepwalking, Huck, but I swear I've never sleepwalked as intensely as this.
tr: “If I didn't die the bloodiest and liveliest supposed death, I'm not a man.
es: Then he goes and says: —Well, then, I reckon I dreamed it, Huck; but hang me if it wasn't the most real dream I've ever seen in my life.

en: En I hain’t ever had no dream b’fo’ dat’s tired me like dis one.”
vi: And never have I felt as tired after sleepwalking as I do this time.
tr: Also, no other supposed death has ever worn me out this much.”
es: And I've never had a dream that left me as tired as this one.

en: “Oh, well, that’s all right, because a dream does tire a body like everything sometimes.
vi: - Oh, it's nothing, a dream always makes one tired.
tr: “Alright dear, such things happen; sometimes dreams can also tire a person.
es: —Well, it's normal, because sometimes dreams tire you out like the devil.

en: But this one was a staving dream; tell me all about it, Jim.”
vi: But this dream is said to be interesting; tell me about it, Jim.
tr: But this time it was a wonderful dream... Tell me all about it, Jim.”
es: But this has been a scary dream; tell me the whole thing, Jim.

en: So Jim went to work and told me the whole thing right through, just as it happened, only he painted it up considerable.
vi: So Jim began to recount everything from that moment, exactly as it had happened, and Jim also embellished it quite a bit.
tr: Jim started right away and told everything as it was from beginning to end, but he embellished it quite a bit.
es: So Jim set to the task and told me everything from beginning to end, just as it had happened, only he embellished it a lot.

en: Then he said he must start in and “’terpret” it, because it was sent for a warning.
vi: Then Jim said we had to figure it out this way, because it was divine retribution.
tr: Then he said he needed to start interpreting the dream, because the dream was a warning.
es: Then he said he had to "interpret it," because it was a warning.

en: He said the first tow-head stood for a man that would try to do us some good, but the current was another man that would get us away from him.
vi: He said that the first stream head was someone trying to help us, but the current was a second person wanting to cut us off from the first.
tr: The first islet was someone who would try to do us good, but the current was another man who would pull us away from him.
es: He said that the first sandbar represented a man who would try to do us some good, but the current was another man who wanted to keep us away from him.

en: The whoops was warnings that would come to us every now and then, and if we didn’t try hard to make out to understand them they’d just take us into bad luck, ’stead of keeping us out of it.
vi: The occasional howls we heard were warnings to us, and if we didn't try to understand them, we could avoid them.
tr: The calls were a warning of what could happen to us at any moment, and if we didn't try hard to understand them, they would bring us bad luck instead of protecting us from it.
es: The shouts were warnings that would come to us from time to time, and if we didn't try with all our might to understand them, then they would bring us bad luck instead of keeping us away from it.

en: The lot of tow-heads was troubles we was going to get into with quarrelsome people and all kinds of mean folks, but if we minded our business and didn’t talk back and aggravate them, we would pull through and get out of the fog and into the big clear river, which was the free States, and wouldn’t have no more trouble.
vi: A bunch of other streams represented the difficulties showing that we were about to clash with troublemakers and all other bad people. But if we paid careful attention to our work, didn't tell anyone about it, and didn't complicate things, we could avoid disaster, escape the fog, reach the clear river, and that would be freedom; from there, we wouldn't encounter any more calamities.
tr: A lot of sandbars meant we would get into trouble with quarrelsome people and all sorts of lowly individuals; but if we minded our own business and didn't respond or provoke them, we would get away and escape the fog, reaching the big clear river which was the free states. Then we would have no more troubles at all.
es: The maze of sandbars was for problems we were going to have with ill-tempered people and all kinds of bad people, but if we minded our own business and didn't respond to them or make them angry, then we would get through and free ourselves from the fog and enter the big, clear river, which were the free states, and we would no longer have any problems.

en: It had clouded up pretty dark just after I got on to the raft, but it was clearing up again now.
vi: By the time I returned to the raft, dark clouds were gathering quite a bit, but now the sky was clearing up. I said:
tr: After I got on the bus, the weather had become cloudy and it had gotten quite dark around, but now the clouds were dispersing.
es: After my return to the raft, it had gotten very dark, but now it was getting light again.

en: “Oh, well, that’s all interpreted well enough as far as it goes, Jim,” I says; “but what does these things stand for?”
vi: - Very good, you guessed it right, Jim. But where should we put these things?
tr: “Alright, you interpreted it very well, Jim,” I said. “Okay, but what do these mean; can you tell me?”
es: —Well, now everything is interpreted until the end, Jim —I say—, but what do those things represent?

en: It was the leaves and rubbish on the raft and the smashed oar.
vi: I said while pointing at the piles of leaves, debris, and the broken paddle on the raft.
tr: I was pointing out the leaves, debris, and broken oar on the raft.
es: They were the leaves and the remnants that were on the raft and the broken oar.

en: You could see them first-rate now.
vi: Now those things are even more visible.
tr: Now everything was clearly visible.
es: Now they could be seen perfectly.

en: Jim looked at the trash, and then looked at me, and back at the trash again.
vi: Jim looked at the debris, then looked at me, and then looked back at the debris.
tr: Jim looked at them, then at me, then back at them again.
es: Jim looked at that trash and then looked at me and then back at the trash again.

en: He had got the dream fixed so strong in his head that he couldn’t seem to shake it loose and get the facts back into its place again right away.
vi: He was so strongly haunted by the dream that he seemed unable to shake it off and properly look at the things around him.
tr: He was so convinced he was dreaming that he couldn't shake off the idea, unable to put the facts back in place.
es: He was already so convinced that it had been a dream that he couldn't seem to free himself from it and put things back in their place.

en: But when he did get the thing straightened around he looked at me steady without ever smiling, and says:
vi: But after he had carefully examined those things, he stared at me, not smiling, and said:
tr: But then, when he had everything sorted out in his mind, he looked at me straight without a smile.
es: But when he finally understood what reality was, he looked at me very intently without smiling at all and said:

en: “What do dey stan’ for?
vi: - What for?
tr: “What does it mean?
es: —What do they represent?

en: I’se gwyne to tell you.
vi: Then I'll tell you this.
tr: I'll tell you.
es: I'm going to tell you.

en: When I got all wore out wid work, en wid de callin’ for you, en went to sleep, my heart wuz mos’ broke bekase you wuz los’, en I didn’ k’yer no’ mo’ what become er me en de raf’.
vi: After I was so tired from messing around there and calling you forever without seeing you, I went to sleep, and in my heart, I was extremely pained because I had lost you. I didn't even care what would happen to me and the raft anymore.
tr: Calling out and looking for you on Tuesday exhausted me, I was devastated because you were lost. I no longer cared about myself or the search.
es: When I got exhausted from working so much and calling out to you and I fell asleep, my heart almost broke because you were lost and I no longer cared what happened to me on the raft.

en: En when I wake up en fine you back agin, all safe en soun’, de tears come, en I could a got down on my knees en kiss yo’ foot, I’s so thankful.
vi: When I woke up and saw you had returned intact, I shed tears, I could have knelt down and kissed your feet because I was so overwhelmingly happy.
tr: When I finally woke up and saw you safe and sound, my eyes filled with tears, I was so grateful that I was ready to kneel and kiss your feet.
es: And when I woke up and saw you again, safe and sound, tears came to my eyes and I could have gotten on my knees and kissed your feet, I felt so grateful.

en: En all you wuz thinkin’ ’bout wuz how you could make a fool uv ole Jim wid a lie.
vi: Yet you could make up lies to tell this Jim.
tr: But your only thought was to lie to poor Jim and deceive him.
es: And all you could think of was how to make old Jim look ridiculous with a lie.

en: Dat truck dah is trash; en trash is what people is dat puts dirt on de head er dey fren’s en makes ’em ashamed.”
vi: Those people are wood, are trash, and those are the filthy things that people put into your mind to make you feel ashamed.
tr: This is the wreckage of your game; wreckage is what you call someone who plays dirty tricks on their friend, making them ashamed.”
es: What you see there is trash, and trash is what people are who put stupid ideas in their friends' heads and make them feel ashamed.

en: Then he got up slow and walked to the wigwam, and went in there without saying anything but that.
vi: Then Jim quietly stood up and walked into the tent, not saying another word.
tr: Then, slowly, he got up and went into the shelter. He didn't say anything else.
es: Then he got up very slowly and went towards the wigwam and entered it without saying more.

en: But that was enough.
vi: That's more than enough.
tr: But that was enough anyway.
es: But that was enough.

en: It made me feel so mean I could almost kissed his foot to get him to take it back.
vi: I felt so guilty that I almost wanted to kneel down and kiss Jim's feet to make him come back.
tr: I was so ashamed and regretful that I could have fallen at his feet at that moment to take back what I had done.
es: It made me feel so mean that I almost could have kissed his feet to make him change his mind.

en: It was fifteen minutes before I could work myself up to go and humble myself to a nigger; but I done it, and I warn’t ever sorry for it afterwards, neither.
vi: It took me fifteen minutes to get up, to apologize in front of a black man. But after doing that, I never had to feel remorse or regret again.
tr: It took me about fifteen minutes to convince myself to humble myself to win the favor of a black man – but in the end, I did it and I never regretted it.
es: It took me fifteen minutes to decide to humble myself before a black man, but I did it and I never regretted it afterwards.

en: I didn’t do him no more mean tricks, and I wouldn’t done that one if I’d a knowed it would make him feel that way.
vi: Later on, I didn't dare to play such inappropriate jokes on Jim, and regarding this matter, if I had known that Jim felt that way, I wouldn't have dared to joke.
tr: I never played such mean tricks on him again, and if I had known he would feel this way, I wouldn't have done such things the first time either.
es: I kept playing tricks on him, and I wouldn't have played that one if I had known he would feel that way.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: Chapter XVI
tr: Chapter Six
es: Chapter 16

en: We slept most all day, and started out at night, a little ways behind a monstrous long raft that was as long going by as a procession.
vi: We slept for most of the day, and at night we followed a large raft that was as long as a procession.
tr: We slept almost all day and set out again at night; we were following a long and huge raft like a ceremonial procession.
es: WE SPENT ALMOST the entire day sleeping and set off at night, a little behind a monstrously long raft that took as long to pass as a procession.

en: She had four long sweeps at each end, so we judged she carried as many as thirty men, likely.
vi: At the four corners of the raft were four large and long oars, and we guessed the raft must carry about thirty to forty people.
tr: There were four long oars at each end of the raft, so we estimated that there were about thirty people on it.
es: It had four long oars at each end, so we thought that probably no fewer than thirty men would travel on it.

en: She had five big wigwams aboard, wide apart, and an open camp fire in the middle, and a tall flag-pole at each end.
vi: On the raft, there were five large tents with an open-air kitchen in the middle, and at each end of the raft, there was a very tall flagpole.
tr: There were five separate shelters spaced apart on the raft, and we also saw an open campfire in the middle and a long flagpole at each end.
es: It had five large wigwams on board and an open fire in the center, with a large flagpole at each end.

en: There was a power of style about her.
vi: This raft looked truly majestic.
tr: This raft looked quite majestic.
es: It was very elegant.

en: It amounted to something being a raftsman on such a craft as that.
vi: On such large rafts, the raft operators must be very valuable.
tr: Working on such a watercraft must have been something to be proud of.
es: Being a rafter on such a vessel meant something.

en: We went drifting down into a big bend, and the night clouded up and got hot.
vi: We rowed on and followed the river to a vast, expansive area. At night, the clouds rose high, and the sky began to heat up intensely.
tr: We started to navigate around a big bend, the weather became cloudy and it started to warm up.
es: We drifted down a large curve, the night became cloudy and it started to get very hot.

en: The river was very wide, and was walled with solid timber on both sides; you couldn’t see a break in it hardly ever, or a light.
vi: The river was very wide, and both banks were densely packed with large trees; it seemed as if there was no place for sunlight to penetrate through.
tr: The river was very wide and dense trees on both banks formed almost a wall; you couldn't see a single open spot or light.
es: The river was very wide and was surrounded by very dense forests on both sides; there was not a clearing or even a light to be seen in them.

en: We talked about Cairo, and wondered whether we would know it when we got to it.
vi: We talked to each other about Cairo, wondering when we would finally reach and see Cairo.
tr: We started talking about Cairo and pondered how we would know when we arrived there.
es: We talked about Cairo and wondered if we would recognize it when we arrived.

en: I said likely we wouldn’t, because I had heard say there warn’t but about a dozen houses there, and if they didn’t happen to have them lit up, how was we going to know we was passing a town?
vi: I said it seemed like we wouldn't get there, because I heard that there were only about a dozen houses there, and if they didn't light up at night, how would we know we had passed by?
tr: Most likely, we wouldn't realize when we got there, because I had heard that there were only about a dozen houses there, and if their lights weren't on as we passed by, how would we know we had passed through a town?
es: I said no, because I had heard that there were only about a dozen houses, and if they didn't have lights, how would we know we were passing by a town?

en: Jim said if the two big rivers joined together there, that would show.
vi: Jim said that the place where two large rivers meet is the right spot.
tr: Jim said we would know when we got there because two large rivers converged there.
es: Jim said that if the two great rivers met there, that would indicate it to us.

en: But I said maybe we might think we was passing the foot of an island and coming into the same old river again.
vi: But I said maybe we were circling around the head of an island and then returning to the old river or something.
tr: But I replied that we might think we had just passed the tip of an island and continued on the same river.
es: But I replied that we might think we were passing by the end of an island and returning to the same river as always.

en: That disturbed Jim—and me too.
vi: That made Jim worried - and me too, for the whole evening.
tr: Upon this, Jim started to waver... and so did I.
es: That worried Jim, and me too.

en: So the question was, what to do?
vi: So the question was: What do we do now?
tr: So what would we do then?
es: So the question was, what to do?

en: I said, paddle ashore the first time a light showed, and tell them pap was behind, coming along with a trading-scow, and was a green hand at the business, and wanted to know how far it was to Cairo.
vi: I said that whenever we saw lights, we should immediately turn to the shore, tell people that my father was following with a merchant ship, and since he was new to the job, he wasn't sure how far Cairo was.
tr: I said I would go ashore with the canoe at the first place we saw lights, and tell the people there that my father was coming behind us with a freight boat, and since he was new to this, he wanted to know how far Cairo was.
es: I said to row, row to the shore as soon as we saw the first light and tell them that father was coming behind in a merchant skiff, and that he was a novice at these things and wanted to know how far it was to Cairo.

en: Jim thought it was a good idea, so we took a smoke on it and waited.
vi: Jim thought that was a good idea. So we sat and smoked, waiting.
tr: Jim liked this idea, we lit our pipes and started to wait.
es: Jim thought it was a good idea, so we started smoking to celebrate it and set about waiting.

en: There warn’t nothing to do now but to look out sharp for the town, and not pass it without seeing it.
vi: At this moment, there was nothing to do but to carefully watch out for the town to avoid passing by without noticing it.
tr: Now all we had to do was keep our eyes wide open and spring into action when we saw a town.
es: Now there was nothing left to do but be very attentive to the town and not pass by without seeing it.

en: He said he’d be mighty sure to see it, because he’d be a free man the minute he seen it, but if he missed it he’d be in a slave country again and no more show for freedom.
vi: Jim said that we would definitely see it, because if we did, we would have to live in a land of slavery again and would not be able to find freedom anymore.
tr: Jim said that when we got near a town, he would definitely see it, because the moment he saw the town, he would be a free man, but if he missed it, he would still be in the land of the blacks and would not reach freedom.
es: Jim said he was absolutely sure he would see it, because as soon as he saw it, he would be a free man, but if he didn't see it, it meant he was back in the zone of slavery and would never reach freedom.

en: Every little while he jumps up and says:
vi: Suddenly, a moment later, he jumped up and said:
tr: He often jumped up and said, "There it is!"
es: At every moment he would jump to his feet and shout:

en: “Dah she is?”
vi: - Look over there!
tr: He often jumped up and said, "There it is!"
es: —There it is!

en: But it warn’t.
vi: But it wasn't.
tr: But she was mistaken.
es: But he wasn't there.

en: It was Jack-o’-lanterns, or lightning bugs; so he set down again, and went to watching, same as before.
vi: It was just a will-o'-the-wisp or a firefly. Then he sat down again, intently watching as before.
tr: The lights she saw turned out to be either swamp fire or fireflies; then she would sit back down and continue watching with her eyes wide open just like before.
es: They were will-o'-the-wisps or fireflies, so he sat back down and watched just like before.

en: Jim said it made him all over trembly and feverish to be so close to freedom.
vi: Jim said that when he got close to the land of freedom, he felt himself trembling like he had a fever. As for me, I can say that it made me tremble feverishly just hearing Jim say that.
tr: Jim said that being so close to freedom made him tremble violently and his heart start to beat rapidly.
es: Jim said that being so close to freedom made him tremble and feel feverish.

en: Well, I can tell you it made me all over trembly and feverish, too, to hear him, because I begun to get it through my head that he was most free—and who was to blame for it?
vi: Because I also began to feel that in his mind, he was the freest man. And who was responsible for that?
tr: I must say that listening to him also made me tremble violently and my heart beat rapidly, because it was beginning to dawn on me that he would indeed soon taste freedom – and who was to blame for that?
es: Well, I can say that listening to him made me tremble and feel feverish too, because I was starting to realize that I was almost free, and who was to blame?

en: Why, me.
vi: It was me, of course.
tr: It was me.
es: Well, me.

en: I couldn’t get that out of my conscience, no how nor no way.
vi: In my consciousness, I couldn't understand how or why that was?
tr: No matter how hard I tried, I couldn't silence my conscience.
es: I couldn't get it off my conscience, no matter what I did.

en: It got to troubling me so I couldn’t rest; I couldn’t stay still in one place.
vi: It made me so restless that I couldn't sit still, couldn't stand still in one place.
tr: I was so restless that I couldn't relax at all, I couldn't stay still.
es: It worried me so much that I couldn't rest; I couldn't stay calm in one place.

en: It hadn’t ever come home to me before, what this thing was that I was doing.
vi: Before, I was never familiar with that idea, but now I was thinking about it.
tr: I had never felt the meaning of what I was doing so deeply before.
es: Until then, I had never realized what I was doing.

en: But now it did; and it stayed with me, and scorched me more and more.
vi: Now, it haunted me, gripped my hands, and made me increasingly restless.
tr: But now I felt it; moreover, it had settled inside me and was burning my heart more and more.
es: But now I did, and I couldn't stop thinking about it and it irritated me more and more.

en: I tried to make out to myself that I warn’t to blame, because I didn’t run Jim off from his rightful owner; but it warn’t no use, conscience up and says, every time, “But you knowed he was running for his freedom, and you could a paddled ashore and told somebody.”
vi: I tried to tell myself that it wasn't my fault, because it wasn't me who made Jim run away from his rightful owner. But there was nothing I could do, always conscious of waking up and saying: you must know that Jim ran away for freedom, and you can't go ashore and tell anyone about it.
tr: I tried to convince myself that it wasn't my fault, because I wasn't the one who helped Jim escape from his owner; but it was no use, because my conscience would stand up each time and say: “But you knew he wanted to be free and you could have gone ashore and told someone.”
es: I tried to convince myself that it wasn't my fault because I wasn't the one who made Jim escape from his rightful owner, but it was no use, because my conscience kept coming back and saying every time: "But you knew he was running away in search of freedom and you could have rowed to the shore and told someone."

en: That was so—I couldn’t get around that noway.
vi: That's it, I couldn't avoid that thought.
tr: This was true – no matter how much I wanted to, I couldn't deny it.
es: It was true: there was no way to deny it.

en: That was where it pinched.
vi: And that's exactly where it appeared.
tr: And that was what hurt the most.
es: That's where it hurt.

en: Conscience says to me, “What had poor Miss Watson done to you that you could see her nigger go off right under your eyes and never say one single word?
vi: Consciousness told me again: What did Miss Watson ever do to you that you could calmly watch her black man run away and not say a word?
tr: My conscience kept asking the same questions: “What did poor Miss Watson ever do to you that you watch her slave escape right before your eyes and don't say a word?
es: My conscience said to me: "What had poor Miss Watson done to you that you saw her negro escape right in front of you and didn't say a single word?

en: What did that poor old woman do to you that you could treat her so mean?
vi: How did that poor woman treat you that you would treat her so badly?
tr: What wrong did the poor woman do to you that you do such a despicable thing to her?
es: What had that poor old woman done to you to treat her so badly?

en: Why, she tried to learn you your book, she tried to learn you your manners, she tried to be good to you every way she knowed how.
vi: She taught you, fed you, and treated you well in every way.
tr: She tried to teach you the book, she tried to teach you manners, she tried to do good to you in her own way.
es: Well, she had tried to get you to learn your book, she had tried to teach you manners, she had tried to make you good by all the means she knew.

en: That’s what she done.”
vi: Isn't that so?
tr: She has no other fault.”
es: That's what she had done."

en: I got to feeling so mean and so miserable I most wished I was dead.
vi: I suddenly felt so cowardly, so vile, and just wanted to die.
tr: I felt so vile and despicable that I wished God would take my life and save me from this misery.
es: I felt so bad and so miserable that I almost wished I had died.

en: I fidgeted up and down the raft, abusing myself to myself, and Jim was fidgeting up and down past me.
vi: I paced restlessly on the raft, scolding myself; and Jim was also nervously pacing like me.
tr: While I was pacing back and forth on the raft, blaming myself in distress, I kept running into Jim, who was pacing just like me.
es: I paced up and down the raft, cursing myself inwardly, and Jim paced up and down in front of me.

en: We neither of us could keep still.
vi: Neither of us could stay silent.
tr: Neither of us could stay still.
es: Neither of us could stay still.

en: Every time he danced around and says, “Dah’s Cairo!” it went through me like a shot, and I thought if it was Cairo I reckoned I would die of miserableness.
vi: Every now and then, he would turn abruptly and say: There's Cairo! The words shot through me like a bullet. And I also thought that if it was Cairo, I might die a miserable death.
tr: Every time Jim started to dance with joy, saying, "There's Cairo!" I felt like I had been struck in the head, and if that really was Cairo, I thought I would die from my torment.
es: Every time he jumped and said, "That's Cairo!" it was like getting shot, and I thought that if it was Cairo, I was going to die of horror.

en: Jim talked out loud all the time while I was talking to myself.
vi: While I was questioning myself, Jim kept talking loudly.
tr: While I was keeping everything to myself, Jim was openly expressing all his thoughts.
es: Jim spoke out loud all the time while I spoke alone.

en: He was saying how the first thing he would do when he got to a free State he would go to saving up money and never spend a single cent, and when he got enough he would buy his wife, which was owned on a farm close to where Miss Watson lived; and then they would both work to buy the two children, and if their master wouldn’t sell them, they’d get an Ab’litionist to go and steal them.
vi: He said that after reaching a free land, the first thing he would do is open a savings account and never spend a penny. When he had enough money, he would buy his wife, who is currently working at a farm near where Ms. Watson lives. Then the couple would work to buy back their two children, and if the owner refused to sell them, they would hire someone to steal them back.
tr: He said that his first task upon reaching one of the free states would be to start saving money. With the money he saved without spending a single cent, he would first buy his wife. Jim’s wife belonged to a farmer living near Mrs. Watson’s house. Then, working together, they would buy their two children; if the owners were unwilling to sell the children, they would pay some abolitionists to steal them.
es: According to him, the first thing he would do when he reached a free state would be to save money and not spend a cent, and when he had enough, he would buy his wife, who was a slave on a farm near where Miss Watson lived, and then they would both work to buy their two children, and if the owner of the children didn't want to sell them, they would get an abolitionist to steal them.

en: It most froze me to hear such talk.
vi: I heard that and felt a chill run down my spine.
tr: Hearing him talk like that chilled my blood.
es: Hearing those things almost froze my blood.

en: He wouldn’t ever dared to talk such talk in his life before.
vi: Never before had he dared to speak of such things.
tr: He would never have dared to say such things before.
es: Before, he would never have dared to say all that.

en: Just see what a difference it made in him the minute he judged he was about free.
vi: Just try to imagine the moment when he felt he was about to be free, how different it was from before.
tr: How much he had changed the moment he felt he was approaching freedom.
es: That's how he had changed as soon as he thought he was almost free.

en: It was according to the old saying, “Give a nigger an inch and he’ll take an ell.”
vi: It was exactly like the proverb people often say: Give a black man an inch and he will take a mile.
tr: Just like the old saying goes, "give a Negro your hand and he'll take your arm."
es: It's like the saying goes: "Give an inch and they'll take a mile."

en: Thinks I, this is what comes of my not thinking.
vi: I thought, this is because I didn't think it through beforehand.
tr: This is the result of thoughtlessness, I was saying to myself.
es: I thought: "This is what happens to me for not thinking."

en: Here was this nigger, which I had as good as helped to run away, coming right out flat-footed and saying he would steal his children—children that belonged to a man I didn’t even know; a man that hadn’t ever done me no harm.
vi: This is a black man whom I helped escape, and now he is determined to say that he will go and take back his child, whose child I don't even know; a black man who has never done anything to harm me at all.
tr: Here was the Negro I almost helped escape, now openly talking about committing a new crime by stealing children, and not just any children, but those of a man I didn't know and who had never done me any harm.
es: There he was, that black man, whom I had practically helped to escape, saying with a straight face that he was going to steal children: children who belonged to a man I didn't even know; a man who had never done me any harm.

en: I was sorry to hear Jim say that, it was such a lowering of him.
vi: I am very sorry to hear Jim speak like that. It was truly cowardly.
tr: Jim saying such things was upsetting me greatly, he had fallen from my favor.
es: I regretted hearing that from him, because he was lowering himself.

en: My conscience got to stirring me up hotter than ever, until at last I says to it, “Let up on me—it ain’t too late yet—I’ll paddle ashore at the first light and tell.”
vi: My consciousness returned to its size, and I became more agitated. Until I responded to my consciousness: Okay, leave it to me, it's never too late. Seeing the lights, I will immediately row the boat to shore and speak out.
tr: My conscience started to ache so much that I finally gave in and said to myself: "This is enough... it's not too late yet... I'll go ashore at first light and report him."
es: My conscience started to hurt more than ever until I finally said to him: "Leave me alone... it's not too late yet; as soon as day breaks, I'll go ashore and tell."

en: I felt easy and happy and light as a feather right off.
vi: After answering, I felt comfortable, happy, as light as a floating feather.
tr: Suddenly, I felt relieved, cheerful, as light as a feather.
es: Immediately, I felt calm and happy and light as a feather.

en: All my troubles was gone.
vi: All the restlessness disappeared.
tr: It was as if all my troubles had ended.
es: All my problems had disappeared.

en: I went to looking out sharp for a light, and sort of singing to myself.
vi: I turned to attentively look at the light, feeling secretly joyful inside.
tr: I started scanning the shore with wide eyes to see if there was any light and began to hum a tune to myself.
es: I looked again very carefully to see if there was a light, humming to myself.

en: By-and-by one showed.
vi: A moment later, a light flashed.
tr: After a while, the first light appeared.
es: After a while, one appeared.

en: Jim sings out:
vi: Jim shouted;
tr: Jim was shouting:
es: Jim shouted:

en: “We’s safe, Huck, we’s safe!
vi: - Don't worry, Huck, jump on, jump on.
tr: "We're safe, Huck, we made it!
es: —We are safe, Huck, we are safe!

en: Jump up and crack yo’ heels!
vi: - Don't worry, Huck, jump on, jump on.
tr: "We're safe, Huck, we made it!
es: Get up and jump for joy!

en: Dat’s de good ole Cairo at las’, I jis knows it!”
vi: This is really our Cairo, I knew it.
tr: Come on, hey, we finally reached Cairo.
es: At last, it's Cairo, I'm sure!

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: This time I have no doubt!"
es: And I go and say:

en: “I’ll take the canoe and go and see, Jim.
vi: - Let me take it down and have a look, Jim.
tr: "Let me go and take a look, Jim.
es: —Well, I'm going to go check with the canoe.

en: It mightn’t be, you know.”
vi: But it's not certain, you know, Jim?
tr: Maybe it's not the place;" I said.
es: You know, maybe it isn't.

en: He jumped and got the canoe ready, and put his old coat in the bottom for me to set on, and give me the paddle; and as I shoved off, he says:
vi: He ran out to prepare the boat, took off his old shirt to lay it down for me to sit on, and then handed me the paddle. As I was leaving, he called after me:
tr: Jim jumped up, went to prepare the canoe, spread his old jacket inside for me to sit on, and handed me the paddle. As I was moving away, he called out after me:
es: With a leap, he prepared the canoe and placed his old cloak at the bottom for me to sit on, handed me the paddle, and as I left, he said to me:

en: “Pooty soon I’ll be a-shout’n’ for joy, en I’ll say, it’s all on accounts o’ Huck; I’s a free man, en I couldn’t ever ben free ef it hadn’ ben for Huck; Huck done it.
vi: - Soon I will be able to shout with joy, and I will say: It's all thanks to you, Huck.
tr: “Soon I will jump for joy and say it’s all thanks to Huck. Now I am a free man and I couldn’t have made it without Huck; I owe everything to Huck.
es: —Soon I will be shouting with joy and I will say that it is all thanks to Huck; I am a free man and I never could have been if it hadn't been for Huck; it was Huck.

en: Jim won’t ever forgit you, Huck; you’s de bes’ fren’
vi: I am a free man, and if it weren't for Huck, I could never be free; it was Huck who created that freedom for me.
tr: Jim will never forget you, Huck; you are Jim’s best friend ever, and now you are poor Jim’s only friend.”
es: Jim will never forget it, Huck; you are the best friend Jim has ever had in his life and you are the only friend old Jim has now.

en: Jim’s ever had; en you’s de only fren’ ole Jim’s got now.”
vi: Jim, I will never forget you, Huck, you are the best friend I have ever had, and now, you are Jim's only friend.
tr: Jim will never forget you, Huck; you are Jim’s best friend ever, and now you are poor Jim’s only friend.”
es: Jim will never forget it, Huck; you are the best friend Jim has ever had in his life and you are the only friend old Jim has now.

en: I was paddling off, all in a sweat to tell on him; but when he says this, it seemed to kind of take the tuck all out of me.
vi: I rowed the boat away, anxious to reveal this matter, but when I heard him say those words, it felt as if my insides were turned inside out.
tr: I was rowing with all my might to report him as soon as possible, but when I heard these things, I suddenly became paralyzed.
es: I was rowing as fast as I could to betray him; but when he said that, it seemed to take all my strength away.

en: I went along slow then, and I warn’t right down certain whether I was glad I started or whether I warn’t.
vi: I rowed slowly, and I couldn't tell whether I was willing or unwilling to go.
tr: I gradually slowed down; I was no longer so sure if I was pleased with having embarked on this task.
es: I started to go slower and wasn't very sure I felt so happy about having set out.

en: When I was fifty yards off, Jim says:
vi: About fifty meters away, Jim spoke again:
tr: When I was about fifty meters away, Jim called out again:
es: When I was five hundred yards away, Jim goes and says:

en: “Dah you goes, de ole true Huck; de on’y white genlman dat ever kep’ his promise to ole Jim.”
vi: - You truly are Huck, you are the only white person who has kept their promise to Jim.
tr: “Come on, put some strength in your arm, my friend Huck, the only white master who kept his promise to poor Jim.”
es: —There goes my faithful Huck; the only white gentleman who has kept his promises to old Jim.

en: Well, I just felt sick.
vi: I feel heartbroken.
tr: No, my stomach couldn't handle this tattling.
es: Well, I almost got sick.

en: But I says, I got to do it—I can’t get out of it.
vi: But I tell myself: I have to do it, I can't stand still.
tr: But still, I thought, I must do it, I couldn't back out anymore.
es: But I told myself: "I have to do it; I can't stop doing it."

en: Right then along comes a skiff with two men in it with guns, and they stopped and I stopped.
vi: At that moment, a boat carrying two people approached, holding guns. They stopped, I also stopped.
tr: Just then, a boat appeared, with two men holding rifles inside.
es: Just then a boat appeared with two men carrying shotguns, and they stopped, and so did I.

en: One of them says:
vi: One person asked:
tr: When they saw me, they stopped; I also stopped.
es: One of them goes and says:

en: “What’s that yonder?”
vi: - What is over there?
tr: "What's that over there?" someone asked.
es: —What is that over there?

en: “A piece of a raft,” I says.
vi: I answered - That's right
tr: “Give me a ride,” I said.
es: —Well, a raft —I replied.

en: “Do you belong on it?”
vi: - Is that raft yours?
tr: "Are you coming from the hall?"
es: —Are you going on it?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: - That's right
tr: “Yes, sir!”
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Any men on it?”
vi: - Is there anyone up there?
tr: “Is there another man?”
es: —And are there men in it?

en: “Only one, sir.”
vi: - Yes, there is only one person
tr: “There is one more man; sir.”
es: —Only one, sir.

en: “Well, there’s five niggers run off to-night up yonder, above the head of the bend.
vi: - There were five black men who just ran away up there, at the head of the river.
tr: “Tonight, five black men escaped just above the bend.
es: —Well, there are five black men who escaped tonight from up there, where the curve is.

en: Is your man white or black?”
vi: Is your person white or black?
tr: Is the man on the raft white or black?”
es: Your man, is he white or black?

en: I didn’t answer up prompt.
vi: I couldn't answer right away.
tr: I couldn't respond immediately.
es: I did not respond immediately.

en: I tried to, but the words wouldn’t come.
vi: I intended to answer but couldn't speak out.
tr: I tried, but the words just wouldn't come to mind.
es: I tried, but the words wouldn't come out.

en: I tried for a second or two to brace up and out with it, but I warn’t man enough—hadn’t the spunk of a rabbit.
vi: For a moment or two, I was flustered and couldn't make up my mind, didn't go outside anymore, didn't have the courage of a rabbit.
tr: For a few seconds, I tried to pull myself together, but I couldn't act like a man; it was as if I had the heart of a rabbit.
es: I struggled for a second or two to muster the strength and say it, but I wasn't man enough: I was more cowardly than a rabbit.

en: I see I was weakening; so I just give up trying, and up and says:
vi: I felt that I had become too weak. I had no choice but to stop thinking like I did earlier and said:
tr: I felt myself losing more and more, and finally, I stopped trying and responded...
es: I saw that I didn't have the strength, so I stopped trying, and I go and say:

en: “He’s white.”
vi: - White skin
tr: “White.”
es: —It's white.

en: “I reckon we’ll go and see for ourselves.”
vi: - Let them go see for themselves
tr: “I guess it would be better if we go and check ourselves.”
es: —I think we are going to see it ourselves.

en: “I wish you would,” says I, “because it’s pap that’s there, and maybe you’d help me tow the raft ashore where the light is.
vi: I said: - Yes, please go and see, because that is my father up there. And perhaps you could help push the raft to the place with the light.
tr: “That would be great; because the man over there is my father. Maybe you could help me move the boat to where the light is.
es: —I hope so —I said—, because it's my father who is there and maybe you can help me tow the raft to the shore where that light is.

en: He’s sick—and so is mam and Mary Ann.”
vi: He is sick, and so are my mother and Mary Anne.
tr: My father is a bit unwell… so are my mother and Mary Ann.”
es: He's sick, and the same goes for mother and Mary Ann.

en: “Oh, the devil!
vi: - Oh, damn it, we're still in a hurry here.
tr: “Hey, you devil!
es: —What the hell!

en: we’re in a hurry, boy.
vi: - Oh, damn it, we're still in a hurry here.
tr: We're in a hurry, kid.
es: We're in a hurry, kid.

en: But I s’pose we’ve got to.
vi: But maybe we should help a little.
tr: But it would still be good to help you.
es: But I suppose it's our duty.

en: Come, buckle to your paddle, and let’s get along.”
vi: Dim, grab the oar.
tr: Come on, turn back so we can get to work.”
es: Come on, grab the oar and let's go.

en: I buckled to my paddle and they laid to their oars.
vi: I held the paddle and pushed the boat forward. They also went.
tr: As I turned back, they also started rowing.
es: I grabbed the paddle and they grabbed their oars.

en: When we had made a stroke or two, I says:
vi: After a few strokes, I said:
tr: After moving forward a bit, I started again:
es: After a couple of strokes, I said to them:

en: “Pap’ll be mighty much obleeged to you, I can tell you.
vi: - My father will be very grateful to you.
tr: “My father will be grateful to you.
es: —Father will be very grateful to you, that's for sure.

en: Everybody goes away when I want them to help me tow the raft ashore, and I can’t do it by myself.”
vi: Everyone who was asked to help push it to the shore just left, and I couldn't do it alone.
tr: Everyone I asked for help to pull the boat ashore on Tuesday is running away, and I am not strong enough to do this job alone.”
es: When I ask someone to help me tow the raft to shore, everyone leaves and I can't do it alone.

en: “Well, that’s infernal mean.
vi: - Oh, it's always like that.
tr: "The world is full of scoundrels, my child.
es: —Well, what a bunch of mean people; but, how strange.

en: Odd, too.
vi: Really bad.
tr: But it's strange, really.
es: —Well, what a bunch of mean people; but, how strange.

en: Say, boy, what’s the matter with your father?”
vi: Hey, kid, how's your dad's illness?
tr: Tell me, what is wrong with your father?"
es: Hey, kid, what's wrong with your father?

en: “It’s the—a—the—well, it ain’t anything much.”
vi: - uh... uh... it's not that dangerous
tr: “Uh… well, there's not much actually.”
es: —It... uh... well, it's nothing serious.

en: They stopped pulling.
vi: They stopped.
tr: They stopped rowing.
es: They stopped rowing.

en: It warn’t but a mighty little ways to the raft now.
vi: There was only a short distance left to the shore.
tr: We had very little distance left to the raft.
es: We were already very close to the raft.

en: One says:
vi: One person said:
tr: One of them looked at me with a frown.
es: One goes and says:

en: “Boy, that’s a lie.
vi: - Kid, you're lying.
tr: "Don't lie, my son.
es: —Kid, you're lying.

en: What is the matter with your pap?
vi: What's wrong with your dad?
tr: What's wrong with your father?
es: What's wrong with your father?

en: Answer up square now, and it’ll be the better for you.”
vi: Answer truthfully or don't blame me
tr: It will be better for you if you give me the correct answer."
es: Answer truthfully, it's in your best interest.

en: “I will, sir, I will, honest—but don’t leave us, please.
vi: - Yes, I... sir, I'm telling the truth... but please don't abandon us.
tr: “I swear to tell the truth, sir... but please, don't go.
es: —Yes, sir, really..., but please don't abandon us.

en: It’s the—the—gentlemen, if you’ll only pull ahead, and let me heave you the headline, you won’t have to come a-near the raft—please do.”
vi: Because... because it's... please, you go ahead, let me follow and then throw the end of the rope, please don't come near the raft, please wait!
tr: His illness... and if you just pull from the front, that's enough, I'll hand you the rope and you won't need to approach the boat... please.”
es: It's the... theee... gentlemen, if you come a little closer and let me throw you the rope, you don't have to come near the raft; please.

en: “Set her back, John, set her back!” says one.
vi: - Back the boat, John, back it up - Someone said.
tr: “Back off, John, back off!” said the other.
es: —Let's go back, John, let's go back! —said one of them.

en: They backed water.
vi: They rowed the boat backward.
tr: They started rowing backwards.
es: They retreated—.

en: “Keep away, boy—keep to looard.
vi: Stay away, kid - move aside, hurry up.
tr: “Stay away, kid… stay behind.
es: Don't get close, boy; stay downwind.

en: Confound it, I just expect the wind has blowed it to us.
vi: You little monkey, the wind might blow that thing onto us.
tr: Damn it, it must have reached us with the breeze.
es: Damn it, the last thing we need is for the wind to have brought it to us.

en: Your pap’s got the small-pox, and you know it precious well.
vi: Your father has smallpox, you probably know that already.
tr: Your father has come down with smallpox and you know it very well.
es: Your father has smallpox and you know it well.

en: Why didn’t you come out and say so?
vi: Why didn't you say so right away?
tr: Why didn't you say it from the beginning?
es: Why didn't you say it from the start?

en: Do you want to spread it all over?”
vi: Do you want the disease to spread?
tr: Do you want everyone to get infected?”
es: Do you want everyone to get infected?

en: “Well,” says I, a-blubbering, “I’ve told everybody before, and they just went away and left us.”
vi: I stammered in reply: - No, no, before I already told everyone, they ignored it, they abandoned us.
tr: I started to stutter. "I... I... I told the ones before you, but they left immediately."
es: —Well —I replied, whining—, it's what I've told everyone before and they left and abandoned us.

en: “Poor devil, there’s something in that.
vi: - Oh dear, there must be something wrong.
tr: “Oh poor thing, it's not your fault either.
es: —Poor devil, you are not wrong.

en: We are right down sorry for you, but we—well, hang it, we don’t want the small-pox, you see.
vi: We feel so sorry for you, but we... Never mind, let's not talk anymore, we don't want to catch smallpox, you hear?
tr: We felt very sorry for your situation, but we… damn it, we don't want to catch smallpox, kid.
es: We are very sorry for you, but... well, damn it, we don't want to catch smallpox, understand?

en: Look here, I’ll tell you what to do.
vi: Look, I told you not to come ashore, if you do, you'll spread the disease everywhere.
tr: Now let me tell you what to do.
es: Look, I'm going to tell you what you can do.

en: Don’t you try to land by yourself, or you’ll smash everything to pieces.
vi: Look, I told you not to come ashore, if you do, you'll spread the disease everywhere.
tr: Don't try to pull the raft ashore by yourself, or you'll tear it to pieces.
es: Don't try to dock alone or you'll ruin everything.

en: You float along down about twenty miles, and you’ll come to a town on the left-hand side of the river.
vi: Row your boat about twenty miles down there and you'll reach a town on the left bank.
tr: After going about twenty miles, you'll see a town on the left side of the river.
es: Keep floating downstream about twenty miles and you'll reach a town on the left side of the river.

en: It will be long after sun-up then, and when you ask for help you tell them your folks are all down with chills and fever.
vi: By then it will be morning.
tr: By then, it will probably be noon. Also, when asking for help, just say that your folks are shivering and have a fever.
es: By then it will be fully daylight, and when you ask for help, tell them your entire family has chills and fever.

en: Don’t be a fool again, and let people guess what is the matter.
vi: Ask someone to guess if it's smallpox, you hear?
tr: This time, don't be foolish and let people guess what the illness is themselves.
es: Don't be foolish again and let people guess what's going on.

en: Now we’re trying to do you a kindness; so you just put twenty miles between us, that’s a good boy.
vi: Alright, now we'll help you with something. Just follow along here and sail down there, you're a good kid.
tr: We're trying to do you a favor, kid. Listen to us and get at least twenty miles away from us.
es: We are trying to do you a favor, so be good and go twenty miles further.

en: It wouldn’t do any good to land yonder where the light is—it’s only a wood-yard.
vi: Don't come ashore where there's light, it's just a wooden shed.
tr: There's no point in landing where the light is… it's just a lumberyard.
es: It wouldn't do you any good to dock where the light is: it's just a sawmill.

en: Say, I reckon your father’s poor, and I’m bound to say he’s in pretty hard luck.
vi: Hey, maybe your dad is very poor, he must have had a lot of bad luck.
tr: Your father must be a poor man… and it seems he hasn't had any luck either.
es: Hey, I figure your father is poor and certainly having bad luck.

en: Here, I’ll put a twenty-dollar gold piece on this board, and you get it when it floats by.
vi: Look, I'm leaving a gold coin worth two dollars on this plank here, when it floats to you, reach out and take it.
tr: I'm putting twenty dollars in gold on this board, you can take it once you're away from us.
es: Look, I'm going to put a twenty-dollar gold coin on this board and when it floats to you, pick it up.

en: I feel mighty mean to leave you; but my kingdom!
vi: Leaving you would be terrible, but dear God, I'm afraid of catching smallpox, you understand?
tr: It's very cruel to leave you on your own, but for God's sake!
es: It's not that I like leaving you, but what the hell!, you don't mess around with smallpox, understand?

en: it won’t do to fool with small-pox, don’t you see?”
vi: That person said again:
tr: Smallpox is no joke, child.”
es: It's not that I like leaving you, but what the hell!, you don't mess around with smallpox, understand?

en: “Hold on, Parker,” says the other man, “here’s a twenty to put on the board for me.
vi: - Wait a minute, Packer. Hey, put the twenty-dollar bill on the plank for me.
tr: "Wait a moment, Parker," said the other man. "Put a twenty on the board from me too.
es: —Wait, Parker —said the other—, take another twenty to put on the board as well.

en: Good-bye, boy; you do as mr Parker told you, and you’ll be all right.”
vi: Alright, goodbye kid, just do as Mr. Packer told you and you'll be fine.
tr: Goodbye, my dear, if you listen to Mr. Parker, everything will be fine."
es: Goodbye, kid; do what Mr. Parker told you and everything will surely go well for you.

en: “That’s so, my boy—good-bye, good-bye.
vi: - That's right. Goodbye now, goodbye.
tr: "Yes, son... stay safe, stay safe.
es: —Exactly, boy; goodbye, goodbye.

en: If you see any runaway niggers you get help and nab them, and you can make some money by it.”
vi: If you see any black person running away, call someone to catch them, and you'll get money for it.
tr: If you see runaway black people, call for help and have them caught, you can also make money this way."
es: If you see runaway slaves, find someone to help you catch them and you'll make some money.

en: “Good-bye, sir,” says I; “I won’t let no runaway niggers get by me if I can help it.”
vi: I replied: - Yes, goodbye gentlemen. If I see any black man, I won't let him get away.
tr: “Goodbye, gentlemen,” I said. “If I have the strength, I will not let any black person pass.”
es: —Goodbye, sir —I replied—; I will not let any runaway slave escape if I can help it.

en: They went off and I got aboard the raft, feeling bad and low, because I knowed very well I had done wrong, and I see it warn’t no use for me to try to learn to do right; a body that don’t get started right when he’s little ain’t got no show—when the pinch comes there ain’t nothing to back him up and keep him to his work, and so he gets beat.
vi: They left, and I returned to the raft, feeling despicable and cowardly, because I knew very well that I had done something wrong. I realized that for me, even if I learned to do the right thing, it would be useless, because a person who doesn't practice doing the right thing when young won't amount to anything when grown up. Later, during difficult times, there would be no one to help or support me, and I might even be beaten.
tr: The men left, and I jumped into the skiff; I was feeling terrible because I knew very well that what I had done was wrong, and I realized that trying to learn to do the right thing was in vain; a person who hasn't been well-mannered and hasn't learned the ways when young, no matter how much they try, it's futile. When it comes down to it, they are doomed to failure because they have nothing to rely on or to help them persevere.
es: They left, and I got back on the raft, feeling bad and traitorous, because I knew very well that I had done wrong, and I saw that it was useless to try to learn to do things right; when someone doesn't start off well when they are young, there's nothing to be done: when the time comes, they have nothing to lean on and support them, so they always lose.

en: Then I thought a minute, and says to myself, hold on; s’pose you’d a done right and give Jim up, would you felt better than what you do now?
vi: I thought for a minute, then told myself: if earlier I hadn't done the wrong thing by bringing Jim out, would I feel more at ease now?
tr: Then I thought a little, wait a minute, I said to myself, let's say you did the right thing and turned Jim in, would you feel better than you do now?
es: Then I thought about it for a minute and said to myself: "Wait a minute; suppose you had done right and turned Jim in, would you feel better than now?

en: No, says I, I’d feel bad—I’d feel just the same way I do now.
vi: But then I said: No. If that were the case, I would feel troubled, just as I am feeling troubled now.
tr: No, I said, I would feel bad – just as I feel bad now.
es: No," I said to myself, "I would feel bad, I would feel just as I do now.

en: Well, then, says I, what’s the use you learning to do right when it’s troublesome to do right and ain’t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the same?
vi: Then I told myself: what's the point of learning to do the right thing when doing the right thing brings distress and doing the wrong thing doesn't cause any discomfort? And aren't the benefits the same either way?
tr: So what's the use of learning to do the right thing? Doing the right thing gets you into trouble; when you do the wrong thing, no one gets hurt, and in both cases, you feel bad.
es: Well, then," I said to myself, "what's the use of learning to do things right when you have problems if you do them right and no problems if you do them wrong and the result is always the same?"

en: I was stuck.
vi: I felt stuck, unable to answer that question.
tr: When I got to this point, I was stuck.
es: I was trapped.

en: I couldn’t answer that.
vi: I felt stuck, unable to answer that question.
tr: I had no answer to give.
es: I couldn't answer that.

en: So I reckoned I wouldn’t bother no more about it, but after this always do whichever come handiest at the time.
vi: In the end, I thought there was no point in worrying about it anymore. However, it still kept lingering in my mind afterward.
tr: So I decided not to worry about this matter anymore and to do whatever seemed most appropriate at the time when the moment came.
es: So I thought I wouldn't worry about it anymore, and from then on, I always do what seems best to me at the moment.

en: I went into the wigwam; Jim warn’t there.
vi: I stepped into the tent. Jim wasn't there.
tr: I entered the shelter, Jim was not there.
es: I entered the wigwam; Jim was not there.

en: I looked all around; he warn’t anywhere.
vi: I looked around, but didn't see him.
tr: I looked everywhere, he was nowhere to be found.
es: I looked around and did not see him anywhere.

en: I says:
vi: I called out:
tr: I called out:
es: I shouted:

en: “Jim!”
vi: - Jim!
tr: “Jim!”
es: —Jim!

en: “Here I is, Huck.
vi: - I'm here, Huck.
tr: “I'm here, Huck.
es: —Here I am, Huck.

en: Is dey out o’ sight yit?
vi: Have they gone far?
tr: Did he get far enough away?
es: Can you still see them?

en: Don’t talk loud.”
vi: Don't speak loudly.
tr: Don't raise your voice, though!”
es: Don't speak loudly.

en: He was in the river under the stern oar, with just his nose out.
vi: It turns out Jim was hiding under the river, beneath the oar at the back, with only his nose sticking out above the water.
tr: He was in the river, had gone under the rudder oar, and only his nose was above the water.
es: He was in the water, under the bow oar, with only his nose out.

en: I told him they were out of sight, so he come aboard.
vi: I told him they had gone far away, and only then did he climb up.
tr: I told him that the men had disappeared from sight, and he got onto the raft.
es: I told him that they couldn't be seen anymore, so he climbed aboard.

en: He says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: “I heard everything you said,” said Jim.
es: He told me:

en: “I was a-listenin’ to all de talk, en I slips into de river en was gwyne to shove for sho’ if dey come aboard.
vi: - I listened to the whole story, then I slipped down to the river and planned to swim to shore if they got on the raft.
tr: “I immediately dove into the river without hesitation and made a plan: If they went up to the deck, I would secretly swim to the shore.
es: —I was listening to that conversation and I got into the water and was going to go to the shore if they came up.

en: Den I was gwyne to swim to de raf’ agin when dey was gone.
vi: But after seeing them leave, I turned back.
tr: When they left, I swam back to the raft again.
es: Then I was going to return to the raft when they had left.

en: But lawsy, how you did fool ’em, Huck!
vi: But how did you manage to fool them so well, Huck?
tr: How cleverly you tricked them, Huck!
es: But, sir, how you fooled them, Huck!

en: Dat wuz de smartes’ dodge!
vi: You're really good at it.
tr: I have never seen a more cunning act than this until today!
es: You were so clever!

en: I tell you, chile, I ’speck it save’ ole Jim—ole Jim ain’t going to forgit you for dat, honey.”
vi: That means you saved Jim once again. Jim will never forget that, Huck.
tr: Poor Jim was saved by your cleverness. Big Jim will never forget this, my heart’s corner.”
es: I tell you, boy, I'm sure you've saved old Jim... Old Jim will never forget it, my boy.

en: Then we talked about the money.
vi: Then we discussed money matters.
tr: Then we talked about the money issue.
es: Then we talked about the money.

en: It was a pretty good raise—twenty dollars apiece.
vi: It was quite a large sum, twenty dollars.
tr: We had twenty dollars each.
es: It wasn't bad at all: twenty dollars each.

en: Jim said we could take deck passage on a steamboat now, and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free States.
vi: Jim said now we could get a boat ticket, and that amount would be enough to reach free territories.
tr: Jim said we could now buy a ticket on a steamboat, and it would be more than enough for both of us until we reached the free states.
es: Jim said that now we could take deck passage on a steamboat and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free states.

en: He said twenty mile more warn’t far for the raft to go, but he wished we was already there.
vi: He said traveling a few dozen miles by raft wouldn't take long, but he wanted to get there even faster.
tr: Going another twenty miles by raft wasn't much, but Jim wanted to be there as soon as possible.
es: He said that twenty more miles wasn't much distance for the raft, but he wished we had already arrived.

en: Towards daybreak we tied up, and Jim was mighty particular about hiding the raft good.
vi: At dawn, we tied the raft and Jim went to find a very clever hiding spot.
tr: When morning came, we tied the raft to a place, and Jim worked hard this time to hide the raft well.
es: Towards dawn, we moored and Jim acted very carefully to hide the raft well.

en: Then he worked all day fixing things in bundles, and getting all ready to quit rafting.
vi: Then, all day long, he diligently tied the belongings into bundles and got ready to leave the raft.
tr: Then he spent the whole day organizing our belongings into bundles.
es: Afterwards, he worked all day organizing things into packages and preparing everything to move forward without the raft.

en: That night about ten we hove in sight of the lights of a town away down in a left-hand bend.
vi: Around ten o'clock that night, we headed towards the town lights on the left bank of the river.
tr: We moved towards the lights we saw around ten in the evening where the river bends on the left side.
es: That night, around ten, we came within sight of the lights of a village on a curve to the left side.

en: I went off in the canoe to ask about it.
vi: I got off the boat and rowed out to ask for information.
tr: I left the raft with the canoe to ask for directions.
es: I went in the canoe to ask.

en: Pretty soon I found a man out in the river with a skiff, setting a trot-line.
vi: After a while, I met a person who was taking a small boat out to the river to set up fishing lines.
tr: Soon, I encountered a man casting a fishing line into the river from his boat.
es: Immediately, I met a man who had gone out to the river with a boat and was preparing some fishing lines.

en: I ranged up and says:
vi: I approached and asked:
tr: I approached and called out:
es: I approached him and asked:

en: “Mister, is that town Cairo?”
vi: - Grandpa, is that town over there Cairo? - Where is Cairo?
tr: "Is this Cairo, sir?"" “Is it Cairo?
es: —Sir, is that town Cairo?

en: “Cairo? no.
vi: No!
tr: No way.
es: —Cairo? No.

en: You must be a blame’ fool.”
vi: Are you crazy?
tr: Are you stupid or what!”
es: You must be a complete idiot.

en: “What town is it, mister?”
vi: - What is that, sir?
tr: "Which town is this, sir?"
es: —What is the name of that town, sir?

en: “If you want to know, go and find out.
vi: - If you want to know, then go there and ask.
tr: "If you're so curious, go and see for yourself.
es: —If you want to find out, go ask about it.

en: If you stay here botherin’ around me for about a half a minute longer you’ll get something you won’t want.”
vi: If you stay here bothering me for even half a minute more, don't blame me.
tr: But if you keep nagging me, things you won't like at all will happen to you."
es: If you stay here bothering me for half a minute more, you're going to get a slap.

en: I paddled to the raft.
vi: I returned to the raft, Jim was extremely disappointed, but I told him it was okay, the place we were heading to could be Cairo.
tr: I returned to the room.
es: I rowed back to the raft.

en: Jim was awful disappointed, but I said never mind, Cairo would be the next place, I reckoned.
vi: I returned to the raft, Jim was extremely disappointed, but I told him it was okay, the place we were heading to could be Cairo.
tr: Jim was very disappointed, but I told him not to dwell on it; Cairo was probably the next town.
es: Jim felt very disappointed, but I told him it didn't matter, that according to my calculations, Cairo would be the next town.

en: We passed another town before daylight, and I was going out again; but it was high ground, so I didn’t go.
vi: We passed through another town before dawn. And I ventured out again, but this place only had mountains, so I didn't go any further.
tr: We passed another town before sunrise, but I didn't go there because it was a high place.
es: We passed another town before dawn, and I was going to ask again, but it was very high, so I didn't go out.

en: No high ground about Cairo, Jim said.
vi: Jim said there are no mountains or hills in Cairo.
tr: Jim reminded me that there were no steep places around Cairo.
es: "Cairo is not high," said Jim.

en: I had forgot it.
vi: I forgot about it too.
tr: However, I had forgotten that.
es: I had forgotten.

en: We laid up for the day on a tow-head tolerable close to the left-hand bank.
vi: During the day, we rested in a hollow on the bank above the river.
tr: We spent the daylight hours on a small island that could be considered close to the left shore.
es: We stayed the whole day on a grassy islet quite close to the left shore.

en: I begun to suspicion something.
vi: I started to suspect something.
tr: A possibility started to come to my mind.
es: I began to suspect something.

en: So did Jim.
vi: So did Jim.
tr: Jim was also getting suspicious.
es: Jim did too.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: I said:

en: “Maybe we went by Cairo in the fog that night.”
vi: - Or maybe we already passed through Cairo on that foggy night, Jim.
tr: “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: —Maybe we passed by Cairo that foggy night.

en: He says:
vi: - Don't talk about that anymore, Huck.
tr: “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: And he replied:

en: “Doan’ le’s talk about it, Huck.
vi: - Don't talk about that anymore, Huck.
tr: “Don’t say such things, Huck.
es: —Let's not talk about that, Huck.

en: Po’ niggers can’t have no luck.
vi: Poor black people never get lucky, do they?
tr: The poor black man never had any luck anyway.
es: We poor Black folks never have luck.

en: I awluz ’spected dat rattlesnake-skin warn’t done wid its work.”
vi: I still think that the snake skin hasn't brought its curse yet.
tr: I was also afraid that touching the rattlesnake skin would continue to bring us bad luck.”
es: I've always suspected that rattlesnake skin hadn't finished its work.

en: “I wish I’d never seen that snake-skin, Jim—I do wish I’d never laid eyes on it.”
vi: - If only we hadn't looked at that snake skin before, wouldn't it have been better, Jim? I think it would have been better if we hadn't looked at it.
tr: "I wish I had never seen that snake skin, Jim... I wish it had never caught my eye."
es: —I wish I had never seen that snake skin, Jim... I wish I had never laid eyes on it.

en: “It ain’t yo’ fault, Huck; you didn’ know.
vi: - That's not your fault, Huck. It's because you didn't know.
tr: “It’s not your fault, Huck; how could you have known.
es: —It's not your fault, Huck; you didn't know.

en: Don’t you blame yo’self ’bout it.”
vi: Don't blame yourself like that.
tr: Don’t blame yourself for this.”
es: Don't blame yourself for that.

en: When it was daylight, here was the clear Ohio water inshore, sure enough, and outside was the old regular Muddy!
vi: The sky is clear. This is indeed the green water of the Ohio River flowing inward here, and out there is the Muddy shore.
tr: When the sun rose, we clearly saw the clear Ohio water flowing from the shore, while farther out, the muddy water we knew was flowing!
es: When dawn broke, we saw the clear water of the Ohio next to the shore, without a doubt, and beside it came the great river as always.

en: So it was all up with Cairo.
vi: So, the plan to go to Cairo is ruined.
tr: So, there was nothing left to argue about regarding Cairo.
es: So nothing to do with Cairo.

en: We talked it all over.
vi: We discussed it with each other for a long time.
tr: We started talking to find a way.
es: We talked about the matter.

en: It wouldn’t do to take to the shore; we couldn’t take the raft up the stream, of course.
vi: It wasn't advisable to go ashore now. Of course, pushing the raft upstream was not possible.
tr: There was no point in approaching the shore; we certainly weren't going to take the raft against the current.
es: It was pointless to go ashore; naturally, we couldn't take the raft upstream.

en: There warn’t no way but to wait for dark, and start back in the canoe and take the chances.
vi: There was no other way, we just had to wait until night, get into the boat, and go back to see if anything had happened.
tr: We had no choice but to wait for darkness to fall and try our luck with the canoe.
es: There was nothing to do but wait until nightfall, return with the canoe, and see if we got lucky.

en: So we slept all day amongst the cottonwood thicket, so as to be fresh for the work, and when we went back to the raft about dark the canoe was gone!
vi: So we spent the whole day sleeping in the dense forest to regain our strength. By dusk, when we returned to the place where we had hidden the raft, we found that the boat had disappeared.
tr: So we slept all day among the dense trees to gather energy, but when we returned to the raft as it got dark, we saw that the canoe had vanished without a trace!
es: So we spent the day sleeping among the cottonwoods, to be rested for the work, and when we returned to the raft at dusk, the canoe had disappeared.

en: We didn’t say a word for a good while.
vi: We fell silent for a moment, not saying a word.
tr: For a long time, neither of us could utter a word.
es: We didn't say a word for a good while.

en: There warn’t anything to say.
vi: There was nothing left to say.
tr: We had nothing to say.
es: There was nothing to say.

en: We both knowed well enough it was some more work of the rattlesnake-skin; so what was the use to talk about it?
vi: Both of us understood that it was the snake's skin bringing bad luck, so there was no point in talking about it anymore.
tr: We knew this was one of the misfortunes brought by the rattlesnake skin; so what was there to say?
es: We both knew perfectly well that it was once again about the rattlesnake skin, so what was the point of talking about it?

en: It would only look like we was finding fault, and that would be bound to fetch more bad luck—and keep on fetching it, too, till we knowed enough to keep still.
vi: At that moment, it truly felt like we had done something wrong, and we thought that more misfortune would come our way. We kept thinking and remained silent.
tr: It would seem as if we were blaming it, and this would bring even more misfortune – until we finally shut our mouths, misfortune would not leave us alone.
es: That would just be like looking for something to blame, and it would undoubtedly bring us even more bad luck, and it would keep bringing it until we understood that the best thing was not to talk about it.

en: By-and-by we talked about what we better do, and found there warn’t no way but just to go along down with the raft till we got a chance to buy a canoe to go back in.
vi: But then, after a while, we discussed with each other how to proceed. And we couldn't find any other way but to keep paddling the raft downstream until we hopefully acquired a boat, then we would return. We didn't want to borrow a boat, because there was no one around.
tr: After a while, we started discussing what to do and decided that we had no choice but to continue on the raft until we found a place to buy a canoe to return.
es: After a while, we talked about what we would have to do and saw that there was no other choice but to continue with the raft until we could buy a canoe to retrace our steps in it.

en: We warn’t going to borrow it when there warn’t anybody around, the way pap would do, for that might set people after us.
