vi: If it were my father, he would have borrowed one, but borrowing like that would make people aware and they would chase us.
tr: We wouldn't borrow one when no one was around, as my father would, because we couldn't risk people coming after us.
es: We were not going to borrow it when no one was around, as father would do, because then someone might chase us.

en: So we shoved out after dark on the raft.
vi: When it was already dark, we crawled back onto the raft.
tr: When darkness fell, we untied the rope and set off on our way.
es: So after it got dark, we went out on the raft.

en: Anybody that don’t believe yet that it’s foolishness to handle a snake-skin, after all that that snake-skin done for us, will believe it now if they read on and see what more it done for us.
vi: Those who still do not believe that touching a shed snake skin is extremely foolish and that the snake skin will bring harm afterwards, will now have to believe it if they see our current situation.
tr: If there is anyone who does not believe that touching a snake's skin is foolish, they will believe it when they see what the snake's skin has done to us; especially if they continue reading and learn what else has happened to us, they may choose not to believe it.
es: And anyone who still doesn't believe that it's foolish to handle snake skins after everything that snake skin did to us will believe it now if they keep reading and see what it continued to do to us.

en: The place to buy canoes is off of rafts laying up at shore.
vi: The place where you can buy a boat is only near where there are many rafts gathered by the riverbank.
tr: In the shores where rafts are pulled ashore, canoes for sale are usually found as well.
es: The place to buy canoes is where there are rafts docked on the riverbank.

en: But we didn’t see no rafts laying up; so we went along during three hours and more.
vi: But we didn't see any place with many rafts gathered, so we had to continue for more than three hours.
tr: But since we couldn't see any rafts pulled ashore, we continued on our way for another three hours.
es: But we didn't see any docked rafts, so we continued on for three hours or more.

en: Well, the night got gray and ruther thick, which is the next meanest thing to fog.
vi: Night had begun to turn a faint gray, and that was a sign that fog was about to set in again.
tr: Meanwhile, gray and dense clouds covered the night sky, which was probably the worst thing after the fog.
es: Well, the night turned gray and the air became very dense, which is the worst thing that can happen after fog.

en: You can’t tell the shape of the river, and you can’t see no distance.
vi: It was impossible to see the uneven riverbank clearly, and we couldn't see far anymore.
tr: One couldn't calculate the shape of the river, nor could they see their surroundings.
es: You can't see the shape of the river or gauge the distance.

en: It got to be very late and still, and then along comes a steamboat up the river.
vi: It was very late at night and quiet. At that moment, a steamboat suddenly appeared, going upstream.
tr: It was very late and there was no sound at all, then we noticed a steamboat coming directly towards us from upstream.
es: It got very late in the midst of the silence, and then, suddenly, a steamboat appeared upstream.

en: We lit the lantern, and judged she would see it.
vi: We lit a lamp and thought that the steamboat would see us.
tr: We immediately lit our lantern so that they could see us.
es: We lit the lantern and thought it would see us.

en: Up-stream boats didn’t generly come close to us; they go out and follow the bars and hunt for easy water under the reefs; but nights like this they bull right up the channel against the whole river.
vi: Steamboats going upstream usually never go close to us; they stay far out and follow places where the water below isn't too swift. But on foggy nights like this, they just go straight ahead.
tr: Boats going upstream usually don't come close to us; they follow the shallows; they prefer the calm waters beneath the reefs. However, on foggy nights like this, they go straight up the river; they don't stop for anything.
es: The boats going upstream generally didn't come close to us; they were looking for sandbars in search of easy water under the reefs; but on nights like this, they go up the middle of the channel facing the entire river.

en: We could hear her pounding along, but we didn’t see her good till she was close.
vi: We could clearly hear the clattering sound but couldn't see the ship clearly until it got closer.
tr: We could hear the sound of the ship, but we didn't see it until it got really close.
es: We could hear its engine, but we didn't see it clearly until it got closer.

en: She aimed right for us.
vi: The ship seemed to be heading straight towards us.
tr: It was coming straight at us.
es: It was coming straight towards us.

en: Often they do that and try to see how close they can come without touching; sometimes the wheel bites off a sweep, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, and thinks he’s mighty smart.
vi: They usually do this to see how close they can get without slowing down. Sometimes their paddle wheel breaks someone's oar, and then the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs, thinking it's quite amusing.
tr: They often do this and want to show how close they can pass without hitting; sometimes they hit the edge of the boat and the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs; he thinks he's very clever.
es: Many times they do that and try to see how close they can get without touching you; sometimes the wheel rips off a plank, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, thinking he's very clever.

en: Well, here she comes, and we said she was going to try and shave us; but she didn’t seem to be sheering off a bit.
vi: As the ship approached, we thought it might hit us, and it didn't seem to be veering away at all.
tr: Here it was coming, we thought it would just graze us, but it seemed like it wouldn't change its course even a little.
es: Well, here it comes, and we decided it was going to try to shave us, but it didn't seem to veer off even a little.

en: She was a big one, and she was coming in a hurry, too, looking like a black cloud with rows of glow-worms around it; but all of a sudden she bulged out, big and scary, with a long row of wide-open furnace doors shining like red-hot teeth, and her monstrous bows and guards hanging right over us.
vi: The ship was very large and moving quickly, looking like a big dark cloud bristling with paddle wheels and surrounded by fireflies. But then suddenly it swerved, looming menacingly, with a row of lit windows resembling a large set of red teeth, and its paddles and oars seemed ready to crash down on us.
tr: It was a big steamer, coming fast; it looked like a huge cloud surrounded by fireflies; then suddenly it was upon us, with its wide-open furnace mouths glowing like red-hot teeth, its massive prow and stanchions above our heads, it was enormous and terrifying.
es: It was big and coming at full speed, like a black cloud with rows of fireflies on the sides; but suddenly it came fully into view, enormous and frightening, with a long row of open furnace doors glowing like red-hot teeth and with monstrous sides and railings right above us.

en: There was a yell at us, and a jingling of bells to stop the engines, a powwow of cussing, and whistling of steam—and as Jim went overboard on one side and I on the other, she come smashing straight through the raft.
vi: There were shouts, then a bell rang to slow the engine, followed by curses, the sound of the engine screeching, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I jumped to the other, the ship's paddle wheel smashed our raft to pieces.
tr: I heard someone shouting at us, bells rang to stop the engine, I heard the hiss of steam; but it was too late, as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other in a desperate attempt to escape, the ship struck the boat right in the middle.
es: Someone shouted at us, and there was a sound of bells to stop the engines, a bunch of curses and the hiss of steam, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other, it crashed into the raft and smashed it to pieces.

en: I dived—and I aimed to find the bottom, too, for a thirty-foot wheel had got to go over me, and I wanted it to have plenty of room.
vi: I plunged into the water and dived deep to the riverbed, because the large wheel, which was about eight or nine meters in diameter, could potentially hit my head, and I needed to stay far away from it.
tr: I dived – I even wanted to go all the way to the bottom, because the 10-meter diameter wheel was going to pass over me and I needed to make room for it.
es: I jumped and aimed to reach the bottom, because a thirty-foot wheel was going to pass over me and I wanted to have plenty of room.

en: I could always stay under water a minute; this time I reckon I stayed under a minute and a half.
vi: I could stay underwater for up to a minute, but this time I thought I had been at the bottom for about a minute and a half.
tr: Normally, I can stay underwater for about a minute, but I think this time I stayed for almost a minute and a half.
es: I have always been able to hold my breath underwater for a minute; I think that time I held it for a minute and a half.

en: Then I bounced for the top in a hurry, for I was nearly busting.
vi: Then I surfaced, as I was nearly out of breath.
tr: Then I surfaced with all my speed, because my lungs were about to burst.
es: Then I quickly surfaced, because I was about to burst.

en: I popped out to my armpits and blowed the water out of my nose, and puffed a bit.
vi: I raised my hand to rub the water out of my nose, snorting a few times.
tr: I almost rose up to my armpits and blew out the water that had filled my nose, then took deep breaths.
es: I stuck my head out quite a bit and blew the water out of my nose, panting a little.

en: Of course there was a booming current; and of course that boat started her engines again ten seconds after she stopped them, for they never cared much for raftsmen; so now she was churning along up the river, out of sight in the thick weather, though I could hear her.
vi: Of course, in this spot, the water was swift, and the ship would start its engine as usual after about ten seconds, as they never cared about the fate of those on small boats. At that moment, the ship chugged away and disappeared into the fog, although I could still hear the engine's sound echoing back.
tr: There was a tremendous, roaring current, and moreover, the ship started its engines again ten seconds later, because they never care about the raftsmen; the ferry was once again moving upstream, spewing foam, disappearing into the mist, but I could still hear its sound.
es: Naturally, there was a huge current, and naturally that ship started up again ten seconds after stopping the engines, because they never cared much about the rafters, so I kept paddling upstream, invisible in the midst of that dense air, although you could still hear the noise it made.

en: I sung out for Jim about a dozen times, but I didn’t get any answer; so I grabbed a plank that touched me while I was “treading water,” and struck out for shore, shoving it ahead of me.
vi: I called out to Jim dozens of times, but there was no response. Then I grabbed onto a nearby plank, kicked the water with my feet, and swam towards the shore, pushing the plank ahead of me.
tr: I called out to Jim at least ten times, but there was no response. While struggling in the water, I grabbed hold of a plank that came into my hand and, holding it in front of me, kicked my feet to swim towards the shore.
es: I called Jim half a dozen times, but without receiving a response; so I grabbed a plank that came my way while I was pedaling in the water and headed towards land, holding on to it tightly.

en: But I made out to see that the drift of the current was towards the left-hand shore, which meant that I was in a crossing; so I changed off and went that way.
vi: But suddenly I realized the water was pulling me towards the left bank, meaning I was going the wrong way, so I turned around and swam with the current.
tr: But then I realized that the current was pushing me towards the left shore, which meant I had reached one of the junctions, so I changed my course and went to the left.
es: But I managed to see that the current was carrying towards the left bank, which meant that I was in the middle of a cross current, so I changed course and followed that way.

en: It was one of these long, slanting, two-mile crossings; so I was a good long time in getting over.
vi: The river was about two miles wide, very far, and it took a long time to cross.
tr: This was a long, sloping, two-mile junction point; that's why it took me quite a long time to reach the shore.
es: It was one of those long, regular crossings of two miles; so it took me a long time to get through it.

en: I made a safe landing, and clumb up the bank.
vi: I reached the riverbank safely, then climbed up onto the shore.
tr: I safely set foot on land and started climbing up from the shore.
es: I made it to land safely and climbed up the shore.

en: I couldn’t see but a little ways, but I went poking along over rough ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I run across a big old-fashioned double log-house before I noticed it.
vi: In front of me, I saw only a small path, but I kept trudging along the rough ground for nearly half a mile, passing an old-style building with two wings, without even noticing when I had done so.
tr: I could hardly see ahead; I advanced about a quarter mile by feeling my way through the rugged terrain and finally found myself in front of a large, old-fashioned, two-winged wooden house.
es: I could only see a very short distance, but I groped my way over rocky ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I stumbled upon one of those old-fashioned log houses that I had never seen before.

en: I was going to rush by and get away, but a lot of dogs jumped out and went to howling and barking at me, and I knowed better than to move another peg.
vi: I was just about to run past when a pack of dogs came out of nowhere and started barking loudly at me. I knew I was in danger again.
tr: I was about to change my path and move away immediately, but when a bunch of dogs came barking and surrounded me, I realized that the smartest thing to do was not to move at all.
es: I was about to run far away from there, but a pack of dogs came out and started howling and barking at me, and I realized it was better not to move.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chapter XVII
tr: Chapter Seventeen
es: Chapter 17

en: In about a minute somebody spoke out of a window without putting his head out, and says:
vi: About a minute later, there was a voice from the window without anyone sticking their head out:
tr: Before half a minute had passed, someone called out from a window without showing their head:
es: AFTER A minute someone said through the window, without sticking their head out:

en: “Be done, boys!
vi: - What are you doing?
tr: “Alright, that's enough children!
es: —Enough, kids!

en: Who’s there?”
vi: Who's there?
tr: Who is there?”
es: Who's going?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: “It's mine.”
es: And I replied:

en: “It’s me.”
vi: - I'm here
tr: “It's mine.”
es: —It's me.

en: “Who’s me?”
vi: - Who are you?
tr: “Who are you?”
es: —Who am I?

en: “George Jackson, sir.”
vi: - Sir, I am George Jackson
tr: “Mr. George Jackson.””
es: —George Jackson, gentleman.

en: “What do you want?”
vi: - What do you want?
tr: “What do you want?”
es: —What do you want?

en: “I don’t want nothing, sir.
vi: - I don't want anything, sir.
tr: "I don't want anything, sir.
es: —I don't want anything, sir.

en: I only want to go along by, but the dogs won’t let me.”
vi: I just want to pass through, but these dogs won't let me.
tr: I just want to go on my way, but the dogs won't let me."
es: I was just passing by, but the dogs won't let me.

en: “What are you prowling around here this time of night for—hey?”
vi: - What are you doing here, fumbling around in the middle of the night?
tr: “Why are you sneaking around my house in the middle of the night?””
es: —And what are you doing lurking around here at this hour of the night, huh?

en: “I warn’t prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.”
vi: - Sir, I wasn't fumbling around at all. I was on the ship and just fell into the river.
tr: “I wasn't walking, sir; I fell into the water from the deck of a steamship.”
es: —I wasn't lurking, sir; I fell off the steamboat.

en: “Oh, you did, did you?
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: “Did you fall into the water?
es: —Really?

en: Strike a light there, somebody.
vi: Can someone light the lamp a bit.
tr: Turn on a light.
es: Don't tell me!

en: What did you say your name was?”
vi: What did you say your name was?
tr: What was your name?”
es: Can someone turn on a light, what did you say your name was?

en: “George Jackson, sir.
vi: - George Jackson, sir.
tr: "Mr. George Jackson." "I am just a child.""
es: —George Jackson, gentleman.

en: I’m only a boy.”
vi: I'm just a boy.
tr: "Mr. George Jackson." "I am just a child.""
es: I am a boy.

en: “Look here, if you’re telling the truth you needn’t be afraid—nobody’ll hurt you.
vi: - Hey, just tell the truth, there's nothing to be afraid of. No one will hit you.
tr: “If you are telling the truth, you have nothing to fear… No one will harm you.
es: —Look, if you tell the truth, you have nothing to fear: no one is going to do anything to you.

en: But don’t try to budge; stand right where you are.
vi: But don't move. Stay right where you are.
tr: But don’t even think about moving from your spot, stay where you are.
es: But don't try to move; stay where you are.

en: Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns.
vi: Bod, Tom, someone get up and bring the gun here.
tr: One of you lift Bob and Tom, and one of you bring the rifles.
es: Someone wake up Bob and Tom and bring the weapons.

en: George Jackson, is there anybody with you?”
vi: George Jackson, is there anyone else with you?
tr: Is there anyone with you, George Jackson?”
es: George Jackson, is there anyone with you?

en: “No, sir, nobody.”
vi: - No, there is no one.
tr: “No, sir, there is no one.”
es: —No, sir, no one.

en: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light.
vi: I heard the sound of someone rummaging in the house, then saw a light turn on.
tr: I heard people moving inside the house, a light turned on.
es: Now I could hear people moving around the house and I saw a light.

en: The man sung out:
vi: The person from earlier said:
tr: The man's anxious voice was heard:
es: The man shouted:

en: “Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool—ain’t you got any sense?
vi: - Move the lamp farther away, Betsy, how stupid, you don't know anything.
tr: “Move that light away quickly, Betsy, you fool... Have you lost all your sense?
es: —Move that light, Betsy, you old fool... don't you have any common sense?

en: Put it on the floor behind the front door.
vi: Put the lamp on the floor, right behind the door.
tr: Leave it on the ground behind the front door.
es: Put it on the floor behind the front door.

en: Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places.”
vi: Bod, Tom, are you both ready? Sit down.
tr: Bob, you and Tom take your positions if you're ready.”
es: Bob, if you and Tom are ready, to your positions.

en: “All ready.”
vi: - Ready all
tr: “We are all ready.”
es: —Ready.

en: “Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
vi: - So, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdson family?
tr: “Tell me, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
es: —And now, George Jackson, do you know who the Shepherdsons are?

en: “No, sir; I never heard of them.”
vi: - No, sir, I have never heard of that name before
tr: “No; sir. I've never heard of it.”
es: —No, sir, I have never heard of them.

en: “Well, that may be so, and it mayn’t.
vi: - Alright, maybe you haven't heard of it, or maybe you have.
tr: “Alright, maybe you're telling the truth, maybe you're not.
es: —Well, maybe you're telling the truth and maybe you're lying.

en: Now, all ready.
vi: Okay, everything is ready.
tr: Yes, everyone is ready.
es: Now, everyone get ready.

en: Step forward, George Jackson.
vi: Step up, George Jackson.
tr: Come closer, George Jackson.
es: Take a step forward, George Jackson.

en: And mind, don’t you hurry—come mighty slow.
vi: Be careful, don't rush, step very slowly.
tr: But don't move quickly… Come very slowly.
es: And be careful, no rush... very slowly.

en: If there’s anybody with you, let him keep back—if he shows himself he’ll be shot.
vi: If someone is with you, make them stay back, if they step up, they will die.
tr: If there's someone with you, they should stay back; if they show themselves, they'll be shot.
es: If there's someone with you, they should stay there; if we see them, we'll shoot them.

en: Come along now.
vi: Now move forward, slowly.
tr: Come on then.
es: Now, go ahead.

en: Come slow; push the door open yourself—just enough to squeeze in, d’ you hear?”
vi: Push the door open yourself, just enough to slip through, understand?
tr: Be slow; open the door carefully… But only open it enough for you to pass through, do you hear me?”
es: Come slowly; open the door yourself. ... just enough to get in, do you hear me?

en: I didn’t hurry; I couldn’t if I’d a wanted to.
vi: I did not hastily step up, even if I wanted to, I couldn't.
tr: I never hurried, and even if I wanted to, I couldn't have.
es: I didn't run; I couldn't even if I had wanted to.

en: I took one slow step at a time and there warn’t a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart.
vi: Each time, I only took one slow step without any noise, only hearing my heart beating.
tr: As I took each step, I heard nothing but the beating of my own heart.
es: I took one slow step after another and there wasn't a sound, only that it seemed to me that I could hear the beating of my heart.

en: The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me.
vi: The dogs were as silent as the people, they followed me a little behind.
tr: The dogs had become as quiet as the people and were following me right behind.
es: The dogs were as quiet as the people, but they were on my heels.

en: When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting.
vi: Reaching the threshold, I heard the sound of unlocking, lifting the door bar, and pulling the latch.
tr: When I reached the three-step ladder made of logs, I heard the locks opening and the bolts being drawn inside.
es: When I reached the three log steps, I heard them removing the bolt and the bar from the door.

en: I put my hand on the door and pushed it a little and a little more till somebody said, “There, that’s enough—put your head in.”
vi: I placed my hand on the door, gently pushed a little, little by little. Then there was a voice: - That's it, alright, stick your head in.
tr: Then I started to slowly push the door with my hand. “Okay, that's enough,” said someone from inside, “stick your head in.”
es: I put my hand on the door, pushed a little and then a little more until someone said: "Okay, that's enough; show us your head."

en: I done it, but I judged they would take it off.
vi: I put my head in, but I was still worried inside, afraid they might cut off my head.
tr: I did as he said, but I was thinking they would probably behead me now.
es: I did it, but thinking they were going to tear it off.

en: The candle was on the floor, and there they all was, looking at me, and me at them, for about a quarter of a minute:
vi: The candle was placed on the floor, and they were all standing around it. They looked at me, and I looked at them for nearly half a minute: three large men holding guns pointed at me, making me shiver, truly.
tr: In the light of the candle on the ground, I saw them all; for a quarter of a minute, they looked at me, and I looked at them.
es: The candle was on the floor, and there they all were, looking at me, and I at them, and we stayed like that for a quarter of a minute: three big men pointing their weapons at me, which I assure you gave me chills; the oldest was gray-haired and about sixty years old, and the other two were thirty or older (all of them very refined and very handsome) and an elderly lady with gray hair and the kindest appearance, who had behind her two young women whom I couldn't see well.

en: Three big men with guns pointed at me, which made me wince, I tell you; the oldest, gray and about sixty, the other two thirty or more—all of them fine and handsome—and the sweetest old gray-headed lady, and back of her two young women which I couldn’t see right well.
vi: The oldest person, with slightly gray hair, was about sixty; the second one was around thirty or a bit older, both looking handsome and composed. And a woman stood there, with graying hair and a small face. Standing behind the woman were two young women whom I couldn't see very clearly.
tr: The three hulking men who had their guns pointed at me were truly intimidating; the oldest one looked to be in his sixties and had gray hair, the other two were in their thirties or a bit older – all of them were healthy and handsome – there was also a gray-haired woman with a sweet gaze and two young girls whom I couldn't see very well in the back.
es: The candle was on the floor, and there they all were, looking at me, and I at them, and we stayed like that for a quarter of a minute: three big men pointing their weapons at me, which I assure you gave me chills; the oldest was gray-haired and about sixty years old, and the other two were thirty or older (all of them very refined and very handsome) and an elderly lady with gray hair and the kindest appearance, who had behind her two young women whom I couldn't see well.

en: The old gentleman says:
vi: The elderly man spoke:
tr: The three hulking men who had their guns pointed at me were truly intimidating; the oldest one looked to be in his sixties and had gray hair, the other two were in their thirties or a bit older – all of them were healthy and handsome – there was also a gray-haired woman with a sweet gaze and two young girls whom I couldn't see very well in the back.
es: The older gentleman said:

en: “There; I reckon it’s all right.
vi: - Okay, fine.
tr: "Alright, no problem.
es: —Okay; I suppose it's fine.

en: Come in.”
vi: Come in
tr: Come inside," said the old man.
es: Come in.

en: As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it and bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and they all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor, and got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front windows—there warn’t none on the side.
vi: As soon as I stepped in, that person immediately locked the door tightly, barring it with a horizontal latch, then told the young man to bring the gun. The whole group stepped into the next room, which had a new carpet laid out, then huddled in a corner near the window facing the street, and no one remained standing there anymore.
tr: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman locked and bolted the door, then told the young men to approach with their rifles. In the large room with a brand-new carpet laid on the floor, everyone gathered in the corner outside the range of the front windows – there were no windows on the side wall.
es: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman closed the door and bolted and barred it, told the young men to come in with their shotguns, and everyone went to the large living room that had a new cloth carpet and gathered in a corner away from the front windows: there were none on the sides.

en: They held the candle, and took a good look at me, and all said, “Why, he ain’t a Shepherdson—no, there ain’t any Shepherdson about him.”
vi: Then they picked up the candle, looked at me carefully, and said: - Oh, it's not the Shepherdsons. It doesn't look like the Shepherdsons at all.
tr: They brought the candle closer and examined me from head to toe. Then they all started talking at once: "No, not a Shepherdson... No; doesn't look like a Shepherdson at all."
es: They grabbed the candle, looked at me closely, and all said: "Well, he's not a Shepherdson, no; he doesn't have anything of a Shepherdson."

en: Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn’t mind being searched for arms, because he didn’t mean no harm by it—it was only to make sure.
vi: Then the older man told me not to worry about letting them search for any weapons - not because they meant any harm to me, but just to be sure.
tr: Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind being searched for weapons, as he had no ill intentions... He just wanted to be sure.
es: Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind if they searched me to see if I was carrying any weapons, because they didn't mean any harm; it was just to be sure.

en: So he didn’t pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right.
vi: He didn't put his hands in my pockets but just felt around the outside, then said: all right.
tr: So he didn't put his hand in my pockets, he just felt from the outside and said it was fine.
es: So he didn't put his hands in my pockets, but only touched my sides with his hands and assured that everything was fine.

en: He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:
vi: He told me to make myself at home now, and talked about all sorts of things about sin too. But the middle-aged woman said:
tr: He told me to relax and consider myself at home; then he asked me to tell everything about myself, but the old woman interrupted:
es: He told me to make myself comfortable and feel at home and to tell them about myself, but the old lady said:

en: “Why, bless you, Saul, the poor thing’s as wet as he can be; and don’t you reckon it may be he’s hungry?”
vi: - Oh dear, Mr. Saul, the boy is soaking wet like this. And perhaps he's still hungry too?
tr: "For God's sake, Saul, don't you see the poor thing is soaking wet? Maybe he's hungry too."
es: —But, man, Saul, poor thing; he's soaked to the bone and, don't you think he might be hungry?

en: “True for you, Rachel—I forgot.”
vi: - Yes, that's right, Rachel, I forgot.
tr: “You are right, Rachel, I forgot.”
es: —You're right, Rachel; I forgot.

en: So the old lady says:
vi: The woman said:
tr: Upon this, the elderly lady said:
es: So the old woman says:

en: “Betsy” (this was a nigger woman), “you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell him—oh, here he is himself.
vi: - Betsy (this is a black woman), ran to find something for him to eat, poor boy, while another girl went to wake Buck up, telling him, oh never mind, here he is.
tr: “Betsy (he was addressing the black woman), run quickly and bring him something to eat, poor thing; girls, one of you go and wake Buck and tell him that…” “Ah, here he comes already.”
es: —Betsy (she was a black woman), run and bring something to eat quickly, poor thing; and one of you girls, go wake up Buck and tell him... ah, here he comes.

en: Buck, take this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him up in some of yours that’s dry.”
vi: Buck, take this boy and change his wet clothes, and put some of your dry clothes on him.
tr: “Buck, take this little stranger; take off his wet clothes and give him some of your dry ones.””
es: Buck, take this little boy and remove his wet clothes and give him something of yours that is dry to wear.

en: Buck looked about as old as me—thirteen or fourteen or along there, though he was a little bigger than me.
vi: Buck was about my age, thirteen or fourteen, though he was a bit bigger than me.
tr: Buck looked to be around my age – either thirteen or fourteen, but he was a bit bigger than me.
es: Buck seemed to be about the same age as me: thirteen or fourteen years old, although he was a bit taller.

en: He hadn’t on anything but a shirt, and he was very frowzy-headed.
vi: He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was very dirty.
tr: He had come with just a shirt on and still seemed like he hadn't fully woken up.
es: He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was all messy.

en: He came in gaping and digging one fist into his eyes, and he was dragging a gun along with the other one.
vi: He walked over, yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, while dragging a gun with the other.
tr: He was yawning on one hand; on the other, he was rubbing his eyes with his fist.
es: He arrived yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, holding a shotgun in the other.

en: He says:
vi: He asked:
tr: In his other hand, he had a rifle.
es: He replied:

en: “Ain’t they no Shepherdsons around?”
vi: - There aren't any Shepherdsons out there, are there?
tr: “Aren't they the Shepherdsons?” he asked.
es: —Is there no Shepherdson around here?

en: They said, no, ’twas a false alarm.
vi: The whole group said: - No, it's just a false alarm It said:
tr: No, false alarm, they said.
es: They said no, that it was a false alarm.

en: “Well,” he says, “if they’d a ben some, I reckon I’d a got one.”
vi: - I thought if there were any of them, I would have caught one
tr: "If they had come, I would have at least taken one of them down, I guess," he said.
es: —Well —he says—, if they had come, I surely would have taken one down.

en: They all laughed, and Bob says:
vi: Everyone laughed. Bod said:
tr: They all laughed out loud.
es: Everyone burst out laughing, and Bob says:

en: “Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you’ve been so slow in coming.”
vi: - Hey, Buck, but you're too late, they might catch all of us.
tr: “They probably would have scalped all of us by now, Buck,” said Bob. “You are coming so slowly.”
es: —But Buck, they could have scalped all of us with how long it took you to get here.

en: “Well, nobody come after me, and it ain’t right I’m always kept down; I don’t get no show.”
vi: - After dark, there's no one left? That's not acceptable. I'm always left behind like this, never getting to see anything.
tr: “But no one lifted me up, this is unfair. You always leave me behind. You don't give me a chance to show myself.”
es: —Well, it's just that no one has informed me, and that's not right. You never tell me anything; you don't let me do anything.

en: “Never mind, Buck, my boy,” says the old man, “you’ll have show enough, all in good time, don’t you fret about that.
vi: Don't worry, Buck my child - The old man said. Then you will be free, don't worry.
tr: “Don't worry, Buck,” said the old man. “In time, you will have plenty of opportunities to prove yourself. Don't be upset about this.
es: —It doesn't matter, Buck, my son —says the old man—, you will be able to do enough in due time, don't worry about that.

en: Go ’long with you now, and do as your mother told you.”
vi: Now go, do as your mother told you.
tr: Come on now, do what your mother says.”
es: Now go do what your mother told you.

en: When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on.
vi: We went upstairs, into the room with Buck, he started to get dressed.
tr: When we went up to Buck's room, he gave me a thick shirt, a short jacket, and pants.
es: When we climbed the stairs to his room, he gave me a thick shirt, a jacket, and some pants, and I put everything on.

en: While I was at it he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to tell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods day before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle went out.
vi: After getting dressed, he asked me what my name was, before I could answer, he showed me a blackbird and a rabbit he had just caught in the forest the day before yesterday, then asked me where Moses was when the candle went out.
tr: While I was getting dressed, he asked my name, but before I had a chance to tell him, he started talking about the blue jay and the baby rabbit he had caught in the forest the day before yesterday. Then, when the candle went out, he asked where Moses was.
es: Meanwhile, he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him, he started to tell me that the day before yesterday he had caught a starling and a little rabbit in the forest and asked me where Moses was when the candle went out.

en: I said I didn’t know; I hadn’t heard about it before, no way.
vi: I said I didn't know and had never heard of that before.
tr: I said I didn't know; I had really never heard anything about it before.
es: I said I didn't know; I had never heard it before, really.

en: “Well, guess,” he says.
vi: He said: - So, try to guess
tr: "Then guess," he said.
es: —Well, then suppose —he suggested.

en: “How’m I going to guess,” says I, “when I never heard tell of it before?”
vi: I answered: - How could I have guessed, since I had never heard of it before
tr: “How should I guess, man?” I said. “This is the first time in my life I'm hearing about this.”
es: —How am I supposed to guess —I replied— when no one has ever told me before?

en: “But you can guess, can’t you?
vi: - But you can guess, it's very easy
tr: “But you can throw something, right?
es: —But you can guess, can't you?

en: It’s just as easy.”
vi: I asked:
tr: It's very easy.”
es: It's just as easy.

en: “Which candle?” I says.
vi: - Which candle?
tr: “Which candle?” I said.
es: —What candle? —I asked.

en: “Why, any candle,” he says.
vi: - Which candle?
tr: “It doesn't matter, just any candle.”
es: —Well, any candle —he replied.

en: “I don’t know where he was,” says I; “where was he?”
vi: I don't know where it is.
tr: “But I don't know where it is,” I said; “where was it?”
es: —I don't know where I was —I replied—; where was I?

en: “Why, he was in the dark!
vi: Where?
tr: “Of course, it was in the dark!
es: —Man, I was in darkness!

en: That’s where he was!”
vi: - Oh, it's in my place, where else
tr: It was in the dark, indeed!”
es: That's where I was!

en: “Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?”
vi: - Oh, if you already know where it is, then why do you still need to ask me?
tr: “If you know where it is, why did you ask me?”
es: —Well, if you already knew where it was, why are you asking me?

en: “Why, blame it, it’s a riddle, don’t you see?
vi: - Damn it, it's a riddle, don't you see?
tr: “Don't drive me crazy, man, I asked you a riddle, didn't you understand?
es: —But man, it's a riddle, don't you understand?

en: Say, how long are you going to stay here?
vi: Hey, how long do you plan to stay here?
tr: How long are you going to stay here?
es: Hey, how long are you going to stay?

en: You got to stay always.
vi: You have to stay here forever.
tr: I think you shouldn't leave at all.
es: You have to stay forever.

en: We can just have booming times—they don’t have no school now.
vi: We can go hunting as much as we want, now we don't have to go to school anymore.
tr: We would have a great time... There's no school these days anyway.
es: We can have a great time... There's no school now.

en: Do you own a dog?
vi: Do you have any dogs?
tr: Do you have a dog? I have one...
es: Do you have a dog?

en: I’ve got a dog—and he’ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in.
vi: I have a dog, I take it to the river, if I throw something into the river, it will swim out and retrieve it.
tr: It fetches the sticks you throw into the river just like that.
es: I have a dog that knows how to go into the river to fetch the things you throw.

en: Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness?
vi: Do you like exploring on Sundays? And running around playing with things like that?
tr: Do you like combing your hair and doing other silly things on Sundays?
es: Do you like that stuff about combing your hair on Sundays and all those silly things?

en: You bet I don’t, but ma she makes me.
vi: You probably don't like it, but I love it.
tr: I'm sure you don't; but my mom makes me do it.
es: I assure you I don't, but mother makes me.

en: Confound these ole britches!
vi: Put these on too.
tr: I hate these pants, I have to wear them, but if it were up to me, I wouldn't wear them in this heat.
es: Darn pants!

en: I reckon I’d better put ’em on, but I’d ruther not, it’s so warm.
vi: Maybe I'll put some more on too. But never mind, it's too hot.
tr: I hate these pants, I have to wear them, but if it were up to me, I wouldn't wear them in this heat.
es: I suppose I'll have to wear them, but I'd rather not, with this heat.

en: Are you all ready?
vi: Are you done?
tr: Okay, are you ready now?
es: Are you ready?

en: All right.
vi: Alright, let's go, my friend.
tr: Okay, are you ready now?
es: Okay.

en: Come along, old hoss.”
vi: The bread was cold, and the beef was also cold.
tr: Let's go, bro.”
es: Come down with me, buddy.

en: Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk—that is what they had for me down there, and there ain’t nothing better that ever I’ve come across yet.
vi: Then there was butter and milk bread. They had prepared those things for me.
tr: Cold cornbread, canned beef, butter, and skimmed milk – they had brought these out for me to eat, and it felt like I had never eaten such a wonderful meal before.
es: Cold cornbread, cold salted meat, butter, and milk with plenty of cream: that's what they had prepared for me downstairs, and I've never eaten anything better in my life.

en: Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes, except the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women.
vi: And it was much better than what I had eaten before. Buck, his mother, and the whole family smoked with small pipes, except for the black woman from earlier and the two young women.
tr: Buck, his mother, and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes; only the black woman and the two young women who were not around were not smoking.
es: Buck and his mother and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes, except for the black woman, who had left, and the two young women.

en: They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked.
vi: The whole family smoked and talked. I ate and talked as well.
tr: They were all smoking and chatting, and I was answering them while eating my meal.
es: Everyone was smoking and talking, and I was eating and talking.

en: The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs.
vi: The two young women sat among the spools of thread, their hair falling down their backs.
tr: The young women were wrapped in blankets, and their loose hair fell down to their waists.
es: The two young women were wrapped in quilts and had their hair down.

en: They all asked me questions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living on a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann run off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went to hunt them and he warn’t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and then there warn’t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just trimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I took what there was left, because the farm didn’t belong to us, and started up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was how I come to be here.
vi: Everyone asked me questions. I told them that my father and family lived on a small farm at the far end of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann got married and we lost contact with her. Then Bill went to find my sister and her husband but never returned with any news. Tom and Mort had died; later, it was just my father and me, but my father fell into hard times and had nothing left; so after he died, I gathered what little was left and left. Since the farm wasn't ours, I went to the river to catch a boat, but somehow I fell into the river and ended up here.
tr: They all asked me questions. I told them that my father, the rest of my family, and I lived on a small farm in the southernmost part of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann had eloped, and we had never heard from her again; Bill had gone to look for them, and we hadn't heard from him either; Tom and Mort had died, and finally, there was no one left but my father and me. My father had become skin and bones due to all the troubles he had faced; when he died, since the farm did not belong to us, I had set off upriver with the remaining belongings, but I had fallen off the deck at night.
es: Everyone was asking me questions, and I told them that father and I and the whole family lived on a small farm over on the other side of Arkansas and that my sister Mary Ann had run away to get married and we hadn't heard from her again, and that Bill went to look for them and we hadn't heard from him either, and that Tom and Mort had died and there was no one left but me and father, and that he had wasted away with so many troubles, so when he died I took what was left, because the farm wasn't ours, and I started up the river with deck passage and had fallen overboard and that's why I was there.

en: So they said I could have a home there as long as I wanted it.
vi: They told me to consider this place my home and stay as long as I wanted.
tr: That was the story of how I came here. They told me I could stay with them as long as I wanted and consider the place my home.
es: Then they told me that I had a home there as long as I wanted.

en: Then it was most daylight and everybody went to bed, and I went to bed with Buck, and when I waked up in the morning, drat it all, I had forgot what my name was.
vi: By then it was nearly morning, everyone went to sleep, and I slept with Buck. When I woke up, it was late, and I had completely forgotten my own name, can you believe it?
tr: It was almost dawn, everyone went to their rooms, and I lay down next to Buck; when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I realized I had forgotten my new name.
es: Then it was almost daylight and everyone went to bed and I went with Buck, and when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I had forgotten what my name was.

en: So I laid there about an hour trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:
vi: I lay there for an hour, trying to remember. When Buck woke up, I asked:
tr: I spent an hour trying to remember it, and finally, when Buck woke up, I said:
es: So I lay there for an hour trying to think of it, and when Buck woke up I asked him:

en: “Can you spell, Buck?”
vi: - Buck, can you spell?
tr: “Buck, can you spell out the letters of your name?”
es: —Are you good at spelling, Buck?

en: “Yes,” he says.
vi: - Okay, it replied
tr: “Of course, I can list them,” he said.
es: —Yes —he replied.

en: “I bet you can’t spell my name,” says I.
vi: - I bet you can't even spell my name, I said. It replied:
tr: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es: —I'm sure you don't know how to write my name —I told him.

en: “I bet you what you dare I can,” says he.
vi: - I told you, whatever you dare to do, I can do it too
tr: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es: —I bet you anything that it will —he replied.

en: “All right,” says I, “go ahead.”
vi: - Okay, let's see you try to spell it out for me
tr: "Not at all, I can list them all at once."" "Alright then," I said, "let's see you list them."
es: —Okay —I said—; let's go see it.

en: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n—there now,” he says.
vi: - G-e-o-r-g-e. J-a-c-k-s-o-n, see for yourself
tr: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n…” “Is that wrong?””
es: —G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n, just so you know —he said.

en: “Well,” says I, “you done it, but I didn’t think you could.
vi: - Good, that's right. I thought you couldn't spell it.
tr: “Alright, you got it right, but I never would have guessed.
es: —Okay —I replied—, you did know it, but I didn't believe it.

en: It ain’t no slouch of a name to spell—right off without studying.”
vi: That name isn't too cumbersome to spell, you can read it right away without having to think about it.
tr: It's not a name that can be spelled out in one go without any effort.”
es: Don't think it's an easy name to write just like that, without studying it.

en: I set it down, private, because somebody might want me to spell it next, and so I wanted to be handy with it and rattle it off like I was used to it.
vi: I remember it carefully in my mind, so that if someone asks me to spell it later, I can quickly say it, acting as if I am very familiar with my own name.
tr: When I was alone, I sat down and started working because someone else might ask me to write my name, and I would need to write it quickly as if I were very accustomed to it.
es: I wrote it down secretly, because maybe someone wanted me to be the one to write it, so I wanted to do it all at once, and present it as if I were already very used to it.

en: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too.
vi: This is quite a kind family. And this house is also very charming.
tr: They were truly a nice family, and their house was really beautiful.
es: It was a very nice family, and the house was also great.

en: I hadn’t seen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so much style.
vi: I have not seen any house in this area as beautiful and stylish as this one.
tr: Until that day, I had never seen such a beautiful and elegant house in the countryside.
es: I had never seen such a good house with so much style.

en: It didn’t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a wooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same as houses in town.
vi: On the front door, there is no iron or wooden latch tied with a deer leather strap, but instead, there is a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city.
tr: There was no iron latch or wooden latch opened with a leather strap on the front door; instead, there was a brass handle like the ones in town houses, which you turned to open.
es: It didn't have an iron latch on the main door, nor a wooden one with a leather cord, but a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city.

en: There warn’t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a bed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them.
vi: In the living room, besides the bed, there is nothing else used as a bed. There are many such rooms in the province where they place beds.
tr: There was no bed in the living room, not even anything resembling a bed; whereas almost all the living rooms in town had beds.
es: In the living room, there were no beds or signs of them, although there are plenty of living rooms in the cities where you can see beds.

en: There was a big fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call Spanish-brown, same as they do in town.
vi: There is a large fireplace, with tiles laid underneath, and the surrounding tiles are very clean and bright red because they pour water on them and scrub them with other tiles. Sometimes people paint a red coat, commonly called Spanish brown, just like the houses in the city.
tr: There was a large hearth with bricks laid at the bottom, and they kept the bricks clean and red by pouring water on them and rubbing them together; sometimes they also dipped the bricks in a red paint called Spanish-coffee, as was done in town.
es: There was a very large fireplace, lined with bricks at the bottom, which they kept clean by using water and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they washed them with a red water paint called Spanish earth, just like in the city.

en: They had big brass dog-irons that could hold up a saw-log.
vi: There are large brass dogs that can support entire house columns.
tr: The brass fittings in the house's fireplace were large enough to hold big logs.
es: They had some bronze fireplace irons with which you could grab an entire log.

en: There was a clock on the middle of the mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging behind it.
vi: In the middle of the fireplace mantel, there is a clock, a cityscape painting on the lower half of the glass, and a round hollow in the middle to represent the sun, through which you can see the pendulum swinging back and forth.
tr: In the middle of the mantelpiece, I saw a clock, and below the glass of the clock's lower half, there was a picture of a town; the empty space in the middle of the clock symbolized the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging right behind it.
es: In the middle of the mantelpiece, there was a clock with a painting of a village on the bottom part of the glass cover, and a round opening in the middle for the dial, and behind it, you could see the pendulum swinging.

en: It was beautiful to hear that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out.
vi: The clock chimes beautifully, and occasionally, a traveling repairman passes by, comes in to clean it, and adjusts it correctly, making it chime continuously for one hundred and ten times until it is taken apart.
tr: It was very nice to listen to the ticking of this clock; sometimes when one of the traveling repairmen cleaned and reset it, the clock could chime one hundred and fifty times before the spring fully unwound.
es: It was a pleasure to hear the ticking of that clock, and sometimes when a tinker passed by and cleaned and tuned it, it would start ringing and give a hundred and fifty chimes before getting tired.

en: They wouldn’t took any money for her.
vi: The homeowner is not easy to sell it at any price.
tr: Moreover, the repairmen never charged any money for the clock.
es: They wouldn't have sold it for anything in the world.

en: Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy.
vi: Then on either side of the clock, there were very strange-looking parrots, made of something like makeup, painted in bright colors.
tr: On each side of the clock, there was a showy parrot; made from something like chalk and painted in gaudy colors.
es: And on each side of the clock there was a very strange parrot made as if from chalk and painted in many colors.

en: By one of the parrots was a cat made of crockery, and a crockery dog by the other; and when you pressed down on them they squeaked, but didn’t open their mouths nor look different nor interested.
vi: Next to the parrot on one side, there is a porcelain cat, and on the other side, there is a porcelain dog; every time you press its head, it lets out a squeak, but it doesn't open its mouth, nor does it show any signs of anger or joy.
tr: Next to one of the parrots was a clay cat, and next to the other was a clay dog; if you pressed on the cat and dog, they would squeak, but their mouths wouldn't open, their appearance wouldn't change; they wouldn't react.
es: Next to one of the parrots there was a porcelain cat and next to the other a porcelain dog, and when they were pressed they squeaked, but they did not open their mouths nor did they seem different or interested.

en: They squeaked through underneath.
vi: It squeaks from its bottom.
tr: They squeaked from their undersides.
es: Next to one of the parrots there was a porcelain cat and next to the other a porcelain dog, and when they were pressed they squeaked, but they did not open their mouths nor did they seem different or interested.

en: There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out behind those things.
vi: Because there are two fans made from pheasant wings installed at the back.
tr: Behind these items, a pair of large fans made from wild turkey feathers were hanging.
es: Behind them there were two fans made of wild turkey feathers.

en: On the table in the middle of the room was a kind of a lovely crockery basket that had apples and oranges and peaches and grapes piled up in it, which was much redder and yellower and prettier than real ones is, but they warn’t real because you could see where pieces had got chipped off and showed the white chalk, or whatever it was, underneath.
vi: On the table in the middle of the room, there is a very beautiful porcelain bowl, filled with apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, looking red and yellow and more beautiful than usual fruits; but they are not real fruits and you can see spots where the outer layer has peeled off, exposing the white clay inside.
tr: On a table in the middle of the room, there was also a very nice clay basket; filled with apples, oranges; peaches, and grapes that looked much redder, yellower, and more delicious than the real ones, but it was obvious they weren't real because in some places the white chalk or whatever the material was underneath was showing.
es: On the table, in the middle of the room, there was a kind of beautiful porcelain basket that had apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, all piled up, and much redder and yellower and prettier than real fruit, but it wasn't real because you could see where pieces had chipped off and underneath the white chalk or whatever it was.

en: This table had a cover made out of beautiful oilcloth, with a red and blue spread-eagle painted on it, and a painted border all around.
vi: On the table covered with an oilcloth tablecloth, beautiful, in the middle of the cloth is painted a blue and red eagle, with a border painted around it.
tr: On the beautiful oilcloth cover that was neatly laid on the table, a red and blue eagle with its wings spread was drawn within a colorful frame.
es: That table had a beautiful oilcloth tablecloth, with a red and blue eagle and a painted border all around.

en: It come all the way from Philadelphia, they said.
vi: They said that the cloth was brought back from Philadelphia.
tr: They said this cover came all the way from Philadelphia.
es: They said it had come from Philadelphia.

en: There was some books, too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table.
vi: There were also a few books, carefully arranged in the corners of the table.
tr: There were also books carefully stacked on each corner of the table.
es: There were also some books, in very neatly arranged piles at each corner of the table.

en: One was a big family Bible full of pictures.
vi: One book was a Bible with many illustrations.
tr: One of them was a large Holy Bible filled with pictures, suitable for family reading.
es: One of them was a large family Bible full of illustrations.

en: One was Pilgrim’s Progress, about a man that left his family, it didn’t say why.
vi: Another book was "The Pilgrim's Progress," about a man who left home without saying why.
tr: Another one was "On the Pilgrimage," about a man who left his home and family for an unspecified reason.
es: Another was The Pilgrim's Progress, about a man who left his family, but it didn't say why.

en: I read considerable in it now and then.
vi: Occasionally, I still read this story.
tr: I occasionally picked up this book and read quite a bit of it.
es: From time to time, I would read a bunch of pages.

en: The statements was interesting, but tough.
vi: But the words in it are quite good, though a bit rough.
tr: The sentences were interesting but of a kind that was hard to understand.
es: What it said was interesting, but difficult.

en: Another was Friendship’s Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn’t read the poetry.
vi: Another book was "Sacrifice for Friends," which had many good stories and poems, but I don't read poetry.
tr: There was also a book called "The Gifts of Friendship" filled with beautiful writings and poems; but I did not read the poems.
es: Another was The Offering of Friendship, full of very beautiful things and poems, but I didn't read the poetry.

en: Another was Henry Clay’s Speeches, and another was dr Gunn’s Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body was sick or dead.
vi: One book was "The Speeches of Henry Clay," and another was "Gunn's Domestic Medicine," which talked about everything we need to do when someone in the house is sick or dies.
tr: Besides a book titled "Speeches of Henry Clay," there was also Dr. Gunn's "Family Medicine," which explained everything to do if someone gets sick or dies.
es: Another was the Speeches of Henry Clay and another was Dr. Gunn's Family Medicine, which said everything to do if someone got sick or died.

en: There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books.
vi: Then there was a book about hymns, and a bunch of other books.
tr: There was a Hymn Book and many other books.
es: There was a hymn book and a bunch of other books.

en: And there was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too—not bagged down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.
vi: There were also some very cute little chairs, with legs splayed out, and very sturdy to sit on, the seat not sagging or sunken like an old basket.
tr: We were also sitting on very beautiful woven wicker chairs, and they were very sturdy – not like old baskets with sagging centers and broken bottoms.
es: And there were some very beautiful cane chairs, and also very sturdy, not sunken in the middle and broken, like an old basket.

en: They had pictures hung on the walls—mainly Washingtons and Lafayettes, and battles, and Highland Marys, and one called “Signing the Declaration.”
vi: They even have paintings hanging on the walls - especially paintings of Washingtons and Lafayettes depicting battles, depicting the Mary plateau, and a painting called The Signing of the Declaration.
tr: There were paintings hanging on the walls – mostly Washingtons and Lafayettes, wars, Highland Marys, and also "The Signing of the Declaration of Independence".
es: On the walls, they had hung pictures mostly of Washington and Lafayette and battles and Mary, Queen of Scots, and another one called The Signing of the Declaration.

en: There was some that they called crayons, which one of the daughters which was dead made her own self when she was only fifteen years old.
vi: There are some paintings they call sketches, one of which depicts one of the daughters of this family who has passed away; she drew it herself when she was just fifteen years old.
tr: There were also pencil drawings, one of which was made by one of their deceased daughters when she was just fifteen years old.
es: There were some called pastels, made by one of the daughters, who had died when she was only fifteen years old.

en: They was different from any pictures I ever see before—blacker, mostly, than is common.
vi: These paintings are different from any paintings I had seen before - they are mostly darker than usual paintings.
tr: These were different from all the pictures I had seen so far; they were darker in color than all of them.
es: They were different from all the pictures I had seen before: almost all darker than what you usually see.

en: One was a woman in a slim black dress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in the middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a black veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and very wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on a tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other hand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule, and underneath the picture it said “Shall I Never See Thee More Alas.”
vi: One depicts a woman in a thin black dress, cinched under the arms, with cabbage-like flares at the wrists, wearing a bonnet with a black veil falling down, with two white ankles wrapped in black ribbons, wearing black shoes as small as blades; the woman in the painting is leaning down sorrowfully beside a tombstone on the right, under a weeping willow, holding a white handkerchief in one hand and a woven basket in the other; under the painting, it is written: Alas, I shall never see you again!
tr: In one of them, there was a woman in a thin black dress. The dress was cinched at the armpits with a belt, the cuffs were puffed up like cabbage, and there was a black veil in front of the shovel-like brimmed hat on her head, black ribbons were tied around her white thin wrists, and she wore small black slippers resembling chisels on her feet.
es: One was of a woman in a tight black dress, with a belt under her armpits and bulges like a cabbage in the middle of the sleeves and a large black hat shaped like a coif, with a black veil and thin white ankles bandaged with a black ribbon and very small black slippers, like spatulas, and she was leaning thoughtfully on a cemetery slab, resting on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, with the other hand hanging down to one side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule, and under the picture, a sign said "I will never see you again, alas.

en: Another one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to the top of her head, and knotted there in front of a comb like a chair-back, and she was crying into a handkerchief and had a dead bird laying on its back in her other hand with its heels up, and underneath the picture it said “I Shall Never Hear Thy Sweet Chirrup More Alas.”
vi: Another painting depicts a young woman with all her hair combed up to the top of her head, tied in a knot in front with a comb that looks like the back of a chair, she is crying, face buried in a handkerchief, with a dead bird lying on its back in her other hand, legs upturned, and under the painting, it is written: Alas, I shall never hear you sing again!
tr: The woman was standing pensively with her right elbow resting on a tombstone, under a weeping willow, and in her other hand hanging by her side, a white handkerchief and a handbag could be seen, and beneath the picture, it said, "Alas, I Shall Never See You Again. " In another picture, there was a young woman with her hair beautifully done up in a bun on top of her head, with a comb resembling a chair back attached behind the bun. She was crying, holding a handkerchief to her face with one hand, and in her other hand lay a dead bird with its claws up; beneath this picture, it said, "Alas, I Shall Never Hear Your Sweet Song Again.
es: " Another was of a young lady with her hair all styled in a pompadour and made into a bun and tied at the back with a large comb like the back of a chair, crying into a handkerchief, and in the other hand, she held a dead bird on its back with its legs up, and under the picture, it said "I will never hear your sweet trill again, alas. "

en: There was one where a young lady was at a window looking up at the moon, and tears running down her cheeks; and she had an open letter in one hand with black sealing wax showing on one edge of it, and she was mashing a locket with a chain to it against her mouth, and underneath the picture it said “And Art Thou Gone Yes Thou Art Gone Alas.”
vi: Then there is another painting of a young woman sitting by a window looking at the moon, tears streaming down her cheeks: one hand holding an open letter with a black seal on one side, lifting a small framed picture to her mouth with a string; under the painting, it is written: Is it true that you are leaving, oh my love!
tr: "In another picture, a young lady was looking at the moon through a window, with tears streaming down her cheeks; in one hand, she held an open letter sealed with black, and with the other hand, she was bringing a medallion on a chain to her lips. The inscription beneath this picture read: "Ah, You Are Gone, Alas, You Are Gone."
es: There was another where a young lady was looking at the moon through a window, and tears were streaming down her cheeks, and in one hand, she held an open letter with a black wax seal on the edge, and she was bringing a locket with a chain to her mouth, and under the picture, it said "And you are gone, yes, you are gone, alas.

en: These was all nice pictures, I reckon, but I didn’t somehow seem to take to them, because if ever I was down a little they always give me the fan-tods.
vi: All those paintings are beautiful, I am sure, but somehow I do not like them much. Because whenever I am sad, they make me feel even heavier.
tr: These were probably beautiful pictures, but they weren't quite to my taste; because whenever I felt a bit down, looking at these pictures made me feel even worse.
es: "I guess those pictures were of great merit, but I don't know why I didn't like them, because when I was feeling a bit down, they always gave me the creeps.

en: Everybody was sorry she died, because she had laid out a lot more of these pictures to do, and a body could see by what she had done what they had lost.
vi: Everyone regretted that she died, because she was planning to paint many more such paintings. Everyone felt that she had gained something while everyone else had lost something.
tr: Everyone was very sad about the girl's death because she could have made many more of these pictures, and people realized what they had missed by looking at what she had done.
es: Everyone was very sad because she had died, because she had many more pictures left to paint, and from the ones she had already painted, you could see what they had lost.

en: But I reckoned that with her disposition she was having a better time in the graveyard.
vi: But I think that with her temperament, it was better for her to rest in the cemetery.
tr: But judging by the tendency in the pictures, she probably had a better time in the cemetery.
es: But I figured that with that state of mind, she would be much better off in the cemetery.

en: She was at work on what they said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it done, but she never got the chance.
vi: She only prayed to live long enough to finish that painting, but she still did not survive.
tr: They said that when she fell ill, she was working on her greatest piece and prayed day and night to stay alive until she finished it, but she never got the chance to complete it.
es: She was painting what they said was going to be her best picture when she got sick, and every day and every night she prayed to stay alive until she finished it, but she didn't get the chance.

en: It was a picture of a young woman in a long white gown, standing on the rail of a bridge all ready to jump off, with her hair all down her back, and looking up to the moon, with the tears running down her face, and she had two arms folded across her breast, and two arms stretched out in front, and two more reaching up towards the moon—and the idea was to see which pair would look best, and then scratch out all the other arms; but, as I was saying, she died before she got her mind made up, and now they kept this picture over the head of the bed in her room, and every time her birthday come they hung flowers on it.
vi: It was a painting of a young woman in a long white dress, standing by the bridge, about to jump into the river, hair flowing down her back, face turned up looking at the moon, tears streaming down, arms crossed in front of her chest, with two other arms reaching forward, and two more arms reaching up towards the moon - the idea was to see which pair of arms was better, and the others would be erased. But as I mentioned earlier, she died before making a final decision; and now they still keep that painting hanging over her bed in her room. Every year on her birthday, they decorate that painting with flowers.
tr: This picture was of a young woman in a long white dress; she was standing ready to jump over the railings of a bridge, her hair let loose, looking at the moon with tears streaming down her face. She had her arms crossed over her chest, her arms extended forward, and she was reaching both towards the moon – she would later erase the other arms, deciding which looked better; but as I said, she died before making a decision, and now they keep this picture at the head of her bed in her room; they hung flowers on the picture on her every birthday.
es: It was a picture of a girl in a long white dress, standing on the railing of a bridge and ready to jump, with her hair loose down her back looking at the moon, her face bathed in tears, with two arms crossed over her chest, two arms extended in front, and two arms reaching towards the moon, and the idea was to see which pair of arms would look best and then erase all the others, but as I was saying, she died before deciding, and now they had that picture above the head of the bed in her room, and every time her birthday came, they put flowers all around it.

en: Other times it was hid with a little curtain.
vi: There used to be a curtain covering it.
tr: At other times, they covered it with a small curtain.
es: The rest of the time, it was covered with a curtain.

en: The young woman in the picture had a kind of a nice sweet face, but there was so many arms it made her look too spidery, seemed to me.
vi: The young woman in the painting has a small and pretty face, but because of the many arms, she looks like a spider, that's how I see it.
tr: The young woman in the picture had a beautiful and sweet face, but having so many arms made her look a bit like a spider to me.
es: The girl in the picture had a kind and pleasant face, but to me, it seemed that so many arms gave her a bit of a spider-like look.

en: This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the Presbyterian Observer, and write poetry after them out of her own head.
vi: This young woman, when she was alive, had a notebook in which she kept pressed leaves and often copied stories or confessions of the sick from the Presbyterian Observer magazine, then wrote poems inspired by her own thoughts beneath them.
tr: While the same young girl was alive, she kept a notebook, pasting old obituaries, accident reports, and articles about enduring suffering with patience from the Presbyterian Observer newspaper into it. She also wrote poems she made up herself for the articles she pasted.
es: When the girl was alive, she had been making a scrapbook in which she pasted obituaries, accidents, and cases of patient suffering that had appeared in the Presbyterian Observer, along with poems that these had inspired in her and which she wrote with her own imagination.

en: It was very good poetry.
vi: The poems were quite remarkable.
tr: These were very good poems.
es: They were very good poems.

en: This is what she wrote about a boy by the name of Stephen Dowling Bots that fell down a well and was drownded:
vi: Below is a poem she wrote about a boy named Stephen Dowling Bost who fell into a well and died:
tr: The poem she wrote for a boy named Stephen Dowling Bots, who fell into a well and drowned, was as follows:
es: This is the one she wrote about a boy named Stephen Dowling Bots, who fell into a well and drowned:

en: ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DEC’D
vi: the poem mourning Stephen Dowling Bost who has died.
tr: DECEASED STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS'S ROOM
es: ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DECEASED

en: And did young Stephen sicken,
vi: Is Stephen sick?
tr: Has little Stephen fallen ill?
es: Was it Stephen and did he get sick?

en: And did young Stephen die?
vi: Did Stephen die?
tr: Is little Stephen dead?
es: Is that what Stephen died of?

en: And did the sad hearts thicken,
vi: Do sad hearts grow heavier
tr: Have sorrowful hearts been constricted,
es: Did your heart suffer?

en: And did the mourners cry?
vi: Are those the people who made you cry?
tr: Have the mourners shed tears?
es: Did the people become sad?

en: No; such was not the fate of
vi: No, it's not fate.
tr: No; this was not his fate
es: No; that was not the fate

en: Young Stephen Dowling Bots;
vi: Stephen Dowling Bost's belongings.
tr: Young Stephen Dowling Bots’;
es: by Stephen Dowling Bots;

en: Though sad hearts round him thickened,
vi: Even though the hearts around you are heavy
tr: Perhaps sorrowful hearts burned,
es: although his sad death grieved many of us,

en: ’Twas not from sickness’ shots.
vi: It's not because of illness either, dear.
tr: But it wasn't because of illness.
es: it was not the illness that took him.

en: No whooping-cough did rack his frame,
vi: No sobbing sound can mend your image.
tr: It wasn't whooping cough that ravaged his body,
es: It was not whooping cough that took him from us,

en: Nor measles drear with spots;
vi: Nothing can erase the pain.
tr: It was unexpected with a hopeless measles;
es: neither was the horrible measles to blame;

en: Not these impaired the sacred name
vi: Nothing can make up for your name.
tr: It was not these that overshadowed the blessed name
es: none of them yielded

en: Of Stephen Dowling Bots.
vi: Oh Stephen Dowling Bost.
tr: With the death of Stephen Dowling Bots.
es: a Stephen Dowling Bots.

en: Despised love struck not with woe
vi: Despite the pain, love remains unbroken.
tr: Love's torment did not burn
es: Nor was it the sorrow of an unshared love

en: That head of curly knots,
vi: The head still has a full set of hair.
tr: Oh, curly-headed one with bangs,
es: the one who wrinkled her forehead in anger and pain;

en: Nor stomach troubles laid him low,
vi: Despite the pain in my gut, it made me fall down.
tr: It was not a stomach ache that laid one down on the bed,
es: it was not the anxieties of poor digestion

en: Young Stephen Dowling Bots.
vi: I am still Stephen Dowling Bost.
tr: Poor Stephen Dowling Bots.
es: the ones that ended Stephen Dowling Bots forever.

en: O no.
vi: Oh, no!
tr: None of them.
es: Oh, no!

en: Then list with tearful eye,
vi: Look with tearful eyes.
tr: Listen with tears in your eyes,
es: Listen attentively, as tearful as I am,

en: Whilst I his fate do tell.
vi: When we hear stories about your fate.
tr: While I was narrating his unfortunate fate.
es: the horrible fate that poor man suffered.

en: His soul did from this cold world fly
vi: The soul flies up to the cold world.
tr: Left with an indifferent farewell
es: How his soul abandoned the cold and sad world

en: By falling down a well.
vi: When you fall into the well.
tr: From the bottom of a well, this cruel world.
es: because our boy fell into a deep well.

en: They got him out and emptied him;
vi: Lift me up and drain the water from my body.
tr: Ah, they pulled it out of the well and emptied its contents;
es: Then they proceeded to drain his lung,

en: Alas it was too late;
vi: But it was already too late for me.
tr: But alas, it was already too late;
es: but it was already too late, alas, for the poor heart;

en: His spirit was gone for to sport aloft
vi: My soul has flown to a place unseen.
tr: His soul had already gone to run and play
es: his soul rose in three clouds of cotton

en: In the realms of the good and great.
vi: where, good, great?
tr: To the realm of nobility and goodness.
es: where the celestial Gathering is celebrated.

en: If Emmeline Grangerford could make poetry like that before she was fourteen, there ain’t no telling what she could a done by-and-by.
vi: If Miss Emmeline Grangerford could write such poems at the age of fourteen, one wonders what she might have accomplished later on.
tr: If Emmeline Grangerford could write such poetry before she was fourteen, it was hard to imagine what she could write in the future.
es: If Emmeline Grangerford was capable of writing poetry like that before she turned fourteen, God knows what she could have done with time.

en: Buck said she could rattle off poetry like nothing.
