vi: Buck said that she could scribble out a poem as easily as playing.
tr: According to Buck, she could easily make up a poem in one go.
es: Buck said that poetry came to her with complete ease.

en: She didn’t ever have to stop to think.
vi: She was always thinking.
tr: She didn't even need to stop and think.
es: She didn't even have to stop to think.

en: He said she would slap down a line, and if she couldn’t find anything to rhyme with it would just scratch it out and slap down another one, and go ahead.
vi: He said she would jot down a line, and if she couldn't find another line to rhyme with it, she would erase it immediately and come up with another one, and so on.
tr: He said that if she wrote a line and couldn't find a rhyme, she would immediately erase that line and write another one, and continue like that.
es: He said she would write a line and if she couldn't find anything that rhymed, she would cross it out and write another and keep going.

en: She warn’t particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful.
vi: She had a particular liking for something, could write anything she chose, and if you asked her to write something, she would. But it had to be sad poetry.
tr: Moreover, she wasn't fixated on a single topic; whatever you told her to write about, she could write on that topic, as long as it was sorrowful.
es: She wasn't picky at all; she could write about anything someone gave her as a topic, as long as it was sad.

en: Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her “tribute” before he was cold.
vi: Whenever someone died, whether a man, woman, or child, she would write something to mourn the deceased before the body turned cold.
tr: Whenever a man, woman, or child died, she would come up with a piece expressing her love and respect for that person before the funeral had even cooled down.
es: Every time a man, or a woman, or a child died, there she was with her "tribute" before the corpse had even cooled down.

en: She called them tributes.
vi: She called these eulogies.
tr: Whenever a man, woman, or child died, she would come up with a piece expressing her love and respect for that person before the funeral had even cooled down.
es: She called them tributes.

en: The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertaker—the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person’s name, which was Whistler.
vi: The neighbors said that in order, it was first the doctor, then Emmeline, and they would arrive at the same time. Then she would enthusiastically come up with a rhyme for the deceased's name, calling it a Whistler.
tr: According to the neighbors, when someone died, first the doctor, then Emmeline, and then the undertaker would come; the undertaker had only once arrived before Emmeline. As a result, Emmeline, who was shaken by this, had delayed writing for the deceased person named Whistler.
es: The neighbors said that first the doctor arrived, then Emmeline, and then the undertaker; the undertaker only beat Emmeline once, and that was because she couldn't find a way to rhyme with the name of someone named Whistler.

en: She warn’t ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long.
vi: Later on, she gradually changed, never complained, but she kept wasting away and couldn't live any longer.
tr: After that, the girl was never the same; she never complained, but she wasted away day by day and didn't live much longer.
es: From then on, she was never the same; she never complained, but she started to become melancholic and didn't live much longer.

en: Poor thing, many’s the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little.
vi: It's so sad, many times I went up to the room where she used to work, took out her notebook to look at, and seeing the pictures she drew made me feel sad and pity her.
tr: Poor thing; many times when her pictures disturbed me and I started to think of her less, I forced myself to go to the little room that used to be hers, and took out her wretched notebook to read what she had written.
es: Poor thing; I would often go up to the little room that had been hers and take out her poor scrapbook and read it when her pictures had irritated me and I felt a bit angry with her.

en: I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn’t going to let anything come between us.
vi: I loved this family, even the deceased, all of them, and I didn't let anything happen.
tr: I loved everyone in the family, dead or alive, and I wouldn't allow anything to come between us.
es: I liked that whole family, the dead and all, and I wasn't going to let anything come between us.

en: Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn’t seem right that there warn’t nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn’t seem to make it go somehow.
vi: Poor Miss Emmeline, when she was alive, she wrote poems about the dead, but no one wrote any poems about her. So, I tried to rack my brain to think of a few lines, but I couldn't come up with anything.
tr: Poor Emmeline had written poems about all the dead while she was alive, and now that she was gone, it didn't seem right to me that no one would write anything for her; so I tried to write a few verses, but somehow I just couldn't manage it.
es: Poor Emmeline wrote poetry for all the dead when she was alive, and it didn't seem right to me that there was no one to write one for her now that she was dead; so I tried to write one or two for her, but I don't know why they didn't come out.

en: They kept Emmeline’s room trim and nice, and all the things fixed in it just the way she liked to have them when she was alive, and nobody ever slept there.
vi: This family kept Miss Emmeline's room very clean and tidy, and everything was left as she liked it when she was alive, and no one slept there.
tr: They always kept Emmeline's room clean and tidy, everything inside was just as she liked it when she was alive, and no one slept in that room.
es: They always kept Emmeline's room tidy and clean, with everything exactly as she liked it when she was alive, and no one ever slept there.

en: The old lady took care of the room herself, though there was plenty of niggers, and she sewed there a good deal and read her Bible there mostly.
vi: Her mother herself cleaned and took care of this room, even though there were many black servants in the house. She would go into this room to sew and often read prayers there.
tr: Despite having a lot of black servants, the old woman cleaned the room herself, sewed a lot there, and usually read her Holy Bible there as well.
es: The old lady took care of the room herself, even though there were many black servants, and she spent a lot of time sewing and reading the Bible, mostly.

en: Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines all down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink.
vi: Quyen, I am talking about the living room. There are many windows here, white curtains with drawings of ancient castles, grapevines around the walls with herds of cows and horses drinking water.
tr: Anyway, I was describing the living room. There were very beautiful curtains on the windows: They were white curtains depicting castles with ivy-covered walls and cattle by the water.
es: Well, as I was saying about the living room, there were some very beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with paintings of castles with ivy all over the walls and cattle going to drink.

en: There was a little old piano, too, that had tin pans in it, I reckon, and nothing was ever so lovely as to hear the young ladies sing “The Last Link is Broken” and play “The Battle of Prague” on it.
vi: There is a small old piano, which I am sure contains pots and pans. Whenever the ladies in the house sing the song "The Last Ties Have Broken" or play "The Battle of Prague," nothing could be more delightful.
tr: There was also an old small piano in the living room; I think there were pans and such inside it. Nothing could be as beautiful as the young ladies singing "The Last Ring Broke" and playing the "Battle of Prague" at this piano.
es: There was also a small and old piano that sounded like a rattle, and we had a great time when the young ladies sang "The Last Link is Broken" and played "The Battle of Prague" on it.

en: The walls of all the rooms was plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.
vi: The walls around the rooms are all plastered, and almost every room has carpets on the floor. And the entire house is whitewashed on the outside.
tr: All the walls of the rooms were plastered, most had carpets on the floor, and the exterior of the house was completely painted.
es: All the rooms had plastered walls and almost all of them had carpets, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.

en: It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the day, and it was a cool, comfortable place.
vi: It is a house with two kitchens. The space between the two kitchens is covered and carefully wooden-floored. Sometimes at noon, placing a table there to sit is very cool and very enjoyable.
tr: This was a two-winged house, and a roof was built over the wide open space in between, with a floor underneath. From time to time, a table was set there for lunch; it was indeed a very cool and comfortable place.
es: It was a double house, and the large open space between the two parts had a roof and was floored; sometimes they would set the table there at noon, and it was a cool and pleasant place.

en: Nothing couldn’t be better.
vi: There is nothing better than that.
tr: Anything better would be a blessing.
es: It was the best thing in the world.

en: And warn’t the cooking good, and just bushels of it too!
vi: And if the meals are delicious, it would be wonderful, nothing could compare.
tr: The food was not only very delicious but also plentiful!
es: And on top of that, they cooked very well and there were heaps of everything!

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Chapter XVIII
tr: Chapter Eighteen
es: Chapter 18

en: Col. Grangerford was a gentleman, you see.
vi: Colonel Grangerford was an aristocrat, you see.
tr: Colonel Grangerford was a true nobleman.
es: COLONEL GRANGERFORD was a gentleman, you understand?

en: He was a gentleman all over; and so was his family.
vi: He was an aristocrat in every way: so was his whole family.
tr: He was a gentleman from head to toe; the other members of the family were no less.
es: He was a gentleman in everything, and the same was true of his family.

en: He was well born, as the saying is, and that’s worth as much in a man as it is in a horse, so the Widow Douglas said, and nobody ever denied that she was of the first aristocracy in our town; and pap he always said it, too, though he warn’t no more quality than a mudcat himself.
vi: He came from a noble background, as people often say, and that is as valuable for a person as it is for a horse; as Widow Douglas used to say, and no one could deny that she was the top aristocrat in the province. My father used to say the same thing, although my father was no more valuable than a stray cat.
tr: He came from a noble family, and just as with horses, nobility increases the value of people. Mrs. Douglas used to say this, and no one could deny that she was the head of the aristocracy in our town. My father always said the same thing, but he himself was no more noble than a catfish.
es: He was of good stock, as they say, and that counts as much in a man as in a horse, as Widow Douglas used to say, and no one denied that she was of the first aristocracy of our town, and father always said it too, although he himself was no better bred than a stray cat.

en: Col. Grangerford was very tall and very slim, and had a darkish-paly complexion, not a sign of red in it anywheres; he was clean shaved every morning all over his thin face, and he had the thinnest kind of lips, and the thinnest kind of nostrils, and a high nose, and heavy eyebrows, and the blackest kind of eyes, sunk so deep back that they seemed like they was looking out of caverns at you, as you may say.
vi: Colonel Grangerford was tall but slender. He had a dusky, oily complexion, and his whole face lacked any rosy hue. Every morning, he shaved his entire gaunt face smooth. He had the thinnest lips, the smallest nostrils, a prominent nose, bushy eyebrows, the blackest eyes set so deep it seemed as if they were looking at you from a dark cavern, so to speak.
tr: Colonel Grangerford was very tall and slender, with a dark-pale complexion that showed not the slightest hint of redness. He shaved every part of his thin face every morning; his lips were very thin, his nostrils were very thin, he had a button nose, thick eyebrows, and his jet-black eyes were so deeply set that one almost thought he was looking out of two caves.
es: Colonel Grangerford was very tall and thin and had a pale brownish skin, without a single red spot; every morning he shaved his entire face, which was very thin, just like his lips and the nostrils of his nose; he had a very high nose and thick eyebrows and very black eyes, so deep-set that it seemed, as if to say, that he was looking at you from the bottom of a cave.

en: His forehead was high, and his hair was black and straight and hung to his shoulders.
vi: His forehead was high, his hair grizzled, straight, and hanging down to his shoulders. His hands were both thin and long.
tr: His forehead was broad, and his black, straight hair reached down to his shoulders.
es: He had a high forehead and gray, straight hair that reached down to his shoulders.

en: His hands was long and thin, and every day of his life he put on a clean shirt and a full suit from head to foot made out of linen so white it hurt your eyes to look at it; and on Sundays he wore a blue tail-coat with brass buttons on it.
vi: Throughout his life, each day he wore a white undershirt and a suit made entirely of white flannel, dazzling to the eyes. Then on Sundays, he added a blue tailcoat with brass buttons.
tr: His hands were long and thin; he wore a clean shirt every day and walked around in a snow-white linen suit; the suit was so white it dazzled the eyes. On Sundays, however, he wore a navy blue frock coat with brass buttons.
es: He had long, thin hands, and every day he wore a clean shirt and a full linen suit so white it hurt your eyes to look at it, and on Sundays, a blue frock coat with copper buttons.

en: He carried a mahogany cane with a silver head to it.
vi: He carried a peachwood cane with a silver handle.
tr: He carried a mahogany cane with a silver knob.
es: He carried a mahogany cane with a silver knob.

en: There warn’t no frivolishness about him, not a bit, and he warn’t ever loud.
vi: He never appeared careless in the slightest, nor did he ever show anger towards anyone.
tr: There was not a trace of frivolity in his demeanor, not at all; he was never seen raising his voice.
es: He was not at all frivolous, not one bit, and he never shouted.

en: He was as kind as he could be—you could feel that, you know, and so you had confidence.
vi: He tried to be good to everyone, and you could feel that, which made you trust him.
tr: A person could not be more kind-hearted – you felt this and trusted him.
es: He was very kind and it showed, so you could trust him.

en: Sometimes he smiled, and it was good to see; but when he straightened himself up like a liberty-pole, and the lightning begun to flicker out from under his eyebrows, you wanted to climb a tree first, and find out what the matter was afterwards.
vi: Occasionally, he smiled, and it was truly charming. But when he stood up straight like the Statue of Liberty, and a gleam began to shine from beneath his eyebrows, you might want to find a tree to climb up immediately, knowing something was about to happen.
tr: Sometimes he would smile, and seeing this smile made one feel very good; but sometimes he would stand as erect as a flagpole symbolizing freedom, and glare so fiercely from under his eyebrows that you felt like climbing a tree first and then asking what the matter was.
es: Sometimes he smiled and it was a pleasure to see, but when he stood stiff as a flagpole and started shooting lightning from his eyes, you first thought of climbing a tree and then finding out what was going on.

en: He didn’t ever have to tell anybody to mind their manners—everybody was always good-mannered where he was.
vi: He didn't need to tell people to behave - yet wherever he went, everyone was obedient.
tr: He never needed to remind anyone of manners – everyone behaved politely in his presence.
es: He never had to tell anyone to have good manners: where he was, everyone always behaved well.

en: Everybody loved to have him around, too; he was sunshine most always—I mean he made it seem like good weather.
vi: Everyone liked having him around - he was like sunlight - I mean to say, it was like encountering good weather.
tr: Moreover, everyone enjoyed having him around; he was almost always sunny – that is, you always felt like the weather was nice when he was around.
es: And everyone loved having him around; he was almost always like a ray of sunshine: I mean, with him it seemed like the weather was always good.

en: When he turned into a cloudbank it was awful dark for half a minute, and that was enough; there wouldn’t nothing go wrong again for a week.
vi: When the sun went behind a cloud, it darkened for half a minute, and that was all. Then for about a week, nothing happened at all.
tr: When he clouded over, however, it would be pitch dark for half a minute, and that was enough; no one would do anything wrong for a week.
es: When he turned into a storm cloud, it darkened for half a minute and that was enough; in a week no one would do anything wrong again.

en: When him and the old lady come down in the morning all the family got up out of their chairs and give them good-day, and didn’t set down again till they had set down.
vi: In the morning, when he and his wife came downstairs, everyone stood up to greet them. Before they came down, no one in the house dared to sit.
tr: When the Colonel and the matron came downstairs in the morning, the whole family would stand up and greet them with a good morning, and they would not sit down until the Colonel and the matron were settled.
es: When he and the elderly lady came down in the morning, the whole family would rise from their chairs to greet them and would not sit down again until they had taken their seats.

en: Then Tom and Bob went to the sideboard where the decanter was, and mixed a glass of bitters and handed it to him, and he held it in his hand and waited till Tom’s and Bob’s was mixed, and then they bowed and said, “Our duty to you, sir, and madam;” and they bowed the least bit in the world and said thank you, and so they drank, all three, and Bob and Tom poured a spoonful of water on the sugar and the mite of whisky or apple brandy in the bottom of their tumblers, and give it to me and Buck, and we drank to the old people too.
vi: Then Tom and Bod went to the liquor cabinet, mixed several types of alcohol together, and brought it to him. He took it in his hand, waited for Tom and Bod to finish pouring everything, and after both of them bowed and said: "Please, father and mother," and greeted in every possible way, then expressed their thanks, everyone finally drank together. After that, Tom and Bod poured a spoonful of water into the sugar, added a bit of sugar to the whiskey or brandy at the bottom of the glass, handed it to me and Buck, and then it was our turn to drink and toast the couple as well.
tr: Then Tom and Bob would go to the sideboard where the pitcher was, pour a drink made from herbs and roots, and hand it to him. Colonel Grangerford would wait with his hand in the air until Tom and Bob had prepared their own drinks. Then the young men would bow and say, "Respectfully, sir and madam," to which the elders would respond with a slight nod and a thank you. Then all three of them would down their drinks. Afterwards, Bob and Tom would pour a little whiskey or apple brandy over the sugar at the bottom of their glasses, add a spoonful of water, and hand the glasses to Buck and me. We would drink to the health of the elders. The biggest was Bob, and Tom was one size smaller than him.
es: Then Tom and Bob would go to the sideboard where the glass jar was kept and pour a glass of herbal liqueur and give it to him, and he would hold the glass in his hand, waiting until Tom and Bob served themselves, and they would bow and say, "To your health, sir and madam," and they would also bow slightly and thank them and the three of them would drink, and Tom and Bob would pour a spoonful of water into the sugar and the little bit of whiskey or apple liqueur left at the bottom of their glasses and give it to Buck and me, and we would also drink to the health of the elders.

en: Bob was the oldest and Tom next—tall, beautiful men with very broad shoulders and brown faces, and long black hair and black eyes.
vi: Bob is the eldest. Then comes Tom, both of them tall, handsome, broad-shouldered, with tanned faces, black long hair, and black eyes as well.
tr: They were broad-shouldered, dark-faced, tall men; they had long black hair and jet-black eyes.
es: Bob was the eldest and then came Tom: two tall and handsome men with very broad shoulders and weathered faces, long black hair, and black eyes.

en: They dressed in white linen from head to foot, like the old gentleman, and wore broad Panama hats.
vi: Both of them wore white woolen clothes, from head to toe, just like that upper-class old man, and wide-brimmed straw hats.
tr: Just like the big boss, they would dress in white linen from head to toe and wear wide-brimmed straw hats.
es: They were dressed in white linen from head to toe, just like the elderly gentleman, and wore wide Panama hats.

en: Then there was Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five, and tall and proud and grand, but as good as she could be when she warn’t stirred up; but when she was, she had a look that would make you wilt in your tracks, like her father.
vi: Then it was Charlotte's turn. She was twenty-five years old, tall, and proud; whenever she wasn't losing her temper, she tried to be kind. But when she did lose her temper, she could make you tremble in your boots, just like her father.
tr: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old, tall, proud, and magnificent, but extremely kind when not provoked; when she was angry, just like her father, she would give such a look that it would make your knees buckle.
es: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old and was tall, proud, and stunning, but very kind when she wasn't angry; although when she was, she would give looks that left one frozen, just like her father.

en: She was beautiful.
vi: She was quite beautiful.
tr: She was a beautiful girl.
es: She was very beautiful.

en: So was her sister, Miss Sophia, but it was a different kind.
vi: As for her younger sister, Sophia, she was completely different from her.
tr: Her sister Miss Sophia was also beautiful, but she had a different kind of beauty.
es: His sister, Miss Sophia, was also the same, but of a different type.

en: She was gentle and sweet like a dove, and she was only twenty.
vi: She was very gentle and as pleasant as a dove. She was only twenty years old.
tr: She was gentle and sweet like a dove; she was only twenty.
es: She was calm and peaceful like a dove, and she was only twenty years old.

en: Each person had their own nigger to wait on them—Buck too.
vi: Each person in the house had their own black servant.
tr: Everyone had a black servant who took care of them – Buck had one too.
es: Each person had their own black servant, and Buck did too.

en: My nigger had a monstrous easy time, because I warn’t used to having anybody do anything for me, but Buck’s was on the jump most of the time.
vi: Even young Buck had one. The black servant they assigned to me had plenty of free time, because I never wanted anyone to do anything for me. But young Buck was always ordering people around, yelling all the time.
tr: My black servant had it easy, really, because I wasn't used to having someone else do things for me, whereas Buck's black servant was working hard.
es: My black servant had a great time because I wasn't used to having anyone do things for me, but Buck's spent his time running around.

en: This was all there was of the family now, but there used to be more—three sons; they got killed; and Emmeline that died.
vi: Those are all the people present in the family. There should have been more, but the three eldest sons were all killed, and Miss Emmeline has also passed away.
tr: This was all that was left of the family now; there used to be more – three more sons; but they had been killed and Emmeline had died on her own.
es: That was the family that remained, but before there were more: three children who had been killed and Emmeline, who had died.

en: The old gentleman owned a lot of farms and over a hundred niggers.
vi: This upper-class old man has several farms with over a hundred black people working.
tr: The old gentleman had many farms and a hundred black slaves.
es: The elderly gentleman had a lot of farms and more than a hundred slaves.

en: Sometimes a stack of people would come there, horseback, from ten or fifteen mile around, and stay five or six days, and have such junketings round about and on the river, and dances and picnics in the woods daytimes, and balls at the house nights.
vi: Occasionally, a group of people would come there, riding horses from a place ten to fifteen miles away. They would stay for five or six days, eating and drinking abundantly on the river or around the house, dancing, and frolicking in the woods during the day. Then at night, they would come into the house and dance again.
tr: Sometimes people would come in groups on horseback from ten or fifteen miles away and stay for five or six days; they would have fun around the house and the river, dance, have picnics in the forest during the day, and hold festivities at the house in the evening.
es: Sometimes a bunch of people would arrive on horseback, from ten or fifteen miles around, and they would stay for five or six days, spending the whole time having fun in the river or nearby, with dances and picnics in the woods during the day and dances in the house at night.

en: These people was mostly kinfolks of the family.
vi: Most of these people were relatives of the family.
tr: Most of these people were relatives of the family.
es: Almost all of them were relatives of the family.

en: The men brought their guns with them.
vi: They also brought guns with them.
tr: The men would bring their rifles with them.
es: The men arrived with their weapons.

en: It was a handsome lot of quality, I tell you.
vi: And it must be said that these were all high-quality and beautiful guns.
tr: It was quite a distinguished crowd, indeed.
es: I assure you that those were distinguished people.

en: There was another clan of aristocracy around there—five or six families—mostly of the name of Shepherdson.
vi: There was another noble family nearby, about five or six families mostly bearing the surname Shepherdsons.
tr: There was another aristocratic family in the vicinity – they consisted of five or six families, and most of their last names were Shepherdson.
es: Nearby there was another clan of aristocrats—five or six families—almost all of them called Shepherdson.

en: They was as high-toned and well born and rich and grand as the tribe of Grangerfords.
vi: They were also renowned, also of noble lineage, wealthy, and as grand as the Grangerfords, all sharing a steamboat landing about two miles from our house.
tr: They were also noble, wealthy, and magnificent like the Grangerford clan.
es: They were of as good a lineage and as refined, rich, and grand as the Grangerford tribe.

en: The Shepherdsons and Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing, which was about two mile above our house; so sometimes when I went up there with a lot of our folks I used to see a lot of the Shepherdsons there on their fine horses.
vi: Occasionally, I would go there with some people from this house, and often saw a group of Shepherdsons riding very beautiful horses passing by.
tr: The Shepherdsons and the Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing about two miles upstream from our house; so when I went there with a bunch of our people, I would see a lot of Shepherdsons on their fine horses.
es: The Shepherdson and the Grangerford used the same dock, which was about two miles upstream from our house, so sometimes when I went there with many of ours, I would see a bunch of Shepherdson who had already arrived with their thoroughbred horses.

en: One day Buck and me was away out in the woods hunting, and heard a horse coming.
vi: One day Buck and I went into the forest to hunt, when suddenly we heard the sound of a horse approaching.
tr: One day, while Buck and I were hunting in the forest, we heard a horse approaching.
es: One day Buck and I were in the hunting woods and we heard a horse approaching.

en: We was crossing the road.
vi: We were crossing the road when Buck said:
tr: It would pass by the road shortly.
es: We were crossing the path, and Buck goes and shouts:

en: Buck says:
vi: We were crossing the road when Buck said:
tr: “Quick, quick!
es: We were crossing the path, and Buck goes and shouts:

en: “Quick!
vi: - Quickly, jump into the forest!
tr: “Quick, quick!
es: —Quick!

en: Jump for the woods!”
vi: - Quickly, jump into the forest!
tr: Let's hide behind the trees!” said Buck.
es: Run through the trees!

en: We done it, and then peeped down the woods through the leaves.
vi: We jumped into the forest, hiding in the bushes and peering through the leaves outside.
tr: We immediately hid and started observing the road through the leaves.
es: We started running and then looked through the leaves of the trees.

en: Pretty soon a splendid young man come galloping down the road, setting his horse easy and looking like a soldier.
vi: A moment later, a young, handsome man rode a horse in this direction, sitting firmly on the horse like a skilled cavalryman.
tr: Soon, a majestic young man galloping at full speed appeared at the end of the road. He looked very comfortable on the horse and resembled a soldier.
es: Soon a splendid young man arrived, galloping down the road, very steady in the saddle and with a soldierly air.

en: He had his gun across his pommel.
vi: He had a gun strapped to the front of his saddle.
tr: He had placed his rifle on the saddle horn.
es: He carried the shotgun crossed over the pommel of the saddle.

en: I had seen him before.
vi: I had met him once before.
tr: I had seen him before.
es: I had seen him before.

en: It was young Harney Shepherdson.
vi: It was Harney Shepherdsons.
tr: It was young Harney Shepherdson.
es: He was young Harney Shepherdson.

en: I heard Buck’s gun go off at my ear, and Harney’s hat tumbled off from his head.
vi: Suddenly, a gunshot from Buck whizzed past my ear, and Harney's hat flew off his head.
tr: Buck's rifle went off right next to my ear, and Harney's hat flew off his head.
es: I heard Buck fire the shotgun next to my ear and Harney's hat fell off his head.

en: He grabbed his gun and rode straight to the place where we was hid.
vi: He quickly grabbed his gun and charged his horse towards the source of the shot.
tr: He immediately grabbed his weapon and headed towards where we were hiding.
es: He grabbed his weapon and headed straight to where we were hiding.

en: But we didn’t wait.
vi: But we didn't wait.
tr: But we didn't stop to wait at all.
es: But we didn't wait.

en: We started through the woods on a run.
vi: We leaped through the forest and ran away.
tr: We immediately started running through the forest.
es: We ran into the forest.

en: The woods warn’t thick, so I looked over my shoulder to dodge the bullet, and twice I seen Harney cover Buck with his gun; and then he rode away the way he come—to get his hat, I reckon, but I couldn’t see.
vi: The forest wasn't very dense, so I could run while glancing back to avoid bullets. Twice I saw Harney aim his gun at Buck but then he lost sight of him.
tr: The forest wasn't very dense, so I kept turning and looking back over my shoulder to dodge the bullets. Twice I saw Buck right in Harney's line of fire. Then Harney turned back, probably to get his hat; I couldn't see that part very well.
es: The forest wasn't very dense, so I looked over my shoulder in case he fired, and twice I saw Harney aiming at Buck with the shotgun and then turning around, I suppose to pick up the hat, but I couldn't see him.

en: We never stopped running till we got home.
vi: We ran straight back home.
tr: But we kept running until we reached home.
es: We didn't stop running until we got home.

en: The old gentleman’s eyes blazed a minute—’twas pleasure, mainly, I judged—then his face sort of smoothed down, and he says, kind of gentle:
vi: The old gentleman looked at us, his eyes brightening a bit, seemingly pleased, I guessed. But then his face fell, and he spoke in a gentle tone:
tr: When he heard what happened, sparks flashed in the old gentleman's eyes – it was essentially out of joy, as far as I could tell – but then his face fell, and he slowly said:
es: The old man's eyes flashed for a minute —I think mostly with pleasure— and then he softened his expression a bit and said in a kind voice:

en: “I don’t like that shooting from behind a bush.
vi: - I don't like the way you shoot from the bushes like that.
tr: “I didn't like you shooting from among the trees.
es: —I don't like that you shot from behind a tree.

en: Why didn’t you step into the road, my boy?”
vi: Why don't you stand in the middle of the road and shoot?
tr: Why didn't you come out directly to the road, my child?”
es: Why didn't you come out to the road, son?

en: “The Shepherdsons don’t, father.
vi: -The Shepherdsons are the same, Dad.
tr: "But the Shepherdsons aren't coming out either, father.
es: —The Shepherdsons don't do it, father.

en: They always take advantage.”
vi: They always look for an advantageous position.
tr: They are always laying ambushes for us."
es: They always take advantage.

en: Miss Charlotte she held her head up like a queen while Buck was telling his tale, and her nostrils spread and her eyes snapped.
vi: Miss Charlotte listened to Buck recount the story, raising her head like a queen, her nostrils flaring and her eyes twinkling.
tr: As Buck was telling his story, Mrs. Charlotte straightened her neck like a queen; her nostrils flared and her eyes sparkled.
es: Miss Charlotte had kept her head high like a queen while Buck told his story, with her nostrils flaring, and now she blinked.

en: The two young men looked dark, but never said nothing.
vi: The two sons had darkened expressions but said nothing.
tr: The faces of the two young men fell, but they didn't say a word.
es: The two younger men had a somber air, but they said nothing.

en: Miss Sophia she turned pale, but the color come back when she found the man warn’t hurt.
vi: Miss Sophia turned pale, but when she heard that the other person was not hit, she returned to her usual self.
tr: Mrs. Sophia, on the other hand, turned pale for a moment, but then the color returned to her face when she heard that the man was unharmed.
es: Miss Sophia turned pale, but regained her color when she learned that the man was not injured.

en: Soon as I could get Buck down by the corn-cribs under the trees by ourselves, I says:
vi: Later, I took Buck down to the mill, sat under the shade of a tree, and had a private conversation. I asked:
tr: When we arrived under the trees by the granary, I asked:
es: As soon as I could take Buck to where the corn was stored and we were alone under the trees, I asked him:

en: “Did you want to kill him, Buck?”
vi: - At that moment, were you really planning to kill him? Buck?
tr: "Did you want to kill him, Buck?"
es: —Did you want to kill him, Buck?

en: “Well, I bet I did.”
vi: - Are you really sure?
tr: “Of course I wanted to.”
es: —Man, of course.

en: “What did he do to you?”
vi: - So what did it do to you?
tr: “What did he do to you?”
es: —What had he/she done to you?

en: “Him?
vi: - It?
tr: “Is it him?
es: —Him?

en: He never done nothing to me.”
vi: It has never done anything to me.
tr: He hadn't done anything to me?”
es: He has never done anything to me.

en: “Well, then, what did you want to kill him for?”
vi: - Uh, so why do you intend to kill it?
tr: “But then why do you want to kill him?”
es: —Well, then, Buck, why did you want to kill him?

en: “Why, nothing—only it’s on account of the feud.”
vi: - Uh, so why do you intend to kill it?
tr: "Just... because of a blood feud."
es: —Well, it's nothing, it's just for the blood revenge.

en: “What’s a feud?”
vi: - What is a plantation?
tr: “What is a blood feud?”
es: —What is a blood feud?

en: “Why, where was you raised?
vi: - Oh my, where did you grow up that you don't know what a plantation is?
tr: "Where did you grow up, my brother?
es: —But where were you raised?

en: Don’t you know what a feud is?”
vi: - Oh my, where did you grow up that you don't know what a plantation is?
tr: How do you not know about blood feuds?"
es: Don't you know what a blood feud is?

en: “Never heard of it before—tell me about it.”
vi: - I've never heard of that before. Try telling me about it.
tr: “I had never heard it before... Tell me about it.”
es: —I had never heard of that... tell me what it is.

en: “Well,” says Buck, “a feud is this way.
vi: Buck said - This is how it is, a plantation is like this:
tr: “Alright,” said Buck, “a blood feud is something like this: A man fights with another man, kills him in the fight; then the dead man's brother comes and kills him; then the brothers from both sides start killing each other; then the cousins get involved – in the end, everyone dies and the blood feud ends like that.
es: —Well —said Buck—, a blood feud is something like this: a man fights with another and kills him, then the brother of the other man kills him; after that, the other brothers from each family start looking for each other, then the cousins get involved and after a while everyone is dead and the blood feud is over.

en: A man has a quarrel with another man, and kills him; then that other man’s brother kills him; then the other brothers, on both sides, goes for one another; then the cousins chip in—and by-and-by everybody’s killed off, and there ain’t no more feud.
vi: One person has a conflict with another person, then kills them. Then the siblings of the person who was killed take revenge. Then the siblings of this person kill the other person. Both sides keep killing each other like that endlessly. Eventually, even their relatives get involved, and gradually everyone gets killed, so there is no more plantation.
tr: “Alright,” said Buck, “a blood feud is something like this: A man fights with another man, kills him in the fight; then the dead man's brother comes and kills him; then the brothers from both sides start killing each other; then the cousins get involved – in the end, everyone dies and the blood feud ends like that.
es: —Well —said Buck—, a blood feud is something like this: a man fights with another and kills him, then the brother of the other man kills him; after that, the other brothers from each family start looking for each other, then the cousins get involved and after a while everyone is dead and the blood feud is over.

en: But it’s kind of slow, and takes a long time.”
vi: But that is a long story.
tr: But it is a slow thing; it takes a very long time.”
es: But it's very slow and takes a lot of time.

en: “Has this one been going on long, Buck?”
vi: - So, how long has this been going on, Buck?
tr: “So, how long has this blood feud been going on; Buck?”
es: —And has this been going on for a long time, Buck?

en: “Well, I should reckon!
vi: - Yeah, I think it's probably been a long time.
tr: “I know as much as they told me!
es: —Of course!

en: It started thirty year ago, or som’ers along there.
vi: It's been thirty years now, or maybe even more.
tr: It started some thirty years ago or so.
es: It started about thirty years ago or so.

en: There was trouble ’bout something, and then a lawsuit to settle it; and the suit went agin one of the men, and so he up and shot the man that won the suit—which he would naturally do, of course.
vi: There was some complicated matter, then there was some lawsuit that needed to be resolved, and the court sentenced one of the people involved.
tr: When an issue arose, they went to court; the case was decided against one of the men, so he got up and shot the man who won the case – naturally, that's what he would do.
es: There was a fight over something and then a lawsuit to resolve it, and one of the men won the lawsuit, so the other went and killed the one who had won it, which is naturally what he had to do, of course.

en: Anybody would.”
vi: So this person stood up and shot the one who was sued, and that was natural, anyone would do that.
tr: Everyone would do the same.”
es: What anyone would do.

en: “What was the trouble about, Buck?—land?”
vi: - What's the trouble, Buck? Is it the land?
tr: “So what was the issue about, Buck?.. Was it a land matter?”
es: —And, what was the problem, Buck? Was it about land?

en: “I reckon maybe—I don’t know.”
vi: - Maybe so, I don't really know either
tr: “Maybe it is so… I don't know for sure.”
es: —I suppose it would be... I don't know.

en: “Well, who done the shooting?
vi: - So, who shot at that time?
tr: “So, who pulled the trigger?
es: —Well, who killed whom?

en: Was it a Grangerford or a Shepherdson?”
vi: Someone from my family found out.
tr: Was it Grangerford or Shepherdson?”
es: Was it a Grangerford or a Shepherdson?

en: “Laws, how do I know?
vi: Someone from my family found out.
tr: “Oh come on, how should I know that?
es: —How the hell am I supposed to know?

en: It was so long ago.”
vi: It was a long time ago.
tr: It happened a very long time ago.”
es: It was a long time ago.

en: “Don’t anybody know?”
vi: - So no one knows?
tr: “Is there anyone who knows?”
es: —Doesn't anyone know?

en: “Oh, yes, pa knows, I reckon, and some of the other old people; but they don’t know now what the row was about in the first place.”
vi: - Oh, yes, my father knows, I'm sure of it, and the people in this house know too. But now they don't know how the fight started from the beginning.
tr: “Yes, my father probably knows, some of the elders surely know; but none of them remember what the initial problem was about.”
es: —Ah, yes, father knows, I suppose, and some of the other old folks; but they no longer know why the first fight happened.

en: “Has there been many killed, Buck?”
vi: - Have many people been killed yet, Buck?
tr: "Were many people killed, Buck?"
es: —Have there been many deaths, Buck?

en: “Yes; right smart chance of funerals.
vi: - Yes, many times we almost had to hold a funeral.
tr: “Yes… Quite a few funerals have been held, to be honest.
es: —Yes; there have been many funerals.

en: But they don’t always kill.
vi: But it's not always possible to shoot him dead.
tr: Though it doesn’t always end in death.
es: But they don't always kill.

en: Pa’s got a few buckshot in him; but he don’t mind it ’cuz he don’t weigh much, anyway.
vi: My father also has a few bullets in him, but he doesn't mind, because they are just small bullets.
tr: My father has a few pellets in his body; but he never minds them, they aren’t very serious anyway.
es: Father has some shrapnel inside, but he doesn't mind because it doesn't weigh much anyway.

en: Bob’s been carved up some with a bowie, and Tom’s been hurt once or twice.”
vi: Bod was stabbed with a hunting knife, and Tom has also been shot a few times.
tr: Bob was stabbed and Tom also has a couple of wounds.”
es: Bob has one or two hunting knife cuts and Tom has been wounded once or twice.

en: “Has anybody been killed this year, Buck?”
vi: - So, did anyone get killed this year, Buck?
tr: "Has anyone been killed this year?"
es: —Has anyone died yet this year, Buck?

en: “Yes; we got one and they got one.
vi: - Yes, on our side we killed one person, and on their side, they also killed one person.
tr: “Yes, one from us, one from them.
es: —Yes; we scored one and they scored another.

en: ’Bout three months ago my cousin Bud, fourteen year old, was riding through the woods on t’other side of the river, and didn’t have no weapon with him, which was blame’ foolishness, and in a lonesome place he hears a horse a-coming behind him, and sees old Baldy Shepherdson a-linkin’ after him with his gun in his hand and his white hair a-flying in the wind; and ’stead of jumping off and taking to the brush, Bud ’lowed he could out-run him; so they had it, nip and tuck, for five mile or more, the old man a-gaining all the time; so at last Bud seen it warn’t any use, so he stopped and faced around so as to have the bullet holes in front, you know, and the old man he rode up and shot him down.
vi: About three months ago, my cousin Bud, who was only fourteen years old, was riding a horse in the forest across the river. He didn't carry any weapons with him, which was so foolish. While he was in a deserted spot, he heard the sound of a horse behind him. Turning around, he saw old Baldy Shepherdson chasing him, holding a gun, with his white hair blowing in the wind. Instead of jumping aside and running into the forest, Bud just kept riding his horse forward. So the two of them kept chasing each other for more than five miles. The old man kept trying to get ahead but couldn't. Finally, Bud saw that it was useless, so he stopped his horse so that if he had to take a bullet, it would be from the front, you understand. So the old man got ahead and shot him dead.
tr: About three months ago, my fourteen-year-old cousin Bud was crossing the forest on the other side of the river on horseback. The damn fool didn’t even take a weapon with him. In a desolate place, he heard a horse coming from behind and when he looked back, he realized that old Baldy Shepherdson, with his white hair flying in the wind, was chasing him with a rifle in his hand; instead of dismounting and hiding in the bushes, he spurred his horse, calculating that he could escape; they started going like this, for about five miles, but the old man was getting closer; finally, Bud was desperate and, thinking he might as well take the bullet from the front, stopped and turned his horse around. The old man caught up with him and shot him from behind.
es: About three months ago my cousin Bud, who was fourteen years old. He was going through the forest on the other side of the river and he wasn't carrying any weapons, which is foolish, and when he was in a lonely place he heard a horse coming from behind and saw old Baldy Shepherdson chasing him with a shotgun in his hand and his white hair flowing in the wind, and instead of jumping off the horse and running, Bud thought he could go faster, so the chase continued for five miles or more and the old man was gaining more ground each time; finally Bud saw that it wasn't worth it and he stopped and faced him so the wounds would be from the front, you know, and the old man caught up to him and killed him.

en: But he didn’t git much chance to enjoy his luck, for inside of a week our folks laid him out.”
vi: But then the old man wasn't lucky for long, because within a week, the people from our side sent him to his maker.
tr: But he didn’t get a chance to rejoice in his fate, because within a week, our folks took care of him too.”
es: But he didn't have much time to enjoy his luck, because in less than a week ours killed him.

en: “I reckon that old man was a coward, Buck.”
vi: - I made that old man a coward, Buck
tr: “That old man was a coward, Buck.”
es: —For me, that old man was a coward, Buck.

en: “I reckon he warn’t a coward.
vi: - No, he's not a coward.
tr: “No, brother, I don't think he was a coward at all.
es: —Well, to me he wasn't a coward.

en: Not by a blame’ sight.
vi: Just look at him and you'll know.
tr: No one can say that about him.
es: Not at all.

en: There ain’t a coward amongst them Shepherdsons—not a one.
vi: Among the Shepherdsons, there's no one who's cowardly.
tr: There are no cowards among the Shepherdsons – not a single one.
es: There isn't a single Shepherdson who is a coward; not one.

en: And there ain’t no cowards amongst the Grangerfords either.
vi: And in the Grangerford family, there's no one who's cowardly either.
tr: There are no cowards among the Grangerfords either.
es: And there isn't a single Grangerford who is a coward either.

en: Why, that old man kep’ up his end in a fight one day for half an hour against three Grangerfords, and come out winner.
vi: You know, one day that old man fought against four Grangerford men for half an hour and in the end, he won the battle.
tr: That old man fought three Grangerfords for half an hour in a skirmish and won.
es: But once that old man held his own in a half-hour fight against three Grangerfords and he won.

en: They was all a-horseback; he lit off of his horse and got behind a little woodpile, and kep’ his horse before him to stop the bullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and capered around the old man, and peppered away at him, and he peppered away at them.
vi: They were all on horseback, he jumped off his horse and hid behind a pile of wood, using his horse as a shield. The Grangerford men stayed on their horses, surrounding him and aiming to shoot. He shot back at them too.
tr: They were all on horseback; the old man got off his horse and took cover behind a small pile of wood, using his horse as a shield against the bullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and circled around him, shooting at him, and he fired back.
es: They were all on horseback; he dismounted and took cover behind some wood and put his horse in front so the bullets would hit it instead of him; but the Grangerfords kept circling the old man on horseback, shooting at him and he shooting back at them.

en: Him and his horse both went home pretty leaky and crippled, but the Grangerfords had to be fetched home—and one of ’em was dead, and another died the next day.
vi: After that, both he and his horse managed to get home, covered in blood, limping; but the Grangerford men had to be carried back. One died immediately, and another died the next day.
tr: Both he and his horse returned bleeding and injured, but the Grangerfords had to be carried home on stretchers – one of them was dead and the other died the next day.
es: He and his horse came home pretty banged up and full of holes, but the Grangerfords had to be carried home, one of them dead, and another died the next day.

en: No, sir; if a body’s out hunting for cowards he don’t want to fool away any time amongst them Shepherdsons, becuz they don’t breed any of that kind.”
vi: No, sir, if the battlefield were filled with cowards, they would never dare to confront the Grangerfords; and no one would keep such people around either.
tr: No sir, if you're looking for a coward, I say don't waste any time trying to find one among the Shepherdsons, because you'll never find a coward or a weakling among them.”
es: No, sir; if anyone is looking for cowards, they shouldn't waste their time with the Shepherdsons, because they don't breed those.

en: Next Sunday we all went to church, about three mile, everybody a-horseback.
vi: That Sunday, we went to church, which was about three or five miles from home. Everyone went on horseback.
tr: Next Sunday, we all rode horses to the church about three miles away.
es: The following Sunday we all went to church, about three miles away, all on horseback.

en: The men took their guns along, so did Buck, and kept them between their knees or stood them handy against the wall.
vi: Each person carried a gun, including Buck. Buck kept his gun on his thigh or leaned it against the wall within arm's reach.
tr: The men took their rifles with them, and Buck went with his gun too. They all kept their rifles between their knees or leaned them against the wall nearby.
es: The men took their shotguns, and Buck did too, and they kept them between their knees or left them handy leaning against the wall.

en: The Shepherdsons done the same.
vi: But the Shepherdsons did the same.
tr: The Shepherdsons did the same thing.
es: The Shepherdsons did the same: it was a most ordinary sermon: all about brotherly love and nonsense like that; but everyone said it was a good sermon and talked about it on the way back, and they had so much to say about faith and good works and sanctifying grace and predestination and I don't know what else that it seemed to me one of the worst Sundays of my life.

en: It was pretty ornery preaching—all about brotherly love, and such-like tiresomeness; but everybody said it was a good sermon, and they all talked it over going home, and had such a powerful lot to say about faith and good works and free grace and preforeordestination, and I don’t know what all, that it did seem to me to be one of the roughest Sundays I had run across yet.
vi: It was really just outward prayer, talking about loving each other like brothers, and other phrases like that, which made me sick to hear, but then everyone said that praying like that was very good, and even on the way back home, they kept saying the same, talking a lot about loyalty, goodness, and other things I didn't even understand. And I felt that this was one of the most boring Sundays I had ever experienced.
tr: The sermon was quite ordinary – the preacher kept talking about brotherly love and such, but everyone liked the sermon. On the way home, the sermon was discussed; everyone had a lot to say about faith, doing good deeds, grace, predestination by God, and many other topics. It felt like one of the hardest Sundays I had ever spent.
es: The Shepherdsons did the same: it was a most ordinary sermon: all about brotherly love and nonsense like that; but everyone said it was a good sermon and talked about it on the way back, and they had so much to say about faith and good works and sanctifying grace and predestination and I don't know what else that it seemed to me one of the worst Sundays of my life.

en: About an hour after dinner everybody was dozing around, some in their chairs and some in their rooms, and it got to be pretty dull.
vi: About an hour after lunch, everyone dispersed. Some sat on chairs, some went to their private rooms, and the atmosphere was really dull.
tr: About an hour after the meal, while some were dozing in their armchairs and others in their rooms, I felt a deep sense of boredom.
es: About an hour after eating, everyone was taking a nap, some in their chairs and others in their rooms, and it was all very boring.

en: Buck and a dog was stretched out on the grass in the sun sound asleep.
vi: Buck, with a dog, lay sprawled on the porch sleeping under the sun.
tr: Buck and a dog had sprawled out on the grass under the sun and had fallen into a deep sleep.
es: Buck and a dog were lying on the grass in the sun, sleeping like logs.

en: I went up to our room, and judged I would take a nap myself.
vi: I also went up to my room and thought I should take a nap.
tr: I decided to go up to our room and take a nap.
es: I went up to our room thinking about taking a nap too.

en: I found that sweet Miss Sophia standing in her door, which was next to ours, and she took me in her room and shut the door very soft, and asked me if I liked her, and I said I did; and she asked me if I would do something for her and not tell anybody, and I said I would.
vi: Teacher Sophia, kind-hearted, was standing at the door next to our room. She pulled me into her private room, gently closed the door, and asked if I liked her. I said I did. She asked me to do her a favor and not to tell anyone. I said okay.
tr: I saw sweet Miss Sophia at the door of her room, which was right next to ours; she took me into her room and, after very slowly closing the door, asked if I liked her. Of course, I did; if that was the case, could I do something for her and keep my mouth shut? Of course, I could.
es: I saw the lovely Miss Sophia standing at her door, which was next to ours, and she made me come into her room, closed the door quietly and asked me if I loved her, and I answered yes, and she asked me if I would do her a favor without telling anyone and I said yes.

en: Then she said she’d forgot her Testament, and left it in the seat at church between two other books, and would I slip out quiet and go there and fetch it to her, and not say nothing to nobody.
vi: Then she said she had left the Bible on the church bench along with two other books, and asked me to quietly go out and fetch them for her; and remember not to tell anyone.
tr: Then she said she had forgotten her Holy Bible, which was left between two other books at the place where she sat in church. She wanted me to go there quietly, retrieve the book, and bring it to her without telling anyone.
es: Then she told me that she had forgotten the New Testament and had left it on the church pew between two other books, and if I would quietly go out and fetch it for her without telling anyone.

en: I said I would.
vi: I said okay, I'll go get them for you.
tr: I said I would go and get the book.
es: I said yes.

en: So I slid out and slipped off up the road, and there warn’t anybody at the church, except maybe a hog or two, for there warn’t any lock on the door, and hogs likes a puncheon floor in summer-time because it’s cool.
vi: I sneaked out of the house and ran straight there. There was no one in the church, maybe just a few pigs. Because the church door was not closed, and in the summer, pigs liked the high wooden floor in the church, which was cooler.
tr: I slipped out quietly and set off. There was no one left in the church, only a couple of pigs, because there was no lock on the door and pigs like to lie on the wooden floor in the summer because it's cool.
es: So I quietly walked down the path and in the church there was no one, except maybe a pig or two, because the door had no lock and pigs like the packed dirt floors in summer, because they are cool.

en: If you notice, most folks don’t go to church only when they’ve got to; but a hog is different.
vi: If you pay attention, you'll see; many people only stop going to church when they absolutely can't, but pigs are different.
tr: If you notice, people don't go to church unless they have to, but pigs are not like that.
es: If you notice, almost no one goes to church except when it's mandatory, but pigs are different.

en: Says I to myself, something’s up; it ain’t natural for a girl to be in such a sweat about a Testament.
vi: I told myself that there must be something going on. A girl getting all worked up about forgetting a Bible like this is not natural.
tr: I had realized something was going on – it wasn't natural for a girl to get so worked up over a Holy Bible; when I shook the book, a small piece of paper fell out.
es: I said to myself: "Something's up; it's not natural for a girl to be so concerned about a New Testament," so I shook it and a small piece of paper with a pencil-written note fell out: "At half-past two."

en: So I give it a shake, and out drops a little piece of paper with “Half-past two” wrote on it with a pencil.
vi: I shook the book, and a small piece of paper with pencil writing fell out, reading "Two thirty."
tr: On the paper, written in pencil, were the words "half past two."
es: I said to myself: "Something's up; it's not natural for a girl to be so concerned about a New Testament," so I shook it and a small piece of paper with a pencil-written note fell out: "At half-past two."

en: I ransacked it, but couldn’t find anything else.
vi: I searched again, but found nothing else.
tr: I thoroughly flipped through the book, but found nothing else.
es: I kept looking but didn't find anything else.

en: I couldn’t make anything out of that, so I put the paper in the book again, and when I got home and upstairs there was Miss Sophia in her door waiting for me.
vi: I couldn't figure out what it was, so I put the piece of paper back. When I returned home, I went upstairs and saw Sophia still waiting for me at the door.
tr: I didn't understand anything, so I put the paper back into the book; when I reached home and climbed the stairs, I saw Sophia waiting for me at the door.
es: That didn't tell me anything, so I put the paper back in the book and when I got home and went up the stairs, Miss Sophia was at her door waiting for me.

en: She pulled me in and shut the door; then she looked in the Testament till she found the paper, and as soon as she read it she looked glad; and before a body could think she grabbed me and give me a squeeze, and said I was the best boy in the world, and not to tell anybody.
vi: She pulled me in, closed the door, then found the piece of paper in the book, and after reading it, she seemed delighted. Suddenly, before I could think of anything, she grabbed my hand and told me I was the best boy in the world, and asked me not to tell anyone.
tr: She immediately pulled me inside and closed the door; then she started flipping through the Holy Bible and was delighted when she found the paper; before I could say anything, she hugged me tightly and said I was the best kid in the world, then reminded me again not to tell anyone.
es: She made me come in and closed the door; then she searched the New Testament until she found the paper, and as soon as she read it, she seemed very happy; and before one could realize it, she grabbed me and gave me a hug saying that I was the best boy in the world and that I shouldn't tell anyone.

en: She was mighty red in the face for a minute, and her eyes lighted up, and it made her powerful pretty.
vi: She blushed for a moment, her eyes brightened, and at that moment, she looked incredibly beautiful.
tr: For a moment, she turned bright red and her eyes sparkled, truthfully, she had become very beautiful.
es: Her face turned very red for a moment, her eyes lit up, and she looked very pretty.

en: I was a good deal astonished, but when I got my breath I asked her what the paper was about, and she asked me if I had read it, and I said no, and she asked me if I could read writing, and I told her “no, only coarse-hand,” and then she said the paper warn’t anything but a book-mark to keep her place, and I might go and play now.
vi: I was surprised, but after calming down, I asked what the piece of paper was about. She asked if I had read the writing, I said no, I had just started learning to write, and she said that the piece of paper was just a bookmark for where she had left off reading, then told me I could go outside and play.
tr: I was all flustered, but then managed to catch my breath and asked what was written on the paper. She then asked me if I had read what was written on the paper, I said no, and then she asked if I could read handwriting, I said I could only read newspaper print; she then said there was nothing important on the paper, that she had just put it in the book to keep the page, and that I could go play now.
es: I was very astonished, but when I caught my breath, I asked her what the paper said, and she asked if I had read it, and when I said no, she asked if I knew how to read manuscripts and I replied that I could only read print, and then she said that the paper was just to mark how far she had read and that I could go play now.

en: I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind.
vi: I went down to the riverbank, thinking about this matter. Suddenly, I saw my black friend following behind.
tr: As I was thinking about this issue and heading towards the river, I realized that my black man had followed me.
es: I went down to the river thinking about all that, and right away I realized that my black man was following me.

en: When we was out of sight of the house he looked back and around a second, and then comes a-running, and says:
vi: When we reached a hidden spot out of sight from the house, he turned back for a second, then ran to me and said:
tr: Once the house was out of sight, he looked around for a moment, then ran up to me and said:
es: When we lost sight of the house, he looked back and all around for a second, and then he came running and said to me:

en: “Mars Jawge, if you’ll come down into de swamp I’ll show you a whole stack o’ water-moccasins.”
vi: - George, if you go down to the pond over there, I'll show you a bunch of otters.
tr: "Master Geooge, you come with me to the swamp, I show you a very poisonous snake.""
es: —George, if you come to the swamp, I'll show you a bunch of water snakes.

en: Thinks I, that’s mighty curious; he said that yesterday.
vi: I thought to myself, how strange, he mentioned that yesterday.
tr: This was very strange, because he had said the same thing yesterday.
es: It seemed very curious to me; he had said the same thing yesterday.

en: He oughter know a body don’t love water-moccasins enough to go around hunting for them.
vi: He also knows that no one really likes otters and no one hunts them either.
tr: He should have understood that I wasn't curious enough about poisonous snakes to go looking for them.
es: He had to know that one doesn't like water snakes enough to go see them.

en: What is he up to, anyway?
vi: But why did he say that?
tr: I wonder what his true intention was?
es: What could he be looking for?

en: So I says:
vi: I asked;
tr: “Okay, let's go,” I said.
es: So I said to him:

en: “All right; trot ahead.”
vi: - Alright, you go ahead
tr: “Okay, let's go,” I said.
es: —Alright; you go ahead.

en: I followed a half a mile; then he struck out over the swamp, and waded ankle deep as much as another half-mile.
vi: I followed him for half a mile, then turned towards the pond, having to wade through ankle-deep water for another half mile: we reached a flat area that was both high and dry, with many trees, bushes, and even some grass.
tr: I followed him for about half a mile, then we entered the swamp and walked for another half mile through water that reached our ankles.
es: I followed him for half a mile; then he reached the swamp and waded through it with water up to his ankles for another half mile.

en: We come to a little flat piece of land which was dry and very thick with trees and bushes and vines, and he says:
vi: He said:
tr: He led me to a small clearing covered with dry and dense trees and bushes.
es: We arrived at a piece of flat, dry land, full of trees, bushes, and ivy, and he said to me:

en: “You shove right in dah jist a few steps, Mars Jawge; dah’s whah dey is.
vi: - George, please step a few steps further inside.
tr: “Just go that way, taking a few steps is enough, Master George, it's all there, I've seen it before, even if I haven't seen it alone.”
es: —Take a few steps in there, George; that's where they are.

en: I’s seed ’m befo’; I don’t k’yer to see ’em no mo’.”
vi: It's in there. I've seen it before, I don't need to look again now.
tr: “Just go that way, taking a few steps is enough, Master George, it's all there, I've seen it before, even if I haven't seen it alone.”
es: I've already seen enough of them.

en: Then he slopped right along and went away, and pretty soon the trees hid him.
vi: After speaking, he immediately ran away and disappeared behind a cluster of trees.
tr: Then he continued on his way and moved away, and a little later he disappeared behind the trees.
es: Then he moved away and was immediately covered by the trees.

en: I poked into the place a-ways and come to a little open patch as big as a bedroom all hung around with vines, and found a man laying there asleep—and, by jings, it was my old Jim!
vi: I stepped inside, to an open space about the size of a room, surrounded by grape leaves, and suddenly saw someone sleeping there. Oh my God, it turned out to be my Jim!
tr: When I proceeded to the place he mentioned, I discovered a clearing the size of a bedroom, completely surrounded by bushes and vines, where a man was sleeping – guess who it was, none other than our big Jim!
es: I wandered around there until I reached an open spot, about the size of a bedroom, all surrounded by ivy, and there I saw a man who was asleep; and by all the devils, it was my old Jim!

en: I waked him up, and I reckoned it was going to be a grand surprise to him to see me again, but it warn’t.
vi: I woke Jim up, and I guessed that when he saw me, he would be terrified again.
tr: When I woke him up, I thought he would be astonished to see me, but that was not the case at all.
es: I woke him up and thought he would be very surprised to see me, but he wasn't.

en: He nearly cried he was so glad, but he warn’t surprised.
vi: But no. He was just so happy he was nearly crying, without being surprised at all.
tr: He was almost about to cry, he was very happy, but he was definitely not astonished.
es: He almost cried with joy, but he wasn't surprised.

en: Said he swum along behind me that night, and heard me yell every time, but dasn’t answer, because he didn’t want nobody to pick him up and take him into slavery again.
vi: He recounted that that night he swam after me and heard me call out a few times but didn't respond, because he was afraid someone would recognize him and take him back to be a slave again.
tr: That night he told me that he swam behind me and heard me calling, but he didn't respond because he didn't want anyone to rescue him and enslave him again.
es: He said he had swum behind me that night and had heard all my screams, but he hadn't dared to respond because he didn't want anyone to pick him up and return him to slavery.

en: Says he:
vi: He said:
tr: “My throat was a bit sore, so I couldn't swim fast,” he said, “I stayed quite far behind you.
es: And he continued saying:

en: “I got hurt a little, en couldn’t swim fas’, so I wuz a considable ways behine you towards de las’; when you landed I reck’ned I could ketch up wid you on de lan’ ’dout havin’ to shout at you, but when I see dat house I begin to go slow.
vi: - I was in a bit of pain so I couldn't swim fast, and you left me far behind. When you got ashore, I thought I could catch up with you on land without having to call out. But when I saw that building, I started to slow down.
tr: Since you climbed onto the rock, I thought I could catch up to you without calling out, but when I saw that house, I immediately slowed down.
es: —I hurt myself a bit and couldn't swim fast, so towards the end I was already very far from you; when you reached the shore, I calculated that I could catch up to you without having to shout, but when I saw that house, I started to go slower.

en: I ’uz off too fur to hear what dey say to you—I wuz ’fraid o’ de dogs; but when it ’uz all quiet agin, I knowed you’s in de house, so I struck out for de woods to wait for day.
vi: I stood far away so I couldn't hear what they were saying to you; I was also afraid of the pack of dogs. When everything went quiet, I knew you had gone inside that house. So I went out into the forest and waited for you all day.
tr: I couldn't hear what they said to you, because I was far away… and I was also afraid of the dogs… but eventually the situation calmed down and I realized you had gone into the house. I waited inside the bushes for the dawn to break.
es: I was too far away to hear what they were saying to you; I was scared of the dogs, but when everything went quiet again, I understood that you were in the house, so I went to the forest to wait for dawn.

en: Early in de mawnin’ some er de niggers come along, gwyne to de fields, en dey tuk me en showed me dis place, whah de dogs can’t track me on accounts o’ de water, en dey brings me truck to eat every night, en tells me how you’s a-gitt’n along.”
vi: Early the next morning, some black people going to work in the fields found me and showed me this hiding spot. This place has a water pond separating it from the inside, so the dogs can't catch the scent. Every night, they bring me some food, and they tell me about how you are doing in there.
tr: Some black people were going to the fields early in the morning, they signaled to me and showed me the well. Because there was water in the well, the dogs couldn't find me; at night, the black people brought me food and told me in detail how you were doing.”
es: Early in the morning, some of the black people who were going to the fields arrived and took me with them and brought me here, where the dogs can't find me thanks to the water, and they bring me food every night and tell me how you are doing.

en: “Why didn’t you tell my Jack to fetch me here sooner, Jim?”
vi: - Why didn't you tell Jack to bring me out here earlier, Jim?
tr: “Jim, why didn't you tell my nigger Jack to bring me here earlier?” I said.
es: —But why didn't you tell my Jack to bring me earlier, Jim?

en: “Well, ’twarn’t no use to ’sturb you, Huck, tell we could do sumfn—but we’s all right now.
vi: - Didn't want to bother you, Huck. You said you couldn't do anything, but now I'm relieved.
tr: "There was no need to bother you, Huck. We couldn't do anything anyway. But now things have changed.
es: —Well, it wasn't worth bothering you, Huck, until we could do something, but now it's fine.

en: I ben a-buyin’ pots en pans en vittles, as I got a chanst, en a-patchin’ up de raf’ nights when—”
vi: I've bought pots, pans, and enough food.
tr: Whenever I get the chance, I buy pots, pans, and food, and at night I fix the raft..."
es: I've been buying gadgets and food whenever I could and fixing the raft at night when...

en: “What raft, Jim?”
vi: How fortunate. Every night I sneak out to patch up the raft, I... - Well, Jim?
tr: "Which raft, Jim?"
es: —What raft, Jim?

en: “Our ole raf’.”
vi: - Our old pond
tr: "Come here, my little lamb.""
es: —Our old raft.

en: “You mean to say our old raft warn’t smashed all to flinders?”
vi: - So, does that mean our raft didn't get destroyed?
tr: “No way, I mean didn't our raft break into pieces?”
es: —Are you going to tell me that our old raft didn't end up in pieces?

en: “No, she warn’t.
vi: - No, not at all.
tr: “No, it didn't work.
es: —No, after that.

en: She was tore up a good deal—one en’ of her was; but dey warn’t no great harm done, on’y our traps was mos’ all los’.
vi: It only broke partially. One end is still intact, nothing happened to it.
tr: A lot of things broke, one side was very bad, but there wasn't a big damage, just almost all of our belongings are gone.
es: It was quite damaged on one end, but nothing serious happened, we just lost almost all the traps.

en: Ef we hadn’ dive’ so deep en swum so fur under water, en de night hadn’ ben so dark, en we warn’t so sk’yerd, en ben sich punkin-heads, as de sayin’ is, we’d a seed de raf’.
vi: If we hadn't dived too deep, if that night we had been a bit braver instead of scared as the saying goes, we could have kept the raft.
tr: We dived very deep, then swam very far underwater, also it was very dark that night, we were very scared and a bit foolish, otherwise we would have already been saved.
es: And if we hadn't dived so much and swum so far underwater, if the night hadn't been so dark, we wouldn't have been so scared or so nervous, as they say, we would have seen the raft.

en: But it’s jis’ as well we didn’t, ’kase now she’s all fixed up agin mos’ as good as new, en we’s got a new lot o’ stuff, in de place o’ what ’uz los’.”
vi: But don't worry, because now it's almost as good as new, and we have a bunch of other things too, right where we lost them.
tr: Actually, it was better that we didn't get saved, the raft is now brand new and we got a lot of new things instead of the ones we lost.”
es: But it's better this way, because now it's all fixed and practically new and we have lots of new things instead of the ones we lost.

en: “Why, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim—did you catch her?”
vi: - How did you manage to find the raft, Jim, did you chase after it?
tr: “So how did you find the raft again, Jim... Did you pull it to shore yourself?” “There was no need to catch him, he was already in the forest.
es: —But, how did you manage to get the raft back, Jim? Did you go to catch it?

en: “How I gwyne to ketch her en I out in de woods?
vi: - How could I chase after it while lying in this forest?
tr: A few of the blacks found him stuck in the trees by the bend below, and then they hid him in a cave by the willow grove.
es: —How am I going to catch it if I'm in the forest?

en: No; some er de niggers foun’ her ketched on a snag along heah in de ben’, en dey hid her in a crick ’mongst de willows, en dey wuz so much jawin’ ’bout which un ’um she b’long to de mos’ dat I come to heah ’bout it pooty soon, so I ups en settles de trouble by tellin’ ’um she don’t b’long to none uv um, but to you en me; en I ast ’m if dey gwyne to grab a young white genlman’s propaty, en git a hid’n for it?
vi: No, my friend, some of the guys found it stuck in a nearby field. They hid it in a hollow under a willow bush, then they argued and debated for a long time about whose raft it was. Just at that moment, I came over and told them that the raft didn't belong to anyone, but to you and me. I asked if they intended to take the property of an upper-class white man by hiding it like that.
tr: They argued so much about who the raft belonged to that eventually I heard about it, and I decided that the raft didn’t belong to any of them, but to you and me. I asked them what it meant to take and then hide a white man's property.
es: No; some of the black men found it stuck between some rocks there at the bend and hid it in a stream among the willows, and they argued so much about who was going to keep it that I found out right away, so I solved the problem by telling them it wasn't any of theirs, but yours and mine; and I asked them if they were going to keep the property of a young white gentleman, only to get a few lashes.

en: Den I gin ’m ten cents apiece, en dey ’uz mighty well satisfied, en wisht some mo’ raf’s ’ud come along en make ’m rich agin.
vi: Then I gave each of them a dime; everyone was very satisfied. Then I told them that if any other rafts floated by, they would get more money.
tr: Then I gave each of them ten cents, they were all very happy and wished that more rafts would get stuck in the trees, so they could get rich too.
es: Then I gave each of them ten cents and they were very satisfied, thinking they hoped more rafts would come so they could get rich again.

en: Dey’s mighty good to me, dese niggers is, en whatever I wants ’m to do fur me, I doan’ have to ast ’m twice, honey.
vi: They treated me very well, my friend! But those black guys, you know. Whenever I needed their help, I didn't have to ask twice, my friend.
tr: These blacks treated me very well, they didn’t refuse me anything, my dear.
es: These black men treat me very well, and when I want them to do something I don't have to ask them twice, my boy.
