en: Dat Jack’s a good nigger, en pooty smart.”
vi: That guy Jack is a good black man, and he's quite quick too.
tr: That Jack is also a very good black man, and very smart too.”
es: That Jack is a good black man, and smart.

en: “Yes, he is.
vi: - Yes, he's good.
tr: “It really is so.
es: —Yes, it's true.

en: He ain’t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and he’d show me a lot of water-moccasins.
vi: He never told me that you were here. He told me to come here so he could show me the otters.
tr: He didn't even tell me you were here; he just told me to come, that he would show me a bunch of poisonous snakes.
es: He never told me that you were here; he told me to come and that he would show me a bunch of water snakes.

en: If anything happens he ain’t mixed up in it.
vi: If anything happens, he won't be implicated.
tr: If any trouble arises, he can easily say he had no part in it.
es: If something happens, he has nothing to do with it.

en: He can say he never seen us together, and it’ll be the truth.”
vi: He can say that he has never seen us together, and people will believe it.
tr: If he says he never saw them together, he wouldn't be lying.”
es: He can say that he has never seen us together, and he will be telling the truth.

en: I don’t want to talk much about the next day.
vi: I don't want to talk much about what happened the next day.
tr: I don't want to say too much about the next day.
es: I don't want to say much about the next day.

en: I reckon I’ll cut it pretty short.
vi: I'll just briefly recount it like this: I woke up at dawn, intending to go back to sleep when I suddenly noticed it was very quiet, as if no one was stirring at all.
tr: It's probably best to keep it short.
es: I think I'm going to summarize it.

en: I waked up about dawn, and was a-going to turn over and go to sleep again, when I noticed how still it was—didn’t seem to be anybody stirring.
vi: I'll just briefly recount it like this: I woke up at dawn, intending to go back to sleep when I suddenly noticed it was very quiet, as if no one was stirring at all.
tr: I woke up at dawn, intending to turn over and go back to sleep, but suddenly I noticed how quiet everything was – there was no sign of movement.
es: I woke up around dawn and was about to turn over to go back to sleep when I noticed that there wasn't a sound; it was as if nothing was moving.

en: That warn’t usual.
vi: That was a bit unusual.
tr: I was not used to this at all.
es: That wasn't normal.

en: Next I noticed that Buck was up and gone.
vi: Then I saw that Buck had gotten up and left at some point. I jumped up, feeling strange, and went downstairs. There was no one there.
tr: I saw that Buck had also gotten up and left.
es: Then I saw that Buck had gotten up and left.

en: Well, I gets up, a-wondering, and goes down stairs—nobody around; everything as still as a mouse.
vi: Everything was silent.
tr: So I got up and went downstairs, wondering what was going on – there was no one around; not a sound from anywhere.
es: Well, then I got up, puzzled, and went down the stairs, and there was no one; everything was quieter than a grave.

en: Just the same outside.
vi: It was the same outside.
tr: It was the same outside.
es: The same outside.

en: Thinks I, what does it mean?
vi: I didn't understand what was going on.
tr: I wondered what this could mean.
es: I thought: "What does this mean?"

en: Down by the wood-pile I comes across my Jack, and says:
vi: Stepping out to the woodpile, I went to ask Jack:
tr: I ran into our Jack by the woodpile.
es: Where the firewood was, I found my Jack and asked him:

en: “What’s it all about?”
vi: - What's going on?
tr: “What is happening?” I asked.
es: —What's happening?

en: Says he:
vi: He replied:
tr: "Don't you know, Master George?" he said.
es: He answered me:

en: “Don’t you know, Mars Jawge?”
vi: - You don't know?
tr: “No, I don't know.”
es: —Don't you know, Mr. George?

en: “No,” says I, “I don’t.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: “No, I don't know.”
es: —No. I don't know anything.

en: “Well, den, Miss Sophia’s run off!
vi: Miss Sophia, she has run away.
tr: “Sophia has run away!
es: —Well, Miss Sophia has run away!

en: ’deed she has.
vi: She really has run away.
tr: Yes, she eloped.
es: It's the honest truth.

en: She run off in de night some time—nobody don’t know jis’ when; run off to get married to dat young Harney Shepherdson, you know—leastways, so dey ’spec.
vi: She ran away in the middle of the night, no one knew. She ran away to marry that guy Harney Shepherdsons, you know.
tr: She ran away at night, but no one knows the exact time. And she ran away with that young Harney Shepherdson...
es: She ran away last night and nobody knows at what time; she ran away to marry that young Harney Shepherdson, you know... at least that's what they believe.

en: De fambly foun’ it out ’bout half an hour ago—maybe a little mo’—en’ I tell you dey warn’t no time los’.
vi: That's what people are saying. The family just found out about half an hour ago, maybe less, and they rushed off immediately.
tr: At least that's what they say. The family noticed it about an hour ago – maybe a little earlier – and didn't waste any time.
es: The family found out about half an hour ago, maybe a bit more, and I assure you they haven't wasted any time; you've never seen such a rush to grab guns and horses in your life!

en: Sich another hurryin’ up guns en hosses you never see!
vi: This time it was a real rush, with guns and horses clattering like never before.
tr: They all grabbed their rifles like lightning and mounted their horses!
es: The family found out about half an hour ago, maybe a bit more, and I assure you they haven't wasted any time; you've never seen such a rush to grab guns and horses in your life!

en: De women folks has gone for to stir up de relations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de river road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him ’fo’ he kin git acrost de river wid Miss Sophia.
vi: The men have gone around notifying all the relatives. Old man Saul and some of the guys took guns to the riverbank to kill that guy, because it's very likely he took Miss Sophia across the river.
tr: The women went to inform the neighbors, and old man Saul and his sons took their rifles and went after the runaways along the river. They want to catch up with the young man and Miss Sophia while they are still on this side of the river and kill the young man.
es: The women have gone to fetch relatives, old Mr. Saul and the boys have taken the guns and hit the road to try to catch that young man and kill him before he can cross the river with Miss Sophia.

en: I reck’n dey’s gwyne to be mighty rough times.”
vi: I guess there might be a lot of trouble coming up.
tr: It looks like all hell is going to break loose soon.”
es: I think very bad times are coming.

en: “Buck went off ’thout waking me up.”
vi: - Why didn't Buck wake up and call me?
tr: “Buck left without waking me up.”
es: —And Buck left without telling me anything.

en: “Well, I reck’n he did!
vi: - I'm sure he did it on purpose.
tr: “Eh, they did it!”
es: —Man, of course!

en: Dey warn’t gwyne to mix you up in it.
vi: They don't want you to get involved in this matter.
tr: “They didn’t want you to get involved in this job.”
es: They weren't going to involve you in that.

en: Mars
vi: Buck loaded his gun and said he was going to catch a Shepherdson.
tr: “They didn’t want you to get involved in this job.”
es: Mr. Buck loaded the shotgun and said he would come back home with a dead Shepherdson.

en: Buck he loaded up his gun en ’lowed he’s gwyne to fetch home a Shepherdson or bust.
vi: Buck loaded his gun and said he was going to catch a Shepherdson.
tr: “Mr. Buck loaded his gun and said he would rather die than bring a Shepherdson home while going.”
es: Mr. Buck loaded the shotgun and said he would come back home with a dead Shepherdson.

en: Well, dey’ll be plenty un ’m dah, I reck’n, en you bet you he’ll fetch one ef he gits a chanst.”
vi: There are a lot of them on the other side, I'm sure of it. Do you think he might manage to capture one?
tr: “Honestly, if he had the chance, he might have really brought one of the Shepherdsons.””
es: Well, surely there will be many of them and he will bring one if he gets the chance.

en: I took up the river road as hard as I could put.
vi: I ran quickly to the riverbank.
tr: I ran at full speed towards the river road.
es: I started running along the river path as fast as I could.

en: By-and-by I begin to hear guns a good ways off.
vi: After a while, I heard gunshots all around.
tr: After a while, I heard gunshots from afar.
es: Soon I began to hear gunshots quite far away.

en: When I come in sight of the log store and the woodpile where the steamboats lands, I worked along under the trees and brush till I got to a good place, and then I clumb up into the forks of a cottonwood that was out of reach, and watched.
vi: When I reached the wooden shack near the ferry dock, I looked around the trees for a hidden spot to hide, then I climbed up a tree branch out of gun range to observe.
tr: When I saw the log depot where the steamships docked and the piles of wood, I found a good spot for myself by hiding among the trees and bushes, then climbed up a poplar tree and sat on a fork high enough to be unreachable from below, and started watching what was happening.
es: When I reached the log warehouse and the pile of firewood where the steamboats dock, I started moving under the trees and bushes until I found a good spot, and then I climbed up a poplar cross where the bullets couldn't reach, and I looked.

en: There was a wood-rank four foot high a little ways in front of the tree, and first I was going to hide behind that; but maybe it was luckier I didn’t.
vi: There was a pile of wood stacked nearly two meters high nearby, and I planned to run there to hide behind it, thinking it might be safer.
tr: A little further from the tree, there was a pile of wood about a meter high, and at first, I thought of hiding there; maybe it was better that I didn't.
es: There was wood piled four feet high a little ahead of my tree, and at first I was going to hide behind it, but maybe it was lucky that I didn't.

en: There was four or five men cavorting around on their horses in the open place before the log store, cussing and yelling, and trying to get at a couple of young chaps that was behind the wood-rank alongside of the steamboat landing; but they couldn’t come it.
vi: Four or five horsemen were galloping around the open ground in front of the wooden shack. They were cursing and shouting, trying to catch two young men hiding behind the pile of wood along the ferry dock. But they couldn't get to them.
tr: Four or five mounted men were wandering around the open area in front of the timber depot, cursing and shouting; they were trying to get two young men hiding behind a stack of wood near the ship dock to come out, but the young men were not coming out.
es: In the open field in front of the log warehouse, there were four or five men circling on their horses, cursing and shouting, and trying to reach a couple of boys who were behind the pile of wood next to the landing, but they couldn't get there.

en: Every time one of them showed himself on the river side of the woodpile he got shot at.
vi: Every time one of the horsemen poked out towards the river, just a bit beyond the pile of wood, someone from the pile would shoot at them.
tr: As soon as one of the young men showed himself on the river side of the wood stack, the men would start shooting.
es: Every time one of them peeked out from the river side of the woodpile, they got shot.

en: The two boys was squatting back to back behind the pile, so they could watch both ways.
vi: The two young men were crouching, leaning against the back of the pile of wood, so they could control both the entrance and exit.
tr: The boys were crouched back to back behind the stack, and in this way, they could see both sides.
es: The two boys stood back to back behind the wood, so they could shoot in all directions.

en: By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling.
vi: After a while, they stopped running around and shouting.
tr: After a while, the men stopped shouting and yelling around.
es: A while passed and the men stopped circling and shouting.

en: They started riding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady bead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle.
vi: They headed towards the warehouse. Immediately, a boy stood up and fired a shot from the pile of wood, hitting one of the group who fell off his horse.
tr: They rode their horses towards the warehouse; at that moment, one of the boys stood up, took aim from the top of the woodpile, and shot one of the riders.
es: They started running towards the warehouse, and then one of the boys aimed steadily over the wood and knocked one of them off his horse.

en: All the men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started to carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the run.
vi: They quickly jumped off their horses to pick up the injured person and take him back to the warehouse, just as the other two boys started to run away.
tr: The men immediately dismounted and dragged the wounded one by the arm towards the warehouse; just then, two boys started to run away.
es: All the men dismounted from their horses, grabbed the injured man, and began carrying him towards the warehouse, and at that moment the two boys started running.

en: They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed.
vi: The two boys had run halfway from there to where I was hiding when suddenly the others saw them and immediately mounted their horses to give chase.
tr: The boys did not attract attention until they were halfway to the tree I was sitting on.
es: They were halfway to the tree where I was before the men noticed.

en: Then the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after them.
vi: The two boys had run halfway from there to where I was hiding when suddenly the others saw them and immediately mounted their horses to give chase.
tr: Then the men saw them, jumped on their horses, and chased after them.
es: Then they saw them and jumped on their horses and raced after them.

en: They gained on the boys, but it didn’t do no good, the boys had too good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my tree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men again.
vi: They almost caught up, but it was no use; the two boys ran very fast and quickly slipped into the pile of wood right in front of the tree where I was hiding. That gave them an advantage over the others.
tr: The men were coming fast, but they still couldn't catch up, because the boys were too far away; they reached the woodpile in front of my tree and took cover behind it again.
es: They were gaining ground on the boys, but it didn't help because the boys had a good lead; they reached the pile of wood in front of my tree and hid behind it, so they were protected from the men again.

en: One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap about nineteen years old.
vi: One of the two boys was Buck, while the other was a skinny boy about nineteen years old.
tr: One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slender young man around nineteen years old.
es: One of the boys was Buck and the other was a thin boy about nineteen years old.

en: The men ripped around awhile, and then rode away.
vi: Those people rummaged around for a while and then left.
tr: The men wandered around the area a bit more, then they left.
es: The men circled for a while and then left.

en: As soon as they was out of sight I sung out to Buck and told him.
vi: As soon as they were out of sight, I called out to Buck.
tr: As soon as they disappeared from sight, I informed Buck.
es: As soon as they were out of sight, I called Buck to see me.

en: He didn’t know what to make of my voice coming out of the tree at first.
vi: At first, he came out.
tr: At first, he couldn't understand why my voice was coming from a tree.
es: At first, he didn't understand why my voice was coming from a tree.

en: He was awful surprised.
vi: He was surprised and scared.
tr: He was very surprised.
es: He was very surprised.

en: He told me to watch out sharp and let him know when the men come in sight again; said they was up to some devilment or other—wouldn’t be gone long.
vi: Then he told me to keep a close watch and let him know if those people came back. He said those people had some sort of scheme and would definitely come back.
tr: He told me to keep my eyes wide open and to inform him if I saw the men again; they were certainly up to something – they wouldn't stay away for long.
es: He told me to stay very alert and to let him know when the men reappeared; he said they were up to something and wouldn't take long.

en: I wished I was out of that tree, but I dasn’t come down.
vi: I wanted to leave this tree, but I didn't dare to.
tr: I wished I wasn't at the top of the tree, I thought, but I didn't dare to come down either.
es: I preferred to leave that tree, but I didn't dare to come down.

en: Buck begun to cry and rip, and ’lowed that him and his cousin Joe (that was the other young chap) would make up for this day yet.
vi: Suddenly, Buck burst into tears and said that he and his cousin Joe (the one who ran with him) would have to keep hiding all day.
tr: Buck started to cry and lament, while also venting his anger; he said that he and his cousin Joe (that is, the other boy) would settle today's account.
es: Buck started shouting and cursing, and swore that he and his cousin Joe (who was the other boy) would get revenge that very day.

en: He said his father and his two brothers was killed, and two or three of the enemy.
vi: He said his father and two brothers were all killed, and that two or three people on the enemy's side were also killed.
tr: His father and two brothers had died, and they had taken care of two or three of the enemy.
es: He said they had killed his father and two brothers and that two or three of the enemies had died.

en: Said the Shepherdsons laid for them in ambush.
vi: He said the Shepherdsons had set up an ambush.
tr: It turned out that the Shepherdsons had lain in ambush waiting for them.
es: He said the Shepherdsons had ambushed them.

en: Buck said his father and brothers ought to waited for their relations—the Shepherdsons was too strong for them.
vi: He said his father and two brothers fought while waiting for their relatives to arrive, but the Shepherdsons were too strong.
tr: According to Buck, his father and brothers should have waited for their relatives – the Shepherdsons had turned out to be too strong.
es: Buck added that his father and brothers should have waited for their relatives because the Shepherdsons were too many for them.

en: I asked him what was become of young Harney and Miss Sophia.
vi: I asked what had happened to Harney and Miss Sophia.
tr: I asked what had happened to young Harney and Miss Sophia.
es: I asked him what was going to happen to young Harney and Miss Sophia.

en: He said they’d got across the river and was safe.
vi: He said the two had crossed the river to the other side and were safe.
tr: They had crossed the river and were safe.
es: He replied that they had already crossed the river and were safe.

en: I was glad of that; but the way Buck did take on because he didn’t manage to kill Harney that day he shot at him—I hain’t ever heard anything like it.
vi: I was very happy to hear that. But Buck wasn't; he was very upset thinking about how he couldn't kill Harney the other day in the forest. I had never seen anything like that before.
tr: I was glad about that; but Buck was grumbling that he hadn't finished Harney off when he fired that day – I had never heard him talk like that before.
es: I was glad, but Buck was furious for not having killed Harney the day he shot at him; in my life, I have never heard anyone say such things.

en: All of a sudden, bang!
vi: Bang!
tr: Suddenly, bam!
es: Suddenly, bang!

en: bang!
vi: Bang!
tr: bam! bam!
es: Suddenly, bang!

en: bang!
vi: Bang!
tr: bam! bam!
es: bang! bang!, three or four shotguns went off.

en: goes three or four guns—the men had slipped around through the woods and come in from behind without their horses!
vi: Three or four gunshots rang out. Both of them abandoned their horses and ran through the forest, sneaking up behind from who knows when.
tr: three or four rifles fired at once – the men had circled around us, gotten behind us, dismounted from their horses, and approached quietly!
es: The men had advanced together through the trees and were coming from behind with their horses!

en: The boys jumped for the river—both of them hurt—and as they swum down the current the men run along the bank shooting at them and singing out, “Kill them, kill them!”
vi: Both of them ran out and jumped into the river. Both of them were injured. And while the two of them swam downstream, the others ran to the riverbank and shot at them, shouting "Kill them, kill them."
tr: The children immediately jumped into the river – both were wounded.
es: The boys ran towards the river (both wounded), and while they swam downstream, the men ran along the bank shooting at them and shouting: "Kill them, kill them!"

en: It made me so sick I most fell out of the tree.
vi: I was so pained by what I heard that I almost fell from the tree.
tr: As they swam downstream, the men ran along the shore shooting at them, shouting, “Kill them, kill them!” I felt so bad that I almost fell from the tree.
es: I felt so bad that I almost fell out of the tree.

en: I ain’t a-going to tell all that happened—it would make me sick again if I was to do that.
vi: I dare not recount what happened afterward because it is too heartbreaking to speak of.
tr: I won’t tell you everything that happened – otherwise, I’ll feel bad again.
es: I'm not going to tell everything that happened because if I did, I would get sick again.

en: I wished I hadn’t ever come ashore that night to see such things.
vi: I think it would have been better if I hadn't gone to the riverbank that night to avoid witnessing those scenes.
tr: I keep thinking to myself, if only I hadn’t gone ashore that night, if only I hadn’t seen these things.
es: I would have preferred never to have reached the shore that night to see such things afterward.

en: I ain’t ever going to get shut of them—lots of times I dream about them.
vi: Later, I could never forget it; many times, I would dream about them in my sleep.
tr: The memory of them will never leave my mind – I’ve had many dreams about them.
es: I'm never going to forget them: I still dream about them many times.

en: I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down.
vi: I stayed up in the treetop until dusk, too scared to climb down.
tr: I stayed in the tree until it started to get dark; I was afraid to come down.
es: I stayed in the tree until it started to get dark because I was scared to come down.

en: Sometimes I heard guns away off in the woods; and twice I seen little gangs of men gallop past the log store with guns; so I reckoned the trouble was still a-going on.
vi: Occasionally, I still heard gunshots in the distant forest, and twice I clearly saw groups of armed horsemen passing by the wooden hut, and I guessed that the trouble was still ongoing.
tr: From time to time, I heard gunshots in the forest, far away; I also saw groups of horsemen passing by the log depot twice with rifles in their hands, so I thought the conflict was still ongoing.
es: Sometimes I heard gunshots in the distance, in the forest, and twice I saw groups of men galloping by the log warehouse with shotguns, so I figured the fight was still going on.

en: I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I was to blame, somehow.
vi: I was so terrified that I resolved never to return to that house again, and I thought that I wouldn't be blamed anyway.
tr: My heart was breaking, and I decided never to go near that house again because I thought it was my fault.
es: I felt so discouraged that I decided not to go near that house again because I thought that somehow it was my fault.

en: I judged that that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was to meet Harney somewheres at half-past two and run off; and I judged I ought to told her father about that paper and the curious way she acted, and then maybe he would a locked her up, and this awful mess wouldn’t ever happened.
vi: I guessed that the piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was meeting Harney somewhere at half-past two to elope. I felt that I should have told her father about that piece of paper and her somewhat strange behavior, so he could have locked her up, and then these horrible murders wouldn't have happened.
tr: I had realized that the piece of paper meant that Sophia and Harney would meet somewhere at two-thirty; if I had told her father about that paper and mentioned that his daughter was acting strangely, maybe he would have locked her in her room, and these terrible events would never have happened.
es: I thought that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia had to meet Harney somewhere at half-past two to run away, and that I should have told her father about the paper and the strange way she was acting, and then maybe he would have locked her up and all that horror would never have happened.

en: When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could.
vi: After climbing down from the tree, I crawled along the riverbank for a while and saw two bodies lying on the water's edge. I mustered all my strength to pull the two bodies further inland and turned them over to see their faces, then I ran away as fast as I could.
tr: After climbing down from the tree, I carefully and quietly advanced along the riverbank and found two bodies floating very close to the shore. I pulled them to the land, covered their faces with something, and left as quickly as possible.
es: When I got down from the tree, I slid along the shore for a while, found the two corpses at the water's edge, and dragged them until they were on dry land; then I covered their faces and left as quickly as I could.

en: I cried a little when I was covering up Buck’s face, for he was mighty good to me.
vi: When I saw Buck's face, I cried for a long time because he was so kind to me.
tr: While covering Buck's face, I shed a few tears because he had treated me very well.
es: I cried a little while covering Buck, because he had treated me very well.

en: It was just dark now.
vi: Then the sky turned completely dark.
tr: It was almost dark now.
es: It had just gotten dark.

en: I never went near the house, but struck through the woods and made for the swamp.
vi: I didn't dare go near the house, but went through the forest to find the swamp.
tr: I didn't head home; instead, I plunged into the forest and reached the swamp.
es: I didn't go back to the house, but went through the forest to the swamp.

en: Jim warn’t on his island, so I tramped off in a hurry for the crick, and crowded through the willows, red-hot to jump aboard and get out of that awful country.
vi: Jim was no longer there. I hurriedly weaved through the willow trees, eager to jump on the boat and escape this terrifying place.
tr: I couldn't find Jim on his island, so I moved towards the creek where the raft was, near the willows, ready to jump on board and leave this dreadful place – the raft was gone!
es: Jim wasn't on his island, so I ran to the stream and hid among the willows, ready to jump aboard and leave that horrible place.

en: The raft was gone!
vi: The raft was gone too.
tr: I couldn't find Jim on his island, so I moved towards the creek where the raft was, near the willows, ready to jump on board and leave this dreadful place – the raft was gone!
es: The raft was gone!

en: My souls, but I was scared!
vi: Oh my God, I was so scared!
tr: My God, I was so scared!
es: My God, what a fright I got!

en: I couldn’t get my breath for most a minute.
vi: For more than a minute, I was breathless.
tr: For almost a minute, I couldn't pull myself together.
es: I was out of breath for almost a minute.

en: Then I raised a yell.
vi: Then I let out a scream.
tr: Then I called out.
es: Then I managed to scream.

en: A voice not twenty-five foot from me says:
vi: Just a few meters from where I stood, a voice suddenly spoke:
tr: Immediately, a response came from about ten meters away…
es: A voice, less than twenty-five feet from me, says:

en: “Good lan’! is dat you, honey?
vi: - Thank goodness, oh my, is that you?
tr: "My God! Is that you, the corner of my heart?
es: —Wow! Is that you, my boy?

en: Doan’ make no noise.”
vi: Keep it down
tr: Don't make any noise."
es: Don't make noise.

en: It was Jim’s voice—nothing ever sounded so good before.
vi: That was Jim's voice. I had never heard a voice that made me feel so reassured.
tr: This was Jim's voice – probably no other voice has ever sounded so beautiful to me in my life.
es: It was Jim's voice, and I had never heard anything so pleasant.

en: I run along the bank a piece and got aboard, and Jim he grabbed me and hugged me, he was so glad to see me.
vi: I jumped over the water's edge and onto the raft. Jim hugged me tightly.
tr: I immediately ran from the shore and jumped onto the raft, Jim hugged me tightly as soon as he caught me, he was very happy to see me. “Oh, may you live long, my dear, I was just afraid that you had died again.
es: I ran a bit along the shore and climbed aboard; Jim grabbed me and hugged me, so happy to see me, and says:

en: He says:
vi: Seeing how happy I was, Jim said:
tr: Jack was in the field and said that you might have been shot, because you hadn't come home.
es: I ran a bit along the shore and climbed aboard; Jim grabbed me and hugged me, so happy to see me, and says:

en: “Laws bless you, chile, I ’uz right down sho’ you’s dead agin.
vi: - Lucky, buddy, I was down here thinking you were dead again.
tr: I was going to take the news to the authorities.
es: —God bless you, child, I was sure you had died again.

en: Jack’s been heah; he say he reck’n you’s ben shot, kase you didn’ come home no mo’; so I’s jes’ dis minute a startin’ de raf’ down towards de mouf er de crick, so’s to be all ready for to shove out en leave soon as Jack comes agin en tells me for certain you is dead.
vi: Jack came here and said maybe you got shot or something since you didn't return home. I was planning to push the raft down there to carry it, and if Jack came back and confirmed you were dead, I would leave immediately.
tr: Jack turned around and until he confirmed that you were definitely dead, I said I would be ready to set out.
es: Jack has been here and says he thought you had been shot because you hadn't come home, so at this moment I was going to take the raft down the stream to be ready to leave as soon as Jack came back and told me for sure that you had died.

en: Lawsy, I’s mighty glad to git you back agin, honey.”
vi: So now that you're back, I'm so happy.
tr: How happy I am to see you again, my heart's corner.” “Alright then…
es: My God, how glad I am that you have returned, my child.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: This is very good; they will think I was killed and my body drifted down the river because they won't be able to find me…
es: And then I go and say:

en: “All right—that’s mighty good; they won’t find me, and they’ll think I’ve been killed, and floated down the river—there’s something up there that’ll help them think so—so don’t you lose no time, Jim, but just shove off for the big water as fast as ever you can.”
vi: - Great, then that's even better. That way, they won't look for me anymore because they think I've been killed and my body has floated down the river. There's a corpse up there, which might make them think that way. Let's go quickly, Jim, push us out to the middle of the river.
tr: There are enough reasons for them to think that up there… So let's not waste any time, Jim, let's act immediately and get to the river quickly.”
es: —All right; it's very good; they won't find me and will believe that I have died and floated down the river... Up there, there's something that will help them believe it, so don't waste time, Jim, let's find the big water as quickly as you can.

en: I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the middle of the Mississippi.
vi: Until our raft had gone upstream for a few miles downstream and reached the middle of the Mississippi River, we were not at ease.
tr: I couldn't feel at ease until we were two miles down and reached the middle of the Mississippi.
es: I didn't feel at ease until the raft had drifted two miles down the center of the Mississippi.

en: Then we hung up our signal lantern, and judged that we was free and safe once more.
vi: Then we hung up the signal light, thinking that once again we had escaped danger and were free.
tr: Then we lit the signal lantern and had no doubt that we were once again free and safe.
es: Then we hung our signal lantern and figured we were free and safe again.

en: I hadn’t had a bite to eat since yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greens—there ain’t nothing in the world so good when it’s cooked right—and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and had a good time.
vi: Since yesterday, I hadn't had anything to eat. Jim took out some fried bread; milk cakes, and there was even meat and green vegetables. There is nothing more delicious in the world than eating something hot like this. I ate and chatted with Jim very happily.
tr: I hadn't put a single bite in my mouth since yesterday; Jim soon brought out cornbread, skimmed milk, pork sausage, cabbage, and greens – when prepared by an expert, no meal could match its taste. We chatted while I ate and had a great time.
es: I hadn't eaten anything since yesterday, so Jim brought out some corn muffins and milk with cream, and pork with cabbage and greens (there's nothing better in the world when it's well-cooked) and while I had dinner, we chatted and had a good time.

en: I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so was Jim to get away from the swamp.
vi: I was glad to have escaped the plantation; and Jim was also glad to have escaped the swamp.
tr: I was very happy to have escaped the blood feuds, and Jim was glad to have gotten out of the swamp.
es: I was very glad to get away from the blood feuds, and Jim from the swamp.

en: We said there warn’t no home like a raft, after all.
vi: We told each other that ultimately, nowhere was better than our raft.
tr: There was nothing like having your own raft.
es: We said there was no home like a raft, after all.

en: Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a raft don’t.
vi: Other places are cramped and suffocating. But on the raft, it's not like that.
tr: Everywhere else felt cramped and suffocating, but not the raft.
es: Other places may seem crowded and stifling, but not a raft.

en: You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.
vi: On the raft, you feel completely free, comfortable, and secure.
tr: On the raft, one feels completely free; carefree and comfortable.
es: On a raft, one feels very free and at ease.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Chapter XIX
tr: The Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 19

en: Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum by, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely.
vi: A few more days and nights passed; I think it can be said that I passed those nights, gliding through them, in a peaceful, gentle, and poetic manner.
tr: Two or three more days and nights passed; or perhaps I should say flowed by, meaning they passed so quietly, smoothly, and pleasantly.
es: Two or three days and nights passed; I think I could say they swam by, so calm, smooth, and wonderful they slipped away.

en: Here is the way we put in the time.
vi: Here, we passed those days and hours like this.
tr: Let me tell you how the time passed.
es: I'm going to tell you how we spent our time.

en: It was a monstrous big river down there—sometimes a mile and a half wide; we run nights, and laid up and hid daytimes; soon as night was most gone we stopped navigating and tied up—nearly always in the dead water under a tow-head; and then cut young cottonwoods and willows, and hid the raft with them.
vi: The river was both large and wide - in some places up to a mile, a mile and a half. We traveled day and night looking for a secluded spot to sleep.
tr: As we went downstream, the river reached an immense width – in some places it was about a mile and a half; we traveled at night and stopped to hide during the day; in the last moments of darkness, we would move out of the current and tie up the raft. Almost every time, we would pull up to an island in the still water, then hide the raft nicely with poplar saplings and willow branches.
es: The river was monstrously large there: in some places, it was a mile and a half wide; we navigated at night and rested and hid during the day; as soon as the night was about to end, we stopped navigating and moored, almost always in the still water under a landing place, and then we cut young poplars and willows and hid the raft underneath.

en: Then we set out the lines.
vi: Near the end of the night, we would stop rowing, find a calm spot near a creek to tie the raft, then cut some wildflower branches or willow branches to cover the raft, and cast the fishing line.
tr: Then we would cast our fishing lines.
es: Then we cast the fishing lines.

en: Next we slid into the river and had a swim, so as to freshen up and cool off; then we set down on the sandy bottom where the water was about knee deep, and watched the daylight come.
vi: Then we would jump into the river to bathe, refreshing and invigorating ourselves. Then we would sit and wait on some sandy bank with water up to our knees, waiting for the daylight to come.
tr: We would go into the river and swim a bit, thus both cleaning and cooling ourselves; we would watch the sunrise from a sandy spot where the water came up to our knees.
es: Later, we would go into the river to swim for a while, to wash and refresh ourselves; then we would sit on the sandy bottom, where the water reached our knees, and wait for daylight to come.

en: Not a sound anywheres—perfectly still—just like the whole world was asleep, only sometimes the bullfrogs a-cluttering, maybe.
vi: All around, there was not a sound, complete tranquility, as if the entire world was asleep. Occasionally, we might hear the croaking of frogs.
tr: There was not a sound around – complete silence – it was as if the whole world was asleep, only occasionally interrupted by the sound of frogs.
es: There wasn't a sound anywhere, everything was in absolute silence, as if the whole world had fallen asleep, except perhaps sometimes the croaking of frogs.

en: The first thing to see, looking away over the water, was a kind of dull line—that was the woods on t’other side; you couldn’t make nothing else out; then a pale place in the sky; then more paleness spreading around; then the river softened up away off, and warn’t black any more, but gray; you could see little dark spots drifting along ever so far away—trading scows, and such things; and long black streaks—rafts; sometimes you could hear a sweep screaking; or jumbled up voices, it was so still, and sounds come so far; and by-and-by you could see a streak on the water which you know by the look of the streak that there’s a snag there in a swift current which breaks on it and makes that streak look that way; and you see the mist curl up off of the water, and the east reddens up, and the river, and you make out a log-cabin in the edge of the woods, away on the bank on t’other side of the river, being a woodyard, likely, and piled by them cheats so you can throw a dog through it anywheres; then the nice breeze springs up, and comes fanning you from over there, so cool and fresh and sweet to smell on account of the woods and the flowers; but sometimes not that way, because they’ve left dead fish laying around, gars and such, and they do get pretty rank; and next you’ve got the full day, and everything smiling in the sun, and the song-birds just going it!
vi: The first thing seen on the other side of the water was just a long, silent row of trees, nothing else could be seen. Then a faint light appeared in the sky, gradually spreading, making the river seem even wider; it was no longer black but grayish. In the distance, we could see black dots floating downstream, drifting endlessly, perhaps sailboats or something, long black objects from the rafts. Sometimes we could hear the splash of oars or the murmur of voices. It was so quiet that the sounds echoed far away. Occasionally, we would see a streak on the water; looking closely, we could recognize it as a tree uprooted and drifting, appearing like that, then mist would roll into coils on the water. In the east, the sky began to redden, then the river, and perhaps the wooden hut on the edge of the forest across the river, maybe a wooden basket of some sort, if suspected of containing something, a dog could be sent in to sniff around. Then a cool breeze would blow, feeling refreshing, gentle, with a fragrant scent of wood and forest flowers. But sometimes, instead, there would be the smell of dead fish around, rising up, pungent and strong. After that, it would be fully daylight. Everything seemed to smile under the sun, and the birds chirped merrily.
tr: When you looked at the horizon over the water, the first thing you saw was a dull line – this was the line of the forest on the opposite shore – nothing else could be distinguished; a pale band appeared in the sky above it; then it spread upward; then the color of the river lightened; it gradually turned from black to gray; you could see small black dots drifting away, continuously moving farther – these were barges and similar things; and there were long black streaks – rafts; sometimes we would hear the creak of an oar or indistinct conversations; it was so quiet that sounds from very far away would reach us; after a while, lines would start to appear on the water, and by looking at the position of the lines, you could tell that there were trees under the water with a fast current passing over them; you could also see the mist gathering and lifting off the surface of the water, the eastern side turning red, the river turning red, and you could make out a log cabin at the edge of the forest, most likely a wood depot on the other side of the river. Then a fresh breeze would come up and cool you, bringing the pleasant scents of the forest and flowers to your nose; but sometimes it wasn't so nice, because it would expose dead garfish or other fish, and as they rotted, they would smell really awful; then the day would fully break; everything would be smiling in the sunlight and the birds would start chirping madly!
es: The first thing you saw, if you looked over the water, was a kind of blurry line that was the forests on the other side; nothing else could be distinguished; then a pale spot in the sky and more paleness appearing, and then the river, soft and distant, which was no longer black but gray; you could see black spots drifting far away: barges and other boats, and long black lines that were rafts; sometimes you heard the creak of an oar, or voices mingled in the silence that made sounds carry from very far away; and after a while, you saw a line in the water, and by its color, you knew there was a current under the surface breaking it and making that line appear; and then you saw the mist floating as it rose from the water and the East turned red, and the river, and you saw a log cabin at the edge of the forest, over there on the other side of the river, which was probably a sawmill, and next to it, piles of wood with gaps made by some vagabonds, so a dog could pass through; then a nice breeze came from the other side, fresh and gentle, smelling very good because it came from the forest and flowers; but sometimes it wasn't like that because someone had left dead fish lying around, pikes and all that, and they smelled a lot, and then full daylight came and everything smiled at the sun, and the birds began to sing.

en: A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast.
vi: At this moment, even if a little smoke rises, no one can see it. We lifted a few fish at the end of the line to make a hot meal.
tr: We were preparing a warm breakfast with some of the fish caught on the lines, thinking a little smoke wouldn't attract attention anymore.
es: At that hour, it didn't matter to make a little smoke because it couldn't be seen, so we took the fish off the lines and prepared a hot breakfast.

en: And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep.
vi: Then we sat back down to watch the deserted river. People started to get tired, and we lay down to sleep.
tr: Then we would watch the solitude of the river for a while; laze around; gradually get drowsy and eventually fall asleep.
es: And then we would contemplate the solitude of the river and laze around, and little by little we would fall asleep.

en: Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and maybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the other side you couldn’t tell nothing about her only whether she was a stern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldn’t be nothing to hear nor nothing to see—just solid lonesomeness.
vi: From time to time, we woke up and looked outside to see if there was anything. Perhaps it was a boat laboriously climbing upstream on the far side of the river; from a distance, it was impossible to tell if it was a stern-wheeler or had paddle wheels on both sides. Then another hour passed, with nothing to see or hear, just silence.
tr: Then we would wake up to a noise and see a steamboat coughing its way upriver, but it would be on the other side of the river and so far away that it was impossible to tell whether its paddle wheel was on the side or the stern. Then for about an hour, nothing else would be heard or seen – just solitude.
es: We would wake up, and when we looked to find out why, sometimes we saw a steamboat puffing upriver, so far on the other side that the only thing you could see was whether it had the wheel at the stern or on the sides; then, for an hour there was nothing to hear or see: only solitude.

en: Next you’d see a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it chopping, because they’re most always doing it on a raft; you’d see the axe flash and come down—you don’t hear nothing; you see that axe go up again, and by the time it’s above the man’s head then you hear the k’chunk!—it had took all that time to come over the water.
vi: Later, a raft drifted by on the outer edge. Perhaps there was a guy on the raft chopping wood, because they often chop wood right on the raft. From inside here, they could see the glint of the axe being raised, and just as the axe was lifted above his head, there was a thud, a sound that took a moment to travel over the water before reaching our ears.
tr: Then you would see a raft passing in the distance, perhaps with an inexperienced raftsman cutting wood on it, because such types always cut wood on the raft; you would see the axe glint as it rises and falls – but you wouldn't hear anything; then the axe rises again; as it reaches above the man's head, you hear the thud! sound, it takes that long for the sound to reach you over the water.
es: Then we would see a raft gliding in the distance, and sometimes one of the guys on board chopping wood, because that's what they almost always do on rafts, and you could see the axe shining and coming down, but you couldn't hear anything; you would see the axe rise again, and when it was above the man's head, then you would hear the chop, which had taken all that time to cross the water.

en: So we would put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness.
vi: Then we lay back down, listening to the quiet return.
tr: That's how we spent the day, lazing around, listening intently to the silence.
es: And so we spent the day, lazing around, listening to the silence.

en: Once there was a thick fog, and the rafts and things that went by was beating tin pans so the steamboats wouldn’t run over them.
vi: Once, in thick fog, boats and rafts had to clang pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamships.
tr: Once, a thick fog descended, and people on rafts and barges were clanging pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamboats as they moved along.
es: Once a dense fog came down, and the rafts and everything that passed by made noise with pans so that the steamboats wouldn't overlook them.

en: A scow or a raft went by so close we could hear them talking and cussing and laughing—heard them plain; but we couldn’t see no sign of them; it made you feel crawly; it was like spirits carrying on that way in the air.
vi: A ferry or raft or something passed by us, so close that we could clearly hear them talking, swearing, and laughing loudly, even though we couldn't see anything, as if we were blindfolded; it really felt like ghostly voices drifting through the air.
tr: A barge or raft passed so close to us that we could hear the people inside cursing and laughing – we could clearly understand what they were saying; but we couldn't see them for even a moment; this sent chills down our spines, as if we were listening to the voices of spirits gliding through the air.
es: A skiff or a raft would pass so close that we could hear what the people on board were saying, their curses and their laughter, we could hear them perfectly, but we couldn't see any sign of them; it was a very strange feeling, as if they were spirits talking in the air.

en: Jim said he believed it was spirits; but I says:
vi: Jim said maybe they really were ghosts. I said:
tr: Jim even said he believed they were spirits.
es: Jim said he thought they were, but I said:

en: “No; spirits wouldn’t say, ‘Dern the dern fog.’”
vi: - No, if it were, it would have said: the fog has lifted.
tr: But I had objected, "No soul would say 'damn this accursed fog'."
es: —No; the spirits would not say: "Damn the damn fog."

en: Soon as it was night out we shoved; when we got her out to about the middle we let her alone, and let her float wherever the current wanted her to; then we lit the pipes, and dangled our legs in the water, and talked about all kinds of things—we was always naked, day and night, whenever the mosquitoes would let us—the new clothes Buck’s folks made for me was too good to be comfortable, and besides I didn’t go much on clothes, nohow.
vi: Then it wouldn't be long before night came again, and we would set off once more. Once the raft reached the middle of the river, we let it drift, letting the current take us wherever it wanted. We lit our cigarettes, dangled our feet in the water, and talked about all sorts of things. All day and all night, we went shirtless, not caring about the mosquitoes. The outfit that Mrs. Buck's family made for me was so nice that it became inconvenient to wear. Besides, I didn't pay much attention to clothes anyway.
tr: Before long, it got dark and we had moved away from the shore. When we reached the middle of the river, we stopped rowing and the raft continued to float downstream with the current; then we lit our pipes, stretched our feet into the water, and started chatting about this and that. Whenever we got a break from the mosquitoes, we were always naked; the clothes Buck's family gave me were so high-quality that I couldn't feel comfortable in them, and besides, I don't really like fussing over my clothes.
es: As soon as it was night, we would head to the river; when we had the raft approximately in the center, we would do nothing and let it float wherever the current took it; then we would light our pipes and dip our legs in the water and talk about all sorts of things; we were always naked, day and night, when the mosquitoes allowed us; the new clothes that Buck's family had made for me were too good to be comfortable; anyway, I didn't really like wearing clothes much either.

en: Sometimes we’d have that whole river all to ourselves for the longest time.
vi: Sometimes it feels like this whole river belongs to us.
tr: Sometimes there would be no one else on the river for a very long time except us.
es: Sometimes we had the whole river to ourselves for very long stretches.

en: Yonder was the banks and the islands, across the water; and maybe a spark—which was a candle in a cabin window; and sometimes on the water you could see a spark or two—on a raft or a scow, you know; and maybe you could hear a fiddle or a song coming over from one of them crafts.
vi: Looking across the water, far away on the other side is the riverbank, and the island, and perhaps there is a light, a candle flame in the window frame. Sometimes there are also a few lights on the water's surface. Those are the lights on the rafts or ferries, and perhaps we can even hear the sound of a violin or singing echoing out.
tr: We would see the shores and islands ahead; maybe a spark – a candle seen from a cabin window – would catch our eye; sometimes we would see one or two sparks on the water – on a raft or a barge; sometimes we would hear the sound of a violin or someone singing from one of the river vessels.
es: In the distance, we could see the banks and the islands on the other side of the water, and sometimes a spark that was a light in the window of a cabin, and sometimes in the middle of the water, we saw a spark or two: you know, a raft or a skiff, and you could hear a violin or a song coming from one of those boats.

en: It’s lovely to live on a raft.
vi: Living on a raft or a float, how interesting it is.
tr: Living on the raft was very beautiful.
es: It's wonderful to live on a raft.

en: We had the sky up there, all speckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at them, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened.
vi: Above us, there is only the high sky, dotted with stars, and we often lie on our backs looking up at the sky, debating with each other about who made those stars, and I just say they exist on their own.
tr: The sky above would be speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs and watch the stars, debating whether they were made or if they appeared suddenly – according to Jim, they were made, but I thought they appeared suddenly; in my opinion, there were too many of them to be made one by one.
es: Above us, we had the sky, all speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs, look at them, and discuss whether someone had made them or if they had just appeared on their own.

en: Jim he allowed they was made, but I allowed they happened; I judged it would have took too long to make so many.
vi: I said if someone made that many stars, it would surely take a lot of time.
tr: The sky above would be speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs and watch the stars, debating whether they were made or if they appeared suddenly – according to Jim, they were made, but I thought they appeared suddenly; in my opinion, there were too many of them to be made one by one.
es: Jim always said that they had been made, but I maintained that they had just appeared; it seemed to me it would take too long to make so many.

en: Jim said the moon could a laid them; well, that looked kind of reasonable, so I didn’t say nothing against it, because I’ve seen a frog lay most as many, so of course it could be done.
vi: Jim said the moon gave birth to those stars. Well, it makes sense, so I couldn't say anything to refute that theory. And since I've seen frogs lay a lot of eggs, it could be that the moon gave birth to those stars.
tr: Jim had said that the moon might have laid them; well, since this seemed reasonable, I didn't object, because I had seen a frog with as many offspring as there were stars, so this was something that could happen.
es: Jim said that the moon might have put them there; well, that seemed quite reasonable, so I didn't say anything against it, because I've seen frogs lay almost as many eggs, so it was certainly possible.

en: We used to watch the stars that fell, too, and see them streak down.
vi: We also often look at shooting stars, watching their trails stretch down to the horizon.
tr: We would also see shooting stars and watch them descend.
es: We also watched the falling stars and saw the trail they left behind.

en: Jim allowed they’d got spoiled and was hove out of the nest.
vi: Jim said those are the bad stars, flying away from their nest.
tr: According to Jim, these were the rotten ones and that's why they were picked out and fell from the nest.
es: Jim said it was because they had misbehaved and had been thrown out of the nest.

en: Once or twice of a night we would see a steamboat slipping along in the dark, and now and then she would belch a whole world of sparks up out of her chimbleys, and they would rain down in the river and look awful pretty; then she would turn a corner and her lights would wink out and her powwow shut off and leave the river still again; and by-and-by her waves would get to us, a long time after she was gone, and joggle the raft a bit, and after that you wouldn’t hear nothing for you couldn’t tell how long, except maybe frogs or something.
vi: A few times during the dark hours, we would encounter passing ships, occasionally they would emit a whole sky full of sparks from their chimneys, and then those sparks would fall like rain onto the river, looking incredibly beautiful. Then it would turn to another direction, its twinkling lights gradually fading, its chugging sounds also quieting down, and the river would return to silence. A moment later, when the ship had gone far away, its waves would reach us, causing the raft to bob slightly; then we wouldn't hear anything anymore, and it was impossible to tell how long it had been. Perhaps only a few sounds of frogs or something else remained.
tr: Every night, we would see a steamship moving in the dark once or twice, spewing countless sparks from its chimney, and as the sparks descended burning onto the river, it would create a magnificent view; then, as the ship turned a corner, its lights would disappear from sight, its noise would cease, and the river would become silent again; long after it had vanished, its waves would slowly reach us and gently rock the raft, and then you would hear nothing, there would be a long silence of indeterminate length, interrupted only by frogs or similar sounds.
es: At night we would see one or two steamboats passing in the darkness, and every now and then they would send out a whole world of sparks from one of the chimneys, which fell into the river and looked beautiful; then the boat would round a bend and the lights would wink and the noise of the boat would disappear, leaving the river silent again, and then the waves it had raised would reach us, long after the boat had disappeared, causing the raft to move a little, and then nothing could be heard for who knows how long, except maybe the frogs or things like that.

en: After midnight the people on shore went to bed, and then for two or three hours the shores was black—no more sparks in the cabin windows.
vi: Past midnight, the people on both sides of the river were all asleep, and the riverbanks were pitch dark for several hours. There was no longer any light in the windows.
tr: After midnight, the people living by the shore would go to bed, and for the next two or three hours, the beaches would be shrouded in darkness – no sparks would flicker in the cabin windows.
es: After midnight, the people of the coast went to bed, and for two or three hours the shores were in darkness: there were no more sparks in the windows of the cabins.

en: These sparks was our clock—the first one that showed again meant morning was coming, so we hunted a place to hide and tie up right away.
vi: Those lights were our clocks. When the first light appeared, it signaled that dawn was approaching, so we would find a place to hide and immediately tie up the raft.
tr: Those sparks marked our time – when we started to see them again, we knew that morning was approaching, and we would immediately tie up the raft and start looking for a place to hide.
es: Those sparks were our clock: the first one that reappeared meant that dawn was arriving, so we immediately looked for a place to hide and moor.

en: One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shore—it was only two hundred yards—and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn’t get some berries.
vi: One morning, just as the sun was rising, I found a boat, rowed through a swift current to reach the main shore, only a few hundred yards away. Then I rowed about half a mile further to a spot with bushes near a pine forest to see if I could find any berries.
tr: One morning, just as dawn was breaking, I found a canoe and entered a swift current – it was only about two hundred meters – and reached the riverbank. Then, I went up a creek among the cypress trees for about a mile to find some berries.
es: One morning, around dawn, I saw a canoe and I crossed a channel to the main shore (it was no more than two hundred yards) and rowed a mile towards a stream among the cypresses, to see if I could get some blackberries.

en: Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it.
vi: As I reached a narrow path just wide enough for cattle to pass through, suddenly two people came running out from that small path.
tr: Just as I was passing a place where the creek cut across a wide path, didn't two men come running for their lives!
es: Just as I was passing a spot where a sort of cow path crossed the stream, a pair of men appeared running as fast as they could.

en: I thought I was a goner, for whenever anybody was after anybody I judged it was me—or maybe Jim.
vi: I thought to myself, this is trouble, because if anyone is looking for someone here, it could only be me or Jim.
tr: Ah, this time I'm done for, I said to myself; because whenever I saw someone running, I thought they were chasing me – or Jim.
es: I thought my time had come, because whenever someone was looking for someone, it seemed to me that it was for me, or maybe for Jim.

en: I was about to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me then, and sung out and begged me to save their lives—said they hadn’t been doing nothing, and was being chased for it—said there was men and dogs a-coming.
vi: I was about to slip away when those people ran up close, calling me and begging me to save them. They said they hadn't done anything wrong, yet people were chasing them. Then they said that people with dogs were about to catch up to them.
tr: I was about to grab the oars to get away quickly, but they were already very close, calling out to me and asking me to save their lives – according to them, they hadn't done anything and were being chased for no reason – there were men and dogs behind them.
es: I was about to leave in a hurry, but they were already very close to me, and they shouted and asked me to save their lives: they said they hadn't done anything and that's why they were being chased, that men with dogs were coming.

en: They wanted to jump right in, but I says:
vi: They wanted to jump right into my boat, but I said:
tr: They immediately wanted to jump into the canoe, but I stopped them:
es: They wanted to get directly into my canoe, but I told them:

en: “Don’t you do it.
vi: - Don't do that, it's just starting.
tr: “Do not mount here.
es: —No, not now.

en: I don’t hear the dogs and horses yet; you’ve got time to crowd through the brush and get up the crick a little ways; then you take to the water and wade down to me and get in—that’ll throw the dogs off the scent.”
vi: I didn't hear any horse sounds. You have enough time to crawl through that bush, follow the small path down to the water, then wade around here before getting into the boat. That way, the dogs won't be able to track you.
tr: I do not hear the sounds of the dogs and horses yet; you still have time to go a bit upstream through the bushes; then you can enter the water, come downstream to me, and then you can mount... That way, the dogs won't catch your scent.”
es: I still don't hear the horses and the dogs; you have time to go through the bushes and climb a little up the stream; then get into the water and wade down to where I am and come over; that way the dogs will lose the trail.

en: They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head, and in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away off, shouting.
vi: They followed; as soon as they stepped onto the boat, I rowed quickly back to where we hid the raft. About fifty minutes later, we heard the sound of dogs and people shouting and yelling.
tr: They did as I said; right after they got into the canoe, I set off towards our little island; within five to ten minutes, we heard the dogs and men passing by, shouting and yelling.
es: That was what they did, and as soon as they were on board, I headed towards our mooring; after five minutes we heard the dogs and the men shouting in the distance.

en: We heard them come along towards the crick, but couldn’t see them; they seemed to stop and fool around a while; then, as we got further and further away all the time, we couldn’t hardly hear them at all; by the time we had left a mile of woods behind us and struck the river, everything was quiet, and we paddled over to the tow-head and hid in the cottonwoods and was safe.
vi: We heard that they had reached the bushes, but we couldn't see them. It seemed like they stopped there and searched around for a while. We went farther away and couldn't hear anything anymore. After traveling a distance of nearly a mile through the forest and reaching the big river, everything was quiet. We turned into a creek and hid in the cotton fields; and thus, we felt completely at ease.
tr: We could hear them coming towards the creek, but we couldn't see them. It seemed to me that they lingered around there for a while. After that, we didn't hear their voices again because we were constantly moving away. We moved in silence until we left the forest about a mile behind and reached the river, then we rowed to our little island, hid among the poplars; we were safe now.
es: We heard them go towards the stream, but we couldn't see them; they seemed to leave it and wander around for a while, and then, as we kept moving away all the time, we could hardly hear them anymore; when we left the forest a mile behind and reached the river, everything was calm and we rowed to the sandbar and hid among the poplars, now safe.

en: One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers.
vi: An elderly man of about seventy years or more, bald with graying sideburns.
tr: One of the men was seventy or older; his head was bald and his sideburns were quite gray.
es: One of those guys was about seventy years old or more, and he was bald with a very gray beard.

en: He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a greasy blue woollen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed into his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses—no, he only had one.
vi: He wore an old wide-brimmed hat, a grayish-blue undershirt, and old, torn blue pants with the cuffs tucked into his boots.
tr: He had an old, tattered hat on his head, and a blue wool shirt covered in grease on his back; he had tucked the frayed cuffs of his blue jeans into his boots; he had homemade suspenders – no, more precisely, he had a single suspender.
es: He wore an old wide-brimmed hat and a greasy blue wool shirt, with old blue jeans tucked into his boots, with homemade suspenders; but no, he only had one left.

en: He had an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over his arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags.
vi: Over his arm, he carried a blue coat with shiny brass buttons. Both men carried large, heavy, and dirty bags.
tr: He had slung an old long denim jacket with makeshift brass buttons over his arm; additionally, he had a swollen, dirty-looking kilim bag in each hand.
es: He carried an old blue fabric overcoat over his arm, with shiny copper buttons, and they both carried large, half-worn travel bags.

en: The other fellow was about thirty, and dressed about as ornery.
vi: The other person was about thirty years old, dressed modestly.
tr: The other man was in his thirties and was as shabbily dressed as the other.
es: The other guy was about thirty years old and was dressed just as plainly.

en: After breakfast we all laid off and talked, and the first thing that come out was that these chaps didn’t know one another.
vi: After finishing breakfast, we lay down to rest, chatted, and the first thing that dawned on us was that the two other people didn't know each other at all.
tr: After breakfast, we all lay down where we were and started talking, and the first thing we noticed was that these men did not know each other.
es: After breakfast, we all lay down to chat, and the first thing that came up was that those guys didn't know each other.

en: “What got you into trouble?” says the baldhead to t’other chap.
vi: The bald old man told the other guy:
tr: "How did you get yourself into trouble?" asked the bald one to the other.
es: —What problem have you had? —asked the bald man to the other.

en: “Well, I’d been selling an article to take the tartar off the teeth—and it does take it off, too, and generly the enamel along with it—but I stayed about one night longer than I ought to, and was just in the act of sliding out when I ran across you on the trail this side of town, and you told me they were coming, and begged me to help you to get off.
vi: - What happened that you have to run away? - I sell a product used to remove black stains on teeth, but it doesn't remove the stains and instead removes the enamel. I stayed an extra night and was planning to sneak away when I met him running towards me on the road. He told me they were coming and asked me to help him escape.
tr: “I was selling a material that removes dental calculus… It really does remove it, but it usually takes the tooth enamel with it. I stayed one night longer than I should have, and just as I was preparing to flee, I met you on the road on this side of the town. You said they were after you and asked me to help you escape.
es: —Well, I was selling a product to remove tartar from teeth, and it's true that it removes it, and generally also the enamel, but I stayed one night longer than I should have and was about to leave when I met you on the path on this side of town, you told me they were coming and asked me to help you escape.

en: So I told you I was expecting trouble myself, and would scatter out with you.
vi: I told him that I was also about to get into trouble, so we ran together.
tr: At that point, I told you I was in trouble too and started running away with you.
es: So I told you that I was also expecting trouble and that I would leave with you.

en: That’s the whole yarn—what’s yourn?
vi: That's all there is to it, so what's your story?
tr: That's all there is to it… What was your problem?”
es: That's all. And you?

en: “Well, I’d ben a-runnin’ a little temperance revival thar, ’bout a week, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was makin’ it mighty warm for the rummies, I tell you, and takin’ as much as five or six dollars a night—ten cents a head, children and niggers free—and business a-growin’ all the time, when somehow or another a little report got around last night that I had a way of puttin’ in my time with a private jug on the sly.
vi: - Me? I'm doing an advertisement stunt to quit drinking. It's been a week, and everyone likes it, especially the women. This stunt is also making money. Look, each person pays a dime to watch, children and black people are free, and each night I make five to six dollars. This stunt was on the rise, but suddenly last night someone went around saying I was just a fraud and that I was secretly selling alcohol.
tr: “I had been holding small meetings against the sale and consumption of alcohol for a week. I had won the love of all the women, big and small, because I was giving the drunks a hard time. I was making about five or six dollars a night – I was charging ten cents per head, it was free for children and black people – business was good, and the number of attendees was increasing. But last night, a rumor started out of nowhere: Apparently, I was secretly taking swigs from a hidden jug.
es: —Well, I had been preaching sermons about temperance for a week and getting along very well with the women, both old and young, because I was making it hard for the drinkers, I assure you, and I was making at least five or six dollars a night, at ten cents a head, children and blacks free, and business was growing more and more, when somehow, last night, they started saying that I didn't mind spending some time alone with a jug.

en: A nigger rousted me out this mornin’, and told me the people was getherin’ on the quiet with their dogs and horses, and they’d be along pretty soon and give me ’bout half an hour’s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me they’d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure.
vi: This morning, a black man came to wake me up and said people were quietly gathering, bringing dogs and horses to catch me for punishment, and they might beat me up badly, or they might tar and feather me, shave all my hair and beard, and drag me on the railroad tracks, who knows.
tr: This morning, a black man came and woke me up and said that people were starting to gather quietly. They would be here soon with their dogs and horses, and after giving me a half-hour head start, they would chase me; when they caught me, they would tar and feather me and ride me on a rail.
es: A black man woke me up this morning and told me that people were gathering quietly, with dogs and horses, and that they were going to come soon, give me a half-hour head start and then try to catch me, and that if they caught me they planned to tar and feather me and run me out of town on a rail.

en: I didn’t wait for no breakfast—I warn’t hungry.”
vi: I didn't even have time for breakfast, and I wasn't hungry either.
tr: I couldn't stay for breakfast – I had lost my appetite.”
es: So I didn't wait for breakfast... I wasn't hungry.

en: “Old man,” said the young one, “I reckon we might double-team it together; what do you think?”
vi: The other person said: - My old friend, I think maybe the two of us could do business together, what do you think?
tr: “Dad, I see that we could make a good team,” said the younger one. “What do you think?”
es: —Old man —said the young man—, it seems to me that we could form a team; what do you think?

en: “I ain’t undisposed.
vi: - For me, it's easy.
tr: "I have no objections."
es: —I don't think it's bad.

en: What’s your line—mainly?”
vi: But what is your main occupation?
tr: "What is your profession... I mean generally?""
es: What do you do, mainly?

en: “Jour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor—tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there’s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes—oh, I do lots of things—most anything that comes handy, so it ain’t work.
vi: - Printing newspapers. That's my main profession. Occasionally, I make some medicines. A stage actor specializing in tragedy, you know. Sometimes, when convenient, I switch to hypnosis or treating mental illnesses. And if I change professions again, I teach singing, geography; sometimes I give a few lectures. Oh, I do many things. Whatever comes my way, I do it, so I don't stick to anything for long.
tr: “I am a master printer who grew up in the trade; I know a bit about medicines; I can act – tragedy and such; if I get the chance, I am interested in hypnotism and phrenology, I can read character by looking at the skull; sometimes, for a change, I teach singing and geography; I give sermons – I do a lot of things – I have a finger in every pie, as long as it's not menial work.
es: —By trade, I am a printing press operator; I work occasionally in over-the-counter medicines; theater actor: tragedy, you know; sometimes a bit of mesmerism and phrenology, when there's an opportunity; singing and geography teacher for a change; a lecture now and then... Well, lots of things; practically anything that comes up, as long as it's not work.

en: What’s your lay?”
vi: So, what do you do for a living?
tr: So what do you do?”
es: What do you specialize in?

en: “I’ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time.
vi: - In my life, I have been a doctor quite a few times.
tr: “Once upon a time, I practiced medicine for a long time.
es: —I have worked quite a bit on the aspect of medicine.

en: Layin’ on o’ hands is my best holt—for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k’n tell a fortune pretty good when I’ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me.
vi: The main thing is to live by these two hands. Treating cancer, paralysis, and similar conditions. But when someone discovers the truth, it's hard to make a living.
tr: Healing with my hands is what I do best – for cancer, paralysis, and similar things; also, if I have a man to gather the necessary information for me, I can read fortunes very well.
es: What I do best is laying on hands for cancer, paralysis, and things like that, and I don't do badly at fortune-telling when I have someone to find out the details for me.

en: Preachin’s my line, too, and workin’ camp-meetin’s, and missionaryin’ around.”
vi: Otherwise, I go preaching, attending evangelical camps.
tr: I also understand preaching; I work in tent meetings and missionary work.”
es: I also work on sermons, open-air preaching, and missions.

en: Nobody never said anything for a while; then the young man hove a sigh and says:
vi: After a while, no one spoke anymore. Then the younger person sighed and said:
tr: No one said anything for a long time; then the young man sighed deeply.
es: For a while, everyone remained silent; then the young man sighed and said:

en: “Alas!”
vi: - Oh my God!
tr: “Ah, what a pity!”
es: —Ouch!

en: “What ’re you alassin’ about?” says the baldhead.
vi: The bald old man asked: - What the heck?
tr: “What are you lamenting?” asked the bald-headed one.
es: —What are you complaining about? —asked the bald man.

en: “To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be degraded down into such company.”
vi: - I think that I have to keep living this kind of life forever, and then gradually lose my dignity among my fellow human beings like this?
tr: "That I have come to live such a life, that I have fallen so low as to live among such people."
es: —To think that I could have had such an easy life and now find myself reduced to this company —and he began to dry his eye with a cloth.
