en: And he begun to wipe the corner of his eye with a rag.
vi: After speaking, she raised the handkerchief to dab at the corners of her eyes.
tr: He began to wipe the corner of his eye with a cloth.
es: —Blessed be!

en: “Dern your skin, ain’t the company good enough for you?” says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.
vi: The old man asked again with a tone that seemed authoritative:
tr: The bald-headed one brazenly stood up: "Oh really, do we not look good enough for you?"
es: Don't you think this company is good? —asks the bald man, very dignified and angry.

en: “Yes, it is good enough for me; it’s as good as I deserve; for who fetched me so low when I was so high?
vi: - It's tough, poor thing, but are the people traveling with you nice? - Yes, they treat me quite well. I can tolerate it. Moreover, who dares to belittle me while I am like this.
tr: “No way, you’re fine, you’re good; besides, this is what I deserve anyway, isn’t someone like me who fell from the top to here worthy of this?
es: —Yes, it is good enough; it is the most I deserve, for who brought me so low when I was born so high?

en: I did myself.
vi: Only I can belittle myself.
tr: I brought this upon myself.
es: Myself.

en: I don’t blame you, gentlemen—far from it; I don’t blame anybody.
vi: I do not avoid you people, I do not avoid anyone.
tr: I am not blaming you, gentlemen… Don’t even think such a thing; I am not blaming anyone.
es: I do not blame you, gentlemen, far from it; I blame no one, I deserve it all.

en: I deserve it all.
vi: I endure everything.
tr: I deserved all of it.
es: I do not blame you, gentlemen, far from it; I blame no one, I deserve it all.

en: Let the cold world do its worst; one thing I know—there’s a grave somewhere for me.
vi: No matter where this cold life leads to the most painful place, let it lead. But one thing I know for sure is that there will be a grave waiting for me somewhere.
tr: Let the merciless life do its worst; the only thing I know is… there is a grave somewhere for me too.
es: Let the cold world perpetuate its revenge; one thing I know: somewhere a grave awaits me.

en: The world may go on just as it’s always done, and take everything from me—loved ones, property, everything; but it can’t take that.
vi: Let life go on as it has always gone on, and take everything from me - loved ones, property, everything. But how can it take away that grave.
tr: No matter how this world turns, even if it takes everything from me – my loved ones, my possessions, everything – it cannot take this from me.
es: The world can continue as it always has and take everything from me: loved ones, possessions, everything; but that it cannot take from me.

en: Some day I’ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor broken heart will be at rest.”
vi: One day, I will close my eyes and forget everything, and my broken, suffering heart will rest.
tr: One day I will enter that grave and forget everything, and at that moment my broken heart will find peace.”
es: Someday I will lie in it and forget everything, and my poor broken heart will be able to rest —and he continued to dry an eye.

en: He went on a-wiping.
vi: He said that and then wiped his tears again.
tr: He started to cry.
es: Someday I will lie in it and forget everything, and my poor broken heart will be able to rest —and he continued to dry an eye.

en: “Drot your pore broken heart,” says the baldhead; “what are you heaving your pore broken heart at us f’r?
vi: The bald old man said: - Why are you dragging your broken, suffering heart to us?
tr: “Damn your poor broken heart,” said the bald-headed man; “why are you pinning that poor broken heart on us?
es: —Bless your poor broken heart —says the bald man—; what broken heart are you talking about?

en: We hain’t done nothing.”
vi: What have we done to you?
tr: What did we do to you?”
es: We haven't done anything.

en: “No, I know you haven’t.
vi: - I know you people won't do anything to me.
tr: “I know you didn't do anything.
es: —No, I know that.

en: I ain’t blaming you, gentlemen.
vi: - I know you people won't do anything to me.
tr: I'm not blaming you, gentlemen.
es: I do not blame you, gentlemen.

en: I brought myself down—yes, I did it myself.
vi: I don't avoid you, it's just that I bring myself down, so I have to endure everything, I don't dare to complain at all.
tr: The reason for my downfall is me… I am responsible for all of it.
es: I have debased myself; yes, I alone.

en: It’s right I should suffer—perfectly right—I don’t make any moan.”
vi: I don't avoid you, it's just that I bring myself down, so I have to endure everything, I don't dare to complain at all.
tr: It is right for me to suffer… This is the most correct… I'm not complaining.”
es: It is fair that I now suffer, perfectly fair; I cannot complain.

en: “Brought you down from whar?
vi: - Where did you lower yourself?
tr: “Where did you fall from?
es: —Lowered from what?

en: Whar was you brought down from?”
vi: Where exactly?
tr: What caused you to fall?”
es: What have you lowered yourself from?

en: “Ah, you would not believe me; the world never believes—let it pass—’tis no matter.
vi: - Even if I say it, no one will believe me. But never mind, it doesn't matter.
tr: “Ah, you wouldn't believe me; no one in the world would believe me... Never mind... It's not important.
es: —Ah, you wouldn't believe me; the world never believes... but leave it; it doesn't matter.

en: The secret of my birth—”
vi: The secret of my life.
tr: The secret of my birth...”
es: The secret of my birth...

en: “The secret of your birth!
vi: - Your secret life?
tr: “What was the secret at his birth?”
es: —The secret of your birth!

en: Do you mean to say—”
vi: Are you trying to say that...
tr: “What do you mean?””
es: Are you going to tell us...?

en: “Gentlemen,” says the young man, very solemn, “I will reveal it to you, for I feel I may have confidence in you.
vi: - Gentlemen - he said solemnly - I will reveal to you, because I see that I can trust you.
tr: The young man said with great seriousness, "Gentlemen; I will reveal my secret to you, because I feel that I can trust you."
es: —Gentlemen —says the young man very solemnly—, I will reveal it to you, for I believe I can trust you.

en: By rights I am a duke!”
vi: I myself am a Duke.
tr: "I am the son of a duke!"
es: In reality, I am a duke!

en: Jim’s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too.
vi: Hearing that, Jim's eyes widened, and it seemed mine did too.
tr: When Jim heard this, his eyes popped out of their sockets; surely, my eyes must have popped out too.
es: Jim's eyes popped out when he heard it, and I think mine did too.

en: Then the baldhead says: “No! you can’t mean it?”
vi: Then the bald old man said:
tr: Upon this, the bald man started to speak:
es: Then the bald guy goes and says: —No! You can't mean it!

en: “Yes.
vi: - Nonsense, how could that be.
tr: “No way! You can't be serious, right?” “Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled to this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure air of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father dying about the same time.
vi: - Yes, my grandfather's father was the eldest son of the Duke of Bilgewater; he fled to this land around the end of the last century to breathe the fresh air of freedom; then he married there, and died, leaving behind a son.
tr: My great-great-grandfather was the eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater; he fled to this country at the end of the last century to breathe the pure air of freedom; he married here; when he died, leaving behind a son, his own father had also died.
es: My great-grandfather, the eldest son of the Duke of Aguasclaras, fled to this country at the end of the last century to breathe the pure air of freedom; he married here and died, leaving a son at the very moment his own father passed away.

en: The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates—the infant real duke was ignored.
vi: The Duke of Bilgewater also passed away around that time. The second son of the duke inherited the title along with all the property, but my grandfather's father, who was the rightful duke, was abandoned. Thus, I should have been the Duke of Bilgewater.
tr: The deceased duke's second son seized the title and estates – the true baby duke was ignored.
es: The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates, and the true duke, newly born, was disinherited.

en: I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”
vi: Yet here I am now, in such a pitiful state. I am shunned, treated with cold contempt; my life is tattered, wandering, painful, and reduced to the lowest state, having to associate with the wretched on every raft.
tr: I am descended from that baby – the right to be the Duke of Bridgewater is mine; but here I am, in a wretched state, stripped of my estates and nobility, people are chasing after me; this cruel world hates me; my clothes are in tatters, I am worn out, my heart is broken, and I have fallen so low as to travel on a raft with outlaws!”
es: I am the direct descendant of that child: I am the true Duke of Aguasclaras, and here I am, forgotten, stripped of my own possessions, persecuted by men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn out, with a broken heart, and reduced to the company of criminals on a raft!

en: Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I.
vi: Jim felt very sorry for him after hearing that. So did I.
tr: Jim felt very sorry for him, and so did I.
es: Jim felt very sorry for him, and so did I.

en: We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how.
vi: We intended to find a way to comfort him, but he said comforting was useless; no one could comfort him anymore. He said that if we wanted to acknowledge him as he was, it would be better than anything else. We said: fine, we would acknowledge him, but he had to tell us how.
tr: We tried to comfort him, but he said it wouldn't work, that he was beyond consolation; he said that if we showed the courtesy of accepting his dukedom, we would be doing him a kindness beyond anything else; we said we would be happy to do so if he told us how.
es: We tried to console him, but he said it was no use, that he couldn't be consoled much; he said that if we wanted to acknowledge his dignity, that would serve him more comfort than anything in the world, so we promised to do so if he told us how.

en: He said we ought to bow when we spoke to him, and say “Your Grace,” or “My Lord,” or “Your Lordship”—and he wouldn’t mind it if we called him plain “Bridgewater,” which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and one of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for him he wanted done.
vi: He said that whenever we talked to him, we had to bow and say "Your Grace," "Your Lordship," and so on... and if we called him by the name Bilgewater, it was okay too, saying that name was just a title, not a name; and he also said that one of us had to stand by when he ate and drank; and had to do all the little tasks he ordered.
tr: When speaking with him, we had to bow and address him as "Your Excellency," "Your Lordship," or "Honorable Duke" – although it was also acceptable to simply call him "Bridgewater" – because that was not his name, but his title; additionally, one of us had to serve him at meals and attend to his small requests.
es: He said we should bow when speaking to him and say "your grace," or "milord," or "your lordship," and that he didn't mind if we simply called him "Clearwaters," because, as he said, that was a title and not a name, and one of us would have to serve him at mealtimes and do all the little things he wanted.

en: Well, that was all easy, so we done it.
vi: All those measurements weren't difficult, so we obediently followed along.
tr: All of this was very easy, and we did it too.
es: Well, that turned out to be easy, so we did it.

en: All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.
vi: Throughout the entire lunch, Jim stood around serving him and said, "Does the Duke need this, need that?" and so on...
tr: During the meal, Jim stood up and served him, asking, "Would His Excellency like a bit of this or that?"
es: Jim spent the entire dinner standing, serving him and saying, "Would your grace like to try a bit of this or that?" and so on, and it was easy to see that he found it very pleasant.

en: But the old man got pretty silent by-and-by—didn’t have much to say, and didn’t look pretty comfortable over all that petting that was going on around that duke.
vi: The Duke seemed very pleased. But the old man remained silent and said nothing.
tr: It was clear that the man was very pleased with this situation. But the old man had become silent; he seemed to be increasingly disturbed by our circling around the shop and serving him.
es: But the old man remained very silent; he didn't have much to say and didn't seem very pleased with all the attention the duke was getting.

en: He seemed to have something on his mind.
vi: He seemed very annoyed with the demeanor of that duke. It seemed like he was thinking about something.
tr: I think he had something on his mind too.
es: He seemed to be thinking about something.

en: So, along in the afternoon, he says:
vi: By the end of the afternoon, he said:
tr: In the afternoon, he started talking to the duke at some point:
es: So in the afternoon, he goes and says:

en: “Looky here, Bilgewater,” he says, “I’m nation sorry for you, but you ain’t the only person that’s had troubles like that.”
vi: - Hey, Bilgewater, I really sympathize with you. But you're not the only one facing such difficulties.
tr: “Look at me, Bridgewater,” he said, “I am very sorry for you, but you are not the only one with such problems?”
es: —Look, Aguassucias —he goes and says—, I feel really bad for you, but you're not the only one who has had problems of that kind.

en: “No?”
vi: - Not so?
tr: "Am I not?""
es: —No?

en: “No you ain’t.
vi: - That's right.
tr: "No; you are not.
es: —No, you are not the only one.

en: You ain’t the only person that’s ben snaked down wrongfully out’n a high place.”
vi: You are not the only one who has been blatantly brought down like that!
tr: You are not the only person who has been unjustly brought down from a high position."
es: You are not the only one who has been thrown out of the heights in a bad way.

en: “Alas!”
vi: - Heavens!
tr: “What a disaster!”
es: —Ouch!

en: “No, you ain’t the only person that’s had a secret of his birth.”
vi: - No, you are not the only one who keeps secrets about your life.
tr: “You are not the only one with a secret about their birth.”
es: —No, you are not the only one who has a birth secret —and I swear she started to cry.

en: And, by jings, he begins to cry.
vi: Upon saying that, I began to cry uncontrollably.
tr: This time, the old man started crying.
es: —No, you are not the only one who has a birth secret —and I swear she started to cry.

en: “Hold!
vi: - Wait a minute, what are you trying to say?
tr: “Wait a minute!
es: —Wait!

en: What do you mean?”
vi: - Wait a minute, what are you trying to say?
tr: What do you mean?”
es: What do you mean?

en: “Bilgewater, kin I trust you?” says the old man, still sort of sobbing.
vi: - Bilgewater, can I trust you? - He asked, his voice still trembling.
tr: "Bridgewater, can I trust you?" asked the old man, continuing to sob uncontrollably.
es: —Aguassucias, can I trust you? —asks the old man, still half-crying.

en: “To the bitter death!”
vi: - I swear to live with it in my heart, and take it to my grave -
tr: "You can take my life, but you can't take my secret!"
es: —Even the cruelest of deaths!

en: He took the old man by the hand and squeezed it, and says, “That secret of your being: speak!”
vi: That man held the old man's hand tightly, then continued - Tell me, what is the secret of your life?
tr: Holding the old man's hand tightly, "Your secret is safe with me. Tell me!" he said.
es: —he took the old man by the hand, squeezed it, and said—: That secret of yours: speak!

en: “Bilgewater, I am the late Dauphin!”
vi: - Bilgewater, I am the crown prince.
tr: “Bridgewater; I am the heir to the French throne who was thought to be dead!”
es: —Dirty waters, I am the missing dolphin!

en: You bet you, Jim and me stared this time.
vi: This time, both Jim and I stared wide-eyed at the old man.
tr: Jim and I were left standing with our mouths agape this time.
es: You can bet that Jim and I kept our eyes wide open that time.

en: Then the duke says:
vi: The duke asked:
tr: The Duke felt the need to repeat:
es: Then the duke says:

en: “You are what?”
vi: - What did you say?
tr: “What are you?”
es: —What are you?

en: “Yes, my friend, it is too true—your eyes is lookin’ at this very moment on the pore disappeared Dauphin, Looy the Seventeen, son of Looy the Sixteen and Marry Antonette.”
vi: - Yes, my friend, what I just said is true. At this moment, in your eyes is the poor prince, Louis the Seventeenth, and here are Louis the Sixteenth and Marie Antoinette.
tr: “Yes, my friend, this is true… these eyes are looking right now at the poor, lost heir; I am Louis XVII; the son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette.”
es: —Yes, my friend, it is true: you are looking at this moment at the poor missing dolphin, Louis the 17th, son of Louis the 16th, and Marie Antoinette.

en: “You!
vi: - Is that you?
tr: "Is it you?
es: —You!

en: At your age!
vi: Are you really this old?
tr: At this age?
es: At your age!

en: No!
vi: Are you really this old?
tr: Impossible!
es: No!

en: You mean you’re the late Charlemagne; you must be six or seven hundred years old, at the very least.”
vi: If you were the last Charlemagne, you would be six hundred years old by now.
tr: Are you saying you are the last Charlemagne? You should be at least six hundred – seven hundred years old though."
es: You mean to say that you are the late Charlemagne; you must be at least six or seven hundred years old.

en: “Trouble has done it, Bilgewater, trouble has done it; trouble has brung these gray hairs and this premature balditude.
vi: - Because hardships have turned me into such a wretched person, Bilgewater. Hardships have made my hair turn completely white and ask like this.
tr: “Troubles have brought me to this state, Bridgewater; I have fallen into this condition because of my troubles; these gray hairs, this bald head are all due to distress and suffering.
es: —There have been so many problems, Aguassucias, so many problems that have turned my hair gray and brought this premature baldness.

en: Yes, gentlemen, you see before you, in blue jeans and misery, the wanderin’, exiled, trampled-on, and sufferin’ rightful King of France.”
vi: Before your eyes, this person in filthy blue clothes, who has been wandering, tormented, trampled upon, and in pain, is the King of France.
tr: Yes, gentlemen; before you stands the legitimate King of France, wandering in misery, exiled, trampled underfoot, wearing blue jeans.”
es: Yes, gentlemen, before you stands, dressed in cowboy clothes and in misery, the vagabond, the exiled, the persecuted, and the suffering legitimate king of France.

en: Well, he cried and took on so that me and Jim didn’t know hardly what to do, we was so sorry—and so glad and proud we’d got him with us, too.
vi: After speaking, the old man kept crying, making Jim and me not know what to do. We often felt sorry for him and proud too because he came here with us.
tr: He cried and whined so much that Jim and I didn't know what to do, we were very upset – but we were also very pleased and proud to be with him.
es: Well, he burst into tears and got so upset that neither Jim nor I knew what to do, feeling both sorry for him and at the same time happy and proud that he was on the raft with us.

en: So we set in, like we done before with the duke, and tried to comfort him.
vi: So we went to comfort him, as we had comforted the duke before.
tr: So we tried to comfort him just as we had done with the duke before.
es: So we set to work, just as we had done before with the duke, and tried to console him as well.

en: But he said it warn’t no use, nothing but to be dead and done with it all could do him any good; though he said it often made him feel easier and better for a while if people treated him according to his rights, and got down on one knee to speak to him, and always called him “Your Majesty,” and waited on him first at meals, and didn’t set down in his presence till he asked them.
vi: But he said that comforting was useless, only death could relieve him of all his sorrows. But he also felt better when we treated him in certain ways, like kneeling on one knee when speaking to him, always addressing him as "Your Majesty," standing by his side when he ate and drank, and not sitting in his presence unless he permitted it.
tr: But he said it wouldn't do any good, nothing would help him except dying and getting rid of everything; although he said he would feel a little better if people treated him as he deserved; they should kneel on one knee while talking to him; call him "Your Majesty," serve him first at meals, and not sit down until he gave permission.
es: But he said it was no use, that the only thing that could console him was to die once and for all and end everything; although he said that sometimes he felt more comfortable and better if people treated him according to his rights, knelt down to speak to him, always called him "your majesty" and served him first at meals and did not sit in his presence until he said so.

en: So Jim and me set to majestying him, and doing this and that and t’other for him, and standing up till he told us we might set down.
vi: So Jim and I had to address him as "Your Majesty," do various things for him, and stand until he allowed us to sit.
tr: So Jim and I started calling him your majesty, doing this and that for him, and standing until he told us we could sit.
es: So Jim and I started to "majesty" him, doing everything he asked of us and standing until he told us we could sit down.

en: This done him heaps of good, and so he got cheerful and comfortable.
vi: That made him very pleased, showing great joy and amusement.
tr: What we did made him feel very good, he became a cheerful and relaxed man again.
es: That made him feel really good and he became very cheerful and happy.

en: But the duke kind of soured on him, and didn’t look a bit satisfied with the way things was going; still, the king acted real friendly towards him, and said the duke’s great-grandfather and all the other Dukes of Bilgewater was a good deal thought of by his father, and was allowed to come to the palace considerable; but the duke stayed huffy a good while, till by-and-by the king says:
vi: But the duke felt uncomfortable about this. Nevertheless, the King still showed great intimacy with the duke. He said that all the dukes of Bilgewater were remembered by his father and were always invited to the palace. But the duke seemed annoyed. A moment later, the King spoke again:
tr: But this time the duke was frowning; he didn't seem at all pleased with the turn of events; still, the king was really friendly to him, saying that his father loved the duke's great-great-grandfather and the other Dukes of Bridgewater very much and often invited them to the palace; but when the duke couldn't shake off his resentment for a while, the king finally said:
es: But the duke seemed to get angry with him and didn't seem at all satisfied with how things were going; but the king was very friendly with him and said that the duke's great-grandfather and all the other dukes of Aguassucias had the highest regard for his father and could visit the palace many times, but the duke remained angry for quite a while, until finally the king goes and says:

en: “Like as not we got to be together a blamed long time on this h-yer raft, Bilgewater, and so what’s the use o’ your bein’ sour?
vi: - We won't be on this wooden raft together for much longer, Bilgewater, so why are you sad?
tr: “It looks like we will stay on this raft for quite a long time; Bridgewater; what's the use of making a face?
es: —The most likely thing is that we are going to spend a lot of time on this raft, Dirtywaters, so, what good is it to get angry?

en: It’ll only make things oncomfortable.
vi: I was not born a duke, it's not my fault.
tr: You only make things more uncomfortable.
es: It only serves to annoy us.

en: It ain’t my fault I warn’t born a duke, it ain’t your fault you warn’t born a king—so what’s the use to worry?
vi: You were not born a king, it's not your fault either. So why worry about it?
tr: It's not my fault that I wasn't born a Duke, and it's not your fault that you weren't born a king… They say, 'A sharp vinegar harms its own container.'
es: It's not my fault I wasn't born a duke and it's not your fault you weren't born a king, so why worry?

en: Make the best o’ things the way you find ’em, says I—that’s my motto.
vi: Accepting and making the best of our circumstances is what we should do.
tr: Appreciate what you have, that's what I say… That is my motto.
es: What I say is that we have to make the most of things as they are: that's my motto.

en: This ain’t no bad thing that we’ve struck here—plenty grub and an easy life—come, give us your hand, Duke, and le’s all be friends.”
vi: Moreover, life here isn't too uncomfortable, food and drink are still plentiful. Come on, let's shake hands, duke, we are friends after all.
tr: It's not a bad thing that we ended up here… There's plenty of food, we're in high spirits… Come on, give me your hand Duke, let's all be friends now.”
es: And it's not bad luck to have ended up here: good food and an easy life; come on, give me your hand, duke, and let's be friends.

en: The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it.
vi: The Duke reached out his hand to shake. Jim and I were glad to see that.
tr: When the Duke did what he said, Jim and I were very happy.
es: The duke gave it to her, and Jim and I were very glad to see that.

en: It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.
vi: The heavy atmosphere suddenly dissipated, and we felt happy as well. On a raft, everyone must be cheerful and harmonious with each other for life to be bearable for a few moments.
tr: All our discomforts flew away, we felt very good, because there is nothing as terrible as resentment on a raft; the first thing you want on a raft is for everyone to be satisfied, to treat others correctly and well.
es: So we stopped feeling annoyed and were very happy because it would have been a shame not to get along on the raft; because the first thing you need on a raft is for everyone to be happy, to feel good, and to get along with each other.

en: It didn’t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warn’t no kings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds.
vi: Before long, I realized that these two guys were not kings or dukes at all but just swindlers and thieves. But I didn't say a word or show any attitude.
tr: It didn't take me long to realize that these two liars were not a king or a duke, but mere braggarts and frauds.
es: It didn't take me long to realize that those liars were not kings or dukes at all, but the lowest of swindlers and frauds.

en: But I never said nothing, never let on; kept it to myself; it’s the best way; then you don’t have no quarrels, and don’t get into no trouble.
vi: That was the best way to avoid troublesome arguments.
tr: But I definitely didn't open my mouth, I didn't reveal that I understood; that was the best, then you don't have to argue, and you don't get into trouble.
es: But I never said anything or revealed it; I kept it to myself; it's the best way; that way there are no fights and you don't get into trouble.

en: If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I hadn’t no objections, ’long as it would keep peace in the family; and it warn’t no use to tell Jim, so I didn’t tell him.
vi: If they wanted to be called kings or dukes, I would call them that as long as it kept the peace. I didn't tell Jim either because it wouldn't do any good.
tr: If they wanted us to call them king and duke, I wouldn't object as long as we could maintain peace in the family; besides, it wouldn't have been useful to explain this to Jim, so I didn't.
es: If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I had no objection, as long as there was peace in the family, and it was no use telling Jim, so I didn't.

en: If I never learnt nothing else out of pap, I learnt that the best way to get along with his kind of people is to let them have their own way.
vi: If I hadn't learned anything else from my father, I learned one thing here: just live with people like this and let them do whatever they want.
tr: If I learned nothing else from my father, I learned that the only way to get along with people like him was not to mess with them.
es: If I learned anything from my father, it's that the best way to get along with people like that is to let them go their own way.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chapter XX
tr: Chapter Twenty
es: Chapter 20

en: They asked us considerable many questions; wanted to know what we covered up the raft that way for, and laid by in the daytime instead of running—was Jim a runaway nigger?
vi: They asked me a lot of questions: Why did we cover the raft like that? Why did we rest during the day and travel at night? Is Jim the black man who is running away?
tr: The duke and the king asked us a lot of questions; they wondered why we hid on Tuesday, why we hid during the day instead of escaping – or was Jim a runaway black man?
es: THEY ASKED us a bunch of questions; they wanted to know why we were hiding the raft like that and resting during the day instead of moving forward: Was Jim a runaway slave?

en: Says I:
vi: I said:
tr: “For God's sake,” I said, “do runaway negroes go south?”
es: I answered: —For God's sake!

en: “Goodness sakes, would a runaway nigger run south?”
vi: - Oh my God, when has there ever been a black man running away to the South?
tr: “For God's sake,” I said, “do runaway negroes go south?”
es: Would a runaway slave flee to the South?

en: No, they allowed he wouldn’t.
vi: They said that wasn't true.
tr: No; they said it wouldn't go.
es: No, they admitted that they didn't.

en: I had to account for things some way, so I says:
vi: I immediately replied:
tr: But I still needed to explain what had happened somehow. I began to explain:
es: I had to explain things somehow, so I said:

en: “My folks was living in Pike County, in Missouri, where I was born, and they all died off but me and pa and my brother Ike.
vi: - My family is in Pike, Missouri. My whole family is dead, only my father, my younger brother Ike, and I are left.
tr: “My family lived in Pike County, Missouri; I was born there. They all passed away, leaving no one but my father and my brother Ike.
es: —My family lived in Pike County, Missouri, where I was born, and they all died except for me, father, and my brother Ike.

en: Pa, he ’lowed he’d break up and go down and live with Uncle Ben, who’s got a little one-horse place on the river, forty-four mile below Orleans.
vi: My father left home to stay with my uncle Ben. My uncle has a motorboat that ferries passengers across the river, down below, forty-four miles from Orleans.
tr: My father said we would leave everything behind and go down the river to stay with Uncle Ben. Uncle Ben had a nice little piece of land on the river, forty-four miles below Orleans.
es: Father said he preferred to leave and go live with Uncle Ben, who has a little house by the river, forty-four miles down from Orleans.

en: Pa was pretty poor, and had some debts; so when he’d squared up there warn’t nothing left but sixteen dollars and our nigger, Jim.
vi: My father is very poor and in debt. So when my father left, he didn't leave anything behind except sixteen dollars and a black man named Jim.
tr: My father was very poor and had accumulated debts; so when he gathered everything, he only had sixteen dollars and our black servant Jim left.
es: Father was very poor and we had some debts, so when he settled everything, there were only sixteen dollars left and our black man, Jim.

en: That warn’t enough to take us fourteen hundred mile, deck passage nor no other way.
vi: With that little money, we couldn't make the journey by steamboat or any other means.
tr: Even if we slept on the deck, this money wouldn't be enough to take us fourteen hundred miles.
es: That wasn't enough to travel fourteen hundred miles, neither on deck nor in any other way.

en: Well, when the river rose pa had a streak of luck one day; he ketched this piece of a raft; so we reckoned we’d go down to Orleans on it.
vi: Then the flood came, and my father luckily got a raft, and we decided to go to Orleans.
tr: Then, when the river rose, my father got lucky and caught this piece of raft; we thought we could go to Orleans by raft.
es: Well, when the river rose, father had a stroke of luck one day; he found this raft, so we thought of going to Orleans on it.

en: Pa’s luck didn’t hold out; a steamboat run over the forrard corner of the raft one night, and we all went overboard and dove under the wheel; Jim and me come up all right, but pa was drunk, and Ike was only four years old, so they never come up no more.
vi: But unfortunately, one night a steamboat hit one side of the raft. We jumped into the river, diving deep to avoid the paddle wheel; Jim and I escaped unharmed. But my father, who was drunk at the time, and my four-year-old brother Ike did not resurface.
tr: But my father's luck didn't last; one night while on the way, a steamboat passed by the corner of the front of the raft, we all tumbled into the water and dived to avoid the paddlewheel. Jim and I managed to come back up, but my father was drunk, and Ike was only four years old, they never surfaced again.
es: Father's luck didn't last long; a steamboat took off the front corner of the raft one night and we all fell into the water and dove under the wheel; Jim and I came out fine, but father was drunk and Ike was only four years old, so they never came out again.

en: Well, for the next day or two we had considerable trouble, because people was always coming out in skiffs and trying to take Jim away from me, saying they believed he was a runaway nigger.
vi: A few days later, we faced many difficulties because there were people on boats in the middle of the river trying to catch Jim, claiming he was a runaway black man.
tr: For the next couple of days, we were in constant trouble because people coming in boats tried to take Jim away from me, saying he was a runaway slave.
es: For a few days we had a lot of trouble, because people kept coming in boats and trying to take Jim, saying they thought he was a runaway black man.

en: We don’t run daytimes no more now; nights they don’t bother us.”
vi: So now we don't travel during the day anymore, but at night to avoid trouble.
tr: So we no longer travel during the day; no one bothers us at night.”
es: That's why we no longer sail during the day; at night they don't bother us.

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke said:
tr: “Give me some time,” said the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Leave me alone to cipher out a way so we can run in the daytime if we want to.
vi: - Let me think if there's a way to travel during the day.
tr: “I will think of a way for us to be able to travel during the day when necessary.
es: —Let me think of a way that we can sail during the day if we wish.

en: I’ll think the thing over—I’ll invent a plan that’ll fix it.
vi: I'll think about it first. I'll come up with a trick that might solve this.
tr: After thoroughly considering the matter... I will make a plan that will set everything right.
es: I will think about it and come up with a plan to organize ourselves.

en: We’ll let it alone for to-day, because of course we don’t want to go by that town yonder in daylight—it mightn’t be healthy.”
vi: For today, let's not rush into it, because obviously, we shouldn't pass through that town during the day, in case something bad happens.
tr: Let's continue like this for today, because we certainly don't want to pass through that town ahead during the day; it might not be very safe.”
es: Today we will continue like this because naturally we do not want to pass through that village over there in the daylight, it might not be healthy.

en: Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat lightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was beginning to shiver—it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see that.
vi: At night, the sky began to darken and it looked like it was about to rain. Lightning flashed at the horizon.
tr: Towards the evening, the sky clouded over, it was going to rain; lightning was flashing on the horizon, the sound of which did not reach us, and the leaves had started to tremble – a very harsh weather was coming, it was not hard to understand this.
es: Towards the night it began to cloud over and it seemed like it was going to rain; the lightning flashed very low across the sky and the leaves were starting to tremble: it was going to be quite strong, it was easy to see.

en: So the duke and the king went to overhauling our wigwam, to see what the beds was like.
vi: The Duke and the King came into our tent to see how the sleeping arrangements were.
tr: The Duke and the King went to inspect our shelter to see how the beds were.
es: So the duke and the king started to prepare our wigwam to see how the beds were.

en: My bed was a straw tick better than Jim’s, which was a corn-shuck tick; there’s always cobs around about in a shuck tick, and they poke into you and hurt; and when you roll over the dry shucks sound like you was rolling over in a pile of dead leaves; it makes such a rustling that you wake up.
vi: My bed was a straw mat, but it was much more comfortable than Jim's, which was a nest made of corn stalks. The corn stalks were stiff, and every time he turned, the dry leaves rustled, waking him up.
tr: The inside of my mattress was filled with straw and it was more comfortable than Jim's corn husk mattress; the husks would remain inside the mattress, poke your back, and hurt you; moreover, when you turned in bed, the dried husks would make a sound as if you were lying in a pile of dry leaves; they would creak so much that you would wake up.
es: Mine was made of straw, better than Jim's, who had a mattress made of corn leaves; in those corn mattresses there are always grains that get into your skin and hurt, and when you turn over, the dry corn leaves sound like you're crushing a bed of dead leaves and make so much noise that they wake you up.

en: Well, the duke allowed he would take my bed; but the king allowed he wouldn’t.
vi: The Duke demanded to sleep on my bed, but the King refused.
tr: The Duke said he would take my bed, but the King did not allow it.
es: Well, the duke preferred to stay with my bed, but the king said no.

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: The Duke said he would take my bed, but the King did not allow it.
es: He pointed out:

en: “I should a reckoned the difference in rank would a sejested to you that a corn-shuck bed warn’t just fitten for me to sleep on.
vi: - You should know that in terms of rank and position, I am no more suited to a bed made of corn stalks than you are.
tr: “I thought the difference in our positions would remind you that it is not appropriate for me to sleep in the bed with the tassels.
es: —I would say that the difference in rank would suggest to you that a corn mattress is not the most suitable for me.

en: Your Grace’ll take the shuck bed yourself.”
vi: Therefore, you should know your place and understand that lying on that bed is the most appropriate...
tr: Your Excellency should sleep in the bed with the tassels.”
es: Your grace will stay with the corn bed.

en: Jim and me was in a sweat again for a minute, being afraid there was going to be some more trouble amongst them; so we was pretty glad when the duke says:
vi: Jim and I were sweating with fear that the two of them would cause trouble again. But fortunately, the duke said:
tr: Jim and I had started to worry again, fearing that there would be trouble between them; so we were relieved by the duke's response:
es: Jim and I started to worry again for a moment, as we feared there might be more trouble between them, so we were very relieved when the duke went ahead and said:

en: “’Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of oppression.
vi: - My fate is unlucky wherever I go.
tr: “It is my fate to be muddied under the iron heel of the mighty.
es: —It is my eternal destiny: to always see myself crushed under the iron heel of pressure.

en: Misfortune has broken my once haughty spirit; I yield, I submit; ’tis my fate.
vi: The suffering and pain that I have endured up to now have made me lose all my spirit. I surrender. That's just how my fate is.
tr: Misfortune has long taken away my proud spirit; I bow, I surrender; this is my fate.
es: Misfortune has broken my once proud spirit; I yield, I submit; it is my destiny.

en: I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”
vi: In this world, only I am lonely... Please let me suffer, I can endure it.
tr: I am all alone in this world… I must endure my suffering; I can bear it.”
es: I am alone in the world: suffering falls upon me and I can endure it.

en: We got away as soon as it was good and dark.
vi: We set off when it was completely dark.
tr: As soon as it got dark enough, we set out immediately.
es: We left as soon as it was dark enough.

en: The king told us to stand well out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we got a long ways below the town.
vi: The king ordered us to push the raft to the middle of the river and only light the lamps once we were far enough from the city. A while later, we saw clusters of flickering lights by the river. That was the town.
tr: The king told us to stay in the middle of the river and not to show any light until we had gone quite a bit downstream of the town.
es: The king told us to head towards the center of the river and not to show any light until we had passed far enough from the town.

en: We come in sight of the little bunch of lights by-and-by—that was the town, you know—and slid by, about a half a mile out, all right.
vi: The raft smoothly glided past about half a mile. After nearly a mile, we hung up the lamps.
tr: After a while, we saw a small cluster of lights – this cluster was the town – and we passed it without any trouble about half a mile offshore.
es: Soon we came into view of the small cluster of lights that was the town and we slipped by about half a mile away, everything perfectly, everything perfectly.

en: When we was three-quarters of a mile below we hoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o’clock it come on to rain and blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us to both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the duke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night.
vi: Around ten o'clock at night, it started pouring rain, the wind howled intermittently, and thunder rumbled. The king told the two of us to take turns keeping watch carefully until the weather cleared up completely. Meanwhile, he and the duke crawled into the tent to sleep.
tr: When we had gone about three-quarters of a mile downstream, we put up the signal lantern; around ten o'clock, it started to rain, and lightning began to illuminate everything around; the king told us both to keep watch until the weather cleared up; then he and the duke went into the shelter to get ready to sleep.
es: When we were three-quarters of a mile further down, we used our signal lantern, and around ten it started to rain, blow, thunder, and lightning like the devil; so the king told us two to keep watch until the weather improved; then he and the duke crawled into the wigwam to spend the night.

en: It was my watch below till twelve, but I wouldn’t a turned in anyway if I’d had a bed, because a body don’t see such a storm as that every day in the week, not by a long sight.
vi: I had to keep watch until midnight. But even if I were in bed, I probably wouldn't be able to close my eyes. In fact, it hadn't rained and stormed like this all week.
tr: The watch on the downstream side was mine until twelve, but even if I had a bed to sleep in, I wouldn't have gone into the shelter; because you can't see such a storm every day, you don't even get the chance to watch it from a distance.
es: I was on watch until twelve, but I wouldn't have gone to bed even if I had one, because you don't see a storm like that every day, not by a long shot.

en: My souls, how the wind did scream along!
vi: The wind howled intermittently, chillingly.
tr: My God, how the wind was howling!
es: Good heavens, how the wind howled!

en: And every second or two there’d come a glare that lit up the white-caps for a half a mile around, and you’d see the islands looking dusty through the rain, and the trees thrashing around in the wind; then comes a h-whack!—bum! bum! bumble-umble-um-bum-bum-bum-bum—and the thunder would go rumbling and grumbling away, and quit—and then rip comes another flash and another sockdolager.
vi: Occasionally, a streak of lightning illuminated the white-tipped land mounds stretching about half a mile. But the island, seen through the rain, looked as if it were covered in a veil of dust. The trees seemed to be whirling in the wind. The sound of crackling and rumbling arose, then gradually spread out into the distance.
tr: Almost every second, there was a flash of light illuminating the foamy waves around us within a half-mile distance; we could see blurry islands in the rain and trees flapping in the wind; then crack! – the thunder rumbled and roared away with crashes and booms, then it went silent – then another crack of lightning and again a thunder.
es: And every one or two seconds there was a flash that lit up the waves for half a mile around and the islands looked dusty in the rain and the trees swayed in the wind; then there was a brrruuum!... boom! boom! boom, boom, boom, boom, boom, boom! and the thunder rolled away growling and buzzing until it disappeared, and then, wham!, there was another flash and another crash.

en: The waves most washed me off the raft sometimes, but I hadn’t any clothes on, and didn’t mind.
vi: Waves splashed strongly, soaking me completely on the raft. But since I wasn't wearing any clothes, I wasn't afraid of getting wet.
tr: The waves were so big they almost knocked me off the raft, but I didn't care since I had no clothes on.
es: Sometimes the waves almost knocked me off the raft, but since I wasn't wearing anything, I didn't mind.

en: We didn’t have no trouble about snags; the lightning was glaring and flittering around so constant that we could see them plenty soon enough to throw her head this way or that and miss them.
vi: Luckily, thanks to the flashes of lightning, we could see the submerged rocks from afar and avoided hitting them.
tr: The bushes and such that the raft could get caught on were no trouble at all; there was so much lightning that we could see them well in advance and steer the raft around them.
es: We had no trouble with the logs coming down; the lightning lit everything up so we could see the logs coming with more than enough time to steer this way or that and avoid them.

en: I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was.
vi: I stood guard halfway through but got too sleepy, Jim said he would guard for me. Jim is always very good to me.
tr: The second watch was mine, but I was getting really sleepy, so Jim said he could take the first half of my watch; Jim has always been such a kind-hearted person.
es: It was my turn for the middle watch, you know, but by that time I was quite sleepy, so Jim said he would take the first half; Jim always behaved very well in that regard.

en: I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warn’t running so high now.
vi: I crawled into the tent, but the king and the duke were sprawled all over, leaving no room for me. I had to sleep outside the tent, despite the howling wind and rain.
tr: I bent down and went inside the shelter, but I couldn't find a place for myself because the king and the duke were lying with their legs spread out; so I went back outside – I didn't mind the rain because the weather was warm and the waves weren't rising that much anymore.
es: I crawled into the wigwam on all fours, but the king and the duke had stretched out so much that there was no room left, so I stayed outside; I didn't mind the rain, because it was warm and now the waves weren't reaching as high.

en: About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard.
vi: Around two o'clock, the waves became more violent. Jim intended to call me but decided not to because he thought the waves weren't too dangerous yet. But he was wrong, right after that, a big wave surged over my head.
tr: Around two in the night, the waves rose again, Jim was about to call out to me, but then he changed his mind because he thought the waves hadn't risen enough to cause any harm yet; however, he was wrong about that, because a little later a giant wave came and knocked me into the water.
es: But around two o'clock they started rising again and Jim was going to call me, although he changed his mind because he figured they weren't high enough to do us any harm, but he was wrong because very soon one of those huge ones came and threw me into the water.

en: It most killed Jim a-laughing.
vi: Jim looked at me and laughed heartily. The waves kept crashing and splashing all over me. Jim laughed so hard he almost burst.
tr: Jim almost died laughing.
es: Jim almost died laughing.

en: He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
vi: He was a black man who laughed easily, something I rarely encountered.
tr: I've never seen a black man who laughs so easily at everything in my life.
es: Anyway, he was the black man who laughed the most of all those I have known.

en: I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.
vi: I went out to stand guard in place of Jim. He had just laid down and was already snoring. Gradually, the storm subsided. At the first light of dawn, I woke Jim up and then steered the raft into hiding.
tr: I took over the watch and Jim immediately lay down and started snoring; the storm was gradually dying down, and when I saw the first cabin light, I woke Jim up and we started looking for a place to hide the raft for the day.
es: I took the watch and Jim lay down and started snoring; after a while the storm subsided and went away, and as soon as we saw the first light of a cabin, I woke him up and we hid the raft in our hiding place for the day.

en: The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game.
vi: After finishing breakfast, the king took out an old deck of cards and played cards for money with the duke, each game worth five xu.
tr: After breakfast, the king took out a worn deck of playing cards and played a game of "Old Maid" with the duke for a while.
es: After breakfast, the king took out a well-worn deck of cards, and he and the duke played a game of seven and a half for five cents a hand.

en: Then they got tired of it, and allowed they would “lay out a campaign,” as they called it.
vi: After they got bored of playing, they discussed launching a new campaign.
tr: Then they got bored of the game and said they were going to "go on an adventure," as they put it.
es: Then they got bored and said they were going to "plan a campaign," as they called it.

en: The duke went down into his carpet-bag, and fetched up a lot of little printed bills and read them out loud.
vi: The duke rummaged through his pocket, took out a stack of pre-printed papers, and read aloud.
tr: After rummaging through his carpet bag for a bit, the duke pulled out a bunch of printed flyers and started reading them aloud.
es: The king went to look in his bag, from which he took out a bunch of printed leaflets and read them.

en: One bill said, “The celebrated dr Armand de Montalban, of Paris,” would “lecture on the Science of Phrenology” at such and such a place, on the blank day of blank, at ten cents admission, and “furnish charts of character at twenty-five cents apiece.”
vi: One paper read: “The renowned doctor of Paris, Armand de Montanbal, will give a lecture on the treatment of neurological diseases on ... day...” The entrance fee is one hào, and reference charts on the nature of the disease will be provided, each chart costing twenty-five xu.”
tr: One of the flyers read: "The Famous Dr. Armand de Montalban from Paris" will give a lecture on "The Science of Phrenology" at such and such a place on such and such a date, admission is ten cents, and for twenty-five cents, he will also do a character analysis."
es: One of them said that "The famous Dr. Armand de Montalban, from Paris," would give a "lecture on the Science of Phrenology" at such and such a place and on such and such a date, with an admission fee of ten cents, and that he would "chart personality graphs for twenty-five cents each."

en: The duke said that was him.
vi: The duke said that he himself was that doctor.
tr: The duke said that he was this doctor.
es: The duke said that was him.

en: In another bill he was the “world-renowned Shakespearian tragedian, Garrick the Younger, of Drury Lane, London.”
vi: Another paper stated that he was Garrick Younger Iung, from Drury Lane, London, a famous artist known worldwide for performing Shakespearean tragedies.
tr: According to another flyer, he was "The World-Renowned Actor Young Garrick from Drury Lane, London," who performed Shakespearean tragedies.
es: On another leaflet, he was the "world-renowned Shakespearean tragic actor, Young Garrick, from Drury Lane, London."

en: In other bills he had a lot of other names and done other wonderful things, like finding water and gold with a “divining-rod,” “dissipating witch spells,” and so on.
vi: In other papers, he had different names and did various strange jobs, such as having a magic wand to find water, find gold, and to dispel witchcraft spells, etc.
tr: According to other flyers, he had many more names and had done other amazing things, like finding water and gold with a "divining rod," "breaking witches' spells," and so on.
es: On other leaflets, he had different names and did other marvelous things, like finding water and gold with a "divining rod," "exorcising witch spells," etc.

en: By-and-by he says:
vi: Then, he said:
tr: Finally, he said:
es: Then he goes and says:

en: “But the histrionic muse is the darling.
vi: - But the most captivating is still the art of theater.
tr: “But my favorite thing is the miracle of theater.
es: —But my favorite is the histrionic muse.

en: Have you ever trod the boards, Royalty?”
vi: Have you ever been on stage?
tr: Have you ever tasted the dust of the stage before, my King?”
es: Do you have experience on the stage, royalty?

en: “No,” says the king.
vi: - Not yet - The king replied.
tr: "No," said the king.
es: —No —replied the king.

en: “You shall, then, before you’re three days older, Fallen Grandeur,” says the duke.
vi: The Duke said:
tr: “Then you must do it without wasting much time, Your Majesty the Deposed King,” said the duke.
es: —Well, you shall have it before three days have passed, fallen grandeur —says the duke—.

en: “The first good town we come to we’ll hire a hall and do the sword fight in Richard III.
vi: - So, in just a few days, you will have the chance to get on stage.
tr: “In the first good town we come across, we'll rent a hall and perform the sword fight from Richard III and the balcony scene from Romeo and Juliet.
es: In the first good town we reach, we rent a hall and perform the duel from "Richard III" and the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet".

en: and the balcony scene in Romeo and Juliet.
vi: When we reach a nearby big town, I will rent a theater and perform a sword-swallowing act in the play: "King Richard and Juliet".
tr: “In the first good town we come across, we'll rent a hall and perform the sword fight from Richard III and the balcony scene from Romeo and Juliet.
es: In the first good town we reach, we rent a hall and perform the duel from "Richard III" and the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet".

en: How does that strike you?”
vi: What do you think?
tr: What do you say to that?”
es: What do you think?

en: “I’m in, up to the hub, for anything that will pay, Bilgewater; but, you see, I don’t know nothing about play-actin’, and hain’t ever seen much of it.
vi: - Bilgewater, I'm willing to do anything as long as there's money. But I've never acted before, and I haven't seen much either.
tr: “I wholeheartedly embrace anything that brings money, Bridgewater, but I don't understand much about acting, and I haven't seen many actors.
es: —I will do anything as long as it makes money, Aguassucias; but you will see that I don't know anything about acting nor have I ever seen it done.

en: I was too small when pap used to have ’em at the palace.
vi: When I was little, my father used to take me to see plays, but I was too young then.
tr: When my noble father watched theater at the palace, I was very young.
es: I was too young when father had a theater in the palace.

en: Do you reckon you can learn me?”
vi: Can you teach me?
tr: Can you teach me?”
es: Do you think you can teach me?

en: “Easy!”
vi: - It's no big deal!
tr: “Easy!”
es: —Easy!

en: “All right.
vi: - That works.
tr: “Alright then.
es: —Very well.

en: I’m jist a-freezn’ for something fresh, anyway.
vi: Anyway, I am looking for something a bit new.
tr: I was already eager to learn something new.
es: Anyway, I'm already eager to do something new.

en: Le’s commence right away.”
vi: Let's start the day.
tr: Okay, let's start right away.”
es: We can start immediately.

en: So the duke he told him all about who Romeo was and who Juliet was, and said he was used to being Romeo, so the king could be Juliet.
vi: Then the duke explained who Romeo was, who Juliet was, and said that he would play the role of Romeo, while the king would now play the role of Juliet.
tr: The Duke told him everything about Romeo and Juliet; he was used to being Romeo, so the king would have to be Juliet.
es: So the duke told him who Romeo was and who Juliet was and said that he was used to being Romeo, so the king could play Juliet.

en: “But if Juliet’s such a young gal, duke, my peeled head and my white whiskers is goin’ to look oncommon odd on her, maybe.”
vi: - But, Duke, Juliet is such a beautiful girl, I'm afraid my bald head is not quite suitable.
tr: “But Juliet is a very young girl, Duke, I feel like I would look a bit odd in this role with my bald head and white sideburns.”
es: —But if Juliet is such a young girl, Duke, with this bald head and this white beard, it might seem too strange.

en: “No, don’t you worry; these country jakes won’t ever think of that.
vi: - Don't worry. The villagers here will never think of that.
tr: “Don't worry about that... These provincial fools won't care at all.
es: —No, don't worry; these bumpkins won't even notice.

en: Besides, you know, you’ll be in costume, and that makes all the difference in the world; Juliet’s in a balcony, enjoying the moonlight before she goes to bed, and she’s got on her night-gown and her ruffled nightcap.
vi: Besides, when you put on the costume, you look completely different. Juliet stood on the balcony, gazing at the moon before going back inside to sleep, and she had put on her nightgown, with a cloak and a cap embroidered with her name to make it easier to escape.
tr: Besides, you'll have a costume and that makes an extraordinary difference; Juliet is standing on the balcony; watching the moon before going to bed, wearing her nightgown and a frilly nightcap.
es: Besides, you know, you'll be in disguise and that changes everything; Juliet is on the balcony watching the moonlight before going to bed, and she is wearing a nightgown and a lace sleeping cap.

en: Here are the costumes for the parts.”
vi: But here are the costumes for that play.
tr: These are the costumes for this role.”
es: I have the two costumes here.

en: He got out two or three curtain-calico suits, which he said was meedyevil armor for Richard III.
vi: He pulled out two or three sets of coarse cloth clothes from the bag, claiming that they were medieval battle costumes of Richard III and his opponent.
tr: He took out two or three sets of drapery; These were III.
es: He took out two or three suits made of calico for curtains, which he said were the medieval armors of Richard III, and the other guy, a long white cotton nightgown and a matching frilled nightcap.

en: and t’other chap, and a long white cotton nightshirt and a ruffled nightcap to match.
vi: Then there was a long white nightshirt with an outer coat for fighting.
tr: Richard's medieval armor and the other man's costume, along with a long white cotton nightgown and a matching ruffled nightcap.
es: He took out two or three suits made of calico for curtains, which he said were the medieval armors of Richard III, and the other guy, a long white cotton nightgown and a matching frilled nightcap.

en: The king was satisfied; so the duke got out his book and read the parts over in the most splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same time, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the king and told him to get his part by heart.
vi: The king was very pleased. After that, the duke took out his book and read passages about the aforementioned events, gesturing and moving his feet to accurately portray the required actions. Then he handed the book to the king, telling him to memorize his parts.
tr: The king looked satisfied; The duke took out his book and began to read the lines dramatically, opening his arms, jumping up and down, and doing the movements of his part, to show her how acting is done; Then he gave the book to the king and asked him to memorize his part.
es: The king was convinced, so the duke took out his book and read the parts with splendid enthusiasm, jumping and acting at the same time to show how it should be done; then he gave the book to the king so he could memorize his part.

en: There was a little one-horse town about three mile down the bend, and after dinner the duke said he had ciphered out his idea about how to run in daylight without it being dangersome for Jim; so he allowed he would go down to the town and fix that thing.
vi: About three miles from where we were, there was a small town. After lunch, the duke said he had found a trick to travel during the day without any danger to Jim. He said he would go into town to take care of this matter.
tr: There was a small town three miles down the bend; after dinner, he said he had thought of something that would allow us to travel during the day without putting Jim in danger; he would go to the town and take care of it.
es: At the turn of a curve, there was a tiny village, and after lunch, the duke informed us that he had already thought of a way to navigate during the day without any danger to Jim; so he said he would go to the village to arrange everything.

en: The king allowed he would go, too, and see if he couldn’t strike something.
vi: The king said he would go along to lend a hand.
tr: The King also wanted to go, hoping an opportunity might arise.
es: The king said he would also go to see if he could get something useful.

en: We was out of coffee, so Jim said I better go along with them in the canoe and get some.
vi: We were out of coffee, so Jim suggested I might as well take the boat with them to buy some.
tr: We were out of coffee, so Jim said it would be good for me to get in the canoe with them and get some coffee.
es: Since we had run out of coffee, Jim and I said that we would also go with them to buy some.

en: When we got there there warn’t nobody stirring; streets empty, and perfectly dead and still, like Sunday.
vi: When we arrived in the town, the streets were completely deserted, not a single person in sight, and everything was as silent as a Sunday.
tr: When we arrived at the town, we didn't see anyone; the streets were empty, not a sound was heard, it was as if it were a Sunday.
es: When we arrived, there was no one; the streets were empty and completely dead and silent, as if it were Sunday.

en: We found a sick nigger sunning himself in a back yard, and he said everybody that warn’t too young or too sick or too old was gone to camp-meeting, about two mile back in the woods.
vi: We encountered a black man lying in the sun on a yard near the main road. He said that only those who were too young, too old, or too weak stayed at home; everyone else had gone to the ceremony in the forest.
tr: We came across a sick black man sunbathing in a garden, and he told us that everyone who wasn't very small, very sick, or very old had gone to a religious meeting about two miles into the forest.
es: We found a sick black man sunbathing in a courtyard, and he told us that everyone who wasn't too young, too sick, or too old had gone on a mission in the forest, about three miles away.

en: The king got the directions, and allowed he’d go and work that camp-meeting for all it was worth, and I might go, too.
vi: The king asked for directions and then invited me to go with him.
tr: The King had the route thoroughly explained and said he would go and see if anything could be made of that meeting, and that I could go with him.
es: The king asked how to get there and said he was going to work with those religious people to see what he could get out of it, and that I could accompany him.

en: The duke said what he was after was a printing-office.
vi: The Duke wanted to find a printing house.
tr: The Duke said he needed to find a printing press.
es: The duke said he was going to look for a printing press.

en: We found it; a little bit of a concern, up over a carpenter shop—carpenters and printers all gone to the meeting, and no doors locked.
vi: We found a small printing workshop located above a carpenter's shop. Both the carpenter and the printer were at a ceremony, and the door was not locked.
tr: We found a small printing press on the upper floor of a carpenter's shop – all the carpenters and printers had gone to the meeting and the doors were not locked.
es: We found it; a tiny workshop above a carpentry shop; all the carpenters and printers had gone to the sermon and the doors were open.

en: It was a dirty, littered-up place, and had ink marks, and handbills with pictures of horses and runaway niggers on them, all over the walls.
vi: The printing workshop was dirty, messy, full of ink stains, and had drawings of horses and black men riding horses and running away, pasted all around the walls.
tr: The printing press was filthy, with a lot of debris and ink stains on the floor. A lot of posters with pictures of horses and runaway slaves were hung on the walls.
es: The place was very dirty and messy, with walls full of ink stains and leaflets with drawings of horses and runaway slaves.

en: The duke shed his coat and said he was all right now.
vi: The Duke took off his coat, saying that his work was now settled.
tr: The Duke took off his jacket and said he would handle it from here.
es: The duke took off his jacket and said that everything was already sorted out.

en: So me and the king lit out for the camp-meeting.
vi: The king and I went to the festival.
tr: I set off with the King towards the tent meeting.
es: So the king and I went to the religious meeting.

en: We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most awful hot day.
vi: It took us about half an hour to get there. Sweat poured out like a bath because it was very hot that day.
tr: When we arrived there half an hour later, we were drenched in sweat; the weather was incredibly hot.
es: We arrived in about half an hour and soaking wet, because it was terribly hot.

en: There was as much as a thousand people there from twenty mile around.
vi: Thousands of people from as far as twenty miles away gathered here.
tr: There were about a thousand people at the campsite, coming from a distance of approximately twenty miles.
es: There must have been at least a thousand people who had come from twenty miles around.

en: The woods was full of teams and wagons, hitched everywheres, feeding out of the wagon-troughs and stomping to keep off the flies.
vi: In the forest, there were horses and carriages everywhere, with horses tied up all around.
tr: The forest was filled with cars, animals tied here and there were feeding in the car troughs, wagging their tails and stamping their feet to fend off flies.
es: The forest was full of draft animals and carts, tied up everywhere, eating what was in the carts and kicking to ward off the flies.

en: There was sheds made out of poles and roofed over with branches, where they had lemonade and gingerbread to sell, and piles of watermelons and green corn and such-like truck.
vi: There were tents made of wooden stakes covered with branches, selling lemons, ginger, large coconuts, leaf cakes, and many other things.
tr: Lemonade and gingerbread were being sold in arbors made of poles and covered with branches, and also watermelons, corn, and similar things were piled up here and there.
es: There were sheds made of sticks and roofed with branches, where they sold lemonade and gingerbread, with heaps of watermelons, green corn, and things like that.

en: The preaching was going on under the same kinds of sheds, only they was bigger and held crowds of people.
vi: In other huts that seemed more spacious, people were praying.
tr: Sermons were also given in similar arbors, but these arbors were larger and could accommodate a lot of people.
es: The preachers were in sheds of the same type, although larger and filled with people.

en: The benches was made out of outside slabs of logs, with holes bored in the round side to drive sticks into for legs.
vi: Benches made of thin planks with holes to insert sticks for footrests but without backrests.
tr: Rows were made from the outer slices of logs, and holes were drilled into the curved sides to attach footrests.
es: The benches were made of pieces of logs, with holes on the underside to insert sticks that served as legs.

en: They didn’t have no backs.
vi: Benches made of thin planks with holes to insert sticks for footrests but without backrests.
tr: These rows had no backrests.
es: They had no backrests.

en: The preachers had high platforms to stand on at one end of the sheds.
vi: The pastor preached from higher wooden platforms in the corner of the hut.
tr: The preachers stood on high pulpits at one end of the arbor.
es: The preachers had high platforms to stand on at one end of the sheds.

en: The women had on sun-bonnets; and some had linsey-woolsey frocks, some gingham ones, and a few of the young ones had on calico.
vi: Women wore hats and woolen coats, some even carried umbrellas.
tr: The women wore wide-brimmed hats; some wore dresses made of linen mixed with wool, some of striped cotton fabric, and some wore calico dresses.
es: The women wore wide-brimmed hats, and some wore dresses made of a linen and wool blend, others of holland cloth, and some of the young women, of calico.

en: Some of the young men was barefooted, and some of the children didn’t have on any clothes but just a tow-linen shirt.
vi: Some of the men were barefoot, and the children wore only coarse cloth garments.
tr: Some of the young men were barefoot, and some children wore nothing but a cheap shirt.
es: Some of the boys went barefoot, and there were children who wore nothing but a coarse linen shirt.

en: Some of the old women was knitting, and some of the young folks was courting on the sly.
vi: The elderly sat knitting while the village boys secretly flirted with the girls.
tr: Some of the elderly women were knitting, and some of the young people were secretly flirting.
es: Some of the older women were knitting and the younger ones were flirting in secret.

en: The first shed we come to the preacher was lining out a hymn.
vi: In the first tent, a pastor led a hymn.
tr: In the first pavilion we reached, the preacher was singing a hymn.
es: In the first shed we arrived at, the preacher was singing a hymn.

en: He lined out two lines, everybody sung it, and it was kind of grand to hear it, there was so many of them and they done it in such a rousing way; then he lined out two more for them to sing—and so on.
vi: He sang the first two lines, everyone sang along, and it sounded quite good.
tr: He sang two lines, and then everyone repeated after him; it sounded magnificent, there were a lot of people and they were singing in a very exhilarating manner; the preacher sang two more lines – they sang again.
es: He would recite two lines, everyone would sing them, and it was very beautiful to hear, because there were many people and they sang very enthusiastically; then he would recite another two lines for them to sing, and so on.

en: The people woke up more and more, and sung louder and louder; and towards the end some begun to groan, and some begun to shout.
vi: The singing grew more and more enthusiastic. The crowd seemed to get more excited, singing louder and louder.
tr: People were becoming more lively and singing louder; by the end, some were shouting, some were screaming.
es: The people were waking up more and more and singing louder and louder, and towards the end, some began to moan and others to shout.

en: Then the preacher begun to preach, and begun in earnest, too; and went weaving first to one side of the platform and then the other, and then a-leaning down over the front of it, with his arms and his body going all the time, and shouting his words out with all his might; and every now and then he would hold up his Bible and spread it open, and kind of pass it around this way and that, shouting, “It’s the brazen serpent in the wilderness!
vi: By the end of the hymn, they were shouting, some even screaming.
tr: After that, the preacher began his sermon with great sincerity; he was moving from one end of the platform to the other; then he would come forward and lean towards the crowd; his arms and body were constantly in motion, and he was shouting his words with all his might; he would also lift and open the Holy Bible from time to time; shaking it this way and that, he would shout: “The brazen serpent in the wilderness!
es: Then the preacher started to preach, and seriously too, and he strode first to one side of the platform and then to the other, and then he leaned over everyone, moving his arms and body all the time and shouting with all his might, and from time to time he would lift the Bible, open it and pass it from one side to the other, shouting: "It is the bronze serpent of the desert!

en: Look upon it and live!”
vi: Then the pastor began to preach.
tr: Look and live!”
es: Look at it and live!"

en: And people would shout out, “Glory!—A-a-men!”
vi: He walked back and forth on the stage, stepping to one side, then the other, moving to the front, his hands and feet never resting.
tr: The people were also shouting: “Oh my God!.. Amen!”
es: And the people shouted: "Glory! Amen!"

en: And so he went on, and the people groaning and crying and saying amen:
vi: After a while, people could no longer hear what the pastor was saying.
tr: The preacher continued, and the people were sighing and groaning; crying; shouting amen:
es: The preacher continued and the people moaned, shouted, and said amen:

en: “Oh, come to the mourners’ bench!
vi: The whole crowd rushed to the bench reserved for the penitents.
tr: “Ah, come to the line of the mourners!
es: —Ah, come to the bench of lamentations!

en: come, black with sin!
vi: They cried, screamed, and rolled around in utter chaos.
tr: Come those who are blackened with sin!
es: Come, blackened by sin!

en: (amen!) come, sick and sore!
vi: Then, the king stepped up.
tr: (amen!) come the sick and wounded!
es: (Amen!) Come, the sick and the sore!

en: (amen!) come, lame and halt and blind!
vi: The pastor invited him to speak to the people.
tr: (amen!) come the crippled and the weak and the blind!
es: (Amen!) Come, the lame and the crippled and the blind! (Amen!)

en: (amen!) come, pore and needy, sunk in shame!
vi: His voice made everyone fall silent.
tr: (amen!) come the poor and the needy; those drowned in shame!
es: Come, the poor and the needy, full of shame! (Amen!)

en: (a-a-men!) come, all that’s worn and soiled and suffering!—come with a broken spirit!
vi: He recounted that he had been a pirate on the Indian Ocean for thirty years.
tr: (amiiin!) come the worn out; come the tainted and the suffering!., come with your broken spirits!
es: Come, all who feel tired, dirty, and suffering! Come with a broken spirit!

en: come with a contrite heart!
vi: In a battle last spring, many of his comrades were killed.
tr: Come with repentant hearts!
es: Come with a contrite heart!

en: come in your rags and sin and dirt!
vi: Now he needed to recruit new people.
tr: Come with your sins and filth in rags!
es: Come with your rags, your sins, and your filth!

en: the waters that cleanse is free, the door of heaven stands open—oh, enter in and be at rest!” (a-a-men! glory, glory hallelujah!)
vi: But last night, on his way, he was robbed of every penny and thrown onto a ship.
tr: The cleansing waters are free, the gates of heaven are wide open – oh, enter, enter and find peace!” (Amiin! Almighty God, Almighty God, Praise be to God!)
es: The waters that purify are free, the gates of heaven are open, ah, enter and rest! (Amen!) (Glory, glory, hallelujah!).

en: And so on.
vi: He felt glad about that incident.
tr: It continued like this.
es: And so on and so forth.

en: You couldn’t make out what the preacher said any more, on account of the shouting and crying.
vi: He silently vowed that from now on, he would live differently.
tr: Because of the shouting and crying, you could no longer understand what the preacher was saying.
es: With so many screams and cries, it was no longer possible to understand what the preacher was saying.
