en: Folks got up everywheres in the crowd, and worked their way just by main strength to the mourners’ bench, with the tears running down their faces; and when all the mourners had got up there to the front benches in a crowd, they sung and shouted and flung themselves down on the straw, just crazy and wild.
vi: He would return to the Indian Ocean to advise the remaining pirates to lead an honest life.
tr: People from within the crowd were standing up; making their way with difficulty, they came to the row of mourners with tears in their eyes; after all the mourners filled the front rows, they sang hymns; they shouted; they threw themselves onto the straw on the ground as if they had gone mad.
es: In the middle of the group, there were people who stood up and elbowed their way to the bench of lamentations, their faces bathed in tears, and when everyone had gathered there in a group in the front benches, they began to sing, scream, and throw themselves onto the straw, completely crazed and out of control.

en: Well, the first I knowed the king got a-going, and you could hear him over everybody; and next he went a-charging up on to the platform, and the preacher he begged him to speak to the people, and he done it.
vi: He believed he could do this better than anyone else because he was familiar with every pirate.
tr: I saw that our king had also gone to their side, drowning out everyone's voices with his shouts; then he broke away from the crowd and walked to the podium, asking the preacher for permission to speak to the people.
es: Well, before I could realize it, the king had set off and could be seen above everyone else, and then he jumped onto the platform and the preacher asked him to speak to the public, and he did.

en: He told them he was a pirate—been a pirate for thirty years out in the Indian Ocean—and his crew was thinned out considerable last spring in a fight, and he was home now to take out some fresh men, and thanks to goodness he’d been robbed last night and put ashore off of a steamboat without a cent, and he was glad of it; it was the blessedest thing that ever happened to him, because he was a changed man now, and happy for the first time in his life; and, poor as he was, he was going to start right off and work his way back to the Indian Ocean, and put in the rest of his life trying to turn the pirates into the true path; for he could do it better than anybody else, being acquainted with all pirate crews in that ocean; and though it would take him a long time to get there without money, he would get there anyway, and every time he convinced a pirate he would say to him, “Don’t you thank me, don’t you give me no credit; it all belongs to them dear people in Pokeville camp-meeting, natural brothers and benefactors of the race, and that dear preacher there, the truest friend a pirate ever had!”
vi: And although he had no money left in his pocket and it would take a long time to get back there, he would still go. And every time he converted a pirate, he would tell them: “Please don’t thank me. All the gratitude belongs to the people of Pokeville festival, those who have helped humanity, and that pastor, the truest friend you have never had.” After speaking, the old man cried loudly.
tr: He told the crowd that he was a pirate, had been pirating in the Indian Ocean for thirty years; in the battles he fought last spring, his crew had dwindled significantly and now he had returned home to find new men, but thank God he had been robbed last night and had disembarked from a steamboat without a single cent in his pocket. He considered himself lucky for what had happened to him, because he was now a new man and for the first time in his life he felt happy; despite being poor, he would immediately start working and return to the Indian Ocean to dedicate his life to setting other pirates on the right path; because he knew all the pirates in that ocean well and was the perfect man for the job; it would be difficult to go there without money in his pocket, but he would still go and whenever he guided a pirate to the right path, he would say to him: “Don't thank me, the honor does not belong to me, but to the dear people at the Pokeville meeting; they are our brothers in this world and the next and the benefactors of humanity – this dear preacher is the best friend a pirate could have!”
es: He told them that he was a pirate, that he had been a pirate for thirty years in the Indian Ocean, and that he had almost lost his crew last spring in a fight and now he had come back home to take some new sailors, but thank God last night he had been robbed and landed from a steamboat without a penny, and now he was glad; it was the best thing that had ever happened to him in his life, because now he was a changed man and felt happy for the first time in his life, and despite how poor he was, he was going to start working immediately to return to the Indian Ocean and spend the rest of his life trying to bring pirates back to the path of truth, because he could do it better than anyone else, as he knew all the pirate crews in that ocean, and although it would take him a long time to get there without money, he would go anyway, and every time he convinced a pirate he would say: "Don't thank me, don't give me any credit; it all belongs to those wonderful people at the Pokeville religious meeting, natural brothers and benefactors of the race, and to that dear preacher you see there, the truest friend a pirate has ever had!"

en: And then he busted into tears, and so did everybody.
vi: Seeing this, everyone else also cried. Then a few people shouted.
tr: Then she burst into tears, and everyone else started crying too.
es: And then she started crying, and everyone else did the same.

en: Then somebody sings out, “Take up a collection for him, take up a collection!”
vi: - Let's raise money to help him!
tr: Then I heard someone shout: "Let's collect money for her, come on, reach into your pockets!"
es: Then someone shouted: "Let's take up a collection! A collection!"

en: Well, a half a dozen made a jump to do it, but somebody sings out, “Let him pass the hat around!”
vi: So, five or six people rushed over, but someone said: - Tell him to hold out his hat and we'll put money into it.
tr: Five or six people rushed to collect money, but someone else shouted, "It would be better if she passed around her hat."
es: Half a dozen jumped to do it, but someone shouted: "Let him pass the hat!"

en: Then everybody said it, the preacher too.
vi: Everyone else said the same, even the pastor.
tr: Everyone, including the preacher, said that would be better.
es: Everyone said the same, including the preacher.

en: So the king went all through the crowd with his hat swabbing his eyes, and blessing the people and praising them and thanking them for being so good to the poor pirates away off there; and every little while the prettiest kind of girls, with the tears running down their cheeks, would up and ask him would he let them kiss him for to remember him by; and he always done it; and some of them he hugged and kissed as many as five or six times—and he was invited to stay a week; and everybody wanted him to live in their houses, and said they’d think it was an honor; but he said as this was the last day of the camp-meeting he couldn’t do no good, and besides he was in a sweat to get to the Indian Ocean right off and go to work on the pirates.
vi: So the king extended his hat, went around the crowd, wiping his tears, blessing them, and thanking everyone for their kindness towards the pirates. Occasionally, a few beautiful girls, with tears streaming down their faces, would step forward and ask for an old kiss to remember. He agreed immediately, and some were hugged tightly and kissed five or six times by him. Then he was invited to stay for a week. Everyone wanted to invite him to their home, saying it was an honor for them. But he declined because he was in a hurry to return to the Indian Ocean to persuade his comrades.
tr: Upon this, the king wiped away his tears and began to walk among the crowd with his hat; meanwhile, he was praying for them, praising and thanking them for doing so much good for the poor pirates far away; from time to time, very cute girls would stand up with tears streaming down their cheeks, kiss him, and beg him to allow them to keep his memory; he never objected, sometimes hugging and kissing some of them five or six times – he was invited to stay in the town for a week; everyone wanted to host him in their home and said it would be an honor; but the king said that since it was the last day of the meeting, it was not necessary, and moreover, he was in a hurry to set sail immediately towards the Indian Ocean and work among the pirates.
es: So the king walked among the people with his hat, wiping his eyes and blessing the people, praising them and thanking them for being so good to the poor pirates far away, and at every moment, the prettiest of the girls, all tearful, would come and ask him if they could kiss him to have a memory of him, and he always kissed them, and some of them he kissed and hugged at least five or six times, and they invited him to stay for a week, and everyone wanted him to sleep in their houses because they said it was an honor, but he said that since it was the last day of the mission, he could no longer do any good, and besides, he was in a hurry to get to the Indian Ocean as soon as possible and start working with the pirates.

en: When we got back to the raft and he come to count up he found he had collected eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents.
vi: Upon returning to the wooden raft, he counted a total of eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents.
tr: When we returned to the room, we saw that he had collected eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents when he counted the money.
es: When we returned to the raft and he did the count, he found that he had gathered eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents.

en: And then he had fetched away a three-gallon jug of whisky, too, that he found under a wagon when he was starting home through the woods.
vi: He also swiped two bottles of whiskey that were under the trunk of a car on the edge of the forest.
tr: Additionally, he had found and taken a three-gallon whiskey barrel from under a car on the way home.
es: And in addition, he had taken a three-gallon demijohn of whiskey that he had found under a cart when coming home through the forest.

en: The king said, take it all around, it laid over any day he’d ever put in in the missionarying line.
vi: He said this was the best haul, even better than the days when he had to preach like that pastor.
tr: He said that all the scams he had pulled off in religious meetings throughout his life paled in comparison to today's.
es: The king said that all things considered, it was the best day he had ever had in the mission work.

en: He said it warn’t no use talking, heathens don’t amount to shucks alongside of pirates to work a camp-meeting with.
vi: He said this was the best haul, even better than the days when he had to preach like that pastor.
tr: There was no need to beat around the bush; when it came to shaking down religious meetings, all the infidels trailed behind the pirates.
es: He said there was nothing to be done, that pagans are worth nothing compared to pirates if one wants to squeeze the most out of a religious mission.

en: The duke was thinking he’d been doing pretty well till the king come to show up, but after that he didn’t think so so much.
vi: The duke thought that he had done something even more interesting than the king.
tr: Until the king arrived, the duke thought he was doing quite well, but then he changed his mind.
es: The duke had thought he had done quite well until the king showed up, but afterward, it didn't seem so.

en: He had set up and printed off two little jobs for farmers in that printing-office—horse bills—and took the money, four dollars.
vi: He had printed some things for a few landowners, like horse purchase papers, and received four dollars.
tr: He had done two small jobs for the farmers at the printing press –horse advertisements– and earned four dollars in return.
es: He had prepared and printed two small jobs for farmers at that printing press (for horse sales) and had been paid four dollars.

en: And he had got in ten dollars’ worth of advertisements for the paper, which he said he would put in for four dollars if they would pay in advance—so they done it.
vi: Then he earned another ten dollars for advertising in a newspaper.
tr: Then he had gotten a ten-dollar advertisement for the newspaper, but he had said he would settle for four dollars if they paid upfront – and they had agreed.
es: He had collected advertisements in the newspaper worth ten dollars, which he said he could reduce to four dollars if they paid in advance, which they did.

en: The price of the paper was two dollars a year, but he took in three subscriptions for half a dollar apiece on condition of them paying him in advance; they were going to pay in cordwood and onions as usual, but he said he had just bought the concern and knocked down the price as low as he could afford it, and was going to run it for cash.
vi: Thus, he made nine and a half dollars and considered that he had done an honest day's work.
tr: The price of the newspaper was two dollars a year, but he had subscribed three people for half a dollar each on the condition that they paid upfront; the men, as usual, wanted to pay with wood and onions, but he had said that he had recently acquired the printing press, had lowered the price as much as possible, and therefore would only accept cash.
es: The price of the newspaper was two dollars a year, but he accepted three subscriptions for half a dollar, on the condition that they paid in advance; they were going to pay in wood and onions, as usual, but he told them he had just bought the business and lowered the prices as much as he could, so he had to collect everything in cash.

en: He set up a little piece of poetry, which he made, himself, out of his own head—three verses—kind of sweet and saddish—the name of it was, “Yes, crush, cold world, this breaking heart”—and he left that all set up and ready to print in the paper, and didn’t charge nothing for it.
vi: Thus, he made nine and a half dollars and considered that he had done an honest day's work.
tr: He had made up a three-stanza poem from his own mind; the poem, which gave a feeling both sweet and sorrowful, was titled, “Damn this broken heart of mine, oh merciless world.” He had prepared the type and made it ready to be printed in the newspaper and had not taken any money for it.
es: He had printed a small poem of three verses invented by himself, very sentimental and sad, titled "Yes, break, cold world, this broken heart," and had left it ready to print in the newspaper, without charging anything in return.

en: Well, he took in nine dollars and a half, and said he’d done a pretty square day’s work for it.
vi: Thus, he made nine and a half dollars and considered that he had done an honest day's work.
tr: In the end, he had pocketed nine and a half dollars and thought that was quite good for a day.
es: Well, he had made nine and a half dollars and said it wasn't bad for a whole day's work.

en: Then he showed us another little job he’d printed and hadn’t charged for, because it was for us.
vi: Then he showed us a notice that he had printed for free, because it was for us.
tr: Then he showed us another advertisement that he had printed and not taken money for, this time it was for us.
es: Then he showed us another leaflet that he had printed and had not charged for, because it was for us.

en: It had a picture of a runaway nigger with a bundle on a stick over his shoulder, and “$200 reward” under it.
vi: It was a picture of a runaway black man, carrying a stick over his shoulder with a bundle hanging from it, with the caption underneath: "Two hundred dollars reward."
tr: The advertisement featured a picture of a black man running away with a bundle tied to a stick over his shoulder, and underneath it said "200 dollars reward".
es: It had a drawing of a fugitive black man with a bundle on his shoulder and written underneath "Reward of two hundred dollars."

en: The reading was all about Jim, and just described him to a dot.
vi: The person in the picture was Jim.
tr: The description detailed Jim's appearance down to the smallest detail.
es: It was all about Jim and described him exactly.

en: It said he run away from St. Jacques’ plantation, forty mile below New Orleans, last winter, and likely went north, and whoever would catch him and send him back he could have the reward and expenses.
vi: The notice also stated that Jim had escaped from the St. Jacque plantation, forty miles below New Orleans, last winter and was apparently heading north. Whoever captured him and brought him back would receive the reward and be reimbursed for other expenses.
tr: It also mentioned that the black man had escaped from the St. Jacques plantation forty miles below New Orleans last winter and was likely heading north, and that those who caught and returned him would receive both the reward and their expenses.
es: It said that he had escaped from the Saint Jacques plantation, forty miles down from New Orleans last winter, and had probably gone North, and whoever captured and returned him could claim the reward and expenses.

en: “Now,” says the duke, “after to-night we can run in the daytime if we want to.
vi: The Duke said: - From today, if we want, we can travel during the day.
tr: “After tonight, if you want, we can travel during the day as well,” said the duke.
es: —And now —said the duke—, starting tonight we can sail during the day if we want.

en: Whenever we see anybody coming we can tie Jim hand and foot with a rope, and lay him in the wigwam and show this handbill and say we captured him up the river, and were too poor to travel on a steamboat, so we got this little raft on credit from our friends and are going down to get the reward.
vi: If we meet anyone, we can tie Jim's hands and feet with a rope, place Jim in that tent, then show this paper and say that we caught him by the river. Because we don't have enough money for the boat, we have to borrow this wooden raft to go claim the reward.
tr: “If we see someone coming, we’ll tie Jim’s hands and feet with rope and lay him in the shelter, show the visitors the notice, and tell them that we caught him while he was going up the river, that we borrowed this raft from our friends because we didn’t have money to travel by steamboat, and that we’re going to collect the reward.
es: When we see someone coming, we can tie Jim hand and foot with a rope and put him in the wigwam, show this leaflet and say that we captured him upriver and that we were too poor to travel on a steamboat, so our friends gave us this raft on credit and we came down to collect the reward.

en: Handcuffs and chains would look still better on Jim, but it wouldn’t go well with the story of us being so poor.
vi: If we had iron chains to put on Jim, it would be better, but it doesn't fit with the story that we're too poor.
tr: Although handcuffs and chains would look better, it would contradict our story of being very poor.
es: It would be better with handcuffs and chains, but that wouldn't fit with the story that we're so poor.

en: Too much like jewelry.
vi: So the rope is more reasonable.
tr: It would be like wearing jewelry.
es: That would be like putting jewelry on him.

en: Ropes are the correct thing—we must preserve the unities, as we say on the boards.”
vi: We all thought that the duke was really wise.
tr: It’s best to use rope – as we always say in plays, we need to maintain consistency.”
es: The right thing is some ropes: we have to maintain the units, as we say on stage.

en: We all said the duke was pretty smart, and there couldn’t be no trouble about running daytimes.
vi: And so, we weren't worried about traveling during the day at all.
tr: We all said that the duke was very clever and that there would no longer be any harm in traveling during the day.
es: We all said that the duke was very clever and that there would be no problems navigating during the day.

en: We judged we could make miles enough that night to get out of the reach of the powwow we reckoned the duke’s work in the printing office was going to make in that little town; then we could boom right along if we wanted to.
vi: We discussed among ourselves that night that we could travel a few more miles to get out of this area and then go wherever we wanted.
tr: We thought we would cover enough distance that night to get away from the commotion caused by what the duke had done at the printing house in that small town; after that, we could continue our journey if we wished.
es: We thought that that night we could cover quite a few miles to get away from the commotion we figured the duke's work would cause at the printing shop in that town; after that, we could navigate whenever we wanted.

en: We laid low and kept still, and never shoved out till nearly ten o’clock; then we slid by, pretty wide away from the town, and didn’t hoist our lantern till we was clear out of sight of it.
vi: We lay down, silently without speaking, until nearly ten o'clock at night without showing ourselves. Then we quietly left, quite far from the town, and didn't put up any signal lights until we were completely out of sight.
tr: We avoided showing ourselves and making noise, we did not appear in public until ten o'clock, then we set out quite far from the town and did not light our lantern until the town was completely out of sight.
es: We remained hidden and silent and did not come out until nearly ten; afterward, we slipped away, quite a distance from the town, and did not raise the lantern until we had lost sight of it.

en: When Jim called me to take the watch at four in the morning, he says:
vi: Jim woke me up to take the watch at four in the morning. He asked:
tr: When Jim woke me up at four in the morning to take over the watch, he asked:
es: When Jim called me to take his four a.m. watch, he said:

en: “Huck, does you reck’n we gwyne to run acrost any mo’ kings on dis trip?”
vi: - Huck, do you think we will encounter any other kings on this trip?
tr: “Huck, do we rob other people on the road?”
es: —Huck, do you think we are going to meet more kings like these on this trip?

en: “No,” I says, “I reckon not.”
vi: I replied: - No.
tr: “No,” I said, “I don't think so at all.”
es: —No —I replied—. I suppose not.

en: “Well,” says he, “dat’s all right, den.
vi: - He said:
tr: “Alright then,” he said.
es: —Alright —he continued—, then it's fine.

en: I doan’ mine one er two kings, but dat’s enough.
vi: - That will do. Two kings like this are more than enough.
tr: “I can handle two scoundrels, but I don't want more.
es: I don't care about one or two kings, but I don't want any more.

en: Dis one’s powerful drunk, en de duke ain’ much better.”
vi: This king is an alcoholic. And that duke over there is no better.
tr: This scoundrel is a complete drunkard, and the shopkeeper is no better.”
es: This one is a drunkard and the duke isn't far behind him either.

en: I found Jim had been trying to get him to talk French, so he could hear what it was like; but he said he had been in this country so long, and had so much trouble, he’d forgot it.
vi: There were times when I saw Jim insistently asking the king to speak French so he could try to understand; but the old man said that he had been in this country for so long that he had forgotten everything. Bookshelf Share
tr: I learned that Jim tried to make the king speak French to hear how it was spoken, but the king said he had forgotten French because he had been in this country for so long and had gone through so many ordeals.
es: I found out that Jim had tried to make him speak in French to see what it sounded like, but he said that he had been in this country for so long and had had so many problems that he had forgotten it.

en: CHAPTER XXI.
vi: Chapter XXI
tr: Chapter Twenty-One
es: Chapter 21

en: It was after sun-up now, but we went right on and didn’t tie up.
vi: The sun was already high, but we continued on without stopping to hide the raft as usual.
tr: The sun had already risen, but we continued on our way, we hadn't tied the raft to anywhere.
es: IT WAS AFTER DAWN, but we kept going without dropping anchor.

en: The king and the duke turned out by-and-by looking pretty rusty; but after they’d jumped overboard and took a swim it chippered them up a good deal.
vi: Occasionally, the king and the duke would step out, looking tired. But when they jumped into the river to bathe, they immediately became alert.
tr: The king and the duke, who were hungover from the night before, staggered out of the shelter one by one; but jumping into the water and swimming a bit did them a lot of good.
es: The king and the duke eventually got up, looking very tired, but after jumping into the water and swimming for a while, they seemed much more lively.

en: After breakfast the king he took a seat on the corner of the raft, and pulled off his boots and rolled up his britches, and let his legs dangle in the water, so as to be comfortable, and lit his pipe, and went to getting his Romeo and Juliet by heart.
vi: After breakfast, the king took off his shoes, rolled up his pants, and dipped his feet into the water. Then he lit a cigarette and sat murmuring to memorize his part in Romeo and Juliet.
tr: After breakfast, the king sat in a corner of the raft, took off his boots, rolled up his pant legs, dangled his feet in the water, got comfortable, lit his pipe, and started memorizing Romeo and Juliet.
es: After breakfast, the king sat in a corner of the raft, took off his boots, rolled up his pants, and left his legs in the water to be comfortable, lit his pipe, and started memorizing his "Romeo and Juliet."

en: When he had got it pretty good, him and the duke begun to practice it together.
vi: Once he had memorized it quite well, he and the duke rehearsed together.
tr: After he had learned his role well, they started practicing together with the duke.
es: When he knew it quite well, he and the duke began rehearsing it together.

en: The duke had to learn him over and over again how to say every speech; and he made him sigh, and put his hand on his heart, and after a while he said he done it pretty well; “only,” he says, “you mustn’t bellow out Romeo!
vi: The duke had to instruct him repeatedly, making him practice long verses and place his hand over his heart. After a while of rehearsing, he praised the king and said: - It's just that every time you call out the name Romeo, you howl like a wolf.
tr: The duke had to teach him how to say each line over and over again; he showed him how to place his hand on his heart and sigh, and after a while, he said he was performing his role quite well; "just," he said, "no bellowing like a bull when you say Romeo!... you'll say it softly, as if you're sick, suffering... you'll say R-o-o-meo!
es: The duke had to show him over and over how to deliver each speech, making him sigh and place his hand on his heart.

en: that way, like a bull—you must say it soft and sick and languishy, so—R-o-o-meo!
vi: You have to say it very gently, like this: Ro-me-o.
tr: The duke had to teach him how to say each line over and over again; he showed him how to place his hand on his heart and sigh, and after a while, he said he was performing his role quite well; "just," he said, "no bellowing like a bull when you say Romeo!... you'll say it softly, as if you're sick, suffering... you'll say R-o-o-meo!
es: After a while, he said he had done it quite well: "Only you mustn't shout 'Romeo!' like a bull; you have to say it softly and languidly, like this: 'Rooomeo!'; that's the point, because Juliet is just a charming girl, you know, and she doesn't bray like a donkey.

en: that is the idea; for Juliet’s a dear sweet mere child of a girl, you know, and she doesn’t bray like a jackass.”
vi: There, like that, because Juliet is a gentle girl, so she can't screech like a donkey.
tr: because Juliet is a sweet and lovely young girl, she doesn't bray like a donkey."
es: After a while, he said he had done it quite well: "Only you mustn't shout 'Romeo!' like a bull; you have to say it softly and languidly, like this: 'Rooomeo!'; that's the point, because Juliet is just a charming girl, you know, and she doesn't bray like a donkey.

en: Well, next they got out a couple of long swords that the duke made out of oak laths, and begun to practice the sword fight—the duke called himself Richard III.; and the way they laid on and pranced around the raft was grand to see.
vi: Then, the two of them took out a pair of wooden swords that the duke had carved, and began to practice fencing. The duke played the role of King Richard III. They chased each other on the raft, looking quite frightening.
tr: Then they brought out a pair of swords made of oak by the duke and began to try sword fighting – the duke called himself Richard III. It was very impressive to watch them fight and jump around on the raft.
es: Well, then they took out a pair of long swords that the duke had made from oak slats and started to practice the duel: the duke said he was Richard III, and it was wonderful to see them jumping and leaping around the raft.

en: But by-and-by the king tripped and fell overboard, and after that they took a rest, and had a talk about all kinds of adventures they’d had in other times along the river.
vi: Suddenly, the king slipped and fell into the water with a splash. They sat down again, talking to each other about all sorts of adventures they had experienced before.
tr: But after a while, the king got tired and lost his balance, falling into the water; after that, they rested a bit and talked about other adventures they had along the river.
es: But then the king tripped and fell into the water, and afterward, they rested and started talking about all the adventures they had had on the river in the past.

en: After dinner the duke says:
vi: After finishing lunch, the duke said to the king:
tr: In the evening after dinner, the duke said, "Alright, Capet, we want this to be a first-class show, so we need to make some additions.
es: After eating, the duke said:

en: “Well, Capet, we’ll want to make this a first-class show, you know, so I guess we’ll add a little more to it.
vi: - We have to make the performance top-notch, you understand?
tr: In the evening after dinner, the duke said, "Alright, Capet, we want this to be a first-class show, so we need to make some additions.
es: —Well, Capeto, we want this to be a top-quality show, you know, so we're going to add something more to it.

en: We want a little something to answer encores with, anyway.”
vi: Therefore, we need to embellish it a bit to make it richer, just in case the audience asks for an encore, saying "encore," so we have something more to perform.
tr: If the audience calls for an encore, we should have something to perform on stage."
es: Anyway, we need to have something to respond to the encores.

en: “What’s onkores, Bilgewater?”
vi: - What is Encore, Bilgewater?
tr: “What do you say, Bridgewater?”
es: —What is this about encores, Aguassucias?

en: The duke told him, and then says:
vi: The Duke explained to the old man, then said:
tr: The Duke told him, then said, "If they want me again, I'll do a Scottish dance or a sailor's dance; you... aha, I've got it... you can perform Hamlet's soliloquy."
es: The duke told him and added:

en: “I’ll answer by doing the Highland fling or the sailor’s hornpipe; and you—well, let me see—oh, I’ve got it—you can do Hamlet’s soliloquy.”
vi: - I will respond to their request with a wild dance from the highlands or from the sailors. As for you, you can perform Hamlet's monologue.
tr: The Duke told him, then said, "If they want me again, I'll do a Scottish dance or a sailor's dance; you... aha, I've got it... you can perform Hamlet's soliloquy."
es: —I can do a Scottish dance or play the sailor's bagpipe and you ... let's see... ah, I know: you can do Hamlet's monologue.

en: “Hamlet’s which?”
vi: - What of Hamlet?
tr: “What's up with Hamlet?”
es: —The what of Hamlet?

en: “Hamlet’s soliloquy, you know; the most celebrated thing in Shakespeare.
vi: - Hamlet's soliloquy. It is the most famous passage of Shakespeare.
tr: “Here is Hamlet's monologue; it is the most famous scene in Shakespeare.
es: —Hamlet's monologue, you know: the most famous one by Shakespeare.

en: Ah, it’s sublime, sublime!
vi: My God, it is incredibly sacred, always captivating the audience.
tr: Oh, what a magnificent scene it is!
es: Ah, it's sublime, sublime!

en: Always fetches the house.
vi: My God, it is incredibly sacred, always captivating the audience.
tr: Everyone is left in awe.
es: It always drives them crazy.

en: I haven’t got it in the book—I’ve only got one volume—but I reckon I can piece it out from memory.
vi: I don't have that entire passage in this book, only a single volume.
tr: It's not in this book though... I only have one volume in my hand... But I think I can recite it from memory.
es: It's not in this book, because I only have one volume, but I think I can remember it by heart.

en: I’ll just walk up and down a minute, and see if I can call it back from recollection’s vaults.”
vi: Let me walk around a bit, see if I can recall it.
tr: I just need to pace for a minute and search through the cellar of my memories.”
es: I'll see if I can extract it from the vaults of memory while walking.

en: So he went to marching up and down, thinking, and frowning horrible every now and then; then he would hoist up his eyebrows; next he would squeeze his hand on his forehead and stagger back and kind of moan; next he would sigh, and next he’d let on to drop a tear.
vi: The Duke walked up and down looking very thoughtful, his eyebrows raised high, making him look very fierce.
tr: Thinking about this, he began to walk back and forth, occasionally furrowing his brows in a terrifying manner; then he would raise his eyebrows, place his hand on his forehead, and step back with a groan; then he would sigh, and shed a tear.
es: So he dedicated himself to pacing up and down, thinking and frowning horribly at every moment; then he would raise his eyebrows; then he would press his forehead with his hand and lean back, as if groaning; then he would sigh and shed a tear.

en: It was beautiful to see him.
vi: Then he sighed deeply, a hot tear rolled down his cheek, looking quite ridiculous.
tr: It was very enjoyable to watch him.
es: It was wonderful to see.

en: By-and-by he got it.
vi: A moment later, he remembered and told us to pay attention.
tr: Gradually, he remembered.
es: Finally, he remembered.

en: He told us to give attention.
vi: A moment later, he remembered and told us to pay attention.
tr: He told us to pay attention.
es: He told us to listen to him.

en: Then he strikes a most noble attitude, with one leg shoved forwards, and his arms stretched away up, and his head tilted back, looking up at the sky; and then he begins to rip and rave and grit his teeth; and after that, all through his speech, he howled, and spread around, and swelled up his chest, and just knocked the spots out of any acting ever I see before.
vi: With a noble gesture, one foot forward, both hands extended in front, head slightly tilted back, he then began to grind his teeth, speaking deliriously and emphasizing certain parts.
tr: He took his most noble stance, put one foot forward, spread his arms, threw his head back and looked up to the sky; he began to shout and scream wildly and grind his teeth; then he recited the tirade howlingly, making gestures with his arms and puffing out his chest.
es: He adopted a most noble posture, with one leg forward, arms extended, and head thrown back, looking at the sky, and began to shout, groan, and gnash his teeth, and after that, throughout his entire speech, he was howling and moving and puffing out his chest and the truth is that it was the most wonderful performance I have seen in my life.

en: This is the speech—I learned it, easy enough, while he was learning it to the king:
vi: With a noble gesture, one foot forward, both hands extended in front, head slightly tilted back, he then began to grind his teeth, speaking deliriously and emphasizing certain parts.
tr: Honestly, it was a performance that surpassed all the actors I had seen until that day. I can repeat his words exactly... I memorized them all easily while he was teaching the king: There is one more possibility, do you mean dying?
es: This was his speech, which I easily memorized while he taught it to the king:

en: To be, or not to be; that is the bare bodkin
vi: I had never seen a performance like that before.
tr: It is a dagger drawn from its sheath
es: To be or not to be; there's the rub

en: That makes calamity of so long life;
vi: Emphasizing every part, truly, I had never seen such a performance before.
tr: Making long life a hell;
es: which turns such a long life into a calamity;

en: For who would fardels bear, till Birnam Wood do come to Dunsinane,
vi: The entire monologue was filled with roaring and then sobbing.
tr: Who until Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane Who can bear this burden
es: for who could bear his burden until Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane,

tr: The main dish of the great nature
es: second course of great nature.

en: And makes us rather sling the arrows of outrageous fortune
vi: It seems like he was born to play this role.
tr: The arrows shot by the cruel fate instead of him
es: And makes us prefer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune rather than fly to others that we know not of?

en: Than fly to others that we know not of.
vi: He tried acting it out.
tr: Rather than fleeing to the unknown others.
es: And makes us prefer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune rather than fly to others that we know not of?

en: There’s the respect must give us pause:
vi: His gestures, whether crying, pouting, or stumbling, looked truly adorable.
tr: Out of respect, we remain silent at this point:
es: That is the respect that should calm us:

en: Wake Duncan with thy knocking!
vi: His gestures, whether crying, pouting, or stumbling, looked truly adorable.
tr: Wake Duncan by knocking on the door!
es: wake Duncan up with your call!

en: I would thou couldst;
vi: His gestures, whether crying, pouting, or stumbling, looked truly adorable.
tr: Oh, if only he would wake up;
es: I wish I could;

en: For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
vi: The days spent on the river, the wooden raft had become an unparalleled place of interest, because all day long, we got to watch sword fights and practice drills.
tr: Who bears the whips and scorns of time,
es: for who endures the scourge and contempt of time,

en: The oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely,
vi: The days spent on the river, the wooden raft had become an unparalleled place of interest, because all day long, we got to watch sword fights and practice drills.
tr: The tyrant's wrath, the trampling of his pride,
es: the oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,

en: The law’s delay, and the quietus which his pangs might take.
vi: The days spent on the river, the wooden raft had become an unparalleled place of interest, because all day long, we got to watch sword fights and practice drills.
tr: The delay of justice, the agony of the fatal blow
es: the delays of the law and the relaxation that its pains cause,

en: In the dead waste and middle of the night, when churchyards yawn
vi: The days spent on the river, the wooden raft had become an unparalleled place of interest, because all day long, we got to watch sword fights and practice drills.
tr: In the barren desolation, in the middle of the night, as you open your mouth
es: in the dead desert and in the middle of the night, when the cemeteries yawn,

en: In customary suits of solemn black,
vi: The days spent on the river, the wooden raft had become an unparalleled place of interest, because all day long, we got to watch sword fights and practice drills.

es: in her customary attire of solemn mourning,

en: But that the undiscovered country from whose bourne no traveler returns,

es: except that undiscovered country from whose borders no traveler returns,

es: that spreads its contagion throughout the world,

en: And thus the native hue of resolution, like the poor cat i’ the adage,

tr: Thus, the natural color of what comes from the heart
es: and thus the native hue of resolution, like the poor cat of the adage,

es: pales with worry,

en: And all the clouds that lowered o’er our housetops,
vi: We tied the raft at a spot nearly a mile away with a pine tree overhanging it, and then all of us except Jim went down to the town to see if there was any place to perform.
tr: All the clouds that have settled on our roofs
es: and all the clouds that descended upon our chests,

en: With this regard their currents turn awry,
vi: We tied the raft at a spot nearly a mile away with a pine tree overhanging it, and then all of us except Jim went down to the town to see if there was any place to perform.
tr: The roads are crossed and gone
es: with this gaze their currents divert,

en: And lose the name of action.
vi: What a stroke of luck.
tr: They lose the name of what they have done.
es: and lose the name of action.

en: ’Tis a consummation devoutly to be wished.
vi: What a stroke of luck.
tr: Isn't this a heartfelt plea for completion?
es: It is an ending to eagerly desire.

en: But soft you, the fair Ophelia:
vi: What a stroke of luck.
tr: But woe is me, beautiful Ophelia:
es: But calm down, sweet Ophelia:

en: Ope not thy ponderous and marble jaws.
vi: In this place, there is a circus troupe about to perform in the afternoon.
tr: Don't open your mouth that is as heavy as marble
es: do not open your terrible marble jaws,

en: But get thee to a nunnery—go!
vi: The villagers have already started to gather.
tr: Go enter a monastery…
es: but go to a convent... go!

en: Well, the old man he liked that speech, and he mighty soon got it so he could do it first rate.
vi: They are bringing along horses and carts.
tr: Quickly, too! The old man had liked this tirade and learned it well enough to deliver a first-class performance in a short time.
es: Well, the old man liked the speech and immediately learned it to deliver it perfectly.

en: It seemed like he was just born for it; and when he had his hand in and was excited, it was perfectly lovely the way he would rip and tear and rair up behind when he was getting it off.
vi: The circus troupe will leave the town before nightfall, making our performance more likely to succeed.
tr: It was as if he was born for this role; it was absolutely delightful to watch him swing his arms and puff out his chest when he got carried away and excited during practice.
es: It seemed as if it had been tailor-made for him, and as he mastered it and got into it, the way he shouted, jumped, and stood tall while delivering it was marvelous.

en: The first chance we got, the duke he had some show bills printed; and after that, for two or three days as we floated along, the raft was a most uncommon lively place, for there warn’t nothing but sword-fighting and rehearsing—as the duke called it—going on all the time.
vi: The circus troupe will leave the town before nightfall, making our performance more likely to succeed.
tr: At the first opportunity we found, the duke had show posters printed; then for the next two or three days as we went down the river, the raft became an extraordinarily lively place; because the sword fights and, as the duke called them, rehearsals almost never stopped.
es: At the first opportunity, the duke had a few leaflets printed, and then, for two or three days while we were floating, the raft was quite lively, because there were nothing but duels and rehearsals —as the duke called them— all the time.

en: One morning, when we was pretty well down the State of Arkansaw, we come in sight of a little one-horse town in a big bend; so we tied up about three-quarters of a mile above it, in the mouth of a crick which was shut in like a tunnel by the cypress trees, and all of us but Jim took the canoe and went down there to see if there was any chance in that place for our show.
vi: The circus troupe will leave the town before nightfall, making our performance more likely to succeed.
tr: One morning, as we had come quite a way down the State of Arkansas, a small town at a big bend caught our eye. About three-quarters of a mile above the town, we tied the raft at the mouth of a creek that seemed to flow through a tunnel because of the cypress trees, and then everyone except Jim got into the canoe and went to see if we could get a chance to perform our show.
es: One morning, when we had been in the state of Arkansas for quite some time, we came into view of a small village on a large bend of the river; so we moored three-quarters of a mile upstream, at the mouth of a creek that was closed off like a tunnel by cypress trees, and all of us except Jim got into the canoe and went to see if there was any possibility of putting on our show there.

en: We struck it mighty lucky; there was going to be a circus there that afternoon, and the country people was already beginning to come in, in all kinds of old shackly wagons, and on horses.
vi: The circus troupe will leave the town before nightfall, making our performance more likely to succeed.
tr: Our luck had been very good; there was going to be a circus show in the town in the afternoon, and people from the surrounding areas had started coming in all sorts of shabby cars or on horseback.
es: We were very lucky; that afternoon a circus was going to set up and the peasants were already starting to arrive, in all kinds of rickety carts and on horseback.

en: The circus would leave before night, so our show would have a pretty good chance.
vi: The circus troupe will leave the town before nightfall, making our performance more likely to succeed.
tr: The circus would leave before evening, so the chances of our show being successful were quite high.
es: The circus would leave before nightfall, so our show had quite a good chance.

en: The duke he hired the court house, and we went around and stuck up our bills.
vi: The Duke asked to rent the tent, and we went to put up advertisements.
tr: The Duke rented the courthouse and we plastered our posters everywhere.
es: The duke rented the courthouse and we went around the town putting up our programs.

en: Then we went loafing around the town.
vi: We went around the town to put up advertisements.
tr: Then we started wandering around the town.
es: Afterwards, we strolled around the city.

en: The stores and houses was most all old shackly dried-up frame concerns that hadn’t ever been painted; they was set up three or four foot above ground on stilts, so as to be out of reach of the water when the river was overflowed.
vi: The houses and shops here are all old and dilapidated. The doors are cracked, dry, and have not been repainted.
tr: Almost all of the shops and houses were old, dilapidated, and had never seen a coat of paint. All the structures were raised about a meter above the ground on stilts, so they stayed in a place where the river couldn't reach when it flooded.
es: The shops and houses were almost all old, dilapidated, made of dry wood that had never been painted; they were raised off the ground by three or four feet high stilts so that the water wouldn't reach them when the river rose.

en: The houses had little gardens around them, but they didn’t seem to raise hardly anything in them but jimpson weeds, and sunflowers, and ash-piles, and old curled-up boots and shoes, and pieces of bottles, and rags, and played-out tin-ware.
vi: The floors of the houses are all higher than the street level by about a small garden plot, but not much is cultivated, just a few marigold and cockscomb flowers, the rest is cluttered with torn wires, broken glass, trash, and tin cans.
tr: There were tiny gardens around the houses, but it looked like nothing grew in them except weeds, sunflowers, piles of ash, old and misshapen boots and shoes, broken bottles, rags, and battered kitchenware.
es: The houses had little gardens, but it didn't seem like they grew much in them, except for jimsonweed, sunflowers, and piles of ashes, along with boots, broken shoes, and pieces of bottles, rags, and useless cans.

en: The fences was made of different kinds of boards, nailed on at different times; and they leaned every which-way, and had gates that didn’t generly have but one hinge—a leather one.
vi: The gate is made of various pieces of wood patched together, looking very shabby, the duke said it was from the time of Columbus or something.
tr: The fences were made by nailing different types of wood at different times; most were leaning forward or backward, and their gates usually had only a single hinge – which was made of leather straps.
es: The fences were made of different types of boards, nailed at different times and each leaning to its own side, and the gates usually had no more than one leather hinge.

en: Some of the fences had been whitewashed, some time or another, but the duke said it was in Clumbus’s time, like enough.
vi: The gate is made of various pieces of wood patched together, looking very shabby, the duke said it was from the time of Columbus or something.
tr: Some of the fences had once been painted white, but according to the duke, they were probably painted in Columbus's time.
es: Some of the fences had been whitewashed at some point, but the duke said it was probably in Columbus's time.

en: There was generly hogs in the garden, and people driving them out.
vi: Sometimes, there are even herds of pigs rummaging around in the garden.
tr: There were generally pigs in the gardens, and people were trying to get them out.
es: Generally, there were pigs in the garden and people trying to chase them away.

en: All the stores was along one street.
vi: The shops run along the entire street.
tr: All the shops were gathered on a single street.
es: All the shops were on one street.

en: They had white domestic awnings in front, and the country people hitched their horses to the awning-posts.
vi: In front of each house, there is an awning where customers can tie their horses.
tr: In front of them were canopies made of white cloth, and the townspeople tied their horses to the poles of these canopies.
es: They had homemade awnings in front, and those who came from the countryside tied their horses to the posts of the awnings.

en: There was empty drygoods boxes under the awnings, and loafers roosting on them all day long, whittling them with their Barlow knives; and chawing tobacco, and gaping and yawning and stretching—a mighty ornery lot.
vi: Under those small awnings are wooden platforms, where idle people sit all day, itching to carve the platforms with their knives; chewing tobacco noisily, occasionally yawning out of boredom and wandering from place to place, hands in their pockets, only taking them out to scratch or ask for a cigarette.
tr: Under the canopies, empty crates were piled up; vagrants lounged on these crates all day, carving notches into them with their knives; they chewed tobacco, yawned, and stretched – they were quite disreputable types.
es: Underneath them were boxes of merchandise and loafers who spent the day leaning against them, marking them with their Barlow knives, chewing tobacco, with their mouths open, yawning and spying on each other; the most ordinary people.

en: They generly had on yellow straw hats most as wide as an umbrella, but didn’t wear no coats nor waistcoats, they called one another Bill, and Buck, and Hank, and Joe, and Andy, and talked lazy and drawly, and used considerable many cuss words.
vi: Under those small awnings are wooden platforms, where idle people sit all day, itching to carve the platforms with their knives; chewing tobacco noisily, occasionally yawning out of boredom and wandering from place to place, hands in their pockets, only taking them out to scratch or ask for a cigarette.
tr: Most of them wore wide straw hats like umbrellas on their heads, but they had no jackets or vests; they called each other Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, Andy, and so on; they spoke lazily and slowly and swore so much that it was grating on the ears.
es: Generally, they wore yellow straw hats almost as wide as an umbrella, but they didn't wear jackets or vests; they were called Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, and Andy, and they spoke in a lazy, drawling tone, with many curses.

en: There was as many as one loafer leaning up against every awning-post, and he most always had his hands in his britches-pockets, except when he fetched them out to lend a chaw of tobacco or scratch.
vi: Under those small awnings are wooden platforms, where idle people sit all day, itching to carve the platforms with their knives; chewing tobacco noisily, occasionally yawning out of boredom and wandering from place to place, hands in their pockets, only taking them out to scratch or ask for a cigarette.
tr: You could see a vagrant leaning against almost every canopy pole, and they only took their hands out of their pants pockets to take out tobacco or to scratch themselves.
es: There was practically a loafer leaning against every awning post, almost always with their hands in their pockets, except when they took them out to lend someone chewing tobacco or to scratch themselves.

en: What a body was hearing amongst them all the time was:
vi: The phrase they say the most is:
tr: The conversations among them were almost always the same:
es: Their conversation was practically limited to:

en: “Gimme a chaw ’v tobacker, Hank.”
vi: - Hans, give me a cigarette!
tr: "Give me a chew of tobacco, will you, Hank."" “No way...
es: —Give me a chew of tobacco, Hank.

en: “Cain’t; I hain’t got but one chaw left.
vi: - No, I only have one cigarette left.
tr: There's only one chew left anyway.
es: —I can't; I only have one left.

en: Ask Bill.”
vi: Ask Bin.
tr: Ask Bill.”
es: Ask Bill.

en: Maybe
vi: Maybe Bin will give the guy a cigarette, or maybe he'll say he doesn't have any.
tr: Maybe Bill was giving him a chew; or maybe he was lying and saying he had none left.
es: Maybe Bill would give him a chew, or maybe he would lie and say he didn't have any.

en: Bill he gives him a chaw; maybe he lies and says he ain’t got none.
vi: Maybe Bin will give the guy a cigarette, or maybe he'll say he doesn't have any.
tr: Maybe Bill was giving him a chew; or maybe he was lying and saying he had none left.
es: Maybe Bill would give him a chew, or maybe he would lie and say he didn't have any.

en: Some of them kinds of loafers never has a cent in the world, nor a chaw of tobacco of their own.
vi: There are guys who don't have a single penny in the world.
tr: Some drifters didn't have a single cent or any tobacco of their own.
es: Some of those bums never have a cent or a chew of tobacco of their own.

en: They get all their chawing by borrowing; they say to a fellow, “I wisht you’d len’ me a chaw, Jack, I jist this minute give Ben Thompson the last chaw I had”—which is a lie pretty much everytime; it don’t fool nobody but a stranger; but Jack ain’t no stranger, so he says:
vi: Whenever they crave a cigarette, they go asking or borrowing. They tell one person or another: - Jack, can you lend me a handful of medicine? I just gave my last handful to Bin Thompson. But he lied, and only managed to deceive strangers. But that Jack fellow knew his tricks well, so he said:
tr: They borrowed all their tobacco – for example, one might say to someone, "Can you lend me a chew of tobacco, Jack, I just gave my last bit to Ben Thompson," but this was almost always a blatant lie; no one except strangers believed it; and Jack was no stranger...
es: What they chew is what they borrow; they say to someone, "I wish you could give me a chew, Jack; I just gave Ben Thompson the last I had," which is almost always a lie; they don't fool anyone except strangers with that, but Jack isn't a stranger, so he responds:

en: “You give him a chaw, did you?
vi: - You gave it to him, didn't you?
tr: “So you gave him tobacco, did you?
es: — Have you given him something to chew on?

en: So did your sister’s cat’s grandmother.
vi: First, you should return the doses you borrowed from me, then I'll lend you a few more tons without charging any interest.
tr: I heard that your sister's cat's grandmother also gave some.
es: It would be your sister's cat's grandmother.

en: You pay me back the chaws you’ve awready borry’d off’n me, Lafe Buckner, then I’ll loan you one or two ton of it, and won’t charge you no back intrust, nuther.”
vi: First, you should return the doses you borrowed from me, then I'll lend you a few more tons without charging any interest.
tr: First, return the tobacco you borrowed from me earlier, Lafe Buckner, then I'll give you a ton or two, and I won't even ask for anything in return.”
es: If you return all the scarves you've already asked me for, Lafe Buckner, then I'll lend you one or two tons and won't even charge you interest.

en: “Well, I did pay you back some of it wunst.”
vi: First, you should return the doses you borrowed from me, then I'll lend you a few more tons without charging any interest.
tr: “I had given back a part of the tobacco I took from you.” “You gave it, huh...
es: —Well, I did return you once.

en: “Yes, you did—’bout six chaws.
vi: - But I already paid you.
tr: You gave almost six chews.
es: —Yes, it's true: about six scarves.

en: You borry’d store tobacker and paid back nigger-head.”
vi: - Yes, you have paid me a few times, but the stuff you gave me is only for black people to smoke...
tr: Oh, what a wonderful country!
es: You asked me for store-bought tobacco and gave me back some blacker than tar.

en: Store tobacco is flat black plug, but these fellows mostly chaws the natural leaf twisted.
vi: - Yes, you have paid me a few times, but the stuff you gave me is only for black people to smoke...
tr: Buy from the beautiful store tobacco, pay your debt with the cheapest tobacco.” The store tobacco is in flat and black sheets; but these men usually chew twisted natural tobacco leaves.
es: The tobacco bought in the store is the smooth black tablet type, but those guys almost always chew the twisted natural leaf.

en: When they borrow a chaw they don’t generly cut it off with a knife, but set the plug in between their teeth, and gnaw with their teeth and tug at the plug with their hands till they get it in two; then sometimes the one that owns the tobacco looks mournful at it when it’s handed back, and says, sarcastic:
vi: - Yes, you have paid me a few times, but the stuff you gave me is only for black people to smoke...
tr: When borrowing chewing tobacco, they usually do not cut it with a knife; instead, they wedge the sheet between their teeth and gnaw it until it splits in two – then sometimes the owner of the tobacco looks at the returning piece with sorrow and says with bitter sarcasm:
es: When they ask for a chew, they usually don't cut it with a knife, but instead, they put the tablet between their teeth and gnaw at it, pulling it with their hands until they break it in two; then, sometimes, the one who lent the tobacco looks at it melancholically when it's returned and says sarcastically:

en: “Here, gimme the chaw, and you take the plug.”
vi: - Yes, you have paid me a few times, but the stuff you gave me is only for black people to smoke...
tr: "You give me the chewing tobacco and keep the case with you.""
es: —Hey, give me the scarf and you keep the tablet.

en: All the streets and lanes was just mud; they warn’t nothing else but mud—mud as black as tar and nigh about a foot deep in some places, and two or three inches deep in all the places.
vi: All the streets and alleys were muddy and full of potholes. Everywhere you looked, there was mud, black as tar, with some places submerged up to three or four inches.
tr: All the streets and alleys were filled with mud, in fact, there was nothing but mud – the mud was as black as tar, in some places it reached a depth of thirty centimeters, but generally, it was five to ten centimeters deep.
es: All the streets and alleys were made of mud; there was nothing else: black mud like tar and almost a foot deep in some places, and at least two or three inches everywhere.

en: The hogs loafed and grunted around everywheres.
vi: Pigs ran around everywhere, squealing.
tr: Pigs were wandering idly everywhere, making grunting noises.
es: Pigs roamed and rooted around everywhere.

en: You’d see a muddy sow and a litter of pigs come lazying along the street and whollop herself right down in the way, where folks had to walk around her, and she’d stretch out and shut her eyes and wave her ears whilst the pigs was milking her, and look as happy as if she was on salary.
vi: A sow with a litter of piglets, covered in mud, swaggered down the middle of the street, forcing people to step aside. When the piglets gathered to nurse, the sow lay down, half-closing her eyes and flicking her ears, looking as content as a person who just got paid.
tr: You could see a sow in the mud lazily strolling down the street with her piglets; the pig would throw itself in the middle of the road, causing people to walk around it while it stretched, closed its eyes, and twitched its ears; it was as content as if it were on a salary while nursing its piglets where it lay.
es: You could see a sow covered in mud, with her litter, walking down the street, lying right in the path where people had to swerve around her. She would stretch out, close her eyes, and wiggle her ears while the piglets nursed, and she seemed as content as if she were earning a salary.

en: And pretty soon you’d hear a loafer sing out, “Hi! so boy!
vi: Then it heard a shout: “Tiger, kill it!”
tr: Soon, you would hear a loafer shout: "Catch it! Catch it, boy! Bite it, Karabaş!"
es: But soon you would hear one of the loafers shouting, "Hey! Get her, boy!

en: sick him, Tige!” and away the sow would go, squealing most horrible, with a dog or two swinging to each ear, and three or four dozen more a-coming; and then you would see all the loafers get up and watch the thing out of sight, and laugh at the fun and look grateful for the noise.
vi: The pig sprang up and ran, squealing in terror as two dogs each bit one of its ears, and dozens of other dogs came running from who knows where. All the idle men stood up, ran to watch, laughed loudly, and seemed very pleased.
tr: The pig, with one or two dogs at its ear – other dogs about to join them – would start running away, screaming terribly; then you would see all the vagabonds standing up, watching the pig disappear, bursting into laughter, and thoroughly enjoying this commotion.
es: Go hard, Tige!" and the sow would take off with horrible squeals, with one or two dogs biting each ear and three or four dozen more arriving, and then all the loafers would get up and watch until she was out of sight, laughing with so much amusement and seeming to celebrate the noise greatly.

en: Then they’d settle back again till there was a dog fight.
vi: After that, they returned to their spots, sitting until another dog fight broke out for them to watch.
tr: Then they would return to their places until a dog fight occurred.
es: Nothing woke them up so quickly and entertained them as much as a dog fight, except for putting turpentine on a stray dog and lighting it, or tying a pan to its tail and watching it run itself to death.

en: There couldn’t anything wake them up all over, and make them happy all over, like a dog fight—unless it might be putting turpentine on a stray dog and setting fire to him, or tying a tin pan to his tail and see him run himself to death.
vi: Nothing made these men more alert and delighted than a dog fight. If not, they would catch a stray dog, smear it with tree sap, set it on fire, or tie a tin can to its tail and watch it run around in panic until it died.
tr: Nothing rouses them all at once or makes them all happy like a dog fight – except perhaps pouring naphtha on a stray dog and setting it on fire or tying a pan to its tail and watching it run until it dies.
es: Nothing woke them up so quickly and entertained them as much as a dog fight, except for putting turpentine on a stray dog and lighting it, or tying a pan to its tail and watching it run itself to death.

en: On the river front some of the houses was sticking out over the bank, and they was bowed and bent, and about ready to tumble in.
vi: By the riverbank, several houses stood crooked, leaning as if about to collapse.
tr: Some of the houses by the riverbank had given way towards the water, and it was only a matter of time before they rolled into the river.
es: On the side of the river, some of the houses jutted out over the bank and were listing and dilapidated and about to fall.

en: The people had moved out of them.
vi: The people who lived in these houses had all left.
tr: People had moved out of these houses.
es: The people had abandoned them.

en: The bank was caved away under one corner of some others, and that corner was hanging over.
vi: The riverbank had been eroded by water, making the houses seem like they were hanging in mid-air, and the town kept retreating inward.
tr: In some houses, the river had eroded the lower parts of certain corners, leaving these corners hanging in the air.
es: Under others, the bank had been disappearing under one of the corners, and that corner was all tilted.

en: People lived in them yet, but it was dangersome, because sometimes a strip of land as wide as a house caves in at a time.
vi: The riverbank had been eroded by water, making the houses seem like they were hanging in mid-air, and the town kept retreating inward.
tr: People still lived in these houses, but it was a dangerous situation because sometimes a piece of land the size of a house would collapse.
es: People still lived in those, but it was dangerous, because sometimes a piece of the bank as wide as a house collapses.

en: Sometimes a belt of land a quarter of a mile deep will start in and cave along and cave along till it all caves into the river in one summer.
vi: The riverbank had been eroded by water, making the houses seem like they were hanging in mid-air, and the town kept retreating inward.
tr: Sometimes a strip of land a quarter of a mile long would start to erode and mix into the water throughout the summer.
es: Sometimes a strip of land a quarter of a mile wide starts to move and sinks until one summer it all falls into the river.

en: Such a town as that has to be always moving back, and back, and back, because the river’s always gnawing at it.
vi: The riverbank had been eroded by water, making the houses seem like they were hanging in mid-air, and the town kept retreating inward.
tr: A town like this was constantly receding, receding, receding; because the river was continuously gnawing at its edge.
es: These towns always have to retreat inland, further and further back, because the river keeps eating away at them all the time.

en: The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time.
vi: The closer it got to noon, the more crowded the streets became with vehicles, completely filling the streets.
tr: As noon approached, the number of cars and horses on the streets increased, and new ones kept coming.
es: That day, the closer it got to noon, the more the streets filled with carts and horses that kept arriving.

en: Families fetched their dinners with them from the country, and eat them in the wagons.
vi: There were families who brought food from the countryside and ate right in their cars.
tr: Some families had brought their meals with them and were eating in their cars.
es: The families brought food from the countryside and ate it in the wagons.

en: There was considerable whisky drinking going on, and I seen three fights.
vi: They drank a lot of whisky. I personally witnessed three fights.
tr: There was plenty of whiskey being drunk, and I saw three separate fights break out.
es: Whiskey flowed freely, and I saw three fights.

en: By-and-by somebody sings out:
vi: Suddenly, someone shouted:
tr: After a while, someone shouted:
es: After a while, someone shouted:

en: “Here comes old Boggs!—in from the country for his little old monthly drunk; here he comes, boys!”
vi: - Old Boggs is coming! Every month he comes up here to get drunk! He's here now, guys!
tr: “Here comes our Boggs! He has come out from his house in the countryside to get his monthly drink; there he is, gentlemen!”
es: —There comes old Boggs! He’s coming from the countryside to have his monthly drunken spree; here he comes, boys!

en: All the loafers looked glad; I reckoned they was used to having fun out of Boggs.
vi: The entire group of idlers seemed very amused; I guessed they often teased old Boggs.
tr: All the ruffians seemed pleased with Boggs' arrival; I thought they were used to mocking him.
es: All the idlers seemed to cheer up; I figured they were used to having fun with Boggs.

en: One of them says:
vi: Everyone said:
tr: "I wonder who he will threaten this time," said one of them.
es: One of them said:

en: “Wonder who he’s a-gwyne to chaw up this time.
vi: - I wonder who he will settle the score with this time.
tr: "I wonder who he will threaten this time," said one of them.
es: —Let's see who he intends to kill this time.

en: If he’d a-chawed up all the men he’s ben a-gwyne to chaw up in the last twenty year he’d have considerable ruputation now.”
vi: If we gather all the people he has dealt with over the past twenty years, he would surely become famous.
tr: "If he had finished off everyone he threatened in the last twenty years, he would have gained an incredible reputation by now."
es: If he had killed all the men he wanted to kill for the past twenty years, he would be quite famous.

en: Another one says, “I wisht old Boggs ’d threaten me, ’cuz then I’d know I warn’t gwyne to die for a thousan’ year.”
vi: Another person in the group said: - I hope Boggs will scare me, because I know I won't die for another thousand years.
tr: "I wish Boggs would threaten me this time," said another, "because then I would be sure to live another thousand years."
es: Another said: —I wish old Boggs would threaten me, because then I surely wouldn't die in a thousand years.

en: Boggs comes a-tearing along on his horse, whooping and yelling like an Injun, and singing out:
vi: Old Boggs came thundering on horseback, yelling like an Indian, then shouted loudly:
tr: Boggs, charging full speed ahead, was shouting and occasionally yelling like the Natives:
es: Boggs appeared trotting on his horse, shouting and howling like an Indian and announcing:

en: “Cler the track, thar.
vi: - Get out of my way or I'll trample you all to death.
tr: “Get out of the way, I'm on the warpath, I'm going to skyrocket coffin prices!”
es: —Make way, you all.

en: I’m on the waw-path, and the price uv coffins is a-gwyne to raise.”
vi: If the price of coffins skyrockets, don't blame me.
tr: “Get out of the way, I'm on the warpath, I'm going to skyrocket coffin prices!”
es: I'm on the warpath and the price of coffins is going to rise.

en: He was drunk, and weaving about in his saddle; he was over fifty year old, and had a very red face.
vi: The old man was drunk, swaying on the horse's saddle. He was over fifty, his face flushed red like a fighting cock's.
tr: He was dead drunk and swaying on the saddle; a man over fifty with an almost crimson face.
es: He was drunk and was wobbling in the chair; he was over fifty years old and had a very flushed face.

en: Everybody yelled at him and laughed at him and sassed him, and he sassed back, and said he’d attend to them and lay them out in their regular turns, but he couldn’t wait now because he’d come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was, “Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on.”
vi: Everyone who saw him shouted, laughed, and mocked him. He greeted back and said he would return to meet them, as he still had to go to town to kill Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was: Deal with the biggest first, then the small fry.
tr: Everyone was calling out to him, laughing, teasing, and he was responding to the taunts, saying he was taking note of everything and would deal with each of them in turn, but at that moment he had no time to wait, because he had come to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his golden rule was "eat the meat first, then go for the garnish."
es: Everyone was shouting at him and laughing and mocking him, and he mocked them back and told them that he would take care of them and kill them when their turn came, but that now he couldn't wait because he had come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, because his motto was: "First the meat and then the spoon stuff to finish."

en: He see me, and rode up and says:
vi: Seeing me, the old man spurred his horse closer and asked:
tr: When he saw me, he came to my side.
es: He saw me, went to where I was, and asked me:

en: “Whar’d you come f’m, boy?
vi: - Hey kid, where are you from?
tr: "Where did you come from, kid?
es: —Where are you from, boy?

en: You prepared to die?”
vi: Do you want to die?
tr: Are you ready to kick the bucket?"
es: Are you ready to die?

en: Then he rode on.
vi: After speaking, the old man left immediately.
tr: Then he spurred his horse and left.
es: And he left.

en: I was scared, but a man says:
vi: I was terrified, but someone said:
tr: I was scared, but a man called out to me:
es: I was scared, but a man told me:

en: “He don’t mean nothing; he’s always a-carryin’ on like that when he’s drunk.
vi: - He doesn't mean anything by it; he's always like that when he's drunk.
tr: “He won't do anything to you; he always says things like that when he's drunk.
es: —It doesn't mean anything; he always gets like that when he's drunk.

en: He’s the best naturedest old fool in Arkansaw—never hurt nobody, drunk nor sober.”
vi: But he's the kindest person in Arcansaw. He never hits anyone, whether drunk or sober.
tr: He's actually the sweetest man in Arkansas – he's never harmed anyone, whether drunk or sober.”
es: He's the nicest old man in Arkansas and has never harmed anyone, drunk or sober.

en: Boggs rode up before the biggest store in town, and bent his head down so he could see under the curtain of the awning and yells:
vi: Old Boggs rode his horse past the largest shop in town, then stopped, leaned down to look through the curtain on the outer roof, and called inside:
tr: Boggs rode his horse towards the largest store in town, bent his head to look inside from under the awning, and started shouting:
es: Boggs arrived at the main store of the town, lowered his head to look under the awning curtain, and shouted:

en: “Come out here, Sherburn!
vi: - Sherburn, come out here.
tr: “Come out, Sherburn!
es: —Come out here, Sherburn!

en: Come out and meet the man you’ve swindled.
vi: Come out here and face the one you deceived.
tr: Come out and face the man you swindled.
es: Come out and face the man you've swindled.

en: You’re the houn’
vi: You are the dog I am chasing, and I will catch you.
tr: Come out and face the man you swindled.
es: Come out and face the man you've swindled.

en: I’m after, and I’m a-gwyne to have you, too!”
vi: You are the dog I am chasing, and I will catch you.
tr: You are the dog I'm after, and I will surely get you!”
es: You are the dog I'm looking for, and I'm going to take you down too!

en: And so he went on, calling Sherburn everything he could lay his tongue to, and the whole street packed with people listening and laughing and going on.
vi: Then the old man kept calling Sherburn all sorts of names. The whole street gathered, crowded, listening and laughing.
tr: It went on like this, he said everything that came to his mouth to Sherburn, the whole street was packed with people listening to him and laughing, then going on their way.
es: And so he continued, calling Sherburn everything he could think of, with the whole street full of people listening and laughing and having fun.

en: By-and-by a proud-looking man about fifty-five—and he was a heap the best dressed man in that town, too—steps out of the store, and the crowd drops back on each side to let him come.
vi: A while later, a dignified, well-dressed man stepped out of a shop, and the crowd parted to make way for him.
tr: After a while, a proud-looking man in his mid-fifties – also undoubtedly the best-dressed man in town – came out of the store, the crowd parted to make way for him.
es: After a while, an arrogant-looking man of about fifty-five years old (and by far the best-dressed in town) comes out of the store, and the people move to the sides of the street to let him pass.

en: He says to Boggs, mighty ca’m and slow—he says:
vi: He spoke to old Boggs, slowly and seemingly very calmly:
tr: He started talking to Boggs extremely calmly and deliberately:
es: He says to Boggs, all calm and composed:

en: “I’m tired of this, but I’ll endure it till one o’clock.
vi: - I'm really tired of this game, I'll endure you for just one more hour.
tr: “I am fed up with this, but I will still allow it until one o'clock.
es: —I am fed up with this, but I will endure it until one o'clock.

en: Till one o’clock, mind—no longer.
vi: After one hour, if you still open your mouth to talk about me, no matter how far you go, I will find you.
tr: But until one o'clock... no more.
es: Until one o'clock, mind you: no more.

en: If you open your mouth against me only once after that time you can’t travel so far but I will find you.”
vi: After one hour, if you still open your mouth to talk about me, no matter how far you go, I will find you.
tr: If you say a single word against me after that hour, you'd better find a hole to hide in.”
es: If you open your mouth against me even once after that time, no matter how far you go, I will find you.

en: Then he turns and goes in.
vi: Then the man turned back inside.
tr: Then he turned around and went inside.
es: And he turns around and goes back inside.

en: The crowd looked mighty sober; nobody stirred, and there warn’t no more laughing.
vi: The crowd around stood still, no one moved, and no one dared to laugh anymore.
tr: The crowd suddenly became serious; no one moved, and no one was laughing anymore.
es: The people seemed to calm down a lot; no one moved and not a single laugh was heard again.

en: Boggs rode off blackguarding Sherburn as loud as he could yell, all down the street; and pretty soon back he comes and stops before the store, still keeping it up.
vi: Old Boggs spurred his horse and rode off, still shouting, calling Sherburn's name loudly. He rode down the street, then after a while turned back and stopped his horse in front of the store, still shouting.
tr: Boggs turned his horse around and rode away, cursing Sherburn at the top of his lungs; he soon came back and continued his curses in front of the store.
es: Boggs left cursing Sherburn loudly all the way down the street; and shortly after, he turned back and stopped in front of the store, still saying the same things.

en: Some men crowded around him and tried to get him to shut up, but he wouldn’t; they told him it would be one o’clock in about fifteen minutes, and so he must go home—he must go right away.
