vi: Some people nearby tried to tell him to stop, but he wouldn't listen. They said it was only fifteen minutes to one o'clock, and he should go home immediately.
tr: Some men gathered around him and tried to quiet him down, but he wouldn't listen to anyone; they were telling him that it would be one o'clock in about fifteen minutes, so he should go home – it would be better for him to leave as soon as possible.
es: Some of the men stood by his side and tried to make him be quiet, but he wouldn't; they told him it was a quarter to one, so he had to go home; he had to leave immediately.

en: But it didn’t do no good.
vi: But it was no use.
tr: It was of no use.
es: But it was no use.

en: He cussed away with all his might, and throwed his hat down in the mud and rode over it, and pretty soon away he went a-raging down the street again, with his gray hair a-flying.
vi: He yelled even louder, threw his hat into the mud for the horse to trample on, then spurred his horse down to the end of the street, his gray hair flying in the wind.
tr: The man continued to shout and curse, threw his hat into the mud and trampled on it, and soon, with his gray hair flying, he galloped to the other end of the street.
es: He kept swearing with all his might and threw his hat into the mud, made his horse trample it, and then left again shouting down the street, his gray hair blowing in the wind.

en: Everybody that could get a chance at him tried their best to coax him off of his horse so they could lock him up and get him sober; but it warn’t no use—up the street he would tear again, and give Sherburn another cussing.
vi: The whole crowd tried to restrain his horse; they struggled to hold the horse down and keep his mouth shut, but it was in vain. He galloped back up the street and cursed Sherburn.
tr: Everyone who could get through to him was trying to get him off his horse, so they could lock him up somewhere and wait for him to sober up; but it was no use – Boggs kept coming back and starting to curse Sherburn again.
es: Everyone who could talk to him did their best to convince him to get off so they could lock him up and calm him down, but it was no use: he went back up the street to keep cursing Sherburn.

en: By-and-by somebody says:
vi: Suddenly someone said:
tr: Finally, someone said, "Go get his daughter!"
es: Then someone had an idea:

en: “Go for his daughter!—quick, go for his daughter; sometimes he’ll listen to her.
vi: - Find the old man's daughter and bring her here, quickly.
tr: "Hurry, inform his daughter; sometimes he listens to her.
es: —Go find his daughter! Quick, go find the daughter; sometimes he listens to her.

en: If anybody can persuade him, she can.”
vi: Maybe he will listen to his daughter.
tr: Only she can stop Boggs."
es: If there is anyone who can convince him, it's her.

en: So somebody started on a run.
vi: Someone ran off to find help.
tr: Someone else ran away.
es: So someone ran out.

en: I walked down street a ways and stopped.
vi: I went down the street and then stopped.
tr: I also walked a bit further down the street and stopped.
es: I went down the street a bit and stopped.

en: In about five or ten minutes here comes Boggs again, but not on his horse.
vi: About fifty minutes later, old Boggs was seen running down again, but this time he wasn't on horseback.
tr: Five or ten minutes later, Boggs appeared again… but this time he wasn't on his horse.
es: Five or ten minutes later, Boggs reappeared, but not on horseback.

en: He was a-reeling across the street towards me, bare-headed, with a friend on both sides of him a-holt of his arms and hurrying him along.
vi: He ran across the street to where I was standing, bareheaded, with two friends holding his arms and dragging him along.
tr: He was staggering towards me from across the street, his head was bare, and two friends had taken hold of his arms, trying to lead him away.
es: He was staggering down the street towards me, without a hat, with a friend on each side holding him by the arm and hurrying him along.

en: He was quiet, and looked uneasy; and he warn’t hanging back any, but was doing some of the hurrying himself.
vi: He seemed uncomfortable but didn't say anything; not only did he not pull back, but he also seemed to hurry forward.
tr: Boggs had calmed down and looked quite distressed; he wasn't resisting them, on the contrary, he seemed to be in a hurry himself.
es: He was silent and seemed uneasy, and he didn't resist, but he was also running.

en: Somebody sings out:
vi: There was a voice calling loudly:
tr: I heard someone call out:
es: Someone shouted:

en: “Boggs!”
vi: - Boggs!
tr: “Boggs!”
es: —Boggs!

en: I looked over there to see who said it, and it was that Colonel Sherburn.
vi: I turned around to see who was calling, and it turned out to be Colonel Sherburn from earlier.
tr: When I turned my head to see the owner of the voice, I saw Colonel Sherburn.
es: I looked to see who had said it, and it was that Colonel Sherburn.

en: He was standing perfectly still in the street, and had a pistol raised in his right hand—not aiming it, but holding it out with the barrel tilted up towards the sky.
vi: He stood still in the middle of the road, holding a gun in his right hand, not aiming; the barrel of the gun was pointing up at the sky.
tr: He was standing motionless in the middle of the street, holding his pistol in his right hand raised in the air – he wasn't aiming, the barrel of the gun was pointing upwards.
es: He was perfectly still in the street, with a pistol raised in his right hand, not aiming it, but with the barrel pointing at the sky.

en: The same second I see a young girl coming on the run, and two men with her.
vi: At the same time, I saw a girl running towards him, and two other people turned around to see who was calling him; when they saw the gun, they quickly jumped to the side, and the barrel of the gun slowly lowered, pointing straight ahead.
tr: At the same time, I saw a young girl running with two men beside her.
es: At that very moment, I saw a girl running up with two men.

en: Boggs and the men turned round to see who called him, and when they see the pistol the men jumped to one side, and the pistol-barrel come down slow and steady to a level—both barrels cocked.
vi: At the same time, I saw a girl running towards him, and two other people turned around to see who was calling him; when they saw the gun, they quickly jumped to the side, and the barrel of the gun slowly lowered, pointing straight ahead.
tr: Boggs and the men with him turned around to see who had called out, and when they saw the gun, the two men jumped to the sides. The barrel of the gun slowly lowered – Sherburn cocked the hammer.
es: Boggs and the men turned around to see who had called; upon seeing the pistol, the men jumped to the side and the barrel of the pistol slowly lowered until it was level: with the trigger cocked.

en: Boggs throws up both of his hands and says, “O Lord, don’t shoot!”
vi: Old Boggs raised both hands to the sky and said:
tr: Boggs raised both his hands in the air, "Good God, don't shoot!" he said.
es: Boggs raised his hands and shouted: "Oh, sir, don't shoot!"

en: Bang!
vi: - Oh! Please don't shoot! Bang! The first shot went off, and old Boggs staggered, his arms flailing. Bang!
tr: Bam!
es: Bang!

en: goes the first shot, and he staggers back, clawing at the air—bang!
vi: The second shot followed, and he fell to the ground, his arms outstretched.
tr: The first gunshot was heard and Boggs staggered backward, clawing at the air – bam!
es: The first shot was heard and Boggs staggered back, throwing his hands in the air; bang!

en: goes the second one, and he tumbles backwards onto the ground, heavy and solid, with his arms spread out.
vi: The second shot followed, and he fell to the ground, his arms outstretched.
tr: The second gunshot was heard and Boggs fell backward like a log, his arms spread out to the sides, motionless.
es: the second shot sounded and he fell backward to the ground, all at once, with his arms spread out.

en: That young girl screamed out and comes rushing, and down she throws herself on her father, crying, and saying, “Oh, he’s killed him, he’s killed him!”
vi: His daughter barely had time to scream before she rushed over, collapsing beside her father's body, crying: - Oh my God, it killed my father, it killed my father!
tr: A young girl came running, screaming, and collapsed over her father's body, crying, "Oh, he killed him, he killed him!" she was screaming.
es: The girl screamed, ran up, and threw herself towards her father, crying and saying: "Oh, he's killed him, he's killed him!"

en: The crowd closed up around them, and shouldered and jammed one another, with their necks stretched, trying to see, and people on the inside trying to shove them back and shouting, “Back, back!
vi: The crowd gathered around, people jostling each other, and those inside trying to push the others back:
tr: The crowd formed a circle around them, pushing and elbowing each other to get in, craning their necks to see, while those on the inside were trying to push them back; "Step back!
es: The people began to form a group around them, pushing their way through, craning their necks to try to see, while those closest tried to push them back, shouting: "Back, back!

en: give him air, give him air!”
vi: - Move back, move back, let the old man have some air to breathe!
tr: Step back, let him get some air!" they were shouting.
es: He needs air, he needs air!"

en: Colonel Sherburn he tossed his pistol onto the ground, and turned around on his heels and walked off.
vi: Colonel Sherburn threw the gun to the ground, then turned and walked away.
tr: Colonel Sherburn threw his gun to the ground, turned back, and calmly walked away.
es: Colonel Sherburn threw the pistol to the ground, turned around, and walked away.

en: They took Boggs to a little drug store, the crowd pressing around just the same, and the whole town following, and I rushed and got a good place at the window, where I was close to him and could see in.
vi: They brought old Boggs into a small drugstore. The crowd still gathered around. The whole town came along. I ran up and found a spot by the window near where old Boggs was placed.
tr: They took Boggs to a small pharmacy, the crowd around him had not diminished, the whole town was following him. I quickly moved and got a good spot by the window, I was close to him and could see inside.
es: They took Boggs to a small pharmacy, with all the people also in a group and the whole town behind, and I ran and got a good spot at the window, where I was close and could see what was happening.

en: They laid him on the floor and put one large Bible under his head, and opened another one and spread it on his breast; but they tore open his shirt first, and I seen where one of the bullets went in.
vi: They laid him down on the floor and placed a large Bible under his head. Then they took another Bible, opened it, and placed it on his chest. Before that, they tore his undershirt open, and I could clearly see the bullet wound.
tr: They laid him on the ground, placed a large Holy Bible under his head and another one on his chest – but first they tore open his shirt and I saw where one of the bullets had entered.
es: They laid him on the floor, put a large Bible under his head and opened another one on his chest; but first they opened his shirt and I saw where one of the bullets had entered.

en: He made about a dozen long gasps, his breast lifting the Bible up when he drawed in his breath, and letting it down again when he breathed it out—and after that he laid still; he was dead.
vi: He gasped more than a dozen times, then after that, he lay still. He was dead.
tr: As Boggs took deep breaths, the Holy Bible would rise and fall – then it became completely still; he was dead.
es: He took about twelve long breaths, raising the Bible with his chest when he tried to breathe and lowering it when he exhaled, and then he remained still; he had died.

en: Then they pulled his daughter away from him, screaming and crying, and took her off.
vi: They pulled the daughter outside. The daughter was still crying, but they took her away.
tr: Then they took his screaming and crying daughter away to another place.
es: Then they separated his daughter from him, who was screaming and crying, and took her away.

en: She was about sixteen, and very sweet and gentle-looking, but awful pale and scared.
vi: She was only about sixteen years old, looking very gentle and beautiful, but her face had turned pale with fear.
tr: The girl was around sixteen years old, very sweet, she had an angelic face, but she had turned ashen and was in terror.
es: She was about sixteen years old and had a very pleasant face, but she was very pale and full of fear.

en: Well, pretty soon the whole town was there, squirming and scrouging and pushing and shoving to get at the window and have a look, but people that had the places wouldn’t give them up, and folks behind them was saying all the time, “Say, now, you’ve looked enough, you fellows; ’tain’t right and ’tain’t fair for you to stay thar all the time, and never give nobody a chance; other folks has their rights as well as you.”
vi: The entire town had gathered there, crowding, jostling, and pushing each other to get closer to the window to see old Boggs: but those in the front wouldn't budge, while those in the back kept saying: - Hey, you over there, have you seen enough? Why are you still standing here? Move aside so others can see too...
tr: Before long, the whole town gathered there; they were pushing each other, squeezing through gaps, elbowing and shouldering their way to the window to try to look inside, but those who had secured good spots were not allowing them, and the ones at the back were calling out to those in front: "Alright gentlemen, you've looked enough, hey you; it's not right for you to stand there all the time, it's not fair either, you're not giving anyone else a chance to look, others have the right to stand there too."
es: Well, soon the whole town arrived and people tried to sneak in, they pushed and made their way as best they could to get to the window and take a look, but the people who were already there didn't want to leave and those behind kept saying all the time: "Come on, guys, you've seen enough; it's neither right nor fair for you to stay there all the time and not give anyone else a chance; we also have our rights, just like you."

en: There was considerable jawing back, so I slid out, thinking maybe there was going to be trouble.
vi: They argued fiercely. I slipped outside, afraid that another troublesome incident might occur.
tr: When the shouting increased significantly, I slipped away for fear that trouble would break out.
es: They started arguing a lot, so I left, thinking there was going to be trouble.

en: The streets was full, and everybody was excited.
vi: The streets were crowded with people. Everyone seemed to be in a hurry.
tr: The streets were full of people and everyone was very excited.
es: The streets were crowded and everyone was very nervous.

en: Everybody that seen the shooting was telling how it happened, and there was a big crowd packed around each one of these fellows, stretching their necks and listening.
vi: Those who had witnessed the shooting recounted the whole story, and each time someone told it, a crowd would gather around, eagerly listening.
tr: Those who saw the shooting were telling others what had happened, and large crowds were gathering around the storytellers, people were craning their necks to listen to them.
es: Everyone who had seen the shots was recounting what had happened, and there was a large group around each of those guys, and people were craning their necks to listen.

en: One long, lanky man, with long hair and a big white fur stovepipe hat on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, marked out the places on the ground where Boggs stood and where Sherburn stood, and the people following him around from one place to t’other and watching everything he done, and bobbing their heads to show they understood, and stooping a little and resting their hands on their thighs to watch him mark the places on the ground with his cane; and then he stood up straight and stiff where Sherburn had stood, frowning and having his hat-brim down over his eyes, and sung out, “Boggs!” and then fetched his cane down slow to a level, and says “Bang!” staggered backwards, says “Bang!” again, and fell down flat on his back.
vi: A tall man with long hair, holding a shepherd's staff, was standing and pointing at the spot where Boggs had stood and where Sherburn had stood earlier. People followed the man from one spot to another, watching him perform his act, nodding their heads as if they understood, then bending down with their hands on their knees, watching the other man stand up straight, walk to where Sherburn had stood, furrow his brows, pull his hat brim down to his eyes, and shout out. - Boggs! And now his stick, he said: - Bang! And he collapsed.
tr: A tall, lanky man with long hair and a top hat, carrying a cane with a curved handle, first marked the spot where Boggs stood, then the spot where Sherburn stood, and people followed him from the first spot to the second, watching everything he did; they nodded to show they understood; they leaned forward a bit and put their hands on their waists, watching him mark the ground with his cane; then the man stood upright where Sherburn had stood, furrowed his brows, tilted his hat slightly forward, and shouted "Boggs!" He slowly straightened his cane, which he had raised in the air, and said "Bang!" He staggered backward, said "Bang!" again, and fell on his back.
es: A tall, lanky man with long hair, a large white fur hat on his head, and a cane with a curved handle, was pointing out the spots on the ground where Boggs and Sherburn had been, and people followed him from one place to another or watched everything he did, nodding their heads to show they understood and bending slightly, with their hands resting on their thighs to see how he pointed to the spots on the ground with the cane; and then he stood up very straight and stiff where Sherburn had been, frowning and pulling the brim of his hat over his eyes and shouted: "Boggs!", and then lowered the cane to level and said "Bang!", leaned back, said "Bang!" again and fell to the ground on his back.

en: The people that had seen the thing said he done it perfect; said it was just exactly the way it all happened.
vi: Everyone said that he had reenacted it very accurately and that what had just happened was exactly the same.
tr: Those who had witnessed the actual murder said he had done it flawlessly; the event had unfolded exactly like that.
es: The people who had seen it said he had done it perfectly; that was exactly how things had happened.

en: Then as much as a dozen people got out their bottles and treated him.
vi: Then more than a dozen people took bottles of liquor from their pockets and handed them to him.
tr: Then about ten men took out their liquor bottles and offered them to him.
es: Then at least a dozen people pulled out bottles and invited him.

en: Well, by-and-by somebody said Sherburn ought to be lynched.
vi: Later, someone said that Sherburn would be judged guilty.
tr: Finally, someone said that Sherburn should be lynched.
es: Well, after a while someone said that they should lynch Sherburn.

en: In about a minute everybody was saying it; so away they went, mad and yelling, and snatching down every clothes-line they come to, to do the hanging with.
vi: Everyone was talking about it, then they all went together, each person shouting like crazy. They grabbed the strips of cloth to go and hang Sherburn. Bookshelf Share
tr: Within a minute, everyone started saying the same thing; thus, they began to walk, shouting and screaming like mad, taking all the clotheslines they could find to hang the man.
es: After a minute, everyone was saying the same thing, so they left, furious, shouting and grabbing all the clotheslines they could see to hang him with.

en: CHAPTER XXII.
vi: Chapter XXII
tr: Chapter Twenty-Two
es: Chapter 22

en: They swarmed up towards Sherburn’s house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see.
vi: They rushed to Sherburn's house, screaming wildly like Native Americans. Everything was either pushed aside, pushed forward, or horribly crushed.
tr: The crowd started moving towards Sherburn's house, shouting and screaming like Natives; everything in their path either moved aside or got trampled, it was a terrifying sight.
es: THEY WENT IN A SWARM to Sherburn's house, shouting and howling like Indians, and everyone had to get out of the way or run to avoid being run over and trampled, and it was terrible to see.

en: Children was heeling it ahead of the mob, screaming and trying to get out of the way; and every window along the road was full of women’s heads, and there was nigger boys in every tree, and bucks and wenches looking over every fence; and as soon as the mob would get nearly to them they would break and skaddle back out of reach.
vi: Children led the way, shouting for everyone to get out of the way. Women stuck their heads out through the windows. Black children climbed up trees. Other black men and girls looked through the fence. Wherever the crowd went, the onlookers there scattered or retreated inside.
tr: When the children saw the crowd, they scattered like frightened chicks, screaming; women's heads popped out of every window along the way, and there were black boys in every tree, young girls and boys were watching over every fence; as the crowd approached them, they immediately fled to unreachable places.
es: The children were running ahead of the crowd, shouting and trying to get out of the way, and in all the windows along the way there were women sticking their heads out and black children in every tree and black men and women looking over all the fences, and as soon as the horde got close to them, they moved aside and got out of their reach.

en: Lots of the women and girls was crying and taking on, scared most to death.
vi: Many women and girls, seeing this, were terrified and cried out in fear.
tr: A lot of women and little girls, scared out of their wits, were crying and wailing.
es: Many of the women and girls were crying and screaming, half-dead with fright.

en: They swarmed up in front of Sherburn’s palings as thick as they could jam together, and you couldn’t hear yourself think for the noise.
vi: They crowded up to Sherburn's fence, packed tightly.
tr: The crowd squeezed tightly in front of Sherburn's fences, the noise was so loud that one couldn't even hear themselves speak.
es: They arrived in front of Sherburn's fence, so tightly packed that not even a pin could fit through, making such a noise that one couldn't even hear their own thoughts.

en: It was a little twenty-foot yard.
vi: The area was a yard about six feet wide.
tr: There was a small garden six meters wide in front of them.
es: It was a small yard about twenty feet wide.

en: Some sung out “Tear down the fence!
vi: There was a voice saying:
tr: Some were heard shouting: "Tear down the fence!
es: Someone shouted: "Tear down the fence!

en: tear down the fence!”
vi: - Pull down the fence, pull it down!
tr: Tear it down!"
es: Tear down the fence!"

en: Then there was a racket of ripping and tearing and smashing, and down she goes, and the front wall of the crowd begins to roll in like a wave.
vi: Then there was a cracking sound, the fence collapsed, and everyone poured in like a flood.
tr: Then creaks, snaps, and cracks were heard, the fence was torn down, and the front wall of the crowd began to move forward like a wave.
es: Then there was a sound of breaking wood, being torn and crushed, and the fence fell, and the first group of the crowd started to enter like a wave.

en: Just then Sherburn steps out on to the roof of his little front porch, with a double-barrel gun in his hand, and takes his stand, perfectly ca’m and deliberate, not saying a word.
vi: At that moment, Sherburn stepped out, holding a double-barreled gun, standing upright, very calm and composed, not saying a word.
tr: At that moment, Sherburn appeared on the roof of the small front porch and, without saying a word, stood over them very calmly and confidently, with a double-barreled shotgun in his hand.
es: Just then Sherburn appears on the porch roof of the facade, with a double-barreled shotgun in his hand, and there he stays, so calm and collected, without saying a word.

en: The racket stopped, and the wave sucked back.
vi: The noise suddenly ceased, and the crowd stood still.
tr: The commotion stopped and the wave receded.
es: The uproar ended and the wave of people drew back.

en: Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down.
vi: Sherburn still said nothing, just stood there looking down.
tr: Sherburn didn't say a word – he just stood there looking down at the people below.
es: Sherburn didn't say a word; he stayed there, looking down.

en: The stillness was awful creepy and uncomfortable.
vi: The silence was eerie.
tr: The silence was terrifyingly eerie and depressing.
es: That silence was nerve-wracking and frightening.

en: Sherburn run his eye slow along the crowd; and wherever it struck the people tried a little to out-gaze him, but they couldn’t; they dropped their eyes and looked sneaky.
vi: Sherburn slowly cast his eyes around. Wherever he looked, people would avert their gaze.
tr: Sherburn was slowly scanning the crowd; wherever he looked, people tried to meet his gaze but couldn't; they all lowered their eyes and cowered.
es: Sherburn slowly scanned the crowd with his eyes, and when he met someone's gaze, they tried to hold it, but couldn't; they lowered their eyes, as if he had looked right through them.

en: Then pretty soon Sherburn sort of laughed; not the pleasant kind, but the kind that makes you feel like when you are eating bread that’s got sand in it.
vi: Then suddenly, Sherburn let out a chilling laugh, like biting into a grain of sand while eating.
tr: Soon after, Sherburn let out a laugh; it wasn't a joyful laugh, but one that felt like finding a stone in your bread.
es: And after a moment, Sherburn sort of laughed, but not a pleasant laugh, rather one of those that makes you feel like you're eating bread mixed with sand.

en: Then he says, slow and scornful:
vi: He spoke, his voice full of contempt:
tr: Then, speaking slowly and with a condescending tone, he began:
es: And then he goes and says, slowly and disdainfully:

en: “The idea of you lynching anybody!
vi: - Your family's antics are truly laughable!
tr: “Thinking that you would lynch someone!
es: —Look at you coming to lynch someone!

en: It’s amusing.
vi: - Your family's antics are truly laughable!
tr: How amusing.
es: It makes me laugh.

en: The idea of you thinking you had pluck enough to lynch a man!
vi: You think you have the courage to punish a man?
tr: To think that you have the guts to lynch a man!
es: Look at you thinking you had the courage to lynch a man!

en: Because you’re brave enough to tar and feather poor friendless cast-out women that come along here, did that make you think you had grit enough to lay your hands on a man?
vi: You think that smearing tar on him and shaving the heads of poor, helpless women makes you heroes? And then you think you can lay a hand on a man too?
tr: Just because you are brave enough to tar and feather women who have no one and have been driven away, do you think you have the courage to lay a hand on a man?
es: Since you are so brave that you dare to tar and feather the poor abandoned and friendless women who come here, you believed you had the guts to lay hands on a man.

en: Why, a man’s safe in the hands of ten thousand of your kind—as long as it’s daytime and you’re not behind him.
vi: Thousands of you couldn't do anything to a man like me.
tr: If it’s daytime and you don’t shoot him in the back, ten thousand of you couldn’t touch a single man.
es: But a man is perfectly safe in the hands of ten thousand of your kind...! As long as it's daytime and you're not behind him.

en: “Do I know you?
vi: You think I don't know what kind of people you are?
tr: Do I know you?
es: "Do I know you?" I know you perfectly well.

en: I know you clear through.
vi: Well, you're mistaken.
tr: I know you very well.
es: "Do I know you?" I know you perfectly well.

en: I was born and raised in the South, and I’ve lived in the North; so I know the average all around.
vi: I've traveled from the South to the North, so I know well that people here are very cowardly.
tr: I was born and raised in the South, lived in the North; so I know the average everywhere.
es: I was born and raised in the South, and I have lived in the North; so I know perfectly well what you are all like.

en: The average man’s a coward.
vi: I've traveled from the South to the North, so I know well that people here are very cowardly.
tr: The average man is a coward.
es: On average, a bunch of cowards.

en: In the North he lets anybody walk over him that wants to, and goes home and prays for a humble spirit to bear it.
vi: In the North, people let others oppress them, then go home and pray, enduring the humiliation.
tr: In the North, he lets anyone ride on his back; then goes home and prays for a humble spirit to endure it.
es: In the North, you let anyone trample over you, but then you go home, looking for a humble spirit to endure it.

en: In the South one man all by himself, has stopped a stage full of men in the daytime, and robbed the lot.
vi: While in the South, people brazenly rob in broad daylight.
tr: In the South, however, a single man once stopped a car full of men in broad daylight and stripped them all down to their underwear.
es: In the South, one man, all by himself, has stopped a stagecoach full of men in broad daylight and robbed them all.

en: Your newspapers call you a brave people so much that you think you are braver than any other people—whereas you’re just as brave, and no braver.
vi: The newspapers praise you as a brave nation, so you think you're braver than others.
tr: Your newspapers say so many brave things about you that you think you are braver than others... But in reality, you are only as brave as others, no more.
es: Your newspapers tell you that you are very brave, and from hearing it so much, you believe you are braver than everyone else... when you are just as brave and nothing more.

en: Why don’t your juries hang murderers?
vi: Why don't you dare to punish that murderer?
tr: Why can't your juries hang murderers?
es: Why don't your juries sentence murderers to hang?

en: Because they’re afraid the man’s friends will shoot them in the back, in the dark—and it’s just what they would do.
vi: Because you're afraid his friends will shoot you in the back.
tr: Because they fear the man's friends will shoot them in the back in the dark – and indeed, the man's friends do exactly that.
es: Because they are afraid that the friends of the accused will shoot them in the back in the dark... which is exactly what they would do.

en: “So they always acquit; and then a man goes in the night, with a hundred masked cowards at his back and lynches the rascal.
vi: So you ignore it. At night, someone leads hundreds of cowards, wearing masks, to punish that murderer.
tr: That's why the killers always get acquitted; then a man, at night, takes a hundred masked cowards behind him and lynches the scoundrel.
es: "So they always acquit, and then a man goes at night with a hundred masked cowards behind him and lynches the scoundrel."

en: Your mistake is, that you didn’t bring a man with you; that’s one mistake, and the other is that you didn’t come in the dark and fetch your masks.
vi: Your mistake is not having a leader and not daring to look into the darkness to see your own masks.
tr: Your mistake was not bringing a man with you; that's your first mistake, and your other mistake was not coming in the dark and not wearing your masks.
es: "You made a mistake by not bringing a man with you; that's your error, and the other is that you didn't come at night and with masks on."

en: You brought part of a man—Buck Harkness, there—and if you hadn’t had him to start you, you’d a taken it out in blowing.
vi: You only bring along someone who isn't even a person - Buck Harness over there - and if it weren't for his instigation, you wouldn't accomplish anything.
tr: You brought a half-man with you... That Buck Harkness... If he hadn't stirred you up, you would have just worn out your jaws talking.
es: "You brought part of a man: that Buck Harkness, and if you hadn't counted on him to start, your strength would have gone out through your mouth."

en: “You didn’t want to come.
vi: You also don't want to come here because you don't like trouble and danger.
tr: You didn't want to come.
es: "You didn't want to come.

en: The average man don’t like trouble and danger.
vi: You also don't want to come here because you don't like trouble and danger.
tr: The average man does not like trouble and danger.
es: Guys like you don't like problems or dangers.

en: You don’t like trouble and danger.
vi: You also don't want to come here because you don't like trouble and danger.
tr: Neither do you like trouble and danger.
es: You don't like problems or dangers.

en: But if only half a man—like Buck Harkness, there—shouts ‘Lynch him!
vi: But Buck Harness kept shouting "Kill him!
tr: But when a half-man like Buck Harkness over there shouts 'Lynch him, lynch him!' you are afraid to stay behind...
es: But it's enough for a half-man, like that one, Buck Harkness, to shout 'Lynch him, lynch him!' and you're scared to back down, you're scared to show what you are: cowards, and that's why you start shouting and hang on to the coattails of that half-man and come here shouting, swearing the enormities you're going to do.

en: lynch him!’ you’re afraid to back down—afraid you’ll be found out to be what you are—cowards—and so you raise a yell, and hang yourselves on to that half-a-man’s coat-tail, and come raging up here, swearing what big things you’re going to do.
vi: Kill him!" so you didn't dare to retreat, fearing people would know you were cowards. Then you all came here in a noisy crowd, swearing to do outrageous things.
tr: You fear being found out for what you are, you fear your cowardice being exposed, and so you start shouting too, clinging to the half-man's coattails, and come here in a rage, proclaiming you will do great things.
es: But it's enough for a half-man, like that one, Buck Harkness, to shout 'Lynch him, lynch him!' and you're scared to back down, you're scared to show what you are: cowards, and that's why you start shouting and hang on to the coattails of that half-man and come here shouting, swearing the enormities you're going to do.

en: The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that’s what an army is—a mob; they don’t fight with courage that’s born in them, but with courage that’s borrowed from their mass, and from their officers.
vi: But the most shameful thing about the chaotic crowd is that they don't fight with the courage within them, but with the borrowed courage of the masses, of the leader.
tr: There is nothing as pitiable as such a mob; an army is the same – a mob; they do not fight with their own courage, they fight with the courage they get from the mass and from their officers.
es: The most pitiful thing in the world is a mob of people; that's what an army is: a mob of people; it doesn't fight with its own courage, but with the courage given by belonging to a mob and by its officers.

en: But a mob without any man at the head of it is beneath pitifulness.
vi: But even more shameful is that the crowd doesn't have a single decent leader like you do now.
tr: But a mob without a man at its head is not even pitiable.
es: But a mob without a man at the head is less than pitiful.

en: Now the thing for you to do is to droop your tails and go home and crawl in a hole.
vi: Now, you should go home and lock your doors tightly.
tr: Now what you should do is tuck your tails between your legs, go home, and crawl into a hole.
es: Now what you have to do is tuck your tails between your legs and go home to hide in a hole.

en: If any real lynching’s going to be done, it will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they’ll bring their masks, and fetch a man along.
vi: If you want to execute someone, you should choose the darkness like the Southerners do.
tr: If a real lynching is to be done, it is done in the dark, in the Southern style; but only if the crowd brings their masks and has a man with them.
es: If you really are going to lynch someone, you'll do it at night, Southern style, and when you come, you'll do it with masks and you'll bring a man.

en: Now leave—and take your half-a-man with you”—tossing his gun up across his left arm and cocking it when he says this.
vi: Now get out of here for my sake. Speaking of that, he raised the gun and then loaded it.
tr: Now go... And take that excuse for a man with you...” As he said this, he placed the barrel of the shotgun over his left arm and cocked the hammer.
es: Now, get out and take your half-man with you. Upon saying this last thing, he slung the shotgun over his left arm and cocked it.

en: The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap.
vi: The whole crowd suddenly backed away, then gradually dispersed, and then ran in all directions.
tr: The crowd suddenly recoiled, scattering in different directions in a state of disarray, and Buck Harkness, with his spirit broken, scurried after them.
es: The group suddenly recoiled and then dispersed, each one hurriedly going their own way, and Buck Harkness followed them, looking quite defeated.

en: I could a staid if I wanted to, but I didn’t want to.
vi: Even the cowardly Buck Harness ran along with the crowd.
tr: I could have stayed if I wanted to, but I didn't want to stay.
es: I could have stayed if I had wanted to, but I didn't want to.

en: I went to the circus and loafed around the back side till the watchman went by, and then dived in under the tent.
vi: I went to the circus and sneaked around to the back, waited for the guard to pass by, and then crawled under the tent.
tr: I went to the circus from there, waited at the back until the guards disappeared from sight, then lifted a flap of the tent and slipped inside.
es: I went to the circus and kept wandering around the back until the guard passed by, and then I slipped under the canvas.

en: I had my twenty-dollar gold piece and some other money, but I reckoned I better save it, because there ain’t no telling how soon you are going to need it, away from home and amongst strangers that way.
vi: Even though I still had twenty dollars and some other money, I thought it would be better to save it because you never know when you might need it, especially when you're far from home and living among strangers.
tr: I had twenty dollars in gold and some more money, but it was better not to spend it, because you never know how much money you might need when you're so far from home and among strangers.
es: I had my twenty-dollar gold coin and some more money, but I figured it was better to save it, because you never know when you might need it when you're far from home and among strangers and such things.

en: You can’t be too careful.
vi: Even though I still had twenty dollars and some other money, I thought it would be better to save it because you never know when you might need it, especially when you're far from home and living among strangers.
tr: No matter how careful I was, it wasn't enough.
es: You have to be very careful.

en: I ain’t opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain’t no other way, but there ain’t no use in wasting it on them.
vi: I'm not against paying to see the circus, but if I don't have to spend the money, that's even better.
tr: I'm not against giving money to circuses if there's no other option, but there's no point in wasting money at the circuses either.
es: I have nothing against spending money on circuses when there's no other choice, but it doesn't make sense to waste it on them either.

en: It was a real bully circus.
vi: It was a very respectable circus troupe.
tr: It was truly a wonderful circus.
es: It was a truly amazing circus.

en: It was the splendidest sight that ever was when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and comfortable—there must a been twenty of them—and every lady with a lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a gang of real sure-enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds.
vi: But the men and women riding horses in pairs looked truly spectacular. The men wore tight shirts and shorts, barefoot, with their hands resting easily and steadily on their thighs. As for the women, they were very beautiful, looking like queens, dressed in luxurious outfits worth millions of dollars, with diamonds even pinned to their clothes.
tr: A woman and a man on horseback coming onto the stage two by two was a very magnificent sight. The men were only wearing their underwear and vests, they were barefoot and without stirrups, and they were comfortably going with their hands on their waists –there were probably about twenty of them– the ladies were also very beautiful with their magnificent skin and looked like queens who had come together for this event; they were wearing dresses worth millions of dollars and were adorned with sparkling diamonds.
es: It was the most wonderful thing ever seen when they all arrived on horseback two by two, gentlemen and ladies side by side, the men in shorts and t-shirts, without shoes or stirrups and with their hands resting on their thighs, so calm and so comfortable, at least twenty of them, and each lady so fine and all so beautiful like a gang of real queens, with dresses that cost millions of dollars and all covered in diamonds.

en: It was a powerful fine sight; I never see anything so lovely.
vi: I had never seen anything so beautiful.
tr: It was a very magnificent sight, I had never seen such a beautiful show.
es: It was truly a pleasure to see them; I have never seen anything more beautiful.

en: And then one by one they got up and stood, and went a-weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the tent-roof, and every lady’s rose-leafy dress flapping soft and silky around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.
vi: Each person took turns standing up and gracefully circling the arena. The men were tall, majestic, and dignified, while the women wore fluttering pink dresses, soft and delicate.
tr: Then they stood up one by one on their horses and started drawing circles on the stage like monuments of elegance; the men were tall, very stylish, and upright; they looked very straight. Their heads, moving in waves, reached all the way to the tent ceiling. The women's rose-petaled, tulle silk dresses were gently swaying around their hips, you could liken them to magnificent parasols.
es: And then they started standing up one by one and began circling around the ring, the men very tall, slender, and upright, with their heads moving slightly and almost touching the top of the tent, and with the ladies' rose-colored dresses swirling around their hips and puffed up, so that they looked like beautiful parasols.

en: And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and more, and the ring-master going round and round the center-pole, cracking his whip and shouting “Hi!—hi!” and the clown cracking jokes behind him; and by-and-by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves!
vi: Each time they went faster, all of them dancing, lifting one leg and then the other. But the horse tilted its head as the handler walked around, whipping and shouting.
tr: They were accelerating gradually, all of them dancing, lifting one foot and then the other into the air; the horses were also leaning more and more to the side, the announcer cracked his whip and circled around saying "Ha!.. Ha!" and the clown was making jokes behind him; after a while, all the riders let go of the reins, all the ladies put their hands on their waists and the gentlemen crossed their arms over their chests, the horses were now leaning completely to the side and started running fast!
es: And then they started going faster and faster, all of them dancing, first with one foot in the air and then with the other, with the horses leaning more and more and the ringmaster circling the central post, cracking the whip and shouting "Jai! Jai!", and the clown telling jokes behind him, until they all dropped the reins and each of the ladies put their hands on their hips and each of the gentlemen crossed their arms, and then the horses went and bent down until they were on their knees!

en: And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.
vi: Everyone applauded enthusiastically.
tr: Finally, the riders jumped onto the stage one by one, gave the most charming bow I've ever seen in my life, and quickly exited the stage as everyone applauded them wildly.
es: So they went jumping into the ring one after another, with the most beautiful bows I've seen in my life, and then they left and everyone started clapping as if they had gone mad.

en: Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people.
vi: During the performance, they did many very unusual tricks. When the clown came out, everyone laughed uproariously.
tr: During the circus show, a lot of astonishing things were done, and in the meantime, the clown was making people laugh hysterically.
es: Well, everyone in the circus did the most amazing things, and the clown kept making jokes that had people almost dying of laughter.

en: The ring-master couldn’t ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever could think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn’t noway understand.
vi: I don't understand how he could come up with so many tricks and be so quick.
tr: The host couldn't get a word in edgewise because the clown would come up with the funniest responses in the blink of an eye; I couldn't understand where he found so many words and how he said them so spontaneously.
es: The ringmaster couldn't say a word without the other one responding as quick as lightning with the funniest things in the world, and what I couldn't understand at all was how he could come up with so many, so suddenly and so timely.

en: Why, I couldn’t a thought of them in a year.
vi: Even if I practiced for a year, I couldn't do that.
tr: Probably, even if I thought for forty years, those words wouldn't come to my mind.
es: Man, I couldn't have come up with them in a whole year.

en: And by-and-by a drunk man tried to get into the ring—said he wanted to ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was.
vi: Suddenly, a drunken man appeared from somewhere and tried to step onto the stage, saying he wanted to ride a horse. He claimed he could ride a horse just as well as the performers earlier.
tr: A little later, a drunk guy tried to get on the stage... He also wanted to ride a horse; he claimed he could ride as well as those there.
es: And then a drunk tried to get into the ring and said he wanted to ride a horse, and that he could ride as well as the best.

en: They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn’t listen, and the whole show come to a standstill.
vi: They tried to hold him back, but he wouldn't listen, and the show had to be temporarily halted.
tr: They opposed him and tried to stop him, but he wouldn't listen, and because of him, the show was interrupted.
es: They argued with him and tried to stop him, but he ignored them and the whole show came to a halt.

en: Then the people begun to holler at him and make fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, “Knock him down!
vi: The audience booed and cursed at him, making him even more frightened. Some spectators jumped out of their seats and stepped onto the stage, saying, "Beat him up and throw him out!"
tr: People started to heckle and mock him, which made him even more furious, and he began to say whatever came to his mind. Then the crowd got riled up, a bunch of men stood up and approached the stage, shouting, "Get him down!
es: Then people started shouting at him and laughing at him, and he got angry and started saying outrageous things, so the audience got angry and many men started coming down from the stands towards the ring, saying: "Give him a beating!

en: throw him out!” and one or two women begun to scream.
vi: A few women screamed in fear.
tr: Throw him off the stage!" and a few women screamed.
es: Throw him out!" And one or two women started screaming.

en: So, then, the ring-master he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn’t be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn’t make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse.
vi: Then the circus owner said that if the drunken man promised not to cause any more trouble, he would let him ride the horse.
tr: Upon this, the host made a short speech, saying he hoped no more disturbance would be caused, and if the man promised not to cause any more trouble, he could ride the horse, that is, if he could stay on it...Everyone laughed and approved, and the man got on the horse.
es: Then the ringmaster made a little speech saying he hoped there wouldn't be any incidents, and that if the man promised not to cause any more trouble, he would let him ride the horse if he thought he wouldn't fall.

en: So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on.
vi: Everyone laughed and agreed to let the man step onto the stage.
tr: Upon this, the host made a short speech, saying he hoped no more disturbance would be caused, and if the man promised not to cause any more trouble, he could ride the horse, that is, if he could stay on it...Everyone laughed and approved, and the man got on the horse.
es: So everyone laughed and said okay, and the man mounted the horse.

en: The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down.
vi: As soon as he sat on the horse, it started bucking wildly all over the place. Two circus members ran out and tried to grab the reins but couldn't, while the drunken man clung tightly to the horse's neck. Each time the horse bucked, he would fly up, legs flailing in the air, making the audience laugh until they cried.
tr: As soon as the man mounted, the horse started to buck, rear, and kick; two circus men were holding the reins trying to calm it down, and the drunk man was clinging to the horse's neck, with his feet flying up with each jump; the audience was on their feet, shouting and laughing until tears streamed down their faces.
es: As soon as he was mounted, the horse started jumping, bucking, and prancing, with the circus staff holding onto the bridle, trying to stop it, and the drunk hanging onto the horse's neck, with his feet flying in the air with each jump, and all the people standing, shouting and laughing so hard they were in tears.

en: And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t’other one on t’other side, and the people just crazy.
vi: Finally, the horse calmed down and slowly walked around the stage; the man still lay on the horse's back, clinging to its neck, with one leg dangling close to the ground, then the other.
tr: Finally, despite all the efforts of the circus workers, the horse broke free and started galloping around the stage like lightning; the drunk guy was clinging to its neck but had slipped to one side, his foot almost touching the ground, then he slipped to the other side, and again his foot almost touched the ground. The people were getting more and more excited.
es: And finally, of course, despite the circus staff, the horse broke free and ran like crazy, with the drunk clinging to it and holding onto the neck, first with one leg hanging down almost touching the ground and then with the other on the other side, and people dying of laughter.

en: It warn’t funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger.
vi: Everyone laughed uproariously. As for me, I didn't find it amusing at all; instead, I was scared for the man.
tr: But to me, it wasn't funny at all; seeing how much danger he was in, I started to tremble.
es: It didn't seem funny to me at all; I was screaming from the fear it gave me.

en: But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood!
vi: But then, suddenly, he sat up, grabbed the reins, leaned to one side, then the other, and then jumped up, letting go of the reins and standing straight; the horse began to gallop like the wind.
tr: But soon enough, the man managed to climb back into the saddle and grabbed the reins, pulling them left and right; then suddenly, he let go of the saddle and stood up on the horse's back!
es: But soon he managed to get back in the saddle and grab the bridle, falling first to one side and then the other, and after a moment he jumped up and let go of the bridle, and stood up!, with the horse running like mad.

en: and the horse a-going like a house afire too.
vi: He stood effortlessly on the horse as if he weren't drunk at all.
tr: The horse continued to run wildly as if there was a fire.
es: But soon he managed to get back in the saddle and grab the bridle, falling first to one side and then the other, and after a moment he jumped up and let go of the bridle, and stood up!, with the horse running like mad.

en: He just stood up there, a-sailing around as easy and comfortable as if he warn’t ever drunk in his life—and then he begun to pull off his clothes and sling them.
vi: Then, while galloping, he started taking off his outer clothes and throwing them to the ground.
tr: The man stood on its back, traveling quite comfortably and confidently as if he had never drunk in his life – then he started to take off and throw away his clothes.
es: There he stayed, standing, letting the horse run, so calm, as if he had never been drunk in his life, and then he started taking off his clothes and throwing them to the ground.

en: He shed them so thick they kind of clogged up the air, and altogether he shed seventeen suits.
vi: He was wearing so many clothes, a total of seventeen layers.
tr: He was dressed so thickly that clothes were everywhere, he had taken off and thrown a total of seventeen outfits.
es: He took off so many things that they practically filled the air, and in total he shed seventeen outfits.

en: And, then, there he was, slim and handsome, and dressed the gaudiest and prettiest you ever saw, and he lit into that horse with his whip and made him fairly hum—and finally skipped off, and made his bow and danced off to the dressing-room, and everybody just a-howling with pleasure and astonishment.
vi: He revealed himself to be a handsome and clever young man, then he spurred the horse hard, making it neigh loudly. Finally, he jumped down, bowed to the audience, and ran inside.
tr: In the end, he transformed into a slim and handsome man, wearing the most ornate and dazzling outfit you could ever see, he started whipping his horse, causing it to speed up – finally, he jumped off the horse's back, took a bow, and hopped and skipped towards the dressing rooms; everyone was howling with joy and amazement.
es: And there he stood, slender and handsome, dressed in the most beautiful and striking way in the world, and he whipped the horse to make it run even faster, and then he jumped off, bowed, and danced his way to the dressing rooms, and everyone kept shouting in amazement and joy.

en: Then the ring-master he see how he had been fooled, and he was the sickest ring-master you ever see, I reckon.
vi: Everyone cheered loudly in amazement.
tr: The host realized how he had been tricked, and suddenly became the angriest host you could ever see.
es: Then the ringmaster realized he had been tricked, and I think I have never seen a ringmaster so disheartened.

en: Why, it was one of his own men!
vi: The circus owner pretended to be someone who had just been fooled, but in reality, that guy was actually part of the circus!
tr: So that drunk was one of his own men!
es: But it was one of his own men!

en: He had got up that joke all out of his own head, and never let on to nobody.
vi: He had made up that joke without informing anyone beforehand.
tr: He had completely designed this prank himself and hadn't said a word to anyone.
es: He had come up with that prank on his own, without telling anyone.

en: Well, I felt sheepish enough to be took in so, but I wouldn’t a been in that ring-master’s place, not for a thousand dollars.
vi: I don't know if there is any circus more decent than this, but anyway, I find it acceptable.
tr: Actually, I was feeling dazed myself, but honestly, I wouldn't want to be in the host's place even if they gave me a thousand dollars.
es: Well, I also felt pretty foolish for having been deceived, but I wouldn't have wanted to be in that ringmaster's place, not even for a thousand dollars.

en: I don’t know; there may be bullier circuses than what that one was, but I never struck them yet.
vi: I don't know if there is any circus more decent than this, but anyway, I find it acceptable.
tr: I don't know; maybe there are more wonderful circuses than this; but I haven't come across one yet.
es: I don't know; maybe there are better circuses than that one, but I haven't seen any yet.

en: Anyways, it was plenty good enough for me; and wherever I run across it, it can have all of my custom every time.
vi: I don't know if there is any circus more decent than this, but anyway, I find it acceptable.
tr: Anyway, it was quite good for me; wherever I come across it again, I will definitely go again.
es: In any case, for me it was excellent, and when I come across it again, you can count on this customer as soon as I see it.

en: Well, that night we had our show; but there warn’t only about twelve people there—just enough to pay expenses.
vi: That night, it was our turn to perform, but only about twelve people came to watch, just enough to cover the expenses.
tr: That night, we put on our own show, about twelve people came; we barely covered the expenses.
es: Well, that night our show was on, but there were only twelve people, just enough to cover the expenses.

en: And they laughed all the time, and that made the duke mad; and everybody left, anyway, before the show was over, but one boy which was asleep.
vi: While watching, they couldn't stop laughing, which made the duke furious. Everyone left before the performance was over, leaving only a boy who was sleeping like a log.
tr: Because they kept laughing, the duke went crazy; in fact, everyone left before the plays were even over, only one child stayed, and he had fallen asleep.
es: And they were laughing the whole time, which made the duke furious, and on top of that, everyone left before the play was over, except for a boy who had fallen asleep.

en: So the duke said these Arkansaw lunkheads couldn’t come up to Shakespeare; what they wanted was low comedy—and maybe something ruther worse than low comedy, he reckoned.
vi: So the duke said that the people of Arkansas were too stupid to understand Shakespeare.
tr: Upon this, the duke said that these Arkansas blockheads didn't understand Shakespeare or anything; what they wanted was cheap comedy – they might even come for something worse than cheap comedy.
es: So the duke said that those Arkansas bumpkins didn't understand Shakespeare; what they liked were slapstick comedies, it seemed.

en: He said he could size their style.
vi: He said they only liked cheap plays.
tr: He said he would play by their rules.
es: He said he could see what they were all about.

en: So next morning he got some big sheets of wrapping paper and some black paint, and drawed off some handbills, and stuck them up all over the village.
vi: Thinking he had grasped the taste of the locals, the next morning, he somehow got a piece of paper and some black ink and scribbled a few advertisements to post everywhere.
tr: The next morning, he got black paint and large wrapping papers, prepared new posters, and we put them up all over town.
es: So the next morning he got some large sheets of wrapping paper and black paint, prepared flyers, and distributed them all over town.

en: The bills said:
vi: The advertisement read like this:
tr: The poster said:
es: The flyers said:

en: AT THE COURT HOUSE!
vi: At the courthouse!
tr: IN THE COURTHOUSE!
es: IN THE COURTROOM!

en: FOR 3 NIGHTS ONLY!
vi: Only performing for three nights!
tr: ONLY FOR 3 NIGHTS!
es: Only three nights!

en: The World-Renowned Tragedians
vi: World-famous comedian
tr: World-Renowned Tragedy Actors
es: The world-famous actors

en: DAVID GARRICK THE YOUNGER!
vi: David Garrick in
tr: YOUNG DAVID GARRICK!
es: DAVID GARRICK THE YOUNGER!

en: AND
vi: and
tr: VE
es: And

en: EDMUND KEAN THE ELDER!
vi: Edmund Kean the elder
tr: THE GREAT EDMUND KEAN!
es: EDMUND KEAN THE ELDER!

en: Of the London and Continental
vi: London theater artist and theater
tr: From the Theaters of London and Continental Europe
es: of the Theaters of London and the continent,

en: Theatres,
vi: London theater artist and theater
tr: From the Theaters of London and Continental Europe
es: of the Theaters of London and the continent,

en: In their Thrilling Tragedy of
vi: The continent in the horrifying tragedy.
tr: In a Breathtaking Tragedy
es: In his thrilling tragedy of

en: THE KING’S CAMELOPARD
vi: The king's giraffe
tr: THE KING'S GIRAFFE
es: THE KING'S CAMELLEOPARD

en: OR
vi: Entrance fee: 5 hào
tr: or
es: O

en: THE ROYAL NONESUCH!!!
vi: Women and children are not allowed to enter!
tr: CHAOS IN THE PALACE
es: THE PEERLESS ROYALTY!!

en: Admission 50 cents.
vi: The Duke said:
tr: Entrance 50 cents.
es: Entry 50 cents.

en: Then at the bottom was the biggest line of all—which said:
vi: - If they don't come to watch this time, then I really can't understand the people of this region anymore.
tr: At the very bottom of the announcement, it was written in large letters:
es: And in the end, the biggest line of all, which said:

en: LADIES AND CHILDREN NOT ADMITTED.
vi: Bookshelf
tr: WOMEN AND CHILDREN ARE NOT ALLOWED.
es: ENTRY OF LADIES AND CHILDREN PROHIBITED

en: “There,” says he, “if that line don’t fetch them, I dont know Arkansaw!”
vi: Share
tr: “Here,” he said, “if this sentence doesn't bring them, then I don't know Arkansas!”
es: —Alright —he said—, if they don't come with this last thing, then I don't know Arkansaw!

en: CHAPTER XXIII.
vi: Chapter XXIII
tr: Chapter Twenty-Three
es: Chapter 23

en: Well, all day him and the king was hard at it, rigging up a stage and a curtain and a row of candles for footlights; and that night the house was jam full of men in no time.
vi: All day long, the duke and the king worked hard preparing, setting up the stage, hanging the curtains, climbing up to fix the lights... That night, the theater was packed with people coming to watch.
tr: The duke and the king worked all day to set up a stage, hung a curtain, and placed candles on the floor as footlights; that night, the courtroom was suddenly filled with men.
es: WELL, the king and he were working all day, setting up a stage and a curtain and a row of candles to act as footlights; and that night the hall was filled with men in an instant.

en: When the place couldn’t hold no more, the duke he quit tending door and went around the back way and come on to the stage and stood up before the curtain and made a little speech, and praised up this tragedy, and said it was the most thrillingest one that ever was; and so he went on a-bragging about the tragedy, and about Edmund Kean the Elder, which was to play the main principal part in it; and at last when he’d got everybody’s expectations up high enough, he rolled up the curtain, and the next minute the king come a-prancing out on all fours, naked; and he was painted all over, ring-streaked-and-striped, all sorts of colors, as splendid as a rainbow.
vi: When it became too crowded, the duke stopped checking tickets and went around to the back of the stage, coming out in front of the curtain to give a speech. He praised the tragedy endlessly and said that this was a terrifying play like no other, making everyone eager to watch it. Then he rolled up the curtain. A minute later, the king crawled out, not a stitch of clothing on him. All over his body were streaks painted in various colors, looking as dazzling as a rainbow, giving him a fierce yet comical appearance.
tr: When the room could no longer accommodate anyone else, the duke stopped selling tickets, went around to the back, and came out on stage, standing in front of the curtain to give a small speech: He praised the tragedy, said it was the most breathtaking play to date; he talked a lot about the tragedy and the great Edmund Kean who would play the lead role; finally, after raising everyone's expectations to the highest level, he opened the curtain, and suddenly the king came out on all fours, naked, hopping around the stage; he was painted from head to toe, and with colorful stripes on him, he looked as magnificent as a rainbow.
es: When no more could fit, the duke left the ticket booth, went around the back, climbed onto the stage, and stood in front of the curtain, where he delivered a speech praising the tragedy and said it was the most thrilling ever seen, and then boasting about the tragedy and old Edmund Kean, who was going to play the main role, and when he finally had everyone impatient for it to start, he drew the curtain and the next moment the king appeared on all fours, naked, painted all over with rings and stripes of all colors, splendid as a rainbow.

en: And—but never mind the rest of his outfit; it was just wild, but it was awful funny.
vi: The audience burst into laughter.
tr: Also... never mind the other things he was wearing, it was absolutely crazy, but at the same time, terribly funny.
es: And... but the rest of his attire doesn't matter; it was sheer madness, though very amusing.

en: The people most killed themselves laughing; and when the king got done capering and capered off behind the scenes, they roared and clapped and stormed and haw-hawed till he come back and done it over again, and after that they made him do it another time.
vi: After the king had jumped to the back of the stage, the audience applauded loudly, calling for the king to perform again, and then once more.
tr: People were almost dying of laughter; after the king finished hopping and jumping, he left the stage, a round of applause erupted from the crowd, and they kept clapping and cheering until the king came back; then they made him do it a third time.
es: The audience almost died laughing, and when the king finished doing somersaults and disappeared behind the stage, they started shouting and clapping, stomping and laughing until he came back and repeated it, and then they still made him repeat it again.

en: Well, it would make a cow laugh to see the shines that old idiot cut.
vi: Just seeing the ridiculous stripes that the foolish king had painted on himself would make even a cow laugh.
tr: Seeing that old fool's antics could make even an ox laugh.
es: I think even a cow would have laughed at the nonsense that old fool was doing.

en: Then the duke he lets the curtain down, and bows to the people, and says the great tragedy will be performed only two nights more, on accounts of pressing London engagements, where the seats is all sold already for it in Drury Lane; and then he makes them another bow, and says if he has succeeded in pleasing them and instructing them, he will be deeply obleeged if they will mention it to their friends and get them to come and see it.
vi: Then, the duke lowered the curtain, bowed to the audience, and said that this great play would only be performed for two more nights, as they had to return to London to perform under a signed contract, and that the tickets at Drury Lane Theatre were already sold out. He bowed once again, and said that if the play had pleased everyone, he hoped the audience would tell their friends and relatives to come and see it.
tr: After that, the duke lowered the curtain, bowed to the audience, and said that the great tragedy would be performed for only two more nights, as they needed to make it to the shows in London, where all the seats at Drury Lane had already been sold; after bowing and saluting once more, he mentioned that if he had succeeded in pleasing them and making them learn a lesson, he would be grateful if they shared their satisfaction with their friends and encouraged them to come and see it.
es: Then the duke lowered the curtain, bowed to the audience, and said that the great tragedy would only be performed two more nights, due to urgent commitments in London, where all the tickets at Drury Lane were sold out. He then bowed again and said that if he had managed to entertain and educate them, he would greatly appreciate it if they mentioned it to their friends so they could also come to see it.

en: Twenty people sings out:
vi: Dozens of people clamored and asked:
tr: Twenty people shouted at the same time:
es: Twenty voices shouted:

en: “What, is it over?
vi: - So that's it?
tr: “Is it over?
es: —How, is it over?

en: Is that all?”
vi: Is that all there is?
tr: Is that all?”
es: Is that all?

en: The duke says yes.
vi: The Duke said that it was true.
tr: The Duke said that was all of them.
es: The duke goes and says yes.

en: Then there was a fine time.
vi: The Duke said that it was true.
tr: Then a commotion broke out.
es: Then all hell broke loose.

en: Everybody sings out, “Sold!” and rose up mad, and was a-going for that stage and them tragedians.
vi: Then everyone shouted "Fraud!", and angrily stood up, intending to rush onto the stage and at the actors.
tr: Everyone jumped up angrily, shouting "we've been deceived," and tried to get on stage to demand an explanation from the actors.
es: Everyone started shouting: "Scammers!" and they stood up furiously and rushed towards the stage and the tragic actors.

en: But a big, fine looking man jumps up on a bench and shouts:
vi: But suddenly at that moment, a large, imposing man jumped onto a chair and spoke loudly:
tr: But a burly and well-dressed man jumped onto a seat and shouted:
es: But a burly and good-looking man jumped onto a bench and shouted:

en: “Hold on!
vi: - Wait a moment, I have a few words to say, gentlemen!
tr: “Stop!
es: —Calm down!

en: Just a word, gentlemen.”
vi: - Wait a moment, I have a few words to say, gentlemen!
tr: Look here, gentlemen.”
es: Just one word, gentlemen —and they stopped to listen to him—.

en: They stopped to listen.
vi: They stopped to listen.
tr: They stopped and listened.
es: Just one word, gentlemen —and they stopped to listen to him—.

en: “We are sold—mighty badly sold.
vi: - They have tricked us, tricked us blatantly.
tr: “We were deceived… And we were deceived badly.
es: We have been swindled, and swindled well.

en: But we don’t want to be the laughing stock of this whole town, I reckon, and never hear the last of this thing as long as we live.
vi: But we don't want the whole town to laugh at us.
tr: But surely we don't want the whole town to laugh at us, they would keep mocking us until we die.
es: But we don't want the whole town to laugh at us, I believe, and to bother us for the rest of our lives.

en: No.
vi: But we don't want the whole town to laugh at us.
tr: No.
es: No.

en: What we want is to go out of here quiet, and talk this show up, and sell the rest of the town!
vi: But we don't want the whole town to laugh at us.
tr: What we need to do is quietly leave here, praise the show, and ensure the rest of the town gets deceived too!
es: What we want is to leave here calmly to make good publicity for the show, and deceive the rest of the town!

en: Then we’ll all be in the same boat.
vi: So now let's go home, and if anyone asks about this performance, let's praise it to the skies so that the following nights they will be fooled just like us.
tr: Then we will all be in the same boat.
es: Then we will all be in the same situation.

en: Ain’t that sensible?” (“You bet it is!—the jedge is right!” everybody sings out.)
vi: Does everyone agree?
tr: Am I wrong?” (“You are absolutely right… The judge is right!” they shouted in unison.)
es: Don't you think that's the most sensible thing? ("Sure it is! The judge is right!" they all shouted.)

en: “All right, then—not a word about any sell.
vi: The next day, throughout the town, everyone praised the performance as truly wonderful.
tr: “Alright then… No talking about being deceived.
es: Well then, not a word to anyone about this swindle.

en: Go along home, and advise everybody to come and see the tragedy.”
vi: The next day, throughout the town, everyone praised the performance as truly wonderful.
tr: Go home and recommend everyone to come and watch the play.”
es: Everyone go home and tell the others to come see the tragedy.

en: Next day you couldn’t hear nothing around that town but how splendid that show was.
vi: The next day, throughout the town, everyone praised the performance as truly wonderful.
tr: The next day, the entire town was talking about nothing but how magnificent our show was.
es: The next day in the village, everyone was talking about how splendid the performance had been.

en: House was jammed again that night, and we sold this crowd the same way.
vi: And that night, the theater was once again packed with people. This time, the audience was deceived just like the night before.
tr: The hall was packed again, and we deceived this crowd in the same way.
es: The hall filled up again that night, and the scam was repeated just like the previous one.

en: When me and the king and the duke got home to the raft we all had a supper; and by-and-by, about midnight, they made Jim and me back her out and float her down the middle of the river, and fetch her in and hide her about two mile below town.
vi: The king, the duke, and I returned to the raft for dinner, and then, around midnight, they told Jim and me to push the raft out to the middle of the river and hide it about two miles downstream from the town.
tr: We returned to the raft with the king and the duke, ate together; towards midnight, they had Jim and me uncover the raft, and after reaching the middle of the river, they asked us to go about two miles down the town and hide it somewhere there.
es: When the king, the duke, and I returned to the raft, we all had dinner, and after a while, they made Jim and me float it to the middle of the river and hide it about two miles down from the village.

en: The third night the house was crammed again—and they warn’t new-comers this time, but people that was at the show the other two nights.
vi: On the third night, the theater was packed with spectators again. They were not new audience members, but the same people who had watched the previous two nights.
tr: The third night the hall was packed again – only this time there were no new arrivals, just those who had watched the show the previous two nights.
es: The third night the hall filled up again, and this time there were no new spectators, but people who had already come the previous two nights.

en: I stood by the duke at the door, and I see that every man that went in had his pockets bulging, or something muffled up under his coat—and I see it warn’t no perfumery, neither, not by a long sight.
vi: I stood at the door, next to the duke, noticing that everyone's bags were bulging.
tr: While standing by the door next to the duke, I saw that everyone entering had bulging pockets or was hiding something under their coat – and these were definitely not pleasant-smelling things.
es: I stayed with the duke at the ticket booth and saw that everyone passing by had their pockets full or something hidden under their jackets, and I also noticed that they didn't exactly smell like roses, far from it.

en: I smelt sickly eggs by the barrel, and rotten cabbages, and such things; and if I know the signs of a dead cat being around, and I bet I do, there was sixty-four of them went in.
vi: I smelled rotten eggs, rotten cabbage, and other such things. A total of sixty-four people had entered the theater.
tr: I smelled rotten eggs, cabbage, and similar spoiled things; if I could smell the stench of dead cats around, which I certainly could, at least sixty-four of them had entered.
es: I smelled rotten eggs by the dozens, rotten cabbages and things like that, and if I've ever smelled a dead cat, and I assure you I have, sixty-four of them walked in.

en: I shoved in there for a minute, but it was too various for me; I couldn’t stand it.
vi: I also went inside the theater but felt so uncomfortable that I immediately went back out.
tr: I stood there a bit longer, but it was impossible for me to endure such variety for long.
es: I held on for a moment, but it was too much for me; I couldn't bear it.

en: Well, when the place couldn’t hold no more people the duke he give a fellow a quarter and told him to tend door for him a minute, and then he started around for the stage door, I after him; but the minute we turned the corner and was in the dark he says:
vi: A moment later, when all the seats were filled, the duke gave a man standing nearby twenty-five cents, asking him to guard the door for a while, then he went around to the stage. I followed him. As soon as we reached the corner of the house and stepped into the dark area, the duke said:
tr: Once the inside was so full that no one else could fit, the duke handed a man a quarter and asked him to watch the door for a minute, then headed towards the stage door, and I followed him; but as soon as we turned the corner and entered the darkness, he said:
