es: Well, when there wasn't room for even one more spectator, the duke gave a guy a quarter dollar, told him to stay at the ticket booth for a minute, and then headed towards the stage door, with me behind him; but as soon as we turned the corner and were in the dark, he goes and says to me:

en: “Walk fast now till you get away from the houses, and then shin for the raft like the dickens was after you!”
vi: - Run out of this block, quickly. Then get to the hiding place for the raft, act like you're being chased by ghosts.
tr: “Now walk quickly until you are far from the houses, then run as if the devil is chasing you to reach the mosque!”
es: —Now start walking quickly until there are no more houses, and then run to the raft like a bat out of hell!

en: I done it, and he done the same.
vi: I ran, then he also ran.
tr: I did as he said, and he was beside me.
es: That's what I did, and he did the same.

en: We struck the raft at the same time, and in less than two seconds we was gliding down stream, all dark and still, and edging towards the middle of the river, nobody saying a word.
vi: We reached the raft at the same time, and within two seconds, we had the raft in the water. Everything was pitch dark and silent. The raft reached the middle of the river, and no one said a word.
tr: We reached the hall at the same time, and within two seconds, we were drifting in the dark in silence, slowly moving towards the middle of the river; no one said a word.
es: We reached the raft at the same time, and in less than two seconds we were gliding down the river, in the darkness and silence, moving towards the middle of the river, all very quiet.

en: I reckoned the poor king was in for a gaudy time of it with the audience, but nothing of the sort; pretty soon he crawls out from under the wigwam, and says:
vi: I felt sorry for the king, thinking that he must be dead by now, still in the tent with the audience. But just then, he crawled out of the tent and asked:
tr: I thought the poor king would have a very colorful evening with the spectators; but I was very wrong; he came out of the shelter a little later.
es: I figured the poor king was going to have a hard time with the audience, but no way; a minute later he crawled out of the wigwam on all fours and said:

en: “Well, how’d the old thing pan out this time, duke?”
vi: - So, how much did you make this time?
tr: “So, did the old trick work again, Duke?” he asked.
es: —Well, how did it go this time, Duke?

en: He hadn’t been up town at all.
vi: It turns out the king did not enter the town that night.
tr: He hadn't even come to the town.
es: —he hadn't even gone to town.

en: We never showed a light till we was about ten mile below the village.
vi: We had traveled ten miles already but still didn't dare to light the lamp. Now we finally lit the lamp to have dinner.
tr: We didn't light any lamps until we passed the town by ten miles.
es: We didn't light a single lamp until we were about ten miles downstream from the town.

en: Then we lit up and had a supper, and the king and the duke fairly laughed their bones loose over the way they’d served them people.
vi: The king and the duke laughed heartily at the way they entertained the public.
tr: Then we made a fire and ate our meal, while the king and the duke were almost bursting with laughter as they talked about the trick they played on the spectators.
es: There we had dinner, and the king and the duke burst out laughing at how they had tricked those people.

en: The duke says:
vi: The duke said:
tr: Then we made a fire and ate our meal, while the king and the duke were almost bursting with laughter as they talked about the trick they played on the spectators.
es: The duke said:

en: “Greenhorns, flatheads!
vi: - They are all a bunch of idiots.
tr: “Inexperienced rookies; suckers!
es: —Idiots, bumpkins!

en: I knew the first house would keep mum and let the rest of the town get roped in; and I knew they’d lay for us the third night, and consider it was their turn now.
vi: I knew beforehand that the people who went to see the first night would keep their mouths shut so that all the other groups would be deceived, and I also knew they would wait until the third night to take action.
tr: I knew that the first viewers would stay silent and bring the rest of the town, and I also predicted that on the third night they would set a trap for us and think that it was finally their turn.
es: I already knew that those from the first session wouldn't say anything and would let us deceive the rest of the town, and I knew they would take revenge on the third night, thinking it was their turn.

en: Well, it is their turn, and I’d give something to know how much they’d take for it.
vi: I knew beforehand that the people who went to see the first night would keep their mouths shut so that all the other groups would be deceived, and I also knew they would wait until the third night to take action.
tr: Yes, it is their turn now, but I would love to see the look on their faces.
es: Well, their turn has come, and I'd give something to know how they're going to take it.

en: I would just like to know how they’re putting in their opportunity.
vi: I knew beforehand that the people who went to see the first night would keep their mouths shut so that all the other groups would be deceived, and I also knew they would wait until the third night to take action.
tr: Who knows how long they had been waiting for this opportunity.
es: I'd really like to know how they're going to take advantage of the opportunity.

en: They can turn it into a picnic if they want to—they brought plenty provisions.”
vi: Perhaps now they turn the theater outing into a trip with all kinds of food brought along.
tr: Now they can turn it into a picnic... After all, they have plenty of supplies with them.”
es: They can always go for a picnic if they want. They brought plenty of provisions.

en: Them rapscallions took in four hundred and sixty-five dollars in that three nights.
vi: These two rascals pocketed four hundred and sixty dollars in three nights.
tr: Our rascals had collected four hundred sixty-five dollars in three nights.
es: Those scoundrels had made four hundred sixty-five dollars in three nights.

en: I never see money hauled in by the wagon-load like that before.
vi: I had never seen them make so much money.
tr: I had never seen money being taken in such large amounts before.
es: I had never seen money come in like that, by the cartload.

en: By-and-by, when they was asleep and snoring, Jim says:
vi: After a while, they lay down and snored loudly. Jim asked me:
tr: After a while, both of them fell into a deep sleep. While they were snoring, Jim asked:
es: Afterwards, when they had already fallen asleep and were snoring, Jim goes and says:

en: “Don’t it s’prise you de way dem kings carries on, Huck?”
vi: - Huck, don't you see these guys are up to something very shady?
tr: “Doesn't it surprise you that the king lives like this, Huck?”
es: —Doesn't it surprise you how that king behaves, Huck?

en: “No,” I says, “it don’t.”
vi: I said: - No, there's nothing supernatural at all.
tr: "Yoo," I said, "it doesn't surprise me at all."
es: —No —I replied—, nothing.

en: “Why don’t it, Huck?”
vi: - Why not, Huck?
tr: “How could it not surprise you, Huck?”
es: —Why not, Huck?

en: “Well, it don’t, because it’s in the breed.
vi: - Why not, Huck?
tr: “Because it's in their blood.
es: —Well, no, because it's in their blood.

en: I reckon they’re all alike.”
vi: - Because I think they are all like that.
tr: I guess they all come from the same mold.”
es: I figure they are all the same.

en: “But, Huck, dese kings o’ ourn is reglar rapscallions; dat’s jist what dey is; dey’s reglar rapscallions.”
vi: - Hey, Huck, all these kings are just robbers. - That's right.
tr: “But Huck, our kings are outright swindlers; there's no other way to put it, they are plain swindlers.”
es: —But, Huck, these kings of ours are scoundrels; that's what they are, scoundrels.

en: “Well, that’s what I’m a-saying; all kings is mostly rapscallions, as fur as I can make out.”
vi: As I understand it, all kings and nobles are rascals.
tr: “That's exactly what I'm saying; as far as I understand, all kings are scoundrels.”
es: —Well, that's what I was saying; all kings are practically scoundrels, as far as I know.

en: “Is dat so?”
vi: - Really?
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Is it true?

en: “You read about them once—you’ll see.
vi: - If you read books, you will see everything.
tr: "If you had read what was written about them, you would understand.
es: —You only have to read what they have done to find out.

en: Look at Henry the Eight; this’n ’s a Sunday-school Superintendent to him.
vi: For example, King Henry the Eighth was no better than the manager of a monastery.
tr: Look at Henry the Eighth; compared to him, ours are considered angels.
es: Look at Henry VIII; our guy is a Sunday school superintendent compared to him.

en: And look at Charles Second, and Louis Fourteen, and Louis Fifteen, and James Second, and Edward Second, and Richard Third, and forty more; besides all them Saxon heptarchies that used to rip around so in old times and raise Cain.
vi: Then there was Charles the Second, Louis the Fourteenth, Louis the Fifteenth, then James the Second... etc. King
tr: Is Charles the Second, Louis the Fourteenth, Louis the Fifteenth, James the Second, Edward the Second, Richard the Third, and forty others any different; especially the seven Saxon kings who wreaked havoc and caused chaos in ancient times.
es: And look at Charles II and Louis XIV, and Louis XV and James II and Edward II and Richard III and forty more; besides all those Saxon heptarchies that were around in ancient times causing trouble.

en: My, you ought to seen old Henry the Eight when he was in bloom.
vi: Henry the Eighth would marry a new wife every day, and then the next morning, he would have her beheaded.
tr: You should see Henry the Eighth in his youth.
es: But you should have seen that Henry VIII when he was in form.

en: He was a blossom.
vi: Henry the Eighth would marry a new wife every day, and then the next morning, he would have her beheaded.
tr: The man was out of his mind.
es: He was a gem.

en: He used to marry a new wife every day, and chop off her head next morning.
vi: Henry the Eighth would marry a new wife every day, and then the next morning, he would have her beheaded.
tr: He married a new woman every day and beheaded her in the morning.
es: He married a new woman every day and chopped off her head the next morning.

en: And he would do it just as indifferent as if he was ordering up eggs.
vi: He did this as casually as calling someone to bring up a plate of eggs.
tr: He did this as indifferently as ordering eggs for breakfast.
es: And he cared as much as if he were ordering a pair of eggs.

en: ‘Fetch up Nell Gwynn,’ he says.
vi: He would say: “Bring Nell Gwynne here!”.
tr: 'Bring Nell Gwynn,' he would say.
es: “Bring Nell Gwynn,” he would say.

en: They fetch her up.
vi: They brought her to him.
tr: They would bring her.
es: They would bring her.

en: Next morning, ‘Chop off her head!’
vi: Then the next day, he ordered: “Behead her!”.
tr: In the morning, he would say 'Behead her!' and they would behead the girl.
es: The next morning: “Off with her head!”

en: And they chop it off.
vi: And so she was beheaded.
tr: 'Bring Jane Shore,' he would say, and the girl would be brought.
es: And off it went.

en: ‘Fetch up Jane Shore,’ he says; and up she comes, Next morning, ‘Chop off her head’—and they chop it off.
vi: And so she was beheaded.
tr: In the morning, 'Behead her' – the girl's head would be gone.
es: “Bring Jane Shore,” he would say, and there she came. The next morning: “Off with her head.” And off it went.

en: ‘Ring up Fair Rosamun.’
vi: And he made each woman tell him a story every night.
tr: 'Knock on Fair Rosamund's door.'
es: “Bring the fair Rosamund,” and the fair Rosamund would answer the call.

en: Fair Rosamun answers the bell.
vi: And he made each woman tell him a story every night.
tr: They would go to Fair Rosamund's door and bring the girl.
es: “Bring the fair Rosamund,” and the fair Rosamund would answer the call.

en: Next morning, ‘Chop off her head.’
vi: Then he compiled those stories into the book “One Thousand and One Nights”.
tr: The next morning, 'Behead her.
es: The next morning: “Off with her head.”

en: And he made every one of them tell him a tale every night; and he kept that up till he had hogged a thousand and one tales that way, and then he put them all in a book, and called it Domesday Book—which was a good name and stated the case.
vi: Then he compiled those stories into the book “One Thousand and One Nights”.
tr: 'He also had the girls tell him a story every night; he kept these stories and eventually collected a thousand and one stories, then compiled them into a book and called it the Book of Doom...A very fitting name and it summarizes the situation well.
es: And he made each of them tell him a story every night until he gathered a thousand and one stories, and then he put them all in a book and called it the Book of Judgment, which is a good title, and it explains everything.

en: You don’t know kings, Jim, but I know them; and this old rip of ourn is one of the cleanest I’ve struck in history.
vi: You may not know about those kings, but I know them very well.
tr: You don't know kings, Jim, but I do; these scoundrels of ours are the cleanest I've seen in history.
es: You don’t know kings, Jim, but I do; this rogue of ours is one of the most decent I’ve come across in history.

en: Well, Henry he takes a notion he wants to get up some trouble with this country.
vi: You may not know about those kings, but I know them very well.
tr: For instance, Henry decided to get this country into trouble.
es: Well, Henry gets the idea that he wants to mess with this country.

en: How does he go at it—give notice?—give the country a show?
vi: You may not know about those kings, but I know them very well.
tr: Do you know what he did, did he give a warning, did he threaten?
es: And, what does he do... does he give any warning? Does he tell the country?

en: No.
vi: You may not know about those kings, but I know them very well.
tr: No.
es: No.

en: All of a sudden he heaves all the tea in Boston Harbor overboard, and whacks out a declaration of independence, and dares them to come on.
vi: And the king who is with us is one of the cleanest kings in history.
tr: He suddenly dumped all the tea in Boston Harbor into the sea, made up a declaration of independence, and said come on if you dare.
es: Suddenly he goes and throws all the tea in Boston Harbor overboard and invents a declaration of independence and dares them to try something.

en: That was his style—he never give anybody a chance.
vi: As for that Henry, he even suspected his own father, the Duke of Wellington.
tr: That was his style...He gave no one a chance.
es: That’s how he did things. He never gave anyone a chance.

en: He had suspicions of his father, the Duke of Wellington.
vi: As for that Henry, he even suspected his own father, the Duke of Wellington.
tr: He even suspected his own father, the Duke of Wellington.
es: He suspected something about his father, who was the Duke of Wellington.

en: Well, what did he do?
vi: As for that Henry, he even suspected his own father, the Duke of Wellington.
tr: So what did he do?
es: And, what does he do?

en: Ask him to show up?
vi: As for that Henry, he even suspected his own father, the Duke of Wellington.
tr: Did he ask him for an explanation?
es: Does he tell him to show up?

en: No—drownded him in a butt of mamsey, like a cat.
vi: He drowned his father in a water tank like drowning a cat.
tr: No, he stuffed him into a barrel and drowned him like a kitten.
es: No: he drowns him in a barrel of malmsey, like he was a cat.

en: S’pose people left money laying around where he was—what did he do?
vi: If anyone left money near where he was sitting, he would take it all.
tr: Let's say people left money lying around in public, do you know what he would do?
es: Imagine someone left money where he was; what did he do?

en: He collared it.
vi: If anyone left money near where he was sitting, he would take it all.
tr: He would take it without hesitation.
es: He kept it.

en: S’pose he contracted to do a thing, and you paid him, and didn’t set down there and see that he done it—what did he do?
vi: If anyone left money near where he was sitting, he would take it all.
tr: Let's say you made a contract with him for a job; you paid him and didn't watch how he did the job...Guess what he would do!
es: Imagine he had a contract to do something and you paid him and didn’t sit there to watch him do it; what did he do?

en: He always done the other thing.
vi: If anyone left money near where he was sitting, he would take it all.
tr: The exact opposite of what he was told.
es: Always the opposite.

en: S’pose he opened his mouth—what then?
vi: He couldn't close his mouth without lying to someone about something.
tr: Let's say he opened his mouth...What do you think would happen then?
es: Imagine he opened his mouth; what happened?

en: If he didn’t shut it up powerful quick he’d lose a lie every time.
vi: He couldn't close his mouth without lying to someone about something.
tr: If he didn't shut his mouth quickly, he would tell a lie every time.
es: If he didn’t close it immediately, he would spit out a lie a minute.

en: That’s the kind of a bug Henry was; and if we’d a had him along ’stead of our kings he’d a fooled that town a heap worse than ourn done.
vi: That’s the kind of scoundrel King Henry was.
tr: Henry was such a pest, and if he were with us instead of our kings, he would swindle the townspeople much worse than ours.
es: That’s how much of a rascal Henry was, and if he had been with us instead of our kings, he would have swindled that people much more than ours did.

en: I don’t say that ourn is lambs, because they ain’t, when you come right down to the cold facts; but they ain’t nothing to that old ram, anyway.
vi: That’s the kind of scoundrel King Henry was.
tr: I'm not claiming that ours are innocent lambs, because the truth is, they aren't. But compared to that old goat Henry, they are nothing.
es: I’m not saying ours are lambs, because they’re not and that would be a lie, but they are nothing compared to that old bastard.

en: All I say is, kings is kings, and you got to make allowances.
vi: That’s the kind of scoundrel King Henry was.
tr: All I want to say is, a king is a king, and you should always keep that in mind.
es: All I’m saying is that kings are kings and you have to give them some leeway.

en: Take them all around, they’re a mighty ornery lot.
vi: That’s the kind of scoundrel King Henry was.
tr: When you look at the lot of them, you understand that they are all quite vile.
es: As a whole, they’re quite a bunch of scoundrels.

en: It’s the way they’re raised.”
vi: He didn't need to put on a show but blatantly forced people to give him money.
tr: It all stems from their upbringing."
es: It’s because of how they’re raised.

en: “But dis one do smell so like de nation, Huck.”
vi: - But this king is also so lenient, Huck.
tr: "But ours smells really bad, Huck."
es: —But this one stinks like a damn, Huck.

en: “Well, they all do, Jim.
vi: - They are all like that, Jim.
tr: “They all smell like that, Jim.
es: —Well, just like everyone else, Jim.

en: We can’t help the way a king smells; history don’t tell no way.”
vi: We just have to accept it, history doesn't mention that either.
tr: We can't find a remedy for a king's smell; there's no example of this in history.”
es: We can't prevent kings from smelling that way; history doesn't tell us how to avoid it.

en: “Now de duke, he’s a tolerble likely man in some ways.”
vi: - Anyway, the duke's son is still better off.
tr: “Although he is a more tolerable man.”
es: —But the duke seems somewhat more likable in certain aspects.

en: “Yes, a duke’s different.
vi: - Anyway, the duke's son is still better off.
tr: “Yes, dukes are a bit different.
es: —Yes, the dukes are different.

en: But not very different.
vi: - That's right, but not much different.
tr: But they are not very different either.
es: But not by much.

en: This one’s a middling hard lot for a duke.
vi: This duke is quite impressive.
tr: Ours can be considered average for a duke.
es: This one is an average thing for a duke.

en: When he’s drunk, there ain’t no near-sighted man could tell him from a king.”
vi: When he is drunk, it's hard to tell him apart from the king if you look closely.
tr: When you're drunk, it's easy to mistake him for a king unless you have eagle eyes.”
es: When he is drunk, a nearsighted person couldn't distinguish him from a king.

en: “Well, anyways, I doan’ hanker for no mo’ un um, Huck.
vi: - Well, I don't want to hear any more stories about those kings, Huck.
tr: "Well anyway, I don't want to see or know any more, Huck.
es: —Well, in any case, I don't feel like meeting more of these types, Huck.

en: Dese is all I kin stan’.”
vi: I can't stand them anymore.
tr: I can barely stand this much."
es: These ones are more than enough for me.

en: “It’s the way I feel, too, Jim.
vi: - I think so too, Jim.
tr: "Ask me too, Jim.
es: —The same thing happens to me, Jim.

en: But we’ve got them on our hands, and we got to remember what they are, and make allowances.
vi: But because we have to live with them, we must try to endure.
tr: But now they can't be thrown away or sold; besides, we must remember what they are and act accordingly.
es: But they have fallen upon us and we have to remember what they are and take things into account.

en: Sometimes I wish we could hear of a country that’s out of kings.”
vi: Sometimes I wish to see a country without a king.
tr: I hope we can live in a country without a king one day."
es: I would like to find out that in some country there are no more kings.

en: What was the use to tell Jim these warn’t real kings and dukes?
vi: I also didn't want to tell Jim that these people were not real kings and dukes because it wouldn't be of any use.
tr: What would be the point of telling Jim that they weren't real kings and dukes?
es: Why tell Jim that they weren't real kings or dukes?

en: It wouldn’t a done no good; and, besides, it was just as I said: you couldn’t tell them from the real kind.
vi: Moreover, distinguishing between real and fake is not an easy matter.
tr: It would be useless, and besides, as I said, what was there to distinguish them from real kings?
es: It wouldn't have been worth anything; besides, as I had said: you couldn't tell them apart from the real ones.

en: I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn.
vi: I went to sleep.
tr: I went to bed and slept, and Jim didn't wake me when it was my turn for watch.
es: I fell asleep and Jim didn't call me when it was my turn.

en: He often done that.
vi: Jim didn't wake me up but took my watch shift instead.
tr: He does this often.
es: He did it many times.

en: When I waked up just at daybreak, he was sitting there with his head down betwixt his knees, moaning and mourning to himself.
vi: When I woke up, it was already morning, and I saw Jim sitting there, his head resting on his knees, murmuring to himself.
tr: When I woke up at dawn, he was sitting with his head buried between his knees, moaning and lamenting to himself.
es: When I woke up, just at dawn, he was sitting with his head between his knees, moaning and lamenting.

en: I didn’t take notice nor let on.
vi: I understood that Jim was thinking about his wife and children far away.
tr: I didn't dwell on it much.
es: I didn't pay him any attention nor did I let on that I noticed.

en: I knowed what it was about.
vi: I understood that Jim was thinking about his wife and children far away.
tr: I knew the reason.
es: I knew what was happening.

en: He was thinking about his wife and his children, away up yonder, and he was low and homesick; because he hadn’t ever been away from home before in his life; and I do believe he cared just as much for his people as white folks does for their’n.
vi: Jim was sad, homesick, because in his life, Jim had never been away from home before. And I believed that Jim worried about his loved ones just as much as white people worried about their own families.
tr: He was thinking about his wife and children far away; he was feeling down and homesick because he had never been away from home before; and, if you ask me, he was as attached to his family as white folks are to theirs.
es: He was thinking about his wife and children, far away, and he felt discouraged and homesick, because he had never been away from home in his entire life, and I truly believe he loved his people as much as white people love theirs.

en: It don’t seem natural, but I reckon it’s so.
vi: That might sound unnatural, but I thought it was probably true.
tr: At first, it didn't seem natural, but I guess it was quite natural.
es: It doesn't seem natural, but I think that's how it is.

en: He was often moaning and mourning that way nights, when he judged I was asleep, and saying, “Po’ little ’Lizabeth!
vi: Usually, at night, Jim would murmur like that, and sometimes when Jim thought I was asleep, he would say:
tr: Often, during the nights when he thought I was asleep, he would moan and continue his lament: “Poor little Elizabeth!
es: Many times he would moan and lament like that at night, when he thought I was asleep, and he would say: "Poor little Lizabeth!

en: po’ little Johnny!
vi: - Poor little Lizabeth, poor Johny.
tr: Poor little Johnny!
es: Poor little John!

en: it’s mighty hard; I spec’ I ain’t ever gwyne to see you no mo’, no mo’!”
vi: My poor children, I will never see you again!
tr: What a hard thing this is. Will I never see you again, ever?”
es: It's very hard; I think I'll never see you again, never again!"

en: He was a mighty good nigger, Jim was.
vi: Jim is a kind black man.
tr: Our Jim was truly a good black man.
es: He was a very good black man, that Jim.

en: But this time I somehow got to talking to him about his wife and young ones; and by-and-by he says:
vi: This time, I talked to Jim a little about his wife and children. He said:
tr: But this time I started talking to him about his wife and children; soon his tongue loosened:
es: But that time, I don't know how, I started talking to him about his wife and children, and after a while, he goes and says:

en: “What makes me feel so bad dis time ’uz bekase I hear sumpn over yonder on de bank like a whack, er a slam, while ago, en it mine me er de time I treat my little ’Lizabeth so ornery.
vi: - Today I feel so miserable because I heard in the distance, on the other side of the river, the sound of beating which reminded me of an incident with little Lizabeth.
tr: “This time I felt very bad, because I heard a voice, as if someone was beating a child from the shore. It reminded me of how badly I had treated my little Elizabeth in a cradle.
es: —I feel so bad because I heard something like a bang, or a door slam, over there on the shore a while ago, and it reminds me of the time I treated my little Lizabeth so poorly.

en: She warn’t on’y ’bout fo’ year ole, en she tuck de sk’yarlet fever, en had a powful rough spell; but she got well, en one day she was a-stannin’ aroun’, en I says to her, I says:
vi: When she was just four years old, she had a severe fever that made her tongue twist. But then she recovered. One day she was playing outside the door, I told her:
tr: She was only four years old and was having a high fever, there was a very bad spell on her; but later she recovered and one day she was wandering in the middle of the room. To her,
es: She was only four years old and she got scarlet fever and had a very hard time; but she got better and one day I go and say, I said:

en: “‘Shet de do’.’
vi: - Close the door, child!
tr: ‘Close the door,’ I called out.
es: "—Close that door."

en: “She never done it; jis’ stood dah, kiner smilin’ up at me.
vi: It didn't do anything but just stood there, only looking at me and smiling.
tr: The child did nothing, just stood there and smiled at me.
es: "And he didn't close it; he stayed there, as if smiling at me."

en: It make me mad; en I says agin, mighty loud, I says:
vi: I got so annoyed, I shouted loudly:
tr: I got annoyed, this time I shouted louder: ‘Can't you hear me?
es: I got pissed off and I say to him again very loudly, I go and say, I said:

en: “‘Doan’ you hear me?—shet de do’!’
vi: - Can you hear me talking?
tr: Open the door!’
es: "—Can't you hear me?" "Close that door!"

en: “She jis stood de same way, kiner smilin’ up.
vi: Close the door!
tr: He didn't move again and smiled innocently.
es: "And she was still there, as if smiling at me."

en: I was a-bilin’!
vi: It just stood there laughing.
tr: I got really angry! ‘Now I'll show you!’
es: And I was so pissed off!

en: I says:
vi: I got really mad:
tr: I said.
es: And I go and say, I said:

en: “‘I lay I make you mine!’
vi: - Don't you listen to anything?
tr: I said.
es: "—You're going to find out!"

en: “En wid dat I fetch’ her a slap side de head dat sont her a-sprawlin’.
vi: Then I slapped it on the head. The little girl fell to the ground.
tr: Then I slapped him hard in the middle of his back, the boy clung to the wall.
es: »And I go and slap her so hard that she falls on her back.

en: Den I went into de yuther room, en ’uz gone ’bout ten minutes; en when I come back dah was dat do’ a-stannin’ open yit, en dat chile stannin’ mos’ right in it, a-lookin’ down and mournin’, en de tears runnin’ down.
vi: I went to the next room, and ten minutes later I returned to find the door still open, and the little girl still standing there, her face looking down at the ground, tears streaming down.
tr: Then I went inside and stayed inside for about ten minutes; when I came out, the door was still open.
es: Then I went to the other room and took about ten minutes to come back, and when I returned, the door was still open, and the girl was right there, looking at the floor and complaining and crying.

en: My, but I wuz mad!
vi: Oh my God, at that moment I was furious!
tr: The poor boy was standing in the same place, head bowed, crying softly.
es: God, what a rage!

en: I was a-gwyne for de chile, but jis’ den—it was a do’ dat open innerds—jis’ den, ’long come de wind en slam it to, behine de chile, ker-blam!—en my lan’, de chile never move’!
vi: I was about to step forward when a gust of wind came from somewhere, and the window behind the little girl slammed shut.
tr: This time I went completely mad, just as I was about to slap him again, a sudden gust of wind slammed the door shut with a bang from behind, but the boy didn't even flinch!
es: I was going to hit her again, but just then, because it was a door that opened inward, just then the wind goes and slams it shut behind the girl, bam!

en: My breff mos’ hop outer me; en I feel so—so—I doan’ know how I feel.
vi: I was terrified and ran over, my whole body trembling, bending down to look at the little girl.
tr: My eyes widened in astonishment... I felt terrible... I can't even describe that feeling.
es: And I swear the girl didn't even move!

en: I crope out, all a-tremblin’, en crope aroun’ en open de do’ easy en slow, en poke my head in behine de chile, sof’ en still, en all uv a sudden I says pow!
vi: She remained still as if nothing had happened.
tr: My face turned pale, and without showing it, I slowly moved behind the boy.
es: I almost lost my breath; and I felt so... I don't know how I felt.

en: jis’ as loud as I could yell.
vi: I burst into tears and hugged her tightly.
tr: Then, when I was sure he wasn't looking at me, I got close to his ear and suddenly shouted:
es: I left there all trembling and I go and open the door very slowly and stick my head right behind the girl, without making a sound, and suddenly I say: "Bam!" as loud as I can.

en: She never budge!
vi: I said, "Poor child of mine!
tr: He didn't even move a muscle, poor thing!
es: And she didn't even move!

en: Oh, Huck, I bust out a-cryin’ en grab her up in my arms, en say, ‘Oh, de po’ little thing!
vi: I said, "Poor child of mine!
tr: Ah, Huck, that's when I started crying too, I took him in my arms and said, 'Oh, my poor child!'
es: Oh, Huck. I started to cry and grabbed her in my arms saying: "Oh, poor thing!

en: De Lord God Amighty fogive po’ ole Jim, kaze he never gwyne to fogive hisself as long’s he live!’
vi: May God forgive this wretched Jim."
tr: Dear Lord, forgive big Jim, because Jim will never forgive himself!
es: May the Lord and all the saints forgive poor Jim, because he will never forgive himself as long as he lives!"

en: Oh, she was plumb deef en dumb, Huck, plumb deef en dumb—en I’d ben a-treat’n her so!”
vi: It turned out, the little girl had been completely mute and deaf for a long time, yet I treated her like that!
tr: Ah, my daughter was deaf and mute, Huck, she couldn't hear or speak... But what did I do to her!"
es: Oh, she had gone completely deaf and mute, Huck, completely deaf and mute, and I was treating her like that!

en: CHAPTER XXIV.
vi: Chapter XXIV
tr: Chapter Twenty-Four
es: Chapter 24

en: Next day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow tow-head out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns.
vi: Near the next day, we anchored the raft under a willow tree, with villages on both sides of the river. The duke and the king started discussing their plan of action in this town again.
tr: Before dark the next day, we docked at a small island covered with poplars in the middle of the river; there was a town on each bank of the river, and the duke and the king began to plan what they would do in the towns.
es: THE NEXT DAY, towards the evening, we moored at a small island of willows in the middle, where there was a town on each side of the river, and the duke and the king started making plans to work in those towns.

en: Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn’t take but a few hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope.
vi: Jim told the duke not to go for too long, just a few hours, because lying all day in the tent and being tied up like that made him very tired.
tr: Meanwhile, Jim chimed in and said he hoped their business wouldn't take more than a few hours, because lying tied up inside the shelter was both very difficult and tiring.
es: Jim spoke with the duke and said that he hoped it wouldn't take more than a few hours, because it was very hard for him to have to stay in the wigwam all day, tied up with ropes.

en: You see, when we left him all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all by himself and not tied it wouldn’t look much like he was a runaway nigger, you know.
vi: Whenever we went away, we tied Jim up so that if anyone suddenly came by and saw him tied up, they would think he had been captured.
tr: When we left the raft, we had to tie him up, because if someone saw him free, we could never convince anyone that he wasn't a captured runaway black man.
es: You see, when we left him, we had to tie him up, because if someone found him alone and untied, it would seem like he was a runaway black man, you know.

en: So the duke said it was kind of hard to have to lay roped all day, and he’d cipher out some way to get around it.
vi: The duke also agreed that lying tied up all day was indeed very hard, so he would think of a better way.
tr: The duke also admitted that keeping him tied up all day was really hard and said he would look for another solution.
es: So the duke said that indeed it was very hard to stay tied up all day and that he was going to think of some way to solve it.

en: He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it.
vi: The Duke was indeed an intelligent person.
tr: Our duke was an extraordinarily clever man, and he soon found a way.
es: The said duke was very clever, and soon an idea occurred to him.

en: He dressed Jim up in King Lear’s outfit—it was a long curtain-calico gown, and a white horse-hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint and painted Jim’s face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead, dull, solid blue, like a man that’s been drownded nine days.
vi: He came up with a plan: to dress Jim in King Lear's clothes, put a white horsehair wig on him; then he used a brush to paint Jim's face, hands, ears, and neck a bluish-gray color, making him look like someone who had been drowned for nine days.
tr: He dressed Jim in a King Lear costume – this costume consisted of a long robe made from curtain fabric, a wig made of white horsehair, and sideburns; then he took the theater paints and painted Jim's face, hands, ears, and neck a dull blue color; in this state, Jim looked like someone who had drowned nine days ago.
es: He dressed Jim in the costume of King Lear: a long calico curtain robe and a white horsehair wig, with its beard, and then took out the theater makeup and painted his face and hands, ears, and neck all in a dull and continuous blue, like a man who had been drowned for nine days.

en: Blamed if he warn’t the horriblest looking outrage I ever see.
vi: It was horrifying, never had anything looked so disgusting.
tr: Honestly, I had never seen such a horrifying sight.
es: Hang me if it wasn't the most horrible sight one could imagine.

en: Then the duke took and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:
vi: Then the Duke took a piece of wood and wrote on it:
tr: The duke also prepared a sign from a piece of wood and wrote on it:
es: Then the duke wrote on a blackboard a sign that said:

en: Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head.
vi: The Arab man is mentally ill, very dangerous when he has an outburst.
tr: Crazy Arab – but he is harmless when he's in his right mind.
es: SICK ARAB; HARMLESS WHEN NOT DRIVEN MAD.

en: And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam.
vi: Then he hung that piece of wood on a tree branch, a few yards away from the tent.
tr: He nailed the sign to a stick and planted the stick a meter or two in front of the shelter.
es: And he nailed the sign to a post and placed the post four or five feet in front of the wigwam.

en: Jim was satisfied.
vi: Jim was very pleased because it was better than being tied up every day, lying there trembling at every sound.
tr: Jim was pleased.
es: Jim was very happy.

en: He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound.
vi: Jim was very pleased because it was better than being tied up every day, lying there trembling at every sound.
tr: He said it was better to look like this than to lie tied up for several years a day and tremble at every sound he heard.
es: He said it was much better than being tied up for years and years every day and trembling every time he heard something.

en: The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone.
vi: The duke told Jim to rest assured, and if anyone wandered around, he should step out of the tent, pretend to be a madman, and howl like a wild animal, so people would be scared and run away immediately.
tr: The Duke told him to act very freely and comfortably, and if someone came there, all he had to do was get out of the shelter and do some crazy things, howl like a wild animal once or twice. Most likely, they would immediately flee and leave him alone.
es: The duke told him to do whatever he pleased and that if anyone came snooping around, he should jump out of the wigwam and make a bit of a fuss and let out a howl or two like a wild animal, and he figured they would leave and let him be.

en: Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldn’t wait for him to howl.
vi: That sounds good. But that's for anyone else; as for Jim, just seeing him would be enough to scare people without him having to howl.
tr: This idea seemed quite reasonable, but if you think about the average person, they probably wouldn't stay there long enough to wait for him to howl.
es: Which was a pretty good idea; but the truth is that a normal man wouldn't wait for him to start howling.

en: Why, he didn’t only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.
vi: These two rascals intended to put on a show like the one they did the other day to make some extra money.
tr: Because Jim not only looked like he was dead, he had a much more frightening appearance.
es: But it not only looked like he had died, but something much worse still!

en: These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn’t be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time.
vi: But then they thought it would be dangerous, and perhaps the news about the previous show had already spread down here.
tr: Our swindlers tried the Curcuna trick again, because there was a lot of money in it, but they didn't find it safe enough; perhaps the news had already reached here from the upper town.
es: Those scoundrels wanted to try the Sin Par again because it brought in a lot of money, but they figured it wasn't worth it, as the news might have already spread.

en: They couldn’t hit no project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he’d lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn’t put up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would drop over to t’other village without any plan, but just trust in Providence to lead him the profitable way—meaning the devil, I reckon.
vi: They couldn't come up with any other tricks, so the duke said he would lie down and think for another hour or two to see if he could come up with something. The king said if there was no new plan, he would leave his fate to the will of God.
tr: They couldn't come up with a plan that was perfectly suitable for here; finally, the duke said he would lie down for a couple of hours and try to come up with something that would fit this Arkansas town exactly. The king decided to take a short trip to the town across the way. He didn't have any plan, but he believed that the Creator would lead him to a profitable business... By the Creator, he probably meant the devil.
es: They couldn't come up with any project that seemed perfect, so in the end, the duke said he was giving up and would think about it for an hour or two to see if he could organize something in the town of Arkansas, and the king said he would go to the other town without any plan, but would trust Providence to give him some lucrative idea, meaning, I guess, that he was referring to the theater.

en: We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king put his’n on, and he told me to put mine on.
vi: At the last resting place, we all bought new clothes.
tr: At our last stop, we all got some clothes from a store; the king put on his new clothes and told me to put on mine too.
es: We had all bought clothes at the store at the last stop, and now the king put on his and told me to put on mine.

en: I done it, of course.
vi: At the last resting place, we all bought new clothes.
tr: Of course, I did what he said immediately.
es: Of course, I did.

en: The king’s duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy.
vi: The king's clothes were jet black, making him look quite dignified.
tr: The king, dressed entirely in black, had become a very dignified man.
es: The king's clothes were all black and had a very elegant and starched look.

en: I never knowed how clothes could change a body before.
vi: Never had I seen clothes change a person so much.
tr: I could never have guessed that clothes could change a person so much.
es: Until then, I had never understood how clothes could change a person.

en: Why, before, he looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he’d take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked that grand and good and pious that you’d say he had walked right out of the ark, and maybe was old Leviticus himself.
vi: Previously, he looked shabby and disheveled, but now when he took off his white hat, bowed, and smiled, he looked so solemn it seemed he could have been a Jewish rabbi.
tr: Previously, it was obvious from a thousand meters away that he was a lowlife, but now, when he took off his new white hat, bowed slightly, and smiled, he looked so important, kind-hearted, and pious that you might think he had just stepped off Noah's Ark or was old Leviticus himself.
es: Before, he had the air of the old scoundrel he really was, but now, when he took off his new beaver hat and bowed and smiled, he looked so elegant and pious that one would think he had just stepped out of Noah's Ark and could have written Leviticus himself.

en: Jim cleaned up the canoe, and I got my paddle ready.
vi: Jim cleaned the boat, and I prepared the oars.
tr: Jim prepared the canoe, and I adjusted the oars.
es: Jim cleaned the canoe and prepared the paddle for me.

en: There was a big steamboat laying at the shore away up under the point, about three mile above the town—been there a couple of hours, taking on freight.
vi: There was a steamboat docked to unload goods on the shore about three miles above the town.
tr: There was a large steamboat anchored about three miles up the town – it had been loading cargo there for a few hours.
es: A steamboat had docked on the shore beyond the cape, about three miles up from the town, and had been there for a couple of hours, loading material.

en: Says the king:
vi: The king said:
tr: “If we look at my outfit,” said the king, “it's probably best that I came from a big place like St. Louis or Cincinnati.
es: And the king goes and says:

en: “Seein’ how I’m dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from St. Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place.
vi: - Just look at the way I'm dressed like this, anyone would think I'm from St. Louis or Cincinnati.
tr: “If we look at my outfit,” said the king, “it's probably best that I came from a big place like St. Louis or Cincinnati.
es: —Since I'm dressed like this, I figure it's better to get to Saint Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big city.

en: Go for the steamboat, Huckleberry; we’ll come down to the village on her.”
vi: Huck, we will take the steamboat to the village down there.
tr: Let's go to the steamboat, Huckleberry; we'll go to town on that boat.”
es: Let's head to the steamboat, Huckleberry; we'll get to town on it.

en: I didn’t have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride.
vi: When it comes to getting to ride a boat, I don't need to be asked twice.
tr: I had no intention of disobeying this order; I grabbed the oar and we moved towards the steamer.
es: There was no need to be told twice to take a ride on a steamboat.

en: I fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water.
vi: I pushed the boat along the shore on this side for about half a mile, then looked for a spot where the water flowed gently to proceed.
tr: I reached the shore about half a mile above the town, then climbed up the rocky shore in relatively calm waters.
es: I reached the riverbank half a mile upstream from the village, and then we slid down along the cliff, in the calm water.

en: Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet-bags by him.
vi: A while later, we encountered a young man who looked rustic and somewhat naive, sitting on a log, wiping the sweat off his face. Next to him were two large bags.
tr: Soon, we came across a man who looked pleasant and innocent, sitting on a log and wiping his sweat, as it was very hot; he had a few large bags with him.
es: We soon encountered a young farmer with an innocent air, sitting on a log and wiping the sweat from his face, as it was very hot, with a couple of cloth suitcases on the ground.

en: “Run her nose in shore,” says the king.
vi: The king said: - Point the bow towards the shore.
tr: “Stick the cannon's nose in,” said the king.
es: —We are going to dock —said the king.

en: I done it.
vi: I pushed the boat back in.
tr: I did as he said.
es: I obeyed—.

en: “Wher’ you bound for, young man?”
vi: - Hey, where are you going?
tr: “Where are you going, young man?”
es: Where are you going, young man?

en: “For the steamboat; going to Orleans.”
vi: - The king asked. - I went to the boat to go to Orleans
tr: “I will take the steamer. I am going to Orleans.”
es: —To the steamboat; I have to go to Orleans.

en: “Git aboard,” says the king.
vi: The king said:
tr: “Let's see,” said the king.
es: —Get on board —said the king—.

en: “Hold on a minute, my servant ’ll he’p you with them bags.
vi: - Come up here! Wait, let my servant carry those bags for you.
tr: “Wait a second, let my servant help you with your bags.
es: One moment, my servant will help you with the luggage.

en: Jump out and he’p the gentleman, Adolphus”—meaning me, I see.
vi: Jump up and help him, Adolphus. (He probably means me).
tr: Go ashore and help the gentleman, Adolphus.” He had said this to me.
es: Jump ashore and give the gentleman a hand, Adolfus —and I saw that it was me.

en: I done so, and then we all three started on again.
vi: I went ashore, carried down a few bags, and then the three of us went together.
tr: I did what he said, then the three of us continued on our way.
es: I obeyed, and the three of us set off again.

en: The young chap was mighty thankful; said it was tough work toting his baggage such weather.
vi: The other man thanked profusely and said that in such hot weather, carrying these things would be truly exhausting.
tr: The young man was grateful; he said that carrying so much stuff in this weather was a terrible job.
es: The boy was very grateful; he said that traveling with luggage in such weather was very tiring.

en: He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him he’d come down the river and landed at the other village this morning, and now he was going up a few mile to see an old friend on a farm up there.
vi: He asked where the king was going, and the old man said that this morning he went to a village up there, then walked a few more miles to visit an old friend at a nearby camp.
tr: He asked the king where he was going, and the king said he had come from down the river and had landed in the other town that morning; he was going to see an old friend at a farm a few miles further up.
es: He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him that he had come down the river and landed in the other village that morning, and that now he was going to travel a few miles to see an old friend at a nearby estate.

en: The young fellow says:
vi: The other man said:
tr: “When I first saw you,” said the young man, “I said to myself, ‘This is definitely Mr. Wilks, which means he almost made it here.’
es: The boy said:

en: “When I first see you I says to myself, ‘It’s mr Wilks, sure, and he come mighty near getting here in time.’
vi: - Just now when I saw you, I thought to myself this must be Mr. Wilks, but then I told myself it couldn't be because if it were Mr. Wilks, he wouldn't be going upriver like this.
tr: “When I first saw you,” said the young man, “I said to myself, ‘This is definitely Mr. Wilks, which means he almost made it here.’
es: —When I saw you, I said to myself: "Surely, it is Mr. Wilks arriving just in time."

en: But then I says again, ‘No, I reckon it ain’t him, or else he wouldn’t be paddling up the river.’
vi: - Just now when I saw you, I thought to myself this must be Mr. Wilks, but then I told myself it couldn't be because if it were Mr. Wilks, he wouldn't be going upriver like this.
tr: But then I thought again, ‘No, it can't be Mr. Wilks, because he is coming upriver.’
es: But then I said to myself again: "No, I guess not, because he wouldn't be rowing upstream."

en: You ain’t him, are you?”
vi: You're not Mr. Wilks, are you?
tr: You are not Mr. Wilks, are you?”
es: It's not you, right?

en: “No, my name’s Blodgett—Elexander Blodgett—Reverend Elexander Blodgett, I s’pose I must say, as I’m one o’ the Lord’s poor servants.
vi: - No, my name is Blodgett, Elexandre Blodgett, Reverend Elexandre Blodgett, to be precise.
tr: “No, my name is Blodgett –Elexander Blodgett– Reverend Elexander Blodgett, to be more precise, for I am one of God's humble servants.
es: —No, my name is Blodgett; Alexander Blodgett; Reverend Alexander Blodgett, I suppose I should say, given that I am one of the Lord's poor servants.

en: But still I’m jist as able to be sorry for mr Wilks for not arriving in time, all the same, if he’s missed anything by it—which I hope he hasn’t.”
vi: But I myself am also wondering why Mr. Wilks hasn't arrived yet, or if something unfortunate has happened to him?
tr: But still, I am saddened that Mr. Wilks could not arrive on time, I wish he could have made it but... I wonder what he missed?”
es: But I can also regret that Mr. Wilks did not arrive on time, if that causes you any inconvenience, although I hope it does not.

en: “Well, he don’t miss any property by it, because he’ll get that all right; but he’s missed seeing his brother Peter die—which he mayn’t mind, nobody can tell as to that—but his brother would a give anything in this world to see him before he died; never talked about nothing else all these three weeks; hadn’t seen him since they was boys together—and hadn’t ever seen his brother William at all—that’s the deef and dumb one—William ain’t more than thirty or thirty-five.
vi: - Actually, he didn't lose anything materially. But he didn't make it in time to see his brother Peter, who had just died. It seems that the two brothers hadn't seen each other since they were young - and they also hadn't seen their younger brother named William. This younger brother was both mute and deaf. William was just over thirty, around thirty-five years old.
tr: “Of course, he didn't lose his property, because he will take them all; but he couldn't see his brother Peter one last time before he died... Maybe he didn't care about this; no one can know for sure... But he would have given everything to see his brother before he died; for three weeks he talked about nothing but his brothers; he hadn't seen them since childhood... In fact, he had never seen his brother William... William was deaf and mute... He must have been around thirty or at most thirty-five years old.
es: —Well, it's not that he's going to lose his possessions, because those belong to him anyway, but he won't be able to see his brother Peter die, which he might not care about, nobody can know, but his brother would have given anything to see him before dying; in these three weeks he hasn't talked about anything else; he hasn't seen him since they were children and he has never seen his brother William in his life, that is, the deaf-mute one, William, who is only thirty or thirty-five years old.

en: Peter and George were the only ones that come out here; George was the married brother; him and his wife both died last year.
vi: Only Peter and George came to live in this area. George was married. Both husband and wife died last year.
tr: The only ones who came here were Peter and George; George was the one who was married; last year both he and his wife passed away.
es: Peter and George were the only ones who came here; George was the married one; he and his wife died last year.

en: Harvey and William’s the only ones that’s left now; and, as I was saying, they haven’t got here in time.”
vi: Now only Harvey and William are left, but they didn't make it in time.
tr: Now only Harvey and William are left, but as I said, they couldn't come in time either.”
es: Now only Harvey and William are left and, as I was saying, they are not going to arrive in time.

en: “Did anybody send ’em word?”
vi: - So, did anyone tell them?
tr: “Were they notified?”
es: —Has anyone notified them?

en: “Oh, yes; a month or two ago, when Peter was first took; because Peter said then that he sorter felt like he warn’t going to get well this time.
vi: - Yes, about two months now, since Peter first got sick.
tr: “Of course, word was sent a month or two ago, that is, when Peter first took to his bed; because Peter had said that this time he felt he would never get up again.
es: —Ah, yes; one or two months ago, when Peter got sick, because Peter said then that it seemed to him like this time he wasn't going to get better.

en: You see, he was pretty old, and George’s g’yirls was too young to be much company for him, except Mary Jane, the red-headed one; and so he was kinder lonesome after George and his wife died, and didn’t seem to care much to live.
vi: He's very old now. George's daughters are too young, they can't help him at all. Only Mary Jane with the red hair can. After George and his wife died, he felt extremely lonely and didn't want to live anymore.
tr: Truth be told, he was quite old, and George's daughters were too young to take good care of him, except for red-haired Mary Jane; so when George and his wife died, Peter became very lonely and didn't seem to want to live any longer.
es: You see, he was very old and George's girls were too young to keep him much company, except for Mary Jane, the redhead; so he felt very lonely when George and his wife died, and he didn't seem to have much desire to live.

en: He most desperately wanted to see Harvey—and William, too, for that matter—because he was one of them kind that can’t bear to make a will.
vi: He desperately wished to see Harvey again, and William too.
tr: He very, very much wanted to see Harvey – and also William – because he was a man who didn't like dealing with wills.
es: He was desperate to see Harvey, and in fact also William, because he was one of those who can't stand making a will.

en: He left a letter behind for Harvey, and said he’d told in it where his money was hid, and how he wanted the rest of the property divided up so George’s g’yirls would be all right—for George didn’t leave nothing.
vi: He left a letter for Harvey, in which he mentioned where he hid the money, and expressed his wish that the inheritance be divided among George's daughters, because George had nothing to leave for his children.
tr: He had left a letter for Harvey, detailing where the money was hidden and how he wanted the properties to be distributed among George's daughters – because George had left nothing behind.
es: He left a letter for Harvey and said that in it he told him where the money was hidden and how he wanted the rest of the property to be divided so that George's girls would be well taken care of, because George hadn't left anything.

en: And that letter was all they could get him to put a pen to.”
vi: That's all the letter said.
tr: The only thing they could get him to do was to dictate this letter.”
es: And that letter was the only thing they managed to get him to write.

en: “Why do you reckon Harvey don’t come?
vi: - Why do you think Harvey can't make it?
tr: “I wonder why Harvey didn't come?
es: —Why do you think Harvey hasn't come?

en: Wher’ does he live?”
vi: Where is Harvey now?
tr: Where does he live?”
es: Where does he live?

en: “Oh, he lives in England—Sheffield—preaches there—hasn’t ever been in this country.
vi: - Over in England, in some place called Sheffield, I heard he's a pastor. Up until now, he has never come back here.
tr: “He lives in Sheffield, England… He works as a priest there… He has never been to this country before.
es: —Ah, he lives in England, in Sheffield; he is a preacher and has never returned to this country.

en: He hasn’t had any too much time—and besides he mightn’t a got the letter at all, you know.”
vi: He's very busy... and maybe he didn't receive Peter's letter...
tr: He didn't have enough time… It is even possible that he never received the letter.”
es: He hasn't had much time, and besides, you know, maybe the letter didn't even reach him.

en: “Too bad, too bad he couldn’t a lived to see his brothers, poor soul.
vi: - Poor Peter, if only he could see his brothers' faces.
tr: “How terrible, it's so sad that he passed away without seeing his brothers, poor man.
es: —A shame, a shame that he couldn't live to see his brothers, poor thing.

en: You going to Orleans, you say?”
vi: Just now, you said you were going to Orleans, right?
tr: You're going to Orleans, aren't you?”
es: And you say you're going to Orleans?

en: “Yes, but that ain’t only a part of it.
vi: - Yes, but that's just the first leg.
tr: “Yes, but going there is just the beginning.
es: —Yes, but that is just the beginning.

en: I’m going in a ship, next Wednesday, for Ryo Janeero, where my uncle lives.”
vi: Next week, I'll board a ship to Rio de Janeiro, where my uncle lives.
tr: We need to go to Rio de Janeiro, where my uncle lives, next Wednesday.”
es: Next Wednesday I am taking a boat to Rio de Janeiro, where my uncle lives.

en: “It’s a pretty long journey.
vi: - Going far, huh?
tr: "It's a very long road.
es: —It's quite a long trip.

en: But it’ll be lovely; wisht I was a-going.
vi: But it must be very enjoyable. I also want to go very much.
tr: But it is very enjoyable; I wish I could have come too.
es: But it will be very nice; I wish I could go.

en: Is Mary Jane the oldest?
vi: Is Mary Jane the oldest one?
tr: Is Mary Jane the eldest?
es: Is Mary Jane the oldest?

en: How old is the others?”
vi: How old are the other girls?
tr: How old was she?"
es: How old are the others?

en: “Mary Jane’s nineteen, Susan’s fifteen, and Joanna’s about fourteen—that’s the one that gives herself to good works and has a hare-lip.”
vi: - Mary Jane is nineteen, Susan is fifteen, and Joanna is fourteen. The youngest one has a cleft lip but is diligent in her work.
tr: “Mary Jane is nineteen years old, Susan is fifteen, and Joanna is fourteen – the one who devotes herself to charity and has a harelip is named Joanna.”
es: —Mary Jane, nineteen years old; Susan, fifteen, and Joanna about fourteen... she's the one who is dedicated to good deeds and has a cleft lip.

en: “Poor things! to be left alone in the cold world so.”
vi: - Poor little girls who are orphaned.
tr: "Poor things! They have been left all alone in this cruel world."
es: —Poor little things! To be left alone like this in this cold world...

en: “Well, they could be worse off.
vi: - The girls should have suffered even more.
tr: "Their situation could have been worse.
es: —Well, they could be worse off.

en: Old Peter had friends, and they ain’t going to let them come to no harm.
vi: But old Peter has many acquaintances, and they didn't let these girls suffer.
tr: Old Peter had friends and they wouldn't let anything happen to those left behind.
es: Old Peter had friends, and they are not going to let anything happen to them.

en: There’s Hobson, the Babtis’ preacher; and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, the lawyer; and dr Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley, and—well, there’s a lot of them; but these are the ones that Peter was thickest with, and used to write about sometimes, when he wrote home; so Harvey ’ll know where to look for friends when he gets here.”
vi: Those people, old Peter is very close to and occasionally writes letters about them whenever he sends letters back to England; therefore, if Harvey comes here, he might also find some familiar friends.
tr: Baptist preacher Hobson, assistant pastor Lot Hovey, Ben Rucker; Abner Shackleford and lawyer Levi Bell; Doctor Robinson and all their wives, widow Mrs. Bartley and... there are so many; though these were the closest to Peter; he would write about them from time to time; so that when Harvey came here, he would know who his friends were."
es: There are Hobson, the Baptist preacher, and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker and Abner Shackleford and Levi Bell, the lawyer, and Doctor Robinson and their wives, and Widow Bartley and... well, lots of them; but those were Peter's closest friends and the ones he sometimes talked about when he wrote home. So Harvey will know where to look for friends when he arrives.

en: Well, the old man went on asking questions till he just fairly emptied that young fellow.
vi: The king kept asking about this matter until the young man had nothing left to say.
tr: Anyway, the old man kept asking questions until he learned everything the young man knew.
es: Well, the old man kept asking questions until he practically got everything out of the boy.

en: Blamed if he didn’t inquire about everybody and everything in that blessed town, and all about the Wilkses; and about Peter’s business—which was a tanner; and about George’s—which was a carpenter; and about Harvey’s—which was a dissentering minister; and so on, and so on.
vi: Strangely, he didn't inquire about anyone else or anything else in the province, but only asked about the Wilks family. Then he asked about Peter's profession - a tanner, George's profession - a carpenter, and then Harvey, who is a minister...
tr: He asked about everyone and everything in that town; he learned everything about the Wilks; he learned everything about Peter, who was a tanner; he learned everything about George, who was a carpenter; he also learned about Harvey, who was a dissident preacher; and it went on like this.
es: Darned if he didn't ask about everyone and everything in that poor town, everything related to the Wilks and what Peter's business was, which was tanning; and George's, which was carpentry; and Harvey's, who was a pastor of a dissenting church, etcetera, etcetera.

en: Then he says:
vi: He asked again:
tr: Finally, he asked the young man:
es: Then he said:

en: “What did you want to walk all the way up to the steamboat for?”
vi: - Why do you have to go back up to the ship?
tr: “Why did you walk so far up to board the steamboat?”
es: —Why did you want to walk all the way to the steamboat?

en: “Because she’s a big Orleans boat, and I was afeard she mightn’t stop there.
vi: - Because it's a big ship, it can't maneuver in here, and I'm also afraid it won't dock there.
tr: “Because a large Orleans ship will come, I fear it may not stop here.
es: —Because it's one of the big boats from Orleans and I was afraid it wouldn't stop there.

en: When they’re deep they won’t stop for a hail.
vi: The Cincinnati ship docks, but as for the St. Louis ship, I don't know.
tr: If it has a heavy load, it will leave without a moment's hesitation.
es: The big ones don't stop when they're called.

en: A Cincinnati boat will, but this is a St. Louis one.”
vi: The Cincinnati ship docks, but as for the St. Louis ship, I don't know.
tr: If it were a Cincinnati ship, it would stop, but this is a St Louis ship.”
es: The ones from Cincinnati do, but this one is from Saint Louis.

en: “Was Peter Wilks well off?”
vi: - Is Peter Wilks wealthy?
tr: “Was Peter Wilks well-off?”
es: —Was Peter Wilks rich?

en: “Oh, yes, pretty well off.
vi: - Quite wealthy.
tr: “Yes, and how.
es: —Ah, yes, quite wealthy.

en: He had houses and land, and it’s reckoned he left three or four thousand in cash hid up som’ers.”
vi: He has a house, land, and it is said that he left three to four thousand đồng buried somewhere.
tr: He had houses and land, and it is also said that he hid three to four thousand dollars in cash somewhere.”
es: He had houses and lands, and it is estimated that he left three or four thousand dollars in cash hidden somewhere.

en: “When did you say he died?”
vi: - When did that old man die?
tr: “When did you say they died?”
es: —When did you say he had died?

en: “I didn’t say, but it was last night.”
vi: - Last night
tr: “I hadn't mentioned it, but he died last night.”
es: —I didn't say it, but it was last night.

en: “Funeral to-morrow, likely?”
vi: - Will the funeral be held tomorrow?
tr: “The funeral is probably tomorrow, right?”
es: —Then the funeral will be tomorrow.

en: “Yes, ’bout the middle of the day.”
vi: - Yes, I heard it's around noon tomorrow.
tr: “Yes, it will be done around noon.”
es: —Yes, around noon.

en: “Well, it’s all terrible sad; but we’ve all got to go, one time or another.
vi: - It's so sad; but we will all be like that eventually.
tr: “How sad; but one day, it will be all of our turns.
es: —Well, it's all very sad, but we all have to leave at one time or another.

en: So what we want to do is to be prepared; then we’re all right.”
vi: So, we should just prepare ourselves in advance.
tr: So the only thing we can do is to be ready; then we can go with peace of mind.”
es: So what we have to do is be prepared and then peace will be with us.

en: “Yes, sir, it’s the best way.
vi: - That's right, sir.
tr: "Yes, sir, this is the best."
es: —Yes, sir, it is the best.

en: Ma used to always say that.”
vi: My mother often says the same.
tr: My mother always used to say that too."
es: My mother always said the same.

en: When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she got off.
vi: When we arrived at the dock, the ship had almost finished unloading and was about to depart.
tr: When we caught the ship, it had almost finished loading and was about to set off.
es: When we arrived at the ship, it had almost finished loading and immediately set sail.

en: The king never said nothing about going aboard, so I lost my ride, after all.
vi: The king didn't say anything about boarding the ship; as a result, I didn't get to go on the ship.
tr: The king didn't say anything about going on deck, so I couldn't board.
es: The king didn't say anything about boarding, so after all, I missed out on the trip.

en: When the boat was gone the king made me paddle up another mile to a lonesome place, and then he got ashore and says:
vi: When the ship was far away from me, the king told me to row another mile further. Upon reaching a deserted place, he stepped ashore and said:
tr: After the ship left, he made me row up to a deserted place a mile away, then he went ashore.
es: When the ship had been gone for a while, the king made me row another mile upstream to a solitary spot, then he got off to the shore and said:

en: “Now hustle back, right off, and fetch the duke up here, and the new carpet-bags.
vi: - Now go down to bring the Duke up here, remember to bring along a few new bags of cloth as well.
tr: “Now go back to the ferry immediately and bring the duke here,” he said. “He should also bring the new kilim-bags.
es: —Now run back and bring the duke with the new canvas suitcases.

en: And if he’s gone over to t’other side, go over there and git him.
vi: If he has gone to the other side of the river, go there to find him and tell him to come up here immediately.
tr: If he has gone to the neighboring town, you follow him and find him.
es: And if he has gone to the other side, go there to find him.

en: And tell him to git himself up regardless.
vi: If he has gone to the other side of the river, go there to find him and tell him to come up here immediately.
tr: Tell him to leave everything and come.
es: Tell him to get ready to come no matter what happens.

en: Shove along, now.”
vi: Hurry up!
tr: Come on, put your back into it.”
es: Come on, go.

en: I see what he was up to; but I never said nothing, of course.
vi: I know what he's planning, but I won't say.
tr: I had understood what his intention was, but of course, I didn't say anything.
es: I understood what he was preparing, but naturally, I didn't say anything.

en: When I got back with the duke we hid the canoe, and then they set down on a log, and the king told him everything, just like the young fellow had said it—every last word of it.
vi: When we brought the duke, we hid him very carefully. The king recounted to the duke the entire story that he had just heard.
tr: When I came back with the Duke, we hid the canoe, then they sat on a log and the king told him everything just as the same young man had said – without skipping a single word.
es: When I returned with the duke, we hid the canoe and they sat on a log and the king told him everything, just as he had told the young man: down to the last word.

en: And all the time he was a-doing it he tried to talk like an Englishman; and he done it pretty well, too, for a slouch.
vi: While talking, he tried to speak in an English accent, and it was quite convincing.
tr: Moreover, while telling, he was trying to speak like an Englishman; he did the imitation quite well, at least for someone as lazy as him.
es: And all the time trying to speak like an Englishman, and he did it quite well, for a vagabond.

en: I can’t imitate him, and so I ain’t a-going to try to; but he really done it pretty good.
vi: While talking, he tried to speak in an English accent, and it was quite convincing.
tr: It's not possible for me to explain how he did it by writing, so I won't even try; but he really did it well.
es: I can't imitate it, so I'm not going to try, but he really did it very well.

en: Then he says:
vi: Then he asked:
tr: It's not possible for me to explain how he did it by writing, so I won't even try; but he really did it well.
es: Then he said:

en: “How are you on the deef and dumb, Bilgewater?”
vi: - Bilgewater, can you play the role of someone who is both mute and deaf?
tr: “How good are you at playing the deaf-mute, Bridgewater?” he said.
es: —How's your deaf-mute act going, Aguassucias?

en: The duke said, leave him alone for that; said he had played a deef and dumb person on the histronic boards.
vi: The Duke said it was fine because he had once pretended to be both mute and deaf.
tr: The Duke said, "You can leave this to me"; he had played the role of a deaf-mute on the theater stage.
es: The duke said that he could be trusted. He said that he had played the role of a deaf-mute on stage.

en: So then they waited for a steamboat.
vi: So we sat there waiting for the steamboat.
tr: After that, they started waiting for the steamboat.
es: So they waited for a steamboat to arrive.

en: About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along, but they didn’t come from high enough up the river; but at last there was a big one, and they hailed her.
vi: Around early afternoon, a few small boats came by, but they didn't go far. A while later, a big boat arrived, and they called us in. A small boat was sent from the big boat to pick us up.
tr: Towards the afternoon, a few small ships came and went, but they weren't far enough upstream. Finally, a big one appeared, and the duke and the king waved to it.
es: Towards the first hour of the afternoon, two boats appeared, but they did not come from too far upstream; finally, a large one appeared and they called it.

en: She sent out her yawl, and we went aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing, and said they wouldn’t land us.
vi: All three of us boarded the boat. This boat came from Cincinnati. But when we got on the boat, they found out we only intended to travel a short distance of four or five miles, they cursed at us for a while and said they wouldn't stop to let us off.
tr: A dinghy was sent from the ship, and we went aboard; the ship was from Cincinnati. When they learned that we only wanted to go four or five miles, they went crazy; they cursed and said they wouldn't take us.
es: They sent the yawl and we boarded; it was from Cincinnati, and when they found out that we only wanted to travel four or five miles, they got furious and cursed us and said they would not disembark us.

en: But the king was ca’m.
vi: But the king was very calm.
tr: But the king, without losing his composure, said:
es: But the king said very calmly:

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: But the king, without losing his composure, said:
es: But the king said very calmly:

en: “If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry ’em, can’t it?”
vi: - If we pay one dollar per mile, will the ship agree to carry the load?
tr: “If gentlemen pay one dollar per mile to be picked up and dropped off by lifeboat, steamships can carry them; isn't that so?”
es: —If the gentlemen can afford a dollar per mile each to be taken up and down in a skiff, then a steamboat can afford to transport them, can't it?

en: So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the village they yawled us ashore.
vi: Hearing that, they immediately agreed and were no longer angry. Upon reaching the place we indicated, the ship carried us to the shore.
tr: Upon this, they softened and said there was no longer a problem, and when we reached the town, they brought us ashore with a lifeboat.
es: So they softened and said fine, and when we got to the town they took us to the riverbank in the skiff.

en: About two dozen men flocked down when they see the yawl a-coming, and when the king says:
vi: More than twenty people rushed out when they saw our boat approaching. The king asked:
tr: When they saw the lifeboat coming, about two dozen men came to the shore.
es: When they saw it arrive, about two dozen men came down to see it, and when the king said:

en: “Kin any of you gentlemen tell me wher’ mr Peter Wilks lives?” they give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to say, “What d’ I tell you?”
vi: - Can you show me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives? The people looked at each other and shook their heads sadly.
tr: When the king said to them, "Gentlemen, can you tell me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives?" they first looked at each other and nodded as if to say, "Didn't I tell you?"
es: —Can any of you gentlemen tell me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives? —they looked at each other, nodding their heads, as if saying: "What did I tell you?"

en: Then one of them says, kind of soft and gentle:
vi: But one person replied in a very polite voice:
tr: One of them answered politely and softly:
es: Then one of them says, in a very kind voice:

en: “I’m sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he did live yesterday evening.”
vi: - I'm very sorry, sir. But we can only tell you where he was staying last night.
tr: “I'm sorry, sir, but the best thing we can do for you is to tell you where he was staying last night.”
es: —I'm sorry, sir, but the most we can do is tell you where he lived until last night.

en: Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went an to smash, and fell up against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his back, and says:
vi: Then suddenly, the king burst into tears, hugging the other person tightly, crying and saying:
tr: Our old rascal suddenly shook as if he had been struck, collapsed onto the man, rested his chin on his shoulder, and began crying towards his back:
es: In the blink of an eye, the old rascal began to tremble, let himself fall against the man, resting his chin on his shoulder and crying on his back, and said:

en: “Alas, alas, our poor brother—gone, and we never got to see him; oh, it’s too, too hard!”
vi: - Oh dear, our unfortunate brother has passed away, we will never be able to see his face again! Oh, the pain!
tr: “Ah, what a pity, what a pity, my poor brother... He passed away and we didn't get the chance to see him; oh, how terrible, how terrible!”
es: —Oh, oh, our poor brother... He is gone and we never got to see him! Oh, this is too much, too much!
