en: But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
vi: I once again paid attention to the faces to see what I could find, but I found nothing in those expressions; I couldn't understand.
tr: But again, I couldn't make anything out – the faces were telling me nothing.
es: But nothing happened; the faces told me nothing.

en: The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home.
vi: In the evening, the king visited familiar people, pretending to be friendly. The old man said that his parishioners in England were eagerly waiting for him, so he had to quickly arrange and settle everything to return.
tr: When evening came, the king walked around, spoke sweet words to everyone, and acted friendly; meanwhile, he hinted in various ways that his congregation in England was eagerly waiting for him, so he had to hurry, sell off the properties, and return home.
es: The king was seeing a lot of people that afternoon, reassuring everyone, very friendly, and he made them understand that in England his parishioners would be worried about him, so he had to hurry and immediately resolve the inheritance issue before leaving.

en: He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldn’t be done.
vi: The old man said he regretted having to rush like that. Everyone said the same, they wished he could stay longer.
tr: He was sad because he had so little time, and the townspeople were very upset too; they were hoping he would stay longer, but they could understand why that wasn't possible.
es: He regretted very much having to rush, and the same was true for the others; they wanted him to stay longer, but they said they understood that it was impossible.

en: And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, too—tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready.
vi: The old man also said that he and William would take those nieces back to their country. Hearing that, everyone was happy for the girls who would have relatives to rely on. The girls were also delighted to hear him say that. The girls urged him to sell the house and land quickly.
tr: Of course, he and William would take the girls home with them; this made everyone happy because the girls would be taken care of, they would be with their relatives; the girls were also happy about this – they were very delighted because they could start a new chapter in their lives and forget their previous troubles; they told him to sell the properties as quickly as possible, they would be ready.
es: And he said that naturally William and he would take the girls home with them, which also pleased everyone a lot, because then the girls would be well protected and among their own relatives, and it also pleased the girls; they liked it so much that they practically forgot they had any problems in the world and told him to sell everything whenever he wanted, that they were ready.

en: Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.
vi: The more joyful they were, the more heartbroken I felt seeing them being deceived. But I had no way to change the situation.
tr: The poor things were so joyful and happy that it broke my heart to see them being deceived and lulled with lies, but I couldn't think of a safe way to intervene and change everything.
es: The poor girls were so happy and content that it broke my heart to see how they were being deceived and lied to so much, but I couldn't see a safe way to intervene and change the general state of things.

en: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
vi: After that, the king announced the sale of the house, property, and the black workers who worked there two days after the burial, but before that, anyone who wanted to buy anything separately could do so.
tr: The king immediately opened an auction for the house, the slaves, and all the property – it would be held two days after the funeral, but those interested could come and make offers beforehand.
es: Well, damned if the king didn't immediately put the house and the slaves and all the lands up for auction immediately, two days after the funeral; but anyone who wanted to could buy privately before if they wanted.

en: So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt.
vi: The next day, after the funeral was over, the girls' joys encountered their first obstacle.
tr: The first blow to the girls' joy came the very next day after the funeral, around noon; a few slave traders arrived, and the king sold the blacks at a reasonable price with a three-day note; two of the boys were sent upriver to Memphis, while their mother was sent downriver to Orleans.
es: So the day after the funeral, around noon, the girls got their first surprise.

en: A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans.
vi: A few slave traders came by, and the king sold all the black people working in the house at a reasonable price and took a promissory note. Thus, the black people left one by one. The two sons went up to Memphis, while the mother went down to Orleans.
tr: The first blow to the girls' joy came the very next day after the funeral, around noon; a few slave traders arrived, and the king sold the blacks at a reasonable price with a three-day note; two of the boys were sent upriver to Memphis, while their mother was sent downriver to Orleans.
es: A pair of slave traders appeared, and the king sold the black people to them at a reasonable price, with three-day promissory notes, according to what they said, and they took them away: the two sons upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to Orleans.

en: I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it.
vi: The mistresses and they hugged each other, crying with infinite sorrow.
tr: I thought the hearts of the poor girls and their blacks would break from grief; they cried and were so distressed while saying goodbye that I couldn't bear to watch anymore.
es: I thought those poor girls and the black people were going to have their hearts broken with grief; they cried together and were so sad that it almost made me sick to see it.

en: The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town.
vi: The girls said they never expected to see the family separated and to have to sell them off like this.
tr: The girls said they never even considered the possibility that the family would be separated or sold out of town.
es: The girls said they had never dreamed of seeing that family separated or sold far from town.

en: I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
vi: They hugged each other and cried continuously, making me want to immediately expose the scoundrels so that the black people could stay with their mistresses.
tr: I can't seem to forget that scene, the image of the poor, miserable girls and the blacks hugging each other and crying won't leave my mind; if I didn't know that the sale was unjust and that the blacks would return in a week or two, I probably wouldn't have been able to stand it and would have blown the whistle on our gang.
es: I will never be able to erase from my memory the vision of those poor girls and the black people so sad, hugging and crying; I think I wouldn't have been able to bear it and would have burst and betrayed our gang if I hadn't known that the sale was invalid and that the black people would be back home within a week or two.

en: The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way.
vi: The sale made everyone in the town resentful, considering it cruel.
tr: This event also caused discomfort in the town, with many people openly stating that separating the mother from her children in such a manner was a complete disgrace.
es: That also attracted a lot of attention in the village, and many came running to say that it was a scandal to separate the mother and children like that.

en: It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.
vi: The honor of the two old swindlers was slightly diminished. But that crazy old man insisted on doing things his way, despite the duke's objections.
tr: Our swindlers seemed to be in a bit of hot water, but despite everything the duke said or did, the old fool stubbornly stuck to his guns; it was not hard to see that the duke was very disturbed by this situation.
es: The impostors took it badly, but the old man insisted on moving forward, despite what the duke might say or do, and I assure you that the duke felt very uncomfortable.

en: Next day was auction day.
vi: The next day was the auction day.
tr: The auction was to be held the next day.
es: The next day was the day of the auction.

en: About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble.
vi: At dawn, the king and the duke went upstairs to wake me up. Seeing their faces, I immediately guessed that something was up.
tr: After the sun had risen in the morning, the king and the duke came to the attic and woke me up; judging by the look on their faces, there was a problem.
es: Well into the morning, the king and the duke went up to the attic to wake me up, and from their expressions, I could see there was trouble.

en: The king says:
vi: The king asked:
tr: "Did you enter my room the night before last?" asked the king.
es: The king goes and says:

en: “Was you in my room night before last?”
vi: - The night before, did you come into my room?
tr: "Did you enter my room the night before last?" asked the king.
es: —Were you in my room the night before last?

en: “No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
vi: - No, Your Majesty, - When it's just us, I usually address him like that.
tr: "No, your majesty," I said – I always addressed him this way when there was no one around except our gang.
es: —No, your majesty —which is how I always addressed him when there were only people from our group present.

en: “Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
vi: - So, did you come in last night?
tr: “So, did you log in last night?”
es: —Were you there yesterday or last night?

en: “No, your majesty.”
vi: - Your Majesty, do you have a letter?
tr: “No; your majesty.” “Do you swear?
es: —No, your majesty.

en: “Honor bright, now—no lies.”
vi: - Swear on your honor, you must not lie.
tr: Don't you dare lie to me.”
es: —Your word of honor; without lying.

en: “Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth.
vi: - I swear on my honor that I'm telling the truth.
tr: "I swear, your majesty. I am telling you the truth.
es: —My word of honor, your majesty. I am telling you the truth.

en: I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
vi: Since Miss Mary Jane took the king and the duke upstairs, I haven't gone near there at all.
tr: Since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke to show you your room, I have not approached your room in any way."
es: I have not been near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you there with the duke to show it to you.

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke asked:
tr: “Well, did you see anyone coming in or going out?” asked the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
vi: - Did you see anyone come there?
tr: “Well, did you see anyone coming in or going out?” asked the duke.
es: —Have you seen anyone else enter it?

en: “No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
vi: - Sir, I don't remember very clearly
tr: “No, Your Excellency, I don't remember seeing anyone.”
es: —No, your grace, not that I remember, I think.

en: “Stop and think.”
vi: - Try to remember.
tr: "Pause and think a little."
es: —Think about it calmly.

en: I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
vi: I remained silent to think if there was any way to speak, then replied.
tr: I pretended to think for a while, and during this time, realizing that my luck had changed, I responded:
es: I was thinking about it for a moment and seeing my opportunity, I said:

en: “Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
vi: - Yes, I saw some black people go in there.
tr: “I saw black people go in there a few times.”
es: —Well, I've seen the black people go in there several times.

en: Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had.
vi: Both of them were startled, then the duke asked again:
tr: They both jumped into the air with unease without realizing it. Then they adopted an attitude as if they had already been expecting this answer from me.
es: The two of them gave a little jump, as if they had never expected it, and then as if it seemed like they had.

en: Then the duke says:
vi: Both of them were startled, then the duke asked again:
tr: "Did you see me come and go from all of them?" asked the duke.
es: Then the duke goes and says:

en: “What, all of them?”
vi: - All of them are black people?
tr: “No…
es: —How, all of them?

en: “No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
vi: - No, not all at once, I only saw it once.
tr: At least I didn't see them all at once. I mean, I don't ever remember them all coming out at the same time, except for one time.”
es: —No, I mean, at least not all at once; I think I never saw them leave together, except for once.

en: “Hello!
vi: - When?
tr: “So, when was that?””
es: —Wow!

en: When was that?”
vi: - When?
tr: “So, when was that?””
es: When was that?

en: “It was the day we had the funeral.
vi: - On the day of the funeral, but not early in the morning, I also woke up late.
tr: “The day of the funeral.
es: The day of the funeral, in the morning.

en: In the morning.
vi: - On the day of the funeral, but not early in the morning, I also woke up late.
tr: In the morning.
es: The day of the funeral, in the morning.

en: It warn’t early, because I overslept.
vi: - On the day of the funeral, but not early in the morning, I also woke up late.
tr: It wasn't very early, because I had overslept.
es: It wasn't early because I slept in late.

en: I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
vi: As I was stepping down the stairs, I saw them.
tr: Just as I was going down the stairs, I saw them.”
es: I was starting to go down the stairs when I saw them.

en: “Well, go on, go on!
vi: - Go ahead!
tr: "Keep telling, go on...
es: —Well, go on, go on!

en: What did they do?
vi: What else did they do?
tr: What did they do?"
es: What did they do?

en: How’d they act?”
vi: How did they do it?
tr: What did they do?"
es: What happened next?

en: “They didn’t do nothing.
vi: - They were just gentle.
tr: “They didn't do anything.
es: —They did nothing.

en: And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see.
vi: I think they went in there to clean the king's room.
tr: As far as I could see, they didn't act strangely either.
es: And nothing special happened either, that I could see.

en: They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
vi: Perhaps the king had already woken up, but they saw him still lying down, so they quietly left to avoid disturbing him.
tr: They tiptoed away; I thought they went inside to tidy up the room, thinking that your majesty had already gotten up, but when they saw that you hadn't, they tried to leave quietly so as not to wake you and get into trouble, of course, if they hadn't already woken you.”
es: They tiptoed away; so I saw very well that they had gone to prepare your majesty's room, or something like that, if you had already gotten up, and upon seeing that you hadn't gotten up, they hoped to disappear and avoid getting into trouble instead of waking you up, if they hadn't already woken you up.

en: “Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly.
vi: Both looked at each other sadly, dejectedly. The king said: - This way, everything is ruined.
tr: “My God, we are doomed!” said the king; both of them looked as if they had been struck by a jinn.
es: —Devil, this one is really good! —says the king, and the two of them were left with a desperate and rather silly expression.

en: They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
vi: The Duke pondered for a moment, then let out a sneer and said:
tr: They stood there scratching their heads for about a minute, then the duke let out a nervous laugh.
es: They stayed there thinking and scratching their heads, and the duke let out a sort of rasping chuckle and said:

en: “It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand.
vi: - The black folks played a high-level trick.
tr: “They say 'a hand is superior to another,' and the blacks did what they had to do.
es: —It's fabulous how those blacks have played their hand.

en: They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region!
vi: They pretended to be very miserable before they left this place.
tr: They looked so sad because they were going to leave these places!
es: They acted as if they were so sad to leave this region!

en: And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody.
vi: I, you, and everyone else thought so.
tr: I truly believed that they were sad. You believed it too, everyone did.
es: And I believed they really were, just like you and everyone else.

en: Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent.
vi: Don't think that the black folks don't have any talent.
tr: No one should tell me anymore that blacks don't have acting talent.
es: Don't ever tell me again that blacks don't have acting talent.

en: Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody.
vi: If I had the capital and a theater, I would immediately hire them as actors.
tr: They acted so well that they could have fooled everyone.
es: They gave a performance that would fool anyone.

en: In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em.
vi: If I had the capital and a theater, I would immediately hire them as actors.
tr: In my opinion, those blacks are worth a treasure.
es: To me, they are worth a fortune.

en: If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song.
vi: So now we have sold them in exchange for a song.
tr: If I had some capital and a theater, they alone would be enough as actors… And we went and sold them for a pittance.
es: If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn't want better actors... And we sold them for a bargain.

en: Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet.
vi: And yet we haven't even sung that song.
tr: Yes, and on top of that, we don't even have cash, just a promissory note.
es: Yes, and we can't even touch that bargain yet.

en: Say, where is that song—that draft?”
vi: By the way, where is that song, that contract? Where?
tr: What did you do with the note?”
es: Hey, where is that bargain... that note?

en: “In the bank for to be collected.
vi: - You have to go to the bank to get it!
tr: “I gave it to the bank, of course, we'll get it when the return comes.
es: —At the bank waiting to get paid.

en: Where would it be?”
vi: - You have to go to the bank to get it!
tr: Where else would it be?”
es: Where else would I be?

en: “Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
vi: - Well, that's still quite fortunate.
tr: “Alright, good then, thank God.”
es: —Well, then it doesn't matter, thank God.

en: Says I, kind of timid-like:
vi: I timidly asked:
tr: I interjected a bit timidly:

en: “Is something gone wrong?”
vi: - What's going on?
tr: "Is there a problem?""
es: —Has something happened?

en: The king whirls on me and rips out:
vi: The king looked at me annoyed and said:

es: The king turned to me and exclaimed:

en: “None o’ your business!
vi: - None of your business!
tr: “This is none of your business!
es: —It's none of your business!

en: You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any.
vi: Don't stick your nose into other people's affairs.
tr: Keep your mouth shut and mind your own business… If you have any, that is.
es: You shut your mouth and mind your own business... If you have any.

en: Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?”
vi: As long as you're in this town, you better keep your mouth shut, got it?
tr: Never forget this as long as you are in this town, do you hear me?”
es: And while you're in this town, don't forget it, understand?

en: Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
vi: Then the old man turned around and said to the duke: - Let's not have anything, just stay silent.
tr: Then he turned to the duke again: “There is no other way but to drink a glass of cold water and keep quiet.”
es: —and then he says to the duke—: we have to endure and say nothing; we have to keep quiet.

en: As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
vi: They walked down the stairs, the duke still whispering:
tr: As they were descending the stairs, the duke let out another laugh:
es: When they started to go down the stairs, the duke laughed again and said:

en: “Quick sales and small profits!
vi: - Sell quickly, even if the profit is small.
tr: “Quick sales; small profits!
es: —Quick sales and small profits!

en: It’s a good business—yes.”
vi: - Sell quickly, even if the profit is small.
tr: What a trade...”
es: It's a good business.

en: v
vi: Quickly have the money in hand.
tr: What a trade...”
es: Yes.

en: The king snarls around on him and says:
vi: The king grinned, looking at the duke and said:
tr: The king replied angrily:
es: The king let out a snort and said to him:

en: “I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick.
vi: - I'm planning to try to sell everything quickly for the maximum profit.
tr: “I was doing my best to get rid of them quickly.
es: —When I sold them so quickly, I was trying to do what was best for us.

en: If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
vi: If it doesn't make much, or doesn't make anything at all, then is that my fault or yours?
tr: If we never made a profit, if we have nothing left, isn't it as much your fault as it is mine?”
es: If it turns out there are no profits, that we gain nothing and get nothing, am I more to blame than you?

en: “Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
vi: - If you had listened to me, the blacks would still be in the house and we would have already escaped with the big bag of money.
tr: “If you had listened to my advice, they would still be in this house, but we would not be.””
es: —Well, if they had listened to me, they would still be in this house and we wouldn't.

en: The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again.
vi: The king, afraid of the secret getting out, ran over to me to threaten me not to tell anyone about seeing the black man coming out of the old man's room, because if I did, everyone would immediately know something was up.
tr: The king replied to him, trying not to let anyone else hear, and then brought the conversation back to me.
es: The king responded to him as best he could and then turned around and went back to dealing with me.

en: He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up.
vi: The king, afraid of the secret getting out, ran over to me to threaten me not to tell anyone about seeing the black man coming out of the old man's room, because if I did, everyone would immediately know something was up.
tr: Even though I saw the blacks quietly leaving the room, he cursed and swore at me for not telling him – he said even the most brainless person could understand that something was going on.
es: He gave me a scolding for not telling him that I had seen the blacks leaving his room in that manner, which even an idiot would have understood meant something was up.

en: And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again.
vi: Then the old man staggered back to his room, cursing himself for a while and saying that it was all his fault for not staying in his room longer like every morning, and swore that from then on he wouldn't be so foolish. Then they went on to discuss something else with each other.
tr: Then he turned back and cursed himself a bit; he said all this happened because he stayed up late and didn't get enough rest that morning, and he swore he would never do such a thing again.
es: And then he changed again and cursed himself above all for a while, saying that everything had happened because he hadn't stayed in bed until late and rested as much as he needed that morning, and that damned if he would ever do it again in his life.

en: So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.
vi: As for me, I was secretly glad that I had exonerated the black men without causing them any harm.
tr: They walked away chatting like that, and I was extremely happy because I blamed the blacks, but they wouldn't suffer any harm from it.
es: So they went off chatting and I felt very happy to have put all the blame on the blacks without having done them any harm.

en: CHAPTER XXVIII.
vi: Chapter XXXVIII
tr: Twenty-Eighth Chapter
es: Chapter 28

en: By-and-by it was getting-up time.
vi: Jim said that engraving letters was the hardest of all.
tr: It was almost time to get up.
es: Little by little, the time for everyone to get up was approaching.

en: So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England.
vi: But Tom insisted that Jim must write.
tr: I came down from the attic stairs and headed towards the stairs to the lower floor, but as I passed by the girls' room, I noticed that the door was open. Mary Jane was sitting inside next to an old trunk, the trunk was open and partially filled – she was preparing to go to England.
es: So I descended the stairs to the lower floor, but upon reaching the girls' room, the door was open and I saw Mary Jane sitting next to her old horsehair trunk, which was open and into which she had been putting things, preparing to go to England.

en: But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying.
vi: The prisoner had to leave his handwriting on the wall for posterity, along with his emblem.
tr: But now she was sitting with a folded nightgown in her lap, crying with her face in her hands.
es: But now she had stopped with a folded dress in her lap and had her face in her hands while she cried.

en: I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would.
vi: Jim said:
tr: Seeing her like that made me feel terrible, anyone's heart would break.
es: I felt very bad seeing that; naturally, just as anyone would have felt.

en: I went in there and says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: I went inside and said to her:
es: I went in and said:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always.
vi: Jim said:
tr: "Ms. Mary Jane, you can't stand seeing people suffer, I can't stand it either... Not at all.
es: —Miss Mary Jane, you can't stand to see people suffer, and neither can I: almost never.

en: Tell me about it.”
vi: Jim said:
tr: Tell me about it."
es: Tell me everything.

en: So she done it.
vi: Jim said:
tr: He narrated.
es: So she told me, and it was about the slaves, just as I expected.

en: And it was the niggers—I just expected it.
vi: Jim said:
tr: He was thinking about the black people – exactly what I had guessed.
es: So she told me, and it was about the slaves, just as I expected.

en: She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: The trip he was going to make to England had almost turned into a nightmare for him; knowing that the mother and her children might never see each other again, could he be happy there even for a single day? Then, with an even more sorrowful gesture, he raised his hands upwards:
es: She said that wonderful trip to England no longer excited her; she didn't know how she could be happy there, knowing that the mother and children would never see each other again, and then she started crying harder than ever, opened her hands, and said:

en: “Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
vi: Jim said:
tr: "My God, my God, even thinking that they will never see each other again!.." “But they will see…
es: —Oh, my God, my God, to think that they will never see each other again!

en: “But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
vi: Jim said:
tr: Within two weeks… I am sure of it!”
es: —But they will see each other, and within two weeks, and I know it! —I replied.

en: Laws, it was out before I could think!
vi: Jim said:
tr: Without even realizing it, the words slipped out of my mouth!..
es: My God, it had slipped out without thinking!

en: And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
vi: Jim said:
tr: Before I could say anything, she hugged my neck and started saying, say it again, say it again, say it again!
es: And before I could even move, she had thrown her arms around my neck, asking me to repeat it, again, to repeat it again, to repeat it again!

en: I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place.
vi: Jim said:
tr: At a moment when I least expected it, he spoke, said too many things, and I was cornered.
es: I realized that I had spoken too much and too soon and that I had gotten myself into a trap.

en: I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out.
vi: - Uncle
tr: I asked for a minute to think; there, with impatience and excitement, in all her beauty, but in a happy and relieved state, she sat like someone whose aching tooth had been pulled.
es: I asked her to let me think about it for a minute; she remained seated, very impatient and nervous, so beautiful, but with a happy and calm air, like a person who has just had a tooth pulled.

en: So I went to studying it out.
vi: Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, I only have this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it.
tr: I also started to ponder in my own way.
es: Then I began to study it.

en: I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie.
vi: Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, I only have this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it.
tr: In a moment when he was cornered, a person who stood up and told the truth would probably have taken great risks; though I had no experience in this matter, so I wasn't absolutely sure, but that's what I thought. Still, it was clear that I was in a situation where telling the truth was better, even safer, than lying.
es: I said to myself: "I figure that someone who goes and tells the truth when they are in a trap is taking a considerable risk, although I have no experience and cannot say for sure, but in any case, it seems to me that this is one of those occasions where the truth appears to be better and indeed safer than the lie.

en: I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular.
vi: Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, I only have this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it.
tr: I should write this down in a corner of my mind and think it over thoroughly at a convenient time, it seemed very strange and against the rules.
es: I have to remember this and think it over again when I have time, because it is most strange and irregular.

en: I never see nothing like it.
vi: - You don't understand anything, Jim, the badge is different, it's not like that.
tr: Such a thing had never happened to me before.
es: In my life, I have never seen anything like it.

en: Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to.
vi: I said:
tr: In the end, well, I said to myself, I will face everything, it will be like sitting on a powder keg and striking a match to see where I will fly, but this time I will take the risk and tell the truth.
es: Well," I finally said to myself, "I'm going to take the risk; this time I'm going to tell the truth even though it's like sitting on a barrel of gunpowder and lighting it to see what happens next."

en: Then I says:
vi: I said:
tr: In the end, well, I said to myself, I will face everything, it will be like sitting on a powder keg and striking a match to see where I will fly, but this time I will take the risk and tell the truth.
es: Then I went and said:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
vi: - Jim is right.
tr: “Miss Mary Jane,” I said, “is there a place not too far outside of town where you could stay for two or three days?”
es: —Miss Mary Jane. Is there any place out of town, not too far, where you could spend three or four days?

en: “Yes; mr Lothrop’s.
vi: - Jim is right.
tr: "Yes... Mr. Lothrop's house.
es: —Yes; at Mr. Lothrop's house.

en: Why?”
vi: He doesn't have any badges.
tr: Why?"
es: Why?

en: “Never mind why yet.
vi: Tom replied:
tr: "Never mind the reason for now.
es: —The reason still doesn't matter.

en: If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to mr Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
vi: - I know, but Jim needs to have a badge before leaving this place.
tr: If I tell you that the Negroes will see each other again, and within two weeks in this very house, and if I prove how I know it... can you go and stay at the Lothrops' for about four days?"
es: If I tell you how I know that the black people will meet again, here in this house, in two weeks, and I prove how I know it, will you go to Mr. Lothrop's house to stay for four days?

en: “Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
vi: So Tom sat down, racking his brain to come up with a badge for Jim.
tr: “Four days!” he said. “I would stay even for a year!”
es: —Four days! —he replied—. I would stay for a year!

en: “All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.”
vi: After a while, he said he had thought of many but didn't know which one to choose.
tr: “Alright then,” I said, “I just want you to promise me one thing…” “If it were someone else, I would ask them to kiss the Holy Book.”
es: —Very well —I added—, the only thing I ask for is your word: it means more to me than someone else's oath on the Bible.

en: She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said:
tr: She smiled, and a very pleasant blush appeared on her cheeks. “If you don't mind, I won't even close the door… in fact, I need to bolt it,” I said.
es: —She smiled and blushed a little, very lovely, and I continued—: If you don't mind, I'm going to close the door, and with the lock.

en: Then I come back and set down again, and says:
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said:

es: Then I sat down again and said:

en: “Don’t you holler.
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said:
tr: “Do not scream.
es: —Don't shout.

en: Just set still and take it like a man.
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said:
tr: Sit quietly in your place and try to react like a man.
es: Stay seated there and take it like a man.

en: I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it.
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: I will tell you the truth and you will brace yourself, Miss Mary, because I am going to tell you something bad, something hard to bear, but I have no other choice.
es: I have to tell the truth and you have to prepare yourself well, Miss Mary, because it's a bad thing and it's going to be difficult for you, but there's no way to avoid it.

en: These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats.
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: These uncles of yours are definitely not your real uncles… just a pair of impostors… common thieves that you know.
es: Those uncles of yours are not uncles at all; they are a pair of frauds, lifelong impostors.

en: There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: Yes, we have passed the hardest part… you can endure the rest more easily.”
es: Well, we've gotten through the worst, and you will be able to handle the rest more easily.

en: It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: Of course, he was shaken when he heard this; but I had already moved to shallow waters, so I told everything without a pause, as sparks increasingly flashed in his eyes; I started from where we first encountered the young fool going up the river to board the steamboat, and as I was recounting how she threw herself into the king's arms in front of the house and kissed him sixteen or seventeen times, the girl suddenly jumped up, she was bright red.
es: Naturally, that left her absolutely stunned, but now I had already said the hardest part, so I continued while her eyes lit up more and more and I told her absolutely everything, from the first time we met the foolish boy who was going to the steamboat to when she had thrown herself into the king's arms at the main gate and he had kissed her sixteen or seventeen times, and then she jumped, her face blazing like a sunset, and said:

en: “The brute!
vi: A symbol of a black man running away carrying a bundle of luggage, and another symbol of two guys following to help, that is, you and me.
tr: "Monster!
es: —Wicked!

en: Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”
vi: So it resolved the matter of the badge, now it just had to finish the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: Come, we can't lose even a minute, not even a second..." "Let them cover them in tar and feathers, then throw them into the river!""
es: Come on, don't waste a minute, not even a second, let's have them tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river!

en: Says I:
vi: It wrote it down on a piece of paper, then read it aloud:
tr: “Absolutely true,” I said.
es: I answered:

en: “Cert’nly.
vi: 1) Here, a captive heart is breaking.
tr: “Absolutely true,” I said.
es: —Of course.

en: But do you mean before you go to mr Lothrop’s, or—”
vi: 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering and decaying.
tr: “But before you go to the Lothrops, or...”
es: But do you mean before going to Mr. Lothrop's house or...?

en: “Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again.
vi: 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering and decaying.
tr: “Ah, what nonsense am I talking!” she said and sat down again.
es: —Ah —she replied—, what am I thinking! —and she sat down again—.

en: “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?”
vi: 3) Here, a lonely heart is broken, a spirit has grown weary after thirty-seven years of solitary confinement.
tr: “Please pretend you didn't hear anything I said, I didn't say anything, okay?”
es: Don't pay attention to what I said, I beg you. You won't, will you?

en: Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first.
vi: 4) Here, the child of Louis the Fourteenth died homeless, without close friends, after thirty-seven years of imprisonment.
tr: She placed her hand, as soft as silk, on mine in such a way that I could have given my life rather than resist her.
es: She gently placed her little hand in mine in such a way that I responded that I would rather die first.

en: “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more.
vi: When reading those sentences, Tom's voice trembled with emotion.
tr: “I completely lost my mind, I got very angry,” she said; “now continue, I won't do it again.
es: —I haven't stopped to think about it because I was so angry —she added—; now go on and I promise I won't act like that again.

en: You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: Tell me what we should do, I will do whatever you say.”
es: Tell me what I have to do and I will do everything you say.

en: “Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble.
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: “I can outsmart these two swindlers, and I've been forced to travel with them for a while now... It's better if I don't tell you the reason... If you report them immediately, the townspeople will rescue me from their clutches, and I will be safe, but there's someone else you don't know about, and they will get into big trouble.
es: —Well —I said—, these two swindlers are tough guys and I have no choice but to keep traveling with them a bit longer, whether I like it or not; I prefer not to tell you why; and if you reported them, this town would free me from their clutches and I would be perfectly fine; but there would be another person you don't know about who would have terrible problems.

en: Well, we got to save him, hain’t we?
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: We need to protect them, don't we?
es: Well, we have to save that person, right?

en: Of course.
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: Of course, I'm right.
es: Of course.

en: Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: Anyway, let's not report them right away.”
es: Well, then we can't report them.

en: Saying them words put a good idea in my head.
vi: Jim said it would take him a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall.
tr: While saying these words, a good idea came to my mind.
es: When I said that, a good idea occurred to me.

en: I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave.
vi: Jim said it would take him a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall.
tr: Maybe Jim and I could get rid of these frauds; they would end up in jail here, and we would just leave.
es: I saw how I could get Jim and myself free from the frauds; make them stay in the local jail and then leave.

en: But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night.
vi: Jim said it would take him a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall.
tr: But I didn't want to travel on the raft during the day without anyone else to answer questions; so I had to adjust my plan for quite late hours.
es: But I didn't want to navigate the raft during the day with no one but me on board to answer questions, so I didn't want the plan to start working until well into the night.

en: I says:
vi: Then he said:
tr: "Ms. Mary Jane, now let me tell you what we are going to do," I said.
es: I continued saying:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at mr Lothrop’s so long, nuther.
vi: - Writing on wood won't work, because there are no wooden walls in the tower prison.
tr: "You won't need to stay at Mr. Lothrop's house for too long.
es: —Miss Mary Jane, I'm going to tell you what we're going to do and you won't have to stay so long at Mr. Lothrop's house either.

en: How fur is it?”
vi: We have to carve the letters into the stone instead.
tr: How far is it?"
es: How far is it?

en: “A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “A little closer than four miles... Just outside the town.”
es: —A little less than four miles, right there in the field.

en: “Well, that’ll answer.
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “Well, this will do the job.
es: —Well, all right.

en: Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something.
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: Now you will go there and stay out of sight until nine or nine-thirty this evening, then tell them to take you home because you forgot something.
es: Now go over there and stay without saying anything until nine or nine-thirty at night and then have them bring you back home: tell them you forgot something.

en: If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe.
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: If you come back before eleven in the evening, light a candle in front of this window; if I am not around, wait until eleven, and if I still do not appear, it means I have left and am safe.
es: If you arrive before eleven, put a candle in this window and wait until eleven; if I don't show up after that, it means I've left and you're safe.

en: Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: Then you can come out and spread the news to everyone, and those scoundrels can be put in jail.”
es: Then go out, spread the news, and have those wretches thrown in jail.

en: “Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “Okay,” he said, “I will do exactly that.”
es: —Very well —he responded—, I will do that.

en: “And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: "But if I cannot escape and get caught with them, you must say that I told you everything in advance and defend me with all your strength.""
es: —And if by any chance I don't manage to escape, but they catch me with them, you have to say that I had told you everything beforehand and defend me as much as you can.

en: “Stand by you!
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “Of course, I will defend you.
es: —Defend you!

en: indeed I will.
vi: But Tom said he would let me help.
tr: “Of course, I will defend you.
es: Of course.

en: They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
vi: Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written.
tr: They can't even touch a single strand of your hair!” he said. As he said these things, I saw his nostrils flare and his eyes shine.
es: They won't lay a finger on you! —he said, and I saw his nostrils flare and his eyes gleam as he said it.

en: “If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here.
vi: Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written.
tr: "If I leave, I won't be here to prove that those swindlers are not your uncles, and even if I were here, I couldn't prove it.
es: —If I escape, I won't be here —I pointed out— to prove that those scoundrels are not your uncles, and if I were here, I couldn't prove it.

en: I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something.
vi: Doing this was really a very difficult and slow task; my hands, already sore, hurt even more, and the work seemed to make no progress at all.
tr: All I could do is swear that they are swindlers and frauds; though that is something.
es: I could swear they were cheats and vagabonds, and nothing more, although that is something.

en: Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be.
vi: Tom said:
tr: Anyway, there are those who can prove it better than I can, and no one will doubt them.
es: Well, there are others who can do it better than I, and they are people who won't be doubted as easily as me.

en: I’ll tell you how to find them.
vi: - I have an idea.
tr: Let me tell you how to find them.
es: I'm going to tell you how to find them.

en: Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper.
vi: We need to find a stone to make a badge and write on it.
tr: Give me a pen and paper.
es: Give me a pencil and a piece of paper.

en: There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’
vi: There is a very large grinding stone in the workshop, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: Here... 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.'
es: That's it: "The Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville."

en: Put it away, and don’t lose it.
vi: There is a very large grinding stone in the workshop, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: Put this paper somewhere safe, don't lose it.
es: Keep it and don't lose it.

en: When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary.
vi: There is a very large grinding stone in the workshop, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: If the court wants evidence about these two, let them send someone to Bricksville and tell them to catch the men staging the Royal Nonesuch and ask for witnesses... The whole town will come to testify in the blink of an eye, Miss Mary.
es: When the judge wants to know something about those two, have someone go to Bricksville and say they have the men who performed in "The Royal Nonesuch," and as for witnesses, you'll get the whole town to come in the blink of an eye, Miss Mary.

en: And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
vi: There is a very large grinding stone in the workshop, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: And they will be quite angry too."
es: And ready for anything, too.

en: I judged we had got everything fixed about right now.
vi: It was a bizarre idea, but we thought we could do it.
tr: I have decided that we have now settled everything.
es: I figured that we already had everything on track and said:

en: So I says:
vi: It was a bizarre idea, but we thought we could do it.
tr: So I continued:
es: I figured that we already had everything on track and said:

en: “Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry.
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Let the auction proceed, there's nothing to worry about.
es: —Leave them with their auction and don't worry.

en: Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money.
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: On the day of the auction, no one has to pay for what they have bought until the end of the day, they just give a promissory note and our swindlers can't go anywhere until they get the money… When we expose their fraud, the promissory notes will become useless and they won't get a single penny.
es: Nobody will have to pay for what they buy until a day after the auction, since it was announced so hastily, and they won't leave until they get that money; the way we've arranged it, the sale won't count and they won't get any money.

en: It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long.
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: It will be just like with the negroes… Since the sale is not valid, the negroes will return soon.
es: It's just like what happened with the black people: the sale isn't valid and the black people will come back very soon.

en: Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: They won't be able to get the negroes' money either… Honestly, I don't think they can get away with this, Mrs. Mary.”
es: Notice that they still can't collect the money from the black people... They're in a very bad situation, Miss Mary.

en: “Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for mr Lothrop’s.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Alright then,” she said, “I’ll go down and prepare breakfast now, then I’ll head straight to Mr. Lothrop’s.”
es: —Well —she replied—, I'm going to go down for breakfast and then I'll go straight to Mr. Lothrop's house.

en: “’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “This is absolutely not possible, Miss Mary Jane,” I said, “you will ruin the whole thing; go before breakfast.”
es: —That can't be, Miss Mary Jane —I indicated—, not at all; go before breakfast.

en: “Why?”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Why do you think I wanted you to leave from the very beginning, Miss Mary?”
es: —Why do you think I wanted you to do all this, Miss Mary Jane?

en: “Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know.
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: "Actually, I had never thought about it... That's right, I don't know.
es: —Well, it hadn't occurred to me... And now that I think about it, I don't know.

en: What was it?”
vi: We carried the stone outside and rolled it home, but it was so heavy that several times it almost crushed our feet.
tr: Why do you want me to leave?"
es: Why?

en: “Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people.
vi: Tom said that someone would definitely get their foot crushed by the stone before we could carry it all the way back.
tr: “Because you are not a brazen type like others.
es: —Well, because you are not a shameless person.

en: I don’t want no better book than what your face is.
vi: Tom said that someone would definitely get their foot crushed by the stone before we could carry it all the way back.
tr: One can read your face like a book.
es: I like your face just the way it is.

en: A body can set down and read it off like coarse print.
vi: Tom said that someone would definitely get their foot crushed by the stone before we could carry it all the way back.
tr: I'm very serious, even deciphering letters and reading a book is harder.
es: One can sit down to read it as if it were written in capital letters.

en: Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
vi: Tom said that someone would definitely get their foot crushed by the stone before we could carry it all the way back.
tr: Can you go downstairs and face your uncles, when they kiss you and say good morning...”
es: Do you think you can go see your uncles when they come to say good morning with a kiss and not... ?

en: “There, there, don’t!
vi: Halfway there, we were exhausted, staggering, and drenched in sweat.
tr: “Oh no, oh no, I can't do it!
es: —Let's go, let's go, don't continue!

en: Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to.
vi: We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out through the hole to where the stone was, and Jim and I lifted the stone, walking as if it was nothing, while Tom commanded.
tr: Right, I should go before breakfast... I'll gladly go right away.
es: Yes, I will leave before breakfast and very happy.

en: And leave my sisters with them?”
vi: We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out through the hole to where the stone was, and Jim and I lifted the stone, walking as if it was nothing, while Tom commanded.
tr: But am I going to leave my sisters with them?”
es: And do I leave my sisters with them?

en: “Yes; never mind about them.
vi: He could command any other child.
tr: “Yes, don't worry about them.
es: —Yes, don't worry about them.

en: They’ve got to stand it yet a while.
vi: He could command any other child.
tr: They can manage for a short while longer.
es: They have to keep enduring for a while.

en: They might suspicion something if all of you was to go.
vi: He could do all sorts of things.
tr: If all of you go at once, the men might get suspicious.
es: They might suspect something if all of you disappeared.

en: I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something.
vi: The hole we dug was quite large, but the rock still couldn't fit through, so Jim took the pickaxe and dug it wider.
tr: You must not see them, nor your sisters or anyone else in town; if one of your neighbors asks you how your uncles are this morning, I'm afraid the answer will be written on your face.
es: I don't want you to see them, nor your sisters nor anyone from the town; if a neighbor asks you how your uncles are this morning, you might reveal something with a gesture.

en: No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them.
vi: Tom took a nail and marked the rock, telling Jim to chisel along the marks.
tr: No; go straight without stopping anywhere, Miss Mary Jane, I'll handle the rest.
es: No, leave immediately, Miss Mary Jane, and I'll handle everything with them.

en: I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: I'll tell Miss Susan that you sent your love to your uncles and that you went out for a few hours to rest, for a change of scenery, or to see a friend, and that you'll be back this evening or early tomorrow morning.”
es: I'll tell Miss Susan to greet your uncles warmly and to say that you have gone away for a few hours to rest a bit and change, or to visit a friend, and that you will be back tonight or early in the morning.

en: “Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: “There's no problem in saying that I went to see a friend, but I'm not going to send them my regards or anything.”
es: —It's fine that I went to see some friends, but I don't want you to greet them on my behalf.

en: “Well, then, it sha’n’t be.”
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: “Alright, since you don't want it.”
es: —Well, then don't tell them anything.

en: It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it.
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: Answering her this way was the best – what harm was there.
es: —Well, then don't tell them anything.

en: It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing.
vi: We helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, then we also got ready to sleep.
tr: It was a small thing and it didn't harm anyone; it's such small things that allow people to proceed safely on their paths; Miss Jane would be comfortable and there would be no cost.
es: He could tell her that, because it didn't hurt anyone, it was something unimportant and caused no problems, and it's the unimportant things that make life easier for people down here; Mary Jane would be at ease, and it cost nothing.

en: Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
vi: But suddenly, Tom said:
tr: “There's just one more thing,” I said, “that money bag.”
es: Then I added: —There's one more thing: the bag with the money.

en: “Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
vi: - Is there any spider in here, Jim?
tr: "Yes, they took that too; when I think about how they took it, I feel like a fool."
es: —Well, they already have that, and I feel very foolish thinking about how they got it.

en: “No, you’re out, there.
vi: - No, there isn't, my friend.
tr: “Don't feel that way at all.
es: —No, you are mistaken there.

en: They hain’t got it.”
vi: - Okay, let me go get some for you.
tr: The bag is not with them.”
es: They don't have it.

en: “Why, who’s got it?”
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared.
tr: “Why, with whom?”
es: —Well, who has it?

en: “I wish I knowed, but I don’t.
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared.
tr: "I wish I knew, but I don't.
es: —I wish I knew, but I don't.

en: I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more.
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared.
tr: I had it, because I stole the bag from them: I was thinking of giving it to you, I know where I hid it, but I'm afraid it's not there anymore.
es: I had it, because I stole it, and I stole it to give it to you, and I know where I hid it but I'm afraid it's no longer there.

en: I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest.
vi: I'd rather have snakes than spiders.
tr: I'm very sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I don't know how to express my sorrow; but I did my best; I'm really telling the truth.
es: I'm terribly sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I can't feel worse; but I did everything I could; I really did.

en: I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
vi: Tom thought for a few minutes and then said:
tr: I was almost caught, so I put it in the first place I came across, and then I ran away – but the place I hid it wasn't a good place at all."
es: They almost caught me and I had to put it in the first place I found and run away, but it wasn't a good place.

en: “Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault.
vi: - That's a good idea.
tr: “Stop blaming yourself already... It's very bad for you to do this and I can't allow such a thing... You had no other choice, it was not in your control.
es: —Well, stop blaming yourself; it makes you feel bad and I won't allow it; you couldn't avoid it; it wasn't your fault.

en: Where did you hide it?”
vi: So where did you put it?
tr: So, where did you hide it?”
es: Where did you hide it?

en: I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach.
vi: - Leave what, Tom?
tr: I didn't want to reopen her wounds, moreover, I couldn't bring myself to say the words that would make her see her father's funeral with a money bag on his belly.
es: I didn't want him to start thinking about his problems again, and I couldn't get my mouth to say something that would make him see that corpse with the bag of money in its stomach again.

en: So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
vi: - A snake, what else?
tr: For about a minute, the words got stuck in my throat. Finally, I said:
es: So for a moment, I didn't say anything, and then I responded:

en: “I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to mr Lothrop’s, if you want to.
vi: - Oh my God, if a snake crawls in here, I will immediately have to squeeze through that hole in the wall to escape.
tr: "It would be better if I didn't say where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, that is, if you can allow it; but if you want, I can write it down on a piece of paper, and you can read it when you go to the Lothrops'.
es: —I prefer not to tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don't mind forgiving me; but I will write it on a piece of paper and you can read it on the way to Mr. Lothrop's house, if you want.

en: Do you reckon that’ll do?”
vi: - Oh, Jim, don't be so scared.
tr: Is there any problem with doing it this way?"
es: Does that seem alright to you?

en: “Oh, yes.”
vi: Can you conquer it?
tr: “Of course not.”
es: —Ah, yes.

en: So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin.
vi: - Conquer?
tr: Upon this, I took a piece of paper and wrote: "I put the bag inside the coffin.
es: So I wrote: "I put her in the coffin.

en: It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night.
vi: - Yes, it's easy.
tr: While you were crying alone at the coffin at night, I was there too.
es: She was there when you spent the night crying.

en: I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
vi: Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: I was hiding behind the door and felt very sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane."
es: I was behind the door and felt very sad for you, Miss Mary Jane."

en: It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
vi: Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: When I thought about her crying alone at night, while the other devils were doing shameful things under her roof and intending to strip her of everything, my eyes welled up with tears again; then, when I folded the paper and gave it to her, I saw that her eyes were also filled with tears. Gripping my hand with all her strength, she said:
es: A few tears welled up in my eyes as I remembered how she had been left crying there alone all night while those devils slept under her own roof, deceiving and robbing her, and when I folded the note and gave it to her, I saw that tears had welled up in her eyes too, and she grabbed my hand very tightly and said to me:

en: “Good-bye.
vi: Just give it a try.
tr: "Goodbye.
es: —Goodbye.

en: I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
vi: Then it might let you wrap it around your neck and even nuzzle its head into your mouth.
tr: I will do everything exactly as you told me; even if I never see you again, know that I will never forget you, I will think of you many times and pray for you!"
es: I will do everything exactly as you have told me, and if I never see you again, I will never forget you and I will think of you many, many times, and I will always pray for you! —and she left.

en: Pray for me!
vi: - I beg you, I don't dare to listen!
tr: Saying this, she left. She said she would pray for me!
es: Pray for me!

en: I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size.
vi: Will it let me put its head in my mouth?
tr: If she knew me, she would probably find a more appropriate occupation for herself.
es: I thought that if she knew me, she would have set herself a task more worthy of her.

en: But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind.
vi: Never.
tr: But she still did it – she was that kind of person.
es: But I bet she did it anyway: she was like that.

en: She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge.
vi: Moreover, I don't want it to sleep with me.
tr: If needed, she was brave enough to pray for the treacherous apostle Judas – she was never the type of girl to back down in the face of difficulties.
es: She had the strength to pray for Judas if it occurred to her, and she never backed down.

en: You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand.
vi: - Jim, don't be so foolish.
tr: No matter what anyone says, in my opinion, she was the bravest girl I have ever seen; in fact, I think you couldn't find someone as courageous as her even if you searched for forty years.
es: People can say what they want, but to me, she was the bravest girl I had ever known; to me, she was full of courage.

en: It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery.
vi: A prisoner must have an animal to keep him company.
tr: It might seem like I'm flattering her, but that's not the case at all.
es: It seems like a compliment, but it isn't.

en: And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all.
vi: Until now, no one has ever kept a snake, so if you are the first to do it, it will be even more glorious.
tr: As for beauty – and also goodness – no one could hold a candle to her.
es: And as for beauty —and also kindness—, she had more than anyone in the world.

en: I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.
vi: Until now, no one has ever kept a snake, so if you are the first to do it, it will be even more glorious.
tr: Since she walked out that door, I haven't seen her; we definitely haven't met again, but I must have thought about her a million times and imagined her saying she would pray for me; if I knew that praying for her would do any good, I would certainly pray with all my heart.
es: I haven't seen her since that time she walked out the door; no, I haven't seen her since then, but I think I've thought about her many, many millions of times and how she said she was going to pray for me, and if it ever occurred to me that it would be worth anything for me to pray for her, I would either pray or burst.

en: Well, Mary
vi: - Tom, I don't want that glory.
tr: Mary
es: Well, I guess Mary Jane went out the back door, because no one saw her leave.

en: Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go.
vi: The snake will bite me.
tr: Jane thus went out, probably using the back door, because no one noticed she had left.
es: Well, I guess Mary Jane went out the back door, because no one saw her leave.

en: When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:
vi: No, I don't want to do that.
tr: When I ran into Susan and Harelip, I said:
es: When I met Susan and the girl with the cleft lip, I told them:

en: “What’s the name of them people over on t’other side of the river that you all goes to see sometimes?”
vi: - Damn it, can't you just try?
tr: “What was the name of the family that lived across the river and that you sometimes visited together?”
es: —What is the name of that family on the other side of the river that you sometimes go to see?

en: They says:
vi: I just want you to try.
tr: “There are a few families,” they said.
es: They answered:

en: “There’s several; but it’s the Proctors, mainly.”
vi: If you don't like it, you don't have to keep it forever!
tr: “But we mostly go to the Proctors.”
es: —There are several; but above all, the Proctor family.

en: “That’s the name,” I says; “I most forgot it.
vi: - But while I was trying, it bit me already.
tr: “That was all of them,” I said. “I almost forgot.
es: —That is the name —I said—; I almost forgot.

en: Well, Miss Mary
vi: Tom, I don't want to do those things.
tr: Miss Mary
es: Well, Miss Mary

en: Jane she told me to tell you she’s gone over there in a dreadful hurry—one of them’s sick.”
vi: If Huck brings a snake in here, I'll leave immediately, for sure.
tr: Jane asked me to tell you that she needs to go there urgently... One of them has fallen ill.”
es: Jane asked me to tell you that she had to leave in a hurry: someone is sick.

en: “Which one?”
vi: - Well, never mind then.
tr: “Which one?”
es: —Which one?

en: “I don’t know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it’s—”
vi: We'll find you a few non-venomous snakes instead.
tr: “I don't know; or rather, I forgot, but most likely…””
es: —I don't know: or if I do know, I've forgotten; but I think it is...

en: “Sakes alive, I hope it ain’t Hanner?”
vi: - I can't stand it either, Tom.
tr: “Oh my God, I hope it's not Hanner!”
es: —My God. I hope it's not Hanna!

en: “I’m sorry to say it,” I says, “but Hanner’s the very one.”
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: “I'm sorry for saying this, but I remember the name as Hanner.”
es: —I'm sorry to say it —I added—, but it's precisely her.

en: “My goodness, and she so well only last week!
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: “Oh no, it had just recovered last week!
