es: —My God, she was doing so well last week!

en: Is she took bad?”
vi: - So, are there any mice here?
tr: Is its condition very bad?”
es: Is she very sick?

en: “It ain’t no name for it.
vi: - No, I didn't see any.
tr: "And how.
es: —I have no idea.

en: They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
vi: - Well, we will find you some mice...
tr: They have been watching over him all night; according to Miss Mary Jane, he might only last a few more hours."
es: They stayed sitting with her all night, said Miss Mary Jane, and they don't think she will last many hours.

en: “Only think of that, now!
vi: - I don't need mice, Tom.
tr: “Oh, such is fate!
es: —Who would have thought!

en: What’s the matter with her?”
vi: They are the most annoying creatures, always bothering people, climbing on them, biting their feet, and preventing them from sleeping.
tr: What kind of illness does he have?”
es: What's wrong with him?

en: I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
vi: I'd rather you put in regular snakes than bring mice in here.
tr: I couldn't find anything reasonable at the moment and blurted out the first thing that came to mind:
es: Nothing reasonable occurred to me to say immediately, so I replied:

en: “Mumps.”
vi: I have no use for mice.
tr: “He has mumps.”
es: —He has mumps.

en: “Mumps your granny!
vi: - But you must have a mouse.
tr: "Your grandmother is mumps!"
es: —Mumps, your grandmother!

en: They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
vi: Don't worry, they all do it that way.
tr: "Do they ever stand by the head of someone with mumps all night?""
es: People don't stay to keep company with those who have mumps.

en: “They don’t, don’t they?
vi: Don't worry, they all do it that way.
tr: “They don't stand; why would they stand?
es: —So, no, eh?

en: You better bet they do with these mumps.
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: But you see, it's necessary to stand by someone who has mumps like this.
es: Well, I bet it's yes when it's mumps like yours.

en: These mumps is different.
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: It's a different kind of mumps.
es: These mumps are different.

en: It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: It's a new type, said Mrs. Mary Jane.”
es: They're a new kind, Miss Mary Jane told me.

en: “How’s it a new kind?”
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: “How is it a new species?”
es: —What new type?

en: “Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
vi: And you also have to play music for them.
tr: “It was a mumps mixed with other things.”
es: —Mixed with other things.

en: “What other things?”
vi: Do you have anything to play music?
tr: “What other things?”
es: —What other things?

en: “Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
vi: - I only have a broken comb and a piece of paper to make a plucked instrument.
tr: “Measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, tuberculosis, jaundice, brain fever, and a whole lot more.”
es: —Well, measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, and consumption, and jaundice and brain fever and I don't know what else.

en: “My land!
vi: But I'm sure they don't like plucked instruments.
tr: “No way!
es: —My God!

en: And they call it the mumps?”
vi: - Yes, they do.
tr: Do they call all of this mumps?”
es: And they call that mumps?

en: “That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
vi: They don't discriminate against any kind of music.
tr: “Miss Mary Jane said so.”
es: —That's what Miss Mary Jane said.

en: “Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
vi: They don't discriminate against any kind of music.
tr: “Alright, but what sense does it make to call this mumps?”
es: —Well, and, why the devil do they call it mumps?

en: “Why, because it is the mumps.
vi: Plucking the instrument is already good enough for the mice.
tr: “Because it's the mumps.
es: —Well, because it's the mumps.

en: That’s what it starts with.”
vi: Plucking the instrument is already good enough for the mice.
tr: Everything started with the mumps.”
es: Start there.

en: “Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it.
vi: Plucking the instrument is already good enough for the mice.
tr: “What you said doesn't make any sense to me.
es: —Well, it doesn't make sense.

en: A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’
vi: All animals like music, and in prison, they like it even more, especially sad music.
tr: Let's say someone first hit their foot somewhere, then got poisoned, fell into a well, broke their neck, and their brain came out, when someone asks how they died, which thick-headed person would say, 'They hit their foot,'?
es: Someone could prick their foot, get infected, fall into a well and break their neck, and their brains could spill out, and then some idiot would come along and say they died because they cut their foot.

en: Would ther’ be any sense in that?
vi: The mice love it.
tr: Does that make sense to you?
es: Would that make sense?

en: No.
vi: The mice love it.
tr: No.
es: No, and this doesn't make sense either.

en: And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther.
vi: The mice love it.
tr: It's utter nonsense. The story you told is just like that.
es: No, and this doesn't make sense either.

en: Is it ketching?”
vi: The mice love it.
tr: I wonder if it's contagious?”
es: Is it contagious?

en: “Is it ketching?
vi: The mice love it.
tr: “Is it not contagious?
es: —Is it contagious?

en: Why, how you talk.
vi: They will come out to see what strange thing you have.
tr: You're the one talking nonsense!
es: What things you say.

en: Is a harrow catching—in the dark?
vi: At night, before going to sleep and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that plucking instrument.
tr: It's like stepping on a rake in the dark.
es: Can one get hooked by a rake in the dark?

en: If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you?
vi: At night, before going to sleep and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that plucking instrument.
tr: If you don't step on one prong, you'll step on another.
es: If it doesn't hit one tooth, it hits the other, right?

en: And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you?
vi: At night, before going to sleep and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that plucking instrument.
tr: Moreover, if you try to lift your foot off the prong you stepped on, the whole rake comes with it.
es: And you can't remove the tooth without dragging the whole rake, right?

en: Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
vi: If you play for about two minutes, you will see all kinds of mice, snakes, spiders, etc., feeling sad for you and gathering around you.
tr: The mumps I'm talking about is like such a rake.
es: Well, this type of mumps is like a kind of rake, so to speak, and not a toy rake, but when you get stuck with it, you really get hooked.

en: “Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip.
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: It spreads that badly. And don't think it's like a broken, old rake; once it spreads, it spreads thoroughly.” “It's really terrible,” said Harelip.
es: —Well, I think it's horrible —said the one with the cleft lip—; I'm going to see Uncle Harvey and...

en: “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: “I should go to Uncle Harvey right away...”
es: —Well, I think it's horrible —said the one with the cleft lip—; I'm going to see Uncle Harvey and...

en: “Oh, yes,” I says, “I would.
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: "Go ahead," I said, "if it were me, I would go immediately.
es: —Ah, yes —I said—.

en: Of course I would.
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: It is absolutely necessary to go to him.
es: That's what I would do. Of course.

en: I wouldn’t lose no time.”
vi: But right now I don't understand anything, I will try to follow if I have to do it.
tr: If it were me, I wouldn't waste any time."
es: I wouldn't waste a moment.

en: “Well, why wouldn’t you?”
vi: I will make those animals satisfied and there will be no trouble in the house.
tr: “Why wouldn't you lose?”
es: —Well, why not?

en: “Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see.
vi: Tom thought for a moment longer to see if there was anything else, then he said:
tr: “If you stop and think for a minute, you can figure it out yourself.
es: —You just need to think about it for a minute and maybe you'll understand.

en: Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can?
vi: - There's one more thing I forgot.
tr: Your uncles have to return to England as quickly as possible, don't they?
es: Aren't your uncles obligated to return to England as soon as they can?

en: And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves?
vi: Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: Surely, they are not thinking of going ahead and making you travel the whole journey alone.
es: And do you think they are going to be so mean as to leave and let you make that whole trip alone?

en: You know they’ll wait for you.
vi: Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: You know they will wait for you.
es: You know they will wait for you.

en: So fur, so good.
vi: Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: There's no problem up to this point.
es: Very well.

en: Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he?
vi: Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: Your Uncle Harvey is a priest, isn't he?
es: Your uncle Harvey is a preacher, isn't he?

en: Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk?
vi: - I don't know, but maybe.
tr: So, would a priest deceive the ship's officer just to get his nephew on board against the rules, especially when there's such an infectious disease in question?
es: Very well, then. Is a preacher going to deceive a ship line employee?

en: is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard?
vi: But it's very dark in here, and I don't need flowers, it just adds more trouble.
tr: So, would a priest deceive the ship's officer just to get his nephew on board against the rules, especially when there's such an infectious disease in question?
es: Is he going to deceive the ship's purser? To get them to let Miss Mary Jane board?

en: Now you know he ain’t.
vi: - You should give it a try.
tr: You know he can't do that.
es: You know perfectly well that he won't.

en: What will he do, then?
vi: The other prisoners also grow flowers.
tr: So what will he do?
es: So what is he going to do?

en: Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’
vi: - it seems that you can grow cattail flowers here, but it's not worth the effort to plant them.
tr: ‘What a pity, but the problems of my church have to be solved on their own, because my nephew has been exposed to a terrible mumps germ made up of many microbes, and my duty is to stay here and wait for three months to see if he gets infected,’ he will say.
es: Well, he'll say: "It's a shame, but my church matters will have to manage as they can, because my niece has been exposed to those horrible pluribusunum mumps, so I have the obligation to stay here waiting the three months needed to see if she has been infected."

en: But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
vi: - Don't think that way.
tr: But if you still think it's best to tell Uncle Harvey everything, forget it, it's not important.” “No way!
es: But it doesn't matter, if you think it's better to tell your uncle Harvey...

en: “Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not?
vi: We will find you a sapling, and you will plant it in that corner of the house over there.
tr: While we could be traveling and having a good time in England, are we going to hang around here waiting to see if Mary Jane gets sick or not?
es: —That, and staying here doing nothing when we could be having fun in England while we waited to see if Mary Jane got it or not.

en: Why, you talk like a muggins.”
vi: Don't call it a cat's tail flower, you must call it Pitchiola.
tr: Now you talked like a complete fool.”
es: What nonsense you speak.

en: “Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
vi: And you must water it with your tears.
tr: “Still, it might be good to tell one of the neighbors.””
es: —Well, in any case, maybe you should tell one of the neighbors.

en: “Listen at that, now.
vi: - What's wrong?
tr: “Can't you hear what I'm saying?
es: —Look now at what he says.

en: You do beat all for natural stupidness.
vi: I have plenty of rainwater here.
tr: I mean, there's no one more foolish than you by birth.
es: You are the most stupid thing I have ever seen.

en: Can’t you see that they’d go and tell?
vi: - You cannot water it with rain; you must water it with tears.
tr: Does it never occur to you that they might go and talk to my uncle?
es: Don't you understand that they would tell everything?

en: Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
vi: Everyone does it that way.
tr: There's no other choice but to not tell anyone anything.”
es: The only thing to do is not to tell anyone.

en: “Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "Hmm, maybe you're right... Yes, you're definitely right."
es: —Well, maybe you're right... Yes, I think you're right.

en: “But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "But still, let's tell Uncle Harvey that she went to his place for a while so he doesn't worry later, right?"
es: —But I think we should still tell Uncle Harvey that she has gone away for a while so he doesn't worry about her.

en: “Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that.
vi: Tom was at a loss for words.
tr: “Yes, Miss Mary Jane wanted you to do that anyway.
es: —Yes, Miss Mary Jane wanted you to tell them.

en: She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see mr’—mr—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?
vi: But after thinking for a while, he told Jim to rub an onion on his eyes to make tears.
tr: ‘Tell them to send my love to Uncle Harvey and Uncle William, kiss them for me, and go across to the other side to see the things… the things… what was the name of that rich family your Uncle Peter always talked about?..
es: She told me: "Tell them to greet Uncle Harvey and Uncle William for me and give them a kiss and tell them that I have gone to the other side of the river to see Mr... Mr... " What is the name of that rich family that your Uncle Peter esteemed so much?... I mean the one that...

en: —I mean the one that—”
vi: He promised to pick an onion and secretly put it in Jim's coffee pot in the morning.
tr: You know, the one…”
es: She told me: "Tell them to greet Uncle Harvey and Uncle William for me and give them a kiss and tell them that I have gone to the other side of the river to see Mr... Mr... " What is the name of that rich family that your Uncle Peter esteemed so much?... I mean the one that...

en: “Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: “I guess you mean the Apthorps, right?”
es: —Man, you must be referring to the Apthorp, right?

en: “Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow.
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: “Of course, ah these names never stick in my mind, they are all so complicated.
es: —Naturally, damn names, I don't know why but half the time I forget them.

en: Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway.
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: Yes, he said that you should say you went to call the Apthorps to the auction to buy this house, because Uncle Peter doesn't want anyone else to buy the house; your sister will stay there until she convinces them to come to the auction, and then she will come home if she is not too tired; if she is tired, she will come in the morning.
es: Yes, she asked me to tell you that she has gone to see the Apthorps to make sure they come to the auction and buy this house, because she knows that her uncle Peter would prefer them to have it more than anyone else, and that she will stay with them until they say they are coming, and then, if she is not too tired, she will come back home, and if she is tired she will come back in the morning anyway.

en: She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: He asked you not to say anything about the Proctors, just to talk about the Apthorps – you will be telling the truth anyway, because he really is going to visit them to discuss the matter of buying the house; that's exactly what he told me.”
es: She asked me not to say anything about the Proctors, and to talk only about the Apthorps, which is perfectly true, because she is going there to talk about buying the house; I know because she told me herself.

en: “All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: "Alright then," they said and immediately ran to their uncle, conveyed their love and kisses, and delivered their sister's message.
es: —Very well —they said, and they went off to find their uncles and give them greetings and kisses and deliver the message.

en: Everything was all right now.
vi: It was really troublesome and annoying.
tr: Everything was now complete.
es: Now everything was in order.

en: The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson.
vi: He talked for a while, making Tom discouraged.
tr: The girls wouldn't say anything because they wanted to go to England; the king and the duke would also prefer Mary Jane to go away and work for the auction instead of hanging around Dr. Robinson.
es: The girls wouldn't say anything because they wanted to go to England, and the king and the duke would prefer that Mary Jane had gone to work so that the auction would go well and she wouldn't be within Dr. Robinson's reach.

en: I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: I was feeling very good; I thought I did this job well... Probably even Tom Sawyer couldn't have done better.
es: I felt great, and I figured I had done very well... I figured not even Tom Sawyer himself could have done it better.

en: Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: Though he would certainly do it by the book, but since I haven't done such things in my life, I'm not as skillful as he is.
es: Of course, he would have done it with more style, but that's not easy for me, because I haven't been educated that way.

en: Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: Anyway, they held the auction in the town square, towards the evening; they dragged it out as long as they could, the old man stood right next to the auctioneer and was striking his most pious poses, occasionally reading a few sentences from the Bible and making fancy speeches; while the duke was wandering around making pitiful sounds like uuu-uuu to gain sympathy.
es: Well, they organized the auction in the public square, around mid-afternoon, and it went on and on; and there was the old man, with his sanctimonious airs, right next to the auctioneer, occasionally quoting something from the Scriptures or some pious saying, and the duke was going back and forth making "goo-goo" sounds so that everyone would feel sorry for him, and smiling at everyone.

en: But by-and-by the thing dragged through, and everything was sold—everything but a little old trifling lot in the graveyard.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: But slowly but surely, the auction progressed and eventually everything was sold. Only a small bag of details remained in the cemetery.
es: But little by little, things started to run out and everything was sold, except for a few that remained in the cemetery.

en: So they’d got to work that off—I never see such a girafft as the king was for wanting to swallow everything.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: They would find it themselves now... I had never seen anyone try to extract oil from a fly as much as our king.
es: Then they set about trying to sell those; in my life, I have never seen even a giraffe like the king, so willing to swallow everything.

en: Well, whilst they was at it a steamboat landed, and in about two minutes up comes a crowd a-whooping and yelling and laughing and carrying on, and singing out:
vi: Hearing that, Jim felt remorseful and promised not to behave like that anymore.
tr: While they were busy with this, a steamboat docked at the pier, and two minutes later, the crowd came towards us, shouting, laughing, and making a racket:
es: And when they were at it, a steamboat docked and about two minutes later a group arrived, shouting and screaming, laughing and making a racket and yelling:

en: “Here’s your opposition line!
vi: Hearing that, Jim felt remorseful and promised not to behave like that anymore.
tr: "Here are your rivals!
es: —Here comes the opposition!

en: here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”
vi: After that, Tom and I went back to our room to sleep.
tr: Two more heirs have come for our Peter Wilks... Whoever pays can choose whichever they want!"
es: Now we have two groups of Peter Wilks' heirs: Step right up, pay, and see!

en: CHAPTER XXIX.
vi: Chapter XXIX
tr: Twenty-Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 29

en: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling.
vi: They approached an old man who looked very polite along with a younger man, who also looked quite mature, with a bandage on his right arm.
tr: They were bringing along a very elegant elderly gentleman, and also a younger man, equally elegant, with his right arm in a sling.
es: THEY BROUGHT AN elderly gentleman of very good appearance and another younger one, also of good appearance, with his right arm in a sling.

en: And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up.
vi: It seemed like this matter was not a joke.
tr: My God, how people were shouting; laughing and making a racket.
es: My God, how those people shouted and laughed, without stopping for a moment!

en: But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any.
vi: Perhaps the king and the duke were also feeling uneasy.
tr: But I didn't find the situation funny at all, and I thought the duke and the king would be scared when they saw them.
es: But I didn't see the humor in it and supposed that the duke and the king would also find it hard to see.

en: I reckoned they’d turn pale.
vi: I'm sure they would be scared pale.
tr: I thought both of them would turn pale as a sheet.
es: I had the feeling they were going to turn pale.

en: But no, nary a pale did they turn.
vi: But no, they didn't show any signs of it.
tr: But no, they didn't turn pale at all.
es: But no, they did not turn pale.

en: The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world.
vi: The duke still calmly wandered around there, looking satisfied. And the king looked up and down, appearing hesitant and worried; it seemed that it pained him to think that there could be such deceitful swindlers in the world.
tr: The duke didn't let on that he understood what was happening, he continued to wander around happily and making a "uuu-uuu" sound like a milk churn spraying cream everywhere; the king, on the other hand, looked at the scene with a pained and sorrowful expression, as if deeply wounded by the existence of such frauds and scoundrels in the world.
es: The duke did not let on that he suspected what was happening, but continued making "goo-goo" sounds to the people, happy and content, like a pitcher pouring out milk, and as for the king, he just looked sadly at the newcomers, as if his stomach hurt just thinking that there could be people in the world with so little shame.

en: Oh, he done it admirable.
vi: Many people stood around the king to support him.
tr: Ah, it was truly an admirable performance.
es: Ah, he did it admirably.

en: Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side.
vi: Many people stood around the king to support him.
tr: Most of the people in the town gathered around the king, trying to show their support for him.
es: Many of the town's characters went to the king to show him they were on his side.

en: That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death.
vi: A moment later, the dignified old man began to speak.
tr: The elderly gentleman came in, utterly dumbfounded.
es: The old gentleman who had just arrived seemed dead with embarrassment.

en: Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation.
vi: I immediately noticed that he spoke exactly like a real Englishman, unlike the king's manner of speaking.
tr: Soon enough, he started to speak, and indeed, he spoke just like an Englishman, very different from the king's speech, although the king's speech was quite good for an imitation.
es: He immediately began to speak and I saw right away that they had an accent just like an Englishman's, not like the king's, although the king did very well with imitations.

en: I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
vi: He spoke roughly like this:
tr: I can't describe how the old man spoke, nor can I imitate it; but turning to the crowd, he said something along these lines:
es: I can't write exactly what the old man said, nor can I imitate it, but he turned to the people and said something like this:

en: “This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake.
vi: - This is truly a strange thing that I could not have anticipated. My brother and I had an unfortunate incident; my brother broke his arm, and our luggage was mistakenly sent to another town.
tr: “I encountered a very surprising situation here that I did not expect at all; I must honestly say that I am not very prepared to face and fight such a thing; because my brother and I had some misfortunes, he broke his arm, and our belongings were mistakenly taken to a town up here last night.
es: —This is a surprise I did not expect, and I sincerely admit that I am not very well prepared to react to it and respond, as my brother and I have suffered some misfortunes; he has broken his arm and last night our luggage was left in a town further up by mistake.

en: I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with.
vi: I am Harvey, the brother of Peter Wilks; and this is my brother William. William cannot hear or speak, and he can't make many signs because he has broken an arm.
tr: I am Harvey, the older brother of Peter Wilks, and this is his brother William, who is deaf and mute – moreover, since his arm is in a sling now, he cannot even use sign language.
es: I am Harvey, Peter Wilks' brother, and this is his brother William, who is deaf-mute, and now he can't even communicate much through signs, given that he only has one free hand.

en: We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it.
vi: In a few days, when we retrieve our luggage, we will have enough evidence.
tr: We are the people we claim to be, and I will prove it when my belongings arrive in a day or two.
es: We are who we say we are, and within a day or two, when the luggage arrives, I will be able to prove it.

en: But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”
vi: But until then, I don't want to say anything more, we will go to the hotel and wait there. Then the two people walked away.
tr: But until then, I will not say anything else and will go to the hotel to wait.”
es: But until then I will not say more, and I am going to the hotel to wait.

en: So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
vi: The king laughed and muttered for a while:
tr: Thus, he walked away with the new deaf-mute by his side, and the king called out after him with a laugh:
es: So he and the new mute set off, and the king burst out laughing and said: —So, you've broken your arm, huh, just in time, right?

en: “Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how.
vi: - A broken arm, yes, that's possible, isn't it, gentlemen? And it's convenient for a trickster who needs to make a signal.
tr: “He broke his arm... no doubt about it! He broke it at just the right time, truly, at a very convenient time for those tricksters who need to use sign language but haven't learned how to use it.
es: And very convenient for a liar who has to speak in signs and hasn't learned them.

en: Lost their baggage!
vi: Losing luggage, now that's an intelligent ruse!
tr: They lost their belongings!
es: They've lost their luggage!

en: That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
vi: Losing luggage, now that's an intelligent ruse!
tr: This is even more marvelous!.. Moreover, very clever... Considering the circumstances!”
es: That's a good one! And it turns out to be very clever, in these circumstances.

en: So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen.
vi: Then the old man laughed loudly, and everyone else laughed along, except for three or four people who did not agree.
tr: He laughed again; the others joined him, but three or four people, maybe six or so, did not laugh.
es: So he laughed again, just like everyone else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen.

en: One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now.
vi: One of those people was the doctor. The second person was a very polite man, carrying a suitcase, who had just disembarked from the ship earlier and was speaking quietly with the doctor, occasionally looking up at the king and nodding their heads. That was lawyer Levi Ben, who had just returned from Louisville. The third person was large and muscular, who had just arrived and was listening to the old man earlier and now listening to the king.
tr: One of them was a doctor; the other was a stern-looking man carrying an old-fashioned cloth bag made of kilim. He had just gotten off the ferry and was whispering with the doctor; occasionally they would look at the king and nod their heads – this man was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville; there was also a burly man who came and listened to everything the old gentleman said, and now he was listening to what the king was saying.
es: One of them was the doctor, another a gentleman with a shrewd appearance, carrying one of those old-fashioned carpet bags, who had just disembarked from the steamboat and was speaking quietly with the doctor, while they occasionally glanced at the king and nodded: it was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville, and another was a tall, sturdy fellow who had approached to hear what the old man was saying and was now listening to the king.

en: And when the king got done this husky up and says:
vi: After the king finished speaking, that person looked up and asked:
tr: When the king finished his words, the burly man called out to him loudly:
es: And when the king finished, the sturdy fellow goes and says:

en: “Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
vi: - If you are Harvey Wilks, then when did you arrive in this town?
tr: "Hey, look at me, if you are Harvey Wilks, when did you arrive in town?"
es: —Listen, one thing: if you are Harvey Wilks, when did you arrive in town?

en: “The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
vi: - The day before the funeral, sir.
tr: “I arrived the day before the funeral, my friend,” said the king.
es: —The day before the funeral, my friend —says the king.

en: “But what time o’ day?”
vi: - But at what time?
tr: “So, what time did you arrive?”
es: —But, at what time?

en: “In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
vi: - In the afternoon, about one or two hours before sunset.
tr: “I came in the evening... About an hour or two before sunset.”
es: —In the afternoon, an hour or two before dusk.

en: “How’d you come?”
vi: - How did you get here?
tr: “How did you come?”
es: —How did he arrive?

en: “I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
vi: - I took the Susan Powell train from Cincinnati to here.
tr: “I came with Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
es: —I came on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.

en: “Well, then, how’d you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin’—in a canoe?”
vi: - So how did you manage to get to the dock in the morning, did you take a boat?
tr: “Well then, what were you doing up at Pint in the morning... Why were you in a canoe?”
es: —So, how is it that you were at La Punta that morning, in a canoe?

en: “I warn’t up at the Pint in the mornin’.”
vi: - I do not go to the dock in the morning.
tr: “I wasn't in Pint in the morning.”
es: —That morning I wasn't at the Punta.

en: “It’s a lie.”
vi: - Nonsense.
tr: "You are lying."
es: —He lies.

en: Several of them jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.
vi: Many people came forward and demanded that the other person not speak in such a manner to a pastor. - Pastor?
tr: A few people immediately went to him and begged him not to speak like that to an old man and a priest.
es: A few of them jumped on him and told him not to talk like that to an old man who was also a preacher.

en: “Preacher be hanged, he’s a fraud and a liar.
vi: Hang him up, he's a fraud.
tr: “To hell with the priest, he's nothing but a fraud and a liar.
es: —As a preacher, nothing; he's a liar and a fraud.

en: He was up at the Pint that mornin’.
vi: He arrived at the dock that morning.
tr: He was at Pint in the morning.
es: That morning he was at the Point.

en: I live up there, don’t I?
vi: I was there myself and saw him.
tr: Don't you know I sit there?
es: I live there, don't I?

en: Well, I was up there, and he was up there.
vi: I was there myself and saw him.
tr: He was there while I was in front of the house.
es: Well, I was there and he was there, and I saw him.

en: I see him there.
vi: I was there myself and saw him.
tr: I'm sure I saw him.
es: Well, I was there and he was there, and I saw him.

en: He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.”
vi: He went by boat, along with Tim Collins and another boy.
tr: He was in a canoe, with Tim Collins and a boy beside him.”
es: He arrived in a canoe, with Tim Collins and a boy.

en: The doctor he up and says:
vi: The doctor asked:
tr: The doctor intervened and asked, "Would you recognize that boy if you saw him again, Hines?"
es: The doctor goes and says:

en: “Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?”
vi: - If you see that boy again, would you recognize him, Hines?
tr: The doctor intervened and asked, "Would you recognize that boy if you saw him again, Hines?"
es: —Would you recognize the boy if you saw him again, Hines?

en: “I reckon I would, but I don’t know.
vi: - Recognize it?
tr: “I probably know him, but I'm not sure.
es: —I suppose so, but I don't know.

en: Why, yonder he is, now.
vi: Ah, there it is.
tr: But wait, there he is.
es: Well, there it is.

en: I know him perfectly easy.”
vi: That person pointed directly at me.
tr: I recognized him immediately.”
es: I recognize it perfectly.

en: It was me he pointed at.
vi: That person pointed directly at me.
tr: He had pointed at me.
es: And he pointed at me.

en: The doctor says:
vi: The doctor said:
tr: The doctor turned to the others:
es: The doctor says:

en: “Neighbors, I don’t know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain’t frauds, I am an idiot, that’s all.
vi: - Ladies and gentlemen, I am not yet sure if the two people who just arrived are frauds or not, but if these two guys here are not swindlers, then I am just a fool.
tr: “I don't know if the newcomers are frauds, my friends; but if these two are not frauds, then I must be a fool.
es: —Neighbors, I don't know if these new ones are two liars or not, but if they're not, then I'm an idiot, that's what I say.

en: I think it’s our duty to see that they don’t get away from here till we’ve looked into this thing.
vi: I think it is our duty to keep them from leaving this place until we understand the situation.
tr: I think our primary duty is to prevent them from escaping until this matter is resolved.
es: I think we need to stop them from leaving here until we've cleared everything up.

en: Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you.
vi: Everyone, follow me to the hotel and confront the two newcomers; I am sure we can find something.
tr: Come on, Hines; the rest of you, follow.
es: Come on, Hines; all of you, come along.

en: We’ll take these fellows to the tavern and affront them with t’other couple, and I reckon we’ll find out something before we get through.”
vi: Everyone appeared angry except for those who sided with the king.
tr: Let's take these men to the inn and confront them with the other two, maybe then we can learn something.”
es: Let's take these guys to the tavern to confront them with the other two and surely before we're done we'll have figured something out.

en: It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started.
vi: So, we all had to go.
tr: The crowd was filled with excitement, although the king's friends were probably not very pleased; still, we all set off together.
es: The people loved it, although perhaps not the king's friends; so we set off.

en: It was about sundown.
vi: At that time, the sun was about to set.
tr: The sun was about to set.
es: It was towards the evening.

en: The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
vi: The doctor took my hand and led me, gently, but he didn't let go of me for a moment.
tr: The doctor held my hand and led me along the way, he was behaving very well but he definitely did not let go of my hand.
es: The doctor took me by the hand and was very kind, but he never let go.

en: We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple.
vi: Everyone entered a large room in the hotel, then summoned the two people from earlier.
tr: We all gathered in the hotel's large hall, the lamps were lit, and the new couple was brought in.
es: We all entered a large room in the hotel, lit some candles, and brought in the two newcomers.

en: First, the doctor says:
vi: The doctor spoke first:
tr: First, the doctor spoke:
es: First, the doctor says:

en: “I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about.
vi: - I don't want to do anything excessive to these two people, but because I think they are swindlers, and they might have schemes that we don't know about.
tr: “I don't want to wrong these two men, but if you ask me, they are swindlers, and they might have accomplices we don't know about.
es: —I don't want to be too harsh on these two men, but I believe they are swindlers and might have accomplices we know nothing about.

en: If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left?
vi: Would they dare to slip away and leave Peter Wilks' bundle of money behind?
tr: If they have accomplices, they would have already taken the bag with Peter Wilks' gold and fled?
es: In that case, won't the accomplices escape with the sack of gold that Peter Wilks left?

en: It ain’t unlikely.
vi: Probably not.
tr: We cannot allow this.
es: It wouldn't be surprising.

en: If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
vi: If these guys aren't swindlers, they would probably take out that bundle of money for us to keep until they can prove they are honest, wouldn't everyone agree?
tr: If these two are not frauds, they will not object to bringing the money and letting us keep it until they prove they are telling the truth… Am I wrong?”
es: If these men are not swindlers, they won't object to us going to fetch the money and keeping it until they prove they aren't; don't you think?

en: Everybody agreed to that.
vi: Everyone answered in agreement.
tr: Everyone agreed to this.
es: Everyone agreed.

en: So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart.
vi: I think they had cornered us right from the start.
tr: I had already decided that our gang was cornered. They had lost from the start.
es: So I thought that from the very beginning they had put our band in serious trouble.

en: But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
vi: But the king only showed a hint of sadness. He said:
tr: But the king replied with sorrow:
es: But the king only put on a sad face and said:

en: “Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
vi: - Dear sirs, I also hope that the money pouch is still there, because I do not want to hinder the discovery of the whole story. But the money pouch is no longer there. If you don't believe me, you can send someone to search.
tr: “Gentlemen; I wish the money were at home, because I have no intention of obstructing the fair, transparent, and detailed investigation of this dirty business; but unfortunately, the money is not there; you can send someone to check if you want.”
es: —Gentlemen, I wish the money were there, for I am not one to put obstacles in the way of a fair, open, and thorough investigation of this sad matter; but, unfortunately, the money is not there; you can send to look for it, if you wish.

en: “Where is it, then?”
vi: - Where did you put the money?
tr: “So where is the money?”
es: —Where is it, then?

en: “Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England.
vi: - When my granddaughter gave it to me, I hid it under the mattress of my bed, because I was staying here for a few days and didn't want to deposit that money into the bank.
tr: “My nephew had given me the money to keep, thinking we would stay here for at most a few days, I didn't see the need to deposit it all in the bank and placed it inside the straw mattress under my bed; I thought the bed was a safe place, we are not very accustomed to negroes, we thought they were like the honest servants in England.
es: —Well, when my niece gave it to me to keep it for her, I hid it in the mattress of my bed, because I didn't want to take it to the bank just for a few days and I thought the bed would be a safe place, since we are not used to black people and I assumed they were honest, just like English servants.

en: The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it.
vi: I thought black people were as honest as my servants, but who would have thought they would take all that money before leaving this place.
tr: The next morning, as soon as I came down the stairs, the negroes had stolen the money; I didn't know the money was gone when I sold them, so we couldn't catch them.
es: The black people stole it the next morning, when I went downstairs, and when I sold them I still hadn't realized it was missing, so they left with it.

en: My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
vi: My servant here can explain this clearly for you to understand.
tr: My servant can confirm what I have said.”
es: Here my servant can confirm it, gentlemen.

en: The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him.
vi: The doctor, along with many others, also said: - Stop it! Nobody believes what that old man says.
tr: The doctor and a few others said, "Nonsense!" and I saw that no one fully believed the king.
es: The doctor and several others said "wow!", and I saw that no one completely believed it.

en: One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it.
vi: Someone asked me if I saw the black people stealing money.
tr: One of the men turned to me and asked if the money had been stolen by the black people.
es: A man asked me if I had seen the black men steal it.

en: I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them.
vi: I said that I only saw them hurrying out of the room. I thought they were afraid of waking up my boss, so they had to step outside.
tr: I said I hadn't seen it, but I had seen them quietly leaving the room and nothing had occurred to me; I thought they were afraid of waking the gentleman and were trying to get away without getting into trouble.
es: I said no, but that I had seen them sneak out of the room and leave and that I had never thought anything bad, because I believed they had been scared of waking my master and were trying to leave before he reprimanded them.

en: That was all they asked me.
vi: But the doctor angrily asked me:
tr: They only asked me this.
es: They didn't ask me anything else.

en: Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
vi: But the doctor angrily asked me:
tr: Then the doctor suddenly turned to me and asked:
es: Then the doctor turned to me and asked:

en: “Are you English, too?”
vi: - Are you English?
tr: “Are you English too?”
es: —Are you English too?

en: I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
vi: I said yes, then he and everyone laughed and said: - Another con artist!
tr: Yes, I said; the doctor and a few others laughed out loud, saying, "Nonsense!"
es: I said yes and he and others burst out laughing and said: "Nonsense!"

en: Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see.
vi: We were being talked up and down for several hours without anyone mentioning anything about eating or drinking.
tr: Then they returned to the general inquiry; one spoke, then the other, hours passed, and no one mentioned eating, it seemed as if food hadn't even crossed their minds – they argued and argued; it was the most complicated situation you could ever see.
es: Well, then they continued with the general investigation, which went on with its ups and downs, hour after hour, and no one said a word about dinner, it seemed like they didn't even remember it, so they kept going and going and it turned out to be very complicated.

en: They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies.
vi: They made the king recount the whole story of the old man, and then they asked that distinguished old man to also recount his whole story. But no one dared to assert whether the old man was telling the truth or the king was lying.
tr: They made the king tell his own story, they made the old gentleman tell his own story; everyone except the biased fools realized that the old gentleman was telling the truth and the king was lying.
es: They made the king tell his version, and then the old man tell his, and anyone who wasn't a mule full of prejudices would have seen that the old gentleman was telling the truth and the other was lying.

en: And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed.
vi: After a while, they told me to step forward and recount everything I knew.
tr: At one point, they asked me to tell everything I knew.
es: And then they forced me to tell what I knew.

en: The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side.
vi: The king glanced at me, so I knew how to speak appropriately.
tr: The king glanced sideways, obviously expecting me to take his side.
es: The king looked at me out of the corner of his eye and I realized what it was convenient for me to say.

en: I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
vi: I began to talk about the city of Sheffield, how we lived there, and everything about the Wilks family in England.
tr: I started talking about Sheffield and how we lived there; I also mentioned the English Wilkses; but I couldn't say much, because the Doctor started laughing and the lawyer Levi Bell said:
es: I started talking about Sheffield and how we lived there and all the Wilks there were in England, and all that; but I hadn't said much when the doctor started laughing and then Levi Bell, the lawyer, goes and says:

en: “Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you.
vi: But before I could finish, that doctor burst out laughing, and then Levi Ben, the lawyer, also spoke:
tr: “Sit here, child. If I were you, I wouldn't stress myself so much.
es: —Sit down, boy; if I were you, I wouldn't tire myself out.

en: I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice.
vi: - Well, the machine isn't used to lying, so it often stumbles over its words.
tr: You're probably not used to lying, you can't make things up on the spot, you need some practice.
es: I figure you're not used to lying and it's not easy for you; you lack practice.

en: You do it pretty awkward.”
vi: I didn't pay attention to the compliment; I was just very happy to have escaped.
tr: You're a very bad liar.”
es: You're doing it quite poorly.

en: I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.
vi: I didn't pay attention to the compliment; I was just very happy to have escaped.
tr: I was in no condition to care about the man's praise; I was very pleased to be left alone.
es: I didn't like that compliment very much, but in any case, I was glad they left me alone.

en: The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says:
vi: Now, the doctor turned to the side and said:
tr: The doctor started to explain something, but then turned and said:
es: The doctor started to say something and then turns around and says:

en: “If you’d been in town at first, Levi Bell—”
vi: - If only you had been in this town from the very beginning, wouldn't that be better, Mr. Levi Ben?
tr: "I wish you had been here when they came to town, Levi Bell...""
es: —If you had been in the town from the beginning, Levi Bell...

en: The king broke in and reached out his hand, and says:
vi: The king raised his hand and interjected:
tr: The king immediately intervened and extended his hand.
es: The king interrupted, reached out his hand, and said:

en: “Why, is this my poor dead brother’s old friend that he’s wrote so often about?”
vi: - So this is the friend that my brother often mentioned in his letters?
tr: “Aren't you the old friend my poor deceased brother often wrote letters about?”
es: —But, is this the old friend of my poor brother, may he rest in peace, whom he told me so much about in his letters?

en: The lawyer and him shook hands, and the lawyer smiled and looked pleased, and they talked right along awhile, and then got to one side and talked low; and at last the lawyer speaks up and says:
vi: The lawyer shook hands with the old man, smiling with satisfaction, then the two exchanged a few words, and stepped aside to speak quietly.
tr: They shook hands with the lawyer, the lawyer smiled, he seemed pleased. After talking for a while, they stepped aside and whispered a bit. Finally, the lawyer said loudly:
es: The lawyer and he shook hands and the lawyer smiled with a satisfied air and they chatted for a while and then they moved to the side and spoke in low voices, and finally the lawyer speaks out loud and says:

en: “That’ll fix it.
vi: A moment later, the lawyer spoke up:
tr: “Then it will be resolved.
es: —That's how things will be sorted out.

en: I’ll take the order and send it, along with your brother’s, and then they’ll know it’s all right.”
vi: - Alright, I will take the documents from both sides to understand the truth of the matter.
tr: If you and your brother provide written instructions, there will be no problem.”
es: We place the order and send it, along with your brother's, and that way you'll see that everything is in order.

en: So they got some paper and a pen, and the king he set down and twisted his head to one side, and chawed his tongue, and scrawled off something; and then they give the pen to the duke—and then for the first time the duke looked sick.
vi: So they took out paper and pen. The king sat down, tilted his head to one side, and scribbled something on it. Then they handed the pen to the duke, who seemed fearful.
tr: Thus, they found a piece of paper and a pen; the king sat down, tilted his head to one side, stuck his tongue out halfway, and scribbled something; then he handed the pen to the duke – the duke looked genuinely on edge for the first time.
es: So they brought a paper and a pen, and the king sat down, tilted his head to one side, bit his tongue, and scribbled something; then they handed the pen to the duke, and for the first time, he looked troubled.

en: But he took the pen and wrote.
vi: But he still took the pen and wrote.
tr: But still, he took the pen and wrote.
es: But he took the pen and wrote.

en: So then the lawyer turns to the new old gentleman and says:
vi: Then the lawyer turned to the old man and said:
tr: The lawyer then turned to the new elderly gentleman:
es: Then the lawyer turns to the newly arrived old man and says to him:

en: “You and your brother please write a line or two and sign your names.”
vi: - You and your brother, please write a few lines here and sign your names below.
tr: “Please, you and your brother each write a few lines and sign them.””
es: —You and your brother, please write a line or two and sign with your name.

en: The old gentleman wrote, but nobody couldn’t read it.
vi: The old man wrote, but no one could read a single word.
tr: The elderly gentleman wrote, but no one could read what he had written.
es: The elderly gentleman wrote, but no one managed to read what it said.

en: The lawyer looked powerful astonished, and says:
vi: The lawyer took an old bundle of letters from his pocket, examined them carefully, then looked at the old man's handwriting, and then at the handwriting of the king and the duke, showing great surprise, he said:
tr: The lawyer was very surprised by this.
es: The lawyer seemed extremely astonished and said:

en: “Well, it beats me”—and snaked a lot of old letters out of his pocket, and examined them, and then examined the old man’s writing, and then them again; and then says: “These old letters is from Harvey Wilks; and here’s these two handwritings, and anybody can see they didn’t write them” (the king and the duke looked sold and foolish, I tell you, to see how the lawyer had took them in), “and here’s this old gentleman’s hand writing, and anybody can tell, easy enough, he didn’t write them—fact is, the scratches he makes ain’t properly writing at all.
vi: - Strange, these old letters are from Harvey Wilks and here are two handwriting samples. Anyone can see that those people did not write like this.
tr: “Well, that’s correct,” he said – taking out a bunch of old letters from his pocket and examining them, then examining the handwriting of the old men: “These are letters from Harvey Wilks; and these are the handwriting of these two, it’s immediately obvious that they didn’t write the letters” (the king and the duke had realized how the lawyer had outsmarted them and were left gaping like fools), “this handwriting you see here is also from this old gentleman, it’s immediately obvious that he didn’t write the letters either… In fact, the scribbles don’t even resemble proper writing.
es: —Well, I don't understand it —and he took a bunch of old letters out of his pocket and examined them; then he examined what the old man had written and then the letters again, and he goes and says—: These old letters are from Harvey Wilks, and here we see these two letters; you can all see that neither of the two wrote the letters (the king and the duke put on the faces of deceived fools, I assure you, seeing how the lawyer had made them take the bait), and this is the handwriting of that gentleman, and you can all easily see that he didn't write them either; in fact, the scribbles he makes can't even be called writing.

en: Now, here’s some letters from—”
vi: As for this old man's handwriting, anyone can easily see that it's not his writing...
tr: Here are these letters too…”
es: Here we have some letters from...

en: The new old gentleman says:
vi: The old man interrupted:
tr: The new elderly gentleman interjected:
es: The new old man goes and says:

en: “If you please, let me explain.
vi: - I would like to offer an explanation.
tr: "If you allow me, I will explain.
es: —Please, allow me to explain it.

en: Nobody can read my hand but my brother there—so he copies for me.
vi: No one can read my handwriting, except for my younger brother. Therefore, my brother always transcribes the letters I write.
tr: No one but my brother can read my handwriting... That's why he transcribes my letters.
es: No one can understand my handwriting, but here my brother copies the letters for me.

en: It’s his hand you’ve got there, not mine.”
vi: The letters you are holding are all in my brother's handwriting, not mine.
tr: The handwriting you see in your letters is not mine but his."
es: What you are showing is his handwriting, not mine.

en: “Well!” says the lawyer, “this is a state of things.
vi: - In that case, - the lawyer said - I also have some letters from William here.
tr: “Alright!” said the lawyer, “It sounds like a reasonable claim.
es: —Good! —says the lawyer—. That's how things stand.

en: I’ve got some of William’s letters, too; so if you’ll get him to write a line or so we can com—”
vi: So if you let him write a few lines, we can... .
tr: I also have some of William's letters with me; if you can get him to write a few lines, we can get a definite result...”
es: I also have some of William's letters here, so if you could tell him to write a line or two, then we can compa...

en: “He can’t write with his left hand,” says the old gentleman.
vi: - My brother cannot write with his left hand.
tr: “He cannot write with his left hand,” the elderly gentleman interrupted.
es: —He cannot write with his left hand —says the elderly gentleman—.

en: “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and mine too.
vi: If my brother's right hand had not been broken, you would clearly see that both letters were written by the same person.
tr: “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote both his own letters and mine. Please compare the handwriting in the letters...
es: If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and also mine.

en: Look at both, please—they’re by the same hand.”
vi: If my brother's right hand had not been broken, you would clearly see that both letters were written by the same person.
tr: You will see that they are the same.”
es: Please compare them yourself and you will see that they are written in the same handwriting.

en: The lawyer done it, and says:
vi: The lawyer looked at it and said:
tr: The lawyer compared the letters and said: “Indeed, the same person wrote it...
es: The lawyer compared them, and says:

en: “I believe it’s so—and if it ain’t so, there’s a heap stronger resemblance than I’d noticed before, anyway.
vi: - I think it's probably true, I see the two handwritings are very similar.
tr: Even if it's not the same person, there is an incredible similarity that I never noticed before.
es: —I think so, and if not, in any case, there is a much greater resemblance than I had noticed until now.

en: Well, well, well!
vi: Alright!
tr: Yes, the matter has become a bit complicated!
es: Well, well, well!

en: I thought we was right on the track of a solution, but it’s gone to grass, partly.
vi: I think we are about to reach a resolution, but some parts are still unclear.
tr: Actually, I thought I was making progress towards a solution, but it seems we've hit a wall again.
es: I thought we were on the track of a solution, but now it has disappeared, at least in part.

en: But anyway, one thing is proved—these two ain’t either of ’em Wilkses”—and he wagged his head towards the king and the duke.
vi: Anyway, there is one thing that can prove these two are not the Wilks brothers.
tr: Still, one thing is certain - these two are definitely not the Wilkses”– he indicated the king and the duke with his head.
es: But, in any case, there is one thing that is proven: neither of those two is a Wilks —with a nod towards the king and the duke.

en: Well, what do you think?
vi: As he spoke, he turned towards the king and the duke.
tr: Yes, in this situation, what do you think our mule-brained old fool did?
es: Well, what can I tell you?

en: That muleheaded old fool wouldn’t give in then!
vi: At this point, the old man still wouldn't admit defeat.
tr: He still wouldn't give up, you say, right?
es: The stubborn old fool wasn't willing to confess even then.

en: Indeed he wouldn’t.
vi: At this point, the old man still wouldn't admit defeat.
tr: Indeed, he didn't give up.
es: Really, he wasn't.

en: Said it warn’t no fair test.
vi: At this point, the old man still wouldn't admit defeat.
tr: He said this was an unfair test.
es: He said that the test wasn't fair.

en: Said his brother William was the cussedest joker in the world, and hadn’t tried to write—he see William was going to play one of his jokes the minute he put the pen to paper.
vi: He said that William was a stubborn and playful person, that when he put pen to paper it was just one of his pranks.
tr: He said his brother William was the most incorrigible jester in the world, he hadn't even tried to write properly... In fact, he had sensed that the moment a pen and paper were placed in front of William, he would make one of his jokes again.
es: He said that his brother William spent his time joking around and hadn't tried to write, and that he was sure William was going to play one of his jokes as soon as he picked up the paper.

en: And so he warmed up and went warbling and warbling right along till he was actuly beginning to believe what he was saying himself; but pretty soon the new gentleman broke in, and says:
vi: Then the old man rambled on for a while until he thought he was actually talking about himself.
tr: He gradually opened up and continued to babble, eventually even starting to believe what he was saying himself – but soon the new old gentleman interrupted:
es: And he kept getting more heated and talking so much that he started to believe what he was saying himself; but soon the new gentleman interrupted him, and said:

en: “I’ve thought of something.
vi: But the other old man interrupted:
tr: “I just thought of something.
es: —I just thought of something.

en: Is there anybody here that helped to lay out my br—helped to lay out the late Peter Wilks for burying?”
vi: - I have an idea, is there anyone here who helped with the shrouding of Mr. Peter Wilks before his burial?
tr: His brother… I mean, was there anyone among you who helped with the burial of the late Peter Wilks?”
es: Is there anyone here who helped dress my her... who helped dress the late Mr. Peter Wilks for the burial?

en: “Yes,” says somebody, “me and Ab Turner done it.
vi: There was a voice speaking: - What! Ab Turner and I did that.
tr: Someone said, "Yes, Ab Turner and I did it."
es: —Yes —someone said—, Ab Turner and I.

en: We’re both here.”
vi: Both of us went there.
tr: "We are both here."
es: Here we both are.

en: Then the old man turns towards the king, and says:
vi: Then the old man turned to ask the king:
tr: Upon this, the old man turned to the king and asked:
es: Then the old man turns to the king and says:

en: “Perhaps this gentleman can tell me what was tattooed on his breast?”
vi: - Could you tell me what tattoo Peter has on his chest?
tr: "Maybe this gentleman can tell us what tattoo the deceased had on his chest, what do you think?"
es: —Could this gentleman tell me what he had tattooed on his chest?

en: Blamed if the king didn’t have to brace up mighty quick, or he’d a squshed down like a bluff bank that the river has cut under, it took him so sudden; and, mind you, it was a thing that was calculated to make most anybody sqush to get fetched such a solid one as that without any notice, because how was he going to know what was tattooed on the man?
vi: - Could you tell me what tattoo Peter has on his chest?
tr: I saw the king stagger slightly, he immediately recovered, otherwise, he would have collapsed like a piece of shore undermined by the river. He had taken the blow suddenly, and it was such a blow that whoever it struck suddenly would be flattened. How could he have known what tattoo the man had on his chest?
es: Hang me if the king didn't have to react at full speed, or he would have shattered like a clod of earth falling into the river, it was so sudden; and I assure you it was something that would have shattered anyone if they had been hit like that without any warning; because, how was he to know what that man had tattooed?

en: He whitened a little; he couldn’t help it; and it was mighty still in there, and everybody bending a little forwards and gazing at him.
vi: This time, it's really dangerous.
tr: He turned a bit pale; he couldn't help it; there wasn't a sound, and everyone was leaning forward a bit, looking at him.
es: He paled a little; he couldn't help it; and you could have heard a fly buzz, because everyone leaned forward a bit to see what he would say.

en: Says I to myself, Now he’ll throw up the sponge—there ain’t no more use.
vi: If he doesn't answer quickly, there will be no way to escape.
tr: This time he will throw in the towel, I said to myself – he had nothing left to do.
es: I said to myself: "Now he's going to have to throw in the towel; he has nothing left to do."

en: Well, did he?
vi: How could he know what tattoo was on the chest of the deceased?
tr: Did he surrender then?
es: Nothing to do? Ha!

en: A body can’t hardly believe it, but he didn’t.
vi: He turned pale for a moment, and everyone seemed to lean forward a bit, staring intently at him.
tr: It's hard to believe, but he still didn't surrender.
es: It's almost impossible to believe, but there he stayed.

en: I reckon he thought he’d keep the thing up till he tired them people out, so they’d thin out, and him and the duke could break loose and get away.
vi: He still wouldn't give in, determined to go all the way to prevent everyone from catching him off guard and escaping.
tr: He was probably planning to drag the matter out until people got tired, so the crowd would thin out and he could escape with the duke.
es: I figure his idea was to keep going with it until he tired people out so they would start leaving, and then he and the duke could flee and escape.

en: Anyway, he set there, and pretty soon he begun to smile, and says:
vi: He still sat there confidently, and after a while, he smiled and answered:
tr: Yet he continued to sit there and finally responded with a smile:
es: In any case, there he stayed, and after a moment he started to smile and said:

en: “Mf!
vi: He still sat there confidently, and after a while, he smiled and answered:
tr: "This is truly a difficult question, isn't it!
es: —Hmm!

en: It’s a very tough question, ain’t it!
vi: - That is indeed a difficult question to answer.
tr: "This is truly a difficult question, isn't it!
es: What a difficult question!

en: Yes, sir, I k’n tell you what’s tattooed on his breast.
vi: Yes, sir, I can tell you what tattoo was on the chest of the deceased.
tr: Let me tell you what tattoo the deceased had on his chest, sir.
es: Yes, sir, I can tell you what he had tattooed on his chest.

en: It’s jest a small, thin, blue arrow—that’s what it is; and if you don’t look clost, you can’t see it.
vi: It was just a very small, blue arrow, which could not be seen unless looked at very closely.
tr: Just a small, thin blue arrow – that's all the tattoo is; but you can't see it unless you look closely.
es: It was a small, very fine, blue arrow... That was it; and if you don't look very closely, you can't see it.

en: Now what do you say—hey?”
vi: So, what do you think?
tr: So what do you think is on his chest... huh?"
es: And now, what do you say?

en: Well, I never see anything like that old blister for clean out-and-out cheek.
vi: I've never seen anyone as brazen as him.
tr: I had truly never seen anyone as brazen and leather-faced as this old trickster.
es: The truth is that in my life I have never seen anyone as shameless as that unscrupulous person.

en: The new old gentleman turns brisk towards Ab Turner and his pard, and his eye lights up like he judged he’d got the king this time, and says:
vi: The old man immediately turned towards Ab Turner and Ab Turner's friend, his eyes lighting up because he thought to himself that this time he had caught the king. The old man asked:
tr: The new elderly gentleman immediately turned to Ab Turner and his friend. This time, it was clear from the sparkle in his eyes that he thought he had caught the king.
es: The old man, with a fiery gaze, immediately turns towards Ab Turner and his companion, as if thinking that this time he has indeed caught the king, and then says:

en: “There—you’ve heard what he said!
vi: - There, you all heard what that man just said!
tr: “So, you heard what he said!” he said.
es: —Well, you have heard what he said!

en: Was there any such mark on Peter Wilks’ breast?”
vi: So, does Peter Wilks have such a tattoo on his chest?
tr: “Was there such a mark on Peter Wilks' chest?”
es: Was there such a tattoo on Peter Wilks' chest?

en: Both of them spoke up and says:
vi: Both of them answered together:
tr: Both men answered at once:
es: Both of them replied:

en: “We didn’t see no such mark.”
vi: - We did not see any such signs
tr: "We did not see such a sign."
es: —We didn't see anything like it.

en: “Good!” says the old gentleman.
vi: - Very good, -
tr: “Alright!” said the elderly gentleman.
es: —Good! —says the elderly gentleman—.

en: “Now, what you did see on his breast was a small dim P, and a B (which is an initial he dropped when he was young), and a W, with dashes between them, so: P—B—W”—and he marked them that way on a piece of paper.
vi: The old man continued - On Peter's chest, do you see a few small letters P and B with the letter W, with dashes between the three letters, like this P - B - W?
tr: “On the tattoo you saw on his chest, there was a small dark-colored P and a B (these were the initials he used when he was young) and a W, with dashes in between: P – B – W” – then he made a copy of the tattoo on a piece of paper.
es: What they did see tattooed on his chest was a small, partially erased capital P and a capital B (which is an initial he stopped using when he was young) and a capital W, with dashes between them arranged like this: P—B—W. And he wrote it on a sheet of paper.

en: “Come, ain’t that what you saw?”
vi: The two men said again:
tr: “Look… Wasn't the tattoo you saw like this?”
es: Come on, wasn't that what they saw?

en: Both of them spoke up again, and says:
vi: The two men said again:
tr: The men both answered again:
es: The other two started talking again and said:

en: “No, we didn’t.
vi: - No, we didn't see anything.
tr: “No, it wasn't.
es: —No, we didn't see it.

en: We never seen any marks at all.”
vi: There were no signs at all.
tr: We never saw these signs.”
es: We didn't see any tattoo at all.

en: Well, everybody was in a state of mind now, and they sings out:
vi: At that moment, everyone was confused, then they screamed:
tr: This time, everyone was confused; they started shouting:
es: Well, now everyone was in a terrible mood and they started shouting:

en: “The whole bilin’ of ’m ’s frauds!
vi: - They're all just a bunch of swindlers!
tr: “They are all swindlers!
es: —They are all swindlers!

en: Le’s duck ’em!
vi: - They're all just a bunch of swindlers!
tr: Let's give them a good soaking!
es: To the pond with them!

en: le’s drown ’em!
vi: Throw them all into the river!
tr: Throw them into the river and drown them, tie them to a post!”
es: Let's drown them!

en: le’s ride ’em on a rail!” and everybody was whooping at once, and there was a rattling powwow.
vi: But the lawyer jumped onto the table and shouted loudly:
tr: There was quite a commotion as everyone was shouting and yelling in unison.
es: Let's run them out on a rail! —Everyone was shouting at once, with an overwhelming uproar.

en: But the lawyer he jumps on the table and yells, and says:
vi: But the lawyer jumped onto the table and shouted loudly:
tr: But the lawyer climbed onto the table and shouted:
es: But the lawyer jumps onto the table and shouts:

en: “Gentlemen—gentlemen!
vi: - Everyone, please listen to me, just one sentence, only one sentence.
tr: “Gentlemen… gentlemen!
es: —Gentlemen... Gentlemen!

en: Hear me just a word—just a single word—if you PLEASE!
vi: - Everyone, please listen to me, just one sentence, only one sentence.
tr: Listen to me for a moment, I will say just one thing – if you want!
es: Allow me a word: just one word... PLEASE!

en: There’s one way yet—let’s go and dig up the corpse and look.”
vi: There is only one way left, let's go dig up the corpse and see.
tr: There is another way… Let's go and exhume the body and see.”
es: We can still see it: let's exhume the corpse to see the tattoo.

en: That took them.
vi: Everyone agreed, wanting to leave immediately, but the lawyer and the doctor spoke loudly:
tr: This is what they liked.
es: That convinced them.

en: “Hooray!” they all shouted, and was starting right off; but the lawyer and the doctor sung out:
vi: Everyone agreed, wanting to leave immediately, but the lawyer and the doctor spoke loudly:
tr: People started to leave the hall shouting "Hurrah!"; but the lawyer and the doctor stopped them:
