es: —Hurray! —everyone shouted, and they set off, but the lawyer and the doctor exclaimed:

en: “Hold on, hold on!
vi: - Wait a minute!
tr: “Wait a moment!
es: —Calm down, calm down!

en: Collar all these four men and the boy, and fetch them along, too!”
vi: Grab all four people and this guy carrying the baby and take them away.
tr: First, hold these four and the boy tightly, we're taking them too!”
es: Grab hold of these four men and the boy so they can come too.

en: “We’ll do it!” they all shouted; “and if we don’t find them marks we’ll lynch the whole gang!”
vi: Everyone shouted: - Alright, and if we don't see those tattoos, we'll hang the whole bunch of you.
tr: “Yes, let's catch him!” shouted the crowd, “If we see that he has no tattoos, we will lynch them all at once!”
es: —That's it! —they all shouted—, and if we don't find the tattoo, we're going to lynch the whole gang.

en: I was scared, now, I tell you.
vi: I was so scared, I couldn't escape anymore.
tr: That's when I really started to get scared.
es: I assure you that now I was scared.

en: But there warn’t no getting away, you know.
vi: I was so scared, I couldn't escape anymore.
tr: But there was no way to get out of this situation.
es: But there was no way to escape.

en: They gripped us all, and marched us right along, straight for the graveyard, which was a mile and a half down the river, and the whole town at our heels, for we made noise enough, and it was only nine in the evening.
vi: They grabbed us tightly and led us straight to the cemetery about a mile down by the river. The whole town followed behind, making a lot of noise. It was only nine o'clock in the evening then.
tr: They held us tightly and took us to the cemetery a mile and a half down the river. The whole town was following us, because the commotion we caused had caught everyone's attention, and it was only nine in the evening.
es: They grabbed all of us and made us go with them directly to the cemetery, which was a mile and a half downstream, and the whole town followed us because we were making a lot of noise and it was only nine at night.

en: As we went by our house I wished I hadn’t sent Mary Jane out of town; because now if I could tip her the wink she’d light out and save me, and blow on our dead-beats.
vi: When passing by the house, I thought if only I hadn't told Miss Mary Jane to go to the suburbs, she would have come to rescue me and expose those scoundrels by now.
tr: As I was passing by our house, I regretted sending Mary Jane out of town; because if I gave her a signal, she could immediately come out and save me and also expose the fraudsters.
es: As I passed by our house, I regretted having sent Mary Jane out of town, because if I could signal her now, she would come to save me and could expose our swindlers.

en: Well, we swarmed along down the river road, just carrying on like wildcats; and to make it more scary the sky was darking up, and the lightning beginning to wink and flitter, and the wind to shiver amongst the leaves.
vi: The whole group followed the riverbank like wild cats.
tr: We were moving along the road by the river in a disorderly mob, like wild animals. As if this situation wasn't frightening enough, the sky had darkened, lightning was striking here and there, and the whistle of the wind passing through the leaves was growing stronger.
es: Well, we arrived en masse at the river road, making more noise than a bunch of wild cats, and to make it scarier, the sky was darkening and some trembling lightning bolts were starting to appear, and the wind was making the leaves shake.

en: This was the most awful trouble and most dangersome I ever was in; and I was kinder stunned; everything was going so different from what I had allowed for; stead of being fixed so I could take my own time if I wanted to, and see all the fun, and have Mary Jane at my back to save me and set me free when the close-fit come, here was nothing in the world betwixt me and sudden death but just them tattoo-marks.
vi: The sky darkened, the wind rustled the leaves, making me extremely frightened.
tr: I was in the most terrifying and dangerous situation I had ever experienced; I was all tangled up; things had taken a very different turn from what I had calculated. Supposedly, I was going to wander around the town as I pleased and even watch the events from the outside. After all, Mary Jane was behind me, and if I got trapped, she would rescue me. But now, there was nothing between me and sudden death except for the signs on a tattoo.
es: It was the most terrible and dangerous situation I had ever been in my life, and I felt dazed; everything was going very differently from what I had thought; instead of happening in a way that I could take my time and enjoy what was happening, with Mary Jane backing me up to save me and give me back my freedom when things got ugly, now there was nothing in the world standing between sudden death and me, except those tattoos.

en: If they didn’t find them—
vi: What if they don't find the tattoo?
tr: If they found the tattoo, that is…
es: If they didn't find them...

en: I couldn’t bear to think about it; and yet, somehow, I couldn’t think about nothing else.
vi: Thinking about the imminent death, I couldn't bear it.
tr: I couldn't bear to think about the matter; but still, I couldn't think of anything else.
es: I couldn't bear to think about it and, yet, I don't know why I couldn't think about anything else.

en: It got darker and darker, and it was a beautiful time to give the crowd the slip; but that big husky had me by the wrist—Hines—and a body might as well try to give Goliar the slip.
vi: The sky was getting darker, making it very convenient to escape, but Hines held my wrist tightly.
tr: The sky grew darker and darker. If I had the chance, I would have bolted and run away, but that giant – Hines – had grabbed me by the wrist. It would probably be easier to try to escape from a giant's hand.
es: It was getting darker and darker and it was a great moment to escape from those people, but the strongman (Hines) had me by the wrist and it was like trying to escape from Goliath.

en: He dragged me right along, he was so excited, and I had to run to keep up.
vi: He was angry, dragging me along roughly, I had to walk faster to avoid being pulled by him.
tr: He was practically dragging me, he was very excited; I had to run to keep up with him.
es: He was practically dragging me along, he was so nervous, and to avoid falling I had to run after him.

en: When they got there they swarmed into the graveyard and washed over it like an overflow.
vi: The crowd of people swarmed to the cemetery like ants, carrying hundreds of shovels, but no one thought to bring a light.
tr: When the crowd arrived at the cemetery, they poured inside and spread among the graves like a flood.
es: When they arrived, they entered the cemetery and filled it with a surge.

en: And when they got to the grave they found they had about a hundred times as many shovels as they wanted, but nobody hadn’t thought to fetch a lantern.
vi: The crowd of people swarmed to the cemetery like ants, carrying hundreds of shovels, but no one thought to bring a light.
tr: Upon reaching the grave, they realized that they had brought a hundred times more shovels than needed, but no one had brought a lantern.
es: And upon reaching the grave, they saw that they had a hundred times more shovels than they needed, but no one had thought to bring a lantern.

en: But they sailed into digging anyway by the flicker of the lightning, and sent a man to the nearest house, a half a mile off, to borrow one.
vi: However, they kept digging by the distant glimmering lights, while one person ran to the nearest house about half a mile from the cemetery to borrow a lamp. They kept digging.
tr: Nevertheless, they began digging by the light of the lightning and sent someone to borrow a lantern from the nearest house half a mile away.
es: But anyway, they started digging by the light of the lightning and sent someone to the nearest house, which was half a mile away, to fetch a light.

en: So they dug and dug like everything; and it got awful dark, and the rain started, and the wind swished and swushed along, and the lightning come brisker and brisker, and the thunder boomed; but them people never took no notice of it, they was so full of this business; and one minute you could see everything and every face in that big crowd, and the shovelfuls of dirt sailing up out of the grave, and the next second the dark wiped it all out, and you couldn’t see nothing at all.
vi: The sky was pitch black, the wind howled, lightning flashed continuously, and thunder roared; but they paid no attention to any of it. They were engrossed in digging, sometimes the lightning lasted for a very bright minute, allowing everything and everyone in the crowd to be seen, even the shovels full of earth being thrown up from the grave. Then after a while, the sky turned pitch black again, and nothing could be seen.
tr: While they were digging with great effort, the sky grew darker, the rain poured down, the wind started to howl, the lightning drew closer and the thunder increased; but they were not even aware of it, all of them were focused on this task; for a moment, you could see everything and every face in that large crowd, the shovelfuls of mud being thrown out of the grave, and the next moment the darkness erased everything and you could see nothing.
es: So they dug and kept digging like prisoners, and the night turned black as pitch and it started to rain and the wind whistled and roared and the lightning became clearer and clearer while the thunder drummed; but those people didn't pay any attention, so enthusiastic were they about the matter; and as soon as everything and everyone's faces in that crowd could be seen with the shovelfuls of earth coming out of the grave, the darkness erased everything the next second and nothing at all could be seen.

en: At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful.
vi: Finally, they managed to lift the coffin and pry out the nails sealing the lid. Everyone tried to jostle each other to get a look inside.
tr: Finally, they reached the coffin and began to remove the lid. In the crowd, there was a new wave of squeezing, elbowing, and pushing; everyone wanted to get closer and see the coffin; we were in a terrible state in that darkness.
es: They finally took out the coffin and began to unscrew the lid, and the crowd jostled and shoved so much to get a spot and see what was happening like I had never seen in my life, and that, in the middle of the darkness, was terrifying.

en: Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.
vi: It was horrifying; Hines kept gripping my wrist and pulling me along. I thought he would forget about me there, as he was also intently watching.
tr: Hines was pulling my wrist so hard that it hurt a lot; he was probably so excited and curious that he had forgotten I even existed.
es: Hines hurt my wrist a lot by pulling on it, and I reckon he had forgotten about my existence, as nervous and panting as he was.

en: All of a sudden the lightning let go a perfect sluice of white glare, and somebody sings out:
vi: Suddenly, a flash of lightning lit up the entire area, and there was a shout.
tr: Suddenly, a lightning bolt flashed, and everything was illuminated in bright white. Someone shouted:
es: Suddenly, the lightning illuminated everything with a white light and someone shouted:

en: “By the living jingo, here’s the bag of gold on his breast!”
vi: - Oh Lord, the money pouch is lying on the chest of this dead person!
tr: “Oh my God, look over there, the bag of gold was right here on his chest!”
es: —By the living God, there is the bag of gold, on the chest!

en: Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.
vi: Hines screamed like everyone else, suddenly grabbed my wrist and pushed quickly, squeezing into the crowd to see; I took the opportunity to slip out, ran to the street without anyone noticing.
tr: A cry of astonishment rose from Hines just like everyone else. He let go of my wrist and started pushing through the crowd to get a look; no one saw that I had immediately disappeared and was running towards the road in the dark.
es: Hines let out a howl, just like everyone else, and released my wrist while giving a shove to make his way to look, and I assure you that no one has ever been seen to shoot off like I did in search of the path in the darkness.

en: I had the road all to myself, and I fairly flew—leastways, I had it all to myself except the solid dark, and the now-and-then glares, and the buzzing of the rain, and the thrashing of the wind, and the splitting of the thunder; and sure as you are born I did clip it along!
vi: I ran like the wind on the road. At least, I felt like it was just me and the darkness, with occasional flashes of lightning, the sound of pouring rain, the howling wind, and the rumbling thunder.
tr: There was no one else on the road but me, I was practically flying – at least on the road, there was nothing but the pitch darkness, the occasional lightning illuminating everything, the patter of the rain, the howl of the wind, and the thunder; I was wildly running along the road!
es: I had the road all to myself and I practically flew; at least I had it all to myself, except for those dense darknesses and the occasional lightning and the pounding rain and the gusts of wind and the cannonade of thunder, and you can believe me when I say that I ran with all my soul!

en: When I struck the town I see there warn’t nobody out in the storm, so I never hunted for no back streets, but humped it straight through the main one; and when I begun to get towards our house I aimed my eye and set it.
vi: Upon arriving at the town, I didn't see a single soul, so I confidently walked down the middle of the main street. As I got closer to home, I kept an eye out to see if I noticed anything.
tr: When I arrived in the town, I saw that no one was left on the streets because of the storm, so I didn't wander through the back streets at all; I went straight down the main street, and as I approached our house, I squinted my eyes and looked carefully.
es: When I arrived at the village, I saw that there was no one around because of the storm, so I didn't look for hidden alleys; instead, I kept running down the main street, and when I started to reach where our house was, I squinted my eyes and saw it.

en: No light there; the house all dark—which made me feel sorry and disappointed, I didn’t know why.
vi: There were no lights at all, the house was pitch dark, and I felt disheartened and disappointed, not understanding why.
tr: I couldn't see any light; the house was shrouded in darkness – seeing this, I felt overwhelmed with disappointment, though I didn't know why.
es: Not a single light; the house was completely dark, which made me feel sad and disenchanted, I don't know why.

en: But at last, just as I was sailing by, flash comes the light in Mary Jane’s window!
vi: But then, just as I passed the house, I saw a flash of light at Mary Jane's room door.
tr: But just as I was about to lose sight of the house, a light turned on in Mary Jane's window!
es: But finally, just as I was passing by, the light in Mary Jane's window suddenly turned on!

en: and my heart swelled up sudden, like to bust; and the same second the house and all was behind me in the dark, and wasn’t ever going to be before me no more in this world.
vi: My heart felt like it was going to burst. Right after that moment, the house returned to complete darkness behind me, and I saw nothing more.
tr: Suddenly, my heart started pounding with excitement; at the same time, the house and everything else remained behind me in the darkness, and I would never see that house again in my life.
es: And my heart started pounding as if it were going to burst, and a second later the house and everything else had been left behind in the darkness, and I would never see it again in this world.

en: She was the best girl I ever see, and had the most sand.
vi: I thought she was truly the most resilient girl I had ever met.
tr: Mary Jane was the best and most honest girl I had ever seen until that day.
es: She was the best girl I have ever seen in my life, and the bravest.

en: The minute I was far enough above the town to see I could make the tow-head, I begun to look sharp for a boat to borrow, and the first time the lightning showed me one that wasn’t chained I snatched it and shoved.
vi: When I had gone quite far out of town, I carefully looked to see if there was a small boat I could borrow temporarily.
tr: After advancing far enough above the town to see our little island, I started scanning the shore to find a boat to borrow; at the first flash of lightning, I saw an unchained boat; I immediately grabbed it and placed the oar.
es: As soon as I was far enough from the town to see that I could reach the sandbar, I started to carefully look for a boat to borrow, and the first one I saw in the light of a lightning bolt that wasn't chained, I got into it and pushed off.

en: It was a canoe, and warn’t fastened with nothing but a rope.
vi: Just then, lightning flashed, and I saw a boat not chained but only tied with a rope.
tr: It was a canoe and was only tied with a rope.
es: It was a canoe and it was only tied with a rope.

en: The tow-head was a rattling big distance off, away out there in the middle of the river, but I didn’t lose no time; and when I struck the raft at last I was so fagged I would a just laid down to blow and gasp if I could afforded it.
vi: I immediately jumped down and hurriedly rowed away. Reaching the raft, I was already exhausted, just wanting to lie down and catch my breath for a moment.
tr: The little island was quite far, somewhere in the middle of the river, but I didn't waste any time; when I finally reached the raft, I was so exhausted that if I had time, I would have immediately lain down to catch my breath for a while.
es: The sandbar was quite far, out there in the middle of the river, but I didn't waste any time, and when I finally reached the raft I was so exhausted that if I could have, I would have stayed there lying down to catch my breath.

en: But I didn’t.
vi: But as soon as I climbed up, I called out:
tr: But I didn't have time.
es: But I couldn't.

en: As I sprung aboard I sung out:
vi: But as soon as I climbed up, I called out:
tr: As soon as I jumped onto the raft, I called out:
es: As I jumped on board, I shouted:

en: “Out with you, Jim, and set her loose!
vi: - Jim, come here, let's set the raft off right away!
tr: "We're leaving immediately, Jim, untie the ropes!"
es: —Get out, Jim, and cast off the lines!

en: Glory be to goodness, we’re shut of them!”
vi: We're so lucky, we've escaped from them.
tr: "May God help us, I think we've escaped from them!""
es: Thank God, we've gotten rid of them!

en: Jim lit out, and was a-coming for me with both arms spread, he was so full of joy; but when I glimpsed him in the lightning my heart shot up in my mouth and I went overboard backwards; for I forgot he was old King Lear and a drownded A-rab all in one, and it most scared the livers and lights out of me.
vi: Jim came out, spreading his arms wide to hug me. He was extremely happy, but when there was a flash of light, I suddenly fell silent, looked at him, and stepped back. I had forgotten that he was pretending to be the dead Arab.
tr: Jim suddenly appeared and approached me with open arms joyfully; but when I saw him in the lightning's flash, my heart leapt into my mouth and I stepped back and fell off the raft; because I had forgotten that he was in the guise of both the old King Lear and the drowned Arab, I was almost scared out of my wits.
es: Jim came running and was approaching me with open arms of joy, but when I saw him in the light of a lightning bolt, my heart jumped into my mouth and I fell into the water on my back, for I had forgotten that he was King Lear and a drowned Arab, all at the same time, and it gave me a mortal fright.

en: But Jim fished me out, and was going to hug me and bless me, and so on, he was so glad I was back and we was shut of the king and the duke, but I says:
vi: But Jim didn't care, he just hugged me tightly, happy for me. He was overjoyed to see that I had returned and escaped from the two swindlers. But I said:
tr: Luckily, Jim pulled me out of the water, he wanted to hug me and pray, he was so happy that I had returned and escaped from the king and the duke, but I stopped him:
es: But Jim pulled me out of the water and was about to hug me and bless me, and all that out of joy at seeing that I had returned and that we had gotten rid of the king and the duke, but I went and said:

en: “Not now; have it for breakfast, have it for breakfast!
vi: - Let's talk later!
tr: “Jim, save all of this for the morning, save everything for the morning!
es: —Not now, let's leave it for breakfast, for breakfast!

en: Cut loose and let her slide!”
vi: Untie the raft and let's go!
tr: Untie the rope so we can get out of here!”
es: Cut the moorings and let the raft slide!

en: So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it did seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us.
vi: So, just two seconds later, we were drifting down the river, feeling happy to be free again, alone on the big river, without anyone disturbing us anymore!
tr: Two seconds later, we had started drifting down the river; how wonderful it was to be free again, to be on our own in the vast river, and for no one to disturb us.
es: So in two seconds we were going down the river and the truth was that it felt good to be free again and alone on the great river without anyone bothering us.

en: I had to skip around a bit, and jump up and crack my heels a few times—I couldn’t help it; but about the third crack I noticed a sound that I knowed mighty well, and held my breath and listened and waited; and sure enough, when the next flash busted out over the water, here they come!
vi: I had to jump up a few times and click my heels for a bit because I couldn't see. But when I clicked my heels for the third time, I heard a familiar sound. I held my breath, listened, and waited to see.
tr: I was so excited that I couldn't stay still; I started spinning on the raft, jumping and clicking my heels together in the air, but when I clicked my heels together for the third time, I heard a very familiar sound – I immediately held my breath and started listening – it was very clear, the next flash of lightning illuminated the surface of the water, here they were coming!
es: I started jumping and running around and clicking my heels in the air a few times, because I couldn't help it; but by the third time I heard a noise I knew very well, and I held my breath and listened to see what was happening, and sure enough, when the next flash of lightning burst over the water, there they were!, rowing so hard that their boat was speeding like a bullet!

en: —and just a-laying to their oars and making their skiff hum!
vi: Just as a flash of lightning lit up the water, I saw them sitting with oars in hand, pushing the boat forward.
tr: – they were rowing with all their might, practically making the boat fly!
es: I started jumping and running around and clicking my heels in the air a few times, because I couldn't help it; but by the third time I heard a noise I knew very well, and I held my breath and listened to see what was happening, and sure enough, when the next flash of lightning burst over the water, there they were!, rowing so hard that their boat was speeding like a bullet!

en: It was the king and the duke.
vi: It was the king with the duke.
tr: The king and the duke were right behind us.
es: They were the king and the duke.

en: So I wilted right down on to the planks then, and give up; and it was all I could do to keep from crying.
vi: I collapsed onto the raft. I did so just to keep myself from bursting into tears.
tr: At that moment, my knees gave way, I collapsed onto the planks and surrendered. I made a great effort not to sob uncontrollably.
es: So I collapsed in a heap among the trunks and gave up on everything; I had to hold back a lot to keep from bursting into tears.

en: CHAPTER XXX.
vi: Chapter XXX
tr: Thirtieth Chapter
es: Chapter 30

en: When they got aboard the king went for me, and shook me by the collar, and says:
vi: As soon as he got onto the raft, the king immediately came to me, grabbed my collar, and asked:
tr: When they left the room, the king immediately grabbed my throat and started shaking me:
es: WHEN THEY GOT on board, the king threw himself at me, grabbed me by the collar of my shirt, and said:

en: “Tryin’ to give us the slip, was ye, you pup!
vi: - Are you planning to abandon us, child?
tr: “So you were trying to get rid of us, you son of a dog!
es: —So, trying to escape, little boy!

en: Tired of our company, hey?”
vi: Are you tired of us already?
tr: Were you getting tired of us, huh?”
es: You had gotten tired of us, hadn't you?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: "No; your majesty," I said.
es: And I replied:

en: “No, your majesty, we warn’t—please don’t, your majesty!”
vi: - Yes, sir, no. I beg you, sir
tr: "We are not bored with you... Please don't do it, your majesty!"
es: —No, Your Majesty, it is not like that... Please, stop, Your Majesty!

en: “Quick, then, and tell us what was your idea, or I’ll shake the insides out o’ you!”
vi: - So, what are you planning to do? Speak quickly, or I'll skin you right now.
tr: “Then what was on your mind, quickly tell me, or I'll rip your liver out!”
es: —Then, quickly tell us what you were planning to do, or I'll rip your guts out piece by piece!

en: “Honest, I’ll tell you everything just as it happened, your majesty.
vi: - I will tell you everything that happened.
tr: “Alright, alright, I will tell you everything as it is, honestly, your majesty.
es: —Honestly, I am going to tell you exactly what happened, Your Majesty.

en: The man that had a-holt of me was very good to me, and kept saying he had a boy about as big as me that died last year, and he was sorry to see a boy in such a dangerous fix; and when they was all took by surprise by finding the gold, and made a rush for the coffin, he lets go of me and whispers, ‘Heel it now, or they’ll hang ye, sure!’ and I lit out.
vi: The man who held my hand, he was very kind, saying that he also had a child as old as me who died last year, so when he saw me in danger, he felt compassion. When everyone was clamoring because they saw the money bundle in the coffin, he let go of my hand and whispered: "Run, or they'll hang you."
tr: The man who held me treated me very well, he kept saying that he had a son around my age but he died last year, he was very upset to see a child in such a dangerous situation; when the gold was found and everyone rushed towards the coffin, he let me go and whispered: “Run away now, or they will definitely hang you!”
es: The man who was holding me was very kind to me and kept saying that he had a son my age who had died last year and that it was very sad for him to see a boy in such a dangerous situation, and when they were surprised to find the gold and rushed towards the coffin, he let me go and said: "Run away, or they will surely hang you," and I took off.

en: It didn’t seem no good for me to stay—I couldn’t do nothing, and I didn’t want to be hung if I could get away.
vi: So I ran. I couldn't do anything else.
tr: So I ran away. There was no point in staying there – I couldn’t do anything and I didn’t want to stay and get hanged when I could escape.
es: It didn't seem to make any sense to stay... I couldn't do anything and I didn't want to be hanged if I could avoid it.

en: So I never stopped running till I found the canoe; and when I got here I told Jim to hurry, or they’d catch me and hang me yet, and said I was afeard you and the duke wasn’t alive now, and I was awful sorry, and so was Jim, and was awful glad when we see you coming; you may ask Jim if I didn’t.”
vi: I just kept running until I found the boat, then went to the raft and told Jim to get away quickly or they'd catch me and hang me. I kept worrying about you and the duke, and so did Jim. Ask Jim if it's true.
tr: So I ran until I found a canoe; when I got here, I told Jim to hurry, otherwise they would catch and hang me, I told him that you and the duke were no longer alive, I was very upset, Jim was upset too, when we saw you coming, we were so happy that we didn’t know what to do, if you don’t believe me, ask Jim.”
es: So I didn't stop running until I found the canoe, and when I got here I told Jim to hurry or they might still come to catch and hang me, and I said that I feared the duke and you might no longer be alive and I got very sad, just like Jim; that's why I was so happy to see you arrive; ask Jim if it's not true.

en: Jim said it was so; and the king told him to shut up, and said, “Oh, yes, it’s mighty likely!” and shook me up again, and said he reckoned he’d drownd me.
vi: Jim also said the same thing. The king shouted at Jim and then grabbed my neck, threatening to drown me in the river.
tr: Jim confirmed me too, but the king told him to shut up and turned back to me: "Of course, I believed it too!" Then he started shaking me again and said the best thing would be to strangle me.
es: Jim said that it was so, and the king told him to shut his mouth and added: "Ah, yes, sure!", and he shook me again and said that he was thinking of drowning me.

en: But the duke says:
vi: But the duke intervened.
tr: But the duke intervened:
es: But the duke goes and says:

en: “Leggo the boy, you old idiot!
vi: - Let the boy go!
tr: "Leave the child, you old fool!
es: —Let go of the boy, you old fool!

en: Would you a done any different?
vi: I ask you, when you escaped, did you think about him?
tr: Would you have acted any differently?
es: Would you have done anything different?

en: Did you inquire around for him when you got loose?
vi: I ask you, when you escaped, did you think about him?
tr: Did you check where he was when he was free?
es: Did you ask about him when you left?

en: I don’t remember it.”
vi: Probably not.
tr: I don't remember at all."
es: I don't remember that.

en: So the king let go of me, and begun to cuss that town and everybody in it.
vi: The king released me, then cursed the town and everyone in it.
tr: The king left me and started cursing the town and everyone in it.
es: So the king let me go and started cursing that town and all its inhabitants.

en: But the duke says:
vi: But the duke said:
tr: But the duke opposed again:
es: But the duke goes and says: —You'd better curse yourself because you deserve it the most.

en: “You better a blame sight give yourself a good cussing, for you’re the one that’s entitled to it most.
vi: - You should curse yourself instead, because you are the one most deserving of curses.
tr: “You should actually curse yourself, because you are the one who deserves the curse the most.
es: But the duke goes and says: —You'd better curse yourself because you deserve it the most.

en: You hain’t done a thing from the start that had any sense in it, except coming out so cool and cheeky with that imaginary blue-arrow mark.
vi: From beginning to end, you haven't accomplished anything worthwhile, except for calmly thinking of the green arrow on the chest of the dead person.
tr: From the beginning, you did nothing that made any sense; your only useful move was fabricating that imaginary blue arrow sign with cold-bloodedness and brazenness.
es: From the beginning, you haven't done a single sensible thing, except when you calmly made up that story about the blue arrow tattoo.

en: That was bright—it was right down bully; and it was the thing that saved us.
vi: If not, they would have detained us, waiting for the Englishmen's luggage to arrive, and then we would be in jail!
tr: It was a brilliant idea – truly wonderful; it was what saved us.
es: That was really good; it was phenomenal. And it was what saved us.

en: For if it hadn’t been for that, they’d a jailed us till them Englishmen’s baggage come—and then—the penitentiary, you bet!
vi: After that, the bundle of money saved us once again.
tr: Otherwise, they would have locked us up somewhere until the Englishman's belongings arrived, and then we would have ended up in jail!
es: Because if it hadn't been for that, they would have put us in jail until the Englishmen's luggage arrived, and then, I bet from there to the penitentiary!

en: But that trick took ’em to the graveyard, and the gold done us a still bigger kindness; for if the excited fools hadn’t let go all holts and made that rush to get a look, we’d a slept in our cravats to-night—cravats warranted to wear, too—longer than we’d need ’em.”
vi: If those madmen hadn't stormed off, tonight you and I would be tying our ties and sleeping forever.
tr: We would have stayed there for life, God knows. But thanks to that trick, they went all the way to the cemetery, and the bag of gold did us an even greater favor; because if those fools hadn't left us in their excitement and rushed towards the grave, we would be sleeping with our neckties on tonight – the mandatory ones – and we would have worn them for much longer than we needed to.”
es: But that trick made them go to the cemetery and the gold thing worked out even better for us, because if they hadn't gotten so nervous and let us go when they rushed to see what was there, tonight we would have slept with ties on, and ties that last forever, which is more than we wanted.

en: They was still a minute—thinking; then the king says, kind of absent-minded like:
vi: They were silent for a moment, then the king said absentmindedly:
tr: They paused for a moment and thought, then the king said absentmindedly:
es: They remained silent for a moment, thinking; then the king goes and says, as if remembering something:

en: “Mf!
vi: - And yet, I mistakenly thought that the black people were stealing.
tr: “We thought the gold was stolen by the blacks!”
es: —Wow!

en: And we reckoned the niggers stole it!”
vi: - And yet, I mistakenly thought that the black people were stealing.
tr: “We thought the gold was stolen by the blacks!”
es: And we thought it had been stolen by the black people!

en: That made me squirm!
vi: I was startled.
tr: I shuddered when I heard this!
es: I got extremely nervous!

en: “Yes,” says the duke, kinder slow and deliberate and sarcastic, “We did.”
vi: The Duke said bitterly: - Yes, I thought so too.
tr: “Yes, indeed,” said the duke, slowly, with a meaningful and mocking tone. “That's what we thought.”
es: —Yes —says the duke, slowly and sarcastically—, that's what we thought.

en: After about a half a minute the king drawls out:
vi: About half a minute later, the king spoke again:
tr: After thinking for about half a minute, the king spoke again:
es: After half a minute, the king blurts out:

en: “Leastways, I did.”
vi: - at least, that's what I think.
tr: “At least… that's what I thought.”
es: —At least, that's what I thought.

en: The duke says, the same way:
vi: The Duke spoke, in the same tone as the king:
tr: The Duke replied in the same manner:
es: The duke says, in the same tone:

en: “On the contrary, I did.”
vi: - I thought so too.
tr: “On the contrary… I thought so.”
es: —On the contrary, I was thinking it.

en: The king kind of ruffles up, and says:
vi: The king seemed to snap:
tr: The king suddenly straightened up:
es: The king gets irritated and says:

en: “Looky here, Bilgewater, what’r you referrin’ to?”
vi: - Hey, Bilgewater, what do you think that means?
tr: “Look at me, Bridgewater, what do you mean?”
es: —Look, Aguassucias, what do you mean?

en: The duke says, pretty brisk:
vi: The Duke replied irritably:
tr: The Duke immediately retorted:
es: And the duke replies, very firmly:

en: “When it comes to that, maybe you’ll let me ask, what was you referring to?”
vi: - So what are you trying to say?
tr: "Actually, I should be the one asking this, what did you mean?"
es: —If we get into that, perhaps you'll allow me to ask what you were referring to.

en: “Shucks!” says the king, very sarcastic; “but I don’t know—maybe you was asleep, and didn’t know what you was about.”
vi: The king sarcastically said: - Perhaps at that moment you were still drowsy and didn't know what you were supposed to be doing.
tr: "For God's sake!" said the king mockingly; "I have no idea... Maybe you are a sleepwalker and were not aware of what you were doing."
es: —Gosh! —says the king, very sarcastically—, well I don't know: maybe you were asleep and didn't know what you were doing.

en: The duke bristles up now, and says:
vi: The Duke jumped up:
tr: The Duke suddenly fumed:
es: Then the duke got really angry and replied:

en: “Oh, let up on this cussed nonsense; do you take me for a blame’ fool?
vi: - Oh, do you think I'm crazy?
tr: “Keep your damn nonsense to yourself; do you think I'm a fool?
es: —Well, enough of this nonsense. Do you take me for a fool?

en: Don’t you reckon I know who hid that money in that coffin?”
vi: Do you think I don't know who hid the money in that coffin?
tr: Do you think I don't know who hid the money in the coffin?”
es: Do you think I don't know who hid the money in the coffin?

en: “Yes, sir!
vi: - Of course you know because you hid it there yourself
tr: “Yes, sir!
es: —Yes, sir!

en: I know you do know, because you done it yourself!”
vi: - Nonsense!
tr: I am aware that you know, because you are the one hiding the money!”
es: I know you know it because you did it yourself! —Lies!

en: “It’s a lie!”—and the duke went for him.
vi: The Duke charged forward.
tr: “A blatant lie!” The Duke suddenly lunged at him.
es: —and the duke lunges at him.

en: The king sings out:
vi: The King cried out:
tr: The King began to shout:
es: The king shouts:

en: “Take y’r hands off!—leggo my throat!
vi: - Let go of me! Don't choke me like that.
tr: "Get your hands off me!.. Stop choking me!.. I take back everything I said!"
es: —Take those hands off! Let go of my neck!

en: —I take it all back!”
vi: I can't speak anymore.
tr: "Get your hands off me!.. Stop choking me!.. I take back everything I said!"
es: I take it all back!

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke said:
tr: “First, admit your crime,” said the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Well, you just own up, first, that you did hide that money there, intending to give me the slip one of these days, and come back and dig it up, and have it all to yourself.”
vi: - It was you who kept the money, then you yourself buried it there, planning to dig it up alone when the opportunity arose.
tr: “Say that you hid the money there, planned to leave me after a few days, return, and dig up the money.”
es: —Well, first you have to confess that you hid that money, and that you were planning to leave me one of these days and come back to dig it up and keep it all for yourself.

en: “Wait jest a minute, duke—answer me this one question, honest and fair; if you didn’t put the money there, say it, and I’ll b’lieve you, and take back everything I said.”
vi: - Wait, Duke, please answer me this question honestly. If you hid the money there, just say so, I will believe you and forget everything that happened until now.
tr: “Wait a moment, Duke… Just answer one question honestly; if you didn't put the money there, tell me, and I will believe you and take back everything I said.”
es: —Man, one minute, duke: answer this question, with all sincerity: if you didn't put the money there, say so and I will believe you and take back everything I've said.

en: “You old scoundrel, I didn’t, and you know I didn’t.
vi: - Old man, I'm not hiding, there's no way I would do that.
tr: “You old swindler, of course I didn't put it, and you know it very well.
es: —You old scoundrel, it wasn't me and you know it.

en: There, now!”
vi: - Old man, I'm not hiding, there's no way I would do that.
tr: Got it?”
es: Let that be clear!

en: “Well, then, I b’lieve you.
vi: - Alright, I believe you.
tr: “Okay, I believe you too.
es: —Well, then I believe you.

en: But answer me only jest this one more—now don’t git mad; didn’t you have it in your mind to hook the money and hide it?”
vi: But answer me one more question, deep down, did you ever think about taking the money and the papers away?
tr: But answer one more question for me… but answer without getting angry; did it never cross your mind to take the money and hide it?”
es: But answer me just one more thing, and don't get angry. Didn't it occur to you to take the money and hide it?

en: The duke never said nothing for a little bit; then he says:
vi: The duke said nothing, and only after a while did he respond:
tr: The Duke couldn't respond for a while; then he said:
es: The duke remained silent for a moment and replied:

en: “Well, I don’t care if I did, I didn’t do it, anyway.
vi: - If you think that way, it's okay.
tr: “Even if I thought about it, it doesn't matter, I didn't do it in the end.
es: —Well, it doesn't matter whether I thought of it or not, because in any case, I didn't do it.

en: But you not only had it in mind to do it, but you done it.”
vi: As for you, not only do you think that way, but you also act that way.
tr: But you didn't just think about it, you did it too.”
es: But you not only thought of it, but you did it.

en: “I wisht I never die if I done it, duke, and that’s honest.
vi: - I swear, if I do that, I will die immediately.
tr: “If I did it, may I never breathe again, duke, I am telling the truth.
es: —May I die if it was me, duke, and I tell you the truth.

en: I won’t say I warn’t goin’ to do it, because I was; but you—I mean somebody—got in ahead o’ me.”
vi: I did think about it, but you or someone else already did it before me.
tr: I am not saying I didn't think about doing it, because I did; but you…I mean someone else… Acted before me.”
es: I'm not saying I wouldn't have done it, because that would be a lie, but you —or whoever it was— beat me to it.

en: “It’s a lie!
vi: I did think about it, but you or someone else already did it before me.
tr: “You're lying again!
es: —Liar!

en: You done it, and you got to say you done it, or—”
vi: - Hmph, it was you who stole, you must confess.
tr: You did it and you will admit it, or else…”
es: It was you and you have to say it or...

en: The king began to gurgle, and then he gasps out:
vi: The king stammered and then sighed:
tr: The king had started to make wheezing sounds, finally he spoke breathlessly:
es: The king began to gurgle and then gasped:

en: “’Nough!—I own up!”
vi: - Yes, then I'll take it.
tr: “Alright!.. I did it!”
es: —Enough! I confess!

en: I was very glad to hear him say that; it made me feel much more easier than what I was feeling before.
vi: I was overjoyed when I heard the king say that.
tr: Hearing him say this had made me very happy; I felt much lighter compared to before.
es: I was very happy when he said it; it made me feel much calmer than before.

en: So the duke took his hands off and says:
vi: The duke let go of the old man and said:
tr: Thus, the duke withdrew his hands and said:
es: So the duke took his hands off him and says:

en: “If you ever deny it again I’ll drown you.
vi: - If you keep denying it, I'll drown you.
tr: “If you deny your crime again, I will drown you in the water.
es: —If you deny it again, I'll drown you.

en: It’s well for you to set there and blubber like a baby—it’s fitten for you, after the way you’ve acted.
vi: Now, you're still sitting there crying like a child!
tr: You deserve to sit here and cry like a baby... After what you've done, this is too little for you.
es: It's very well that you stay there sitting and crying like a child. It's what you deserve after what you've done.

en: I never see such an old ostrich for wanting to gobble everything—and I a-trusting you all the time, like you was my own father.
vi: I've never met an old man as greedy as you. Yet, I always trusted you like my own father.
tr: I've never seen an old ostrich like you who is out to devour everything – yet I always trusted you, I considered you like my own father. If I were in your place, I would wish the ground would swallow me up.
es: In my life, I've never seen even an ostrich swallow everything, and I trusted you all the time, as if you were my own father.

en: You ought to been ashamed of yourself to stand by and hear it saddled on to a lot of poor niggers, and you never say a word for ’em.
vi: You should be ashamed when you see innocent black people being blamed.
tr: You are so cruel that you wouldn't object to blaming your crime on poor black people.
es: You should be ashamed of yourself for staying there and hearing how they blamed a bunch of poor black people, without saying a word for them.

en: It makes me feel ridiculous to think I was soft enough to believe that rubbage.
vi: Honestly, I was foolish to believe in those tricks.
tr: The foolishness is on me for being naive enough to believe your nonsense.
es: I feel ridiculous remembering that I was such an idiot to believe that stupidity.

en: Cuss you, I can see now why you was so anxious to make up the deffisit—you wanted to get what money I’d got out of the Nonesuch and one thing or another, and scoop it all!”
vi: Now I understand that you made up the story about missing money so that I would give up the money I earned from the play, and you could take it all.
tr: Damn you, now I understand why you were so eager to cover it up... You had your eyes on the money I earned from Curcuna and other jobs, you were after taking it all!”
es: Damn you, now I understand why you were so willing to fix the deficit: you wanted to keep the money that I had taken from the "unparalleled" and with one thing and another, keep everything.

en: The king says, timid, and still a-snuffling:
vi: The king sniffled and replied:
tr: The king, still sniffling, began to speak hesitantly: "But it was you who suggested making up the deficiency, duke, not me."
es: The king goes and says, all timid and still with a breathless voice:

en: “Why, duke, it was you that said make up the deffisit; it warn’t me.”
vi: - It was you who came up with that idea of covering the cost, not me.
tr: The king, still sniffling, began to speak hesitantly: "But it was you who suggested making up the deficiency, duke, not me."
es: —But, Duke, it was you who mentioned compensating for the deficit, not me.

en: “Dry up!
vi: - Shut up.
tr: “Shut up!
es: —Shut up!

en: I don’t want to hear no more out of you!” says the duke.
vi: I don't want to hear you talk anymore!
tr: I don't want to hear you talk anymore!” said the duke.
es: I don't want to hear a single word from you! —says the duke—.

en: “And now you see what you got by it.
vi: Now you see the result.
tr: “Do you see what you've achieved now?
es: And now look at what you've done.

en: They’ve got all their own money back, and all of ourn but a shekel or two besides.
vi: They have gotten back all their money and even more from us.
tr: Not only did they take back all their money, but they also seized our meager possessions.
es: They've recovered all the money, and on top of that, ours too, except for a few pennies.

en: G’long to bed, and don’t you deffersit me no more deffersits, long ’s you live!”
vi: Now go to sleep. As long as you are alive, don't do anything that harms my money anymore!
tr: Go to bed now...
es: Go to sleep and don't ever talk to me about deficit or no deficit in your entire life!

en: So the king sneaked into the wigwam and took to his bottle for comfort, and before long the duke tackled his bottle; and so in about a half an hour they was as thick as thieves again, and the tighter they got, the lovinger they got, and went off a-snoring in each other’s arms.
vi: So the king crawled into the tent, grabbed a bottle of wine, and took a swig. Then the duke also grabbed another bottle. About half an hour later, the two scoundrels were friendly with each other again as usual, hugging each other to sleep, snoring loudly.
tr: And don't ever talk to me about making up for anything ever again in your life!” The king quietly took the bottle of liquor and went into the shelter; soon after, the duke also started drinking from his own bottle; about half an hour later, they were on good terms again, even their bonds had strengthened and become more affectionate; they fell asleep in each other's arms and started snoring.
es: So the king went back to the wigwam and sought company in his bottle, and shortly after the duke started on his, and after about half an hour they were friends again, and the more friendly they got, the more affectionate they became, until they ended up snoring, embraced with each other.

en: They both got powerful mellow, but I noticed the king didn’t get mellow enough to forget to remember to not deny about hiding the money-bag again.
vi: Both of them calmed down, but I noticed that the king wasn't quite at ease yet about not being able to deny hiding the bundle of money.
tr: Both of them seemed to be in high spirits, but the king didn't get drunk enough to deny hiding the money bag again.
es: The two became very talkative, but I saw that the king wasn't so far gone as to forget that he shouldn't repeat that he wasn't the one who had hidden the bag with the money.

en: That made me feel easy and satisfied.
vi: That made me very pleased.
tr: This made me feel more at ease and happy.
es: That made me feel calm and satisfied.

en: Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.
vi: We waited until they were snoring loudly, then we sat down and talked to each other, and I recounted the entire story to Jim.
tr: When they started snoring, Jim and I, of course, talked for a long time, and I told him everything.
es: Naturally, when they started snoring, we talked for a long time and I told Jim everything.

en: CHAPTER XXXI.
vi: Chapter XXXI
tr: Chapter Thirty-One
es: Chapter 31

en: We dasn’t stop again at any town for days and days; kept right along down the river.
vi: For many days after that, we didn't dare stop in any town, but kept going straight ahead.
tr: We did not stop in the towns for days again, we went down the river without stopping.
es: FOR DAYS AND DAYS we did not dare to stop in any other town, but continued down the river.

en: We was down south in the warm weather now, and a mighty long ways from home.
vi: We headed south, where the climate was warm and it was also quite far from home.
tr: We had now moved well south, the weather had warmed up, and we were far from home.
es: We had already reached the South, where it was hot and we were very far from home.

en: We begun to come to trees with Spanish moss on them, hanging down from the limbs like long, gray beards.
vi: The trees were dense, with vines hanging from large branches, looking like long gray nets.
tr: We had started to see trees covered with Spanish moss, the moss hanging from the branches like long gray beards.
es: We began to find trees full of black moss, which hung from the branches like large gray beards.

en: It was the first I ever see it growing, and it made the woods look solemn and dismal.
vi: It was the first time I saw those trees, and it seemed to make the forest even more solemn and sorrowful.
tr: I was seeing this moss for the first time, it had given the forest a very solemn and gloomy atmosphere.
es: It was the first time I had seen them, and it gave the forest a solemn and sad appearance.

en: So now the frauds reckoned they was out of danger, and they begun to work the villages again.
vi: By this point, the two swindlers thought the danger was over, so they went into the villages to scavenge again.
tr: Our swindlers, thinking they were now far enough from danger, started doing business in the towns again.
es: The scoundrels figured they were out of danger and started working in the towns again.

en: First they done a lecture on temperance; but they didn’t make enough for them both to get drunk on.
vi: At first, they talked about alcohol addiction, but they couldn't even make enough money to buy alcohol for themselves to drink.
tr: First, they organized a meeting against alcohol, but they didn't even get enough money to get drunk.
es: First, they gave a lecture on temperance; but they didn't make enough to get the two of them drunk.

en: Then in another village they started a dancing-school; but they didn’t know no more how to dance than a kangaroo does; so the first prance they made the general public jumped in and pranced them out of town.
vi: When they reached another village, they opened a dance class, but they only danced like kangaroos, so the public just joined in and chased them away immediately.
tr: They established a dance school in another town; but they knew less about dancing than kangaroos; so the moment they started jumping around awkwardly, the townspeople intervened and chased them out of town.
es: Then, in another town, they opened a dance school, but they danced worse than a kangaroo, so at the first pirouette the audience turned on them and expelled them from the town.

en: Another time they tried to go at yellocution; but they didn’t yellocute long till the audience got up and give them a solid good cussing, and made them skip out.
vi: Another time, they tried to give a speech, but after just a few sentences, the audience stood up and cursed them out, then kicked them out.
tr: Then they started a public speaking course, but since they couldn't speak very well, the audience cursed and chased them away.
es: Another time they tried to give elocution lessons, but they didn't "elocute" much, because the audience got up and started cursing them and made them leave.

en: They tackled missionarying, and mesmerizing, and doctoring, and telling fortunes, and a little of everything; but they couldn’t seem to have no luck.
vi: They also tried preaching, hypnosis, healing, and fortune-telling, each a little bit, but it seemed like all these attempts were unlucky.
tr: They tried missionary work, spiritualism, medicine, and fortune-telling; they did everything a little bit, but it seemed their luck had run out.
es: They tried being missionaries, hypnotists, doctors, fortune-tellers, and a bit of everything, but it seemed they had no luck.

en: So at last they got just about dead broke, and laid around the raft as she floated along, thinking and thinking, and never saying nothing, by the half a day at a time, and dreadful blue and desperate.
vi: In the end, they were so bored that they lay on the raft for half a day without saying a word, looking very sad and disappointed.
tr: Finally, they were left penniless, lying on a raft slowly drifting down the river, spending half the day thinking without speaking, looking terribly unhappy and hopeless.
es: So, finally, they were practically out of money and did nothing but lie on the raft as it floated downstream, thinking and thinking, without saying a word all day, very sad and desperate.

en: And at last they took a change and begun to lay their heads together in the wigwam and talk low and confidential two or three hours at a time.
vi: In the end, they huddled together and discussed something for two or three hours, looking very secretive.
tr: After a while, things started to change; every day, they would huddle together in the shelter for two or three hours, whispering secretly.
es: Finally, they started to change and began talking in the wigwam in a low and confidential tone for two or three hours straight.

en: Jim and me got uneasy.
vi: Jim and I were worried, surely they were plotting something nefarious again.
tr: Jim and I were on edge.
es: Jim and I got nervous.

en: We didn’t like the look of it.
vi: After thinking for a while, we guessed that they were planning to break into a house or a shop, or perhaps they were about to counterfeit money.
tr: Their intentions didn't seem very good.
es: We didn't like it.

en: We judged they was studying up some kind of worse deviltry than ever.
vi: After thinking for a while, we guessed that they were planning to break into a house or a shop, or perhaps they were about to counterfeit money.
tr: We thought they were making a more diabolical plan than ever.
es: We thought they were planning something worse than before.

en: We turned it over and over, and at last we made up our minds they was going to break into somebody’s house or store, or was going into the counterfeit-money business, or something.
vi: After thinking for a while, we guessed that they were planning to break into a house or a shop, or perhaps they were about to counterfeit money.
tr: After talking amongst ourselves many times, we decided that they were either going to rob someone's house or shop, or maybe even print counterfeit money.
es: We talked about it many times and finally decided that they were going to rob someone's house or store, or that they were planning to counterfeit money, or something similar.

en: So then we was pretty scared, and made up an agreement that we wouldn’t have nothing in the world to do with such actions, and if we ever got the least show we would give them the cold shake and clear out and leave them behind.
vi: So we got really scared and agreed that we would definitely not get involved in their actions, and if possible, we would run away immediately.
tr: We were both scared of this, and we swore that we would never get involved in such crimes, even if it killed us; at the first opportunity, we would get rid of them and immediately escape, leaving them behind.
es: Then we got really scared and decided that we wouldn't have anything to do with it, and that if the slightest opportunity arose, we would sneak away and abandon them.

en: Well, early one morning we hid the raft in a good, safe place about two mile below a little bit of a shabby village named Pikesville, and the king he went ashore and told us all to stay hid whilst he went up to town and smelt around to see if anybody had got any wind of the Royal Nonesuch there yet.
vi: One early morning, we hid the raft in a safe place, two miles away from a shabby village named Pikesville.
tr: In the morning, we hid our raft in a safe place about two miles down from a rundown town called Pikesville; the king went ashore and told us to hide until he scouted the town to see if there was any news of the Royal Nonesuch here.
es: Well, one early morning we hid the raft in a good, safe spot, about two miles below a village called Pikesville, and the king went ashore and told us all to stay hidden while he went to town to see if anyone had found out about "The Royal Nonesuch" ("a house to rob, that's what you mean," I said to myself, "and when you're done robbing it, you're going to come back and wonder what happened to me and Jim and the raft, and you can wait for us sitting down").

en: (“House to rob, you mean,” says I to myself; “and when you get through robbing it you’ll come back here and wonder what has become of me and Jim and the raft—and you’ll have to take it out in wondering.”)
vi: The Duke went ashore, instructing us to hide and wait for him to go to town to see if there was any gossip about the Royal Nonesuch performance.
tr: ("That means until you find a house to rob," I muttered; "then you'll come back here after robbing the house, and when you don't see anyone, you'll wonder what happened to me, Jim, and the raft... wonder all you want.")
es: Well, one early morning we hid the raft in a good, safe spot, about two miles below a village called Pikesville, and the king went ashore and told us all to stay hidden while he went to town to see if anyone had found out about "The Royal Nonesuch" ("a house to rob, that's what you mean," I said to myself, "and when you're done robbing it, you're going to come back and wonder what happened to me and Jim and the raft, and you can wait for us sitting down").

en: And he said if he warn’t back by midday the duke and me would know it was all right, and we was to come along.
vi: He said that if he didn't return by noon, the Duke and I would follow him.
tr: The king also said that if he didn't return by noon, the duke and I should understand that everything was fine and go into town.
es: And he said that if he didn't come back by noon, the duke and I would know that everything was fine and we should meet up with him.

en: So we stayed where we was.
vi: The duke seemed restless and irritable.
tr: Thus, we continued to wait where we were.
es: So we stayed where we were.

en: The duke he fretted and sweated around, and was in a mighty sour way.
vi: The duke seemed restless and irritable.
tr: The duke was wandering around restlessly and kept making faces.
es: The duke was nervous, sweaty, and in a terrible mood.

en: He scolded us for everything, and we couldn’t seem to do nothing right; he found fault with every little thing.
vi: He scolded us over the smallest things.
tr: He was scolding us for everything, as if he thought we couldn't do anything right; he found fault in even the smallest things.
es: He scolded us for everything and nothing we did seemed right to him; he found everything wrong.

en: Something was a-brewing, sure.
vi: Surely something is about to happen.
tr: We had no doubt that something was going on.
es: Of course, they were preparing something.

en: I was good and glad when midday come and no king; we could have a change, anyway—and maybe a chance for the change on top of it.
vi: I was very glad that by noon the king had not returned.
tr: By noon, when the king didn't come, I was very happy; at least there would be a change – maybe we could find an opportunity to make the real change we had in mind.
es: I was very glad when noon came and the king hadn't returned; now things were going to change, and maybe an opportunity would present itself.

en: So me and the duke went up to the village, and hunted around there for the king, and by-and-by we found him in the back room of a little low doggery, very tight, and a lot of loafers bullyragging him for sport, and he a-cussing and a-threatening with all his might, and so tight he couldn’t walk, and couldn’t do nothing to them.
vi: So, the duke and I went ashore and into the village to find the king. A while later, we saw him behind a fishing boat, being pushed into a cramped house, and being taunted by a gang of ruffians... He was cursing loudly and threatening those people.
tr: So, we went to town with the duke and started looking for the king. After a while, we found him in the back room of a filthy tavern, dead drunk and in trouble with a few idle men; he was cursing at the top of his lungs and threatening them, but he was so drunk that he couldn't even get up and do anything to them.
es: So the duke and I went to town and started looking for the king; after a while, we found him in the back room of a seedy tavern, half-drunk, with a bunch of drunks who were provoking him for fun while he cursed and threatened them with all his might, so drunk that he couldn't walk or do anything to them.

en: The duke he begun to abuse him for an old fool, and the king begun to sass back, and the minute they was fairly at it I lit out and shook the reefs out of my hind legs, and spun down the river road like a deer, for I see our chance; and I made up my mind that it would be a long day before they ever see me and Jim again.
vi: When the duke arrived and saw this, he said that it was just a crazy old man. The king scolded the duke back. Taking advantage of their fierce argument, I slipped away, running like the wind down the riverside road.
tr: The duke also taunted him, calling him an old fool, and the king retorted; suddenly, they started fighting! I immediately ran outside and started running as fast as I could, skipping along the river path like a deer – because we had found the chance we were looking for, and I was determined to do what was necessary so they would never see me and Jim again.
es: The duke was mocking him for being an old fool and the king responded, so as soon as I saw things heating up, I took off at full speed and ran down the river road like a deer, because I had seen our opportunity and decided that they could wait forever before seeing Jim and me again.

en: I got down there all out of breath but loaded up with joy, and sung out:
vi: I ran to the hidden raft, out of breath, but feeling very happy inside. I called out:
tr: I reached the raft's location, out of breath but filled with joy, and called out:
es: I arrived breathless but very happy and shouted:

en: “Set her loose, Jim! we’re all right now!”
vi: - Jim, let's release the raft, we're free now.
tr: “Untie it, Jim, we can go now!”
es: —Cast off the moorings, Jim; everything is set!

en: But there warn’t no answer, and nobody come out of the wigwam.
vi: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the tent.
tr: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the shelter.
es: But no one answered me nor came out of the wigwam.

en: Jim was gone!
vi: Jim was gone!
tr: Jim was not there!
es: Jim had disappeared!

en: I set up a shout—and then another—and then another one; and run this way and that in the woods, whooping and screeching; but it warn’t no use—old Jim was gone.
vi: I called out loudly once, then again - and again; ran in all directions into the forest, howling, shouting, but it was useless - Jim was lost.
tr: I called out in case he could hear… I called again, and then again; I ran frantically back and forth in the forest, but it was no use – our Jim had disappeared.
es: I shouted once, then again and again, and started running through the forest up and down, shouting and yelling, but it was all for nothing: Jim had disappeared.

en: Then I set down and cried; I couldn’t help it.
vi: I sat down and sobbed uncontrollably.
tr: I sat down and started to cry, I couldn't help it.
es: Then I sat down and started to cry; I couldn't help it.

en: But I couldn’t set still long.
vi: After a while, I returned to the main road, thinking about what to do next.
tr: But I couldn't sit for long.
es: But I couldn't stay sitting for long.

en: Pretty soon I went out on the road, trying to think what I better do, and I run across a boy walking, and asked him if he’d seen a strange nigger dressed so and so, and he says:
vi: Suddenly, I saw a boy coming from somewhere, and I asked if he had seen a black man dressed like that. He replied:
tr: After a while, I set off thinking about what I could do, and on the way, I came across a boy and asked him if he had seen a strange-looking black man dressed like this and that.
es: After a while, I went back to the path trying to think about what I should do, and I met a boy who was walking by and asked him if he had seen a strange black man dressed in such and such a way, and he goes and says:

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “I found it,” he said.
es: —Yes.

en: “Whereabouts?” says I.
vi: - So where is he? I asked:
tr: "Where?" I asked.
es: —Where? —I asked.

en: “Down to Silas Phelps’ place, two mile below here.
vi: - At Mr. Silas Phelps' house, two miles from here.
tr: “Two miles down, at Silas Phelps' place.
es: —By Silas Phelps' house, two miles down.

en: He’s a runaway nigger, and they’ve got him.
vi: He is a runaway black man; they caught him.
tr: There was a runaway negro, they caught him.
es: He's a runaway slave and they've caught him.

en: Was you looking for him?”
vi: Are you looking for him?
tr: Were you looking for that negro too?”
es: Were you looking for him?

en: “You bet I ain’t!
vi: - No, I didn't find it.
tr: “What do you mean, search for him, brother!
es: —Absolutely!

en: I run across him in the woods about an hour or two ago, and he said if I hollered he’d cut my livers out—and told me to lay down and stay where I was; and I done it.
vi: I met it in the forest two hours ago. It said if I made a sound, it would cut open my stomach, take out my liver, and make me lie down and stay still there. I had to lie down.
tr: A couple of hours ago, I ran into him in the forest, and he said if I made a sound, he would rip my lungs out. ‘Sit down where you are and don't move an inch,’ he said; so I did.
es: I found him in the forest one or two hours ago and he told me that if I screamed, he would rip out my guts and that I should stay still, where I was, which is what I did.

en: Been there ever since; afeard to come out.”
vi: Since then, I've been in the forest, too scared to come out. The boy said:
tr: I've been waiting since then, too scared to come out.”
es: I've been there since then because I was scared to leave.

en: “Well,” he says, “you needn’t be afeard no more, becuz they’ve got him.
vi: - Well, now you don't have to be afraid anymore, they have already caught it.
tr: “You don't need to be afraid anymore, because it can't do anything to you,” he said.
es: —Well —he goes and says—, you don't have to be afraid anymore because they've caught him.

en: He run off f’m down South, som’ers.”
vi: It seems like it ran towards the South.
tr: “It escaped from somewhere in the South.”
es: He escaped from I don't know where in the South.

en: “It’s a good job they got him.”
vi: - It's fortunate that it has been caught.
tr: “They've done a good job catching him, indeed.”
es: —It's a good thing they caught him.

en: “Well, I reckon!
vi: - Getting a two hundred dollar reward, that's pretty sweet.
tr: "I think so too!" "A two hundred dollar bounty has been placed on his head."
es: —Man, absolutely!

en: There’s two hunderd dollars reward on him.
vi: - Getting a two hundred dollar reward, that's pretty sweet.
tr: "I think so too!" "A two hundred dollar bounty has been placed on his head."
es: They were offering a reward of two hundred dollars for him.

en: It’s like picking up money out’n the road.”
vi: - Getting a two hundred dollar reward, that's pretty sweet.
tr: "It's like finding money on the street."
es: It's like finding money on the ground.

en: “Yes, it is—and I could a had it if I’d been big enough; I see him first.
vi: - Oh right, if I were a bit older, it wouldn't have escaped me because I was the one who met it first.
tr: “Very true... I wish I were bigger, then I would have gotten the money; I saw it first.
es: —Yes, it's true, and it could have been mine if I had been older. I saw it first.

en: Who nailed him?”
vi: So who caught it?
tr: So who caught it?”
es: Who caught it?

en: “It was an old fellow—a stranger—and he sold out his chance in him for forty dollars, becuz he’s got to go up the river and can’t wait.
vi: - An old man, then he sold it to another person for forty dollars because he had to leave immediately with his friend, so he couldn't wait.
tr: “An old man… a stranger… sold the reward money for forty dollars because he had to go upriver and couldn't wait.
es: —A strange guy, a stranger, who sold his right to him for forty dollars because he has to go upriver and can't wait.

en: Think o’ that, now!
vi: Isn't that strange?
tr: Look at that!
es: Imagine that!

en: You bet I’d wait, if it was seven year.”
vi: As for me, I would wait, even for seven years.
tr: If it were me, I would have waited even seven years.”
es: Well, I would wait even if it were seven years.

en: “That’s me, every time,” says I.
vi: - Me too.
tr: “I would have expected that too,” I said.
es: —I say the same thing —I replied—.

en: “But maybe his chance ain’t worth no more than that, if he’ll sell it so cheap.
vi: But maybe he has some unclear issues, so he sold it cheaply like that.
tr: “But maybe it doesn't fetch more money if he sold it so cheaply.
es: But maybe it's because their rights aren't worth much if they sell them for so little.

en: Maybe there’s something ain’t straight about it.”
vi: - Oh, what's unclear about this matter?
tr: Maybe there's something fishy going on.”
es: Maybe there's something illegal there.

en: “But it is, though—straight as a string.
vi: I saw the wanted poster with my own eyes, it even had its picture, saying it escaped from some plantation, seems like it was down in New Orleans.
tr: “But everything is by the book.
es: —Well, I'm telling you no, it's completely legitimate.

en: I see the handbill myself.
vi: I saw the wanted poster with my own eyes, it even had its picture, saying it escaped from some plantation, seems like it was down in New Orleans.
tr: I saw the advertisement with my own eyes.
es: I myself have seen the reward notice.

en: It tells all about him, to a dot—paints him like a picture, and tells the plantation he’s frum, below Newrleans.
vi: I saw the wanted poster with my own eyes, it even had its picture, saying it escaped from some plantation, seems like it was down in New Orleans.
tr: It describes the black man in the smallest detail, almost drawing his picture. Moreover, it also mentioned which plantation below New Orleans he belonged to.
es: It gives all the details about him, down to the last one, as if it were in a painting, and it says which plantation he comes from, beyond New Orleans.

en: No-sirree-bob, they ain’t no trouble ’bout that speculation, you bet you.
vi: Hey, do you have a cigarette?
tr: No; brother, I definitely don't think there's anything fishy going on.
es: No, sir, you can bet there's nothing strange about it.

en: Say, gimme a chaw tobacker, won’t ye?”
vi: Can I have one?
tr: If you have any, give me some chewing tobacco.”
es: Hey, give me some chewing tobacco, do you have any?

en: I didn’t have none, so he left.
vi: I said there wasn't any. So he left.
tr: I had no tobacco, the boy left.
es: I had nothing left, so he left.

en: I went to the raft, and set down in the wigwam to think.
vi: I went back to the raft, sat in the tent, and pondered.
tr: So I turned to the shack, went inside the shelter, and started thinking.
es: I went to the raft and sat in the wigwam to think.

en: But I couldn’t come to nothing.
vi: I thought so hard that my head hurt, but I still couldn't find a way to get out of this troublesome boat.
tr: Nothing came to my mind.
es: But nothing came to mind.

en: I thought till I wore my head sore, but I couldn’t see no way out of the trouble.
vi: I thought so hard that my head hurt, but I still couldn't find a way to get out of this troublesome boat.
tr: I thought until my head was about to burst, but I couldn't find a way out of this trouble.
es: I thought until my head hurt, but I couldn't see a way out of that problem.

en: After all this long journey, and after all we’d done for them scoundrels, here it was all come to nothing, everything all busted up and ruined, because they could have the heart to serve Jim such a trick as that, and make him a slave again all his life, and amongst strangers, too, for forty dirty dollars.
vi: After a long and arduous journey, after so many hardships with those swindlers, now it seemed like we were getting nowhere.
tr: This long journey, all the things we did for those two swindlers, had been in vain, everything was ruined; because they were treacherous enough to play such a trick on Jim; to make him a lifelong slave among strangers for just forty dollars.
es: After all the journey and what we had done for those heartless people, everything had ended, everything had fallen apart and been destroyed, because they had the bad blood to play such a trick on Jim and turn him back into a slave for his entire life, and on top of that among strangers, for forty filthy dollars.

en: Once I said to myself it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home where his family was, as long as he’d got to be a slave, and so I’d better write a letter to Tom Sawyer and tell him to tell Miss Watson where he was.
vi: They were willing to play such a trick on Jim for just forty dollars and make him a slave again; being a slave near his home would be a thousand times better than in a strange place. So, I decided to write a letter to Tom Sawyer to tell him to inform Miss Watson where Jim was.
tr: When I thought that if Jim was going to remain a slave where his family found him, it would be a thousand times better for him to be a slave in his own home, I decided it was best to write a letter to Tom Sawyer and ask him to tell Miss Watson where Jim was.
es: Once I told myself that it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home, where his family was, if he had to be a slave, so it would be better to write a letter to Tom Sawyer to tell Miss Watson where he was.

en: But I soon give up that notion for two things: she’d be mad and disgusted at his rascality and ungratefulness for leaving her, and so she’d sell him straight down the river again; and if she didn’t, everybody naturally despises an ungrateful nigger, and they’d make Jim feel it all the time, and so he’d feel ornery and disgraced.
vi: But after thinking it over carefully, I abandoned that idea immediately. For two reasons: she would surely be disgusted with the ungrateful black man who left her, and she would sell him right away. And if she didn't do that, then Jim would always feel miserable and despicable.
tr: But a little later, I changed my mind, for two reasons: Miss Watson would be very angry and hate him for the lowliness and treachery of abandoning her, so she would sell him down the river again; even if she didn't sell him, everyone naturally hates a treacherous black man and they would constantly make Jim feel this, so he would feel base and dishonored.
es: But I immediately gave up the idea for two reasons: she would be indignant and angry at his bad faith and ingratitude for escaping from her, so she would sell him down the river again, and if not, everyone naturally despises an ungrateful black man and would remind Jim of it all the time, so that he would feel miserable and dishonored.

en: And then think of me!
vi: What to do now?
tr: And what about me?
es: And, what would they think of me!

en: It would get all around that Huck Finn helped a nigger to get his freedom; and if I was ever to see anybody from that town again I’d be ready to get down and lick his boots for shame.
vi: Then there was the rumor that Huck Finn had helped a black man escape. If I met anyone in town, would I have to kneel down and shamefully lick their shoes?
tr: Everyone would hear that Huck Finn helped a black man gain freedom; I would have to bow my head and lick their boots in shame whenever I saw anyone from that town.
es: Everyone would find out that Huck Finn had helped a black man gain his freedom, and if I ever saw anyone from town again, it would have to be to bow down and lick their boots out of shame.

en: That’s just the way: a person does a low-down thing, and then he don’t want to take no consequences of it.
vi: That's life: whoever does something wicked doesn't want to face the consequences of it.
tr: That's how it always is: Someone does something despicable, and then doesn't want to face the consequences.
es: That's how things are: someone does something wrong and then doesn't want to face the consequences.

en: Thinks as long as he can hide it, it ain’t no disgrace.
vi: That's life: whoever does something wicked doesn't want to face the consequences of it.
tr: As long as he can hide his fault, he assumes he hasn't done anything shameful.
es: They think that as long as they can hide, they won't have to feel ashamed.

en: That was my fix exactly.
