vi: The more I thought about it, the more my conscience gnawed at me, and the more I felt despicable and lowly.
tr: I had fallen into exactly such a predicament.
es: And that was my situation.

en: The more I studied about this, the more my conscience went to grinding me, and the more wicked and low-down and ornery I got to feeling.
vi: The more I thought about it, the more my conscience gnawed at me, and the more I felt despicable and lowly.
tr: The more I thought about what I had done, the more my conscience troubled me, and I felt increasingly base and despicable.
es: The more I thought about it, the more my conscience gnawed at me, and the more wicked, low, and miserable I felt.

en: And at last, when it hit me all of a sudden that here was the plain hand of Providence slapping me in the face and letting me know my wickedness was being watched all the time from up there in heaven, whilst I was stealing a poor old woman’s nigger that hadn’t ever done me no harm, and now was showing me there’s
vi: Finally, I felt as if the hand of God had just slapped me in the face, telling me that God was still watching all my sinful deeds. I had stolen a black slave from a poor woman who had never done anything to harm me.
tr: Finally, I decided it was clear that God's blow had suddenly struck my face; it reminded me that my sins had been seen from above from the beginning, that God had witnessed me stealing the black man of a poor old woman who had never harmed me, and that He would not allow such vile sins to continue; I was so scared that I nearly lost my mind.
es: And finally, when I suddenly realized that it was the hand of Providence slapping me in the face and telling me that my wickedness was always known up in heaven, because I had stolen a black man from a poor old woman who had never done anything wrong to me, and now it was showing me that there is always Someone who sees everything and does not allow such wickedness beyond a certain point, I almost fell to the ground from the fear it gave me.

en: One that’s always on the lookout, and ain’t a-going to allow no such miserable doings to go only just so fur and no further, I most dropped in my tracks I was so scared.
vi: I felt my guilt and was terribly afraid.
tr: Finally, I decided it was clear that God's blow had suddenly struck my face; it reminded me that my sins had been seen from above from the beginning, that God had witnessed me stealing the black man of a poor old woman who had never harmed me, and that He would not allow such vile sins to continue; I was so scared that I nearly lost my mind.
es: And finally, when I suddenly realized that it was the hand of Providence slapping me in the face and telling me that my wickedness was always known up in heaven, because I had stolen a black man from a poor old woman who had never done anything wrong to me, and now it was showing me that there is always Someone who sees everything and does not allow such wickedness beyond a certain point, I almost fell to the ground from the fear it gave me.

en: Well, I tried the best I could to kinder soften it up somehow for myself by saying I was brung up wicked, and so I warn’t so much to blame; but something inside of me kept saying, “There was the Sunday-school, you could a gone to it; and if you’d a done it they’d a learnt you there that people that acts as I’d been acting about that nigger goes to everlasting fire.”
vi: I tried to console myself by thinking that I was born wicked, so it wasn't entirely my fault. But inside me, something still said: There's that seminary, you have to go there to learn, and if you do, they will teach you that those who do what you did to that black man will be burned to death.
tr: Yet I did my best to find excuses for the mischief I had done; I said that I had been raised as a sinner, so it wasn't my fault; but still, a voice inside me said: "There was the church's Sunday school, you could have gone there; if you had gone, they would have taught you the right thing, they would have told you that those who treat blacks the way you do will burn in hell forever."
es: Well, I did everything I could to make things easier for myself by telling myself that I had been raised poorly, so it wasn't all my fault, but inside me, there was something that kept repeating: "There was Sunday school and you could have gone; and if you had gone, they would have taught you that people who do the things you have done for that black man are destined for eternal fire."

en: It made me shiver.
vi: I shuddered in fear, and I thought I must pray to become an honest person.
tr: I shivered from head to toe.
es: That made me tremble.

en: And I about made up my mind to pray, and see if I couldn’t try to quit being the kind of a boy I was and be better.
vi: I shuddered in fear, and I thought I must pray to become an honest person.
tr: I decided to pray, maybe I could stop being a sinful child and try to be better.
es: And I decided to start praying and see if I could stop being a bad boy and become better.

en: So I kneeled down.
vi: I knelt down.
tr: I knelt down.
es: So I knelt down.

en: But the words wouldn’t come.
vi: But I couldn't think of any words.
tr: But the words just wouldn't come to my mind.
es: But the words wouldn't come out.

en: Why wouldn’t they?
vi: Why is that?
tr: Why wouldn't they come?
es: Why not?

en: It warn’t no use to try and hide it from Him.
vi: Perhaps it's because one cannot lie to God or oneself.
tr: It was impossible to hide from God what a servant knew.
es: It was no use trying to hide it from Him.

en: Nor from me, neither.
vi: Perhaps it's because one cannot lie to God or oneself.
tr: I couldn't hide it from myself either.
es: Nor from myself either.

en: I knowed very well why they wouldn’t come.
vi: I knew why I couldn't find the words for a prayer, simply because I wasn't being straightforward or sincere.
tr: I knew very well why the words wouldn't come to my mind.
es: I knew very well why they wouldn't come out of me.

en: It was because my heart warn’t right; it was because I warn’t square; it was because I was playing double.
vi: I knew why I couldn't find the words for a prayer, simply because I wasn't being straightforward or sincere.
tr: Because I wasn't praying from the heart, because I wasn't being honest, because I was being hypocritical.
es: It was because my soul was not clean; it was because I had not repented; it was because I was playing both sides.

en: I was letting on to give up sin, but away inside of me I was holding on to the biggest one of all.
vi: I intended to abandon my sins, but my conscience was still burdened with them...
tr: I wanted to say that I would stop sinning, but something inside me insisted on one of the greatest sins.
es: I acted as if I were going to renounce sin, but inside I was still determined on the worst of all.

en: I was trying to make my mouth say I would do the right thing and the clean thing, and go and write to that nigger’s owner and tell where he was; but deep down in me I knowed it was a lie, and He knowed it.
vi: God knows everything, so don't pray for deceitful things.
tr: I was trying to open my mouth to say that I would do the right thing, clean up the mess I had made, and write to the owner of the black man to inform him of his whereabouts; but deep down I knew it was a lie – God knew it too.
es: I tried to force my mouth to say that I was going to do what was right and correct and write to the owner of that black man to tell her where he was; but deep down I knew it was a lie, and so did He.

en: You can’t pray a lie—I found that out.
vi: I understood that.
tr: You can't pray falsely – this is what I learned.
es: You can't pray lies, as I understood then.

en: So I was full of trouble, full as I could be; and didn’t know what to do.
vi: I was extremely worried.
tr: I was in such great distress that I was at a loss for what to do.
es: So I was full of problems, all the problems in the world, and I didn't know what to do.

en: At last I had an idea; and I says, I’ll go and write the letter—and then see if I can pray.
vi: A moment later, I came up with an idea and told myself: I will write a letter to see, and then pray to see if it works.
tr: Finally, an idea came to my mind; I thought to myself, let me go and write this letter, and then try to pray.
es: Finally, I had an idea and said to myself: "I will write the letter and then try to pray."

en: Why, it was astonishing, the way I felt as light as a feather right straight off, and my troubles all gone.
vi: Strangely, as soon as I thought of that, I felt as light as a feather. All my worries disappeared completely.
tr: Strangely enough, I suddenly felt as light as a feather, all my troubles had almost vanished.
es: And, well, I was amazed at how I immediately felt as light as a feather again, and without any more problems.

en: So I got a piece of paper and a pencil, all glad and excited, and set down and wrote:
vi: I grabbed a pencil and a piece of paper, eagerly sat down to write.
tr: I took paper and pen and started writing with joy and excitement:
es: So I grabbed a sheet of paper and a pencil, feeling very happy and encouraged, and I sat down to write:

en: Miss Watson, your runaway nigger Jim is down here two mile below Pikesville, and mr Phelps has got him and he will give him up for the reward if you send.
vi: “Miss Watson, your black man Jim ran away down here, two miles from Pikesville. Mr. Phelps caught him and will return him to you for a reward if you send the money down.”
tr: Miss Watson, your runaway negro Jim is two miles below Pikesville, in the hands of Mr. Phelps, and if you send the reward, he will send your negro to you.
es: "Miss Watson, your runaway negro Jim is here two miles down from Pikesville and Mr. Phelps has him. He will return him for the reward if you send for him."

en: HUCK FINN.
vi: Huck Finn
tr: HUCK FINN
es: "HUCK FINN"

en: I felt good and all washed clean of sin for the first time I had ever felt so in my life, and I knowed I could pray now.
vi: I felt relieved as if I had just shed all my sins. And I thought now I could pray.
tr: I now felt as if I had done a good deed and, for the first time in my life, cleansed of sin; now I could pray.
es: I felt good and clean of sin for the first time in my life and understood that now I could pray.

en: But I didn’t do it straight off, but laid the paper down and set there thinking—thinking how good it was all this happened so, and how near I come to being lost and going to hell.
vi: But I didn't pray immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper down and sat thinking. Everything had gone well just when I was most desperate.
tr: But I didn't start praying right away; I put down the paper and began to think – how good it was that things had ended this way, how close I had come to going down the wrong path and ending up in hell, I had narrowly escaped at the last moment.
es: But I didn't do it immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper aside and stayed there thinking: thinking how good it was that everything had happened this way and how close I had been to losing myself and going to hell.

en: And went on thinking.
vi: I thought again about the journey with Jim along this river.
tr: The more I thought, the more I thought.
es: And I kept thinking.

en: And got to thinking over our trip down the river; and I see Jim before me all the time: in the day and in the night-time, sometimes moonlight, sometimes storms, and we a-floating along, talking and singing and laughing.
vi: Jim was always by my side, day and night, under the moon as well as in the storm. We talked, laughed, and sang on the raft drifting along the water.
tr: Then I started thinking about our journey down the river; the nights, the days, sometimes in the moonlight, sometimes in the storm, the moments I spent with Jim came to mind; we had traveled down the river for so long, talked, sung songs, laughed, and had fun.
es: And I started thinking about our journey down the river and saw Jim in front of me all the time: day and night, sometimes in the moonlight, other times in the middle of storms, and when we floated down, chatting and singing and laughing.

en: But somehow I couldn’t seem to strike no places to harden me against him, but only the other kind.
vi: I couldn't find a single thing that made me hate Jim; on the contrary.
tr: But for some reason, I had no memory that would harden my heart against him; on the contrary, I remembered things that softened it.
es: But I don't know why it seemed that I couldn't find anything to harden me against him, but quite the opposite.

en: I’d see him standing my watch on top of his’n, ’stead of calling me, so I could go on sleeping; and see him how glad he was when I come back out of the fog; and when I come to him again in the swamp, up there where the feud was; and such-like times; and would always call me honey, and pet me and do everything he could think of for me, and how good he always was; and at last I struck the time I saved him by telling the men we had small-pox aboard, and he was so grateful, and said I was the best friend old Jim ever had in the world, and the only one he’s got now; and then I happened to look around and see that paper.
vi: Jim stood guard for me, and instead of waking me up, he let me sleep; Jim was happy and joyful when he saw me return safely; and Jim always called me by a dear name, indulged me, and would do anything for me. Then I remembered when I saved Jim and told the others that there was someone with smallpox on the raft, and Jim told me I was his best friend in the world. Thinking that, I looked down at the piece of paper I had just written.
tr: I remembered how he took my watch after his own, how he couldn't bring himself to wake me up, how happy he was when I returned from the fog, how delighted he was when we met in the swamp where there was a blood feud; many similar things came to mind; he always called me the apple of his eye, patted my head, did everything he could think of for my comfort, always treated me well; lastly, I remembered the night I saved him by telling the men there were flowers on the raft, how grateful he was, how he said I was the best friend he had in this world, even his only friend now; as I thought about these things, I looked around and saw the paper.
es: I saw him take my watch in addition to his own, instead of waking me up, so that I could sleep more, and I saw how happy he was when I returned in the middle of the fog, and when we met again in the swamp, far away where the blood feud was, and all those moments, and how he always called me his boy and caressed me and did everything he could for me, and how good he had always been, until I reached the moment when I had saved him when I told the men that we had smallpox on board and how grateful he was and that he had said that I was the best friend he had in the world, old Jim, and the only one he has now, and then, when I looked around randomly, I saw the piece of paper.

en: It was a close place.
vi: What a dilemma.
tr: It was right in front of me.
es: It was hard for me to make up my mind.

en: I took it up, and held it in my hand.
vi: I picked up the piece of paper, fiddling with it in my hand.
tr: I took the paper and held it in my hand.
es: I grabbed the paper and held it in my hand.

en: I was a-trembling, because I’d got to decide, forever, betwixt two things, and I knowed it.
vi: My body trembled because this was the moment I had to decide to follow one of two choices.
tr: I was trembling because I knew I had to make a definite choice between two paths.
es: I was trembling, because I had to decide forever between two things, and I knew it.

en: I studied a minute, sort of holding my breath, and then says to myself:
vi: I thought for a minute, held my breath, then told myself:
tr: I looked at the paper a bit more, held my breath, and finally said to myself:
es: I looked at it for a minute, as if holding my breath, and then I said to myself:

en: “All right, then, I’ll go to hell”—and tore it up.
vi: - Alright, I'm ready to go to hell.
tr: “Whatever, if I go to hell, I go to hell.” I tore up the paper and threw it away.
es: "Well, fine, I'll go to hell!" and I broke it.

en: It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said.
vi: So I tore the piece of paper to shreds.
tr: These were terrible thoughts and terrible words, but they had already come out of my mouth.
es: They were terrible ideas and words, but it was already done.

en: And I let them stay said; and never thought no more about reforming.
vi: I chased away everything in my mind, and said that I would follow the wicked path because I was born that way, and could not be otherwise.
tr: I didn't feel like taking them back, and from that day on, I didn't even think about changing my mind.
es: That's how I left it, and I didn't think about reforming anymore.

en: I shoved the whole thing out of my head, and said I would take up wickedness again, which was in my line, being brung up to it, and the other warn’t.
vi: I chased away everything in my mind, and said that I would follow the wicked path because I was born that way, and could not be otherwise.
tr: From that moment on, I pushed them all out of my mind; I would continue to sin, because this was my path, I was raised for this, I couldn't follow another path.
es: I got it all out of my head and said I would go back to being bad, which was my thing, because that's how I was raised, and the other way didn't suit me.

en: And for a starter I would go to work and steal Jim out of slavery again; and if I could think up anything worse, I would do that, too; because as long as I was in, and in for good, I might as well go the whole hog.
vi: I had to take action to rescue Jim from a life of slavery. If I could think of anything more wicked, I would do it too.
tr: Now, what I needed to do was find a way to free Jim from slavery again; if I had to do something worse for this, I would do it, because I was already neck-deep in this and I wouldn't be able to sleep peacefully until I finished it completely.
es: To start with, I was going to do whatever it took to get Jim out of slavery, and if I thought of something worse, I would do that too, because once you're in it, it doesn't matter if it's eight or eighty.

en: Then I set to thinking over how to get at it, and turned over some considerable many ways in my mind; and at last fixed up a plan that suited me.
vi: I thought about the action plan. After much deliberation, I decided to choose the plan that I found most suitable.
tr: I started making plans to rescue Jim and mulled over a lot of ideas in my mind; finally, I settled on one plan.
es: Then I started thinking about how to get it and turned it over and over in my mind until I found a plan that suited me.

en: So then I took the bearings of a woody island that was down the river a piece, and as soon as it was fairly dark I crept out with my raft and went for it, and hid it there, and then turned in.
vi: I pushed the raft towards an island with many trees down the river, waited until it got dark, then hid the child in a place and returned to the tent.
tr: I set my sights on a densely wooded island down the river, and as soon as it got dark, I emerged from my hiding place with my raft and headed for the island. I hid the raft on the island and lay down to sleep.
es: So I saw the position of a wooded island that was a little downstream, and as soon as it started to get a bit dark, I went out secretly with my raft and hid it there, and then I went to bed.

en: I slept the night through, and got up before it was light, and had my breakfast, and put on my store clothes, and tied up some others and one thing or another in a bundle, and took the canoe and cleared for shore.
vi: I slept there all night, waking up before dawn. I had a light meal, put on my clothes, and stepped into the boat to row to the shore.
tr: I slept soundly through the night, woke up before dawn, had breakfast, put on the new clothes I had bought from the store, bundled up the others, got into the canoe, and went ashore.
es: I slept all night and got up before dawn, had breakfast, put on the clothes from the store and the rest in a bundle, and took the canoe to go ashore.

en: I landed below where I judged was Phelps’s place, and hid my bundle in the woods, and then filled up the canoe with water, and loaded rocks into her and sunk her where I could find her again when I wanted her, about a quarter of a mile below a little steam sawmill that was on the bank.
vi: I docked the boat at a spot I guessed was the Phelps' house, hid the bundle of clothes at the edge of the forest, then let water flood the boat, put stones in it to sink it so that I could find it later if needed.
tr: I made sure to land somewhere near Phelps' farm, hid my bundle in the woods, filled the canoe with water, put a few stones in it, and sank it at a spot where I could find it later, about a quarter mile down from a sawmill on a small creek that flowed into the river.
es: I arrived where I thought the Phelps' house should be and hid the bundle in the woods; then I filled the canoe with water and stones and sank it where I could find it again whenever I wanted, about a quarter of a mile down from a small steam mill on the shore.

en: Then I struck up the road, and when I passed the mill I see a sign on it, “Phelps’s Sawmill,” and when I come to the farm-houses, two or three hundred yards further along, I kept my eyes peeled, but didn’t see nobody around, though it was good daylight now.
vi: Then I walked up the road. Passing by the workshop, I saw a sign that read: Phelps' Workshop. I walked to a few houses a few hundred yards away, peering inside but not seeing anyone, even though it was already quite bright.
tr: I set out, and as I passed by the sawmill, I saw a sign that read "Phelps' Sawmill." When I reached the area of the farmhouses about two or three hundred meters away, I kept my eyes wide open and scouted the surroundings, but despite it being almost daylight, there was no one around.
es: Then I set off, and when I passed by the mill I saw a sign that said "Phelps' Sawmill," and when I reached the houses, two or three hundred yards further on, I was very attentive, but no one was in sight, even though it was already fully daylight.

en: But I didn’t mind, because I didn’t want to see nobody just yet—I only wanted to get the lay of the land.
vi: But it didn't matter because I didn't want to meet anyone yet, I just wanted to scout out the place.
tr: There wasn't supposed to be anyone anyway, because I didn't want to see anyone yet – I was just trying to get familiar with the area.
es: But I didn't mind because I still didn't want to meet anyone: I just wanted to see what everything was like.

en: According to my plan, I was going to turn up there from the village, not from below.
vi: According to the plan, I pretended to be someone coming from the town, not from downstream.
tr: According to my plan, they would see me coming from the direction of the town, not from below.
es: According to my plan, I was going to appear there, coming from the town, and not from the river.

en: So I just took a look, and shoved along, straight for town.
vi: According to the plan, I pretended to be someone coming from the town, not from downstream.
tr: So I just took a look around and headed straight towards the town.
es: So I took a look around and headed straight to the town.

en: Well, the very first man I see when I got there was the duke.
vi: The first person I met turned out to be the duke.
tr: When I arrived in town, the first person I saw was the duke.
es: Well, the first person I saw when I arrived was the duke.

en: He was sticking up a bill for the Royal Nonesuch—three-night performance—like that other time.
vi: He was posting an advertisement for the play "The Royal Nonesuch."
tr: He was putting up posters for the Royal Nonesuch – a three-night show – just like last time.
es: He was putting up a poster for "The Royal Nonesuch" (three performances), just like the last time.

en: They had the cheek, them frauds!
vi: They still knew no fear.
tr: How brazen these conmen were!
es: What nerve those two scoundrels had!

en: I was right on him before I could shirk.
vi: I hadn't managed to avoid him before he saw me.
tr: Since we ran into each other suddenly, I couldn't escape from there.
es: I stood beside him before he could even move.

en: He looked astonished, and says:
vi: He looked surprised and called out:
tr: He looked at me in astonishment:
es: He seemed astonished and said:

en: “Hel-lo!
vi: - So you're here?
tr: "Oh my goodness!"
es: —Hello!

en: Where’d you come from?”
vi: Where did you put the raft?
tr: "Where did you come from?"
es: Where did you come from?

en: Then he says, kind of glad and eager, “Where’s the raft?—got her in a good place?”
vi: Did you hide it in a safe place?
tr: Then, with joy and eagerness, "Where is Sal?
es: —and then he adds, as if he were very happy—: Where is the raft? Did you put it in a good place?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: Did you find a good place?" he asked.
es: And I replied:

en: “Why, that’s just what I was going to ask your grace.”
vi: - I was also about to ask the duke that question.
tr: "I was just about to ask you the same thing, your excellency.""
es: —Man, that was what I was going to ask your grace.

en: Then he didn’t look so joyful, and says:
vi: He seemed unhappy and said:
tr: Suddenly, his mood soured.
es: Then he didn't seem so happy and asked:

en: “What was your idea for asking me?” he says.
vi: - What do you mean by asking me that question? I said:
tr: “What do you mean you were going to ask me?”
es: —Why were you going to ask me?

en: “Well,” I says, “when I see the king in that doggery yesterday I says to myself, we can’t get him home for hours, till he’s soberer; so I went a-loafing around town to put in the time and wait.
vi: - Yesterday, when I saw the king in that house, I thought it would be a long time before he sobered up, so I wandered down the street to kill time.
tr: “When I saw the king in the tavern yesterday, I thought we wouldn't be able to take him anywhere for a few more hours until he sobered up; so I started wandering around the town to pass the time.
es: —Well —I go and say—, when I saw the king yesterday in that tavern, I told myself that it would take us hours to get him home until he had sobered up, so I started wandering around the town to kill time and wait.

en: A man up and offered me ten cents to help him pull a skiff over the river and back to fetch a sheep, and so I went along; but when we was dragging him to the boat, and the man left me a-holt of the rope and went behind him to shove him along, he was too strong for me and jerked loose and run, and we after him.
vi: At that moment, someone came and gave me a dime, asking me to take the boat across the river and then go catch a stray sheep. So I followed him. But when we brought the sheep to the boat. The sheep was so strong that it broke free and ran away, and we had to chase it.
tr: A man offered me ten cents to take a sheep across the river with a boat and come back, and I accepted; but while pulling the sheep onto the boat, the man left the rope with me for a moment to push the sheep from behind, but the sheep was stronger than me and suddenly broke free and ran away, so we chased after it.
es: A man came and offered me ten cents if I helped him take a boat to the other side of the river and come back with a sheep, so I went with him; but when we were taking it to the boat and the man gave me the rope and went behind the boat to push, the sheep turned out to be too much for me alone and it broke free and ran off, and we ran after it.

en: We didn’t have no dog, and so we had to chase him all over the country till we tired him out.
vi: We ran through every nook and cranny until evening without finding it, so I headed back to the raft.
tr: Since we didn't have a dog, we had to chase it over hills and valleys until it got tired.
es: We didn't have a dog, so we had to chase it all over the field until it got tired.

en: We never got him till dark; then we fetched him over, and I started down for the raft.
vi: When I got back, the raft was gone too.
tr: We couldn't catch it until it got dark, but finally we caught it and took it across, and I headed towards the raft.
es: We didn't catch it until dusk; then we took it to the other side and I headed towards the raft.

en: When I got there and see it was gone, I says to myself, ‘they’ve got into trouble and had to leave; and they’ve took my nigger, which is the only nigger I’ve got in the world, and now I’m in a strange country, and ain’t got no property no more, nor nothing, and no way to make my living;’ so I set down and cried.
vi: I told myself that something bad must have happened to the others, so they left and took my black friend with them. So I sat down and cried.
tr: When I came to the place where we had hidden the raft and couldn't find it, I thought, ‘It seems they got into trouble and had to leave; they took my nigger too, the only nigger I had in this world, and now I'm left in a foreign land without any possessions, penniless, and there's nothing I can do to earn a living,’ I said to myself; I sat down and started to cry.
es: When I arrived and saw that it had disappeared, I said to myself: "They've gotten into trouble and had to leave, and they've taken my black man, who is the only black man I have in the world, and now I'm in a strange country and I have nothing of my own, I have nothing left at all nor any way to make a living," so I sat down to cry.

en: I slept in the woods all night.
vi: I had to sleep in the forest all night.
tr: I slept in the forest that night.
es: I fell asleep in the forest all night.

en: But what did become of the raft, then?—and Jim—poor Jim!”
vi: Poor Jim!
tr: So what happened to the raft then? And Jim, poor Jim!”
es: But then, what happened to the raft?... And Jim. Poor Jim!

en: “Blamed if I know—that is, what’s become of the raft.
vi: - He has forty dollars.
tr: “If I know what happened to the raft, I am a scoundrel.
es: —Hang me if I know; I'm referring to what happened with the raft.

en: That old fool had made a trade and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the doggery the loafers had matched half-dollars with him and got every cent but what he’d spent for whisky; and when I got him home late last night and found the raft gone, we said, ‘That little rascal has stole our raft and shook us, and run off down the river.’”
vi: When we caught him at that dilapidated house, it was exactly when he was gambling and lost everything, only having a little change left to buy alcohol. When I brought him back, the raft was already gone. We thought you had stolen the raft and fled.
tr: That old fool had sold something and gotten forty dollars; when we found him in the tavern, ruffians had swarmed around him and taken every last cent from him through trickery, except for the money he had spent on whiskey. Late in the evening, when we took him back and noticed the raft was gone, we said, ‘That little rascal stole our raft and took our belongings down the river.’”
es: The old fool made a deal and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the tavern, some clumsy guys had started playing half-dollars with him and had taken every last cent except what he had spent on whiskey, and when I went to take him home late at night and we saw that the raft had disappeared, we said to ourselves: "That little rascal has stolen the raft and escaped down the river."

en: “I wouldn’t shake my nigger, would I?—the only nigger I had in the world, and the only property.”
vi: - But what about my black man? He is my only relative.
tr: “But I'm not going to leave my black man behind, am I? In this world, I have only one black man; I have no other possessions.”
es: —I wasn't going to escape without my black man, was I? The only black man I had in the world, my only possession.

en: “We never thought of that.
vi: - We don't think so.
tr: “This had never crossed our minds.
es: —That hadn't occurred to us.

en: Fact is, I reckon we’d come to consider him our nigger; yes, we did consider him so—goodness knows we had trouble enough for him.
vi: In fact, we already consider it our property.
tr: To be honest, we had started to see him as our own black person; yes, we were now looking at him as our black person... God knows he didn't suffer any less because of us.
es: The truth is, I reckon we had come to consider him as our black man; yes, that's it; God knows we had been quite bothered about him.

en: So when we see the raft was gone and we flat broke, there warn’t anything for it but to try the Royal Nonesuch another shake.
vi: So when we saw the raft was gone, we returned empty-handed and had to put on this act.
tr: When Sal left, we were left penniless and had no choice but to try Curcuna at the Palace again.
es: So when we saw that the raft had disappeared and we were left without a cent, there was no choice but to try "The Unmatched Royalty" again.

en: And I’ve pegged along ever since, dry as a powder-horn.
vi: I haven't had anything to eat yet.
tr: Since then, even the last pennies in my pocket are gone, I'm dried up.
es: And here I am since then, drier than a desert.

en: Where’s that ten cents?
vi: Give me that penny.
tr: Is that ten cents still there?
es: Where are those ten cents?

en: Give it here.”
vi: Give me that penny.
tr: Give it to me.”
es: Give them to me.

en: I had considerable money, so I give him ten cents, but begged him to spend it for something to eat, and give me some, because it was all the money I had, and I hadn’t had nothing to eat since yesterday.
vi: I still had a lot of money, so I gave him a dime and told him to buy something for us to eat together, because that was all the money I had and I hadn't eaten anything since yesterday.
tr: I had enough money, so I gave him ten cents, but I begged him to use it to buy something to eat, and he had to share the food with me because I had no other money and hadn't eaten anything since yesterday.
es: I had quite a bit of money, so I gave him ten cents, but I begged him to spend it on something to eat and to give me something, because I had no more money and hadn't eaten since yesterday.

en: He never said nothing.
vi: He didn't say anything.
tr: He didn't say a word.
es: He didn't say a word.

en: The next minute he whirls on me and says:
vi: A minute later, he asked me:
tr: But a moment later, he turned to me in a hurry and said:
es: The next moment he threw himself at me saying:

en: “Do you reckon that nigger would blow on us?
vi: - Do you think that black guy will rat us out?
tr: “Do you think that black man will report us?
es: —Do you think that black guy is going to snitch on us?

en: We’d skin him if he done that!”
vi: If he does, we'll skin him alive.
tr: If he does, we'll skin him alive!”
es: If he snitches, we'll skin him alive!

en: “How can he blow?
vi: - How dare it accuse you?
tr: “Where is he reporting?
es: —How is he going to snitch?

en: Hain’t he run off?”
vi: It has already run away, hasn't it?
tr: Didn't he run away?”
es: Hasn't he escaped?

en: “No!
vi: - That old man sold it, but he didn't give me a single penny.
tr: “No!
es: —No!

en: That old fool sold him, and never divided with me, and the money’s gone.”
vi: That money is all gone now.
tr: Our old fool sold it and didn't share the money with me, and now he is also penniless.”
es: The old fool sold it and didn't share it with me, and now there's nothing left. —He sold him?

en: “Sold him?” I says, and begun to cry; “why, he was my nigger, and that was my money.
vi: I burst into tears:
tr: “Did he sell him?” I started crying; “but he was my black man and the money was my money.
es: —I said, and I began to cry—; but he was my black man, so he was my money.

en: Where is he?
vi: - Sell him?
tr: Where is he now?
es: Where is he?

en: —I want my nigger.”
vi: He is my black man. He is my money. Give me back my black man.
tr: I want my black man back.”
es: I want my black man.

en: “Well, you can’t get your nigger, that’s all—so dry up your blubbering.
vi: - You won't get it back, so stop crying.
tr: “You can't get your money back, so stop whining.
es: —Well, your black man is not going to come and that's it, so stop whining.

en: Looky here—do you think you’d venture to blow on us?
vi: Listen here, are you planning to accuse us?
tr: Look at me… do you think he can risk reporting us?
es: Come on: do you think you would dare to snitch on us?

en: Blamed if I think I’d trust you.
vi: I can't trust you.
tr: I don't trust you much either.
es: Hang me if I trust you.

en: Why, if you was to blow on us—”
vi: I saw a fierce look in his eyes.
tr: If you also try to report us…”
es: Damn, if you were going to snitch on us...

en: He stopped, but I never see the duke look so ugly out of his eyes before.
vi: I saw a fierce look in his eyes.
tr: He was silent, but I had never seen the shopkeeper look this angry.
es: He fell silent, but he had never seen the duke cast such a terrible look.

en: I went on a-whimpering, and says:
vi: I kept crying and said:
tr: I continued to complain:
es: I kept crying and said:

en: “I don’t want to blow on nobody; and I ain’t got no time to blow, nohow.
vi: - I don't want to accuse anyone.
tr: “I don't want to report anyone, I don't have time for that anyway.
es: —I don't want to snitch on anyone, and besides, I don't have time to do it; I have to find my black man.

en: I got to turn out and find my nigger.”
vi: I have to go find my black man.
tr: I just want to go and find my black man.”
es: —I don't want to snitch on anyone, and besides, I don't have time to do it; I have to find my black man.

en: He looked kinder bothered, and stood there with his bills fluttering on his arm, thinking, and wrinkling up his forehead.
vi: He stood there, still holding the advertisement in his hand, frowning in thought.
tr: He hesitated for a moment, rubbing his forehead while the flyers under his arm fluttered in the wind, and paused to think.
es: He seemed annoyed and stayed with the programs fluttering above his arm, thinking and furrowing his brow.

en: At last he says:
vi: He said:
tr: Finally, he spoke:
es: Finally, he said:

en: “I’ll tell you something.
vi: He said:
tr: “Listen carefully.
es: —I'm going to tell you something.

en: We got to be here three days.
vi: - We stayed there for three more days.
tr: We will stay here for three days.
es: We have to stay here for three days.

en: If you’ll promise you won’t blow, and won’t let the nigger blow, I’ll tell you where to find him.”
vi: If you promise me that you won't report me, and won't let the black guy report me, then I'll tell you where to find him.
tr: If you promise not to report us, and that the black man won't report us either, I will tell you where to find him.”
es: If you promise not to snitch and not to let the black guy snitch, I'll tell you where it is.

en: So I promised, and he says:
vi: I promise. He said again:
tr: I promised her.
es: So I promised him, and he continued:

en: “A farmer by the name of Silas Ph—” and then he stopped.
vi: - There was a ranch owner named Silas Ph...
tr: “The name of the farmer who took him is Silas Ph…” then he fell silent.
es: —A farmer named Silas Ph... And then he fell silent.

en: You see, he started to tell me the truth; but when he stopped that way, and begun to study and think again, I reckoned he was changing his mind.
vi: He suddenly stopped.
tr: He was actually going to tell me the truth, but then he stopped and reconsidered, and as far as I could understand, he changed his mind.
es: That is, he had started to tell me the truth, but when he fell silent and began to think and reflect, I figured he was changing his mind.

en: And so he was.
vi: He probably intended to tell the truth, but then changed his mind.
tr: He was actually going to tell me the truth, but then he stopped and reconsidered, and as far as I could understand, he changed his mind.
es: And that was it.

en: He wouldn’t trust me; he wanted to make sure of having me out of the way the whole three days.
vi: He still didn't trust me and wanted me to leave this place within three days.
tr: Apparently, he had concluded that he couldn't trust me and thought it best for me to stay out of the way for three days.
es: He didn't trust me; he wanted to make sure I wouldn't cause him problems for the entire three days.

en: So pretty soon he says:
vi: He continued:
tr: A little later, he said:
es: So after a moment, he goes and says:

en: “The man that bought him is named Abram Foster—Abram G. Foster—and he lives forty mile back here in the country, on the road to Lafayette.”
vi: - The person who bought Jim is Abram Foster, forty miles away from here, in the countryside, on the way to Lafayette
tr: “The name of the man who took it is Abram Foster… Abram G. Foster… He lives forty miles from here, inland on the Lafayette road.”
es: —The man who bought it is named Abram Foster, Abram G. Foster, and he lives forty miles across the country, on the road to Lafayette.

en: “All right,” I says, “I can walk it in three days.
vi: I said:
tr: “Okay, I can walk there in three days,” I said.
es: —Very well —I said—. I can cover that in three days.

en: And I’ll start this very afternoon.”
vi: - Alright, I will go there this afternoon, it will take just three days to arrive.
tr: “It would be good to start right this afternoon.”
es: And I am leaving this very afternoon.

en: “No you wont, you’ll start now; and don’t you lose any time about it, neither, nor do any gabbling by the way.
vi: - No, you should go right now. On the way, don't linger or chat with anyone, otherwise you'll get into trouble.
tr: “No, you must start immediately,” he said. “Do not waste any time, do not dawdle on the road.
es: —No, not a chance, you leave right now, and don't waste time or start chatting around.

en: Just keep a tight tongue in your head and move right along, and then you won’t get into trouble with us, d’ye hear?”
vi: I also only hope for that, I already have a plan in my head.
tr: Keep your mouth shut along the way and walk without stopping, then you won't have any problems with us, do you hear me?”
es: Keep your mouth shut and get moving; that way you won't have any problems with us, do you hear me?

en: That was the order I wanted, and that was the one I played for.
vi: He said:
tr: I was already waiting for this order and trying to hear it.
es: That was the order I wanted to receive and the one I was waiting for.

en: I wanted to be left free to work my plans.
vi: - Just go right away.
tr: I wanted to be left alone to implement my own plan.
es: I wanted freedom to carry out my plans.

en: “So clear out,” he says; “and you can tell mr Foster whatever you want to.
vi: When you meet Mr. Abram Foster, you can say whatever you want.
tr: “Get lost,” he said; “You can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want.
es: —So get lost —he says—, and you can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want.

en: Maybe you can get him to believe that Jim is your nigger—some idiots don’t require documents—leastways I’ve heard there’s such down South here.
vi: Maybe you can convince him that Jim is your black servant, and he probably won't ask for any papers.
tr: Maybe you can convince him that Jim is your slave... Some fools don't ask for documents... At least I've heard that there are some who don't ask for documents this far South.
es: Maybe you'll get him to believe that Jim is your black man, because there are idiots who don't demand documents, or at least that's what I've been told happens here in the South.

en: And when you tell him the handbill and the reward’s bogus, maybe he’ll believe you when you explain to him what the idea was for getting ’em out.
vi: Maybe you can convince him that Jim is your black servant, and he probably won't ask for any papers.
tr: If you tell him that the advertisement and the reward are fake, that you made it all up to keep others away from your slave, he might believe you.
es: And when you tell him that the flyer and the reward are fake, maybe he'll believe you when you explain why they were distributed.

en: Go ’long now, and tell him anything you want to; but mind you don’t work your jaw any between here and there.”
vi: Just go, say whatever you want when you meet him, but remember not to say a word from here to there.
tr: Now go and tell him whatever you want; but make sure it's your feet doing the work, not your mouth, between here and there.”
es: Now get lost and tell him whatever you want, but be careful not to wag your tongue anywhere until you get there.

en: So I left, and struck for the back country.
vi: I walked towards the outskirts.
tr: So I left there and set off inward.
es: So I started walking towards the field.

en: I didn’t look around, but I kinder felt like he was watching me.
vi: Although I didn't turn my head back, I still felt that he was watching me.
tr: I wasn't looking around, but I could feel him watching me.
es: I didn't look back, but I had the feeling that I was being watched.

en: But I knowed I could tire him out at that.
vi: Although I didn't turn my head back, I still felt that he was watching me.
tr: Of course, I knew I would tire him out soon enough.
es: But I knew I could make them tired of watching me.

en: I went straight out in the country as much as a mile before I stopped; then I doubled back through the woods towards Phelps’.
vi: I walked straight out to the outskirts about a mile away, then stopped, turned into the forest, and headed back to Mr. Phelps' house.
tr: I walked about a mile through the fields, then turned back and headed towards the Phelps farm through the forest.
es: I kept walking towards the field for at least a mile before stopping; then I retraced my steps through the forest towards Phelps' house.

en: I reckoned I better start in on my plan straight off without fooling around, because I wanted to stop Jim’s mouth till these fellows could get away.
vi: I planned to carry out my plan immediately so that Jim wouldn't have time to report them, adding more trouble.
tr: I had to start executing my plan immediately without lingering around, because I wanted to keep Jim's mouth shut until these scoundrels left.
es: I figured it was best to start with my plan without wasting any time because I wanted to prevent Jim from saying anything until those guys left.

en: I didn’t want no trouble with their kind.
vi: I planned to carry out my plan immediately so that Jim wouldn't have time to report them, adding more trouble.
tr: I didn't want to get into trouble with people like them.
es: I didn't want trouble with people like that.

en: I’d seen all I wanted to of them, and wanted to get entirely shut of them.
vi: Just hoping to escape from them would be a relief.
tr: I'd already had enough trouble with them, there was no need to face them again.
es: I was already fed up with them and wanted to lose sight of them forever.

en: CHAPTER XXXII.
vi: Chapter XXXII
tr: Chapter Thirty-Two
es: Chapter 32

en: When I got there it was all still and Sunday-like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody’s dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it’s spirits whispering—spirits that’s been dead ever so many years—and you always think they’re talking about you.
vi: When I arrived there, I saw that everything was as quiet as a Sunday. The sun was scorching hot. Everyone had gone to the fields to work. Only the buzzing of the flies made the atmosphere even more melancholic. I felt as if everyone had died. Every gust of wind that blew through made the leaves rustle, making the scene even sadder.
tr: When I arrived there, the surroundings were as calm as a Sunday, and it was also hot and sunny; the laborers had gone to the fields; there was a faint buzzing of insects and flies in the air, I felt very lonely and deserted, as if everyone except me had died and gone away. It was such a weather that if a breeze rustled the leaves, you would feel sorrowful, because it would seem as if spirits –even those that had been dead for many years– were whispering, and you would always think they were talking about you.
es: WHEN I ARRIVED everything was calm, as if it were Sunday, it was hot and the sun was shining; the slaves had gone to the fields and all you could hear was that buzzing of insects and flies in the air that makes you feel as lonely as if the whole world had died and disappeared, and if a breeze blows and makes the leaves tremble, you feel sad because it's as if they were spirits saying something, spirits that have been dead for many years, and you always think they are talking about you.

en: As a general thing it makes a body wish he was dead, too, and done with it all.
vi: Overall, looking at this scene, one just wanted to die to forget everything.
tr: In fact, generally in the face of such a thing, one comes to wish that they too had died and severed their connection with this world.
es: In general, it makes you want to be dead, and to have finished with everything.

en: Phelps’ was one of these little one-horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike.
vi: The Phelps' camp was a small cotton plantation with an iron fence running around it.
tr: The Phelps' farm was one of the small cotton plantations, all of which are similar to each other.
es: The Phelps' house was one of those very small cotton plantations, which are all alike.

en: A rail fence round a two-acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up-ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass-patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log-house for the white folks—hewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud-stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round-log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke-house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger-cabins in a row t’other side the smoke-house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash-hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.
vi: A gate made of pieces of sawed-off wood. In the yard, there were a few patches of grass, bare and withered. A two-room wooden house for white people, made of small planks, patched together with mortar that had been whitewashed many times. A kitchen, with a wide roof extending to the main house. A woodshed behind the kitchen. Three rooms for black people right beside it. Next to the fence, at the back, there was a small shed for dumping ashes. On the kitchen door, a few water barrels were scattered around. Dogs lay basking in the sun. In the corner of the garden, there were a few sparse trees. Outside the fence, there was another garden with a melon trellis. Beyond that was the cotton field, and beyond the cotton field was the forest.
tr: The two-acre yard was surrounded by a fence; logs cut into slices and arranged in steps of varying heights like barrels served both to climb the fence and to help women mount horses; in the wide yard, there were patches of yellowed grass here and there, but most of the yard was bare and flat, looking like an old hat with its nap worn off; a large two-story wooden house was built for the whites – the gaps in the walls made of logs smoothed with an ax were filled with mud or adobe, and these strips of mortar had been whitewashed at some point. The kitchen, with its round log walls, was connected to the house by a wide, open but roofed passage. Behind the kitchen, there was another wooden shack used for smoking, and beyond that, there were three negro cabins. A small cabin stood alone leaning against the back fences, with an ash silo and a large cauldron for soap making right next to it. On a table next to the kitchen door, there was a bucket of water and a gourd dipper. A hunting dog had curled up and fallen asleep right there in the sun; there were other dogs sleeping around as well. Three large trees in the corner shaded the yard. A grapevine covered part of the fence, outside the fence there was a vegetable garden and a watermelon field, and beyond that, the cotton fields began, and after the fields, there was a forest.
es: A log fence around a two-acre yard; an entrance made of sawn logs placed on the ground, like steps of different heights to climb over the fence and for women to mount horses; some tufts of grass in the yard, but generally everything very arid and smooth, like an old worn-out hat; a large double-log house for the whites: logs finished with the holes filled with adobe or mortar and with those separations that are whitewashed from time to time; a round-log kitchen with a wide, open but roofed passage leading to the house, a log cabin for smoking meat behind the kitchen, three small log cabins for the blacks, placed in a row on the other side of the smokehouse, another isolated cabin against the back fence and some sheds on the other side; a lime deposit and a large cauldron in which to boil soap next to the shed; a bench next to the kitchen door, a bucket of water and a gourd; a dog sleeping in the sun; more dogs sleeping on either side, bushes and mulberry trees in a spot next to the fence; on the other side of the fence, an orchard and a watermelon patch, and then the cotton fields and beyond that the woods.

en: I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash-hopper, and started for the kitchen.
vi: I walked around for a while and then climbed onto the roof to enter the kitchen area.
tr: I wandered around and entered the courtyard by climbing the steps near the ash silo, then headed towards the kitchen.
es: I turned around and climbed over the back gate next to where the quicklime was, and went to the kitchen.

en: When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning-wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was dead—for that is the lonesomest sound in the whole world.
vi: After taking a few steps, I heard the hissing sound of a wheel echoing for a moment, then gradually fading away. At that moment, I felt like dying because that sound was so pitiful.
tr: As I moved a little further, I heard the whirring of a pulley rising and falling; that's when I thought, God take my life and save me – there is no sound that makes a person feel so lonely.
es: After a few steps, I heard the dull hum of a spinning wheel and then I realized that I would be better off dead, because it is the loneliest sound in the whole world.

en: I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I’d noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.
vi: I kept walking straight in, my mind blank, leaving everything to God.
tr: I continued on my way without a specific plan, trusting that God would give me the right words when the time came; because I had realized that if I let myself relax, God always made me say the right words.
es: I went on, without making any concrete plan, trusting only that Providence would put the right words in my mouth when the time came, for I had noticed that Providence always put the exact words in my mouth if I left it alone.

en: When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still.
vi: Halfway there, a dog, then another, jumped at me. Of course, I stood still, looking at it.
tr: When I was halfway down the road, first one dog, then another dog got up and came towards me, so I immediately stopped and started waiting without moving, of course.
es: When I was halfway there, first one dog and then another got up, so naturally I stood in front of them, completely still.

en: And such another powwow as they made!
vi: For nearly half a minute, I felt like I was spinning in the middle of a wheel trying to deal with the dogs.
tr: The barking of the dogs raised a commotion!
es: And what a commotion they made!

en: In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may say—spokes made out of dogs—circle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a-barking and howling; and more a-coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.
vi: About fifteen of them surrounded me, pointing their snouts straight at me, barking loudly. Several other dogs crawled through the fence and from the corners of the garden came to completely encircle me.
tr: After about fifteen seconds, I had become like the hub of a wheel, with the spokes of the wheel made up of dogs; around fifteen dogs had gathered around me, stretching their necks and noses towards me, barking or howling; other dogs were also coming; I could see them jumping over fences, darting out from every conceivable corner.
es: After a quarter of a minute, you could say that I was like the hub of a wheel and the spokes were the dogs, a circle of fifteen of them revolving around me, with their necks and noses pointed at me, barking and howling, and more kept coming; you could see them jumping over fences and coming out of corners from everywhere.

en: A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling-pin in her hand, singing out, “Begone you Tige! you Spot! begone sah!” and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me.
vi: A black woman ran out from the kitchen, holding a rolling pin in her hand, chasing the dogs! She struck each one of them, and they yelped and ran away.
tr: A black woman rushed out of the kitchen with a rolling pin in her hand. "Shoo! Come on, back off! Come on, Çomar! Hop, shoo!" she shouted, hitting first one and then the other with the rolling pin; the dogs howled and retreated, and the rest quickly scattered; a moment later, half of them came back, wagging their tails and started circling around me, trying to befriend me.
es: From the kitchen ran out a black woman with a rolling pin in her hand, shouting: "Out! You, Tige! You, Spot! Out, I say!" And she gave a hit first to one and then to the other, who went away howling, and then followed the rest, and after a second half of them came back, wagging their tails and becoming friends with me.

en: There ain’t no harm in a hound, nohow.
vi: But just a second later, they came back, wagging their tails around me, looking very friendly.
tr: After all, dogs don't harm humans.
es: The truth is that dogs are not bad creatures.

en: And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow-linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother’s gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do.
vi: Following the black woman was a black girl and two black boys, wearing only thick fabric shirts, clinging to their mother's clothes and hiding behind her, looking at me fearfully, as all black children usually do.
tr: A small black girl and two black boys came out after the black woman; the children wore nothing but linen shirts and were all clinging to the hem of their mother's dress, casting shy and furtive glances at me from behind her; children are always like that anyway.
es: And behind the woman appeared a black girl and two black boys who were wearing nothing but linen shirts and were clinging to their mother's dress, looking at me very shyly from behind her skirts, as they all do.

en: And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty-five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning-stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing.
vi: Then I saw a white woman step out from the house, about forty-five to fifty years old, bareheaded, holding a knitting needle in her hand, followed by several white children, also hiding behind their mother and looking at me.
tr: A white woman, around forty-five or fifty years old, came out of the house with her head uncovered; she still had a distaff in her hand; white children followed her, behaving just like the black children.
es: Then the white woman, who must have been forty-five or fifty years old, ran out of the house, without a hat and with the spindle of the spinning wheel in her hand, and behind her, her white children, who were just as shy as the black ones.

en: She was smiling all over so she could hardly stand—and says:
vi: She smiled with a very delighted expression and said:
tr: The woman's mouth was stretched to her ears, she looked as if she might collapse from smiling:
es: She was grinning from ear to ear, and she goes and says:

en: “It’s you, at last!
vi: - Is that you?
tr: “You finally came!..
es: —It's you at last!

en: —ain’t it?”
vi: I didn't have time to think and immediately replied:
tr: It's you, isn't it?”
es: Right?

en: I out with a “Yes’m” before I thought.
vi: - Yes, ma'am
tr: Before I had time to think, the words "Yes, ma'am," had already slipped out of my mouth.
es: I blurted out a "yes, ma'am" before thinking about it.

en: She grabbed me and hugged me tight; and then gripped me by both hands and shook and shook; and the tears come in her eyes, and run down over; and she couldn’t seem to hug and shake enough, and kept saying, “You don’t look as much like your mother as I reckoned you would; but law sakes, I don’t care for that, I’m so glad to see you!
vi: She hugged me tightly, tears streaming down. Hugging and shaking weren't enough, she kept talking nonstop: - You don't resemble your mother as much as I thought. But thank God, I'm so happy to see you!
tr: As soon as the woman caught me, she took me into her arms; then she started shaking both of my hands; tears were streaming down her cheeks; it seemed like she couldn't get enough of hugging and shaking my hand. "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but it doesn't matter at all, I'm so glad to see you!" she said.
es: He hugged me and then took both of my hands and squeezed them many times, not stopping from saying: "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but the truth is I don't care at all. I'm so glad to see you!

en: Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up!
vi: I just want to give you a big hug!
tr: "Oh my dear, I could just eat those cheeks of yours!
es: My God, my God, I could just eat you up!

en: Children, it’s your cousin Tom!—tell him howdy.”
vi: Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Say hello to him!
tr: Kids, your cousin Tom is here!.. Say welcome to him."
es: Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Come on, say hello to him.

en: But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her.
vi: But they still put their fingers in their mouths and hid behind their mother.
tr: But the little ones hid even further behind their mother, watching me with their fingers in their mouths.
es: But they lowered their heads, put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind their mother's skirts.

en: So she run on:
vi: She continued:
tr: The woman called out inside:
es: Then she continued saying:

en: “Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right away—or did you get your breakfast on the boat?”
vi: - Lize, bring the hot food up for you. Or have you already had breakfast on the train?
tr: “Lize, quickly prepare a hot breakfast for him… Or did you have breakfast on the ferry?”
es: —Lize, quickly, prepare him a hot breakfast right now. Or did you already have breakfast on the boat?

en: I said I had got it on the boat.
vi: I said I had eaten on the train.
tr: I said that I had breakfast on the ferry.
es: I said that I had breakfast on the boat.

en: So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after.
vi: She led me into the house, the children running behind.
tr: Upon this, he grabbed my hand and dragged me towards the house, with the children following us.
es: Then she went towards the house holding my hand, and the children came behind.

en: When we got there she set me down in a split-bottomed chair, and set herself down on a little low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and says:
vi: Once inside, my grandmother sat me down on a reclining chair, then she sat down on a small stool, took my hands, and asked:
tr: When we arrived at the house, he sat me down on a wicker chair, and he settled on a small stool directly opposite me. Taking my hands in his palms, he began to speak again:
es: When we arrived, she made me sit in a wicker chair and she sat on a low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and she goes and says:

en: “Now I can have a good look at you; and, laws-a-me, I’ve been hungry for it a many and a many a time, all these long years, and it’s come at last!
vi: - Now, let me take a good look at my nephew's face.
tr: “Now let me take a good look at you; My God, I have wanted to see you for so many years, and finally, we have met!
es: —Now I can look at you properly and, God bless me, I have been longing to see you all these years, and finally you have arrived!

en: We been expecting you a couple of days and more.
vi: It's been worth all these years of waiting for you.
tr: We were expecting you a few days ago.
es: We have been waiting for you for two days or more.

en: What kep’ you?—boat get aground?”
vi: Why are you so late, did the train run aground?
tr: Why were you so late?.. Did the steamer run aground?”
es: Why did it take you so long? Did the ship run aground?

en: “Yes’m—she—”
vi: - Madam, yes, the train is...
tr: “Yes, ma'am...”
es: —Yes, ma'am... it's just that...

en: “Don’t say yes’m—say Aunt Sally.
vi: - Don't call me grandma, call me Aunt Saly.
tr: "Don't call me ma'am, call me Aunt Sally."
es: —Don't call me yes ma'am; call me Aunt Sally.

en: Where’d she get aground?”
vi: So where did the ship run aground?
tr: "Where did it run aground?"
es: Where did it run aground?

en: I didn’t rightly know what to say, because I didn’t know whether the boat would be coming up the river or down.
vi: I don't know how to say it right away, because I don't know if the boat is coming down from above or going up from below.
tr: Suddenly, I didn't know what to say because I didn't know whether the steamboat was coming from upstream or downstream.
es: I didn't know exactly what to say, because I didn't know if the boat would come upstream or downstream.

en: But I go a good deal on instinct; and my instinct said she would be coming up—from down towards Orleans.
vi: But I guess it's the boat coming up from Orleans.
tr: But the best thing was to trust my instincts; according to my instincts, the steamboat was coming from downstream, from the direction of Orleans.
es: But I do many things by instinct, and my instinct said it would come upstream from Orleans more or less.

en: That didn’t help me much, though; for I didn’t know the names of bars down that way.
vi: But even so, I'm still not at ease because I don't know the names of the docks down there.
tr: But this information was of no use to me because I didn't know where the steamboat could run aground on its way here.
es: But that didn't help me much either, because I didn't know the names of the bars in that part.

en: I see I’d got to invent a bar, or forget the name of the one we got aground on—or—Now I struck an idea, and fetched it out:
vi: I think I need to make up a name or pretend to forget the place where it got stuck, or...
tr: So, I would either have to make up a name of a sandbar or say that I forgot where we ran aground... Then another idea suddenly came to my mind:
es: I saw that I would have to invent a bar or forget the name of the one we had run aground on or... Then an idea occurred to me and I blurted it out.

en: “It warn’t the grounding—that didn’t keep us back but a little.
vi: Suddenly, an idea came to me, and I said:
tr: “The reason for our delay was not that we ran aground.
es: —It wasn't the grounding... That didn't delay us much.

en: We blowed out a cylinder-head.”
vi: - It's not that the ship got stuck, it's that the boiler exploded.
tr: One of the cylinder heads exploded.”
es: It was that a cylinder head blew out.

en: “Good gracious! anybody hurt?”
vi: - Lord, is there anything wrong?
tr: "Oh my God! Did anything happen to anyone?""
es: —My God! Is anyone injured?

en: “No’m.
vi: - No, sir, only one black man was killed.
tr: “No, ma'am.
es: —No, ma'am.

en: Killed a nigger.”
vi: - No, sir, only one black man was killed.
tr: Only a black man died.”
es: He killed a black man.

en: “Well, it’s lucky; because sometimes people do get hurt.
vi: - Lucky. The last few times, there were still people getting injured.
tr: “Anyway, you were lucky; because sometimes people get hurt too.
es: —Well, thank goodness; because sometimes those things kill someone.

en: Two years ago last Christmas your uncle Silas was coming up from Newrleans on the old Lally Rook, and she blowed out a cylinder-head and crippled a man.
vi: Two years ago, your Uncle Silas came up from New Orleans, and the Lally Rock steamboat also had a boiler explosion that injured someone.
tr: Two years ago, around Christmas time, Uncle Silas was coming from New Orleans with the old Lally Rook when the steamboat's cylinder cover exploded and a man was crippled.
es: Last Christmas it was two years since your uncle Silas came from New Orleans on the old Lally Rook and blew a cylinder head and left a man paralyzed.

en: And I think he died afterwards.
vi: It seems that person died later.
tr: I think he died later.
es: And I think he died afterward.

en: He was a Baptist.
vi: It seems that person died later.
tr: The man was a Baptist.
es: He was a Baptist.

en: Your uncle Silas knowed a family in Baton Rouge that knowed his people very well.
vi: Uncle Silas knew a family in Baton Rouge who knew him well.
tr: Uncle Silas knew a family from Baton Rouge who knew that family well.
es: Your uncle Silas knew a family from Baton Rouge that knew his very well.

en: Yes, I remember now, he did die.
vi: Oh, I remember now, he did die.
tr: Yes, now I remember, the man had died.
es: Yes, now I remember he did indeed die.

en: Mortification set in, and they had to amputate him.
vi: Oh, I remember now, he did die.
tr: He got gangrene, and they had to amputate one of his limbs.
es: He got gangrene and they had to amputate.

en: But it didn’t save him.
vi: Oh, I remember now, he did die.
tr: But he still couldn't be saved.
es: But even that didn't save him.

en: Yes, it was mortification—that was it.
vi: Oh, I remember now, he did die.
tr: Of course, he had gangrene… now I remember.
es: Yes, it was gangrene, that's what it was.

en: He turned blue all over, and died in the hope of a glorious resurrection.
vi: Oh, I remember now, he did die.
tr: The man turned purple and died with the hope of resurrection by God's grace on Judgment Day.
es: He turned all blue and died with the hope of a glorious resurrection.

en: They say he was a sight to look at.
vi: Uncle Silas always mentions you whenever he comes here.
tr: They say he had a very strange appearance.
es: They say it was scary to see him.

en: Your uncle’s been up to the town every day to fetch you.
vi: Uncle Silas always mentions you whenever he comes here.
tr: Uncle went to town every day to bring you.
es: Your uncle has gone to town every day to look for you, and he just went out again only an hour ago; he must be about to return.

en: And he’s gone again, not more’n an hour ago; he’ll be back any minute now.
vi: He just left less than an hour ago and will be back soon.
tr: He went to town again about an hour ago; he will be here soon.
es: Your uncle has gone to town every day to look for you, and he just went out again only an hour ago; he must be about to return.

en: You must a met him on the road, didn’t you?—oldish man, with a—”
vi: You must have met him on the way, right? He's old, so he's a bit confused...
tr: You must have met him on the way… An elderly man…”
es: You must have met him on the road, right? Older now, with a...

en: “No, I didn’t see nobody, Aunt Sally.
vi: - I didn't meet anyone, Aunt Saly.
tr: “No, I didn't see anyone, Aunt Sally.
es: —No, I haven't seen anyone, Aunt Sally.

en: The boat landed just at daylight, and I left my baggage on the wharf-boat and went looking around the town and out a piece in the country, to put in the time and not get here too soon; and so I come down the back way.”
vi: The ship docked early in the morning, I left my luggage at the dock and wandered around the town to avoid coming back here too early.
tr: The ferry arrived at dawn, and I left my belongings on a ship at the dock and wandered around the town a bit, and then in the countryside; I thought I’d pass the time so I wouldn’t arrive here too early; that’s why I came from the back.”
es: The boat arrived just at dawn, I left my luggage on the dock and went for a walk around the town and also through the countryside to pass the time and not arrive too early; that's why I came in from the back.

en: “Who’d you give the baggage to?”
vi: - Who do you give the luggage to?
tr: “To whom did you leave your belongings?”
es: —To whom did you give the luggage?

en: “Nobody.”
vi: - I didn't send it to anyone
tr: “To no one.”
es: —No one.

en: “Why, child, it’ll be stole!”
vi: - What if someone steals it?
tr: “But they will steal, my nephew!”
es: —But, child, they are going to steal it from you!

en: “Not where I hid it I reckon it won’t,” I says.
vi: - No, I hid it in a very secret place, no one can take it.
tr: "No one can find it where I have hidden it," I said.
es: —No, where I hid it, I don't think so —I said.

en: “How’d you get your breakfast so early on the boat?”

es: —The captain saw me up and thought it would be better if I ate something before disembarking, so he took me to the upper cabins, where the officers eat, and gave me everything I wanted.

en: I was getting so uneasy I couldn’t listen good.

vi: I just wanted to pull those kids away immediately to inquire about who I am.
tr: My mind was always on the children; I wanted to pull them aside and press them a bit to find out who I was.
es: I was thinking about the children all the time; I wanted to take them away to get some information from them to find out who I was.

en: But I couldn’t get no show, ms Phelps kept it up and run on so.

es: But there was no way. Mrs. Phelps did nothing but talk.

en: Pretty soon she made the cold chills streak all down my back, because she says:

en: “But here we’re a-running on this way, and you hain’t told me a word about Sis, nor any of them.

tr: “But I've been talking for two hours and you haven't said a word about your brother or anyone else.
es: —But here we are talking and you still haven't told me anything about my sister or the others.

en: Now I’ll rest my works a little, and you start up yourn; just tell me everything—tell me all about ’m all every one of ’m; and how they are, and what they’re doing, and what they told you to tell me; and every last thing you can think of.”
vi: Whatever you think and remember, just tell me everything.
tr: Now let me rest a bit and you tell me; tell me everything... Are they in good health, what are they doing, what did they tell you to convey to me; tell me everything that comes to your mind.”
es: Now I'll stop talking and it's your turn; tell me everything, tell me how everyone is, down to the last one, how they're doing, what they're up to, what they've told you to tell me, and everything you remember.

en: Well, I see I was up a stump—and up it good.
vi: I was speechless.

en: Providence had stood by me this fur all right, but I was hard and tight aground now.
vi: God has abandoned me.
tr: Until that moment, God had been my helper, but from then on, there was no corner left to escape to. There was no point in pretending any longer...
es: Providence had supported me up to that moment, but now it was up to me to manage as best I could.

en: I see it warn’t a bit of use to try to go ahead—I’d got to throw up my hand.
vi: Well, I have no choice but to risk it.

es: Kids, don't say a word.

vi: The man replied: - I don't know.

es: —I can't imagine it —said the old man—, and I must confess that I don't feel at ease at all.

vi: I'm also very worried.

es: He jumped to the window next to the head of the bed and gave Mrs. Phelps the opportunity she was looking for.

vi: I stepped out, and when he turned back, he saw his wife standing there smiling, her face as red as a stove, while I stood next to her, timid and fearful.
tr: She quickly reached towards the foot of the bed and pulled me out; when the man turned back, Mrs. Phelps was grinning with all her teeth showing, and I was standing beside her obediently and drenched in sweat.
es: She leaned at the foot of the bed and gave me a tug to pull me out; and when her husband turned from the window, there she was, all smiling and radiant like the sun, and I beside her, quiet and sweaty.

es: —It's Tom Sawyer!

en: By jings, I most slumped through the floor!
