es: I swear I almost fell to the ground!

en: But there warn’t no time to swap knives; the old man grabbed me by the hand and shook, and kept on shaking; and all the time how the woman did dance around and laugh and cry; and then how they both did fire off questions about Sid, and Mary, and the rest of the tribe.
vi: But the man grabbed my hand and kept shaking it, while his wife jumped around, laughing and talking. The couple asked me countless questions about Sid, Mary, and all the relatives.
tr: But before I could pull myself together, the old man hugged me and shook my hand; while he was shaking my hand, the woman was jumping around us, both laughing and crying; then both of them started bombarding me with questions about Sid, Mary, and the rest of the tribe.
es: But I didn't have time to change tactics; the old man grabbed my hand and shook it over and over, and all the while the woman danced around us laughing and crying; then the two of them started asking me loads of questions about Sid and Mary and the rest of the tribe.

en: But if they was joyful, it warn’t nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was.
vi: But if they were happy one-fold, I was happy ten-fold. I felt as if I was born anew, I was joyful because I knew who I was.
tr: They were very happy, but I couldn't contain my joy; because I felt like I was reborn, I was very pleased to learn who I was.
es: But if they were happy, that was nothing compared to me, because it was like being born again. I was overjoyed to find out who I was.

en: Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldn’t hardly go any more, I had told them more about my family—I mean the Sawyer family—than ever happened to any six Sawyer families.
vi: The past two hours, I was scared out of my wits. I also told them many more things about my family - that is, about Tom Sawyer's family.
tr: They continued with their questions for two hours; finally, my jaw was too tired to speak; I had told them so much about my family – that is, the Sawyer family – that it would have been enough for at least six Sawyer families.
es: Well, they stuck with me for two hours, and finally, when my tongue was so tired that I could hardly move it, I had already told them more things about my family (I mean the Sawyer family) than could have happened to six Sawyer families combined.

en: And I explained all about how we blowed out a cylinder-head at the mouth of White River, and it took us three days to fix it.
vi: Then I recounted the story of the boiler explosion on the White River, and how I had to stay there for three days.
tr: I also told them how the cylinder head blew at the mouth of the White River and how they spent three days repairing it.
es: And I explained all the details of how a cylinder head had blown at the mouth of the White River and it had taken us three days to fix it.

en: Which was all right, and worked first-rate; because they didn’t know but what it would take three days to fix it.
vi: Then I recounted the story of the boiler explosion on the White River, and how I had to stay there for three days.
tr: There was no problem here either, in fact, it was quite convincing; because they had no idea whether it would take three days to repair a cylinder head.
es: Which was very good and worked wonderfully, because they didn't know if it took three days to fix it.

en: If I’d a called it a bolthead it would a done just as well.
vi: Then I recounted the story of the boiler explosion on the White River, and how I had to stay there for three days.
tr: They would probably have believed me just as much if I had said a bolt had broken.
es: If I had told them that we had blown a bolt, they wouldn't have cared.

en: Now I was feeling pretty comfortable all down one side, and pretty uncomfortable all up the other.
vi: By this time, I felt quite at ease, but there were still many things to worry about.
tr: While on one hand I felt very comfortable, on the other hand I didn't feel comfortable at all.
es: Now I felt very calm on one hand and very uneasy on the other.

en: Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable, and it stayed easy and comfortable till by-and-by I hear a steamboat coughing along down the river.
vi: Playing the role of Tom Sawyer was very easy, but my heart skipped a beat whenever I heard the chugging sound of a boat on the river because what if Tom was on that boat?
tr: Being Tom Sawyer was very easy and comfortable; this ease and comfort lasted until I heard the sound of a steamboat from the river – but then I said to myself, what if Tom Sawyer is on that steamboat?
es: Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable for me, and it continued to be so until after a while I heard a steamboat coming down the river.

en: Then I says to myself, s’pose Tom Sawyer comes down on that boat?
vi: Playing the role of Tom Sawyer was very easy, but my heart skipped a beat whenever I heard the chugging sound of a boat on the river because what if Tom was on that boat?
tr: Being Tom Sawyer was very easy and comfortable; this ease and comfort lasted until I heard the sound of a steamboat from the river – but then I said to myself, what if Tom Sawyer is on that steamboat?
es: Then I said to myself: "What if Tom Sawyer is on that boat?

en: And s’pose he steps in here any minute, and sings out my name before I can throw him a wink to keep quiet?
vi: Playing the role of Tom Sawyer was very easy, but my heart skipped a beat whenever I heard the chugging sound of a boat on the river because what if Tom was on that boat?
tr: What if he suddenly appears and says my name before I can even wink at him to keep quiet?
es: What if he arrives at any moment and calls me by my name before I can give him a wink to not say anything?"

en: Well, I couldn’t have it that way; it wouldn’t do at all.
vi: It can't be left like this.
tr: I couldn't allow this – then all my plans would be ruined.
es: Well, I couldn't let it happen because it would ruin everything.

en: I must go up the road and waylay him.
vi: I have to go out on the street to pick it up first.
tr: I had to go up the road and meet him.
es: I had to go to the road and stop it in time.

en: So I told the folks I reckoned I would go up to the town and fetch down my baggage.
vi: Thinking that, I told everyone that I wanted to go get the luggage.
tr: So I told my aunts that I would go to town and get my things.
es: So I told those two that I would go to town to fetch my luggage.

en: The old gentleman was for going along with me, but I said no, I could drive the horse myself, and I druther he wouldn’t take no trouble about me.
vi: The husband also wanted to go with me, but I refused, as I could drive the carriage myself and didn't want to trouble him.
tr: The big man was going to come with me, but I didn't agree, I could ride the horse by myself, there was no need for him to bother.
es: The old man wanted to come with me, but I told him no, that I could drive the horse myself and that I preferred he didn't trouble himself for me.

en: CHAPTER XXXIII.
vi: Chapter XXXIII
tr: Thirty-Third Chapter
es: Chapter 33

en: So I started for town in the wagon, and when I was half-way I see a wagon coming, and sure enough it was Tom Sawyer, and I stopped and waited till he come along.
vi: I drove the horse-drawn carriage to the town. Halfway there, I encountered another carriage coming towards me. It was indeed Tom Sawyer. I stopped the carriage and waited for him to come closer. I shouted: - Stop the car!
tr: So I jumped into the car and set off towards the town; I had just reached halfway when I saw a car coming from the opposite direction. I immediately recognized Tom Sawyer, stopped where I was, and waited until he approached. When I shouted "Stop!", the driver pulled the reins right beside me.
es: SO I SET off towards the town with the cart, and when I was halfway there, I saw another cart coming, and sure enough, it was Tom Sawyer, so I stopped and waited until he arrived.

en: I says “Hold on!” and it stopped alongside, and his mouth opened up like a trunk, and stayed so; and he swallowed two or three times like a person that’s got a dry throat, and then says:
vi: Tom opened his mouth wide, stood still in silence, swallowed a few times, and then said:
tr: Tom stared with his mouth open, then after swallowing two or three times as if his throat was dry, he managed to speak:
es: I said to him: "Stop!", and he stopped next to me, opened his mouth wide, and stayed like that; he swallowed two or three times, just like a priest when his throat gets dry, and then he said:

en: “I hain’t ever done you no harm.
vi: - I haven't done anything to harm you.
tr: "I had never done anything bad to you.

en: You know that.
vi: - I haven't done anything to harm you.
tr: You know this.
es: And you know it.

en: I says:
vi: I said:

es: I replied:

tr: “I didn't come back,” I said, “because I never left.”
es: —I haven't returned... I never left.

en: When he heard my voice it righted him up some, but he warn’t quite satisfied yet.
vi: Hearing my voice, it seemed less scared, but still trembling.
tr: When he heard my voice, he came to his senses a bit, but he was still not fully convinced.
es: When he heard my voice, he calmed down a bit, but he still wasn't entirely convinced.

en: He says:

es: —Don't do anything bad to me, because I wouldn't do it to you.

en: Honest injun now, you ain’t a ghost?”
vi: You're not a ghost, are you?
tr: Tell the truth, are you a ghost or not?”
es: Do you swear that you are not a ghost?

en: “Honest injun, I ain’t,” I says.
vi: - I'm not a ghost.

en: “Well—I—I—well, that ought to settle it, of course; but I can’t somehow seem to understand it no way.
vi: - But I still don't understand.
tr: “Well then… I… I… now I believe of course; but I still can't understand.
es: —Well... I... Well, of course that should be enough, but the truth is I don't understand anything.

en: Looky here, warn’t you ever murdered at all?”
vi: So, weren't you killed?
tr: Weren't you killed?”
es: Look, have you never been murdered?

en: “No.
vi: - No, I have never been killed.
tr: Weren't you killed?”
es: —No.

en: I warn’t ever murdered at all—I played it on them.
vi: - No, I have never been killed.
tr: "Yo. I wasn't killed... I had arranged everything.
es: They never killed me... It was a trick of mine.

en: You come in here and feel of me if you don’t believe me.”
vi: Come closer and if you don't believe it, just touch me and see.
tr: If you don't believe me, come and touch me."
es: Come closer and touch me if you don't believe me.

en: So he done it; and it satisfied him; and he was that glad to see me again he didn’t know what to do.
vi: It came close to touch me, realizing it was true, it was so happy but it didn't know what to do yet.
tr: When he finally touched me, he believed it, he was so happy to see me again that he didn't know what to do.
es: That was what he did, and he was convinced, and he was so happy to see me again that he didn't know what to do.

en: And he wanted to know all about it right off, because it was a grand adventure, and mysterious, and so it hit him where he lived.
vi: It came close to touch me, realizing it was true, it was so happy but it didn't know what to do yet.
tr: He immediately wanted me to tell him everything because I had experienced a tremendous and mysterious adventure, which was just his kind of thing.
es: He wanted to find out everything immediately, because it was a great mysterious adventure, so it was what he liked.

en: But I said, leave it alone till by-and-by; and told his driver to wait, and we drove off a little piece, and I told him the kind of a fix I was in, and what did he reckon we better do?
vi: And it wanted to know everything immediately, but I told it I would explain later, and for now, to tell the driver to wait.
tr: But I said we should leave the talking for later; I asked the driver to wait a bit and took Tom aside. I told him what kind of trouble we were in and asked what the best solution would be.
es: But I told him to leave all that for later and told his coachman to wait, and we moved aside a bit and I told him the problem I had and asked him what he thought was best to do.

en: He said, let him alone a minute, and don’t disturb him.
vi: Then I pulled it aside, told it about my dilemma, and asked how to handle it.
tr: He asked me to leave him alone for a minute and not to disturb him at all.
es: He said to let him think for a moment and not to tell him anything.

en: So he thought and thought, and pretty soon he says:
vi: After thinking for a minute, it said:
tr: After thinking deeply for a while, he turned to me:
es: So he kept thinking and thinking, and after a moment he goes and says:

en: “It’s all right; I’ve got it.
vi: - Alright, I've got a plan.
tr: “Alright, I found it.
es: —Alright; I have it now.

en: Take my trunk in your wagon, and let on it’s your’n; and you turn back and fool along slow, so as to get to the house about the time you ought to; and I’ll go towards town a piece, and take a fresh start, and get there a quarter or a half an hour after you; and you needn’t let on to know me at first.”
vi: Take my chest, put it in your car and act like it's yours, then you drive back slowly, timing it so you get home just in time. I'll head to the city for a bit and then start back, arriving about fifteen minutes or half an hour after you, and at first, you have to act like you don't know who I am.
tr: Let's put my stuff in your car, and you'll act like it's your stuff. Now go back and slowly head towards home, you should return at the time you are supposed to. I'll first go back to the town, then I'll hit the road again and follow you fifteen minutes or half an hour later.
es: Put my trunk in your cart and say it's yours; and come back slowly, so you arrive at the house around the estimated time; I will retrace my steps a bit to start over and arrive a quarter or half an hour after you, and at first, you don't have to say that you know me.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: At first, don't let on that you know me.”
es: I replied:

en: “All right; but wait a minute.
vi: - Wait a minute.
tr: “Alright, but wait a minute,” I said.
es: —Very well, but wait a moment.

en: There’s one more thing—a thing that nobody don’t know but me.
vi: There's one more thing.
tr: “There is one more issue… An issue that no one else knows but me.
es: There is something else: something that no one else knows but me, and that is that there is a black man there whom I want to steal to set him free, and his name is Jim; Miss Watson's old Jim.

en: And that is, there’s a nigger here that I’m a-trying to steal out of slavery, and his name is Jim—old Miss Watson’s Jim.”
vi: That is, there's a black man here, I'm trying to save him from being enslaved, his name is Jim. Miss Watson's Jim, you know.right
tr: There is a black man here whom I am trying to free from slavery… His name is Jim… he is Miss Watson’s black man.”
es: There is something else: something that no one else knows but me, and that is that there is a black man there whom I want to steal to set him free, and his name is Jim; Miss Watson's old Jim.

en: He says:
vi: It was surprised:
tr: “What did you say?
es: And he goes and says:

en: “What!
vi: - What?
tr: “What did you say?
es: —What!

en: Why, Jim is—”
vi: Jim?
tr: But Jim…”
es: But Jim already...

en: He stopped and went to studying.
tr: He suddenly fell silent and began to think again.
es: He stopped and kept thinking about it, and then I go and say:

en: I says:
vi: I said immediately:
tr: “I know what you're going to say,” I said.
es: He stopped and kept thinking about it, and then I go and say:

en: “I know what you’ll say.
vi: - I know what you're going to say.
tr: “I know what you're going to say,” I said.
es: —I know what you're going to say.

en: You’ll say it’s dirty, low-down business; but what if it is?
vi: You're going to say this is a bad, despicable thing: but so what?
tr: “You're going to say that this is a very dirty and vile job, but no matter what...
es: You're going to say that it's a dirty and vile matter, but what do I care?

en: I’m low down; and I’m a-going to steal him, and I want you keep mum and not let on.
vi: I know it's not good, but I'm going to steal it.
tr: I accept its vileness and I will definitely save him, so I want you to stay silent and not let anyone suspect anything.
es: I'm vile and I'm going to steal it and I want you to stay quiet and not say anything.

en: Will you?”
vi: You have to keep it a secret and not tell anyone, okay?
tr: Will you do this?”
es: Do you want to?

en: His eye lit up, and he says:
vi: Its eyes lit up:
tr: Tom's eyes sparkled.
es: His eyes lit up and he said:

en: “I’ll help you steal him!”
vi: - I will help you steal it back!
tr: "I will help you save him!"
es: —I'm going to help you steal it!

en: Well, I let go all holts then, like I was shot.
vi: - I will help you steal it back!
tr: I was almost speechless with astonishment.
es: I was stunned, as if I had been shot.

en: It was the most astonishing speech I ever heard—and I’m bound to say Tom Sawyer fell considerable in my estimation.
vi: What surprised me the most was that I had never heard of it and I am ready to say that Tom deserves a lot of my admiration.
tr: These were the most surprising words that had ever come out of Tom's mouth until that day... Additionally, I must say that Tom Sawyer had significantly fallen in my esteem.
es: That was the most astonishing thing I had ever heard in my life, and I have to say that Tom Sawyer fell a lot in my esteem.

en: Only I couldn’t believe it.
vi: But the thing is, I still can't believe it, Tom Sawyer as a person who would steal black people??
tr: But on the other hand, I couldn't believe it.
es: I just couldn't believe it.

en: Tom Sawyer a nigger stealer!
vi: But the thing is, I still can't believe it, Tom Sawyer as a person who would steal black people??
tr: Tom Sawyer, the Negro thief!
es: Tom turned into a thief of black people!

en: “Oh, shucks!” I says; “you’re joking.”
vi: I said: - Stop it, don't joke like that. - I'm being serious.
tr: “No way, you must be joking,” I said.
es: —Well, let's go! —I said—. You're joking.

en: “I ain’t joking, either.”
vi: I said:
tr: “I am not joking at all.”
es: —Joking, nothing.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “joking or no joking, if you hear anything said about a runaway nigger, don’t forget to remember that you don’t know nothing about him, and I don’t know nothing about him.”
vi: - Alright, joke or no joke, if you hear about a runaway black man, you have to remember that you know nothing about him, and I know nothing about him either.
tr: “Anyway, whether it's a joke or not, if you hear talk about a runaway black man, don't let on that you know anything, remember I don't know anything either.”
es: —Well, then —I said—, joke or not, if you hear anything about a runaway black man, don't forget that you know nothing about him and neither do I.

en: Then we took the trunk and put it in my wagon, and he drove off his way and I drove mine.
vi: He went to get the chest and put it in my car, then he went his way, and I went mine.
tr: Then we took the chest and put it in my car, he went his way, and I went mine.
es: Then he took out his trunk and put it in my cart, and he went on his way and I went on mine.

en: But of course I forgot all about driving slow on accounts of being glad and full of thinking; so I got home a heap too quick for that length of a trip.
vi: But somehow I completely forgot to drive slowly, because I was too excited and thinking about many things. As a result, I got home too quickly.
tr: But of course, I had completely forgotten what he said about driving slowly, I was very happy and my head was full of thoughts; I returned home in an unusually short time for that journey.
es: But, naturally, I forgot that I had to go slowly because I was so happy and full of ideas, so I arrived home too early for such a long trip.

en: The old gentleman was at the door, and he says:
vi: Mr. Phelps was standing at the door waiting for me, and when he saw that I had returned, he said:
tr: The old man was standing at the door:
es: The old man was at the door and says:

en: “Why, this is wonderful!
vi: - Well, I never expected this horse to run so fast.
tr: “Isn't this wonderful?
es: —Man, what a marvel!

en: Whoever would a thought it was in that mare to do it?
vi: - Well, I never expected this horse to run so fast.
tr: Who would have guessed that this mare could accomplish such a feat.
es: Who would have thought that mare was capable of running so much!

en: I wish we’d a timed her.
vi: - Well, I never expected this horse to run so fast.
tr: I thought she was getting old.
es: I wish we had timed her.

en: And she hain’t sweated a hair—not a hair.
vi: And yet it doesn't sweat a bit, not a single hair is wet.
tr: And she hasn't even broken a sweat, wow.
es: And she hasn't sweated a drop, not a single drop.

en: It’s wonderful.
vi: It's amazing.
tr: Truly magnificent.
es: She is a marvel.

en: Why, I wouldn’t take a hundred dollars for that horse now—I wouldn’t, honest; and yet I’d a sold her for fifteen before, and thought ’twas all she was worth.”
vi: Now, even if someone offers a hundred dollars, I wouldn't sell it anymore. Yet before, I intended to sell it for just fifteen dollars, thinking that's all it was worth.
tr: Now, I'll sell this horse to anyone who kisses my hand for a hundred dollars; whereas this morning, I was lamenting that she wasn't even worth fifteen dollars and thought I couldn't ask for more.”
es: Man, now I wouldn't accept even a hundred dollars for that mare, really, and yet before I would have sold her for fifteen and been quite happy.

en: That’s all he said.
vi: He only said maybe.
tr: He didn't say anything else.
es: He didn't say anything else.

en: He was the innocentest, best old soul I ever see.
vi: I have never seen an old man as kind and gentle as him.
tr: He was the kindest-hearted, most well-intentioned man I had ever seen until that day.
es: He was the most innocent and kindest person I have ever seen in my life.

en: But it warn’t surprising; because he warn’t only just a farmer, he was a preacher, too, and had a little one-horse log church down back of the plantation, which he built it himself at his own expense, for a church and schoolhouse, and never charged nothing for his preaching, and it was worth it, too.
vi: He was originally a landowner and also served as a pastor. He personally spent money to build a church at the end of the plantation, and he preached there without taking any money.
tr: But this was not surprising, because he was not only a farmer but also a priest, and he had a tiny church at the back of the plantation. He had paid for the expenses of the church and the classroom out of his own pocket, and despite giving very good sermons, he didn't take a penny from anyone.
es: But it wasn't surprising, because he was not only a farmer but also a preacher, and he had a small log church at the back of the plantation that he had built out of his own pocket to serve as a church and a school, and he never charged anything for preaching, and the truth was that he did it very well.

en: There was plenty other farmer-preachers like that, and done the same way, down South.
vi: In the South, there are many people who are both landowners and pastors like that.
tr: There are many farmer-priests like him in the South, and they all behave the same way.
es: Down in the South, there were many farmer-preachers like him who did the same thing.

en: In about half an hour Tom’s wagon drove up to the front stile, and Aunt Sally she see it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards, and says:
vi: About half an hour later, Tom's car arrived in front of the door. Aunt Saly also saw it through the window.
tr: About half an hour later, Tom's car appeared on the road in front, and since the road was only about fifty meters away, Aunt Sally immediately noticed:
es: After about half an hour, Tom's cart appeared at the front door and Aunt Sally saw it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards away, and she said:

en: “Why, there’s somebody come!
vi: She said:
tr: “Aaa, someone is coming!
es: —Well, someone has come!

en: I wonder who ’tis?
vi: - Who could it be?
tr: I wonder who?
es: Who could it be?

en: Why, I do believe it’s a stranger.
vi: It might be a stranger, Jimmy (the name of a child).
tr: It seems to be a stranger.
es: It seems to be a stranger.

en: Jimmy” (that’s one of the children) “run and tell Lize to put on another plate for dinner.”
vi: Go tell Lize to set an extra plate.
tr: Jimmy (it was the name of one of the children) run and tell Lize to set another plate on the table.”
es: Jimmy —who was one of their children—, run and tell Lize to set another plate for the meal.

en: Everybody made a rush for the front door, because, of course, a stranger don’t come every year, and so he lays over the yaller-fever, for interest, when he does come.
vi: Everyone rushed to the front door because it was very rare for strangers to visit here.
tr: Everyone rushed to the front door, because it was not common for a stranger to come to the farm. So the arrival of a stranger caused more excitement than the arrival of yellow fever.
es: Everyone rushed to the front door because, naturally, strangers don't arrive every year, so they are more interesting than yellow fever.

en: Tom was over the stile and starting for the house; the wagon was spinning up the road for the village, and we was all bunched in the front door.
vi: Tom had reached the fence and was walking into the house, the carriage continued into the village, and we were all standing outside the door.
tr: Tom was coming towards the house, having passed the fences, the car had turned towards the town, and we were all gathered at the front door.
es: Tom had already crossed the door and was heading towards the house; the cart was turning towards the town and we were all crowded at the entrance.

en: Tom had his store clothes on, and an audience—and that was always nuts for Tom Sawyer.
vi: Tom had reached the fence and was walking into the house, the carriage continued into the village, and we were all standing outside the door.
tr: Tom was wearing brand new clothes; and there was a large audience in front of him...
es: Tom was wearing the clothes bought at the store and had an audience, which was what Tom Sawyer liked most in the world.

en: In them circumstances it warn’t no trouble to him to throw in an amount of style that was suitable.
vi: Tom was dressed in ready-made clothes, looking dignified.
tr: This was his moment to shine. It was hard to even imagine how he would show off under such circumstances.
es: In such circumstances, it was not difficult for him to put on all the airs he needed.

en: He warn’t a boy to meeky along up that yard like a sheep; no, he come ca’m and important, like the ram.
vi: He was not a timid person like a sheep.
tr: He was coming not meekly like a lamb, but upright like a ram.
es: He was not a boy to arrive meek as a lamb; no, he arrived calmly and with an air of importance, like a ram.

en: When he got a-front of us he lifts his hat ever so gracious and dainty, like it was the lid of a box that had butterflies asleep in it and he didn’t want to disturb them, and says:
vi: As he approached us, he gracefully and politely took off his hat, as if he were holding a lid with butterflies perched and sleeping on it that he didn't want to disturb. He asked:
tr: The way he took off his hat and greeted us, you would think he was trying not to disturb the delicate butterflies sleeping underneath it.
es: When he got in front of us, he took off his hat very elegantly and very finely, as if it were the lid of a box inside which butterflies were sleeping and he didn't want to disturb them, and he goes and says:

en: “mr Archibald Nichols, I presume?”
vi: - Excuse me, is this the house of Archibald Nichols? Mr. Phen replied: - That's not right.
tr: "Am I honored to meet Mr. Archibald Nichols?" he said.
es: —Mr. Archibald Nichols, I presume?

en: “No, my boy,” says the old gentleman, “I’m sorry to say ’t your driver has deceived you; Nichols’s place is down a matter of three mile more.
vi: I'm sorry, but the coachman has deceived you. Mr. Nichols' house is still three miles away from here.
tr: “No; my son,” said the old man, “unfortunately, the coachman has deceived you; Nichols's house is three miles down the road.
es: —No, boy —said the old man—. I'm sorry to tell you that your driver has deceived you; Nichols' house is about three miles further.

en: Come in, come in.”
vi: Come in first.
tr: Come inside. Come inside.”
es: Come in, come in.

en: Tom he took a look back over his shoulder, and says, “Too late—he’s out of sight.”
vi: Tom turned around and said: - It's too late, the bus has gone too far.
tr: Tom turned and looked over his shoulder. "Too late... it's out of sight," he said.
es: Tom glanced over his shoulder and says: —Too late, you can't see it anymore.

en: “Yes, he’s gone, my son, and you must come in and eat your dinner with us; and then we’ll hitch up and take you down to Nichols’s.”
vi: - Come in and have dinner with us first, then we will arrange a car to take you to Mr. Nichols' house.
tr: “Yes, he left, my son, you should come and eat with us; after that, we will get in my car and I will take you to the Nichols’ place.”
es: —Yes, he has gone, my son, and you must come in and eat with us, and then we will harness the mare and take you to Nichols' house.

en: “Oh, I can’t make you so much trouble; I couldn’t think of it.
vi: - Oh, I wouldn't dare trouble you both.
tr: "Well, I don't want to trouble you that much; absolutely not.
es: —Ah, I can't cause you so much trouble; not even think about it.

en: I’ll walk—I don’t mind the distance.”
vi: It's just a short walk to get there.
tr: I'll walk... It's not very far."
es: I'll go on foot... I don't mind the distance.

en: “But we won’t let you walk—it wouldn’t be Southern hospitality to do it.
vi: - But we won't let you walk. Southern people are very hospitable.
tr: “But I can't let you walk... It wouldn't befit Southern hospitality.
es: —But we are not going to let you go on foot; that would not be Southern hospitality.

en: Come right in.”
vi: Just come in here first.
tr: Come inside immediately.”
es: Just go on.

en: “Oh, do,” says Aunt Sally; “it ain’t a bit of trouble to us, not a bit in the world.
vi: Aunt Saly said: - Please come in, we don't mind at all.
tr: “Please come in,” said Aunt Sally; “it’s no trouble for us at all, it’s nothing really.
es: —Yes, please —said Aunt Sally—; it's no trouble at all.

en: You must stay.
vi: You must stay here for now.
tr: You must stay for a while.
es: You must stay.

en: It’s a long, dusty three mile, and we can’t let you walk.
vi: The road to there is as far as three miles and very dusty, we can't let you walk.
tr: The road is three miles but everything is covered in dust, we can’t let you walk.
es: It's three long miles and there's a lot of dust; we can't let you go on foot.

en: And, besides, I’ve already told ’em to put on another plate when I see you coming; so you mustn’t disappoint us.
vi: Moreover, we have already set extra plates.
tr: In fact, when I saw you coming, I told them to set another plate at the table, don’t disappoint us.
es: And besides, I've already told them to set another plate when I saw you coming, so you mustn't disappoint us.

en: Come right in and make yourself at home.”
vi: Make yourself at home, Thompson.
tr: Come in and make yourself at home.”
es: Come inside, make yourself at home.

en: So Tom he thanked them very hearty and handsome, and let himself be persuaded, and come in; and when he was in he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, and his name was William Thompson—and he made another bow.
vi: So Tom thanked very enthusiastically and skillfully, pretending to reluctantly step into the house; then he said that he was from Ohio and his name was William Thompson.
tr: Tom sincerely and gracefully thanked them, entered without further ado; after entering, he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, that his name was William Thompson, and bowed again in greeting.
es: So Tom thanked them very animatedly and courteously and allowed himself to be persuaded; once inside, he said he was from Hicksville, Ohio, and that his name was William Thompson, and made another bow.

en: Well, he run on, and on, and on, making up stuff about Hicksville and everybody in it he could invent, and I getting a little nervious, and wondering how this was going to help me out of my scrape; and at last, still talking along, he reached over and kissed Aunt Sally right on the mouth, and then settled back again in his chair comfortable, and was going on talking; but she jumped up and wiped it off with the back of her hand, and says:
vi: He rambled on endlessly about all the things he made up in Ohio, and I started to feel uneasy and worried about how he intended to help me get out of this difficult situation. Finally, in the middle of the conversation, he suddenly stood up and kissed Aunt Saly right on the mouth, then sat back down properly in his chair and continued talking. Aunt Saly jerked back, wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, and said:
tr: So he went on and on, making up a bunch of things about Hicksville and the people living there; I was starting to get tense. I was wondering how any of this would provide a solution to our situation; finally, without stopping his speech, he leaned over and kissed Aunt Sally on the mouth, then sat back down in his chair and settled in, about to continue his words when Aunt Sally suddenly jumped up, wiped her lips with the back of her hand, and shouted:
es: Well, he didn't stop talking and talking and talking, making up things about Hicksville and all kinds of people that came to his mind, and I was getting nervous and wondering how that was going to help me out of the predicament; finally, while he was still talking, he got up and gave Aunt Sally a kiss right on the mouth and then sat back down in his chair as calmly as ever and was about to continue talking; but Aunt Sally jumped up, wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, and said:

en: “You owdacious puppy!”
vi: - This boy is too rude!
tr: "You shameless dog!"
es: —You insolent, rude person!

en: He looked kind of hurt, and says:
vi: It seemed to be offended, saying:
tr: Tom looked at her as if he were hurt:
es: He seemed to be in pain, and he goes and says:

en: “I’m surprised at you, m’am.”
vi: - Madam, why is it so?
tr: "You surprised me a lot, ma'am." “Surprised? Did I surprise you?
es: —I am surprised, ma'am. —Does it surprise you...

en: “You’re s’rp—Why, what do you reckon I am?
vi: - Who do you think I am?
tr: Now I will show you…
es: But, who do you think I am?

en: I’ve a good notion to take and—Say, what do you mean by kissing me?”
vi: What do you mean by kissing me?
tr: What are you trying to do?”
es: I really feel like grabbing and... But, what is this about giving me a kiss?

en: He looked kind of humble, and says:
vi: It again made a very polite response:
tr: Tom answered with a modest demeanor:
es: He seemed to shrink, and said:

en: “I didn’t mean nothing, m’am.
vi: -Madam, it doesn't mean anything at all, I thought you liked it that way.
tr: “Nothing, ma'am.
es: —It wasn't with bad intentions, ma'am.

en: I didn’t mean no harm.
vi: -Madam, it doesn't mean anything at all, I thought you liked it that way.
tr: I had no ill intentions.
es: I didn't mean to upset you, I... I... I thought you would like it.

en: I—I—thought you’d like it.”
vi: Are you crazy?
tr: I thought you would like it.”
es: I didn't mean to upset you, I... I... I thought you would like it.

en: “Why, you born fool!”
tr: "Yes, you little fool!"
es: —What an idiot!

en: She took up the spinning stick, and it looked like it was all she could do to keep from giving him a crack with it.
vi: She grabbed the rolling pin intending to hit him with it but managed to restrain herself -
tr: He grabbed the spindle stick, seeming to barely restrain himself from hitting her with it.
es: —he grabbed the spindle of the spinning wheel and it seemed like he was going to hit him with it—.

en: “What made you think I’d like it?”
vi: Why would you think I would like that?
tr: "What made you think I would like it?"
es: Why would I like it?

en: “Well, I don’t know.
vi: - I don't know.
tr: "I don't know.
es: —Well, I don't know.

en: Only, they—they—told me you would.”
vi: They said that you like it that way.
tr: But they told me... they told me you would like it."
es: It's just that... It's just that...

en: “They told you I would.
vi: They said that you like it that way.
tr: “So they said that.
es: They told me it would be like this. —They told you it would be like this.

en: Whoever told you’s another lunatic.
vi: - Whoever told you that is crazy.
tr: Whoever said it must be a fool.
es: Well, the one who told you is another lunatic.

en: I never heard the beat of it.
vi: I have never heard anyone say something so strange.
tr: I've never heard such a thing.
es: I've never heard anything like it.

en: Who’s they?”
vi: Who are they?
tr: Who are you talking about?”
es: Who told you?

en: “Why, everybody.
vi: - Everyone says so, ma'am.
tr: "Well... everyone."
es: —Well, everyone.

en: They all said so, m’am.”
vi: - Everyone says so, ma'am.
tr: "They all said so, ma'am.""
es: That's what they said, ma'am.

en: It was all she could do to hold in; and her eyes snapped, and her fingers worked like she wanted to scratch him; and she says:
vi: At this point, Mrs. Saly couldn't stand it any longer, her eyes blinked, her fingers twitched as if wanting to scratch it, and she asked:
tr: Aunt Sally was about to lose herself, her eyes were bulging, her fingers were spread as if she wanted to scratch him.
es: She could barely contain herself, her eyes were blazing with anger, and she moved her fingers as if she wanted to scratch him, and she said:

en: “Who’s ‘everybody’?
vi: - Who are all these people?
tr: "'Everyone' you say, who are they?"
es: —Who is everyone?

en: Out with their names, or ther’ll be an idiot short.”
vi: What are their names? Speak quickly, or don't blame me.
tr: "Quickly give their names; otherwise, this world will be short one more fool.""
es: Give me their names or there will be one less idiot in this world.

en: He got up and looked distressed, and fumbled his hat, and says:
vi: Tom stood up, pretending to be disappointed, picked up his hat, and said:
tr: Tom stood up gloomily, speaking while playing with his hat:
es: Tom stood up, looking hurried, turning his hat around, and said:

en: “I’m sorry, and I warn’t expecting it.
vi: - I'm sorry.
tr: “I'm sorry, I didn't expect it at all.
es: —I'm sorry, and I didn't expect it.

en: They told me to.
vi: I didn't expect things to turn out this way.
tr: They told me so.
es: They told me.

en: They all told me to.
vi: They all told me to kiss you because you really like it.
tr: They all said so.
es: They all told me.

en: They all said, kiss her; and said she’d like it.
vi: They all told me to kiss you because you really like it.
tr: They said if you kiss her, she will like it.
es: Everyone told me "give her a kiss," and they said she would like it.

en: They all said it—every one of them.
vi: They all told me to kiss you because you really like it.
tr: They all said it… every single one of them.
es: Everyone said it, to the last one, but I'm sorry, ma'am, and I won't do it again.

en: But I’m sorry, m’am, and I won’t do it no more—I won’t, honest.”
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: But I'm very sorry, ma'am, I won't do it again… I swear.”
es: Really, I won't.

en: “You won’t, won’t you?
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: "Won't you do it, won't you do it?
es: —So you won't do it again, right?

en: Well, I sh’d reckon you won’t!”
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: Just try and let's see!"
es: Man, I assure you!

en: “No’m, I’m honest about it; I won’t ever do it again—till you ask me.”
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: “No; I swore, I will never do it again. Of course, unless you want me to.”
es: —No, I mean it; I will never do it again until you ask me to.

en: “Till I ask you!
vi: - My request?
tr: "What if I don't want to?
es: —Until I ask you for it!

en: Well, I never see the beat of it in my born days!
vi: Since I was little, I have never seen anything as strange as this.
tr: I've never seen such rudeness in my life!
es: Well, I have never heard anything like it in my entire life!

en: I lay you’ll be the Methusalem-numskull of creation before ever I ask you—or the likes of you.”
vi: Since I was little, I have never seen anything as strange as this.
tr: If you think I'll ask again, you must be the most foolish child ever... especially from someone like you!"
es: I assure you that you are going to be the dumbest Methuselah in creation before I ask you for anything like that.

en: “Well,” he says, “it does surprise me so.
vi: Since I was little, I have never seen anything as strange as this.
tr: “I am really surprised,” said Tom.
es: I assure you that you are going to be the dumbest Methuselah in creation before I ask you for anything like that.

en: I can’t make it out, somehow.
vi: Especially from someone like you.
tr: “Honestly, I just can't understand it.

en: They said you would, and I thought you would.
vi: It looked around, seemingly wanting to meet a friendly gaze, then looked at Mr. Phelps and asked:
tr: They said you would like it; I thought you would like it too.
es: Neither to you nor to anyone like you.

en: But—”
vi: It looked around, seemingly wanting to meet a friendly gaze, then looked at Mr. Phelps and asked:
tr: But…”
es: —Well —says Tom—, I am very surprised. I don't know why, but I don't understand it.

en: He stopped and looked around slow, like he wished he could run across a friendly eye somewheres, and fetched up on the old gentleman’s, and says, “Didn’t you think she’d like me to kiss her, sir?”
vi: - Do you think she wants the child to kiss her, sir?
tr: He paused and slowly looked around, as if searching for a friendly face; then he asked the old gentleman: “Didn't you think she would like me kissing her, sir?”
es: They said she would like it and I believed it too. But... —he fell silent and slowly looked from side to side, as if trying to find a friendly gaze somewhere, and finally stopped at the old man and asked him—: Didn't you think, sir, that she would like me to kiss her?

en: “Why, no; I—I—well, no, I b’lieve I didn’t.”
vi: - No, I don't think so.
tr: “No way, I… don't think so at all.”
es: —Well, no; I... I... don't think so.

en: Then he looks on around the same way to me, and says:
vi: Then it looked at me again in the same way and asked:
tr: He looked around again with the same expression, this time he asked me:
es: Then he kept looking until he stopped at me and asked:

en: “Tom, didn’t you think Aunt Sally ’d open out her arms and say, ‘Sid Sawyer—’”
vi: - Tom, do you think Aunt Sally will open her arms and call: Sid Sawyer?
tr: “Tom, didn't you think Aunt Sally would open her arms and say 'Sid Sawyer'?””
es: —Tom, didn't you think that Aunt Sally would open her arms and say, "Sid Sawyer..."?

en: “My land!” she says, breaking in and jumping for him, “you impudent young rascal, to fool a body so—” and was going to hug him, but he fended her off, and says:
vi: - Oh my God - Aunt Saly exclaimed and jumped towards him - you little rascal, did you trick me? Just as she was about to hug him, he pushed her away and said:
tr: Aunt Sally exclaimed, "Oh my God!" and rushed towards him, "you little impudent rascal, how dare you deceive me like this?" She wanted to hug him but Tom pulled back.
es: —My God! —she said, interrupting him and jumping towards him—, insolent creature, to deceive her like that... —and she was about to give him a hug but he pushed her away and said:

en: “No, not till you’ve asked me first.”
vi: - No, we have to wait for Auntie's request first!
tr: "It won't happen, not unless you want it.""
es: —No, first you have to ask me for it.

en: So she didn’t lose no time, but asked him; and hugged him and kissed him over and over again, and then turned him over to the old man, and he took what was left.
vi: So she immediately asked for it, and hugged it tightly, kissing it several times, then turned it towards her husband, who also kissed it for a while.
tr: Aunt Sally wanted to kiss him without further delay; then she hugged him, kissed him repeatedly, then gave him to the old man and took the rest herself.
es: So she did not waste any time, but asked for it and filled it with hugs and kisses over and over again, and then handed it to the old man, who did the same.

en: And after they got a little quiet again she says:
vi: After a while, when everything was quiet, she said:
tr: After calming down a bit, she said:
es: And when they calmed down a bit, she said:

en: “Why, dear me, I never see such a surprise.
vi: - Auntie has never been so surprised.
tr: “Oh my God, what a wonderful surprise this is.
es: —But my God, I have never seen such a surprise.

en: We warn’t looking for you at all, but only Tom.
vi: Your uncle and I thought only Tom was coming. The letter only mentioned that Tom would come.
tr: We were only expecting Tom, we had no idea you were coming.
es: We were not expecting you at all, only Tom.

en: Sis never wrote to me about anybody coming but him.”
vi: It says
tr: My sister never mentioned anyone else coming.”
es: My sister never told me that anyone else was coming besides him.

en: “It’s because it warn’t intended for any of us to come but Tom,” he says; “but I begged and begged, and at the last minute she let me come, too; so, coming down the river, me and Tom thought it would be a first-rate surprise for him to come here to the house first, and for me to by-and-by tag along and drop in, and let on to be a stranger.
vi: - That’s because aunt only wanted Tom to come, and didn’t want anyone else to come.
tr: “Because indeed, it was not planned for someone else to come along with Tom,” said our Tom, “but I begged him until he was fed up and at the last minute he allowed me to come too; then while coming down the river with Tom, we thought it would be a great surprise if he came first and then I came and acted like a stranger.
es: —Because he only thought of sending Tom —he said—, but I begged and begged and at the last moment he let me come too; so when we were going down the river, Tom and I thought it would be a great surprise if he arrived at the house first and then I appeared suddenly, pretending to be a stranger.

en: But it was a mistake, Aunt Sally.
vi: But I kept asking, and finally, my mom let me go too.
tr: But we made a mistake, Aunt Sally.
es: But we were wrong, Aunt Sally.

en: This ain’t no healthy place for a stranger to come.”
vi: After getting off the boat, Tom and I discussed that we should surprise aunt, so he would arrive first and I would pretend to just pass by and drop in, acting like a stranger.
tr: This is not a place where a stranger can come with peace of mind.”
es: This house is not safe for strangers.

en: “No—not impudent whelps, Sid.
vi: - I almost broke my teeth.
tr: “No… I have no intention of making those insolent brats comfortable, Mr. Sid.
es: —No, not even for insolent children, Sid.

en: You ought to had your jaws boxed; I hain’t been so put out since I don’t know when.
vi: It's been a long time since I was so shocked.
tr: You will learn to sit with decorum, I haven't been this angry in a long time.
es: I should have slapped you; God knows how long it’s been since I’ve had such a surprise.

en: But I don’t care, I don’t mind the terms—I’d be willing to stand a thousand such jokes to have you here.
vi: Oh, thinking about the moment you kissed her like that, I was scared to death.
tr: But it doesn't matter, I don't care how you came here… I can endure thousands of jokes without a word just to see you here.
es: But it doesn’t matter, I don’t care about the form: I’m willing to endure a thousand jokes like this as long as you’re here.

en: Well, to think of that performance!
vi: Oh, thinking about the moment you kissed her like that, I was scared to death.
tr: How much of an actor you are!
es: What a performance you’ve put on!

en: I don’t deny it, I was most putrified with astonishment when you give me that smack.”
vi: We had lunch in the wide corridor connecting the main house with the kitchen.
tr: I can't deny that when you kissed me, I was so shocked that my heart nearly stopped.”
es: I won’t deny it, I was almost petrified with astonishment when you kissed me.

en: We had dinner out in that broad open passage betwixt the house and the kitchen; and there was things enough on that table for seven families—and all hot, too; none of your flabby, tough meat that’s laid in a cupboard in a damp cellar all night and tastes like a hunk of old cold cannibal in the morning.
vi: The table was set with all sorts of dishes, enough for seven servants to finish, and every dish was hot.
tr: We ate our meal in the wide open passage between the house and the kitchen; there was enough food on the table to feed seven families – and it was all hot; it wasn't the kind of food that had sat all night in a damp cellar cupboard and wilted, looking like cannibal leftovers in the morning.
es: We dined in that wide passageway open between the house and the kitchen, and on the table, there was enough for seven families and everything was hot; none of that fibrous and tough meat that is kept in an icebox in a damp basement all night and in the morning tastes just like a piece of old, cold cannibal.

en: Uncle Silas he asked a pretty long blessing over it, but it was worth it; and it didn’t cool it a bit, neither, the way I’ve seen them kind of interruptions do lots of times.
vi: Uncle Silas cared a lot about the food and never let it get cold.
tr: Uncle Silas said a rather long prayer before the meal, but it was worth it; and the food didn't get cold at all, otherwise, I had witnessed many times before how the food got cold because of prayers.
es: Uncle Silas said a very long grace, but it was worth it, and things didn't get cold one bit, as I've seen happen many times with that kind of interruption.

en: There was a considerable good deal of talk all the afternoon, and me and Tom was on the lookout all the time; but it warn’t no use, they didn’t happen to say nothing about any runaway nigger, and we was afraid to try to work up to it.
vi: Throughout that entire afternoon, Tom and I had to be constantly on guard while talking about various things. But no one mentioned the runaway black man, and we were also afraid to bring it up.
tr: In the afternoon, there was hardly any silence; even though Tom and I listened intently, it was of no use, they didn't say anything about a runaway black man, and we were afraid to bring up the subject.
es: We spent the whole afternoon talking; Tom and I were alert the entire time, but it was all for nothing, because they didn't say a word about the runaway black man and we were afraid to bring up the subject ourselves.

en: But at supper, at night, one of the little boys says:
vi: At dinner, a child asked:
tr: But in the evening, at dinner, one of the little children asked:
es: But that night, at dinner time, one of the boys goes and says:

en: “Pa, mayn’t Tom and Sid and me go to the show?”
vi: - Dad, can you take Tom, Sid, and me to the theater?
tr: "Dad, can Tom, Sid, and I go to the show?"
es: —Father, can't Tom, Sid, and I go to see the show?

en: “No,” says the old man, “I reckon there ain’t going to be any; and you couldn’t go if there was; because the runaway nigger told Burton and me all about that scandalous show, and Burton said he would tell the people; so I reckon they’ve drove the owdacious loafers out of town before this time.”
vi: - No - the father replied - maybe it won't be performed, and even if it is, you kids won't be able to go, because the runaway black man told Mr. Burton that he would inform everyone, this time they might kick those useless guys out of here.
tr: “No,” said the old man, “and besides, there won't be any show; even if there was, you couldn't go; because the runaway black man told me and Burton everything about that disgraceful show, and Burton went to tell the townspeople; by now, they must have driven those shameless rascals out of town.”
es: —No —answered the old man—. I think there won't be one, and even if there were, you couldn't go, because the runaway black man has told Burton and me everything that happens in that scandalous show, and Burton said he was going to tell the people, so I think we've driven those boastful loafers out of town.

en: So there it was!—but I couldn’t help it.
vi: I don't know what to do.
tr: Here was Jim mentioned! But there was nothing to be done at that moment.
es: That's how things were! But we couldn't do anything.

en: Tom and me was to sleep in the same room and bed; so, being tired, we bid good-night and went up to bed right after supper, and clumb out of the window and down the lightning-rod, and shoved for the town; for I didn’t believe anybody was going to give the king and the duke a hint, and so if I didn’t hurry up and give them one they’d get into trouble sure.
vi: Tom and I also slept in the same room upstairs and shared a bed. Using the excuse of being too tired, we asked to go to bed immediately after eating. Then we climbed out the window, slid down the lamppost to the ground, and went into town. Because I didn't believe that anyone here had informed the king and the duke, if I didn't go and inform them, they would be in danger.
tr: Tom and I were going to sleep in the same room and in the same bed; right after dinner, we said goodnight to everyone, claiming we were very tired, and went to our room, immediately climbed out of the window, slid down the lightning rod, and headed quickly to the town; because I thought no one had informed the king and the duke, so if we didn't hurry and tell them what had happened, they would get into big trouble.
es: Tom and I had to sleep in the same room and in the same bed, so since we were tired, we said goodnight and went to bed immediately after dinner.

en: On the road Tom he told me all about how it was reckoned I was murdered, and how pap disappeared pretty soon, and didn’t come back no more, and what a stir there was when Jim run away; and I told Tom all about our Royal Nonesuch rapscallions, and as much of the raft voyage as I had time to; and as we struck into the town and up through the the middle of it—it was as much as half-after eight, then—here comes a raging rush of people with torches, and an awful whooping and yelling, and banging tin pans and blowing horns; and we jumped to one side to let them go by; and as they went by I see they had the king and the duke astraddle of a rail—that is, I knowed it was the king and the duke, though they was all over tar and feathers, and didn’t look like nothing in the world that was human—just looked like a couple of monstrous big soldier-plumes.
vi: On the way, Tom told me all about how everyone thought I had been killed, then my father disappeared and didn't come back, and how there was a commotion when Jim ran away. As for me, I told him about the two scoundrels performing in the play "The Royal Nonesuch," and about the journey on the wooden raft from then until now. Around half-past eight, we had reached the middle of the town when we suddenly saw a crowd of people carrying torches, banging pots and pans, and blowing horns. We quickly jumped to the side of the road to let them pass. As they went by, we saw they were leading the king and the duke, who were trapped in an iron bar, their bodies covered in tar and feathers, no longer looking human.
tr: Tom told me how I was thought to have been murdered, how my father disappeared shortly after and never returned, and the commotion that ensued when Jim escaped; I, in turn, told Tom everything about the Royal Nonesuch con men and our raft journey as much as time allowed; when we reached the town and got to the middle of it, we saw an angry mob coming; they had torches, and they were coming with terrifying shouts and screams, some banging pans, others blowing horns; we immediately threw ourselves aside to let them pass; as the crowd passed by, I saw that the king and the duke were each mounted on a pole – or rather, I realized they were the king and the duke, but they were covered in tar and feathers, they no longer resembled any human beings in this world – they looked more like a pair of gigantic soldier pincushions.
es: We went out through the window and climbed down the lightning rod to go to town, as I didn't think anyone was going to say a word to the king and the duke, so if I didn't run to warn them, they were surely going to get into a big mess. On the way, Tom told me that everyone had believed the story about my murder, and that father had disappeared immediately and hadn't returned, and the commotion that ensued when Jim escaped. I told Tom the whole story of our scoundrels from "The Peerless Royalty," and everything I had time to tell him about our raft journey. When we reached the town, towards the center (it must have been around eight-thirty), a bunch of people appeared running with torches, shouting and howling, banging pots and blowing horns; we stepped aside to let them pass, and I saw that they were carrying the king and the duke mounted on a rail. That is, I knew they were the king and the duke, although they had been smeared with tar and feathers and didn't look like beings from this world, but rather a kind of monstrous feather dusters.

en: Well, it made me sick to see it; and I was sorry for them poor pitiful rascals, it seemed like I couldn’t ever feel any hardness against them any more in the world.
vi: Seeing that scene, I felt moved and sorry for those two wretched scoundrels.
tr: I was devastated when I saw them. I felt sorry for these pitiful wretched scoundrels, and I felt that I could never be hard-hearted towards them again.
es: Well, I regretted seeing them and felt sorry for those poor rascals, as if I couldn't hold anything against them anymore.

en: It was a dreadful thing to see.
vi: Seeing that scene, I felt moved and sorry for those two wretched scoundrels.
tr: Their condition was truly hair-raising.
es: It was horrible to watch.

en: Human beings can be awful cruel to one another.
vi: How can people be so disgustingly cruel to one another?
tr: How cruel people can be to one another.
es: Human beings can be terribly cruel to one another.

en: We see we was too late—couldn’t do no good.
vi: We know that it is already too late, there's nothing we can do anymore.
tr: We realized that we were very late – there was nothing we could do.
es: We saw that we had arrived late, that we couldn't do anything anymore.

en: We asked some stragglers about it, and they said everybody went to the show looking very innocent; and laid low and kept dark till the poor old king was in the middle of his cavortings on the stage; then somebody give a signal, and the house rose up and went for them.
vi: When asked a few people, they said that everyone went to watch the play, pretending not to know anything. Wait until the king is gesticulating on stage, then someone gives a signal, and the whole theater rushes up to capture him.
tr: We asked passersby what had happened; according to what they said, everyone had gone to the show in seemingly innocent poses, and the poor old king hadn’t shown any sign until the middle of his antics on stage; then, when someone gave a signal, all the spectators rose up and pounced on them.
es: We asked some of the stragglers what had happened and they said that everyone had gone to the performance with innocent faces and had remained so calm and quiet until the poor king was in the middle of his antics on stage; then someone gave a signal and the entire audience stood up and rushed at them.

en: So we poked along back home, and I warn’t feeling so brash as I was before, but kind of ornery, and humble, and to blame, somehow—though I hadn’t done nothing.
vi: We returned home, and we were no longer as eager as when we left. I felt somewhat to blame even though I had nothing to do with this incident.
tr: We returned home, and now I felt neither cheerful like at the beginning, but base, vile, and guilty – even though I had done nothing.
es: So we went back home, and I no longer felt as proud as before, but rather shrunk and ashamed and as if I were to blame, even though I hadn't done anything.

en: But that’s always the way; it don’t make no difference whether you do right or wrong, a person’s conscience ain’t got no sense, and just goes for him anyway.
vi: Whether one does right or wrong, if a person doesn't realize it, it still gnaws at them just the same.
tr: But isn't it always like this; whether you do right or wrong changes nothing, the conscience has no logic, it aches incessantly in any case.
es: But that's what always happens; it doesn't matter whether one does things right or wrong, because the conscience has no common sense and it always gets on top of you no matter what happens.

en: If I had a yaller dog that didn’t know no more than a person’s conscience does I would pison him.
vi: Whether one does right or wrong, if a person doesn't realize it, it still gnaws at them just the same.
tr: If I had a dog as foolish as my conscience, I would poison it immediately.
es: If I had a yellow dog that wasn't smarter than people's conscience, I would poison it.

en: It takes up more room than all the rest of a person’s insides, and yet ain’t no good, nohow.
vi: Whether one does right or wrong, if a person doesn't realize it, it still gnaws at them just the same.
tr: This wretched thing takes up more space inside a person than anything else and serves no purpose.
es: It takes up more space than everything else, and yet, I don't know why, it's good for nothing.

en: Tom Sawyer he says the same.
vi: Tom Sawyer said the same thing.
tr: Tom Sawyer thought the same thing.
es: Tom Sawyer says the same thing.

en: CHAPTER XXXIV.
vi: Chapter XXXIV
tr: Chapter Thirty-Four
es: Chapter 34

en: We stopped talking, and got to thinking.
vi: We stopped talking and started thinking.
tr: We stopped talking and started thinking.
es: WE STOPPED TALKING and started thinking.

en: By-and-by Tom says:
vi: A moment later, Tom said:
tr: Shortly after, Tom said:
es: After a while, Tom says:

en: “Looky here, Huck, what fools we are to not think of it before!
vi: - Hey Huck, we were so dumb. It was possible, but we couldn't think of it.
tr: “Huck, why didn't we think of this before? We were so stupid.
es: —Hey, Huck, we're fools for not having thought of it before!

en: I bet I know where Jim is.”
vi: I know where Jim is now.
tr: I know exactly where Jim is.”
es: I bet I know where Jim is.

en: “No! Where?”
vi: - where?
tr: “No way! Where is it?”
es: —No! Where?

en: “In that hut down by the ash-hopper.
vi: - in the tent below the ash house.
tr: "In the cabin near the ash silo.
es: —In that cabin next to the one with the quicklime.

en: Why, looky here.
vi: - in the tent below the ash house.
tr: "In the cabin near the ash silo.
es: —In that cabin next to the one with the quicklime.

en: When we was at dinner, didn’t you see a nigger man go in there with some vittles?”
vi: Don't you remember seeing a black man go in there with some food?
tr: Remember, didn't you see a black man going there with a tray while we were having dinner?"
es: Listen to this: when we were eating, didn't you see a black man taking some food?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: "I saw it, didn't I."" “Where was that tray going?”” “Probably to a dog.”
es: —Yes.

en: “What did you think the vittles was for?”
vi: - Who do you think he gave it to?
tr: “I thought so too.
es: —Who do you think the food was for?

en: “For a dog.”
vi: - For the dog.
tr: But it wasn't going to the dog.”
es: —For a dog. —Me too.

en: “So’d I. Well, it wasn’t for a dog.”
vi: - I thought so too. But it's not for the dog.
tr: But it wasn't going to the dog.”
es: Well, it wasn't for a dog.

en: “Why?”
vi: - Why?
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “Because part of it was watermelon.”
vi: - Because there is a piece of melon in it.
tr: “Because there was also a watermelon on it.”
es: —Because he was also carrying a watermelon.

en: “So it was—I noticed it.
vi: - That's right, I noticed that too.
tr: “Of course... I had seen it too.
es: —It's true, I already saw it.

en: Well, it does beat all that I never thought about a dog not eating watermelon.
vi: But I thought dogs could eat melons, so I didn't suspect anything.
tr: This is what you call intelligence, it never occurred to me that dogs don't eat watermelon.
es: Imagine that it didn't occur to me that dogs don't eat watermelons.

en: It shows how a body can see and don’t see at the same time.”
vi: - The black man unlocked the door when he entered, locked it again when he left, and then gave the key to Mr. Phelps.
tr: Is there a better proof of human obliviousness than this?”
es: That shows that one can see things and not see them at the same time.

en: “Well, the nigger unlocked the padlock when he went in, and he locked it again when he came out.
vi: - The black man unlocked the door when he entered, locked it again when he left, and then gave the key to Mr. Phelps.
tr: “The black man unlocked the padlock and went inside, and when he came out, he put the lock back in place.
es: —Well, the black man opened the padlock when he entered and locked it again when he left.

en: He fetched uncle a key about the time we got up from table—same key, I bet.
vi: That means there is someone inside.
tr: When we got up from the table, he brought my uncle a key... that was the key, I'm sure of it.
es: When we got up from the table, he returned a key to the uncle, and I bet it was the same one.

en: Watermelon shows man, lock shows prisoner; and it ain’t likely there’s two prisoners on such a little plantation, and where the people’s all so kind and good.
vi: If it's locked, it means someone is imprisoned. But it doesn't make sense that in this small plantation there would be two people imprisoned, because I see everyone is good.
tr: The watermelon shows there was a person there, and the lock shows they were imprisoned; in such a small plantation, there probably aren't two prisoners, since everyone here gets along just fine.
es: The watermelon indicates that he is a man; the lock, that he is imprisoned, and it is unlikely that there are two prisoners on such a small plantation where all the people are so good and so kind.

en: Jim’s the prisoner.
vi: It's clear that Jim is imprisoned.
tr: The prisoner is none other than our Jim.
es: The prisoner is Jim.

en: All right—I’m glad we found it out detective fashion; I wouldn’t give shucks for any other way.
vi: I am determined to find Jim.
tr: Alright... I'm glad we figured this out like detectives, otherwise, it wouldn't be any fun.
es: Very well, I'm glad I figured it out like the detectives; otherwise, I wouldn't like it.

en: Now you work your mind, and study out a plan to steal Jim, and I will study out one, too; and we’ll take the one we like the best.”
vi: Now, you come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll think of another plan, then we'll see which one is better and do it.
tr: Now use your brain and come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll come up with one too, and we'll use whichever one we like better.”
es: Now you have to start thinking about it and come up with a plan to steal Jim; I'll come up with another one and we'll go with the one we like best.

en: What a head for just a boy to have!
vi: Tom is really clever.
tr: Such a mind in such a little boy!
es: What a head for just being a boy!

en: If I had Tom Sawyer’s head I wouldn’t trade it off to be a duke, nor mate of a steamboat, nor clown in a circus, nor nothing I can think of.
vi: If I had a mind like his, I wouldn't have been tormented by the king and the duke for so long.
tr: If I had a mind like Tom Sawyer's, I wouldn't give it up even if they made me a duke, or even if they made me a steamboat captain, a circus clown, or anything else that came to mind.
es: If I had Tom Sawyer's head, I wouldn't trade it for being a duke, a steamboat pilot, a circus clown, or anything else I could think of.

en: I went to thinking out a plan, but only just to be doing something; I knowed very well where the right plan was going to come from.
vi: I'm thinking of a plan, but only vaguely.
tr: I started making a plan, but I was doing it just for the sake of doing something; I knew very well whose mind the right plan would come from.
es: I started thinking of a plan, but just to do something.

en: Pretty soon Tom says:
vi: A moment later, Tom asked:
tr: Soon enough, Tom turned to me:
es: I knew very well where the best plan was going to come from. Right away Tom goes and says:

en: “Ready?”
vi: - Have you finished thinking?
tr: “Are you ready?”
es: —Ready?

en: “Yes,” I says.
vi: - Okay. - I replied.
tr: "Yes," I said.
es: —Yes —I replied.

en: “All right—bring it out.”
vi: - You tell me.
tr: “Alright… let's hear it.”
es: —Well, tell me about it.

en: “My plan is this,” I says.
vi: I said: - My plan is like this.
tr: “Here is my plan,” I said.
es: —My plan is this —I said—.

en: “We can easy find out if it’s Jim in there.
vi: We go find Jim, this part is easy.
tr: “We can easily find out if Jim is there or not.
es: We can easily find out if it's Jim who is there.

en: Then get up my canoe to-morrow night, and fetch my raft over from the island.
vi: Tomorrow morning, I'll retrieve my canoe hidden at the island.
tr: Tomorrow night, I'll go get my canoe, go to the island, and bring the raft.
es: Then, tomorrow night I take out my canoe and we bring my raft from the island.

en: Then the first dark night that comes steal the key out of the old man’s britches after he goes to bed, and shove off down the river on the raft with Jim, hiding daytimes and running nights, the way me and Jim used to do before.
vi: At night, we'll steal his keys after he goes to sleep. Then we'll head straight to the river, get Jim on the raft, hide during the day, and travel at night, just like Jim and I used to do before.
tr: On the first moonless night, I'll wait for the old man to fall asleep, then I'll steal the key from his pocket, and Jim and I will go down the river on the raft, hiding during the day and traveling at night, just like Jim and I used to do before.
es: On the first dark night we have, we take the key from the old man's pants when he goes to bed and we head down the river with Jim, hiding during the day and navigating at night, like Jim and I used to do before.

en: Wouldn’t that plan work?”
vi: Does that sound good?
tr: Do you think this plan will work?”
es: Wouldn't that plan work?

en: “Work?
vi: - Can it be done?
tr: “To be useful?
es: —Work?

en: Why, cert’nly it would work, like rats a-fighting.
vi: Of course it can, but it's like mice biting each other.
tr: Absolutely, it would be as easy as pulling a hair out of butter.
es: Of course it would work, like two and two make four.

en: But it’s too blame’ simple; there ain’t nothing to it.
vi: What kind of plan is this, so simple, nothing thrilling or sensational.
tr: But it's too simple, there's no difficulty at all.
es: But it's too simple; it says nothing.

en: What’s the good of a plan that ain’t no more trouble than that?
vi: If people talk about it later, it will just be in passing.
tr: What good is a plan that doesn't create more challenges?
es: What good is a plan that doesn't pose any problem?

en: It’s as mild as goose-milk.
vi: That's really boring.
tr: It's as calm as goose milk.
es: It's too bland.

en: Why, Huck, it wouldn’t make no more talk than breaking into a soap factory.”
vi: I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, as his plans were always the best.
tr: This plan is no harder than sneaking into a soap factory, Huck.”
es: Man, Huck, it wouldn't create more sensation than if it were a robbery in a soap factory.

en: I never said nothing, because I warn’t expecting nothing different; but I knowed mighty well that whenever he got his plan ready it wouldn’t have none of them objections to it.
vi: I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, as his plans were always the best.
tr: I didn't say anything, because I wasn't expecting any other attitude from him. But I knew very well that when he prepared his own plan, there would be nothing to object to.
es: I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, but I knew very well that when he had his plan ready, none of those objections could be made.

en: And it didn’t.
vi: Indeed. He talked about his plan.
tr: It was truly a flawless plan.
es: And so it happened.

en: He told me what it was, and I see in a minute it was worth fifteen of mine for style, and would make Jim just as free a man as mine would, and maybe get us all killed besides.
vi: After listening, I realized it would take fifteen people like me to come up with it, and only then could Jim become as free as I am.
tr: As soon as he explained it to me, I realized it was fifteen times better than my own plan, plus it adhered to the code and in the end, Jim would be at least as free as I was, and there was also the possibility that all of us might die.
es: He told me what it was and in a moment I understood that it was worth fifteen of mine in terms of elegance, and that it would leave Jim just as free as my plan, and that it could also get us all killed.

en: So I was satisfied, and said we would waltz in on it.
vi: I agreed, and we immediately set out to execute it.
tr: I found the plan very satisfying and immediately suggested we implement it.
es: So I was very happy and said we could go ahead with it.

en: I needn’t tell what it was here, because I knowed it wouldn’t stay the way, it was.
vi: I don't need to explain the plan here, as it would change during execution and many other things would need to be added.
tr: I don't feel the need to explain the plan here because I was sure things wouldn't go according to plan.
es: I don't need to recount here what it was because I knew it would keep changing.

en: I knowed he would be changing it around every which way as we went along, and heaving in new bullinesses wherever he got a chance.
vi: There is one thing that is most certain: Tom Sawyer was very eager to rescue that black man from slavery.
tr: I knew that once we took action, he would change the plan in any direction and come up with new inventions at every opportunity.
es: I knew he would change it at every moment as we progressed, adding new adventures whenever he had a chance.

en: And that is what he done.
vi: That was beyond my imagination.
tr: And that's exactly what he did.
es: And so he did.

en: Well, one thing was dead sure, and that was that Tom Sawyer was in earnest, and was actuly going to help steal that nigger out of slavery.
vi: This was a respectable boy, well-educated, and had a special temperament.
tr: The only thing that was certain was that Tom Sawyer was serious and would indeed help me steal that black man.
es: Well, there was one thing that was beyond doubt, and that was that Tom Sawyer was serious and indeed was going to help steal the black man to free him.

en: That was the thing that was too many for me.
vi: But his family was the same.
tr: Frankly, in my opinion, this boy had crossed the line.
es: That was what left me astonished.

en: Here was a boy that was respectable and well brung up; and had a character to lose; and folks at home that had characters; and he was bright and not leather-headed; and knowing and not ignorant; and not mean, but kind; and yet here he was, without any more pride, or rightness, or feeling, than to stoop to this business, and make himself a shame, and his family a shame, before everybody.
vi: He was outstanding, not dull; he knew various things, not ignorant; he was not bad, but kind-hearted.
tr: Here was a well-bred, respectable boy standing before me; he was definitely a person of character; the other people in his house were also people of character; he was sharp-witted, not a fool; knowledgeable, not ignorant at all; not mean, but kind-hearted; yet he didn't hesitate to get involved in such a terrible deed, as if he didn't care about his honor, reputation, or name, and was willing to embarrass both himself and his family in front of everyone.
es: This was a boy who was respectable and well-raised and who had a reputation to lose, and back home he had a family also with a reputation, and he was smart and not a fool, and he knew things, he was not ignorant, and he was not mean but kind, and yet there he was without any pride or sanctimoniousness or feelings, ready to get involved in such a matter and to fill himself with shame and fill his family with shame, in front of everyone.

en: I couldn’t understand it no way at all.
vi: Yet now, he humbly bowed to do such a thing, something that would bring shame to him and his family before everyone.
tr: I absolutely couldn't comprehend what he was doing.
es: I couldn't understand it at all.

en: It was outrageous, and I knowed I ought to just up and tell him so; and so be his true friend, and let him quit the thing right where he was and save himself.
vi: It was truly disgraceful, and I thought I must tell him that immediately. As his close friend, I had to advise him to abandon that idea, to save himself.
tr: He had embarked on an ugly task, and I needed to tell him that; I had to act like a true friend, make him turn back while there was still time, and save himself.
es: It was absurd and I realized that I would have to tell him and show him that I was a good friend of his and let him leave it where it was and save himself.

en: And I did start to tell him; but he shut me up, and says:
vi: I was just about to speak when he stopped me and said:
tr: I had just started to speak when he silenced me with a gesture and said:
es: And I started to tell him, but he made me be quiet and replied:

en: “Don’t you reckon I know what I’m about?
vi: - You think I don't know what I'm doing?
tr: “Do you think I am someone who doesn't know what they're doing?
es: —Do you think I don't know what I'm doing?

en: Don’t I generly know what I’m about?”
vi: - You think I don't know what I'm doing?
tr: Don't I usually act knowing what I'm doing?”
es: Don't I know what I'm doing in general?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Didn’t I say I was going to help steal the nigger?”
vi: - I told you I would help you get back the black guy, didn't I?
tr: “Didn't I tell you I would help you save the black man?”
es: —Didn't I say I was going to help rob the black man?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - That's right.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Well, then.”
vi: - So, what else are you planning?
tr: “Alright then.”
es: —Well, that's that.

en: That’s all he said, and that’s all I said.
vi: It only said maybe, and I said the same.
tr: He didn't say anything else, and I didn't raise my voice anymore.
es: He didn't say anything more, and neither did I.

en: It warn’t no use to say any more; because when he said he’d do a thing, he always done it.
vi: I knew saying more would be useless because when it says something, it will definitely do it.
