tr: There was no point in saying anything else, because if he set his mind on something, he would definitely do it.
es: It wasn't worth it anymore, because when he said he was going to do something, he always did it.

en: But I couldn’t make out how he was willing to go into this thing; so I just let it go, and never bothered no more about it.
vi: But I still don't understand why it wants to plunge into things like this. I just let it be and didn't bother thinking about it anymore.
tr: But I could never understand how he was so willing to do this job; so I left it to fate and didn't think about the matter again.
es: But even though I didn't understand how he was willing to get involved in something like that, I left it and didn't worry about it anymore.

en: If he was bound to have it so, I couldn’t help it.
vi: When we got home, it was already dark and very quiet.
tr: If doing this was written in his destiny, there was nothing I could do.
es: If he was determined to do it, I couldn't stop him.

en: When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it.
vi: We made our way to the tent below the ash house to investigate.
tr: When we arrived, it was dark and quiet; so we headed directly to the shack near the ash silo, we wanted to take a look.
es: When we returned, the house was completely dark and silent, so we went to the cabin next to where the quicklime was to examine it.

en: We went through the yard so as to see what the hounds would do.
vi: We went through the yard to see if the dogs would bark loudly.
tr: We went straight through the courtyard to see what the dogs would do.
es: We crossed the yard to see what the dogs were doing.

en: They knowed us, and didn’t make no more noise than country dogs is always doing when anything comes by in the night.
vi: But the dogs recognized us and didn't bark at all.
tr: They knew us and made as much noise as shepherd dogs seeing people at night would make.
es: They already knew us and made no more noise than any country dog would when someone appears at night.

en: When we got to the cabin we took a look at the front and the two sides; and on the side I warn’t acquainted with—which was the north side—we found a square window-hole, up tolerable high, with just one stout board nailed across it.
vi: Approaching the tent, looking carefully in front and on both sides, we saw a small square window with a board nailed tightly outside.
tr: When we reached the shack, we scouted the front and both sides; on the side I hadn't seen before – the north side – we saw a square window that could be considered quite high, with only one thick board nailed over it.
es: When we arrived at the cabin, we looked at the front and both sides, and from the side I didn't know (which faced north), we saw the square hole of a window, quite high, with a single wooden plank nailed over it.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: “Here is the exit ticket,” I said.
es: I go and say:

en: “Here’s the ticket.
vi: - This spot is good.
tr: “Here is the exit ticket,” I said.
es: —This is very good.

en: This hole’s big enough for Jim to get through if we wrench off the board.”
vi: This hole is both large and just enough for Jim to fit through if we can remove that plank.
tr: “If we remove the board, this hole will become big enough for Jim to pass through.”
es: That hole is big enough for Jim to get out if we pull off the board.

en: Tom says:
vi: Tom said:
tr: “As easy as playing three stones,” said Tom.
es: And then Tom says:

en: “It’s as simple as tit-tat-toe, three-in-a-row, and as easy as playing hooky.
vi: - Well, that's as easy as turning your hand over.
tr: “As easy as skipping school.
es: —That's easier than walking and simpler than fooling a fool.

en: I should hope we can find a way that’s a little more complicated than that, Huck Finn.”
vi: I think we could find a way that's even harder than that.
tr: I hope we can find a way a bit more complicated than this, Huck Finn.”
es: I'd say we can find a slightly more complicated way, Huck Finn.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “how’ll it do to saw him out, the way I done before I was murdered that time?”
vi: - Okay, let's saw that plank.
tr: “Alright then,” I said, “How about cutting the wall with a saw to get him out? That's what I did before he was killed.”
es: —Well, then —I replied—. What do you think if we make a hole between the logs like that time I was murdered?

en: “That’s more like,” he says.
vi: - That's somewhat acceptable, seems secretive and challenging.
tr: “This is better,” he said.
es: —That's something —he said—.

en: “It’s real mysterious, and troublesome, and good,” he says; “but I bet we can find a way that’s twice as long.
vi: - That's somewhat acceptable, seems secretive and challenging.
tr: “Truly mysterious, challenging, and good,” he said. “But I am sure we can find a way that will take at least twice as long.
es: It's mysterious, complicated, and fine, but I'm sure we can find something that lasts at least twice as long.

en: There ain’t no hurry; le’s keep on looking around.”
vi: But I think we can find a way that takes twice as long, there's no need to rush, so we can look around here first.
tr: We are in no hurry, let's keep looking around.”
es: There's no rush, let's keep looking.

en: Betwixt the hut and the fence, on the back side, was a lean-to that joined the hut at the eaves, and was made out of plank.
vi: Between the tent and the fence, there was a long roof as long as the tent, but narrower, only about one meter.
tr: Between the fence and the shed, at the back where the shed's roof eaves met, there was a storage made of planks.
es: Between the cabin and the fence, at the back, there was a shed attached to the cabin by the roof and made of wooden planks.

en: It was as long as the hut, but narrow—only about six foot wide.
vi: Between the tent and the fence, there was a long roof as long as the tent, but narrower, only about one meter.
tr: It was as long as the shed, but narrow... only two meters wide.
es: It was as long as the cabin, but narrow: only about six meters wide.

en: The door to it was at the south end, and was padlocked.
vi: The entrance door was tightly locked.
tr: The door was at the south end and had a padlock on it.
es: The door was on the south side and had a padlock.

en: Tom he went to the soap-kettle and searched around, and fetched back the iron thing they lift the lid with; so he took it and prized out one of the staples.
vi: Tom went to the shed, looked around, and brought back an iron bar used to pry open box lids. He used the iron bar to pry open a door.
tr: After Tom went over to the soap cauldron and did some investigating, he returned with an iron rod used to lift the lid; with this rod, he pried out one of the nails.
es: Tom went to the soap cauldron and started searching, and came back with that iron thing used to lift the lid, so he pried off one of the padlock's handles.

en: The chain fell down, and we opened the door and went in, and shut it, and struck a match, and see the shed was only built against a cabin and hadn’t no connection with it; and there warn’t no floor to the shed, nor nothing in it but some old rusty played-out hoes and spades and picks and a crippled plow.
vi: The chain fell down. We opened the door and stepped inside, then closed the door again. Striking a match, we saw that this roof was just leaning against the tent and had no passage through. Inside, there were only a few worn-out shovels and hoes.
tr: The chain fell to the ground and we opened the door and went inside. After closing the door behind us, we lit a match to see around. The storage was only built against the wall of the shed and there was no connection between them; the floor of the storage was dirt, and inside there were only a few rusty hoes, shovels, picks, and a broken plow.
es: The chain fell off, we opened the door and went in, closed it, and when we lit a match we saw that the shed was only built next to the cabin, with no passage to it, that it had no floor, and there was nothing but a few rusty hoes and shovels, some picks, and a broken plow.

en: The match went out, and so did we, and shoved in the staple again, and the door was locked as good as ever.
vi: When the match went out, we stepped out, reattached the iron hook, and the door closed as before.
tr: When the match went out, we went outside and put the nail back in place, the door was locked as before.
es: The match went out and we left and put the handle back on, so the door was closed just as well as before.

en: Tom was joyful.
vi: Tom was secretly pleased.
tr: Tom was cheerful.
es: Tom was delighted, and he said:

en: He says;
vi: He said:
tr: “Alright, now it's done,” he said.
es: Tom was delighted, and he said:

en: “Now we’re all right.
vi: - That's settled.
tr: “Alright, now it's done,” he said.
es: —Now everything is in order.

en: We’ll dig him out.
vi: We'll dig a hole for him.
tr: “We will dig it out.
es: We are going to take him out through a tunnel.

en: It’ll take about a week!”
vi: It will take about a week.
tr: It will take about a week!”
es: It will take us a week!

en: Then we started for the house, and I went in the back door—you only have to pull a buckskin latch-string, they don’t fasten the doors—but that warn’t romantical enough for Tom Sawyer; no way would do him but he must climb up the lightning-rod.
vi: Then we went back to the room. I entered through the back door, just had to lift the leather strap to open it, because they didn't tie it. But Tom Sawyer thought that wasn't thrilling enough, so he had to climb up the column.
tr: We went out and headed home, I entered through the back door – you just need to pull a leather strap, they don't lock the doors – but for Tom Sawyer, this wasn't romantic enough: He insisted on climbing up the lightning rod.
es: Then we went to the house and I entered through the back door (you just have to pull a leather cord, because they don't lock the doors there), but Tom Sawyer didn't think it was romantic enough, and the only thing that would do for him was to climb up the lightning rod.

en: But after he got up half way about three times, and missed fire and fell every time, and the last time most busted his brains out, he thought he’d got to give it up; but after he was rested he allowed he would give her one more turn for luck, and this time he made the trip.
vi: Three times he climbed halfway up and then slid down. The third time he fell so hard it seemed like he might have cracked his head, he decided to give up, but after thinking for a while, he climbed again. This time he made it.
tr: But after climbing halfway up three times and falling, and narrowly avoiding cracking his head open the last time, he started to think he might have to give up; but after resting for a while, he decided to give it one last try, hoping his luck would turn, and this time he succeeded.
es: But after climbing halfway up three times and failing and falling all three times, and almost breaking his head the last time, he thought it would be better to give up, but after resting he decided he would try one more time to see how it would go, and that time he managed to make it.

en: In the morning we was up at break of day, and down to the nigger cabins to pet the dogs and make friends with the nigger that fed Jim—if it was Jim that was being fed.
vi: The next morning, we got up early and went down to the house of the black people to get acquainted with the black man who always brought food for Jim.
tr: We woke up at dawn and went to the negro cabins to both pet the dogs and befriend the negro who fed Jim –that is, if the negro being fed was Jim.
es: In the morning we got up at dawn and went down to the cabins of the black people to pet the dogs and make friends with the black person who was bringing food to Jim, if it was Jim he was bringing it to.

en: The niggers was just getting through breakfast and starting for the fields; and Jim’s nigger was piling up a tin pan with bread and meat and things; and whilst the others was leaving, the key come from the house.
vi: They had just finished breakfast and were about to go to the fields, while the black man who usually went to Jim was packing meat pies and other things into an iron pot. When everyone had left, the key was brought down.
tr: The negroes had just had breakfast and were preparing to head out to the fields; the one who fed Jim was placing bread, meat, and other things on a tray; as the others left, the key also came from the house.
es: The black people had just finished breakfast and were starting to go to the fields, and Jim's black person was filling a metal bowl with bread and meat and other things, and while the others were leaving, they brought him the key to the house.

en: This nigger had a good-natured, chuckle-headed face, and his wool was all tied up in little bunches with thread.
vi: This black man looks very gentle. His clothes are tied up in several places with strings.
tr: This black man was good-natured and had a cheerful face, he had tied his hair in thin strands with strings.
es: The black man had a friendly face, very smiling, and wore his hair all tied up in curls with pieces of thread.

en: That was to keep witches off.
vi: That is to ward off evil spirits.
tr: He did this to keep witches away.
es: It was to ward off witches.

en: He said the witches was pestering him awful these nights, and making him see all kinds of strange things, and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and he didn’t believe he was ever witched so long before in his life.
vi: He said that in the past few nights, evil spirits have been disturbing him a lot; he saw many strange things, heard all kinds of strange voices and noises, and he couldn't believe that in his life until now he had been so harassed by evil spirits.
tr: He said that the witches had been bothering him a lot for a few nights, causing him to see strange things and hear strange words and noises; he couldn't remember the witches ever haunting him for this long before.
es: He said that those nights the witches were giving him a hard time and making him see all kinds of strange things and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and that he believed he had never been bewitched for so long in his entire life.

en: He got so worked up, and got to running on so about his troubles, he forgot all about what he’d been a-going to do.
vi: He spoke very passionately and repeatedly recounted those frightening things, completely forgetting what he was supposed to do now.
tr: He got really excited and started to list his troubles without stopping, completely forgetting the work he was doing.
es: He got so nervous talking about his problems that he forgot everything he had to do.

en: So Tom says:
vi: Tom asked:
tr: Tom reminded him:
es: Then Tom said to him:

en: “What’s the vittles for?
vi: - What is this food for?
tr: “What are these foods for?
es: —Who is that food for?

en: Going to feed the dogs?”
vi: To feed the dog?
tr: Are you going to feed the dogs?”
es: Are you going to feed the dogs?

en: The nigger kind of smiled around gradually over his face, like when you heave a brickbat in a mud-puddle, and he says:
vi: The black man gradually revealed a smile and replied:
tr: A smile slowly spread across the rich man's face, just like waves spreading when a brick is thrown into a swamp.
es: The black man began to smile slowly until his face was filled with it, like when a brick is thrown into a mud puddle, and he said:

en: “Yes, Mars Sid, a dog.
vi: - The dog is very strange.
tr: “Yes, Master Sid, I will feed the dog.
es: —Yes, little master Sid, a dog.

en: Cur’us dog, too.
vi: - The dog is very strange.
tr: And it's a strange dog.
es: A very curious dog.

en: Does you want to go en look at ’im?”
vi: Do you want to go see it?
tr: Would you like to come and see it?”
es: Do you want to come see it?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Of course
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: I hunched Tom, and whispers:
vi: I nudged Tom and whispered:
tr: I nudged Tom with an elbow and whispered:
es: I gave Tom a nudge and whispered to him:

en: “You going, right here in the daybreak?
vi: - Why is this happening in broad daylight?
tr: “Are you going to enter the cabin directly at sunrise?
es: —Are you going there at dawn?

en: That warn’t the plan.”
vi: Wasn't that the plan?
tr: That wasn't our plan.”
es: That wasn't the plan.

en: “No, it warn’t; but it’s the plan now.”
vi: - It wasn't like that before, but now it has to be.
tr: “It wasn't... but now the plan is this.”
es: —No, it wasn't, but now it is the plan.

en: So, drat him, we went along, but I didn’t like it much.
vi: We went out, but I didn't like it much.
tr: Damn it, we followed the black man, but I didn't really like it.
es: So, damn it, there we went, but I didn't like it one bit.

en: When we got in we couldn’t hardly see anything, it was so dark; but Jim was there, sure enough, and could see us; and he sings out:
vi: When stepping into the tent, we couldn't see anything because it was too dark. But Jim was indeed in there, Jim saw us and shouted loudly:
tr: When we entered, we couldn't see anything at first, it was very dark; but Jim was definitely there and could see us, he called out excitedly:
es: When we arrived, you could hardly see anything because it was so dark, but there was Jim, without a doubt, and he could see us, and he shouted:

en: “Why, Huck!
vi: - Oh, Huck, and Tom too?
tr: "Hey, Huck! My dear friend!
es: —But, Huck! My God!

en: En good lan’! ain’ dat Misto Tom?”
vi: - Oh, Huck, and Tom too?
tr: And isn't that Mr. Tom next to you?"
es: Isn't that Tom's place?

en: I just knowed how it would be; I just expected it.
vi: I knew this would happen sooner or later.
tr: I knew very well what was going to happen, it was exactly as I expected.
es: I knew what was going to happen, it was what I expected.

en: I didn’t know nothing to do; and if I had I couldn’t a done it, because that nigger busted in and says:
vi: What can we do now?
tr: I was at a loss for what to do, even if I wasn't, there was nothing I could do, because the black man intervened:
es: I didn't know what to do, and even if I did, I wouldn't have done it, because the black man appeared saying:

en: “Why, de gracious sakes!
vi: The black man exclaimed:
tr: "By the morning light!
es: —By all the saints!

en: do he know you genlmen?”
vi: - Oh Lord, does he know you guys?
tr: Does this black man know you or what?"
es: Does he know you, young gentlemen?

en: We could see pretty well now.
vi: Tom looked at the black man, seemingly astonished, and asked again:
tr: We could now see the inside quite well.
es: Now it could be seen quite well.

en: Tom he looked at the nigger, steady and kind of wondering, and says:
vi: Tom looked at the black man, seemingly astonished, and asked again:
tr: Tom turned his head to the black man and looked at him curiously:
es: Tom looked at the black man, very intently and as if wondering something, and then he said:

en: “Does who know us?”
vi: - Who knows us?
tr: “Does anyone know us?”
es: —Who knows us?

en: “Why, dis-yer runaway nigger.”
vi: - This black guy.
tr: "There's the runaway black man.""
es: —Well, this runaway black man.

en: “I don’t reckon he does; but what put that into your head?”
vi: - I don't really know.
tr: “I don't think you know him at all, but why do you ask?”
es: —I don't think so; but, why did it occur to you?

en: “What put it dar?
vi: But why do you think so?
tr: “Why would I leave?
es: —Why?

en: Didn’ he jis’ dis minute sing out like he knowed you?”
vi: - He just called you guys, didn't he?
tr: Didn't he just call out to you as if he knew you?”
es: Didn't you just say that you knew them?

en: Tom says, in a puzzled-up kind of way:
vi: Tom seemed confused and said:
tr: Tom replied, pretending to be surprised:
es: Tom goes and says, seemingly surprised:

en: “Well, that’s mighty curious.
vi: - Strange, isn't it?
tr: “This is strange.”
es: —Well, this is certainly curious.

en: Who sung out?
vi: Who's calling?
tr: “Who called out?” “When did they call out?” “What did they say?”
es: Who said anything?

en: When did he sing out?
vi: When did they call?
tr: “Who called out?” “When did they call out?” “What did they say?”
es: When did they say it?

en: what did he sing out?”
vi: How did they call?
tr: “Who called out?” “When did they call out?” “What did they say?”
es: What did they say?

en: And turns to me, perfectly ca’m, and says, “Did you hear anybody sing out?”
vi: Then it calmly turned back to me and continued to ask: - Did you hear someone calling?
tr: He turned to me very calmly: “Did you hear anyone call out?””
es: —and he turns to me, very calmly, and says to me—: Did you hear anyone say anything?

en: Of course there warn’t nothing to be said but the one thing; so I says:
vi: Of course, I couldn't say otherwise and tell:
tr: Of course, there was only one answer that could be given to this question.
es: Naturally, I could only say one thing, so I replied:

en: “No; I ain’t heard nobody say nothing.”
vi: - No, I didn't hear anyone calling.
tr: "No; I didn't hear anyone say anything."
es: —No; I haven't heard anyone say anything.

en: Then he turns to Jim, and looks him over like he never see him before, and says:
vi: Then it turned back to Jim, acting like a stranger, and asked:
tr: Then he turned to Jim and, looking at him as if he were someone he had never seen before in his life, asked:
es: Then he turns to Jim and looks him up and down as if he had never seen him before and asks: "Did you say something?"

en: “Did you sing out?”
vi: - Did you just call us?
tr: "Did you call out to us?""
es: Then he turns to Jim and looks him up and down as if he had never seen him before and asks: "Did you say something?"

en: “No, sah,” says Jim; “I hain’t said nothing, sah.”
vi: Jim replied:
tr: "No, sir," said Jim, "not a single word came out of my mouth, sir."
es: —No, sir —says Jim—; I haven't said anything, sir.

en: “Not a word?”
vi: - No, I didn't call anything.
tr: “Not a single word came out?”
es: —Not a word?

en: “No, sah, I hain’t said a word.”
vi: - No, I didn't call anything.
tr: "No, master, not a single word came out."
es: —No, sir, I haven't said a single word.

en: “Did you ever see us before?”
vi: - Have you ever met us?
tr: “Have you seen us before?”
es: —Have you seen us before now?

en: “No, sah; not as I knows on.”
vi: - Not yet.
tr: "No, sir, I don't remember ever seeing you before."
es: —No, sir; not that I know of.

en: So Tom turns to the nigger, which was looking wild and distressed, and says, kind of severe:
vi: Tom turned around, the black man now frightened and disappointed, spoke in a stern voice:
tr: Thereupon, Tom turned to the black man, who was in a state of shock and worry, and asked very seriously:
es: So Tom turns to the black man, who was all flustered and confused, and says, very sternly:

en: “What do you reckon’s the matter with you, anyway?
vi: - Why do you think someone called?
tr: “What’s wrong with you?
es: —But, what's wrong with you?

en: What made you think somebody sung out?”
vi: - Why do you think someone called?
tr: Where did you get the idea that someone was calling out?”
es: Why did you think someone said something?

en: “Oh, it’s de dad-blame’ witches, sah, en I wisht I was dead, I do.
vi: - Oh, sir, it's those ghosts haunting me again.
tr: “Ah, that accursed witch, master, I wish God would take my life so I could be free.
es: —Oh, it's those damned witches, young master, and I wish I had died, truly.

en: Dey’s awluz at it, sah, en dey do mos’ kill me, dey sk’yers me so.
vi: If they keep hovering around me like this, I'm afraid I'll die of fright.
tr: She always does this, she kills me, she scares me a lot.
es: They're always up to those things, young master, and they almost scare me to death.

en: Please to don’t tell nobody ’bout it sah, er ole Mars Silas he’ll scole me; ’kase he say dey ain’t no witches.
vi: Please don't tell anyone about this, or Mr. Silas will scold me; he says there are no such things as ghosts.
tr: Whatever happens, don't tell anyone about this, master, or Master Silas will be angry with me, because he says there's no such thing as a witch.
es: Please, don't tell anyone, young master, or old Mr. Silas will scold me because he says witches don't exist.

en: I jis’ wish to goodness he was heah now—den what would he say!
vi: Please don't tell anyone about this, or Mr. Silas will scold me; he says there are no such things as ghosts.
tr: My God, I wish he were here too... then what would happen?
es: I wish he were here now... Let's see what he would say!

en: I jis’ bet he couldn’ fine no way to git aroun’ it dis time.
vi: Please don't tell anyone about this, or Mr. Silas will scold me; he says there are no such things as ghosts.
tr: Surely this time he couldn't deny their existence.
es: I'm sure he wouldn't find a way to explain it this time.

en: But it’s awluz jis’ so; people dat’s sot, stays sot; dey won’t look into noth’n’en fine it out f’r deyselves, en when you fine it out en tell um ’bout it, dey doan’ b’lieve you.”
vi: Please don't tell anyone about this, or Mr. Silas will scold me; he says there are no such things as ghosts.
tr: But it always happens like this, those who don't want to believe won't believe; they make excuses and don't learn the truth; and when you tell them, they never believe it.”
es: Stubborn people die of stubbornness; they never want to look at things to see what's really happening, and when someone sees it and tells them, they go and don't believe it.

en: Tom give him a dime, and said we wouldn’t tell nobody; and told him to buy some more thread to tie up his wool with; and then looks at Jim, and says:
vi: Tom gave him a penny and told him not to be afraid, promising not to tell anyone. He also told him to buy more rope to tie up the clothes. Then he turned to Jim and said:
tr: Tom gave her ten cents and told her that we wouldn't tell anyone anything; after advising her to get some more string to tie her hair, he looked at Jim and said:
es: Tom gave him ten cents and told him that we wouldn't tell anyone and that he should go buy more thread to tie his hair, and then he looks at Jim and goes and says:

en: “I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this nigger.
vi: - I don't know if Silas intends to hang this black man or not.
tr: “Uncle Silas, do you think he will hang this black man?”
es: —I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this black man.

en: If I was to catch a nigger that was ungrateful enough to run away, I wouldn’t give him up, I’d hang him.”
vi: If I caught any ungrateful black man running away, I would have to hang him, no mercy.
tr: “If I caught a black man who was unfaithful enough to run away, I would never forgive him, I would hang him right then and there.”
es: If I caught a black man ungrateful enough to escape, I wouldn't turn him in; I would hang him myself.

en: And whilst the nigger stepped to the door to look at the dime and bite it to see if it was good, he whispers to Jim and says:
vi: And while the black man stepped outside the door to take a closer look at the half-dollar, raising it up to bite and see if it was good, Tom whispered into Jim's ear:
tr: While the black man stepped outside into the light to look at the ten cents and bit the coin to see if it was real, Tom leaned over and whispered to Jim:
es: And while the black man went to the door to look at the ten-cent coin and bite it to see if it was good, he whispered to Jim in a low voice:

en: “Don’t ever let on to know us.
vi: - Don't reveal that you know us.
tr: "Don't let anyone know that you recognize us.
es: —Don't let them find out that you know us.

en: And if you hear any digging going on nights, it’s us; we’re going to set you free.”
vi: At night, if you hear the sound of digging, it's us digging. We will get you out.
tr: If you hear digging sounds at night, it's us: We will rescue you."
es: And if you hear digging at night, it's us coming to set you free.

en: Jim only had time to grab us by the hand and squeeze it; then the nigger come back, and we said we’d come again some time if the nigger wanted us to; and he said he would, more particular if it was dark, because the witches went for him mostly in the dark, and it was good to have folks around then.
vi: Jim only had time to grab our hands and squeeze tightly. The black man turned around, and we told him that we would come whenever he needed us. He said he hoped so because ghosts often came to him at night, so having someone around would make him less scared.
tr: Jim only had time to grab and squeeze our hands, the other black man came back and we told him that we could come again if he wanted; he especially wanted us to come when it was dark, because witches mostly came at night and it would be good to have someone with him.
es: Jim had no time other than to grab our hands and squeeze them. Then the black man returned and we said we would come back again if he wanted, and he said yes, especially if it was at night, because the witches attacked him at night, and then it was really convenient for him to have people by his side.

en: CHAPTER XXXV.
vi: Chapter XXXV
tr: Chapter Thirty-Five
es: Chapter 35

en: It would be most an hour yet till breakfast, so we left and struck down into the woods; because Tom said we got to have some light to see how to dig by, and a lantern makes too much, and might get us into trouble; what we must have was a lot of them rotten chunks that’s called fox-fire, and just makes a soft kind of a glow when you lay them in a dark place.
vi: Almost an hour before breakfast time, we ran into the forest. Tom said we needed light to dig the earth, but using a lamp would be too conspicuous, so we had to gather glowing rotten branches that people call firefly wood.
tr: There was still about an hour until breakfast, so we left and went into the forest; because Tom had said that we would need some light to see ahead while digging, but a lantern would be too much and could get us into trouble; we needed to find some rotten wood called foxfire. When you put this wood in a dark place, it emitted a faint light.
es: THERE WAS STILL almost an hour left before breakfast, so we went to the forest because Tom said we needed some light to see while we dug, but a lantern gave too much and could get us into trouble, so we needed to gather a bunch of that phosphorescent rotten wood they call "foxfire" that only gives off a kind of soft glow when placed in a dark spot.

en: We fetched an armful and hid it in the weeds, and set down to rest, and Tom says, kind of dissatisfied:
vi: We collected an armful and hid it in the thick grass. While resting, Tom said, looking somewhat dissatisfied:
tr: We gathered an armful of foxfire and hid it among the grass, then sat down to rest a bit. Tom, still unsatisfied, said:
es: We gathered a lot, hid it among the grass, and sat down to rest, when Tom suddenly says, sounding displeased:

en: “Blame it, this whole thing is just as easy and awkward as it can be.
vi: - Everything is too easy and boring.
tr: “Damn it, this job is way too easy and it breaks the code.
es: —Damn it, all of this is so easy it's disgusting.

en: And so it makes it so rotten difficult to get up a difficult plan.
vi: Finding a difficult plan is not easy.
tr: That's why it makes it difficult to come up with a hard plan, damn it.
es: That's why it's so hard to organize a complicated plan.

en: There ain’t no watchman to be drugged—now there ought to be a watchman.
vi: There is no guard for the prisoner so I can use the sleeping potion.
tr: There's no guard to give a sleeping pill to... Yet there should definitely be a guard.
es: There's no guard to drug, and there should be a guard.

en: There ain’t even a dog to give a sleeping-mixture to.
vi: There is no guard for the prisoner so I can use the sleeping potion.
tr: There's not even a dog we can give a sleep-inducing mixture to.
es: Not even a dog to give something to make it sleep.

en: And there’s Jim chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the leg of his bed: why, all you got to do is to lift up the bedstead and slip off the chain.
vi: And Jim is only shackled by one leg to the bed, so all I have to do is lift the bed and pull the chain out.
tr: Also, Jim is chained to the leg of his bed with a three-meter chain, all we have to do is lift the bed and remove the chain.
es: And then, Jim is chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the bedpost; but you just have to lift the bed and remove the chain!

en: And Uncle Silas he trusts everybody; sends the key to the punkin-headed nigger, and don’t send nobody to watch the nigger.
vi: And Uncle Silas gave the key to that foolish black man.
tr: Uncle Silas trusts everyone; he sends the key to that empty-headed black man and doesn't send anyone to watch over him.
es: And Uncle Silas trusts everyone. He sends the key to that scatterbrained black man and doesn't send anyone to watch over him.

en: Jim could a got out of that window-hole before this, only there wouldn’t be no use trying to travel with a ten-foot chain on his leg.
vi: Jim could also crawl out through the window hole, but he can't drag the chain far.
tr: If Jim wanted, he could have already gotten out of that window hole, though he couldn't go anywhere with a three-meter chain on his foot.
es: Jim could have escaped through that window by now, except he can't run with a ten-foot chain on his leg.

en: Why, drat it, Huck, it’s the stupidest arrangement I ever see.
vi: It's so boring, I find all the arrangements too ordinary, so we have to create all sorts of difficulties.
tr: I'm getting discouraged, Huck, I've never heard of such a stupid setup before.
es: Damn it, Huck, it's the most absurd system I've ever seen.

en: You got to invent all the difficulties.
vi: It's so boring, I find all the arrangements too ordinary, so we have to create all sorts of difficulties.
tr: We'll have to invent all the difficulties ourselves.
es: You have to invent all the difficulties.

en: Well, we can’t help it; we got to do the best we can with the materials we’ve got.
vi: It's so boring, I find all the arrangements too ordinary, so we have to create all sorts of difficulties.
tr: Anyway, there's nothing else to do, it's best to make do with the materials we have and get this job done as best as we can.
es: Well, we can't avoid it, we have to do the best we can with the material we have.

en: Anyhow, there’s one thing—there’s more honor in getting him out through a lot of difficulties and dangers, where there warn’t one of them furnished to you by the people who it was their duty to furnish them, and you had to contrive them all out of your own head.
vi: Rescuing him from here must involve many difficulties and dangers to be impressive.
tr: The honor of rescuing Jim by facing a lot of difficulties and dangers is great. Moreover, if the people who were supposed to create these difficulties were lazy and you had to create all the difficulties and dangers yourself, you add to your honor.
es: In any case, we have something left: it's more honorable to get him out amidst difficulties and dangers when the people who had the obligation to create them didn't, and one had to invent them by their own means.

en: Now look at just that one thing of the lantern.
vi: Rescuing him from here must involve many difficulties and dangers to be impressive.
tr: Let's consider the simplest thing, like this lantern.
es: Just think about that lantern thing.

en: When you come down to the cold facts, we simply got to let on that a lantern’s resky.
vi: If no one causes those difficulties for us, we have to think and create those difficulties ourselves.
tr: Looking at the solid facts, we have to pretend there's a danger in using the lantern.
es: If we only see the facts themselves, we simply have to pretend that the lantern thing is dangerous.

en: Why, we could work with a torchlight procession if we wanted to, I believe.
vi: Ah, I think we could use the saw if we have the chance.
tr: Yet if we wanted, we could work with a whole parade of lanterns, no one would notice.
es: But we could work with a torch procession if we wanted to, I think!

en: Now, whilst I think of it, we got to hunt up something to make a saw out of the first chance we get.”
vi: Ah, I think we could use the saw if we have the chance.
tr: By the way, we need to make a saw without wasting any time, we need to find suitable materials.
es: Now that I think about it, we have to find something that can act as a saw as soon as we can.

en: “What do we want of a saw?”
vi: Ah, I think we could use the saw if we have the chance.
tr: “What are we going to do with the saw?”
es: —Why do we need a saw?

en: “What do we want of it?
vi: - What are you using the saw for?
tr: “What are we going to do?
es: —Why do we need a saw?

en: Hain’t we got to saw the leg of Jim’s bed off, so as to get the chain loose?”
vi: - Saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain.
tr: Don't we need to cut the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?”
es: Don't we have to saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?

en: “Why, you just said a body could lift up the bedstead and slip the chain off.”
vi: - So you just said that if we lift the bed, we can pull the chain out right away?
tr: “Why? You just said that lifting the bed and removing the chain would be enough.”
es: —But you said that it's enough to lift the bed and pull the chain...

en: “Well, if that ain’t just like you, Huck Finn.
vi: - You're as dumb as a cow.
tr: “This is just the kind of thing for you, Huck Finn.
es: —Well, that's typical of you, Huck Finn.

en: You can get up the infant-schooliest ways of going at a thing.
vi: You play like a child.
tr: In some matters, you're such a wimp, man!
es: You come up with the same ideas as a schoolboy.

en: Why, hain’t you ever read any books at all?—Baron Trenck, nor Casanova, nor Benvenuto Chelleeny, nor Henri IV., nor none of them heroes?
vi: Haven't you ever read books? Baron Trenck, Casanova. Benvenuto Cellini, Henry the Fourth, all those heroes, haven't you ever read about them?
tr: Have you never read a book before? Have you never heard of Baron Trenck, Casanova, Benvenuto Cellini, IV. Henry, or the other heroes, for God's sake?
es: Haven't you ever read a book in your life? The Baron Trenck, or Casanova, Benvenuto Cellini, or Henry IV, or any of those heroes?

en: Who ever heard of getting a prisoner loose in such an old-maidy way as that?
vi: Has anyone ever rescued a prisoner in such a womanly way?
tr: Where have you ever seen a prisoner being freed using methods fit for old ladies?
es: Who has ever heard of freeing a prisoner in such a simple way?

en: No; the way all the best authorities does is to saw the bed-leg in two, and leave it just so, and swallow the sawdust, so it can’t be found, and put some dirt and grease around the sawed place so the very keenest seneskal can’t see no sign of it’s being sawed, and thinks the bed-leg is perfectly sound.
vi: You have to saw the bed leg in half, then erase all traces of sawdust so no one can see, smear some dirt or grease on the sawed part so that even the sharp-eyed warden can't see the cut and thinks the bed leg is intact, then lift the chain off.
tr: No, the greatest experts in this field cut the leg of the bed, but leave it in place and swallow the sawdust so it can't be found; they smear mud and grease on the cut so that even the most vigilant guards won't realize it's been cut, thinking the bed leg is completely intact.
es: No, the way the best authorities do it is to saw the bed leg in two and leave it like that and eat the sawdust, so they can't find it, and put some dust and grease around the spot, so that not even the sharpest steward perceives the slightest sign that it has been sawed and believes that the bed leg is perfectly fine.

en: Then, the night you’re ready, fetch the leg a kick, down she goes; slip off your chain, and there you are.
vi: That's it.
tr: But on the night you're ready, you give the bed leg a kick, it splits in two; you remove your chain, and that's it.
es: Then, the night you're ready, you kick the leg and the bed falls, you take off the chain and that's it.

en: Nothing to do but hitch your rope ladder to the battlements, shin down it, break your leg in the moat—because a rope ladder is nineteen foot too short, you know—and there’s your horses and your trusty vassles, and they scoop you up and fling you across a saddle, and away you go to your native Langudoc, or Navarre, or wherever it is.
vi: Then you just have to place the rope ladder into the loophole, climb out, and slide down into a moat. Down there, horses and servants are ready to help you mount, and then you go; go back to your homeland, Languedoc or Nava, or somewhere else.
tr: Then all you have to do is tie the rope ladder to the barred windows, climb down, and fall into the ditch and break your leg – because the rope ladder is five or six meters too short – and right in front of you, you'll find your horses and loyal servants, who will grab you, put you on a saddle, and you'll head off to your homeland, Languedoc, Navarre, or wherever it is.
es: All you have to do is take the rope ladder to the walls, go down it, break your leg in the moat, because rope ladders are always nineteen feet short, you know, and there are the horses and trusted vassals who pick you up, mount you, and take you to your Languedoc or your Navarre or wherever you were born.

en: It’s gaudy, Huck.
vi: Oh, it's wonderful.
tr: How grand it would be, Huck, if only this cabin had a ditch too.
es: It's a thrill, Huck.

en: I wish there was a moat to this cabin.
vi: I want a trench leading to that hut.
tr: How grand it would be, Huck, if only this cabin had a ditch too.
es: I wish this cabin had a moat.

en: If we get time, the night of the escape, we’ll dig one.”
vi: If we have time, we will dig a trench.
tr: If we find the time, let's dig one on the night of the escape.”
es: If there's time, the night of the escape we'll dig one.

en: I says:
vi: I asked:
tr: If we find the time, let's dig one on the night of the escape.”
es: And I go and say:

en: “What do we want of a moat when we’re going to snake him out from under the cabin?”
vi: - But we were planning to let it slip out at the foot of the prison cell wall, weren't we? Why do we need to dig a trench?
tr: "Well, but if we're going to get him out from under the shed, what use is the trench?"
es: —Why do we need a pit when we're going to take it out from under the cabin?

en: But he never heard me.
vi: It didn't hear me say anything.
tr: I asked. But she didn't even hear me.
es: But he didn't hear me.

en: He had forgot me and everything else.
vi: It had forgotten that I was sitting there, and forgotten everything.
tr: She had forgotten me and everything else.
es: He had forgotten about me and everything else.

en: He had his chin in his hand, thinking.
vi: It rested its chin on its hand, thinking.
tr: She was thinking with her chin resting in her palm.
es: He had his chin resting on his hand and was thinking.

en: Pretty soon he sighs and shakes his head; then sighs again, and says:
vi: After a while, it sighed and shook its head. Then it sighed again and said:
tr: After a while, she sighed, shook her head from side to side, and then sighed again, saying:
es: After a moment, he sighs and shakes his head; then he sighs again and says:

en: “No, it wouldn’t do—there ain’t necessity enough for it.”
vi: - No, it's not possible, it's not really necessary.
tr: “No, no, that won't do... it's not necessary enough.”
es: —No, that wouldn't be right; it's not entirely necessary.

en: “For what?” I says.
vi: - What did you say you don't need?
tr: "What is it?" I said.
es: —What? —I asked.

en: “Why, to saw Jim’s leg off,” he says.
vi: - Ah, the matter of sawing off Jim's leg.
tr: “Cutting off Jim's leg, of course,” he said.
es: —Man, cut off Jim's leg —he answered me.

en: “Good land!” I says; “why, there ain’t no necessity for it.
vi: - Oh my God! Why is that?
tr: “My God!” I said, “It is definitely not necessary at all.
es: —Darn! —I said—, I don't see any need.

en: And what would you want to saw his leg off for, anyway?”
vi: So what are you planning to do by cutting off Jim's leg?
tr: Why do you even want to cut off his leg?”
es: And besides, why do you want to cut off his leg?

en: “Well, some of the best authorities has done it.
vi: - Some famous people do that.
tr: “Some of the greatest masters did it that way.
es: —Well, that's what some of the most authoritative authors do.

en: They couldn’t get the chain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved.
vi: They can't remove the chains, so they just cut off one of their arms.
tr: They couldn't remove the chain, so they cut off their hands and escaped.
es: They can't tear off the chain, so they cut off the hand and pull.

en: And a leg would be better still.
vi: Better to have one leg left than none.
tr: Cutting off a leg would be even better.
es: And a leg would be even better.

en: But we got to let that go.
vi: But maybe we shouldn't do that.
tr: But let's skip that for now.
es: But we will have to give up on that.

en: There ain’t necessity enough in this case; and, besides, Jim’s a nigger, and wouldn’t understand the reasons for it, and how it’s the custom in Europe; so we’ll let it go.
vi: This case doesn't really require it, and besides, Jim is a black man, he wouldn't understand why we would do such a thing.
tr: In Jim's case, it's not really necessary, plus Jim is a black man and won't understand why it's customary in Europe; so let's not do it this time.
es: In this case, there isn't enough need, and besides, Jim is black and wouldn't understand the motives or the European custom, so we'll let it go.

en: But there’s one thing—he can have a rope ladder; we can tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough.
vi: But we can make him a rope ladder. We could tear the bed sheet into strips and make him a rope ladder.
tr: But there's something else... A rope ladder could work; we can tear up our sheets and easily make a rope ladder for him.
es: But, on the other hand, we can do something else: we can tear the sheets into strips and make a very easy rope ladder for him.

en: And we can send it to him in a pie; it’s mostly done that way.
vi: And we could hide the rope ladder inside a cake and give it to him.
tr: We can send this ladder to him inside a pie, that's usually how it's done.
es: And we can send it to him inside a cake; it's almost always done that way.

en: And I’ve et worse pies.”
vi: And we could hide the rope ladder inside a cake and give it to him.
tr: I've eaten the worst pies just...”
es: I've eaten worse cakes.

en: “Why, Tom Sawyer, how you talk,” I says; “Jim ain’t got no use for a rope ladder.”
vi: That's how they usually do it.
tr: “What nonsense are you talking about, Tom Sawyer?” I said. “What is Jim going to do with a rope ladder?”
es: —But, Tom Sawyer, what things you say —I commented—; a rope ladder is of no use to Jim.

en: “He has got use for it.
vi: And it has to be a really big cake.
tr: “It is essential to use it.
es: —It has to be worth something to him.

en: How you talk, you better say; you don’t know nothing about it.
vi: - What are you talking about?
tr: What nonsense are you talking about, you should have said from the beginning that you don't understand these things at all.
es: More like, what things you say; you don't know anything about this.

en: He’s got to have a rope ladder; they all do.”
vi: Why would Jim need a rope ladder?
tr: A rope ladder is indispensable, all the masters use a rope ladder.” “Okay, but what will he do with the rope ladder?”
es: He needs a rope ladder; it happens to everyone.

en: “What in the nation can he do with it?”
vi: - Do what?
tr: “What will he do?
es: —What the hell is he going to do with her?

en: “Do with it?
vi: - Do what?
tr: “What will he do?
es: —What to do with it?

en: He can hide it in his bed, can’t he?”
vi: He could hide it in the bed.
tr: He can hide it inside his bed, can't he?
es: You can hide it in the bed, can't you?

en: That’s what they all do; and he’s got to, too.
vi: Everyone does that, so Jim has to do it too.
tr: They all do that; he has to do it too.
es: That's what everyone does, and he has to do it too.

en: Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time.
vi: Huck, it seems like you never want to do anything by the rules, you always want to do something new.
tr: Huck, it seems like you don't want to do anything according to the rules, you are intent on discovering everything from scratch.
es: Huck, it seems like you never want to do things right; you want to make it up every time.

en: S’pose he don’t do nothing with it?
vi: So you don't think they need to leave any traces??
tr: Let's say he didn't use it for anything…
es: Suppose he does nothing with it.

en: ain’t it there in his bed, for a clew, after he’s gone?
vi: So you don't think they need to leave any traces??
tr: Won't it remain as a clue inside the bed after he leaves?
es: Doesn't he have it there in the bed to leave a clue when it's gone?

en: and don’t you reckon they’ll want clews?
vi: So you don't think they need to leave any traces??
tr: Don't you ever consider that they will want a clue?
es: And don't you think they'll look for clues?

en: Of course they will.
vi: So you don't think they need to leave any traces??
tr: Of course they will want it.
es: Of course they will.

en: And you wouldn’t leave them any?
vi: So you don't think they need to leave any traces??
tr: And won't you leave them any clue?
es: And, don't you plan to leave them any?

en: That would be a pretty howdy-do, wouldn’t it!
vi: I said:
tr: Does this fit the code at all?
es: That would be great, I assure you!

en: I never heard of such a thing.”
vi: - Alright, if everyone else is doing it, then we should follow suit to comply with the rules.
tr: I've never heard of such a thing in my life, honestly.”
es: I've never heard anything like it.

en: “Well,” I says, “if it’s in the regulations, and he’s got to have it, all right, let him have it; because I don’t wish to go back on no regulations; but there’s one thing, Tom Sawyer—if we go to tearing up our sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we’re going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, just as sure as you’re born.
vi: But Tom Sawyer, if we tear the bed sheets into pieces to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into trouble with Aunt Sally.
tr: “Since the rule is like this and it has to be a rope ladder, fine, let it be; I really don't want to go against any rule; but there's something else, Tom Sawyer... If we tear our sheets to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into big trouble with Aunt Sally, I know this for sure.
es: —Well —I said—, if that's part of the rules and he needs it, then we'll make one for him, because I don't want to break any rules; but I'm telling you one thing, Tom Sawyer, if we start tearing up sheets to make a ladder for Jim, we're going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, you can be sure of that.

en: Now, the way I look at it, a hickry-bark ladder don’t cost nothing, and don’t waste nothing, and is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as any rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain’t had no experience, and so he don’t care what kind of a—”
vi: Now I think this, making a ladder out of bark would also keep it hidden. As for Jim, he has no experience, so anything would be fine for him.
tr: If you ask me, a ladder made of walnut tree bark is both cost-free and doesn't require wasting anything else, plus it can be put inside a pie or among the straw of the mattress just like rope ladders; besides, Jim has no experience in these matters anyway, so I doubt he'll care what kind of ladder we use...”
es: It seems to me that a ladder made of walnut bark costs nothing and doesn't ruin anything, and it can be hidden just as well inside a cake and concealed in a straw mattress as any rope ladder, and as for Jim, he has no experience, so he doesn't care what kind of...

en: “Oh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I’d keep still—that’s what I’d do.
vi: - Huck Finn, if I were as dumb as you, I'd rather keep quiet.
tr: “Gene saçmaladın, Huck Finn, cahil cahil konuşup duruyorsun iki saattir…
es: —Oh, gosh, Huck Finn, if I were as ignorant as you, I would keep my mouth shut, I assure you.

en: Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping by a hickry-bark ladder?
vi: Has anyone ever heard of someone escaping from prison using a bark ladder?
tr: Hiçbir şey bilmiyorsan bari çeneni tutmayı bileydin. Bir mahkûmun ağaç kabuğundan merdivenle kaçtığı da nerede duyulmuş?
es: Who has ever heard of a state prisoner escaping with a walnut bark ladder?

en: Why, it’s perfectly ridiculous.”
vi: That's utterly ridiculous. - Fine, it's up to you.
tr: Böyle gülünç şey olur mu hiç?”
es: It's completely ridiculous.

en: “Well, all right, Tom, fix it your own way; but if you’ll take my advice, you’ll let me borrow a sheet off of the clothesline.”
vi: Or maybe we could borrow a bedsheet from the clothesline outside?
tr: “Alright, Tom, let it be as you wish; but listen to me and please allow me to borrow from the hanging laundry.”
es: —Well, alright, Tom, do it as you like, but if you want to take my advice, let him borrow one of the sheets that are hanging out to dry.

en: He said that would do.
vi: It said that's fine too.
tr: He did not object to this.
es: He said he was fine, and that gave him another idea, and he said:

en: And that gave him another idea, and he says:
vi: But then it came up with another idea:
tr: In fact, another idea came to his mind:
es: He said he was fine, and that gave him another idea, and he said:

en: “Borrow a shirt, too.”
vi: - Borrow another shirt.
tr: “Also, borrow a shirt.”
es: —Borrow a shirt as well.

en: “What do we want of a shirt, Tom?”
vi: - What for, Tom?
tr: “Well, what are we going to do with the shirt, Tom?”
es: —Why do we want a shirt?

en: “Want it for Jim to keep a journal on.”
vi: - Let Jim write his diary in there
tr: “For Jim to keep a diary.”
es: —So that Jim writes a diary.

en: “Journal your granny—Jim can’t write.”
vi: - Diary my foot, Jim doesn't even know how to write.
tr: "Come on now... Jim can't read or write."
es: —Diary, your grandma... Jim doesn't know how to write.

en: “S’pose he can’t write—he can make marks on the shirt, can’t he, if we make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron barrel-hoop?”
vi: - He doesn't know how to write, but he can scribble a few lines. We can make him a pen out of an iron spoon or a piece of iron from a barrel hoop.
tr: “Let's say he can't write... can't he draw pictures and signs on the shirt either? We can make him a pen from an iron spoon or a piece of barrel hoop.”
es: —Let's suppose he doesn't know... He can make marks on the shirt, can't he? Especially if we make a pen for him with an old pewter spoon or with a piece of an old barrel stave.

en: “Why, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.”
vi: - Should I pluck a goose feather to make him a pen? It would be quick too.
tr: "Well, but we can pluck a goose's feather and make a much better pen, Tom, and it would be quicker.""
es: —But, Tom, we can pluck a feather from a goose, and it turns out better, and faster, too.

en: “Prisoners don’t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull pens out of, you muggins.
vi: How could the imprisoned people see a goose to get goose feathers for making pens, how foolish are you?
tr: “Prisoners in jail don't have geese to pluck feathers from to make pens, you fool.
es: —Prisoners don't have geese running around the dungeons to pluck feathers from, you fool.

en: They always make their pens out of the hardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or something like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because they’ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall.
vi: They always have to use something really hard, really rough, like the bronze leg of a candlestick or something else they can grab in the prison tower to make a pen. Then it takes weeks, even months to make a pen, because they have to grind it against the prison wall at night.
tr: They always make their pens from old brass candlesticks or other hard, rigid, and difficult-to-bend objects they have at hand; making a pen can take weeks, even months, because they have no choice but to rub what they have against the wall to turn it into a pen.
es: They always make the quills from the hardest, most difficult, and most complicated piece of an old copper candlestick or something they can get their hands on, and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to sharpen it, because they have to do it by rubbing it against the wall.

en: They wouldn’t use a goose-quill if they had it.
vi: Even if they had goose feathers, they wouldn't use them.
tr: Even if they could find goose feathers, they wouldn't use them.
es: They wouldn't use a goose feather even if they had one.

en: It ain’t regular.”
vi: Because that would not be according to the rules.
tr: It doesn't follow the rules.”
es: It's not right.

en: “Well, then, what’ll we make him the ink out of?”
vi: - Then what will we use for ink?
tr: “Well then, how are we going to make the ink?”
es: —Well, then, what do we use to make the ink?

en: “Many makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that’s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood.
vi: - Many people use rust with tears as ink, but that's a common and very feminine style. Famous guys use their own blood as ink.
tr: “Most prisoners mix rust with their tears; but this is typical of the lower class and women; the experts use their own blood.
es: —Many do it with iron rust and tears, but those are the more common prisoners and women; the most authoritative authors use their own blood.

en: Jim can do that; and when he wants to send any little common ordinary mysterious message to let the world know where he’s captivated, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out of the window.
vi: Jim can do that. And whenever he wants to send a small, ordinary but secret letter to let people know where he's imprisoned, he can write it on the bottom of an iron plate, then throw it out the window.
tr: If Jim can do this and wants to send a simple mysterious message to let the world know where he is being held, he can scratch it onto the back of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window.
es: Jim can do it, and when he wants to send any ordinary mysterious message so the world knows where he is captive, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window.

en: The Iron Mask always done that, and it’s a blame’ good way, too.”
vi: The Iron Mask gang often did that, it's really amazing.
tr: The Man in the Iron Mask always does it that way, and in my opinion, it’s a remarkably good method.”
es: That’s what the Man in the Iron Mask always did, and besides, it turns out great.

en: “Jim ain’t got no tin plates.
vi: - How could Jim have a metal plate?
tr: “Jim doesn't have a tin plate.
es: —Jim doesn't have any tin plates.

en: They feed him in a pan.”
vi: They fed him using a pot.
tr: They serve him food on a tray.”
es: They feed him in a bowl.

en: “That ain’t nothing; we can get him some.”
vi: - That doesn't matter.
tr: “It doesn't matter, we'll take him a plate.”
es: —That doesn't matter, we can get some for you.

en: “Can’t nobody read his plates.”
vi: I'll get him a few plates. - But who can read his handwriting?
tr: "No one can read what is written on his plate"
es: —And no one will be able to read what it says on the plate.

en: “That ain’t got anything to do with it, Huck Finn.
vi: - It's okay.
tr: “This has nothing to do with our topic, Huck Finn.
es: —That has nothing to do with the matter, Huck Finn.

en: All he’s got to do is to write on the plate and throw it out.
vi: He just needs to write on the disc and throw it out.
tr: All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it out.
es: All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it.

en: You don’t have to be able to read it.
vi: There's no need to read it.
tr: We don't need to be able to read it.
es: It doesn't need to be read.

en: Why, half the time you can’t read anything a prisoner writes on a tin plate, or anywhere else.”
vi: Most people can't read what a prisoner writes on the iron disc.
tr: Half of what a prisoner writes on a tin plate or elsewhere is unreadable anyway.”
es: But half the time, you can't read anything that state prisoners write on a tin plate, or anywhere else.

en: “Well, then, what’s the sense in wasting the plates?”
vi: - It's such a waste of a disc.
tr: “So why are we wasting the plates then?”
es: —Well, then, what's the point of ruining those dishes?

en: “Why, blame it all, it ain’t the prisoner’s plates.”
vi: - It's not a prisoner's plate to worry about wasting.
tr: “What difference does it make, they are not the prisoner's plates.”
es: —But, damn it, they are not the prisoner's dishes.

en: “But it’s somebody’s plates, ain’t it?”
vi: - So, it's someone's plate, right?
tr: “But it's someone's plate, isn't it?”
es: —But they belong to someone, don't they?

en: “Well, spos’n it is?
vi: - So, it's someone's plate, right?
tr: “Let's say it is so, so what?
es: —Well, let's suppose so.

en: What does the prisoner care whose—”
vi: - Well, let's say it belongs to someone, but why should the prisoner care?
tr: Why would the prisoner care about who the plate belongs to…”
es: What difference does it make to the prisoner?

en: He broke off there, because we heard the breakfast-horn blowing.
vi: It suddenly stopped talking because we had heard the bell calling us for breakfast.
tr: He fell silent here, because we had heard the breakfast bell ring.
es: And then he stopped because we heard the breakfast horn sounding.

en: So we cleared out for the house.
vi: We hurried back home.
tr: Thus, we headed home.
es: So we went to the house.

en: Along during the morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt off of the clothes-line; and I found an old sack and put them in it, and we went down and got the fox-fire, and put that in too.
vi: That morning, I borrowed a bedsheet and a shirt from the clothesline, found an old bag, stuffed those things in it, then went downstairs to get some rotten firewood and put everything into the bag.
tr: That morning, I borrowed a sheet and a shirt from the hanging laundry; I found an old sack and put both inside, then we went to find the foxfire and put it in the sack as well.
es: That morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt from the clothesline and found an old sack to put them in; we went down to get the "fox fire" and put that in the sack too.

en: I called it borrowing, because that was what pap always called it; but Tom said it warn’t borrowing, it was stealing.
vi: I called it borrowing because my father usually called it that. But Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing.
tr: I said borrowed because my father always said so; but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing.
es: I said that it was borrowing, because that's what father always called it, but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing.

en: He said we was representing prisoners; and prisoners don’t care how they get a thing so they get it, and nobody don’t blame them for it, either.
vi: He said that the two of us were representing the imprisoned; and for the imprisoned, any way to get them supplies was acceptable, and no one would blame them for it.
tr: According to him, we were representing prisoners; prisoners didn't care how they got something and no one blamed them for it.
es: He said we were pretending to be prisoners and that prisoners don't care how they get things as long as they get them and that no one minds.

en: It ain’t no crime in a prisoner to steal the thing he needs to get away with, Tom said; it’s his right; and so, as long as we was representing a prisoner, we had a perfect right to steal anything on this place we had the least use for to get ourselves out of prison with.
vi: For a prisoner, taking what they need to escape is not a crime, it's their right, Tom said. So if we were representing the imprisoned, we had every right to steal anything on their behalf, at least anything that could be used to escape from prison.
tr: Tom said it wasn't a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needed to escape; it was his right, so as long as we were representing a prisoner, we had every right to steal even the least of what we needed to free ourselves from prison.
es: It's not a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needs to escape, Tom said; it's his right, and as long as we were pretending to be prisoners, we had every right to steal anything around if it helped us get out of jail.

en: He said if we warn’t prisoners it would be a very different thing, and nobody but a mean, ornery person would steal when he warn’t a prisoner.
vi: He also said that if we weren't prisoners, then it would be a different story, and if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, they would just be a very bad person.
tr: If we weren't prisoners, everything would be different, if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, he could only be a common person.
es: He said that if we weren't prisoners it would be very different, and that it was mean and low to steal when you weren't a prisoner.

en: So we allowed we would steal everything there was that come handy.
vi: Therefore, we thought we could steal anything we could get our hands on.
tr: So, we said we could steal anything that came our way.
es: So we agreed to steal anything that would be useful to us.

en: And yet he made a mighty fuss, one day, after that, when I stole a watermelon out of the nigger-patch and eat it; and he made me go and give the niggers a dime without telling them what it was for.
vi: Yet, one day, I stole a watermelon from the black man's garden to eat, and he scolded me harshly, then he gave the black people a dime without saying what it was for.
tr: Yet, when I stole and ate a watermelon from the negroes' garden in the following days, he got very angry with me. "Go give the negroes ten cents and don't tell them why," he said.
es: And yet, one day after that, he made a huge fuss when I stole a watermelon from the negroes' garden and ate it, and he made me go give the negroes ten cents without explaining why.

en: Tom said that what he meant was, we could steal anything we needed.
vi: Tom said that we should only steal things we needed.
tr: This time, Tom said we could only steal what we needed.
es: Tom said that what he meant was that we could steal anything we needed.

en: Well, I says, I needed the watermelon.
vi: I said that I needed a watermelon.
tr: "But I needed that watermelon," I said.
es: "Well," I said, "I needed the watermelon."

en: But he said I didn’t need it to get out of prison with; there’s where the difference was.
vi: He said we didn't need a watermelon to escape from prison.
tr: But he said I didn't need the watermelon to escape from prison, that was the difference.
es: But he said I didn't need it to get out of jail; that was the difference.

en: He said if I’d a wanted it to hide a knife in, and smuggle it to Jim to kill the seneskal with, it would a been all right.
vi: He said if I could hide a knife and give it to Jim so he could kill the warden, that would be very good.
tr: If I sent the watermelon with a knife inside to Jim to kill the head guard, there was no problem.
es: He said that if I had wanted to hide a knife inside it and pass it to Jim to kill the guard with, that would have been fine.

en: So I let it go at that, though I couldn’t see no advantage in my representing a prisoner if I got to set down and chaw over a lot of gold-leaf distinctions like that every time I see a chance to hog a watermelon.
vi: I had to agree, although I thought it was pointless to be so far-fetched, and I'd rather just eat a watermelon.
tr: So I gave in, but if I had to sit and split hairs like this every time I got a chance to swipe a watermelon, there was no advantage to representing a prisoner at all.
es: So I let it go, though I didn't see the point of pretending to be a prisoner if I had to think about such difficult distinctions every time I saw a chance to take a watermelon.

en: Well, as I was saying, we waited that morning till everybody was settled down to business, and nobody in sight around the yard; then Tom he carried the sack into the lean-to whilst I stood off a piece to keep watch.
vi: Then, that morning, after waiting for everyone to go out to the fields, Tom took the sack to the back of the hut while I stayed behind to keep watch.
tr: Anyway, as I said, we waited until everyone started to get busy with their own work that morning, and by then no one was visible in the courtyard anymore; while Tom was carrying the sack to the storeroom, I kept watch from a bit of a distance.
es: Well, as I was saying, that morning we waited until everyone went to work and no one was seen in the yard. Then Tom took the sack to the shed while I stayed a few steps behind to keep watch.

en: By-and-by he come out, and we went and set down on the woodpile to talk.
vi: A little later, he came out, and the two of us sat down on the logs to talk.
tr: After a while, he came out again, and we went and sat on a pile of wood and started talking.
es: After a while, he came out and we sat down to talk on the woodpile.

en: He says:
vi: He said:
tr: After a while, he came out again, and we went and sat on a pile of wood and started talking.
es: He goes and says:

en: “Everything’s all right now except tools; and that’s easy fixed.”
vi: - Everything is done, only the tools are missing, but this is not too difficult.
tr: “Everything is ready now,” said Tom, “but only the tools are left; we can easily take care of that.”
es: —Now everything is in order, except for the tools, and that's easy.

en: “Tools?” I says.
vi: - What tool?
tr: “The tools?”
es: —Tools? —I asked.

en: “Yes.”
vi: - I asked.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Tools for what?”
vi: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for?
tr: “What are the tools for?”
es: —Tools for what?

en: “Why, to dig with.
vi: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for?
tr: “Of course, to dig.
es: —Man, to dig.

en: We ain’t a-going to gnaw him out, are we?”
vi: Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr: We won't be gnawing at the soil to get it out, I suppose.”
es: We aren't going to make a tunnel with our teeth, right?

en: “Ain’t them old crippled picks and things in there good enough to dig a nigger out with?” I says.
vi: Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr: "Won't the old pickaxes inside be enough to get a black man out?""
es: —Don't we have enough with those old picks and shovels to dig out a black man?

en: He turns on me, looking pitying enough to make a body cry, and says:
vi: It turned to look at me with a pitying expression that could make one cry, then said:
tr: He turned and looked at me with such pity that I could have cried at that moment.
es: He turned towards me, with a face so sorrowful it made you want to cry, and then he says:

en: “Huck Finn, did you ever hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels, and all the modern conveniences in his wardrobe to dig himself out with?
vi: - Huck Finn, have you ever heard of a prisoner having a pickaxe to dig with?
tr: “Huck Finn, have you ever heard of a prisoner with a pickaxe and a shovel, a prisoner who fills his locker with all modern tools to dig his way out?
es: —Huck Finn, have you ever heard in your life of a prisoner who has picks and shovels and all those conveniences in the closet to make a tunnel?

en: Now I want to ask you—if you got any reasonableness in you at all—what kind of a show would that give him to be a hero?
vi: - Huck Finn, have you ever heard of a prisoner having a pickaxe to dig with?
tr: If you have even a little bit of sense in your head, I ask you, how will he become a hero if he escapes this way?
es: What I want to ask you, assuming you still have a minimum of reason, is what motive would that be to make him a hero.

en: Why, they might as well lend him the key and done with it.
vi: Why not just give him the key to make it easier?
tr: We might as well just hand him the key.
es: Man, they could also lend him the key and be done with it.

en: Picks and shovels—why, they wouldn’t furnish ’em to a king.”
vi: I said:
tr: A pickaxe and a shovel… they wouldn't even give such tools to kings.”
es: Picks and shovels... But they wouldn't even give those to a king.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “if we don’t want the picks and shovels, what do we want?”
vi: - Well, if we don't need hoes and shovels, then what do we need?
tr: “Alright, let's say we don't want pickaxes and shovels, then what do we want?”
es: —Well, then —I said—, if we don't need picks and shovels, what do we need?

en: “A couple of case-knives.”
vi: - A few knives.
tr: "Two pocketknives.""
es: —A pair of kitchen knives.

en: “To dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?”
vi: - Can you really dig it up??
tr: "To pierce through the foundations of the cabin?"
es: —To make a tunnel underneath that cabin?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “Yes.” "Oops!
es: —Yes.

en: “Confound it, it’s foolish, Tom.”
vi: - I think this is crazy. - I need to know.
tr: But this is very silly, Tom."
es: —Damn it, Tom, that's nonsense.

en: “It don’t make no difference how foolish it is, it’s the right way—and it’s the regular way.
vi: In my opinion, that's the proper way to do it. There's no other way.
tr: “Whether it is foolish or not, this is the truth… the one that complies with the rules.
es: —It doesn't matter if it's nonsense, it's the right thing to do and it's how things are done.

en: And there ain’t no other way, that ever I heard of, and I’ve read all the books that gives any information about these things.
vi: I haven't heard of any other way. I've read all the books about these matters.
tr: So far, I haven't heard of any other way, despite reading all the books that provide all kinds of information on such matters.
es: There is no other way that I know of, and I've read all the books that provide information about these things.

en: They always dig out with a case-knife—and not through dirt, mind you; generly it’s through solid rock.
vi: They always dig with a knife, and you should remember that it's not just digging soil, but often digging through stone as well.
tr: They always dig with a knife… not the soil; they usually drill the rock with a knife.
es: They always do it with a knife, and not by digging in the ground, mind you; usually, it's in stone.

en: And it takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever.
vi: And that takes countless weeks.
tr: They work for weeks, it almost takes forever.
es: It takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and all the time without stopping and without stopping.

en: Why, look at one of them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the harbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was he at it, you reckon?”
vi: Do you know how long it took a prisoner to dig the Deep Castle in Marseille?
tr: One of the prisoners lying in the dungeon at the bottom of Deef Castle in the port of Marseille escaped by drilling the rock with a knife; guess how long it took?”
es: You only have to look at one of those prisoners from the underground dungeons of Deef Castle, in the port of Marseille, who made a tunnel that way; how long do you think he spent digging?

en: “I don’t know.”
vi: - I don't know.
tr: "I don't know."
es: —I don't know.

en: “Well, guess.”
vi: - Try to guess.
tr: "Then guess.""
es: —Well, then make a guess.

en: “I don’t know.
vi: - Try to guess.
tr: "How should I know.
es: —I don't know.

en: A month and a half.”
vi: - A month and a half at most.
tr: A month and a half?"
es: A month and a half.

en: “Thirty-seven year—and he come out in China.
vi: - Thirty-seven years, then he crawled all the way to China.
tr: "Thirty-seven years... it came all the way from China.
es: —Thirty-seven years... And it came out in China.

en: That’s the kind.
vi: Just like that.
tr: This is the rule of this matter.
es: That's what is right.

en: I wish the bottom of this fortress was solid rock.”
vi: If only this foundation were made of hard stone, it would be so much better.
tr: I wish the base of this castle was also rock."
es: I wish the foundation of that fortress were made of stone.

en: “Jim don’t know nobody in China.”
vi: - Jim doesn't know anyone in China, does he?
tr: "Jim doesn't know anyone in China."
es: —Jim doesn't know anyone in China.

en: “What’s that got to do with it?
vi: - What does that have to do with anything?
tr: “But what does this have to do with anything?
es: —What does that have to do with anything?

en: Neither did that other fellow.
vi: The other person is the same.
tr: That man didn't know anyone either.
es: Neither does that guy.

en: But you’re always a-wandering off on a side issue.
vi: But you're straying from the point, let's get back to the main topic.
tr: But you always get hung up on trivial things.
es: But you always go off on tangents.

en: Why can’t you stick to the main point?”
vi: But you're straying from the point, let's get back to the main topic.
tr: Why do you stray away from the main issue?”
es: Why don't you talk about the main issue?

en: “All right—I don’t care where he comes out, so he comes out; and Jim don’t, either, I reckon.
vi: - Alright, I don't need to know where he gets to, as long as he gets outside.
tr: “Alright, well… it doesn't matter where it came from, it has emerged in the end; it probably doesn't matter for Jim either.
es: —Well... I don't care where he comes out, as long as he comes out; and I reckon Jim doesn't either.

en: But there’s one thing, anyway—Jim’s too old to be dug out with a case-knife.
vi: The only thing is, Jim is too old and weak to dig his way out with a knife.
tr: However, there is one problem… Jim is too old to be removed with a knife.
es: But anyway, there's another thing: Jim is too old to hold out until we make a tunnel with a knife.

en: He won’t last.”
vi: He won't live to see that day!
tr: He doesn't have enough time left.”
es: He won't last that long.

en: “Yes he will last, too.
vi: - Yes, it's possible to live.
tr: “Don't worry, he has enough life left.
es: —Well, it will last.

en: You don’t reckon it’s going to take thirty-seven years to dig out through a dirt foundation, do you?”
vi: You probably think it would take thirty-seven years to dig through this foundation, don't you?
tr: You don't really think it will take thirty-seven years to dig the soil, do you?”
es: You don't think it's going to take us thirty-seven years to make a tunnel in the ground, do you?

en: “How long will it take, Tom?”
vi: - So how long does it take?
tr: “Well, how long will it take, Tom?”
es: —How long will it take us, Tom?

en: “Well, we can’t resk being as long as we ought to, because it mayn’t take very long for Uncle Silas to hear from down there by New Orleans.
vi: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss.
tr: “Of course, we can't expect it to last as long as it normally would, because it won't take long for Uncle Silas to get news from New Orleans.
