es: —Well, we can't risk taking as long as we should, because maybe Uncle Silas won't take that long to receive news from New Orleans.

en: He’ll hear Jim ain’t from there.
vi: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss.
tr: He will find out that Jim is not from there.
es: He will find out that Jim is not from there.

en: Then his next move will be to advertise Jim, or something like that.
vi: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss.
tr: Then maybe he will put ads in the newspapers for Jim or do something similar.
es: Then what he will do is put up a notice about Jim, or something like that.

en: So we can’t resk being as long digging him out as we ought to.
vi: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss.
tr: We can't risk getting him out in the necessary time.
es: So we can't risk taking as long in the tunnel as we should.

en: By rights I reckon we ought to be a couple of years; but we can’t.
vi: Exactly, we would need several years, but we can't do that.
tr: If you ask me, it would probably take a few years, but we can't wait that long.
es: To do it right, I figure we would need to take a couple of years; but we can't.

en: Things being so uncertain, what I recommend is this: that we really dig right in, as quick as we can; and after that, we can let on, to ourselves, that we was at it thirty-seven years.
vi: So, we dig straight in, dig really fast, then we leave it and just think that we've been digging for thirty-seven years.
tr: Since things are so uncertain, I suggest this: Let's dig as fast as we can, and then we can pretend we've reached the end of thirty-seven years whenever we want.
es: With things so up in the air, what I recommend is that we start digging for real as fast as we can and then we can tell ourselves that it took thirty-seven years.

en: Then we can snatch him out and rush him away the first time there’s an alarm.
vi: Then we pull him out, and when there's an alarm, we push him away immediately.
tr: That is, as soon as we sense things are changing, let's get him out and escape immediately.
es: Then we can get him out and take him away quickly as soon as there's an alarm.

en: Yes, I reckon that’ll be the best way.”
vi: In my opinion, that's the best way.
tr: Yes, I think this is the best.”
es: Yes, I figure that's the best.

en: “Now, there’s sense in that,” I says.
vi: - Yeah, what you said sounds reasonable.
tr: “Now you've said something wise,” I said.
es: —Well, it makes sense —I said—.

en: “Letting on don’t cost nothing; letting on ain’t no trouble; and if it’s any object, I don’t mind letting on we was at it a hundred and fifty year.
vi: Imagining it doesn't cause any trouble anyway.
tr: “There's no harm in pretending we've reached the end, and we won't get into trouble; if we have a purpose, I don't even mind pretending to dig for a hundred and fifty years.
es: Pretending it was thirty-seven years is no trouble; there's no problem, and if necessary, I don't mind pretending it took us one hundred and fifty years.

en: It wouldn’t strain me none, after I got my hand in.
vi: You can imagine that you'll dig for a hundred and ten years if you want.
tr: Once the job is done, it won't be a problem for me.
es: It's no effort for me if I set my mind to it.

en: So I’ll mosey along now, and smouch a couple of case-knives.”
vi: Alright, let me go get a few knives.
tr: The best thing now is for me to go and find two knives.”
es: So I'm going to go get a couple of kitchen knives.

en: “Smouch three,” he says; “we want one to make a saw out of.”
vi: It said: - Take three back, I need one to make a saw.
tr: “Find three,” he said, “we will make a saw from one of them.” “Tom, if it is not against the rules and ungodly, I will suggest something,” I said.
es: —Find yourself three —he says—; we need one to turn it into a saw.

en: “Tom, if it ain’t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,” I says, “there’s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the weather-boarding behind the smoke-house.”
vi: I said: - Tom, if you don't give it to me, it's against the rules, then I'll tell you there's a rusty saw blade stuck on the roof behind the kitchen.
tr: “I had seen the tip of a rusty saw under the cover of the trench behind the smokehouse.”
es: —Tom, if it doesn't go against the rules or against the religion that I suggest it to you —I said—, there is an old and rusty saw half-covered under the shed that is behind the meat smoker.

en: He looked kind of weary and discouraged-like, and says:
vi: It seemed bored and disappointed, and replied to me:
tr: Tom said in a weary and disheartened tone:
es: He looked at me as if tired and discouraged and said:

en: “It ain’t no use to try to learn you nothing, Huck.
vi: - I don't know how to teach you anymore.
tr: “There’s no use in trying to teach you anything, Huck.
es: —You can't be taught anything, Huck.

en: Run along and smouch the knives—three of them.”
vi: Just go and bring back three knives, remember, three of them.
tr: Quickly go and bring three knives… three of them.”
es: Go get the knives, and make it three —and so I did.

en: So I done it.
vi: So I ran away.
tr: I did as he said.
es: Go get the knives, and make it three —and so I did.

en: CHAPTER XXXVI.
vi: Chapter XXXVI
tr: Chapter Thirty-Six
es: Chapter 36

en: As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the lightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our pile of fox-fire, and went to work.
vi: That night, we waited until everyone had gone to sleep, then climbed down the lamppost, ran to the porch, took out the fireflies, and began our work.
tr: That night, at a moment when we thought everyone was asleep, we slid down the lightning rod, entered the shed, closed the door behind us, took out our foxfire pile, and started working.
es: THAT NIGHT, as soon as we calculated that everyone had fallen asleep, we climbed down the lightning rod, locked ourselves in the shed, took out our pile of "foxfire," and got to work.

en: We cleared everything out of the way, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log.
vi: We moved all the clutter away, clearing an area of about a meter in the middle of the ground.
tr: We cleared everything around to open up a one to one and a half centimeter space in the middle of the log at the bottom.
es: We cleared everything around us, about four or five feet along the bottom of the trunk.

en: Tom said he was right behind Jim’s bed now, and we’d dig in under it, and when we got through there couldn’t nobody in the cabin ever know there was any hole there, because Jim’s counter-pin hung down most to the ground, and you’d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole.
vi: Tom said that spot was right behind Jim's bed, and we would dig from there into the cell. Once we dug through, no one on the other side would know there was a hole because the bedspread of Jim's bed hung down close to the ground; you would have to lift it up and look down to see the hole.
tr: Tom said we were exactly behind Jim's bed, we were going to dig right under his bed, and when we got there, no one entering the cabin would realize there was a hole there, because the cover of Jim's bed almost reached the floor, and to understand there was a hole underneath, you would have to lift the cover.
es: Tom said we were right behind Jim's bed and that we would dig underneath, and when we got there no one would notice there was a hole, because Jim's quilt hung almost to the floor and you would have to lift it to look underneath to see it.

en: So we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we was dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn’t see we’d done anything hardly.
vi: So we took out our daggers and dug, digging until nearly midnight. Eventually, we were exhausted, our hands blistered, and still, we hadn't made much progress.
tr: So we dug and dug with our knives until midnight; finally, we were as tired as dogs, our palms were blistered, but still, we had hardly done anything.
es: So we started digging with the knives until almost midnight, when we felt extremely tired, with our hands full of blisters, and yet you could hardly notice what we had done.

en: At last I says:
vi: Finally, I said:
tr: Finally, I said:
es: Finally, I said:

en: “This ain’t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job, Tom Sawyer.”
vi: - Tom Sawyer, this is not a thirty-seven-year job, but a thirty-eight-year job.
tr: "Tom Sawyer, this job will last not thirty-seven years, but even thirty-eight years."
es: —This is not going to last thirty-seven years; this job is for thirty-eight years, Tom Sawyer.

en: He never said nothing.
vi: It didn't say anything but just sighed, then after a moment, it stopped digging.
tr: He didn't make a sound.
es: He said nothing.

en: But he sighed, and pretty soon he stopped digging, and then for a good little while I knowed that he was thinking.
vi: I knew what it was thinking.
tr: But he sighed deeply and a little later he put down the pickaxe; in the ensuing silence, I could feel that he was thinking.
es: But he sighed and immediately stopped digging, and then I saw that he was thinking for a while.

en: Then he says:
vi: It said:
tr: But he sighed deeply and a little later he put down the pickaxe; in the ensuing silence, I could feel that he was thinking.
es: Then he said:

en: “It ain’t no use, Huck, it ain’t a-going to work.
vi: - It's useless, Huck. Doing it this way won't get us anywhere.
tr: “It's no use, Huck,” he said. “It won't work.
es: —This isn't working, it's not going to work.

en: If we was prisoners it would, because then we’d have as many years as we wanted, and no hurry; and we wouldn’t get but a few minutes to dig, every day, while they was changing watches, and so our hands wouldn’t get blistered, and we could keep it up right along, year in and year out, and do it right, and the way it ought to be done.
vi: If we were prisoners, we could take as many years as we wanted, no need to hurry, just spend a few minutes each day digging.
tr: If we were prisoners, it would work, because then we would have as many years as we wanted, we wouldn't be in a hurry; moreover, we could dig for just a few minutes a day, when the guards change shifts, so our hands wouldn't blister; since we would continue for years, we would follow the rules and do this job the right way.
es: If we were prisoners it would work, because we would have all the years we wanted without any rush, and we could only dig for a few minutes a day, while the guard changed, so we wouldn't get blisters on our hands, and we could keep going constantly, year after year, and do it well, the way things should be done.

en: But we can’t fool along; we got to rush; we ain’t got no time to spare.
vi: But we don't have that much time.
tr: But we don't have time to waste, we must hurry; this job must be finished soon.
es: But we can't waste time, we have to hurry; we don't have that much time.

en: If we was to put in another night this way we’d have to knock off for a week to let our hands get well—couldn’t touch a case-knife with them sooner.”
vi: If we plan to do another night like this, we would need to rest for a week to let our hands heal, otherwise, we won't be able to hold the knife to dig right away.
tr: If we work like this for one more night, we will have to wait a week for our hands to heal... Soon we won't be able to hold the knife.”
es: If we spend another night like this, we would have to rest for a week for our hands to heal; it would take us all that time to touch a kitchen knife again.

en: “Well, then, what we going to do, Tom?”
vi: - So what should we do, Tom?
tr: “Well, what are we going to do then, Tom?”
es: —So, what are we going to do, Tom?

en: “I’ll tell you.
vi: Let me tell you something.
tr: “I will tell you.
es: —I'm going to tell you.

en: It ain’t right, and it ain’t moral, and I wouldn’t like it to get out; but there ain’t only just the one way: we got to dig him out with the picks, and let on it’s case-knives.”
vi: I don't want to give up, because that would be wrong and unethical. But the only way left is for us to dig with a hoe and put the knife away.
tr: Actually, it is neither right nor moral... I didn't want such words to come out of my mouth; but there is only one way left; we will dig with a pickaxe and pretend we dug with a knife.”
es: It's not right, and it's not moral, and I wouldn't like it to be known, but it's the only way: we have to take it out with the picks and pretend they are kitchen knives.

en: “Now you’re talking!” I says; “your head gets leveler and leveler all the time, Tom Sawyer,” I says.
vi: I said: - See that? Your mind is clearer now, Tom Sawyer.
tr: “Now it's done!” I said, “Your brain works better every time, Tom Sawyer.
es: —That's the way to talk! —I said—. You're thinking better and better, Tom Sawyer.

en: “Picks is the thing, moral or no moral; and as for me, I don’t care shucks for the morality of it, nohow.
vi: Whether it's moral or not, using a hoe is still right.
tr: Whether it's moral or immoral, the best way is to dig; and if you ask me, I don't care about morality at all.
es: What matters are the picks, whether they are moral or not, and as for me, I don't give a damn about morality.

en: When I start in to steal a nigger, or a watermelon, or a Sunday-school book, I ain’t no ways particular how it’s done so it’s done.
vi: When I set out to steal a black man, or a watermelon, or a book from the monastery school, I don't care whether it's moral or not.
tr: Once you start stealing a black person, a watermelon, or a hymn book, I don't think it matters how you do it.
es: When it occurs to me to steal a black person, or a watermelon, or a Sunday school book, I don't care much about how as long as I do it.

en: What I want is my nigger; or what I want is my watermelon; or what I want is my Sunday-school book; and if a pick’s the handiest thing, that’s the thing I’m a-going to dig that nigger or that watermelon or that Sunday-school book out with; and I don’t give a dead rat what the authorities thinks about it nuther.”
vi: What I need is my black man, what I need is my watermelon, or what I need is the book from the monastery school, and if the hoe is the most convenient, then I use the hoe. I take the hoe to dig out that black man, that watermelon, or that book, and I don't give a damn about what the reputable people think about it!
tr: I want my black person, I want my watermelon, or I want my hymn book; if the easiest way to get it is by digging, then I'll dig out the black person, the watermelon, or the hymn book; I don't give a damn about what the experts say on this matter.”
es: What I want is my black person or my watermelon or my Sunday school book, and if the best thing is a pick, then that's what I'm going to use to get that black person, or that watermelon, or that Sunday school book, and I don't give a damn what the most authoritative authors say about it.

en: “Well,” he says, “there’s excuse for picks and letting-on in a case like this; if it warn’t so, I wouldn’t approve of it, nor I wouldn’t stand by and see the rules broke—because right is right, and wrong is wrong, and a body ain’t got no business doing wrong when he ain’t ignorant and knows better.
vi: It says - In this case, using a hoe and discarding the knife is also acceptable. If not, then I wouldn't accept that and would definitely not stand still and watch the rules being distorted.
tr: “There is a valid reason for using picks and considering them as knives here,” he said. “If it weren't so, I would never approve, and I can't just stand by while rules are being violated... Because right is right; wrong is wrong, and if a person is not ignorant, if they know they shouldn't do it, they won't do wrong.
es: —Well —he goes and says—, there is an excuse to use the picks and pretend they are something else in a case like this; otherwise, I wouldn't approve it, nor would I allow the rules to be broken, because what is right is right and what is wrong is wrong, and one doesn't have to do things wrong when one is not ignorant and knows what is right.

en: It might answer for you to dig Jim out with a pick, without any letting on, because you don’t know no better; but it wouldn’t for me, because I do know better.
vi: For you, you can use the hoe instead of the knife without any hesitation because you have no other choice. But I'm different because I know better ways.
tr: Getting Jim out using a pick without any pretense might be a solution for you, that's how much you know about these things, but it's not a solution for me, because I know it's wrong.
es: It would be fine for you to get Jim out with a pick, without pretending it's something else, because you don't know what is right, but it wouldn't be right for me to do it, because I do know.

en: Gimme a case-knife.”
vi: Give me the knife!
tr: Give me a knife.”
es: Pass me a kitchen knife.

en: He had his own by him, but I handed him mine.
vi: It was already holding a knife, but I still handed it my knife.
tr: He had his own knife in his hand, and I gave him my own knife.
es: He had his next to him, but I handed him mine.

en: He flung it down, and says:
vi: It threw it down and said:
tr: He threw the knife to the ground and repeated:
es: He threw it on the ground and said:

en: “Gimme a case-knife.”
vi: - Give me the knife.
tr: “I am asking you to give me a pocketknife.”
es: —Give me a kitchen knife.

en: I didn’t know just what to do—but then I thought.
vi: I didn't know what to do, but then I figured it out.
tr: At first, I didn't know what to do... But then I thought.
es: I didn't know what to do, but then I thought about it.

en: I scratched around amongst the old tools, and got a pickaxe and give it to him, and he took it and went to work, and never said a word.
vi: I rummaged through the old stuff, took out a hoe, and handed it to him. He took it and started working without saying anything.
tr: I reached for the old tools, took an old pickaxe and gave it to him, he took the pickaxe and started working without saying a single word.
es: I searched among the old tools and found a pickaxe, handed it to him, and he grabbed it and started working without saying a word.

en: He was always just that particular.
vi: It's still the same, very principled.
tr: That's how meticulous he was.
es: It was always that special.

en: Full of principle.
vi: It's still the same, very principled.
tr: He was a man of principles.
es: Everything beginnings.

en: So then I got a shovel, and then we picked and shoveled, turn about, and made the fur fly.
vi: I picked up a shovel, and both of us toiled for half an hour and dug a fairly large hole.
tr: Upon this, I also took a shovel, and then we dug the soil using the pickaxe and the shovel in turns.
es: Then I grabbed a shovel and we started digging with the pick and shovel, taking turns, like madmen.

en: We stuck to it about a half an hour, which was as long as we could stand up; but we had a good deal of a hole to show for it.
vi: I picked up a shovel, and both of us toiled for half an hour and dug a fairly large hole.
tr: We worked for another half hour, then we couldn't stand the sleeplessness anymore; but by then, we had already opened a fairly large hole.
es: We continued like this for about half an hour, which was all we could endure; but in return, we had made a good hole.

en: When I got up stairs I looked out at the window and see Tom doing his level best with the lightning-rod, but he couldn’t come it, his hands was so sore.
vi: When I went upstairs and looked out the window, I saw Tom trying hard to climb the lamp post again, but he couldn't manage it because his hands were too sore.
tr: I went upstairs, and when I looked out the window, I saw Tom desperately trying to climb the lightning rod, but he couldn't manage it because his palms were blistered.
es: When I went upstairs, I looked out the window and saw that Tom was doing everything he could with the lightning rod, but he couldn't climb because his hands were so cracked.

en: At last he says:
vi: Finally, he said:
tr: “It's no use, it's impossible to do this,” he said finally.
es: Finally, he said:

en: “It ain’t no use, it can’t be done.
vi: - It's useless, we can't climb.
tr: “It's no use, it's impossible to do this,” he said finally.
es: —It's useless, I can't.

en: What you reckon I better do?
vi: Do you have any other way?
tr: “Do you think I have any other choice?
es: What do you think I should do?

en: Can’t you think of no way?”
vi: Do you have any other way?
tr: Can you think of a way?”
es: Can't you think of anything?

en: “Yes,” I says, “but I reckon it ain’t regular.
vi: - Yes, but I'm afraid you might say it's not according to the rules.
tr: "He's coming," I said, "but it doesn't seem to follow the rules.
es: —Yes —I said—, but I suppose it's not in the regulations.

en: Come up the stairs, and let on it’s a lightning-rod.”
vi: You should take the stairs up.
tr: Go up the stairs and pretend you came out of the lightning rod."
es: Go up the stairs and pretend they are a lightning rod.

en: So he done it.
vi: So it did as I told it to.
tr: That's exactly what he did.
es: That's what he did.

en: Next day Tom stole a pewter spoon and a brass candlestick in the house, for to make some pens for Jim out of, and six tallow candles; and I hung around the nigger cabins and laid for a chance, and stole three tin plates.
vi: The next day, Tom stole a tin spoon and a brass candlestick from the house to make a pen for Jim, along with six tallow candles. As for me, I went down to the black people's quarters to find an opportunity to steal three iron plates.
tr: The next day, Tom stole a tin spoon and a brass candlestick from home; we were going to make a pen for Jim with these, and he also got six candles; I hung around the negro cabins and found an opportunity to steal three tin plates.
es: The next day, Tom stole a pewter spoon and a copper candlestick from the house to make some pens for Jim, as well as six tallow candles, and I stayed around the cabins of the black people waiting for an opportunity and stole three tin plates.

en: Tom says it wasn’t enough; but I said nobody wouldn’t ever see the plates that Jim throwed out, because they’d fall in the dog-fennel and jimpson weeds under the window-hole—then we could tote them back and he could use them over again.
vi: Tom said that wasn't enough. But I thought no one would see the plates Jim threw out. That way, we could pick them up and use them again.
tr: Tom said these weren't enough; but I said no one would see the plates Jim threw, because they would fall among the dog daisies and hawthorns under the window – we could collect the plates and use them again.
es: Tom said it wasn't enough, but I replied that no one would ever see the plates Jim threw, because they would fall among the bushes and weeds under the window, so we could retrieve them to be used again.

en: So Tom was satisfied.
vi: Tom agreed.
tr: Tom was satisfied.
es: Then Tom was convinced.

en: Then he says:
vi: He said:
tr: “Now we need to figure out how to get the necessary things to Jim,” he said.
es: Afterwards, he goes and says:

en: “Now, the thing to study out is, how to get the things to Jim.”
vi: - Now, how to get those things to Jim.
tr: “Now we need to figure out how to get the necessary things to Jim,” he said.
es: —Now what we have to study is how to get things to Jim.

en: “Take them in through the hole,” I says, “when we get it done.”
vi: I said: - Now that we've finished digging, we can put it in that hole.
tr: "After completing the hole, we pass them through the hole," I said.
es: —We will give them to them through the hole —I said—, when we have finished it.

en: He only just looked scornful, and said something about nobody ever heard of such an idiotic idea, and then he went to studying.
vi: It seemed to not accept my opinion and was deep in thought.
tr: After sarcastically looking and saying that no one had ever heard such a foolish idea, he began to think.
es: He looked at me disdainfully and said something like he had never heard such a stupid idea, and then he started to study it.

en: By-and-by he said he had ciphered out two or three ways, but there warn’t no need to decide on any of them yet.
vi: A moment later, it said it had found two or three ways, but there was no need to decide on any of them yet.
tr: After a while, he said that he had found two or three ways, but for now, it was not necessary to decide on any of them.
es: After a while, he announced that he had already discovered two or three ways, but it was not yet necessary to decide on one.

en: Said we’d got to post Jim first.
vi: First of all, we must inform Jim.
tr: First, we should reach Jim.
es: He said that first we had to inform Jim.

en: That night we went down the lightning-rod a little after ten, and took one of the candles along, and listened under the window-hole, and heard Jim snoring; so we pitched it in, and it didn’t wake him.
vi: That night, around ten o'clock, we climbed down the lamp post again, bringing a candle with us, and listened at the window hole to hear Jim snoring. We threw the candle in, but Jim still didn't wake up.
tr: That night, shortly after ten o'clock, we came down from the lightning rod and took one of the candles with us; when we stood under the window, we heard Jim snoring; we threw the candle inside, but he didn't wake up.
es: That night we climbed down the lightning rod shortly after ten, with one of the candles, we listened under the window and heard Jim snoring, so we threw it inside and didn't wake him up.

en: Then we whirled in with the pick and shovel, and in about two hours and a half the job was done.
vi: We then started digging and shoveling the earth, and after about two and a half hours, we were completely done.
tr: After working with the pickaxe and shovel for about two hours, we had completed half the job.
es: Then we started digging with the pick and shovel, and after about two and a half hours we had finished the job.

en: We crept in under Jim’s bed and into the cabin, and pawed around and found the candle and lit it, and stood over Jim awhile, and found him looking hearty and healthy, and then we woke him up gentle and gradual.
vi: We crawled under Jim's bed into the cell, found the candle, lit it, and stood looking at Jim for a while. He was still as gentle and healthy as usual. We gently shook him awake.
tr: First, we went under Jim's bed, then into the cabin, felt around and found the candle, and lit it. We stood over Jim for a while; he looked quite lively and healthy; we woke him up slowly.
es: We got into the cabin under Jim's cot and searched until we found the candle and lit it, and we stared at Jim for a while to check his strong and healthy appearance, and then we woke him up slowly and gently.

en: He was so glad to see us he most cried; and called us honey, and all the pet names he could think of; and was for having us hunt up a cold-chisel to cut the chain off of his leg with right away, and clearing out without losing any time.
vi: Seeing us, Jim was overjoyed, almost crying, and called us with all the affectionate names he could think of. He wanted us to find a piece of iron to saw off the chain on his leg and then escape immediately, without delay.
tr: He was so happy to see us that he almost cried; he called us "my dear" and said all the affectionate words he could think of; he asked us to find a chisel to cut the shackle on his leg, and then we would escape without wasting any time.
es: He was so happy to see us that he almost started to cry and called us his children and all the affectionate things he could think of, and he asked us to find a chisel to take the chain off his leg immediately so he could leave without wasting time.

en: But Tom he showed him how unregular it would be, and set down and told him all about our plans, and how we could alter them in a minute any time there was an alarm; and not to be the least afraid, because we would see he got away, sure.
vi: But Tom thought that wasn't according to the rules and sat down to tell Jim a series of plans.
tr: But Tom told him how against the rules that was, sat down and explained our plan from start to finish, and said that we could change everything in a minute in case of an emergency; there was no need for him to be afraid because we would definitely ensure his escape.
es: But Tom showed him that wouldn't be proper and sat down to explain our plans and how we could change them in a moment if there was any alarm and that he shouldn't worry, because we would make sure he escaped, no doubt.

en: So Jim he said it was all right, and we set there and talked over old times awhile, and then Tom asked a lot of questions, and when Jim told him Uncle Silas come in every day or two to pray with him, and Aunt Sally come in to see if he was comfortable and had plenty to eat, and both of them was kind as they could be, Tom says:
vi: Jim happily agreed. Tom also asked Jim a lot of questions. Jim said that Mr. Silas came to pray with him every few days, and Aunt Sally also came to check if he was eating well and properly, and that both of them were kind to him.
tr: Jim said it was no problem, we sat together for a while and talked about the old days, then Tom asked many questions. Jim told him that Uncle Silas came almost every day to pray with him, and Aunt Sally also came to check if he was comfortable and had plenty of food; they both treated him very well.
es: Then Jim said that was fine and we stayed chatting for a while about the old times, and then Tom asked a lot of questions, and when Jim told him that Uncle Silas came daily or every two days to pray with him and that Aunt Sally visited to see if he was comfortable and had enough food and that they were both very kind, Tom said:

en: “Now I know how to fix it.
vi: Tom said:
tr: “Now I have found a way to handle this,” said Tom.
es: —Now I know how to organize it.

en: We’ll send you some things by them.”
vi: - Alright, we will send you the items through them.
tr: “We will send you some things with them.”
es: We will send you some things with them.

en: I said, “Don’t do nothing of the kind; it’s one of the most jackass ideas I ever struck;” but he never paid no attention to me; went right on.
vi: I said: - Don't do that, I've never seen anyone so foolish before. But Tom didn't bother to listen.
tr: “We could never do such a thing in life,” I said. “This is the most foolish idea I’ve ever heard.” But he didn’t even listen to me, he continued speaking.
es: —Don't even think about it; it's one of the dumbest ideas I've ever heard in my life —I said, but he ignored me and went ahead.

en: It was his way when he’d got his plans set.
vi: When he already had an intention in his mind, he always did things that way.
tr: It was always like this when he made his plans.
es: That's what happened when he had made a plan.

en: So he told Jim how we’d have to smuggle in the rope-ladder pie and other large things by Nat, the nigger that fed him, and he must be on the lookout, and not be surprised, and not let Nat see him open them; and we would put small things in uncle’s coat-pockets and he must steal them out; and we would tie things to aunt’s apron-strings or put them in her apron-pocket, if we got a chance; and told him what they would be and what they was for.
vi: It told Jim that we would secretly slip the rope ladder and many other things into a cake brought by Nat, the black man who still brought food for Jim. It also reminded Jim not to let Nat see him open those things. But the small items, we would put them in Uncle Silas's coat pocket and Jim had to steal them from there; we would tie the odds and ends to Aunt Sally's apron strings or put them in her kitchen apron pocket, if there was an opportunity, and tell Jim what those things were for.
tr: He explained to Jim that we had to send the rope ladder and other big things through the black man Nat, who brought him food; Jim had to always be alert, not look surprised, and not cause Nat to open them; we would put some small things in uncle's coat pockets, and Jim would steal them from there; we would tie some things to aunt's apron strings or put some in her apron pocket if we got the chance; he also explained what these things were and what they would be used for.
es: Then he told Jim that we would have to pass him the cake with the rope ladder and other sizable things through Nat, the black man who brought him food, and he had to be alert and not be surprised or let Nat see him when he opened them, and that we would put the small things in the uncle's jacket pockets and he had to steal them, and that if we had the chance we would tie things to the aunt's apron strings or put them in the apron pocket, and he told him what they would be and what for.

en: And told him how to keep a journal on the shirt with his blood, and all that.
vi: Then it told Jim how to use his blood to write a diary on the shirt, etc...
tr: He also explained how to keep a diary with his blood on the shirt and other things.
es: He also asked him to keep a diary written in blood on his shirt and all those things.

en: He told him everything.
vi: Then it told Jim how to use his blood to write a diary on the shirt, etc...
tr: He listed everything one by one.
es: He told him everything.

en: Jim he couldn’t see no sense in the most of it, but he allowed we was white folks and knowed better than him; so he was satisfied, and said he would do it all just as Tom said.
vi: Although Jim didn't understand anything, Tom said that white people should know more than Jim. So Jim agreed and said he would follow everything Tom told him.
tr: Jim didn't understand the reason for most of it, but he said that we were white and would know better; he was satisfied and would do everything exactly as Tom said.
es: Jim didn't understand most of it, but he acknowledged that since we were white we knew more than he did, so he was quite happy and stated that he would do everything just as Tom had told him.

en: Jim had plenty corn-cob pipes and tobacco; so we had a right down good sociable time; then we crawled out through the hole, and so home to bed, with hands that looked like they’d been chawed.
vi: Jim has many wooden pipes, and also tobacco. So we sat down and had a very pleasant conversation. After that, we crawled back through the hole and returned to the sleeping quarters.
tr: Jim had plenty of corncob pipes and tobacco; so the conversation lasted quite a while; then we crawled out of the hole, went home, and lay down in our beds, our hands looking like they had been chewed and spat on.
es: Jim had plenty of corn cob pipes and tobacco, so we had a great time in his company; then we crawled out on all fours through the hole and went to bed, with our hands raw.

en: Tom was in high spirits.
vi: Our hands were all bruised, but Tom was very pleased.
tr: Tom was so delighted, you can't imagine.
es: Tom was very excited.

en: He said it was the best fun he ever had in his life, and the most intellectural; and said if he only could see his way to it we would keep it up all the rest of our lives and leave Jim to our children to get out; for he believed Jim would come to like it better and better the more he got used to it.
vi: He said it was the most interesting and clever game, and he wished to continue it for the rest of his life, even extending eighty years into the future, to the time of our grandchildren.
tr: He said this was the most fun and most contemplative event of his life; if he could find a way, we could spend the rest of our lives on this, and then leave it to our children to get Jim out, because he thought Jim would like it more as he got used to it.
es: He said it was the most fun and the most intellectual thing in his life, and that if he could manage it, we would spend our lives doing it and leave Jim for our children to rescue, because he believed Jim would like it more and more as he got used to it.

en: He said that in that way it could be strung out to as much as eighty year, and would be the best time on record.
vi: He said it was the most interesting and clever game, and he wished to continue it for the rest of his life, even extending eighty years into the future, to the time of our grandchildren.
tr: Maybe we could extend the rescue to eighty years and achieve the longest duration ever.
es: He said that if we kept going like this, it would last at least eighty years and break all time records.

en: And he said it would make us all celebrated that had a hand in it.
vi: And surely we would become famous figures.
tr: Moreover, everyone involved in this would become famous.
es: And he added that it would make all of us who had been involved in it famous.

en: In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass candlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in his pocket.
vi: In the morning, we went to the woodpile and chopped the brass candlestick into several pieces, then Tim put them into his pocket along with some spoons.
tr: In the morning, we went to the woodpile and cut the brass candlestick into suitable pieces, Tom put these and the iron spoon in his pocket.
es: In the morning we went to the woodpile, broke the copper candlestick into several more manageable pieces, and Tom put them in his pocket along with the pewter spoon.

en: Then we went to the nigger cabins, and while I got Nat’s notice off, Tom shoved a piece of candlestick into the middle of a corn-pone that was in Jim’s pan, and we went along with Nat to see how it would work, and it just worked noble; when Jim bit into it it most mashed all his teeth out; and there warn’t ever anything could a worked better.
vi: We went down to the black people's house; while I distracted Nat, Tom slipped a piece of the candlestick into the bread in the pot of food meant for Jim and then followed Nat. When Jim bit into the bread, it felt like his teeth were going to break.
tr: Then we went to the negro cabins, and when Nat was distracted, Tom slipped a piece of the candlestick into a piece of cornbread in Jim's pan, then we went to Nat to see if it would work, and indeed our plan worked very well; when Jim bit into the bread, he almost broke all his teeth; it was really hard to come up with a plan that would work better than this.
es: Then we went to where the cabins of the black people were, and while I distracted Nat, Tom put a piece of the candlestick in the middle of the cornbread that was in the bowl for Jim, and we went with Nat to see how it would turn out, which worked wonderfully; when Jim took a bite, he almost broke all his teeth, and that was a sign of how well everything was going.

en: Tom said so himself.
vi: Jim didn't complain, he just said that it was a common grit that often got mixed into the bread.
tr: Tom said this himself.
es: Tom himself said so.

en: Jim he never let on but what it was only just a piece of rock or something like that that’s always getting into bread, you know; but after that he never bit into nothing but what he jabbed his fork into it in three or four places first.
vi: After that, Jim didn't bite directly into the bread anymore but used a fork to poke three or four spots to check first.
tr: Jim didn't show any reaction, he acted as if a piece of stone had come out of his bread as usual; but after that, he didn't bite into anything without poking it three or four times with his fork.
es: Jim didn't say what it was about, but he pretended it was a little stone or one of those things that always get into the bread, you know; but from then on, he never took a bite of anything without first stabbing it with a fork three or four times.

en: And whilst we was a-standing there in the dimmish light, here comes a couple of the hounds bulging in from under Jim’s bed; and they kept on piling in till there was eleven of them, and there warn’t hardly room in there to get your breath.
vi: While we were standing in the dim light, suddenly two dogs crawled out from under Jim's bed, followed by others one after another, making a total of eleven dogs crowding the entire room.
tr: While we were standing there in the dim light, a pair of dogs came out from under Jim's bed, followed by other dogs, and eleven dogs entered, leaving no room to breathe.
es: And while we were standing in that dim light, two of the dogs that had crawled into the hole under Jim's cot appeared and kept coming and coming until there were eleven of them and there was hardly any room left to breathe.

en: By jings, we forgot to fasten that lean-to door!
vi: Oh no, we forgot to lock the door.
tr: Oh no, we had forgotten to close the shed door.
es: Heck, we had forgotten to close the shed door!

en: The nigger Nat he only just hollered “Witches” once, and keeled over on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was dying.
vi: The black man Nat only had time to shout "Ghost!" before he staggered and collapsed on the floor, groaning as if he were about to die.
tr: Black Nat collapsed among the dogs after shouting "Witches!" just once and began to moan as if he were dying.
es: Black Nat only screamed "Witches" once and then knelt on the ground among the dogs and began to moan as if he were dying.

en: Tom jerked the door open and flung out a slab of Jim’s meat, and the dogs went for it, and in two seconds he was out himself and back again and shut the door, and I knowed he’d fixed the other door too.
vi: Tom forcefully pushed the door open, threw a piece of meat from Jim's food supply outside, and the pack of dogs rushed out. Tom ran out after them, then came back and did not forget to close the door.
tr: Tom immediately opened the door and threw out a slice of meat that had come to Jim; the dogs followed it out. Tom disappeared for two seconds but then came back and closed the door, and I realized he had closed the other door as well.
es: Tom flung the door open, threw a piece of Jim's meat through it, and the dogs rushed out to get it. In two seconds, he was out, back in, and had closed the door, and I realized he had also closed the other one.

en: Then he went to work on the nigger, coaxing him and petting him, and asking him if he’d been imagining he saw something again.
vi: Tom sweetly coaxed the black man and asked him what he had seen.
tr: Then the old black man started working on him, trying to cheer him up, pampering him, and asking if he had seen the same thing again.
es: Then he started talking to the black man, very understanding and affectionate, asking him if he had imagined seeing something again.

en: He raised up, and blinked his eyes around, and says:
vi: He sat up, blinked for a while, and said:
tr: The man lifted his head, blinked his eyes as he looked around, and said:
es: The black man lifted his head, blinked, and said:

en: “Mars Sid, you’ll say I’s a fool, but if I didn’t b’lieve I see most a million dogs, er devils, er some’n, I wisht I may die right heah in dese tracks.
vi: - Sid, you might think I'm crazy, but I really just saw a million dogs, or demons, or something.
tr: “Master Sid, you call me a fool, but I almost saw a million dogs, or were they devils?
es: —Mr. Sid, you may think I'm a fool, but may I die right here if it didn't seem like I saw almost a million dogs, or devils, or something.

en: I did, mos’ sholy.
vi: - Sid, you might think I'm crazy, but I really just saw a million dogs, or demons, or something.
tr: “Master Sid, you call me a fool, but I almost saw a million dogs, or were they devils?
es: I assure you, Mr. Sid.

en: Mars Sid, I felt um—I felt um, sah; dey was all over me.
vi: I thought I could die right then and there. I was so scared, they all jumped at me.
tr: Let me be a dog if I'm lying, may I not be blessed to go from one place to another. Master Sid, it seems to me... It seems to me that they all fell upon me.
es: I touched them... I touched them, young master; they were everywhere.

en: Dad fetch it, I jis’ wisht I could git my han’s on one er dem witches jis’ wunst—on’y jis’ wunst—it’s all I’d ast.
vi: But at that moment, I couldn't do anything.
tr: Oh, if I could catch one of them, if I could catch just one of those witches, I wouldn't want anything else... just for a moment... that's all I want.
es: Damn it, I wish I could get my hands on one of those witches just once, just once, that's all I ask.

en: But mos’ly I wisht dey’d lemme ’lone, I does.”
vi: I just wanted them to leave me alone.
tr: But most of all, I want them to leave me alone.”
es: But above all, I wish they would leave me alone, that would be the best.

en: Tom says:
vi: Tom said:
tr: “Hmm, let me tell you what I think,” said Tom.
es: Tom goes and says:

en: “Well, I tell you what I think.
vi: - Ah, simple.
tr: “Hmm, let me tell you what I think,” said Tom.
es: —Well, I'm going to tell you what I think.

en: What makes them come here just at this runaway nigger’s breakfast-time?
vi: They came in here again while this black man on the run was having breakfast because they were hungry, maybe.
tr: “What could be bringing them here exactly at the breakfast time of this runaway negro?
es: Why do they come here precisely at the time of this runaway black man's breakfast?

en: It’s because they’re hungry; that’s the reason.
vi: They came in here again while this black man on the run was having breakfast because they were hungry, maybe.
tr: If you ask me, they are hungry, that's why they are coming.
es: It's because they're hungry, and nothing more.

en: You make them a witch pie; that’s the thing for you to do.”
vi: You have to make a separate cake for the devil.
tr: You should make them a witch pie, I think that's the best remedy for your problem.”
es: You have to make them a witch's pie. That's it.

en: “But my lan’, Mars Sid, how’s I gwyne to make ’m a witch pie?
vi: - Oh, Sid, I don't know what cakes for ghosts are.
tr: “Oh Great God, help me, Lord Sid, am I going to make a witch beetle?
es: —But, for God's sake, Sid, how am I going to make them a witch pie?

en: I doan’ know how to make it.
vi: - Oh, Sid, I don't know what cakes for ghosts are.
tr: “Oh Great God, help me, Lord Sid, am I going to make a witch beetle?
es: I don't know how to make one.

en: I hain’t ever hearn er sich a thing b’fo’.”
vi: I've never heard of that before.
tr: I haven't even heard of it before.”
es: I've never heard of anything like it in my life.

en: “Well, then, I’ll have to make it myself.”
vi: - Then let me do it.
tr: “Alright, alright, it seems I will have to do it myself.”
es: —Well, then I'll have to do it myself.

en: “Will you do it, honey?—will you?
vi: - That's very kind.
tr: “Are you really going to do it? My dear, are you saying it's true?
es: —Will you do it, my boy? Will you really?

en: I’ll wusshup de groun’ und’ yo’ foot, I will!”
vi: I will kneel down at your feet and bow.
tr: I'll kiss your hands and feet, please just do it!”
es: I'll kiss the ground you walk on, truly!

en: “All right, I’ll do it, seeing it’s you, and you’ve been good to us and showed us the runaway nigger.
vi: - Because you were kind enough to show us the runaway black man.
tr: “Alright, I will do it; after all, you have a special place; you treated us very well and showed us the runaway black man.
es: —Very well, I will do it for you because it is about you and because you have behaved well with us and have shown us the runaway black man.

en: But you got to be mighty careful.
vi: But you must be very careful.
tr: But you must be very careful.
es: But you have to be very careful.

en: When we come around, you turn your back; and then whatever we’ve put in the pan, don’t you let on you see it at all.
vi: When we put it in the pot, you must not look into it.
tr: When we come back, turn your back; no matter what we put in your pan, do not look at what it is.
es: When we appear, you have to turn your back, and then, whatever we put in the bowl, you have to act like you don't see it.

en: And don’t you look when Jim unloads the pan—something might happen, I don’t know what.
vi: When Jim takes the food out of the pot, you must not look, and especially not touch it, in case something happens, I won't know what to do.
tr: Also, do not look while Jim is taking things from your pan… I don't know what will happen if you look.
es: And you must not look when Jim empties the pot, because something might happen. I don't know what.

en: And above all, don’t you handle the witch-things.”
vi: When Jim takes the food out of the pot, you must not look, and especially not touch it, in case something happens, I won't know what to do.
tr: Above all, do not touch the witch's items.”
es: Above all, do not touch the witches' things.

en: “Hannel ’m, Mars Sid?
vi: - Not allowed to touch?
tr: “Touch it, Mr. Sid?
es: —Touch them, Mr. Sid?

en: What is you a-talkin’ ’bout?
vi: - Not allowed to touch?
tr: What are you saying?
es: What are you saying?

en: I wouldn’ lay de weight er my finger on um, not f’r ten hund’d thous’n billion dollars, I wouldn’t.”
vi: Then even if you give me millions of dollars, I wouldn't bother touching it.
tr: Even if they gave me fourteen hundred billion dollars, I wouldn't touch it.”
es: I wouldn't lay a finger on them, even if I had a hundred billion dollars, truly.

en: CHAPTER XXXVII.
vi: Chapter XXXVII
tr: Chapter Thirty-Seven
es: Chapter 37

en: That was all fixed.
vi: Everything was already arranged.
tr: Everything was arranged.
es: THAT WAS SETTLED.

en: So then we went away and went to the rubbage-pile in the back yard, where they keep the old boots, and rags, and pieces of bottles, and wore-out tin things, and all such truck, and scratched around and found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes as well as we could, to bake the pie in, and took it down cellar and stole it full of flour and started for breakfast, and found a couple of shingle-nails that Tom said would be handy for a prisoner to scrabble his name and sorrows on the dungeon walls with, and dropped one of them in Aunt Sally’s apron-pocket which was hanging on a chair, and t’other we stuck in the band of Uncle Silas’s hat, which was on the bureau, because we heard the children say their pa and ma was going to the runaway nigger’s house this morning, and then went to breakfast, and Tom dropped the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas’s coat-pocket, and Aunt Sally wasn’t come yet, so we had to wait a little while.
vi: We went to the pile of trash in the backyard, rummaged around, and found an old tin washbasin, patched up the holes to steal some flour and fill it up. After that, we went back to the house, had breakfast, and picked up a few boat nails. Tom said those were very good for prisoners to use to write their names and their sufferings on the prison bed. We put one nail into Aunt Sally's kitchen apron pocket hanging on the chair, and the other nail into Uncle Silas's hatband on the desk, because we heard the kids say their parents would visit the runaway slave this morning. I also put a spoon into Uncle Silas's outer coat pocket. Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, so we had to wait for a while. A moment later, Aunt Saly arrived, her face flushed red.
tr: Thus, we went to the pile in the backyard where old boots, rags, broken bottles, useless pots and pans, and other junk were found. After some searching, we found an old and deep pan, patched up its holes as best as we could to bake a pie in it, then took it to the cellar and filled it to the brim with flour. While preparing for breakfast, we also found two small nails. Tom said these would be suitable for the prisoner to carve his name and sufferings into the dungeon walls. Then he put one in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was hanging on a chair, and the other into the band of Uncle Silas's hat, which we saw on the drawer at that moment, because we had heard the children talking about their parents going to the runaway negro's house this morning. After that, we went to breakfast, and Tom put the tin spoon into Uncle Silas's coat pocket. Since Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, we waited at the table for a while.
es: Then we went to the dump in the backyard, where they have old boots, rags, broken bottles, and worn-out things and all that, and we searched until we found an old tin basin, patched the holes as best as we could to make the pie in it and took it down to the basement to fill it with stolen flour, and when we were going to have breakfast we found a couple of nails that, according to Tom, would be very useful for a prisoner to write his name and sorrows on the dungeon walls, and we left one of them in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was hanging on a chair, and we stuck the other one in the ribbon of Uncle Silas's hat, which was on the desk, because we heard the children say that their father and mother were planning to go that morning to see the runaway negro, and then we went to have breakfast and Tom left the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas's jacket pocket, but since Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, we had to wait a while.

en: And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:
vi: One hand pouring coffee, the other knocking on the head of the nearest child, and said:
tr: When Aunt Sally arrived, she was bright red, her eyebrows were furrowed, and she barely waited for the prayer; then, while pouring coffee with one hand, she started hitting the nearest child's head with the thimble on her other hand's finger, saying:
es: When she arrived, she was all hot, flushed, and in a bad mood, and she could hardly wait for the blessing of the table, so she started serving coffee with one hand and thimbling the head of the nearest child with the other, while saying:

en: “I’ve hunted high and I’ve hunted low, and it does beat all what has become of your other shirt.”
vi: - I searched all over the house but couldn't find a single shirt.
tr: “I searched upstairs, I searched downstairs, it's nowhere to be found, what happened to your other shirt?”
es: —I have searched everywhere and I don't understand what happened to your other shirt.

en: My heart fell down amongst my lungs and livers and things, and a hard piece of corn-crust started down my throat after it and got met on the road with a cough, and was shot across the table, and took one of the children in the eye and curled him up like a fishing-worm, and let a cry out of him the size of a warwhoop, and Tom he turned kinder blue around the gills, and it all amounted to a considerable state of things for about a quarter of a minute or as much as that, and I would a sold out for half price if there was a bidder.
vi: My heart seemed to drop, the piece of cake stuck in my throat and caused a cough, the piece of cake shot out, flew across the table, hit the eye of the child sitting in front of me, and stuck there. The child let out a scream. As for Tom, his face turned pale for a moment, but then returned to normal.
tr: I felt like I had slipped and fallen between my heart, lungs, and liver, then a hard piece of cornbread met a cough on its way down my throat and shot out of my mouth, exploding in the eye of one of the kids across the table. The child let out something like a war cry and writhed like a fishing worm, while Tom had turned almost purple up to his ears. Moreover, all of this happened in about a quarter of a minute. The breakfast table had become such a dangerous place that if there had been an auction at that moment, I would have sold myself at half price to escape.
es: My heart sank between my lungs and livers and all that, and a hard piece of corn husk got stuck in my throat, so I started coughing, spat it all over the table, and hit one of the kids in the eye, making him squirm like a worm on a hook and let out a scream like an Indian on the warpath. Tom turned as red as a poppy, and then there was a big mess for about a quarter of a minute or so, and I would have confessed everything right then and there at the first opportunity.

en: But after that we was all right again—it was the sudden surprise of it that knocked us so kind of cold.
vi: Then another event made us all shiver.
tr: But after that, we pulled ourselves together – what had shaken us so much was the suddenness of the situation.
es: But then everything settled down again, because the surprise had caught us all off guard.

en: Uncle Silas he says:
vi: Uncle Silas said:
tr: “Extremely unusual and strange, I can't understand it at all,” said Uncle Silas.
es: Uncle Silas said:

en: “It’s most uncommon curious, I can’t understand it.
vi: - Strange, I clearly remember taking off my shirt because...
tr: “Extremely unusual and strange, I can't understand it at all,” said Uncle Silas.
es: —It is most curious. I cannot understand it.

en: I know perfectly well I took it off, because—”
vi: - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself.
tr: “I know very well where I took it off, because…”
es: I know perfectly well that I took it off, because...

en: “Because you hain’t got but one on.
vi: - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself.
tr: “Because there was only one on it.
es: —Because now you only have one shirt.

en: Just listen at the man!
vi: - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself.
tr: Do you hear what you're saying?
es: What things you say!

en: I know you took it off, and know it by a better way than your wool-gethering memory, too, because it was on the clo’s-line yesterday—I see it there myself.
vi: - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself.
tr: I know you took it off, and I have a much more reliable source than your hazy memory because I hung it on the clothesline yesterday... I saw it there with my own eyes.
es: I already knew that you had taken it off and I remember it better than you, because yesterday it was on the clothesline and I saw it myself.

en: But it’s gone, that’s the long and the short of it, and you’ll just have to change to a red flann’l one till I can get time to make a new one.
vi: But now it's gone.
tr: But it's gone now... there's no ifs or buts about it, the only thing we can do is for you to wear your red undershirt until I sew a new one.
es: But it has disappeared and there's nothing more to say, so you'll have to wear a red flannel one until I find the time to make you another.

en: And it’ll be the third I’ve made in two years.
vi: But now it's gone.
tr: Moreover, this will be the third one in two years; one has to be constantly on guard so you don't go without a shirt; I can never understand how you manage to ruin so many shirts.
es: And it will be the third one I've made for you in two years.

en: It just keeps a body on the jump to keep you in shirts; and whatever you do manage to do with ’m all is more’n I can make out.
vi: Just go get another shirt to wear, and I'll make you a new one.
tr: Moreover, this will be the third one in two years; one has to be constantly on guard so you don't go without a shirt; I can never understand how you manage to ruin so many shirts.
es: I spend half my time just sewing shirts for you, and what I don't understand is what the devil you do with them.

en: A body ’d think you would learn to take some sort of care of ’em at your time of life.”
vi: You must take better care of your clothes.
tr: All I can do is hope that at some point in your life you'll learn to take care of your shirts.”
es: Logically, at your age, you should have already learned to take care of them a little.

en: “I know it, Sally, and I do try all I can.
vi: - I know, Saly, but that is not entirely my fault.
tr: “I know, Sally, believe me, I'm doing my best.
es: —I already know, Sally, and I try as much as I can.

en: But it oughtn’t to be altogether my fault, because, you know, I don’t see them nor have nothing to do with them except when they’re on me; and I don’t believe I’ve ever lost one of them off of me.”
vi: I haven't seen that shirt except when I wear it, and if I wear it, there's no reason for it to get lost.
tr: But it can't be entirely my fault, because you know that when they're not on me, I neither see them nor have anything to do with them; moreover, I don't think I could lose them at a moment when they're not on me.”
es: But it can't all be my fault, because you know I don't see them or have anything to do with them except when I'm wearing them, and I don't think I've lost any while wearing them.

en: “Well, it ain’t your fault if you haven’t, Silas; you’d a done it if you could, I reckon.
vi: - Well, it's not your fault if you don't know.
tr: “If you can't do it, it's not your fault, Silas… if you could, you would, surely.
es: —Well, that's not your fault; you would have lost them if you could, I think.

en: And the shirt ain’t all that’s gone, nuther.
vi: And it's not just about losing one shirt.
tr: Moreover, the only thing missing isn't just the shirt.
es: Besides, it's not just the shirt that's missing.

en: Ther’s a spoon gone; and that ain’t all.
vi: That's not all.
tr: A spoon has gone missing, even other things have disappeared.
es: A spoon is also missing, and that's not all.

en: There was ten, and now ther’s only nine.
vi: Ten spoons, now there are nine.
tr: There were ten spoons, but now there are only nine.
es: There were ten and now there are only nine.

en: The calf got the shirt, I reckon, but the calf never took the spoon, that’s certain.”
vi: Maybe the calf took the shirt, but a calf would never take a spoon. That's for sure.
tr: Let's say the calf took the shirt, but calves definitely don't steal spoons, that's for sure.”
es: Maybe the calf ate the shirt, but what I can assure you is that the calf didn't eat the spoon.

en: “Why, what else is gone, Sally?”
vi: - What else is lost, Saly?
tr: “What else is gone, Sally?”
es: —What else is missing, Sally?

en: “Ther’s six candles gone—that’s what.
vi: - Six more candles are missing, it could be that mice took them away.
tr: “Six candles are missing... the candles are gone.
es: —Six candles are missing, that's what's missing.

en: The rats could a got the candles, and I reckon they did; I wonder they don’t walk off with the whole place, the way you’re always going to stop their holes and don’t do it; and if they warn’t fools they’d sleep in your hair, Silas—you’d never find it out; but you can’t lay the spoon on the rats, and that I know.”
vi: But I don't understand how they got in, because you always seal the holes, and they shouldn't be able to get in. If they could get in, they might even crawl into your hair while you sleep.
tr: Sometimes the mice take the candles away, I guess that's what happened this time too; anyway, I don't know how they don't take everything we have, you were supposed to block their holes, but you didn't; if they weren't so stupid, they would make a nest in your hair, Silas... you wouldn't even notice; but look, you can't blame the mice for the spoon, I know this for sure.”
es: The rats could have eaten the candles, and I reckon that's what happened; I wonder why they don't just take everything already, because you spend your life saying you're going to plug the holes and you never do, and if they weren't idiots, they'd sleep on your head, Silas, and you wouldn't even notice; but you can't blame the rats for the spoon, I'm sure of that.

en: “Well, Sally, I’m in fault, and I acknowledge it; I’ve been remiss; but I won’t let to-morrow go by without stopping up them holes.”
vi: - Alright, I know it's my fault. I've been too careless lately, starting tomorrow I won't leave any gaps unfilled.
tr: “Alright, Sally, my fault, I admit it; I was careless; but tomorrow I will definitely close those mouse holes.”
es: —Well, Sally, it will be my fault and I admit it; I have let it slide, but I assure you that tomorrow I will plug all the holes.

en: “Oh, I wouldn’t hurry; next year’ll do.
vi: - Oh, there's no rush, next year is fine...
tr: "No way, don't rush at all, you can do it next year.
es: —There's no rush; as long as you cover them next year, it's enough.

en: Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!”
vi: The sound of a hand slapping the table, the child who was dipping their finger into the sugar bowl quickly pulled it out.
tr: Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!"
es: Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!

en: Whack comes the thimble, and the child snatches her claws out of the sugar-bowl without fooling around any.
vi: The sound of a hand slapping the table, the child who was dipping their finger into the sugar bowl quickly pulled it out.
tr: The thimble came down on the head and the child had to pull his empty claws out of the candy jar.
es: Thimble tap and the girl takes her fingers out of the sugar bowl without saying a word.

en: Just then the nigger woman steps on to the passage, and says:
vi: At that moment, a black woman walked in and said:
tr: Just then, the black woman entered the passage:
es: Just then, the black woman arrives at the passage and says:

en: “Missus, dey’s a sheet gone.”
vi: - Madam, a bedsheet is also missing.
tr: “Madam, one sheet is missing.”
es: —Ma'am, a sheet is missing.

en: “A sheet gone!
vi: - Missing bed sheet!
tr: “Are we missing a sheet!
es: —A sheet is missing!

en: Well, for the land’s sake!”
vi: How strange?
tr: For God's sake, what's happening?”
es: Well, what's going on here!

en: “I’ll stop up them holes to-day,” says Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful.
vi: Uncle Silas with a sad expression: - I will go and seal the holes today. - Stop it, sir.
tr: “I will plug the holes right away today,” said Uncle Silas with sadness.
es: —Today I will cover the holes —says Uncle Silas, with a remorseful look on his face.

en: “Oh, do shet up!—s’pose the rats took the sheet?
vi: What mouse would carry off a bedsheet?
tr: “Woman, be quiet!.. Do you think the mice took the sheet?
es: —Come on, shut up! Do you think the rats took the sheet?

en: Where’s it gone, Lize?”
vi: Where did it go missing? Lize!
tr: Where could the sheet have gone; Lize?”
es: Where has it disappeared to, Lize?

en: “Clah to goodness I hain’t no notion, Miss’ Sally.
vi: - Madam, I don't know.
tr: "I have no idea, Miss Sally.
es: —I swear to God I have no idea, Miss Sally.

en: She wuz on de clo’sline yistiddy, but she done gone: she ain’ dah no mo’ now.”
vi: Yesterday, it was still on the clothesline, but now it's gone, no longer there.
tr: Yesterday it was on the clothesline, but now it's not there."
es: Yesterday it was on the clothesline but it has disappeared; it's not there anymore.

en: “I reckon the world is coming to an end.
vi: - This is complete chaos.
tr: “The end of the world has come, I guess.
es: —This looks like the end of the world.

en: I never see the beat of it in all my born days.
vi: I've never seen anything like this before, from childhood until now, shirts, then bed sheets; then spoons; then...
tr: I have never seen such nonsense in my life until today.
es: I've never seen anything like this.

en: A shirt, and a sheet, and a spoon, and six can—”
vi: A boy walked in from somewhere:
tr: A shirt, a sheet, a spoon, and six candles...”
es: A shirt, a sheet, a spoon, and six ve...

en: “Missus,” comes a young yaller wench, “dey’s a brass cannelstick miss’n.”
vi: - Madam, another brass candlestick is missing.
tr: A young maid burst in, calling out, "Madam, one of the brass candlesticks is missing."
es: —Sita —says a light-skinned black woman as she arrives—, a bronze candelabrum is missing.

en: “Cler out from here, you hussy, er I’ll take a skillet to ye!”
vi: - Get out of here, you damn idiot, or I'll beat you up right now.
tr: "Get out of here quickly, you shrew, or I'll smash the pot on your head!"
es: —Get out of here, shameless, or I'll hit you with a frying pan!

en: Well, she was just a-biling.
vi: Aunt Saly was boiling with anger.
tr: Aunt Sally had completely lost her mind.
es: Well, she was furious.

en: I begun to lay for a chance; I reckoned I would sneak out and go for the woods till the weather moderated.
vi: I sat silently praying, planning to sneak outside to go into the forest and wait until the atmosphere calmed down a bit.
tr: I started looking for an opportunity to slip away; I could wander in the forest until the weather softened a bit and then come back.
es: I started to wait for an opportunity. I thought it was best to go to the forest until the weather improved.

en: She kept a-raging right along, running her insurrection all by herself, and everybody else mighty meek and quiet; and at last Uncle Silas, looking kind of foolish, fishes up that spoon out of his pocket.
vi: Everyone was silent, fearful. Finally, Uncle Silas was dumbfounded to find the spoon in his pocket.
tr: Aunt Sally had lost control and was ranting while everyone else in the house was silent and looking down; finally, Uncle Silas reached into his pocket and pulled out the spoon with a somewhat bewildered expression.
es: She kept shouting, organizing an insurrection all by herself, while the rest of us were meek and quiet, until Uncle Silas, looking very surprised, pulled the spoon out of his pocket.

en: She stopped, with her mouth open and her hands up; and as for me, I wished I was in Jeruslem or somewheres.
vi: Aunt Saly stood still, raised her hand, and opened her mouth wide. As for me, I just wanted to sink into the ground.
tr: Aunt Sally froze with her mouth open and hands in the air; if you ask me, I wished I could be in Jerusalem or somewhere at that moment.
es: Aunt fell silent, with her mouth open and raising her hands, and as for me, I wished I had been in Jerusalem or anywhere else.

en: But not long, because she says:
vi: Aunt Saly said:
tr: But her state didn’t last long, because she said:
es: But not for long, because she goes and says:

en: “It’s just as I expected.
vi: - I knew it right away.
tr: “Just as I expected.
es: —I was expecting that.

en: So you had it in your pocket all the time; and like as not you’ve got the other things there, too.
vi: So you still kept it in your coat pocket. There might even be other things in that pocket too.
tr: So it was in your pocket all along, I wonder if the other missing items are there too.
es: So you had it in your pocket, and surely you have all the other things.

en: How’d it get there?”
vi: How did it get in there?
tr: How did the spoon get in there?”
es: How did it get there?

en: “I reely don’t know, Sally,” he says, kind of apologizing, “or you know I would tell.
vi: - I really don't know.
tr: “I really don’t know, Sally,” he said apologetically, “otherwise I would tell you, you know.
es: —I really don't know, Sally—he says, as if making excuses—, or you know very well that I would tell you.

en: I was a-studying over my text in Acts Seventeen before breakfast, and I reckon I put it in there, not noticing, meaning to put my Testament in, and it must be so, because my Testament ain’t in; but I’ll go and see; and if the Testament is where I had it, I’ll know I didn’t put it in, and that will show that I laid the Testament down and took up the spoon, and—”
vi: Maybe while having breakfast, because I was so engrossed in reading the Bible, I put the spoon in my pocket thinking it was the holy book.
tr: Before breakfast, I was working on Acts 17. I don’t know how it happened, but I must have unknowingly put it in my pocket thinking it was the Bible; it must be so, because the Bible is not in my pocket, but let me go and check, if the Bible is still in its previous place, I will be sure that I didn’t put it in my pocket, then I will put the Bible and take the spoon and put it in my pocket...”
es: I was studying my text from Acts 17 before breakfast and I figure I put it there, without realizing it, when what I wanted was to put my New Testament, and it must be that because what I don't have is the New Testament, but I'll check, and if the New Testament is where it was before, I'll know that I didn't put it away and that will prove that I left the New Testament on the table and grabbed the spoon and...

en: “Oh, for the land’s sake!
vi: Let me go check if the Bible is still there or not.
tr: “Ah, for God's sake!
es: —Well, for the love of God!

en: Give a body a rest!
vi: Maybe I put the Bible down and picked up the spoon, and...
tr: Be quiet already!
es: Leave me alone!

en: Go ’long now, the whole kit and biling of ye; and don’t come nigh me again till I’ve got back my peace of mind.”
vi: - Oh no, everyone please go away, don't let anyone come near me while I'm in a rage.
tr: Get out, all of you, children and everyone, get out, and don't come near me until I get my head straight.”
es: Now everyone out and don't come near me again until I've calmed down a bit.

en: I’d a heard her if she’d a said it to herself, let alone speaking it out; and I’d a got up and obeyed her if I’d a been dead.
vi: If she had only whispered to herself, I would have heard it already, let alone shouting like this; even if I were dead, I would have risen to listen.
tr: Even if he didn't speak loudly and said it to himself, I would still hear it; even if I were dead, I would immediately get up and obey.
es: I would have heard her even if she were talking to herself, and even more so because she said it out loud, and I would have gotten up to obey her even if it had killed me.

en: As we was passing through the setting-room the old man he took up his hat, and the shingle-nail fell out on the floor, and he just merely picked it up and laid it on the mantel-shelf, and never said nothing, and went out.
vi: We walked past the bedroom and saw my uncle putting away his hat, the boat nail stuck in his hat fell to the floor. He just quietly picked it up and placed it on the coat rack, said nothing, and walked out.
tr: As we passed through the living room, the old man dropped the nail while taking his hat; he just bent down, picked up the nail, and placed it on the mantelpiece, then left without saying a word.
es: As we passed through the room, the old man grabbed the hat and the nail fell out, but he simply picked it up and left it on the shelf without saying a word, and left.

en: Tom see him do it, and remembered about the spoon, and says:
vi: Seeing that, Tom remembered the spoon. He said:
tr: Tom had seen what he did, and thinking about the spoon issue, he said:
es: Tom saw it, remembered the spoon, and said:

en: “Well, it ain’t no use to send things by him no more, he ain’t reliable.”
vi: - Well, maybe we can't trust him to send things through him anymore.
tr: “There is no point in sending anything with him anymore, he is not reliable.”
es: —Well, it's no use sending things with him anymore, because he's not trustworthy —and he added—, but in any case, he did us a favor with the spoon, without knowing it, so let's do him one without him knowing: let's cover the rat holes.

en: Then he says: “But he done us a good turn with the spoon, anyway, without knowing it, and so we’ll go and do him one without him knowing it—stop up his rat-holes.”
vi: But he did us a favor regarding the spoon that the other guy didn't know about, so we should thank him by sealing up the mouse holes.
tr: Then he continued: “But he was very useful with the spoon, even without realizing it; so we should go and do something useful for him without his knowledge – let's plug the mouse holes.”
es: —Well, it's no use sending things with him anymore, because he's not trustworthy —and he added—, but in any case, he did us a favor with the spoon, without knowing it, so let's do him one without him knowing: let's cover the rat holes.

en: There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole hour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape.
vi: In the basement, there were many rat holes, so it took us an hour to seal them all, but we did it very carefully.
tr: There were indeed a lot of mouse holes in the cellar; we spent almost an hour, but in the end, we did a perfect job and tightly sealed all of them.
es: There were heaps of them in the basement and it took us a whole hour, but we did the job well, without forgetting anything.

en: Then we heard steps on the stairs, and blowed out our light and hid; and here comes the old man, with a candle in one hand and a bundle of stuff in t’other, looking as absent-minded as year before last.
vi: Suddenly, there were footsteps on the stairs, and we quickly turned off the lights and hid. Uncle Silas came, holding a candle in one hand and some tools in the other, looking dazed.
tr: Just as we finished our work, we heard someone coming down the stairs to the cellar, and we immediately turned off our light and hid; the old man was coming down absentmindedly with a candle in one hand and sealing materials in the other.
es: Then we heard footsteps on the stairs, turned off the light, hid, and the old man appeared, with a candle in one hand and a bunch of tow in the other, as distracted as ever.

en: He went a mooning around, first to one rat-hole and then another, till he’d been to them all.
vi: He went around from one rat hole to another.
tr: He went from one mouse hole to another, visiting all the holes.
es: He started searching everywhere, first one of the holes and then another, until he saw them all.

en: Then he stood about five minutes, picking tallow-drip off of his candle and thinking.
vi: Then he stood up and paused for a few minutes, thinking.
tr: Then, fiddling with the dripping parts of the candle in his hand, he stood there thinking for about five minutes.
es: Then he stood still for about five minutes, removing the tallow from the candle and thinking, until he slowly and pensively turned towards the stairs saying:

en: Then he turns off slow and dreamy towards the stairs, saying:
vi: He walked towards the stairs in a trance, mumbling:
tr: Finally, he slowly and dreamily murmured as he headed towards the stairs:
es: Then he stood still for about five minutes, removing the tallow from the candle and thinking, until he slowly and pensively turned towards the stairs saying:

en: “Well, for the life of me I can’t remember when I done it.
vi: - I don't remember when I plugged these holes.
tr: “I never remember when I did it.
es: —Well, the truth is that I don't remember when I did it.

en: I could show her now that I warn’t to blame on account of the rats.
vi: I have to go tell Saly right now, and that way I won't be blamed for the mice.
tr: He now accepts that I am not guilty about the mice.
es: Now I could prove to you that the rat problem is not my fault.

en: But never mind—let it go.
vi: But never mind, saying it wouldn't help anyway.
tr: But anyway… It's best to let it be.
es: But it doesn't matter: let's leave it at that.

en: I reckon it wouldn’t do no good.”
vi: But never mind, saying it wouldn't help anyway.
tr: The other way wouldn't benefit anyone anyway.”
es: I figure it wouldn't be worth anything.

en: And so he went on a-mumbling up stairs, and then we left.
vi: As he just went up the stairs, we sneaked out after him.
tr: He went up the stairs saying such things, and we followed him.
es: He went up the stairs talking to himself, and then we left.

en: He was a mighty nice old man.
vi: He is always nice.
tr: He was a very charming old man.
