es: He was a very nice old man, and he still is.

en: And always is.
vi: He is always nice.
tr: He always remained that way.
es: He was a very nice old man, and he still is.

en: Tom was a good deal bothered about what to do for a spoon, but he said we’d got to have it; so he took a think.
vi: Tom was very worried about how to get a spoon. After thinking for a while, he told me what to do now.
tr: Tom was very worried about what we would do with the spoon, but we had to take it. So he sat down and started to think.
es: Tom was very worried about how to find another spoon, because he said we needed it; so he started thinking.

en: When he had ciphered it out he told me how we was to do; then we went and waited around the spoon-basket till we see Aunt Sally coming, and then Tom went to counting the spoons and laying them out to one side, and I slid one of them up my sleeve, and Tom says:
vi: We went to wait at the place where the spoon basket was until Aunt Saly arrived. Tom counted the spoons and set one aside, then slipped one into his sleeve. Then Tom said:
tr: After forming the plan in his mind, he told me what we would do; then we went and waited around the spoon basket until Aunt Sally came, Tom was counting the spoons and setting aside the ones he counted, I slipped one of the spoons into my cuff, Tom turned to him:
es: When he made up his mind, he told me what we had to do; then we went to wait where the basket of spoons was until we saw Aunt Sally coming, and Tom started counting the spoons and setting them aside while I hid one in my sleeve, and Tom goes and says:

en: “Why, Aunt Sally, there ain’t but nine spoons yet.”
vi: - Saly, there are only nine spoons here.
tr: “Aunt Sally, there are still only nine spoons here.”
es: —Hey, Aunt Sally, there are still only nine spoons.

en: She says:
vi: She said:
tr: “Go play with Git, don't disturb my peace,” said Aunt Sally.
es: And she responds:

en: “Go ’long to your play, and don’t bother me.
vi: - Please, don't bother your aunt anymore.
tr: “Go play with Git, don't disturb my peace,” said Aunt Sally.
es: —Come on, keep playing and don't bother me.

en: I know better, I counted ’m myself.”
vi: Your aunt knows already, she counted it herself.
tr: “I know how many there are, I counted them myself.”
es: I know what there is. I've counted them myself.

en: “Well, I’ve counted them twice, Aunty, and I can’t make but nine.”
vi: - Auntie, I counted twice and still only see nine.
tr: “But I counted them all twice, Aunt, there were nine.”
es: —Well, I counted them twice, Aunt, and I only get nine.

en: She looked out of all patience, but of course she come to count—anybody would.
vi: She seemed to be unable to bear the impatience any longer, but she counted again.
tr: He seemed to have completely lost his patience, but of course, he still came to count – anyone would have come.
es: She seemed to lose her patience, but naturally came to count them, as anyone would have done.

en: “I declare to gracious ther’ ain’t but nine!” she says.
vi: After finishing counting, she said:
tr: “Damn it, there are only nine here!” he said.
es: —For heaven's sake, there are only nine! —he said—.

en: “Why, what in the world—plague take the things, I’ll count ’m again.”
vi: - There really are only nine - How strange, let me count again.
tr: “Why, damn your spoon-like... may your name be cursed, let's count again, it's for the best.”
es: But, what the devil, what is going on with these things? I'm going to count them again.

en: So I slipped back the one I had, and when she got done counting, she says:
vi: I gently let go of the spoon I was holding, then only spoke after she finished counting:
tr: I placed the spoon back among the others and when he finished counting, he said:
es: Then I put back the one I had hidden, and when he finished counting, he said:

en: “Hang the troublesome rubbage, ther’s ten now!” and she looked huffy and bothered both.
vi: - Here are ten! She was both delighted and worried.
tr: “God, give me patience, and now I have ten more!” He looked both angry and worried at the same time.
es: —By all the demons, now there are ten! —she said, very irritated and uneasy at the same time.

en: But Tom says:
vi: But then Tom said:
tr: But Tom intervened:
es: But Tom goes and says:

en: “Why, Aunty, I don’t think there’s ten.”
vi: - No, auntie, how could there be ten?
tr: "No, Auntie, I don't think there are ten.""
es: —But, aunt, I don't think there are ten.

en: “You numskull, didn’t you see me count ’m?”
vi: - Didn't you see that I just counted?
tr: “You idiot, didn't you see what I just counted?”
es: —Don't be silly, didn't you see me counting them?

en: “I know, but—”
vi: - I know, but...
tr: “I know, but…””
es: —I know, but...

en: “Well, I’ll count ’m again.”
vi: - Okay, count again.
tr: “Alright, let's count again then.”
es: —Well, I'm going to count them again.

en: So I smouched one, and they come out nine, same as the other time.
vi: I counted again, and after finishing, I still only saw nine like before.
tr: Upon this, I took one of them, and when she counted, there were still nine spoons.
es: So I swiped one and only nine came out, just like the last time.

en: Well, she was in a tearing way—just a-trembling all over, she was so mad.
vi: That made her so angry she was about to go crazy.
tr: Aunt Sally was now completely out of her mind... She was trembling and had gone mad.
es: She got extremely nervous and started trembling all over because she was so angry.

en: But she counted and counted till she got that addled she’d start to count in the basket for a spoon sometimes; and so, three times they come out right, and three times they come out wrong.
vi: But she kept counting over and over, counting inside the basket and then outside the basket, sometimes it was enough, sometimes it was missing.
tr: But she counted again, and again, until she got so dizzy that she started counting wrong. If the count was correct three times, it was wrong three times.
es: But she kept counting and counting until she got so confused that she even counted the basket as if it were a spoon, so three times she got the count right and three times she got it wrong.

en: Then she grabbed up the basket and slammed it across the house and knocked the cat galley-west; and she said cle’r out and let her have some peace, and if we come bothering around her again betwixt that and dinner she’d skin us.
vi: Too frustrated, she grabbed the spoon basket and threw it into the corner of the house, hitting the cat lying there, and then yelled at us to get out so she could have some peace.
tr: Upon this, she couldn't take it anymore, grabbed the basket and threw it, managing to hit the cat; she immediately disappeared and asked us to leave her alone for a while, saying that if we bothered her until dinner, she would skin us alive.
es: Then she grabbed the basket, threw it to the other side of the room, kicked the cat, and said we should leave her alone and that if we bothered her again, she would skin us alive.

en: So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket whilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all right, along with her shingle nail, before noon.
vi: So we took the spoon and put it into her kitchen apron pocket while she was shouting at us to leave. By near noon, Jim had received both the spoon and the nail. We found the whole thing very amusing.
tr: Thus, we had secured that single spoon; while she was giving us the marching orders, I slipped the spoon into the pocket of her apron; thus, Jim was able to get both the spoon and the nail before noon.
es: So we kept the missing spoon and left it in the pocket of her apron while she ordered us to leave, and Jim got it along with the nail before noon.

en: We was very well satisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the trouble it took, because he said now she couldn’t ever count them spoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn’t believe she’d counted them right if she did; and said that after she’d about counted her head off for the next three days he judged she’d give it up and offer to kill anybody that wanted her to ever count them any more.
vi: He said that after she counted like that for three more days, she would give up, and if anyone asked her to count again, she might even kill them.
tr: Because of this, we were very pleased with ourselves, and Tom said we had been rewarded for our trouble twice over, because even if they took her life, his aunt would never count those spoons again. No matter how many times she counted, she wouldn't believe she had counted correctly. Later, he said that his aunt couldn't pull herself together for the next three days, and if anyone asked her to count again, she would be ready to commit murder.
es: We were very happy with all that, and Tom said it was worth twice the trouble it had caused us, because now she wouldn't be able to count the spoons twice without getting confused even if her life depended on it; and even if she counted them right, she wouldn't believe it, and he said that when her head got tired of counting, she would give up and threaten to kill anyone who asked her to count them again.

en: So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn’t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn’t care, and warn’t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn’t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first.
vi: That night, we again hung the bed sheet over the wire as usual and stole another one from the closet. Then we left it, then took it away, repeatedly for several days, until she no longer knew how many sheets there were and didn't bother to count them anymore.
tr: Upon this, that night we hung the sheet back on the clothesline and stole a sheet from Aunt Sally's closet; for a few days, we kept putting it back and stealing it again; finally, she lost count of how many sheets she had and said she didn't care, wouldn't wear out her soul over it, and would rather die than count the sheets again.
es: So that night we put the sheet back on the clothesline and stole one from the closet, and we kept putting it in and taking it out for a couple of days until she no longer knew how many sheets she had and didn't even care because she wasn't going to let it ruin her life or count them again even if it cost her life; she would rather die first.

en: So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon and the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up counting; and as to the candlestick, it warn’t no consequence, it would blow over by-and-by.
vi: Now we were at ease. At ease about the shirt, the sheet, and the candles, thanks to the story of the little girl, the mouse, and the mixed-up counting, but nothing was mentioned about the brass candlestick.
tr: Thanks to the calf, the mice, and the counting confusion, our problems with shirts, sheets, spoons, and candles were resolved; as for the candlestick, it didn't cause much of a fuss and would eventually be forgotten over time.
es: So now everything was in order regarding the shirt and the sheet, the spoon and the candles, with the help of the veal; the rats and the accounts that didn't add up, and as for the candelabrum, it didn't matter, in time they would forget about it.

en: But that pie was a job; we had no end of trouble with that pie.
vi: But surely it would come out eventually. But making the cake was really a whole project. We encountered one difficulty after another before we could finish that cake.
tr: But making börek was a troublesome task, it seemed like we would never get rid of the trouble of baking that börek.
es: But the cake gave us a lot of work; it only caused us problems.

en: We fixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it done at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and we had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through, and we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with the smoke; because, you see, we didn’t want nothing but a crust, and we couldn’t prop it up right, and she would always cave in.
vi: We took it into the forest, cooked it there, and were very pleased when it was done. But it wasn't something that could be done in a single day. We had to use three bowls full of dough, got burns all over our bodies, and our eyes stung.
tr: We set up our arrangement somewhere deep in the forest and started baking the börek; in the end, we managed to bake it, and it turned out quite well, but it took more than a day; we had to use three pans full of flour, and while working on it, we burned ourselves in many places and our eyes were scorched by the smoke; because what we really needed was the outside of the börek and we couldn't get it right, every time the top would collapse inward.
es: We prepared it in the forest and cooked it there, and finally, we had it done and very satisfactory; but it took us more than a day and we had to use three basins full of flour before finishing it, and we got burned all over and the smoke got into our eyes; because the thing is, we only wanted to get a crust and we couldn't get it to hold well, because it always collapsed.

en: But of course we thought of the right way at last—which was to cook the ladder, too, in the pie.
vi: Finally, we figured out that we had to stuff the entire rope ladder into the cake first.
tr: But in the end, we managed to get it right, that is, we finally figured out to bake the ladder inside the börek.
es: But, naturally, we finally came up with something that would work, which was to cook the ladder with the cake as well.

en: So then we laid in with Jim the second night, and tore up the sheet all in little strings and twisted them together, and long before daylight we had a lovely rope that you could a hung a person with.
vi: The next night, we crawled over to Jim's place, tore the bed sheet into small strips and twisted them together, and by dawn, we had made a very nice rope that could support the weight of a person.
tr: For this, we went to Jim's place the second night, tore the sheet into small strips and tied them together, and by the time we had made a very nice rope long enough to hang a man, it was still far from morning.
es: So that night we went to see Jim, tore the sheet into strips and twisted them all together, and before dawn, we had a great rope that would be enough to hang someone.

en: We let on it took nine months to make it.
vi: By late morning, we went out into the forest, but we couldn't fit it into the cake.
tr: But we pretended that preparing the rope took nine months.
es: We pretended it had taken us nine months to braid it.

en: And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie.
vi: By late morning, we went out into the forest, but we couldn't fit it into the cake.
tr: We took the rope and went to the forest before noon, but we couldn't fit it into the pastry.
es: In the morning we took her to the forest, but she wouldn't fit into the pie.

en: Being made of a whole sheet, that way, there was rope enough for forty pies if we’d a wanted them, and plenty left over for soup, or sausage, or anything you choose.
vi: A rope made from an entire bed sheet would require forty cakes to hold it all, and there would still be leftovers to put in soup and sauces.
tr: Since we made it from a large sheet, we had enough rope to fit into forty pastries if we wanted; moreover, there was plenty left for soup, sausages, or any other meals we preferred.
es: Since she was made from an entire sheet, there was enough rope for forty pies if we had wanted, and there would still be some left for soup, sausages, or whatever one might want.

en: We could a had a whole dinner.
vi: A rope made from an entire bed sheet would require forty cakes to hold it all, and there would still be leftovers to put in soup and sauces.
tr: This rope would be enough for a large dinner.
es: We could have used her for an entire dinner.

en: But we didn’t need it.
vi: But we didn't need that.
tr: But we didn't need that much.
es: But we didn't need that much.

en: All we needed was just enough for the pie, and so we throwed the rest away.
vi: All that was necessary was to stuff enough into the cake, and we discarded the rest.
tr: We only needed enough rope to fit into the pie, so we threw the rest away.
es: The only thing we needed was enough for the cake, so we threw the rest away.

en: We didn’t cook none of the pies in the wash-pan—afraid the solder would melt; but Uncle Silas he had a noble brass warming-pan which he thought considerable of, because it belonged to one of his ancesters with a long wooden handle that come over from England with William the Conqueror in the Mayflower or one of them early ships and was hid away up garret with a lot of other old pots and things that was valuable, not on account of being any account, because they warn’t, but on account of them being relicts, you know, and we snaked her out, private, and took her down there, but she failed on the first pies, because we didn’t know how, but she come up smiling on the last one.
vi: We didn't cook anything in the bowl, for fear that the tin would melt. But Uncle Silas had a copper warming pan that we treasured, as it was an heirloom with a wooden handle, sent from England. He had hidden it in the attic along with a lot of jars, bottles, and other valuable items. Actually, it is not highly valued, but because it is an antique, it is considered important. We took it out to the forest, the first cake we cooked got burnt, but the next one turned out fine.
tr: Fearing that the metal would melt, we didn't make the pie in the pan we found; instead, we used Uncle Silas's beautiful brass bed warmer. He valued this warmer greatly because this long-handled bed warmer, belonging to his ancestors, had come over with William the Conqueror on the Mayflower or one of the first ships, and it was stored in the attic along with a lot of old pots and other valuable things; their value, of course, came not from their monetary worth but from being heirlooms; so we took this bed warmer and went to the woods, but we failed with the first pies because we didn't quite know how to do it, but on the last try, it rose beautifully.
es: We didn't bake any of the cakes in the basin, because we feared the welded part would melt, but Uncle Silas had a wonderful copper heater that he valued greatly, because it had belonged to one of his ancestors, and it had a long wooden handle that had come from England with William the Conqueror on the Mayflower or one of those pilgrim ships and was hidden in the attic, with a bunch of old pots and valuable things, not because they were worth anything, which they weren't, but because they were like relics, you know, and we secretly took it out and brought it to the woods, but it failed us on the first cakes because we didn't know how to use it well, although it worked great on the last one.

en: We took and lined her with dough, and set her in the coals, and loaded her up with rag rope, and put on a dough roof, and shut down the lid, and put hot embers on top, and stood off five foot, with the long handle, cool and comfortable, and in fifteen minutes she turned out a pie that was a satisfaction to look at.
vi: We took it out, cleaned it, rubbed it with flour, placed it on the charcoal stove, then added some scraps of paper, put a wet lump of dough, covered it, and put glowing charcoal on the lid. Then we stood more than a meter away, holding a long, cool handle, and fifteen minutes later, we had a very beautiful-looking cake.
tr: To cook it properly, we first spread the dough on the bottom of the warmer, placed it on the coals, and then put the rope ladder on top of the dough. After spreading another layer of dough on top and closing the lid, we placed pieces of coal on top; thanks to the long handle, we comfortably held the pan about a meter and a half away without being affected by the heat, and after fifteen minutes, we had an appetizing pie.
es: We put dough around all the edges, filled it with a rope of rags and then covered it all with dough and closed the lid, and on top we put some embers and stepped back five feet, with the long handle, so calm and comfortable, and after fifteen minutes we got a cake that was a pleasure to see.

en: But the person that et it would want to fetch a couple of kags of toothpicks along, for if that rope ladder wouldn’t cramp him down to business I don’t know nothing what I’m talking about, and lay him in enough stomach-ache to last him till next time, too.
vi: But anyone who eats that cake will suffer from a stomachache and be bedridden.
tr: But anyone who tried to eat the pie would need a few boxes of toothpicks. Because if swallowing the rope ladder inside the pie isn't hard, then I don't know what I'm talking about. Also, the person eating it would be writhing in stomach pain.
es: But whoever ate it would have to take a couple of barrels of toothpicks, because if that rope ladder didn't clog all their teeth, then I don't know what I'm talking about, and on top of that, they would have a stomach ache for the rest of their life.

en: Nat didn’t look when we put the witch pie in Jim’s pan; and we put the three tin plates in the bottom of the pan under the vittles; and so Jim got everything all right, and as soon as he was by himself he busted into the pie and hid the rope ladder inside of his straw tick, and scratched some marks on a tin plate and throwed it out of the window-hole.
vi: When we placed that devilish cake into the pot to bring it to Jim, Nat didn't dare to look. Then we put three iron plates at the bottom of the pot, beneath the other food. So Jim had everything he needed. As soon as he received those items, Jim immediately broke the cake to take the string and hid it in the straw, then made a few marks on the iron plates and threw them out through the window.
tr: When we placed the witch pie on Jim's tray, Nat wasn't looking; we had also placed three iron plates right under the pie; that way, Jim could take everything, and the moment he was alone, he opened the pie and hid the rope ladder inside the straw mattress, carved some marks on the iron plate, and threw it out the window hole.
es: Nat didn't look when we put the witch pie in Jim's bowl and placed the three tin plates at the bottom of the kettle under the bowl, so everything reached Jim perfectly, and as soon as he was alone, he broke the pie and hid the rope ladder in the straw mattress, scribbled on a tin plate, and threw it out the window hole.

en: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
vi: Chapter XXXVIII
tr: Thirty-Eighth Chapter
es: Chapter 38

en: Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all.
vi: Jim said that engraving was the hardest of all.
tr: Making the pens was a difficult job that required a lot of effort, as was making the saw; but Jim said the hardest part would be carving writing into the walls.
es: PREPARING THE FEATHERS was a very difficult job, just like with the saw, and Jim said that the inscription was going to be the hardest part of all.

en: That’s the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall.
vi: Jim said that engraving was the hardest of all.
tr: But these were things that the prisoner absolutely had to write on the wall.
es: It was what the prisoner had to engrave on the wall.

en: But he had to have it; Tom said he’d got to; there warn’t no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.
vi: But Tom insisted that Jim had to write.
tr: No matter what, they had to be written; Tom said he was obliged to do it; there wasn't a single case where prisoners didn't carve writing and their coat of arms into the wall before leaving.
es: But it was necessary; Tom said he had to do it; there wasn't a single case of a State prisoner who didn't leave an inscription, along with his coat of arms.

en: “Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he says; “look at Gilford Dudley; look at old Northumberland!
vi: The prisoner had to leave his handwriting on the wall for posterity, along with his emblem.
tr: “Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he said; “Look at Gilford Dudley, at old Northumberland!
es: —Look at Lady Jane Grey —he goes and says—; look at Gilford Dudley; look at that Northumberland!

en: Why, Huck, s’pose it is considerble trouble?—what you going to do?—how you going to get around it?
vi: Jim said:
tr: What does it matter if doing this is harder than making a camel jump through a hoop? What are we going to do then? Are we going to beat around the bush?
es: But, Huck, let's say it's a lot of work. What are you going to do about it? How are you going to manage?

en: Jim’s got to do his inscription and coat of arms.
vi: Jim said:
tr: Jim has to carve his inscription on the wall, engrave his coat of arms.
es: Jim has to leave his inscription and his coat of arms.

en: They all do.”
vi: Jim said:
tr: Everyone is doing it.”
es: It's what everyone does.

en: Jim says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: "But Master Tom, I don't have a master," said Jim.
es: And Jim goes and says:

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I hain’t got no coat o’ arm; I hain’t got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, just this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it.
tr: "In fact, I don't have anything other than these pots and pans and an old shirt, and I need to use them for daily writing anyway."
es: —But, Mr. Tom, I don't have a coat of arms; I have nothing but this old shirt and you know that I have to write the diary on it.

en: “Oh, you don’t understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different.”
vi: - You don't understand anything, Jim, the badge is different, it's not like that.
tr: “Ah, you just don't understand, Jim, a coat of arms is something very different.”
es: —Well, Jim, it's just that you don't understand; a coat of arms is very different.

en: “Well,” I says, “Jim’s right, anyway, when he says he ain’t got no coat of arms, because he hain’t.”
vi: I said: - Jim is right. He doesn't have any badges.
tr: “Still, Jim is right in saying he doesn't have a coat of arms,” I said, “because he really doesn't have one.”
es: —Well —I said—, in any case, Jim is right when he says he doesn't have a coat of arms, because he doesn't.

en: “I reckon I knowed that,” Tom says, “but you bet he’ll have one before he goes out of this—because he’s going out right, and there ain’t going to be no flaws in his record.”
vi: Tom replied:
tr: “We probably know,” said Tom, “but there will be one before this is over… because he does everything right and there won't be the slightest flaw in his record.”
es: —I already knew that —says Tom—, but I bet you he will have it before he leaves here, because he is going to leave as he should, without any blemish on his record.

en: So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his’n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms.
vi: - I know, but Jim needs to have a badge before leaving this place. So Tom sat down, wracking his brain to come up with a badge for Jim.
tr: Jim and I started sharpening the pencils on a piece of brick; Jim was making his out of brass, and I was using the spoon. Meanwhile, Tom was lost in thought about the coat of arms.
es: So while Jim and I were sharpening the feathers on a brick, Jim his with the copper and I mine with the spoon, Tom started working on thinking about the coat of arms.

en: By-and-by he said he’d struck so many good ones he didn’t hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he’d decide on.
vi: After a while, he said he had thought of many but didn't know which one to choose.
tr: A little later, he said that he had come up with a lot of beautiful coats of arms and couldn't decide which one to choose, but he would probably settle on one eventually.
es: After a while, he said that so many had occurred to him that he didn't know which one to choose, but there was one that seemed to be his favorite.

en: He says:
vi: Finally, he picked one design and said:
tr: “The crest will be curved or on the right side.
es: He goes and says:

en: “On the scutcheon we’ll have a bend or in the dexter base, a saltire murrey in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and under his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron vert in a chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field azure, with the nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway nigger, sable, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister; and a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto.
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: Inside the band surrounding the crest, there will be a dark red diagonal stripe and an outstretched dog representing the people. Under the dog's paw, there will be a solid chain representing slavery. At the top, there will be a green ornament and three vertical lines on a sky blue background with dots spread in the middle of a deliberate zigzag mark. At the top, a picture of a runaway black man: Pitch black, with a bundle on his shoulder over the mark indicating illegitimacy. There are two red lines supporting him, which represent you and me. At the very bottom, a curved crest band. There is an inscription on it: Maggiore fretta, minore otto.
es: —On the shield, we will place a gold bar on the dexter base, a purple saltire on the falcon, with a dog, couchant, in franchise, and under the foot, an embattled chain, for—slavery, with a green chevron with a dented point and three vector lines on a field of azure, with the points of the teeth rampant in a dancette; as a crest, a fugitive black man, sable, with a bundle on his shoulder over a bar of bastardy, and a pair of gules of support, which are you and me; as a motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto.

en: Got it out of a book—means the more haste, the less speed.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: I saw it in a book... it means the more you hurry, the slower you go.”
es: I got it from a book; it means that no matter how early you get up, it doesn't make the sun rise any sooner.

en: “Geewhillikins,” I says, “but what does the rest of it mean?”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Wow, so what does the rest mean?” I asked.
es: —Damn it —I said—, but what does all the rest mean?

en: “We ain’t got no time to bother over that,” he says; “we got to dig in like all git-out.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “We don't have time to waste on this, we need to start digging immediately.”
es: —We don't have time to waste on that —he goes and says—; we need to start digging like the condemned.

en: “Well, anyway,” I says, “what’s some of it?
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Couldn't you at least tell me the meaning of some of them?
es: —Well, in any case —I asked—; at least tell me something, what is a falquín?

en: What’s a fess?”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: For example, what is a strip?”
es: —A falquín... A falquín is...

en: “A fess—a fess is—you don’t need to know what a fess is.
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: "Strip... strip thing... you don't need to know what it is.
es: You don't need to know what a falquín is.

en: I’ll show him how to make it when he gets to it.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: I'll show you how to do it, and then you'll do it."
es: I'll teach you how to make one when the time comes.

en: “Shucks, Tom,” I says, “I think you might tell a person.
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Don't break me, you can tell any person, can't you, Tom?
es: —Damn, Tom —I said—; I thought you could tell it.

en: What’s a bar sinister?”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: What is the sign indicating illegitimacy?”
es: What is a bar sinister?

en: “Oh, I don’t know.
vi: A symbol of a black man running away carrying a bundle of luggage, and another symbol of two guys following to help, meaning you and me.
tr: “You are asking unnecessary questions.
es: —Ah, I don't know.

en: But he’s got to have it.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: It just has to be there.
es: But it is necessary.

en: All the nobility does.”
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: All the nobles have it.”
es: All the nobility has it.

en: That was just his way.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: This was just right for her.
es: That's how he was.

en: If it didn’t suit him to explain a thing to you, he wouldn’t do it.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: If she didn't feel like explaining something to you, she wouldn't explain it.
es: If it didn't suit him to explain something, he wouldn't explain it.

en: You might pump at him a week, it wouldn’t make no difference.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: Even if you nagged her for a week, you wouldn't get a single word out of her.
es: You could spend a week asking him about it, and it wouldn't matter.

en: He’d got all that coat of arms business fixed, so now he started in to finish up the rest of that part of the work, which was to plan out a mournful inscription—said Jim got to have one, like they all done.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: After completely deciding on the weapon matter, he turned to the remaining part of the work, namely planning our sorrowful inscription. Like all prisoners, Jim should also have such an inscription.
es: Since he had everything arranged regarding the coat of arms, he began to finish that part of the task, which consisted of planning a very sad inscription, because it said that Jim had to leave, just like everyone else had done.

en: He made up a lot, and wrote them out on a paper, and read them off, so:
vi: It wrote it down on a piece of paper, then read it aloud:
tr: He made up a bunch of words and wrote them down on a piece of paper, then read them aloud:
es: He invented many, which he wrote on a paper, and when he read them, they said:

en: 1. Here a captive heart busted.
vi: 1) Here, a captive heart is breaking.
tr: 1. A captive heart withered away here.
es: 1. Here, a captive's heart was broken.

en: 2. Here a poor prisoner, forsook by the world and friends, fretted out his sorrowful life.
vi: 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering away, deteriorating.
tr: 2. A poor prisoner, separated from the world and his friends, spent his miserable life here.
es: »2. Here a poor prisoner, abandoned by the world and friends, suffered a life of sorrows.

en: 3. Here a lonely heart broke, and a worn spirit went to its rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.
vi: 3) Here, a lonely heart breaks, a spirit has grown weary after thirty-seven years of solitary confinement.
tr: 3. A completely lonely heart was broken here, a worn-out soul found peace after thirty-seven years of complete solitary captivity.
es: »3. Here a lonely heart was broken and a shattered spirit departed to its eternal rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.

en: 4. Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.
vi: 4) Here, the child of Louis the Fourteenth died homeless, without close friends, after thirty-seven years of imprisonment.
tr: 4. Homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of arduous captivity, the noble stranger who found peace here is the true son of Louis XIV. Louis XIV's own son.
es: »4. Here, without home or friends, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble foreigner, the natural son of Louis XIV.»

en: Tom’s voice trembled whilst he was reading them, and he most broke down.
vi: When reading those sentences, Tom's voice trembled with emotion.
tr: Tom's voice was trembling as he read these, he was almost about to cry.
es: Tom's voice trembled as he read it, and he almost started to cry.

en: When he got done he couldn’t no way make up his mind which one for Jim to scrabble on to the wall, they was all so good; but at last he allowed he would let him scrabble them all on.
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: After finishing reading, he couldn't decide which one Jim should carve into the wall, they were all equally good; but finally, he said he would allow him to carve all of them.
es: When he finished, there was no way he could decide which one Jim should write on the wall, because they were all great, but he finally decided to let him write them all.

en: Jim said it would take him a year to scrabble such a lot of truck on to the logs with a nail, and he didn’t know how to make letters, besides; but Tom said he would block them out for him, and then he wouldn’t have nothing to do but just follow the lines.
vi: Jim said it would take him about a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall.
tr: Jim reminded him that carving so many words into the logs with a nail would take at least a year, and besides, he didn't even know how to write the letters; but Tom said he would draw the letters himself beforehand and all Jim had to do was follow the lines and carve.
es: Jim said it would take him a year to write so many things on the logs with a nail, because he didn't know how to make letters; but Tom promised to draw them for him so that Jim would only have to follow the drawing.

en: Then pretty soon he says:
vi: Then he said:
tr: But he soon changed his mind:
es: And shortly after, he said:

en: “Come to think, the logs ain’t a-going to do; they don’t have log walls in a dungeon: we got to dig the inscriptions into a rock.
vi: - Writing on wood won't work, because there are no wooden walls in the tower prison.
tr: “I thought about it, logs won't do; there can't be log walls in dungeons: We need to carve the inscription into a rock.
es: —Now that I think about it, those logs are no good; in the dungeons, you don't have logs; we have to make the inscriptions on a stone.

en: We’ll fetch a rock.”
vi: We have to carve the letters into stone instead.
tr: Let's bring a rock.”
es: We have to bring a stone.

en: Jim said the rock was worse than the logs; he said it would take him such a pison long time to dig them into a rock he wouldn’t ever get out.
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would be a long time before he could finish and escape.
tr: Jim immediately interjected, saying that carving into the rock would be even harder than carving into the log. It would take so long to carve those words into a rock that it would never see the light of day again.
es: Jim said that the stone was worse than the logs; that it would take him so much time to write on the stone that he would never escape.

en: But Tom said he would let me help him do it.
vi: But Tom said he would let me help.
tr: But Tom said he would allow me to help him.
es: But Tom said he would let me help him.

en: Then he took a look to see how me and Jim was getting along with the pens.
vi: Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written.
tr: Then he looked at what Jim and I had done to the pens.
es: Then he took a look to see how Jim and I were doing with the feathers.

en: It was most pesky tedious hard work and slow, and didn’t give my hands no show to get well of the sores, and we didn’t seem to make no headway, hardly; so Tom says:
vi: Doing this was really a very difficult and slow task, my hands were already hurting and hurt even more, but the work seemed to make no progress. Tom said:
tr: It was an extremely slow and laborious task, and it not only prevented my hands from healing but also made it seem like we had made almost no progress.
es: It was the most tedious, hard, and slow work, it didn’t help at all to get rid of the blisters on my hands, and we hardly seemed to make any progress, so Tom goes and says:

en: “I know how to fix it.
vi: - I have an idea.
tr: “I know how we will do it,” said Tom.
es: —I know how to fix it.

en: We got to have a rock for the coat of arms and mournful inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with that same rock.
vi: We need to find a stone to make a badge and write on it.
tr: “We need to find a rock for the coat of arms and the mournful inscription, then we can kill two birds with one stone with that rock.
es: We need a stone for the coat of arms and the melancholic inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with one stone.

en: There’s a gaudy big grindstone down at the mill, and we’ll smouch it, and carve the things on it, and file out the pens and the saw on it, too.”
vi: There is a large grinding stone in the workshop below, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: Inside the mill, there is a large and impressive millstone, we will take it, engrave everything on it, and sharpen the pens and saw on it as well.
es: Where the mill is, there is a huge grinding stone that we can bring to write things on it and also sharpen the quills and the saw.

en: It warn’t no slouch of an idea; and it warn’t no slouch of a grindstone nuther; but we allowed we’d tackle it.
vi: It was a bizarre idea, but we thought we could do it.
tr: This wasn't a bad idea. It was truly a tough millstone; still, we felt we could bring it.
es: It wasn't a bad idea, and it wasn't a bad grinding stone either, but we decided to give it a try.

en: It warn’t quite midnight yet, so we cleared out for the mill, leaving Jim at work.
vi: It wasn't yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: It wasn't midnight yet, so we left things to Jim and set off towards the mill.
es: It wasn't midnight yet, so we went to the mill and left Jim with his work.

en: We smouched the grindstone, and set out to roll her home, but it was a most nation tough job.
vi: We carried the stone outside and rolled it home, but it was so heavy, several times it almost crushed our feet.
tr: We removed the millstone from its place and started rolling it towards home, but this was really beyond us.
es: We grabbed the stone and started rolling it home, but it was extremely difficult.

en: Sometimes, do what we could, we couldn’t keep her from falling over, and she come mighty near mashing us every time.
vi: We carried the stone outside and rolled it home, but it was so heavy, several times it almost crushed our feet.
tr: Despite doing our best, we couldn't prevent it from toppling over from time to time, and each time we narrowly escaped being crushed underneath it.
es: Sometimes, no matter what we did, we couldn't stop it from falling, and at any moment it was about to crush us.

en: Tom said she was going to get one of us, sure, before we got through.
vi: Tom said that someone was bound to have the stone fall on their foot before we got it home.
tr: "By the time we get there, one of us will definitely be stuck under this stone," said Tom.
es: Tom said it would surely take one of us out before we managed to finish.

en: We got her half way; and then we was plumb played out, and most drownded with sweat.
vi: Halfway there, we were exhausted, staggering, and drenched in sweat.
tr: We got it halfway, but we were too exhausted to take another step, we were about to drown in our own sweat.
es: We got halfway and were already exhausted and almost drowning in sweat.

en: We see it warn’t no use; we got to go and fetch Jim.
vi: We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out of the hole to where the stone was, Jim and I lifted the stone, moving as if it were nothing, while Tom directed us.
tr: We realized we couldn't manage this, we had to go and get Jim.
es: We saw there was nothing else to do; we had to go get Jim.

en: So he raised up his bed and slid the chain off of the bed-leg, and wrapt it round and round his neck, and we crawled out through our hole and down there, and Jim and me laid into that grindstone and walked her along like nothing; and Tom superintended.
vi: We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out of the hole to where the stone was, Jim and I lifted the stone, moving as if it were nothing, while Tom directed us.
tr: Jim lifted the bed and freed the chain from the bedpost, then wrapped the chain around his neck and we crawled out through the hole together. We went with Jim, easily lifted the millstone, and started carrying it, while Tom supervised us.
es: So he lifted the bed, took the chain off the leg of the cot, put it around his neck, and we crawled through the hole to where the stone was, and Jim and I started pushing it and made it roll quite easily, while Tom supervised.

en: He could out-superintend any boy I ever see.
vi: He could command any other kid.
tr: He surpassed all the children I had seen in supervising.
es: He was the best supervisor in the world.

en: He knowed how to do everything.
vi: He could do all sorts of things.
tr: He knew how everything should be done.
es: He knew how to do everything.

en: Our hole was pretty big, but it warn’t big enough to get the grindstone through; but Jim he took the pick and soon made it big enough.
vi: The hole we dug was quite large, but the rock still couldn't fit through, so Jim took the pickaxe and dug it wider.
tr: Our hole was quite wide, but still not big enough to pass the millstone through. However, Jim took the pickaxe and soon enlarged the hole.
es: Our hole was already quite large, but not large enough to fit the stone through it; then Jim grabbed the pickaxe and immediately made it bigger.

en: Then Tom marked out them things on it with the nail, and set Jim to work on them, with the nail for a chisel and an iron bolt from the rubbage in the lean-to for a hammer, and told him to work till the rest of his candle quit on him, and then he could go to bed, and hide the grindstone under his straw tick and sleep on it.
vi: Tom took a nail and marked the rock, telling Jim to chisel along the lines he had drawn. He told Jim to work until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: Then Tom used a nail to carve letters onto the stone and stood over Jim to make sure he continued; instead of a chisel, he would use the nail, and instead of a hammer, he would use an iron bar we found among the odds and ends in the storeroom. He told him to work until the remainder of his candle was used up, and then he could go to bed, but he had to place the millstone under his mattress and sleep on it.
es: Afterwards, Tom drew the phrases on it with the nail and put Jim to work, with the nail serving as a chisel and a bolt as a hammer; he said to work until the candle was used up and then he could go to bed and hide the millstone under the mattress and sleep on top of it.

en: Then we helped him fix his chain back on the bed-leg, and was ready for bed ourselves.
vi: We helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, then we also prepared to go to sleep.
tr: Afterwards, we helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, and we were ready to go to bed ourselves.
es: Then we helped him put the chain back on the leg of the cot and got ready to go to bed.

en: But Tom thought of something, and says:
vi: But suddenly, Tom said:
tr: But it seemed like Tom had come up with something new.
es: Tom thought of something, and he goes and says:

en: “You got any spiders in here, Jim?”
vi: - Are there any spiders in here, Jim?
tr: "Are there any spiders here, Jim?" he asked.
es: —Ah, are there spiders here?

en: “No, sah, thanks to goodness I hain’t, Mars Tom.”
vi: - No, there isn't, buddy.
tr: “No, master, thank God, no, Master Tom.”
es: —No, sir, thank God, no, Mr. Tom.

en: “All right, we’ll get you some.”
vi: - Okay, let me go get some for you.
tr: “Okay, we will bring it to you.”
es: —Very well, we will bring you some.

en: “But bless you, honey, I doan’ want none.
vi: - Okay, let me go get some for you.
tr: “Oh, live long, my flower's corner, I don't want spiders.
es: —But, for God's sake, my child, I don't want spiders.

en: I’s afeard un um.
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared.
tr: I'm already scared of spiders.
es: They scare me.

en: I jis’ ’s soon have rattlesnakes aroun’.”
vi: I'd rather have snakes than spiders.
tr: If they come, then rattlesnakes will follow.”
es: I even prefer rattlesnakes.

en: Tom thought a minute or two, and says:
vi: Tom thought for a few minutes and then said:
tr: After thinking for a minute or two, Tom said:
es: Tom stayed thinking for a moment, and then he says:

en: “It’s a good idea.
vi: - A good idea.
tr: “Actually, it's a good idea.
es: —It's a good idea.

en: And I reckon it’s been done.
vi: - A good idea.
tr: I think it can be done.
es: And I reckon it has been done before.

en: It must a been done; it stands to reason.
vi: - A good idea.
tr: In fact, it must be done; it seems reasonable.
es: It must have been done; it makes sense.

en: Yes, it’s a prime good idea.
vi: - A good idea.
tr: Yes, this is a top-notch idea.
es: Yes, it's a phenomenal idea.

en: Where could you keep it?”
vi: So where did you put it?
tr: Where can you hide it?”
es: Where would you have it?

en: “Keep what, Mars Tom?”
vi: - What to leave, Tom?
tr: “What will I hide, Master Tom?”
es: —Have what, little Tom?

en: “Why, a rattlesnake.”
vi: - A snake, what else?
tr: “A rattlesnake, of course.”
es: —Man, a rattlesnake.

en: “De goodness gracious alive, Mars Tom!
vi: - My God, if a snake crawls in here, I will immediately have to squeeze through that hole in the wall and run away.
tr: “Trust me, you follow me, Master Tom!
es: —By all the saints in heaven, Tom!

en: Why, if dey was a rattlesnake to come in heah I’d take en bust right out thoo dat log wall, I would, wid my head.”
vi: - My God, if a snake crawls in here, I will immediately have to squeeze through that hole in the wall and run away.
tr: If a rattlesnake comes out of the grass, I'll jump out of this log with my bare head.”
es: But if I see a rattlesnake come in here, I'll fly through that log wall, even if I have to break it with my head.

en: “Why, Jim, you wouldn’t be afraid of it after a little.
vi: - Oh, Jim, don't be so scared.
tr: "But Jim, after a while, you won't be afraid of it at all.
es: —Man, Jim, after a while you wouldn't be afraid of her anymore.

en: You could tame it.”
vi: Can you conquer it?
tr: You can tame it."
es: You could tame her.

en: “Tame it!”
vi: - Conquer?
tr: “Tame it?”
es: —Tame her!

en: “Yes—easy enough.
vi: - Yes, it's easy.
tr: “Yes… very easy.
es: —Yes, it's easy.

en: Every animal is grateful for kindness and petting, and they wouldn’t think of hurting a person that pets them.
vi: Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: All animals feel gratitude towards kindness and caresses, and they wouldn't even think of harming the people who caress them.
es: All animals appreciate gestures of affection and caresses; it would never occur to them to harm a person who caresses them.

en: Any book will tell you that.
vi: Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: Every book says so.
es: You can see it in any book.

en: You try—that’s all I ask; just try for two or three days.
vi: Just try it.
tr: You try it… I don't want anything else; just try for two or three days.
es: Try it, that's all I'm saying; try it for two or three days.

en: Why, you can get him so, in a little while, that he’ll love you; and sleep with you; and won’t stay away from you a minute; and will let you wrap him round your neck and put his head in your mouth.”
vi: Then it might let you wrap it around your neck and even tuck its head into your mouth.
tr: Shortly after you take it, it will love you, sleep with you, not stay away from you for even a moment, allow you to wrap it around your neck and put its head in your mouth.”
es: You can make it so that in a short time it loves you, sleeps with you, and doesn't leave your side for a moment; that it lets you put it around your neck and stick your head in its mouth.

en: “Please, Mars Tom—doan’ talk so!
vi: - I beg you, I don't dare to listen!
tr: “Don’t say such things, Master Tom…
es: —Please, Mr. Tom... Don't say such things!

en: I can’t stan’ it!
vi: - I beg you, I don't dare to listen!
tr: I can’t stand it anymore!
es: I can't stand it!

en: He’d let me shove his head in my mouf—fer a favor, hain’t it?
vi: Will it let me put its head into my mouth?
tr: Letting him stick his head into my mouth… for the sake of kindness, is that it?
es: You would let me put your head in my mouth, as a favor, right?

en: I lay he’d wait a pow’ful long time ’fo’ I ast him.
vi: Never.
tr: It would take forever to ask him for that.
es: I bet you'd have to wait a long time before I'd ask you for that.

en: En mo’ en dat, I doan’ want him to sleep wid me.”
vi: Moreover, I don't want it to sleep with me.
tr: Besides, I don’t even want him to sleep with me.”
es: And besides, I don't want you to sleep with me.

en: “Jim, don’t act so foolish.
vi: - Jim, don't be so foolish.
tr: “Don't act so foolishly, Jim.
es: —Jim, don't be silly.

en: A prisoner’s got to have some kind of a dumb pet, and if a rattlesnake hain’t ever been tried, why, there’s more glory to be gained in your being the first to ever try it than any other way you could ever think of to save your life.”
vi: A prisoner must have an animal to befriend. Until now, no one has ever kept a snake, so being the first to do so would be even more glorious.
tr: It is mandatory for prisoners to have a quiet pet; if no one has had a rattlesnake before, the honor of being the first person to try this, instead of other conceivable ways to save their life, is greater.”
es: A prisoner has to have a pet, and if it's never been tried with a rattlesnake, you can achieve more glory by being the first to try it than in any other way you can think of to save your life.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no sich glory.
vi: - Tom, I don't want that glory.
tr: "But Master Tom, I don't want such a big reputation.
es: —But, Tom, I don't want that glory.

en: Snake take ’n bite Jim’s chin off, den whah is de glory?
vi: The snake will bite me.
tr: If the snake bites Jim's jaw, what good is the reputation to Jim then?
es: The snake goes and bites Jim on the chin, and then, where's the glory?

en: No, sah, I doan’ want no sich doin’s.”
vi: No, I don't want to do that.
tr: No, master, I don't want to do such things."
es: No, sir, I don't want to do any of that.

en: “Blame it, can’t you try?
vi: - Damn it, can't you just try it?
tr: “You are something else, what do you have to lose by trying?
es: —Damn it, can't you try?

en: I only want you to try—you needn’t keep it up if it don’t work.”
vi: I just want you to try it. If you don't like it, you don't have to keep it forever!
tr: I just want you to try… If it doesn't work, you don't need to keep feeding it.”
es: I just want you to try... You don't need to keep going if it doesn't go well.

en: “But de trouble all done ef de snake bite me while I’s a tryin’ him.
vi: - But while I was trying, it bit me already.
tr: “But while I was trying to tame it, it would finish me off on the street.
es: —But the problem ends if the snake bites me while I'm trying.

en: Mars Tom, I’s willin’ to tackle mos’ anything ’at ain’t onreasonable, but ef you en Huck fetches a rattlesnake in heah for me to tame, I’s gwyne to leave, dat’s shore.”
vi: Tom, I don't want to do those things. If Huck brings a snake in here, I'll leave immediately, definitely.
tr: I'm willing to do almost anything that makes sense to me, but if Huck and you bring me a rattlesnake and ask me to tame it, I'll leave immediately, there's no other way.”
es: Tom, I'm willing to try almost anything that seems reasonable, but if you and Huck bring me a snake to tame, I'm out of here, I assure you of that.

en: “Well, then, let it go, let it go, if you’re so bull-headed about it.
vi: - Well, never mind then.
tr: “Alright then, if you are so stubborn, let it be as you say.
es: —Well, then leave it, leave it, since you're being so stubborn.

en: We can get you some garter-snakes, and you can tie some buttons on their tails, and let on they’re rattlesnakes, and I reckon that’ll have to do.”
vi: We'll find you a few non-venomous snakes instead.
tr: We will bring you a few small snakes, you can put buttons or something on their tails and pretend they are rattlesnakes, this should be sufficient.”
es: We can get you some snakes and tie some buttons to their tails and pretend they are rattlesnakes; I suppose we'll have to settle for that.

en: “I k’n stan’ dem, Mars Tom, but blame’ ’f I couldn’ get along widout um, I tell you dat.
vi: - I can't stand it either, Tom.
tr: “I can endure it with ten, Master Tom, but without ten, I will be much more comfortable, don't forget that.
es: —I could put up with that, said Tom, but damned if I couldn't manage without them, I assure you.

en: I never knowed b’fo’ ’t was so much bother and trouble to be a prisoner.”
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: Being a prisoner is such a hard and troublesome job, my friend.”
es: I had never understood that being imprisoned was such a hassle.

en: “Well, it always is when it’s done right.
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: “Of course it is, but only if you do it right.
es: —Well, it always is when things are done right.

en: You got any rats around here?”
vi: - So, are there any mice here?
tr: So, is there a mouse here?”
es: Are there rats around here?

en: “No, sah, I hain’t seed none.”
vi: - No, I didn't see any.
tr: “No, master, I have never buried a child.”
es: —No, sir, I haven't seen any.

en: “Well, we’ll get you some rats.”
vi: - Well, then we'll find you some mice...
tr: “Alright, we will bring you a few.”
es: —Well, we will bring you some rats.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no rats.
vi: - I don't need mice, Tom.
tr: “Master Tom, I don't want any rats.
es: —But, Tom, I don't want to have rats.

en: Dey’s de dadblamedest creturs to ’sturb a body, en rustle roun’ over ’im, en bite his feet, when he’s tryin’ to sleep, I ever see.
vi: They are the most annoying creatures, always bothering people, climbing on them, biting their feet and preventing them from sleeping.
tr: They are very troublesome creatures, they disturb people, when you're trying to sleep they crawl over you and bite your feet.
es: They are the most disgusting creatures there are, and they climb on you and bite your feet when you're trying to fall asleep.

en: No, sah, gimme g’yarter-snakes, ’f I’s got to have ’m, but doan’ gimme no rats; I hain’ got no use f’r um, skasely.”
vi: I'd rather you put in regular snakes than bring mice in here. I have no use for mice.
tr: No, master, if you must bring something, just bring snakes, I don't want rats, they are of no use to me anyway.”
es: No, sir, I prefer snakes, if necessary, but no rats; I don't like them at all, and I mean it.

en: “But, Jim, you got to have ’em—they all do.
vi: - But you must have mice.
tr: “But Jim, you have to have mice... everyone has mice.
es: —But, Jim, there have to be rats...

en: So don’t make no more fuss about it.
vi: Don't worry, everyone does it that way.
tr: So stop complaining already.
es: It says so in all the books. So don't make a fuss about it.

en: Prisoners ain’t ever without rats.
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: Is there such a thing as a prisoner without mice?
es: Prisoners never lack rats.

en: There ain’t no instance of it.
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: I've never heard of such a thing in my life.
es: There isn't a single case.

en: And they train them, and pet them, and learn them tricks, and they get to be as sociable as flies.
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: In fact, they train the mice, pet them, teach them tricks, and develop a bond with them.
es: And they tame them, pet them, and teach them tricks, and thus they learn to be very sociable.

en: But you got to play music to them.
vi: And you also have to play music for them.
tr: But you should play music for them.
es: But you have to play them some music.

en: You got anything to play music on?”
vi: Do you have anything to play music with?
tr: Do you have the necessary instruments for that?”
es: Do you have something to play music?

en: “I ain’ got nuffn but a coase comb en a piece o’ paper, en a juice-harp; but I reck’n dey wouldn’ take no stock in a juice-harp.”
vi: - I only have a broken comb and a piece of paper to make a plucking instrument. But I am sure they don't like plucking instruments.
tr: “I only have a mountain and a piece of paper, and also a mouth harmonica, but whether you want to listen to the mouth harmonica, I don't really think so.”
es: —I only have a wooden comb, a piece of paper, and a berimbau, and I don't think they'll like a berimbau very much.

en: “Yes they would.
vi: - Yes, they do.
tr: “Is that possible? Of course, they listen.
es: —Surely, yes.

en: They don’t care what kind of music ’tis.
vi: They don't differentiate between types of music.
tr: They don't care what kind of music it is.
es: They don't care about the type of music.

en: A jews-harp’s plenty good enough for a rat.
vi: Plucking the zither is good enough for the mice.
tr: A mouth harp is perfectly suitable for a mouse.
es: A berimbau is phenomenal for a rat.

en: All animals like music—in a prison they dote on it.
vi: All animals like music, and in prison, they like it even more, especially sad music.
tr: All animals love music… especially in a prison environment, they adore it.
es: All animals like music, and in prisons, they love it.

en: Specially, painful music; and you can’t get no other kind out of a jews-harp.
vi: All animals like music, and in prison, they like it even more, especially sad music.
tr: Particularly sad music, and anyway, a mouth harp doesn't produce any other kind of music.
es: Especially sad music, and with a berimbau, it's the only music you can play.

en: It always interests them; they come out to see what’s the matter with you.
vi: The mice love it.
tr: It always catches their interest; they get up to see what is troubling you.
es: They are always interested; they come out to see what's happening to you.

en: Yes, you’re all right; you’re fixed very well.
vi: They will come out to see what strange thing you have.
tr: Yes, now it's right, you're in a very good state now.
es: Yes, it's going to go very well for you, you have everything.

en: You want to set on your bed nights before you go to sleep, and early in the mornings, and play your jews-harp; play ‘The Last Link is Broken’—that’s the thing that’ll scoop a rat quicker ’n anything else; and when you’ve played about two minutes you’ll see all the rats, and the snakes, and spiders, and things begin to feel worried about you, and come.
vi: At night, before going to sleep, and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that zither.
tr: At night before going to bed, in the early morning hours, you want to sit in your bed and play the mouth harp; play 'The Last Ring Broke'... it's the piece that interests the mice the most: After playing for about two minutes, you'll see that all the mice, snakes, spiders, and other things are worried about you and come to you.
es: What you need to do is sit on the bed at night before you go to sleep, and in the morning do the same and play the berimbau; play "The Last Link is Broken," which is what rats love, and after playing for two minutes, you'll see that all the rats, snakes, and spiders and all that start to worry about you and come out.

en: And they’ll just fairly swarm over you, and have a noble good time.”
vi: If you play for about two minutes, you will see all kinds of mice, snakes, spiders, etc., feeling sad for you and gathering around you.
tr: They will literally climb all over you and have a great time.”
es: And they will all come to keep you company, and they will have a great time.

en: “Yes, dey will, I reck’n, Mars Tom, but what kine er time is Jim havin’?
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: “Ten years is a long time, Master Tom, but how will Jim spend that time?
es: —Yes, I suppose they will, said Tom, but how is Jim going to handle it?

en: Blest if I kin see de pint.
vi: But right now I don't understand anything, I will try to follow if I have to.
tr: I don't understand what good this will do.
es: Hang me if I understand it.

en: But I’ll do it ef I got to.
vi: But right now I don't understand anything, I will try to follow if I have to.
tr: But if I must, I will do it.
es: But if it's necessary, I'll do it.

en: I reck’n I better keep de animals satisfied, en not have no trouble in de house.”
vi: I will make those animals satisfied and there will be no trouble in the house.
tr: Probably the best thing is to keep the animals happy so that there won't be any trouble.”
es: I reckon it's better to keep the animals happy and not have problems at home.

en: Tom waited to think it over, and see if there wasn’t nothing else; and pretty soon he says:
vi: Tom thought for a moment longer to see if there was anything else, then he said:
tr: Tom thought for a while longer, but it seemed like nothing else came to mind. Suddenly, he started speaking again:
es: Tom stayed thinking if something was missing, and after a moment he goes and says:

en: “Oh, there’s one thing I forgot.
vi: - There is one more thing I forgot.
tr: “Hah… I forgot something.
es: —Ah, I forgot something.

en: Could you raise a flower here, do you reckon?”
vi: Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: Do you think you can grow flowers here?”
es: Do you think you could grow a flower here?

en: “I doan know but maybe I could, Mars Tom; but it’s tolable dark in heah, en I ain’ got no use f’r no flower, nohow, en she’d be a pow’ful sight o’ trouble.”
vi: - I don't know, but maybe. But it's very dark in here, and I don't need flowers, it just adds more trouble.
tr: "I don't know, maybe I can manage, Master Tom; but the ox is very stubborn, and the flowers can't help me with my work.
es: —I don't know, but maybe yes, said Tom, although it's quite dark here and a flower isn't much use to me, and it would be very difficult for me.

en: “Well, you try it, anyway.
vi: - You should give it a try.
tr: It's very difficult." "Still, you should give it a try.
es: —Well, try it anyway.

en: Some other prisoners has done it.”
vi: The other prisoners also grow flowers.
tr: Some prisoners have managed to do it."
es: Some other prisoners have already done it.

en: “One er dem big cat-tail-lookin’ mullen-stalks would grow in heah, Mars Tom, I reck’n, but she wouldn’t be wuth half de trouble she’d coss.”
vi: - here you can probably see cattail flowers, but planting them is not worth the effort.
tr: “A huge catfish might grow here too, Master Tom, but it's not worth the trouble, I'm telling you from the start.”
es: —I reckon one of those cat-tail plants could grow here, said Tom, but it wouldn't be worth half the effort it would take.

en: “Don’t you believe it.
vi: - Don't think that way.
tr: "Don't think like that.
es: —Don't believe it.

en: We’ll fetch you a little one and you plant it in the corner over there, and raise it.
vi: We will find you a sapling, and you will plant it in that corner of the house over there.
tr: We'll bring you a small one, you can plant it in that corner over there, and it will grow and thrive.
es: We'll bring you a tiny one and you plant it in that corner and cultivate it.

en: And don’t call it mullen, call it Pitchiola—that’s its right name when it’s in a prison.
vi: Don't call it a cat's tail flower, you must call it Pitchiola.
tr: Also, don't call it mullein, call it Pitchiola... that's its real name when it's in prison.
es: And don't call it barbasco, but pitchiola, which is a name that sounds very nice in a prison.

en: And you want to water it with your tears.”
vi: And you must water it with tears.
tr: And you need to water it with your tears."
es: The best thing is to water it with your tears.

en: “Why, I got plenty spring water, Mars Tom.”
vi: - What's wrong? I have plenty of rainwater here.
tr: "Why, there's plenty of water in this, Tom."
es: —But I have plenty of water from the fountain, said Tom.

en: “You don’t want spring water; you want to water it with your tears.
vi: - You cannot water it with rainwater, you must water it with tears.
tr: “You didn't want to use water, you should have watered it with your tears instead.
es: —You don't need water from the fountain; what you need is to water it with your tears.

en: It’s the way they always do.”
vi: Everyone does it that way.
tr: This is always done this way.”
es: That's what everyone does.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I lay I kin raise one er dem mullen-stalks twyste wid spring water whiles another man’s a start’n one wid tears.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: “But Master Tom, can I use water for a big plant, and for another one, can I grow it with tears, is that okay?”
es: —But, Uncle Tom, I can grow a barbasco this big with water from the fountain, whereas with tears it will barely grow.

en: “That ain’t the idea.
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "That's not what's important.
es: —It's not about that.

en: You got to do it with tears.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: It must be watered with your tears."
es: It must be done with tears.

en: “She’ll die on my han’s, Mars Tom, she sholy will; kase I doan’ skasely ever cry.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: “But the flower died because of me, Master Tom, yes, it definitely died; because I don't cry easily.”
es: —He will die on me, Uncle Tom, I'm sure of it; because I almost never cry.

en: So Tom was stumped.
vi: Tom was at a loss for words.
tr: Tom was cornered.
es: So Tom didn't know what to do.

en: But he studied it over, and then said Jim would have to worry along the best he could with an onion.
vi: But after a moment of thinking, he told Jim to rub an onion in his eyes to produce tears.
tr: But after thinking for a bit, he told Jim that he should do his best to make his eyes water by cutting an onion.
es: But he thought about it and said that Jim would have to cry as much as he could with an onion.

en: He promised he would go to the nigger cabins and drop one, private, in Jim’s coffee-pot, in the morning.
vi: He promised to pick an onion and secretly put it into Jim's coffee pot in the morning.
tr: He promised to go to the black cabins in the morning and secretly put an onion in Jim's coffee pot.
es: He promised that he would go to the black people's cabins and secretly put one in Jim's coffee in the morning.

en: Jim said he would “jis’ ’s soon have tobacker in his coffee;” and found so much fault with it, and with the work and bother of raising the mullen, and jews-harping the rats, and petting and flattering up the snakes and spiders and things, on top of all the other work he had to do on pens, and inscriptions, and journals, and things, which made it more trouble and worry and responsibility to be a prisoner than anything he ever undertook, that Tom most lost all patience with him; and said he was just loadened down with more gaudier chances than a prisoner ever had in the world to make a name for himself, and yet he didn’t know enough to appreciate them, and they was just about wasted on him.
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, sharpening pencils, carving letters into stone, writing a diary, and so on. It was really troublesome and annoying. He talked for a while, making Tom discouraged. Tom said that he had come up with all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem like a waste of effort.
tr: Jim said he preferred us to send tobacco in his coffee; he didn't like any of the tasks asked of him; raising cow tails, playing music to mice with a mouth harp, feeding and petting snakes and spiders or other animals were not sensible tasks; besides, he was already busy with pens, inscriptions, and diaries, which had made being a prisoner the most challenging, worrying, and responsible job he had ever seen. Hearing this, Tom completely lost his patience; he told Jim that he had been given more chances to become famous as a prisoner than he could ever have, but he didn't know how to appreciate these chances and didn't deserve them.
es: Jim said he would prefer tobacco in the coffee, and he made so many problems with that, and with the work and the issue of growing the barbasco, the jew's harp and the rats and petting the snakes and spiders and everything else, on top of what he had to do with the feathers and the inscriptions and the diaries and all that, that he said being a prisoner was the hardest thing he had ever done in his life, until Tom lost his patience with him and told him that he had received more opportunities than any prisoner in the world to become famous and yet he didn't know how to appreciate it, and that with him it was nothing but a waste of time.

en: So Jim he was sorry, and said he wouldn’t behave so no more, and then me and Tom shoved for bed.
vi: Hearing that, Jim felt regretful and promised not to behave that way anymore. After that, Tom and I went back to our room to sleep.
tr: Jim regretted what he said, promised not to behave like that again, and we went out to sleep.
es: So Jim said he was sorry and that he wouldn't behave the same way again, and then Tom and I went to bed.

en: CHAPTER XXXIX.
vi: Chapter XXXIX
tr: Chapter Thirty-Nine
es: Chapter 39

en: In the morning we went up to the village and bought a wire rat-trap and fetched it down, and unstopped the best rat-hole, and in about an hour we had fifteen of the bulliest kind of ones; and then we took it and put it in a safe place under Aunt Sally’s bed.
vi: The next morning, we went to the village to buy a mouse trap and then brought it down to the house. Within about an hour, we had caught up to fifteen big ones. Then we carefully stored them under Aunt Saly's bed.
tr: In the morning, we went to the village and bought a mouse trap in the shape of a wire cage, reopened the best of the holes we had blocked, and caught about fifteen of the largest mice in about an hour; then we took the cage and hid it under Aunt Sally's bed, thinking it was safe.
es: IN THE MORNING we went to the village, bought a wire mousetrap, brought it home and uncovered the best of the rat holes, and after about half an hour we had already caught fifteen of the best in the mousetrap; then we grabbed it and put it safely under Aunt Sally's bed.
