en: But while we was gone for spiders little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it there, and opened the door of it to see if the rats would come out, and they did; and Aunt Sally she come in, and when we got back she was a-standing on top of the bed raising Cain, and the rats was doing what they could to keep off the dull times for her.
vi: But while we were out looking for spiders, little Tomas Phelps saw the mouse trap there and opened it to take a look. All the mice ran out in a frenzy, just as Aunt Saly walked in.
tr: But when we went out to hunt spiders, Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Alexander Phelps, you found the cage, got curious if the mice would come out, opened the lid, and the mice got out, and then didn't Aunt Sally come into the room... When we came back, she was on top of the bed screaming her head off, and the mice were doing their best to keep her entertained.
es: But while we were looking for spiders, little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it and opened the door to see if the rats would come out, and they did, and when we came back Aunt Sally was up on the bed raising all kinds of hell while the rats did everything they could to keep her entertained.

en: So she took and dusted us both with the hickry, and we was as much as two hours catching another fifteen or sixteen, drat that meddlesome cub, and they warn’t the likeliest, nuther, because the first haul was the pick of the flock.
vi: When we got back, we saw her standing on the bed, screaming loudly, while the mice were running for their lives.
tr: So she gave us all a good beating, and because of that meddlesome kid, we had to spend almost two extra hours catching another fifteen or sixteen mice, and the ones we caught weren't much to look at, because the first ones we caught were the finest of the bunch.
es: Then she shook us with the stick and it took us at least another two hours to catch another fifteen or sixteen, because of that silly kid, and they weren't the best either, because the first batch had been unbeatable.

en: I never see a likelier lot of rats than what that first haul was.
vi: She took a stick and gave the two of us a good beating.
tr: I had never seen such robust mice together as the ones we caught the first time.
es: In my life I have never seen a better group of rats than that first batch.

en: We got a splendid stock of sorted spiders, and bugs, and frogs, and caterpillars, and one thing or another; and we like to got a hornet’s nest, but we didn’t.
vi: We caught a bunch of spiders, bedbugs, frogs, and insects; we even wanted to take a hornet's nest, but we didn't succeed.
tr: We had a magnificent collection of spiders, insects, frogs, caterpillars, and similar things; we even thought of finding a beehive, but we couldn't manage that.
es: We managed to get a splendid variety of spiders, beetles, frogs, and caterpillars, among other things, and we almost took a wasp nest, but we didn't succeed.

en: The family was at home.
vi: The whole family of hornets was still in the nest.
tr: The bee family was fully at home.
es: The family was at home.

en: We didn’t give it right up, but stayed with them as long as we could; because we allowed we’d tire them out or they’d got to tire us out, and they done it.
vi: We kept waiting, intending to tire them out and then catch them.
tr: We didn't give up immediately, we lingered there as long as we could, either they would get tired and leave, or we would. In the end, we gave up.
es: We didn't give up immediately, but endured as much as we could, because we tried to tire them out or let them tire us out, which is what happened in the end.

en: Then we got allycumpain and rubbed on the places, and was pretty near all right again, but couldn’t set down convenient.
vi: But instead, we went looking for snakes and caught a few dozen grass snakes, put them in a bag, and brought them back to the room.
tr: We applied andiz powder to the places they stung us, we felt a bit relieved, but for a while, we couldn't sit comfortably on our bottoms.
es: Then we went to put some ointment on the stings and almost got better, although we couldn't sit comfortably.

en: And so we went for the snakes, and grabbed a couple of dozen garters and house-snakes, and put them in a bag, and put it in our room, and by that time it was supper-time, and a rattling good honest day’s work: and hungry?—oh, no, I reckon not!
vi: But instead, we went looking for snakes and caught a few dozen grass snakes, put them in a bag, and brought them back to the room.
tr: Then we went snake hunting, caught a few dozen small snakes, put them in a sack, and then hid the sack in our room; by then, it was dinner time, we had worked hard all day and were starving.
es: Then we went out to look for snakes and caught a couple of dozen water snakes and house snakes and put them in a sack in our room, which brought us to dinner time after a whole day of work; were we hungry? No, of course not!

en: And there warn’t a blessed snake up there when we went back—we didn’t half tie the sack, and they worked out somehow, and left.
vi: But instead, we went looking for snakes and caught a few dozen grass snakes, put them in a bag, and brought them back to the room.
tr: But when we returned, we couldn't find a single snake in the room – we had left the sack's mouth loose, and the snakes had found a way out.
es: When we returned, there wasn't a single damn snake left; we hadn't tied the sack well and somehow they had found their way out and left.

en: But it didn’t matter much, because they was still on the premises somewheres.
vi: But instead, we went looking for snakes and caught a few dozen grass snakes, put them in a bag, and brought them back to the room.
tr: It didn't really matter, though, because they were still somewhere in the house.
es: But it didn't matter much, because they had to be somewhere in the house.

en: So we judged we could get some of them again.
vi: Just then, it was time for dinner.
tr: We thought we could catch some of them again.
es: So we thought we would find them again.

en: No, there warn’t no real scarcity of snakes about the house for a considerable spell.
vi: But the bag wasn't tied tightly at the top, so the snakes all crawled out.
tr: For a while, there was never a shortage of snakes in the house.
es: No, for many days snakes were not scarce in that house.

en: You’d see them dripping from the rafters and places every now and then; and they generly landed in your plate, or down the back of your neck, and most of the time where you didn’t want them.
vi: Every now and then, a snake would fall from the ceiling.
tr: From time to time, you could see them falling from the roof beams and other places; they generally fell onto your plate or slid down your neck, meaning they mostly appeared in the places you least wanted them to.
es: You could see them hanging from the beams and other times tucked away somewhere, and they generally fell onto someone's plate or crawled down their neck, almost always where it wasn't pleasant.

en: Well, they was handsome and striped, and there warn’t no harm in a million of them; but that never made no difference to Aunt Sally; she despised snakes, be the breed what they might, and she couldn’t stand them no way you could fix it; and every time one of them flopped down on her, it didn’t make no difference what she was doing, she would just lay that work down and light out.
vi: Every now and then, a snake would fall from the ceiling.
tr: They were very beautiful and striped snakes, even if a million of them came, they wouldn't harm you; but it didn't matter to Aunt Sally, she was disgusted by snakes of any kind, she couldn't stand them at all; if one of them fell on her, she would drop whatever she was doing and dash outside.
es: Well, they were all very pretty with their stripes and all, and even if there were a million of them, they wouldn't have harmed anyone, but Aunt Sally didn't care about that; she was disgusted by snakes, no matter what kind they were, and she couldn't stand them in any way, and every time one fell on her, no matter what she was doing, she would stop and run away.

en: I never see such a woman.
vi: And it would fall into the food dish, onto our backs, or onto our necks.
tr: I had never seen a woman like her.
es: I've never seen a woman like that; you could hear her screams all the way to Jericho.

en: And you could hear her whoop to Jericho.
vi: Each one looked beautiful, but it was different for Aunt Saly.
tr: Moreover, her screams could reach the heavens.
es: I've never seen a woman like that; you could hear her screams all the way to Jericho.

en: You couldn’t get her to take a-holt of one of them with the tongs.
vi: She was terribly disgusted by snakes.
tr: The poor woman couldn't even hold the snakes with tongs.
es: She couldn't even grab one with tongs.

en: And if she turned over and found one in bed she would scramble out and lift a howl that you would think the house was afire.
vi: Every time a snake fell, she would scream and run away.
tr: When she opened her bed and found a snake inside, she would throw herself outside and scream so loudly that you would think the house was on fire.
es: If she turned around and found one in the bed, she would run and start screaming as if the house was on fire.

en: She disturbed the old man so that he said he could most wish there hadn’t ever been no snakes created.
vi: I've never seen a woman so afraid of snakes.
tr: Aunt Sally disturbed the peace of the big man so much that he got to the point where he wished snakes had never been created.
es: It annoyed the old man so much that he said he almost wished snakes had never been created.

en: Why, after every last snake had been gone clear out of the house for as much as a week Aunt Sally warn’t over it yet; she warn’t near over it; when she was setting thinking about something you could touch her on the back of her neck with a feather and she would jump right out of her stockings.
vi: It took about a week for all the snakes to leave the house.
tr: Even a week after the last snake was thrown out of the house, Aunt Sally still hadn't recovered; she didn't even seem like she would recover; if you touched her neck with a feather while she was sitting and thinking about something, she would jump three meters into the air.
es: But man, even after there hadn't been a single one in the house for a week, Aunt Sally still hadn't recovered; she was still so scared that when she was sitting thinking about something, if you touched her on the neck with a feather, she would jump out of her shoes.

en: It was very curious.
vi: Aunt Saly was still scared.
tr: It was a very strange thing.
es: It was very curious.

en: But Tom said all women was just so.
vi: It's really strange, but Tom said that all women are like that.
tr: But Tom said all women were like that.
es: But Tom said all women were the same.

en: He said they was made that way for some reason or other.
vi: It's really strange, but Tom said that all women are like that.
tr: For some reason, they were created that way.
es: He said that for some reason or another they were made that way.

en: We got a licking every time one of our snakes come in her way, and she allowed these lickings warn’t nothing to what she would do if we ever loaded up the place again with them.
vi: Every time a snake crawled past her place, we would get a beating.
tr: Whenever Aunt Sally saw a snake, we would get a beating; moreover, she said that if we filled the house with snakes again, the beatings would be nothing compared to what she would do.
es: He would give us a beating every time he encountered one of the snakes, and he said that was nothing compared to what he would do to us if we filled the house with them again.

en: I didn’t mind the lickings, because they didn’t amount to nothing; but I minded the trouble we had to lay in another lot.
vi: I wasn't afraid of the beatings because they didn't hurt at all. I just dreaded having to catch more snakes.
tr: I didn't mind the beatings much because they hardly hurt, but catching another sack of snakes was no easy task.
es: The beatings didn't bother me, because they were really nothing, but I did care about how difficult it was for us to find another bunch.

en: But we got them laid in, and all the other things; and you never see a cabin as blithesome as Jim’s was when they’d all swarm out for music and go for him.
vi: I've never seen a room as lively as Jim's when all those creatures crawled out to listen to the music and gathered around Jim.
tr: Still, we caught more snakes and completed the others. There was no place as lively as Jim's cabin anymore; all the animals would flock to Jim to listen to music.
es: But we got them, along with the other critters, and in your life, you have never seen a cabin as lively as Jim's when they all came out to hear the music and approached him.

en: Jim didn’t like the spiders, and the spiders didn’t like Jim; and so they’d lay for him, and make it mighty warm for him.
vi: I've never seen a room as lively as Jim's when all those creatures crawled out to listen to the music and gathered around Jim.
tr: Jim couldn't warm up to the spiders, and the spiders couldn't warm up to him.
es: Jim didn't like spiders and the spiders didn't like Jim; so they would wait and then make his life impossible.

en: And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the grindstone there warn’t no room in bed for him, skasely; and when there was, a body couldn’t sleep, it was so lively, and it was always lively, he said, because they never all slept at one time, but took turn about, so when the snakes was asleep the rats was on deck, and when the rats turned in the snakes come on watch, so he always had one gang under him, in his way, and t’other gang having a circus over him, and if he got up to hunt a new place the spiders would take a chance at him as he crossed over.
vi: Jim couldn't even blink in peace; when the snakes slept, the mice would come out, and when the mice went back in, the snakes would come out to stand guard, so there was always a group at his feet and another at his head. When Jim tried to find another place to lie down, the spiders would crawl over.
tr: They attacked him at every opportunity and made his life miserable. Additionally, Jim complained that there was no place for him to sleep between the mice, snakes, and millstones; even if he managed to squeeze in and lie down, he couldn't sleep because there was constant movement in the bed; since the creatures didn't all sleep at the same time, they took turns using the bed, so while the snakes slept, the mice would be running around; when the mice slept, the snakes would take over. One gang was always under Jim while the other was holding a circus on top of him, and if he tried to find another place to sleep, the spiders would attack him while he walked.
es: And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the mill wheel, he hardly had any room left on the cot, and in what little space he had, he couldn't sleep, because it never stopped, and it never stopped because they never all slept at the same time, but took turns, so when the snakes slept, the rats were on guard, and when the rats went to bed, it was the snakes' turn to be on guard, so he always had a bunch of critters underneath him and another bunch making a circus on top, and if he got up to find a new spot, the spiders would pounce on him during the change.

en: He said if he ever got out this time he wouldn’t ever be a prisoner again, not for a salary.
vi: He said if he got out this time, he would never want to be a prisoner again, even if they paid him.
tr: He said that if he ever got out, he would never be a prisoner again, even if they paid him.
es: He said that if he ever escaped, he would never be a prisoner again, not even if they paid him a salary.

en: Well, by the end of three weeks everything was in pretty good shape.
vi: Three weeks later, everything was fine.
tr: At the end of three weeks, everything had finally fallen into place.
es: Well, after three weeks everything was in perfect shape.

en: The shirt was sent in early, in a pie, and every time a rat bit Jim he would get up and write a little in his journal whilst the ink was fresh; the pens was made, the inscriptions and so on was all carved on the grindstone; the bed-leg was sawed in two, and we had et up the sawdust, and it give us a most amazing stomach-ache.
vi: The shirt had been brought in first, each time a rat bit it, Jim would get up and write a line in the diary; when the ink was still wet, the pen was done, the letters and symbols were engraved on the grindstone; the bed legs had been sawed in half, and we had to eat all the sawdust.
tr: The shirt had been sent in the pie ahead of schedule, and Jim would get up and write in his journal while the ink was still fresh every time a rat bit him; the pens were made, the inscription and others were carved on the millstone; we had cut the bed leg in two and eaten the sawdust, after which we were struck with a terrible stomachache.
es: The shirt had arrived right away inside a cake, and every time a rat bit Jim, he would get up and write something in the diary while the ink was fresh; the pens were made, the inscriptions and everything else had already been engraved on the stone; the bed leg was sawed in two and we had eaten the sawdust, which gave us a terrible stomachache.

en: We reckoned we was all going to die, but didn’t.
vi: The shirt had been brought in first, each time a rat bit it, Jim would get up and write a line in the diary; when the ink was still wet, the pen was done, the letters and symbols were engraved on the grindstone; the bed legs had been sawed in half, and we had to eat all the sawdust.
tr: We all thought we were going to die, but nothing happened.
es: We thought we would all die, but we didn't.

en: It was the most undigestible sawdust I ever see; and Tom said the same.
vi: The shirt had been brought in first, each time a rat bit it, Jim would get up and write a line in the diary; when the ink was still wet, the pen was done, the letters and symbols were engraved on the grindstone; the bed legs had been sawed in half, and we had to eat all the sawdust.
tr: In my life, I had never seen sawdust so hard, sitting in one's stomach like a stone; Tom said the same thing.
es: It was the most indigestible sawdust I've seen in my life, and Tom said the same.

en: But as I was saying, we’d got all the work done now, at last; and we was all pretty much fagged out, too, but mainly Jim.
vi: After finishing that, we had such severe stomachaches that we thought we were going to die.
tr: But as I said, we had finally finished all the work, and we were all exhausted, but Jim was almost pickled by now.
es: But he also said that we had finally finished all the work, even though we were all exhausted, especially Jim.

en: The old man had wrote a couple of times to the plantation below Orleans to come and get their runaway nigger, but hadn’t got no answer, because there warn’t no such plantation; so he allowed he would advertise Jim in the St. Louis and New Orleans papers; and when he mentioned the St. Louis ones it give me the cold shivers, and I see we hadn’t no time to lose.
vi: Uncle Silas had written several letters to the plantation down in Orleans to inform them to send someone to take the black man back, but there was no reply, because there was no such plantation down there. Finally, he said he would post a notice about Jim in the St. Louis and Orleans newspapers. When he mentioned St. Louis, it made me shiver all over.
tr: The old man wrote letters several times to the plantation south of Orleans, asking them to come and get their runaway Negro, but received no reply, because there was no such plantation; he then said he would place an ad for Jim in the St. Louis and New Orleans newspapers; when he mentioned the St. Louis newspapers, my hair stood on end, we had no time to lose.
es: The old man had written twice to the plantation south of Orleans to come and get his runaway black man, but he had received no response, because that plantation didn't exist, so he said he would put an ad about Jim in the Saint Louis and New Orleans newspapers, and when he mentioned the Saint Louis ones, I got chills and saw that we had no time to lose.

en: So Tom said, now for the nonnamous letters.
vi: At that moment, Tom decided to write an anonymous letter.
tr: Upon this, Tom said it was time for the anonymous letters.
es: Tom said it was time for the anonymous letters.

en: “What’s them?” I says.
vi: - What is it?
tr: "Oh really?" I said.
es: —What is that? —I asked.

en: “Warnings to the people that something is up.
vi: - I asked.
tr: “Warnings to people that something is going to happen.
es: —Warnings to people that something is going to happen.

en: Sometimes it’s done one way, sometimes another.
vi: - It's to let people know what's happening.
tr: Some give their warnings this way; some give them that way.
es: Sometimes it is done in one way and other times in another.

en: But there’s always somebody spying around that gives notice to the governor of the castle.
vi: - It's to let people know what's happening.
tr: But there is always someone who spies and sends a warning to the castle's chief.
es: But there is always some spy who warns the governor of the castle.

en: When Louis XVI.
vi: In the past, when Louis XVI planned to escape from prison, there was a maid who did that.
tr: XVI.
es: When Louis XVI was going to escape from the Tuileries, it was a maid.

en: was going to light out of the Tooleries, a servant-girl done it.
vi: In the past, when Louis XVI planned to escape from prison, there was a maid who did that.
tr: When Louis was about to escape from the Tuileries, a maid did this.
es: When Louis XVI was going to escape from the Tuileries, it was a maid.

en: It’s a very good way, and so is the nonnamous letters.
vi: Usually, the mother of the prisoner would exchange clothes with her child; the mother would stay behind, while the child would disguise themselves in the mother's clothes to escape.
tr: I think it's a very good method, anonymous letters too.
es: That's very good, and anonymous letters too.

en: We’ll use them both.
vi: Usually, the mother of the prisoner would exchange clothes with her child; the mother would stay behind, while the child would disguise themselves in the mother's clothes to escape.
tr: We will use both.
es: We will do both things.

en: And it’s usual for the prisoner’s mother to change clothes with him, and she stays in, and he slides out in her clothes.
vi: Usually, the mother of the prisoner would exchange clothes with her child; the mother would stay behind, while the child would disguise themselves in the mother's clothes to escape.
tr: Also, it is customary for the prisoner's mother to switch clothes with him; thus the mother stays inside and the prisoner leaves in his mother's clothes.
es: Normally, the prisoner's mother changes clothes with them and stays inside the castle, and he goes out dressed in the mother's clothes.

en: We’ll do that, too.”
vi: We will do the same.
tr: We will do that too.”
es: We are going to do that too.

en: “But looky here, Tom, what do we want to warn anybody for that something’s up?
vi: - But we have to inform them.
tr: “But Tom, why would we want to warn people that something is going to happen?
es: —But, listen, Tom, why do we want to warn anyone that something is going to happen?

en: Let them find it out for themselves—it’s their lookout.”
vi: Whoever knows, let them be.
tr: Let them find out for themselves… after all, they are the ones keeping watch.”
es: Let them find out on their own, it's their business.

en: “Yes, I know; but you can’t depend on them.
vi: Whoever knows, let them be.
tr: “I know that too, but you can't trust them.
es: —Yes, I already know. But you can't count on them.

en: It’s the way they’ve acted from the very start—left us to do everything.
vi: - I know already, but if we don't inform them, then no one and nothing will interfere with us.
tr: It has been like this from the very beginning... They left everything for us to do.
es: It's what they've done from the beginning: they've let us do everything ourselves.

en: They’re so confiding and mullet-headed they don’t take notice of nothing at all.
vi: - I know already, but if we don't inform them, then no one and nothing will interfere with us.
tr: They are so naive and thick-headed that they don't realize anything.
es: They are so confident and so oblivious that they don't even notice us.

en: So if we don’t give them notice there won’t be nobody nor nothing to interfere with us, and so after all our hard work and trouble this escape ’ll go off perfectly flat; won’t amount to nothing—won’t be nothing to it.”
vi: So all the hard and difficult work has no value, no meaning at all??
tr: That's why if we don't warn them, there will be no one or nothing to intervene with us, after working so hard and suffering so much, this escape will work perfectly: It will have no meaning... There will be no place left to remember.”
es: So if we don't warn them, there will be nothing and no one to interfere, and after all the work and all the worry we've put into this escape, it will go off as if nothing happened; it will have no value... It won't draw any attention!

en: “Well, as for me, Tom, that’s the way I’d like.”
vi: - I like it that way.
tr: “If you ask me, this would be the best, Tom.”
es: —Well, as far as I'm concerned, Tom, that's the best thing.

en: “Shucks!” he says, and looked disgusted.
vi: It looked at me with disdain.
tr: "Oh, come on, you too," he said, grimacing.
es: —Darn!

en: So I says:
vi: - Don't speak anymore, please. I said:
tr: "Oh, come on, you too," he said, grimacing.
es: —he exclaimed, with a look of displeasure, so I said to him:

en: “But I ain’t going to make no complaint.
vi: I don't object, you can do it however you want.
tr: “I'm not complaining,” I said.
es: —But I am not going to complain.

en: Any way that suits you suits me.
vi: I don't object, you can do it however you want.
tr: “If you think it's appropriate, it's fine with me too.
es: What you decide is fine with me.

en: What you going to do about the servant-girl?”
vi: So where did you find that maid?
tr: But how will you handle the maid issue?”
es: Where are we going to find the maid?

en: “You’ll be her.
vi: - You will be the maid.
tr: “You will be the maid.
es: —That's your job.

en: You slide in, in the middle of the night, and hook that yaller girl’s frock.”
vi: In the middle of the night, you sneak in and put on that yellow dress.
tr: You will sneak in late at night and steal that half-breed girl's dress.”
es: You sneak in the middle of the night and take the dress from that fair-skinned girl.

en: “Why, Tom, that’ll make trouble next morning; because, of course, she prob’bly hain’t got any but that one.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “But Tom, we'll get into trouble in the morning, the girl probably doesn't have any other clothes.”
es: —But, Tom, then he will have problems in the morning, because he might not have another one.

en: “I know; but you don’t want it but fifteen minutes, to carry the nonnamous letter and shove it under the front door.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “I know, but you will take the dress for only fifteen minutes; all you have to do is take the anonymous letter and throw it inside under the front door.”
es: —I know, but you only need a quarter of an hour to take the anonymous letter and slip it under the main door.

en: “All right, then, I’ll do it; but I could carry it just as handy in my own togs.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “Alright then, I'll do it; but I could have carried the letter just fine with my own clothes too.”
es: —Then, very well, agreed; but I could still take her without changing my clothes.

en: “You wouldn’t look like a servant-girl then, would you?”
vi: - In that case, you won't be a close maid anymore.
tr: “But then you won't look like a servant girl, will you?”
es: —Then you wouldn't look like a maid, would you?

en: “No, but there won’t be nobody to see what I look like, anyway.”
vi: - But who is looking at me?
tr: "No, but there won't be anyone to see what I look like anyway."
es: —No, but anyway, no one is going to see what I seem or stop seeming.

en: “That ain’t got nothing to do with it.
vi: - It's okay.
tr: “This has nothing to do with the matter.
es: —That has nothing to do with it.

en: The thing for us to do is just to do our duty, and not worry about whether anybody sees us do it or not.
vi: I'm doing this because it's my duty, not because I worry about whether anyone sees me or not.
tr: What is important for us is to do our duty and not to care whether others see us or not.
es: What matters is that we fulfill our duty and not worry about whether someone sees us doing it or not.

en: Hain’t you got no principle at all?”
vi: Don't you understand anything?
tr: Can't you act a bit more principled?”
es: Don't you have any principles?

en: “All right, I ain’t saying nothing; I’m the servant-girl.
vi: - Alright, I am the maid, so who is Jim's mother?
tr: “Alright, okay, I didn't say anything; I am a maid.
es: —Very well, I won't say anything; I am the maid.

en: Who’s Jim’s mother?”
vi: - I am Jim's mother.
tr: Who is Jim's mother then?”
es: Who is Jim's mother?

en: “I’m his mother.
vi: - I am Jim's mother.
tr: "Her mother is me.
es: —I am the mother.

en: I’ll hook a gown from Aunt Sally.”
vi: I will wear Aunt Saly's shirt.
tr: I will swipe one of Aunt Sally's dresses."
es: I will put on one of Aunt Sally's dresses.

en: “Well, then, you’ll have to stay in the cabin when me and Jim leaves.”
vi: - Alright, so when Jim and I escape, you have to stay behind in that prison cell.
tr: “Alright, then when Jim and I escape, you will need to stay in the cabin.”
es: —Well, then you'll have to stay in the cabin when Jim and I leave.

en: “Not much.
vi: - It's not just that.
tr: “Not really.
es: —Not much time.

en: I’ll stuff Jim’s clothes full of straw and lay it on his bed to represent his mother in disguise, and Jim ’ll take the nigger woman’s gown off of me and wear it, and we’ll all evade together.
vi: I will stuff straw into Jim's clothes and put it on the bed to pretend to be his mother. Jim will wear Aunt Sally's clothes that I bring, and the three of us will escape together.
tr: I will fill Jim’s clothes with straw and lay them in bed to represent his disguised mother, and Jim will take a woman’s dress from me and wear it, and we will all retreat together.
es: I will stuff Jim's clothes with straw and leave them on the bed to represent his disguised mother; Jim will take off my dress, put it on, and we will escape together.

en: When a prisoner of style escapes it’s called an evasion.
vi: When a famous prisoner escapes, it's called a jailbreak.
tr: Retreating is what you call the escape of a prisoner with honor.
es: When a fine prisoner escapes, it is called an evasion.

en: It’s always called so when a king escapes, f’rinstance.
vi: When a famous prisoner escapes, it's called a jailbreak.
tr: For example, when a king escapes, he retreats.
es: For example, that's what they always say when a king escapes.

en: And the same with a king’s son; it don’t make no difference whether he’s a natural one or an unnatural one.”
vi: When a famous prisoner escapes, it's called a jailbreak.
tr: The same applies to the king’s son; whether he is legitimate or illegitimate does not change anything.
es: And the same goes for the son of a king; it doesn't matter if he is a legitimate or illegitimate son.

en: So Tom he wrote the nonnamous letter, and I smouched the yaller wench’s frock that night, and put it on, and shoved it under the front door, the way Tom told me to.
vi: Then Tom wrote an anonymous letter, and that night I put on a woman's yellow dress, took the anonymous letter, and slipped it under the door, just as Tom instructed.
tr: Thereupon, Tom wrote the anonymous letter, I stole the mulatto girl's dress, and that night I wore the dress and slipped the letter under the front door as Tom instructed.
es: So Tom wrote the anonymous letter and that night I stole the light-colored girl's dress, put it on, and slipped under the front door what Tom had told me.

en: It said:
vi: The letter says:
tr: The letter said:
es: It said:

en: Beware.
vi: Attention: Something big is about to happen.
tr: Attention.
es: "Careful." "Trouble is approaching."

en: Trouble is brewing.
vi: Attention: Something big is about to happen.
tr: Trouble is coming.
es: "Careful." "Trouble is approaching."

en: Keep a sharp lookout.
vi: Pay close attention.
tr: Keep your eyes wide open.
es: "Stay very alert."

en: UNKNOWN FRIEND.
vi: The anonymous friend.
tr: A FRIEND
es: "AN UNKNOWN FRIEND"

en: Next night we stuck a picture, which Tom drawed in blood, of a skull and crossbones on the front door; and next night another one of a coffin on the back door.
vi: The next night, we pasted a picture that Tom drew, with blood, of a human skull with two crossed bones on the front door. And the following night, we pasted another picture on the back door, this time of a coffin.
tr: The next night we pasted Tom's drawing of a skull and crossbones made with blood on the front door; the following night we pasted a picture of a coffin on the back door.
es: The next night we nailed a drawing of a skull and crossbones that Tom made with blood on the front door, and the following night we nailed another drawing of a coffin on the back door.

en: I never see a family in such a sweat.
vi: The whole family was terrified.
tr: I had never seen a family so worried before.
es: I had never seen a family so scared.

en: They couldn’t a been worse scared if the place had a been full of ghosts laying for them behind everything and under the beds and shivering through the air.
vi: The whole family was terrified.
tr: If the house were haunted, with ghosts jumping out from behind everything, from under the beds, flying in the air, they wouldn't be this scared.
es: They couldn't have been more frightened even if the house had been filled with ghosts waiting for them behind every piece of furniture and under the beds or floating in the air.

en: If a door banged, Aunt Sally she jumped and said “ouch!” if anything fell, she jumped and said “ouch!” if you happened to touch her, when she warn’t noticing, she done the same; she couldn’t face noway and be satisfied, because she allowed there was something behind her every time—so she was always a-whirling around sudden, and saying “ouch,” and before she’d got two-thirds around she’d whirl back again, and say it again; and she was afraid to go to bed, but she dasn’t set up.
vi: The door slamming shut even startled Aunt Saly.
tr: If a door slammed, Aunt Sally would jump and scream "Oh!", if something fell, she would immediately jump and scream "Oh!", if you touched her absentmindedly, she would do the same; she couldn't feel at ease no matter which way she turned, because she constantly thought something was behind her – so she frequently spun around suddenly and screamed "Oh!" and before she could settle down, she would turn the other way and scream again; she was afraid to go to bed, but she was also afraid to sit down.
es: If a door slammed, Aunt Sally would jump and say "oh!", and if something fell, she would jump and say "oh!", and when someone touched her before she realized it, she would do the same; she couldn't look to one side and feel satisfied, because she said there was always something behind her, so she spent her time turning around suddenly and saying "oh!", and before she finished turning around, she would twist again and say the same thing, and she was afraid to go to bed, but she didn't dare to stay sitting either.

en: So the thing was working very well, Tom said; he said he never see a thing work more satisfactory.
vi: She was too scared to sleep but didn't say anything.
tr: So our plan is working very well, said Tom; he said he had never seen a plan work so perfectly.
es: So things were going very well, Tom said; according to him, he had never seen anything go so well.

en: He said it showed it was done right.
vi: She was too scared to sleep but didn't say anything.
tr: All of this showed how correctly we had done everything.
es: He commented that this showed things were well done.

en: So he said, now for the grand bulge!
vi: So the plan was going very well.
tr: According to what Tom said, it was time to set off the big bomb!
es: So, he said, let's get everything going!

en: So the very next morning at the streak of dawn we got another letter ready, and was wondering what we better do with it, because we heard them say at supper they was going to have a nigger on watch at both doors all night.
vi: Early the next morning, just as dawn was breaking, we finished writing another letter and marveled at how clever we were. By dinner time, they said that the black men would stand guard all night at both the front and back doors of the house.
tr: The next morning at dawn, we prepared another letter and started thinking about how to deliver it, because we had heard at dinner that they would station a black man at each door all night.
es: So the next morning, just at dawn, we prepared another letter, and we were thinking about the best way to deliver it, because at dinner time we had heard them say that they were going to put a black man on guard at each door all night.

en: Tom he went down the lightning-rod to spy around; and the nigger at the back door was asleep, and he stuck it in the back of his neck and come back.
vi: Tom slid down the lamp post, pasted the letter on the back of one of the black men, and climbed back up.
tr: Tom slid down the lightning rod to scout around and, finding the black man at the back door asleep, slipped the letter down his neck and returned.
es: Tom went down the lightning rod to see how things were, and since the black man at the back door was asleep, he slipped it into his shirt from behind and came back.

en: This letter said:
vi: The letter read as follows:
tr: This letter read as follows:
es: The letter said:

en: Don’t betray me, I wish to be your friend.
vi: "Do not betray me, I want to be your friend.
tr: Don't turn me in, I want to be your friend.
es: "Do not betray me, I wish to be your friend.

en: There is a desprate gang of cutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your runaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as you will stay in the house and not bother them.
vi: Currently, there is a very dangerous gang of murderers who will steal your runaway black man, and they advise you not to stop them.
tr: A bloodthirsty gang from the Indian Territory is going to steal your runaway negro tonight, they were trying to scare you into staying home and not interfering with them.
es: There is a desperate band of murderers from Indian territory who are going to steal your fugitive black man tonight, and they have tried to scare you into staying home and not bothering them.

en: I am one of the gang, but have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life again, and will betray the helish design.
vi: I am one of them, but I want to leave them and live an honest life, so I want to inform you.
tr: I am also part of the gang, but I am a religious person and I want to leave the gang and live an honest life again, so I decided to inform you of this diabolical plan.
es: I am from the band, but I have repented and want to leave it and lead an honest life again and I want to betray their infernal plans.

en: They will sneak down from northards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go in the nigger’s cabin to get him.
vi: They will come down from the North, through the fence, at exactly midnight, carrying a fake key to enter the black man's room and steal him away.
tr: At exactly midnight, they will come from the north, jump over the fence, and unlock the negro's cabin with a skeleton key to take him away.
es: They will arrive at exactly midnight from the north, by the fence, with a false key, and will go to the black man's cabin to take him away.

en: I am to be off a piece and blow a tin horn if I see any danger; but stead of that I will BA like a sheep soon as they get in and not blow at all; then whilst they are getting his chains loose, you slip there and lock them in, and can kill them at your leasure.
vi: I will stand nearby, if I see any danger, I will blow a whistle. When they get close, I will not blow the whistle but will bleat like a sheep. Then, while they are unchaining him, you should come and lock them inside and you can kill them however you wish.
tr: I will supposedly stand a bit far away and if I see any danger, I will blow a horn; but actually, I will bleat like a sheep when they get inside and won't blow the horn at all; while they are unchaining the negro, you can quietly approach and lock them all inside, then kill them at a suitable time.
es: I have to stay behind and blow a horn if I see danger, but what I will do is bleat like a sheep as soon as they arrive and not blow the horn; then, while they are removing the chains, you can go and lock them up and kill them whenever you want.

en: Don’t do anything but just the way I am telling you, if you do they will suspicion something and raise whoop-jamboreehoo.
vi: Do not do anything other than what I have told you above; otherwise, they will suspect something and will howl to call the whole gang to rescue them.
tr: Do not disobey my words, if you act on your own, they will suspect something and turn the place into hell.
es: Do nothing more than what I tell you; because if not, they will surely suspect something and create a disaster.

en: I do not wish any reward but to know I have done the right thing.
vi: I do not ask for any reward, but just know that I have done a righteous deed."
tr: I don't want any reward, all I want is to do the right thing.
es: I do not desire any reward, but to know that I have acted rightly.

en: UNKNOWN FRIEND
vi: The Anonymous Friend
tr: A FRIEND
es: "AN UNKNOWN FRIEND"

en: CHAPTER XL.
vi: chapter xl
tr: Chapter Forty
es: Chapter 40

en: We was feeling pretty good after breakfast, and took my canoe and went over the river a-fishing, with a lunch, and had a good time, and took a look at the raft and found her all right, and got home late to supper, and found them in such a sweat and worry they didn’t know which end they was standing on, and made us go right off to bed the minute we was done supper, and wouldn’t tell us what the trouble was, and never let on a word about the new letter, but didn’t need to, because we knowed as much about it as anybody did, and as soon as we was half up stairs and her back was turned we slid for the cellar cupboard and loaded up a good lunch and took it up to our room and went to bed, and got up about half-past eleven, and Tom put on Aunt Sally’s dress that he stole and was going to start with the lunch, but says:
vi: After breakfast, we felt refreshed and went to the river to pull up the boat and then went fishing, bringing along lunch as well. It wasn't until nearly evening that we returned, finding the whole family very worried. After dinner, they urged us to go to bed, but halfway up the stairs, seeing Aunt Saly had already turned away, we sneaked down to the cupboard to grab some cold food and dollars, brought them back to the room, and went to sleep until one-thirty. Tom wore Aunt Saly's dress that he had just stolen and took the food away. He told me:
tr: After breakfast, we were feeling very good, we took our lunch with us and went fishing on the river with my canoe, we had a great time, we went and checked the raft and saw that it was in good condition, then when we returned late for dinner, we found them anxious and worried, not knowing what to do. Right after dinner, they sent us to our beds and definitely did not tell us what the problem was. The last letter was not mentioned at all, but there was no need for that, because we knew as much as everyone else, after climbing the stairs halfway, when Aunt Sally turned her back, we quietly went to the cupboard in the cellar, took quite a bit of food, went up to our room, and lay in our beds; at half-past eleven, we got up again, Tom immediately put on the dress he had stolen from Aunt Sally and just as he was about to leave with the food, he stopped:
es: AFTER BREAKFAST we felt so good that we took out the canoe to go fishing in the river, with some sandwiches, and we had a lot of fun; we went to where the raft was, saw that it was fine, and got home late for dinner, and we saw them so scared and worried that they didn't even know where to look and made us go to bed as soon as we finished dinner without telling us what was going on, not a word about the new letter, but it wasn't necessary, because we were more informed than anyone, and as soon as we went up half the stairs and Aunt Sally turned around, we went to the basement pantry, took out plenty of food, brought it up to our room, and went to bed. Around eleven-thirty we got up and Tom put on Aunt Sally's dress that he had stolen to go with the food, but he said:

en: “Where’s the butter?”
vi: - Where is the butter?
tr: "Where is the butter?"
es: —Where is the butter?

en: “I laid out a hunk of it,” I says, “on a piece of a corn-pone.”
vi: - I put a big piece into the bread already.
tr: “I had taken a mold,” I said, “I had put it on the cornbread.”
es: —I got a good piece —I said— on a slice of cornbread.

en: “Well, you left it laid out, then—it ain’t here.”
vi: - Why isn't there?
tr: “So, you must have taken it out but didn't put it in the bag,” he said, “because it's not here.”
es: —Well, you left it there; it's not here.

en: “We can get along without it,” I says.
vi: - It's okay without butter.
tr: "We can manage without butter," I said.
es: —We can do without her —I replied.

en: “We can get along with it, too,” he says; “just you slide down cellar and fetch it.
vi: - You go downstairs and get it.
tr: “We would manage better if we had butter,” he said; “all you have to do is go down to the cellar and get it.
es: —We can also go with her —he said—, so go back to the basement and bring her.

en: And then mosey right down the lightning-rod and come along.
vi: - You go downstairs and get it.
tr: Then you come down from the lightning rod.
es: Then slide down the lightning rod and come over.

en: I’ll go and stuff the straw into Jim’s clothes to represent his mother in disguise, and be ready to ba like a sheep and shove soon as you get there.”
vi: I'll go stuff straw into Jim's clothes to pretend to be his mother, then I'll be ready there to bleat like a sheep. As soon as you arrive, just come right in.
tr: Now I'm going to go and stuff Jim's clothes with straw, pretending to be his disguised mother; when you get there, be ready to bleat like a sheep and run away immediately.”
es: I'm going to put the straw in Jim's clothes so he can pretend to be his disguised mother and be ready to bleat like a sheep and take off as soon as you arrive.

en: So out he went, and down cellar went I.
vi: Then it went out, and I went down to the basement. I took a piece of bread, turned off the light, and sneaked through the lower house.
tr: So he went outside, and I went down to the cellar.
es: So he left and I went to the basement.

en: The hunk of butter, big as a person’s fist, was where I had left it, so I took up the slab of corn-pone with it on, and blowed out my light, and started up stairs very stealthy, and got up to the main floor all right, but here comes Aunt Sally with a candle, and I clapped the truck in my hat, and clapped my hat on my head, and the next second she see me; and she says:
vi: Suddenly, Aunt Saly appeared holding a candle, and I quickly put the piece of bread into my hat and put it on my head. Seeing me, she asked:
tr: The butter pat, the size of a fist, was still where I had left it. I took it along with the bread underneath, turned off my light, and started to quietly climb the stairs. I reached the ground floor without any issues, but there Aunt Sally suddenly appeared with a candle. I quickly stuffed what I was holding into my hat and put the hat on my head. At that very moment, she saw me:
es: The piece of butter, the size of a fist, was where I had left it, so I took the piece of cornbread where I had placed it and went up to the main floor, but Aunt Sally appeared with a candle and I stuffed everything into my hat and put it on my head. When she saw me, she immediately said:

en: “You been down cellar?”
vi: - Did you come up from the basement?
tr: “Had you gone down to the cellar?”
es: —Have you gone down to the basement?

en: “Yes’m.”
vi: - Yes... sir.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes, ma'am.

en: “What you been doing down there?”
vi: - What are you doing down there?
tr: “What were you doing there?”
es: —What were you doing there?

en: “Noth’n.”
vi: - Not doing anything, sir.
tr: "Nothing."
es: —Nothing.

en: “Noth’n!”
vi: - Right?
tr: "Nothing at all, you say!"
es: —Nothing!

en: “No’m.”
vi: - That's correct.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —No, ma'am.

en: “Well, then, what possessed you to go down there this time of night?”
vi: - So what are you going down there for in the middle of the night?
tr: “Alright, what came to your mind at this hour of the night that made you come down, let's see?”
es: —Well, then, what has made you come down at this hour of the night?

en: “I don’t know ’m.”
vi: - Sir ... I don't know.
tr: “I don't know.”
es: —I don't know.

en: “You don’t know?
vi: - Don't know?
tr: "Don't you know?
es: —Don't you know?

en: Don’t answer me that way.
vi: Don't answer me like that, Tom.
tr: Don't give me such answers, Tom, I want to know what you're doing down there."
es: Don't tell me those things, Tom.

en: Tom, I want to know what you been doing down there.”
vi: I want to know what you were doing down there?
tr: Don't give me such answers, Tom, I want to know what you're doing down there."
es: I want to know what you were doing down there.

en: “I hain’t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if I have.”
vi: - I didn't do anything, Aunt Saly, I swear.
tr: “I wasn't doing anything, Aunt Sally, I swear, I wasn't doing anything.”
es: —I wasn't doing anything, Aunt Sally. May I die if it's not true.

en: I reckoned she’d let me go now, and as a generl thing she would; but I s’pose there was so many strange things going on she was just in a sweat about every little thing that warn’t yard-stick straight; so she says, very decided:
vi: I thought she would let it go, because she usually did so. But perhaps lately there have been many unusual things happening in the house, so she pays attention to every little thing. She spoke very firmly.
tr: If it were any other time, he would probably let me go, but I guess because there were too many strange things going on, even the slightest thing that didn't seem right was worrying him; so he said with a very determined expression:
es: I figured that now she would let me go, and generally that's what she would have done, but I guess so many strange things were happening that anything that wasn't crystal clear made her nervous, so she goes and says, very determined:

en: “You just march into that setting-room and stay there till I come.
vi: - Go into the room and don't wait there.
tr: "Go straight to the living room and wait until I come."
es: —Go into the room and stay there until I come back.

en: You been up to something you no business to, and I lay I’ll find out what it is before I’m done with you.”
vi: Let me see how things are first, then we'll talk.
tr: "You definitely did something naughty, and you can't go anywhere until I find out what it is.""
es: You went and did something you shouldn't have, and I bet I'll find out what it was before I'm done with you.

en: So she went away as I opened the door and walked into the setting-room.
vi: - She left, and I opened the door and stepped into the living room.
tr: When I opened the door and entered the living room, he moved away.
es: So he left while I opened the door and entered the room.

en: My, but there was a crowd there!
vi: To my surprise, a crowd was in the room.
tr: My God, it was so crowded inside!
es: My God, how many people were there!

en: Fifteen farmers, and every one of them had a gun.
vi: Fifteen people were camping, each holding a gun in their hands.
tr: There were fifteen farmers, each holding a rifle.
es: Fifteen farmers, and each one of them with a weapon.

en: I was most powerful sick, and slunk to a chair and set down.
vi: I plopped down.
tr: Suddenly, I felt faint and barely managed to collapse into a chair.
es: I felt terrible, I let myself fall into a chair and sat down.

en: They was setting around, some of them talking a little, in a low voice, and all of them fidgety and uneasy, but trying to look like they warn’t; but I knowed they was, because they was always taking off their hats, and putting them on, and scratching their heads, and changing their seats, and fumbling with their buttons.
vi: They were whispering to each other, everyone looking annoyed and uncomfortable, but still pretending as if nothing was wrong. But I knew, because I saw them repeatedly taking off and putting on their hats, standing up and sitting down, and fiddling with their coat buttons.
tr: While sitting and waiting in the room, some were chatting in low voices, all of them were restless and nervous, but they tried to appear otherwise; I could tell their state from the way they kept taking off and putting back on their hats, scratching their heads, changing places, and fiddling with their buttons.
es: They were also seated, some talking a little, in low voices, and all of them restless and nervous, trying to pretend they weren't; but I knew they were because they kept taking off their hats and putting them back on, scratching their ears and changing seats and buttoning and unbuttoning.

en: I warn’t easy myself, but I didn’t take my hat off, all the same.
vi: I was also impatient, but I didn't take off my hat like they did.
tr: I wasn't comfortable either, but I couldn't take off my hat.
es: I wasn't calm either, but in any case, I didn't take off my hat.

en: I did wish Aunt Sally would come, and get done with me, and lick me, if she wanted to, and let me get away and tell Tom how we’d overdone this thing, and what a thundering hornet’s-nest we’d got ourselves into, so we could stop fooling around straight off, and clear out with Jim before these rips got out of patience and come for us.
vi: I hope Aunt Sally comes to kick me out so I can run out and tell Tom that we have made too big a deal of it and now we have to run away with Jim before those people get angry and catch us, which would be disastrous.
tr: I wish Aunt Sally had come in right away and finished with me; she could have beaten me if she wanted to, but she should have let me go as soon as possible because I needed to tell Tom how far we had gone and how we had stirred up a hornet's nest. We needed to stop dawdling and get Jim out before these men lost their patience and stormed the cabin.
es: What I felt like was for Aunt Sally to arrive and give me the beating to get it over with, if she wanted, and let me go to tell Tom how we had exaggerated everything and what a mess we had gotten ourselves into, so that we could stop fooling around and take off with Jim before those bumpkins ran out of patience and came after us.

en: At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I couldn’t answer them straight, I didn’t know which end of me was up; because these men was in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right now and lay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn’t but a few minutes to midnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the sheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me a-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that scared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter beginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty soon, when one of them says, “I’m for going and getting in the cabin first and right now, and catching them when they come,” I most dropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and Aunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:
vi: Then a moment later, she came and asked me many questions, but I couldn't answer right away because I didn't know how to respond. But the other person was impatient and wanted to start immediately. They looked like they were going crazy. They said there were only a few minutes left until midnight. A few others said to wait, to listen for the bleat of the sheep as a signal. Meanwhile, Aunt Saly kept pressing me with questions, I was so scared that I started trembling and felt like I was about to collapse. The room was getting hotter by the minute. The butter in my hat began to melt, dripping down past my ears and running down my neck. Suddenly, someone said: - Let me go there first, wait for them to arrive and then catch them. I almost collapsed, a streak of butter running down my forehead. Aunt Saly saw it, her face turned pale, and she exclaimed:
tr: Finally, Aunt Sally arrived and started asking me questions, but I couldn't answer her questions properly; my mind was elsewhere because the men were getting quite restless. Some of them wanted to start immediately and finish off the bandits, saying there were only a few minutes left until midnight; others were trying to hold them back and wait for the sheep to bleat. Meanwhile, Aunt Sally was bombarding me with questions like rain. I started trembling and was scared to death. Meanwhile, the inside of the house was getting warmer and warmer. The butter had started to melt, running down my neck and behind my ears. A little later, when one of the men said, "I say we go to the cabin first, let's go out right now and catch them when we get back," I almost fainted. At that moment, the melted butter started running down my forehead, and when Aunt Sally saw this, she turned as white as a sheet:
es: He finally arrived and started asking me questions, but I couldn't answer them properly and didn't know what to say, because those men were so nervous that some wanted to start immediately and pounce on those bandits, because as they said, there were only a few minutes left until midnight, while others tried to hold them back and wait for the signal; meanwhile, there was Aunt Sally, asking questions non-stop, and I was trembling all over and about to faint from fear, and it was getting hotter and hotter and the butter was starting to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears, until one of them goes and says: —I am about to go to the cabin immediately and catch them there when they arrive. I almost fainted and a stream of butter dripped down my forehead. When Aunt Sally saw it, she turned as white as a sheet, and she goes and says:

en: “For the land’s sake, what is the matter with the child?
vi: -Oh my God, what's wrong with the boy?
tr: “For God's sake, what happened to this child!
es: —For heaven's sake, what's wrong with this boy?

en: He’s got the brain-fever as shore as you’re born, and they’re oozing out!”
vi: It looks like he has meningitis, his brain is leaking out here.
tr: I'm sure he had brain fever, moreover, his brain started to ooze!”
es: He surely has brain fever and his brains are coming out!

en: And everybody runs to see, and she snatches off my hat, and out comes the bread and what was left of the butter, and she grabbed me, and hugged me, and says:
vi: Everyone ran over to see. She lifted the hat off my head, the piece of cake fell down, and the remaining butter stuck to my head; then she grabbed me and shook me while saying:
tr: Everyone came running, and when Aunt Sally took off my hat, the rest of the bread and butter fell with a plop. When Aunt Sally saw this, she hugged me and said:
es: Everyone came running to see what was happening, she took off my hat and with it came out the bread and what was left of the butter; then she hugged me, saying: —You gave me such a scare! And I'm so glad it's nothing worse, because we have nothing but problems, and misfortunes never come alone, and when I saw that I thought you were going to die, because I imagined from the color that it was as if your brains were going to...

en: “Oh, what a turn you did give me!
vi: - Oh, you scared me.
tr: “Ah, how you scared me!
es: My God, my God, why didn't you tell me what you had gone down to get?

en: and how glad and grateful I am it ain’t no worse; for luck’s against us, and it never rains but it pours, and when I see that truck I thought we’d lost you, for I knowed by the color and all it was just like your brains would be if—Dear, dear, whyd’nt you tell me that was what you’d been down there for, I wouldn’t a cared.
vi: It's really fortunate that it's not as bad as I thought.
tr: I am so glad that nothing bad happened, thank God; we have a terrible misfortune over our heads these days. When I saw what was oozing from your forehead, I almost died of fright, because when I saw its color and consistency, it seemed to me that your brain was leaking... My dear, why didn't you tell me why you went down to the basement, I wouldn't have been angry with you.
es: I wouldn't have minded.

en: Now cler out to bed, and don’t lemme see no more of you till morning!”
vi: Why didn't you tell me right away to stop me from worrying? Now go to sleep, don't show your face here again from now until morning.
tr: Now go to your bed, I don't want to see you around here again until morning!”
es: Now go to bed and don't let me see you again until tomorrow!

en: I was up stairs in a second, and down the lightning-rod in another one, and shinning through the dark for the lean-to.
vi: In just a second, I jumped upstairs, slid down the black pole, and slipped into the darkness heading towards the porch.
tr: In one second, I reached the stairs, in the next, I slid down the lightning rod and quickly reached the shed in the dark.
es: I went up the stairs in a second, went down the lightning rod in another, and searched for the shed in the middle of the darkness.

en: I couldn’t hardly get my words out, I was so anxious; but I told Tom as quick as I could we must jump for it now, and not a minute to lose—the house full of men, yonder, with guns!
vi: I was so worried that I couldn't say anything more. But I quickly told Tom that he had to get out immediately, not to delay even a minute, as the house was full of people, and they were carrying guns.
tr: I was so anxious that words barely came out of my mouth, but I quickly explained everything to Tom as best as I could; we had to leave immediately, there wasn't a minute to lose... The house was filled with men, all of them armed with rifles!
es: I could barely speak because I was so worried, but I told Tom as quickly as I could that we had to get out without wasting a minute: the house was full of armed men!

en: His eyes just blazed; and he says:
vi: Its face lit up, it asked:
tr: Tom's eyes sparkled.
es: His eyes shone brightly, and he goes and says:

en: “No!—is that so?
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: “No way!.. Really?
es: —No!

en: Ain’t it bully!
vi: Huck, if we perform this trick again, I think we could draw up to two hundred people.
tr: Isn't it amazing?
es: Really?

en: Why, Huck, if it was to do over again, I bet I could fetch two hundred!
vi: Huck, if we perform this trick again, I think we could draw up to two hundred people.
tr: If I had the chance to do it again, I could bring two hundred men, Huck!
es: Man, Huck, if we had to do it again, we would surely bring two hundred!

en: If we could put it off till—”
vi: How about we postpone until... I interrupted it:
tr: Actually, if I waited a bit longer...”
es: If we could postpone it...

en: “Hurry! hurry!” I says.
vi: - We have to go right away.
tr: "Hurry up!" "Hurry! I said."
es: —Quick! Quick! —I replied—.

en: “Where’s Jim?”
vi: Where is Jim?
tr: "Where is Jim?""
es: Where is Jim?

en: “Right at your elbow; if you reach out your arm you can touch him.
vi: - Next to you, just reach out and you'll touch it.
tr: "Right behind your elbow, if you extend your arm, you can touch it.
es: —Right there next to you; if you stretch out your arm, you can touch it.

en: He’s dressed, and everything’s ready.
vi: Jim has finished putting on his clothes.
tr: She put on her dress, everything is ready.
es: He's already dressed and everything else is ready.

en: Now we’ll slide out and give the sheep-signal.”
vi: Now let's sneak outside and signal.
tr: Now let's go outside and you can bleat like a sheep."
es: We can go and give the signal of the bleat.

en: But then we heard the tramp of men coming to the door, and heard them begin to fumble with the pad-lock, and heard a man say:
vi: At that moment, we heard the sound of everyone's footsteps thundering, then the sound of a lock being opened, and someone said:
tr: But at that moment, we heard the men approaching the door, and while they were trying to open the padlock by feel, we heard a man speaking:
es: But then we heard the footsteps of the men approaching the door and the noise they made when opening the padlock, and one of them said:

en: “I told you we’d be too soon; they haven’t come—the door is locked.
vi: - I said it was still too early; they haven't arrived yet, the door is still locked.
tr: “I told you we came early; they haven't arrived yet… the door is still locked.
es: —I told you it was too early; they haven't arrived: the door is closed.

en: Here, I’ll lock some of you into the cabin, and you lay for ’em in the dark and kill ’em when they come; and the rest scatter around a piece, and listen if you can hear ’em coming.”
vi: A few people went inside to hide in the dark, ready to kill them as soon as they arrived, while the others spread out a bit and listened carefully.
tr: Some of you will be locked inside the cabin and will wait in the dark to kill them when they arrive; the rest should spread out and stay alert.”
es: Come on, some of you go to the cabin, wait for them in the dark, and kill them when they arrive, and the rest of you spread out and pay attention to hear them coming.

en: So in they come, but couldn’t see us in the dark, and most trod on us whilst we was hustling to get under the bed.
vi: They stepped in, but in the darkness, they couldn't see us. They almost stepped on us while we were crawling under the bed. But we managed to crawl through and quietly slipped out.
tr: They entered, but they couldn't see us in the dark. They almost stepped on us as we scrambled under the bed.
es: So they came in, but in the darkness they couldn't see us and almost all of them stepped on us while we tried to get under the bed.

en: But we got under all right, and out through the hole, swift but soft—Jim first, me next, and Tom last, which was according to Tom’s orders.
vi: Jim went out first, then me. Tom went out last. That was according to Tom's orders.
tr: But we got under the bed without anything happening to us, quickly crawled out through the hole – according to Tom's orders, Jim went first, then me, and finally Tom.
es: But we managed to get in there and out through the hole, quickly but without making any noise. Jim first, then me, and Tom last, which was what Tom had ordered.

en: Now we was in the lean-to, and heard trampings close by outside.
vi: We crawled towards the door, Tom told us to stop and look through the crack of the door first, but it was too dark to see anything.
tr: Now we were inside the storeroom, and we could hear people moving around outside.
es: We were already in the shed and we heard the footsteps of those walking nearby.

en: So we crept to the door, and Tom stopped us there and put his eye to the crack, but couldn’t make out nothing, it was so dark; and whispered and said he would listen for the steps to get further, and when he nudged us Jim must glide out first, and him last.
vi: He nudged Jim with his elbow to signal him to crawl forward. He went last.
tr: We crawled towards the door, Tom stopped us and peered through a crack to look outside, but he couldn't see anything, it was too dark; then he turned to us and whispered that he would wait for the footsteps to fade away; when he gave the signal, Jim would go first, and he would go last.
es: So we crawled to the door and Tom stopped us there and started looking through the crack, but he couldn't see anything because it was so dark, and he whispered to us that he would listen until the footsteps moved further away, and when he nudged us, Jim had to go out first and he would go last.

en: So he set his ear to the crack and listened, and listened, and listened, and the steps a-scraping around out there all the time; and at last he nudged us, and we slid out, and stooped down, not breathing, and not making the least noise, and slipped stealthy towards the fence in Injun file, and got to it all right, and me and Jim over it; but Tom’s britches catched fast on a splinter on the top rail, and then he hear the steps coming, so he had to pull loose, which snapped the splinter and made a noise; and as he dropped in our tracks and started somebody sings out:
vi: He then pressed his ear against the crack to listen, still hearing footsteps rustling outside. After that, he nudged us, and we crawled stealthily, holding our breath, without making a sound, and continued towards the fence like the Indians. Jim and I climbed over, but Tom got his clothes caught on the top of the post and was stuck there for a while. Suddenly, hearing footsteps approaching, he had to yank hard, breaking the post with a loud snap. He just managed to run after us when a voice shouted:
tr: This time he put his ear to the crack and listened, listened, listened, but there were always people walking outside; finally, he gave us the signal and we quietly slipped out, not even breathing, moving stealthily towards the fences. We moved in a single file and reached the fence, Jim and I climbed over it, but Tom's pants got caught on a splinter at the top of the fence at the last moment, and we heard someone approaching; then Tom forced the pants and the splinter snapped with a crack; as he started following us, we heard someone shout:
es: So he put his ear to the crack and listened, listened, and listened, and the footsteps kept circling nearby all the time; finally, he nudged us and we left bent over, without breathing or making the slightest noise, sneaking in single file towards the fence until we got there and Jim and I jumped over it; but Tom got his pants caught on a splinter in the top log, so he had to pull to free himself, causing the splinter to break and make a noise, and when he dropped down to follow us, someone shouted:

en: “Who’s that?
vi: - Who's there?
tr: “Who is there?
es: —Who goes there?

en: Answer, or I’ll shoot!”
vi: Answer quickly, or I'll shoot!
tr: Answer; otherwise, I will shoot!”
es: Answer or I'll shoot!

en: But we didn’t answer; we just unfurled our heels and shoved.
vi: We didn't answer, just kept our heads down and ran.
tr: But we did not answer, instead, we spread our compasses and started to run away quickly.
es: But we didn't respond; we stood up and started running.

en: Then there was a rush, and a bang, bang, bang!
vi: A group of people rushed over. Bang, bang, bang!
tr: There was a commotion behind us, bam, bam, bam!
es: Then we heard some running and a bang, bang, bang!, and how the bullets whistled!

en: and the bullets fairly whizzed around us!
vi: Bullets whizzed around us.
tr: and bullets whizzed around us!
es: Then we heard some running and a bang, bang, bang!, and how the bullets whistled!

en: We heard them sing out:
vi: They shouted:
tr: One of them was heard shouting:
es: We heard them shout:

en: “Here they are!
vi: - Here they are!
tr: “There they are!
es: —There they are!

en: They’ve broke for the river!
vi: They're running to the riverbank!
tr: They are heading towards the river!
es: They're going to the river!

en: After ’em, boys, and turn loose the dogs!”
vi: Brothers, chase after them. Release them quickly!
tr: Follow them, gentlemen! Release the dogs!”
es: Let's follow them, boys, and release the dogs!

en: So here they come, full tilt.
vi: They rushed in.
tr: They were all coming after us at once.
es: So they started running at full speed.

en: We could hear them because they wore boots and yelled, but we didn’t wear no boots and didn’t yell.
vi: We could hear them clearly because they wore boots and shouted, while we neither wore boots nor shouted.
tr: We could hear them because they had boots on and were shouting, but we didn't have boots, and we weren't shouting.
es: We could hear them well because they were wearing boots and shouting, but we neither wore boots nor shouted.

en: We was in the path to the mill; and when they got pretty close on to us we dodged into the bush and let them go by, and then dropped in behind them.
vi: We turned onto the small path leading to the workshop. When they ran close behind us, we stepped aside and hid in the bushes to let them pass, then stepped out and ran behind them.
tr: We were on the road to the mill, and when they got close enough, we dove into the bushes and waited for them to pass, then continued on the road behind them.
es: We were heading towards the mill, and when they got very close, we hid among the bushes, let them pass, and then got behind them.

en: They’d had all the dogs shut up, so they wouldn’t scare off the robbers; but by this time somebody had let them loose, and here they come, making powwow enough for a million; but they was our dogs; so we stopped in our tracks till they catched up; and when they see it warn’t nobody but us, and no excitement to offer them, they only just said howdy, and tore right ahead towards the shouting and clattering; and then we up-steam again, and whizzed along after them till we was nearly to the mill, and then struck up through the bush to where my canoe was tied, and hopped in and pulled for dear life towards the middle of the river, but didn’t make no more noise than we was obleeged to.
vi: The dogs came running, barking loudly as if there were a million of them. We stood still, waiting for the dogs to reach us. They were all domestic dogs, so when they saw us, they wagged their tails happily and then ran ahead following the people who were rummaging and shouting. Then we turned back up towards the river, whistling casually behind them; we walked near the workshop and then turned into the bushes where my boat was tied. We all jumped into the boat and rowed to the middle of the river, trying not to make too much noise.
tr: They had silenced the dogs so they wouldn't scare off the robbers, but now someone had let them loose, and here they were coming, barking madly, but they were our dogs; so we waited for them to catch up to us, and when they saw us, all their excitement died down; after a few murmurs, they continued barking and running towards the shouting ahead; we started running after them and almost reached the mill, at one point diving into the bushes and getting to where my canoe was tied, we got into the canoe and started paddling towards the middle of the river with all our might, but we were definitely not making more noise than necessary.
es: They had kept the dogs very quiet so as not to scare the thieves, but now they had let them loose and they were making so much noise it was as if there were a million of them, but they were ours, so we stopped until they reached us, and when they saw that it was just us and that we offered no adventure, they simply greeted us and ran off towards where the noises and shouts were coming from, and we went back up towards the river, running behind them until we almost reached the mill and then we came out from the bushes where my canoe was tied, got into it and started rowing like mad towards the middle of the river, making no more noise than necessary.

en: Then we struck out, easy and comfortable, for the island where my raft was; and we could hear them yelling and barking at each other all up and down the bank, till we was so far away the sounds got dim and died out.
vi: So we rowed away, gently and comfortably, heading towards the island where I had hidden the raft. We could still hear people shouting and dogs barking along the riverbank. It wasn't until we had gone far that those sounds gradually faded and disappeared completely.
tr: We proceeded comfortably towards the island where my raft was hidden; we could hear those behind us shouting and barking on the shore, but then we got quite far away and the sounds gradually faded.
es: Then we calmly set the bow towards the island where my raft was and heard them shouting and barking at each other up the riverbank, until we were so far that the noises faded and disappeared.

en: And when we stepped onto the raft I says:
vi: Once on the raft, I said:
tr: When we got onto the raft, I said:
es: When we reached the raft, I went and said:

en: “Now, old Jim, you’re a free man again, and I bet you won’t ever be a slave no more.”
vi: - Jim, you are free now, and you will probably never have to be a slave again.
tr: "Now you are a free man again, big Jim, and you will never be a slave to anyone again."
es: —Now, old Jim, you are free again, and I bet you will never be a slave again.

en: “En a mighty good job it wuz, too, Huck.
vi: We were all very delighted.
tr: "You did a very good job, Huck.
es: —And you did very well, Huck; it was very well planned and very well executed, and there is no one in the world who can make a plan as complicated and splendid as this one.

en: It ’uz planned beautiful, en it ’uz done beautiful; en dey ain’t nobody kin git up a plan dat’s mo’ mixed-up en splendid den what dat one wuz.”
vi: We were all very delighted.
tr: It was a very nice plan, everything went very well; no one else could come up with such a complex and real plan."
es: —And you did very well, Huck; it was very well planned and very well executed, and there is no one in the world who can make a plan as complicated and splendid as this one.

en: We was all glad as we could be, but Tom was the gladdest of all because he had a bullet in the calf of his leg.
vi: But Tom was the most delighted because he got a bullet in his calf.
tr: We were all very content with our situation, but the most content among us was Tom, because he had taken a bullet to his calf.
es: We were all very happy, but Tom was the happiest of all because he had been shot in the calf.

en: When me and Jim heard that we didn’t feel so brash as what we did before.
vi: Jim and I heard it and couldn't be happy anymore.
tr: When Jim and I heard this, the joy we felt for being saved was short-lived.
es: When Jim and I found out, we didn't feel as happy as before.

en: It was hurting him considerable, and bleeding; so we laid him in the wigwam and tore up one of the duke’s shirts for to bandage him, but he says:
vi: The wound hurt him a lot, and there was a lot of blood. We put him in the tent and tore one of the duke's shirts that was left there to bandage him. But he said:
tr: He was in a lot of pain and was bleeding; we laid him inside the shelter and tore one of the duke's shirts to bandage his wound.
