es: It hurt him a lot and he was bleeding, so we laid him down in the wigwam and tore one of the duke's shirts to bandage him, but he goes and says:

en: “Gimme the rags; I can do it myself.
vi: - Let me do it.
tr: “Give me the cloths, I can do it myself,” he said.
es: —Give me those strips; I can do it myself.

en: Don’t stop now; don’t fool around here, and the evasion booming along so handsome; man the sweeps, and set her loose!
vi: Don't stop here, that's the only way the escape will succeed.
tr: “Don’t stop; there’s no point in lingering here any longer, this retreat news will echo everywhere soon; to the helm, untie the rope!
es: Now don't stop, don't stay around here, with an escape going so well. To the oars and let's go!

en: Boys, we done it elegant!
vi: Let the raft go!
tr: We did a very neat job, kids!.. It was really very neat.
es: Boys, it turned out great!

en: —’deed we did.
vi: We did it very skillfully, truly skillfully.
tr: XVI.
es: Really, it did.

en: I wish we’d a had the handling of Louis XVI., there wouldn’t a been no ‘Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven!’ wrote down in his biography; no, sir, we’d a whooped him over the border—that’s what we’d a done with him—and done it just as slick as nothing at all, too.
vi: I think we have the talent of Louis the Sixteenth, no, we have surpassed that. We did it as easily as playing.
tr: If only they had given us the responsibility for Louis XVI’s escape, his biography wouldn’t say, “The son of Saint Louis ascended to heaven!”; no, sir, we would have whisked him across the border in no time… that’s how we would have made him retreat… as easily as pulling a hair out of butter. To the helm…
es: I wish we had been in charge of Louis XVI's escape, and then in his biography they wouldn't have written that "Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven"; no, sir; we would have made him cross the border, that's what we would have done with him and with great ease: to the oars... to the oars!

en: Man the sweeps—man the sweeps!”
vi: Alright, let's go, hurry up.
tr: To the helm!”
es: I wish we had been in charge of Louis XVI's escape, and then in his biography they wouldn't have written that "Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven"; no, sir; we would have made him cross the border, that's what we would have done with him and with great ease: to the oars... to the oars!

en: But me and Jim was consulting—and thinking.
vi: Jim and I looked at each other thoughtfully.
tr: But Jim and I were talking on one hand and thinking on the other.
es: But Jim and I were consulting each other, and thinking, and after a minute or so I go and say:

en: And after we’d thought a minute, I says:
vi: A minute later, I said
tr: “Tell me, Jim,” I said after about a minute.
es: But Jim and I were consulting each other, and thinking, and after a minute or so I go and say:

en: “Say it, Jim.”
vi: - Jim, speak up!
tr: “Tell me, Jim,” I said after about a minute.
es: —You say it, Jim.

en: So he says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: He started to speak:
es: And he says:

en: “Well, den, dis is de way it look to me, Huck.
vi: - I think this way, Huck.
tr: “Let me tell you this from my own perspective, Huck.
es: —Well, this is what it seems to me, Huck: if it were him we were freeing and one of the boys got shot, would he say: "Go ahead, save me and don't think about a doctor to save that other one"?

en: Ef it wuz him dat ’uz bein’ sot free, en one er de boys wuz to git shot, would he say, ‘Go on en save me, nemmine ’bout a doctor f’r to save dis one?’
vi: Suppose you were the one being rescued, and one of your rescuers got injured, would you have the heart to leave that injured person to wait for death?
tr: If we had caught Tom and someone got hurt, wouldn't we have said, 'Don't waste time trying to catch me, go find a doctor'?
es: —Well, this is what it seems to me, Huck: if it were him we were freeing and one of the boys got shot, would he say: "Go ahead, save me and don't think about a doctor to save that other one"?

en: Is dat like Mars Tom Sawyer?
vi: Probably not!
tr: Is this something Master Tom Sawyer would say?
es: Would Tom Sawyer do that?

en: Would he say dat?
vi: And Jim wouldn't do that either.
tr: Would he say such a thing?
es: Would he say that?

en: You bet he wouldn’t!
vi: If there is no doctor, Jim definitely won't leave this place even if he has to wait for forty more years.
tr: He would never say that!
es: You can bet he wouldn't!

en: Well, den, is Jim gywne to say it?
vi: I, Jim, am speaking very sincerely.
tr: Well then, would Jim say such a thing?
es: Well then, are you going to say it, Jim?

en: No, sah—I doan’ budge a step out’n dis place ’dout a doctor; not if it’s forty year!”
vi: I told Tom to let me go find a doctor.
tr: No, master... if a doctor isn't found, I won't take a step from here, even if it takes forty years!”
es: No, sir, I won't take a step out of here without a doctor; even if it takes forty years.

en: I knowed he was white inside, and I reckoned he’d say what he did say—so it was all right now, and I told Tom I was a-going for a doctor.
vi: I told Tom to let me go find a doctor.
tr: I knew deep down that he was white and I had predicted that he would say so – in this situation, there was nothing to be done, so I told Tom that I would go and bring a doctor.
es: I already knew that inside he was white and I figured he was going to say what he had said, so now everything was fine and I told Tom that I was going to look for a doctor.

en: He raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and wouldn’t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose himself; but we wouldn’t let him.
vi: He insisted on not listening; but Jim and I also wouldn't give in. He tried to crawl out from the raft's side, but we didn't let him do that either.
tr: He objected a lot, yelled and screamed, but Jim and I absolutely did not change our minds; upon this, he tried to crawl and untie the raft, but we did not allow that either.
es: He started to make a fuss, but Jim and I stood firm and didn't want to give in; so he said he would get off and untie the raft by himself; but we didn't let him.

en: Then he give us a piece of his mind, but it didn’t do no good.
vi: He grumbled for a while, then stopped.
tr: He tried to give us advice – but that didn’t work either.
es: Then he scolded us, but it was to no avail.

en: So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:
vi: Seeing that I had prepared the room, it said:
tr: When he saw that I was preparing the tea, he called out from where he was lying:
es: So when he saw me preparing the canoe, he said:

en: “Well, then, if you’re bound to go, I’ll tell you the way to do when you get to the village.
vi: - Fine, if you are determined to go, I will tell you what needs to be done when you enter the village.
tr: “Since you say you will go, let me tell you what to do when you reach the town.
es: —Well, then, if you have to go, I'm going to tell you what you should do when you get to the village.

en: Shut the door and blindfold the doctor tight and fast, and make him swear to be silent as the grave, and put a purse full of gold in his hand, and then take and lead him all around the back alleys and everywheres in the dark, and then fetch him here in the canoe, in a roundabout way amongst the islands, and search him and take his chalk away from him, and don’t give it back to him till you get him back to the village, or else he will chalk this raft so he can find it again.
vi: You close the door, blindfold the doctor, and tie him up tightly. Tell him he must remain silent, then place a bundle of gold in his hand, take him through all the shortcuts and alleys in the dark, then lead him down to the boat and take a round trip around the islands. You must search all his pockets, not letting him keep a single piece of chalk, otherwise he will use the chalk to mark this raft and later find his way back.
tr: When you enter, close the door and immediately blindfold the doctor, then make him swear to take our secret to the grave and leave a pouch of gold in his hand, then take him down to the shore through dark back alleys and deserted roads, put him in a canoe and bring him here by navigating through the islands, search him and if he has chalk in his pocket, take it, and do not give it back until you take him back to the town, otherwise he will mark this raft with chalk to find it later.
es: You close the door and blindfold the doctor very well and make him swear that his lips are sealed; you give him a bag full of gold coins and then take him out and lead him around all the alleys in the dark. Then you bring him here in the canoe, turning between the islands, search him and take the chalk away from him and don't give it back until he has returned to the village, because if not, he will mark the raft with chalk to find it again.

en: It’s the way they all do.”
vi: I promise to do exactly that, while Jim must hide in the forest until he sees the doctor come and leave the raft before returning.
tr: They always do this.”
es: That's what everyone does.

en: So I said I would, and left, and Jim was to hide in the woods when he see the doctor coming till he was gone again.
vi: I promise to do exactly that, while Jim must hide in the forest until he sees the doctor come and leave the raft before returning.
tr: I walked away, saying I would do exactly as told, and Jim would hide among the trees when he saw the doctor coming, then reappear once he left.
es: So we told him we would do it and left, and Jim had to hide in the forest when he saw the doctor coming until he left again.

en: CHAPTER XLI.
vi: Chapter XLI
tr: Chapter Forty-One
es: Chapter 41

en: The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up.
vi: The doctor is an elderly person and seems kind.
tr: The doctor was an old man; more precisely, he was an extremely polite and chubby old man when I woke him up.
es: THE DOCTOR WAS OLD; a very nice and kind old man.

en: I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting yesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and about midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off and shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it and not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted to come home this evening and surprise the folks.
vi: I woke him up and told him that my brother and I were on the Spanish island hunting since yesterday afternoon on a raft. In the middle of the night, unfortunately, I accidentally pulled the trigger while dreaming. The gun went off and hit my leg. So I invited the doctor to come and treat it, and not to say anything about this, not to let anyone know, because tonight we want to return home and surprise our family.
tr: I told him that my brother and I had set up camp on a raft we found while hunting on Spanish Island yesterday afternoon, that he had kicked his rifle in his sleep at midnight, and that the rifle had gone off and shot him in the leg; we wanted him to come and treat my brother and not tell anyone, because we intended to return home this evening and surprise our folks.
es: When I woke him up, I told him that my brother and I were on Española Island hunting yesterday afternoon and had camped on a piece of raft we found, but that, around midnight, I must have hit the shotgun while dreaming, because it went off and hit him in the leg. We wanted him to go treat it without saying anything or telling anyone, because we intended to go home that afternoon to surprise the family.

en: “Who is your folks?” he says.
vi: He asked: - Who are your family members?
tr: "Who are your people?" he asked.
es: —What family are you from? —he asks.

en: “The Phelpses, down yonder.”
vi: - The Phelps house, down there.
tr: “The Phelpses who live down there.”
es: —From the Phelps family, down the river.

en: “Oh,” he says.
vi: - Ah, I see.
tr: “Haa,” he said.
es: —Ah —he says, and after a minute he repeats—:

en: And after a minute, he says:
vi: Later, he asked again:
tr: A minute later, he asked, “How did you say he was shot?”
es: —Ah —he says, and after a minute he repeats—:

en: “How’d you say he got shot?”
vi: - How did you say your friend got injured?
tr: A minute later, he asked, “How did you say he was shot?”
es: How did you say he shot himself?

en: “He had a dream,” I says, “and it shot him.”
vi: - He was sleepwalking and then got shot.
tr: “He kicked in his dream,” I said, “and the rifle went off.”
es: —He had a dream and shot himself —I replied to him.

en: “Singular dream,” he says.
vi: - Strange!
tr: “So, in his dream,” he said.
es: —Strange dream —he commented.

en: So he lit up his lantern, and got his saddle-bags, and we started.
vi: Then the doctor lit the lamp, grabbed his medicine bag, and went out.
tr: He lit his lantern, took his bag, and we set off.
es: So he lit the lantern, grabbed the first aid kit, and we set off.

en: But when he sees the canoe he didn’t like the look of her—said she was big enough for one, but didn’t look pretty safe for two.
vi: But when he saw the boat, he didn't like it, saying that it was too small, just enough for one person, and not safe for two people.
tr: But when he saw the canoe, his face fell – he said that the canoe would be enough for one person, but it didn't look very safe for two.
es: But when he saw the canoe, he didn't like it; he said it was fine for one person, but it didn't seem safe for two.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: "You have nothing to worry about, sir, it carried the three of us comfortably," I said.
es: And I go and say:

en: “Oh, you needn’t be afeard, sir, she carried the three of us easy enough.”
vi: - Don't worry, sir, the three of us are still sitting comfortably.
tr: "You have nothing to worry about, sir, it carried the three of us comfortably," I said.
es: —Ah, don't be afraid, sir, he took all three of us with ease.

en: “What three?”
vi: - Why are there three people?
tr: “Three?”
es: —What three?

en: “Why, me and Sid, and—and—and the guns; that’s what I mean.”
vi: - Me, Sid, and... and... the gun makes three.
tr: “Ben, Sid and… and… rifles; I meant rifles.”
es: —Well, for me and Sid... and... and the shotguns; that's what I meant to say.

en: “Oh,” he says.
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: “Haa,” he said.
es: —Ah.

en: But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he’d look around for a bigger one.
vi: He stepped onto the side of the boat, tested it, then shook his head and said he would have to find a bigger boat, but all the boats were chained and locked.
tr: But she put her foot on the gunwale and gave the canoe a little test; shaking her head, she said we needed to find a bigger one.
es: But he put his foot on the gunwale and made it move, shook his head, and said he would look for a bigger one.

en: But they was all locked and chained; so he took my canoe, and said for me to wait till he come back, or I could hunt around further, or maybe I better go down home and get them ready for the surprise if I wanted to.
vi: He stepped onto the side of the boat, tested it, then shook his head and said he would have to find a bigger boat, but all the boats were chained and locked.
tr: However, all the canoes were locked and chained; so she took my canoe and told me to wait until she returned, suggesting that I could either fish a bit more or go home and prepare our folks for a surprise.
es: But they were all chained and locked, so he got into my canoe and said to wait until he came back, or that if I couldn't keep looking, or maybe it would be better to go home and prepare the family for the surprise, if that's what I wanted.

en: But I said I didn’t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.
vi: So he climbed back into my boat and told me to wait for him to return.
tr: But I said I wouldn't go anywhere, described to her how to find the raft, and she set off.
es: But I told him no, so I explained how to find the raft and he set off.

en: I struck an idea pretty soon.
vi: I suddenly had an idea.
tr: Before long, I started to have second thoughts.
es: Then an idea occurred to me.

en: I says to myself, spos’n he can’t fix that leg just in three shakes of a sheep’s tail, as the saying is?
vi: I told myself: what if he can't cure Tom's leg right away?
tr: What if Tom couldn't finish treating his leg in one go, what if it took three or four days?
es: I said to myself: "What if he can't fix his leg in a jiffy, as the saying goes?

en: spos’n it takes him three or four days?
vi: What if it takes three or four days to heal?
tr: What if Tom couldn't finish treating his leg in one go, what if it took three or four days?
es: What if it takes him three or four days?

en: What are we going to do?—lay around there till he lets the cat out of the bag?
vi: What would we do? Wait there until he finishes?
tr: What would we do then? Were we supposed to wait until the doctor raised a fuss?
es: What are we going to do? Wait around until he tells someone?

en: No, sir; I know what I’ll do.
vi: What should I do then?
tr: No sir, I knew exactly what I was going to do.
es: No, sir; I know what I'm going to do.

en: I’ll wait, and when he comes back if he says he’s got to go any more I’ll get down there, too, if I swim; and we’ll take and tie him, and keep him, and shove out down the river; and when Tom’s done with him we’ll give him what it’s worth, or all we got, and then let him get ashore.
vi: I will wait, and whenever he comes back, if he says he won't go anymore, I will go down there, swim down if necessary, we will capture and tie him up, then take him down there, and after he finishes treating Tom, we will reward him with everything we have. Then we will let him go ashore.
tr: I would wait, and if he said he needed to come back when he arrived, I would swim after him the second time; then I would trick him, tie him up, and we would take the raft and set off; once Tom was done with him, we would pay him whatever he asked, even give him everything we had in our pockets, and leave him on the shore.
es: I'll wait, and when he comes back, if he says he has to return, I'll go with him even if I have to swim, we'll tie him up and take him down the river, and when Tom is healed we'll pay him whatever it takes, or everything we have, and then we'll let him disembark."

en: So then I crept into a lumber-pile to get some sleep; and next time I waked up the sun was away up over my head!
vi: Then I lay back on the pile of wood nearby to take a quick nap. When I woke up, I saw the sun was directly overhead.
tr: So, I leaned my back against a pile of wood and fell asleep; when I woke up, the sun had already risen!
es: So I got into a pile of firewood to sleep a bit, and when I woke up, the sun was already quite high.

en: I shot out and went for the doctor’s house, but they told me he’d gone away in the night some time or other, and warn’t back yet.
vi: I jumped up and ran straight to the doctor's house, but they said the doctor had left the night before and hadn't returned yet.
tr: I immediately rushed to the doctor's house, but they told me he had gone to see a patient at night and hadn't returned yet.
es: I ran to the doctor's house but they told me he had left at night and hadn't come back yet.

en: Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off.
vi: I thought to myself, this is really bad for Tom. I have to go to the island right away.
tr: That means Tom's condition is very bad, I thought, so I should go to the island immediately.
es: “Well,” I thought, “it seems like Tom is doing poorly, so I'm heading straight to the island.”

en: So away I shoved, and turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas’s stomach!
vi: I turned around, and at the corner of the road, I bumped right into Uncle Silas's stomach.
tr: I set off right away and turned the corner, but I almost headbutted Uncle Silas in the stomach!
es: And I set off, but when I turned the corner, I almost ran straight into Uncle Silas.

en: He says:
vi: He asked:
tr: “Tom!
es: He goes and says:

en: “Why, Tom!
vi: - Oh, Tom, where have you been all this time?
tr: “Tom!
es: —Hey, Tom!

en: Where you been all this time, you rascal?”
vi: - Oh, Tom, where have you been all this time?
tr: Where have you been for hours, you rascal?” he said.
es: Where have you been all this time, rascal?

en: “I hain’t been nowheres,” I says, “only just hunting for the runaway nigger—me and Sid.”
vi: - I'm not going anywhere, Sid and I are chasing the runaway black man.
tr: “I was nowhere,” I said, “I was just after that runaway black man... me and Sid.”
es: —I haven't been anywhere —I said—, except hunting the runaway black man with Sid.

en: “Why, where ever did you go?” he says.
vi: - Where have you been?
tr: "So where did you go?" he asked.
es: —Well, where have you been? —he asks—.

en: “Your aunt’s been mighty uneasy.”
vi: Your aunt is worried sick about you.
tr: "Your aunt was almost going to lose her mind."
es: Your aunt was worried.

en: “She needn’t,” I says, “because we was all right.
vi: I replied
tr: “There was no need to panic,” I said, “because we are both fine.
es: —Well, there was no reason —I said—, because it was very good.

en: We followed the men and the dogs, but they outrun us, and we lost them; but we thought we heard them on the water, so we got a canoe and took out after them and crossed over, but couldn’t find nothing of them; so we cruised along up-shore till we got kind of tired and beat out; and tied up the canoe and went to sleep, and never waked up till about an hour ago; then we paddled over here to hear the news, and Sid’s at the post-office to see what he can hear, and I’m a-branching out to get something to eat for us, and then we’re going home.”
vi: - Auntie, don't worry, we're fine. We ran after the people with the dogs, but they ran too fast, and we got lost. Then we thought we heard them by the river, so we took the boat to chase them and crossed to the other side of the river, but we still couldn't find them. Then we went ashore to rest, we were so tired, we tied the boat and took a nap, we just woke up an hour ago. After that, we rowed the boat back here to get some news. Sid ran to the post office to gather information, and I came here to find something to eat before we head home.
tr: We followed the men and the dogs, but they were faster than us, so we lost them after a while; at one point, we thought the sounds were coming from the river, so we got into a canoe and went after them, we went across but saw no one; we tried to come back up the river, but we were exhausted; we tied the canoe somewhere and fell asleep and woke up just an hour ago, then came here to find out what happened, Sid went to the post office thinking someone might have heard something, and I was going to get something to eat, then we were going to come home.”
es: We followed the men and the dogs, but they ran faster than us and we got lost, but we thought we had heard them in the water, so we took out a canoe, followed them and crossed to the other side, but we didn't see them; then we followed the riverbank upstream until we got tired, tied up the canoe and fell asleep, and we haven't woken up until an hour ago; then we came rowing to see what was happening and Sid has gone to the post office to see if he finds out anything and I'm walking around to see if I can get something to eat before going home.

en: So then we went to the post-office to get “Sid”; but just as I suspicioned, he warn’t there; so the old man he got a letter out of the office, and we waited a while longer, but Sid didn’t come; so the old man said, come along, let Sid foot it home, or canoe it, when he got done fooling around—but we would ride.
vi: So both of them went to the post office to look for Sid. But I knew, of course, that Sid wasn't there. My uncle received a new letter that had just arrived. We waited a little longer without seeing Sid.
tr: Upon this, we went to the post office to find "Sid"; but just as I "suspected", he wasn't there; the old man received a letter from the post office, we waited a bit longer but Sid didn't show up; then the old man suggested that we leave, Sid could walk home or come down by canoe after dawdling enough, but we would go by horse.
es: So we went to the post office to look for "Sid," but as I suspected, he wasn't there; so the old man picked up a letter that had arrived for him and we waited a while longer. Since Sid didn't show up, the old man said we should leave and that Sid could walk home, or take the canoe, when he finished fooling around in town, but that we would return in the cart.

en: I couldn’t get him to let me stay and wait for Sid; and he said there warn’t no use in it, and I must come along, and let Aunt Sally see we was all right.
vi: He said we should go home to let Aunt Sally know we were okay, and that Sid would find his way back on his own.
tr: He didn't let me stay and wait for Sid; he said it wouldn't be of any use; I had to go with him and tell Aunt Sally that we were both fine.
es: I couldn't get him to let me stay to wait for Sid, because he said it wouldn't do any good, and I had to go back with him so Aunt Sally could see that we were all right.

en: When we got home Aunt Sally was that glad to see me she laughed and cried both, and hugged me, and give me one of them lickings of hern that don’t amount to shucks, and said she’d serve Sid the same when he come.
vi: When we got home, Aunt Sally was overjoyed, half laughing, half crying, hugging me tightly, giving me a delicious cake, and she said Sid would get the same when he returned.
tr: Aunt Sally was so pleased to see me when we arrived that she hugged me while both laughing and crying at the same time, then gave me a good spanking, but it almost didn't hurt at all. She said she would do the same to Sid when he arrived.
es: When we got home, Aunt Sally was so happy to see me that she started laughing and crying at the same time while hugging me and giving me one of those beatings of hers that you couldn't even feel, and then she said she would do the same to Sid when he got home.

en: And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard.
vi: The house was crowded with people, they were eating, drinking, and talking noisily.
tr: The inside of the house was filled with farmers who had come for dinner and their wives; there was more chatter than I had ever heard in my life.
es: The house was full of farmers and their wives who had come to eat and wouldn't stop talking.

en: Old ms Hotchkiss was the worst; her tongue was a-going all the time.
vi: Mrs. Hotchkiss kept chattering incessantly.
tr: The worst was old Mrs. Hotchkiss, her tongue never stopped working:
es: The worst was old Mrs. Hotchkiss, who was chattering away like there was no tomorrow.

en: She says:
vi: Mrs. Hotchkiss kept chattering incessantly.
tr: The worst was old Mrs. Hotchkiss, her tongue never stopped working:
es: She goes and says:

en: “Well, Sister Phelps, I’ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an’ I b’lieve the nigger was crazy.
vi: - Ms. Phelps, I went to see that cell, and I found that black man really strange.
tr: “I turned that cabin upside down, Brother Phelps, I had no doubt that the Negro was insane.
es: —Well, Sister Phelps, I've searched that cabin everywhere and I think the black man was crazy.

en: I says to Sister Damrell—didn’t I, Sister Damrell?—s’I, he’s crazy, s’I—them’s the very words I said.
vi: I also told Ms. Damrell the same thing, didn't I, Ms. Damrell?
tr: I was just telling Brother Damrell… didn't I say so, Brother Damrell?.. I was saying he was truly mad… I said it exactly like that.
es: I told Sister Damrell, didn't I, Sister Damrell? I said, he's crazy, with these very words.

en: You all hearn me: he’s crazy, s’I; everything shows it, s’I.
vi: Well, it's really bizarre.
tr: You all heard me: I said he was a lunatic; everything points to it.
es: You've all heard me: he's crazy, that's what I say; and it shows in everything.

en: Look at that-air grindstone, s’I; want to tell me’t any cretur ’t’s in his right mind ’s a goin’ to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s’I?
vi: Just look at that grinding stone and you'll see.
tr: Looking at the state of that millstone, no sane creature would write such nonsensical, crazy things on a millstone, I said.
es: Just look at that millstone, that's what I say; no one can tell me that someone who goes and writes all those crazy things on a millstone isn't crazy, that's what I say.

en: Here sich ’n’ sich a person busted his heart; ’n’ here so ’n’ so pegged along for thirty-seven year, ’n’ all that—natcherl son o’ Louis somebody, ’n’ sich everlast’n rubbage.
vi: Things like a broken heart, living miserably for thirty-seven years, then the child of Louis... so many things.
tr: No sir, this man's heart is broken, no sir, he's been there for thirty-seven years… he was even the son of someone named Louis, and a lot more nonsense.
es: Here this person had their heart broken, and that one suffered for thirty-seven years, and all that: natural son of Louis something-or-other, and all those nonsense.

en: He’s plumb crazy, s’I; it’s what I says in the fust place, it’s what I says in the middle, ’n’ it’s what I says last ’n’ all the time—the nigger’s crazy—crazy ’s Nebokoodneezer, s’I.”
vi: This black man is really bizarre!
tr: Look at the trouble of the madman, I realized it from the very beginning, I said the same thing there, and I'm saying it now… that Negro is a lunatic… even crazier than Nebuchadnezzar.”
es: He's nuts, that's what I say and I say it to begin with, in the middle, and to end with: that black man is crazy; he's crazy; crazier than Nebuchadnezzar, that's what I say.

en: “An’ look at that-air ladder made out’n rags, Sister Hotchkiss,” says old ms Damrell; “what in the name o’ goodness could he ever want of—”
vi: Mrs. Damrell said:
tr: “That cloth ladder he made, Hotchkiss Brother,” said old Mrs. Damrell, “For God's sake, what could he have made it for?..”
es: —If you only need to look at that ladder made of rags, Sister Hotchkiss —says old Mrs. Damrell—; why on earth would anyone want...

en: “The very words I was a-sayin’ no longer ago th’n this minute to Sister Utterback, ’n’ she’ll tell you so herself.
vi: Mrs. Damrell said:
tr: “I was just telling Brother Utterback the same thing, look, ask him if you want, he will tell you.
es: —The same thing I was saying a moment ago to Sister Utterback, and if not, let her say so.

en: Sh-she, look at that-air rag ladder, sh-she; ’n’ s’I, yes, look at it, s’I—what could he a-wanted of it, s’I. Sh-she, Sister Hotchkiss, sh-she—”
vi: - But that ladder made entirely of rags, I wonder what it uses that for?
tr: I took a look at that rope ladder… yes, I looked carefully and wondered why he made it. Ask Mrs. Hotchkiss, she will tell you…”
es: She has seen that rag ladder, that's what I say; yes, look at it, that's what I say; what was I going to do with it? Sister Hotchkiss says...

en: “But how in the nation’d they ever git that grindstone in there, anyway?
vi: - But how did it manage to bring the millstone in there?
tr: “So how did they get that huge millstone in there?
es: —But, how the heck did they get that millstone in there?

en: ’n’ who dug that-air hole?
vi: Who dug that hole?
tr: Who dug that hole?
es: And, who made the hole?

en: ’n’ who—”
vi: - I was just about to ask that.
tr: Who…”
es: And, who...?

en: “My very words, Brer Penrod!
vi: How on earth did he manage to bring that millstone in there?
tr: “That's what I said, Brother Penrod!
es: "That's what I say, brother Penrod!"

en: I was a-sayin’—pass that-air sasser o’ m’lasses, won’t ye?
vi: Did he carry it all by himself?
tr: I told you… you went through that hole, didn’t you?..
es: "I was saying, pass me that little plate of molasses, please, I was saying to sister Dunlap a minute ago, how did they get that mill wheel in there?"

en: —I was a-sayin’ to Sister Dunlap, jist this minute, how did they git that grindstone in there, s’I.
vi: There must have been someone helping him, no, a lot of people helping; it must have taken more than a dozen people to help that black guy.
tr: I was just telling Brother Dunlap that, how did they get that big millstone there, I said.
es: "I was saying, pass me that little plate of molasses, please, I was saying to sister Dunlap a minute ago, how did they get that mill wheel in there?"

en: Without help, mind you—’thout help!
vi: If I find out who they are, I'll skin all the black people in this area!
tr: And without any help… without anyone helping!
es: "And without help, mind you, without help!"

en: Thar’s wher ’tis.
vi: Damn!
tr: That's the issue.
es: "That's the point."

en: Don’t tell me, s’I; there wuz help, s’I; ’n’ ther’ wuz a plenty help, too, s’I; ther’s ben a dozen a-helpin’ that nigger, ’n’ I lay I’d skin every last nigger on this place but I’d find out who done it, s’I; ’n’ moreover, s’I—”
vi: - More than a dozen people?
tr: It's obvious that someone from outside helped, and what help it was, at least a dozen people helped that black man, if I were in your place, I would skin every black person here if necessary to find out who helped, in fact, if it were up to me…”
es: "Don't tell me, I say; they had help, I say, and a lot of help, that's what I say; heaps of help, I say; a dozen helped that black man, and as for me, I'd whip all the blacks here until I found out who they were, that's what I say; and, furthermore, I say..."

en: “A dozen says you!—forty couldn’t a done every thing that’s been done.
vi: Even forty people couldn't finish all that stuff.
tr: “You say a dozen!.. To do that much work, at least forty people would be needed.
es: —A dozen, you say! Not even forty could have done so many things.

en: Look at them case-knife saws and things, how tedious they’ve been made; look at that bed-leg sawed off with ’m, a week’s work for six men; look at that nigger made out’n straw on the bed; and look at—”
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: Look at this saw made from a pocket knife, how meticulously they worked; see how the leg of the bed was cut, that job would take six people a week to finish; didn't you see what they put on the bed made of straw?..”
es: Just look at those saws made from kitchen knives and everything else, the care with which they are made; just look at the leg of that cot sawed with them, which is a week's work for six men... Just look at that black doll made of straw on the bed and just look at...

en: “You may well say it, Brer Hightower!
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: “Well, that's right, you said it, Brother Hightower!
es: —You are absolutely right, Brother Hightower!

en: It’s jist as I was a-sayin’ to Brer Phelps, his own self.
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: I was just telling Brother Phelps the same thing.
es: That's what I was telling Brother Phelps here.

en: S’e, what do you think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s’e?
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: What do you say, Brother Hotchkiss?
es: He says, "What do you think of all this, Sister Hotchkiss?", he says.

en: Think o’ what, Brer Phelps, s’I?
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: I wonder what Brother Phelps thinks?
es: What do I think of what, Brother Phelps?, I say.

en: Think o’ that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s’e?
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: When he sees the bedpost cut like that?
es: "What do you think of the bed of that cot being sawed like that?", he says.

en: think of it, s’I?
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: When he sees the bedpost cut like that?
es: What do I think?, I say.

en: I lay it never sawed itself off, s’I—somebody sawed it, s’I; that’s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn’t be no ’count, s’I, but sich as ’t is, it’s my opinion, s’I, ’n’ if any body k’n start a better one, s’I, let him do it, s’I, that’s all.
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: Just think about it; that's how I see it, whether you accept it or not; maybe no one will accept it, but still, that's my opinion, if anyone has a better idea, let them come forward and say it.
es: What I think is that it didn't saw itself, I say; someone did it, I say; that's my opinion, for what it's worth; maybe it's worth nothing, I say, but whether it's worth something or not, it's my opinion, I say, and if someone has a better one, I say, let them say it, I say, and that's all.

en: I says to Sister Dunlap, s’I—”
vi: It's exhausting, and then there's the bed leg that's been sawed off, it would take six people a whole week to finish, and the black man made of straw placed on the bed, and then the...
tr: I told Brother Dunlap...”
es: I tell Sister Dunlap, I say...

en: “Why, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o’ niggers in there every night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps.
vi: - Strange, he has to have a group of black people in there every night, working for four weeks to get that much, Mrs. Phelps.
tr: “Oh, goodness gracious, Brother Phelps, for four weeks there were probably a houseful of black people there every night, only just managing to get all that work done.
es: —Well, hang me, there must have been a whole gang of blacks who spent every night for four weeks to have done so much work, sister Phelps.

en: Look at that shirt—every last inch of it kivered over with secret African writ’n done with blood!
vi: Look at that shirt, every inch of it has a secret sign written in blood by Africans!
tr: Look at this shirt… every inch of it is covered with secret African writings in blood!
es: Just look at that shirt; it's completely covered inch by inch with that secret African writing done in blood!

en: Must a ben a raft uv ’m at it right along, all the time, amost.
vi: There must always be a group there, no doubt about it.
tr: It must have been a raft full of black people coming to work.
es: There must have been a bunch of them all the time, or almost.

en: Why, I’d give two dollars to have it read to me; ’n’ as for the niggers that wrote it, I ’low I’d take ’n’ lash ’m t’ll—”
vi: I'd pay two dollars right away to anyone who can read those secret words to me, and any black person who writes for me also has to explain what it means...
tr: I'll pay two dollars to have this writing read; as for the black people who wrote it, I know exactly what I'll do to them…”
es: Man, I'd give two dollars for someone to read it to me, and as for the blacks who wrote it, I'd whip them until...

en: “People to help him, Brother Marples!
vi: - Someone helped it, I'm sure you all would think the same if you stayed in that room for a while.
tr: “Someone must have been helping them, that's for sure, Brother Marples!
es: —People who helped him, Brother Marples!

en: Well, I reckon you’d think so if you’d a been in this house for a while back.
vi: - Someone helped it, I'm sure you all would think the same if you stayed in that room for a while.
tr: If you had been living in this house for a while, you would think the same.
es: Well, you could be sure of that if you had been in this house for some time now.

en: Why, they’ve stole everything they could lay their hands on—and we a-watching all the time, mind you.
vi: They can steal everything, even if you're standing next to it.
tr: They stole everything they could get their hands on… Even while we were constantly on watch.
es: But they stole everything they could, and that's with us being vigilant all the time.

en: They stole that shirt right off o’ the line!
vi: They steal the shirt right off the clothesline.
tr: They took that shirt straight from the clothesline!
es: They stole that shirt from the clothesline!

en: and as for that sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther’ ain’t no telling how many times they didn’t steal that; and flour, and candles, and candlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand things that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and Silas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day and night, as I was a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor sight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold you, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only fools us but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets away with that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs right on their very heels at that very time!
vi: And the bed sheet they used as a rope, who wouldn't say they could steal that?
tr: I can't even remember how many times they stole the sheet they used to make the rope ladder; plus flour, candles, candlesticks, spoons, an old bed warmer, and a thousand other things I can't even think of right now, and now my new calico dress is gone; Silas, Sid, Tom, and I were on watch day and night, I told you, not one of us caught them, we didn't even see or hear them; so at the last minute, you might not believe your ears but they passed right under our noses; they tricked us; and not just us, they tricked the robbers from the Indian Territory too; in fact, they escaped quite comfortably with that black man, even though there were sixteen men and twenty-two dogs behind them!
es: And as for the sheet they used to make the ladder, God knows how many times they stole it; and flour and candles and candlesticks and spoons and the old heater and almost a thousand things I can't even remember, my new calico dress, and that's with me and Silas and my Sid and my Tom watching all day and all night, as I was telling you, and none of us could see or hear anything they were doing, and now, at the last minute, they escape right under our noses and fool us, and not only fool us but also the Indian Territory thieves, and they go and escape with that black man without anyone laying a hand on them, and that's with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs chasing them just as they were escaping!

en: I tell you, it just bangs anything I ever heard of.
vi: Then flour, candles, candlesticks, spoons, even the old feather duster, and a thousand other things I can't remember; then my cloth shirt.
tr: This beats all the stories I've heard so far.
es: I'm telling you, I've never heard anything like it in my life.

en: Why, sperits couldn’t a done better and been no smarter.
vi: Then flour, candles, candlesticks, spoons, even the old feather duster, and a thousand other things I can't remember; then my cloth shirt.
tr: Ghosts couldn't have done better, couldn't have been more cunning.
es: Not even spirits could have done it better or with more intelligence.

en: And I reckon they must a been sperits—because, you know our dogs, and ther’ ain’t no better; well, them dogs never even got on the track of ’m once!
vi: So then Silas, Sid, Tom, and I spent all day guarding.
tr: Actually, I'm afraid they might be ghosts… You know our dogs, there's none better; even those dogs couldn't find their tracks!
es: And I reckon they must have been spirits, because you know your dogs and there are none better; and those dogs didn't pick up their trail even once!

en: You explain that to me if you can!—any of you!”
vi: There!
tr: Someone explain this to me if they can!.. Anyone!”
es: Let someone who understands it explain it to me! Let's see who would be able to understand it!

en: “Well, it does beat—”
vi: Like I said, none of us saw or heard anything.
tr: “True, there's really no one better...”
es: —Well, the truth is that...

en: “Laws alive, I never—”
vi: Yet suddenly, it passed right under our noses and made a mess of us; not only that, but there was a whole gang of red-skinned thieves too, and now it has taken the black man away and even sixteen people with twenty dogs chasing couldn't catch it!
tr: "I have never heard such a thing in my life...""
es: —For God's sake, never...

en: “So help me, I wouldn’t a be—”
vi: Even the devil couldn't do something more terrifying and quick than that.
tr: “Then help me, how can it be that...”
es: —God bless me, I wouldn't have believed it...

en: “House-thieves as well as—”
vi: Our dogs, you know, yet the whole pack couldn't find any trace...
tr: “They have both robbed the house and also...”
es: —House burglars, in addition to...

en: “Goodnessgracioussakes, I’d a ben afeard to live in sich a—”
vi: - Creepy, I've never...
tr: “My Almighty Lord, I would be afraid to live in such a place...”
es: —By God and all the saints, I would be scared to live in a... —Fear of living!

en: “’Fraid to live!—why, I was that scared I dasn’t hardly go to bed, or get up, or lay down, or set down, Sister Ridgeway.
vi: - It's really scary!
tr: “So you were scared!.. I was so scared that I couldn't lie down, I couldn't get up, I couldn't stretch out, I couldn't sit, Brother Ridgeway.
es: Man, I was so scared that I hardly dared to lie down, stretch out, or sit down, Sister Ridgeway.

en: Why, they’d steal the very—why, goodness sakes, you can guess what kind of a fluster I was in by the time midnight come last night.
vi: Terrifying, I don't dare to sleep, don't dare to lie down, don't dare to sit.
tr: Do you know what they stole… My God, you can't imagine how panicked I was when I returned to bed in the middle of the night.
es: But they were even stealing... My God, you can imagine the state I was in at midnight yesterday.

en: I hope to gracious if I warn’t afraid they’d steal some o’ the family!
vi: I keep praying to God, hoping it won't steal anyone from my family!
tr: Still, thank God, with this courage, they could have stolen a family member too!
es: I swear I was afraid they would take someone from the family!

en: I was just to that pass I didn’t have no reasoning faculties no more.
vi: I keep praying to God, hoping it won't steal anyone from my family!
tr: I was out of my mind, my mind had stopped working.
es: I had reached a point where I couldn't even reason anymore.

en: It looks foolish enough now, in the daytime; but I says to myself, there’s my two poor boys asleep, ’way up stairs in that lonesome room, and I declare to goodness I was that uneasy ’t I crep’ up there and locked ’em in!
vi: During the day, I almost go crazy, there are two nephews sleeping upstairs, I have to lock the door tightly.
tr: Now it sounds very silly, I mean in the daytime; but I say to myself, the poor two children are sleeping all alone in the room upstairs, God is my witness, I was so disturbed that I went upstairs and locked their door!
es: Now in the daytime, it seems silly, but I was saying to myself: "There are my two poor little boys sleeping, all alone upstairs, in that room," and I truly tell you I was so scared that I went up the stairs and locked them in.

en: I did.
vi: During the day, I almost go crazy, there are two nephews sleeping upstairs, I have to lock the door tightly.
tr: I really did that.
es: That's what I did, and what anyone would do.

en: And anybody would.
vi: Who wouldn't be scared?
tr: Anyone would have done the same thing.
es: That's what I did, and what anyone would do.

en: Because, you know, when you get scared that way, and it keeps running on, and getting worse and worse all the time, and your wits gets to addling, and you get to doing all sorts o’ wild things, and by-and-by you think to yourself, spos’n I was a boy, and was away up there, and the door ain’t locked, and you—”
vi: Every day it gets more terrifying, then ghosts and spirits haunt me, making me do foolish things.
tr: Because if a person is scared and the things that scare them continue, even if things are getting worse, they feel like they are losing their mind and start doing ridiculous things; you find yourself putting yourself in a child's place, far away upstairs, and the door is not locked…”
es: Because, you know, when one is so scared it gets worse because the head starts to stop working, the most absurd things come to mind, and over time one begins to think: "Suppose I were a boy and I was up there with the door unlocked and it was..."

en: She stopped, looking kind of wondering, and then she turned her head around slow, and when her eye lit on me—I got up and took a walk.
vi: Then, I think if I were the child lying up there, and saw the door wasn't locked then...
tr: He suddenly stopped, as if something had come to his mind, slowly turned his head, and finally, we made eye contact – I immediately got up and went for a walk.
es: —She fell silent with a somewhat astonished air, then slowly turned her head, and when she looked at me... I got up and went for a walk.

en: Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little.
vi: Then, I think if I were the child lying up there, and saw the door wasn't locked then...
tr: This morning I can explain better why we weren't in that room, but first I need to retreat to a corner and think about it, I said to myself.
es: I said to myself: "I will be able to explain better why we weren't in the room this morning if I go aside and think about it for a bit," and so I did.

en: So I done it.
vi: Aunt stopped, looked around, and when her eyes saw me, I stood up and walked outside immediately.
tr: I moved a little away.
es: I said to myself: "I will be able to explain better why we weren't in the room this morning if I go aside and think about it for a bit," and so I did.

en: But I dasn’t go fur, or she’d a sent for me.
vi: She pulled me back, kissed me, and patted my head.
tr: But I didn't go too far, otherwise he might have sent someone after me.
es: But I didn't dare go too far, because I had been sent for.

en: And when it was late in the day the people all went, and then I come in and told her the noise and shooting waked up me and “Sid,” and the door was locked, and we wanted to see the fun, so we went down the lightning-rod, and both of us got hurt a little, and we didn’t never want to try that no more.
vi: She pulled me back, kissed me, and patted my head.
tr: After hours had passed and everyone had left, I went into the house and told Aunt Sally that "Sid" and I woke up to the noise and gunshots at night; the door was locked, we didn't want to miss the fun, so we came down from the lightning rod and got hurt, we would never try such a thing again.
es: As it got late, everyone left and then I went in and told her that Sid and I had been woken up by the screams and noises, and since the door was closed and we wanted to see what was happening, we climbed down the lightning rod and both of us got a bit hurt, so we couldn't do it anymore.

en: And then I went on and told her all what I told Uncle Silas before; and then she said she’d forgive us, and maybe it was all right enough anyway, and about what a body might expect of boys, for all boys was a pretty harum-scarum lot as fur as she could see; and so, as long as no harm hadn’t come of it, she judged she better put in her time being grateful we was alive and well and she had us still, stead of fretting over what was past and done.
vi: Sitting there lost in thought, suddenly she startled, her voice filled with panic:
tr: Then I went on to tell Uncle Silas the story I had told him before; upon which he said he forgave us, maybe everything was alright; what could one expect from two boys, as far as he knew, all boys had their heads in the clouds; so, since no one was harmed, it was better to be thankful that we were alive and healthy, still with him, rather than worrying about what had happened before.
es: Then I went to tell her everything I had told Uncle Silas before, and then she said she forgave us and that it was logical and to be expected from boys, because all boys were crazy, as far as she knew, and as long as nothing had happened to us, she thought it was better to feel grateful that we were alive and well and to keep loving us, instead of worrying about things that had already happened.

en: So then she kissed me, and patted me on the head, and dropped into a kind of a brown study; and pretty soon jumps up, and says:
vi: Sitting there lost in thought, suddenly she startled, her voice filled with panic:
tr: He kissed me, patted my head, and after a while, he got lost in thought, but soon he suddenly jumped up:
es: She kissed me, stroked my head, became very thoughtful and after a moment she jumped up and said:

en: “Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet!
vi: - It's almost dark and Sid still hasn't come back!
tr: “My Almighty Lord, it's almost getting dark, Sid still hasn't come!
es: —God bless me, it's almost night and Sid still hasn't arrived!

en: What has become of that boy?”
vi: Did something happen to him?
tr: Did something happen to the child?”
es: What could have happened to that boy?

en: I see my chance; so I skips up and says:
vi: I felt so lucky, I suddenly stood up and said:
tr: I should have taken advantage of this opportunity; I immediately jumped up and said:
es: There I saw my opportunity, so I also jumped and said:

en: “I’ll run right up to town and get him,” I says.
vi: I felt so lucky, I suddenly stood up and said:
tr: "I'll quickly run to the town and find him.""
es: —I'm going to the village to bring it —I say.

en: “No you won’t,” she says.
vi: - No, don't go anymore.
tr: "No way," he said.
es: —No, no way —she says—.

en: “You’ll stay right wher’ you are; one’s enough to be lost at a time.
vi: Isn't one missing child enough?
tr: "Stay where you are, it's enough that one of you is missing.
es: You stay where you are; it's enough that one gets lost.

en: If he ain’t here to supper, your uncle ’ll go.”
vi: If it doesn't come back by mealtime, let me go look for it.
tr: If he doesn't come back by dinner, your brother-in-law will go look for him."
es: If he doesn't arrive by dinner time, your uncle will go.

en: Well, he warn’t there to supper; so right after supper uncle went.
vi: By dinner time, he still hadn't returned. So after eating, Uncle Silas left immediately.
tr: Tom didn't come to dinner either, so after the meal, my brother-in-law went to check on him.
es: Well, he didn't arrive at dinner time, so immediately afterward the uncle went out.

en: He come back about ten a little bit uneasy; hadn’t run across Tom’s track.
vi: By ten o'clock, he returned, looking sad, because there was no sign of Tom anywhere.
tr: She came back around ten o'clock, a little worried, having not encountered Tom anywhere.
es: He returned around ten a little uneasy: he hadn't found a trace of Tom.

en: Aunt Sally was a good deal uneasy; but Uncle Silas he said there warn’t no occasion to be—boys will be boys, he said, and you’ll see this one turn up in the morning all sound and right.
vi: Aunt Sally was very worried; but Uncle Silas said it was nothing to worry about, and that he would be back by morning.
tr: Aunt Sally was now quite anxious; but Uncle Silas said it was nothing important... "He's just a child, after all," he said, "you'll see, he'll turn up safe and sound in the morning."
es: Aunt Sally is very uneasy; but Uncle Silas said there was no reason to be, that it was just boys being boys and that he would show up in the morning safe and sound.

en: So she had to be satisfied.
vi: Aunt Sally felt somewhat reassured, but she still sat there, keeping the light on so that Tom could see it and find his way back.
tr: Aunt Sally had to be content with this.
es: So she had to keep quiet, but she said that in any case she would stay up waiting for him and leave a light on so he could see it.

en: But she said she’d set up for him a while anyway, and keep a light burning so he could see it.
vi: Later, I went upstairs.
tr: But she said she would stay up for a while and keep the light on, as she wanted to see him if he came back.
es: So she had to keep quiet, but she said that in any case she would stay up waiting for him and leave a light on so he could see it.

en: And then when I went up to bed she come up with me and fetched her candle, and tucked me in, and mothered me so good I felt mean, and like I couldn’t look her in the face; and she set down on the bed and talked with me a long time, and said what a splendid boy Sid was, and didn’t seem to want to ever stop talking about him; and kept asking me every now and then if I reckoned he could a got lost, or hurt, or maybe drownded, and might be laying at this minute somewheres suffering or dead, and she not by him to help him, and so the tears would drip down silent, and I would tell her that Sid was all right, and would be home in the morning, sure; and she would squeeze my hand, or maybe kiss me, and tell me to say it again, and keep on saying it, because it done her good, and she was in so much trouble.
vi: She also brought the candle up, led me into the room, and comforted me so much that I felt embarrassed and didn't dare to look her in the face anymore. Then she sat down beside the bed and talked to me for a long time, saying that Sid was really a clever boy. From time to time, she asked me if he might be lost somewhere, or injured, or drowned, or where he might be lying at that moment. Then her tears quietly fell, and I had to tell her that Sid was still safe and that he would surely be back by morning. After that, she held my hand tightly, perhaps kissed me too, and told me to keep repeating those words to reassure her because she was very worried.
tr: Then, as I was going to bed, she took her candlestick and went upstairs with me, tucked me in, and mothered me so well that I began to wish the ground would swallow me up; I was too ashamed to even look at her face. She sat on the edge of the bed and talked to me for a long time, telling me how extraordinary a child Sid was, as if she never wanted to stop talking about him. From time to time, she asked me questions, wondering if he was lost, injured, or even drowned. She was worried that he might be suffering somewhere or lying lifeless, and tears streamed down her face because she couldn't be there to help him. I told her that Sid was fine and that he would definitely come home in the morning; then she squeezed my hand, even kissed my cheek, and asked me to say it again, to keep saying it, because it made her feel better and she was very worried.
es: And then, when I went to bed, she came up with me and brought her candle, tucked me in, and treated me so well that I felt like a scoundrel, as if I couldn't look her in the eyes. She sat on the bed to chat with me for a long time and said what a splendid boy Sid was; it seemed as if she didn't want to stop talking about him, constantly asking me if I thought he might have gotten lost or hurt, or maybe drowned, and that he could be suffering somewhere right now, or dead, without her there to help him, while silent tears fell, and I told her that Sid was fine and that he would surely be home by morning. She would squeeze my hand, or give me a kiss, and ask me to repeat it and not stop, because it did her so much good and she was having such a hard time.

en: And when she was going away she looked down in my eyes so steady and gentle, and says:
vi: Then she stepped out, turned back to look at me affectionately, and said:
tr: As she was leaving, she looked straight into my eyes and said in a very calm and sweet voice:
es: When she was about to leave, she looked me in the eyes very intently and affectionately, and then she said:

en: “The door ain’t going to be locked, Tom, and there’s the window and the rod; but you’ll be good, won’t you?
vi: - Auntie didn't lock the door, Tom.
tr: "The door will not be locked, Tom; besides, there is the window and the lightning rod; but you will behave, won't you?
es: —Tom, I'm not going to lock the door, and there's the window and the lightning rod, but you're going to be good, right?

en: And you won’t go?
vi: There's a window over there, near the lamppost, but you have to be good, okay, don't go anywhere.
tr: You won't go, will you?
es: And you're not going to leave?

en: For my sake.”
vi: You must love Auntie!
tr: For my sake?"
es: Do it for me.

en: Laws knows I wanted to go bad enough to see about Tom, and was all intending to go; but after that I wouldn’t a went, not for kingdoms.
vi: I was anxious and just wanted to see how Tom was doing. He was about to get up and go, but then he didn't.
tr: God knows, I was dying to go, I was worried about Tom's situation, I was ready to leave immediately, but after he said those things, I couldn't go even if they took my life.
es: God knows how much I wanted to go out and see what was happening with Tom, and that I had no other intention; but after that, I wouldn't have left even if they had given me entire kingdoms.

en: But she was on my mind and Tom was on my mind, so I slept very restless.
vi: But I still thought about Aunt Saly, thought about Tom tossing and turning, unable to sleep.
tr: If Aunt Sally was on my mind, so was Tom; that's why I couldn't sleep at all.
es: But I couldn't stop thinking about her and Tom, so I slept very restlessly.

en: And twice I went down the rod away in the night, and slipped around front, and see her setting there by her candle in the window with her eyes towards the road and the tears in them; and I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn’t, only to swear that I wouldn’t never do nothing to grieve her any more.
vi: Twice I slid down the lamppost and went outside, then turned back to look at the candle in the window and saw Aunt Saly's eyes looking out onto the street, tears streaming down, and I thought I had to do something for her, but I couldn't do anything.
tr: Twice I climbed down the lightning rod, wandered around the front in the dark of the night, and saw Aunt Sally waiting by the candlestick at the window, her eyes fixed on the road, shedding tears; I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn't, the only thing I could do was to swear that I would never do anything to upset her again.
es: That night I climbed down the lightning rod twice and went to the main entrance, and there I saw her sitting with her candle at the window, looking at the road and crying nonstop, and I thought that I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn't, except swear that I would never do anything to make her sad again.

en: And the third time I waked up at dawn, and slid down, and she was there yet, and her candle was most out, and her old gray head was resting on her hand, and she was asleep.
vi: The third time, I got up at dawn, went downstairs, and saw Aunt Saly still sitting there, she had fallen asleep on her hand.
tr: On the third time, I woke up at dawn and went down. She was still there, the candle in her candlestick was almost out, and her gray-haired old head had fallen onto her arms, she had fallen asleep.
es: The third time I woke up was at dawn, I climbed down the lightning rod and there she was, with the candle almost finished, with her old head resting on her hand; she had fallen asleep.

en: CHAPTER XLII.
vi: chapter xlii
tr: Chapter Forty-Two
es: Chapter 42

en: The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything.
vi: Uncle Silas went looking for Tom before breakfast but returned without any trace of him. The couple sat at the table, thinking silently, looking very sad. Their coffee had gone cold, but they still had no appetite to eat.
tr: The old man went to town again before breakfast, but once again he couldn't find any trace of Tom; now both of them were sitting at the table, lost in deep thought, not uttering a word and looking very sorrowful; their coffee was getting cold, and they weren't eating anything.
es: THE OLD MAN RETURNED to the village before breakfast, but he found no trace of Tom, and the two sat at the table, thinking without saying anything, with a very sad air while their coffee grew cold, and without eating anything.

en: And by-and-by the old man says:
vi: After a while, he said:
tr: After a while, the old man said:
es: After a while, the old man goes and says:

en: “Did I give you the letter?”
vi: Have I given the letter to her yet?
tr: “Did I give you the letter?”
es: —Have I given you the letter?

en: “What letter?”
vi: - Which letter?
tr: “What letter?””
es: —What letter?

en: “The one I got yesterday out of the post-office.”
vi: - The letter I received at the post office yesterday.
tr: “The letter I got from the post office yesterday.”
es: —The one they gave me yesterday at the post office.

en: “No, you didn’t give me no letter.”
vi: - No, you didn't give me any letter.
tr: “You didn't give me a letter.”
es: —No, you haven't given me any letter.

en: “Well, I must a forgot it.”
vi: - Maybe I forgot.
tr: “So, I must have forgotten.””
es: —Well, I must have forgotten.

en: So he rummaged his pockets, and then went off somewheres where he had laid it down, and fetched it, and give it to her.
vi: He searched in his pocket but couldn't find it, then went somewhere to get the letter and handed it to her.
tr: The old man searched his pockets, then got up and looked for the place where he had put the letter, finally found it, and gave it to him.
es: He started searching in his pockets and then went somewhere to find where he had left it, brought it, and gave it to her.

en: She says:
vi: She said:
tr: “Ah, from St. Petersburg...
es: She goes and says:

en: “Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis.”
vi: - The letter from Petersburg has arrived, it's her letter.
tr: From my sister...”
es: —But it's from Saint Petersburg, from my sister.

en: I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn’t stir.
vi: I thought to myself that perhaps it would be better to go outside and play for a while.
tr: It would have been good to go for a new walk, but I couldn't move from my place.
es: I decided that another walk would do me good, but I couldn't even move.

en: But before she could break it open she dropped it and run—for she see something.
vi: But Aunt Sally hadn't had time to open the letter when she suddenly dropped it and ran out.
tr: Fortunately, Aunt Sally dropped the letter just as she was about to open it and started running – because she had seen something.
es: Before she could open it, she dropped it and started running, because she had seen something.

en: And so did I.
vi: But Aunt Sally hadn't had time to open the letter when she suddenly dropped it and ran out.
tr: I saw the same thing.
es: And so did I.

en: It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old doctor; and Jim, in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind him; and a lot of people.
vi: There was Tom lying on a padded stretcher, then the doctor, then Jim, dressed in cloth clothes, his hands tied in front of him with a bunch of people following behind.
tr: Tom Sawyer was on a bed; that old doctor was beside him; Jim was standing behind them with his hands tied, wearing a calico dress; and there were many other people as well.
es: It was Tom Sawyer lying on a mattress, and the old doctor and Jim in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind his back, and a bunch of people.

en: I hid the letter behind the first thing that come handy, and rushed.
vi: I quickly picked up the letter and hid it.
tr: I hid the letter in the first suitable place and dashed outside.
es: I hid the letter behind the first thing that came to mind and ran out.

en: She flung herself at Tom, crying, and says:
vi: Aunt Sally rushed to Tom, crying and saying:
tr: Aunt Sally collapsed onto Tom, crying.
es: She rushed towards Tom, crying, and goes and says:

en: “Oh, he’s dead, he’s dead, I know he’s dead!”
vi: - Oh, it's dead, I knew it...
tr: “Ah, he left, he left. He left us!”
es: —Oh, he's dead, he's dead, surely he's dead!

en: And Tom he turned his head a little, and muttered something or other, which showed he warn’t in his right mind; then she flung up her hands, and says:
vi: Tom turned his head and whispered something, and then Aunt Saly raised both her hands again.
tr: Tom turned his head slightly and muttered something, apparently not in his right mind, then Aunt Sally raised her arms:
es: Tom turned his head slightly and said something that showed he wasn't right in the head, and she raised her hands to the sky and said:

en: “He’s alive, thank God!
vi: - Oh, dear God, it's still alive! It's you.
tr: "He's alive; thank God! This is enough for me now!"
es: —He's alive, thank God!

en: And that’s enough!” and she snatched a kiss of him, and flew for the house to get the bed ready, and scattering orders right and left at the niggers and everybody else, as fast as her tongue could go, every jump of the way.
vi: Then she kissed him, rushed into the house to prepare the bed, and shouted orders that made the black people flustered.
tr: She planted a kiss on Tom's cheek and hurriedly went home to prepare the bed, all the while rapidly giving orders to the black people and everyone else around her as best as she could.
es: And that's enough for me! She gave him a kiss and ran to the house to prepare the bed, giving orders left and right to the black servants and everyone, as fast as she could and with every step she took.

en: I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house.
vi: I followed the group to see what they would do with Jim while the doctor and Uncle Silas followed Tom into the house.
tr: I followed the men to see what they would do to Jim; the old doctor and Uncle Silas also went into the house after Tom.
es: I followed the men to find out what they were going to do with Jim, and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed Tom to the house.

en: The men was very huffy, and some of them wanted to hang Jim for an example to all the other niggers around there, so they wouldn’t be trying to run away like Jim done, and making such a raft of trouble, and keeping a whole family scared most to death for days and nights.
vi: The people seemed angry, some wanted to hang Jim immediately as an example for other black people, but others said they shouldn't do that because he wasn't a local black person, and what if his owner came to claim compensation.
tr: The men were very aggressive and some wanted to hang Jim, so that he would be an example to the other negroes living there, and they wouldn't try to escape like Jim, causing a lot of trouble, terrifying a whole family for days and nights.
es: The men were furious and wanted to hang Jim to set an example for all the other blacks in the area, so they wouldn't try to escape like Jim had done or cause so much commotion and have an entire family almost scared to death for days and nights.

en: But the others said, don’t do it, it wouldn’t answer at all; he ain’t our nigger, and his owner would turn up and make us pay for him, sure.
vi: Hearing that, they calmed down a bit.
tr: But others didn't want to hang him; it wasn't a solution, after all, he wasn't our negro and his owner could come and demand money for the negro.
es: But the others said, "No, that can't be done; that black man isn't ours, and surely the owner will show up and make us pay for him."

en: So that cooled them down a little, because the people that’s always the most anxious for to hang a nigger that hain’t done just right is always the very ones that ain’t the most anxious to pay for him when they’ve got their satisfaction out of him.
vi: They cursed Jim terribly.
tr: Upon this, the men calmed down a bit, because those who are most eager to hang negroes who want to do something wrong are always the least willing to pay the money after dealing with him.
es: So they cooled down a bit, because the people who are most eager to hang a black man who has done something are always the same ones who don't want to pay for him once he has served their purpose.

en: They cussed Jim considerble, though, and give him a cuff or two side the head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let on to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own clothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time, but to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands, too, and both legs, and said he warn’t to have nothing but bread and water to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction because he didn’t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our hole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around about the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the daytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was tapering off with a kind of generl good-bye cussing, and then the old doctor comes and takes a look, and says:
vi: Every now and then, someone would kick Jim. But Jim didn't say anything and acted as if he didn't know who I was. Then they locked Jim back in the old cell, dressed him in old clothes, chained him to the large plank on the floor, chained both his hands and feet, and said they would only give him bread and water until his owner came or he was sold at auction. Then they sealed the hole we had dug and assigned two people to stand guard with guns every night; during the day, they tied a fierce dog at the door. Once everything was done, they were about to leave, bidding Jim farewell with a curse when the doctor arrived, took a quick look, and said:
tr: Nevertheless, they cursed and swore at Jim, hit him a few times, but Jim didn't utter a word, nor did he show any sign of knowing me. They took him to the same cabin, dressed him in his own clothes, and chained him again, this time not to the bedpost but to a large ring attached to a log. They chained his hands and feet as well. From then on, until his owner came or he was sold at auction, he would be given nothing but bread and water. They closed the hole we had opened. Additionally, every night, a few armed farmers would stand guard around the cabin, and during the day, a guard dog would be tied to the door. They had almost finished their work and were leaving with final curses when the old doctor came in, took a look, and said:
es: They called Jim all sorts of names and hit him on the head from time to time, but Jim didn't say anything; he never let slip that he knew me. They took him to the same cabin, put his own clothes on him, and chained him up again, but this time not to the leg of a cot, but to a huge ring nailed to the lower trunk, and they also chained his hands and both legs and said they wouldn't give him anything to eat but bread and water until his owner showed up or they sold him at an auction, if he didn't show up after a certain time, and they filled in the hole we had made and said that every night there would be a couple of farmers with shotguns guarding the cabin and with a bulldog at the door. By then they had finished their work, and were about to leave with a sort of general curse of farewell when the old doctor appeared, who saw all that and goes and says:

en: “Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obleeged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger.
vi: - Everyone, don't treat him so badly, because he is not a bad black man.
tr: “Do not treat him badly for no reason, because he is not a bad negro.
es: —Do not treat him worse than necessary, because he is not a bad black man.

en: When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well.
vi: When I came to find that boy, I had no one to help me to extract the bullet. And I couldn't leave the boy there, as he was getting more critical by the minute. He went crazy, absolutely refused to let me come near, and told me that if I drew chalk on the raft, he would kill me. I felt there was nothing I could do with him. Suddenly, at that moment, this black man crawled out from somewhere and said he would lend a hand.
tr: When I found the child, I realized I couldn't remove the bullet without help, but the child was in such bad shape that he couldn't be left alone to find help; his condition was gradually worsening, and after a considerable amount of time, he lost consciousness and wouldn't let me approach him anymore, saying he would kill me if I chalked the raft, he babbled such nonsense for a long time that I thought I couldn't be of any help to him; so, I said I needed to find help somehow; as soon as I said this, that negro suddenly appeared and said he would help, and indeed, he helped very well.
es: When I arrived where I found the boy, I saw that I couldn't remove the bullet without some help and that he wasn't in a condition to be left alone while I went to get it, and he kept getting worse and worse, and after a while, he lost his mind and wouldn't let me get close; he said that if I marked the raft with chalk, he would kill me and all sorts of absurd things. When I saw that I couldn't do anything for him, I said to myself: "I need someone to help me," and just then that black man appeared out of nowhere and said he would help me, and he really did help me.

en: Of course I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was!
vi: Of course, I immediately thought he was the runaway black man.
tr: Of course, I realized he was a runaway negro, but what could I do?
es: Of course, I thought he must be a runaway black man, but that's how things were, and I had to stay there all the rest of the day and all night.

en: and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night.
vi: So I had to stay there for a whole day and night.
tr: Moreover, I had to wait there all day and night.
es: Of course, I thought he must be a runaway black man, but that's how things were, and I had to stay there all the rest of the day and all night.

en: It was a fix, I tell you!
vi: It was really a tight spot!
tr: I thought I was in trouble!
es: I assure you it has been difficult!

en: I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet never a skiff come close enough for me to hail.
vi: At home, I had some patients waiting, I wanted to run back to check on them, but I couldn't, because I was also afraid that if the black man ran away, I would be blamed; and at that time, there were no boats passing by to call for help.
tr: I had a few patients with colds, I wanted to go back to town to see them too, but I couldn't go, then the negro would escape and I would be blamed; besides, no boats were passing by nearby.
es: I had a couple of patients with fevers and naturally, I would have liked to go to town to see them, but I didn't dare because the black man could escape and then it would be my fault; however, not a single skiff came close enough for me to call.
