en: So there I had to stick plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I see plain enough he’d been worked main hard lately.
vi: So I had to wait until this morning. And I have never seen a black man more skillful and loyal than him; he even sacrificed his freedom to do that. He was also very tired. I could clearly see that he must have been working a lot recently.
tr: I stayed on the raft until dawn this morning, and I must say I have never seen a negro take such good care of a patient, so faithfully, he risked his freedom to help me, moreover, he could barely lift his arm, it was clear he had been worked very hard recently.
es: So I had to stay there until dawn this morning, and I have never seen a black man who knew better how to take care of a sick person or was more faithful, even though he had to put his freedom at risk, and on top of that, he was exhausted and it was clear that he had had a lot to do recently.

en: I liked the nigger for that; I tell you, gentlemen, a nigger like that is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too.
vi: A black man like that is worth a thousand dollars, and deserves to be treated better.
tr: I was very pleased with the negro's behavior; such a negro is worth a thousand dollars, gentlemen… He also deserves to be treated well.
es: That's why I liked that black man; and I assure you, gentlemen, that a black man like that is worth a thousand dollars and should be treated well.

en: I had everything I needed, and the boy was doing as well there as he would a done at home—better, maybe, because it was so quiet; but there I was, with both of ’m on my hands, and there I had to stick till about dawn this morning; then some men in a skiff come by, and as good luck would have it the nigger was setting by the pallet with his head propped on his knees sound asleep; so I motioned them in quiet, and they slipped up on him and grabbed him and tied him before he knowed what he was about, and we never had no trouble.
vi: Then I saw some people coming by boat, luckily the black man was sitting on the plank, head down on his knees, fast asleep. I signaled the boat to come closer, they jumped up and held the black man tightly and tied him up, so it wasn't too difficult for us. As for the boy, he also fell asleep.
tr: He found everything I needed, and made the child as comfortable as if he were at home… Maybe even more comfortable, since it was very quiet around; but I was in a bad state, both of them were on my mind; I had to wait there until this morning; then a boat approached and by chance, the negro was sitting at the helm with his head between his knees, sleeping; I signaled to the people on the boat to approach quietly, before the negro knew what was happening, they grabbed him tightly and tied his hands and feet, there was no trouble at all.
es: I didn't have everything I needed and the boy was recovering just as if he were at home, and maybe better because it was very quiet, but there I was with both of them in my hands, and I had to stay there until dawn; then some men appeared in a skiff, and luckily the black man was sitting next to the mattress with his head resting on his knees, sleeping like a log; so I signaled to them silently, and they approached, grabbed him, and tied him up without him realizing what was happening, and we haven't had any problems.

en: And the boy being in a kind of a flighty sleep, too, we muffled the oars and hitched the raft on, and towed her over very nice and quiet, and the nigger never made the least row nor said a word from the start.
vi: We moved the oars to the raft, rowed gently, then docked and tied the raft. From start to finish, this black man did not show any sign of wanting to move or say a word.
tr: The child was also sleeping, we tied the raft to the boat and quietly pulled it to a safe place; meanwhile, the negro didn't make any fuss from the beginning, he didn't even say a word.
es: Since the boy was also half asleep, we wrapped the oars with some cloths, hooked up the raft, and towed it silently, and the black man didn't make any fuss or say a word from the beginning.

en: He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”
vi: He is not a bad black man, that's what I think.
tr: He is not a bad negro, gentlemen; that is my opinion.”
es: He is not a bad black man, gentlemen; that's what I have to say about him.

en: Somebody says:
vi: Someone said:
tr: "By God, it sounds good, doctor," said someone.
es: Someone said:

en: “Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I’m obleeged to say.”
vi: - Yes, I think so too.
tr: "By God, it sounds good, doctor," said someone.
es: —Well, that says a lot about him, doctor, it must be said.

en: Then the others softened up a little, too, and I was mighty thankful to that old doctor for doing Jim that good turn; and I was glad it was according to my judgment of him, too; because I thought he had a good heart in him and was a good man the first time I see him.
vi: Then the others also calmed down a bit. I silently thanked that old doctor for speaking up for Jim; he was an exceptionally kind person.
tr: Then the others softened a bit too; I was grateful to the old doctor for doing this kindness for Jim, and I was also very pleased that I was not mistaken about him; from the very beginning, from the moment I first saw him, I had thought he was a kind-hearted man.
es: Then the others also softened a bit, and I was very glad that the old doctor behaved so well with Jim, and also that it matched what I had thought of him, because it seemed to me that he was a man of good heart since I first saw him.

en: Then they all agreed that Jim had acted very well, and was deserving to have some notice took of it, and reward.
vi: Everyone agreed that Jim had done very well, deserving praise and a reward.
tr: Then they all decided that Jim had behaved very well and therefore deserved better treatment; he should be rewarded for his kindness.
es: Then everyone decided that Jim had acted very well and deserved some compensation.

en: So every one of them promised, right out and hearty, that they wouldn’t cuss him no more.
vi: So everyone sincerely promised that they would not scold Jim anymore.
tr: They each sincerely swore that they would never curse at him again.
es: So everyone promised, immediately and wholeheartedly, that they would not curse him again.

en: Then they come out and locked him up.
vi: Then they went out, locked Jim in there, and locked the door.
tr: Then they went outside and locked the door behind them.
es: Then they went out and locked him up.

en: I hoped they was going to say he could have one or two of the chains took off, because they was rotten heavy, or could have meat and greens with his bread and water; but they didn’t think of it, and I reckoned it warn’t best for me to mix in, but I judged I’d get the doctor’s yarn to Aunt Sally somehow or other as soon as I’d got through the breakers that was laying just ahead of me—explanations, I mean, of how I forgot to mention about Sid being shot when I was telling how him and me put in that dratted night paddling around hunting the runaway nigger.
vi: I wished someone would say that they could remove some of the chains for Jim because those chains were too heavy, and give Jim vegetables, meat with bread, and water.
tr: I had hoped they would remove some of my chains because they were very heavy, or maybe they would give meat and vegetables along with bread and water, but it never crossed their minds. I thought it best not to get involved in this matter, but I had to relay what the doctor said to Aunt Sally, of course, I would do this as soon as I got past the massive waves rising right in front of me. That is, as soon as I made the explanations, because they would want to know why I forgot to tell how Sid was shot while we were going by canoe that night to find the runaway slave.
es: I hoped they would say they could remove one or two of the chains, because they were very heavy, or that he could eat some meat and vegetables with the bread and water, but it didn't occur to them, and I figured it was better not to get involved in the matter, but rather to tell Aunt Sally the doctor's story as best I could once the storm that was coming over me passed; I mean the explanations of how I had forgotten to mention that Sid had been shot when I started to tell how he and I had spent that night rowing between the islands in search of the runaway black man.

en: But I had plenty time.
vi: But no one thought of that at all.
tr: But I had plenty of time.
es: But he had plenty of time.

en: Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him.
vi: Aunt Sally was on duty in the sick room day and night, and whenever I saw Uncle Silas hanging around there, I would avoid him.
tr: Aunt Sally spent the whole day and night in the sick room; and whenever I noticed Uncle Silas looking around, I would disappear.
es: Aunt Sally stayed with the sick person all day and all night, and every time she saw Uncle Silas with that long face, I would escape from him.

en: Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt Sally was gone to get a nap.
vi: The next morning, seeing Tom was better, and Aunt Sally went to sleep for a while, I sneaked into the sick room, if he was awake, we would come up with a reasonable story together.
tr: I heard the next morning that Tom was much better, and they said Aunt Sally had gone to get some sleep.
es: The next morning I found out that Tom was doing much better, and they said that Aunt Sally had gone to take a nap.

en: So I slips to the sick-room, and if I found him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that would wash.
vi: The next morning, seeing Tom was better, and Aunt Sally went to sleep for a while, I sneaked into the sick room, if he was awake, we would come up with a reasonable story together.
tr: I sneaked into the sickroom, thinking that if I found Tom awake, we could come up with a story to fool the whole family.
es: So I went to the room and, if I found him awake, I figured we could come up with a story that the family would believe.

en: But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and pale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come.
vi: But he was still asleep, his face pale, not rosy like the day he first arrived.
tr: But he was sleeping, and he was sleeping peacefully; his face was pale, not flushed like when he arrived.
es: But he was asleep and very peaceful, and pale, not with his face all flushed like when he arrived.

en: So I set down and laid for him to wake.
vi: I sat down, waiting for him to wake up.
tr: So I sat down and waited for him to wake up.
es: So I sat down and waited for him to wake up.

en: In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding in, and there I was, up a stump again!
vi: About half an hour later, Aunt Sally walked in, startling me.
tr: About half an hour later, Aunt Sally quietly slipped in, and there she had caught me again!
es: After about half an hour, Aunt Sally arrived quietly and there I was, in trouble again!

en: She motioned me to be still, and set down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful now, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he’d been sleeping like that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the time, and ten to one he’d wake up in his right mind.
vi: She told me to be quiet, then sat down beside me. She seemed happy that Tom had returned to normal.
tr: She signaled me to be quiet and sat down next to me, then started whispering. We could all be happy now because Tom was doing very well, and he had been sleeping like this for a long time, looking healthier and more peaceful by the minute; he would probably wake up soon, feeling much better.
es: She motioned for me not to say anything and sat down next to me, and started whispering that now we could all be happy, because all the symptoms were improving and he had been sleeping for a long time, getting better and more peaceful, and she bet ten to one that when he woke up he would have regained all his senses.

en: So we set there watching, and by-and-by he stirs a bit, and opened his eyes very natural, and takes a look, and says:
vi: Then we sat there watching. A moment later, he stirred, opened his eyes very naturally. He looked around and then said:
tr: Upon this, we sat down and began to watch it; it slowly started to move, then naturally opened its eyes, and looked around:
es: We stayed there watching him, and after a while, he moved a little, opened his eyes quite naturally, looked around, and said:

en: “Hello!—why, I’m at home!
vi: - Why am I at home?
tr: “Hello! But I'm at home!
es: —Hello! But I'm at home!

en: How’s that?
vi: - Why am I at home?
tr: How did this happen?
es: How did it happen?

en: Where’s the raft?”
vi: Where is the raft?
tr: Where is Sal?”
es: Where is the raft?

en: “It’s all right,” I says.
vi: - Everything is calm now - I replied.
tr: "In very good condition," I said.
es: —Everything is going well —I replied.

en: “And Jim?”
vi: - What about Jim?
tr: “What about Jim?”
es: —And Jim?

en: “The same,” I says, but couldn’t say it pretty brash.
vi: - Same here - I replied, my voice not very calm.
tr: “The same,” I said, but I had said it a bit hesitantly.
es: —Same —I said, but without much conviction.

en: But he never noticed, but says:
vi: It spoke again:
tr: He didn't notice at all:
es: But he didn't notice and said:

en: “Good! Splendid!
vi: - That's great!
tr: “Very good! Wonderful!
es: —Great! Splendid!

en: Now we’re all right and safe!
vi: - That's great!
tr: Now we are all safe and sound!
es: Now we are in order and safe!

en: Did you tell Aunty?”
vi: Did you tell Auntie? I was about to answer when Aunt Saly interrupted and asked
tr: Did you tell my aunt?” I was just about to say yes when Aunt Sally interrupted:
es: Have you told Auntie?

en: I was going to say yes; but she chipped in and says: “About what, Sid?”
vi: - About what, child?
tr: "What was he going to say, Sid?"
es: I was about to say yes, but she intervened and goes and says: —What, Sid?

en: “Why, about the way the whole thing was done.”
vi: - About everything that has happened.
tr: “How did we accomplish this great task?”
es: —Man, how we organized everything.

en: “What whole thing?”
vi: - What's the matter?
tr: “Which big task?”
es: —What do you mean by everything?

en: “Why, the whole thing.
vi: - What's the matter?
tr: “Big deal.
es: —Man, everything that has happened.

en: There ain’t but one; how we set the runaway nigger free—me and Tom.”
vi: - The story of us releasing the black man...
tr: It's not just one thing, first of all, how we saved the runaway black man… me and Tom.”
es: It's the only thing to tell; how Tom and I set the black man free.

en: “Good land!
vi: - What?
tr: "My Almighty Lord!
es: —My God!

en: Set the run—
vi: Release the black man ...
tr: Save?
es: What did you put him in ...?

en: What is the child talking about!
vi: This kid, what is he saying?
tr: What is this child talking about!
es: What is this boy talking about!

en: Dear, dear, out of his head again!”
vi: He’s babbling again.
tr: For God's sake, he lost himself again!"
es: My God, my God, he's lost his mind again!

en: “No, I ain’t out of my HEAD; I know all what I’m talking about.
vi: - No, I didn't dream it.
tr: "No, I haven't lost myself; I know exactly what I'm saying.
es: —No, I haven't lost my mind; I know perfectly well what I'm saying.

en: We did set him free—me and Tom.
vi: It was Tom and I who set him free...
tr: We saved him... me and Tom.
es: Yes, Tom and I did set him free.

en: We laid out to do it, and we done it.
vi: It was Tom and I who set him free...
tr: We planned for a long time and finally succeeded.
es: We decided to do it and we did it.

en: And we done it elegant, too.”
vi: So it began to tell the story, while Aunt Saly sat quietly listening to it.
tr: And in a very stylish way."
es: And we did it with a lot of style.

en: He’d got a start, and she never checked him up, just set and stared and stared, and let him clip along, and I see it warn’t no use for me to put in.
vi: As for me, I felt that interrupting would be pointless.
tr: Tom was excited, Aunt Sally no longer stopped him, she just sat and watched his speech with a stern look, I realized there was no point in interrupting.
es: —It had started moving and she couldn't stop it; she just sat there watching and watching and let it go on. I realized that it made no sense for me to intervene—.

en: “Why, Aunty, it cost us a power of work—weeks of it—hours and hours, every night, whilst you was all asleep.
vi: - We had to put so much effort into it, weeks, hours, nights when the whole family was asleep.
tr: "You can't imagine how hard we worked, Aunt... We struggled for weeks... Every night while you were sleeping, we worked for hours.
es: But, auntie, it took us a tremendous amount of work, whole weeks, hours and hours every night, while you all slept.

en: And we had to steal candles, and the sheet, and the shirt, and your dress, and spoons, and tin plates, and case-knives, and the warming-pan, and the grindstone, and flour, and just no end of things, and you can’t think what work it was to make the saws, and pens, and inscriptions, and one thing or another, and you can’t think half the fun it was.
vi: Then we stole candles, bed sheets, aunt's clothes, then spoons, iron plates, daggers, incubators, millstones, flour, and all sorts of other things. You can't imagine what those saws, pens, and those markings were for; and you couldn't imagine the fun of it.
tr: We had to steal the candles, the sheet, the shirt, and your dress, the spoons, the tin plates, the knives, the bed warmer, the millstone, the flour, and many other things; you would be amazed at how long it took to prepare the saw, the pens, the inscriptions, and other things, and you could never guess how much fun it was.
es: We had to steal candles and the sheet and the shirt and your dress and the spoons and the tin plates and the kitchen knives and the heater, the grindstone and the flour and all sorts of things, and you can't imagine the work it took us to make the saws and the pens and the inscriptions and everything else; you have no idea how much fun we had.

en: And we had to make up the pictures of coffins and things, and nonnamous letters from the robbers, and get up and down the lightning-rod, and dig the hole into the cabin, and made the rope ladder and send it in cooked up in a pie, and send in spoons and things to work with in your apron pocket—”
vi: Then we also drew coffin shapes, wrote anonymous letters from the robbers, we kept sliding up and down the lamp post; then dug a hole in the prison, made a rope ladder, then baked a cake and stuffed the rope ladder into it, then put spoons and other things into your kitchen apron pocket.
tr: We made coffin pictures and sent anonymous letters from robbers, constantly went up and down the lightning rod, made that hole in the cabin, made a rope ladder and sent it inside a pie, put the spoons and such in your apron pocket..."
es: We had to draw the coffins and the rest, the anonymous letters from the thieves, and go up and down the lightning rod, and make the hole in the cabin and the rope ladder and bake it into a cake and send him spoons and things to work with, which we put in the pockets of your apron...

en: “Mercy sakes!”
vi: - Oh Lord! - Aunt Saly exclaimed. -... .
tr: “For God's sake!”
es: —God help me! —...

en: “—and load up the cabin with rats and snakes and so on, for company for Jim; and then you kept Tom here so long with the butter in his hat that you come near spiling the whole business, because the men come before we was out of the cabin, and we had to rush, and they heard us and let drive at us, and I got my share, and we dodged out of the path and let them go by, and when the dogs come they warn’t interested in us, but went for the most noise, and we got our canoe, and made for the raft, and was all safe, and Jim was a free man, and we done it all by ourselves, and wasn’t it bully, Aunty!”
vi: Then we brought mice and snakes in there to keep Jim company; then aunt kept Tom here for so long that the butter on his hat melted and almost ruined our plans. Then we were chased, I got stuck and got shot. We hid by the roadside to let them pass, then took the canoe to the raft. Everything went well, and Jim was free. Do you find it exciting?
tr: “… also, we filled the cabin with mice, snakes, and such to accompany Jim; then you kept Tom here with butter on his hat for so long that you almost ruined everything, because before we could get out, the men came to the cabin, we had to hurry, they heard our voices and shot at us, I got hit, we went off the road while escaping, and they passed us; when the dogs came, they didn't do anything to us, they followed the noise, we jumped into our canoe and reached the raft, we were safe now, and Jim was free, we did it all by ourselves, isn't it wonderful, Aunt!””
es: And filling the cabin with rats and snakes and everything else to keep Jim company, and then you made Tom stay here so long with the butter inside his hat that you almost ruined everything, because the men arrived before we had left the cabin and we had to run out and they heard us and shot at us and I got hit, and we moved off the path and let them pass, and when the dogs came they didn't find us interesting, but went where there was more noise; we took out the canoe and went to the raft and we were safe and Jim was a free man, and we did it all by ourselves and it was great, Aunt!

en: “Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days!
vi: - Since the day I was born, I've never heard of such a strange story.
tr: “If I've ever heard such a thing in my life, may I be damned!
es: —Well, in my life I've never heard anything like it!

en: So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death.
vi: So it turns out you brats caused all this trouble, making everyone frantic and scared to death.
tr: So it was you, you little rascals, you caused all those troubles, you drove everyone out of their minds, you scared us to death.
es: So it was you, rascals, who organized all this commotion and left us all not knowing what to think, almost scared to death.

en: I’ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o’ you this very minute.
vi: Do you really enjoy making me suffer every night?
tr: Now I feel like giving you a good beating.
es: It makes me more eager than ever to make you pay for it right now.

en: To think, here I’ve been, night after night, a—you just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I’ll tan the Old Harry out o’ both o’ ye!”
vi: You little devils, I'll give you a lesson to stop playing such mischievous pranks.
tr: When I think about what I went through here night after night... oh, just wait until you get better, you brat, then I'll skin both of you alive!”
es: To think that I've spent night after night here... wait until you're fully recovered, scoundrel, and you'll see how I beat the devil out of you!

en: But Tom, he was so proud and joyful, he just couldn’t hold in, and his tongue just went it—she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:
vi: But Tom was very delighted. He kept chattering non-stop. Aunt Sally was both annoyed and amused. She said:
tr: Aunt Polly was so proud and cheerful that she couldn't contain herself and kept on talking – Aunt Sally was also fuming now and then, and they were both talking at the same time like a chorus of cats. Aunt Sally said at one point:
es: But Tom was so proud and so happy that he couldn't stop, and he kept on talking while she intervened and spat fire all the time, both at once, like a meeting of cats, and in the end she says:

en: “Well, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it now, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again—”
vi: - Now you all have had your fun, but if I catch you having any more dealings with it...
tr: "Well, for now, enjoy yourself as much as you want because if I catch you around him again...""
es: —Well, have as much fun as you can now, because I assure you that if I catch you talking to him again...

en: “Meddling with who?”
vi: - Relationship with whom?
tr: "Around whom?"
es: —Talking to whom?

en: Tom says, dropping his smile and looking surprised.
vi: - Tom asked, laughing, looking very surprised.
tr: Tom's smile suddenly froze, he was very surprised.
es: —asks Tom, stopping his smile and looking surprised.

en: “With who?
vi: - With whom?
tr: “Who?
es: —With whom?

en: Why, the runaway nigger, of course.
vi: The black guy who ran away, of course.
tr: The runaway black man, of course?
es: Well, with the runaway black man, of course.

en: Who’d you reckon?”
vi: Who else do you think?
tr: Who did you think?”
es: What did you think?

en: Tom looks at me very grave, and says:
vi: - Tom looked at me very seriously and asked:
tr: Tom's face suddenly clouded over and he turned to me.
es: Tom looked at me very seriously, and then he said:

en: “Tom, didn’t you just tell me he was all right?
vi: - Tom, why did you just tell me that everything is fine?
tr: “Tom, didn't you just tell me that he was fine?
es: —Tom, didn't you just tell me that he was fine?

en: Hasn’t he got away?”
vi: Has he escaped yet?
tr: Hadn't he escaped?”
es: Hasn't he escaped?

en: “Him?” says Aunt Sally; “the runaway nigger?
vi: Sister Saly asked: - The black man who ran away?
tr: “Is it him?” said Aunt Sally; “The runaway black man?
es: —Him? —says Aunt Sally— The runaway black man?

en: ’Deed he hasn’t.
vi: Of course not yet.
tr: He didn't escape at all.
es: Of course not.

en: They’ve got him back, safe and sound, and he’s in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he’s claimed or sold!”
vi: They have caught him and locked him back in that room, only giving him bread and water, carefully chained, waiting until someone comes to claim or sell him.
tr: They caught him tight and brought him back, put him in his cabin again, only give him bread and water, and chained him from all sides; he will stay that way until his owner comes or he is sold!”
es: They've brought him back here safe and sound, and he's in the same cabin, on bread and water, and loaded with chains until someone comes to claim him or we sell him!

en: Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:
vi: Tom was lying on the bed when he suddenly sat up, his eyes bloodshot, his nostrils flaring like a fish's gills, then he looked at me and shouted:
tr: Tom sat up in his bed with sparks flying from his eyes, his nostrils flaring like gills, and shouted in anger:
es: Tom sat up abruptly in bed, with his eyes wide open and flaring his nostrils as if they were gills, and he shouts at me:

en: “They hain’t no right to shut him up!
vi: - They have no right to capture Jim.
tr: "They have no right to shut it down! They have no right to push it around at all!..
es: —You have no right to keep him locked up!

en: Shove!—and don’t you lose a minute.
vi: You run away immediately, set him free!
tr: Don't waste a single minute.
es: Get out, and don't waste a minute.

en: Turn him loose!
vi: You run away immediately, set him free!
tr: Set it free!
es: Let him go!

en: he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”
vi: He is not a slave, he is as free as anyone on this earth!
tr: It is not a slave, it is as free as everyone living in this world!"
es: He is not a slave. He is as free as anyone else!

en: “What does the child mean?”
vi: -This kid talks strangely, doesn't he?
tr: “What is this child trying to say?”
es: —What is this boy talking about?

en: “I mean every word I say, Aunt Sally, and if somebody don’t go, I’ll go.
vi: - Aunt Sally, everything I said is true.
tr: "I mean everything I said, Aunt Sally, if no one goes and frees him, I will go myself.
es: —I mean it, Aunt Sally, and if no one goes, I will.

en: I’ve knowed him all his life, and so has Tom, there.
vi: Both Tom and I know him well.
tr: I've known him since I can remember, and Tom knows him too.
es: I've known him all my life just like Tom here.

en: Old Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was ashamed she ever was going to sell him down the river, and said so; and she set him free in her will.”
vi: Miss Watson has been dead for two months now, and she was very ashamed of planning to sell him down South. She said that she agreed to let him be free.
tr: Old Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was so ashamed of thinking about selling him down the river that she freed him in her will."
es: Old Miss Watson died two months ago and felt ashamed for having intended to sell him down the river and said so, and she granted him freedom in her will.

en: “Then what on earth did you want to set him free for, seeing he was already free?”
vi: - You know that it is already free, so what freedom are you planning to return to it?
tr: “Alright, but why were you trying to save him, my child? He was already free!”
es: —So, why the hell did you want to set him free if he was already free?

en: “Well, that is a question, I must say; and just like women!
vi: - That's the real issue.
tr: “This is exactly the kind of question a woman would ask!
es: —Well, that is indeed a question, I must say, typical of a woman!

en: Why, I wanted the adventure of it; and I’d a waded neck-deep in blood to—goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!”
vi: It's just that I like adventure, and I had to plunge into blood and fire to do it. Oh my God! Aunt Polly!
tr: Of course, I saved it for the adventure. I was even willing to risk drowning in my own blood for this. Oh my God, Aunt Polly!”
es: Man, well, because I wanted to try the adventure, and I would have been capable of getting into blood up to my neck for... Good heavens, AUNT POLLY!

en: If she warn’t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as sweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!
vi: At that moment, I seemed to see Aunt Polly standing inside the doorway, gentle and majestic like a fairy.
tr: Indeed, Aunt Polly was there, standing like an angel in front of the door with her usual sweet cheeks and kind face, looking at us.
es: May I die right now if he wasn't there, right next to the door, with an air as complacent and satisfied as an angel who had just gorged on cake!

en: Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me.
vi: Aunt Saly ran out and hugged Aunt Polly tightly, almost bumping her head into her, then started crying, while I slipped under the bed.
tr: Aunt Sally immediately rushed towards him, hugged him around the neck, and started crying, and in the meantime, I slipped under the bed because things were starting to get heated for us.
es: Aunt Sally jumped towards her and almost took her head off with a hug. She started crying with her, and I found a good spot under the bed, because I had the feeling that things were getting pretty tough for us.

en: And I peeped out, and in a little while Tom’s Aunt Polly shook herself loose and stood there looking across at Tom over her spectacles—kind of grinding him into the earth, you know.
vi: I peeked out, and in a moment, Tom's Aunt Polly came in, staring at him through her glasses as if she was about to crush him.
tr: When I looked surreptitiously, I saw that Tom's Aunt Polly had freed herself from her sister's arms and was looking at Tom over her glasses – as if she was going to bury him into the ground.
es: I looked from underneath and after a while Aunt Polly let go and stood there looking at Tom over her glasses, you know, as if she were tearing him to pieces.

en: And then she says:
vi: Then she said:
tr: Then she said:
es: And then she goes and says:

en: “Yes, you better turn y’r head away—I would if I was you, Tom.”
vi: - Tom, you'd better turn away. If it were me, I would do the same.
tr: “You'd really do well to turn your head... If I were you, I'd do the same, Tom.”
es: —Yes, you'd better look the other way; it's what I would do in your case, Tom.

en: “Oh, deary me!” says Aunt Sally; “is he changed so?
vi: Aunt Saly exclaimed:
tr: “Oh my God!” said Aunt Sally, “Has he changed that much?
es: —Oh my God! —says Aunt Sally— Has he changed that much?

en: Why, that ain’t Tom, it’s Sid; Tom’s—Tom’s—why, where is Tom?
vi: - Oh, hey, it's not Tom, it's Sid, Tom! Tom!
tr: This isn't Tom, Sid; Tom is… Tom is… Where did Tom go now?
es: But that's not Tom, it's Sid; Tom is... but, where is Tom?

en: He was here a minute ago.”
vi: Where has Tom run off to, he was just here!
tr: He was here a second ago.”
es: He was here just a moment ago.

en: “You mean where’s Huck Finn—that’s what you mean!
vi: - Do you mean to say that Huck Finn is somewhere around here?
tr: “I suppose you mean where Huck Finn is… because you are talking about him!
es: —You mean where Huck Finn is... that's who you mean!

en: I reckon I hain’t raised such a scamp as my Tom all these years not to know him when I see him.
vi: Is it possible that I've been raising that kid for so many years and still wouldn't recognize him?
tr: After raising and growing up a rascal like Tom, I would certainly recognize him when I see him.
es: I reckon I haven't raised a rascal like my Tom all these years not to recognize him when I see him.

en: That would be a pretty howdy-do.
vi: Is it possible that I've been raising that kid for so many years and still wouldn't recognize him?
tr: It would indeed be very strange.
es: That would be good.

en: Come out from under that bed, Huck Finn.”
vi: Huck Finn, come out from under the bed!
tr: Come out from under the bed, Huck Finn.”
es: Come out from under the bed, Huck Finn.

en: So I done it.
vi: I crawled out, but it wasn't as natural as before.
tr: I came out from under the bed, feeling shy and embarrassed.
es: That was what I did.

en: But not feeling brash.
vi: I crawled out, but it wasn't as natural as before.
tr: I came out from under the bed, feeling shy and embarrassed.
es: But I didn't feel very happy.

en: Aunt Sally she was one of the mixed-upest-looking persons I ever see—except one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he come in and they told it all to him.
vi: Aunt Sally was in a state of panic, and Uncle Silas, upon hearing everything, was no less panicked.
tr: I had never seen a person as bewildered as Aunt Sally before, but then I did: When Uncle Silas, to whom they were telling the story, came in, his state was even more dire.
es: Aunt Sally became one of the people who understood the least of anything I have ever seen in my life, except for one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he came and they told him everything.

en: It kind of made him drunk, as you may say, and he didn’t know nothing at all the rest of the day, and preached a prayer-meeting sermon that night that gave him a rattling ruputation, because the oldest man in the world couldn’t a understood it.
vi: That night, he called the whole family to pray so that he could regain his composure.
tr: He was practically dead drunk, wandered around in a daze for the rest of the day, and became incredibly famous because of the sermon he gave that night, as even the oldest folks couldn't understand a single word he said.
es: You could say it was as if he got drunk, and he spent the rest of the day not understanding anything. That night he preached a sermon at the church meeting that gave him a phenomenal reputation, because not even the oldest person in the world would have understood it.

en: So Tom’s Aunt Polly, she told all about who I was, and what; and I had to up and tell how I was in such a tight place that when ms Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer—she chipped in and says, “Oh, go on and call me Aunt Sally, I’m used to it now, and ’tain’t no need to change”—that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to stand it—there warn’t no other way, and I knowed he wouldn’t mind, because it would be nuts for him, being a mystery, and he’d make an adventure out of it, and be perfectly satisfied.
vi: Then Tom's Aunt Polly recounted everything about who I was, what I was like, and I had to stand up and explain everything from the beginning. Aunt Sally interrupted: - You can just call me Aunt Saly, I'm used to it, no need to change it. Aunt Polly said that Tom was right, Miss Watson had set Jim free.
tr: Thus, Tom's Aunt Polly explained everything about who I was and what I had done, and then I tried to explain how difficult it was for me when Mrs. Phelps thought I was Tom Sawyer – but she interrupted me: "Oh, alright, just call me Aunt Sally again, I'm already used to it, no need to say anything else – I had to accept my fate when Aunt Sally mistook me for Tom Sawyer – there was no other way, besides, I knew Tom wouldn't object, because he loved such things, he liked mysterious affairs, would immediately turn them into an adventure, and then he would be happy.
es: So Aunt Polly told everyone who I was, and I had to confess that I was in such a bad situation that when Mrs. Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer... —and then she intervened and said: "Come on, come on, call me Aunt Sally, I'm used to it and there's no need to change things"—, that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to accept it, because I couldn't do anything else, and I knew Tom wouldn't mind, on the contrary, he would love it because it was a mystery and he would turn it all into an adventure and be very happy.

en: And so it turned out, and he let on to be Sid, and made things as soft as he could for me.
vi: That's it.
tr: So, he accepted being Sid and tried to make things easier for me.
es: That's how things turned out, and he pretended to be Sid and made everything as easy as he could for me.

en: And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free!
vi: Tom took upon himself all the hardships and struggles to free a black man who was already free!
tr: Aunt Polly confirmed what Tom had said about Mrs. Watson's will freeing Jim; so our Tom Sawyer had indeed gone through all that trouble to rescue a free black man!
es: His Aunt Polly said that Tom was right in what he had said about old Miss Watson having declared Jim free in her will, so, of course, Tom Sawyer had gotten into all that mess and all that adventure to free a black man who was already free, and that’s why I couldn’t understand until that moment and that conversation how Tom could help someone to set a black man free with the way he had been brought up.

en: and I couldn’t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he could help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.
vi: And it wasn't until now that I understood why someone as educated as Tom would join me in freeing a black man.
tr: Until that moment when the conversation took place, I hadn't understood how someone as well-bred as him could have freed a black man.
es: His Aunt Polly said that Tom was right in what he had said about old Miss Watson having declared Jim free in her will, so, of course, Tom Sawyer had gotten into all that mess and all that adventure to free a black man who was already free, and that’s why I couldn’t understand until that moment and that conversation how Tom could help someone to set a black man free with the way he had been brought up.

en: Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
vi: Then Mrs. Polly said that Aunt Sally had written her a letter saying that Tom and Sid had arrived safely; and she had told herself:
tr: Anyway, Aunt Polly said to herself this time when she received Aunt Sally's letter confirming that Tom and Sid had arrived safely:
es: Well, Aunt Polly said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had arrived safe and sound, she had said to herself: "Well, well!"

en: “Look at that, now!
vi: - When I let it go alone without anyone accompanying it, I didn't think this situation would happen.
tr: "Here comes trouble!
es: Well, Aunt Polly said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had arrived safe and sound, she had said to herself: "Well, well!"

en: I might have expected it, letting him go off that way without anybody to watch him.
vi: - When I let it go alone without anyone accompanying it, I didn't think this situation would happen.
tr: What else could happen if I let him wander all that way without anyone to watch over him?
es: It was to be expected, for having let him go alone without anyone to watch over him.

en: So now I got to go and trapse all the way down the river, eleven hundred mile, and find out what that creetur’s up to this time; as long as I couldn’t seem to get any answer out of you about it.”
vi: Now I have to struggle and travel over a thousand miles down there to see if there's anyone else named Sid. And when I asked, she didn't respond at all.
tr: Well then, now go down the river for eleven hundred miles and find out what our rascal is up to this time if you have nothing better to do; and on top of that, I keep sending letters to my brother but he never replies."
es: So now I have to go all the way down the river, eleven hundred miles, and find out what the boy is up to this time, because there was no way you could answer me."

en: “Why, I never heard nothing from you,” says Aunt Sally.
vi: Aunt Saly said:
tr: “But I haven't seen any of your letters,” said Aunt Sally.
es: —But we didn't get any news from you here —says Aunt Sally.

en: “Well, I wonder!
vi: - I haven't received any news from you?
tr: “Yeah, I wonder why!
es: —Wow, how strange!

en: Why, I wrote you twice to ask you what you could mean by Sid being here.”
vi: - I wrote to you twice asking what it means that Sid is there?
tr: I wrote to you twice and asked what you meant by saying Sid was there.”
es: But I wrote to you twice to ask what you meant by saying that Sid had arrived.

en: “Well, I never got ’em, Sis.”
vi: - I did not receive any letter from you.
tr: "No, I didn't receive any letter, sister."
es: —Well, sister, but they never arrived for me.

en: Aunt Polly she turns around slow and severe, and says:
vi: - It's you again, Tom!
tr: Aunt Polly slowly turned to Tom with a stern expression on her face.
es: Aunt Polly turned around very slowly and sternly, and then said:

en: “You, Tom!”
vi: - It's you again, Tom!
tr: "Tom, you did it!""
es: —You, Tom!

en: “Well—what?” he says, kind of pettish.
vi: - What did you say?
tr: “What have I done?” Tom asked meekly.
es: —Well... what? —he replies, sounding angry.

en: “Don’t you what me, you impudent thing—hand out them letters.”
vi: - It replied, mischievously. - Don't ask me anything else.
tr: “Don't tell me what I've done, you shameless one, you... Take out the letters, let's see.”
es: —Don't come asking me what, insolent; give me those letters.

en: “What letters?”
vi: Hand over the letter! - Which letter?
tr: "Which letters?"
es: —What letters?

en: “Them letters.
vi: - What letter?
tr: “Those letters.
es: —Those letters.

en: I be bound, if I have to take aholt of you I’ll—”
vi: I'm really annoyed now, if you keep lying, I will...
tr: If you don't give them to me right away, if I have to find them myself, then...”
es: I assure you that if I have to lay a hand on you, I'm going to...

en: “They’re in the trunk.
vi: - Yes, it's in that box.
tr: "The letters are in the chest.
es: —They are in the trunk.

en: There, now.
vi: - Yes, it's in that box.
tr: Yes, there.
es: That's already been said.

en: And they’re just the same as they was when I got them out of the office.
vi: It's still exactly as it was when I picked it up from the post office.
tr: I definitely didn't touch them, they are just as I received them from the post office.
es: And they are just as they were when they were given to me at the post office.

en: I hain’t looked into them, I hain’t touched them.
vi: I haven't looked at it, nor have I touched it.
tr: I didn't open or even touch them.
es: I haven't seen them. I haven't touched them.

en: But I knowed they’d make trouble, and I thought if you warn’t in no hurry, I’d—”
vi: But I guessed there would be some trouble, so I...
tr: But I knew the letters would cause trouble, and I thought you weren't in a hurry..."
es: But I knew they were going to cause problems and I thought they weren't urgent for you and that...

en: “Well, you do need skinning, there ain’t no mistake about it.
vi: - I will definitely skin you alive.
tr: "You're itching to skin me alive, huh?
es: —Well, you deserve a beating, there's no doubt about that.

en: And I wrote another one to tell you I was coming; and I s’pose he—”
vi: I also wrote another letter, informing her that I am about to come down here, or maybe it also...
tr: I have no doubt about that anymore. Also, I had sent another letter informing you that I would come here, and I believe Tom..."
es: I wrote you another one to tell you that I was going to come, and I suppose that...

en: “No, it come yesterday; I hain’t read it yet, but it’s all right, I’ve got that one.”
vi: - That letter just arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but I have already put it away.
tr: "No, it arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but there's no problem. It's with me."
es: —No, it arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but it arrived fine, I have that one.

en: I wanted to offer to bet two dollars she hadn’t, but I reckoned maybe it was just as safe to not to.
vi: I want to bet two dollars right now that Aunt Saly doesn't have that letter, but on second thought, I realized it would be better to stay silent.
tr: I would bet two dollars that the letter is not with Aunt Sally, but it seemed wiser to keep quiet at that moment.
es: I would have bet two dollars that it wasn't, but I figured it might be safer not to bet.

en: So I never said nothing.
vi: So I didn't say a word.
tr: I didn't say anything.
es: So I didn't say anything.

en: CHAPTER THE LAST
vi: The Final Chapter
tr: Final Chapter
es: Last Chapter

en: The first time I catched Tom private I asked him what was his idea, time of the evasion?—what it was he’d planned to do if the evasion worked all right and he managed to set a nigger free that was already free before?
vi: As soon as I got a chance to meet Tom alone, I immediately asked him what he thought during the escape? How would he plan if the escape was successful and how would he restore freedom to Jim?
tr: When I first caught Tom alone, I asked him what idea he had in mind during the escape. What he was thinking of doing if the escape went smoothly and we managed to free a slave who was already free. Upon this, he told me the plan that had been in his mind from the beginning:
es: THE FIRST TIME I could see Tom alone, I asked him what he had thought about during the escape, what he planned to do if the escape went well and he managed to free the black man who was already free before.

en: And he said, what he had planned in his head from the start, if we got Jim out all safe, was for us to run him down the river on the raft, and have adventures plumb to the mouth of the river, and then tell him about his being free, and take him back up home on a steamboat, in style, and pay him for his lost time, and write word ahead and get out all the niggers around, and have them waltz him into town with a torchlight procession and a brass-band, and then he would be a hero, and so would we.
vi: He said that if we managed to rescue Jim safely, we would let him sit on a raft drifting downstream, and together we would venture all the way to the river's mouth. At that point, we would tell him that he was free, then put him on a steamboat home, reward him, gather all the black folks around to dance and escort him into town with a proper parade, complete with drums and trumpets; he would become a hero, and so would the two of us.
tr: If we could save Jim, we would go down the river on the raft together, have many adventures until we reached the mouth of the river, then we would tell Jim he was free, give him a comfortable journey home on a steamboat, give him money for the time he lost, inform all the blacks in the village beforehand, and they would take Jim to the village with a band and a torchlight procession; thus Jim would be a hero, and so would we.
es: He replied that what he had planned from the beginning, if we managed to get Jim out and keep him safe, was to continue with him down the river on the raft and have lots of adventures there, and then tell him he was free and take him back home on a fine steamboat, and pay him for all the time he had lost and write ahead so that all the black people would come to greet him and take him dancing into town with a torchlight procession and a band. Then he would be a hero and so would we.

en: But I reckoned it was about as well the way it was.
vi: But I think we've almost done just that already.
tr: But the point where things had come now was just as good.
es: But I figured things were fine just the way they were.

en: We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom, they made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him all he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do.
vi: We helped Jim get free from the chains. When Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally learned how Jim had helped the doctor take care of Tom, they were very moved, praised him endlessly, gave Jim all the food he liked, let him rest, and didn't make him do anything at all.
tr: We had immediately freed Jim from his chains, and then Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally, having learned how much the doctor had helped treat Tom, had made him their favorite, fulfilled his every wish, never let him lack for anything, and moreover, had given him no work to do.
es: We didn't take long to remove Jim's chains, and when Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally found out how well he had helped the doctor take care of Tom, they showered him with praise, pampered him a lot, and gave him all the food he wanted so he could enjoy himself and not have to do anything.

en: And we had him up to the sick-room, and had a high talk; and Tom give Jim forty dollars for being prisoner for us so patient, and doing it up so good, and Jim was pleased most to death, and busted out, and says:
vi: Tom gave Jim forty dollars for being a very patient prisoner and playing that role very well. Jim was overjoyed and exclaimed:
tr: We brought him to Tom's room and had many conversations, and Tom, because he had endured imprisonment for our sake with great patience and had been very successful, gave Jim forty dollars. Jim was almost going to lose his mind from joy:
es: We took him up to the sickroom, where we chatted for a long time, and Tom gave Jim forty dollars for having been so patient as a prisoner with us and for having done everything so well, and Jim almost died of happiness and started shouting:

en: “Dah, now, Huck, what I tell you?—what I tell you up dah on Jackson islan’?
vi: - Hey Huck, didn't I tell you?
tr: “Ha, see, Huck, what did I tell you? What did I tell you on Jackson Island? I told you my chest was hairy, so what was that a sign of?
es: —Well, Huck, what was I telling you? What I told you on Jackson Island?

en: I tole you I got a hairy breas’, en what’s de sign un it; en I tole you I ben rich wunst, en gwineter to be rich agin; en it’s come true; en heah she is!
vi: I told you that I have a lot of hair on my chest, which is a sign of good luck; and I also said that I was once wealthy and that I would be rich again in the future.
tr: I had told you once that I was rich, and I said I would be rich again.
es: I told you that I have a lot of hair on my chest and that it's a good sign, and I told you that I was rich once and that I was going to be rich again, and now it has come true, look at it!

en: Dah, now!
vi: So now it's true, isn't it? Here, here's the money.
tr: And it came true! Oh boy!
es: Do you get it?

en: doan’ talk to me—signs is signs, mine I tell you; en I knowed jis’ ’s well ’at I ’uz gwineter be rich agin as I’s a-stannin’ heah dis minute!”
vi: I told you, I knew for sure that one day I would be rich again, and it's true just like I am right now.
tr: I trust in omens, I never doubt the truth of omens. Just as I know I am alive right now, I knew for sure that I would be rich again!”
es: Don't tell me you don't: signs are signs and don't forget it; I knew I was going to be rich again, as sure as the sun rises in the East!

en: And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le’s all three slide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a couple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I ain’t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn’t get none from home, because it’s likely pap’s been back before now, and got it all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up.
vi: Then Tom kept talking, saying that one night the three of us should go out there to get some tools and go on an adventure for a few weeks into Indian territory. I said okay, I liked that idea too, but I didn't have money to buy tools, and I thought there wouldn't be any at home either; because my father had probably returned and taken all the money from Judge Thatcher to go drinking.
tr: Then Tom started talking, and after a long conversation, he said, "Let's all sneak out of here within a few nights, disguise ourselves, and have some amazing adventures in the Indian Territory for a few weeks." I said, "Alright, that's fine with me." But I didn't have any money to buy clothes, and when I got home, I wouldn't have any money either; because my father had probably already returned to the village, taken all the money from Judge Thatcher, and spent it on liquor.
es: Then Tom started talking and talking and said that one of these nights the three of us could escape and form a band in search of amazing adventures among the Indians, in their territory, for two or three weeks. I said that was fine, that it suited me perfectly, but I didn't have money to buy clothes and I figured they wouldn't send it from home, because father had probably already returned and Judge Thatcher would have given him everything and he would have drunk it all.

en: “No, he hain’t,” Tom says; “it’s all there yet—six thousand dollars and more; and your pap hain’t ever been back since.
vi: Tom said:
tr: “It’s not like that at all,” said Tom. “All your money is there… Six thousand dollars, maybe even more. Your father hasn’t been seen since he went out looking for you.
es: —No, nothing like that —and then Tom says—; it's all still there: six thousand dollars and more; your father never came back.

en: Hadn’t when I come away, anyhow.”
vi: - No, not yet. All more than six thousand dollars are still there, and your father hasn't returned since then.
tr: In fact, when I set out for here, he was nowhere to be found.”
es: At least not until I came here.

en: Jim says, kind of solemn:
vi: Jim said solemnly:
tr: Jim joined the conversation a bit sadly:
es: Jim said, very solemnly:

en: “He ain’t a-comin’ back no mo’, Huck.”
vi: - He is not coming back anymore, Huck.
tr: “Dad will never come back again, Huck.”
es: —He is not coming back anymore, Huck.

en: I says:
vi: I asked"
tr: “Dad will never come back again, Huck.”
es: And I go and say:

en: “Why, Jim?”
vi: - Why did Jim say that?
tr: “Why, Jim?”
es: —Why, Jim?

en: “Nemmine why, Huck—but he ain’t comin’ back no mo.”
vi: - I am sure of that, don't ask anymore.
tr: “Never mind the reason, Huck, but I know it won't happen again.”
es: —It doesn't matter why, Huck, but he won't be coming back anymore.

en: But I kept at him; so at last he says:
vi: But I kept asking persistently, and finally he said:
tr: But I wasn't satisfied with this, and when I pressed him further, he confessed:
es: But I insisted, so in the end he goes and says:

en: “Doan’ you ’member de house dat was float’n down de river, en dey wuz a man in dah, kivered up, en I went in en unkivered him and didn’ let you come in?
vi: - Do you remember that floating house on the river? There was a dead person inside, with a cloth covering their face. I went in and lifted it to see, then didn't let you in to look, right?
tr: “Don't you remember that house going down? You know, during the flood. There was a man inside the house, but his face wasn't visible; then I went inside, saw the man's face, but I didn't let you go inside.
es: —Don't you remember that house that was floating down the river and there was a man inside, all covered up, and I went in and uncovered him and didn't let you go in?

en: Well, den, you kin git yo’ money when you wants it, kase dat wuz him.”
vi: You can take your money back whenever you want, because the dead person in that house is him.
tr: That's why you can go and get your money whenever you want, because that man was your father.”
es: Well, now you can ask for your money whenever you want, because it was him.

en: Tom’s most well now, and got his bullet around his neck on a watch-guard for a watch, and is always seeing what time it is, and so there ain’t nothing more to write about, and I am rotten glad of it, because if I’d a knowed what a trouble it was to make a book I wouldn’t a tackled it, and ain’t a-going to no more.
vi: Now, Tom was almost completely recovered. He tied the bullet to a string and wore it around his neck like a watch, occasionally taking it out to check the time. I don't know what else to write for this book. If I had known how difficult writing a book would be, I wouldn't have written it, nor would I have intended to write it.
tr: Tom is quite well now, and he put the bullet in a pocket watch case and hung it around his neck. He keeps looking at it frequently as if it were a watch. So that's how it is, there's nothing left to write about, and I'm very pleased with that. If I had known that writing this book would be this difficult, I would never have started, and if I ever undertake such a task again, may I be damned.
es: Tom is almost well now and he wears the bullet hanging around his neck in a watch case, and he always checks what time it is, so there's nothing more to write about. I'm really glad, because if I had known how hard it was to write a book, I wouldn't have started it, and I don't plan to do it again.

en: But I reckon I got to light out for the Territory ahead of the rest, because Aunt Sally she’s going to adopt me and sivilize me, and I can’t stand it.
vi: But anyway, I still have to go to the territory of the Native Americans because Aunt Saly intends to raise and civilize me; and I cannot stand that, as I already know enough about it.
tr: But I guess it's time for me to quietly slip away to the Indian Territory, because Aunt Sally is thinking of adopting me and then making a man out of me; I can't bear that.
es: But I reckon I have to head to the territory before anyone else, because Aunt Sally is going to adopt me and civilize me, and I can't stand it.

en: I been there before.
tr: I've tried that before.
es: I know what it's like to go through that.

en: THE END.
tr: SON

en: YOURS TRULY, HUCK FINN.
